column2: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- During the week ended Feb. 25, member bank reserves decreased $343,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

BERN, Switzerland, Feb. 26 -The State Department's successive retreats before Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's pressure on the personnel of the Voice of America have caused a kind of nervous chill in some European circles not ordinarily much concerned about such matters.

The Carter Handicap, the Aqueduct stakes race that is world famous because of its triple dead heat in 1944, has been increased in value to $50,000 added for its 1953 running. Cyrus S. Jullien, president of the Queens County Jockey Club, which conducts the thoroughbred sport at Aqueduct, reported the increase yesterday.
A Voice of America official described yesterday as fantastic the testimony of a former employe, that he tried to recruit her into a Communist-style community of "free love."

HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 26 (AP) -Cary Middlecoff of Memphis sank a 40-foot putt on the eighteenth green today to tie Al Besselink of Grossinger, N. Y., for the first-round lead in the $20,000 Houston open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) - The Government rested its case and dropped one of its three perjury charges against Dr. Joseph W. Weinberg today but the key count in the indictment survived defense attacks.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Obesity was described today by the Joint Legislative Commission on Problems of the Aging as the greatest single hazard to human life in the country. It urged state and local health departments, health associations, medical societies and others to unite in a campaign to combat it.

Two books about Africa will be published by Doubleday. Scheduled for June is Robert C. Ruark's "Horn of the Hunter," an account of his safari in Africa illustrated with thirty-two pages of photographs and twenty-four chapter-head drawings. In July, the concern will issue a novel by Peter Viertel entitled "White Hunter, Black Heart," wherein the central character is "a man who thought he was a Hemingway hero -- and tried to live like one."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, gravely entreated Congressional Republicans today not to attempt to harden President Eisenhower's proposed denunciation of Soviet "perversion" of the wartime Yalta and Potsdam Agreements.

Events today: PhilharmonicSymphony, Igor Stravinsky conducting, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; Jennie Tourel, mezzo - soprano, Town Hall, 8:30; "The Rake's Progress,"' Metropolitan Opera, 8:30; Eugene Stoia, violinist, and Dorothy Dring Smutz, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:15.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 27 -- Eighth Army headquarters reported that three United Nations patrols killed nearly seventy Communist troops and wounded as many more in three sharp fights along the western front in Korea yesterday. About the same number of the enemy were killed elsewhere along the front by small-arms and artillery fire of the Allied forces.

Additions to a collection of "art by the yard" fabrics introduced here last year are scheduled to arrive at Macy's on Monday. Initiated by Riverdale Fabrics and the Associated American Artists Gallery, the patterns of this group, as of the first one, were all designed by painters associated with this gallery.

As a Puerto Rican and a former working newsman, I would like to commend Peter Kihss and THE NEW YORK TIMES for the objective, wellwritten and comprehensive series of articles on the Puerto Rican migration to New York. The information is the most descriptive and accurate I have read in any newspaper or magazine in the past few years.

As a result of modern methods of instruction developed through research, public school children are no longer hindered by classmates whose intellectual level may be different from theirs. Instead they are channeled into appropriate groups after studies of their abilities and characteristics.

Mrs. Ralph Rizzo, 40 years old, a custodial desk officer at the Women's House of Detention, 10 Greenwich Avenue, was arrested yesterday on a grand larceny indictment that charged she had stolen more than $10,000 in departmental funds.

AMITYVILLE, L. I., Feb. 26 - Four boxer dogs owned by the Rev. James J. Comerford, pastor of St. Martin's Roman Catholic Church, mauled and severely injured a 5-year-old boy who ventured behind the church rectory shortly before noon yesterday.

THERE are far too many distinguished men quitting baseball these days for the safer but more prosaic world of business. One such is Dick Bartell, the bellicose Rowdy Richard, who has retired for the life of automobile salesman on the Pacific Coast. He'll probably get rich at it, too, because he's a cinch to sell more cars than anyone else in California.

Because ten years ago Joan Plauth, then 5 years old, didn't cotton to the gift of a pair of rabbits her father had thought she might like, Ralph E. Plauth is now in the business of raising laboratory animals at the rate of 10,000 a week.

TORONTO, Feb. 25 -- Interprovincial Pipe Line Company announced today that a price of $18 (Canadian) a share has been set for 1,439,552 shares of $5 par value stock which are being offered to shareholders on the basis of two new shares for each five shares held. Subscription warrants are being mailed to shareholders.

MIAMI, Feb. 26 -- The 4-year-old gelding Pomace, who ran his first thirteen races for the chairman of The Jockey Club, George D. Widener, ran for the first time for Mr. and Mrs. A. E. Reuben's Hasty House Farms at Hialeah today. It was a brisk, winning run.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Feb. 26 -- A prominent Fundamentalist clergyman was publicly censured here today by the Western Section of the World Presbyterian Alliance for "disruptive and deceptive" assaults on the integrity of the World Council of Churches, the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the United States of America, and most of the major Protestant denominations in this country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Mutual Security Agency has moved to cut down on shipments to and from Communist China by putting strict regulations on vessels carrying foreign aid into the Asian coastal area.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Donald S. Tydings, whose stormy career as a Federal revenue enforcement official in Atlanta, is under investigation, testified today that a bootlegger in Georgia's capital once guaranteed payment of a $3,000 bank note on which Mr. Tydings had defaulted.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 26 -- All else being fairly equal, the deciding factor that will determine the battlefront upon which Leo Durocher will depend to drive his Giants to that 1953 pennant can be summed up in one five-letter word -- power.

United States Attorney Frank J. Parker announced yesterday that his staff in cooperation with special agents of the Treasury Department had started a drive against unscrupulous individuals who have been making out income tax returns for persons not too familiar with the law.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Britain is prepared to withdraw her troops from the Suez Canal zone provided that Egypt recognizes the principle that the British base is vital for Middle Eastern defense and agrees that British forces can return there in the event of war.
A delicacy in decoration and a subtlety in coloring distinguish a new group of ceramic objects made by Thomas J. Williams and now on view at the Willow, 182 West Fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Four agreements involving the payment by the Federal Republic of Germany of about $1,750,000,000 to this country and its nationals will he signed in London tomorrow, the Department of State announced tonight.
The first public demonstration Wednesday of the Amy's new Skysweeeper gun marked the opening of a new chapter in air defense techniques.
TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 27 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,538, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korea time:

Several West Side tenement residents, including a grandmother who moved into the area thirty-six years ago as a bride, complained at City Hall yesterday about the threat of eviction under the Port of New York Authority's timetable for new approaches to the Lincoln Tunnel.

The Atlas Corporation, one of the nation's largest closed-end investment companies, reported yesterday $39.38 as its net asset value at the end of 1952, a new high. This compares with $37.83 a share on Dec. 31, 1951.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 -- Pierre S. du Pont refused today to agree with his cross-examiner that E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. controls General Motors Corporation, the world's largest automobile maker, with a billion-dollar block of stock.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 -- Wheat futures showed relative strength today, while corn and oats weakened under rather persistent selling pressure. The dominating influence in corn was the expected free selling of Commodity Credit Corporation stocks in the next few weeks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Use of a Congressional veto procedure in handling future reciprocal trade treaties is explored in a study of international trade policy issues made public today by the Foreign Commerce Department of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

Gross income from the sales of products and services reached a new record of $693,941,000 last year for the Radio Corporation of America, a gain of 16 per cent over the previous record of $598,955,000 set in 1951, according to the company's thirty-third annual report, mailed to 181,000 stockholders yesterday.

A Federal grand jury reported last night that it had not found sufficient evidence to indict Patrolman William Brennan for violation of the Civil Rights Law in the alleged beating of two Negroes while they were handcuffed together in the West Fifty-fourth Street police station last Aug. 8.

SCHENECTADY, Feb. 26 -Chester I. Hall of this city retired from the General Electric Company today after thirty-four years' service, during which he acquired 139 company patents -- the largest number held by an active employe.

Prices were irregular at the close of New York commodity exchanges yesterday after a day of light trading. Cottonseed oil volume reached highs for the year for the second consecutive day. Hides were the only other item to show more activity. Coffee, cocoa and hides closed higher and lead and tin were lower. Sugar, potatoes, rubber, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, zinc and wool ended mixed.

A record consolidated net income last year of $86,400,000 was reported yesterday by the Sinclair Oil Corporation and its subsidiaries, including a non-recurring profit of $9,600,000 from the sale of gas properties in the Southwest. The consolidated income is equivalent to $7.08 a share and compares with $81,898,490 or $6.78 a share shown in 1951.

Mr. Eisenhower's second Presidential press conference was lively and interesting. His opening remarks were brief and useful. Mr. Merriman Smith of The United Press played the role reserved for the senior correspondent present. He opened with the first question and, when he thought, and everybody else seemed to think, that the proceedings had gone on long enough, he uttered the historic words, "Thank you, Mr. President," and the meeting Broke up.

EL PASO, Tex., Feb. 26 (UP) -- Immigration authorities today questioned Rosaura Revueltas, Mexican movie actress, who is charged with entering this country illegally to star in a motion picture that a member of Congress has said is being made "by a bunch of Communists."

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee resolution condemning the persecution of minorities within the Soviet bloc is sound and just. There should be such a condemnation because the accusation is true and because it is the duty of free countries to stand up for the rights and liberties of all people in all parts of the world.

Plans for erecting a nine-story building containing apartments with one and one-half, two and three rooms were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of 232-34 East Seventy-seventh Street, between Second and Third Avenues, by the Rexton Realty Company to a client of Blumenson Sussman.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 26 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, titular head of the Democratic party, tonight chided the Republicans for an implied departure from their campaign farm platform, and warned against any "dismemberment" of the public domain through cessions to the states.

Workers who are entitled to retire on pension at 60 or 65 prefer to stick to their jobs until they are 68, according to a study of thirteen industry-wide pension funds carried out by the State Labor Department and published this week in The Industrial Bulletin.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Loading of revenue freight for the week ended Feb. 21 totaled 689,553 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 7,803 cars or 1.1 per cent more than for the preceding week, 6,002 cars or 0.9 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 45,292 cars or 6.2 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -An alien property official proposed today that the Government drop responsibility for nearly $1,000,000,000 worth of claims against enemy property seized during World War II.

Thomas H. MacDonald, Federal Commissioner of Public Roads, admitted yesterday that he had been incorrect in asserting that Federal funds had been used to build the Southern State Parkway on Long Island.

The Young Men's Board of Trade, which last year brought about the contribution of 1,100 pints of blood as a result of two mass drives in the Worth Street textile industry, received a certificate of merit yesterday from J. Harrison Heckman, executive director of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26 -- The California State Supreme Court has ruled legal a plan of the State Toll Bridge Authority to sell $62,000,000 in bonds for construction of a high-level bridge between San Rafael and Richmond, to the north of here on opposite sides of San Francisco Bay.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 26 (AP) -- A mysterious voice, amplified by loudspeakers, urged Danish soldiers last night to protest against their extended service terms as ferry carrying troops for maneuvers docked at Korsoer Harbor in southwest Zealand.

August rehearsals of "The Girl in Pink Tights" are contemplated by Shepard Traube, who will produce and direct the Joseph FieldsJerome Chodorov-Sigmund Romberg -Leo Robin musical. The other day Mr. Traube, who staged and co-produced the current "Time Out for Ginger," was saying that terms had been cabled to Jeanmaire in Paris to appear in the show and that she was expected here soon.

The decision of the Temporary State Commission on the Use of Television for Educational Purposes in Albany on Tuesday against present use of state funds to build and operate educational television stations was condemned by the New York Board of Rabbis at its annual meeting here yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 26 (AP) -- A Communist charge that Lady Mountbatten of Britain was visiting India to bring the nation into the western-proposed Middle East defense organization brought shouts of "lie" and "falsehood" from Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru in Parliament today.

Melvyn Douglas and other cast members appearing in "Time Out For Ginger" at the Lyceum Theatre will present a twelve-minute excerpt from the play on the Arthur Murray television show over Channel 5 on Sunday, March 8, at 10 P. M. The segment of the play to be televised has not been selected.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 26 -- Negotiations are now going on between Washington and a shipping firm in Helsinki for the sale of the 7,717-ton Finnish tanker Wiima, according to reports in Singapore tonight that are quoted in The Straits Times.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Assemblyman William H. Mac Kenzie, Republican of Belmont, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said today that his committee would hold a public hearing next Thursday on a bill to establish a temporary state commission to examine the state's divorce and family relationship laws.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 26 -- The budget-bothered United Nations has put some of its money into an investment that it earnestly hopes will turn out to be a dud.
PARIS, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Warren Lee Pierson, chairman of Trans World Airlines, today advised European countries to cheapen their money if they want to compete in American market

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 26 -- The Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly suspended its debate on the Korean question today until Monday because no delegates were willing to speak at the meetings scheduled for tomorrow morning and afternoon and for Saturday morning.

Three men accused of attacking a bartender and an off-duty patrolman in a bar and grill at 431 DeKalb Avenue, Brooklyn, shortly after 3 A. M. yesterday, were held on charges of assault in the Classon Avenue precinct.

Among the large number of this week's art exhibitions is a show of sculpture, at the Argent Gallery, by members of the National Association of Women Artists residing in and about New York. There are twenty-two entries in all and they are characterized more by loyalty to traditional realism and good workmanship than by adventurousness.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 25 -- Fully confident of their ability to transform this predominantly agricultural country into a substantial industrial one, Government experts have issued a warning of impending serious unemployment among the rural population.

The two-story factory at 65-71 Eckford Street in Brooklyn has been purchased by the Sealtite Manufacturing Corporation from Theodore Anuskewicz David M. Engelson was attorney for the buyer and the Title Guarantee and Trust Company insured title.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 26 -Eugene (Gene) Beck, resort lifeguard, who suffered a paralyzing injury Aug. 24, 1949, when he fell on a stone jetty while trying to warn two children away from a danger zone, died late last night at the home of his aunt, Mrs. Fay Beck, at 4 North Virginia Avenue. He was 29 years old.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 26 -Joseph M. Schenck, one of the pioneers of the motion picture industry, has resigned as executive head of production of Twentieth CenturyFox, the company announced here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee withheld today its approval of thirty-nine Navy nominations for temporary promotion to the grade of rear admiral. The thirty-nine were those captains recommended for promotion by the second selection board to pass over Capt. Hyman G. Rickover, atomic submarine expert.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- A consistent demand for British Government securities that brought fresh gains to virtually all of them helped to steady the leading industrials here today. Many industrials had declined early in the session but by the close most had recovered to yesterday's levels and some advances were made in store and shipbuilding issues.

Secretary of State Dulles informed members of Congress yesterday that any meeting between President Eisenhower and Premier Stalin is "entirely in the realm of conjecture" and that no present plans for such a meeting exist. The President's own reply to the question asked him at his press conference on Wednesday made this clear.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Department store sales in the week ended Feb. 21 were 2 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board in the following listing of percentage changes from like periods of 1952:

EVERYTHING seemed to pile up at once. First Amos' heart went bad and the doctor told him he had to take it easy for the rest of his life. And then his marriage went on the rocks. It had been in a state of rigor mortis for years, but it was a shock to Amos, just the same, when his beautiful wife, Edie, looked at him with hatred in her eyes and demanded a divorce.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals cleared the way today for William Vander Wyde, 39 years old, a Manhattan longshoreman, to appeal his firstdegree murder conviction to the United States Supreme Court. The court certified that a question of constitutional law was involved in its decision of Jan. 15 upholding the conviction.

TORONTO, Feb. 26 -- The police charged today that an international ring had smuggled at least twenty babies into the United States and sold them in the last three months. They arrested a Brooklyn couple as recipients of one of the babies and said they expected to arrest others, including a doctor and possibly nurses and a lawyer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Fundamental changes in the methods and structure of agriculture in order to remedy deep-rooted and serious problems of the migratory farm workers were urged today by the National Planning Association.
OTTAWA, Feb. 26 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian business men today were urged by Trade Minister C. D. Howe to develop new markets in Latin America.

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26 -- A bit of feuding between Manager Steve O'Neill of the Phillies and Manager Chuck Dressen of the Dodgers seemed today to be in the making, as a result of O'Neill's assertion that "Brooklyn will never -- never, I say -- have another year like last year."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- A method of detecting diseases by measuring the "breathing patterns" of patients with an electronic device has been developed by the National Bureau of Standards.

The practicality and savory goodness combined in meat pies are recognized by home cooks around the world. Now, while meat is down to more reasonable price levels, we might borrow some of these ideas from abroad and concoct such delicacies as the English beefsteak pie, Puerto Rican pork-filled empanadillas or German veal and ham pasty.

Construction of four bauxite (aluminum ore) carriers for the Pan-Ore Steamship Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Aluminum Company of America, is progressing in Swedish and British yards, it was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- President Eisenhower's Administration will go along with legislation providing emergency powers under which the President could freeze prices, wages and rents for ninety days in event of war or other national emergency, Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, predicted today.

San Francisco did the expectable and entirely right thing when it gave the equivalent of a ticker-tape welcome to General Van Fleet upon his return from Korea. He has done a signal service for his country, just as he did in Greece, and it is a pleasure to recognize it and applaud it. He is a good patriot and a good human being and we rejoice in both.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 26 -- The import of consumer goods into Korea has been stepped up by the United Nations Reconstruction Agency as part of the campaign to fight inflation.

Charles H. Silver. a member of the Board of Education, paid tribute last night to the administration of Mayor Impellitteri for making possible "gratifying progress" in the construction of new schools. At the same time. Mr. Impellitteri underscored his record in this respect.
A program of works for piano and chamber orchestra was performed at Town Hall last evening under the direction of Frederick Prausnitz, with Joseph Bloch as piano soloist.

Coincidentally with the swearing in of 100 new firemen yesterday, Commissioner Jacob Grumet announced that the forty-two-hour week would become effective in "some divisions" of the department beginning April 1. Yesterday's new crop of firefighters brought the strength of the uniformed force to 8,961.

Current efforts being made to preserve the 300-year-old Van Cortlandt manor house on the Albany Post Road, and an announcement from England that many of its stately homes are now open to the public in order to help pay the maintenance costs and taxes, remind us that houses can be white elephants.

Choosing the right summer camp for their youngsters is a job many parents, together with their youngsters, must tackle soon. A new play, "Blazing the Trail," showing a typical family group at odds over their decisions, may be a helpful starter for parents or youth groups interested in discussion of this subject.
LONDON, Feb. 26 -- The Navy will be the only branch of Britain's forces to cost this country's taxpayers less in the financial year beginning April 1 than in the current year.

William H. Weber has purchased the store and apartment building at 1422 Springfield Avenue in Irvington, N. J., from Betty Kaufman. The property has two stores and seven apartments and was sold through J. I. Kislak, Inc., as broker.

The world premiere of Elliott Carter's String Quartet, composed in 1951, was played last night in the McMillin Theatre of Columbia University by the Walden Quartet, along with quartets by Boccherini and Hindemith.

A multitude of decorative antique objects, among them many one-of-a-kind finds, are on exhibition and sale at the Ninth Annual Antiques Show at Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street. The Greenwich Village settlement house yearly event will benefit its Family Service program.
The proud motto of THE TIMES, concerning the fitness of printable news, hardly demanded the front-page-cumpicture treatment of Mrs. Agnes Meyer's shrill cry in behalf of the wounded educators.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 26 -- An international Communist conference to plan for sabotage in the coal, iron and steel industries of the European Coal and Steel Community nations is planned for West Germany in the next few weeks, authoritative sources said today.

The "grandfather" storm of the year, so far, raged over the Atlantic earlier this-week, delaying the America by twenty-four hours, Capt. Harold Milde, master of the liner, said yesterday when his vessel docked at West Forty-sixth Street.

ROME, Feb. 26 -- The progress toward the creation of the European Defense Community and a European army achieved yesterday by the foreign ministers of six prospective member countries in their conference here is a direct result of the recent European visit of John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, and Harold E. Stassen, Director of the Mutual Security Agency, Johan Willem Beyen, Netherlands Foreign Minister, said today.
Officials of the United States Lawn Tennis Association joined in honoring William Talbert yesterday as he received the J. P. Allen Award of the Lawn Tennis Writers Association of America.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 26 -- Dr. Julius Klein, United States consultant who solved Peru's economic problems, is in Rio De Janeiro conferring with leaders from President Vargas down, at the invitation of Finance Minister Horacio Lafer. He said today there was no commitment on either side but he is learning the details of the economic and financial situation and would then give his impressions to the Government.

TRENTON, Feb. 27 -- Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons took the stand today at the first public hearing of the Joint Legislative Committee investigating the ouster of Nelson F. Stamler as Deputy Attorney General and accused him of bringing about his own dismissal through jealousy and vindictiveness.

EL PASO, Tex., Feb. 27 -- Ben Margolis, Los Angeles lawyer, filed a request today for a writ of habeas corpus before United States District Judge R. E. Thomason, asking the release of the Mexican movie actress, Rosaura Revueltas, who is held by Immigration Service officials as an illegal alien.

Pat Marcune, Coney Island lightweight, defeated Lauro Salas, former 135-pound champion of the world, in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The contest was a close one that warmed up after a slow start, and the action was pleasing to the crowd of 4,034.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- The United States, Britain and France signed an agreement here today with the German Federal Republic by which West Germany assumed responsibility for Germany's pre-war external debts. Reparations still owing from World War I were not included, however.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- A self-watering flowerpot was patented this week by John Dodds of Greenville, S. C. A rubber girdle ground the middle and upper portion of the pot serves as a reservoir and forces the water gradually in through the pores.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, declared today he had inherited a State Department needing remedial action and that he welcomed Congressional inquiries that might make the agency "more competent, loyal and secure."

The New York Cotton Exchange has sold its twenty-four-story building at 60 Beaver Street and 2-8 William Street to Charles F. Noyes and has leased back a portion of the space. Mr. Noyes, head of the real estate brokerage company bearing his name, said he acquired the property as a personal investment.

The Board of Education has disposed of one matter of business forehandedly, unanimously re-electing Dr. William Jansen to a second ten of six years as Superintendent of Schools. The new term begins next Sept. 1, and Dr. Jansen's statutory retirement at age 70 will occur at the end of the 1957-58 school year.
A former convict, charged with committing a burglary at an East Side home as detectives trailed him, was captured in mid-Manhattan yesterday after a two-block chase, in which three shots were fired.

Assistant United States Attorney, Daniel H. Greenberg testified yesterday that Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan had told him he had an agreement with former Deputy Attorney General James McInerney, exempting the New York police from questioning by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in complaints of police brutality in violation of the Federal civil rights law.

Investment banking syndicates were busy yesterday competing for four issues of bonds of Texas counties and municipal school districts totaling $21,675,000. Syndicates headed by the Nations City Bank of New York submitted the best bids for $16,675,000 of the bonds.

Average market price of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange fell in January from $43.23 to $43, the Exchange reported yesterday. This brought the average to the lowest point since Nov. 30, when it was $42.26.

KANSAS CITY, Feb. 27 -- Dr. Clarence R. Decker announced today his resignation as president of the University of Kansas City, the climax of three stormy days on the campus that saw the vice president and three deans resign in protest against his administration.

The current concern over police brutality is centered -- and perhaps properly so -- on connivance in high places. We should not forget, however, the crucial role of the individual cop; whatever else may contribute to this deplorable situation, it is difficult to believe that we could have police brutality without brutal policemen.

Should J. Edward Lumbard Jr. be confirmed by the Senate to succeed Myles J. Lane as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, he will head a staff that handles 30 per cent of the nation's criminal and civil Federal prosecution.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 27 -- From warehouses bulging with the greatest quantity of goods ever received in spontaneous response to a disaster, the flood-stricken Dutch began sending aid to orphans of other storms today.

FONTAINEBLEAU, France, Feb. 27 -- A major increase in Allied naval strength in the Mediterranean, including the trebling of the number of aircraft carriers on constant duty there from two to at least six, plus the addition of 440 new naval jet fighters, is now being actively considered by Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe.
LAKE WALES, Fla., Feb. 27 -The Yankees will start their spring exhibition campaign next Saturday at St. Petersburg with a shortstop experiment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The United States Court of Appeals heard arguments today on whether the Attorney General, Herbert Brownell Jr., had legal authority to order Serge Rubinstein Russian-born financier, detained at Ellis Island pending final adjudication of deportation proceedings.

The construction of the new $412,000 Army Reserve Training Center on the Bronx campus of New York University, to be begun on April 1, will mean the demolition of the distinguished old Brown House and the eviction of fifty veterans' families living in emergency housing units nearby, it was learned yesterday.
TORONTO, Feb. 27 (Canadian Press) -- Interprovincial Pipe Line Company reported net income today of $4,107,689 for the year ended Dec. 31, 1952. This compares with $3,352,706 for 1951.

Among those concerned with the rising toll of automobile accidents there is reason for optimism in the news from Albany. A bill, now before the Joint Legislative Committee on Motor Vehicle Problems, has been introduced in the Legislature to strengthen a law designed to remove drunken drivers from the road.

Commodity prices closed irregular yesterday on the New York Exchanges. Activity continued light. Cocoa, potatoes, hides and tin were higher and cottonseed oil, rubber and zinc ended lower. Sugar, soybean oil, wool and lead closed mixed.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 27 -- West Germany's economic recovery and industrial potential in relation to the objectives of United States foreign policy have been reviewed by Ambassador William H. Draper Jr., President Eisenhower's special representative, and Dr. James B. Conant, United States High Commissioner, in consultations that ended today.

HONG KONG, Feb. 27 -- Sir Arthur Morse, retiring chief manager of the Hong Kong-Shanghai Banking Corporation, declared in the annual report to the bank's stockholders today that the rice problem in the Far East was giving rise to "great disquiet" and had become a "far more serious problem than is generally realized."

Robert Montgomery will produce a new television mystery program entitled "Eye Witness" over the National Broadcasting Company network beginning March 30. It will be presented on Mondays from 9 to 9:30 P. M., just preceding the hour-long "Robert Montgomery Presents" program, on which he also will continue as producer and host.

American and foreign-flag scheduled international airlines flew 1,377,848 passengers into and out of the United States last year as against 1,059,205 passengers brought in or taken out of the country during the same period by all the steamship lines, according to figures from the United States Customs Bureau.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Demand for British Government securities was again the feature of the securities markets here today. Many such issues improved up to 3/8 per cent. Trading in other categories was quiet and interest in industrials was selective, with store and textile shares the firmest spots.

Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish leaders here have endorsed the annual fund appeal of the American Red Cross. The goal in New York City is $7,000,000 and the national goal is $93,000,000. The drive begins tomorrow and will continue through March.
WARSAW, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Poland published today a weighty book designed to show how the United States "carries on a hostile policy toward Poland and its regime."

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- Dr. Alexander O. Gettler, toxicologist to the office of the Chief Medical Examiner of New York City, was honored tonight by the American Academy of Forensic Sciences, now holding its fifth annual convention in Chicago.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 27 -- Seton Hall University established a national major college basketball record for successive victories in one season, beating Baldwin-Wallace College of Berea, Ohio, 83 -- 75, before 3,600 tonight at the Seton Hall gymnasium. It was Seton Hall's twenty-seventh straight victory, breaking the mark held jointly by L. I. U. and Holy Cross.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver said today that the states could claim national parks and forests if the Federal Government gave the off-shore oil lands to coastal states.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 28 -- F-84 Thunderjets of the Fifth Air Force flew within sight of the Yalu River yesterday and loosed bombs, rockets and machine-gun fire on the Communist training center of Chusan. The target area, which the fighter-bombers left smoking and burning, is only a few minutes flying time from Communist MIG fighter bases on the other side of this river boundary between North Korea and Manchuria.
The Weather Bureau here cast a twinkling eye yesterday over a profound statement from the Miami Chamber of Commerce.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--President Eisenhower's nomination of Charles E. Bohlen to be Ambassador to Russia was sent to the Senate today.
Brass, the newly popular decorative material, is available in a number of new practical forms at New Design, 33 East Seventy-fifth Street.

A report on what science is doing today that will benefit all tomorrow will be published March 9 by Knopf under the title "Preview for Tomorrow: The Unfinished Business of Science." The author is Bruce Bliven, who for twenty years has been writing on scientific subjects.

The order of the Mutual Security Agency that will tighten up on ships carrying American aid materials into the Chinese coastal area is good sense. It merely puts the pressure of our shipping contracts upon carriers to stay away from Communist China after we have paid to have goods taken to Formosa.

The total membership of Communist parties throughout the world has declined by about 1,000,000 persons in the last three years, information recently published in Pravda, organ of the Soviet Communist party, indicates.

The leather industry is looking forward to a good season in anticipation of heavy consumer demand for spring footwear, the Tanners Council of America announced yesterday. The council, in a message to its members prior to the opening of the Leather Show at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Tuesday, said stores bought shoes early and buyers are more concerned with effective merchandising than prices.

In an effort to acquaint repre senttives of civic organizations with the procedure of the Municipal Civil Service examinations, the Municipal Civil Service Commission conducted yesterday the first of a series of medical tests of Fire Department candidates while invited members of civic groups looked on.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- Heavy deliveries on March contracts of wheat, corn and oats proved too big a handicap today and sharp recessions were registered, although there was substantial buying support in the early part of the trading session and wheat scored a sharp recovery near the close.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Officials said tonight American inbestors, business and other private claimants will get about $547,500,000 of the $1,750,000,000 which the German republic has agreed to pay this country over a period of years.
Cotton futures declined 8 to 12 points yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, following early steadiness.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--The Interstate Commerce Commission today wrote another chapter in the rate rivalry between a group of automobile manufacturers headed by Chrysler Corporation, and General Motors and Ford, when it approved a rise in railroad rates on new passenger automobiles from assembly points in the South.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 27 (AP)--Amid expressions of closer international relations between the United States and Japan, Yale accepted today from the Japanese people a bronze, life-size bust of Bob Kiphuth, its famed swimming coach.

Stanley A. Davis Jr., a suspended patrolman who was accused of invading the home of a Brooklyn man and shooting him down before his wife and children, was convicted last night of first-degree manslaughter.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Governor Dewey today proclaimed March as Red Cross Month in the state and urged all citizens to support without reservation the 1953 drive for funds. He also made a strong plea on behalf of the organization's blood donor program.
Edgar Kaiser, president of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, is negotiating with officials of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., for a merger of the two companies.

The theft of fur coats and pelts valued between $150,000 and $200,000 was described yesterday by Brooklyn detectives as they prepared to leave tomorrow by plane for Antwerp, Belgium, where a 50-year-old furrier is being held for United States authorities.

A re-examination of the laws that govern the practice of medicine is the object of identical bills introduced at Albany in the Assembly and Senate. If passed, a temporary state commission composed of three Senators, three Assemblymen and five persons to be appointed by the Governor would study the state laws that govern the licensing of medical practitioners and suggest needed reforms.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Feb. 27 (UP) The United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., approved today a 16-cent-an-hour "package" wage increase in settlement of a dispute that has halted production of Army tanks and Diesel locomotives at the American Locomotive Company plant here since last October.

ROME, Feb. 27 -- Confidence that the Bonn parliament would ratify the European Defense Community Treaty before the end of March was expressed by Dr. Konrad Adenauer. West German Chancellor and Foreign Minister, shortly before he left for home today after having attended the Rome conference of the defense community powers.

CANTON, N. Y., Feb. 27 -- An eight-inch snowfall provided a perfect setting for St. Lawrence University's eighteenth annual carnival today, but the Larries had to be content with runner-up honors to Middlebury in the opening events at the Snow Bowl.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 27 (UP) -- Officials of the Ambassador Hotel said today they had "bought up" the contract of Libby Burke, professional dancer, subpoenaed to appear before a House Un-American Activities Committee hearing here next month.

MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 27 -- One of Long Island's most valuable assets, 150 miles of Atlantic Ocean shore line, is getting its backbone strengthened with jetties, its inlets made navigable and highway bridges constructed or modernized this year through public works and special projects costing $40,170,000.

BERLIN, Feb. 27 -- Pastor Reinhold George, 40, of the leading Evangelical church in East Berlin was arrested last night after conducting vesper services. It appeared that his arrest might be part of a growing Communist drive against church youth groups.

As the guardian of the checkbook learns afresh the first of every month there is nothing easier in the world than to buy something. It is far easier to buy, for example, than it is later on to pay. Merchants, utilities, services are in business for the sole purpose of selling something, and they go out of their way to make this as comfortable an affair as possible.

The American Council of Christian Churches replied yesterday to an attack made on Thursday against its first president, the Rev. Dr. Carl McIntire, by the Western Section of the World Presbyterian Alliance meeting in Buck Hill Falls, Pa.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee has put off until next week any decision regarding the proposed promotion of seven generals on the retired list.

The annual Jewish Feast of Lots, or Purim, will start at sundown today and continue until sundown tomorrow. It is a celebration of the defeat of Haman, chief minister of the ancient Persian King Ahasuerus, when Haman sought to have Jews in Persia destroyed.
SPORTSMEN'S Show highlights:

A 4-year-old girl bitten outside her home in the Ozone Park area of Queens last Friday by a rat that later died of rabies is receiving daily anti-rabic injections to prevent the disease from developing the Department of Health said yesterday.
Minot Frazier (Mickey) Jelke was found guilty in General Sessions early last night on two counts involving the procurement of girls for prostitution. The all-male blue ribbon jury recommended mercy.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 27 -- The determination of the Nationalist regime here to force children to be educated in the Afrikaans dialect instead of English, the other legal national language, appears to be bringing on a new constitutional crisis.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The national capital is planning a warm but arduous welcome for Gen. James A. Van Fleet, the retiring commander of the United Nations Forces in Korea, when he gets to Washington next week on his trip home.

CAMADEN, N. J., Feb. 27 -- A Federal Court judge today fixed at $1,000,000 the amount of a bond to release the 10,000-ton tanker Monitor, seized by the Government Feb. 17 on grounds its ownership was alien.

Local government financing will figure largely again next week in the marketing of near issues of securities. Major borrowings will include sales Tuesday of $23,000,000 of highway and bridge bonds by the State of Maine, and $9,200,000 of Pascagoula River Bridge revenue bonds by the State of Mississippi.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 27 -- Ten Moslem religious leaders and more than 700 other persons were arrested here today for demonstrating against the Ahmadiya Community, a Moslem sect that is opposed by orthodox Moslems.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UP) -- A network of floating Atlantic emergency stations paid off dramatically when all ten persons aboard the Navy patrol plane were picked up within thirty-five minutes after the plane ditched in mid-ocean.

Bethlehem Steel Corporation's rated annual steelmaking capacity is expected to exceed 19,000,000 tons when the company's current expansion and modernization program is complete, E. G. Grace, chairman, announced yesterday in his annual report to stockholders and employes.
BOSTON, Feb. 27 -- Arthur J. B. Cartier, United States marshal for Boston, said today that he would refuse to relinquish his post unless President Eisenhower preferred charges.
The department store offers a "great opportunity for successful retailing careers," Thomas W. MacLeod, president of Stern Brothers, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Foreign Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives approved unanimously today the Eisenhower Administration's proposed United States manifesto against Soviet Russia's "perversion" of the wartime Yalta and Potsdam agreements and its resulting "subjugation of free peoples."

The fourteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 9-11 East Seventy-ninth Street has been sold by the Andear Amusement Corporation to a client of Paul Shaw, attorney. The building, on a plot 37 to by 100 feet, contains seven duplex suites and a ground floor doctor's apartment.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 27 -- Delegates at the United Nations expect the Security Council to be called into closed session next month to try to find a successor to Trygve Lie as Secretary General.

NEWARK, Feb. 27 -- Two paying passengers and twenty-six reporters, radio commentators, photographers and some top echelon officials of the Central Railroad of New Jersey gave Old 7209 an appropriate farewell this morning on its last run between this city, and Elizabethport, seven miles distant.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Saturday, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Frequent and bigger raids on the Communist China mainland may be expected in the future, George Yeh, Nationalist China's Foreign Minister, said yesterday.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in February dropped to its lowest since October, but was above the corresponding month last year. The turnover was above the million-share mark in every session with sales expanding to 2,372,250 shares, on Feb. 25, the largest since October, 1951, following news off reduced margin requirements and lifting of price controls on copper.
SCULTHORPE, England, Feb. 27 (Reuters) -- United States airmen stationed near this Norfolk village of 600 have finally broken the ice with the local girls, but it took a flood disaster to do it.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, called on the Eisenhower Administration today to make public the terms of all compromise settlements reached in tax cases.

MISS FANNY BRICE made as many persons happy by her eerie acting and eerier singing as by anything else that happened in her lifetime. A great deal of that comic and yet somehow wonderfully hard-fisted exuberance lives on in this book about her, "The Fabulous Fanny,"* by Norman Katkov. She dominates a page as triumphantly as she ever dominated a stage.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- President Eisenhower asserted his leadership today to preserve the Council of Economic Advisers and the objectives of the Employment Act of 1946. The fate of both had been in doubt in recent weeks.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 27 -- The Giants have only one unsigned player on their roster, but the batter could become serious within the next two days.

ST. CLAIR, Mich., Feb. 27 (AP) -- General Foods Corporation said today it was selling its Diamond Crystal-Colonial Salt division to the Moore family of St. Clair, the original founders of the business.

SARASOTA, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias clipped five strokes off par to take a two stroke lead at the end of the first eighteen holes of the Sarasota women's invitation golf tournament today.

In an adjoining column Arthur J. Goldberg, general counsel of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, takes issue with our editorial of Feb. 18 which proposed to substitute an eighty-day waiting period for the present Taft-Hartley injunction in emergency disputes that would endanger the "national health and safety."

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- Celluloid collars, open-top cars and Irenee du Pont's memory were discussed today in Federal District Court here before Judge Walter J. LaBuy as the du Pont anti-trust trial ended the week on a humorous note.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- An informed source said today Britain has laid before the United States Government proposals aimed at "real progress" toward making the pound a freely convertible currency.

A shrewd hunch, a vain race with a subway train and then another hunch paid off for two Brooklyn policemen yesterday as they captured two youths who only minutes earlier, they said, had mugged and robbed a broker.

TORONTO, Feb. 27 (AP) -- A Toronto doctor was arrested today on charges of making false statements in an alleged attempt to smuggle a Canadian baby into New York. A Brooklyn couple, awaiting trial in the case, told the police they had paid $400 for the infant.

HAVANA, Feb. 27 -- The political picture of Cuba underwent a radical change tonight as President Fulgencio Batista and his Cabinet postponed the election scheduled for next November to June, 1954, and announced that Senor Batista would continue as President until the Congress elected at that time decided how long he should remain in office and when Presidential elections should be held.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Dhe Konservativ Guvernment suferd its ferst difiet in Parlement tuudel on dhe kuestshen ov simplifaid speling, but noubudi wuried mutah abaut dhe konsikuensez bikoaz ounli 118 memberz aut ov 625 wer prezent foar dhe vouting.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- A marine corporal from Michigan will receive the Medal of Honor from President Eisenhower March 12, the first war hero to be decorated by the new President.

The latest ideas in purifying the air over the nation's cities are being adopted by industry at the rate of $120,000,000 a year. A report to this effect was put before the Air Pollution Abatement Conference in Detroit yesterday by R. T. Griebling of the Air Pollution Control Association.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 27 (UP) -- Mark-Ye-Well heads a field of eight horses named overnight to start in tomorrow's $135,000 Santa Anita Handicap in which he is expected to lead them to the wire.

Now that the problem of the Sudan has been settled by the Feb. 12 agreement granting self-determination to the Sudanese, the Suez Canal Zone is the next on the list. This is one of the nerve centers of the world. It is the focal point where three continents meet. Even with the Suez Canal knocked out by bombs, that neck of land would be vital to the defense of the West.

Jean Madeira, who had been scheduled to make her first appearance as Baba, the bearded lady, at last night's performance of "The Rake's Progress" at the Metropolitan Opera House, on short notice undertook to substitute as Mother Goose as well.

A continued demand for residential property in Jersey City, N. J., is reported by J. I. Kislak, Inc. Sales there handled by the broker included 89 Gates Avenue, for William McLaughlin to Leo F. Clark; 14 Sherman Place, for Russell Woodell to Clay A. Dickinson; 136 Clendenny Avenue, for Anthony J. Mongiello to Patsy J. Juliano, and 267 Lembeck Avenue, for John R. Burnett Jr. to Harry B. Garrison.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Ten Navy airmen crash-landed a crippled plane in mid-Atlantic today and were snatched to safety in a dramatic rescue by the Coast Guard.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- The creation of a Federal Department of Welfare cannot destroy the essential voluntary services to communities in this country, Fred K. Hoehler, executive director of the Citizens Committee of Greater Chicago and former Director of Welfare of Illinois, today told the Midwest Conference of the National Council on Family Relations here.

Former Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind yesterday put forth proposals that he said constituted "a very mild dose of self-regulation" to curb what he described as excesses of the press in reporting criminal trials and contraventions of the legal code of ethics by prosecutors in giving out information improperly.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Senator Frank Carlson of Kansas, one of President Eisenhower's closest campaign advisers, held out new hope in a Senate speech today for drastic cuts in Federal spending and a tax reduction this year.

Five Staten Island bookmakers yesterday lost their bid to be released from jail while they appeal their contempt of court convictions. They are serving 30-day sentences for refusal to testify before the grand jury investigating gambling and corruption in Richmond.

A site for a new factory at 228th Street and 145th Avenue in Springfield Gardens, Queens, has been purchased by the Standard Cellulose and Novelty Company, manufacturer of plastic novelties and party goods. The parcel, comprising 10,000 square feet, was acquired from the Consolidated Fur Corporation in a transaction negotiated by the Trylon Business Exchange.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 27 -- The first indication of the Government's decision to resort to deficit financing to meet the additional development expenditure required to implement the nation's five-year plan came today from the Finance Minister, Sir Chintaman Deshmukh, when presenting the annual budget to the House of the People (lower House of Parliament).
PARIS, Feb. 27 -- Premier Rene Mayer's substantial majority in the National Assembly was threatened today by the opposition to the European army project by the followers of Gen. Charles De Gaulle.
" A Pin to See the Peep Show," the drama by F. Tennyson Jesse and E. M. Harwood about a British murder case, is being scheduled for Broadway early next season under the sponsorship of Nancy Davids.

VIENNA, Feb. 27 (AP) -- President Theodor Koerner asked the conservative People's party today to nominate one of its members to be Austria's Chancellor. The general supposition was that Dr. Leopold Figl would be nominated to succeed himself.
DULUTH, Minn., Feb. 27 (AP) -- The Oliver Iron Mining Company, a United States Steel Corporation subsidiary, is mapping plans for a $60,000,000 ore beneficiation plant at Two Harbors, Minn.

Sales of the Standard Oil Company (Kentucky) in 1952 were the largest in its 67-year history, but earnings increased only $494,551 over 1951 because of higher taxes and operating costs, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

The State Congress of Industrial Organizations assailed yesterday the Governor's Commission on Educational Television for rejecting a Board of Regents proposal to build and operate a ten-station television network in the state.

Importers were surprised yesterday to learn that a bill had just been introduced in Congress to remove tariff duties entirely from imports of automobiles, trucks, buses and certain parts. The general duty rate on vehicles is 10 per cent.

HOUSTON, Feb. 27 (UP) - Mike Homa, a 29-year-old former pro basketball player from Rye, N. Y., scored a three-under-par 69 today to share the thirty-six-hole lead in the $20,000 Houston open golf tournament with Dr. Cary Middlecoff of Memphis at 139.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 27 -Alarmed by an increase in both the extent and intensity of Communist activity, the Federal Government intends to press for an early decision on its suit to ban the Communist party in West Germany.

One of the largest international debt-settlement agreements in history was signed in London yesterday between Western Germany and eighteen other nations, including the United States, Britain and France. Under this agreement Western Germany undertakes to pay a total of $3,270,000,000 to some thirty nations in final settlement of Germany's pre-war and post-war obligations.
Foreign movies comprise the day's offerings, with three films opening at first-run houses. At the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse is a pair of French films, "Ramuntcho" and "Sextette."

It would be nice to report this morning that when Mambo, the male gorilla, met Sumaili, the female gorilla, at the Bronx Zoo for the first time yesterday, it was love at first sight. Unfortunately, it just wasn't so.

NEWARK, Feb. 27 -- A National Labor Relations Board election to determine the choice of union representation for 5,000 employes of six major breweries in this area was won overwhelmingly today by the American Federation of Labor.
MIAMI, Feb. 27 -- There'll be big doings at the Hialeah cavalry post tomorrow.

Bonds called for payment before maturity in February totaled $17,744,000, the smallest amount for any month since April 1952, and the least for a February since 1949. The month's total compared with $124,241,000 in the preceding month and $26,114,000 in February 1952.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- The State Banking Department announced today that the Bank of Huntington and Trust Company, 250 Main Street, Huntington, Suffolk County, has received a certificate of authority to operate a personal loan department at one or more of its authorized places of business.
Five exhibitions of paintings by European and American artists are among those on view this week.

The Foreign Minister of the Netherlands attributes the progress toward unity achieved at the Rome meeting of the sponsors of the European Defense Community to the recent visit to Europe of the American Secretary of State and the Director of the Mutual Security Agency.
PARIS, Feb. 25 -- Beautiful tailoring and distinctive detailing characterized the spring collections of Manguin, Patou and Kogan.

Bands of contrasting graining, metal tipped legs and mitered construction for bases are some of the "fashion" features displayed in a new group of moderately priced furniture, now on view at Sloane's.

By noon yesterday most of the week's gains had been erased the New York Stock Exchange, but the afternoon saw a minor rally that produced a net gain for the day and left the market most exactly at its level of Feb. 6.

We can see a difference in the western sky these days as the hour of twilight approaches. Those inky purple patches that were everywhere at the appointed hour for sunset a month ago have been undergoing a gradual change. The onrushing night has been offering an increasingly feeble resistance to the revealing light of day.

DARWIN, Australia, Feb. 27 (Reuters) -- An American husband-wife anthropological team has turned up fresh evidence that the Australian aborigine has a common ancestry with the Malay peoples of Southeast Asia.

The American-Hawaiian Steamship Company, the oldest operator in the intercoastal steamship business and one of the senior lines of the American merchant marine, announced yesterday that it was suspending its service temporarily.
MANILA, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The United Kingdom spoke out against barter at the United Nations trade promotion conference today. Israel, Indonesia and Czechoslovakia said they were for it, if necessary.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 27 -- Communism is gaining recruits daily in Pakistan, partly because of a severe economic recession and partly in reaction against a seeming tendency of the United States to favor India in that country's disputes with her smaller neighbor, according to views of high officials, editors and others ascertained in a week's tour of the three major cities of Western Pakistan.

As Frank Landaus, a chauffeur for a fabrics concern, approached his company's offices at 1:30 A. M. yesterday, he recognized a neighbor and former fellow-worker at the entrance to the building at 609 West Fifty-first Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement today by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, concerning the management of the State Department:

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad should have a minimum net income this year of about $4,000,000, Frederic C. Dumaine Jr., president, told a meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 27 -- A two-day conference to raise funds for United Nations technical aid projects closed today without reaching its $25,000,000 goal.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 27 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury today returned an indictment charging the J. R. Watkins Company and thirteen persons with conspiracy to evade taxes on alcohol used in liniment taken internally.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 27 -- Twenty-nine Jersey Central passenger trains were tied up, delaying hundreds of New York commuters between Elizabeth and Plainfield from ten minutes to more than an hour during the morning rush period today.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Jacob L. Holtzmann, chairman of a special committee of the Board of Regents on Educational Television, said today that an application had been filed with the Federal Commnnications Commission for a one year's extension of construction permits granted for seven stations.
The espousal in your Feb. 18 editorial of an eighty-day waiting period in emergency disputes in lieu of the injunction is, in fact, an implicit recognition of the evils of the injunction.

DETROIT, Feb. 27--Negotiations between the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., on revision of their five-year escalator contract were conducted behind closed doors today.

Frozen fish processed in conventionalized shapes -- squares, rectangles, rounds, sticks and cubes -- is a piscatorial innovation in prospect for the future. New Yorkers probably will not be able to purchase the products until some time next summer, but food editors sampled them yesterday at a meeting at the St. Regis Hotel arranged by the originator, SeaPak Corporation, St. Simons Islands, Ga. Since 1949 this concern has been freezing shrimp.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. took the first steps today in a program that is expected to result in the eventual replacement by Republicans of most of the ninety-four United States Attorneys who have served in Democratic Administrations.

New bonds publicly offered here in February were up sharply from a year ago and the total was the largest for any February in over twenty-five years. The heaviest industrial and public utility bond financing in several months helped well the February offerings.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 27 -- Beating a three-day deadline imposed by a statute of limitations, the special Hudson County grand jury investigating conditions along the waterfront today handed up two indictments in connection with the bombing of the headquarters here of Local 1247, International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., on March 2, 1951.

Seized last July by Government agents and charged with desertion, a 36-year-old veteran with an honorable discharge filed suit yesterday in Federal Court for a $50,000 judgment against the Government for "culpable negligence and carelessness."

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27 -Chuck Dressen sent his Dodgers through a six-inning game today and the old saying that "the pitchers are ahead of the hitters," proved true again. The team managed by Roy Campanella made three hits and won the game, 1 -- 0, while Duke Snider's boys made only two hits.

It will soon be possible to drop into a "health center," drop a coin in a machine and receive a massage to relieve aching joints and muscles. Such a center has been developed by Grant S. Jardine in Peoria, Ill. Mr. Jardine opened his center about a month ago and reports business booming since. He plans to open another establishment in Chicago soon and then branch out throughout the nation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- A continuing rise in industrial production marked the trend of business in this country during January and February, the Federal Reserve Board said today in its monthly report on economic developments.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 (AP) -- A New York medical examiner said flatly today that infants do not suffocate from pillows, bedcovers or bedclothing. Dr. Jacob Werne said he had performed or witnessed autopsies on several thousand infants in the last twenty-two years without finding a single case of suffocation from those means caused by faulty posture of the baby.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The index of consumer prices, issued in completely revised form for the first time, dropped two-tenths of a point between mid-December and mid-January, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Feb. 27 -- President Eisenhower spent a couple of hours at the practice tee this morning, but still could not break 90 on his first eighteen-hole round on the Augusta National Golf Club course.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore and Controller J. Raymond McGovern proposed tonight to Mayor Impellitteri and members of the New York City Board of Estimate that a conference be held here at 1 P. M. on Monday for the purpose of making a new approach to the problem of solving the city's fiscal woes.
NEWARK, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Milt Campbell, Plainfield High School star, won the first two events in the twenty-ninth Newark Athletic Club track and field championships today.

Parking violations charged to owners of United Nations cars in Thirty-fourth Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas have brought another protest from the Thirty-fourth Street-Midtown Association. Letters urging that the vehicles be kept from idling at the curb were sent to Secretary General Trygve Lie and Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan yesterday by N. Peter McLean, executive secretary of the association.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Robert N. Denham, former general counsel for the National Labor Relations Board, today indirectly accused Paul M. Herzog, N. L. R. B. chairman, of getting him dismissed.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 27 -- The Nationalist newspaper Die Transvaler reports from Windhoek in the South-West Africa trust territory an extraordinarily large sale to native Africans in South-West Africa of the favorite weapon of the Kenya Mau Mau secret society with which its members have committed most of their murders.

BONN Germany, Feb. 27 -- A warrant has been issued by the British High Commissioner's court for the arrest of former Gen. Bernhard Lammerding, commander of the S. S. division Das Reich in France in 1944.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Average primary market prices increased 0.1 per cent over the week ended Feb. 24 to 109.7 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

In your excellent review of the Hamiltonian and Jeffersonian traditions (Topics of The Times, Feb. 22), you seem to follow the politicians in assuming that these traditions are entirely consistent. If the New Dealers did not express an agreement with Hamilton to the effect that "government is the business of the rich, the well-born and the educated," they certainly utilized his theory to an amazing degree, especially in the latter two categories.
Thirteen hundred persons attended a dinner last night given by The Friars in the Waldorf-Astoria to honor Bob Hope for his fifteen years of service as a motion picture and radio star.

In your editorial of Feb. 19 on the protracted Chinese-Soviet economic negotiations in Moscow you suggest that the Chinese "are learning again that the Soviet Union is giving nothing away" and have found Soviet deliveries to China disappointing. This conjecture finds striking support from official Communist figures.
Local anesthesiologist condemned yesterday the introduction of a bill in the State Legislature that would outlaw the use of sodium pentothal as an anesthetic on persons under 16 years old.
TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 28 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,539, for the period to 6 A. M., Saturday, Korean time:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Department of Agriculture will continue to support dairy products at 90 per cent of parity for another year beginning April 1, Secretary Ezra Taft Benson announced today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 27 -- With deck officers restrained by court order from taking any mass strike action, radio operators sat down late this afternoon with officials of the Pacific Maritime Association in an unsuccessful attempt to win a wage increase similar to one that the shipowners had denied yesterday to the deck officers.
The State Liquor Authority said yesterday it had refused renewal of a lencese and had filed charges against an East Side restaurant known as Bill Connolly's, Inc., at 958 Second Avenue.

GENEVA, Feb. 24 -- The International Committee of the Red Cross is suffering from acute financial anemia, partly because it is so famous that much of the world takes its existence for granted, partly, perhaps, because it is much too discreet for its own good.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of use to the homemaker.

Jennie Tourel sang a request program last night. It was the tenth anniversary of the mezzo-soprano's first Town Hall recital, and a capacity audience came to listen. During the course of her activities in this country Miss Tourel has worked up a sizable, faithful following; and, as might be expected, enthusiasm ran somewhat higher than high.
I have read with interest your editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES, Feb 21, with reference to the new word "andor" and especially was it interesting to me, since I am the author of the bill.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today that he would not shake hands with Andrei Y. Vishinsky unless the Soviet Foreign Minister made the first move.
DETROIT, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The auto industry is "gathering momentum for one of the best production years in history," Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Congressional investigations into the extent to which communism might have infiltrated into the country's educational system took a new turn today. The House Committee on Un-American Activities voted unanimously to recommend contempt proceedings against a witness -- Barrows Dunham of 127 Bentley Avenue, Cynwyd, Pa.--who invoked constitutional protection and refused to testify beyond giving his name, address and time and place of his birth.

The nation's top track and field performers, who have specialized in records, racing thrills and disputed finishes all season, will make their final 1953 appearance in Madison Square Garden tonight, at the thirty-fourth annual indoor games of the New York Chapter, Knights of Columbus.
CLINTON, Ill., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Nurses who walked out of Clinton's only hospital in a dispute over administration agreed today to return to work "unconditionally."

MANHATTAN, Kan. A STUDENT of that peculiarly American phenomenon "sports fever" could not do better, right now, than visit this Kansas college town where everybody is "nuts about basketball." The scene here is typical of hundreds of other communities over the country, though there are few perhaps where the mania is more highly concentrated upon a single sport.

LEOPOLD STOKOWSKI'S old recording, vintage 1940, of Gliere's Ilya Mourometz attracted many people toward the virtually unknown score, and also raised a few questions about how the symphony would sound in an uncut version (Stokowski's was abridged).
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 28 (AP) -- New Haven's unkempt Potter's Field, burial place of hundreds of homeless and penniless, is to have its barren face lifted.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- A Greco-Roman cargo ship that plied between the Greek islands and the southern coast of France in the third century before Christ is being raised from the bottom of the Mediterranean Sea off Marseille, it was announced today.

TOKYO, Sunday, March 1 -- The United States heavy cruiser Los Angeles steamed into Wonsan Harbor yesterday and started pounding that Communist port on the North Korean east coast with her 8-inch-gun batteries. Navy planes from Carrier Task Force 77 spotted the enemy's coast artillery and storage positions for the cruiser.
CAMDEN, N. J., Feb. 28 -- The eightieth anniversary of poet Walt Whitman's arrival in Camden finds a dwindling number of visitors to his two-story, gray clapboard home here.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Carmen Basilio, Canastota, N. Y., welterweight, tonight pounded out a unanimous ten-round decision over Vic Cardell of Hartford. Conn., in a nationally televised boxing match at the Toledo Arena.

CALL it a landscape with figures. Call it a novel of character which deals in a sensory, naturalistic way with the intricate human relationships of an Australian village. But it would be trivially inaccurate to decide that "The Intruder" is "regional" because the author is Australian and places her story in a setting that is familiar to her.

FLOWER and garden shows may be seen during the next few weeks in many cities across the country. In Cleveland, Ohio, the Home and Flower Show has already opened, and will continue through March 8 in Cleveland's Public Auditorium.

TORONTO, Feb. 23 (UP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs, with two rookies in the line-up, shut out the New York Rangers, 3 -- 0, tonight to take third place in the National Hockey League, 2 points ahead of the idle Chicago Black Hawks.
CANTON, N. Y., Feb. 28 -- St. Lawrence's University's Larries today rose to their greatest heights in skiing by capturing their eighteenth annual Winter Carnival ski meet against five other foes.

RAMSEY, N. J., Feb. 28 -- The Bible School of the First Presbyterian Church in this small Bergen County community is going ahead with its plans to publish its annual "Who's Who" directory in May, but liquor advertisements will be discontinued in this year's edition.
American ideas and methods which have been responsible for a national output measured in astronomical terms are in the process of being adopted by Western Europe to increase stocks of defense needs.

AT a time when our Formosa policy is a matter of grave concern and wide discussion it is a good thing to have a background of sound fact and measured judgment. It can be found in astonishingly compact form in Joseph W. Ballantine's modest book.

BUTLER, N. J., Feb. 28 -- A $443,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation will help to make possible the construction of the Forrest S. Chilton 3d Memorial Hospital in near-by Pompton Plains. The forty-seven-bed institution is estimated to cost $872,000.

STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 28 -- Dr. Leo Davidoff, a neurosurgeon, will be honored by the Stamford Chapter of Hadassah on Wednesday at the Stamford Jewish Center, when he will receive the second annual "Honor Thy Neighbor" award in recognition of his medical contributions and work in behalf of the Hadassah-Hebrew University Medical School.
" The primary responsibility for bipartisanship [in foreign policy] rests upon the Administration in power."

IF the current season is not a distinguished one, the critics are in part responsible, for they have failed to endorse at least one drama which had been enthusiastically received by its audiences. "The Emperor's Clothes," while it may not have been a work of technical perfection, was sincerely written, genuinely moving and provocative.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The resentment of a number of Republicans in Congress over the absence from the Administration's text of the "secret agreements" resolution of any criticism of Presidents Roosevelt and Truman for making these agreements with Soviet Russia was probably a response the President and Secretary of State Dulles could largely have forestalled by including in the language the stipulation Senator Taft now proposes to insert.

In one of the greatest exhibitions of middle-distance running ever seen at Madison Square Garden, Marvelous Mal Whitfield last night broke two world indoor records and narrowly missed cracking two others.

ADD to the strange-job category the avocation of publicist Allan Ullman who continues to turn out smooth, ultra-readable novelizations of screen-plays -- after the story has arrived at the shooting-script level, with publication after the actual release.

RALEIGH, N. C., Feb. 28 (UP) -- Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, said tonight the Democrats could not regain power in Washington if the "conspiracy" to drive the South out of the party continued.

GENEVA, Feb. 26 -- The tremendous differences in farm productivity, closely related to differences in general industrial and commercial development, that characterize Western European agriculture are reduced to comparative statistics in a study published jointly today by the United Nations Food Agriculture Organization and the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UP) -- The Air Force's floating ice island is making a slow-motion trip around the top of the world and in time may be on the Russian side of the North Pole.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Feb. 28 -- New Jersey State Highway officials said this week they finally had solved an alignment problem for a new Route 202 near Boonton and construction there might start in the fall. Survey of the new route has been completed.
Samuel S. Koenig, 81 years old, Republican Assembly District leader on the lower East Side for fifty years and still active in politics, was honored last night at a dinner in the Astor Hotel.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 -- Eighteen waterfront unions deferred action today on a proposal to stage a sympathy walkout Monday in support of 300 striking tugboat workers.

Richard H. Balch, Democratic State Chairman, asserted yesterday that the plan of Governor Dewey's Administration to increase rents. lift controls in some areas and de-control vacant apartments would create hardship for tenants, who must make their voices heard at Albany to retain rent controls.

BERLIN, Feb. 28 -- Spurred by fear that their last escape route to the West might be cut soon, a record-breaking number of refugees fled to West Berlin today, bringing the total for February to about 41,000. The largest number to seek refuge in any previous month was 25,400, the figure for January.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Feb. 28 -- Unless March produces a near-record amount of snow, northern New York will count the winter of 1952-53 as the most open in its modern weather history. And unless a large amount of snow is forthcoming, there will be more simulated parachute drops for the ironically named Exercise Snowstorm now under way here.

The planning of fashion, as seen in the coordination of all its related elements, is increasingly evident this spring. The costume, a 1953 essential, has reached a high point in its development. All of its component parts are closely integrated Blouses harmonize with suits; dress and coat lining of identical fabric tell a new inside story.
