HOW designs and inscriptions on postal paper, are used by many governments to diffuse knowledge and advocate policies among the peoples of the world is told in "Postage Stamps as Propaganda," a twenty-seven page monograph just published by Public Affairs Press, 2153 Florida Avenue, Washington, D. C.

THE Caribbean, the most mysterious and perverse of seas, is the locale of this tale of a painstaking search against great odds -- a search by determined men for the motorship Christophe and her crew and the evil persons (or thing) that made her vanish, leaving no sea-borne trace.

DARIUS MILHAUD has pretty definite ideas about the use of the written word as a form of communication. Words are for others, notes are for himself. Despite the fact that he has just completed his autobiography, he regards writing as being far, far down on the scale of the world's pleasures.

DETROIT, Feb. 28 -- The schools and colleges of the Detroit metropolitan area, off to a promising start in the field of educational television, hope to be operating their own ultra-high frequency channel by the end of this year.
Stanton Griffis, former Ambassador to Spain, advocated yesterday that the United States, for its own protection, should assist Spain in strengthening her military defense against Russia.

Post Wheeler, retired diplomat and author, announced last week that he had sent to the Treasury Department in Washington a check for $25, representing the return of a month's increase in his pension as a foreign service officer.

HARTFORD, Feb. 28. -- The Connecticut General Assembly, which has been asked by Gov. John Davis Lodge to raise $42,000,000 in additional taxes, will get down to brass tacks on the state budget with a Finance Committee hearing on the state sales tax scheduled for Thursday.
Two large questions have been raised by the six-week effort of the Eisenhower Administration to mount a counter-offensive in the cold war. They are:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, said today a suggested budget-balancing ceiling of $66,000,000,000 on Federal spending this fiscal year was impossible. The Republican leader's colleague, Senator Frank Carlson, Republican of Kansas, proposed the spending limit in a Senate speech Friday.

On Feb. 22 a letter written by Prof. John Hanna of Columbia University Law School was published in your columns. Professor Hanna, who happens to be a former instructor of mine, was perturbed about the fate of the conservative teacher in the liberal environment he finds prevailing in American universities.

PORTRAYING the once-glamorous life of Occidentals on the China coast, this novel focuses on Shanghai twenty years ago. The well-documented narrative winds, with nostalgic interest, along such crowded thoroughfares as the Bund and Nanking, Bubbling Well and North Szechuan Roads, past the Astor House, the British Consulate and the Customs Building, over the Whangpoo River, Soochow Creek and the Grand Canal.

BUSINESS going on as usual in these premises, and how formidably it does involve human beings. That is the theme or idea or dominant thought of "Nine to Five," a novel which sets out to render -- between the standard eight daytime hours of business, with a few illuminating nighttime flashbacks -- the lives of quite a number of people employed by a big investment firm in Boston.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -Today's issue of The Congressional Record carries this curious heading on Page 1548:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The revised Consumers' Price Index -- the most important Government statistic in our economic life -- came out this week with its body streamlined and its motor tuned up. The economic mechanics had been tinkering with it for three years.

A man, charged with driving while intoxicated, eluded three police patrol cars in a wild, fifteen-minute fifteen-mile chase down the West Side Highway early yesterday and was trapped only after his 1949 automobile had crashed into an abutment at Twenty-third and West Streets.

A ground-breaking ceremony for a $2,550,000 student residence, Frank W. Olin Hall, will be held at 4 P. M. on Wednesday at the Cornell University Medical College, 1300 York Avenue. The building will be named for a Cornell alumnus who at his death was a prominent chemical manufacturer.

IN one of the first books for young people to come out of post-war Germany, we meet the Lechow family, refugees from the East Zone. The father is still in a prison camp in Russia, one son is dead, but Frau Lechow and her four children work valiantly to make the best of the two rooms assigned to them in a battered town crowded with other refugees.

BE prepared -- to be thrilled by adventure according to the finest traditions of scouting. Here, reprinted from the pages of Boys' Life magazine, are fifteen stories that translate the Scout motto into action.

This theory upon which the Stratfordians must depend absolutely * * * is one that every creator knows to be false.

ON March 19 Chicago's new $10,000,000 Greyhound Terminal on the north side of the Loop will be opened to public inspection. The next day, a Friday, buses will begin using the new building, which is bounded by Clark, Randolph and Lake Streets, and service will be discontinued at Greyhound's present stations on South Wabash Avenue and North State Street.

The Maritime Administration expects to break out from the Reserve Fleet in May twenty or more ships especially designed for service in ice-cluttered waters to transport supplies for the growing network of air bases in the Greenland area.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28 (AP) -Day in and day out, close of fifteen years without a strike, 900 unionized tile setters here have kept busy -- the result of a unique labor-management approach.

LUXEMBOURG -- Beauty, here, is strictly in a nutshell. A goodly supply of it, natural and man-made, is squeezed into the 999 square miles of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg -- green-clad hills and valleys, studded here and there with cities, towns, villages, hamlets, solitary farmsteads or ancient castles.

THE final round of the Vanderbilt Cup tournament last Tuesday ended the busiest six weeks of tournaments bridge New York has ever known. Between Jan. 5 and Feb. 20 the city was host to the world championship team match, a contest between European and American champion women the master's individual tournament, and the Vanderbilt Cup team tournament.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 28 -- A majority of the Second Senate of the Federal Constitutional Court is hostile toward the Government's suit on the Allied-West German treaty system, authoritative Allied sources reported tonight.

THE forthcoming stand of the New York City Opera will be the longest spring season the company has ever given. Its span from March 19 to May 3 makes it a week longer than last year's spring season and twenty-five days longer than the 1951 spring season.

So February comes to its end, and no matter how it bows out, in rain or snow or starlight or chill wind under a lowering cloud, it has been a rare month, a time of early beginnings. Seldom does March walk in, in this latitude, and find gray birch catkins in the woods.

THREE years have passed since the signing of the Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship, Alliance and Mutual Aid at Moscow. During that period, judging by all the outward signs, the partnership between the world's two leading Communist powers has grown steadily stronger.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 28 -- The varied ideas, customs and achievements of hundreds of peoples in the world today and data on past cultures are being recorded and systematically filed here.

Earthquake waves are transmitted at different rates of speed in different regions beneath the surface. The reason is that the density and elastic properties of the material below the earth's crust vary. From the arrival times of earthquake waves it is possible to deduce various properties of the earth's interior.

BY all the signs and portents, which are mainly box-office receipts, motion-picture business is on the rise again. At least, it has built up rather nicely over the vast couple of weeks, with a peak of prosperity developing over the Washington's Birthday long week-end.
SARASOTA, Fla., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Mrs. Babe Zaharias shot a three-under-par 73 today and increased her lead after 36 holes of the 54-hole Sarasota women's invitation golf tournament to three strokes.

The establishment of pension plans is the order of the day. Income tax laws are generally favorable to such plans. But what shall be done for the employes who, by reason of attained age, are excluded from their benefits?
Metallic yarns made of laminated aluminum foil are providing a wide new range of color effects to textile fabrics and their increased use is creating an important new segment of the textile industry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Congressional outcry over the failure of the Navy's promotion system to make a rear admiral out of Capt. Hyman G. Rickover is beginning to remind veterans of the row over General "Billy" Mitchell and his advocacy of air power.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- A century ago Neill S. Brown, astute United States Minister to Czarist Russia, complained of "the secrecy with which everything is done." He reported to Washington: "It is only by weighing circumstances that opinions can be arrived at; and formed this way they are always liable to be fallacious."

C. Douglas Dillon, this country's new Ambassador to France, sailed for his new post yesterday afternoon aboard the United States liner America. He expressed hopes of resolving the "natural misunderstandings" that had arisen between the two nations.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 28 -- Japanese opinion was pictured yesterday as unconvinced of the necessity of rearmament, as disturbed "by the American proposals to prepare Asians to fight Asians, as lacking knowledge of what the Chinese Communists are doing or planning to do and as having less confidence than some Americans in the capacity of the present Nationalist leadership on Formosa to liberate China.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Plans for two Congressional committees to combine their forces in hunting out Communists in the educational field were disclosed here today by Congressional sources. They hinted that the White House, through Maj. Gen. W. B. Persons, White House liaison aide, would take a hand in working out the combined program.

The full installation and operation of a new two-way frequency modulation radio system replacing the Fire Department's obsolete radio system, which has been in use since 1937, was announced yesterday by Commissioner Jacob Grumet.

BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 28 -- A $1,500,000 expansion of the Louisiana State University football stadium was voted here today by the university board of supervisors despite urgent pleas to delay action to provide a possible chance for use of the money in building a new library.

ADMINISTRATIONS may come and go, hut James David Preston just stays. Currently at work for the Eighty-third Congress, Mr. Preston has been a Senate fixture since the days of President McKinley, back in 1897.

HOUSE plants are catching. Introduce a cliff dweller to a potted plant, merely hint at the fact that it will grow in a city apartment and -- stand back. First it's philodendron or Chinese evergreen; next week gardenias.

A collector's item, the 1933 recording of "Der Rosenkavalier," with Lotte Lehmann singing what many have considered the ideal interpretation of the Marschallin role, will be one of the musical attractions of the Wednesday noon to 2 P. M. concert at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

MONTREAL, Feb. 28 (UP) -- Detroit's dynamic Red Wings shaded the Montreal Canadiens, 4 -- 3, tonight to move 6 points in front of the National Hockey League and virtually clinch a fifth straight championship.

i The Thrift Shop of the Travellers Aid Society of New York will I be the beneficiary of the annual luncheon and fashion show to be held Thursday in the Terrace Room of the Plaza. Contributions of rummage, suitable for resale later at Everybody's Thrift Shop, 922 Third Avenue, will be accepted by Mrs. Emilio PittareUi, chairman of the committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Republican Senators favoring revision of President Eisenhower's manifesto against Soviet "perversion" of wartime agreements came forward today with an amendment designed to remove any possible implication of approval of secret clauses involving territorial concessions to Russia.

A NEW model 400 Graflex 22 twin-lens reflex camera with a Graphex shutter with speeds from one second to 1/400th, time and bulb, is announced by Graflex, Inc. The shutter synchronizes Type M flash lamps to 1/25th of a second, Type F lamps to 1/100th, and zero delay electronic at all shutter speeds.

ONE fine day this spring a small blond woman of 35, who happens to be the daughter-in-law of the President of France, will try to become the first woman in the world to fly faster than the speed of sound.

ALARMED at the steady increase of teenage "hot-rod" drivers and the upswing in highway accidents and fatalities attributable to their antics, the National Automobile Dealers Association has decided to wipe out the hot-rod evil at its source.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 28 -Recent political developments in the Patiala and East Punjab States Union, where the Sikhs with the support of the Communists have securely entrenched themselves in power with the Congress party in opposition, have been causing considerable concern to India's central Government.

IN an interesting little book published recently. "First Steps in a Grown-Up World" by Mary Edge Harlan (Abelard Press, $1.95), we came upon a brief but helpful reference to cooperative play groups and baby sitting projects.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UP) -- The million-dollar Eisenhower inauguration made a profit of better than 10 per cent. The committee that ran the big show has not finished counting the money yet but an aide said today the profit would be "in excess of $100,000."

The adoption of resolutions opposing anti-Semitism is not enough to meet the problem, Rabbi Ira Eisenstein declared in his sermon yesterday noon at the Synagogue of the Society for the Advancement of Judaism, 15 West Eighty-sixth Street. He is president of the Rabbinical Assembly of America which is composed of conservative rabbis.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- New and increasingly positive signs of an impending clash between national security requirements and campaign promises of budget and tax cuts have thrown the Republican party into a state of much anxiety and gloom.
Gov. John D. Lodge of Connecticut called upon the press of the country yesterday to help maintain "the principle of individual conviction" upon which the nation was founded.

PARIS, Feb. 28 -- France has experienced at least fourteen major changes in its form of government since 1789. This once prompted a cynic to remark that French Constitutions should be classified as periodical literature.

THE team of "Ike and Beetle" is back in business again after a lapse of seven years. Their last collaborative effort was when President Eisenhower was Supreme Commander of the Allied Expeditionary Forces guiding free nations to victory in World War II, and Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, the junior member of the firm, was his Chief of Staff.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 28 -- Navy's basketball team, enjoying one of the most successful seasons in its history, closed its regular campaign on a gala note today when it swept to an 84-60 victory over Army in the traditional battle between the service schools.

A vigorous denial that "extreme leftist inspiration" was back of Guatemala's social reform program was made yesterday by Dr. Guillermo Toriello-Garrido, Ambassador from Guatemala to the United States, in an address here.

IF James Burnham would brush the chips off his shoulders and set himself the task of writing a careful treatise on the strategy and tactics of how to liberate Eastern Europe from the Communist yoke he would be performing a first-class public service, and his views on the subject would be well worth hearing because he knows a great deal about Soviet Russia, communism and the prisoners of that evil combination.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taf Benson, disclosed today he was planning a fighting campaign across the nation to win support for a new farm program. It will include price supports as a form of minimum wage guarantee for farmers.

Michael Hoffman's brilliant and incisive reports to THE TIMES on European economic and financial developments fully deserve the attention which they receive in governmental and business circles, here and abroad. His dispatch, published Feb. 16, is particularly timely on the eve of the forthcoming negotiations with British and other European visitors which are to be conducted this month on the future of monetary and economic cooperation in NATO.

Two officials in the Voice of America headquarters here testified under oath yesterday that Hebrew language broadcasts had been ordered stopped last December, at the time when open Soviet anti-Semitism could have made them most effective. However, the order later was suspended before its effective date.

NOT too long ago it was generally believed that outside of the tropics orchids could only be grown by master gardeners or in carefully controlled greenhouses of the wealthy. Recently, however, the realization that many varieties of "exotic" orchids are, in fact, remarkably tough and hardy as house plants is becoming more widespread.

One of the three student leaders selected to address the faculty-student conference at the recent induction of Dr. Buell G. Gallagher as president of City College was foreign-born, 34-year-old Peter Sugar, who chose the occasion to express words of gratitude to his adopted country and his college.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UP) -- A proposal to give surplus American butter to needy friendly foreigners was made in the House of Representatives today.

PARIS, Feb. 28 -- A new stage in the struggle for a European union will begin Wednesday when Ambassador Herve Alphand, French chairman of the Interim Committee on the European army, will submit to the representatives of the five other signatories -- West Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg -- revised versions of the proposed French protocols to the treaty for a European Defense Community.

THE biggest ticket business in New York is conducted by the television and radio networks. Last year N. B. C. and C. B. S., the chains distributing the bulk of tickets, issued some 8,000,000 complimentary tickets to their various television and radio broadcasts.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 28 -- With more corporate office headquarters, thruway projects and airport improvements being developed in Westchester, county planners are taking a comprehensive look at the impacts of the transition and reported today a picture less gloomy than many home owners had feared.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 28 -- Although it is still winter according to the calendar, the Union County Mosquito Extermination Commission already is stepping up its war against Jersey's summer pests because of what George Powers, the commission's superintendent, terms a "wonderful winter."
I was amazed at Barbara Ward's article.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Stan Benham of Lake Placid and Jim Bickford of Saranac Lake today streaked down the Mount Van Hoevenberg bobsled run in record time to win the Adirondack A. A. U. two-man championship.
VIENNA, Feb. 28 -- Dr. Leopold Figl was entrusted today by President Theodor Koerner with the task of forming a new Government as a result of last week's general elections.

THIS new selection from George Orwell's essays is a companion volume to "Shooting an Elephant," published in 1950, the year of Orwell's early death. It is an equally rich, provocative mixture of politics, literary criticism and personal reminiscence.

City College's basketball team overcame a 34-30 half-time deficit to down Brooklyn College, 61 -- 57, at the losers' gymnasium last night. An overflow crowd of more than 3,000 kept up a constant chant as the Beavers pulled out a game in which the score changed hands twelve times.

EL PASO, Tex., Feb. 25 -- The Mexican movie actress, Rosaura Revueltas, who is being held here by United States Immigration Service officials, said this afternoon that George Negrete, the noted Mexican movie actor and executive secretary of the Mexican National Association of Actors, had informed her here by phone from Mexico City that the association had invoked a ban against all American movie actors now working in Mexico.
KANSAS CITY, Kan., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Wes Santee of Kansas ran the fastest indoor mile in Big Seven history, 4:08.3, in the final of the Conference indoor track meet tonight.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 28 (UP) -- A steamship company today asked Federal authorities to investigate possible sabotage after the second of its vessels went aground off the Mexican coast within a month.

REMARKABLY few singers of popular songs are all-around masters or mistresses of their field. There are, of course, numerous talented stylists or operators within a limited area who are beyond cavil in their specialties but it would scarcely use up the fingers of one hand to count those singers who, tackling almost any product of Tin Pan Alley, the musical stage or the back-room dive, can leave these songs better than they found them.

Bevo Francis, the most-talked-about college basketball player in the land, was among the 4,500 spectators who saw the New York Knickerbockers rally for an 85-74 victory over the Fort Wayne Pistons last night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

Re Hanson W. Baldwin's "Europe in 1953 -- A Reporter's Vignettes" (Feb. 15) -- to get the humor of -the Viennese chauffeur's allusion to "Erbsenkoenig und Menschenfeind" (King of the Peas, and Enemy of Humans) one must know of the play "Alpenkoenig and Menschenfeind" (King of the Alps and Enemy of Humans) written by Ferdinand Raimund, a popular Viennese playwright (1790-1836).

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UP) -- Senator Hugh Butler, chairman of the Interior and Insular Affairs Committee, said today that it. might vote to give to states a share in oil revenues from areas beyond their seaward "historical boundaries" as well as full title to submerged land inside those lines.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UP) -The question of whether motion picture stars and other entertainers can qualify for a special tax exemption because they work abroad headed for a showdown today, with the prospect that Congress would have to provide the answer.

Most merchants, some of whom operate the largest stores in the country, favor a manufacturer's right to fix minimim retail prices of his products, the Bureau of Education on Fair Trade declared last week. The organization, representing virtually all pro-fair trade retail interests, based its contention on a survey of fair-trade sentiment among stores of all sizes and types from coast to coast.

Many people will see snakes -- in a nice way -- on Fourth Avenue tomorrow. Fleming-Joffe, Ltd., the world's largest dealers in reptile skins, will be completing its move uptown from "The Swamp" at 10 Jacobs Street, down under the Brooklyn Bridge, where it has been for almost 100 years in the traditional and once flavorous center of the tanning and leather business.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 18 -- An apparent increase in the smuggling of drugs from Mexico to the United States has disturbed American control officials.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 28 -- Navy ended Army's five-year domination of the service swimming rivalry with a decisive 56-to-28 victory her today.

ROME, Feb. 28 -- Before leaving for Paris at noon today French Foreign Minister Georges Bidault threw some cold water over the hopes of those who thought that the decisions taken by the countries of the European Coal and Steel Community in Rome this week had removed all the difficulties standing in the way of early ratification of the European Defense Community Treaty by all the six powers concerned.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- London was somewhat mystified today by the unexpected and violent demonstration in Teheran in favor of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, but on the basis of information available it appeared that Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's attempt to bring pressure on the sovereign had backfired.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Temple staged a brilliant second-half rally tonight to turn back tournament-bound Manhattan College, 62 -- 57, before 4,000 fans at the Memorial Field house.

TRENTON, Feb. 28 -- Preparatory to enforcing New Jersey's new Motor Vehicle Security Responsibility Law. beginning April 1, William J. Deardon, Director of Motor Vehicles, announced today that an official leaflet explaning the law could be obtained at any motor vehicle license agency during the license renewal period.

THE majority report of the Temporary State Commission on the Use of Television for Educational Purposes, peremptorily rejecting the plan of the Board of Regents for a state-wide system of educational video, ranks as an incredibly clumsy and shocking document.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 28 -- Creation of a Labor-Industry Relations Board to offer voluntary mediation services in local labor disputes was announced today by Mayor Nicholas S. LaCorte. Named to the eleven-man board were representatives of the clergy, labor and industry.

THE great hospital ward with its Korean wounded and veterans of other wars has been waiting tensely for this moment. All morning the men have talked of other things from their beds or busy wheelchairs, but their thoughts and looks have never strayed far from the single one among them -- an Airman first class -- who lies silent and slack with apathy as always, unmindful of the tension about him.
THE idea of a musical recital on the E flat alto saxophone may strike one as faintly comical -- until one hears the new Sigurd Rascher Recital just issued by Concert Hall Society.

IF winter comes, the drive-ins cannot be far behind; and this year the open air theatres will be a spring and summer bumper crop. The construction restrictions because of scarcity of building materials held down last year's openings of new drive-ins to approximately 600.

SINCE the end of the war, Yugoslavia's film studios have produced twenty-five features, all but two of them concerned with the liberation of the country from the Germans and the accompanying political and economic revolution.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, March 1 (AP) -- Chinese Communist infantrymen banged into the United Nations lines all across the Korean Peninsula in the chill pre-dawn darkness today, but dug-in Allied troops stood their ground.

TODAY will see the final performances of the New Dance Group Festival at the Ziegfeld Theatre with Eve Gentry and Daniel Nagrin as guest soloists in the evening bill and Ronne Aul at the matinee. Seven works new to New York are on the day's list.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Feb. 28 --- A selected group of sixteen young men started recently the second semester of a five-year program of intensive "work-study" education at Adelphi College to prepare for positions of administrative responsibility in business and industry.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 28 -- Edible fish caught off New Jersey are the subject of a study being conducted by the Food Technology Department of Rutgers University's College of Agriculture.

CAIRO, Feb. 28 -- The unexpectedly happy outcome of negotiations between Britain and Egypt on the Sudan a little more than a fortnight ago have raised hopes here for an early settlement of the other major issue that has divided the two countries -- Egypt's demand for the immediate and unconditional evacuation of the "foreign troops" manning Great Britain's army and air base in the Suez Canal Zone.

Five thousand members of the New York Typographical Union No. 6, A. F. L., employed by New York commercial printing plants will receive gains totaling $6 a week under terms of a new contract ratified yesterday.

SEVENTY-FIVE-YEAR-OLD Paul Sachs, who has trained as many museum men as Ray Arcel has prize-fighters, ought to know what he is talking about when he appraises a museum. He was a visitor at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, the other day, looking at the handsome show, admirably selected from the vast collection and intelligently and attractively installed by the director, James Johnson Sweeney.

SOUTH HAVEN, Mich., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Three Navy fliers were rescued from Lake Michigan today after they had been forced by engine trouble to ditch their medium torpedo bomber in the icy, choppy waters.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 28 -- During the feudal slumber in which Guatemala existed under the regime of Gen Jorge Ubico, from 1930 to 1944, the law and the general were one. He traveled around the country dispensing justice on the spot and, as often as not, deciding on a man's guilt or innocence by the "cut" of his face.

NOW that his "I Confess" is being unveiled for public inspection, Alfred Hitchcock, a director who obviously likes to keep occupied, is back at the same stand again. Not only does the master of suspense have two properties set for filming but another one also is intriguing him, he revealed last week.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- The New York Good Roads Association accused "special interest groups" today of blocking the development of a progressive highway program by their unwillingness to take a realistic attitude toward the need for taxes to finance such a move.

DAVE was told by his father directly after his graduation from high school, "Don't listen to any heavy nonsense. Life will be your advice." And, within that frame, in an honest and compassionate family chronicle, Albert Halper has fashioned a series of disconnected episodes to portray the growing up of a boy on and off the West Side streets of Chicago, where the author himself was raised.

THE dogwood family, which numbers some of the most ornamental shrubs and trees, is so diverse that it is often difficult to believe that the species are related. Blooms, as different from each other as night from day, will appear first on one kind, then on another from March into July.
LONDON. Feb. 28 (Reuters@-- Results of today's British football games: I

The American Junior Red Cross chapters of Greater New York, which have become an integral part of the school system, will begin their annual enrollment campaign tomorrow in an effort to bring the membership rolls beyond the 1,000,000 mark.

HOUSTON, Feb. 28 -- Cary Middlecoff of Memphis, who for two days had to share the lead in the $20,000 Houston Open golf tournament, pulled one stroke ahead today with a 37, 35 -- 72 to bring his 54-hole total to 211.

Management should become alert to the challenge to pensions that has developed with the widening of Social Security benefits, Leroy A. Lincoln, chairman of the board of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company told the American Management Association in Chicago recently.

ACTING on the entirely laudable theory that no one should permit Cole Porter to be idle for too long, the firm of Cy Feuer and Ernest Martin disclosed the other day that they had reached an agreement with Mr. Porter to compose a score for a musical to be offered some time next season.

Much of the political history of the U. S. under the Truman Administration grew out of investigations by Congress -- notably into charges of corruption and communism in government. The investigations enabled Republicans and dissident Democrats to seize the initiative and deliver telling political blows against the White House.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Committee for Economic Development asserted in a report today that continued financial aid to Great Britain was the alternative to collapse of the Anglo-American alliance and diplomatic and economic isolation for the United States.

Partly for scientific, partly for sentimental reasons, the attention of the medical world was focused early last month on Marius Renard, a 16-year-old French lad. Young Renard ruptured a kidney when he fell three stories from a ladder on Dec. 18, 1952. To stop a hemorrhage the surgeons of the Necker Hospital in Paris removed the kidney.

I FANCY the elephants would have been gentler masters than we: more live-and-let-live in allowing other species to stay here. Our way is to kill good and bad, male and female and babies, till the last few survivors lie hidden away from our guns.
LONDON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Favored Arsenal was upset by Blackpool, 2 -- 1, today in the quarter-final round of the Football Association Cup tournament.
A huge question mark appeared last week over the economic outlook for Brazil as the result of its need for a $300,000,000 credit from the Export-Import Bank.

CAIRO, Feb. 28 -- At the first working meeting of the Egyptian Constituent Committee today, former Premier Aly Maher, the chairman, mentioned equality for women as one of the rights that had been sanctioned by charters and constitutions emerging from World War II.

Howard S. Cullman announced last week that he and "a group" were seriously considering the erection of an office building that would contain a theatre when the city's antiquated building code was amended to permit the construction of playhouses in commercial structures and apartment houses.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 28 -- Despite unusually warm, bright weather and another batch of fish that obstructed operations at the Avon Lake generating station of the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company, demand for electrical power is holding at a high level here.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- A call for accommodations in private homes to take care of the overflow of tourists from hotels and guest houses at Easter has already gone out here as carriers and hotelmen prepare for a record influx.

MARKED by a continued high "plateau" of activity, business and industry are swinging into the closing month of the first quarter. Definite signs of the widely heralded readjustment are still lacking, although some see the green light gradually changing to amber.

WHEN so much contemporary poetry, even the most noted, has its references merely in other writings or in postures toward life consciously assumed. Mark Van Doren's work refreshes us like a stream down a dry watercourse.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 28 -- Ohio's One-Hundredth General Assembly will go to Chillicothe on Tuesday to commemorate the meeting of the state's first Assembly there 150 years ago. The Assembly has designated the city, forty-five miles south of Columbus, as the state capital for the day.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 28 -- Agricultural production in West Germany today covers 65 per cent of the Federal Republic's needs and is 16 per cent higher than pre-war production, according to the Ministry of Food and Agriculture.

The question of Japanese intrusion into what the Koreans have declared to be their own territorial waters has again produced some considerable Korean-Japanese friction. The Japanese have asked the United States to use good offices and there is talk of making an appeal to the United Nations. The good offices certainly can and should be used.

PERTH AMBOY, N. J., Feb. 28 -- New Jersey's future plans for dealing with its Puerto Rican residents may well be determined by an "educational experiment" now under way in this city's Adult Evening School, where 36 Spanish-speaking local men and women are studying labor relations and citizenship as part of a six-week course under the sponsorship of the school and the Rutgers University Institute of Management and Labor Relations.
CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (UP) -- Big Ten Commissioner Kenneth L. Wilson today defended the Conference's action in placing Michigan State College on probation for countenancing a fund to assist athletes.

ALBERT MARRE'S production of "Love's Labor's Lost" at the City Center served as a welcome reminder of the delicacy of the Elizabethan spirit. This delicacy is something that has been almost overlooked in recent years, for the tendency has been to stress the robust and lusty elements of the age.

AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 28 (UP) -Contrary to general expectations, defense overshadowed the offense today in one of the first major game-condition football experiments under the National Collegiate A. A.'s new, controversial limited substitution rule.

ANDOVER, Mass., Feb. 28 -- Taking firsts in four of the nine events, a powerful Andover track squad today paced a field of eight teams with 42 points, to capture the annual interscholastic prep school meet.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- Employment in Illinois at mid-December, excluding farm help, reached a new high mark of 3,441,300 persons, an increase of 67,400 over the month before, the State Labor Director reported. There has been an increase of 94,500 persons since the same month in 1951.

ATLANTA, Feb. 28 (UP) -- Two Georgia legislators, who denounced the musical "South Pacific" as propaganda, vowed today to introduce bills to outlaw movies, plays and musicals having "an underlying philosophy inspired by Moscow."
ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 28 -- Turkey, Greece and Yugoslavia signed a five-year treaty of "friendship and collaboration" today.
TOKYO, Sunday, March 1 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,540, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Sunday, Korean time:

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan contradicted Assistant United States Attorney Daniel H. Greenberg yesterday on the alleged agreement to let the police investigate themselves and exclude the Federal Bureau of Investigation from Federal civil rights cases here.

NEWARK, Feb. 28 -- A thirtyminute "sit-down strike" was staged by a dozen prisoners in the Essex County Jail here last night, Sheriff Joseph A. Bonnet reported today. The demonstration was without violence and the prisoners returned voluntarily to their cells.
Poet, dramatist, critic and recently librettist for "The Rake's Progress."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 28 -- The scheduled departure tonight for the United States of Gen. Ciro de Espirito Santo Cardoso, Brazilian War Minister, calls attention again to a whole series of recent or forthcoming international visits that show the uneasy state of South America.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 28 -- Diplomatic representatives of nine Central and South American republics and government and education leaders from this country will attend the second Conference on Inter-American Culture and Education at Rutgers University on April 17 and 18, it was announced today.
LAEL TUCKER'S novel "Lament for Four Virgins," adapted into a play by the author and set to music by Samuel Zimbalist, is now making the rounds of the producers.
HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 28 -- Jack Molinas led Columbia to a 63-59 victory tonight, but the Lions had to overcome a hard-pressing Dartmouth five.

The price decline of the Treasury's long-term bonds to nearly 6 market points below "par" may be inflicting a pinch on borrowers and on investment dealers with securities for sale, but to the institutions that make up the financial cornerstone of the economy -- the nation's banks and insurance companies -- the adverse effects of the market decline are negligible.
A plan to combat crime among narcotics addicts by establishing clinics where users can receive minimum doses at a cost of 15 to 30 cents was advanced yesterday by the Richmond County Medical Society.
Both wild animals and wild men are subject to the aches and pains of civilized man, finds Dr. Erwin A. Acker-knecht, medical historian of the University of Wisconsin.

Under the direction of the Protestant Graduate and Faculty Group, Columbia University is sponsoring a series of three lectures. The first, held last Tuesday, dealt with literature and religion. On March 3 the lecture will be on "Myth and Symbol in Contemporary Literature," and on March 17 on "Modern Literature and the Christian Tradition."

MANILA, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Recommendations for increased regional and international marketing research as an aid to trade were approved today by a committee of the United Nations Trade Promotion Conference.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, March 1 -- President Rhee, in a statement marking the thirty-fourth anniversary of Korea's "Independence Day," asked statesmen of the world today not to sacrifice Korea to the forces of evil.
PUSAN, Korea, Feb. 28 -- A Governmental crisis was narrowly averted today as a new law was promulgated prescribing a ceiling on the number of won that can be converted to the new hwan currency.

THE sharp-pronged dissection of women by women is as delicate an art in novel writing as at any Dior-gowned cocktail party. Helen Hull, with her story of Anice Lang, a successful editor in a publishing house, acidly etches a heroine women will readily recognize -- though few readers of either sex will applaud her.

A ONE-MAN show of one hundred photographs taken during the years 1948 to 1952 by Dan Weiner, a leading magazine photographer, will open on Tuesday and run through March 31 at the Camera Club, 121 West Sixty-eighth Street. The pictures will be arranged in groups of related themes covering the range of Mr. Weiner's work during the last five years.

ORIANA ATKINSON has made the Catskill country "thirty miles back from the Hudson" her especial province, and she writes of its early days with comprehensive knowledge, warm affection and sounding gusto.

A GENEROUS sampling of work by young American photographers was placed on display last week at the Museum of Modern Art under the title "Always the Young Strangers," and honoring Carl Sandburg's seventy-fifth birthday.

A YOUTH'S coming of age and a jungle journey with survival at stake are the themes of this adventure story. Young Roger Fenwick dislikes Dr. Allen Grove intensely, but goes with him on a mysterious geologic mission to northeastern India.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 28 (Reuters) -- India expects to export 1,000,000 tons of jute manufactures in 1956 -- the final year of her first five-year plan -- against 650,000 in the base year 1950.

Two and one-half years ago, financially assisted by the Kellogg Foundation and the American Association of School Administrators, a nation-wide Cooperative Program in Educational Administration was set up, designed to improve training and service of city superintendents of schools, principals and other officials charged with the administration of the public schools.

In your book section of Feb. 22 David Dempsey attempts to make a case for the publishers of some pocket-sized books which we have requested the distributors to remove from the newsstands in Youngstown.
SANTA FE, N. M., Feb. 28 -- The 681,000 citizens of New Mexico will be the nation's best-educated body of people on the subject of communism if the state's new civil defense program is successful.

THE prison-camp escape literature that has come out of World War II can be divided into two kinds: the desperate escape-or-certain-death story and the vervy escape-for-escape's-sake yarn. The first has usually been told by German, Russian or Central European authors while the second seems to have become a special province of the British.

The annual luncheon and fashion show, entitled "Bustles and Bonnets,'' will be held on Tuesday in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf Astoria. Mrs. Frederic H. Rahr and Mrs. Mary Dalton Brown are co-chairmen of the executive committee.

EVER since the son of Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette disappeared into the sordid obscurity of the Temple prison, his ultimate fate has been the subject of speculation and mystery. Most romantics (and many hard-headed historians) refuse to believe that he died there after being systematically maltreated. Consequently, he has had as many reappearances as a retiring actress.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation completed agreements today bringing improved pension and social insurance benefits to 78,000 workers in three unions, effective May 1.

" LISTEN . . . have you heard the story about the dog who was pestered by fleas and how he got rid of them? No? -- Well then I will tell you." With this familiar introduction, which has preceded folk tales for generations, Kurt Wiese retells the legend of the dog so beset by fleas that he turns to his worst enemy, the fox, for help.

THE author describes himself as a nephew of Joseph Stalin, on the side of Stalin's first wife, Katherine Svanidze. According to the pattern of his account, he recalls some twelve shorter or long meetings with his uncle, beginning with Stalin's first wedding, which he witnessed as a boy, and ending with a long heart-to-heart talk with Stalin at Sochi, on the Black Sea, in November, 1945.

Cardinal Hayes High came within a half-point of capturing the senior team title at the twenty-sixth Catholic High Schools A. A. indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

THIS is one of the most provocative books I have read in recent years, written by one who is an advocate of "world - mindedness." Viewing our current crisis in history, Norman Cousins is convinced that "our time is almost like a summing-up of man himself, so frequently poised between affirmation and negation, promise and despair, altruism and selfishness, clarity and confusion."

The Secretary of State has put the problem of the relationship of his department to Congressional committees in the proper frame of reference. Mr. Dulles deserves executive and popular support and Congressional respect in the positions that he has taken.

An automobile carrying a wedding party of six, including the bride-to-be, was in collision with a truck and then swerved into a halted bus at 1 P. M. yesterday at the intersection of Sixtieth Street and Seventh Avenue, in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.

RED TOP is the name of a new Italian canning-type tomato which was developed in an attempt to produce an earlier-maturing paste tomato suitable for canning. This low, compact variety will appeal to the home gardener who prefers a solid, firm-fleshed fruit to a large, juicy one.

In the Feb. 8 issue of the Book Review, Oscar James Campbell, chairman of the Department of English at Columbia, reviewed "This Star of England: 'William Shake-speare' Man of the Renaissance," by Dorothy and Charlton Ogburn.

THE twentieth century is an epoch of massive paradoxes. Sociologists sometimes label it "the post-Christian period." At the same time no comparable stretch of time since the Reformation has been so rich in creative theology.

To meet and talk to Ralph K. (Colonel) Strassman, vice president and head of the New York office of the Ward Wheelock Company, Philadelphia ad agency, is a novel experience. The six-foot-two 195-pound athletic looking 77-year-old executive is a man of many facets.

Two contrasting movements -- strength in stock prices and softness in Treasury bonds -- featured the abbreviated trading in financial markets last week, which started with the Washington's Birthday holiday on Monday. Firmer prices for stocks in the heaviest trading of the year reflected the reduction in margin requirements.

Little did he dream when he was a young Irish immigrant more than 100 years ago that his name would symbolize one of the world's largest international trading and industrial organizations William Russell Grace landed on the shores of Peru in 1849 to seek a better life in the New World.

Sales in department stores for the country as a whole advanced by 2 per cent above 1952 in the week ended Feb. 21, on the basis of Federal Reserve Board figures. The week before there was an increase of 3 per cent. In the latest week four districts had increases, five had decreases and three were unchanged.

The dramatic gains made in medical research in the last few decades are usually evaluated in the saving of human lives. Of extreme significance, however, is the fact that medical research also pays off in dollars.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The nation's largest privately owned bus terminal opens for business in Chicago's Loop on March 19. It cost more than $10,000,000, the Greyhound Corporation said, and it is the Loop's first multi-million-dollar structure in nearly twenty years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The danger of partial or complete blindness from atomic-bomb radiations appear to be much less than first indicated from early studies at Hiroshima, a Navy medical researcher said today.

HAVANA, Feb. 28 -- General Manager Branch Rickey of the Pirates will make Ralph Kiner renegotiate his entire contract -- for less money -- if the Pittsburgh outfielder does not report to duty by Monday, it was indicated today.

HONOLULU, Feb. 28 -- Samuel Wilder King became Hawaii's eleventh, and possibly last, Governor under the islands' territorial status today when he took the oath of office in colorful ceremonies before Iolani Palace, the seat of the government here and a monument to the days of the Hawaiian monarchy more than half a century ago.

IT'S always a particular pleasure to a reviewer when one of his special favorites comes forth with a book even better than usual, a novel worth urging not only upon the full-time or part-time devotees of that author, but even upon that amorphous figure, the General Reader.

Topped by 6-foot 11-inch Walter Dukes of Seton Hall, three players from the Atlantic Coast and two from the Pacific Coast were named yesterday to the 1953 Associated Press all-America collegiate basketball team.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 28 -- Although ending on a somewhat damp note the Giants concluded their first week of preliminary training today with Leo Durocher enthusing at his best.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- The Journal of the American Dental Association published a report today asserting that ammoniated dentifrices had not lived up to the promise of widely advertised claims and had no special value in reducing tooth decay.

THE baseball writers don't have to wait for the first robin to know that spring is approaching. They get advance notice on receiving those two fact-packed compendiums, the Green Book from the National League and the Red Book from the American League, statistical twins that are crammed with fascinating tidbits for exclusive distribution among the inkstained wretches of the Fourth Estate.
" Der Rosenkavalier" was presented at the Metropolitan yesterday afternoon, with Thomas Hayward appearing for the first time in the brief but exhausting role of the Italian tenor in Act I.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 28 -- Yale's athletes carried off most of the honors in their busiest sports day of the season today, concluding the program with a thrilling basketball victory over Princeton at the Paine Whitney Gymnasium, 67 to 64.

Word has been received at the headquarters of the Methodist Church, 150 Fifth Avenue, that the Rev. Dr. Friederich Wunderlich, president of the Methodist Theological Seminary, Frankfurt, Germany, was elected on Thursday as Bishop of the German Central Conference of the Methodist Church.

THIS survey by Norman Bentwich of Israeli institutions and problems is already partly dated, as he himself anticipates in a preface. Israel's Government has a new complexion. A controversial nationality law, for better or worse, now regulates the status of citizenship.

TO most Americans, Edwin Booth is a nebulous figure. The country's Great Tragedian, he is as well known by name and as little known personally as any hundred of our national heroes. Even to people of the theatre Edwin Booth is hardly more than a tradition, a statue in Gramercy Park, a memory hallowed by the gentlemen of The Players, the club he founded in solemn ceremony on New Year's Eve.

The University of Michigan has established a long-range development program designed to expand the institution's teaching, research and service resources. A new organization, to be known as the Development Council, will seek to strengthen the university's financial position and instill increased interest in its public responsibilities.
MADRID, Feb. 28 (Reuters) -- Spain is drastically revising her high school system to bring it into line with twentieth century education.

Boarding five-masted schooners and "monstrous" paddle-wheelers for the treacherous run through Hell Gate, having money refused at the Custom House and playing ball in open fields north of City Hall were incidents in the early life of Fred L. Kraemer.

MUSSORGSKY'S "Boris Godunov" returns next Friday to the Metropolitan Opera House in a new production which can only rank as one of the most important accomplishments up to the present time of Mr. Bing's administration.

Mayor Impellitteri and his seven colleagues on the Board of Estimate will go to Albany tomorrow in an effort to salvage some of the major items in the city's $218,700,000 fiscal program for 1953-54, which was rejected last Monday in a memorandum issued by Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore and State Controller J. Raymond McGovern.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 28 -- Making two goals in the third period. Princeton's hockey team scored a 4-2 Pentagonal League victory over Brown in Baker Rink today.

IVAN SANDERSON, zoologist, author and TV personality, was inspired to write this book by Miguel Covarrubias' brilliant, realistic paintings of Central American wild life. Like many informational stories, tailored to a pattern, this is better fact than fiction.

TRENTON, Feb. 28 -- Nelson F. Stamler, recently dismissed from his post as a New Jersey deputy attorney general, last month told the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council that he once had received from Willie Moretti, gambler, the names of persons he had bribed in Bergen County.

John (Honey) Russell, coach of undefeated and top-ranked Seton Hall, was named "coach of the year" yesterday by the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association.

Jet plane speeds of 20,000 miles an hour -- fifteen times as fast as the earth rotates -- are possible within the foreseeable future, Prof. Frederick K. Teichmann, head of New York University's Guggenheim School of Aeronautics, told a Cooper Union audience last week.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 28 -- Calumet Farm's Mark - Ye - Well faced a field of set-ups in the $135,000 Santa Anita Handicap today and was hard pressed to capture the classic for the first time in four tries by the stable.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Gov. Frank Clement, who was criticized sharply by E. H. Crump, political leader in Memphis, said today he would refuse "to surrender my independence."

PETER HADLEY, second oldest of the four Hadley children, tells what happened when he and Pop, a police inspector and grower of rare daffodils, start out to develop a red daffodil. The mystery story, set in England, involves gypsies, judges, reporters, neighbors and other assorted characters.

Miss Ward, in her article "A Briton Explains British 'Insularity'" (Feb. 15), writes: "It was an Englishman, John Stuart Mill, who gave the classic definition of freedom as 'the liberty of each limited by the like liberty of all.'"

The prospects for European unity have been looking up during the past week. This is another way of saying that the prospects for European freedom have been improving, for Europe will not be securely free until it is united by close economic and defensive bonds.

Industry is flourishing, employment is almost at its peak, the press periodically records the introduction of new electronic devices, new drugs, new artificial fibers, new plastics, yet the number of applications for patents on inventions is no greater for each 10,000 of our population than it was in 1865.

LAST week's signing of a record $8,000,000 contract to keep "I Love Lucy" on television another two years was economic confirmation of the obvious. The weekly TV adventures of Lucille Ball and her husband, Desi Arnaz -- "andor" Lucy and Ricky Ricardo -- clearly are not susceptible to the usual mundane standards of appraisal.

CAREFULLY delimited, this book deals not with the total life of Mozart but with that period of his life which was spent largely in Salzburg, his birthplace. The period covered brings him to 1783, a point at which he was only 27 and had yet to compose nearly all of the great works by which he is remembered.

IF the flying saucers prove anything they prove that science has not yet seeped down into the multitude. A belief in witches, devils and evil spirits may strike drivers of automobiles and owners of television sets as amusing and pathetic, but the widespread belief in flying saucers and the acceptance of tales of "little men" who were found in one that was wrecked are cut from the same pattern.

SOME TIME this month the de Havilland Comet, the world's first turbojet commercial airliner, will make its debut on the North American continent. It will be based in Canada, not the United States, and it will be used by the Royal Canadian Air Force and not on a commercial route.

ON the 10-mills brown, which is the first unit in the new regular Egyptian series, the word "Defence" is inscribed, whereas "Postes" (Postage) is French. Information reaches J. H. Stolow that the stamp will be reissued with the French "Defense" substituted.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 28 -- After a hectic week entertaining Argentine President Juan D. Peron as a guest of the nation, the Chilean Chief Executive, 75-year-old Carlos Ibanez del Campo, today awaited tomorrow's elections, which will determine whether he will have either a recalcitrant or a rubber-stamp Congress.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Republican leaders meeting here today accused the Democrats of "abusing the concept of civil service'' by locking thousands of party members into civil service jobs in the last seven years. They concluded, however, that their party should not follow what they called an established pattern of "putting people in and throwing people out just to fill jobs."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 28 -- Although President Eisenhower's campaign speeches were generally interpreted as at least an implied promise to end the Korean war quickly, anyone paying a casual visit to the General Assembly this week would have had the impression that this is where he came in.
ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Niagara's basketball team defeated Cornell tonight, 57 -- 47, to rack up its nineteenth victory against five losses.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -Georgetown defeated Fordham, 74 -- 63, in basketball tonight with spectacular performances by two New York boys.
VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28 -- Jackie Robinson arrived at the Dodger camp today and immediately and emphatically made it clear that he will be regular second baseman this year.

After a first careful look, Republicans in Congress have come up with a picture of budget balancing prospects that is variously characterized as "not very pleasant," "gloomy" and "grim." This outlook seems to surprise some members, but it will not surprise anyone who has a clear understanding of the nature, dimensions and complexities of the budget problem.
TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 28 -- Mobs screaming loyalty for Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi drove Premier Mohammed Mossadegh out of his home today while Government guards held off the demonstrators with gunfire.

THE wax begonia is so easy to grow that even indoor gardeners who have trouble with other house plants can depend on it. Its performance, indoors in winter and in the garden during the summer, has exceeded that of any other plant in my garden.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 -- Ernie Beck, Pennsylvania's All-America center, scored 30 points to spark the Quakers to a 76-59 victory over a surprisingly tough Harvard team in an Eastern Intercollegiate contest at the Palestra tonight.

Moving in commanding style from the outset, Al Parsells' Ramapo Polo Club halted Buddy Combs' Red Bank team 16 to 9, in a twenty-goal match that featured the weekly double-header at the Squadron A Armory last night.

LITTLE by little, dancing seems to be edging its way into Hollywood; or, if not dancing, at least dancers. The Coast Guard announced yesterday the beginning of this year's international ice observation and ice patrol services.

TAIPEI, Sunday, March 1 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek called on Formosa and the rest of free China yesterday to mobilize all their manpower and resources and speed united efforts for recovery of the Communist-held Chinese mainland in the near future.

BONN, Feb. 28 -- A much more vigorous, enterprising and imaginative United States policy toward the people of Eastern Europe and their Russian jailers is in the making. First steps toward implementing this policy have yet to be taken, but in the meantime references to "liberation" and hopeful forecasts of Soviet surrenders of territory as a result of internal stresses and strains have aroused optimism among those who have suffered most from Russian imperialism.

The lifting of controls had no immediate effect on consumer items in the wholesale markets here last week, Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office, reported. Goods of all types remained in adequate supply. Orders were placed for Easter and summer merchandise.

THE future of the Missouri Basin, which covers one-sixth of the land surface of the United States, will be deeply affected by what is, or is not done about the recommendations in the recent report of the commission appointed by former President Truman to study this specific problem.

NOVELS of academic life are frequently disappointing: the people so often seem slightly unreal and their problems unimportant. Theodore Morrison -he has been teaching writing at Harvard for a quarter of a century - succeeds where many others have failed.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Feb. 28 (AP) -- A French-made, British-distributed movie of Jean-Paul Sartre's drama, "The Respectful Prostitute," was assailed today in a leading West German film trade weekly as "intentionally anti- American."

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 28 -- Demonstrations against the Ahmadiya Community, a Moslem sect that is opposed by orthodox Moslems, continued here today, but on a smaller scale than yesterday. One hundred twenty-two persons were arrested today, compared with 712 yesterday.
The undersigned believe that the jurists' report to Secretary-General Trygve Lie is open to serious objections.

TRENTON, Feb. 28 -- Despite continued complaints by parent and teacher organizations and other educational groups throughout New Jersey that more state aid for public schools is urgently needed, no bill is before the Legislature to increase funds for this purpose.
FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., Feb. 28 -- The Army Signal Corps next Tuesday will observe the ninetieth anniversary of its founding at its chief training and research and development center here.

Alonzo Westervelt, 33 years old, a steamfitter of 1110 Avenue K, Brooklyn, was arraigned in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday on three charges of felonious assault and held in $3,500 bail for a hearing on Tuesday.

MANILA, Sunday, March 1 (AP) -- In resigning his post, Defense Secretary Ramon Magsaysay said yesterday that it would be "useless" for him to continue in his post "with the specific duty of killing Huks as long as the Administration continues to foster and tolerate conditions which offer a fertile soil for communism."

EZIO PINZA apparently has decided that his "future" lies in radio and television. In addition to his guest appearances in both media, Mr. Pinza is going to branch out with two weekly programs of his own, one in radio and one in television.

Each year when they pass out honors to the daredevils of distinction in the sport of speedboating, there is one coveted prize that means more than the cups, bowls, baubles and most of the championships.

GEORGE AXELROD, Broadway's most recently arrived prodigy, whose initial plunge into playwriting produced the resounding splash called "The Seven Year Itch," has been stringing words together in a highly profitable manner for more than a third of his thirty years.

SPACE travel has received more advance notice than any other coming attraction in the entire history of science. The Wright brothers' historic Kitty Hawk flights of 1903 attracted far less attention than the use of a new toothpaste ingredient does today.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 28 -A good deal of steam has gone out of the European drive to persuade the United States to agree to a general increase in the price paid for gold by monetary authorities throughout the world.

THE hero of this long, earnestly conceived, painstakingly written third novel is a moderately successful man living in a small Midwestern town, moderately unhappily married and moderately dissatisfied with his life. Under these circumstances, Allan Seager has his work cut out to convince his readers that Amos Berry would commit the immoderate act of murder.

THIS latest collection of poems by Carleton Drewry bears a rather odd title. Few people have ever heard this almost-archaic adjective pronounced. It is a curious fact that the title poem was originally called (in The Saturday Review) "The Writhing Wood."

A GERMAN fighter pilot with thirty-five Russian planes to his credit, Heinrich von Einsiedel was shot down over Stalingrad and taken prisoner by the Russians in 1942. He was 21 at the time, a grandson of Bismarck, and an unattractive, swash-buckling youngster with a strong streak of self-pity and only an embryonic comprehension of the world at large.
ANYONE who has grown dahlias is enthusiastic about them. For few other flowers offer more spectacular bloom and are less demanding or more impervious to disease and insects.
LONDON, Feb. 28 -- The career of Premier Mohammed Mossadegh in Iran is an enigma to Western diplomats.

Under these circumstances, Allan Seager has his work cut out to convince his readers that Amos Berry would commit the immoderate act of murder.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Feb. 28 -- The village-owned hook mill was put out of commission today for the second time in three years by a sharp gust of wind. Ripping off two of the mills four latticed sail-covered arms, the wind dashed them to the ground in much the same fashion that two arms were sheared off the shaft in a similar freakish windstorm on May 20, 1949.

EAST BERLIN, Pa., Feb. 28 (UP) -- George F. Kennan, technically still United States Ambassador to Moscow, said today that he was holding himself available for a new assignment in the Eisenhower Administration.

Commercial bankers, encouraged by their apparent success in opposing legislative efforts of New York savings banks to obtain additional branch office privileges, have turned their attention to savings bank investments. In a report issued last week the New York State Bankers Association announced the commercial banks' opposition to a bill pending in the Legislature to permit savings banks to invest in the stocks of the larger commercial banks.

THIS latest collection of poems by Carleton Drewry bears a rather odd title. Few people have ever heard this almost-archaic adjective pronounced. It is a curious fact that the title poem was originally called (in The Saturday Review) "The Writhing Wood."

A GERMAN fighter pilot with thirty-five Russian planes to his credit, Heinrich von Einsiedel was shot down over Stalingrad and taken prisoner by the Russians in 1942. He was 21 at the time, a grandson of Bismarck, and an unattractive, swash-buckling youngster with a strong streak of self-pity and only an embryonic comprehension of the world at large.

Among the 300 courses offered this spring by the Extension Division of the City College School of General Studies will be twenty "self-help" courses, twelve "do-it-yourself" courses and a class on planning financial security for the family.

New York University's School of Education, aided by a grant from the Field Foundation, is now evaluating its intensive, year-and-a-half training program designed to help meet the nation's shortage of elementary school teachers.

RUMFORD, Me., Feb. 28 -- Tauno Pulkkinen, 29 - year - old member of the Finnish Ski Club of Brooklyn, today won the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association cross-country race. Pulkkinen led a field of sixty-three with a time of 1 hour 24 minutes 44 seconds.
MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Radio Liberation, an American-financed station to broadcast anti-Communist programs to the Soviet Union from political exiles, will go on the air here tomorrow.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 24 -- A severe business depression and a sharp drop in tourism have occurred in Guatemala as a result of the political situation there. Nevertheless the country's immediate economic future seems strong enough because of continuing bumper coffee crops and profitable world prices for coffee, Guatemala's chief export.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The movie industry offered to compromise today on its plea for exclusive use of special radio frequency bands for theatre television.

The sixty-five vessel fleet of the United Fruit Company last year exceeded its 1951 performance in the number of passengers carried, in distances traveled and in freight moved for other shippers, according to the company's annual report issued last week.

WE were hardly prepared for the effect on our friends. They were devastated. They kept saying, "How brave you are." All we proposed to do was to include our two children, aged 7 @and 8, on a three-month trip to Europe last spring but by sailing day we were pretty nervous about the whole thing, and boarded the ship prepared for the worst, with a suitcase full of peanut butter, terramycin and toilet paper.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Senate Interior and Insular Affairs Committee began hearings this week on this nation's status, past, present and future, in regard to petroleum production.

MR. MASON's supply of technicolor ink was never more prodigally spent than in this swashbuckling thriller based on the career of Sir Francis Drake. Gaudy as a Chinese pheasant and noisy as a kindergarten recess, "Golden Admiral" is entertainment at its best.

The trend toward multiple night openings among stores throughout the country appears to have passed its peak, according to a survey made last week by THE NEW YORK TIMES. Developments, however, are still mixed. While the competitive rush to more night openings is abating, at least temporarily, experimentation is still going on.

The Emperor Napoleon, known to the English as General Bonaparte during his stay on St. Helena, spoke rather freely to Dr. Barry O'Meara, surgeon of H. M. S. Bellerophon, who had accompanied him into exile.
RED BANK, N. J., Feb. 28 -- Two near-by Monmouth County municipalities are protesting route plans of the Garden State Parkway Authority for the North Jersey shore spur of the new superhighway.

Mrs. Herbert D. Manley will give a tea Tuesday afternoon in her home, 911 Park Avenue, for members of the committee aiding in the plans for the thrift drive now under way for the benefit of the Play Schools Association.

The man-made fibers and yarns that are being woven into many and interesting materials are newcomers in the fashion world. They are chemistry's miracles. From the laboratory and test tubes they have come, to be fashioned into fascinating fabrics through the combined efforts of scientist and industrialist.

The Maritime Administration's merchant marine officer training and seaman upgrading program for the fiscal year 1954 is expected to meet stiff opposition when the House Appropriations Committee holds hearings on the agency's $3,600,000 request for anticipated operational costs.

DETROIT, Feb. 28 -- The United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., announced today that the General Motors Corporation had agreed to reopen its five-year "escalator" contract with the union, but that the management's offer of wage improvements had been rejected as inadequate.
English furniture of the Queen Anne and Georgian periods and many complementary decorative room accessories will be auctioned on Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Feb. 28 -- President Eisenhower today summoned the nation's top military leaders and a bipartisan Congressional group to a White House luncheon on Tuesday to hear Gen. James A. Van Fleet's reasons for believing an all-out United Nations offensive in Korea now would certainly succeed.

HANOI. THE war in Indo-China, a conflict which in its seventh year has ground on for a longer time than World War II, continues to involve 800,000 men in fighting that goes on through dry season and monsoon, rice swamps and dense jungles, divisional battles and guerrilla ambushes.

BLESSED with enviable imaginations, Peter and Penny are never at a loss for adventure. According to mood, they can and do turn themselves into Eskimos, circus performers or lions in Africa -- "The kitchen sink is the water-hole where they go to drink."

ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 28 -- While ten months have passed since the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church here received a check for $17,000, the identity of the benefactor and the explanation of his contribution still were a mystery today.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28 -- The sieges of smog that have afflicted Los Angeles for a decade have burgeoned into a political issue.

MIAMI, Feb. 28 -- Greentree Stable's Straight Face, vigorously dusted by Ted Atkinson's famous feathered whip, collected cash at the rate of a little better than $1,000 a second in the $153,600 Flamingo Stakes at Hialeah Race Course today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- If the Eisenhower Administration continues its rapid decontrol timetable, most, or all, of the few remaining price ceilings on food and consumer goods will vanish next week. More prices will rise.
DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company today became the first member of the rubber industry to sign a new contract in 1953 with the United Rubber Workers, C. I. O.
DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company today became the first member of the rubber industry to sign a new contract in 1953 with the United Rubber Workers, C. I. O.

HAVING injected a little amateur psychology into a recent discussion of autobiography. I am delighted to have received support and, what is even better, some really illuminating comment from a distinguished professional source.
BERLIN, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Russians and the French joined today to honor eleven heroes who perished in combat against the Nazis.

THIS department has no desire to become involved in a dispute over which orchestra pension fund is the oldest in the country. The point is that all pension funds serve a useful purpose. If there is competition among orchestras as to which supports the soundest pension set-up, that is all to the good, for standards are bound to rise everywhere and the musicians who need to be helped will benefit accordingly.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Feb. 28 (UP) -- Indiana clinched its first undisputed Big Ten basketball championship tonight with an easy victory over defending champion Illinois, 91 to 79, before 6,900 fans.

If one had asked the going price of refined copper last week, there would have been at least six different answers. Piecemeal decontrol had plunged the market into one of the most confused pricing tangles in copper history.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The reception in political and professional circles accorded new Administration proposals to raise the Federal Security Agency to Cabinet status indicates the great importance that has come to be attached to Federal welfare activities.

THE present (eighty - sixth) annual exhibition assembled by the American Water-Color Society, in the galleries of the National Academy, is one of the most diverse and qualitatively high level in the organization's long series.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- While the political and economic issues Foreign Minister Anthony Eden and Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler are going to Washington to discuss with members of the new Republican Administration are global, the talks will be informal and exploratory and they can have no concrete results at the present time.

The question of suspending the Hebrew language broadcasts to Israel first came to the attention of the State Department on Nov. 30, 1951, Reed Harris, acting administrator of the State Department's International Information Administration, said yesterday.

I enjoyed every word of Robert Whalen's "The Best Time to Work -- If Any" (Feb. 15). It confirmed a theory I've held for years. But he didn't give space to another angle, to wit, the Type 1 man married to a Type 2 wife. That's me and several others I know.

FOR THIS WEEK: Branches of spring-flowering shrubs and trees, cut and brought indoors, will open quickly now. Keep in water and spray occasionally with warm water. . . . It is too early to remove winter coverings, even though a couple of days have been mild. . . . When pruning fruit don't forget the blueberries.

BALTIMORE -- On the desks of the members of the Maryland Assembly last month were placed copies of a 152-page book outlining what Delegate John W. Logan, of the House Ways and Means Committee, described as "the biggest piece of fiscal legislation ever presented to the State Legislature."

In an impatient and fickle age such as ours consistency of vision through long years has been a positive disadvantage to many artists. Not, however, to Georges Braque who has risen from Montmartre to riches and helped to revolutionize modern art by simply painting, tirelessly and deliciously, the contents of his studio.
BOSTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Harvard defeated Yale, 5 -- 2, as the ancient rivals opened their fiftieth series tonight in a Pentagonal Hockey League game that featured an Arena double-header.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28 -- The salary siege which caused Vic Raschi and Whitey Ford to lose five days of training ended today. The pitchers came to terms with Roy Hamey, assistant to General Manager George M. Weiss, and joined the Yankee squad on Miller Huggins Field.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Eisenhower Administration has not abandoned its plan to set up a new system for handling internal security cases of Government employes, but there were guarded admissions this week that a few snags had been hooked in the process of working it out.

MOSCOW, Sunday, March 1 -The Central Committee of the Communist party, in a resolution carried on the first pages of all newspapers today, demanded highest political vigilance from all workers and charged the United States with sending into Russia spies, wreckers and murderers.

HANOI. THE war in Indo-China, a conflict which in its seventh year has ground on for a longer time than World War II, continues to involve 800,000 men in fighting that goes on through dry season and monsoon, rice swamps and dense jungles, divisional battles and guerrilla ambushes.

It's a silver anniversary gift for Hubert Packard, wrestling coach at the Choate School of Wallingford, Conn. His squad presented to him an unbeaten season capped by a victory in the New England interscholastic tournament at Cambridge, Mass., on Saturday, and Packard is happy.

CHICAGO, March 1 -- Price trends in the grain market were irregular last week, with wheat and rye showing a strong undertone, while coarse grains were weak. The pessimistic weather reports from the Southwest encouraged wheat bulls, while corn and oats felt steady pressure because of expected liberal offerings of Government off-grade corn, and liberal deliveries on March contracts of oats.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 1 -- Two explosive innings and five home runs marked the Giants' first intracamp game of the training season today. Bobby Thomson's squad brought down Whitey Lockman's team, 7 to 6, in a six-inning skirmish.

THE stagecoach robbers, the cattle rustlers and the other low-down, ornery varmints who prey on the unwary in Oklahoma can breathe easier now.
