John Leonard Martin has just resigned as deputy sheriff after so short a time on the job that he hardly had a chance to put a notch in the handle of his trusty six-shooter. Honest John has decided to bring his shiningly honest face back into baseball.
SANTIAGO, March 1 (UP) -- The first voting was orderly and there were no reports of violence, but Opposition politicians accused officials of "bribery" and "interference" in some districts.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 25 -- If the Caribbean Legion is training 1,200 men a month for new adventures in Latin America, as Generalissimo Rafael L. Trujillo of the Dominican Republic asserted recently in New York, it has escaped the scrutiny of United States military men in Mexico and Guatemala, whose job it is to watch the Legion's activities.

Although the stories of the Gospels have provided a vivid picture of Jesus -- allowing persons to feel as if they had seen and heard Him speak -- "logical - minded unimaginative people make great mistakes by studying the texts too intensively," the Most Rev. Philip Carrington asserted in a guest sermon yesterday morning.

All who wish Iran well must be disheartened by the news from Teheran this past week-end. Behind the spectacle of rioting mobs filling the streets, there is clearly apparent the clash of rival cliques, each putting its own interests above those of the state, of the Iranian people, and of the larger world community of independent nations to which Iran belongs.

Two of this week's important art exhibitions will open on successive days. On Wednesday the Museum of Modern Art will put on view forty paintings from the collection of Edward G. Robinson, and the next day the Whitney Museum of American Art will show recent acquisitions.

Organizations claiming to represent 90 per cent of the city's Chinese colony of 40,000 called yesterday for an early landing on China's mainland by Nationalist forces. They also assured Chiang Kai-shek of their support and called on the population of the mainland to aid his forces when the time came.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Instructions have been issued to all employes of the Bureau of the Budget that they must report any knowledge they may have of conduct on the part of any colleague that would be "inimical to the effective operation, security and standing" of the bureau.

Handicapped in various respects, and matching wits and inducements against a highly competitive' field, the New York City Convention and Visitors Bureau did an excellent job of selling this city as a place to visit in 1952. Attendance reached 2,448,369 in 701 conventions, and these delegates and visitors spent an estimated $175,000,000 while here.

Shipbuilding and ship repair activities of the Bethlehem Steel Company were maintained at a fairly high level during 1952, but the future in these fields was viewed with some foreboding last week in the company's annual report.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- So narrow are the Republican majorities in this Congress that campaign leaders are already mapping out prospective close states and districts for 1954 battlegrounds.

TOKYO, Monday, March 2 -- Eighth Army infantrymen threw back a series of four large-scale probing attacks by Chinese Communist troops totaling about a battalion of 750 men in strength across a three-mile section of the western front.

The Central Circulation Branch of the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street will be closed for alterations March 21, but temporary, limited service will be given in the main lobby of the building.
Teresa Victoria, lyric soprano, and Albert Cambetes, bass-baritone, made a joint appearance Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 1 -- The Chilean public put on a spectacular display of indifference today in the elections for Congress. Although no official figures were available early tonight, estimates by political leaders and observers who watched the public staying away from the polling places in droves put absenteeism as high as 50 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- President Eisenhower flew back to Washington and the cares and problems of state late today after three pleasant days on the rich-colored fairways and greens of the Augusta National Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 105 Korean war casualties. The total included 20 dead, 79 wounded, one missing in action, one captured and 4 injured in battle zone accidents. The following were listed from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America with a membership of 300,000, celebrated its forty-first anniversary yesterday with the announcement of plans for a new $10,000,000 Medical Center in Jerusalem. It also was announced that the organization had raised and expended $80,000,000 during its existence for the maintenance of a comprehensive medical and social welfare network in Palestine.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., March 1 (AP) -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet said today that he had no report or plan to give the President or Congress on the Korean situation.
HOUSTON, March 1 (AP) -- Dr. Cary Middlecoff missed a three-foot putt on the eighteenth green today to throw the $20,000 Houston open into a five-way tie for the $4,000 first prize.

PITTSBURGH, March 1 -- Last week saw a paradox in the steel industry. Steel companies were able to supply defense needs and at the same time have more steel tonnage available for civilian use than before Korea. In the face of this the Government was dragging its feet on decontrolling steel.

Four model acts giving the state broad powers over local law enforcement authorities were proposed yesterday by the Ameriacn Bar Association Commission on Organized Crime for adoption by legislatures throughout the country.

An 11-year-old boy sounded a fire alarm early yesterday afternoon after discovering a fire raging through a multiple-family dwelling in Richmond Hill, Queens, and then was overcome by smoke and burned trying to make his way to the third floor to rescue his widowed mother and her twelve other children.

MANILA, Monday, March 2 -- President Elpidio Quirino accepted Ramon Magsaysay's resignation as Secretary of Defense yesterday with unaccustomed executive celerity and designated Secretary of Justice Oscar Castelo as acting secretary in Mr. Magsaysay's stead.

Business men in this city expect employment to go up 5 per cent by May, a survey by the State Employment Service disclosed yesterday. The poll, which covered 4,100 companies employing 200,000 persons, indicated that job rolls would go up more rapidly in civilian goods industries than in those engaged in defense work.
Through a movement originating in Detroit some time ago and apparently now concurred in by Henry Ford, we are being urged that the United States alone go on a free-trade basis.

Helen Traubel will return to the stage of the Metropolitan Opera for the first time this season during the opera's eighteenth week, which begins on Monday, March 9. Miss Traubel will sing the female lead in the Wednesday evening "Tristan und Isolde."

Two conflicting popular theories exist about women's remembrance of childbirth. One, semi-folklore, suggests that "blessed forgetfulness" blots out any unpleasant memories. The other, better borne out by bridge table conversations, indicates that many a mother remembers every detail.

The blight of atomic secrecy, falsely identified as security, has stunted the development of sound national policies and is handicapping proper liaison with our allies, adequate civilian defense and atomic progress.

CHICAGO, March 1 -- Average daily purchases of grain and soybean futures were larger than the previous week, with soybeans again holding the lead in activity. Much of the professional trade was switched to soybeans. Future purchases of that commodity were 61,000,000 bushels for four days against 75,000,000 bushels for five days the week before.
An importation from France and an entry from Hollywood are the new films arriving in first-run houses this week. The programs follow:

Those who challenge the conservatism of national and personal self-interest are being stoned today as were the prophets of old, the Rev. Dr. Jesse William Stitt said yesterday in his sermon at the Village Presbyterian Church, 139 West Thirteenth Street.

MUNICH, Germany, March 1 (AP) -- Edmund Schechter, chief of the radio branch of the United States High Commission in Germany, said today that so far as he knew he had never been rejected by the Voice of America for security reasons.

WATERLOO, N. Y., March 1 (UP) -- Kenneth Brush ended a controversy yesterday in which he and the village's three other barbers were accused of refusing to serve 8-year-old Clyde (Butch) Williams because he was a Negro. He trimmed the boy's hair himself.

DAYTON, Ohio, March 1 (AP) -- A University of Dayton team that has been beaten thirteen times in twenty-seven games knocked Seton Hall, the nation's top-ranked collegiate basketball team, out of the unbeaten ranks, 71 -- 65, tonight in one of the biggest upsets of the season.

IRON MOUNTAIN, Mich., March 1 (AP) -- A young Norwegian, Jon Riisnaes, who is now an exchange student at the University of New Hampshire, won both the North American ski-jumping championship and the annual Kiwanis Club tournament today before a crowd estimated at nearly 35,000.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Representative Robert W. Kean, Republican of New Jersey, announced today that he would introduce in the House of Representatives tomorrow a bill to carry out President Eisenhower's request for expansion of Social Security coverage.

Special prayers for Pope Pius XII were asked yesterday in Roman Catholic churches of New York in preparation for the double anniversary the pontiff is observing today. It is the seventy-seventh anniversary of his birth and the fourteenth anniversary of his election to the Papacy.

PASADENA, Calif., March 1 -- The possibility that barren, arid mountain sides can be made to "lift themselves by their bootstraps" into well-forested natural reservoirs is being explored with conside rable optimism by scientists of the California Institute of Technology in collaboration with the United States Forestry Service.

Cherry has been given a mellow antiqued fruitwood finish for a new collection of nineteenth - century reproductions just introduced by Charak, 444 Madison Avenue, and available from that showroom through decorators.

LONDON, March 1 -- A diocesan letter issued by Dr. Cyril Garbett, Archbishop of York, urging a "cordial welcome" for President Tito when the Yugoslav head of state visits Britain in three weeks, has aroused an interchurch controversy here and revived Roman Catholic objections to the visit.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 1 -- A new approach to the training of future military officers has been undertaken at Princeton University. The aim of the new course in military science is to give students a wider liberal arts training and to educate them in the close relationship of civilian and military problems.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Whatever comes of the high level discussions this week on Britain's program of "trade, not aid," the proposals to be canvassed put Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler in a good position to tell their counterparts here to "put up or shut up."

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- The Bureau of Agricultural Economics predicted today that retail food prices probably would be fairly stable the rest of this year and would average slightly lower than last year.
SEOUL, Korea, March 1 -- A people whose country has been torn in two by war celebrated today the thirty-fourth anniversary of their declaration of independence.

BONN, Germany, March 1 -- The failure of the West German Government to defend Germany's interests in the proposed European army and the presence of authoritarian elements in the coalition parties were the basis of a detailed and forceful attack on the policies of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's regime today.

Three Brooklyn youths set sail yesterday from Staten Island in a patched-up Army surplus raft and were headed in the general direction of Europe before a combined air and sea rescue by the police and the Coast Guard halted the adventure.

The Rev. Dr. Carl Hermann Voss, chairman of the executive council of the American Christian Palestine Committee, took issue yesterday with a campaign to rid newsstands of obscene literature now being conducted in the Flat-bush section of Brooklyn by the Decent Literature Committee of Our Lady Help of Christians Roman Catholic Church.

Along about this time of year the second wave of those whose New Year's resolutions mentioned keeping a diary have begun to drop and fall by the wayside. For the last couple of weeks the entries have grown shorter and have lacked the studied phrase.

The heads of five line organizations in the Police Department went yesterday to Washington, where they will seek to be heard today at the Congressional open hearing into the handling of Federal civil rights cases involving alleged brutality by New York policemen.

State officials who took part in the recent rejection of the city's $218,700,000 program for balancing its 1953-54 budget were reported yesterday to be critical of the city's failure to impose already authorized special taxes to obtain about $40,000,000 of sorely needed revenue.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1 -- Irv Noren can be the deciding factor in giving Casey Stengel a Yankee outfield the equivalent of last year's when the graying Yankee skipper appraised his picket line as the best in the major leagues. It depends on whether the coast fly-chaser flashes the brand of ball that caused the Yankees to obtain him from the Senators last year.
March, right in character, blew in snowily yesterday and prematurely made April fools of any number of local skiers.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 1 (AP) -- Ralph Kiner agreed today with Branch Rickey that he's a holdout -- "if he doesn't accept my acceptance of his offer."

ALBANY, March 1 -- The Dewey Administration's residential rent control bill, which is reported to raise ceilings generally by 15 per cent over 1943 levels, is slated for formal introduction in the Senate and Assembly tomorrow.

The New York Americans defeated the Swiss Football Club of the German-American Soccer League, 4 -- 1 yesterday and reached the final round of the annual challenge cup competition of the United States Soccer Football Association before 2,500 fans at Sterling Oval.

In February alone more than 40,000 refugees from Communist East Germany flooded into West Berlin. This latest influx, together with the large number of similar refugees who escaped earlier, has created pressing problems, far beyond the capacities of West Berlin alone.

LYNN, England, March 1 (UP) -- Sue, a sow that had saved herI life in the recent flood by stand-I ing on her hind legs five hoursI with her snout through the styI roof, gave birth today to six piglets.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The possibility of extended debate that could attain filibuster proportions concerned Senate leaders tonight as they considered scheduling next in the Senate a measure that would give the states title to oil-rich submerged lands within historic offshore boundaries.

Two five-story apartment buildings at 644 and 652 St. Mary's Street, the Bronx, have been sold by Isaac Behr, who built them, to Katz Brothers for cash over a first mortgage of $206,000. E. Osborne Smith, Inc., was the broker in the sale.
Building up a lead of three goals before their rivals could strike once, the New York Rangers subdued the Toronto Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

On record sales of $1,065,735,454, largest in the industry, the American Tobacco Company realized last year a net income of $34,068,963 against $33,109,669 on sales of $942,552,034 in 1951. According to the annual report, released today, 1952 net income is equal to $4.79 a share on 6,454,110 common shares compared with $4.64, the year before.

There is dynamic competition in the chemical industry. In a report released over the week-end the Manufacturing Chemists Association, Inc., noted that the number of chemical companies with securities listed on the New York Stock Exchange had increased 70 per cent in the last twenty-five years.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- The Republican National Chairman, C. Wesley Roberts, said tonight that the party expected to start this month handing out the "grass roots" jobs now that most of the top Administration posts had been filled.

The Civil Aeronautics Board will open hearings in Washington tomorrow morning on the applications of six airlines to start allfreight service across the Atlantic to Europe and the Middle East. The hearings are expected to last two to four weeks.

A sandwich and a glass of milk before the curtain and a bird and bottle after it is our preferred solution to the common problem on how to eat and still get to the theatre on time. That not all theatre-goers agree with us, however, is shown by the number of restaurants that have introduced a special pre-theatre dinner -- a meal that is more than a snack yet is served expeditiously.

The Citizens Committee for New York City's 300th Anniversary Celebration has been almost completed, Lee Thompson Smith, whom Mayor Impellitteri named chairman some weeks ago, announced yesterday. The celebration will run until the end of the year.
In your delightful little article about the restoration of the British sausage to its legitimate contents you state that the inventor of this food is unknown.

With the rise of modern markets there was born a school of economists obsessed with the idea that business cycles run on some kind of celestial timetable. W. S. Jevons discovered we had a swing every ten years, give or take a year.

The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday that on Saturday, March 14, it would run a special train up the Harlem Valley from New York to Chatham and down the Hudson Valley from Rensselaer, N. Y., to the Grand Central Terminal to collect funds for the disaster- ridden people of the Netherlands.
" Have you seen the new Larry Aldrich collection?" This is a question that fashion scribes ask each other as the new seasons roll in.

A hint of what television comedy could be if the likes of George Jessel and Fred Allen really were turned loose on their own was offered Saturday night ever the National Broadcasting Company network en the "All-Star Revue.." It was an hour of amiable diversion that had the distinction of an underlying intelligence not found too often in variety programming.
TOKYO, Monday, March 2 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,541, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korean time:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 1 -- Barbara Stanwyck and Clifton Webb, who share top billing in the recently completed "Titanic," will be teamed again by Twentieth Century-Fox in a contemporary comedy-drama to be filmed this summer in Rome.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 1 -- The world's industrial production reached a record index figure of 133 in 1951 on a basis of 100 for 1948, according to the fourth statistical yearbook of the United Nations, released today. In 1950, the index figure was 118.

Georgetown University's team yesterday became the eleventh quintet to accept a bid to compete in the National Invitation Tournament which starts Saturday night at Madison Square Garden, it was disclosed by Asa S. Bushnell, chairman of the committee.
PINE HILL, N. Y., March 1 -- Jack Kaufhold of the German Ski Club captured the slalom in the New York Ski Council's annual interclub competition at the Belleayre Mountain ski center today.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 1 (UP) -- A National Front group called on the Premier in a special letter to use all the powers at his command -- he has ostensibly dictatorial powers, voted him by a reluctant Parliament -- to prevent "foreign intrigues" and disorders.

Bills to make the treatment of non-criminal adult narcotics addicts compulsory under Federal law are being prepared for submission to Congress, State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein disclosed yesterday.
HAVANA, March 1 (AP) -- General Manager Branch Rickey of the Pittsburgh Pirates today declared Home Run King Ralph Kiner a holdout as of midnight tonight.

Neglect to warm up sufficiently for the 880-yard run, the first event of his prodigious "triple" at Saturday's Knights of Columbus games at Madison Square Garden, had much to do with Mal Whitfield's distressingly near-miss in his bid to crack the world indoor records for 800 meters and the half-mile.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 1 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh ousted his Army Chief of Staff today and fought stubbornly to restore his grip over Parliament and the country while mobs in the streets turned against him with cries of "Death or the Shah."

SYRACUSE, N. Y., March 1 (AP) -- The Syracuse Nationals climbed back into contention for the Eastern Division title in the National Basketball Association by defeating the leading New York Knickerbockers, 79 -- 64, before 6,408 fans tonight.

Four young paratroopers, whose home towns have a combined population of less than 150,000 and no building taller than seven stories, agreed yesterday on their first visit here that it would be a tough job to parachute into New York.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message appealing for funds for the American Red Cross:

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, March 2 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor expressed confidence today that the multi-nation Eighth Army could withstand any assault the million-man Communist forces in Korea might launch.
Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. said yesterday that he was not a candidate for Mayor, but apparently left the way open for any movement to draft him for the Democratic nomination.

The Veterans Administration said yesterday that 150,000 New York veterans of World War II would lose National Service Life Insurance worth at least a billion dollars unless they reinstated their lapsed policies before the terms expired this year.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., March 1 -- Two new fields of fundamental research in nuclear physics have been opened by tests at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory, according to an announcement by the Oak Ridge Institute of Nuclear Studies.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 1 -- Peewee Reese, the Dodgers' captain, arrived today too late to see the two-hour, six-inning intra-squad game in which Duke Snider's team evened matters with Roy Campanella's boys by scoring a 2-1 victory.

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved in a narrow trading range last week but closed in slightly lower territory. Net changes for the week in active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were one to twenty-four points lower, or five cents to $1.20 a bale, from the levels of the preceding week.

Market prices for the outstanding $56,300,000 of dollar bonds of the Republic of Bolivia reflect the skepticism with which investors view the possibility that Presdent Victor Paz Estenssoro will be able to make a success of his Government's tin nationalization experiment. The Bolivian per cent loan is quoted in the over-the-counter market at about 12 7/8 bid, 13 3/8 asked, down from a 1952 high of 20 1/2.

C. C. Mallory, president of the Grace Line, announced yesterday the appointment of Lewis A. Lapham to the newly created post of executive vice president Mr. Lapham resigned last week as president of the American - Hawaiian Steamship Company, effective March 15, almost at the same time that the company made public the suspension of intercoastal steamship services.

Two surveys reporting over the week-end differed widely as to the numbers of self-service drug stores. The American Druggist, as reported by the retail department of the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, defines self-service drug stores as those in which all items, except in prescription, fountain and tobacco departments, are available on counters from which customers help themselves.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 1 -- The most favorable omen in Argentine-Brazilian relations in some time is the departure tonight of Joao Alberto Lines de Barros, chief of the Commercial Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, for Buenos Aires in the hope of concluding the commercial agreement that has been hanging fire many months.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 1 -The President Wilson, carrying Adlai E. Stevenson, former Democratic Presidential nominee and Governor of Illinois, to the Orient on his world tour, will depart on schedule tomorrow at 4 P. M., despite the threat of labor trouble on San Francisco's waterfront, a spokesman for the American President Lines said today.
SARASOTA, Fla., March 1 (UP) -- Mrs. Babe Didrikson Zaharias of Tampa coasted home with a 73 today to win the $3,500 Sarasota women's open golf tournament by seven strokes.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 1 -- Subject to the reaction of members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Greece, Turkey and Yugoslavia intend to establish a joint military planning board so that military consultations among them will become even more intimate than those provided for in the treaty of friendship and collaboration signed in Ankara yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, expressed his own and the Eisenhower Administration's deep faith in the United Nations tonight, but he cautioned against "exaggerated hopes" for the organization as an instrument of peace and human welfare.
BERLIN, March 1 -- Ernst Reuter, Mayor of West Berlin, said today he did not believe the Russians would completely split the city in two.

RAHWAY, N. J., March 1 (AP) -- The principal terms of a merger of Merck Co., Inc., of Rahway, and Sharp Dohme, Inc., of Philadelphia, two of the nation's largest drug concerns, have been approved by the boards of directors of the two companies.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 1 -- If he decides tomorrow to answer the United States charge that Russian material is prolonging the war in Korea, Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky will have no difficulty, even though he is not on the list of speakers of the United Nations Political and Security Committee.

As you have done so many times before, your editorial of Feb. 19 "Tax Bill or Transit Bill" repeats your position that the essential step in the transit problem is a fare rise. As a city planner I for one am getting weary of the thesis that no transit authority has any value unless it can raise the fare and that municipal solvency and the entire future of the city are hinged on this point.

The consideration which, more than any other, perhaps, attracted wide public attention to the revision of the Consumer Price Index, introduced last week, was the importance of the index in adjusting wages to changes in the cost of living.
The third of the Bennington Composers Conference Series took place last night at the Lexington Avenue Y. M.-Y. W. H. A., Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street.

PARIS, March 1 -- While Premier Rene Mayer warned France today that rejection of the European army treaty would leave her isolated and powerless, the National Council of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's party, Reunion of the French People backed up its leader by formally condemning the treaty with or without the protocols that the French Government proposed.

Plans for building 150 houses in the $25,000 price class have been announced in connection with the sale of forty-six and one-half acres at Rosedale Avenue and North Street, White Plains, N. Y., by the Accad Realty Corporation to the North and Rosedale Corporation.

With matinee and evening performances yesterday, the New Dance Group brought to a conclusion its festival series at the Ziegfeld Theatre. There probably never has been another dance festival that laid as little emphasis upon dancing and as much upon pantomime, ranging from the obvious through the interesting to the totally obscure.

A 16-year-old boy was shot and killed by a narcotics squad detective early yesterday morning when the boy allegedly charged at the detective with a bayonet as the detective was attempting to break up a fight at a social club dance at 145 Suffolk Street.

Secretary of the Interior Douglas McKay has now affirmed before committees of both House and Senate the Administration's belief that the coastal states and not the Federal Government should have title to undersea oil found within their historic offshore boundaries.

Objective reporting of political campaigns was stressed last night by William H. Stringer, managing editor of The Christian Science Monitor, at a forum-dinner in the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.
TOKYO, Monday, March 2 -- Japan's lower house of the Diet, in an unprecedented move, voted today to refer to a censure committee a motion to reprimand Premier Shigeru Yoshida.

Although the management of the Playhouse has been shadow boxing lately with prospective tenants, arrangements finally were concluded for "Room Service" to open there April 6 after a week of previews. It will represent the first Broadway revival of the successful John Murray-Allen Boretz farce, originally produced and directed by George Abbott in 1937.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., March 1 (AP) -- Arthur Tyler of Rochester piloted his four-man bobsled to the Adirondack Amateur Athletic Union championship today in record time.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- President Eisenhower urged the country today to support the 1953 American Red Cross drive for funds because, he said, it was dedicated to "strengthening the nation" by helping its people to help their neighbors in time of need.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., March 1 -- Were the Army, Navy or Air Force carrying on in the harbor here today, they likely would termed the sailing dinghy proceedings "operation freeze."
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., March 1 (AP) -- Arthur Tyler of Rochester piloted his four-man bobsled to the Adirondack Amateur Athletic Union championship today in record time.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- President Eisenhower urged the country today to support the 1953 American Red Cross drive for funds because, he said, it was dedicated to "strengthening the nation" by helping its people to help their neighbors in time of need.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1 (AP) -- Houdry Process Corporation filed suit in Federal Court here yesterday against Socony-Vacuum Oil Company asking $21,700,000 damages for alleged patent infringement on Houdry Processes for catalytic cracking of petroleum.
A strong demand for the British pound sterling and continued softness in the Canadian dollar were the focal points in the foreign exchange market last week.

RUMFORD, Me., March 1 -- Bernhard Blikstad, transplanted Norwegian from New York's Telemark S. C., today achieved the most important triumph of his ski-jumping career by taking the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's Class A championship.

Iris Rogers, New York soprano, who made her debut here two years ago, was heard in her second local recital last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. With the excellent assistance of Fritz Jahoda at the piano, she gave a program of taste and charm.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 1 -- The Indonesian Government took over full control of the rich Bangka Island tin mines yesterday in the first step of what will eventually lead to nationalization of all strategic mining industries in the country.

The magic of recorded sound and light enabled President Eisenhower to give to the nation yesterday a message on behalf of the American Red Cross that had been recorded several days ago. Briefly on the screen the TV public saw some who had been helped by the Red Cross and others who had helped it.

The Westbury Hotel, a fourteen-story building occupying the block-front on the west side of Madison Avenue from Sixty-ninth to Seventieth Streets, has been sold by the Henry Phipps Estate to the Knott Hotels Corporation in a deal negotiated by the Cross Brown Company, brokers.

A "remarkable change for the better" in the public attitude toward Puerto Ricans here was reported yesterday by the Mayor's Committee on Puerto Rican Affairs. The fifty-one-member group issued a summary report on its work since organizing in September, 1949, on the eve of a five-day conference on mutual problems to start today in San Juan between city and Puerto Rican officials.

The purchase of a 219-acre farm in northern New Jersey by the New York Stake of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints (Mormon) was announced yesterday at the stake's quarterly conference in the Manhattan Ward Chapel, 142 West Eighty-first Street.

HONG KONG, March 1 -- Mao Tse-tung, chairman of Red China's Central People's Government, proclaimed a new electoral law in Peiping today for the election of delegates to the All-China People's Congress and the local People's Congresses that are scheduled to be established throughout the country this year.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- William L. Laurence, science writer for THE NEW YORK TIMES, told a youth forum tonight that the United States was able to maintain its lead in atomic research "for an indefinite time."

ALBANY, March 1 -- Governor Dewey's controversial plan to require liability insurance for all motor vehicles registered in the state was scheduled today to receive its first major test on Tuesday, when the Assembly Ways and Means Committee expects to vote on it.

PASADENA, Calif., March 1 -- Appropriations totaling $17,695,000 for projects which include resource conservation and the study of human behavior were announced by the Ford Foundation today. Of the sums to be appropriated, $9,000,000 will be made available to the Fund for the Advancement of Education.

The Philippines loses an admirable Defense Secretary with the resignation of Ramon Magsaysay, but this move may work out for the best in the long run. The situation that existed after President Quirino withdrew his confidence and support from Mr. Magsaysay had become so difficult as to be intolerable to the intrepid Huk fighter.

A new work about the Pilgrims by George F. Willison, author of "Saints and Strangers," will be published by Doubleday on March 16. Using William Bradford's history of the colony as a basis for his book, Mr. Wilson employs commentary to integrate the journals, letters and other accounts written by the Pilgrims themselves.

The largest operating property in the Bell System, the New York, Telephone Company, is planning to spend approximately $190,000,000 this year for expansion purposes, Keith S. McHugh, president, announced yesterday in his 1952 report to the stockholders.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UP) -- The Government hopes it may be able to spare some 40,000,000 taxpayers the annual chore of making out income tax returns, it was disclosed today.

Col. Charles A. Lindbergh, who completed the first non-stop flight from New York to Paris on May 21, 1927, has written his autobiography up to June, 1927, which will appear in ten installments in The Saturday Evening Post beginning April 11, and as a book to be published by Scribner's this fall.

I am dismayed to note that neither President Eisenhower's transmittal letter to the Congress nor the proposed draft resolution regarding the Second World War agreements makes explicit mention of the twelve million refugees and expellees from the Oder-Neisse territories, from the Sudetenland and the Balkan countries.

HARTFORD, March 1 -- William H. Taft 3d of New Haven, son of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, may be nominated soon by President Eisenhower as Ambassador to Ireland, Connecticut Republican party leaders said today.

A three-point program designed to mitigate the effects of the Russian campaign against minority groups living within the Soviet Union's borders was offered yesterday by Lessing J. Rosenwald, president of the American Council for Judaism.

EAST LANSING, Mich., March 2 (UP) -- More than a score of Michigan State's top athletes received numerous offers to enter other schools, including rival Big Ten institutions, under circumstances violating Conference regulations, it was disclosed in a United Press survey released today.

EL PASO, Tex., March 2 (AP) -- deportation hearing for a Mexican actress starring in a controversial union-sponsored film dragged on tonight as her attorney accused the United States Immigration Service of conspiracy.

IT'S like nibbling peanuts. Once started, none has the will power to stop. That's the way any baseball follower devours the facts plucked forth from that inexhaustible grab bag, the American League's Red Book. Like its National League counterpart, the Green Book, this is designed as a cram course for all baseball writers before they head for the palm trees, pelicans, oranges, flamingoes and players now thriving in Florida.

A pre-war pattern of competition in the steamship passenger business is developing again among companies serving east coast South American ports, Robert C. Lee, vice chairman of the board of the Moore-McCormack Lines, said yesterday.

HARTFORD, March 2 -- W. Ellery Allyn, Connecticut Insurance Commissioner, said tonight that an average 10 per cent cut in fire insurance rates would go into effect in this state on April 1. The saving to policy holders was put at $1,570,000 a year.

HOUSTON, Tex., March 2 (UP) -- Cary Middlecoff, who missed a chance to win the $20,000 Houston open golf tournament yesterday, toured the Memorial Park course in 33, 36 -- 69 today to finish two strokes ahead of his nearest competitor in the five-way play-off for first Place.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (UP) -The Senate today unanimously confirmed Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce as Ambassador to Italy after Senator Alexander Wiley had assured the Senators that the appointment "in no way" involved American relations with the Vatican.

Futures prices rose 5 to 21 points yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange on a small volume of business. The market opened 3 points lower to 3 points higher than Friday's close and held steady all day. The prompt stopping of ten March notices brought in some trade covering.

Well timed for Lenten dishes is a new cannister of grated Italian Parmesan cheese. It is the only thing of its kind now on the market, its manufacturer, the Robin Packing Company, reports. Parmesan cheese, to be sure, may be had in grated form.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Prince Faisal Al Saud, Foreign Minister of Saudi Arabia and Viceroy of the Hejaz, heard President Eisenhower promise this morning to improve what he regarded as the deteriorated relations between their two countries. Then the Prince went outside and threw snowballs at American photographers.

Textile commitments for fall production of men's pants and sportswear are being placed early to permit a quick start on the season, it was learned yesterday at a combined exhibit of suppliers in the New Yorker Hotel.
Indiana's newly-crowned Big Ten champions topped the United Press college basketball ratings yesterday for the fourth straight week.

Danny Giovanelli, 141, Brooklyn, stopped previously unbeaten Danny (Jo) Perez, 138 1/2, New York, after six rounds of the main bout scheduled for ten rounds last night at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- Spokesmen for large sections of the dairy industry came out today against a stand-by law for price, wage and rent controls after controls expire April 30. They appeared before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee as it opened four weeks of public hearings on the controls issue.

In the first announcement of the new Administration's policy on the merchant marine, Robert B. Murray Jr., Under Secretary of Commerce for Transportation, said yesterday that the Department of Commerce would continue to promote a strong, active, privately owned American-flag fleet.

A warning that "a thoughtless wave of price increases' on drug and cosmetic products might well result in decreased sales and profits, was issued yesterday by the National Wholesale Druggists Association.

Seventy-five shorthand reporters went on strike yesterday, halting a National Labor Relations Board hearing and threatening to interfere with proceedings before the United States Tax Court and the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Charles E. Bohlen, President Eisenhower's choice for Ambassador to Russia, made it plain today to Senators holding his confirmation in their hands that he never would join in Republican condemnations of the wartime Yalta agreement.

The one-story taxpayer containing four stores on a plot 107 by 142 feet at 193-25 to 193-33 Jamaica Avenue in Hollis, Queens, has been sold by William Rand to Albert Pittel and Isidore Gensburg. Berman-Glassman Associates, Inc., and Thomas G. Sarris were brokers in the transaction, in which the buyers paid cash above mortgages of $59,000.

The Metropolitan Opera's 1953-54 season will open on Nov. 16 with a new production of Gounod's "Faust," which will be conducted by Pierre Monteux. Other operas that will be revived next season in new productions will be Wagner's "Tannhaeuser" and Rossini's "The Barber of Seville."

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 3 -- Its existence threatened by a vote of censure, the Government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida won a new lease on life when the lower house of the Diet (Parliament) approved today the national budget for the next fiscal year by a vote of 241 to 196.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 2 -Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin, who has been visiting the principal battlefields in the Tonkin Delta and in the Thai country of Indo-China, is also having important military consultations with Jean Letourneau, the French Minister for the Associated States; Gen. Raoul Salan, the Commander in Chief in Indo-China and Gen. Gonzales de Linares, the commander of ground forces in North Vietnam.

The New York Stock Exchange opened again yesterday with activity on dividend and other news developments, then lost its early enthusiasm and drifted through the remainder of an undistinguished day. In the slowest and narrowest market since Feb. 20, THE NEW YORK TIMES rail average dropped 0.08 point to 72.20, the industrial average rose 0.50 to 309.15 and the combined average rose 0.21 to 190.67.
PITTSBURGH, March 2 (AP) -- United States Steel Corporation will start work soon on a new research center near Pittsburgh for developing better steels and steel technology.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The annual $2,800 Westinghouse Grand Science Scholarship was awarded tonight to E. Alan Phillips, 15 years old, of Lincoln, Mass.

MIAMI, March 2 (AP) -- Atalanta, 3-to-1 second-choice, stayed in front after taking a quick load today and just managed to last to take the $25,000 added Black Helen Handicap in a photo finish before a crowd of 19,797 at Hialeah Park.
BONN, Germany, March 2 -- West Germany expects to man the first squadrons of the new Luftwaffe with young Germans who already have volunteered in hundreds for service with the air arm.
One large oil company reported yesterday that it did not contemplate an increase in gasoline prices, but two others announced that their prices were being raised.

BONN, Germany, March 2 -Hermann J. Abs, head of the West German delegation to the London debt conference, said today that West Germany could not begin debts repayment April 1, as provided in the agreement, because it would be materially impossible for Parliament to ratify the agreement before the end of the month.

A method of treating new symptoms of multiple sclerosis, which if successful, could give victims the limited freedom of diabetics who carry their own medications with them, was described at a meeting yesterday of the executive campaign committee of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society.

Prime Minister Churchill has rightly "rejected in principle" a proposal that has caused many puzzled frowns and arched eyebrows. The Hungarian Government offers to release a jailed British business man, Edgar Sanders, if the Government of Malaya will release a condemned Communist woman terrorist leader, Lee Meng.

BONN, Germany, March 2 -- The Blohm Voss shipyards of Hamburg, one of the greatest shipbuilding concerns in the world until dismantled by the British, received permission from the Allied Military Security Board today to construct and repair floating docks and repair merchant ships.

Newspapers are going "all out" in efforts to get their share of the advertiser's dollar, it would appear from an announcement yesterday by the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

Sales of Manhattan and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 6.5 per cent during February in comparison with the same month last year, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. In January these stores had a sales drop of 2.5 per cent.

LONDON, March 2 -- Prime Minister Churchill rejected in principle today the Hungarian Communist Government's offer to exchange Edgar Sanders, British business man, who is serving a prison term in Hungary, for Lee Meng, woman leader of Malayan Communist guerrillas, who is under sentence of death in Taiping, Malaya.

PARIS, March 2 -- The International Committee Against Concentration Camps, formed by Dav/'t Rousset,.a French author, reportel today after a two-week study in Tunisia that there were no suct camps in that French protectora6, hut that certain measures taken b? the authorities there violated human rights.

Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, announced yesterday the appointment of Dr. John A. Krout, associate provost, as vice president and provost, and the appointment of acting Dean William C. Warren as full dean of the Columbia Law School.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 2 -- An unusual type of world traveler is the Rev. Dr. Leila Anderson, a cheery, chic person, who is circling the globe to prepare herself for a novel missionary project in the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The State Department finally has discovered something that is harder to interpret than the Russian mind. It is the State Department's own directive to all its official broadcasters and librarians to stop using material by "Communists, fellow travelers, et cetera."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 2 -- A state-wide television network with stations at five State-supported universities, to be used exclusively for educational purposes, was recommended to the Ohio Legislature today by the Ohio Program Commission, a state planning body.
ALBANY, March 2 -- Legislative leaders are receiving strong public protests against two bills that would relax child labor laws on farm employment.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- James M. McInerney, former Assistant Attorney General, insisted today that he had made no commitment of any kind to New York City police officials that would forestall or foreclose Federal prosecution of policemen charged with brutality in civil rights cases or limit the freedom of action of the Department of Justice in such cases.

The much-heralded visit of Foreign Secretary Eden and Chancellor of the Exchequer Butler starts tomorrow morning with their arrival in New York. There has been a great deal of fanfare about this trip, which began even before President Eisenhower took office.

To open Day Care Week, Mrs. Vincent R. Impellitteri, wife of the Mayor, and Deputy Mayor Charles Horowitz led a group of officials in a ceremony yesterday at the new Hamilton House Day Care Center. The center, in the Alfred E. Smith Houses at 60 Catherine Street, is among 108 similar units welcoming guests this week.

Richard H. Balch, the Democratic state chairman, and the Public Education Association, in separate statements yesterday, sharply criticized the Temporary State Commission on the Use of Television for Educational Purposes for finding that there was no ustification at this time for spending state money on a chain of educational television stations.

CAIRO, March 2 -- The Arab attitude toward West Germany's restitution agreement with Israel and the agenda for the forthcoming session of the Arab League were discussed today at a meeting attended by Premier Mahammed Naguib and Arab diplomats accredited to Cario.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- A House subcommittee produced evidence today that Donald S. Tydings, a Federal Revenue Bureau official, tried to put a $3,000 "bite" on an Atlanta bootlegger who was fighting a $678,000 black market liquor case.

Women headed by !rs. Reginald V. Hiscoe and Ars. A. Schuyler Clark, and including Ars. Colley F WiUiazns, are active in plans for the entertainment, known as the Skyline Dinner Dance, to be held -4:pril 23 in the St. Regis Roof for the benefit of the Kips Bay Boys Club.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Congressional leaders said after a White House meeting this morning that President Eisenhower might submit a reorganization plan next week to make a Cabinet-status department out of the Federal Security Agency.

CHICAGO, March 2 -- The much discussed possibility that Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson will take the witness stand in behalf of the du Pont anti-trust trial defendants and be cross-examined by Government lawyers representing a fellow-Cabinet member appeared definite today.

MOBILE, Ala., March 2 -- Approximately 4,000 union employes of the Alabama Dry Dock and Shipbuilding Company were on strike today and the company's Big Pinto Island yard was shut down. Members of Local 18 of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O., were picketing the entrances.

Recently American correspondents in Europe have reported that France and other countries have grave misgivings that if Britain attempts the convertibility of the pound sterling by making some arrangement toward this end with the United States it will react adversely on Europe and on the European Payments Union.

When Maj. Albert J. Myer took command of the first United States Army Signal Corps in 1863 it numbered less than 100 men. He probably never envisioned that the Corps would grow to a peak strength of more than 355,000 in the Second World War. He would be gratified at the proud list of accomplishments which paralleled its numerical increase.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (UP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson canceled today the embargo on imports of Canadian meats and livestock. President Eisenhower promptly acted to prevent long-run injury to United States cattlemen by clamping a lid on the number of Canadian cattle that may be imported at special low-duty rates.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 2 (AP) -- Several players were bruised and cut tonight in a fight that broke out after the University of Louisville handed Seton Hall its second straight basketball defeat, 73 -- 67.

CHICAGO, March 2 --Fairly general precipitation in the Southwest last week caused an initial slump in wheat prices on the Board of Trade here today. Lows for the day were made at the start for the bread grain; later there was a good recovery.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- An examiner for the Federal Power Commission heard testimony today that natural gas reserves in the Big Piney, Wyo., field -- a portion of the supply which would be tapped to serve the Pacifice Northwest -- total 65,500,000,000 cubic feet.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, urged Congress today to allow the states to take the oil and other natural wealth from submerged lands within claimed offshore boundaries without letting them have title to the disputed sea bottom.

A vacant parcel of about 18,000 square feet on the northeast side of Kings Highway, between East Thirty-second Street and New York Avenue, in Brooklyn, has been assembled for improvement with a two-story nursing home. The land was bought by Lester Dworman, builder, who will erect the structure to be used by Dr. Samuel Berson.

Women who do most of the buying in this country can help themselves get better value for their money, Dr. Persia Campbell, a member of the Queens College staff, said last night at a branch meeting in the Garden City Casino of the American Association of University Women.

NEW DELHI, India, March 2 -Scientists from seven Commonwealth countries began a two-week conference here today to discuss common defense problems and for an exchange of information on the latest developments in scientific aspects of military defense.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, March 3 (AP) -- The Eighth Army said today it was spreading Puerto Rican soldiers of the Sixty-fifth Infantry Regiment among other Eighth Army units in Korea, ending the Sixty-fifth as an all-Puerto Rican outfit.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 2 -- Alvin Dark, field captain and star shortstop of the Giants, may now be classified a "holdout."
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 2 -- Some of the writers here laughed when Manager Chuck Dressen sent Jim Baxes, the 200-pound third baseman, to left field today and started hitting fungoes to him.
Indiana's Big Ten champions replaced Seton Hall as the nation's No. 1 basketball team yesterday in The Associated Press poll of sports writers and broadcasters.

The Palisades Interstate Park Police were searching along the Palisades near the George Washington Bridge yesterday for a 15-year-old Brooklyn boy who disappeared Sunday while trying to scale the 300-foot cliffs. The hunt, ended by darkness, will be resumed today.

Pressure on youngsters to "adjust to the group" -- a goal some specialists consider paramount in child-education today -- can be disastrous to the development of individual integrity and a threat to the future of democracy as well, Dr. Fritz Redl declared yesterday.

ALBANY, March 2 -- D. Mallory Stephens, chairman of the Temporary State Rent Commission, said tonight that the Republican majority of the commission was in accord on a 15 per cent rent increase for tenants who had not agreed voluntarily to a rise as a condition of obtaining a two-year lease.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Harold E. Stassen, Director for Mutual Security, announced today the appointment of William J. Donovan, wartime head of the Office of Strategic Services, as special consultant in a new drive to cut off strategic supplies now reaching countries of the Soviet bloc.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 2 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky, in his ninety-two-minute speech this afternoon made only a brief reply to recurrent charges by other United Nations states that Moscow has embarked upon a policy of religious persecution of Jews, Christions and Moslems.

Sales of the Eastman Kodak Company in 1952 rose to a new high for the third successive year, but earnings declined to $45,803,851 from $49,025,906 earned in 1951, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Thomas J. Hargrave, chairman, and Albert K. Chapman, president.

ALBANY, March 2 -- Two pending changes in the election law would simplify rather than complicate the nomination by one political party of a member of another as a candidate for city-wide office in New York City, Louis J. Lefkowitz, chairman of the Republican State Law Committee, said today.

TRENTON, March 2 -- The New Jersey State Supreme Court today ruled that retail stores cannot be bound by price maintenance agreements unless they enter such contracts willingly, and that non-signers of agreements of this type who sell products for less than the advertised price cannot be accused of unfair competition.

The Red Cross appealed yesterday for the contribution of at least 20,000 pints of blood in March. It urged donors to improve on the record of last month, when only 17,579 pints were received toward the same goal.
March was officially proclaimed Red Cross Month by Mayor Impellitteri yesterday as Deputy Mayor Charles Horowitz and Red Cross officials raised the red and white emblem in City Hall Park.

SAN JUAN, P. R., March 2 -- New York officials told the Puerto Rican Government today that adjustment of the 50,000 Puerto Ricans who might migrate to the mainland this year would be aided if trained social workers and nurses could come to join the city's Health and Hospital Departments, and most of all if more English were taught to migrants.

LONDON, March 2 -- Influenced by an all-round advance in British Government securities, most sections of the stock market here closed on a rising note today despite profit-taking sales in advance of tomorrow's ending of the current bookkeeping account.

Consolidated net income of the General Public Utilities Corporation, the nation's tenth largest public utility system, last year reached a record $18,491,740. A. F. Tegen, president, announced yesterday. This was equal to $2.17 each on the 8,531,329 shares of common stock outstanding at Dec. 31, and compared with $14,647,641, or $1.72 a share, earned in 1951.
Certificates of business merit were presented yesterday by the city to more than 150 business concerns that were established in New York at least seventy-five years ago.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 2 -- Following are excerpts from the official translation of remarks in Russian by Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky today in the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly:

GUATEMALA, March 2 -- The Guatemalan Congress opened its regular session here today and elected as its President for 1953 Guillermo Obando Arriola, a labor leader and member of the Revolutionary Action party. Thirty-four of the fifty-four members of Congress who had completed their four-year terms were replaced by recently elected deputies.

Two pieces of legislation affecting public libraries deserve favorable action at this session of the Legislature. One bill would permit but not mandate the merger of the Buffalo Public Library, the Grosvenor Library and the Erie County Public Library. The other bill would amend the 1950 law for state aid to libraries and speed up but not increase such aid, to encourage the organization of larger units of library service.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Roger Lyons, director of the religious programs of the Voice of America, flew here from New York this afternoon to deny hotly under oath that he did not believe in God, as had been implied by a fellow official in earlier testimony today.

LYNN, Mass., March 2 -- The General Electric Company's defense production amounts to nearly one-third of its output, J. W. Belanger the company's defense products group vice president, said here tonight.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 2 -- plan to develop a "bar mitzvah bond" between boys in Israel and the United States who are confirmed on the same day was started tonight at the bar mitzvah, or confirmation, celebration of Azriel Daichowsky of Tel Aviv, which was linked with that of David Mayer Dobin of 12-10 Waterview Place, Bayswater, Queens, New York, last Monday.

The Little Orchestra Society, under Thomas Scherman, concluded its sixth New York season last night at Town Hall. Rudolf Serkin was the guest artist and he was heard as the exhilarating soloist in two works for piano and orchestra.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- A detailed program for the sale to private industry of twenty-nine Government-owned synthetic rubber production facilities under conditions designed to promote free competition was recommended to President Eisenhower and the Congress tonight by Harry A. McDonald, Administrator of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
Custom and ready-to-wear designs, created and made in Rome, were shown yesterday when Eleanora Garnett presented her spring collection at her salon at 47 East Fifty-first Street.

The Soviet doctor whom the Russians credited with exposing the alleged plot by nine doctors to kill high Soviet political and military figures is the wife of one of the accused, Soviet defectors have told Western authorities in Europe.

A smaller increase in jobs is forecast for the next few months by producers of defense goods in this city than is seen by civilian goods manufacturers. This is the first time this disparity has been noted since the Korean outbreak, it was reported by the New York State Employment Service in a survey just released.

Although the fate of the European Defense Community still hangs in the balance as a result of domestic political developments in France and Germany, the idea of European unification continues on the march. It has found new expression in a draft constitution for a European supranational political authority as a first step toward an ultimate United States of Europe.

A room on the ground floor of Philosophy Hall at Columbia University became an art gallery yesterday. The paintings, sculpture and other creative work by seventy professors, teachers, research workers, clerks, maintenance men and by mothers, wives and other relatives of university personnel, drew a large audience and one as mixed as the contributors.

BARRING another outbreak of hoof and mouth disease, American big-bame hunters can begin making plans to return to their old hunting grounds in Canada next fall, for the Secretary of Agriculture officially has lifted the ban on Canadian game.
An analysis of 520 issues of American newsreels by the Motion Picture Association of America has revealed that newsreel coverage of the foreign scene underwent considrable expansion in 1952.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 2 -- Efforts by Mount Vernon to use zoning powers to perpetuate automobile parking on private property at the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad station plaza in the business center of that city were defeated here today in Supreme Court.

ROME, March 2 -- Pope Pius XII is expected to resume public audiences March 19, the Vatican announced today, the Pontiff's 77th birthday. The Pope was stricken with influenza eight weeks ago. Bronchial complications developed, but more than seven weeks ago he was declared to be without fever.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The American Zionist Council urged John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, today to reply to the recent Soviet break with Israel by withholding arms from Arab states unless they made peace with that country.
Twenty persons were heard yesterday by the City Planning Commission on rezoning Brooklyn. The hearing was held in Brooklyn Borough Hall with Chairman John J. Bennett presiding.

A good deal of the steam has gone out of the drive in Europe for a general increase in the "official" price of gold, according to a dispatch from our correspondent Michael L. Hoffman in Zurich. Advocates of such a proposal received a severe setback, observes Mr. Hoffman, when they failed to win the endorsement of the International Chamber of Commerce, which considered monetary policy last week in Paris.

LONDON, March 2 -- Prime Minister Churchill stated today that he would be "quite ready at any time to meet President Eisenhower and Marshal Stalin on the basis outlined by the President if suitable arrangements could be made."

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 3 -- Fighting along the Korean front dropped off sharply yesterday morning following heavy attacks at four points on the western front by estimated total of 750 Chinese the night before.

ALBANY, March 2 -- Richard H. Balch, Democratic State Chairman, said today that the Administration attitude toward rent control and educational television "can unveil the arbitrary and ruthless character of the Dewey machine" and "destroy the Dewey myth once and for all."
ALBANY, March 2 -- A bill establishing an extra $10 fee for distinctive automobile license plates was introduced in the Legislature tonight with the backing of the Dewey Administration.

The three twelve-story office buildings recently completed at 3440, 3450 and 3460 Wilshire Boulevard in Los Angeles, Calif., have been sold by the Tishman Realty Construction Company, Norman Tishman, president, to the Prudential Insurance Company.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 2 -- Having failed to acquire a clear-cut victory in yesterday's Congressional elections, President Carlos Ibanez del Campo faced today the problem of establishing a coalition Cabinet.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 2 -- Generals and G.I.'s of virtually all fourteen North Atlantic Treaty nations can be found side by side here these days, earphones on their heads and portable microphones in their hands. They are hard at work learning French (or English) from tape recorders.

The largest motion picture studio in the East turns out a vast number of films -- long ones, short ones, some animated, some musical, some in color. They are in seven languages, have world-wide distribution, have won "Oscars" and other citations of merit that are displayed in the reception room.
The new crisis in Iran again emphasizes the political instability and military weakness of the Middle East.
The city of Philadelphia announced yesterday that it would receive bids March 24 on bond issues totaling $33,350,000. Dated April 1, 1953, the bonds will come due Jan. 1, 1955 to 1994.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 2 -- Hal Wallis, the producer, is in the process of concluding negotiations to purchase the Vina Delmar novel "About Mrs. Leslie" as the basis for Shirley Booth's next film.

Sidelined in the last eight games, first because of a sore toe and then with a fractured jaw, Al McGuire will return to action with the New York Knickerbockers against the Rochester Royals tonight at Madison Square Garden. The Boston Celtics face Clair Bee's Baltimore Bullets in the 7:30 preliminary game.

Irene of California is at her best in the eighteen suits that constitute half the collection of her designs now being shown at Jay Thorpe's, the remainder being afternoon and evening dresses. The opening took place yesterday afternoon.
CAMP DRUM, N. Y., March 2 -- The second tactical problem of Exercise Snowstorm will start tomorrow morning with another simulated parachute assault on entrenched aggressor forces.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told a conference sponsored by the American Association for the United Nations today that the majority in this country in favor of the United Nations must learn to "make more noise" than the minority against it.

The Life Saving Benevolent Association of New York presented medals and cash awards yesterday to nine persons who risked their lives to save others from drowning last year. The ceremony took place in the Janet Roper room of the Seamen's Church Institute, 25 South Street.

Charles D. Hoffman of New York has purchased a vacant blockfront of about 40,000 square feet on the easterly side of Broadway, between East Eleventh and East Twelfth Streets, in Bayonne, N. J., from the Safeway Stores, Inc. The deal was negotiated for the seller by the A. F. Roe Company as broker.

I have been walking my dogs in Central and Riverside Parks for twenty years. One evening I saw a gang of boys with their pockets full of stones trying to see who could break the most lamps. It seemed that the one who broke the most lamps got the greatest applause.

TRENTON, March 2 -- Willie Moretti, murdered Bergen County gambler, once told a political leader that Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll had received $190,000 in bribes, Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons today told the joint legislative committee investigating his ouster of Nelson F. Stamler as deputy Attorney General.

Raymond M. Hilliard, executive director of the Welfare and Health Council of New York City, yesterday asserted that removal of residential rent ceilings would cause an immediate increase in city and state relief costs that could easily throw welfare budgets out of balance.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 2 -Adlai E. Stevenson sailed tonight on the first lap of a world tour, his departure delayed for almost three hours by a labor-management dispute involving ship's radio operators.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 2 -- The third day of political crisis began today with students of Teheran University staging the biggest demonstration since Saturday in support of Dr. Mossadegh. They paraded the main streets of Teheran ran carrying a large portrait of the Premier in front of their procession and with loudspeaker cars blaring forth pro-Mossodegh slogans and denouncing the Majlis (lower house of Parliament) and the Shah's court.

PARIS, March 2 -- French production of aluminum increased 17 per cent between 1951 and 1952, according to official figures. This places France in fourth place in world production. The United States is in the lead, with 850,000 tons in 1952; Canada second, with 450,000, and the Soviet Union third, with 300,000.

Although it is customary, along Broadway, to speak despairingly of the relatively small number of plays -- and especially of good plays -- that are attempted each season, a steady reader of the theatrical news diligently gleaned from the Rialto by Sam Zolotow and his assistants will in time perceive that the launching of a play is a highly precarious and peculiar adventure.

A positive step toward improving the quality of the federal bureaucracy, which is already higher than many people seem to believe, has been taken with the grant of the first Rockefeller Public Service Awards. Eleven civilians who are making the Federal Government their career have been named as winners of these awards, which are intended to give recognition to federal employes for outstanding public service.

A Senate subcommittee headed by Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican of New Hampshire, will begin today its investigation of New York waterfront crime. The hearings, which will be closed to the public, will be held at the United States Court House, Foley Square.

Traffic on segments of the Henry Hudson Parkway near the George Washington Bridge will be limited for several weeks starting about March 25 to permit the final phases of construction of the new link between the span and the southbound lanes of the parkway.

The National Broadcasting Company has made a final decision to discontinue its hour-long "All-Star Revue" television program after April 18, a development that had been rumored in recent weeks. The program presently has two sponsors -- although it could accommodate three -- whose contracts expire on that date.

PARIS, March 2 -- In a statement tonight Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister, said the protocols proposed by the French to the European army treaty were "interpretive and complementary" and did not entail any impairment of the treaty.

The New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, playing for the benefit of its own pension fund last night at Carnegie Hall, was at the top of its bent. Under the direction of Bruno Walter, it did some of the finest orchestral playing of the season.

A mass meeting to protest anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union and the racial policies of the Malan Government in South Africa was held last night by the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, C. I. O., at the close of a two-day conference in the New Yorker Hotel.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2 -- The Yankee holdout siege ended today!

The undersigned, respectively majority and minority leader of the New York City Council, feel compelled to defend the Council from the criticism contained in an editorial headed "Confusing Procedure" in your issue of Feb. 26.
CHICAGO, March 2 -- A five-year, $200,000 nutrition research program was announced today by directors of the National Association of Frozen Food Packers at the national frozen foods convention here.
TOKYO, Tuesday, March 3 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,542 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Tuesday, Korean time:
DETROIT, March 2 (AP) --The internal combustion gasoline engine will furnish power for American passenger automobiles for many years to come.
Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo, a member of the State Senate, has been elected general counsel and a director of the City Title Insurance Company.

A hassle has developed that threatens to beset the last Broadway weeks of "Two's Company," which has been plagued by misfortune since its out-of-town premiere. The latest contretemps involves Bette Davis, star of the revue, and its producers, James Russo and Michael Ellis.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, lost none of that easy assurance he has shown in five weeks on a new job when he discovered today that the black shoes he wore to a Senate hearing were not mates.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The National Production Authority today voided requirements that copper users must get 60 per cent of their refined copper allotment from domestic sources and 40 per cent from higher-price foreign markets.

DETROIT, March 2 (UP) -- Ted Lindsay drove home four goals tonight as the Detroit Red Wings routed the Boston Bruins, 10 -- 2, before 10,973 fans at Olympia to increase their National Hockey League lead to 8 points over second-place Montreal.

AMSTERDAM, March 2 -- The reason for the Netherlands' refusal to sign the German debt agreement in London is the Government's dissatisfaction over the lack of proper compensation for indirectly looted Ausland bonds.

Your editorial dealing with the proposed amendment to the city's building code with respect to theatre design and construction points up again one of the major causes for obsolescent building regulations -- namely, the cumbersome amendment procedures required to keep specification-type codes up to date.

ONE of the rarest of human qualities is the ability to judge ourselves with any objectivity. The man who can look inward with detachment, with perception and with honesty is not to be found in every organization and every community. Yet there are such men, and it is about a very real, human and likable one that Theodore Morrison has written his distinguished novel, "The Stones of the House."*

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- President Eisenhower nominated Harry Nelson Routzohn, Dayton, Ohio, lawyer and friend of Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, today to be Solicitor of the Labor Department. Three or four nominations to other top departmental posts are expected to follow soon.

C. H. Masland Sons may sell its products independently in the next ninety days, trade sources reported yesterday. Since 1938, Alexander Smith, Inc., one of the country's largest carpet manufacturers, has acted as sole selling agent for Masland, one of the most important Wilton carpet producers.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals upheld yesterday an injunction obtained by the Government enjoining the United Steel Workers, C. I. O., from striking at the American Locomotive Company, Inc., at Dunkirk, N. Y.

ALBANY, March 2 -- The end of the veterans emergency housing program appeared in sight as the Assembly approved tonight an Administration bill calling for abandonment of the program by Sept. 30. The emergency housing was authorized in 1945 to aid veterans of World War II, with the understanding it would be demolished after five years.

Commodity prices closed higher yesterday on the New York exchanges in general light volume. Almost all items had extremely small turnovers but hides and soybean oil sales volume was highest in a month. Cocoa, hides, potatoes, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, wool and zinc were higher.

RUMFORD, Me., March 2 -- This lumber and paper mill town, host to more than 150 skiers for the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's Nordic championships during the past weekend, has been virtually assured of being chosen as the site for the training camp for the American cross-country and classic combined squad to compete in the world title games at Falun, Sweden, next winter.

The Port Watchmen's Union is the Port of New York will decide by March 16 whether to accept or reject a proposal for a new two-year contract offered Sunday by the New York Shipping Association. Secret mail ballots will go to the 2,200 union members this week, Samuel Nathan, president of the independent group, said here yesterday.

Spring showers are going to bring out a bumper crop of attractive rainwear this year. There will be coats of pongee -- delights for packing because of their lightness and ability to shed wrinkles -- linen, rayons with the slub of silk, fascinating new blends of silk and Orlon and many handsome cottons.

Contracts have been awarded to the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation and to the American Bridge Division of the United States Steel Corporation for the construction of the world's second-longest suspension bridge. The structure will link the northern and southern peninsulas of Michigan across the Straits of Mackinac.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 2 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, accused the Eisenhower Administration today not only of blocking an armistice in Korea but of planning to expand the war in the Far East, using "Asian boys as cannon fodder."

A new book of personal adventure and travel by Justice William 0. Douglas has been scheduled for May publication by Doubleday. Entitled "North From Malaya: Adventure on Five Fronts," the book idescribes places and peoples of "freedom's frontiers": Malaya, the IPhilippines, Indo-China, Burma and the Formosa-Korean front. "
ALBANY, March 2 (UP) -- The State Department of Commerce today reported the following winter sports conditions:
A little light now or sleet, changing to rain before night-fall, was forecast for the city today.

Attendance has been good at the semi-annual Allied Shoe Products and Style Exhibit, which opened at the Belmont Plaza Hotel on Sunday, exhibitors reported yesterday. Traffic was moderate on the opening day, but improved considerably yesterday.
CHICAGO, March 2 (AP) -- The Pure Oil Company today reported net income of $27,304,373, equal to $6.17 a common share, for 1952. This compared with $33,593,727, or $7.88 a share, in 1951.

PHILADELPHIA, March 2 (AP) Federal Judge Allan K. Grim today denied a motion for a mistrial in the Government's anti-trust suit against the National Football League. The judge listened to a description of the mathematical data that resulted in college football's restricted television program.

Reports yesterday from the Internal Revenue Bureau offices in the city indicated that 25 to 30 per cent of the total of income tax returns already have been filed, well in advance of the March 16 deadline.

TAIPEI, Formosa, March 2 (AP) -- The Nationalists reported today a big guerilla raid in South China on the landward approach to strategic Hainan Island and said planes from Formosa had been showering the Red mainland with leaflets.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (UP) -- The Senate passed a $947,325,579 supplemental appropriation bill today after confirming the action of the House of Representatives, which had chopped $1,200,000,000 in military requests from the measure.

TAIPEI, Formosa, March 2 -- Foreign Minister George K. C. Yeh of Nationalist China said today he foresaw no solution to the Korean war problem unless the United States assumed leadership in uniting the countries of the Far East and "exerted pressure" on Red China.

ALBANY, March 2 -- Mayor Impellitteri, Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore and other city and state officials conferred for more than seven and a half hours this afternoon and tonight in an effort to find a mutually acceptable program for solving New York City's financial problems.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 2 -- Foreign Ministry officials asserted today that the Eisenhower Administration's policy toward Israel was as cordial as that of the Truman Administration despite unofficial reports that the United States was beginning a new policy intended to coax Arab states into a Middle East defense organization.

The nation's steel mills have scheduled operations at an estimated 99.5 per cent of rated capacity this week, indicating production of 2,244,000 tons of ingots ana steel for castings, the .4_merican Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
