Among the strongest voices that have been raised against the proposed "treaty supremacy" amendments to the Constitution by Senator Bricker of Ohio and the House of Delegates of the American Bar Association is that of a committee of the New York City Bar Association.

RANGOON, Burma, March 2 -- A Burmese Army sentry at a restricted area of an army supply depot shot and wounded two Soviet Embassy officials at midnight yesterday when they approached the area in a private car and refused to stop on being challenged.

SAN PELAYO, Spain, March 1 -- A group of about 200 farmers, including the Mayors of ten villages, gathered today on a plateau near this small Castilian town to witness what Rafael Cavestany, Minister of Agriculture, called the "symbolic beginning" of a new agrarian policy designed to cope with one of Spain's fundamental problems, the extreme subdivision of land holdings.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (UP) -- Consumers had a record $16,555,000,000 worth of credit outstanding on installment plan purchases at the end of January, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 2 (AP) -- General of the Army Omar N. Bradley said here today that there are four courses of military action the United Nations could take in Korea. We warned that some of them carried the risk of all-out war with the Chinese Communists or even World War III.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 2 -- Communist mobs shouting "Yankees, go home" hurled stones at American-owned automobiles today in the third day of street fighting that has taken the lives of at least two persons and injured seventy-three others.
Spring hats designed exclusively for B. Altman Co. by Tesche were previewed yesterday. They will be displayed at a fashion show Monday at 2:30 P. M. in the store's third-floor millinery salon.

Your editorial on the proposed whittling down of Olympic National Park and the subsequent correspondence is most heartening to conservationists, but is not THE TIMES using its large guns on comparatively small game?
TOKYO, Wednesday, March 4 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,543 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Wednesday, Korean time:

Two instructors at Brooklyn College were suspended yesterday as a result of their failure to answer questions about possible Communist affiliation when they testified on Feb. 10 before a Congressional subcommittee. The suspensions brought to six the number of teachers or administrative aides in municipal colleges against whom such action has been taken since the hearing.

A resolution calling for a study by the City Planning Commission of relocating families displaced by housing and other improvements was adopted unanimously by the City Council yesterday. The resolution was introduced by Minority Leader Stanley M. Isaacs, Manhattan Republican-Liberal, and Councilman Earl Brown, Manhattan Democrat.

A plan to encourage visual therapy through the use of original works of art and fine reproductions in voluntary hospitals was announced yesterday at a symposium sponsored by the United Hospital Fund of New York.

Record business loans carried by member banks of the Second Federal Reserve District last year brought income from risk assets to an average of 55 per cent of total income, the highest ratio since 1929, according to a report made by Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
CHICAGO, March 3 (AP) -- Standard Oil Company (Indiana) today reported net income of $119,981,438, equal to $7.81 a share, for 1952. This compared with $148,697,356, or $9.71 a share, in 1951.

The ailments from which Premier Stalin was reported to be suffering resemble in a marked degree those that caused the death twenty-nine years ago last January of his predecessor, Lenin, founder of the Soviet Government and the Communist International.

Adolph Zukor, chairman of the board of Paramount Pictures and film pioneer, will be accorded a testimonial dinner tonight at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by Variety Clubs International as part of year-long series of nation-wide tributes to Mr. Zukor's half century in the motion picture industry.

CHILLICOTHE, Ohio, March 3 (AP) -- Ohio celebrated its 150th birthday today in this, the state's first capital. Hundreds of citizens splashed through a pelting winter rain that soaked everything except their rollicking spirits.

Five buildings occuping a plot 90 by 100-feet at 150 to 158 East Fifty-sixth Street have been sold by Frederick Brown to an investing client of Goodman Mabel, attorneys, who recently bought from Mr. Brown the property at 667-76 Lexington Avenue, southeast corner of Fifty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The State Department told Congress today that recognition of state claims to offshore boundaries beyond the three-mile limit would force abandonment of the international position this country had maintained for a century and a half.

The Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company was directed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg to establish a fund for the maintenance and replacement of its rolling stock and equipment. Judge Greenberg directed that this fund be set apart each month from the company's earnings to be decided upon by the board of directors "in the exercise of good business judgment."

ABOARD U. S. S. DIXIE, Wednesday, March 4 (UP) -- A critically ill Navy lieutenant rode a stretcher on a swaying line across heaving seas today in a dramatic mid-Pacific transfer to this destroyer tender from the minesweeper U. S. S. Swift.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 3 -- The Communist and Radical parties, politically united as a Peoples' Front, today offered their support to President Carlos Ibanez del Campo if he would accept a program they outlined. Their accession would give the President a healthy working majority in Chile's new Congress that was elected Sunday.

TRENTON, March 3 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll defended Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons today as a "good citizen who made a real sacrifice when he accepted his present office." Mr. Parsons' discharge of Nelson F. Stamler as deputy attorney general in charge of the gambling inquiry in Bergen County is now being investigated by a joint legislative committee.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (UP) -- Federal Judge Alexander Holtzoff dismissed today one of the two perjury charges against Dr. Joseph W. Weinberg, the "Scientist X" once accused of giving atomic secrets to Communist agents.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 23 -- No one should doubt the courage of the German Bundestag. Its members are busy on a law that gives the husband the last word in quarrels with his wife.

The United States jumped from seventh to fourth place among the leading shipbuilding countries of the world last year, launching sixty-four ships of 467,545 gross tons, according to statistics made public yesterday by Lloyds Register of Shipping.

A group of parent-educators were asked yesterday whether they might not be by-passing a whole segment of the parent population -- those who found fine shades of understanding difficult to achieve, but were capable of intelligent and decisive action -- after years of effort in helping parents to understand child behavior.

The Country Club Apartments at 162-70 Hartsdale Road in Hartsdale, N. Y., have been sold by Samuel Miller and Associates of Mount Vernon to Hartsdale Ventures, Inc., represented by Benjamin Duhl, lawyer.

Sales of the Philco Corporation last year reached a new high of $366,963,850, an increase of 20 per cent over the 1951 volume of $305,328,670, but earnings were lower because of greater taxes and operating costs, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- A Congressional committee served notice today that unless Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, approved, it would take no action on an Air Force proposal to spend more than $3,000,000 on acquisition of land for a proposed Air Force bomber base at Plattsburg, N. Y.

MELBOURNE, March 3 (AP) -- The Australian Olympic Organizing Committee has nothing to show in the way of preparations for the 1956 games but "the finest cricket ground in the world" and a few long-range plans that still are in the discussion stage.

The growth outlook for personal savings over the years ahead is "strongly upward," a spokesman for the American Bankers Association asserted yesterday. Dr. E. Sherman Adams, who heads the association's Department of Monetary Policy, told the group's annual savings and mortgage conference at the Hotel Statler that such growth "would considerably complicate the investment problems confronting the managers of savings institutions."

ON a sunny spring afternoon in 1950 a 6-year-old child, Barbara Horne, was walking home from school in the East Fifties of New York City. A young man appeared on the roof of a tall apartment building, brandishing a rifle. He fired. Barbara fell dead and her killer committed suicide by jumping to his death. Who he was and what were the motives for his insane crime were questions that nearly drove Barbara's father mad.
Public utility enterprises received bids from banking syndicates yesterday for the purchase or underwriting of more than $18,000,000 of new securities -- bonds and preferred stock.

Shifting the scenery in which the many - sided drama that is the life of New York has its setting is a continuing process as the changing pattern of that life creates new demands on the narrow stage to which its star acts are confined.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- A New London, Conn., defense contractor told the Senate today "there is tremendous waste" in defense purchasing because of a lack of competitive bidding and unnecessary use of secret classifications.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 1 -- The ban on the use of German shipping in the delivery of goods to Israel under the 3,000,000-mark ($714,300) reparations treaty with the West German Republic will be lifted. A Foreign Ministry spokesman said today the Government acceded to a Bonn demand for revision of the clause in the reparations pact forbidding German ships to anchor in Israel.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (UP) -- A House of Representative Agriculture subcommittee decided today to call Secretary Ezra T. Benson for questioning about the impact of foreign dairy imports on domestic prices.
CHICAGO, March 3 (AP) -- Joseph Torzewski, 45-year-old South Bend (Ind.) player, excelled today in all-events action of the American Bowling Congress tournament.

Those who have enjoyed Oldric Royce's custom designs will be pleased to learn that, in addition to his custom designing, he now offers made-to-measure styles with prices considerably lower than custom ones.

Holding that what went on in the jury room could not be used as a basis for criminal contempt, the Appellate Division yesterday dismissed such a judgment imposed against John W. Diefendorf, a precious-metal salesman, by General Sessions Judge Jonah J. Goldstein.
PARIS, March 3 -- The French Government is greatly disappointed by the British reply to French proposals for close British association with a European army, officials in Paris indicated tonight.

A high-cheeked woman with the narrow face and long upper lip that characterize the Irish came to Cavanagh's Restaurant yesterday to see that the Fourth Estate properly renewed its acquaintance with the cooking of Ireland.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- A retired school teacher from New York, who refused to say whether she was a Communist, gave members of the Senate Internal Security subcommittee a tongue-lashing today. She said they had used "cloak and dagger" tactics to depict her as a mystery woman in the Communist underground.

Isabel Mourao, Brazilian pianist, made her second recital appearance at Town Hall last evening, and in the opening minutes of her program proved herself to be a versatile and technically proficient artist.

Reporting on operations of J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., at the annual meeting held here yesterday, John P. Stevens Jr., board chairman, told stockholders that while definite improvement has been made by the textile industry, conditions were not yet satisfactory.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Donald S. Tydings, a tax official, acknowledged today that he was buying diamond-studded jewelry for a woman friend at a time he was in trouble over a $3,000 bank loan guaranteed by a man described as a notorious law violator.

Jascha Heifetz, who opened his recital last night in Carnegie Hall by playing the prelude of a Bach partita at a far livelier clip than the music demanded, continued with an evening of superlative violin playing, of which perhaps only he, of all living virtuosos, is capable.

Coleman Company, Wichita, Kan., introduced yesterday a new year-round air conditioning line that it claims cuts water bills sharply when used in the summer. The company, a large, producer of home heating equipment and camp stoves, showed its new unit at a press luncheon in the Biltmore Hotel.

THIS is the time of year when the prophets and soothsayers study the natural omens and portents and come forth with their varied estimates on the imminence of spring, and the first of these reports has just arrived from our yaupon-leaf reader on the Outer Banks, one Aycock Brown of Dare County, N. C.

NEW DELHI, March 3 -- The Indian Government announced today what was regarded as a substantial liberalization of exchange restrictions governing repatriation of investments from non-sterling-area countries in Government-approved projects.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Mar. 3 -- United States military authorities in Europe have now largely completed negotiations with European aircraft manufacturers for an estimated total of 1,200 new supersonic jet fighters to be supplied by the United States to North Atlantic Treaty allies within the next twenty-eight months.
About midnight tonight 30,000 chicks are scheduled to start pecking their way out of their shells into an international arrangement known as "Operation Peep-Peep."

ALBANY, March 3 -- The Assembly today gave its approval to one section of Governor Dewey's highway-safety program by passing bills increasing fees for motor-vehicle driving licenses and expanding the membership of the State Police from 900 to 1,200 men.

B. Gertz, Inc., subsidiary of Allied Stores Corporation, which operates department stores in Jamaica and Flushing, Queens, has made several major shifts in merchandise management, Ralph F. Waltz, managing director of Gertz, announced yesterday.

Seven persons lost their lives and fifteen others were injured yesterday as one of the most deadly fires in recent city history swept a Bronx factory building and sent billows of dense, acrid smoke skyward over lower West Bronx.

Morris Friedman, operator, has purchased the two-story taxpayer with eight stores and two lofts at 669-83 Allerton Avenue, the Bronx from Hyman Friedman, Inc., for cash above mortgages of $72,377. The property is assessed at $87,000.

The nation's seventy-nine medical schools received grants of $1,687,501 from the National Fund for Medical Education in 1952, according to the Fund's annual report issued yesterday. It was explained that rising deficits in the schools now total $10,000,000 a year.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 3 (AP) -- A new effort to shift the Browns' baseball franchise to Milwaukee before the start of the 1953 season ran into difficulty today, and influential parties on both sides agreed there was no chance of it immediately.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 3 (AP) -- Two Baltimore women amateur players -- Mary Ann Downey and Mrs. Maurice Glick -- tied for the medal with scores of 76 in the qualifying round of the twenty-fifth annual Florida East Coast golf tournament today.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- A group of industry and Government officials will examine the problem of the diversion of United States drugs to Communist China and other Soviet dominated areas, the Office of International Trade of the Commerce Department said today.
HARRISBURG, Pa., March 3 -- Widespread job discrimination against minority groups throughout Pennsylvania was reported today by a special fourteen-member committee appointed by Gov. John S. Fine.

MANDALAY, Burma, March 3 (Reuters) -- The Burmese Army announced today it had begun an all-out offensive to trap and crush a strong force of Chinese Nationalists that has been operating in Northern Burma since the Communists took over in China.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 3 -- At its forthcoming sessions at United Nations Headquarters during April the Economic and Social Council will consider a recommendation from the February conference of its Transport and Communications Commission that meetings at government level be held to draw up an international convention covering the transport of dangerous goods.

The rules committee of the City Council agreed yesterday to schedule a vote in the next two weeks on a resolution by Councilman Earl Brown, Democrat of Manhattan, to appropriate $50,000 and appoint a five-man board to investigate reported police brutality.

A busy schedule of college basketball on local campus floors tonight is highlighted by Pennsylvania's visit to Columbia, where, in all likelihood, the Eastern League championship will be determined. The Lions and Quakers, with identical 7-2 records in Ivy League competition, will meet before a capacity turnout at University Hall.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 3 (UP) -- A woman doctor who failed in the most important operation of her life was found blameless today in the death of the patient -- her own baby.

ALBANY, March 3 -- Representatives of Protestant and Jewish church groups, bar associations and self-styled "victims" of the present laws will appear Thursday at a public hearing to urge a study of New York's divorce law.

Net earnings of the American Gas and Electric System, the nation's biggest utility from the standpoint of electric output, reached a record $27,738,000 equal to $2.39 a share, in the twelve months ending Jan. 31, the company announced yesterday. This compares with $24,511,000 or $2.24 a share in the previous twelve months.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 3 -- The 7-month-old controversy between Mario Lanza and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer resulting from the singer's failure to report for work in "The Student Prince," is almost over. Mr. Lanza is expected to return to the studio fold next month, Edgar J. Mannix, general manager of the studio, said today.

" The Merchant of Venice," the third and final fortnightly revival at the City Center, will open there at 8 o'clock tonight and continue through March 15. The Shakespearean play hasn't been done on Broadway since 1947, when Donald Wolfit acted Shylock. Performing that stint in the latest presentation will be Luther Adler, who is costarred with Margaret Phillips as Portia.
Two years ago, Joseph Ricciardi of 160 Eldert Street, Brooklyn, appeared before Judge Louis Goldstein in Kings County Court for arraignment on an indictment charging him with burglary.

The withdrawal of the Grand Street Boys' Association's track stars from the Pioneer Club's meet to be held at Harlem's 369th Regiment Armory on Saturday drew criticism yesterday at the weekly luncheon of the Metropolitan Track Writers Association.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Florida Power and Light Company of Miami today filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of $15,000,000 of first mortgage bonds. Proceeds are to be used to provide additional electric and gas facilities and for other corporate purposes. Construction expenditures are estimated at $70,000,000 for 1953-1954.

Last year, the 102d of its operation, the American Express Company and its consolidated subsidiaries transacted a total volume of business of $2,500,000,000, representing the gross sales of Travelers Cheques, travel service, money orders and foreign remittances and revenue from international freight forwarding and other services rendered by the world-wide organization.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, the Senate Republican Leader, broke with and defeated the Eisenhower Administration today in the opening skirmish on the first important foreign policy issue to be presented to the Republican Congress.
Nassau County, N. Y., announced yesterday that it will receive bids March 17 on $27,094,000 of sewage collection district bonds. Dated April 15, 1953, the bonds will come due April 15, 1954 to 1982.

SUFFOLK COUNTY AIR FORCE BASE, Westhampton, L. I., March 3 -- There can be little doubt that the fastest and deadliest defenders of the New York metropolitan area are the Air Force's jet fighters based here. Their type holds the official world's speed record, and they are housed in push-button hangars that allow their pilots to scramble up to intercept attacking planes moments after radar observers have discovered the enemy's aerial approach.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Through hours of bristling and at times explosive exchanges -- many of them on television -- Reed Harris, deputy director of the State Department's International Information Administration, today accused Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Wisconsin Republican and chairman of a subcommittee investigating the Voice of America, of "trying to wring my public neck."

The stock market yesterday moved ahead cautiously with aircrafts, fertilizers and electric equipment issues in the front. Plus signs were registered for all but one of the ten most active issues of the day and the lone exception was American Telephone Telegraph, which closed unchanged.

TRENTON, March 3 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll disclosed today that New Jersey was all but ready, after months of indecision, to approve the Army Engineers' plans for deepening the Delaware River channel to a depth of forty feet as far north as the Trenton Marine Terminal.
CHICAGO, March 3 (AP) -- The Chicago office of the Production and Marketing Administration announced today it would buy corn from the grain trade at current market prices.
Tenants won a victory yesterday in their fight to prevent the replacement of elevator operators by automatic elevators when doormen were not provided for their protection.
Patriotic Americans, anticipating the addition of Hawaii as the forty-ninth state, already are deluging the Government and flag makers with designs for a new Star Spangled Banner.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor proposed today about twenty major amendments that would amount substantially to repeal of the Taft-Hartley law.

In a dispatch to this newspaper Robert Trumbull reports from Karachi that Pakistani leaders are united in their desire to see their country included in the planning of a Middle East defense accord. The United States and, indeed, the whole of the free Western World must rejoice at this willingness of the Pakistanis to stand up and be counted.
BERLIN, March 3 -- United States authorities here are considering the re-establishment of a "little airlift" of military planes to help ferry refugees from Berlin to West Germany.

A plan for the national promotion of men's pants was revealed last night by the Associated Pants Manufacturers of America. Eugene Given, president of the association, speaking at a meeting in the New Yorker Hotel, asserted that a continuing campaign would insure a growing market for the industry, which is producing about 50,000,000 pairs of slacks a year.
The trade-mark of Fisk Tires -- the boy with a tire over his arm, lighting his way to bed above the legend "Time to Re-Tire" -- is now being made from a weather resistant plastic in a six-foot size.

Gilbert Frank Puckett, who once practiced law in the Middle West, where no one knew that he was a fugitive from justice in New Jersey, is no longer wanted. Thirty-three years after his escape from the Budd Lake road camp, the New Jersey Parole Board yesterday paroled him, retroactively to 1940.

A detailed program has been announced by which the twenty-nine synthetic rubber producing facilities owned by the Government will be transferred to private ownership and operation. The plan, which has been recommended to the President by Harry A. McDonald, head of the R. F. C., has been worked out with the idea of obtaining for the Government the maximum return on its investment "consonant with the attainment of a competitive industry."
Confidence was expressed by import trade sources yesterday that a bill to reduce complexities of United States Customs procedure would be introduced in Congress by April 1.

LONDON, March 3 -- The Duke of Edinburgh will stand with the royal Dukes of Gloucester and Kent twenty-five feet from his wife when the Archbishop of Canterbury crowns her as Queen Elizabeth II at 12:30 P. M. on June 2 in Westminster Abbey.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 3 -- Soldiers and policemen broke up a Communist demonstration today, before it could get started, in the fourth day of reaction since the feuding between Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi and Premier Mohammed Mossadegh broke into the open.
ALBANY, March 3 -- A bill broadening police powers to deal with obscene or immoral publications was approved unanimously in the Assembly today and sent to the Senate.

Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley promised yesterday that a traffic light would be installed in May at the intersection of East Tremont Avenue and Purdy Street for the Parkchester apartment development in the Bronx. The light has been an object of a two-year campaign by tenants.
The Cunard liner Media docked here at 7:30 A. M. yesterday, two and one-half days late because of gales and high waves that buffeted the vessel on the entire tenday crossing from Liverpool.

The Museum of Modern Art will open to the public tomorrow an exhibition made up of forty paintings from the collection of Edward G. Robinson, motion-picture star, whose home is in Los Angeles. A benefit preview for the museum's New York School Fund was held last evening and a preview for museum members will be held this evening.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Hawaii scored an easy victory toward her long-standing bid for statehood today when the House Interior and Insular Affairs Committee approved a bill to bring the island territory into the Union immediately after the 1954 elections.

MEXICO CITY, March 3 -- Virtually all Government payments and expenditures have been halted pending review of Mexico's economic status and as part of President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines' revolutionary drive to wipe out official corruption.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 3 -- "Either my hitters are good or my pitchers aren't so hot," was Manager Chuck Dressen's comment after today's free-hitting practice game in which his regulars blew a 7-0 first-inning lead and finished on the short end of a 13-11 score in six innings.
The Senate's waterfront crime hunters came to the Port of New York yesterday and loaded their guns with information about rackets and corruption that had been gathered by local investigators.

SAN JUAN, P. R., March 3 -- Puerto Rico wants atomic power and has a Federal promise that the situation will be studied, it was disclosed today as a dozen New York City and state officials studying the migration of Puerto Ricans looked over the island's "Operation Bootstrap" program for industrialization.

The carnival of commercialism that pervaded telecasts of last year's Easter Parade on Fifth Avenue is expected to be curtailed this year through more cautious planning by the networks and stations covering the event on April 5.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, described the American Red Cross today as an "auxiliary part of the Armed Forces" and called on the public and service men to support the current drive 'to the fullest extent."

Under an agreement reported by Drew Middleton and scheduled for signature war criminal Alfred Krupp will sell all his holdings in the coal, iron and steel industry by 1960. In return the Allies will lift all remaining controls on his other industrial enterprises. Krupp will be left with a fortune estimated at about 140 million dollars.

ALBANY, March 3 -- Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., was disclosed today to have added a new complication to the problems confronting state and city officials who are seeking a long-range solution to New York City's financial difficulties.

The Administration will continue the policy of "trade, not aid," in its dealings with foreign countries, it was asserted yesterday by Arthur Z. Gardiner, economic adviser to the Bureau of Near East, South Asian and African Affairs of the Department of State.

MIAMI, March 3 (AP) -- The English-bred Royal Vale flashed to a North American speed record today as he upset the form to win the $25,000 added Miami Beach Handicap, the last feature race of the richest of all Hialeah seasons.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Spokesmen for two major ports of entry. New York City and Philadelphia, asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to authorize all-freight air service across the Atlantic to Europe and the Middle East.

ALBANY, March 3 -- Joseph D. McGoldrick, State Rent Administrator, estimated today that 1,000,000 of the 2,300,000 residential tenants in New York State would have to pay 15 per cent rent increases under the administration's rent control bill, which was introduced in the Legislature today.

Senator Jenner's statement published Feb. 25 should clear the air on the dangers to academic freedom from current Congressional investigations. So long as these inquiries are limited to proof of the presence of teachers who operate under Communist party discipline they present no threat to proper academic freedom.

Dr. Rollo May, chairman of the Joint Council of New York State Psychologists on Legislation, representing psychological associations and training institutions, assailed last night the Milmoe-Waters bill, now before the State Legislature which would amend the Medical Practice Act to include "diagnosis and treatment of mental conditions" as part of the definition of the practice of medicine.

BURBANK, Calif., March 3 -- James J. Jeffries, former world heavyweight boxing champion, died tonight at the age of 77. Mr. Jeffries suffered a stroke recently. He had been in ill health for several years.

Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed firm 19 points higher to 2 points lower than on Monday, with old crop months showing the most strength. It was reported that some of the late buying may have been fixations against exports to Europe.

PARIS, March 3 -- A Socialist motion to stage a formal debate soon on the case of the two missing Jewish war orphans, Robert and Gerald Finaly, was defeated, 300 to 227, by the National Assembly today after the Minister of Justice, Leon Martinaud-Deplat, had declared that the Government was doing its duty by prosecuting those responsible for the children's disappearance.

The International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., asserted yesterday that the General Electric Company could increase wages 21 cents an hour without cutting its profits below the level of other electrical manufacturers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 3 -- Dr. J. M. A. H. Luns, Foreign Minister of the Netherlands, told the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly today that, despite the Communists' rejection of an armistice in Korea, the members of the United Nations must "reaffirm our unflinching determination to remain strong and united in a just cause."

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 3 -- The French have been pressing on with the pacification of South Vietnam (Cochin China) by a large scale operation that began Feb. 25. The operation has a twofold aim: (1) To clean up the Saigon River, and (2) to reopen the road linking Saigon with Cape St. Jacques, a rocky promontory where the Saigon River meets the sea.

LOS ANGELES, March 3 -- Max Viault, retired milling executive, died at Santa Monica Hospital today after stabbing himself in the chest accidentally while carving a roast last night. He was 73 years old.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 3 -- Merwin L. Bohan is resigning March 31 as head of Point Four work in Brazil as a result of policy disagreements with the Technical Cooperation Administration in Washington, a reliable source here said today.

The Correspondents Fund of the Overseas Press Club of America, Inc., made a final payment of $92,214 yesterday to take title to a five-story building at 35 East Thirty-ninth Street for a Memorial Press Center in honor of American newspaper correspondents who died overseas in line of duty since the beginning of the second World War.

The United States Military Academy at West Point received a certificate of merit yesterday from the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program for the 5,000 pints that cadets and station personnel have contributed. In ceremonies at the academy Maj. Gen. F. A. Irving, superintendent, accepted the award from John S. Sinclair, chairman of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross.

Berenice Bramson, soprano from Katonah, N. Y., made an auspicious debut last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. She gave a song recital which was beautifully sung and which contained some lovely music that is often overlooked.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Department of Justice announced today that denaturalization proceedings had been instituted against Sidney Steinberg, a Communist, of New York.
LONDON, March 3 (AP) -- The sterling area's gold-dollar reserves climbed $125,000,000 in February to $2,103,000,000, the highest since December, 1951, the Treasury announced today.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, March 4 (UP) -- Following are the texts of the statement on Premier Stalin's illness issued by the Soviet Government and of the medical bulletin signed by the Minister of Health and the physicians:

BOSTON, March 3 -- Arthur J. B. Cartier, United States Marshal for Massachusetts, received today official notification of his removal, but said that it did not change his determination "to fight this matter out in the courts."

Attendance was heavy at the Leather Show, which opened yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Most of the orders were for samples as manufacturers of shoes, handbags, luggage and other leather goods postponed buying in the belief that the price structure will change.

The visit to Washington of two top officials of the British Government -- the Foreign Secretary and the Chancellor of the Exchequer -- serves to emphasize two harsh facts of international life. One is the inextricable connection between economic and political decisions.

Prices closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges in continued light activity. Cocoa, soybean oil, rubber, wool and tin were higher. Lead and zinc ended lower and sugar, potatoes, cottonseed oil and hides closed mixed.

ALBANY, March 3 (AP) -- The Legislature's outnumbered Democrats today lost strategy moves to force a vote on proposals to give the state the entire pari-mutual breakage at flat tracks and extend the 15 per cent local tax to clubhouse admissions.

An illuminated scroll bearing testimony that Allen Fleming Myers' "high standard of perfection" has been an inspiration to the employes of Ames Rollinson was presented to him at a surprise party yesterday to celebrate his fiftieth year with the company, which has been printing such testimonials since 1869.

ALBANY, March 3 -- The Assembly is scheduled to approve tomorrow a bill amending the state charter of the Knights of Pythias, a fraternal benevolent order, to repeal a provision barring membership to all but white persons. It will be the first time the Legislature has voted to end a discriminatory practice in a social organization.

TRENTON, March 3 -- Democratic county chairman and other party officials from all of the state's twenty-one counties will gather here tomorrow night in an effort to agree on a nominee for Governor. With only nine days left in which prospective candidates may file nominating petitions, only one Democrat and two Republicans have taken this step.

NEWARK, March 3 -- A slate of five candidates for a Charter Commission that would study and make recommendations relating to the improvement of Newark's municipal operations was named today by the Newark Citizens Committee on Municipal Government.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- The State Department has prepared a new directive reported to unfreeze some types of Communist writings for anti-Communist propaganda use.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (UP) -- Marian Anderson will make her first commercial appearance in Constitution Hall since the Daughters of the American Revolution barred her fourteen years ago.

BONN, Germany, March 3 -- The mutual Security Agency and the West German Government have reached a basic agreement on the main features of a $60,000,000 program to increase the productivity of West German industry through medium-term credits and scientific planning, production and management.

Adolphus Hohensee, who styles himself "farmer, nutritionist, naturopath, chiropractor," was arraigned in Magistrate's Court at Second Avenue and Second Street yesterday on a charge of failing to give deeds to at least fifteen persons to whom he had sold land, according to the office of State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein.

The decision of Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican of New Hampshire, to do a regular series of radio programs for the Columbia Broadcasting System is an unfortunate mistake in judgment. It must be hoped that both the Senator and the network will reconsider the implications of the broadcasts.

LONDON, March 3 (AP) -- The sea ferry ship Farringford was reported missing with thirty persons aboard tonight in a fog that blanketed most of England. Air, sea and road travel stalled in many places.

The Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society has bought from the Vatican a half-completed monastery in Jerusalem to house 100 women attending the Hebrew University there, it was announced yesterday by Ben Touster, president of the society.

Every step taken toward decontrol of rents becomes a political battleground, and the new bill introduced in the New York Legislature yesterday is no exception. More than seven years have passed since the Second World War ended. The housing shortage has been somewhat alleviated, but New York City is certainly not ready for return of a fully free market.

In an unusual liaison between motion pictures and television, which may have far-reaching effects, Twentieth Century-Fox and the Ed Sullivan "Toast of the Town" Columbia Broadcasting System television show have concluded an agreement under which "miniature world premieres" of forthcoming Fox pictures will be shown as regular monthly features of the popular, hour-long Sunday video program over a two-year period.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce took the oath of office today as Ambassador to Italy. The former Republican Representative and playwright was sworn in by Fred M. Vinson, Chief Justice of the United States, in the office of John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 3 -- A plan for a $9,000,000 international campaign for Dutch flood rehabilitation has emerged from discussions here between Netherlands officials and welfare leaders and the International League of Red Cross Societies.

Scoring 100 or more points in a game for the tenth time this season, the New York Knickerbockers routed the Rochester Royals, 109 -- 88, before 10,027 fans at Madison Square Garden last night. It was a surprisingly easy triumph for Joe Lapchick's club, which needed this victory to even the season's series between the quintets.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 3 -- Stanley La Benskey, who was acquited here last June on charges of having murdered two Negroes at a Yonkers tavern after objecting to their presence at the bar, was sentenced in County Court today to nine months' imprisonment in the Westchester County Penitentiary for illegal posession of the pistol that caused the deaths.

Everyone knows, including the management of the Metropolitan Opera, that Saint-Saens' "Samson et Dalila" is not exactly an action-crammed opera. There are long stretches when hardly anything happens on the stage, which is also true of a good deal of Wagner, but the difference is that Saint-Saens did not charge his music with drama.

LONDON, March 3 -- The pace of the advance by British Government securities quickened on the stock markets here today and gains of up to one-half of 1 per cent were made. Buying of British funds was strengthened by hopes, confirmed after the markets closed, of a rise in gold and dollar reserves.

Adelphi College has solved a problem of expanding its facilities for a training program for nurses and broadening its medical research projects and community services through the simple device of acquiring a hospital.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3 -- He is 35 years old; he is facing his eleventh full-time campaign in the major leagues, his eighth as a Yankee, and he is heading for his fifteenth year in organized baseball yet Allie Reynolds is looking forward to another year as pitcher that will equal, if not exceed, the twenty-game victory peak he achieved last year.
New fixtures and lamps from two European nations that have greatly influenced lighting devices in this country have just arrived here.

Canada was the subject of a seminar for several hundred business and professional men who took a couple of hours off yesterday afternoon to attend a "Know Your Neighbor" meeting in Town Hall. It was the first of a series of six weekly gatherings for this purpose, with economic factors being a dominating feature.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet, former Commander of the Eighth Army in Korea, spent a crowded day here today, receiving honors at the hands of his Commander in Chief, his superior officers, much of the diplomatic corps, and friends and colleagues of long standing.

Bergdorf Goodman, the specialty shop that graces the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, is celebrating its silver anniversary. March 5 marks the day when Edwin Goodman, president, who is now chairman of the board, moved the shop uptown from the earlier location at Forty-ninth Street.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., March 3 -- Clergymen and merchants of this village of 16,000 arranged today for the printing of Roman Catholic, Jewish and Protestant prayers on the menus of thirty restaurants so patrons might ask for divine blessing while waiting for food.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- This country's exports of unmanufactured tobacco in 1952 declined about 24 per cent from 1951, but within the nation a record was established in the manufacture and consumption of cigarettes.

The bond market had a distinctly better tone yesterday in all of the investment-grade departments. Both in the secondary corporate market, which has become very thin lately in the wake of sales of new issues at progressively rising yields, and in the supply-swamped municipal market, traders reported growing interest on the buying side.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 3 -- The Giants' contract-signing worries for 1953 are over, and so far as Alvin Dark is concerned there won't be any for 1954 either.
A veteran attorney, Joseph Marrell, 46 years old, with offices at 305 Broadway, was arrested yesterday with two men on charges of ambulance chasing.
Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., and its theatre affiliate, the new Stanley Warner Corporation, have begun operating as separate entities following reorganization, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, March 4 -- United States officials said early today that the news of Premier Stalin's paralytic stroke was an event of such momentous importance that they could make no official comment pending receipt of further information.

CHICAGO, March 3 -- Weather news was again a depressing factor in the wheat market here today, and rather sharp declines were registered early on the forecast for more precipitation this week in the Southwest.

Two more books about undersea exploration and adventure are planned for publication this year. Last month Harper issued Capt. J. Y. Cousteau's "The Silent World," written in collaboration with Frederic Dumas. On March 30 Julian Messner will issue "The Undersea Adventure" by Philippe Diole in a translation from the French by Alan Ross.

Trade and industrial reports, on the whole, make it clear that business is moving with "good momentum," the National City Bank of New York declares in its monthly letter, being issued today. Any doubts as to the 1953 outlook, the bank adds, are centered on the premise that the momentum may be too strong to last and sales expectations too optimistic.

ALBANY, March 3 -- Following are the texts of statements by D. Mallory Stephens, chairman of the Temporary State Commission on Rents and Rental Conditions, explaining the new rent control bill introduce today and how the 15 per cent increase formula would work, and by Senator Francis J. Mahoney and Assemblyman Eugene F. Bannigan, Minority Leaders of the Legislature:

MOSCOW, Wednesday, March 4 -- The Government announced shortly before 8 A. M. today [Tuesday midnight, Eastern standard time] that Premier Stalin had suffered a brain hemorrhage Sunday night with paralysis of the right hand and leg, loss of speech and loss of consciousness.

Coach Bill Cook and Manager Frank Boucher haven't given up on their New York Rangers. Both declared yesterday at the weekly luncheon meeting of the metropolitan hockey writers at Leone's Restaurant that they were hopeful the Broadway Blues would continue in the role as "spoilers" in the National Hockey League. The Rangers will skate against the Chicago Black Hawks tonight at Madison Square Garden.

Chinese, here in New York and throughout the world, have been celebrating the third anniversary of the resumption of the Chinese Presidency by Chiang Kai-shek. Much of the comment has revolved around the question of training for an assault on the mainland, the demand for such an assault and speculation as to its proximity.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- The Senate Armed Services Committee unanimously approved today a House-passed bill extending the dependency allotment system for military personnel to July 1, 1955.

NEW DELHI, India, March 3 -- The Communist party in the House of the People or lower house of Parliament came under severe fire from Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru today when it made a strong protest against the Indian Government's having given permission to four United States destroyers from Korea to berth and refuel at Calcutta on their way home.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 3 -- A possibility that the Matson passenger ship Lurline, booked solidly for three months with 720 passengers, might be delayed in sailing for Hawaii tomorrow afternoon was foreseen today by officials of the American Radio Association, C. I. O.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. opposed today, in a letter to a Michigan man, the idea of a national crime commission or a clearing house agency for information on racketeers or other criminals. He saw in the suggestion the possibility of a centralized police force and asserted:

Holding off a gallant bid by the West Coast trio in the second half, Cornell University's polo team gained the semi-final round of the national intercollegiate championship tournament last night by defeating Stanford University, 10 to 8, at the Squadron A Armory.

SILVER CITY, N. M., March 3 (UP) -- Fist fighting broke out today between fifty Silver City residents and camera men making a controversial film, "The Salt of the Earth," sponsored by the International Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers Union.

The colorful history of the application of decoration to glass is portrayed in an exhibit of antique and modern glass objects that opens today at Steuben Glass, 718 Fifth Avenue. Assembled by the Corning Museum of Glass, the display will continue through April 11 and in the autumn be sent on a tour around this country.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Twenty years ago tonight, in a deepening financial crisis that caused bank after bank to close its doors to demanding depositors, the country awaited the inauguration on the morrow of Franklin D. Roosevelt as the thirty-second President of the United States.

CHICAGO, March 3 -- Irenee du Pont, a millionaire who is glad to pay his taxes and never has been interested in the stock market, spoke his mind today on subjects ranging from the New Deal to the United Nations, which he said should be a powerless debating society.

TOKYO, Wednesday, March 4 -- Swift American Sabre jets, flying protective cover for fighter-bombers on strikes over far North Korea yesterday, engaged Communist MIG's in a series of swirling dogfights that ended a five-day lull in the air battles.

FORT LEE, N. J., March 3 -- The body of 15-year-old Gerard Keefe of 3505 Foster Avenue, Brooklyn, was found this morning at the base of a 100-foot cliff about a quarter of a mile north of the George Washington Bridge. The youth had been missing since Sunday, when he disappeared while on a hike.

PHILADELPHIA, March 3 (AP) -- Any sponsor who would like to televise the home games in the New York area of the New York Football Giants need only step up and guarantee the club a full house at all home games.
Another of the apartment buildings on Park Avenue with apartments of many rooms and a bath for every three rooms is to give way to a modern office building William A. White Sons announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- President Eisenhower said today the American people could reduce the chances of a third world war by building a strong and vigilant civil defense organization.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 4 -- The Dutch public and officials reacted in sharply contrasting terms today to news of Premier Stalin's illness. The average man displayed a feeling of foreboding about what might ensue as power dropped from the hands of the man who had become synonymous with dictatorial rule.
A group of labor officials played "teacher" yesterday for seventy field service workers of the American Cancer Society, offering a curriculum that ranged from labor history to union structure.

The classic, inevitable and most difficult crisis of any totalitarian regime has now gripped the Soviet Union. As Stalin lies unconscious and paralyzed in his sickbed, the fundamental question arises inexorably: Who succeeds to the power that was the leader's? The stroke which felled Stalin could not fail to split the orderly pyramid of command and obedience whose peak he was.

BONN, Germany, March 4 (AP) -- West Germany's agreement to pay reparations to Israel for Nazi persecution of the Jews moved a stage nearer ratification today. It passed its first reading in the Bundestag.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 4 -- The almost universal reaction of Israelis upon learning today of Premier Stalin's illness was one of relief -- a relief that ended quickly as they asked worried questions as to what would come after Stalin.

NEW ORLEANS, March 4 (UP) -- Tahitian King, Ben Whitaker's leading hope for the 3 - year - old classics, launched his 1953 campaign today with an easy victory in the Quatrain Purse at the Fair Grounds.
BERLIN, March 4 -- The news of Premier Stalin's critical illness loosed rumors that flew about Berlin today alternately inciting hope and consternation among the credulous.

TRENTON, March 4 -- After deliberating tonight for three hours Democratic leaders representing New Jersey's twenty-one counties narrowed their governorship choice to three candidates and selected a committee of nine who will try within the next few days to make a final selection.

Prominent women are actively interested in the performance of Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus on the afternoon of April 17 at Madison Square Garden, which will benefit the Legal Aid Society. The benefit has been arranged by members of the Ways and Means Committee of the Women's Division of the Legal Aid Society, of which Mrs. Andrew Y. Rogers is chairman and who has Mrs. Robert A. Hendrickson Jr. among her aides.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, accepted today the resignation of John Carter Vincent, saying that the veteran career diplomat's performance of duty had fallen short of the required standard demanded "at this critical time."

With the news of Stalin's illness, dealers in foreign bonds reported considerable interest yesterday in the dollar bonds of all Iron Curtain countries. The old Imperial Russian 5 1/2s of 1921 and 6 1/2s of 1919, traded on the American Stock Exchange, experienced the greatest activity. There are about $75,000,000 of these bonds outstanding and yesterday more than $500,000 principal amount of them changed hands.

A syndicate represented by Herrick, Feinstein Rossman, attorneys, has purchased the thirteen-story apartment house at 530 West End Avenue, southeast corner of Eighty-sixth Street, from Jack and Morris Weiner in a deal negotiated by Nat Schneir and Paul Hayman, brokers.

A struggle for control of the United States Hoffman Machinery Corporation ended yesterday when George E. Bowdoin, president, announced an increase in the board of directors from eleven to fifteen had been approved at a special board meeting.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (UP) -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet said today he would rather face bullets in Korea than the Capital's press and radio corps.

The Borden Company and its consolidated subsidiaries in 1952 achieved a new sales record for the third successive year with $768,019,612, a gain of 6 per cent over the 1951 volume of $722,770,380. Net income, however, declined about 2 per cent to $17,667,137, or $4.11 a share from $18,080,371, or $4.20 a share, the year before.

A vacant plot of about 4,000 square feet at the southwest corner of Roosevelt Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street in Woodside, Queens, has been sold by Lester P. McArdle to the Laman Realty Corporation for improvement with an office, showroom and warehouse building Queens Industrials were the brokers.

The National Committee of the Communist party of the United States sent a message of "deepest grief" for the illness of Premier Stalin to the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist party in Moscow yesterday. The statement closed with an expression of hope for the Soviet leader's recovery.

CAMPECHE, Mexico, March 4 (AP) -- The ranking United States diplomatic official in Mexico flew here today to take charge of American interests in the dispute over thirteen United States shrimp boats captured and brought to port by a Mexican gunboat.

MIAMI, March 4 (AP) -- Joey Maxim gave Tampa's Danny Nardico an early boxing lesson tonight but had to get off the deck from a seventh-round knockdown to win a unanimous ten round decision at Miami Stadium before 5,525 fans. Maxim weighed 183 1/2 pounds, Nardico 176 1/2.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 4 -- The United Nations, in agreement with the Arab Governments, has arranged for $100,000,000 to be spent on projects in the Middle East for the benefit of Arab refugees, John B. Blandford Jr., who has resigned as head of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees, said today.

Lieut. Gen. C. R. Huebner, director of the New York State Civil Defense Commission, announced yesterday that industrial plants throughout the state would receive awards for the protection of equipment and training of personnel under the civil defense program.

Joseph D. Nunan, Jr., former Commissioner of Internal Revenue, pleaded not guilty in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday to a charge of perjury and trial was set for April 6. He had been accused of making false statements before a special Federal grand jury checking his finances.

ROME, March 4 -- The news that Premier Stalin was dangerously ill and probably dying caused apprehension in Italian Government circles. No official comment was forthcoming, but it was evident that most persons were less inclined to be elated over the foreseen early end of the arch-foe of the Western world than to be pre-occupied over possible developments of Soviet policy under his successor.

The Harcord Manufacturing Company has contracted to purchase the property of the Air Reduction Company at 125 Monitor Street in Jersey City, N. J., in a transaction negotiated through the Joseph J. Garibaldi Organization as broker.

Seventy-eight crew members on the French liner Liberte were examined and cleared for shore leave within fifty minutes yesterday as the Immigration Service sharply modified the strict alien screening procedures it had been enforcing under the provisions of the McCarren-Walter Immigration and Nationality Act.

PARIS, March 4 -- The uncertainties for the Soviet Union and for the rest of the world as a result of the Stalin illness was the reaction uppermost in all circles of France today when the news was received from the Moscow radio.

ALBANY, March 4 -- Senator Walter J. Mahoney, Senate Finance Committee Chairman and one of the Republican leaders consulted by Governor Dewey in the formation of party policy, announced today that he would vote against compulsory insurance for all automobile owners.

The two hold-up men were a little too brazen. They asked their victim for a rope with which to tie him and a key with which to lock him up. In spite of a pistol pointed at him, Leo Precker, a 52-year-old jeweler, couldn't be pushed that far.

Stalin is practically irreplaceable in the Soviet mythology. As head of the tightest and most powerful dictatorship in the world, the dying chieftain may be temporarily succeeded by the Council of Ministers and later by a committee or by the uneasy winner among the top contenders for the throne. But who can inherit Stalin's colossal personal prestige?

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 4 -- Warner Brothers said tonight that it would taper off on the production of new pictures for a period which it "hopes will not exceed ninety days." The company stressed that the move did not foreshadow a complete shutdown of production and added that, during the period of lull, efforts would be concentrated on the expansion and rebuilding of studio facilities destroyed and damaged in two big fires last year.

TOKYO, Thursday, March 5 -- Japan, always deeply concerned over developments inside the Soviet Union, her traditional enemy and mighty neighbor, received calmly the news of the serious illness of Premier Stalin.

ALBANY, March 4 -- The Assembly approved and sent to the Senate today a bill that would give a person accused or suspected of wrongdoing before an investigating body the right to testify at a public hearing provided that a waiver of immunity was signed.

GARY, Ind., March 4 -- A new process of extrusion of high-alloy seamless steel tubing, one in which the heated metal is forced through a die like toothpaste being squeezed out of a tube, was demonstrated today in the Gary plant of United States Steel Corporation's National Tube Division.

BONN, Germany, March 4 -- The combined steel group of the Allied High Commission decontrolled today the Krupp industrial empire in exchange for an agreement by Alfred Krupp von Bohlen und Halbach to liquidate his holdings in steel, iron and coal and a pledge not to re-enter these industries within his lifetime.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 4 (UP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman, who once called Joseph Stalin "a decent fellow" who was a prisoner of the Politburo, said today he was sorry to hear the Soviet dictator had been stricken.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 4 -- Leading Communist officials in this country believe Premier Stalin is dead, that he was dead when his illness was first announced and that a serious struggle for power in the Soviet Union is about to ensue if it has not already begun.

Two bills designed to relieve wholesale salesmen who carry more than one line of products from the burden of the unincorporated business tax have been introduced in the State Legislature at Albany. Louis A. Capaldo, president of the National Council of Salesmen's Organizations, said the bills are Assembly No. 1611 and Senate No. 1473.

ALBANY, March 4 -- The Assembly passed legislation today to strengthen the hand of the State Education Department and the Attorney General in dealing with tie-ups between physicians and pharmacists with drug manufacturing or distributing companies.

LONDON, March 4 -- The drug antrycide, hailed five years ago as the salvation of Africa's cattle raising, has proved effective -- except for one drawback -- in extensive field trials conducted by the pharmaceutical division of Imperial Chemical Industries.

If vaudeville stays on at the Palace long enough it may help eventually to revive the art of stilt-walking, which at the moment is considerably more moribund than vaudeville was a few years back. Not so very long ago stilts were used by comedians, clowns, children, sandwich men and even by skaters.

MANILA, Thursday, March 5 (AP) -- The second United Nations trade promotion conference for Asia and the Far East ended yesterday with a strong Russian bid for an immediate increase of trade apparently ignored.
August Horrmann.. chairman of Rubsam Hrrman Brewing Company, has been elected to the additional office of president, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Hoffmann succeeds the late William Lucas.

Food, clothing and money have been sent to the Netherlands to help alleviate suffering from the recent floods, but yesterday a group of American girls presented something almost as important -- rag dolls for their counterparts in the devastated country.

" The Merchant of Venice" is an interesting drama and the production that opened at the City Center last evening is interesting, too. Especially in the romantic scenes. For Margaret Phillips is a mettlesome Portia, despite an accent that is not exactly Shakespearean, and Nancy Marchand is a spirited Nerissa.

New evidence that the addition of Vitamin B12 to the diet of children living under deprived conditions can stimulate a significant increase in height and weight was offered here yesterday at the annual scientific session of the National Vitamin Foundation, Inc.

Fifty-five hundred employes of Pan American World Airways will receive wage increases under an agreement announced yesterday by Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., and James Horst, director of its air transport division.
Michael A. Brown Jr. has been made sales manager for Rayonier, Inc.

European originals imported by Russeks were previewed for the press yesterday. The trend toward casual elegance, as seen in these clothes, showed that the American influence on fashion has been accepted internationally. From France, Italy, Spain and England have come spring and summer clothes by leading couturiers chosen expressly for American women.

In addition; to-app..earing with Rosalind Russell in the hit play "Wonderful Town" at the Winter Gardenj EdithAdams, singer, will return to the F-wnie Kovac's morning teleVision program over Channel '2 6n' ll[orlay, March I6, at 8:30. She appeared on the-program regularly befor going into the play, her first stage appearance.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 4 -- With only one of his Dodger hurlers, big Chris Van Cuyk, not in shape to throw, Manager Chuck Dressen today found himself ready to announce his pitching rotation for the first three games at Miami, starting Saturday afternoon.

Hans de Meiss-Teuffen, son of a Swiss baron, who has vagabonded all over the world by sailboat and on foot, has written in collaboration with Victor Rosen on account of his adventures. Among his experiences recounted in "Wanderlust" are sailing solo across the Atlantic in a thirty-foot sloop in a "record-breaking" fifty-eight days and becoming a seagoing spy in a sailboat provided by Hitler, but radioing back valuable information to England.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today nominated Albert J. Robertson, a Des Moines banker, and Ormonde A. Kieb, Newark, N. J., real estate man, to be assistant postmasters general.

Goldman, Sachs Co. and associates will place on the market today 200,000 shares of common stock of Federal Paper Board Company in a transaction marking the first public distribution of the company's shares. The offering represents outstanding stock being sold by certain stockholders.

Four waterfront figures were indicted yesterday on charges of having lied to a Federal grand jury investigating payroll padding at the Claremont Terminal in Jersey City while it was being operated by Dade Brothers, a cargo exporting concern, as a shipping center for Air Force supplies.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- President Eisenhower expressed his sympathy for the Soviet peoples today but his Administration was keeping its eyes on the Communist satellite capitals even more than on the Kremlin.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The chief spokesmen on foreign and financial policy of the United States and Britain met around the conference table late today to begin a series of discussions on a common approach to the economic and political ills besetting the non-Communist world.

SILVER CITY, N. M., March 4 (AP) -- Citizens protesting a union sponsored movie paraded noisily through this southwestern New Mexico mining area for two and a half hours today, but threatened violence failed to develop. More than thirty state police and sheriff's office cars lined the route of the parade, ready for possible trouble.

Many parties will be given at the annual luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of the Travelers Aid Society, to be held today in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Because of the demand for tables, the event was transferred from the Terrace Room. Mrs. Emilio Pittarelli is chairman of the benefit committee.

Robert B. Anderson, the 42-year-old Texan who left a half-million-acre ranch to become Secretary of the Navy under President Eisenhower, was "piped aboard" the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn yesterday.
ALBANY, March 4 -- The Legislature's Conservation Committees today found themselves in the middle of a first-class dispute over the issue of state-wide fluoridation of public water supplies.

The report of the Consolidated Natural Gas Company for 1952, issued yesterday, showed a net income for the year of $15,441,276, after all charges. This was equal to $4.19 a common share, compared with a net of $18,562,552 or $5.67 a share in 1951.

In its issue of Feb. 3 THE NEW YORK TIMES published a letter from Charles Linton, Jakarta, Indonesia, concerning the impact of American motion pictures on the people of that country. I have only recently returned from Indonesia and therefore want to point out that Mr. Linton's comments grossly distort the situation.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4 -- One of the most amazing comebacks in recent baseball history will be effected if the hopes of Ewell Blackwell, towering right-hander on the Yankees' extensive pitching staff, are realized.

The Puget Sound Power and Light Company, the $112,000,000 prize in the battle between private and public power advocates in the Pacific Northwest, announced yesterday that it is maintaining an "open door" policy with respect to the sale of its properties.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The National Labor Relations Board, voting 3 to 2, ordered a new run-off election at the Pratt and Whitney division, United Aircraft Corporation plant, North Haven, Conn., because the winning union, the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., had distributed a fraudulent telegram in the pre-election campaign.

The Metropolitan Opera Company will tour sixteen cities in the United States and Canada between April 13 and May 30, it was announced yesterday. The tour will open with a series of eight performance in Cleveland, and will end with seven performances in Toronto.

Attendance at the closing session of the Leather Show at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel continued at record levels yesterday. Registration was estimated at 7,500 to 8,000. Heavy sampling was reported and sizable orders are expected to develop later in the year.

Although some statements in S. J. Rundt's letter published Feb. 20 may be debatable, I was glad to note that the vital importance of maintaining Austria in the family of free nations by continuing economic aid was given strong recognition by the former Chief of the United States Economic Intelligence in Austria.

MOSCOW, Thursday, March 5 -- Physicians fighting for Premier Stalin's life used leeches, oxygen and special drugs in the last twenty-four hours, but a special bulletin told crowds waiting in Moscow's falling snow and cold that their leader continued to sink.

A fresh look has been given to an old art by the group of craftsmen represented in a new exhibition of tapestries arranged by the American Craftsmen's Educational Council in the gallery of America House, 32 East Fifty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The Army denied today that it had shown no interest in a light submachine gun reported to shoot faster, farther and straighter and cost $35 less than a similar weapon now in use.

MILWAUKEE, March 4 (AP) -- Action to terminate the contract between the Milwaukee Brewers of the American Association and Milwaukee County for use of the new $5,000,000 stadium here was started today in the County Board of Supervisors.

The basic cause of the Republican victory last November was the continuing evidence of petty graft in Washington and official blindness to ethics and "proprieties" under the Democratic administration, W. H. Lawrence, political reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared yesterday.

The second annual meeting of the National Committee on Alcoholism will be held tomorrow in the Statler Hotel. Five hundred persons are expected to attend the discussion panels and annual luncheon of the committee, which was established eight years ago.

Mal Whitfield, Herb McKenley, Andy Stanfield and George Rhoden will be absent from Saturday's Pioneer Club games at the 369th Regiment Armory only because of a mix-up on dates, Mike Howard, chairman of the Grand Street Boys Association's sports committee, explained yesterday.

Sophie of Saks Fifth Avenue has bowed to the fashion that recognizes the full skirt. This is evident in her spring and summer collection, presented yesterday afternoon in the Salon Modern of the Fifth Avenue store. Silks, cottons, laces and chiffons, belled into wide hems, frequently held out over billowing petticoats from the snuggest of waistlines.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 4 -- Bertram D. Tallamy, Superintendent of Public Works of the State of New York, urged today the adoption of flexible, long-range road programs in New York and other states. The programs, he said, should be designed for overall acceleration if warranted by a deterioration in economic conditions.

The television carnival produced, staged and directed by Senator McCarthy may not have proved very much about the Voice of America, but it has proved that Mr. McCarthy's methods have not changed essentially. And it is safe to predict that they will not change until the American people realize that the kind of spectacle they have been witnessing the last three weeks is a destructive performance whose harmful effects outweigh whatever good might emerge.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet, fresh from the battlefields of Korea, told the Armed Services Committee of the House of Representatives today that victory was the only solution to the long conflict there.

Future improvement of the position of Western European countries in the American market will depend largely on whether they follow monetary and economic policies which will permit their exports to compete with American products in price as well as in quality and delivery schedules, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Premier Stalin's chances of surviving the brain hemorrhage that disabled him Sunday night were considered slim yesterday by medical experts here and abroad.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., March 4 -- Eighty - to - ninety - mile - an - hour winds that ripped tents and damaged a helicopter, and a driving rain that turned this military reservation into a sea of mud, hampered the closing phases of Exercise Snowstorm today.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The United States "categorically" rejected again today charges by Communist Czechoslovakia that the Mutual Security Act was an instrument of aggression interfering in the domestic affairs of the Prague regime.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- Philadelphia could provide at least 900 tons of air cargo for Europe this year if direct air freight services were available, representatives of the city said today.

HONG KONG, March 4 -- Communist China's official news agency issued a detailed bulletin tonight informing the Chinese people that Premier Stalin had suffered a brain hemorrhage and was in a serious condition. But there was no immediate official reaction from Peiping.

Ground was broken yesterday in the courtyard of the Cornell University Medical College, York Avenue at Sixty-eighth Street, for a tunnel that will connect the college with a projected $2,550,000 student residence. Construction of the dormitory will be started in two weeks on the west side of York Avenue.

Two new directors of the Marine Midland Corporation were elected yesterday at the annual stockholder meeting held in Buffalo. They are Earl J. Machold, president of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation and Cloud Wampler, president of the Carrier Corporation.

A food plan whereby the retailer of food freezers is relieved of all financing of food by household purchasers in New York was announced yesterday by Admiral-New York Corporation and the Beinecke Frosted Food Company, an affiliate of the Beinecke Meat Company, for nearly a hundred years a supplier of meats to hotels, restaurants and steamships.

THE past few weeks were happy ones for the bonefish specialists, and reports from Bimini, Bermuda and the Florida Keys indicate that more big fish were taken in one month than had been taken in twenty years.

An unusual custom that was followed by Blevins Davis and Robert Breen, producers of "Porgy and Bess," the American folk opera, in all of the European countries where the show played also will be employed for the Broadway presentation.

New York University fought off a late challenge by City College to win the thirty-eighth basketball game between these two old rivals, 82 -- 68, at Alumni Gymnasium on the Violets' University Heights campus last night.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The twenty-eight-nation International Materials Conference, whose staff has been notified it will be liquidated soon, has ended the international allocation of sulphur.

TAIPEI, Formosa, March 4 -- Chinese Nationalist circles believe that Premier Stalin's departure will not necessarily lead to an internal revolt, but they feared it might be the signal for sudden Soviet aggressive adventures undertaken to forestall internal dissension.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Legislation granting relief to contractors suffering heavy losses on defense contracts because of circumstances beyond their control has been drafted by the Senate Small Business Committee. Senator Edward J. Thye, Republican of Minnesota, chairman of the committee, announced today.

TWO books are on our table this morning. One is "The Honest Rainmaker,"* by A. J. Liebling, a magnificently informal portrait of Col. John R. Stingo, whose awesome exploits in games of skill and chance deserve to be legendary. The other is "The Wonderful World of Books," a lively symposium on the pleasures and rewards of reading.

MANILA, Thursday, March 5 -- President Elpidio Quirino warned Philippine Army officers yesterday of an impending "electoral crisis" in the Philippines connected with the resignation of Ramon Magsaysay as Secretary of Defense and his probable opposition candidacy for President in the national elections next November.

The Bull liner Puerto Rico, which has been operating between New York and San Juan and St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands since 1949, will be withdrawn from service after the completion of her March 19 voyage from this port, E. Myron Bull, president of the company, announced yesterday.

LONDON, March 4 -- The chief interest in the stock market today shifted back to South African gold-mining shares. Hopes for beneficial outcome of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's and Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler's talks in the United States and reports of good development at some of the new mines stimulated strong buying of most shares, apart from the old non-uranium producers.

MOSCOW, Thursday, March 5 -- Under the direct supervision of the Central Committee of the Communist party and the Council of Ministers of the Soviet Union, Soviet medical science continued to fight with all its skill and experience today to save Premier Stalin from the "heavy" illness that struck him Sunday.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- At a second stormy session with the Senate subcommittee investigating the Voice of America. Reed Harris, deputy director of the Government's International Information Administration, charged today that "one-sided" methods employed by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Wisconsin Republican and panel chairman, were hurting the American position in the "cold war" with Russia.

Chairmanship of the New York City Mental Health Fund was accepted yesterday by Maj. Gen. Russell L. Maxwell, vice president in charge of personnel and public relations of the American Machine and Foundry Company.

A bullet fired into her body almost fifteen years ago caused the death Tuesday night of Mrs. Emita Krueger, 55 years old, a member of the McCormick Harvester family and wife of Karl Krueger, orchestra conductor, in her home at 1150 Fifth Avenue, the Medical Examiner's office reported yesterday.

Using an acetylene torch, burglars cracked open a safe in a realty office at 1441 St. Nicholas Avenue, a block away from the Wadsworth Avenue police station, and escaped with from $10,000 to $15,000 early yesterday morning, the police reported.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- In heeding the powerful sentiment among Republican Senators that the text of the Administration's "secret treaties" resolution should not, directly or indirectly, seem to give Congressional approval to these agreements and the manner in which they were made, Senator Taft was fulfilling one obligation of a majority leader that at times is bound to conflict with another.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, March 4 (AP) -- Five of the six members of the United Staes women's squash racquets team now touring Britain won first-round matches tonight in the Scottish women's amateur tournament.

Today's new film is "The Story of Three Loves," a three-part romantic drama in Technicolor produced by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, at the Radio City Music Hall. Pier Angeli, Ethel Barrymoe, Leslie Caron, Kirk Douglas, Moira Shearer, James Mason, Farley Granger and Agnes Moorehead are featured.

PHILADELPHIA, March 4 (UP) -- Tom Gola, La Salle's All-America center, was injured tonight as the Explorers closed their regular season with a 65-45 triumph over Temple in the second game of a double-header at St. Joseph's Field House tonight. Pennsylvania Military College defeated Drexel, 69 -- 39, in the opener.
BONN, Germany, March 4 -- The West German Bundestag will hold its third and final reading of the Allied-German treaties March 19, its Council of Elders announced today.

Gerardo (Jerry) Anastasia, brother of Albert Anastasia and a Brooklyn longshoremen's union delegate, went on trial yesterday in Special Sessions on a twelve-count information stemming from his refusal to answer questions at a State Crime Commission hearing last Dec. 5.
