While conceding the desirability of an equable increase in rent ceilings, I can find no legitimate benefit except administrative expediency in the proposal to decontrol apartments as they become vacant.

Stock market prices dipped yesterday as operators attempted to assess the possible effects of Premier Stalin's illness and Gen. James A. Van Fleet's statements before the House Armed Services Committee. "War baby" stocks -- those that might earn less if stepped-up arms spending were no longer necessary -- were notably soft.

Through the fog of confusion, indecision, politics and double talk that obscures any progress made on state-city talks about municipal finances it is possible to discern one hopeful sign. There appears to be more courage on the state's side toward insisting that before there can be anything else some treatment must be found for the transit illness.

ROME, March 4 -- The Vatican heard the news of Premier Stalin's grave illness direct from Moscow through its monitoring service. The Pope was informed shortly afterward by Msgr. Giovanni Battista Montini, one of the two Prosecretaries of State.

An increase last week of 1,521,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 157,378,000 barrels, compared with 155,857,000 a week earlier and 152,073,000 a year ago.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 4 (UP) -- The defending champion and the co-medalists swept with ease today through the first round of the Women's Florida East Coast golf championship.

New issues of public utility and railroad securities totaling more than $27,000,000 will be offered to investors today. The issues represent new first mortgage bonds and preferred stock of utility enterprises, and railroad serial equipment trust certificates.
MEXICO CITY, March 4 -- Carlos Arruza, who is generally rated as the greatest bullfighter since the fabled Manolete, has "cut the pigtail," the matador's dramatic symbol of retirement.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 4 -- Delegates to the United Nations General Assembly were shocked today by the news of Premier Stalin's serious illness, and several expressed apprehension over the possible course of the Soviet Union's policy under whoever now gained control in the Kremlin.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The National Association of Manufacturers asked Congress today to keep in the Taft-Hartley Law a provision that President Eisenhower said might be used to break unions and that Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Senate Republican leader, was willing to eliminate.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 4 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe; General Lauris Norstad, Commander in Chief of Allied Air Forces in Central Europe, and other ranking air commanders will confer tomorrow on steps to strengthen the two main tactical air commands that control between them about 2,000 North Atlantic Treaty aircraft in and near Germany.

ALBANY, March 4 -- Conferences between state and New York City officials to find a mutually satisfactory solution to the city's need for additional revenue to balance next year's expense budget will resume in New York tomorrow morning.

District Attorney George B. DeLuca of the Bronx said yesterday he was conducting a detailed investigation into the fire in which seven persons perished in a Bronx factory Tuesday morning and that the results of the inquiry would be submitted to a grand jury.

PALO HINCADO, Puerto Rico, March 4 -- On a mountaintop in this green heart of Puerto Rico Dolores Rivers, 45-year-old tobacco and banana farmer and father of eight children, stood on the porch of the three-room wooden home he built with his own hands and gazed down the valley at the fifty-eight-foot concrete bridge whose building he supervised.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- An intensive sales campaign can develop consumer buying that will more than compensate for any sag in Government defense spending in the coming year, Walter Williams, Under-Secretary of Commerce, told the American Retail Federation today.

Britain's Foreign Secretary, Anthony Eden, and her Chancellor of the Exchequer, Richard A. Butler, arrived here yesterday for a series of economic talks with President Eisenhower and his aides. The purpose of the visit of these officials is to try to work out a program of economic cooperation with the United States.

TRENTON, March 4 -- Nelson F. Stamler, ousted as deputy attorney general in charge of the investigation of gambling and official corruption in Bergen County, testified under oath before a grand jury in November that the prosecutorship of Union County was offered to him if he would clear out of Bergen within two weeks and drop criminal action against two Mayors.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L. I., March 4 -- The existence of one of the largest and best known works of art in the United States connected with aviation is threatened today because the building of which it is a part may be destroyed to make way for a new structure.

A group of eleven table settings that go on view today at Plummer's, Ltd., 734 Fifth Avenue, should provide a number of ideas for spring entertaining. They have been arranged by William Pahlmann, using flatware, china, crystal and accessories available either from his own shop or at Plummer's.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old, a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

A first mortgage of $1,000,000 at 4 1/2 per cent interest has been placed by John J. Reynolds, Inc., broker, on the twelve-story loft building at 619 West Fifty-fourth Street and 615 West Fifty-fifth Street for Ossining Associates, Inc.

The uncertain stock market was affected by two new factors yesterday. One was Premier Stalin's illness. The other was the statement by Gen. James A. Van Fleet before the House Armed Services Committee that victory is the only solution to the Korean war.
BONN, Germany, March 4 (AP) -- The West German Government appealed to the free world today to help East German refugees fleeing Communist terror.

A month's study by two committees of the International Longshoremen's Association, under a "clean house" order issued by the American Federation of Labor, is expected to result in submitting concrete proposals at a meeting of the union's New York District Council on Tuesday.

The career of Adolph Zukor in the motion-picture industry, a career that has extended for exactly fifty years, was hailed by industry leaders, theatrical celebrities and prominent citizens last night at a dinner attended by more than 1,000 persons in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 4 -- Manager Leo Durocher looked at some pretty slick pitching but not an overabundance of slugging today as the Giants engaged in their second intra squad game of the training season.

ALBANY, March 4 -- The Temporary State Commission on Rents and Rental Conditions recommended today that state controls be lifted from all store rentals in New York City and that a 15 per cent rent increase be authorized for all commercial and business tenants whose rents were still at the levels fixed by the first State Rent Control Act in 1947.

Rules on stock exchanges are sticky things. Only members may ever buy or sell stock for their own accounts on the floor of such institutions -- at least, that was the rule until yesterday, when a sensational but very brief exception was made for a 10-year-old boy.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 4 -- The American people are enjoying a steadily rising living standard, accompanied by a tremendous expansion in industrial and residential areas, but they are paying for it with more mosquito bites.

Elimination of waste in the management of the city's transit lines would save $32,000,000 a year, Walter Hoving, chairman of the executive committee of the New York City Affairs Committee, declared yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 4 -- Demand faded for the grain market today, and price recessions were the rule. The announcement of the grave condition of Stalin tended to make traders a little cautious, although no immediate change in the political situation is looked for.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- James P. McGranery, former Attorney General, told a House Judiciary subcommittee today that he had ordered the immediate abrogation of a purported agreement to bypass the Federal Bureau of Investigation in civil rights brutality cases involving New York City policemen after J. Edgar Hoover, Director of the F. B. I., had informed him of its existence.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 4 -- The oil question moved back into the spotlight today as Teheran quieted down after four days of disorders following the open break between Premier Mohammed Mossadegh and Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.
CLEVELAND, March 4 (UP) -- Seton Hall scored a 109-82 victory over John Carroll while the fabulous freshman, Bevo Francis, led Rio Grande College to a 109-55 triumph over Wilberforce College tonight.

John David Provoo, former Army staff sergeant convicted of treason, was sentenced to life imprisonment yesterday for the second time within a few days because on the first occasion Federal Judge Gregory F. Noonan forgot to impose a mandatory $10,000 fine in addition to the life imprisonment sentence.

Continental custom design is offered in the 1953 Rambler line presented yesterday by the Nash division of the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation. The cars have been styled by Pinin Farina of Turin, Italy, in collaboration with Nash engineers.

Among the art exhibitions of the week are two group shows -- one at the Midtown Gallery in which members of the group herald the spring with attractive flower paintings, and one at the Niveau Gallery in which five twentieth century French painters reveal that there is plenty of talent in the work of some of the less familiar men.

WASHINGTON, March. 4 (AP) -- The Petroleum Administration for Defense estimated today that consumption of aviation gasoline by the nation's civilian aircraft will reach 34,500,000 barrels by 1963, an increase of more than 60 per cent over 1952 consumption.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Within a half hour after lunching at the White House, Senator Price Daniel, Democrat of Texas, asserted today he knew that "President Eisenhower still is for vesting full ownership of offshore lands, within historic boundaries, in the states."

MOSCOW, March 4 -- The newspapers came out late this morning in Moscow -- not until about 9 o'clock at most kiosks -- and they brought the sad news to the populace of the heavy illness of Premier Stalin.

Consolidated net income from shipments of products and from investments of the Babcock Wilcox Company last year amounted to $8,689,241, against $8,004,782 for 1951, the annual report of Alfred Iddles, president, disclosed yesterday.

Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican of New Hampshire, said yesterday he had decided to offer a series of radio talks to all stations here. The talks originally were announced as an exclusive feature of the Columbia Broadcasting System.
CALGARY, March 4 (AP) -- More than 300,000,000 barrels of oil were discovered last year in western Canada, it was announced today by the reserves committee of the Canadian Petroleum Association.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., March 4 -- The reported need for the annual importation of hundreds of thousands of aliens for seasonal farm work appears questionable in the face of the vast annual waste of manpower involved in the prevailing migratory labor system, the Southwest Regional Conference on Migrant Labor was told today.

With Jim McFadden leading the attack, the Chicago Black Hawks subdued the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. McFadden tallied twice as the visitors skated their way to an easy 4-1 victory over the Broadway Blues.

PHILADELPHIA, March 4 (AP) -- George Preston Marshall today challenged the Government to prove that the public objects to the National Football League's radio and television policy. He accused the Government of trying to create a monopoly rather than eliminate one.

The kind of diet for which most overweights are looking is one that takes off pounds without the discomforts of hunger and fatigue. Desirable, too, is a pattern of eating to discourage regaining weight once reducing is completed.

ALBANY, March 4 -- The Legislature approved and sent to Governor Dewey today the bill incorporating the plan for reconstruction of the Southern State Parkway in Nassau County and authorizing the issuance of $40,000,000 in bonds to be retired by imposing a 10-cent toll.

BOSTON, March 4 -- Dr. John Sloan Dickey, president of Dartmouth College, called tonight for educators who had "no need to take refuge in any American tribunal behind a privilege against incrimination by their own words."

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 25:
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The City of New York asked the Federal Communications Commission today for permission to use radio signals from Station WNYC to turn the city's street lights on and off.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 4 -- The scheduled sailing of the Matson liner Lurline for Honolulu with a full passenger list of about 750 was delayed today by the refusal of two sets of radio operators to sign aboard.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- Gen. Walter Bedell Smith believes that when Stalin dies his power probably will be divided among three men -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov Gergi M. Malenkov and Lavrenti P. Beria.
Color gives a spring accent to fifteen room settings to go on view today at Altman's. They are keyed to the needs of young homemakers.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (UP) -- American battle casualties in Korea increased by 411 last week to a new total of 130,732, the Defense Department reported today.

Activity was light on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday. Prices closed irregular and only rubber and hides had better than average volume. Cocoa, hides, wool and zinc ended lower. Potatoes, soybeans oil, cottonseed oil and tin were mixed, and sugar, lead and rubber were higher.

Four meet marks were broken and a conference record tied in the qualifying trials of the seventh Metropolitan Collegiate swimming championships held in the New York University Alumni pool last night. The finals will be conducted tomorrow night.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 4 -- Harold (Bud) Haabestad, sophomore forward, led the way with 23 points tonight as Princeton's basketball team avenged an early season loss by defeating Rutgers, 74 -- 59, before 1,000 persons in Dillon Gym.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 4 -- The abandonment of a foreign policy of containment in favor of one of "seizing the initiative" in Asia was recommended today by a section of the Commonwealth Club of California. The proposals were made after two years of study of Pacific Ocean problems.
LONDON, March 4 -- The apparently approaching death of Premier Stalin will almost certainly precipitate a period of great uneasiness in world affairs.

TOKYO, Thursday, March 5 -- Hard fighting South Korean infantrymen, backed by United Nations artillery and air power, retook a height on the central front yesterday, after nearly twenty-four hours of fighting with Chinese Communist forces.

Sales of dolls this year will set a record of about $100,000,000 on the retail level, a gain of 10 per cent over 1952, David Rosenstein, president of the National Association of Doll Manufacturers, predicted yesterday. Unusually heavy buying in advance of the American Toy Fair which opens on Monday at the New Yorker and McAlpin Hotels indicates excellent business, he said.

ELIZABETH, N. J., March 4 -- A "common sense" code of social behavior for teen-agers, containing recommendations on student drinking, parties, driving and parental chaperoning, has been drawn up by an association of twenty-one northern New Jersey private schools.
Before a capacity crowd of 3,400 at the Fordham gym, Manhattan's smooth-working quintet swept off with the mythical metropolitan title last night by vanquishing the Rams by 80 to 66.
MOSCOW, Thursday, March 5 (UP) -- The text of the bulletin issued by Premier Stalin's physicians this morning follows:

Despite a protest by Commissioner Francis J. Bloustein against any move that would be a "step backward" in the city's efforts to solve its traffic problem, the City Planning Commission yesterday took initial action toward divesting itself of control over the construction of parking garages for fewer than 500 cars.
Futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 1 to 18 points yesterday after early steadiness.

PHILADELPHIA, March 4 -- The Connelly Containers Company, whose block-long plant burned to the ground in a $3,000,000 fire in southwest Philadelphia less than six weeks ago, resumed production of paper boxes today in new quarters.

President Eisenhower's proposed resolution rejecting Soviet perversion of wartime agreements and reaffirming the principles of the Atlantic Charter now faces delay in Congress. This is in part the result of the unfortunate controversy that has arisen over the wording of this first concrete measure of the Eisenhower Administration in the field of foreign policy.

Maurice Herzog, 34-year-old French mountain climber, arrived here yesterday aboard the French liner Liberte for a six-week lecture tour, arranged by the French Government and the American Alpine Club. He has scaled the 26,493-foot Himalayan peak of Annapurna, the highest ascended by man.

While Fifth Avenue stores scored 19 per cent higher than those on Fourteenth Street, they would still get only a "C" grade in retail salesmanship, according to a survey made by students of the City College School of Business and Civic Administration.

The price of lead declined one-half cent a pound yesterday to 13 cents, the lowest level in more than two and one-half years. A lead mining executive returned from a three-week survey of Western mine areas with a report that the western states are "aroused" over the weak market situation.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- A crisis in White House relations with Congress was reached today over Republican efforts to harden President Eisenhower's proposed declaration denouncing the Russians for "perverting" the wartime Yalta and Potsdam agreements into instruments for subjugating free peoples.

The Eisenhower Administration's objective is to "restore the American free enterprise system" and the Government will not compete with bankers in the credit field, Representative Jesse P. Wolcott, Republican of Michigan, chairman of the House Banking and Currency Committee, asserted yesterday.

I read with interest the story by William M. Freeman on the rodent business in Altamont, N.Y. I find the article interesting not only for the subject-matter -- like most women I rather instinctively malign the rat -- but rather for what seems to me to be a story within the story.

NEW DELHI, India, March 4 -- The Communists were evicted today from their parliamentary headquarters in Windsor Place, one of the most fashionable residential sections of New Delhi. They had renamed the area "Red Square" upon their occupancy last year.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 4 -- (AP) -- Whiffenpoof, a 7-year-old brown gelding from the Duntreath Farm, today dashed to victory in Gulfstream Park's $10,000 added Inaugural Handicap.
TOKYO, Thursday, March 5 (AP) -- United Nations Command commuque 1,544, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korean time:
BONN, Germany, March 4 -- Progress toward a European army may be slowed as a result of any new Soviet regime's concentration on the consolidation of its power.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican of New Jersey, noting the Labor Department's fortieth anniversary, said today he believed the department's function was to serve the whole nation and not one segment of our society.

Most available evidence points to Georgi M. Malenkov as the man most likely ultimately to inherit Joseph Stalin's power, but that result is not yet a foregone conclusion and such figures as Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Lavrenti P. Beria and Nikolai A. Bulganin cannot be ruled out of consideration.

The big one got away from Columbia's aspirants for the Eastern League basketball championship last night. Lu Rossini's Lions could not possibly have picked a worse time for their weakest performance of the year, as they dropped a 59-45 decision to the University of Pennsylvania.

THE big rookie was making his first swing around the big leagues, so fearful that he'd be shipped back to the minors that he studied every star in wide-eyed wonder. It didn't take him long to decide on the hitter he wanted to imitate. The first time he saw Shoeless Joe Jackson he knew. This, by the way, was back in 1915.

LONDON, March 4 -- Both Prime Minister Churchill and Clement Attlee, leader of the Opposition, sent messages of sympathy to the Soviet Embassy today soon after they had learned of Premier Stalin's illness and the prospect of his death.

Howard Greer is one designer who does not underestimate the sorcery of sheer chiffon, the illusion of veiled nudeness and the charm of a well-draped decolletage. He knows how to put all the excitement that many women dream of into a whole collection of dresses.
Kansas City, Mo., announced yesterday that it plans to receive bids March 25 on an issue of $8,000,000 of school district bonds dated April 1, 1953, and due on April 1, 1954 to 1973.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- Congressional leaders split today on predictions that if Soviet Premier Stalin died it might trigger World War III or bring about the downfall of the Kremlin.

Walter Berger and Leo Bercow have acquired the apartment property bounded by Main Street, Seventy-ninth Avenue, Seventy-eighth Road and 146th Street in Kew Gardens, Queens, through the purchase of stock of Kew Terrace Apartments, Inc.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 5 -- The first intact Russian-built MIG-15 jet fighter -- the newest known type of Russian jet fighter -- to land west of the Iron Curtain came down this morning at Roenne Airport on the Danish island of Bornholm. It came from a Polish Baltic base.

EASTERN FRONT, Korea, March 5 (AP) -- Gen. Mark W. Clark said today after accepting an invitation to visit Indo-China that the fight there "cannot be separated" from the war in Korea. He would not say whether his trip may mean closer coordination and liaison between his United Nations Command in Korea and the French in Indo-China.

Joseph Stalin was considered a master military strategist who worked quietly behind the scenes, sifting campaign details with special emphasis on logistics but never losing his perspective on the over-all political aspects of the situation.

The James Weldon Johnson Community Center, located in the East Harlem inter-racial housing development of the same name, will be the beneficiary of the evening performance of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus on April 17 at Madison Square Garden.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 5 -- Ruben Gomez, Puerto Rican Negro right-hander who might give the Giants the sort of lift Joe Black provided for the Dodgers last year, finally arrived in camp today. However, since he has been pitching over a stretch of twelve months, it is not likely the delay in reporting here is apt to bother the young man.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., March 5 (UP) -- Representative Daniel A. Reed, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, denied tonight he was trying to block President Eisenhower's request for speedy extension of Social Security coverage.
Wide art horizons are reached in three of this week's larger exhibitions of paintings and sculpture.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania football team in a joint letter to university authorities, today termed its 1953 football schedule too difficult for an Ivy League school with no spring training.

I have always been under the impression that when an important New York City transit service is to be discontinued there must be a public hearing and the Board of Estimate must give official approval. However, certain city officials apparently plan to force through the abandonment of the Third Avenue elevated between City Hall and Chatham Square without giving its thousands of daily riders a chance to voice their disapproval.

Quick-to-make desserts have not received as much attention as main dishes, and even appetizers, that can be prepared in a matter of minutes. Oversight rather than lack of inspiration must be responsible, for there are many possibilities in the field of easily assembled pastries, puddings, cakes and so forth.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 5 -- There is a never-ending fascination and appeal in every trip to spring training. It's always the same and yet it's always different. Perhaps that's why a tourist bravely risks sunstroke with the spirit of adventure in his heart.

A network of expanded medical and social welfare services, involving $33,000,000 in building funds, will be in operation by the end of the year under auspices of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, it was reported yesterday by Milton Weill, president.

STRASBOURG, France, March 5 -- Lines were drawn tonight for a contest over the proposed six-nation European constitution, which will be finally revised by a Special Assembly of the European Coal and Steel Community in a four-day session opening tomorrow.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 5 -- A demand of radio operators for radio increase of 9.5 per cent in} basic monthly, pay was agreed to this afternoon by the Pacific Maritime Association.

As the Western World awaited news from Moscow, and the first intimation of the line that Stalin's successors will pursue, it was announced in Tokyo that Gen. Mark Clark will shortly make a trip to the Indo-Chinese battleground. This announcement again points up the fact that the war in Asia against Communist imperialism is being fought on at least two fronts.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Representative Daniel A. Reed, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, declared today that the excess-profits tax on corporations "must terminate" on schedule June 30 "to remove one great obstacle to a balanced budget."

STOWE, Vt., March 5 -- Everything was in readiness tonight for the country's most important Alpine races, the national giant slalom and the North American downhill, slalom and combined championships. Starting tomorrow and continuing through Sunday, they will be held over lightning-fast courses dropping down the eastern face of Mount Mansfield.

TRENTON, March 5 -- State Senator Kenneth C. Hand of Elizabeth today became the tenth avowed candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor and the third to file nominating petitions. The deadline for filing is next Thursday, and prior to yesterday only Paul L. Troast, State Turnpike Authority chairman, and Assembly-man Fred E. Shepard had taken this step.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Soft coal operators who mine a large volume of southern and western tonnage have set out to build a new collective bargaining front to meet John L. Lewis next fall and to break the power of the steel industry in coal wage negotiations.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- James Clement Dunn, a veteran career diplomat, was sworn in today as Ambassador to Spain, succeeding Lincoln MacVeagh.

Cornell's team eliminated the defending champion, the New Mexico Military Institute, in the semi-final round of the national intercollegiate indoor polo championship at the Squadron A Armory las night.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 5 -- Charley Thompson, burly rookie catcher, became the first player in the Dodgers' camp to get a ride off the field in the station wagon ambulance to the base hospital today after being hit on the head by a bat.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Walter Spencer Robertson of Richmond, Va., banker and public utility executive, is the probable selection to be Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs. He would succeed John M. Allison, who is expected to be the next Ambassador to Japan.

The men who stand in the first rank of Soviet power after Stalin's death have risen to the top in Soviet life from varied beginnings and through varied careers. But they are united in that their rise to power has been made possible by demonstrations of complete loyalty to Stalin and by the ability to meet successfully the challenges offered them by their different jobs and assignments in the Communist party and the Soviet state.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Administration's advisory committee on Taft-Hartley law changes came close to breaking up today just as it was getting started.

MILWAUKEE, March 5 -- Big league baseball fever continued to mount in Wisconsin today as indignation grew over the refusal of the Braves to cooperate in moving the Browns' American League franchise to Milwaukee.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The fatal illness of Premier Stalin caught this country's psychological warfare strategists virtually unprepared to exploit a situation that is regarded as holding great potential advantages in the "cold war."

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- President Eisenhower indicated today that if the Senate investigation into the Voice of America, being conducted by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, or other Congressional inquiries, reached a point of inviting international misunderstandings and difficulties he might intervene.

The National Shipping Authority yesterday asked for bids from American underwriters for protection and indemnity insurance on Government-owned merchant vessels being operated by private shipping companies acting as general agents.
WASHINGTON, March 5--President Eisenhower today complimented business for what he termed the admirable restraint it had shown in pricing policies since the removal of most price controls.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 5 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander, was reported to have reached substantial agreement today with his top Allied air commanders on the need for more funds and more staff officers to strengthen the two main Allied air commands in West Germany.

A proposal of the Richmond County Medical Society to combat crime among narcotics addicts by providing clinics where they could obtain narcotics cheaply under medical controls was denounced yesterday by State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein.
Middle Western railroad systems borrowed $10,500,000 in the public market yesterday to help finance the purchase of new equipment costing $13,825,000.

Joseph Stalin became the most important figure in the political direction of one-third of the people of the world. He was one of a group of hard revolutionaries that established the first important Marxist state and, as its dictator, he carried forward its socialization and industrialization with vigor and ruthlessness.

The Soviet Union won greater rewards, if at a cost of severe trials, under the foreign policy of Premier Stalin than it had ever known before. Stalin extended Russian borders beyond the farthest limits ever reached by the czars, while even beyond these borders -- in East Europe and China -- he brought an additional 600,000,000 persons under his sway.

CHICAGO, March 5 -- Dean Rusk, president of the Rockefeller Foundation, told 900 college faculty leaders and administrators meeting here today that higher education could use $300,000,000 to $400,000,000 a year "of new money not now available," then stressed that endowments and foundations could not supply that kind of money.
The place of zinc was trimmed a quarter cent a pound yesterday to 11 cents, East St. Louis basis, by a major custom smelter. Other suppliers soon matched the new price.

Stalin's writings and speeches were hailed innumerable times as representing works of genius entitling him to a place alongside Karl Marx, Friedrich Engels and V. I. Lenin, architects of communism.
TOKYO, March 5 (AP) -- A Navy pilot shot down for the second time in two weeks over Wonsan harbor on the Korean East Coast, was rescued dramatically under fire yesterday by a helicopter.

Higher standards of acting and the encouragement of greater community interest in the theatre were some of the solutions recommended to evolve new interest in the theatre at a forum presented yesterday by the Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy at the ANTA Playhouse, 245 West Fifty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -- House of Representative scandal investigators decided today to ask the Justice Department to investigate possible perjury prosecution against Donald S. Tydings, a cousin of former Senator Millard E. Tydings, Democrat of Maryland.

A letter to all members of the Legislature from the committee on insurance law of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, made public yesterday, asks why automobile owners have not been required to explain whether they were insured.

The Automobile Club of New York sent a telegram to Governor Dewey yesterday urging him to veto a measure approved by the Legislature that would authorize tolls on the Southern State Parkway, and a second one to Mayor Impellitteri asking him also to request the Governor to veto the tolls.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 5 -- Generalissimo Rafael L. Trujillo, strong man of the Dominican Republic and its new Secretary of Foreign Affairs as well as the chief of its delegation to the United Nations, announced today that he would sign a treaty of mutual defense and friendship with the United States at 4 P. M. tomorrow, along with Secretary of State John Foster Dulles at the State Department in Washington.

ALBANY, March 5 -- Thirty speakers appeared before the Assembly Ways and Means Committee today to register their views on a bill that would set up a commission to study New York's marriage and divorce laws. Only two of them opposed the measure.

Commodity prices closed irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Hides continued active, with volume the best since January. Sales of potato and rubber futures were about average and the other items were inactive. Hides, cocoa, potatoes, cottonseed oil and soybean oil were higher.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- On the accuracy of the information that will be gathered by the Government of the United States with respect to developments in the Soviet world under the post-Stalin regime, and on the wisdom and courage displayed by the Government in basing policies and actions on the evaluation of this information, the security of this nation and the prospect of World War III will largely, if not wholly, depend.

The number of plants making steel in this country climbed from 128 to 143 during the past fourteen years, American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday after comparing the industry's 1939 and 1953 capacity figures. Oregon, Utah and Tennessee were not listed as steel-producing states in 1939.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -- The Office of International Trade of the Department of Commerce announced today three changes in export license regulations designed to "benefit" export trade.
LONDON, Friday, March 6 (AP) -- The Moscow home radio gave the news of Premier Stalin's death to the Soviet people at 6:05 A. M. [10:05 P. M. Thursday, Eastern standard time].

With the death of Joseph Stalin, the three key positions he held in the state and Communist party hierarchies of the Soviet Union became vacant. The replacements will provide important clues to the relative importance of the figures competing for Stalin's place.

DETROIT, March 5 (UP) -- Gordie Howe and Ted Lindsay each scored twice tonight as the Detroit Red Wings defeated the New York Rangers, 7 to 1, at Olympia to move within three games of their fifth straight National Hockey League championship.
Futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange failed to develop a definite trend yesterday, and the close was 3 points lower to 7 points higher than on Wednesday.

There is certainly a great deal of point in Dr. Hocking's criticism of public opinion surveys in Germany. But suppose the types of questions he terms misleading were posed to Americans concerning communism. If Americans were asked, "What would you do if some Communists made a bid for power?" and "Is there more good harm in the ideas of communism?" It requires little clairvoyance to know how most of us would respond.

On record sales of $2,623,887,509, the General Electric Company and its consolidated affiliates realized last year net earnings of $151,719,905, second highest in the company's history and 9.8 per cent ahead of the $138,116,527 earned in 1950, Ralph J. Cordiner, president, reported yesterday in the sixty-first annual statement to stockholders.

BATON ROUGE, La,. March 5 (AP) -- Chandler Harper, the Portsmouth, Va., pro with a sore arm but a sure eye, and Fred Faas Jr., New Orleans-pro, shot four-underpar 68's in the first round today to tie for the lead in the $10,000 Baton Rouge open golf tournament.

CAMPECHE, Mexico, March 5 (AP) -- An official of the Bureau of Fisheries recommended today that fifteen Texas and Florida shrimp fishing boats held here be fined 15,000 pesos ($1,720) each and their cargoes and tackle confiscated.

The price of chartering tankers has become so low that Armercian concerns are laying up some of their older, smaller ships, and foreign oil companies, normally hirers of other tankers, have put their own vessels up for charter.
A snow squall with all the earmarks of a March blizzard swept across the city for about an hour yesterday morning, and then disappeared as suddenly as it had come.

Lawrence S. Sullivan, convicted bookmaker and purported associate of gamblers on Staten Island, pleaded not guilty yesterday to criminal contempt of court and was held in $1,000 bail for trial on March 26.

Farm price supports must be continued -- and continued vigorously, Representative Clifford R. Hope, Republican of Kansas, chairman of the House Committee on Agriculture, told the Commodity Club of New York, Inc., at a dinner last night at the Astor Hotel.
The city of Omaha, Neb., announced yesterday that it will offer on March 26 an issue of $3,350,000 of water revenue bonds dated April 1, 1953, and due April 1, 1958 to 1973.

TOKYO, Friday, March 6 -- The United Nations Command, in broadcasts to Communist China and North Korea, is challenging the leaders of those Communist satellites to take advantage of the changeover in Soviet leadership "to begin acting like Chinese and Koreans rather than puppets."

PHILADELPHIA, March 5 (AP) -- The seizure of the tanker Merrimac, a war surplus vessel, on the ground that she was owned by a corporation controlled by aliens, was announced by Federal agents today. Agents boarded the tanker when it docked yesterday at Fort Mifflin and made the seizure on a United States district court writ.

With the most engaging frankness the other day an explorer announced on returning to New York from an exploration in South America that his trip had failed. He had discovered nothing much of interest, he said, had no wonders to recount, and far from being a Marco Polo might just as well have stayed in his offices in the American Geographical Society, instead of going to all that bother.

It is the intention of Kenneth Banghart and Diana Green to bring "I Found April," starring Constance Bennett, to Broadway the week of April 6 rather than hold off the introduction until after Labor Day, as previously planned.

Driscoll's office in New Jersey, said today that "more and more it is becoming only too clear that I have been the victim of some gigantic and evil conspiracy in New Jersey Republican politics."

A broad study of the problem of reducing excessive fumes from buses and trucks in the interest of the city's health has been started by the Department of Air Pollution Control, Dr. Leonard Greenburg, Commissioner of the new agency, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -- William G. (Big Bill) Lias, West Virginia gambler, offered today to settle the Government's $2,850,000 tax case against him for $1,200,000. An offer of a $1,600,000 settlement made by the gambler last May to take the Government's tax claim for the years 1942 through 1948 out of tax court was rejected.

APPLETON, Wis., March 5 -- The Interlake division of Consolidated Water Power and Paper Company held open house for scientist, technicians and news men at its mill here yesterday to celebrate the start of operation of its new evaporation and burning plant for disposal and utilization of spent sulphite liquor.

BERLIN, March 5 -- Dr. Israel Goldstein, President of the American Jewish Congress, said today that if Georgi M. Malenkov succeeded Premier Stalin it probably would mean a stiffening of the Soviet attitude toward Jews.

PARIS, March 5 -- European officials and diplomats here who know the Soviet Union best agree in contending that the West would go wrong in expecting any great change in Soviet policy in the near future as a result of the passing of power from Premier Stalin's hands.

" The River and the Gauntlet," by Brig. Gen. S. L. A. Marshall, a report on the defeat of the Eighth Army by the Chinese Communist forces in the Battle of the Chongchon River, Korea, in November, 1950, will be published by Morrow on April 22.

CHICAGO, March 6 (AP) -- A former Army civilian employe who, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said, admitted he was a Communist when he held wartime jobs at military installations was seized Wednesday night by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- During the week ended March 4, member bank reserves increased $115,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

LONDON, March 5 -- Uncertainty about Russian policy in the event of Premier Stalin's death made for increased caution on the stock market today, but underlying firmness overcame the effect of early profit-taking and by the close prices showed appreciably more gains than losses.

The American Smelting and Refining Company officially opened its new central research laboratories in a red-brick, "E"-shaped structure on a twenty-seven-acre plot in South Plainfield, N. J., yesterday. At the same time a formal installation ceremony was held for a company branch of the Scientific Research Society of America.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- President Eisenhower's proposed United States declaration against "perversion" of the wartime Yalta and Potsdam agreements into instruments for enslaving peoples was put on the shelf in Congress today.
More than $400,000,000 will be spent by the pulp and paper industry this year for new plant facilities that will increase productive capacity substantially.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Officials of the Federal Maritime Administration testified today that they had found no evidence of waterfront racketeering in the loading of 110 ships operated for the Government by private agents.

The entire campus of Williams College was aware yesterday that two Chinese paintings from the college museum that had been held by customs authorities in Boston on their return on Feb. 11 from a Canadian exhibition were back where they belonged after a two-week delay.

LAHORE, Pakistan, March 5 (AP) -- Policemen opened fire at three places in Lahore today, killing at least six persons and injurying several others, when a mob staged new anti-Government demonstrations.

A group of faculty members from the Maritime Academy at Kings Point, L. I., are aboard the new Mariner-class cargo ships, at sea, studying all phases of their operation preparatory to writing a textbook about the vessels.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 5 (UP) -- One track record was broken arid another equaled today at Gulfstream Park, where 16,887 fans watched the second program of a forty-one-day meeting.

The cigarette industry is in the midst of major changes, including a growing demand for king-size and filter-type cigarettes and a shift in the distribution system, O. Parker McComas, president of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., said yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Financial Analysts of Philadelphia.
John B. Muller has been made Eastern regional sales manager of the lighting division and Alfred C. Viebranz merchandising manager of the photolamp sales department of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc.

LONDON, March 5 -- After testing chlorophyll against the smell of foul gases, skunks, perspiration, chopped onions, garlic and various brands of scent, chemists at Glasgow University have come to the conclusion that as far as they can detect in the laboratory, chlorophyll has no deodorant properties whatsoever. The report is printed in today's issue of The British Medical Journal.

ALBANY, March 5 -- The Temporary State Commission on Rents and Rental Conditions was rebuked tonight by the Republican leaders of the Legislature, who asserted that they would not stand for decontrolling rent on small stores.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Several hundred persons face the possibility of losing Civil Service status and probably their Government jobs under an Executive Order to be issued by President Eisenhower next week.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 5--Elimination of restrictions on Federal-aid funds so they could be applied to toll road construction was urged in a resolution adopted today at the twenty-ninth annual convention of the Association of Highway Officials of the North Atlantic States here.

WASHINGTON, March 5--Leland V. Boardman, special agent in charge of the New York office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, asserted today that Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan had notified him that he would not make New York City policemen available to any Federal law enforcement agency for questioning and that they would respond, only to summonses from a Federal grand jury.
FRANKLIN, N. J., March 5 -- A rare feathered visitor, the western tanager, is frequently seen feeding on the front lawn of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Cherepy's home here.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 5 (AP) -- Mary Lena Faulk, defending champion from Thomasville, Ga., and Mrs. Maurice Glick, one of the co-medalists from Baltimore, reached the semi-finals today in the women's Florida East Coast Golf Tournament.

The coordinating council of the five metropolitan county medical societies, representing 13,000 physicians, announced yesterday its opposition to the Seelye-Morgan bill to license chiropractors in the state and its favoring of the Metcalf-Rabin bill to appoint a commission to study the licensing of healing arts practitioners.

CHICAGO, March 5 -- Purchases of green coffee in South and Central America by United States importers have been reduced to a virtual trickle because producers are asking prices above Office of Price Stabilization ceilings, Chicago market sources said today.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission revoked today an order authorizing the Burlington and New York Central Railroads to build special facilities for carrying coal to power plants supplying the atomic energy installation near Paducah, Ky.
An agreement to place a minimum of 100 Negroes in "seasonal permanent" jobs in New York's brewing industry was announced yesterday by the Urban League of Greater New York.

One of the largest peacetime awards to a textile manufacturer was announced yesterday by the Armed Services Textile and Apparel Procurement Agency in New York. J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., was awarded contracts for 14,868,223 yards of cotton sateen at a cost of $14,586,907.

NEW DELHI, India, March 5 -- President Rajendra Prasad today dissolved the state government of the Patiala and East Punjab States Union, strategic area near the India-Pakistan border, where the Communists have succeeded in setting up a "parallel government" over some districts during the past year. President Prasad took over all powers in the 10,000-square mile state by a proclamation issued under the emergency provisions of the Constitution.

CLEVELAND, March 5 (AP) -- Northwest Airlines, Inc., failed to win damages today in its $900,000 suit against the Glenn L. Martin Company. The action resulted from an airline crash in which thirty-seven persons died.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 5 -- To the many distinctions which already have accrued to Mickey Mantle in his meteoric baseball career will be added another this year, if the plans of Manager Casey Stengel materialize.
COPENHAGEN, March 5 (AP) -- Within a few hours after the pilot landed the MIG Danish and British air force officers from Copenhagen were studying the plane to learn its jealously guarded secrets.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 5 -- Just as castles and towns of yore were protected from the enemy by strong walls, communities in the near future probably will ward off invasions of "super" mosquitoes by protective barriers of chemical sprays of insecticides and repellents.

ALBANY, March 5 -- Following is the text of the conclusions in the report of three members of the Temporary Commission on the use of television or educational purposes dissenting from the majority report issued Feb. 24. WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The broad outlines of the British Commonwealth program for expanding trade and liberating exchange in the free world began to take form today in a round of conferences between Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler and their opposite numbers here.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 5 -- Superior Court Judge John M. Comley ruled today that State Highway Commissioner G. Albert Hill had the authority to construct Fairfield County's Thruway as a relocation of U. S. Route 1, the Boston Post Road.

Fair trade minimum retail prices stil are binding on stores throughout New Jersey, Maurice Mermey, director of the Bureau of Education on Fair Trade, declared yesterday. He said these minimums must be observed by stores handling fair traded merchandise even if retailers involved have not signed contracts with manufacturers.

CHICAGO, March 5 -- A prediction by the Department of Agriculture that the heavy impounding of wheat under the loan would cause higher prices inspired buying and lifted prices for the near months one cent or more. The firmness in wheat inspired absorption of other grains also, but most of the day's trading was dull.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- David L. Cole, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, has been marked for replacement, but his successor has not been chosen.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 5 -- The plans of President Juan D. Peron of Argentina to achieve closer relations with Chile suffered a setback today when the leaders of Chile's Progressive Feminist party accused the Argentine President of dabbling in domestic political affairs.

ALBANY, March 5 -- The Court of Appeals ruled unanimously today that money bequeathed to a Hungarian resident was properly deposited for her account with the New York City treasurer and should not be turned over for probable use by an Iron Curtain country.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -- The Senate was called on today to open the nation's doors to a British sailor's daughter brought up as a Chinese child -- until an American colonel found his shirts starched and ironed.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- Representative Kit Clardy, Republican of Michigan, protested in the House of Representatives today against payment of an $8,100-a-year pension to John Carter Vincent, retiring career diplomat and storm center of repeated loyalty investigations.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Nostalgic memories of cracker barrel and pickle jug gatherings are among the most cherished of his youth, President Eisenhower told the American Retail Federation at a luncheon meeting here today. The President, expressed the hope that today's retailers could give present-day youngsters memories comparable to those he has carried through life.

The Poetry Center of the Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A. last night presented Louis MacNeice, the English poet, in a reading of his own and other poets' works at the Kaufmann Auditorium. Also taking part in the event was Hedli Anderson, folk-singer and wife of the poet.

TOKYO, Friday, March 6 -- F-84 Thunderjets of the Fifth Air Force made a record-breaking flight of 800 miles round-trip yesterday in an attack on Communist industrial targets near Chongjin in far northeast Korea. The strike by fifteen F-84's was the deepest penetration of North Korea by land-based fighter-bombers in the Korean war.

ALBANY, March 5 -- The Senate Finance Committee reported favorably today a bill that would force New York City to abandon its tax on retail liquor licenses. The tax is 25 per cent of the cost of the state license and is producing $3,500,000 in revenues to the city annually.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Chronic complaint to the contrary, nothing ever really stands still in the United States Post Office Department.

The Admiral Corporation, Chicago, has appointed the Russel M. Seeds Company, same city, to handle the newspaper and magazine advertising and printed materials for its television and radio divisions, effective May 1.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 5 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan, leader of the Nationalist party now in power, announced today his Government would seek victory in the election April 15 on the issues of segregating races from one another, combating communism and the Government's mandate from the people to legislate as opposed to the courts testing the Government's rights over legislation.
Two hold-ups, in which the assailant wore a woman s stocking over his head to form a mask, were committed yesterday in the midtown area.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- Dr. Joseph W. Weinberg -- the man called "Scientist X" during a Congressional investigation of alleged atomic spying -- was acquitted today of falsely swearing he had never been a member of the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- President Eisenhower authorized John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, tonight to send the United States' "official condolences" to the Soviet Government on the death of Premier Stalin.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, March 5 -- Foreign Minister Johan W. Beyen declared today it would be "the greatest folly" if Premier Stalin's death were allowed to slow up the drive for ratification of the European Defense Community Treaty.
DETROIT, March 5 -- Leading automobile manufacturers tended to discount the decontrol action today as meaningless. They pointed out that most 1953 models were listed at below-ceiling prices.

LONDON, March -- In a debate in the House of Commons today on Government defense policy Prime Minister Churchill described the period through which the world is passing as "critical but formative, grave but not unhopeful."

The New York Post Office, in a project designed to cut down its operating expenses, help the letter writer find a mail box in the dark, and brighten the appearance of city streets, has halted the practice of painting street letter boxes the traditional drab green. It has turned instead to coating them with glistening aluminum paint.
The seventeenth annual Eastern Golden Gloves amateur boxing tournament ended at Madison Square Garden last night.

The fears and fancies many young women with heart disease may have about bearing children safely are needless if at the very start of pregnancy they are examined by their doctor, remain under close observation, abide faithfully by his instructions and follow the common-sense rules applying to all pregnancies.

BONN, Germany, March -- The elimination of the Krupp family from West Germany's great steel and coal industries has been accompanied by orders from the Allied High Commission liquidating and reorganizing into independent units two more steel and coal aggregates controlling 18 per cent of this country's crude steel, 9 per cent of its rolled steel and 8 per cent of its hard coal production.

Necklines were the point of interest in the Mainbocher spring and summer collection which was offered for its initial review yesterday morning. There are fatal defects in the New York compulsory insurance bills. By superficially corrective draftsmanship and by granting extreme bureaucratic rule-making powers the proponents of compulsion have tried but failed dismally to eliminate in New York the defects in law and practice existing in Massachusetts.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5 (UP) -- A school bus carrying forty-eight crippled and handicapped children collided with a tractor-trailer today, injuring four of the pupils and tossing others on the floor, where they lay helpless for ten minutes when the door jammed. A school matron also was injured.

This writer is not in a position to report the quality of Guido Cantelli's performance of Brahms' "Tragic Overture," with which, as guest conductor, he opened the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall.

Larger and better trained sales forces will be required "in the very near future", if industry is to maintain present high levels of employment and provide jobs for the nation's growing population, H. E. Humphreys Jr., .president of the United States Rubber Company,: said yesterday.

In a purchase and quick resale of a Washington Heights property the forty-seven-family apartment building at 609-15 Fort Washington Avenue, near West 187th Street, was sold by investing clients of Marco Shemaria, attorney, to Hyman Katz, who was represented by Jacques Katz.

The Appellate Division, First Department, in a unanimous opinion, has sustained a temporary injunction issued by the Supreme Court barring Local 66, International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., from picketing three embroidery shops in the Bronx that the local sought to organize.

THE NEW YORK TIMES deserves the profound gratitude of those who care, for publishing the statement of Reed Harris, acting administrator of the State Department's International Information Administration, in which he tried to set the record straight and explain the real reason for the planned abolition of Hebrew broadcasts.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 5 -- At its forthcoming session, opening March 16, the United Nations Commission on the Status of' Women will have before it a recent breakdown on women employed in professional categories with the United Nations and its specialized agencies throughout the world. As of Nov. 30, 1952, the total was 673, compared with 2,580 men.

Greater production of newer products by new plants and processes and recent plant expansions lifted sales last year of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., to a new high of $1,602,239,431 from the previous peak of $1,531,128,120 set in 1951.

FORT DIX, N. J., Friday, March 6 -- A 21-year-old Brooklyn soldier, who was being held here for psychiatric examination in the fatal shooting of an officer during maneuvers last month, escaped last night, but was captured two hours later in an abandoned motor pool.
TOKYO, Friday, March 6 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,545, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korean time:

George Jessel has signed a long-term contract with the American Broadcasting Company covering his exclusive services as a performer and producer for both television and radio. It becomes effective June 1.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 5--Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky, who was reported to have been informed of the death of Premier Stalin before the public announcement by the Moscow radio, plans to leave for Moscow tomorrow.

HONG KONG, March 5 -- Mao Tse-tung, the Chinese Communist leader, sent a telegram to Premier Stalin expressing Red China's "deep concern" over the Soviet leader's illness and expressing the hope his health would be restored, the Peiping radio reported this morning.
SAN JUAN, P. R., March 5 -- The Mayor's Committee on Puerto Rican Affairs in New York asked today for a frank talk here and got it.

ROME, March 5 -- Italy's two new armored divisions, both of them assigned to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, made their first appearance in public today when they were reviewed by Randolfo Pacciardi, defense minister.

GENEVA, March 5 -- The position of Western Europe in world economy has deteriorated markedly since World War II. As a result the goal of enabling this region to develop as part of a smoothly running free economy envisaged by the United States is farther away than ever, the secretariat of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe concluded in a monumental study of post-war economic development published here today.

CHICAGO, March 5 -- Tugs maneuvered the 634-foot ore ship, Marine Angel, through bridges spanning the Chicago River today and into Lake Michigan, whence the big vessel proceeded to the American Shipbuilding Company's yards on the Calumet River for a preliminary refitting.

The United Fruit Company plans to file an appeal with the Supreme Court of Guatemala as soon as possible against the Government's seizure last month of 233,973 acres of the company's land, Kenneth H. Redmond, president of the company, said yesterday in Boston.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- The Government announced today that explosives with the force of 15,000 tons of TNT would be unleashed on two ordinary frame houses in an atomic test in Nevada scheduled for March 17.

Charlie Chaplin's "Limelight" won honors in three categories yesterday in the eleventh annual voting poll of the Foreign Language Press Film Critics Circle here. The results were announced last night by Dr. Manfred George, editor of the newspaper Der Aufbau and president of the group, in a presentation ceremony broadcast over WNYC.

Despite substantial pay-offs by public utility companies, New York bank loans to business rose $21,000,000 last week, registering their second successive weekly advance. The increase was the fourth this year and held the decline since the start of 1953 to $163,000,000, against an increase of $73,000,000 a year ago.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5 -- The Soviet campaign against the Jews is "an open invitation to the Arab countries" to begin a new war with Israel and "to push the Israelis into the sea," Dr. Joseph J. Schwartz, executive vice chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, said here tonight.
ALBANY, March 5 -- The State Court of Appeals refused today to hear an appeal from a lower court ruling that cleared two former Ricmmond County legal officers of charges of professional misconduct.

NEWARK, March 5 -- Devices designed to make life safer and easier for the disabled homemaker should not be overlooked as a boon to the normal woman in eliminating fatigue and other accident hazards, according to Mrs. Julia Judson, director of home management of the Department of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation of New York University.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., March 5 -- A "grass roots" approach to the problems of migrant farm workers, embracing all segments of the communities in which they work, was charted today by the Southwest Regional Conference on Migrant Labor.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Feb. 28 totaled 668,805 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 20,748 cars, or 3.0 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 87,039 cars or 11.5 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 117,056 cars, or 14.9 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 5 -- A majority of United Nations staff members generally support Secretary General Trygve Lie's personnel policy, but object to the "automatic" dismissal of United States citizens who decline to answer the loyalty interrogations of the Federal grand jury or Senate subcommittees.

HOUSTON, Tex., March 5 -- A Republican slate for all precinct, county and district offices will be presented to county voters here next year, Joe Ingraham, chairman of the Harris County Republican Executive Committee, announced today.

MOSCOW, Friday, March 6 -- Premier Joseph Stalin died at 9:50 P. M. yesterday [1:50 P. M. Thursday, Eastern standard time] in the Kremlin at the age of 73, it was announced officially this morning. He had been in power twenty-nine years.
The city Government is facing the most serious financial and political crisis to confront any Administration since 1933, when leading banking houses rescued a Democratic regime from fiscal disaster.

BREWSTER, N. Y., March 5 -- A St. Patrick's dance planned by the men's club of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Lawrence O'Toole here to aid the parish's new school building fund will not be held in the town's only school hall, it was revealed today, because the Brewster Ministerial Association, consisting of the community's Protestant pastors, has raised a protest.

Columbia University faculty members and their wives gathered in front of 60 Morningside Drive last evening to serenade Grayson Kirk, the university's fourteenth president, as he and his wife finished moving into the house that President Eisenhower vacated last January.

Beef prices continue to fall with mark-downs noted this week-end on chuck and round steaks and rib roast. Popular cuts of beef are now 20 per cent lower than they were a year ago, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 5 -- In a private meeting today the Majlis or lower house of Parliament failed to remove the obstacles keeping it from meeting officially. The body has been unable to attain a quorum since Tuesday when Ayatollah Sayed Abolghassem Kashani, Speaker and arch opponent of Dr. Mossadegh, requested the Deputies to abstain because the Premier had changed the chief of the Majlis guards.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 5 -- Yugoslavia's Communist leaders have met at least informally to discuss the consequences of the news from Moscow. It is not known whether any decisions were taken or contemplated, but it may be assumed that President Tito subscribes to the view prevalent here that a struggle for power is about to ensue among the heirs to Premier Stalin.

MEXICO CITY, March 5--President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines' efforts to restore political unity have run into difficulties with Gen. Miguel Henriquez Gruzman, who continues to defy the Mexican tradition that defeated Presidential candidates fade into oblivion.

Martin J. Parkinson, 63-year-old former convict and head of three locals of the International Union of Operating Engineers, A. F. L., once controlled by Joey Fay, has been ordered by the State Parole Board to resign his union posts by March 31, it was learned last night.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet, former Commander of United Nations ground forces in Korea, told the Senate Armed Services Committee today that he had been handicapped during the entire twenty-two months he had had the command by shortages of ammunition and manpower.
LONDON, March 5 -- Britain apparently has reached the limit of her concessions to Iran on the oil nationalization issue.

Lord Ismay, British wartime military advisor at the Teheran, Yalta and Potsdam conferences, said yesterday he "would be surprised" if there were any change in Soviet Union policy with Premier Stalin's death.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 5 -- Howard Hughes, controlling stock owner in R.K.O.-Radio Pictures, has been charged with having operated the company with "pique, caprice and whim" to the "detriment" of other investors in an amended complaint to a minority stockholders' suit on file in Federal Court in Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- Testimony at a Federal Power Commission hearing today indicated geologists will be unable to estimate the quantity of gas and oil in the vast Canadian Peace River area until there is a market for it.

The boxing fire stoked by the interference of the New York State Athletic Commission will flare again at Madison Square Garden tonight when Billy Graham, East Side welterweight, engages Joey Giardello, Philadelphia middle-weight.

BUENOS AIRES, March 5 -- Argentina and Brazil concluded today an important trade pact, with Argentina agreeing to export to Brazil 1,500,000 tons of wheat in exchange for bananas, coffee, timber, scrap iron and other products.

Liquidation of Brazil's dollar trade debt will be speeded up to achieve a current credit status by mid-April, according to an announcement made yesterday by Mario da Camera, head of the Brazilian Treasury delegation in New York.
