Prices seemed to hover for the most part around or below the $50 mark in Stein Blaine's presentation of youthful spring and summer fashions yesterday at the Plaza Hotel. To give them a look of luxury, the evening fashions in some instances were topped by this shop's elegant furs.

The formation of the Joint Conference for Better Government in New York City, a nonpartisan, city-wide agency seeking more efficient and less costly operation of the city government, was announced yesterday by Harold W. McGraw, vice president of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company.

For the many Communist parties outside the Soviet Union the situation caused by the passing of power from Stalin's hands creates a crisis comparable only with that created inside the Soviet Union itself. For a quarter of a century they have been Stalin's creatures.

NEWARK, March 5 -- A new radiation device in the treatment of cancer, which is being perfected at the Government's Atomic Energy plant at Oak Ridge, Tenn., will be donated to the Black-Stevenson Clinic of Presbyterian Hospital here, it was announced today at the dedication and opening of the clinic.

Russian exiles in New York, who for thirty-five years have followed the news from their homeland with increasing anguish as the dictatorship of Joseph Stalin consolidated its power, read the Moscow dispatches eagerly yesterday. They viewed his passing from the Soviet political scene as offering hope for the future.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5 (AP) -- Nicholas Kerbawy, general manager of the Detroit Lions, testified today that the champions of the National Football League made a $114,000 profit in 1952 with the help of $113,000 from radio and television programs.

LONDON, March 5 (Reuters) -- A Labor member of Parliament urged the government today to examine American seamen in British ports about whether they are loyal to their President and stand up when the American national anthem is played.

TRENTON, March 6 -- A wide-open contest for the Republican nomination for Governor was forecast here tonight as State Chairman John J. Dickerson announced that his efforts to unite factions behind a single candidate had failed.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6 -- A ten-year-old girl who underwent a "rare and involved" operation in which nearly half of her brain was removed a year ago has shown such marked improvement that she is attending a private school.
ROME, March 6 -- Premier Stalin's death, though expected almost hourly since the announcement that he was gravely ill, caused renewed apprehensions here as to future developments of Soviet policy.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- President Eisenhower has accepted the resignations of members of the atomic-energy labor relations panel set up by President Truman in 1949.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 6 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, in what turned out to be his last official act as Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union, delivered a tearful tribute here this morning to "the great Stalin," and sailed on the Liberte this afternoon for home and possibly an uncertain future.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 6 -- Attorneys for nineteen United States citizens ousted from the United Nations during the loyalty controversy accused Secretary General Trygve Lie today of bowing to "Red hunt" pressures.

The fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building housing forty families at 39 and 41 West Sixty-seventh Street has been purchased by Philip S. Zipes, operator, who was represented by Fred W. Weitzner, attorney. Reuben Lesser was the attorney for the seller of the building, which formerly was a cooperative.

In fine cookery, recipes -- especially for sauces, soups and meat dishes -- often include glace de viande or meat glaze among the ingredients. This is an extract in congealed, concentrated form; culinary tradition decrees that it must be made with beef and no other ingredients, except perhaps chicken legs and wings for added flavor.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The flags that hung over the diplomatic missions here today were a graphic picture of a world split into Communist and non-Communist camps.

The Noranda Corporation has acquired title to the six-story fifty-eight-family apartment house at 1065 Jerome Avenue, the Bronx, through the purchase of stock of the Carsamor Realty Corporation. Allan S. Feldman Co. and Benjamin Horowitz were the brokers.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., March 6 -- The extension to the estimated 1,000,000 migrant farm workers of standards and benefits accorded to industrial workers and alien contract farm labor was urged today by the Southwest Conference on Migrant Labor.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 6 -- Stockholm took the news of Premier Stalin's death more or less in its stride. The National Broadcasting System announced the passing of the Kremlin dictator in the day's first routine newscast at 6:30 A. M. which was followed by routine jazz music.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 6 (AP) -- Ten-time champion Willie Mosconi gave Jimmy Caras, a former titleholder, a quick, easy lesson in it the art of pocket billiards in the world tourney last night.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- A star witness before a House of Representatives investigating subcommittee testified today political influence controlled promotions in the Internal Revenue Bureau for many years.

CHICAGO, March 6 (AP) -- For the first time in years the United States is exporting beef cattle to Canada, market men noted today. Price, they say, is the controlling factor, rather than the March 2 lifting of this country's embargo against Canadian cattle.

Nikita S. Khrushchev has had a long career in the Soviet Union Government. The Ukrainian-born party officer was secretary of the Moscow Communist party in 1937 and had risen to the Presidium before his new appointment.
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 6 -- Preliminary talks for obtaining increased United States aid for the French campaign in Indo-China apparently is the reason for the visits of leading personalities.

HACKENSACK, N.J., March 6 -- Superior Court Judge J. Wallace Leyden upheld today the contention of John E. Selser, attorney for Joe Adonis and the late Willie and Solly Moretti, that all information they might have given him confidentially was "privileged" and that he need not answer the state's questions about it.
WINNIPEG, March 6 (Canadian Press) -- Importation of slaughter cattle to Manitoba from St. Paul, Minn., was criticized today by the Winnipeg Livestock Exchange.

MOSCOW, Saturday, March 7 -- Thousands of grieving Moscow citizens have filed past Stalin's bier in the Hall of Columns through the night. A Government announcement early today said that the body of the late Premier would be taken Monday to lie beside that of Lenin in the famous tomb in Red Square.

The very fact that there is so little ground for an accurate forecast of the nature or direction of Soviet policies and acts is all the more reason for a fresh clarity and dynamism on our part. This is most certainly not the time for us to sit back and await an adversary's initiative.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 6 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh was reported today to have told a group of Deputies that there was no need for his Government to ask the Majlis, the lower house of parliament, for a vote of confidence. The Premier was said to think that most anti-Government activities were carried on outside the Majlis and that a vote of confidence would have no practical effect.

LONDON, March 6 -- The stock market here recovered strongly from a weak opening today following news of Premier Stalin's death, and in many cases the rally more than eliminated early losses, particularly among the industrial leaders. Active trading again developed in gold shares, although declines as well as rises were scattered throughout list.

The annual National Invitation Basketball Tournament, an event that ranks second only to the National Collegiate A. A. championship in the college basketball world, will begin tonight with a triple-header at Madison Square Garden.

April 1 will be an important one in the history of the little Peoria Eastern Railway Company, which owns 212 miles of track extending from Peoria, Ill., to Indianapolis, Ind., and which will pay to holders of its $4,000,000 of income mortgage 4 per cent bonds of 1950, their first installment of interest in forty years.

The Detroit Edison Company is planning to borrow $40,000,000 on thirty-five-year first mortgage bonds at a interest cost not exceeding 4 per cent. The company will sell the bonds either privately or after public sealed bidding, depending upon market conditions.

The American Newspaper Publishers Association has sent to all United States Senators a memorandum of its views on proposals that it said would exempt the International Typographical Union from certain Taft-Hartley Act provisions.
IOWA CITY, Iowa, March 6 (AP) -- Burwell (Bumpy) Jones of Michigan dethroned the Olympic champion, Ford Konno of Ohio State, in the 220-yard free-style event in the Big Ten swimming meet tonight.
MOSCOW, March 6 (UP) -- Following is the text of tonight's Moscow radio announcement on reorganization of the Soviet Government:

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- (UP) -- President Eisenhower named today John M. Allison, Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs, to be Ambassador to Japan. He will succeed Robert D. Murphy, named to be Assistant Secretary of State for United Nations Affairs, following John D. Hickerson, who has held the post since it was created three and one-half years ago.

What was Joseph Stalin really like? The dictator who wielded more absolute power over more human beings than any ruler in history now lies powerless under the gleaming columns of a hall that recalls the pale pomp of the last czars. The people in that stony-faced and endless funeral procession far outnumber those who saw him alive.

A demand that the Legislature extend the present State Rent Law or permit the city to enact its own controls was made yesterday by City Council President Rudolph Halley. At the same time he accused the State Administration of a "rent grab."

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 16 (AP) -- Patty Berg set a women's record for Brentwood Municipal Golf Course at 33, 36 -- 69 today and took the first-round lead in the Jacksonville women's open. Miss Berg was three strokes in front of Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias of Tampa; Betty Jameson of San Antonio, Tex., and Marilynn Smith of Wichita, Kan.
PARIS, March 6 -- A report on the future of the European Payments Union, drafted by its managing board, reveals a sharp conflict between the British and the Continentals.

SAIGON, March 6 (AP) -- Gen. Raoul Salan, commander of French Union forces in Indo-China, predicted today that French and Vietnamese troops would carry the war into the Communist-led Vietminh's own backyard within two years.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- Support for bills to set up standby price and wage control legislation was voiced today by Americans for Democratic Action and several women's and consumers groups.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee voted today, 13 to 2, to approve President Eisenhower's nomination of former Representative Albert M. Cole, Republican of Kansas, to be the government's top housing administrator.

Once or twice a year they get insistent around the house that something must be done about the books. The study, where they are kept, seems perfectly satisfactory to its usual occupant, but nevertheless they get insistent.

The 60-year-old driver of a northbound Fifth Avenue bus suffered a stroke shortly after noon yesterday and his coach veered sharply into traffic in the opposite lane just north of Twenty-third Street at Madison Square, causing an accident in which four persons were injured, none seriously.

A majority of the Board of Estimate decided yesterday to stand firm on Mayor Impellitteri's $218,700,000 fiscal program for 1953-54, refusing to purchase substantial financial aid from Governor Dewey's Republican Administration at a price considered politically ruinous by the Democratic leaders of the city's five counties.

The latest Cinema 16 program will be presented on Sunday morning at the Paris Theatre and again on Wednesday evening at the Central Needle Trades Auditorium. The following subjects are included: "Christ Among the Primitives," an art film; "The Garden Spider," an Italian-made science short; Jordan Belson's color abstraction, "Mambo"; "Images From Debussy," and "Song of the Prairie," a Czech puppet satire on Westerns.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Charles E. Wilson, the Secretary of Defense, assured the public today that "there is sufficient ammunition available in the Far East Command to counter any enemy attack in Korea."

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The Labor Department Advisory Committee, set up by the Eisenhower Administration in an effort to get labor and industry to compose their differences over the Taft-Hartley Law, cracked up in dissension today.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 6 (AP) -- Bernadotte Stable's Dandolo, a 71-to-1 outsider, staged one of the season's biggest upsets when he outgamed Odgen Phipps' Torch of War in the Atlantic City purse before 17,156 at Gulfstream Park today.

The thirty-third annual New York Book Week of the American Merchant Marine Library Association will open on March 16. Books will be collected for the libraries of the Merchant Marine and Coast Guard and to replenish various stations, lightships, lighttowers and patrol and weather ships.

In current discussions, official and unofficial, of the city's financial problems two attitudes are visible. One is to accept at full face value the city's statement of revenue expectations and revenue needs, and then supply tax and other sources to meet these claimed needs. The other is to shut the door tight, and say no more new taxes at all.
The following is a round-up of household hints that may be of interest to homemakers:

VIENNA, March 6 -- Since Vienna is the principal European front of the cold peace where the quadripartite machinery born of the wartime still operates after a fashion, news of Premier Stalin's death and the accession of Georgi M. Malenkov to power struck home with more than general impact.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Howard Maier, a political specialist for the Voice of America, testified today that he had received a reprimand from the State Department for having written a script for a counter-propaganda radio broadcast that had been denounced in what he termed the Communist-controlled press.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6 -- On the eve of baseball's 1953 spring training exhibition season, Commissioner Ford C. Frick, from near-by Belleair, issued a warning to all sixteen managers in the two major leagues to keep in mind that "fans who pay admission to our games are entitled to see a real performance by real major league players."
ALBANY, March 6 -- Federal legislation to permit reactivation of the State Guard for use in civil defense emergencies was urged today by the State Civil Defense Commission.

The Voice of America in a late broadcast to satellite peoples behind the Iron Curtain yesterday said Moscow's announcement that Georgi M. Malenkov had succeeded Premier Stalin did not necessarily mean an orderly transition and bloodless accession to power.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 6 -- The Government Information Office today explained the exclusion from South Africa of two Bishops of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, Frederick Jordan and Howard Prim. The Bishops were elected in Chicago last May as heads of the fifteenth and seventeenth Episcopal districts of the church here.
MIAMI, March 6 -- Manager Chuck Dressen today brought to Miami "the best-conditioned squad of Dodgers ever to leave Vero Beach."
TOKYO, March 6 -- General Clark said today that the Eighth Army had "ample" artillery ammunition to throw back any all-out Communist offensive.

LONDON, Saturday, March 7 (AP) -- Joseph Stalin's ten doctors said today the post mortem results "fully confirm" their original diagnosis that death was brought on by a brain hemorrhage due to high blood pressure and hardening of the arteries.

PARIS, March 6 -- Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister, told the National Assembly today that one of the purposes of the visit he and Premier Rene Mayer would make in Washington at the end of this month was to explain France's "two great tasks: the consolidation of the French Union and the creation of Europe."

LONDON, March 6 -- Persons here whose business it is to forecast the course of Soviet policy received little indication of its trend from the appointment of Georgi M. Malenkov as the successor to Premier Stalin.

Two youths aspiring to the mantle of Barney Oldfield decided they would race each other in automobiles along the Belt Parkway in Brooklyn. They lacked cars but soon remedied the deficiency the police said, when one stole a 1947 sedan in front of a Queens home and the other a 1947 sedan at a Brooklyn home.

WINFIELD, N. J., March 6 -- Many residents here and in nearby Linden rubbed sleepy eyes when a huge free plastic Navy observation balloon suddenly hovered over the area and then landed in the rear of a residence at 5-C Seafoam Avenue, near the Rahway River, at 6:30 A. M. today. Many startled persons called the police.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.2 per cent in the week ended March 3 to 109.9 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Events today: "Rigoletto," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P. M.; Luther College Concert Band, Town Hall, 5:30; "La Forza del Destino," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Philharmonic- Symphony, Guido Cantelli conducting, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Greenwich House Music School Orchestra, Town Hall, 8:30; "La Boheme," Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:30.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 6 -- Traffic circles are being rebuilt in New Jersey as a safety measure and to expedite travel.

BOSTON, March 6 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers increased their Eastern Division lead over Syracuse to three full games tonight by whipping the Nationals, 75 -- 66, in the opener of a National Basketball Association double-header. A capacity crowd of 13,909 watched at the Boston Garden.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The General Services Administration reported today it was nearer its objective of obtaining manganese ore exclusively from Western Hemisphere sources. The Government agency concluded contracts with two-score Mexican mines insuring the delivery of 230,500 tons of manganese ore in the next three years to a processing plant to be constructed at El Paso, Tex.

What is our state legislation becoming? At present there are bills before the New York State Senate and Assembly seeking a law which would allow only medical doctors to diagnose or treat mentally ill persons.

CHICAGO, March 6 -- The challenge that free men and free institutions face will not be lessened by the death of Joseph Stalin, Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, declared tonight.

Asserting that the relatively high level of imports of petroleum is causing serious damage to the domestic industry, Russell B. Brown, general counsel of the Independent Petroleum Association of America, asked yesterday for curbs on such imports.

TOKYO, Saturday, March 7 -- South Korean infantrymen fought a daylong battle yesterday at "Rocky Point" on the central Korean front north of Kumwha to hold an outpost the Republic of Korea troops took Thursday from the Chinese Communists.

GENEVA, March 6 -- The Soviet Union will continue a "peaceful policy that will insure cooperation, including economic cooperation and the establishment of businesslike relations with all countries," Amazasp Arutiunian, Soviet delegate to the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, said today.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- A corn industry advisory committee today urged Secretary of Agriculture Ezra T. Benson to place greater emphasis of research and marketing programs aimed at broadening the domestic and foreign use of corn. The committee said mounting supplies of this grain "point up sharply the urgency of finding new and expanded outlets."

The one-story taxpayer at 29-01 to 29-21 Francis Lewis Boulevard in Bayside, Queens, has been sold by Alvin Greenstein and David Meltzer to Albert Pittell for cash above mortgages of $80,000. The building, on a triangular plot 207 by 133 by 161 feet, contains seven stores and a branch of the New York Public Library.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 6 -- Harold J. Adonis, former executive clerk of New Jersey's Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, is preparing to start a hunger strike in his jail cell here on Sunday to force a decision on his extradition, his Dutch attorney, Jan Roggeveen, said today.

TRENTON, March 6 -- In a small, quiet building at 152 State Street, opposite New Jersey's State House here, a group of courteous inspectors of the state's Division of Motor Vehicles is carrying out an experiment designed to improve highway safety and determine as far as possible what constitutes a "safe" driver.

NEW DELHI, India, Saturday, March 7 (AP) -- The United States Embassy said today that two American women were slain in their beds last night in the American Presbyterian Mission at Dehradun, 100 miles north of here.

General Van Fleet's expressed dissatisfaction with ammunition supplies in Korea raises the sort of questions that were expected to be asked upon his return. The people of the United States, and their properly designated representatives in the Congress, are deeply concerned with every aspect of the war in Korea.

STRASBOURG, France, March 6 -- The draft of Europe's new charter was submitted to the European Constitutional Assembly today and met a flood of amendments insuring that the four-day session for its final revision will be a struggle between proponents of a supranational organization and of intergovernmental cooperation.

PARIS, March 6 -- A Roman Catholic priest has broken the mystery of two "kidnapped" Jewish children, according to reports received here from Bayonne. The priest, Father Ibarburu, according to the report, told of taking the two boys, Robert and Gerald Finaly across the Pyrenees into Spain.

MOSCOW, March 6 -- Georgi Maximilianovich Malenkov was named head of the Soviet Government tonight in place of the late Joseph Stalin in a series of changes in the highest Soviet leadership.

THE HAGUE, March 6 -- Bolivia exported only 1,776 tons of tin in concentrates in December, more than 1,000 tons under the monthly average for last year, the International Tin Study group reported today. It was the second successive month of abnormally low shipments, with November at 1,850.

Competition from imports will eliminate the domestic briarwood pipe industry unless offset by adequate tariff duties, it was asserted yesterday in a statement issued by the American Smoking Pipe Manufacturers Association.

A historic production, and one of the most important undertakings of Rudolph Bing's direction of the institution, took place last night in the Metropolitan Opera House. This was the first performance in America of the greatest of Russian operas, "Boris Godunov," in the actual form in which its composer, Modest Mussorgsky, created the libretto and the music.
The Police Department is planning to place the enforcement of gambling and vice laws in the hands of individual commanders for each of the five boroughs in a move to "concentrate responsibility."

The curious gaze of an anxious world is focused today on a grim and ancient citadel on the banks of the Moscow River. But the walls are thick and the towers high and the gates are shut. The Kremlin lies in the heart of a teeming city, but it could be on the moon for all one knows of what goes on behind its forbidding battlements.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were steady yesterday and closed 2 to 8 points higher on the active months than on Thursday.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 6 -- Drivers of school buses serving this resort's north side went on "strike" today against high school students because they were "fed up" with the youths' rowdy, "almost savage" antics.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The Defense Department today listed almost a quarter of a million pounds of freight shipments that it said transatlantic airlines of the United States had been unable to handle promptly for it during a two-and-one-half-month period.

A man who had hitherto preferred to remain in the shadows, Anastas I. Mikoyan was recognized as Russia's top business man and probably also the big-best business man in the world. WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Joseph M. Dodge, Director of the Budget, began a detailed review today of recommendations by departments and agencies for reductions in outlays budgeted last January by outgoing President Harry S. Truman.

EL PASO, Tex., March 6 -- Rosaura Revueltas, Mexican actress starring in the controversial union-sponsored movie, "Salt of the Earth," today gave up her fight to block deportation and prepared to return to Mexico.

Consolidated net income of the Pittsburgh Consolidation Coal Company last year amounted to $14,866,395, exclusive of profit on the disposal of properties and investments, George H. Love, president, reported yesterday.

BONN, Germany, March 6 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer implored West German countrymen and the peoples of other European Defense Community Nations tonight to move swiftly toward unity rather than sit idle hypnotized by the political developments in Moscow.

HAVANA, March 6 -- The Cuban Branch of the Inter-American Regional Organization of Workers is setting out to split hemispheric labor into separate Latin-American and United States organizations, Francisco Aguirre, Cuban labor leader, said today.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The British-American financial discussions continued today behind an official news blackout reminiscent of the proceedings of the Combined Chiefs of Staff in World War II.

ANCIENT witchcraft is defended in Margaret Murray's "The God of the Witches"* on the ground that it was the religion of the pagans. The witch-hunters of the world's earlier days were offering brisk resistance to rooted beliefs that were in opposition to their own. Writing as an anthropologist, Miss Murray draws on vast quantities of European and Asian lore.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today revised its regulations affecting securities issues of $300,000 or less.

Among this week's larger art exhibitions is a show at the New School of paintings and sculpture by the Provincetown-New York Artists, a group of thirty or more men and women who are linked together by their part-time residence in the famous art colony.

NEW DELHI, India, March 6 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru paid tribute to the late Premier Stalin today as a leader whose "weight and influence had been cast in favor of peace" but who also was "ruthless in the pursuit of his objectives."

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- American Jewish leaders emphasized here today that despite the anti-Semitic campaign behind the Iron Curtain and "threats from Soviet Russia and the Arab States," Israel would adhere to democratic ideals and principles and would not be diverted from achieving economic independence.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 6 -- The United Nations was urged by Indonesia today to call for a direct meeting between President Eisenhower and the new Soviet ruler, Premier Georgi M. Malenkov.

Prices closed generally higher yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges in continued light trading. Potato, hide and cocoa volume was about average and the No. 6 sugar market was active. Cocoa, sugar, potatoes, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, lead and tin were higher.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -- The Senate ordered a Federal Bureau of Investigation loyalty and security investigation of its 1,800 employes today, but shouted down a proposal by Senator Wayne Morse for a similar check on the Senators themselves.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Ever since the first settlers discovered that squirrels were good eating, hunters have been trying to lure the animals out of hollow trees by making oral chirping sounds. George L. Herter of Waseca, Minn., says hunters can now give a really accurate imitation of the squirrel's bark and chatter by using the mechanical invention he patented this week.

HONG KONG, March 6 -- Mao Tse-tung has ordered a three-day period of mourning to express Red China's "boundless grief" over the death of Premier Stalin, the Peiping radio announced tonight. He eulogized the late Soviet leader as "the great Comrade Stalin -- the great leader of the working people of the world, the most esteemed and dearest friend and teacher of the Chinese people."

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The high rate of personal income which marked the close of 1952 carried over into the start of this year, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce said today. The January rate of personal income was an annual rate of $280,500,000,000, virtually unchanged from December's level, but 6 per cent higher than the corresponding month a year ago.

MANILA, March 6 -- The name of the Philippine Ambassador to Washington, Brig Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, merged from an over-heated political situation here today as a possible running mate for President Elpidio Quirino in the November elections.

CHICAGO, March 6 -- A group of educators headed by Dr. Buell Gallagher, president of City College of New York, agreed here today that membership in the Communist party should not be sufficient evidence to warrant dismissal of members of college and university faculties and staffs.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- President Eisenhower, who is engaged in talks on international trade and other mutual problems with the British delegation headed by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, announced today that French and West German delegations would come here for similar discussions.

NEW DELHI, India, March 6 -- In a move that could have national repercussions, the leaders of three strong Hindu organizations that oppose Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's tolerant policies toward the predominantly Moslem Government of Jammu and Kashmir State, the territory in dispute with Pakistan in the United Nations, were arrested along with nineteen of their followers here today.

A Voice of America radio engineer who committed suicide by stepping in front of a truck was buried in Queens yesterday shortly after Washington sources released the text of a note indicating he had been driven to his death by fear of persecution by the Senate inquiry into the Voice of America.

The modern Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, which is now in its twenty-sixth season, paid its first visit to New York last night and made an impressive occasion of it. Under the leadership of William Steinberg, who is in his first season as conductor of the orchestra, the visitors played at Carnegie Hall with a freshness and enthusiasm that spoke well for the future of this organization.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- President Eisenhower declined to comment today on the selection of Georgi M. Malenkov as Premier of the Soviet Union. He concentrated instead on unifying British-American policies in the war against Communist aggression and apparently made some progress, particularly in the economic war against Communist China.

Ossie Davis, the young Negro actor recently seen on Broadway in one of the leading roles in the short-lived "Touchstone," and before that in such productions as "Jeb," "The Green Pastures" and "The Wisteria Trees," now has turned his hand to playwriting.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- President Eisenhower began today to reconstitute the Council of Economic Advisers by nominating Arthus F. Burns, Professor of Economics at Columbia University, as a member. It is understood that he will be head of the agency when its pattern finally is set.

A stranger to these shores who has achieved national fame here for her ceramic creations of American birds arrived in New York from England on Thursday for first-hand observation of her feathered models in their native habitat.

The 1953 appeal for contributions to the Roman Catholic Bishops' Fund for Victims of War will start here tomorrow, when a letter from Cardinal Spellman will be read at all masses. Envelopes that will be distributed tomorrow will be returnable on March 15, the closing date of the drive.

New York University's team retained its Metropolitan Collegiate Swimming Association title last night when it tallied 76 points to outscore seven rivals in its own pool on University Heights. TOKYO, March 7 -- A slip of the tongue by Japan's outspoken Premier Shigeru Yoshida a week ago brought a sharp rebuff to the veteran diplomat-politician from fellow lawmakers and threatened to tip the delicate balance by which Mr. Yoshida currently directs Japan's government.

WHEN Champlain opened up the St. Lawrence River to Europeans the old quest of the Northwest Passage was given new impetus. It seemed reasonable to think that the Great Lakes and the mighty rivers which, the Indians said, lay beyond might provide a water route to the China Sea.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 7 -- Communist agents are taking advantage of the famine conditions in the northeast states of Brazil to provoke disorders by urging hungry drought victims to loot food shops, it is reported here.

Governor Dewey, cast as King Thomas I, was crowned "Ruler of the Universe" and Mayor Impellitteri was portrayed as a hesitant Tiger tamer last night when state and city political leaders underwent their annual lampooning at the Inner Circle dinner and show.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 7 -- Dr. Ali Shayegan, an adviser to Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, announced today that a reply to the latest British oil proposals would not be made "until the internal situation becomes absolutely calm, political problems are resolved and the position of the Mossadegh Government is clarified."

EACH month of the outdoor garden year is notable for a certain perennial. This group of plants can be counted on to bloom at approximately the same time year after year, thus offering a workable background for succession of bloom.

STRASBOURG, France, March 7 -- In a series of votes, the Constitutional Assembly, considering a basic charter for Europe, moved today toward the acceptance of a six-nation union with supranational powers in a limited field. In its early stages the prospective union would be under the supervision of a committee of ministers representing the national Governments.

BONN, Germany, March 7 -- The radical Right-Wing leadership of the Free Democratic party in the key state of North P. Rhine-Westphalia was enthusiastically confirmed at an extraordinary congress of the party organization in Dortmund today.

WHEN the great Yiddish writer Sholom Aleichem came to New York Mark Twain was among the first to visit him. The story goes that Twain then remarked, "I wanted to meet you because I understand that I am the American Sholom Aleichem."

Most home owners feel that their "acres," however small, are incomplete without some kind of pool. It's the water that counts; shape of the pool and type of coping should be subordinate, as a frame is to the picture it holds.

Two performances of the Easter show at Radio City Music Hall have been taken over for Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association as its spring benefit. The performances are those of the afternoon of March 26 and the evening of April 14.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Senator Joseph McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said today his Senate Investigations subcommittee had found nothing to indicate any wrong-doing by Raymond Kaplan, a Voice of America employe whose death has been ruled a suicide.

ELIZABETH, N. J., March 7 -- To aid the industrial development of the meadowland here, sand, rock and silt are being sucked from the bottom of Newark Bay and poured through a 3,000-foot-long pipe into a 150-acre tract. The job is expected to turn the area into a site for industry.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The appointment of the Rev. Marion J. Creeger of New York as director of the General Commission on Chaplains was announced here today. The commission represents forty-two Protestant denominations in the administration of a chaplaincy program for an estimated 3,000,000 men and women in the armed forces.

THE exhibition of recent acquisitions to the permanent collection at the Whitney Museum would provide many a smaller institution with an impressive collection of twentieth century American painting and sculpture.

THE culture of tuberous begonias in the United States received its greatest impetus from the embargo of 1915 on tubers from Europe. After several unsuccessful attempts in various sections of California, plantings were made in the Monterey Bay region.
IOWA CITY, March 7 (AP) -- Ohio State won its fifth straight Big Ten Conference swimming title today with its Olympic champion, Ford Konno, in isolation in near-by University Hospital with the Mumps.

THE objection to the majority of the books on hunting is that they are compiled by hunters rather than writers. Not every Hemingway turns to the gun for relaxation and literary profit, but "Killers in Africa" is an exception to what has almost become accepted as a rule.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Any who felt a few months ago that the coming of a Republican Administration to Washington would put a damper on the investigative activities of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy were sharply revising their estimates this week.

IN a distinctive season of Hollywood history, which has seen the rise of the three, four and five part picture, the starring of a lion, a monkey and a talking mule, and a picture with no dialogue at all, the latest oddity turns out to be a six-year-old boy named George Winslow, who owns a natural bass voice and a brand-new seven-year contract with Twentieth Century-Fox.

THE efforts of modern parents to save their marriages for the sake of their children have made good, bad and indifferent novels, and Mr. Saroyan's, four-fifths of the way, is one of the good ones. Simply and tautly, with scarcely any of the flabbiness and sentimentality that have marred so much of his writing, he tells a compelling and moving story which, like any really good story, implies a moral problem.

In one of the most action-packed finals seen in many seasons, Yale University's polo team gained the national intercollegiate indoor championship last night by topping Cornell, 9 to 8, in the twenty-seventh tournament at the Squadron A Armory.
War offices and intelligence services throughout the world began last week a reappraisal of the strength of Soviet Russia and her Communist empire.
LONDON, March 7 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill does not plan to send any personal condolences, now or later, on the death of Premier Stalin, a spokesman said today.

Manufacturers who fix retail prices on their products in New Jersey were a sad lot last week. Their gloom resulted from widespread misunderstanding on the part of retailers, the general public and almost everybody of three State Supreme Court decisions on Monday relating to fair trade.

MADRID, March 7 -- Ecclesia, which speaks editorially for the Roman Catholic episcopacy in Spain, announced today that the Vatican and the Spanish Government were negotiating a concordat, or treaty, to define the relations of the church and the Spanish state.

MANY horticultural societies and garden club organizations are marking flower show week with luncheons, meetings, lectures and other special programs. Flower show week begins today when the thirty-seventh International Flower Show opens in Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue and Forty-sixth Street, at 2 P. M.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 7 (UP) -- Illinois' track team piled up 21 points in the two hurdle events today to upset Michigan and win the Big Ten indoor title for the third straight year before 3,412 fans.
ST. LOUIS, March 7 -- Citizens will cast ballots in next Friday's municipal primary election here to nominate candidates for Mayor, Controller and Aldermen in the city's fourteen-odd wards.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Organizations and individuals interested in the rights and welfare of American Indians hailed as "milestones" in the fight for equal rights for Indians, two court decisions recently announced. In each case the contention that Indians were not entitled to public aid while living on reservations because they were wards of the Federal Government was rejected by the courts.

HEMINGWAY is now a great writer in a truly extraordinary way. He is receiving all the benefits of literary history as if he were Shakespeare or John Donne. In Mr. Young's critical study, as in Carlos Baker's recent full-length work, he gets the kind of attention generally devoted only to dead authors and their masterpieces.

WASHINGTON -- With absolutely no respect for the wishes and the plans of the Greater National Capital Committee for its annual National Cherry Blossom Festival, Washington's cherry trees last week were on the point of bursting into bloom a month earlier than usual.

Playing his last game of a brilliant four-year career, Capt. Vern (Kangaroo) Stokes paced St. Francis College of Brooklyn to a 66-49 basketball victory over Brooklyn College last night at the Second Corps Armory in Brooklyn.

FORT WORTH, Tex., March 7 (AP) -- Oklahoma A. M.'s balanced team, featuring Mickey Wilborn, who scored 16 points, and the Norwegian star, Fredrik Eckhoff, spreadeagled the field today to win the university division of Southwestern Recreation track and field meet as ten records fell and two others were tied in four classes.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Members of Congress from four states and the Upper Colorado River Commission today laid the groundwork for proposed legislation to authorize a multimillion-dollar water storage program.

A small collection of Dutch, French, British and American paintings, assembled by the late Lionel F. Straus of New York, will be auctioned Wednesday evening at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Eisenhower Administration's domestic policy is evolving slowly and undramatically as the joint product of the Executive and the Legislative branches of Government.

OF special significance for local nontheatrical film enthusiasts is a recent announcement by the New York Public Library regarding the free availability of certain 16-millimeter documentaries. DALLAS, Tex., March 7 (UP) -- The Southwest Journalism Forum announced tonight its 1953 reporting and editing awards would be presented to Ralph McGill, James Reston, Richard Rovere, Clifton Utley and Edward R. Murrow.

Since the Korean war started, the Army, Navy and Air Force have increased the size of their Reserve Officers Training Corps on American campuses. At present more than 300,000 students are taking officer-training programs in 372 colleges and universities.

TRENTON, March 7 -- The public hearings being held here by the joint legislative committee investigating the ouster of Nelson F. Stamler as deputy attorney general and other matters relating to the Attorney General's office are causing increasing concern to state Republican party leaders.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- A 127-page report issued today by the Office of Education, Federal Security Agency, showed that the Federal Government contributed $315,702,680 in the fiscal year ending June 30, 1952, to building and operating schools in "Federally impacted" districts.

Toy manufacturers will offer Santa Claus a helping hand tomorrow when the fiftieth annual American Toy Fair opens at the McAlpin and New Yorker Hotels. A preview of the playthings for 1953 will be shown to retailers and wholesalers at the ten-day exhibit.
Moscow, March 7 -- Moscow was a city of silence, solemnity and sorrow today as the impact of Premier Stalin's death was borne home to millions of Russians.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- A full-scale Congressional investigation of the conduct of the Korean war, possibly by a special committee, was proposed today by Robert A. Taft of Ohio, majority leader of the Senate.
TOKYO, Sunday, March 8 (UP) -- The statement by the United Nations Prisoner-of-War Command on the Yoncho rioting follows:

A $1,025,000 suit against the city by Max Schuster, father of the late Arnold L. Schuster, was dismissed by Supreme Court Justice Michael F. Walsh in Brooklyn yesterday on the eve of the first anniversary of the slaying of the 24-year-old salesman.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Three Congressional investigating committees are riding high and hard these days.

MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L. I., March 7 -- Negro and white officers and airmen joined here today in praise of the Armed Forces' non-segregation policy, an integration program that was criticized at its outset four years ago by many military leaders and Government officials as using the services for a social experiment.

YONKERS, March 7 -- Cricket Folly's Brigadier, a trim fawn dog with some white on his neck, who won't be out of the puppy class until March 21, dominated the annual specialty show of the New York Boxer Club today at the Ramp.

JERSEY CITY, March 7 -- The Federal Government brought another weapon -- the Taft-Hartley Law -- into play here today in its war against crime and racketeering on the New Jersey waterfront.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss, a Naval Reserve officer, New York banker and a member of the Atomic Energy Commission in the Truman Administration, has been offered -- and likely will accept -- the post of executive assistant to President Eisenhower for consultation on atomic matters.
E. M. Forster's "Toward a Definition of Tolerance" (Feb. 22) was, for me, extremely provocative. I personally wonder how Mr. Forster can define a noun by using its verb.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 7 (UP) -- Automobiles occupied by dummies will be subjected to an atomic explosion in the test this month to see what would happen to persons sitting in cars during an attack.

SEVERAL years ago actors eager to get started in their profession were happy to work in the new medium of television for fifty dollars a show or, if lucky, a hundred. Today many performers, recommended and promoted by agents, work steadily in television at anywhere from several hundred to a thousand dollars show, having become featured players.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- The Government announced tonight that it would fire an atomic projectile from what is probably the world's first atomic cannon during the series of nuclear experiments that will start soon at the Nevada proving ground.

VINELAND, N. J., March 7 -- Within seven hours after two young armed robbers had attacked a Vineland grocery owner last night a man and his wife were arrested after an all-night search and charged with armed robbery and as an accomplice.

Spring planting starts in March and continues until June. The most important part of the season's work is seed sowing, primarily of flowers, vegetables and, perhaps, herbs. BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 7 -- Derailment of a freight car on the main New York to Boston line of the New Haven Railroad at Fairfield Avenue, here, at 3:38 A. M. today delayed some twenty-five passenger trains in both directions from one and one-half hours to half an hour. The tracks finally were cleared by noon. No one was injured.

The Long Island Sound skipper who has become Mister Cruiserman himself, William Edgar John of Rye, has taken over another yachting job. At the organization meeting the other night of the newly formed Eastern Cruiser Association he was elected the first commodore, another major post for this busy mariner who is also vice president in charge of cruisers for the American Power Boat Association and chairman of the A. P. B. A.'s cruiser racing commission.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- Plans for industrial plant facilities announced during February indicated an expenditure of $20,441,000 in the Chicago area, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported. Expansion programs announced during the first two months of the year amounted to $38,348,000, compared with $28,770,000 during the same 1952 months.

WEST POINT, N. Y., March 7 -- Army scored an exciting 5-to-4 hockey triumph before a capacity crowd of 1,600 at the Smith Rink tonight by defeating the Royal Military College of Canada.

PARIS, March 7 -- There is little doubt that the rather tenuous balance of the "cold war" is likely to be disturbed during coming weeks as a result of Joseph Stalin's death. The relative power of the opposing strategic political and economic forces will remain unchanged for a considerable time. But the psychological atmosphere has, perforce, become something different.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 7 -- Jim Plecas, a reserve forward, threw in a one-handed push shot from the right side as the final buzzer sounded to give the Yale basketball team a 70-68 overtime victory over Harvard at the Indoor Athletic Building tonight. Harvard had led many times during the game, by margins of 1 to 6 points, but each time the Bulldogs rallied to tie the score.

A Kingsbridge Veterans Hospital group of specialists in therapeutic radiology, surgery, physics and internal medicine -- whose collaborative efforts are stressed as the key to successful treatment -- has recruited a giant million-volt X-ray generator for a pinpoint attack on deep-seated cancer.
DETROIT, Mich., March 7 (AP) -- Kaiser-Frazer Corporation announced today development of a new automatic metering device for safely defueling aircraft gasoline tanks.

STOWE, Vt., March 7 -- Dartmouth's 19-year-old sophomore, Ralph Miller of Hanover, N. H., today defeated some of the world's foremost skiers in capturing the North American downhill championship. Mrs. Andrea Mead Lawrence, 20-year-old Rutland, Vt., mother, continued her domination in the women's competition by taking the women's title.

TRENTON, March 7 -- A plan for reorganizing the lower courts of New Jersey in an effort to improve their efficiency, and a proposal for increasing the salaries of some judicial and law enforcement officials were outlined here this week by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll.

SOMETHING new in photographic shows may be seen through March at the Camera Club, 121 West Sixty-eighth Street, where Dan Weiner hung his first one-man exhibition last week. Representative of his work during the past five years, the display comprises a series of themes on several phases of human experience seen through the understanding eyes of a photographer whose mastery of his craft matches his concern with the material he photographs.

A complete reorganization to insure a full educational program for all students is now taking place in the Westbury, L. I., public schools. Under the direction of Everett A. McDonald Jr., Superintendent of Schools, the school system is developing a new course of study and a new plan of programming. It is hoped that the new curriculum, which will permit students greater opportunity to choose their courses of studies, will reduce the rate of dropout.

The crux of Africa's problems of economic and social development is the native attitude toward land, according to Emory Ross, executive secretary of the African Committee of the Foreign Missions Division of the National Council of Churches.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (UP) -- Eighteen senators sought today to wean inland supporters away from legislation to grant to coastal states ownership of offshore lands by offering to confirm state control of lands under inland waters.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N. Y., March 7 -- There's a hot time brewing for Tuesday here when voters decide whether $930,000 should be spent for school construction. As a prelude, charges of irregular campaigning have been submitted to the Westchester County district attorney and sheriff and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
The dual-purpose plant--one in which planning of skills, layout and material flow makes possible almost-instant conversion from civilian products to war materiel--is a full-scale reality.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 7 -- Development of 8,000,000 kilowatts of additional electric power capacity -- equal to that of four gigantic dams like the Grand Coulee, the world's largest -- and the reclamation of 1,000,000 acres, about 1,500 square miles, of potential cropland in the Pacific Northwest, are among goals set for 1960 by Federal and state agencies of the region.

" IT'S almost as if the painters had become the patrons of the public," an artist remarked the other night as the conversation among a group of painters, sculptors and museum people turned to the huge group exhibitions which have become a commonplace of the national art scene.

Anniversaries are usually marked by celebrations, but last week one occurred of an event that nearly everybody wants to forget -- the national bank holiday. Yet, the twentieth anniversary of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's action in closing the nation's banks on March 6, 1933, affords an opportunity for contrasting banking and economic conditions now with what they were two decades ago.

MEXICO CITY -- A Catholic country that has retained clear traces of its pagan past, Mexico celebrates Easter with a unique combination of solemnity and spring festivities. Spring in this land of even year-round climate has never inspired the rites of colder latitudes, but Mexicans love flowers, decorations and gaiety at any time, and Easter time has become a special, traditional occasion for them.

COURTESY shown to visiting motorists this month by law enforcement officers in Florida is to receive due recognition in the form of prizes awarded by the Florida division of the American Automobile Association in a special month-long courtesy campaign. Ballots for the month-long contest will be furnished to visitors who drop in at A. A. A. offices throughout the state. The contest closes March 31.

OPERA is riding the crest of its popularity in America. More people are seeing and hearing opera this season than at any other time in our history. Audiences numbered in the thousands several decades ago now total millions. They have burst beyond the confines of the opera house and spilled into movie theatres, college and high school auditoriums, into civic centers as well as private living rooms equipped with a television screen.

NEWARK, March 7 -- More than $100,000 worth of salacious movies, photographs and books went up in flames here today in a demonstration staged by the Newark police and fire departments to "bring home the menace of pornography."
Headquarters of the Soviet delegation to the United Nations, 680 Park Avenue, was opened to the public yesterday for "expressions of condolences" on the death of Joseph Stalin.

ROME, March 7 -- Of eighty ecclesiastics who composed the Albanian Roman Catholic secular clergy at the advent of the Communist regime in November. 1944, fifty-four are known to have been killed and nineteen are in prison, according to the Catholic Fides News Agency, which quoted a "well-informed person who left Albania recently."

The Luther College Concert Band from Decorah, Iowa, gave a program late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall under the leadership of Weston H. Noble, its director for the last five years. The organization, which is celebrating its seventy-fifth anniversary this season, played in Brooklyn in 1914 and 1936, but this was its first appearance in Manhattan.

ON June 28, 1939, four-engine flying boat of Pan American Airways lifted off the waters of Manhasset Bay and headed for Europe. Master Pilot R. O. D. Sullivan was in command of the plane and twenty-two paying passengers, winnowed out of a list of more than 500 "first - flight applicants," were aboard.
The handling of big ships and major ocean terminals is a highly complicated science that will never be fully understood by the landlubber.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Voice of America's immediate difficulties stem from Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's pursuit of Communists and Communist sympathizers among its personnel. But actually the Voice has been a child of misfortune almost from birth.
Chance and a brave policeman combined last night to avert a possible death of a man and his son-in-law on the Third Avenue Elevated tracks.

MANY American gardeners who were, so to speak, in the primary grades a few years ago, now are steadily advancing into the upper class where specialists abound. The spring books announced by publishers give evidence of this, for there are more on hobby plants, or specialties, than on any other subject.

Although snow and frigid winds may yet sweep down from the north, The New York Times offers its Spring Garden Section to winter weary gardeners. It has four subdivisions in which are discussed current events and future trends in horticulture, basic garden problems, crops and flowers.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 7 (AP) -- Second Baseman Owen Friend clouted two homers, one a game-winning blow, today as the Detroit Tigers nipped the Philadelphia Phillies, 6 -- 5, in a ten-inning grapefruit league opener for both clubs.

Only in a Tru Balance girdle will you know the wonderful, comfortable secret of Natural Control. No other girdle but Tru Balance is designed to follow the natural flow of your body muscles. You look so much better, feel so much freer, are controlled so much more perfectly in a Tru Balance.

MY problem, sir, is this: What do I do now? We have this house, and a neighborhood gardener passed by one day and told me I'd better do something about the grounds because I've got to keep up with the Joneses. That's what he said.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The keeper of Government records reported today on a housecleaning project he said had saved the taxpayers nearly $4,00,000 in office space and equipment last year.

The fight between the truckers and the railroads has come into the open. Largely quiescent in the last few years while the railroads were backing legislation in many states for a weight-distance tax on heavy motor trucks, the trucking associations in the last few months have started striking back.

SUCCESS in America, not the solid achievement that made this country uniquely productive but the ephemeral, quick-silver, press-agented fame that feeds and fattens on its own hyperbole, that blows up beyond its capacities and goes pop at the first pinch of reality, revealing plenty of nothing -- this is the theme of "Prince Bart."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 7 -- United Nations diplomats wound up today their latest debate on Korea without even the formality of a new attempt to break the deadlock that has held up the signing of an armistice.

FREDERIC R. MANN is a peppery business man in Philadelphia who spends his spare time serving his city's welfare. Two of his major interests are the Department of Recreation and the Robin Hood Dell Concerts, and thanks to his enthusiasm, the twain have met to conduct an unusual experiment next summer.

Almost two and a half billion dollars in special stand-by war risk coverage has been issued to United States-flag steamship lines since this type insurance was made available by the Maritime Administration about six months ago.

DETROIT, March 7 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, joined with Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt today in rallying Michigan party workers to strengthen their organization during the lull before the 1954 Congressional campaign.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- The Chicago City Council's Crime Investigating Committee, seeking to determine whether any of the city's administrative and police officials are linked with organized criminals, is facing collapse under a challenge to its legal status.

Puccini's one-act opera, "Sister Angelica," was presented yesterday afternoon by the N. B. C. Television Opera Theatre. With its presentation, the network rounded out the triptych of one-act operas that Puccini designed for performance in a single evening, "Gianni Schicchi" and "The Cloak" having been televised earlier by the company.

ONE of our early musical adventures, back in Boston about 1912, was the discovery at a concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra of a strange and exotic-sounding pair of orchestral pieces, entitled "Gymnopedies," by one Eric Satie.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Two Republican Senators -- George D. Aiken of Vermont, and Charles W. Tobey of New Hampshire -- said today they favored dropping an Administration move to condemn Soviet Russia for enslaving free people.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 7 -- A new exhibition on "Horsemen of the Americas," featuring literature inspired by the cowboys of the United States, the vaqueros of Mexico and the gauchos of Argentina and Uruguay, has been opened in Princeton University's Firestone Library.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7 -- Paced, as usual, by Ernie Beck, Pennsylvania's basketball team defeated Cornell, 58 -- 50, before 5,702 tonight to assure itself of at least a tie for the Ivy League championship. The triumph also moved Penn a step nearer the N. C. A. A. tournament.

A STRANGE but interesting first novel has been written by George Lanning of life and love in the modern world. His central character. Herbert Komar, is a public accountant, 60 or so, a man who has spent most of his life in boarding houses a specimen of that urban isolation that borders on invisibility.

Dr. John F. Gummere, chairman of the Secondary Education Board, called on trustees of American schools and colleges yesterday to pool their knowledge and not jealously guard their trusts as "some pseudo secret." He urged them to form a group for the study of joint problems and understand that what helps one helps all.

Rarely has the death of one single man caused so much wishful thinking among so many millions of people. Yet wishful thinking is the only proper way in which to describe the innumerable theories which have been advanced following the announcement of Stalin's gradual death.
ALBANY, March 7 -- The century-old Washington Market on New York's lower West Side will be the subject of a study to be undertaken soon by the State Temporary Commission on Agriculture.
The annual National Antiques Show was preparing yesterday for its ninth consecutive edition, which will open at 1 P. M. tomorrow and run through next Sunday in Madison Square Garden.

" YOU ought to put it in a flower show," was her neighbor's verdict, as they stood admiring the prized African violet plant. This was no ordinary African violet -- at least, not in the eyes of its proud owner.

TOOLS for all too many gardens are scattered over the cellar or garage, some here, some there, with no thought of keeping them together conveniently. It is really a lot better to keep them all in one place, handy and orderly. A separate tool house is not necessary, although it is the ideal solution. Most gardeners, however, do not have enough tools to go to the expense of putting up a separate structure.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 7 -- Politics has produced many examples of the man who assumes dual executive functions and is said to "wear two hats." But this week Dr. J. M. A. H. Luns, chairman of the Netherlands delegation to the United Nations, cleared up the mystery about how two men wear the same pair of striped pants.
American holders of dollar bonds of foreign issuers recently got another slap in the face, although most of them don't yet know it.

With the first day of spring on March 21, more than 400 Columbia College alumni, their wives and -- for the first time -- their teen-aged children are expected to arrive on Morningside Heights to meet the deans and the faculty and enjoy a bit of intellectual recreation.

As soon as grass shows a tinge of green and the earth has thawed, gardeners and non-gardening home owners come out to survey their properties and plan what needs to be done to put them in order for outdoor living.

The University of North Carolina launched an unusual experiment in education last week when 200 faculty members got together for a "self-examination" conference on "The State of the University." For two days selected members of the faculty examined themselves and their institutions in relation to these four university objectives: research and graduate teaching, undergraduate teaching, student-faculty relationships and the integrated mission of the total university in the service of the state.

A GREAT many male readers, including this reviewer, have long been prejudiced against the Latham-Primrose novels of Leslie Ford. We've felt that the nebulous and protracted romance of Mrs. Grace Latham and Col. John Primrose received much more attention from the author than did the often fumbling plots and inadequate detection, and some have even unkindly suggested that the books should be classed as hammock romances rather than as mystery novels.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 179 casualties of the Korean war. The list included thirty-two killed, 139 wounded, six injured in accidents and one missing. One soldier previously reported as missing now was listed as captured by the enemy. The following are from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut:...

PRINCETON, N. J., March 7 -- A committee of nine state Democratic leaders, chosen at a party caucus in Trenton on Wednesday to select a nominee for Governor around whom all party elements could rally, met here today without achieving their aim.

BONN, Germany, March 7 -- The Federal Constitutional Court rejected today a plea by the Government parties asking a finding that the Allied-West German treaties were constitutional. In ruling the coalition's suit inadmissible, the court frustrated Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's hope that the constitutionality of the treaties would be upheld by the court before they came up in the Bundestag March 19 for their third and final reading.

WILLA CATHER had elements of greatness -- a heart wide enough to embrace all humanity, a quick, far-seeing eye and an ear that, miraculously, it seems, translated common speech into something one might have heard a moment ago and will remember all one's life.

An institution of learning with nearly 6,000,000 alumni -- the world-renowned International Correspondence Schools -- is celebrating its sixty-second anniversary this year. Built up chiefly through mail-order advertising, in which it pioneered, the institution's alumni list reads like a Blue Book of famous people.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 7 -- An important meeting of military chiefs of the free world will begin here Monday and continue for five days for the announced purpose of studying "certain problems that might be encountered in the defense of Europe."
When, in the near future, Hawaii achieves its long-cherished dream of statehood, the United States will acquire a state that is "healthy" not only economically, socially and culturally but actually.

MARY CONROY was a sturdy, forthright Missouri girl of Irish stock. By her eighteenth birthday in 1865 she had met and lost, temporarily, her true love -- not once, but twice -- and had sent a false love packing. Mary was described by the man she loved as a sunflower of a girl: "pretty and hardy.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 7 -- Andrei A. Gromyko returned today -- nobody is saying for how long -- to the job that pushed him into the spotlight of world diplomacy, the leadership of the Soviet delegation to the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Chinese, who know a great deal about the struggle of life, write the word "crisis" with two characters, the first of which means "danger," and the second of which means "opportunity."

PRINCETON, N. J., March 7 -- One of the most successful careers in Princeton hockey history ended today as Capt. Henry E. (Hank) Bothfeld sparked the Tigers to a 5-4 victory in their season finale against Dartmouth.

A COMBINATION of a rich cooky-like dough with boiled rice seems as unlikely a mixture as potatoes with noodles. But it turns out in actuality to be delicious when the rice is blended with strawberries in the manner detailed in the German cake (torte) recipe appearing here today.

WHEN the Eskimo families came down to Point Barrow, Alaska, to pick up supplies for the long winter ahead, Bob and Jeanie Hamilton had a fine reunion with their friend Oolak. The two American children joined Oolak and his family on the trip back to Beechy Point on the Arctic Ocean, finding life on the string of cargo boats a novel experience.

INTERNATIONAL uncertainties created by the death of Premier Stalin overshadowed domestic developments last week. Business and industry here were alert to any changes in United States policies which may result and to repercussions from establishment of a new regime at Moscow.

SILVER CITY, N. M., March 7 -- In curious contrast to the atmosphere of incipient mob violence that had pervaded this mountain mining town for a week, the Left Wing Hollywood group filming the controversial "Salt of the Earth" folded its gear and left town unmolested and virtually unnoticed today.

CAIRO, March 7 -- A Foreign Ministry spokesman announced tonight that the Egyptian Government had been informed that John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, would visit Egypt early in May.

If the passing of Premier Stalin is to lead to better relationship between Russia and the United States, the successor Soviet regime will have to do something about straightening out Russia's debt to the outside world.

LONDON, March 7 -- Diplomats and experts in psychological warfare here believe that the best chance for the Western democracies to exploit and profit from Stalin's death lies in the Far East where rivalry between Mao Tse-tung and the new dictators of Russia may lead, in their opinion, to a rift such as occurred between Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7 -- It was just the other night that Charles Dillon Stengel, the circuitous conversationalist, launched into an hour-long monologue. He opened with a discussion of Connie Mack and wound up in a Tulsa oil field. Baffled listeners still don't know how he got there because most of them had fallen off the sled after the first couple of sharp turns.

NOT since Johannes Gutenberg invented movable type has the air of the educational world been as charged as it is today with intimations of change. What fires the mind of many a topnotch schoolman with visions of a new day in pedagogy is television, arrived on the scene at the very moment when the shortage of teachers has become an acute worry and the costs of college a growing concern.

TYRONE POWER, as dashing a movie hero as ever fought off evil with sword and fist and received the meaningful kiss of a good woman, is now astounding the crowds who go to see "John Brown's Body," a performance of Stephen Vincent Benet's epic, in which the actors not only appear on the stage in person but also have to create the illusion of the whole Civil War without a prop.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The "secret agreements" resolution, designed by the State Department to be a propaganda weapon against post-war Soviet Russian foreign policy, now rests in a Senate committee pigeonhole where its text destined it to go, even before the collapse and death of Stalin made its propaganda value very doubtful.

COMMERCIAL nut production here in the Northeast is most conspicuous by its absence. For the home garden, however, where returns are measured in the pleasure of harvesting an edible nut crop rather than in dollars and cents, quite a number of nut trees more than pay their way.

A STORM of trouble was blowing over one of John Bull's uneasy islands in the Caribbean. A dark Messiah, Hercules Smith, had come out of Africa to save his people, and his hurricane campaign was making front-page news.

I WAS struck by a statement by Sean O'Casey in his recent front-page article in the Book Review: "For some curious reason, it is thought that the one who writes a book or composes a play must be a very special kind of soul; a soul that has been admitted to knowledge denied to even very intelligent people."

TO judge by the hullabaloo, everyone agrees that "Wonderful Town" is the best new musical of the season. Derived from "My Sister Eileen," this is the humorous antic in which Rosalind Russell gives a convulsing and ingenious performance.

Plans are being advanced rapidly for the entertainment known as the April in Paris Ball to be held on the night of April 20 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of various philanthropies here and in France. Mrs. William C. T. Gaynor and Mrs. Henry B. Hyde are co-chairmen of the New York committee and among their aides is Mrs. Winston F. C. Guest.

IN a story of New York family and school life Frieda Friedman tackles a problem that often vexes responsible parents everywhere. How far should they go to curb a child's volatile fancy and develop a regard for truth without destroying the sense of dramatic living that springs from imagination?

SEA CLIFF, L. I., March 7 -- After eighteen months of discussion, voters in the school districts of Glen Head, Glenwood Landing and Sea Cliff will go to the polls tuesday in the Se Cliff High School auditorium to decide if the three districts shall consolidate into one.

ALBANY, March 7 -- The Legislature has been asked to take the first step to make possible the storage of valuable foreign art treasures and documents in an abandoned iron mine in Columbia County. The old mine shafts have been converted since World War II by a corporation formed among area residents into storage vaults designed to be impervious to an atomic attack.

In the city of Moscow near the Red Square there stands what is described as a beautiful building, erected two or three generations ago to be a noblemen's club. In this building is a great room called the Hall of Columns and in this room whatever was mortal of the man born Joseph Vissarionovich Djugashvili lies in state.

ELIZABETH, N. J., March 7 -- Two men -- a bartender and a customer -- were shot dead shortly before noon today in the Shamrock Bar at 12 South Broad Street, diagonally across the street from the Union County Courthouse, in what the police believed to have been a hold-up that netted $53.
BALTIMORE, March 7 (UP) -- Native Dancer, the "horse of the year" last season and early favorite for the 1953 title, today headed a list of 135 nominations for the $100,000 added Preakness Stakes.

PARIS, March 7 -- The French Government order to half-staff the flags of military buildings and warships in tribute to Stalin and the eulogy to the late Soviet chief's war leadership delivered yesterday in the National Assembly by its President, Edouard Herriot, provoked a strong criticism from anti-Communists today.

RANGOON, Burma, March 7 -- The Government offensive against the Chinese Nationalists based in northeastern Burma after their retreat from Yunnan Province in the civil war with the Chinese Communists began officially at midnight last Thursday in Northern Shan State. The army drove toward Monghsu, where 2,000 Nationalist are stationed, and which, the War Office announced today, was captured after two hours fighting.

" THE longer I live," Thomas Hardy once wrote to Edmund Gosse, "the more does B[rowning]'s character seem the literary puzzle of the nineteenth century. How could smug Christian optimism worthy of a dissenting grocer find a place inside a man who was so vast a seer and feeler when on neutral ground?"

MOSCOW, March 7 -- Pravda, which ordinarily is issued in a four-page edition, appeared today in six pages, reaching the streets considerably later in the morning than is customary because of the extraordinary news it had to report in the aftermath of Premier Stalin's death.

With the news that Georgi M. Malenkov has succeeded to Stalin's former positions as the first man in both the Soviet Government and the Communist party, world attention centers upon him today. The manner in which he manipulates the reins of power that are now his, and the goals he pursues with that power, will affect the destiny of every human being on this planet.

HOWARD SWAN, a professional musician, is chairman of the Department of Music in Occidental College and a trained historian. His background explains his approach here, which is not technical but rather a way of looking at history through music.

IT would be a pity if so interesting and enthusiastic a volume on so fascinating a subject should be overshadowed by interest in the means by which it was produced. Albro Gaul's study of the insect world happens to be the first book to be printed without the use of movable type, on the Higonnet-Moyroud photographic type-composing machine.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 7 -- Harvard's hockey team won the Big Three title and tied Yale for second place in the Pentagonal League by defeating the Elis, 4 -- 2, before a crowd of 3,800 in the New Haven Arena tonight.

Joseph Rosenstock, who became general director of the New York City Opera Company last spring, has received a new contract that retains his services through May, 1954, Newbold Morris, chairman of the board of directors of the City Center of Music and Drama, announced yesterday.

SAN JUAN, P. R., March 7 -- Thirteen New York City and State officials called today for expanded Federal aid in all fields to enable Puerto Rico to speed the build-up of an economy that could "stand on its own feet and thus provide adequately for its people."

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 7 (UP) -- Without unlimbering their big guns, the Philadelphia Athletics defeated the Washington Senators in their exhibition opener before 2,036 today, 6 -- 2.

Dial. president of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation.

Editors of a new magazine called Latinitas are more than satisfied with the six hundred or seven hundred American subscribers their first number has picked up. That figure will not impress circulation managers of magazines who are claiming readers in the millions; advertising agencies will not be interested.

A new method of identifying obliterated mold numbers on bars of gold, which will make it much simpler for Government agents to trace "leaks" of the precious metal from legitimate channels into the black market, has been perfected by the United States Customs Laboratory at 201 Varick Street.
The recipients of twelve $3,000 fellowship awards for a year's residence at the American Academy in Rome were announced yesterday.

Sharp decline in prices of lead and zinc was largely responsible for the decline in net income last year of the American Smelting and Refining Company to $31,635,814 from $39,742,313 earned in 1951, according to the annual report to be issued today.

BONN, Germany, March 8 -- The German Center party denounced the Allied peace contract and the European Defense Community treaty today at its national convention at Cologne. The party's ten members in the Bundestag, the lower house of Parliament, have been instructed to vote against the pacts when they come up on March 19 for their third and final reading.

French moderns and a well-known British artist, Graham Sutherland, are sharing with United States painters and sculptors the large number of this week's art exhibitions. Recent paintings by Sutherland at Curt Valentini's and by Manessier at the Pierre Matisse Gallery will be shown beginning tomorrow.

MOSCOW, Monday, March 9 -- The body of Generalissimo Stalin was placed at rest at high noon today under the pink Kremlin walls in a mausoleum where lie the remains of Lenin, his revolutionary collaborator.
