While the cases are being investigated, the city will keep their names confidential, he added.

PARIS, March 8 (AP) -- French war veterans, among them soldiers who fought in Korea, will mount a guard around the tomb of France's Unknown Soldier tomorrow as a protest against the Government's order that flags should fly at half-staff during Stalin's funeral.
BAYARD, N. M., March 8 (UP) -- Fire damaged the local headquarters of the left-wing union that is sponsoring a controversial movie and set off a new dispute today between the union and authorities.

Howard Mumford Jones, Professor of English at Harvard University and author of several works of non-fiction, is represented on the publishing lists of two concerns. Set for April 16 is "The Pursuit of Happiness" (Harvard University Press).

Especially is this found true in the experience of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, 122 East Twenty-second Street, New York 10. Through the 185 agencies of New York Catholic Charities more than 430,000 needy men, women and children of every race and faith were reached during 1952.

AMSTERDAM, March 8 -- The Netherlands Bank last week published details of gold and foreign exchange reserves at the end of December as compared with the end of September in millions of guilders, as follows: gold, 2,060, against 1,234; convertible currencies, 544, against 1,090; European Payments Union currencies, 681, against 663, and non-convertible currencies, 375, against 400, for a total of 3,660, against 3,387.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat of Colorado, charged tonight that "powerful interests" were holding back color television from the public because they were more interested, for the present, in selling black-and-white receiving sets.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- The National (Railway) Mediation Board announced tonight the strike that has paralyzed the Chicago Great Western Railway for six weeks had been settled.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 8 -When Crown Prince Akihito of Japan boards the liner President Wilson at Yokohama March 30 to cross the Pacific he will occupy completely refurnished quarters newly named the Neptune suite.

ALBANY, March 8 -- Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore and State Controller J. Raymond McGovern accused New York City officials tonight of abandoning their responsibility for city finances and announced that the state would put into effect its own program for meeting urgent city revenue needs.
STOWE, Vt., March 8 -- Mrs. Andrea Mead Lawrence today disclosed once again that she's probably the foremost woman skier in the world.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, urged President Eisenhower today to withdraw his nomination of former Representative Albert M. Cole of Kansas to be the Government's top housing official.

It is regrettable that Secretary Durkin's fifteen-member industry, labor and public advisory committee began its consideration of possible changes in the Taft-Hartley Act with an argument over procedure that resulted in an immediate adjournment without consideration of their agenda on its merits.

With the production of petroleum in Western Canada expected to increase substantially this year to meet heavier demand at home, it is possible that the natural gas and petrochemical industries also will enjoy substantial growth that would compare favorably with oil, the Canadian Bank of Commerce reported yesterday in its monthly bank letter.

As the world of nature puts on new hues, homemakers may feel the urge to change colors in their houses. Repainting walls may seem a simple way. Some cautions, bits of advice and aids in developing color schemes, received from various sources, may make it an easy one.
Several hundred junior high school students, many of whom talked like psychiatrists, attacked yesterday the problem of vandalism in the public schools and parks.

Two Broadway theatrical successes were under attack yesterday -- one by organized lawyers, and the other-by organized chambermaids. The lawyers lost the first round of their battle; the chambermaids, appeared to stand a good chance of winning theirs. an deplored "the growing sensitivity of people to any sort of open and frank discussion of important issues."

Accusing the Communist nations of Europe of anti-Semitism, Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, urged yesterday that the United States use its diplomatic power to induce the Soviet Union to permit Jews to migrate from Russia and the satellite lands to Israel.

The 1953 eight-day appeal of the Bishops' Fund for Victims of War was opened yesterday by Cardinal Spellman, the chairman, with a pastoral letter read at all masses in the Roman Catholic churches of the nation.

Having gained recognition as a modern American classic, "Porgy and Bess" will begin its fifth New York engagement this afternoon at the Ziegfeld. Although the official opening is scheduled for tomorrow night, the sponsors, Blevins Davis and Robert Breen (the latter also served as director), have adopted a new wrinkle.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (UP) -- Representative Clare Hoffman, Republican of Michigan, said today that President Eisenhower's plan to raise the Federal Security Agency to Cabinet status would have to be accompanied by a wholesale ouster of holdover Democrats.

Attention is focused on the blouse this season because of the importance of the suit. A versatile blouse, such as any one of those illustrated here, can play an important role this spring. It can enhance the costume, if carefully selected.
MOSCOW, March 8 -- Sergei Prokofieff, the Russian composer, died Wednesday of a cerebral hemorrhage at his country home outside Moscow, it was learned today. He was 61 years old.

LONDON, March 8 -- One loophole in the Allied embargo on the delivery of strategic goods to Communist China -- but by no means all the loopholes -- will be plugged by the measures announced yesterday in a communique on the British-United States political talks in Washington.

Something cooled off the New York Knickerbockers yesterday at Madison Square Garden and the Boston Celtics sped to an 89-78 victory over the home quintet before 13,743 fans. The triumph cut to two lengths the Knicks' first-place lead over the Hub squad in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association. Each club has four games remaining on the schedule.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 8 (UP) -- The Athletics unveiled their two star pitchers today but the occasion was a big success for the Senators. Washington tagged Bobby Shantz for five runs in the first inning and went on to score a 13-10 victory.

SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., Monday, March 9 -- Two schoolgirls, one 5 years old and the other 8, who had been reported missing late yesterday afternoon from the Lakeside School of the Edwin Gould Foundation, a charitable institution for children just south of here, were found murdered last night in a near-by woods.

If a man disavows his religious heritage he must supplant the lack with "positive commitments" or be overcome by a spiritual vacuum, the Very Roy. Dr. James A. Pike, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, declared yesterday.

Churchgoers were urged yesterday by Bishop Horace W. B. Donegan of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York to maintain their "righteous indignation" at recent disclosures of corruption in the city.

CAIRO, March 8 -- A series of actions designed to encourage the flow of foreign capital and technicians into Egypt and to intensify the assault on some of the more pressing economic problems of the country was started last week by the Government of Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib.

The language of the official statements covering the outcome of the just-concluded British-American conferences in Washington is vague and general. There are no startling developments, no reversals of policy. There are no dramatic new commitments, but rather a further extension of previously agreed areas of joint concern and action.

The means of combating what was described as a widespread apathy to Jewish culture and traditions among many persons of that faith were discussed yesterday at the Second Greater New York Assembly on Jewish Education.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Monday, March 9 -- President Marshal Tito has left Yugoslavia amid secrecy on an "unofficial" visit to Britain, it was announced early today.

CHICAGO, March 8 -- Irregular price fluctuations marked the grain trade last week. Rains put pressure on new crop wheat deliveries. Small receipts brought moderate support to corn. Export sales of wheat have been large, but apparently they entailed little hedge lifting and consequently had no great effect on the market.

PARIS, March 8 -- The communique issued in Washington yesterday on the talks between high British and United States officials was read by European experts today as indicating Britain henceforth would cooperate more fully with this Continent in both the monetary and the defense spheres.

A realignment of merchandising responsibilities at Macy's New York, resulting from the resignation of Daniel Tate as merchandise administrator, was announced over the week-end by Wheelock H. Bingham, president.

The emphasis is on spring in the collection of Designs of Today wallpapers by Richard E. Thibaut, Inc., at its showroom at 44 East Fifty-third Street. The papers are comparatively moderate in price. The collection is marked by a delicacy of line, a lack of large-scale pattern and pleasant colorings.

Assailing the present city administration as the most reckless and extravagant since that of the late Mayor James J. Walker, Stanley M. Isaacs, the only Republican member of the City Council, yesterday urged the forces of good government to unite in the selection of a candidate for Mayor without regard to national party lines.

BONN, Germany, March 8 -- The Soviet Union has completed delivery of 500 tanks, enough to equip three armored divisions by Soviet standards, to the East German Army as part of a program to increase the striking power of the newest of the satellite armies.

DETROIT, March 8 (UP) -- Third-period goals by Gordie Howe and Tony Leswick enabled the Detroit Red Wings to gain a 3-1 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs and their fifth straight National Hockey League championship tonight at Olympia.
LONDON, March 8 -- The death of Premier Stalin has once again brought international politics to the forefront. The stock markets must bear this in mind when attempting to assess the future.

The Texas Company and the Gulf Oil Corporation have signed new agreements with the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., calling for 5 to 15 per cent increases in seamen's pay and other benefits, Neal Hanley, national secretary of the union, announced yesterday.

PARIS, March 8 -- The setting back from April 10 to May 1 of the opening of a single market for steel, which has just been announced by the coal-steel community's high authority, is considered here a consequence of French and German differences over fixing of coal and steel prices.

TRENTON, March 8 -- Clendenin Ryan, financier and crusader against crime, announced here tonight that he would be a candidate for Governor of New Jersey. He said he would file as an independent before the deadline on Thursday.

" Spring leading into summer" is the forecast for one small part of New York this week, for the thirty-seventh International Flower Show opened yesterday in Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets.
MADRID, March 8 -- For the twenty-fifth consecutive day there was not a cloud in the sky over Spain today from the Pyrenees to the Mediterranean coast.

I have read the recent article by Joseph J. Ryan, titled: "U. S. Loses Favor of Foreign Seamen." Unlike Mr. Ryan I cannot bring myself to shed crocodile tears on the fate of foreign seamen because of the questions on morals and politics put to them under the McCarran-Walter Act.

Now that the news has gotten out that William Faulkner, the man from Yoknapatowpha County who writes, has been plying his trade at a typewriter located on the very premises of his publisher on Madison Avenue, some serious thinking must be in process among not only publishing houses seeking to pry unborn or unfinished novels from authors disinclined to work but also among authors themselves.

TOKYO, Monday, March 9 -- United States F-86 Sabre jets flying protective cover for fighter-bombers over far North Korea yesterday shot down three of Red China's Soviet-designed MIG jets, probably destroyed one other MIG and damaged another.

HARTFORD, March 8 -- Col. Raymond S. Watt of Stratford, executive secretary to Gov. John Davis Lodge, was appointed today by the State Veterans Home Commission as commandant of the State Veterans Home at Rocky Hill, succeeding the late Col. Raymond F. Gates. The post pays $12,000 a year.

The alert news department of the National Broadcasting Company offered yesterday afternoon a thoroughly interesting visual documentary on the life of Stalin, including some forty-year-old newsreels of the regime of Nicholas II and of the earliest days of the Communists.

ALBANY, March 8 -- There were fewer motor vehicle deaths for each 100,000,000 miles driver in 1952 than ever before in New York's history, James R. Macduff, State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, reported today.

LONDON, Monday, March 9 (AP) -- The Moscow radio began relaying today a description of the funeral of Generalissimo Stalin, broadcast from the Hall of Columns near Red Square, where Stalin's body had been lying in state.

HONG KONG, March 8 -- Georgi M. Malenkov, new Soviet Premier, is already being presented in China as a man who needs no introduction. This preliminary build-up has been accompanied by a series of official statements in which the Peiping Government has served notice that Red China intends to stand resolutely by the Side of the Soviet Union even though Joseph Stalin is no longer at the helm in Moscow.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 8 -- Hoyt Wilhelm, who saved innumerable games for the Giants last year, lost little time revealing to a crowd of 7,113 onlookers today that he has by no means lost his magic touch.

A motion to "vacate and withdraw the proposed order to increase the Walsh-Healey Act minimum wage in the woolen and worsted industry from $1.05 to $1.20 an hour has been filed with Secretary of Labor Durkin, it was announced over the week-end by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -Young Americans of the Jewish faith were called upon today by President Eisenhower to "renew their study and their application of the ideals that belong equally to the traditions of America and to the ancient teachings of the Jewish religion."

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 8 (AP) -- Patty Berg played steadier than Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias and Louise Suggs today to win the Jacksonville women's open golf tournament with 214 -- two under men's par -- for the 54 holes. She had a one-under-par 71 on the final round.

Gross operating income of the Continental Oil Company last year increased to $397,185,390 from $379,793,015 in 1951, but earnings declined, according to the annual report of L. F. McCollum, president, and James J. Cosgrove, board chairman, released today.

Federal Bureau of Investigation agents raided a Bronx warehouse last night and arrested four men in the hijacking last Feb. 3 of a truckload of television and radio tubes valued at $500,000. Of the loot, tubes valued at $175,000 were recovered, according to L. V. Boardman, special agent in charge of the New York office.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Many influential voices in Congress were raised today in opposition to the proposal by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Republican leader of the Senate, for a full-scale Congressional inquiry into the conduct of the Korean war.

March continued to blow hot and cold in its second week, but reactions to its "effort here were on the chilly side. A few children and some hapless Parents were lured to the snowy slopes Central Park for limited winter sports, but most New Yorkers stayed at home with the persistent feeling that the advent of spring was not yet.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- President Eisenhower attended services at his home church today and heard a prayer that "the wisdom and strength to uphold what is right," be given him.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 8 -- Because tomorrow was set as the day of funeral services for Joseph Stalin it was uncertain tonight whether Andrei A. Gromyko, acting head of the Soviet delegation, would take part tomorrow in proceedings of the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

Lavrenti P. Beria, Soviet secret police chief, apparently has emerged as second in command to Georgi M. Malenkov, Chairman of the Council of Ministers, or Premier, as a result of the shuffle of the Soviet Government and Communist party high command announced Friday.

About 12,000 manufacturers, wholesalers, retailers and farmers from every state and from England, Canada, Alaska, Hawaii and Scandinavia have made reservations for the twenty-first annual convention of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors in the Atlantic City Auditorium, March 15 to 20.
The American merchant marine -- safest afloat -- still has the second highest accident rate of any industry, the Marine Index Bureau reported here yesterday.

ROME, March 8 -- Premier De Gasperi left tonight for Strasbourg to discuss plans for ratification of the European Defense Community treaty with the Foreign Ministers of the five other powers involved and especially with Foreign Minister Bidault of France and Chancellor Adenauer of West Germany.

Two operas - "The Rake's Progress" and "Der Rosenkavalier" -will receive their final performances of the season at the Metropolitan Opera during the nineteenth week, which begins on Monday, March 16. The week also will see the third performance of "Boris Godunov" and the season's first appearances of Blanche The-bom and Kurt Baum as the title singers in "Samson et Dalila."

WASHINGTON, March 8 (UP) -Representative Francis E. Walter, Democrat of Pennsylvania, said today in an interview that shipping companies had helped to smuggle Moscow-trained Communists and criminals into the United States.

For the first time in its history, no maternal deaths were reported last year at the Presbyterian Hospital of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, according to the hospital's annual report released yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Senator Robert A. Taft declared today that the prevention of any Communist onslaught in the Middle East was contingent on a permanent peace between Israel and the Arab nations and the economic up-building of the area.

The Harbor Carriers of the Port of New York at their annual meeting last week elected Thomas F. Horan as president for the coming year. Mr. Horan is president of the Horan Transportation Corporation, he succeeds Charles F. Kellers, president of the McWilliams Blue Line, Inc., who has served two terms as head of the organization.

BALTIMORE, March 8 (AP) -- Former Senator Millard E. Tydings said today that any letters of recommendation he had written for a cousin now under investigation for his conduct as an Internal Revenue official "were based upon my belief in his qualifications and fitness."

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -The Defense Department identified today 149 Korean war casualties, including twenty-nine dead, 101 wounded, six missing in action, eleven captured and two injured in battle zone accidents. The following casualties are from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

RIO DE JANEIRO -- The chorus of praise that greeted announcement of the $300,000,000 loan from the Export-Import Bank to cover Brazil's arrears on her commercial debts in the United States has faded out and been replaced by varied complaints about the amount of the loan and its conditions.

What had been regarded as one of the most closely knit of the advertising agencies came apart yesterday with announcement that Anderson Fowler Hewitt is resigning from Hewitt, Ogilvy, Benson Mather, Inc., "due to disagreement on policy decisions." Mr. Hewitt was one of the founders of the agency, one of its principal owners and up to his resignation had been chairman of the board and chief executive officer since July, 1952.

A conflict between citizens and plainclothes policemen in a Brooklyn bar and grill brought contradictory stories yesterday in Felony Court as to who struck the first blow and what happened after that.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8 -- The ball players do much more than loosen up their muscles in spring training. They also limber up their vocal chords and polish their repartee for the bench jockeying chores they will have to perform during the course of the season. The Yankees and Cardinals were at it again today after a brisk conversational workout in the opening game of the Grapefruit League competition yesterday.

The Puerto Rican Government in effect informed the estimated 100,000 to 150,000 potential voters of Puerto Rican background in this city that the executives remained politically neutral in the current Mayoralty maneuvers, as the first group of thirteen New York city and state officials returned yesterday from a San Juan conference on ways of easing Puerto Ricans' problems here.

Richard Loo, a young baritone from Hawaii, made his New York debut in a recital last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. Accompanied by Sergius Kagen, Mr. Loo sang music by Purcell, Handel, Duparc, Hahn, Poulenc, Schubert, Wolf, Hart, Swanson, Naginski and Kagen.

LONDON, Monday, March 9 (UP) -- The "heroic Korean people is defending the independence of its motherland in a stubborn struggle," Mr. Malenkov said. He added: "Courageous fights are being waged for national independence by the people of Vietnam" (The Communist forces in Indo-China).

TEHERAN, Iran, March 8 -- The Iranian reply to British proposals for settlment of the dispute over Iran's oil nationalization will be speeded up as a result of yesterday's Washington communiqu about the talks of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles and British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, the Government newspaper Bakhtar Emruz said tonight.
KARACHI, Pakistan, March 8 -- One man was killed and six were injured tonight as a result of firing by the police on an alleged unruly mob at Rawalpindi. The authorities have imposed a curfew.

It is four years since the Air Force at Mitchel Air Base, Long Island, stopped separating those of its garrison who were light-skinned from those who were dark-skinned. Today there are 27 Negro officers and 448 Negroes of other ranks in a complement of 8,000. As Lieut. Col. Howard E. Reed, the base personnel officer, explained, all airmen are put through a battery of aptitude and qualifying tests.

PARIS, March 8 -- Early in the morning of April 13, 1945, Premier Stalin learned of the death a few hours earlier of President Roosevelt. Later the same day he took the step, unusual for him, of receiving the United States Ambassador, Averell Harriman, to try to ascertain what the consequences of the succession of Harry S. Truman would be for the Soviet Union.

Principal foreign exchanges during the past week followed an irregular trend with the British pound sterling developing an easier tone and the Canadian dollar holding fairly steady. The market experienced no reaction from the sudden announcement of the illness and then the death of Premier Joseph Stalin.

La Salle will open the defense of its National Invitation Tournament title tonight in the middle game of another basketball triple-header at Madison Square Garden. The Explorers, seeded second to Seton Hall, will meet a St. John's quintet that survived the first round by upsetting St. Louis, 81 -- 66, on Saturday.

PITTSBURG, March 8 -- Here it is the last month of the first quarter with no signs of a falling off in steel demand or production. And at the rate new business was coming into the mills it seemed a sure bet that there would be no decline in the near future.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8 -- One of the few disappointments in the Yankees' triumphant campaign of 1952, Jim McDonald, right-handed pitcher, showed Casey Stengel today that he is determined to regain his spot among the world champion's starting pitchers as the Yankees downed the Cardinals, 5 to 2, at Lang Field before 4,229 sun-bathing fans.

The recent action of the Brazilian Government in creating a free exchange rate alongside the official exchange rate for the cruzeiro should lead to a solution of the blocked accounts held by United States exporters, Dr. Orozimbo Octavio Roxo Loureiro, commercial and investment banker of Sao Paulo, said last week.

Andrius Kuprevicius, Lithuanian pianist, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The serious young artist, who has concertized in Europe and South America, presented a carefully detailed series of interpretations in which he disclosed pianistic gifts of more than average merit, at times reaching real distinction.

The economic outlook is promising and challenging, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York declares in its annual report issued today. Signed by Allan Sproul, the bank's president, the report notes that by the end of 1952 the United States economy had largely completed the physical tasks of making room for an expected defense program the is expected to continue at high levels for some time.

SEBRING, Fla., Monday, March 9 (UP) -- A high-powered Briggs Cunningham sports car, clinging unshakeably to the lead for nearly eight hours, won the Florida International Grand Prix endurance race early today.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., March 8 -Off a snow-covered shore today the dinghies at the Larchmont Yacht Club set sail in the frigid but ice-free water.

The Golden Gate Quartet, which began in Norfolk, Va., and has gained fame for its Biblical narratives sung in close harmony with a strong rhythmic accent, celebrated its fifteenth anniversary last night by appearing as the stellar attraction in a program of gospel singing at Town Hall.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (UP) -Senator Karl E. Mundt, one of the "fathers" of the Voice of America, said today that the program had "definitely demonstrated its effectiveness" despite admitted mistakes.

Many of your readers must have been interested, as I was, in M. A. DeWolfe Howe's letter, published recently in THE TIMES, with its excerpt from the diary of George Templeton Strong describing the horrifying conditions among city children in 1851.

MONMOUTH, Ill., March 8 (UP) -- A New York woman summoned here by an urgent telephone call found the bodies of a middle-aged doctor and his wife in their home today and a coroner's jury later decided the doctor had killed his wife and then turned the gun on himself.

TOKYO, Monday, March 9 -Calm was reported today in the prisoner-of-war stockades on the islands off southeast Korea, where twenty-four die-hard Communist North Koreans were killed last week and forty-two injured during two mutinous outbreaks.

SUFFERN, N. Y., March 8 -- A state' of emergency was declared tonight by the police for residents of five estates in an exclusive community three and a half miles northeast of here after a break occurred in the natural gas pipeline constructed by the Algonquin Gas Transmission Company.

ALBANY, March 8 -- Republican leaders were said tonight to be planning to bring residential rent control to a vote in both the Senate and the Assembly this week to clear the way for adjournment of the Legislature by March 21.

Although they are committed to the cellar in the National Hockey League race, the New York Rangers made a considerable amount of trouble for the Canadiens of Montreal at Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The return of Vyacheslav M. Molotov to the international arena as Soviet Foreign Minister will give Secretary of State John Foster Dulles even less pleasure than Andrei Y. Vishinsky would have if he had remained Foreign Minister.

Ten chaplains on active duty with the armed forces were in a group of eighty-five who received theological degrees yesterday at a convocation in the Nathan Lamport Auditorium, Yeshiva University, Amsterdam Avenue at 186th Street.

The common lead pencil looks like a simple device but, as with many things, its appearance deceives. The pencil industry currently is grossing more than $40,000,000 annually in a competitive market led by four major producers.

CHICAGO, March 8 -- The American Bar Association announced today that Herbert R. O'Conor of Baltimore, former Democratic Senator from Maryland, had been chosen to take over the leadership of its fight against communism.

The National Labor Relations Board has authorized Charles T. Douds, its regional director here, to turn over to the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the United States Attorney's office any information that might be helpful in prosecuting crooked unionists or employers.
A new taxpayer on lot 25 by 70 feet at 452-54 East Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by John Ramagalia to Morris Friedman, operator, in a deal negotiated by Langsam Schiffman, brokers.

Chairmen of the various committees for the benefit luncheon and fashion show of the Nearly New Shop, which will be held on March 25 in the Plaza, will report on the progress of their committees at a tea to be given today by Mrs. Valentine Zahn in her home at 1010 Fifth Avenue.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 8 -- The thirteenth dog show of the Saw Mill River Kennel Club, the only one in the country without variety group or best-in-show competition, today brought disappointment to both of yesterday's main winners at specialty events.
Cotton prices in the domestic market again held to a narrow trading range last week, but closed the period mostly in firmer ground.

Mrs. Evans Hicks, wife of the dean at Peddle School in Hightstown, N. J., is somewhat perplexed. A woman who never cared for athletics, Mrs. Hicks finds her household teeming with sports activity and, to her amazement, she enjoys it. The explanation? She has two growing sons and a sports-minded husband.

United States Steel Company has sold 100,000 tons of steel products, including pipe for irrigation, to Israel for delivery over the next three years. This was described by Israeli trade representatives here as the largest, one-lump purchase of steel in Israeli history.

PITTSBURGH, March 8 (AP) -Harmarville trimmed the Brooklyn German-Hungarians, 5 -- 1, today in a fifth-round national open cup game. Brooklyn protested the game for failure of Referee Harry King of Philadelphia to appear.

" High Noon," the Western drama produced by Stanley Kramer and directed by Fred Zinnemann from a script by Carl Foreman, was voted the best picture of 1952 in the thirtieth annual poll of the nation's film critics, reviewers and commentators conducted by The Film Daily, trade publication.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 8 -- The Technicolor Corporation, working quietly, has developed its own three-dimensional system of photography, and Hal Wallis Productions has obtained the first commitment to use this device.
STRASBOURG, France, March 8 -- Premier Stalin's death and the advent of Georgi M. Malenkov have served to stimulate action here toward realization of a European union of states.
IPOH, Malaya, March 9 -- The Sultan of Perak today reprieved Lee Meng, 25-year-old Communist bandit leader, and commuted the death sentence against her to life imprisonment.
MIAMI, March 8 -- Russ Meyer, the so-called Mad Monk, blew his top only once today as the Dodgers made it two straight over their Boston cousins, the Braves, 4 -- 1, before 9,969 customers.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The farming industry, according to a Bureau of Census report, has been engaged in a steadily losing battle to maintain its population over a ten-year period beginning in April, 1940, with the result that the farm population dropped roughly 5,500,000 in that time.

A syndicate of investors organized by Daniel D. Cantor has purchased Blossom Gardens, a development of four garden apartment buildings at 133-11-27 to 133-16-36 Blossom Avenue and 42-60-68 to 42-84-98 Saull Street, in Flushing, Queens, from the Blossom Gardens Realty Corporation.
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 8 -An enthusiastic crowd observed as a national holiday today the anniversary of the French-Vietnamese agreements of March 8, 1949, that gave Vietnam its independence.

Brig. Gen. Ciro de Espirito Santo Cardozo, Brazilian Minister of War who is touring military installations in this country, was greeted yesterday by Cardinal Spellman at the Cardinal's residence, 452 Madison Avenue.

A mortgage of $1,826,500, insured by the Federal Housing Administration, has been placed on the Blair Hall apartments which were recently completed in Rego Park, Queens. The development was built by Blair Hall, Inc., Samuel Derfner, president, and comprises six-story buildings with 758 apartments.
BATON ROUGE, La., March 8 (AP) -- Sammy Snead today added the $10,000 Baton Rouge open to his list of victories with a final round of 71 for a 72-hole total of 275.

ALBANY, March 8 -- The State Health Department reported today that the first six months' operation of the controversial Metcalf-Hatch Law had been "highly beneficial to medical research" and had "in no way proved detrimental to animal welfare."

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The American Automobile Association said today in a report that it never had seen anything to equal the vacation tide of United States motorists. During the year, the association predicted, 66,000,000 persons will climb into 22,000,000 cars and set out to see the sights.
A small but delicious demonstration of Great Britain's desire for "trade not aid" is a little package of its traditionally celebrated kippers in a new form -- cooked, skinned, boned, frozen.
It is still too early to determine what part of the current "credit boom" is temporary, the National Industrial Conference Board says in a survey issued for publication today.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Val Peterson, the new Civil Defense Administrator, said tonight that it might be necessary to draft men and women into Civil Defense work.

It was a lavish assemblage of imports that Bergdorf Goodman showed yesterday morning in its fourth-floor showroom. The collection told the story of the spring and summer trends as developed in France, England and Italy. There were several examples of Dior's "tulip" silhouette, which widens over the bosom and tapers into a very slim waist.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Supreme Court ruled 6 to 3 today that an employer who discharged an employe for refusing to cross another union's picket line at a customer's plant was protected by his contract with the offending employe's union.

La Salle's defense of the National Invitation Tournament basketball championship ended abruptly at Madison Square last night, when the Redmen of St. John's registered a 75-74 upset over the Explorers of Philadelphia to gain the semi-finals. The setback, only the Explorers' third in twenty-eight games this season, was a severe shock to La Salle's followers, who bitterly criticized the officiating.

Thirty copies of a ten-page brief, outlining the necessity, purpose and application of twenty-two proposed bills to amend the theatre building code were sent yesterday by James F. Reilly, executive director of the League of New York Theatres, to the City Hall office of Councilman Thomas J. Mirabile, chairman of the City Council's Building Committee.

ALTHOUGH one swallow doesn't make a summer, two first novels published within two weeks of each other offer heartening evidence that things are looking up below the Mason-Dixon Line as far as fiction is concerned. The young Southern writers who have been competing with each other to see who can imagine the most gruesome psychological horrors and explore the most noisome extremes of degeneracy no longer have a near monopoly on Southern literary talent.

Everything has its season -- hunting, fishing, skiing, oysters and reading in bed. No legal seasonal limitations, such as are drafted for fishermen, apply to the pastime of reading in bed, but it can be said that the season for reading in bed now is on the wane.

Booming sales in the final two quarters of 1952 could not overtake the declines in the first half and American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation reported consolidated net volume of only $277,153,664, against $305,111,668 in 1951. Sales of foreign subsidiaries, not consolidated, were $73,835,468 against $66,298,830.

ROME, March 9 -- While Communists and neo-Fascists battled in the streets of Rome, large numbers of Communist workers interrupted their labors for twenty minutes this morning during the funeral in Moscow of Joseph Stalin.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 9 -- Columbia came to the end of the trail in its fruitless pursuit of the Eastern Intercollegiate League basketball crown tonight. Faced by a resourceful Princeton team, the Lions found themselves outfought and outgeneraled as they went down to a 70-to-58 defeat before 1,100 persons at Dillon Gymnasium.

Sylvia Siegler, president of the Show of the Month Club, filed yesterday a $3,000,000 treble damage civil antitrust suit in Federal Court charging the Shubert Theatre interests with violation of interstate commerce regulations in having denied her organization access to theatre tickets.
George M. Pottenger has been promoted to assistant vice president and division sales manager of the chemical division of the Koppers Company, Inc.

Once again, yesterday, the stock market opened with a show of bullish enthusiasm, failed to attract a following and ended with a negligible net change. This time the movement in THE NEW YORK TIMES averages was upward, but only barely so.

Judge Harold R. Medina of the United States Court of Appeals indicated yesterday that when he hands down a decision in the investment banking anti-trust case being tried in his court he would not rule on the legality of the price maintenance clauses generally used by the investment banking business.

JERSEY CITY, March 9 -- Charged with conspiracy and violation of the Taft-Hartley Act through payments of $16,400 to insure labor peace on the Hoboken docks, Douglas E. Yates, a vice president of the Jarka Stevedoring Corporation, was paroled in custody of his attorney late today by United States Commissioner M. Lester Lynch here.

ALBANY, March 9 (AP) -- Governor Dewey commuted to life imprisonment today the death sentence of Al Keshner, a garment manufacturer convicted of arranging an insurance fire that caused a detective's death. Keshner, 43 years old, had been scheduled to die in the Sing Sing electric chair Thursday night.

Saks-34th has been named "Brand Name Retailer of the Year" in the women's specialty store category of the fifth annual contest sponsored by Brand Names Foundation, Inc., Henry E. Abt, president, announced yesterday.

LONDON, March 9 (AP) -- Following are translations of the orations by Premier Georgi M. Malenkov, Deputy Premier Lavrenti P. Beria and Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov at the funeral of Joseph Stalin in Moscow today, as broadcast:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 9 -- Warner Brothers announced today the "perfection" by studio technicians of a multi-track sound recording and projection system, which, the studio says, matches in depth and range the "hearing power of the human ear."

At 2:45 in the morning a year ago today Gen. Fulgencio Batista drove into Columbia Barracks, outside of Havana, and became Dictator of Cuba. Some Cubans are celebrating today, and all are taking stock.

GUATEMALA, March 9 -- The United Fruit Company filed a suit in the Supreme Court today for an injunction against President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman over the seizure of 207,400 acres of its Pacific Coast holdings. President Arbenz, the final arbiter in agrarian reform conflicts, denied the company's appeal, saying it was exempt from the agrarian law.

Pursers and purser-pharmacist on passenger and cargo ships under contract with the Staff Officers Association of America, A. F. L., have received a 9 1/2 per cent increase in basic wages, plus 5 per cent on over-all pay. The action resulted from union wage review talks with the Committee for the Companies and Agents, Atlantic and Gulf Coasts.
Record attendance was reported yesterday at the opening of the American Toy Fair at the New Yorker and McAlpin Hotels and at the International Toy Exhibit at the Governor Clinton Hotel.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., March 9 -- By substituting sound business management for political control, this "All American" city of 32,500 has repealed a sales tax, improved local services and ended 1952 with a $493,000 surplus, Robert P. Aex, City Manager, reported today.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 9 -- Stun Musial walked through the gate, glanced at the shy kid in a Braves' uniform and put out his hand in greeting.

In the new four years the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago expects to raise about $280,000,000 of new capital to help finance a $500,000,000 construction program during the period, Charles Y. Freeman, chairman, and Willis Gale, president, told stockholders in the annual report issued today. They added, however, that no conclusion had been reached as to the type of securities to be issued or when they would be sold.

STRASBOURG, France, March 9 -- Quoting the words of George Washington on the difficulties in drawing up the United States Constitution, Paul-Henri Spaak of Belgium, chairman of the special European Assembly, presented today the draft of a European constitution to the foreign ministers of France, West Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The right of the Army to withhold an officer commission from a soldier whose loyalty has been questioned was upheld today by the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Administration and Congressional Republicans are cautiously examining the possibility of putting through Congress a resolution denoucing Soviet enslavement of people but making no mention of wartime agreements with the Russians signed by Democratic Presidents.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 9 -- On the heels of the accession to power of Premier Georgi M. Malenkov, a long standing exponent of party "purity" and ruthless discipline, the Dutch Communist party has made its first overt move to put down criticism within its ranks of the Soviet Union's recent policy on Jews.

BERLIN, March 9 -- To the sound of countless shuffling feet and periodic funeral marches several hundred thousand silent East Berliners trooped past top East German and Russian officials today in honor of Stalin.

WILMINGTON, N. C., March 9 (UP) -- Wind-fanned fire today burned out the heart of the Wilmington waterfront, injuring twenty-one persons, two critically, causing possibly $15,000,000 in damage and jolting the city with explosions.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Senate Permanent Investigating subcommittee brought to light today plans for early public inquiry into why ninety-six merchant vessels on which the United States holds $25,000,000 in mortgages continue to carry and deliver behind the Iron Curtain materials used largely against American and United Nations troops in Korea.

CHICAGO, March 9 -- Light to fairly heavy rains in the dry sections of the Southwest caused a rather sharp price recession in wheat futures, and this sapped the strength in other grains. A sharp decline in rye on what seemed to be heavy long liquidation was also an unsettling factor.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Supreme Court, in a 7-to-0 decision, ruled today that Dr. Edward A. Rumely, executive secretary of the Committee for Constitutional Government, was not in contempt of Congress when he refused to disclose the names of persons who had bought books in amounts of $500 or more from his organization.
TOKYO, Tuesday, March 10 -- United Nations troops lost and then regained an outpost position northwest of Kumhwa, on the central Korean front, after four hours of stiff local fighting yesterday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady yesterday rising 1 to 5 points on active months.

ALBANY, March 9 -- The Assembly passed unanimously and sent to Governor Dewey tonight two bills increasing the amounts that life insurance companies may spend for expenses, including the training of agents and security benefits for employes.

Subway passengers will be able to ride from Flushing, Queens, to Times Square in two minutes less than the usual time when two "superexpress" trains begin operating on the I. R. T. Flushing line on Thursday morning.
CHICAGO, March 9 (AP) -- Three California onion farmers say they have made a total paper profit of approximately $180,000 in trading on the Chicago onion market during the last ten days.

TRENTON, March 9 -- Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons threatened today to institute legal proceedings against The Saturday Evening Post unless it "willingly" withdrew an article scheduled for publication in the March 21 issue.
HAVANA, March 9 (AP) -- Cuba's textile mills say the Government's campaign against smuggling cloth into Cuba is bearing fruit.
Shipping officials are studying the possibility of seeking from labor unions a new system of nationwide bargaining at the same time each year as a limiting influence on recurrent work stoppages.

Two new films will arrive in first-run theatres today. At the Fifty-second Street Trans-Lux, the attraction is "Lili," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer romantic comedy-drama in Technicolor with Leslie Caron, Jean Pierre Aumont, Mel Ferrer, Zsa Zsa Gabor and Kurt Kasznar.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The British financial mission informed this Government during the recent discussions here that the economic mud military objectives of the British-American alliance could not be realized unless it was made easier for Britain and the rest of the world to earn dollars by selling goods and services in this market.
The Communist version of the transfer of power -- the king is dead; long live the king -- is occurring with seeming smoothness and surprising speed.

The State Legislature has passed a bill which would authorize the Commissioner of Health and the Commissioner of Housing and Buildings in the City of New York, by a joint certificate, to permit the continued occupancy until July 1, 1955, of certain cellar and basement rooms and apartments which are now illegally occupied.

The twice-canceled debut concert of a new chamber orchestra conducted by Franz Allers, which originally was scheduled to take place under the auspices of the New Friends of Music, will be heard on Easter Sunday afternoon, April 5, at Town Hall.

In her spring custom collection shown yesterday at 6 West Fifty-seventh Street, Sally Milgrim favored a waistline lowered ever so slightly and a silhouette slim to the front and width, in almost every case, some form of back movement.

A wooden plaque carved in the shape of a trefoil, the Girl Scout emblem, was presented yesterday to the Girl Scouts of the United States as a birthday gift from the Boy Scouts of America. A picture of President and Mrs. Eisenhower adorns the center of the plaque.

The approach of March 15 makes us acutely aware of the impact of federal income taxation. There is another date on the tax calendar of March which is significant. March 1 marked the fortieth anniversary of the origin of our national income tax system.

Rear Admiral William S. Maxwell, retired, chairman of the board of American Friends of Russion Freedom, Inc., appealed yesterday for an awareness by the American people that the manifestation of friendship for the Russian people can be a positive step toward peace.

PARIS, March 9 -- The Government proposed today a reduction in income tax rates to encourage honesty. The proposal was contained in a bill submitted to the National Assembly to reform the country's tax structure, which has been criticized as unwieldy and ineffective.

PARIS, March 9 -- In the hope that the visit to Washington last week of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden will have induced the British to go further in backing the European army treaty, the French Government plans to send a new note on the subject to London within a few days.

LONDON, March 9 -- New hope for the release of Edgar Sanders, the British business man serving a prison term in Hungary, following his conviction for alleged espionage, was raised today by the action of the Sultan of Perak in commuting to life imprisonment the death sentence passed on Lee Meng, 25-year-old woman Communist bandit leader in Malaya.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 9 -- State Democratic leaders, chosen at a party caucus in Trenton last week to select a candidate for Governor who would be acceptable to all factions of the party, held their third meeting here tonight without reaching a decision.

It is no accident that the family clothing store has become a significant distribution outlet in recent years, scoring a volume gain at the expense of the department and men's-wear store, says the March issue of "The Bach Letter." The publication is the house organ of Henry Bach Associates, Inc., ad agency.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., March 9 -- The Army's winter training maneuvers, Exercise Snowstorm, will come to an end here Thursday when the 505th Regimental Combat Team completes a three-day field problem against an aggression force.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 9 -- It is believed in Belgrade that President Marshal Tito, who is traveling by ship to Britain, intends to convey to the British certain fears held here about United States policy in the Far East.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 9 -- The Pacific Gas and Electric Company has just spent its billionth dollar on a post-war construction program, 74 per cent of which has been financed by the sale of securities and 26 per cent from internal sources.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Witnesses before a Senate inquiry committee testified today that the Soviet Union was doing "a bigger job" than this country in circulating propaganda books and pamphlets in Europe and the Middle East.

Two five-story apartment houses at 8-10 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn, have been sold by Samuel Globerman to clients of S. J. Hodes, attorney, for cash above mortgages of $90,000 in a transaction negotiated through Engelman Co., brokers.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Southern Democrats led the opposition to statehood for Hawaii today as Republican leaders sought to push the bill through the House for the third time.

WASHINGTON March 9 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, said after a White House meeting today that he believed chances were good for agreement by the Senate, the House of Rpresentative and the Administration on about fifteen changes in the Taft-Hartley Law, some of them "substantial."
The Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington was asked yesterday to state exactly what it meant by Minklers Corners, N. Y.

The United States Maritime Service Training Station at Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, has adjusted its curriculum to give greater prominence to the training of active licensed and unlicensed personnel needed to man the fast, modern freighters of the Mariner class.
MIAMI, Fla., March 9 -- For the first time in two years the Dodgers beat Robin Roberts as they outscored the Phils, 6 -- 5, tonight in a three-hour contest under the Miami Stadium lights.

Senator Taft displayed a capacity for sound second thought when, after a White House conference of legislative leaders, he denied ever specifically advocating a broad Congressional investigation of the Korean war. He originally implied, at least, that an investigation deal not only with the conflicting statements about an "ammunition shortage" in Korea but also with most other aspects of the war, including its strategy, the armistice negotiations and the handling of enemy prisoners of war.

A suit for $3,600,000 damages was started yesterday in Supreme Court against the Pan American Airways. The action resulted from the crash of the Yankee Clipper, which was carrying a group of United Service Organizations performers when it crashed into the Tagus River, near Lisbon, Portugal, Feb. 23, 1943, killing twenty-four and injuring a number of others.

The Presbytery of New York announced last night that the Rev. Dr. Wesley Megaw, minister of the Fort Washington Presbyterian Church since 1925, had accepted a call to the pastorate of the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.

MOSCOW, March 9 -- At the funeral of Joseph Stalin today, Premier Georgi M. Malenkov pledged to the Soviet people today that his Government would maintain peace and bring them an ever higher standard of living.

An investing syndicate headed by Bernard Friedman has purchased the fifty-five-family apartment house which was built about three years ago at 314-18 East Mosholu Parkway South, the Bronx. It was sold by a client of James Leibman, lawyer, for cash above mortgages of $342,000. Mrs. Anne Inselstein was broker in the sale.
TUCSON, Ariz., March 9 (AP) -- Outfielder Larry Doby and Pitcher Early Wynn ended holdouts today, accepting 1953 Indian contracts that increased their salaries around $5,000 each.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Bonwit Teller, Inc., of New York, today was denied a Supreme Court review of a decision that it had committed an unfair labor practice by not giving a union permission to address employes on company, time and property. The original decision was given by the United States Circuit Court in New York. Bonwit Teller permits no union activities in its stores.

Blood transfusions given to a 13-year-old boy at Sydenham Hospital on a court order overruling the religious objections of his parents appeared last night to have saved the lad's life from dangerous complications following an appendectomy.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 9 -- Reversing a position taken on Jan. 26, Republican leaders of the Westchester Board of Supervisors recommended today a withdrawal of the county's objections to the plan of Governor Dewey for conversion of state institutes of applied arts and sciences into local community colleges.

ALBANY, March 9 -- Governor Dewey announced tonight without disclosing any details that he would submit to the Legislature a state administration program for solving New York City's financial crisis in a series of special messages later this week.
ALBANY, March 9 (UP) -- The State Commerce Department today reported the following ski conditions at New York resorts:

ALBANY, March 9 -- The proposed residential rent control bill was amended today by the Temporary State Commission on Rents and Rental Conditions to delete a new provision that would have authorized automatic rent increases to offset any increases in real property taxes.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Diplomatic officials watched closely the first speeches of Russia's new leaders today for signs of any change in major Soviet policies. They reported finding few.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the law enacted by Congress in 1951 to require the registration of gamblers and the purchase of a $50 tax stamp was constitutional.

MOSCOW, March 9 -- In the vastness of Red Square, filled by a multitude, there was a moment of silence. Then the great golden hands of the clock high in the Spassky tower of the Kremlin pointed straight up. With one voice the tower's iron bells and the steel salute guns of the Kremlin began to speak in crashing tones.

The George Polk Memorial Awards for 1952 have been voted to six newspapers, a magazine and a television program by the journalism department of Long Island University, Dr. William Marion Hudson, acting president, announced yesterday.

In Washington it now appears that an effort will be made to revive the "secret agreements" resolution but without any reference to secret agreements. The original resolution took the form of a policy statement of the Administration and Congress denouncing Soviet Russia's perversion of the wartime understandings reached at Yalta and Potsdam.

CHICAGO, March 9 -- The United States Court of Appeals reversed today and remanded for a new trial the convictions of the Chief of Police and two other police officers of Cicero on charges of violating civil rights in connection with a race riot in the Chicago suburb in July, 1951.

The measures taken to reduce the element of danger in some household appliances were described yesterday by Miss Mildred C. Sommer of the Underwriters Laboratories, Inc., at a luncheon of the Twentieth Century Club in the Masonic Temple, Richmond Hill, Queens.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 9 -- The Security Council will meet Wednesday to try to reach agreement on a candidate for Secretary General of the United Nations acceptable to both the Western powers and the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- The Senate passed and sent to the White House today a bill to correct a blunder that would have force the demotion of about 5,400 junior naval officers.

The National Broadcasting Company has agreed to give Alben W. Barkley's regular fifteen-minute time period on television next Sunday, to a Florida Senator who disagreed with Mr. Barkley's statements of March 1.
TOKYO, March 10 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1549, for the twenty-four-hour period ending at 6 A. M., Tuesday, Korean time:

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 9 (AP) -- C. W. Winters' Whirla Lea, showing improvement over recent engagements, gained her first triumph of the winter season as she captured the first division of the Osceola Purse before 19,245 at Gulfstream Park today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 9 -- After a lapse of two years, the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly resumed today its efforts to learn the fate of about 3,000 members of the Greek armed forces, allegedly detained against their will in the Soviet Union and in Balkan countries, with the exception of Yugoslavia.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 9 -- United Nations delegates voted approval today of Korean assistance programs planned to help repair the destruction of war and put the country on a firmer economic basis.

HONG KONG, March 9 -- A vote of confidence in the Soviet Union under Georgi M. Malenkov's new leadership was registered today by Mao Tse-tung in a memorial article eulogizing Premier Stalin for his "theoretical and practical" contributions to the world Communist revolution.

Dr. Abraham Granott, chairman of the board of directors of the Jewish National Fund in Jerusalem, land reclamation and development agency of the World Zionist Movement and the State of Israel, arrived here by airplane yesterday.

When the doors of Grand Central Palace open at 10 A. M. this morning, spring, in the guise of the thirty-seventh International Flower Show will be waiting for anyone who wishes a preview. And until the doors close at 10 P. M. tonight, some of those who come will be gardeners from the suburbs, others city people who ask only to see flowers in bloom.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Representative Harold H. Velde, Republican of Illinois, chairman of the House of Representatives Committee on Un-American Activities, declared tonight that it was "entirely possible" his group would investigate reports of Communist infiltration of churches next year.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., March 9 (AP) -- A reactor, or atomic furnace, capable of producing useful amounts of electric power has been developed here.

Brig. Gen. John Reed Kilpatrick, president of Madison Square Garden, yesterday forwarded a letter of protest to Carl Voss, referee-in-chief of the National Hockey League, regarding the injury sustained by Eddie Kullman, New York Rangers' forward, against the Montreal Canadiens last Sunday night.

After its triumphant foreign tour the current version of George Gershwin's "Porgy and Bess" has settled down in the Ziegfeld Theatre, where it opened yesterday afternoon. If any proof were needed that foreign travel enriches a tourist's art, this production brings all the proof anyone needs.

The one-story factory with second floor offices on a plot 100 by 100-feet at 207 Railroad Avenue in Harrison, N, J,, has been sold by the Harrison Engineering Company to the Fidelity Tool and Machine Company through J. I Kislak, Inc., broker.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UP) -- The Senate voted 64 to 18 today to approve former Representative Albert M. Cole, Republican of Kansas, as Federal housing chief after Democrats attacked him as an enemy of public housing.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Congress is generally composed of citizens whose days are fully given over to official labor, largely collective, and who as individuals are obliged to continue their work after sessions. But the night school of a group of Senators that lately has come into being is something added as well as something new.

At a public hearing before the Board of Health yesterday, representatives of the dairy industry urged repeal of the regulation requiring the dating of milk and prohibiting its sale more than forty-eight hours after the day and hour appearing on the bottle cap or container.

Three four-story tenements with stores on a plot 50 by 88 feet at the northwest corner of Eighth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street have been sold by-the Hemmer-dinger Realty Corporation to the Realty Surplus Corporation, which plans to alter the property into modern apartments.

Six Japanese museum curators, who accompanied a priceless collection of their native art to this country a few months back for a tour of five museums, were at the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday, preparing the collection for its New York showing.

BONN, Germany, March 9 -- West German economists are drawing up plans to raise the level of investment and consumer spending as a precautionary measure against possible repercussions from the deterioration of Western Europe's economic situation.

Public offering of 300,000 shares of General Telephone Corporation common stock is being made today by a syndicate of investment houses headed by Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis; Mitchum, Tully Co. and Stone Webster Securities Corporation. The stock is priced at $37.875 a share.

Stalin's funeral yesterday closed one Soviet era and began another. The three triumvirs, Malenkov, Beria and Molotov, appeared before the populace to assert the legitimacy of their succession. Stalin had trained them, they argued, and the people need have no fears. Stalin had shown the road, and they would follow it.

Uncertainty over the fate of legislation to compel automobile owners to carry liability insurance in New York State raises the question whether our Legislature is elected to represent, and make laws for, all the people or a minority with special interests. The question is put vividly by the position taken by Senator Walter J. Mahoney of Erie County, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee and one of the most influential Republican leaders.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Robert B. Anderson, Secretary of the Navy, has arranged for the retention on active duty of Capt. Hyman G. Rickover, expert on atomic propulsion for war vessels, for another year and his consideration for promotion to the rank of rear admiral by a selection board that will meet in July.
ST. LOUIS, March 9 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture officials disclosed today they had a new method for producing Dextran, a blood plasma extender, that might reduce its cost.

A dozen teams will square off tonight in four preliminary elimination basketball tournaments to trim the field for the National Collegiate Athletic Association regional playoffs on Friday and Saturday.
Japan is about to undo one of the most controversial accomplishments of the Allied occupation forces.

PARIS, March 9 -- The first significant indication of the attitude of the Malenkov regime in the Soviet Union is its effort to reassure the outside world of Moscow's desire for peaceful co-existence with other systems of government and to urge the Communist parties abroad to press purification in their ranks because this is a time for "greater vigilance."

ATLANTIC CITY, March 9 -- Unaccustomed serenity prevailed today on school buses here as drivers ended the strike called last Friday in protest against rowdyism by students of the Atlantic City High School. Gone were the roughhouse, switch knives and fist fights that had plagued the bus men.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 9 -- Ernie Beck, Pennsylvania's all-America center, scored 27 points tonight to pace a 77-49 victory over Harvard as the Quakers gained their first Ivy League basketball title since 1945 and earned a berth in the N. C. A. A. tournament.

The Celanese Corporation of America yesterday reported for 1952, a net income of $9,214,367 after taxes, equivalent to 77 cents a share on the common stock. This compares with $24,800,263, or $3.56 a common share, in 1951. Sales declined to $166,711,033 from $202,651,014 in 1951.

LONDON, March 9 -- A fresh advance by British Government securities was the main feature of business on the Stock Exchange today. In other markets, while the undertone stayed firm, profit-taking imparted a rather irregular appearance to final prices.
STOWE, Vt., March 9 -- The East definitely will be represented in the National Alpine Championships at Aspen, Colo., next weekend.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio and Senate majority leader, ranged himself today on the side of those opposing a full-scale Congressional investigation of the conduct of the Korean war. Remarks he made at the Capitol last week made it appear he might favor such an inquiry, and his comments kicked up a flurry of excitement over the week-end.
SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., March 9 -- The knife used on one of the two schoolgirls slain near here was sought today as a clue to Rockland County's murderer, apparently a mental case.

New York's organized chambermaids swept to a victory of sorts yesterday when producers of the Broadway play "Mid-Summer" agreed to insert a paragraph in their printed programs disavowing any resemblance between domestics of today and the one appearing in their drama.

Prices closed generally higher yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges in continued light volume. Rubber was fairly active and potatoes and the No. 6 sugar market were moderately active. Potatoes, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, wool, lead and zinc were higher.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 9 (AP) -- W. A. (Dub) Pagan, West Palm Beach fireman, opened defense of his title in the forty-sixth annual south Florida golf championship today with a four-under-par 66 to win the medal in a field of fifty-two starters.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 9 -- Iran will reply to British oil-settlement proposals by the end of the week, the Government newspaper Bakhtar Emruz announced tonight. Premier Mohammed Mossadegh promised this to United States Ambassador Loy W. Henderson at their meeting today, according to the paper.

ALBANY, March 9 -- A broad revision of state aid programs for welfare and tuberculosis care was proposed tonight by Governor Dewey's Administration. On the basis of this year's case loads, the effect of the program would be to increase state assistance to localities by nearly $5,000,000, of which almost $2,400,000 would go to New York City.

All citizens concerned with the health and welfare of young children were urged yesterday by the National Child Labor Committee to telegraph or telephone their representatives in Albany "expressing vigorous opposition" to a bill that, if passed, would "subject thousands of children in New York State to inhuman exploitation."
The appeal of the American National Red Cross for funds to support its work focuses attention this month on its many activities around the world and around the corner here at home.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- President Eisenhower today appointed Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss, a Naval Reserve officer of New York and Virginia, a special assistant to serve as "liaison adviser on atomic energy matters." This full-time position on the Presidential staff for Admiral Strauss had been forecast on Saturday.

Responding to the upward movement of interest rates generally, commercial paper rates edged higher yesterday. Dealers in the paper, which usually represents business borrowing on inventories, began offering six-month notes of so-called "prime borrowers" at 2 3/8 per cent, compared with the previous rate of 2 1/4 per cent.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 9 (AP) -- First post at Tanforart Racetrack drew nearer tonight, but top horsemen still hero after the Santa Anita meeting said they were standing fast for a bigger cut of the profits.

GENEVA, March 9 -- Two recent proposals originating in Europe point to a road the United States Government could follow to work out a method of establishing the type of tariff that best fitted United States national interests.

CAIRO, March 9 -- Mahmoud Fawzi, Egyptian Foreign Minister, said tonight that Egypt had protested to Britain against alleged "oppressive measures" by British authorities in the southern Sudan. A copy of the note of protest was said to have been sent to Governor General Sir Robert Howe.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 9 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said today that the death of Stalin had increased the world's chances for peace and that "the Eisenhower era begins as the Stalin era ends."

Albert Spalding, the concert violinist, whose previous writing had been his autobiography, "Rise to Follow," will have his first novel published by Holt on March 30. It is a story about another violinist, the eighteenth-century Italian, Giuseppe Tartini. Titled "A Fiddle, a Sword and a Lady," it describes Tartini's adventures in Italy and the discoveries he made in music.

There is nothing in the early developments to give encouragement to the belief that the death of Stalin would provide the occasion for a quick break between Peiping and Moscow. There has always been a tinge of wishful thinking in the promotion of the "Chinese Tito" school of thought, and merely because a Chinese-Soviet break would be so obviously advantageous many persons have assumed that it was possible or even probable.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 9 -- There was something faintly familiar about the manner in which the Yankees beat the Red Box here this afternoon, 6 to 4, with an assortment of two home runs, five doubles and sundry singles. There was a familiar touch, too, to the last-inning rally the Red Sox staged when they almost pulled the game out of the fire.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Defense counsel attacked the validity of a Congressional subpoena as the trial of Sidney Buchman, Hollywood writer-producer, on charges of contempt of Congress opened here today.
ALBANY, March 9 -- Following is the text of the statement issued by Governor Dewey today on the New York City financial situation:
A check of housewares departments here has yielded several new devices for the kitchen.

ALBANY, March 9 -- The controversial Hughes-Preller Branch Bank Bill was amended tonight to reduce the number of savings banks which would be permitted to open additional branches and to restrict further the new territory they can penetrate.

CHICAGO, March 9 -- Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the board of directors of General Motors Corporation, testified today at the du Pont anti-trust trial that he was on his own as the head of General Motors from the time he became president in 1923.
New York City has borrowed $30,000,000 on tax anticipation notes due April 30 at 1 5/8 per cent interest, Controller Lazarus Joseph said yesterday. The notes were sold by allotment as follows:

Mussorgsky's "ur - Boris," the original version of the opera, with the new orchestration of Karol Rathaus, was repeated last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, and a new Boris headed the cast -- Cesare Siepi.
NOTTINGHAM, England, March 19 (AP) -- Don Cockell, former British light-heavyweight champion, won from 39-year-old Tommy Farr of Wales on a seven-round technical knockout tonight.

Proposals for inclusion in "stand-by" controls of import quota curbs on cheese and other dairy and agricultural products authorized under the Defense Production Act will be opposed by importing groups, trade sources indicated yesterday.

The art of displaying fine objects advantageously is to be noted in several of the 200 exhibits that make up the huge annual National Antiques Show at Madison Square Garden. A seven-day event under the management of Morton Yarmon, the fair opened yesterday to a crowd queued up outside the Garden for an hour before being admitted.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The long feud between animal grazers in eleven Western public lands states and land conservationists flared again today as the Wild Life Institute met here to map a campaign against threatened legislation affecting the tenure and use of about 320,000,000 acres of public grazing and forest property.
A novel method of calculating the bus service requirements within the borough was introduced yesterday in Queens by Borough President James A. Lundy.

BERLIN, March 9 (AP) -- West Berlin received a new flood of refugees from the Soviet Zone today and hundreds of them said they had been forced out by a brutal campaign to seize all private shops and factories.

ALBANY, March 9 -- Governor Dewey indicated today that he would call the Legislature into special session some time in May to deal with the problems uncovered by the State Crime Commission in its investigation of the New York waterfront.

LOS ANGELES, March 9 (AP) -- The passenger service of the Pacific Electric Railway Company, serving 125 communities in four Southern California counties, has been sold for $8,000,000 to a new corporation, Western Transit Systems, Inc.

ALBANY, March 9 -- The Senate Finance Committee approved tonight the bill proposed by Senator Gilbert T. Seelye, Republican of Saratoga, providing for the licensing of chiropractors by the Department of Education.

LONDON, March 9 -- Observers in London particularly noted today three points in the speeches made at the funeral of Stalin in Moscow: their emphasis on the continuance of the late leader's policies; their reassertions of the Soviet Union's will for peace; and the constant reiteration of the need for internal unity.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 9 -- The desert sun shone with unusual brilliance for Leo Durocher today.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 9 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander, has established as of today his "first Soviet Army headquarters," and for the time being he has placed Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery in charge of it.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Supreme Court, dividing 6 to 3, ruled in favor of the printers' and musicians' unions and the National Labor Relations Board today on two charges of "featherbedding" in violation of the Taft-Hartley Law.

The nation's steel-makers set a new high production record last week by operating at 100.3 per cent of rated capacity to turn out 2,262,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings, American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday. It was the first time this year that the rate had topped 100 per cent.

The impact of the new synthetic fibers on the textile industry may lead to one of the biggest mergers of textile manufacturers in this century. Reports continue to persist that the American Woolen Company is negotiating for the purchase of Robbins Mills, Inc., and the fact that officials of both companies have not denied the reports lends weight to the likelihood of a merger in the near future.

Existing laws in the State of New York permit the employment of children over 14 on farms when the schools are not in session. To some growers of small fruits and vegetables whose crops ripen all at once and who have found it hard to get labor at the critical moment these laws seem too restrictive.

I venture to suggest that the interested reader is beginning to feel that in the current Congressional inquiry into New York police-F. B. I. relations much time, space and public money are being consumed over one word -- "agreement." Much conflicting evidence and newspaper discussion has revolved around the one word.

Record sales of $262,915,557 were achieved last year by the Phelps Dodge Corporation. This represented an increase of 1.8 per cent over the previous high of $258,162,395 set in 1951. Earnings, however, declined from the year before.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- A Veterans Administration loyalty review board today heard behind closed doors the appeal of James Kutcher, a legless Newark, N. J., veteran, for reinstatement as an employe of the agency.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 9 -- Following is the text of a statement read today by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles at his press conference here:

MANILA, Tuesday, March 10 -- Ramon Magsaysay bolted President Elpidio Quirino's Liberal party last night and joined the opposition Nacionalistas. The former Secretary of Defense has had repeated public assurances from Nacionalistas party leaders that he would be their candidate for President in the November national elections.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 9 (AP) -- Gardnar Mulloy, top-ranked amateur tennis player in the united States, opened his bid today for the championship of the first annual masters invitation tennis tournament by defeating Harry Clarkson, Ocala, Fla., 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2.

THE "Standing Room Only" sign should be in evidence well before 10:30 this morning at the City Council's chambers. Individuals and groups representing the shooting fraternity of this city will speak their minds concerning the controversial anti-firearms legislation at a Council hearing.

Signs of an upturn in Western European production, following the recent period of recession, was reported yesterday by Thomas T. Wilson, assistant to the director of the Office of International Trade, Department of Commerce. He spoke at a luncheon of the Export Managers Club in the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Office of International Trade of the Department of Commerce named its special industry "task" group today to investigate the diversion of sulfa drugs and antibiotics from European nations to purchasers behind the Iron Curtain.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (UP) -- House of Representatives investigators were told today that members of the South Carolina Congressional delegation backed an alcohol tax unit investigator six times when he was in trouble or wanted a promotion.

SAN BRUNO, Calif., March 10 (AP) -- First Repeater, the even-money favorite, won the inaugural feature at Tanforan today, before an opening-day crowd larger than last year's -- despite a boycott by organized horsemen.
Steel mills in this country turned out more ingots and steel for castings last month than in any previous February -- 8,938,000 net tons.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- Lamp manufacturers from coast to coast are shipping 20 to 60 per cent more floor lamps this season than during the comparable period last year, Georgee H. Weiner, chairman of the National Home Lamp Council, reported today.

Judge Harold R. Medina and a Department of Justice lawyer disagreed in U. S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit here yesterday as to what Congress had in mind about market stabilization practices when it adopted the Securities Act and the Securities Exchange Act in the Thirties. The question came up during the course of the investment banking anti-trust trial.

After a trial without jury Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell reserved decision yesterday in the case of James Delany Garst, 26-year-old newspaper man, who is charged with violating the Selective Service Act for refusing to be inducted into the armed services.
