WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Some union leaders declared today that they considered themselves released from no-strike pledges at atomic energy plants because members of the Government's atomic labor panel had been dismissed and nothing had been done to replace them.

DETROIT, March 10 -- The Packard Motor Car Company will introduce at the Chicago automobile show Saturday three custom cars designed for the motorist who is not concerned with easy-installment buying.
SODOM, Israel, Feb. 22 -- Eager life is returning to the salt-sodden shores of the Dead Sea in Israel.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- The Du Pont anti-trust trial turned into a class in "how to organize a big business" today as Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of General Motors Corporation, continued an unusual discussion on the subject before Federal District Judge Walter J. LaBuy.

The underlying tax philosophy in Canada is that "business deserves a break." but none the less Canada is no tax haven, J. Harvey Perry, director of research of the Canadian Tax Foundation of Toronto, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Henry Ford 2d said today that President Eisenhower had found his proposal for removal of all tariff barriers "an interesting idea." Mr. Ford, who is president of the Ford Motor Company, spent about half an hour with the President at the White House.

Attendance continued at record levels yesterday at the American Toy Fair at the New Yorker and McAlpin Hotels and local showrooms. Registration for the first two days of the ten-day event was about 6,000, well above last year's figure.

Spyros P. Skouras, president of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, pledged the support of the motion picture industry yesterday to the 1953 Red Cross campaign, which has a city-wide goal of $7,000,000.

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 10 -- The Bergen County Special Grand Jury on gambling handed up today six indictments citing four persons on three counts of malfeasance, one of perjury and two of false swearing.

ALBANY, March 10 -- Governor Dewey proposed today, in special message to the Legislature, the creation of a new five-member authority to take over and operate the city's transit system under a statutory mandate to eliminate the operating deficit by economies improved efficiency or a fare increase.

Four new films will open at first-run theatres today. "The Stars Are Singing," a Paramount musical comedy-romance in Tech nicolor with Rosemary Clooney Anna Maria Alberghetti and Lauritz Melchior, is at the Astor. Norman Taurog directed and Irving Asher produced. "She's Back on Broadway," a Warner Brothers musical in WarnerColor featuring Virginia Mayo, Gene Nelson, Frank Lovejoy, Steve Cochran and Patrice Wymore, is at the Paramount Henry Blanke produced and Gordon Douglas directed.
Motifs of the past, from architecture, works of art or events of the time, predominate in three collections of patterned decorative materials that will go on view today.

Plans are being advanced rapidly for the entertainment known as the Moonlight Mist Ball, to be held April 30 at the Plaza under the auspices of the New York City Cancer Committee of American Cancer Society, Inc. Underwritten by Prince and Princess Artchil Gourielli (Helena Rubinstein), the entire proceeds from the event will augment the society's general fund for education, research and service.

The predominant impressions carried away from the collection of imports and custom designs presented yesterday at Henri Bendel under the supervision of Mr. Leon were the importance of chiffon and the interest centered on the location of the waistline.

The General Railway Signal Company has notified the New York Stock Exchange that it will ask its stockholders at the annual meeting to amend the certificate of incorporation in respect to changes in the capital structure.

LONDON, March 10 -- Prices moved narrowly and rather aimlessly in quiet stock markets here today. Gains and losses were about equal in number. Selected store and shipping issues were in steadiest demand.
CHICAGO, March 10 (UP) -- The boom in Midwestern farm land values has ended, the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago said today.

Four 1953 lines of trucks, including 192 models representing an initial production investment of $50,000,000, were introduced yesterday by the Ford Motor Company. The vehicles range from 4,000 to 55,000 pounds rating, the latter being the largest truck ever built by the organization.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Dr. Bella V. Dodd of New York, self-identified as a former member of the Communist party national committee, swore before the Senate Internal Security subcommittee today that Communists had got into many legislative offices of Congress and into a number of groups advising the President of the United States.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 10 -- Deportation proceedings against Dr. Hsi-yen Liu, a Chinese pediatrician on the staff of the University of Michigan Medical School, were stayed today through the intervention of Representative George Meader, Republican of Michigan.

ALBANY, March 10 -- Two major changes in the bill revising the method of fixing special franchise valuations for railroad and utility properties were proposed today by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment.

Many parties will be given tomorrow at the annual Loyola luncheon and card party for the benefit of the Jesuit Seminaries in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. A feature of the entertainment will be an elaborate fashion display of spring and summer wear in furs, gowns and hats, with appropriate jewelry.

New York University, whose football teams reached their zenith in the late Nineteen Twenties, announced yesterday that it would discontinue intercollegiate competition in the sport, effective immediately.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Representative Joseph R. Bryson, Democrat of South Carolina, died tonight after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage while attending a dinner. He was 60 years old.

The abolition of the shape-up system of hiring on New York City's docks and the substitution of twelve geographically selected employment centers was recommended yesterday afternoon to the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., by a ten-man committee that has been studying the problem for a month.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- President Eisenhower, according to reports current tonight, is planning to recast the entire membership of the Civil Service Commission, with Philip Young, Dean of Columbia University's Graduate School of Business, slated to be chairman.

GENEVA, March 10 -- A French Socialist and a British peer joined forces in the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe today to condemn the degradation of the worker's status in Communist countries, in a manner that started pencils scurrying in the Russian delegation.
The City of Chicago borrowed $21,500,000 yesterday in the public market on bonds maturing from 1954 to 1971 at an interest cost of 2.7036 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Dr. Philip H. Abelson, a 40-year-old scientist whom the Navy honored for his wartime work in nuclear physics, will become director of the geophysical laboratory of the Carnegie Institution of Washington on Sept. 1, Dr. Vannevar Bush, president of the institution, announced today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 10 -- The Screen Writers Guild, at its fifth annual awards dinner tonight in the Hollywood Paladium, selected Sonya Levien as the first recipient of its new Laurel for Achievements Award.

Resort hotel advertising that makes reference to the location of churches is not in the reference itself a violation of the New York State Law Against Discrimination, the New York State Commission Against Discrimination announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -High officials of the national military establishment assured the Senate Armed Services Committee today that all United States troops overseas had sufficient ammunition of all kinds to carry out their missions and to repel any attack within the capability of the forces facing them.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 10 -- The United States began turning over a fleet of jet aircraft to Yugoslavia today as part of the military aid program, which, according to officials of both countries, will be heightened by increased deliveries in the coming months.
CHICAGO, March 10 -- Improved weather in the Southwest, with the possibility of more rain took the edge off demand for wheat, and prices were sharply lower.

In his ten years at Albany Governor Dewey has taken no step of greater political courage than in prescribing a self-sustaining, independent Transit Authority for New York City. He does this as the first measure of a program "to save the city from the catastrophic mismanagement of its own officials."

There can be no question that the most ruthless of all fevers is that one known simply as spring fever. It is far more disturbing in effect than, say, the mild little discomfort usually associated with the common cold.

Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, has achieved an "understanding" on foreign policy with Secretary of State John Foster Dulles and with President Eisenhower, R. A. Butler, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, declared here last night.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The White House gave the go-ahead signal today to hundreds of thousands of home owners who want to add a new room for the new baby, re-roof the house or add an extra bathroom.

Legislation to provide prisoners with legal counsel at state expense and with the privilege of sending uncensored mail to lawyers was endorsed in principle yesterday at a public hearing of the committee on justice of the New York Criminal and Civil Courts Bar Association.

In spite of record production levels in 1952, the nation's proved reserves of liquid petroleum and natural gas reached new peaks at the year end according to the American Petroleum Institute and the American Gas Association in their annual report released today.

A storm described by the Weather Bureau as "terrific in intensity," with winds of hurricane force, swept the North Atlantic steamship lanes off Cape Race, Newfoundland, yesterday, causing delays of up to two days to New York-bound liners.

Lillian A. Hudson, the first educational director of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, was honored yesterday by the Nursing Staff Association at the Lillian D. Wald birthday anniversary tea held at the service's offices, 598 Madison Avenue.

The sculptural qualities of crystal are emphasized in a group of decorative glassware introduced at the new showrooms of Daum Crystallerie, Inc., 225 Fifth Avenue, and available there through decorators. Setting the theme of the collection is a tall fluid shape called "The Flame," which has no function and exists only as a piece of sculpture.

The New York Customs District took in $24,221,571 in collections in February, or $96,012 less than in January. The income, however, represented a $2,866,324 increase over the collections made in February, 1952.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -The Navy reported today that a dislodged bomb exploded on the flight deck of the carrier Oriskany in Korean waters March 6, killing two men and injuring fifteen others.
PITTSBURGH, March 10 (AP) -- A Texas company has reversed the usual pattern by coming to western Pennsylvania to look for gas wells.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The president of the American Bar Association said tonight that residents of the United States were "the most lawless people in the world" and that lawyers especially should awaken to "the enormity of this problem."

Three unnamed racketeers, said to be widely known in the metropolitan area, were indicted yesterday by a Brooklyn Federal Grand jury on charges of income tax evision. The indictments were handed up to Judge Robert A. Inch of the United States District Court by the March panel.

BONN, Germany, March 10 -- The Foreign Affairs Committee of the Bundestag, lower house of the West German Parliament, has recommended to the Federal Government that it coordinate, systematize and expand scientific research in the history, economy and sociology of the Communist-controlled countries of Europe.

A BOOK was published last Monday with more advance hullabaloo and pre-publication publicity than any first novel has received in many years. Instead of the usual 200 or so free copies distributed to critics of newspapers and magazines, 2,500 were sent out to book sellers, publishers and people in the theatre and movie world. A long-playing record with dialogue

TORONTO, March 10 -- Canadian rejection last month of an American bid to harness Yukon power fell into focus today with the revelation that a Canadian Exploration Corporation plans to spend up to $2,000,000,000 in the territory's greatest boom since gold rush days.

ALBANY, March 10 -- Governor Dewey's program to make Federal Social Security coverage available to an estimated 40,000 public employes not now participating in any retirement program went half-way through the Legislature today.

MINNEOLA, L. I., March 10 -Nassau County legislators, stymied by a constitutional block in Albany when they sought to end the Levittown Hall dispute by creating a joint park district for Hempstead and Oyster Bay Townships, amended the proposal today to establish a special district for the operation of the community hall and nine Levitt-built swimming pools with privileges to be extended to residents of both towns.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 10 -Bob Wiesler, Johnny Schmitz and Johnny Sain clicked off the first Yankee shutout of the spring training season when they limited the Red Sox to three hits, fanned nine and wrapped up a 2-0 victory today for the world champions' third straight victory before 5,026 at Lang Field.

The specialists who have the task of trying to decide how much of Monday's three main funeral speeches in Moscow can be taken seriously are rereading for guidance a funeral speech made twenty-nine years ago: Stalin's address of January 26, 1924, after Lenin died. The comparison suggests that Premier Georgi M. Malenkov particularly reread that basic model before preparing his own speech over Stalin's bier.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court unanimously confirmed yesterday the sentence of 12 1/2 to 25 years imposed on James J. Moran, former First Deputy Fire Commissioner, for extortion in a fuel oil installation shakedown racket, and suspended his indeterminate sentence for conspiracy on the same charge.

The need for a systematic plan for personnel administration in Government service was outlined here last night by Charles P. Taft, attorney of Cincinnati, and unsuccessful Republican candidate for Governor of his state.
Revenues and earnings of United Air Lines, Inc., last year were the highest in its 27-year history, W. A. Patterson, president, reported in the annual statement mailed to stockholders yesterday.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, former United States delegate to the United Nations, told 300 members of the Women's City Club yesterday that an attempt should be made to win ratification by the Senate of the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Following is the vote by which the House today passed, 274-138, and sent to the Senate a bill to admit Hawaii to statehood:

James J. Breslin, former plain-clothes man, was found guilty yesterday by a blue ribbon jury in Kings County Court of criminal contempt for refusing to testify before the Brooklyn rackets grand jury about his financial affairs. The jury deliberated forty minutes.
Following is the text of a statement by Chancellor Henry T. Heald on athletics at New York University:
TOKYO, Wednesday, March 11 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,550, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Wednesday, Korean time:

LOS ANGELES, March 10 -- Twenty-three motion-picture actors and other film workers who refused to answer questions of the House of Representatives' Committee on Un-American Activities in 1951, filed suit today in State Supreme Court against the committee and the principal motion-picture producing organizations for $51,750,000.

The Prudential Insurance Company of America, continuing its expansion and decentralization program, set new records in 1952, Carrol M. Shanks, the president, said yesterday in his annual report to policyholders.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -Representative Sidney A. Fine, Democrat of the Bronx, twitted Governor Dewey today for entertaining a proposal to tapen off rent control while the Repblican-controlled Legislature proposed to continue authority for the use of cellars as dwellings because of a housing shortage.

A cargo of treasures from the remote past of the Holy Land has arrived in New York, the first of several shipments by sea and air of rare antiquities and historical objects from Israel to be exhibited at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the first stopping place in a nation-wide tour.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., March 10 (AP) -- The blind are helping to spot airplanes that might be enemies, the Air Defense Command disclosed today.

Thomas Jefferson might be disappointed at an announcement made this week by the Bureau of the Census. Jefferson believed, as he said, that "those who labor in the earth are the chosen people of God." He went further; he said that, "generally speaking, the proportion which the aggregate of the other classes of citizens bear in any state to that of its husbandmen is the proportion of its unsound to its healthy parts."

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Representative Harold H. Velde, Republican of Illinois, lost little time in explaining his position today as members of the House of Representatives Committee on Un-American Activities, which he heads, repudiated his statement that an investigation of the clergy was "entirely possible."

MIAMI, March 10 -- Manager Steve O'Neil, irate because he thought the Dodgers had played too rough last night, was even more burned up tonight when the Brooks scored a run in the eighth to win, 3 -- 2, for their fourth straight victory and the Phils' fourth consecutive loss.

A ceremony to mark the formal start of building the superstructure of the 1.61-mile South Street Elevated Highway was held yesterday at South and Jackson Streets. Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, drove a rivet into a steel girder as fifteen city officials watched.

An electronic-mechanical device designed to stretch a jet's range by telling its pilot exactly how much fuel his engine or engines consume an hour in terms of weight rather than volume, was displayed yesterday at the Wings Club in the Biltmore Hotel.

Arthur A. Mitchell, 53-year-old apartment house superintendent, was held without bail yesterday on a homicide charge in the slaying of Milton Hirsch, 66, of 601 West 142d Street, whose dismembered body was found in two paper bundles near the Fulton Fish Market last Thursday.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -The Senate Foreign Relations Committee put an end today to all present efforts to revive in one diluted form or another the Eisenhower Administration's proposal for a United States denunciation of the Soviet Union's enslavement of peoples.

TORONTO, March 10 -- Jack Shinder, Brooklyn salesman, was fined $150 today for giving false information when registering the birth of a child he and his wife later adopted. Magistrate Gullen said he was "more or less the victime of circumstances."

Many local stores have run into a slump in sales of television receivers, dealers representing all types of retail outlets said yesterday. Out-of-town reports indicate that the slump, which has been building up since the beginning of the year, is also being felt in at least five other cities.
HARTFORD, March 10 -- The Connecticut State Senate, controlled overwhelmingly by Republicans, approved a bill tonight that would change the boundary lines of its thirty-six state Senate districts.

Charles Dyson has been elected a director of the Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company, it was announced yesterday by Sam S. Mullin, president. Mr. Dyson is a former executive vice president and director of Burlington Mills Corporation.

TOKYO, Wednesday, March 11 -- Stiff local fighting increased yesterday in mud and drizzles of rain along the 155-mile Korean front. In the western sector, United Nations troops sent two raiding parties into Communist territory to chop up Chinese defense positions. In the center and among the eastern mountains. Allied soldiers beat off a series of Communist probing attacks.

BONN, Germany, March 10 -- A United States Air Force jet fighter plane was shot down today by two Russian-built MIG-15's in the United States zone in the first attack on United States combat aircraft in Germany since the start of the "cold war."

Two alleged bookmakers were held yesterday in $350,000 bail each as material witnesses in the Staten Island special grand jury investigation into crime and official corruption. The bond is believed to be the largest ever set in this area.

ALBANY, March 10 -- The sponsor of two bills relaxing restrictions against child labor on farms defended the measure today as a means of keeping children from "serious mischief" heading toward juvenile delinquency.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Representative Frances P. Bolton, Republican of Ohio, reintroduced today her bill to provide grants and scholarships in the field of nursing to the amount of $5,000,000 the first year, $10,000,000 the second year and $15,000,000 the third. She told the House that the need for such legislation is greater than ever before.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., March 10 -The District Attorney's office of Dutchess County appealed to the court in behalf of a prisoner sentenced excessively and Charles Marshall, 50 years old, of Amenia, N. Y., won freedom today after having served sixteen days of a sixty-day jail term.

Seton Hall took a basketball thriller from Niagara, 79 to 74, and Duquesne beat Western Kentucky, 69 to 61, to advance to the semi-finals in the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden last night.

The General Motors Corporation, the world's largest industrial enterprise, last year transacted sales of $7,549,154,419, the largest in its forty-four-year history, on lower civilian products but larger defense business than in 1951.
TOKYO, March 10 -- Adlai E. Stevenson warned the United States today against being "lulled to sleep" by hopes favorable to a change in foreign policy by the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- General Public Utilities Corporation of New York applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authority to borrow $7,000,000 from four banks. Under the proposal, G. P. U. will issue $1,750,000 of notes to each of four banks, the Marine Midland Trust Company of New York, Bankers Trust Company, Manufacturers Trust Company and the Mellon National Bank and Trust Company.

A letter received from one of our indefatigable civic organizations asks for suggestions respecting a candidate for Mayor next fall. It happens that I have lately reviewed the record of the La Guardia administration, now, in retrospect, epoch-making. Those who are giving thought to the next election as aspirants or citizens might profit by remembering the kind of man Fiorello La Guardia was and the qualities that made him an outstanding Mayor.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 10 -- The Iranian Government, charging that British spies and agents are using Iraq as a base for espionage against Iran, has demanded that the Baghdad Government take immediate action to halt such operations.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The House Merchant Marine Committee was told today that three subsidized shipping lines had paid $64,824 to New York waterfront labor racketeers during a period in which the companies received about $54,000,000 from the Government.

Gunther Jaeckel's spring and summer collection, presented yesterday, was of interest because of the wide variety of styles gathered together for the occasion. There were among them some of the best of the creations of New York's top designers, fashions from California and selections from the French couture, with attention focussed particularly on those from the house of Jacques Griffe.
LOS ANGELES, March 10 (AP) -- The whereabouts of Ralph Kiner, the Pirates' holdout home-run hitter, became somewhat of a mystery today.

When Al Turco was in the ring fifteen years ago he had one basic rule -- keep punching until you drop. Yesterday Turco, now 39 years old and in the fruit and vegetable business, got into a price war with a rival ten times his size. However, he kept punching until he dropped.
L. J. Phillips Co. and Austin Hermann were the brokers in the sale reported yesterday of the three four-story buildings at Eighth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 10 (AP) -Joan Merciadis, 20-year-old Modesto (Calif.) girl playing the tennis circuit for the first time, upset Mrs. Barbara Scofield Davidson, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, in the first annual Masters Invitation today.

LONDON, March 10 -- The coronation of Queen Elizabeth II in June will cost more than three times what her fathers coronation cost sixteen years ago. The bil for her crowning wil be 2,271,000. The bill for the coronation of George VI was 689,400.

HAVANA, March 10 -- Cuba celebrated today the first anniversary of President Fulgencio Batista's coup with eulogies and pledges to the armed forces by the President while students rioted at the National University. In the fighting three bystanders were shot and wounded by the police.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 10--Secretary General Trygve Lie today coupled a defense of the policy he had followed toward Communist and allegedly subversive Americans on the United Nations payroll with a bitter attack on the Soviet Union's refusal to recognize him as Secretary General.

NEWARK, March 10 -- The 32-year-old twin sons of Arthur T. Vanderbilt, Chief Justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court, have entered Republican politics as prospective candidates for the New Jersey Assembly.

The riots which swept Teheran recently have simmered down, but this comparative calm cannot disguise the serious situation building up in Iran -- a situation which could easily confront that country and the world with grim developments. For the moment the aged Premier, barricaded behind Sherman tanks and ruling by means of martial law, seems to be strengthening his position.

New issues of public utility securities valued at more than $13,000,000 will be offered to investors today by investment banking syndicates. The funds will be used largely to finance capital outlays. The offerings are:

The organizing of the Independent Motion Picture Distributors Association of America, Inc., a group of independent distributors of foreign films, to counteract "the threat which has recently arisen toward the concept of free and competitive enterprise in the field," was announced yesterday at a meeting at the offices of Joseph Burstyn, 113 West Forty-second Street.

The National Multiple Sclerosis Society reported last night a grant of $27,000 to the University of Buffalo for the first year of a proposed two-year study of the possible infectious origin of the disease.

LONDON, March 10 -- Prime Minister Churchill reaffirmed today his willingness to consider again the Hungarian Government's offer to exchange Edgar Sanders, a British subject serving a sentence for alleged espionage in Hungary, for Lee Meng, convicted Chinese woman, a Communist guerrilla in Malaya.
JERUSALEM, March 10 -- The ordinary budget of 216,330,000 (Israeli), which is to be balanced by internal revenue, was introduced in the Knesset (Parliament) today by Finance Minister Levi Eshkol.

PHILADELPHIA, March 10 (UP) -- Tiny and terrific Lebanon Valley, short on student body and height but keen on basketball savvy, upset Fordham, 80 -- 67, tonight after Holy Cross defeated Navy, 87 -- 74, in the opening of the National Collegiate Athletic Association elimination series at the Palestra before 4,029.

The American Museum of Natural History, which is one of the world's great institutions teaching about the ways and the characteristics of odd, bizarre members of the animal kingdom, reported yesterday that it would start a new study about the oddest, most bizarre animal of all -- man himself.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 10 -- Milk shakes and ice cream sundaes adopted from the United States are winning the African native away from his centuries-old devotion to beer, which may have been taken over by the Africans from the Egyptian brewers, whose beer dates to about 3000 B. C.

Ethel Barrymore will star in a one-act play by Tennessee Williams on the C. B. S. television network's "Omnibus" program on Sunday, March 29, at 4:30 P. M. The playwright also will appear to discuss his twenty-minute drama, the first of his plays to be televised.

PHILADELPHIA, March 10 -Dr. Arthur S. Flemming, Acting Director of the Office of Defense Mobilization, decried tonight the "attitude of indifference" shown by many Americans toward the problem of civil defense.

The four-story apartment house accommodating forty-seven families on a plot about 100 by 113 feet at 1143-51 Forty-third Street in Brooklyn has been sold by the Hanover Management Corporation to the newly organized West End Court, Inc., of which Meyer Burger is president. Harry Rubin was the broker and the Security Title and Guaranty Company insured title. The attorneys were Hyman Stein for the buyer and Lesser Lesser for the seller.

PARIS, March 10 -- The French news agency said tonight that it had learned from "an authorized source" that negotiations were now being conducted with Spanish civil and religious authorities for the return to France of two missing Jewish war orphans, Robert and Gerald Finaly. The agency indicated that their return was imminent.
The American Kennel Club re-elected its officers, named four directors and approved four clubs for membership and eight delegates at its annual meeting in the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- In the first official step to carry out the promise of the Eisenhower Administration to end segregation in the District of Columbia, Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, asked the Supreme Court today to uphold two laws forbidding restaurants here to refuse to serve Negroes.

ALBANY, March 10 -- Following is the text of a special message sent by Governor Dewey to the Legislature today urging creation of a new authority to take over and operate New York City's Transit system:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 10 -- For the first time in the six-year history of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund there will be no new United States contribution to plan on when the welfare agency acts next week on assistance programs for thirty countries.

After a tense debate that touched on all the historic obstacles to European unification the Constitutional Assembly at Strasbourg set a new milestone on the long road toward that goal when it adopted a draft of the first European constitution ever agreed upon. The draft now goes to the Governments of the six nations involved for further action.

NEWARK, March 10 -- The I. C. C. directive approving an increase of 15 per cent in intrastate commuter fares for the Jersey Central and its subsidiary will bring the rates of those carriers to the level of those of other roads operating in New Jersey, officials of the Board of Public Utility Commissioners said today.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- A Kentucky lawyer accused leaders of a big union today of being "labor dictators" who "fattened their own purses" at the expense of workers on the Government's billion-dollar Paducah atomic project. The head of the union, however, denied the charge as "strictly untrue" and said the lawyer was trying to promote a rival organization.

Mrs. Gloria Teich of 779 Riverside Drive was about to unlock the door of her automobile, parked on the drive between 155th and 156th Streets, at 2 P. M. yesterday, when she thought she saw the vehicle sink.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Hawaii statehood bill was passed by the House of Representatives today, 274 to 138, but only after adoption of a provision making the territory's admission contingent upon Congressional approval of its new Constitution.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The United States lodged the "strongest possible protest" today against the attack by two Czechoslovak MIG fighter planes on two United States F-84 jet fighters over the United States zone of Germany early this morning.
Two group shows of paintings by members of clubs in the region of Greenwich Village and two one-man shows of sculpture in uptown galleries reveal that work in traditional veins still is flourishing.

Your editorial of March 4 and the presentments of the Kings County grand jury on slums make very clear the conditions under which thousands of New York families must live. We believe that landlords should be permitted to raise rents at least 15 per cent over the 1943 levels.
The Detroit Red Wings, enjoying a seven-game winning streak, make their final appearance of the season at Madison Square Garden tonight against the New York Rangers.

A merger of two of the nation's leading investment companies to form a $185,300,000 combine was agreed upon yesterday by the Tri-Continental Corporation and the Capital Administration Company, Ltd. Both are closed-end investment concerns and have substantially the same management. Certain inter-company assets will be written off.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (UP) -- Representative Daniel A. Reed, Republican of upstate New York, announced today that he would force action by the House of Representtaives on his 10-per-cent-tax-cut bill on April 15 unless Republican leaders surrendered and gave it a green light first.

CHICAGO, March 10 (AP) -- George Ehrenberg, 19-year-old Chicago sign-painter, rolled a 288 game and a 702 series to gain second place today in the singles event of the American Bowling Congress tournament. His 288 matched Robert Boncel, Milwaukee, for high tourney game honors so far in the ninety-three-day meet.

Whether the substances sold as chlorophyll kill objectionable odors or not was a pungent issue between scientists and manufacturers here yesterday. The Chlorophyll industry Committee, representing United States makers of substances containing chlorophyll, said their pills made users smell good, while two of the nation's leading chlorophyll chemists said this could not possibly be true.

LITTLE effort was made, by its proponents, to justify the need for the controversial Pino anti-firearms bill which was discussed before the City Council yesterday, although representatives of several sportsmen's groups pointed out the many features of the bill which would provide obstacles to sportsmen and gun dealers in the city.

Eddie Albert seems to be having his troubles in finding his niche in television. After his ill-fated comedy series in the fall, he now is having a tryout in afternoon video at 3 P. M., Monday through Friday, over the C.B.S. network. So far the show has not jelled.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 10 -- Stan Musial rifled one over the fence in batting practice and smiled in obvious satisfaction. Stan the Man is taking dead aim at his seventh National League batting championship a mark that will bring him even with Rogers Hornsby and one shy of Honus Wagner's record figure of eight. He seems quietly confident that he can make one and maybe both.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 10 (AP) The Louisville Times in a copyrighted story today quoted a former Army officer as saying that Army artillery in Korea had been firing hundreds of shells in "shows" for visiting dignitaries despite the contention over charges of ammunition shortages there.

In 1870, Emily Wooldridge was the only woman aboard the Maid of Athens on its trip to South America. When the ship caught fire off the southern tip of the continent, Mrs. Wooldridge, her husband and their crew were forced to abandon ship and take refuge on a deserted island, spending six weeks there preparing an open boat for the return to civilization.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 10 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles called on the peoples of the free world today to build up their strength, even at the cost of sacrifices, and to "make their intentions so clear that they will thus reduce the risk that war might come about through miscalculation on the part of the aggressors."

The price of lead, which was trimmed a half cent a pound just a week ago, advanced by the same amount yesterday in the first increase so far this year, and was quoted generally at 13 1/2 cents, New York basis.
United Nations, N. Y., March 10 -- Following are excerpts from the statement by Secretary General Trygve Lie today before the United Nation General Assembly:

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Controlled Materials Plan, under which the Government has doled out available supplies of steel copper and aluminum to industry, will go out of existence June 30, Arthur S. Flemming, acting director of the Office of Defense Mobilization, announced today.

ALBANY, March 10 -- Governor Dewey signed today bills increasing the official strength of the State Police force from 900 to 1,200 and raising drivers' license fees to provide the extra funds for the larger police membership.

Patrolman John A. Brullman of the East 104th Street station was indicted yesterday by a Brooklyn Federal grand jury on a charge of violating the Civil Rights Act. The charge was based on a beating Brulllman allegedly gave Francis D. Galatis, a 46-year-old subway motorman.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- Reinhold Pabel, 38 years old, an escaped German prisoner of war, who turned a seven-year masquerade into a prosperous book business, was charged today with being in this country without a visa.

Volume improved on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday although potatoes showed a sharp drop in sales. The close was generally higher with price rises noted on cottonseed and soybean oils, lead, tin, wool and hides. Sugar, potatoes and zinc closed mixed and cocoa and rubber were lower.

KANSAS CITY, March 10 (AP) -- St. Peter's College of Jersey City used a balanced attack to beat Southwestern State of Weatherford, Okla., 81 -- 60, in the first round of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics basketball tournament today.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- Valley Farm's Impasse, an improving son of Contradiction, made it two straight at the current meeting when he turned back nine other 3-year-olds in the featured seventh race at Gulfstream Park, entitled the Illinois Athletic Club Purse.
The lines of men and women waiting to pay their income taxes lengthened yesterday at Internal Revenue offices here as the time shortened before the deadline of midnight next Monday.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady with gains of 3 to 15 points net yesterday.

GLEN COVE, L. I., March 10 -- Joseph De Mario, who had parked his school bus for a moment here today, gazed in helpless horror as it departed driverless with twenty-two small children toward a busy highway. This driver's nightmare ended when the loose bus ran into a used car lot, banged into several cars and stopped just as the children had quit laughing and were beginning to wish Mr. De Mario was on board.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The State Department asserted again, in a letter made public today, that recognition of any state boundary "beyond the three-mile limit would directly conflict with international law, as the United States conceives it."

At an unusually late session last night the City Council by a vote of 19 to 1 adopted a rent-control resolution offered by Majority Leader Joseph T. Sharkey and other Democrats asking the State Legislature either to vote down the proposed 15 per cent rise in rents or to let the city enact its own rent-control legislation.

Fifth Avenue will share in the wearing of the green on St. Patrick's Day come rain or shine. A bright emerald hued five-inch dividing line will be painted on the pavement from Washington Square to 110th Street, the Department of Traffic announced yesterday.

"I propose to use whatever authority exists in the office of the President," said Mr. Eisenhower in his State of the Union message last month, "to end segregation in the District of Columbia." And, he added, "serious attention" should be given to the problem of providing "an effective voice in local self-government" for the District's citizens.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 10 -- Six Danish fishing vessels with a total of twenty-three crewmen, seeking shelter from a Baltic storm off the Polish coast, were taken last Sunday to a Polish port in Danzig Bay by a Polish patrol vessel and placed under arrest.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., March 10 -- The Navy today abandoned its plan to develop a secret ordnance test facility on the northwest portion of Santa Catalina Island and announced that the project would be transferred to another site.
The season's first shipment of sour grass from Florida has been reported by Mrs. Frances Foley Gannon, director of the consumers' service bureau of the city Department of Markets.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 10 -- Massachusetts Institute of Technology experts did not recommend specific sites for Voice of America radio transmitters, Dr. James R. Killian Jr., president of the institute, said tonight.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 10 (UP) -- Wally Lammers, rookie shortstop of the Cardinals, suffered a concussion in a collision at second base today as the Braves whipped the Redbirds, 7 -- 5, before 2,648 at Braves Field.

More than 400 persons, representing a cross section of the country's principal advertisers, will gather a week from today for the annual three-day spring meeting of the Association of National Advertisers. The convention will be held in The Homestead, Hot Springs, Va.

The smoothly integrated passing of the reins of government from the Truman to the Eisenhower Administration has been a cause of general satisfaction. But the unexplained circumstances surrounding President Eisenhower's acceptance of the resignations of the Atomic Energy Labor Relations Panel appear to be an exception to the rule.

MOSCOW, March 10 -- With the appointment of Vassili V. Kuznetsov as the new Soviet Ambassador to Communist China Premier Georgi M. Malenkov and his Government associates moved swiftly today to deepen and strengthen the bonds that unite the Soviet Union and Communist China.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -Railroads operating interstate through northern New Jersey were authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to increase commuter fares, for distances up to thirteen miles, by 4 to 6 per cent.

In the celebration of the fourth anniversary of the French-Vietnamese agreement looking to Vietnam's independence the Vietnamese Premier, Nguyen Van Tam, took a pickaxe to the door of the Saigon Central Prison. The door fell in and about a hundred prisoners were released.

STRASBOURG, France, March 10 -By a vote of 50 to 0, with five abstentions, the special European Constitutional Assembly tonight approved the draft charter that creates a union, limited in scope but wielding supranational powers and comprising the historic foes of France and West Germany along with Italy, the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) reported yesterday for 1952 estimated consolidated net income of $518,000,000 after charges, taxes and reserves, or $8.55 a capital share. This compares with $528,460,779 or $8.72 a share in 1951.

CAIRO, March 10 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Premier of Egypt, put out a statement tonight in Which he accused British officials in the Sudan of acts of coercion and intimidation wholly incompatible with the letter and spirit of the British-Egyptian agreement of Feb. 12.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 10 (UP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman said today that he planned to "sleep, eat and read whodunits" during his April vacation in Hawaii.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 10 -The Giants scarcely performed in a manner to bring forth any praise from Manager Leo Durocher today, but they had enough to flatten out a nondescript cast of White Sox that General Manager Frank C. Lane tried to palm off in the guise of major leaguers.

The Renegotiation Board has just amended its regulations to provide that renegotiation of subcontracts for new durable productive equipment, such as machine tools and other items with long lives, will be based on the useful life of the equipment and the amount of time it is used in performing renegotiable defense contracts.

On Feb. 22 THE NEW YORK TIMES, in an article by Max Frankel, said that "Dr. Taylor and Sarah Lawrence College were harassed last year by several groups, including the Westchester County American Legion, for allegedly maintaining Communists and subversive teachers on the staff."

A second legal move was undertaken yesterday to compel the Board of Education to renovate Public School 19, at Fourteenth Street and First Avenue. The ninety-four-year-old school has been a source of contention since January, when a parent refused to send his daughter to classes there on the ground that it was "filthy and unsanitary."

The performance of Geminiani's Concerto Grosso No. 12, which the Edouard Nies-Berger Chamber Orchestra played last evening at Central Presbyterian Church, 593 Park Avenue, had vigorous competition from the compressed-air drills of an emergency crew repairing a gas leak next door.

Much better known on the screen than he was on Broadway, Walter Slezak returns tonight after an absence of a dozen years in Hollywood. At 8 o'clock he will resume his local career as the star of "My 3 Angels," which will have its premiere at the Morosco.
The combination of a wildcat strike and torrential rain has closed one of the world's biggest copper mines, the Chuquicamata mine in Chile, operated by subsidiaries of Anaconda Copper Mining Company.

ALBANY, March 10 -- Governor Dewey appeared to have succeeded tonight in coralling enough Republican votes for legislative approval of his entire fiscal program for New York City despite indications of solid Democratic opposition to two key features of it.

Emphatically denying that city officials, as charged by Governor Dewey, are responsible for the city's financial crisis, Mayor Impellitteri yesterday called the Board of Estimate to meet in special executive session at City Hall at 11 o'clock this morning to deal with the state's fiscal program for the city.

Five special trains from cities in New England and four from upper New York State will unload passengers this morning who are bent on seeing the International Flower Show at Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets. The show will be open today through Saturday from 10 A. M. to 10 P. M.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Senator Homer E. Capehart said after a White House visit today that President Eisenhower favored his bill for granting to the President the authority to freeze all wages, prices and rents for ninety days in the event of an emergency.
DUBLIN, March 11 (AP) -- Despite bitter protests from some members, the Dail (Irish Parliament) tonight approved by a 65-to-23 vote the purchase of a racehorse for $700,000 from the Aga Khan.

As counsel for a number of foreign Governments in this country I should like to call to your attention a bill now pending in the New York State Assembly, the enactment of which would constitute a stride forward in the recognition of our international obligations.
TOKYO, Thursday, March 12 (AP) -- United Nation Command communique 1,551, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Thursday, Korean time:

A Queens motorist with experience in the field of speeding was charged with using his background to extort money from two other drivers and arrested yesterday by detectives of the Queens Village precinct.

The duo-pianists Arthur Gold and Robert Fizdale appeared last night at the Museum of Modern Art in a program of twentieth. century music for two pianos. The earliest work heard was Erik Satie's "En habit de cheval," written in 1911; the newest was Samuel Barber's ballet suite "Souvenirs," written in 1952, and heard for the first time here at this performance.

An increase last week of 1,822,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 159,434,000 barrels, compared with 157,612,000 a week earlier and 153,678,000 a year ago.
ROME, Thursday, March 12 -- Two hundred thousand railroad workers went on a forty-eight-hour strike last midnight, trying up international and internal Italian communications by rail.

TORONTO, March 11 (Canadian Press) -- Toronto is to have another big hotel. M. H. Lifton, real estate dealer, announced today that a United States hotel chain has bought a downtown block of land at Queen Street West and University Avenue and plans to erect a modern multi-million-dollar hotel.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 11 -- Prince Feisal al-Saud, Saudi Arabian Foreign Minister, attributed today to British "provocative acts" the territorial dispute over the Buraimi oasis but made it clear that he did not intend to press for an immediate United Nations airing of the case.

Speeds of more than 1,500 miles an hour on tracks laid in this country are now being recorded. However, it is not a train made up of pullmans, coaches, dining and freight cars that travel over 7,920,000 feet in sixty minutes. Instead, it's a sled.
Twenty-four persons, the majority of them women, were knocked down and injured at 5:15 P. M. yesterday when a private automobile mounted the sidewalk in Forty-sixth Street, west of Broadway.

CHICAGO, March 11 -- The shooting down of an American plane in West Germany by Russian-built MIG's threw a scare into the bear camp on the Board of Trade today, and sparked a brisk upturn in prices all along the line. Crop news in the Southwest was less favorable, which helped the recovery. Soybeans advanced in the face of weakness in meal, as the oil mar- ket was decidely strong.

Irked by what he termed the interference of Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx in the plans for building the $50,000,000 Cross Bronx Expressway, Robert Moses notified Mayor Impellitteri yesterday that he did "not care to carry any further" his responsibility as City Construction Coordinator if "borough politics" was to be permitted to interfere with his job.

Frank Costello continued yesterday to be a prime target of Government agencies. After a yearlong investigation by four Treasury Department racket squad agents, a Federal grand jury indicted the 61-year-old gambler on charges of evading $73,417 in income taxes for the years 1946 through 1949.

Maj. Gen. Kenneth E. Webber assumed command yesterday of the Eastern Air Procurement District of the Air Materiel Command at 655 Madison Avenue. Extending from Fairfield County, Conn., to the South Carolina border, the office supervises prime contractors with the largest volume of orders of those in any procurement district.
Gen. James A. Van Fleet's testimony about Korea appears to have generated more heat than light -- heat that was only partly dissipated Tuesday by Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 11 -- The text of the statement to the United Nations General Assembly today by Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., chief United States delegate, follows:

NEW CITY, N. Y., Thursday, March 12 -- A 16-year-old student at Lakeside School admitted here early this morning that he had killed two girl students last Sunday night, District Attorney John Skahen announced.
BONN, Germany, March 11 -- More than 2,000,000 new jobs have been created in West Germany since economic recovery began with currency reform in the summer of 1948.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Treasury Department acted today to reopen trade in hog bristles and other Chinese-type goods originating in South Korea. Through arrangments concluded with the South Korean Republic, the Treasury Department announced it will facilitate the importation of the bristles and act promptly to expand the concession to other types of products.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 11 (AP) -- East Texas State of Commerce led all the way in defeating St. Peter's College of Jersey City, 85 -- 68, today in the opening second round game of the National Association of Intercollegiate Basketball tournament.

Twenty-eight survivors from the Liberian tanker Angy, which split in two on Sunday in storm-tossed North Atlantic waters as the result of fire and explosion, were removed yesterday from the ship's stern section by the American freighter Claiborne.

The shipping industry is maintaining a close watch on the progress of a report advocating the relaxation of the fifty-fifty division of Government-financed cargoes. The report, which was handed to President Eisenhower last week, evoked strong protests yesterday from three maritime unions.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11 -- Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, charged tonight that the failure of some national leaders, Republicans and Democrats alike, to tell "the whole brutal truth about the world" has harmed this country and, unless the policy is changed, "may destroy us."

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- President Eisenhower took another step today to give positive direction to the National Security Council, the agency having the greatest responsibility for the nation's strategy.

ST. LOUIS, March 11 (AP) -- Archie Moore, the light-heavyweight champion, battered Nino Valdes for a unanimous decision tonight in their ten-round nationally televised bout at the St. Louis Arena. Moore weighed 180 pounds and Valdes, a big but agile Cuban, scaled 209 1/2.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11 -- Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad declared today a dividend of 75 cents a share on capital stock, representing an increase of 25 cents a share over the semi-annual dividends of 50 cents paid for the last three years.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 11 -- The winning streak being complied by the Yankees came to an abrupt end today when the Senators scored four runs in the fifth inning for a 7-4 victory at Tinker Field. The Bombers had won three in a row and were leading in this one, 3 to 0, when the roof caved in on Right-Hander Al Cicotte.

Improvements in the use of nuclear fissionable materials are "snowballing," it was reported yesterday by Dr. Clarence E. Larson, director of the Oak Ridge National Laboratory of the Atomic Energy Commission.
The Board of Transportation announced yesterday that it expected to save $294,825 in the purchase of 900,000 tons of coal because it had rejected bids made two weeks ago in the declining coal market.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee investigating Communist infiltration of education was told by the president of Brooklyn College today that communism was "on the run," especially in schools and institutions of higher learning.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (UP) -- The Defense Department announced today that United States battle casualties in Korea rose 260 last week to a new total of 130,992. The list includes 23,134 dead, 95,063 wounded, 9,184 missing, 2,215 captured and 1,396 previously missing but returned to military control.

Prices closed irregularly lower yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Volume was generally below normal levels but domestic sugar was active. Rubber, potatoes, sugar, lead, zinc and hides were lower. Cocoa, wool, cottonseed oil and soybean oil ended higher and tin closed mixed with no sales.

New York's thrifty may be enabled to enjoy additional returns from their savings bank accounts under a proposal advanced yesterday. Richard L. Maloney Jr., president of The New York Savings Bank, suggested that the Banking Board consider "removal" of the ceiling on the saving bank dividend rate of 2 1/2 per cent.

Stocks opened quietly yesterday, picked up momentum under the leadership of the steels and motors and drove ahead to make the best gains since Nov. 18 and record the second best day since the November election. Advances ranged from fractions to 3 points.
CAMP DRUM, N. Y., March 11 -- United States forces, represented by the 504th Regimental Combat team, consolidated their gains today, after driving ahead three miles today in a pre-dawn "assault."

" The United States and Mexico," by Howard F. Cline, an evaluation of modern Mexico and American foreign policy, will be published on March 23 by Harvard University Press. Mr. Cline reviews the geographical, historical, political, economic and social background of Mexico and discusses this country's policy "for good and for ill" vis-a-vis our Southern neighbor.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 11 -- Leadership of the campaign against the restriction of public liberties and the intensification of racial segregation apparently is passing into the hands of the clergy, notably that of the Anglican Church.
Blood donors at the Naval Supply Depot in Bayonne, N. J., received added encouragement Tuesday when Bill Haymes, entertainer, sang there while donating a pint of his blood to a Red Cross bloodmobile.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower conducted her first press conference in the White House at 11 A. M. today and reporters got a gay self-portrait of a First Lady who enjoyed her job.
The Weather Bureau yesterday issued the following forecasts and lists of winter sports conditions:

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- A "dramatic new approach" to the problem of lagging American private capital investment abroad and appointment of an Ambassador Extraordinary to underdeveloped areas has been proposed by Eric Johnston, chairman of the International Development Advisory Board.
BONN, Germany, March 11 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and his Government are resolved to go to great lengths to improve French-German relations and thus strengthen the base of European unity.

A major baking company has just announced that it is adding vitamin D to its white bread. This nutrient, in adequate amounts in infant feeding, prevents the rickets that used to be a major plague of childhood. It assists in the utilization of bone-building calcium, and that is why it was introduced into a prime calcium source -- fresh and evaporated milk -- some time ago.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 11 -- To meet the needs of an economy that has grown rapidly since the Second World War, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development made a loan of $14,000,000 today to Northern Rhodesia.

A vacant plot 130 by 100 feet at 8629 Bay Parkway in Brooklyn has been purchased as a site for a home for the aged by the First United Lemberger Ladies Charity, Inc., represented by Robert Feingold, attorney. The Relco Holding Corporation was the seller and the Greenfield Sales Company was the broker.

STRASBOURG, France, March 11 -- In the opinion of members of the special European Constitutional Assembly, the document they adopted last night and forwarded to their Governments today affords a decisive if modest start toward European union. Accepted only by France, West Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg, it nevertheless represents resources and population equivalent to those of the United States and remains open for the admission of the other free nations of Europe.

Before the thirty-seventh International Flower Show starts its fifth day at 10 A. M. today, gardens that were in bloom on Sunday will have been freshened and new entries of cut flowers will have been added. Today camellias, roses and freesias, amaryllis and African violets compete for honors as well as the admiration of visitors.

ALBANY, March 11 -- In the second of a series of special messages on New York City finances, Governor Dewey urged the Legislature today to ratify a constitutional amendment that would enable the city to obtain $100,000,000 more a year from real estate taxes.

ALBANY, March 11 -- The Joint Legislative Committee on the Sabbath Law rejected today a proposal that persons who observed Saturday as their Sabbath day be permitted to conduct their businesses on Sunday if this did not interfere with the rest and repose of the balance of the community.

TRENTON, March 11 -- Former State Senator Robert B. Meyner, with the approval of prominent party leaders, today announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Governor. As a result of his action, the party was started on its first primary contest for Governor since the Nineteen Twenties.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 11 -- Informed Indonesian quarters said today that there was little likelihood that Indonesia would follow Britain's lead in denying port facilities to ships carrying strategic war materials to Communist China, although, as a member of the United Nations, this country has embargoed the shipment of vital raw materials, such as rubber.

Lord Dunsany, Irish poet and playwright, will arrive here this morning aboard the Queen Mary for a holiday and business visit. The 75-year-old dean of Irish letters will be met by Eddie Dowling, for whom he will read a play, and by Patrick Mahony, Irish playwright and author of "The Magic Of Maeterlinck," a biography of the Belgian author.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra under Charles Munch began its final visit of the season at Carnegie Hall last night, but even though it will be back in Boston next week, the bulk of its seasonal traveling lies ahead of it. In April the orchestra takes off on a trans-continental tour, and if it keeps on playing as it did last night, the communities on the orchestra's itinerary may look forward to some lively music-making.
MERCED, Calif., March 11 (AP) -- The boycott of Tanforan race track by the Horsemen's Benevolent Protective Association and the Jockey's Guild was ended today.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- An Apprpriations subcommittee of the House of Representatives turned its fire today on eight members of the Truman Cabinet who, before leaving the Government, drew lump-sum payments for accumulated leave ranging from $3,900 to $6,900.

With play resuming tonight at Madison Square Garden in the National Invitation Tournament, local basketball fans are hopeful that an all-Metropolitan district final may result. In the first game of this evening's semi-final, St. John's will oppose Duquesne at 7:45 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Congressional committees seeking to draft a bill to settle the offshore oil dispute, found themselves stalled today over conflicting views of President Eisenhower and Cabinet members.

NEWARK, March 11 -- Fumes caused by a fire killed fourteen workmen today when they were trapped in huge metal tanks of the $20,000,000 Anheuser-Busch Brewery. More than thirty others were taken to hospitals.

BONN, Germany, March 11 -- The Czechoslovak Government protested today that the two planes of a United States air patrol, one of which was shot down yesterday by Czechoslovak jets, had violated "Czechoslovak air space." Investigating officers of the United States Air Forces in Germany dismissed the protest as ridiculous.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 11 (UP) -- Henry Ford II, president of the Ford Motor Company, called upon big business today to "deal with the Government on a basis of mutual understanding, rather than partisan hostility."
WASHINGTON, March 11 (UP) -- President Eisenhower has decided to keep the Presidential yacht Williamsburg in service for intimate government conferences, the Navy disclosed today.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 11 -- The dedication of the Dodgers' beautiful little Holman Stadium today was a rousing success on all counts. There were more fans, 5,532, than there were seats and the Brooks scored their fifth straight Grapefruit League triumph by beating the Athletics, 4 -- 2.

Twenty public school teachers suspected of possible membership in the Communist party will be called before the Board of Education's special investigator within the next four weeks, it was learned yesterday.

The long series of Communist provocations which began with Soviet attacks on American airplanes in the Far East as far back as August, 1945, and has thus far involved at least a dozen American and several other Western aircraft, has now reached a climax in the shooting down of an American jet fighter over Germany.

PITTSBURGH, March 11 (AP) -- David J. McDonald, who learned trade unionism as the late Philip Murray's secretary, followed his teacher into the presidency of the United Steel Workers today with a promise to make his union the largest in the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

In commending the work of the Organization for Rehabilitation through Training to the citizens of New York Governor Dewey gives recognition to a group that has done much to aid and rehabilitate the uprooted and downtrodden Jewish people of the world. On its twenty-sixth anniversary it can report notable progress in breaking down the walls of the economic ghettos which have plagued the Jews throughout their history.

Carrie Munn calls her spring custom collection "wonderful nonsense." Show yesterday at 640 Madison Avenue, it was all of that, delightful froth and whimsy. This designer feels no compulsion to create along more or less orthodox lines. She designs what she feels is gay and amusing, and the whole collection reflects it.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 11 -- Miss Margaret Webster, Shakespearean director and actress, appeared today before a legislative committee at the state capital to urge lease of state-owned land to build the proposed American Shakespeare Festival Theatre and Academy.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 11 -- "Some hope" of increasing trade with Latin American countries was reported today by Robert H. Wylie, San Francisco port manager, on his return from a tour of that region.

In the fashion show presented by Rosette Pennington of 20 East Fifty-sixth Street at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday, spring evening designs were dramatic and flattering. Filmy sheers in exotic color combinations depicted a season of evening elegance. To the full-length dresses, the emphasis was on the graceful waltz-length.

LONDON, March 11 -- An agreement between a new Anglo-Canadian syndicate and the Government of Newfoundland to explore and exploit selected areas in Newfoundland and Labrador was announced here tonight.

AMONG the knightly years that have gone with the old world to the grave (or into historical novels) few are more stirring than those that concerned Roland and Oliver and Charlemagne and the traitorous Ganelon in the passages of Spain. Out of the "Song of Roland" Mario Pei has made one more romance, "Swords of Anjou."*

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 11 -- Now that Red Skelton is back in shape again, following a siege of illness, Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer is planning to keep him busy. After the completion of "The Great Diamond Robbery," which had to be postponed when the comedian was hospitalized last December, Mr. Skelton will become involved with "Half a Hero," now taking final shape in the typewriter of Max Shulman.

The Columbia Theatre Associates last night gave the first of seven performances m Brander Matthews Hall of a new "ballet-biography" of Edgar Allan Poe entitled, "Poor Eddy," written by Elizabeth Dooley, with music by Albert Rivett, choreography by Doris Humphrey, direction by Milton Smith, scenery by Lester Polakoff, and with Charles Weidman in the title role.

MOORESTOWN, N. J., March 11 -- Motorists who travel on the 118-mile New Jersey Turnpike are learning the hard way that a heavy foot on the "gas" pedal can prove costly on this heavily policed toll road.

The Herman Hickman television program, presented on Friday evenings over the N. B. C. network, will move to the A. B. C. network on March 29, where it will be offered on Sundays from 6:30 to 6:45 P. M. The General Cigar Company will continue as sponsor.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, March 11 (UP) -- The Fairbanks News-Miner reported today that a yellow air attack alert was called in Alaska Saturday night from the Aleutian Islands to Anchorage and Fairbanks.

The Studebaker Corporation, which began in 1852 as a small blacksmith and wagon-building shop with a capital of $68,000 and two proprietor-employes, last year made $14,291,789 on record sales of $585,313,447. It starts its second century with a net worth of over $112,000,000 and more than 26,000 employes.

A new manual containing the first major changes in twenty-five years in departmental classification of merchandise for department stores was issued yesterday by the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

" What does the boss do with all the money the company takes in," no longer is a whispered question in lunch rooms. More and more corporations these days in the interest of better employe relations are distributing separate annual reports to employes, much the same as those sent to shareholders.

CHICAGO, March 11 (UP) -- The council of the Chicago Medical Society has voted to dismiss charges of unethical conduct against Dr. Loyal Davis, a prominent surgeon, who charged that fee splitting was becoming increasingly common here.

A major factor in the battle against domestic and international communism is the elimination of discrimination based on creed, race, color or national origin in employment and in places of public accommodation, resort or amusement, the New York State Commission Against Discrimination said yesterday.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 11 (AP) -- Ralph Kiner, the Pirates' home run king, promised today to report immediately to the Havana training camp if Branch Rickey, general manager, would hold to a previous salary offer.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended March 4:

With goodwill now valued more highly than ever, the advertising specialty business will continue to grow and prosper, it was predicted yesterday by W. E. Coffman, president of the Advertising Specialty National Association.

LONDON, March 11 -- In a blunt rebuttal to Egyptian accusations, Selwyn Lloyd, British Minister of State, declared today that it was "absolutely untrue" that the British Government was failing to carry out in good faith the Anglo-Egyptian agreement on the political future of the Sudan.

As expected, Governor Dewey has endorsed reluctantly for second and final passage a constitutional increase in the rate that New York City can exact in taxation of real estate. The proposed amendment would have to go to referendum in November, and as a hedge against possible defeat he offers a county real estate tax as a stopgap substitute.

All speculation (most of it futile) on possible changes in the foreign policy of the Soviet Union following Stalin's death notwithstanding, the war in Korea and Indo-China continues. Our new Administration is putting more pressure on the Communist forces in the Far East so as to make it a bit more profitable for Moscow to stop supplying materiel to its Chinese satellites.

Three masked bandits, one of them armed, entered the basement office of the Swiss Pavilion Restaurant at 38 East Fiftieth Street yesterday and took $900 from Paul Berger, the proprietor, and $10 from a delivery boy.

New issues of debt securities totaling $50,000,000 will be placed on the market today by underwriting syndicates. The offerings are intended to increase working capital of a finance company and to finance new construction projects of two public utility companies. The new issues are as follows:
The consumer remains boss of the American economy, supply and demand still dictate retail prices and fair-trade legislation will not bolster retail levels in a sagging market.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses announced yesterday that the Mayor's Committee on Slum Clearance, of which he is chairman, had recommended a new slum clearance study for a section of Greenwich Village. The survey would be made in connection with a plan for 1,000 new apartments, new buildings for New York University and a new school and playground.

A letter that arrived last week at Metropolitan Opera Fund headquarters, 530 Fifth Avenue, contained not the expected contribution, but a bill. Although the yellowed document was non-negotiable, fund officials were as delighted as if it had been a three-figure check.

LONDON, March 11 -- It was no particular surprise to oil men in London today when a Venice court ruled against the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company in its efforts to get possession of a cargo of Iranian oil.

Akron, Ohio, sold $6,745,000 of school bonds yesterday, due from 1954 to 1974, to a syndicate headed by National City Bank of New York at a bid of 100.52 for interest of 2 3/4 per cent. Reoffering was at yields ranging from 1.3 per cent to 2.95 per cent.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 11 (UP) -- Lou Perini president of the Braves, proposed today that the major leagues adopt a rule prohibiting the transfer of a big-league franchise to a minor league city before Oct. 1.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 11 -- The Italian court decision rejecting British claims on Iran's nationalized oil was believed here to have strengthened Premier Mohammed Mossadegh in his continuing struggle with internal political opponents and in his resistance to claims for compensation by the expropriated Anglo-Iranian Oil Company.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 11 -- Brazil's import economies, intended to cure her dollar deficit, are backfiring and throwing hundreds of workers out of employment.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- Senator Wayne Morse, Independent of Oregon, forced the Senate today to listen to the reading of a full account of its proceedings on Monday.

Once again the Government's annual report on American tobacco consumption reflects a booming national economy. The production and use of cigarettes, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics tells us, reached a new high last year, the 435,000,000,000 cigarettes manufactured representing a total 4 per cent higher than that reported in 1951.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 11 -- The Western powers split today on the selection of a successor to Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, who submitted his resignation last fall. The United States nominated Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, Philippine Ambassador to the United States, and Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Secretary of State for External Affairs, was nominated by Denmark with the support of Britain and France.

The Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway System reported yesterday a net income of $70,737,705 for 1952, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $13.29 a common share. This compared with $73,345,778, or $13.83, in 1951.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 12 (Delayed by Censor) -- The six-nation Commonwealth division, first of its kind in the history of British arms, has been withdrawn from the Korean battle front and placed in reserve for the first time since it was formed in July, 1951. The division was relieved in the line on Jan. 31.

Expressing belief that Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. was the logical choice for the Democratic nomination for Mayor Secretary of State Thomas F. Curran, New York County Republican Chairman, named yesterday nine Manhattan Republicans whom he would be willing to support for the Republican nomination.
CHICAGO, March 11 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Futures prices closed steady, 4 to 12 points higher on the day, after moderate trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old, a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
Recent discussions with regard to the Bricker amendment and other similar propositions touch on a point of the greatest importance to our country and to the world.
Frank Borrell, the easy-going police chief of Cliffside Park, N. J., was indicted yesterday, along with a cousin and two members of his police force, by the Bergen County rackets grand jury.

With a variety of factors tending to increase the period when young persons may be dependent on their parents, additional research is needed on problems of parent-child relationships when the child has reached adulthood, Dr. Jules V. Coleman declared yesterday.

A man who was arrested Tuesday night as drunk and disorderly was scolded by Magistrate Nicholas F. Delagi in mid-Manhattan Court yesterday for "baiting" a policeman at this time, when the Police Department is being investigated by the Federal Government for alleged beating of Negroes.

GENEVA, March 11 -- Gunnar Myrdal, Executive Secretary of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe told the Soviet Government today that he would not be bullied into breaking off informal relations between his United Nations secretariat and Western organizations of which the Russians do not approve.

SEOUL, Korea, March 11 -- The Rehabilitation Mission to Korea, sponsored by the American Korean Foundation, landed in Korea today to combat civilian illnesses and injuries resulting from the war. Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, president of Penn Stage College and younger brother of the President, is chairman of the foundation.

The Weylin Hotel, a fifteen-story building at 531 Madison Avenue, southeast corner of East Fifty-fourth Street, has been purchased by Byro Associates, Inc., a syndicate formed recently by business and professional men. The purchase, said to have been for a price exceeding $2,200,000, was made by acquiring the stock of the Hotel Weylin Company owned by Louis and Charles Loeber.

The four-story building containing sixteen small apartments at 41-30 Forty-third Street in Sunnyside, Queens, has been sold by Andrew Schelle to Elmer Royal for investment. The Advance Realty Company was the broker in the sale of the property which occupies a plot 38 by 100 feet.

MEXICO CITY, March 11 -- A crewman of one of the fifteen United States shrimp boats held in the Gulf of Mexico port of Campeche for alleged illegal fishing was shot and killed by a Mexican Army guard last night during a brawl on one of the boats.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- A Republican member of the Armed Services Committee of the House of Representatives accused the Army's General Staff today of engineering a scheme to create a "Prussian-type" command system for the Department of Defense.

DENVER, March 11 -- "Five of six" instructors suspected of un-American activities are still on the payroll of the University of Colorado, State Senator Morton G. Wyatt Jr., Republican of Lamar, declared today.

Curtained output in May and June because of industry-wide strikes and increased operating costs against lower average prices for some refined products reduced the net income of the Skelly Oil Company last year despite a higher gross income than in 1951.

LONDON, March 11 -- The stock markets were subdued today under the shadow of the international situation. Prices fell at the start and despite a rally small losses predominated. Rhodesian copper and oil shares provided an exception, both markets maintaining their rising trend.

RANGOON, Burma, March 11 (AP) -- Defense Minister Ba Swe said today the Burmese Government had conclusive proof "a few Americans" had been active in training and arming 12,000 Chinese Nationalist guerrillas now fighting Burma's army near this country's borders with Communist China and Thailand.
