SAN FRANCISCO, March 11 (AP) -- The defending champion, Willie Mosconi',-clinched :the world ]oplt billiard title forthe fourth'time in a row and the.eleventh.timein the .last twelve years when he defeated Luther Lassiter of Elizabetk-.City; mN C., 150-33, in two innings t'0-- ,night.

ALBANY, March 11 -- The Senate Majority Leader, Arthur H. Wicks of Kingston, announced today his support of the proposal to license chiropractors. He said he had been assured of enough votes for passage of the bill in the Senate.
ST. LOUIS, March 11 (AP) -- Beer can no longer be sold in ball parks of four Cardinal farm clubs, Anheuser-Busch Inc., owner of the Redbirds, announced today.
Future progress in civil rights will be largely a product of community action rather than court action, John N. Popham, Southern regional correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared yesterday.

PARIS, March 11 -- Eight months after its consideration of the measure began, the French National Assembly voted 390 to 210 today to approve a bill to amnesty several tens of thousands of Frenchmen convicted of having collaborated with the Nazis during World War II or of having supported the Vichy Government of Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 11 -- Col. C. C. Larsen, chief of Denmark's Eastern Air Command, said today that an examination of the MIG jet fighter that landed on Bornholm Island last Thursday had disclosed nothing that was not already known in the West about this Soviet-built aircraft. He said similar planes had been shot down by the United States Air Force in Korea.

Tommy Ivan's Detroit Red Wings, winners of the National Hockey League title for five straight seasons, made their final appearance of the season at Madison Square Garden last night and blanked the New York Rangers, 2 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson announced the creation today of the Foreign Agricultural Service, the primary responsibility of which will be to stimulate this country's sagging exports in agricultural products.

PARIS, March 11 (UP) -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery has changed his mind about dressing up like a Russian general to sit across the table from high Allied officers and point out weak points in the strategy as seen by Soviet eyes.

Following is the text of a policy statement on Congressional investigation of communism in education, adopted here yesterday by the general board of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.:

Wholesale prices of refined sugar were generally raised a quarter-cent a pound here yesterday, bringing it to 8 3/4 cents. First announcement came from National Sugar Refining Company, to go into effect at the close of business on Friday, March 20.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., March 11 (AP) -- A woman top kick is giving the orders now in an Air Force Headquarters Squadron Section composed of about 450 airmen and airwomen -- mostly men.

THE only angling tournament in which it is possible to take the first prize without producing a single fish on the dock is scheduled to begin on May 18, when the Bimini tuna tournament, sponsored by the Bimini Big Game Fishing Club, starts its five-day run.

A hundred firemen and twenty pieces of apparatus, including two fireboats, were employed yesterday in a ninety-minute battle with a fire in the understructure of Pier 13, North River, at Dey Street. Three alarms were sounded between 4 and 5 P. M.
A test of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act regarding the permanent resident status of 400 employes of the United Nations who are aliens was under way here yesterday.

TOKYO, Thursday, March 12 -- United Nations liaison officers at the truce conference site at Panmunjom told the Communists again yesterday that truck convoys moving on the North Korean roads ostensibly to supply the enemy armistice delegation had no immunity from air attack except churian border met a few enemy jets and "probably destroyed" one of the foe, the Air Force said.

If everyone were a Frenchman "My 3 Angels" would be celestial entertainment. This is the comedy that Sam and Bella Spewack have adapted from Albert Husson's "La Cuisine des Anges." With Walter Slezak mincing comically through the leading part, it opened at the Morosco last evening under the direction of that protean man of the theatre, Jose Ferrer.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- A resolution for the removal of Representative Harold H. Velde, Republican of Illinois, as chairman of the Committee on Un-American Activities, was introduced in the House of Representatives today by Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Democrat of Manhattan.

For the third time in six years the House of Representatives has voted to grant statehood to Hawaii. On the two previous occasions, in 1947 and 1950, the bill failed to come to a vote in the Senate. But the prospects now appear to be brighter than ever before, as last year for the first time the platforms of both parties favored "immediate" statehood for the islands.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Supreme Court heard arguments today, then took under advisement an appeal by the Times-Picayune Publishing Company of New Orleans from an injunction granted by a Federal District court restraining it from using the unit rate, or forced combination, policy in selling advertising space in The Times-Picayune and The New Orleans States, morning and afternoon newspapers published by it.

NEW ORLEANS, March 11 (UP) -- Ben F. Whitaker, Texas oilman and sportsman, said today that Tahitian King, a top contender for the Kentucky Derby, would not enter the $40,000 Louisiana Derby at the Fair Grounds on Saturday because he was "not ready."

Educational and cultural groups in the metropolitan area banded together yesterday in a last-ditch stand for educational television in the event the plans of the State Board of Regents are defeated. They intend to fight for at least one station here.

ALBANY, March 11 (AP) -- New York's State Education Commissioner disclosed today that an employe named as a Communist informer at a United State Senate hearing still was a member of the Education Department's Albany staff.

Helen Traubel made her first appearance of the season in last night's "Tristan und Isolde" at the Metropolitan Opera, singing, of course, Isolde. Also in the otherwise familiar cast was Martha Lipton, singing her first Brangaene at the house. Fritz Stiedry conducted.

CHICAGO, March 11 (AP) -- Rodney Dee Brodie, the surviving one of Siamese twins, passed a milestone today in his long pull for a normal life when surgeons finally covered his brain completely with skin.

Despite a five-fold expansion in United States-India trade over the last fifteen years, there is still a wide range of economic opportunities open to American business, a fifteenth anniversary statement issued here yesterday by the India Chamber of Commerce of America noted.

ROME, March 11 -- Mme. Assila Sadek, mother of former Queen Narriman of Egypt, arrived in Rome at the end of last week, and since then a great number of rumors about the Egyptian Royal Family have been circulating.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (UP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to dismiss a demand by the Pennsylvania Railroad to raise intrastate fares on the Long Island Rail Road. The action means a hearing will be required on the Pennsylvania demand.

Walter P. Marshall, president of the Western Union Telegraph Company, declared yesterday that the company "is convinced that the nation can best be served by a unified telegraph system, both nationally and internationally, just as it is now served in the voice field by a unified telephone system."
MOSCOW, March 11 -- The Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov, today received the British Ambassador, Sir Alvary Gascoigne, for a ten-minute discussion in his Kremlin offices.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 11 -- The White Sox today appeared to be more like the entry that will represent Chicago in the American League this year than did the team that lost here yesterday.

A building containing a store and seventeen apartments at 211 East Twenty-first Street, near Gramercy Park, was sold by Schwartz Grossman to B. J. Frost for investment in a deal negotiated by Morris Balaban, broker, and Sherman Management Company, co-broker, in a deal marking the first change of ownership of the property in twenty-five years.
The Gouverneur Hospital Social Service Committee is in need of used clothing.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 11 (AP) -- Bruce S. Campbell's Ram o'War and Mrs. Vera S. Bragg's Tribe won the two divisions of the $15,000 added Fountain of Youth Handicap at Gulfstream Park today before a crowd of 18,501.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 11 -- George V. Allen, former United States Ambassador to this country, left here today after declaring that Yugoslavia was on the brink of a new era, domestically and internationally, that probably would be more significant than the period since the break with the Cominform.

A single blossom is featured in the "flower show" now on view at B. Altman. It is the "New Yorker rose" developed by Jackson Perkins. Long stemmed and brilliant red, it appears on a series of bedroom ensembles, on decorative fabrics and on ten table settings arranged by the garden clubs of New Jersey and New York.

Ireland wants more United States and Canadian tourists to view its many scenic and historic wonders and Donal F. Collins of Killarney, vice president of the Irish Tourists Association, arrived here yesterday on the Cunarder Samaria to see what could be done about it.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11 -- Bishop Fred P. Corson, head of the Methodist Church in the Philadelphia area and former president of Dickinson College, was elected chairman of the executive committee of Temple University's Board of Trustees today.
DETROIT, March 11 (AP) -- Chrysler Corporation announced today the development of a new powder metal with greatly improved capacity to withstand bending and twisting.

As the first Secretary-General of the United Nations, Trygve Lie has filled with dignity and a heroic effort to be impartial one of the most difficult posts in the world. He has served for seven years now and will serve until his term expires next February if there is no agreement on his successor in the current meetings of the Security Council.

CHICAGO, March 11 -- Government charges that the multi-million dollar purchasing operations of General Motors Corporation were revamped to suit du Pont sales wishes were denied under oath today by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., General Motors chairman, at the anti-trust trial before Judge Walter J. LaBuy in Federal District Court here.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- The Senate today confirmed Francis White, Baltimore business man and former United States Foreign Service officer, as Ambassador to Mexico.

TRENTON, March, 11 -- The text of a statement by Stanley Frank, a free lance writer, that was read today into the record of the New Jersey legislative committee that is investigating the ouster of Deputy Attorney General Nelson F. Stamler by Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons follows:

The National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. yesterday denounced "certain methods" of Congressional committees investigating communism in education, and authorized a "watchdog" committee to safeguard American freedom against both Communist infiltration and "wrong methods of meeting that infiltration."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 11 -- The United States charged before the United Nations today that the Soviet Union's leaders had decided on a planned policy of imperialism because they lived in fear of their own people.

The Girl Scouts of the United States of America, whose first troop was organized forty-one years ago today in Savannah, Ga., announced yesterday the receipt of anniversary congratulations from President Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The State Department's Voice of America has predicted that "blood will have to flow in the Kremlin" befor the world will know whether Georgi M. Malenkov is the "unchallenged" leader of the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Representative Frank J. Becker, Republican of Nassau County, said today that Carl R. Gray, administrator of Veterans Affairs, had agreed to stop putting state veterans' counselors out of veterans' hospitals and other veterans' facilities for at least the remainder of this session of Congress.

LONDON, March 11 -- Britain's priceless crown jewels, watched over in the Tower of London by a battalion of Her Majesty's Guards, will be removed in great secrecy to Westminster Abbey on a day just before the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II on June 2.

The note of elegance associated with the Coronation was sounded at Elizabeth Arden's yesterday afternoon, when her spring and summer collection, designed by Count Sarmi, was presented. The presentation worked up to a crescendo in the finale, when glamorous evening gowns were shown.

The student body and the press at New York University voiced a mixed reaction yesterday to the university's decision to drop football. Two undergraduate newspapers supported the discontinuance of the sport and two opposed the move.

ALBANY, March 11 -- Following is the text of a special message that Governor Dewey sent to the Legislature today urging the approval of a constitutional amendment increasing New York City's real estate tax limit:

The first awards in this area for the protection of plant personnel and equipment under the civil defense program were presented yesterday to the representatives of three corporations in a brief ceremony at City Hall.

PARIS, March 10 -- Ninety French Roman Catholic priests have left their churches and orders to go into factories in the principal industrial areas of France in an attempt to bridge the gap that has existed for more than a century and a half between the church and the French proletariat.

Electric power production for the week ended March 7 rose to 8,172,952,000 kilowatt-hours from 8,069,760,000 in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The figure for the week ended March 8, 1952, was 7,496,710,000.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 11 (AP) -- Robert Gordon 3enzies, Australian Prime lVlinis[er, in a bid to allay Washington and London fears, ordered Howard Beale, his Suply Minister, tonight to lrivestigate on the spot and in person the security situation at the Woomera rocket range.

The American Jewish Congress, an affiliate of the World Jewish Congress, said yesterday that Sydney Silverman, a Labor Member of Parliament, had not had the official support of the organization when he applied for a visa to speak at a dinner on behalf of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, convicted American traitors who are under sentence of death.

TRENTON, March 11 -- Charges that Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons had furnished the major part of the material contained in a Saturday Evening Post article that he sought to suppress were introduced today at a public hearing of a joint legislative committee investigating the ouster of Nelson F. Stamler as deputy attorney general.
Buying interest continued at the American Toy Fair yesterday. Attendance continued at record levels, with major producers reporting bookings considerably ahead of last year.

BOSTON, March 11 (AP) -- The high-flying New York Knicker-bockers were forced to play three overtime periods to defeat the Baltimore Bullets, 113 -- 107, tonight in a National Basketball Association game at Boston Garden.

HARRISBURG, March 11 -- High speed is not the major cause of traffic accidents on the 327-mile Pennsylvania Turnpike, a legislative investigating committee was told today at a public hearing. Most mishaps, it was said, occur at speeds between forty-one and fifty miles an hour.
Increases in earnings, net assets and net asset value for the common stock were reported yesterday by the United Corporation in its annual report to stockholders for 1952.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 11 -- "A great game, baseball," said Eddie Stanky, a dreamy look in his eyes. "I learn something new about it every day. In fact, it's so great a game that Casey Stengel also learns something new about it every day. It's a never-ending source of wonder to me."

Judge Harold R. Medina of the United States Court of Appeals expressed disagreement yesterday with the idea that defense counsel in the investment banking antitrust trial should be informed at once whether Herbert Brownell, the new Attorney General, goes along with hold-over Department of Justice lawyers in their contention that the Securities and Exchange Commission has no jurisdiction over the market stabilization activities of underwriters.

A jury in Richmond County Court at St. George, S. I., required just thirty-five minutes late yesterday afternoon to acquit Mrs. Catherine Friedt, 25 years old, of 44 St. Stephen's Place, New Dorp, S. I., of the charge of murder in the second degree for the killing of her 8-month-old son, William Jr., on April 1, 1950.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 12 -- Yugoslavia offered informally today to make a treaty of friendship and collaboration with Britain similar to the Balkan treaty in which she is joined with Greece and Turkey.

Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, American Zionist leader assailed as "mischievous propaganda" last night reports that the United States Government "has especially favored the State of Israel and has poured fabulous sums of money into that country."

FREEHOLD, N. J., March 12 (AP) -- The home of racketeer Vito Genovese at Atlantic Highlands is scheduled to be sold by the Sheriff on April 6 to satisfy a $32,000 judgment brought by a construction concern.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- President Eisenhower submitted to Congress today a reorganization plan to convert the Federal Security Agency into a Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

ANTWERP, Belgium, March 12 (AP) -- Samuel Sedletz, a Brooklyn furrier, sailed for New York today on the motorship Luluaba under guard of two Brooklyn detectives. He was arrested here last December at the request of the Brooklyn police in connection with a $200,000 fur theft.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The last price controls on consumer goods were dropped by the Government today when the Office of Price Stabilization freed coffee, coffee concentrates, home heating oil, beer and ales, soybeans and animal feeds.

Prize-winning flowers at the International Flower Show in Grand Central Palace included yesterday a strain of carnations more than 125 years old, still other carnations, roses, and daffodils known to gardeners not longer than five years.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 12 -- Work to complete ten big air bases being built in France by the United States Air Force under the North Atlantic Treaty program will speed up in the next few weeks, according to military authorities here.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on March 7 totaled 685,016 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 16,211 cars, or 2.4 per cent more than in the preceding week, 28,096 cars, or 3.9 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 64,506 cars, or 8.6 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Guido Cantelli, guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, opened his concert last night in Carnegie Hall with the first performance of a C major symphony allegedly composed by Mozart when he was 14. Mozart could have written a fresh and fine symphony at that age.
New York Harbor's towboat workers yesterday voted formal acceptance of a 17-cent wage increase by a 3-to-1 margin.

Twelve thousand doctors who served in World War II have joined a new, nation-wide Medical Veterans Association, which is striving for a voice in the drafting of future legislation to provide medical manpower for the armed forces.

The International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., has filed a suit for $1,500,000 damages against eighteen steamship companies as a result of the strike of three locals of the American Federation of Labor dock union several months ago.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 12 -- The Boston Red Sox are a cinch to win the pennant. Whoa. Don't hurry me. Let me finish the sentence. Please. Ready? The Boston Red Sox are a cinch to win the pennant in approximately 1958. As far as 1953 is concerned -- well, they just ain't got nuthin'.
ROME, March 12 -- Pope Plus XII did not attend the solemn mass that was celebrated in the Sistine Chapel this morning to commemorate the fourteenth anniversary of his coronation.

HANOVER, N. H. March 12 -- An alarm against communism in the Americas and a blunt castigation of this country's "namby-pamby" policy toward Guatemala and other Communist-dominated states in Latin America were made today by Spruille Braden, former Assistant Secretary of State for American Republic Affairs, in a Great Issues lecture at Dartmouth College.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 12 -- The Technicolor Motion Picture Corporation announced today that its laboratories are prepared to develop and turn out prints of films photographed in rival single-negative processes such as Eastman Color and Ansco Color.

ALBANY, March 12 -- Governor Dewey proposed today in a special message to the Legislature that New York City be authorized to impose a payroll tax that is capable of producing $60,000,000 a year in additional revenue as part of a long-range plan for enabling the city to meet the mounting cost of local government.

A metallic gleam is perceptible in two of the three products announced yesterday as award winners in the annual design competition conducted by the American Institute of Decorators. The winning designers will receive citations, and the designs will be put on display for the twenty-second conference of the group at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, beginning March 28.

BAYONNE, N. J., March 12 -- The aircraft carrier Antietam, the first vessel of her type to be equipped with a new-type canted flight deck, arrived here today after a series of sea tests to determine the feasibility of the deck. Capt. Samuel G. Mitchell, skipper of the carrier, was the first pilot to land a jet plane on the new deck. More than 2,000 landings were made in the tests.
The Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, said yesterday that church people had an obligation to fight crime and civic corruption.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (UP) -- Secretary Benson said today the Government would support butter prices at from 63.75 to 66.75 cents a pound during the twelve months starting April 1, but he cautioned dairy farmers to make good on their pledge to "develop a new program that will reduce Government support purchases and minimize losses."

A civil service employe of the Navy was accidentally shot and killed at 2:15 P. M. yesterday in the fifteenth floor offices of the commandant of the Third Naval District at 90 Church Street. He was struck in the head by a bullet from a .38 caliber revolver being cleaned by a Marine sentry.

Sales, crude oil production and capital expenditures of the Shell Oil Company last year were the highest in its history in spite of critical shortages of certain materials, the thirty-first annual report informed stockholders yesterday.

The first two superexpress subway trains on the I. R. T. run from Flushing, Queens, to Times Square proved so successful yesterday that Sidney H. Bingham, chairman of the Board of Transportation, had trouble boarding one of the cars for the run that lessens the traveling time by 2 1/2 minutes.

ALBANY, March 12 -- A special state commission studying means of better co-operating state activities proposed today the appointment of an administrative officer for the state court system who would have charge of the business-management side of the judicial system.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (UP) -- The Foreign Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives said today that Russia had violated at least thirty-seven provisions of sixteen international agreements on seventy-two separate subjects since the end of World War II.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12 -- Long before the Yankees started to work here some three weeks ago, they were a "pat" ball club. Casey Stengel knew then who's who and where in his scheming for a fifth straight world championship.

A first issue of hospital revenue bonds of the Georgia State Hospital Authority is being offered to investors today by a banking syndicate headed by the Robinson-Humphrey Company, Inc., and Blyth Co., Inc.

The American Red Cross honored yesterday six blood program nurses who have served continuously for the last five years in donor centers or bloodmobile operations. Eleven home nursing and baby program instructors also were honored with service pins for long terms of Red Cross activity.

The battle of Park Commissioner Robert Moses versus Bronx Borough President James J. Lyons went into its second round yesterday as Mr. Lyons, staggering under a Moses punch of Wednesday, shot back at the Board of Estimate meeting by calling Mr. Moses a "Pooh-bah" and shouting that what Mr. Moses had said had been a "damnable lie."

One cannot separate, at least in American food habits, the lemon from the fish. That food of sea and stream demands a touch of acidity, supplied by the tang of the lithe yellow fruit in many ways. One thinks first perhaps of that indispensable squeeze of lemon that teases out the best in a raw oyster.

BOSTON, March 12 (UP) -- Boston rallied in the opening period tonight to tie the champion Detroit Red Wings, 2-2, before 7,494 Boston Garden fans in a National Hockey League game that enhanced the Bruins' chances for a berth in the Stanley Cup play-offs.

MOSCOW, March 12 -- Both Pravda and Izvestia devoted their leading editorials today to the cause of peace, which was described by Pravda as the "sacred desire of the peoples." Izvestia said that Soviet foreign policy had been, was and would be a "policy of peace and friendship between peoples."

NEW CITY, N. Y., March 12 -- Sixteen-year-old Carlton Brant Mason Jr., a slim six-footer, was put into Rockland County Jail here today to await trial for the murder last Sunday of two litle girls who were fellow boarders with him at the Lakeside School for underprivileged children.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, told Congress today that the Taft-Hartley Act had made labor-management relations less stable and had created an atmosphere that stifled union growth.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 12 -- The Yugoslav Government decided today to grant amnesty to a "small number" of peasants who have been imprisoned for failure to fulfill quotas in compulsory deliveries of agricultural products.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (UP) -- The American Federation of Labor said today Federal rent control was the "most vital" of anti-inflation measures and should be continued to save the "lowest income families" from rent increases of 10 to 36 per cent.

Louis Sheroff, a 31-year-old Queens letter carrier, told postal inspectors yesterday that "the job got too much for me" when he was accused of throwing away a bundle of mail scheduled for delivery on his route.

Vince Martinez, 23-year-old Paterson welterweight, will oppose Chico Vejar, 21-year-old Stamford (Conn.) collegian, in a ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight that is expected to draw one of the biggest "gates" in recent years.
Rain fell here and along most of the rest of the Atlantic Coast yesterday, on the sixty-fifth anniversary of the famous blizzard of '88.

After reading the articles by Peter Kihss which recently appeared in three consecutive issues of THE TIMES it is apparent that there has been some exaggeration concerning the home relief case load having gone up considerably because of the large number of Puerto Rican migrants. Mr. Kihss' investigations, both in Puerto Rico and here, have covered in a very thorough manner this socio-economic problem; in doing so your newspaper has performed another valuable public service.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 12 -- Gil Hodges hit his second two-run homer of the exhibition season in the first inning today but thereafter the Dodgers fell apart and the Athletics beat them, 8 -- 2. It was the Brooks' first loss in six games.

A three-story taxpayer building containing six stores and twelve apartments at 21-16 to 21-24 Cornega Avenue in Far Rockaway, Queens, has been purchased by Joseph and Fanny Rosenfeld from the 2116 Cornega Realty Corporation. Allan S. Feldman Co. and Benjamin Horowitz were the brokers.

International airlines serving the United States announced yesterday through the New York office of the International Air Transport Association that beginning March 23 they would pay a new, uniform rate of commission to their travel agents for international passages.

First signs of spring are showing up at market stands. Strawberries from Louisiana, dandelion greens from New Jersey, the first carload of asparagus from California and larger shipments of buck shad from the Carolinas and Georgia are giving the markets a new look.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Rules establishing procedures by which witnesses whose reputations have been attacked at public hearings may present evidence and question witnesses in their own defense were announced today by Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of upstate New York, chairman of the House Judiciary subcommittee to investigate the Department of Justice.

The Queensboro Council for Social Welfare has been told by the Roman Catholic Charities of Brooklyn that Catholic agencies would withdraw from the council if planned parenthood groups remain as members.

Two hundred persons were forced to evacuate a fifteen-story midtown office building just before noon yesterday when a fire broke out among stocks of synthetic buttons stored in the tenth-floor quarters of a button-manufacturing concern.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Eisenhower Administration agreed today to give Congress by May 1 its estimate of necessary. Federal expenditures in the 1954 fiscal year, which starts July 1, so that decisions on tax reduction and related legislative problems could be made without further delay.

Whitney North Seymour, a former president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, who has been installed as the new president of the American Arbitration Association, has outlined a constructive program for this nonprofit organization's work in the next year.

AN AIR BASE IN KOREA, Friday, March 13 (AP) -- Lieut. Dick Kempthorn, a star in the Michigan backfield in 1949, ripped off a canopy and a gunsight mounting with his bare hands and freed a fellow pilot from a burning fighter plane recently.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12 (AP) -- America's touring troupe of golf professionals, aided by rarely used "winter rules," gave par a beating today in the first round of the $10,000 St. Petersburg open tournament.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 12 (UP) -- A new robot has been developed for the Air Force that enables a plane to take off, fly to a given destination and land without a human hand touching the controls.
The Concert Choir Margaret Hillis conducting, presented its last concert but one of the season at Town Hall last evening.

LONDON, Friday, March 13 (AP) -- A British sculptor won first, prize today and a Russian-born American split the second prize with three others in the "unknown political prisoner" sculpture competition. Two Americans were among seven sharing the third prize in the competition sponsored by the British Institute of Contemporary Art.
Subtly handled, easy-to-wear and feminine designs were characteristic of Marion Vallee's hats shown yesterday at the noon hour in the millinery department of Saks-34th.
The Cunard liner Queen Mary docked here early yesterday morning, more than a day behind schedule because of Channel fog and North Atlantic storms.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A recommendation that the Government, as a means toward stabilizing the livestock market, consider the purchase of beef to feed Republic of Korea troops was advanced to the Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson, today by a livestock industry committee.

The renewal of demand for wool sweaters as a basic item in men's and boys' apparel stocks this fall was predicted yesterday by Michael Pauker, president of Barclay Knitwear Company, Inc. He said his company, one of the largest in the knitwear field, is planning a 40 per cent increase in sweater production and four-fifths of the output will be in worsteds.
Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, declared here last night that the free world must not change its foreign policy because of the death of Premier Stalin.
The Coast Guard continued yesterday its sea and air search for eight persons adrift on the 240-foot bow section of the split Liberian tanker Angry.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The report of Arthur J. Altmeyer, Social Security Commissioner, for the fiscal year that ended June 30, 1952, issued today, urged extending as soon as possible Old Age and Survivors Insurance to cover the 13 per cent of the paid civilian jobs not yet under a retirement system.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Arthur Gardner, vice president of the Bundy Tubing Company, Detroit, has been selected to be Ambassador to Cuba.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- During the week ended March 11, member bank reserves increased $122,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Selling methods will have to change, since the American woman, who does most of the buying in this country, has changed in the last decade, Samuel H. Black said yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Home Fashions League in the Roosevelt Hotel
Three of this week's art exhibitions are, for quite different reasons, worthy of attention from gallery-goers.

LAST September George Santayana died in Rome, a frail old philosopher who had been retired from his Harvard professorship for forty years. For his last twenty years he had lived in Rome, indifferent to the shrill clamor of the Fascisti and unmoved by the frightfulness and vast suffering of World War II because such a spectacle of human folly was no more than his philosophy of pessimism and disillusion had led him to expect.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A subcommittee of five Senators, headed by Mrs. Margaret Chase Smith, Republican of Maine, was appointed today to carry forward the Armed Services Committee's investigation of ammunition short-ages in the military forces with a view to finding "the officials and conditions responsible for this situation."

ROME, March 12 -- Former Queen Narriman of Egypt left her husband, the deposed King Farouk, and departed by air today for Zurich, Switzerland, with her mother, Mme. Assila Sadek. The infant king of Egypt, Fuad II, remained in Rome with his father.

The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway borrowed $7,950,000 in the public market yesterday on trust certficates maturing over fifteen years to help finance the acquisition of new equipment costing about $10,022,886.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Un-American Activities Committee of the House of Representatives today adopted a resolution barring the start or announcement of any new investigation unless approved by the full committee.
BERLIN, March 12 -- The West Berlin police said today they had arrested one of four men who last July 8 kidnapped Dr. Walter Linse, anti-Communist leader in West Berlin.

TOKYO, March 12 -- Adlai E. Stevenson said today that the Orient is the modern world's "area of decision" and urged free Asians to join together in opposing Communist imperialism with strength and patience.
TRENTON, March 12 -- Major contests were forecast today in both the Democratic and Republican state primaries.

AUGUSTA Ga., March 12 (AP) -- Patty Berg, the professional from St. Andrews, Ill., put her putter to work today and in scoring a 72 took a two-stroke lead in the fourteenth annual women's titleholders golf championship.

The city's vast slum-clearance program, which so far has involved the expenditure and commitment of millions of dollars and the relocation of thousands of families, came under attack yesterday by top city officials at the Board of Estimate's meeting in City Hall.

The Lehigh Valley Railroad Company last year purchased system bonds of the face value of $14,513,000 at a total cost of $11,300,457, according to the road's pamphlet report for 1952. At the year-end the bonded debt of the road in the hands of the public amounted to $79,536,500.

Arthur Godfrey will take a leave of absence from his television and radio programs at the end of April to undergo a surgical operation in an effort to correct the effect of hip injuries he suffered in an automobile accident twenty-years ago.

LONDON, March 12 -- On the authority of Prime Minister Churchill himself Britain's High Commissioner in Germany, Sir Ivone Kirkpatrick, was instructed tonight to protest to the Chairman of the Soviet Control Commission "in the strongest terms" against the "deliberate attack" on the British bomber over Germany.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Department store sales in the 'week ended-March 7 were 8 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1952:

It will be Seton Hall against St. John's in the final of the National Invitation Tournament tomorrow night. This was resolved last night at Madison Square Garden when Seton Hall lived up to expectations by defeating Manhattan, 74 -- 56, and St. John's upset Duquesne, 64 -- 55.

Preparations for tax payments raised business loans from New York banks $68,000,000 last week, according to data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The advance, the third in so many weeks, cut the decline in business borrowings since the start of this year to $95,000,000, against a rise of $46,000,000 a year ago.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- Business should make plans to bring about a substantial increase in consumer spending in the next two or three years to offset a decline in defense and investment spending, Prof. Sumner Slichter, Harvard University economist, asserted today. He addressed the annual conference of the Central States group of the Investment Bankers Association of America.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- A Rutgers Law School professor accused the House Un-American Activities Committee today of being prepared to "embark upon an investigative scrutiny of school and college classrooms on the basis of testimony by student-informers."

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 12 (AP) -- Mrs. Max Kahlbaum's Wardonna, a daughter of Challedon-War Risk, triumphed today at Gulfstream Park in the featured Rose of Sharon Purse, a six-furlong race for 3-year-old fillies.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 12 (AP) -- Jerry Moss, 16-year-old former national boys tennis champion, scored his second upset victory of the masters invitation today when he toppled Gustavo Palafox, Mexican champion, 0 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4.

As has happened so often this year, the market opened strong and optimistic, lost momentum and closed mixed and slightly lower on the day. Volume was 1,780,000 shares, against 1,890,000 on Wednesday, as activity petered-out in the afternoon.

The fabulous Gabor girls are ever with us, but it is sister Eva who moves to the head of the class for the moment. She has started her own disk jockey radio show from 12 midnight to 2 A. M. over station WABC, and yesterday morning she negotiated the coup of the season. For an hour and a half she made Walter Winchell sound like an ordinary mortal

BONN, Germany, March 12 -- The policy of the Communist party in West Germany remains one of implacable opposition to democratic rule, with the party relying on "demonstrations and strikes" to mobilize workers against the Allied-German treaties.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 12 -- French military circles now are awaiting a large scale offensive by the Communist-led Vietminh against Laos to start from Vietminh bases in the Thai tribal country of North Vietnam. If it materializes, it would be a resumption of the autumn drive that the victorious French defense of Nasan stopped. The Vietminh forces then abandoned their projected winter offensive against Laos.
Following is a list of past incidents between Soviet and Western aircraft in Europe, and between United States planes and Communist aircraft and guns in the Far East:

De Pinna has discovered a young man with a definite flair for creating millinery. Designer of both custom and ready-to-wear models, Mr. Harold came from Georgia to turn forth at the Plaza Hotel yesterday one of the most dramatic collections of hats in many a day.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Eisenhower Administration will soon issue an Executive order setting aside all recent postmaster examinations won by Democrats, a highly placed Republican Senator said today.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Farmers have put a record quantity of 445,800,000 bushels of 1952 crop wheat under the Government's price support program, involving an outlay of slightly more than a billion dollars.
MOBILE, Ala., March 12 -- Workers went back on the job today at the Alabama Dry Dock and Shipbuilding Company after union ratification of a new contract that ended an eleven-day strike.

Testimony presented to the Senate Armed Services Committee this week indicated there had been, at times, both absolute and relative ammunition shortages in Korea, though none of them had been serious enough to impair the combat effectiveness of the Eighth Army.
TOKYO, Friday, March 13 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,552, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korean time:

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 (UP) -- Dissension flared in the University of Pennsylvania football family today as Athletic Director Francis T. Murray criticized the policies of Head Coach George Munger, and the university president, William H. Du Barry, announced that a "searching study" of the institution's athletic policies was under way.

MIAMI, March 12 (AP) -- The Greentree Stable's Straight Face was withdrawn today from the $100,000 added Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park on March 21. Straight Face won the $153,600 Flamingo Stakes at Hialeah on Feb. 28.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (UP) -- House of Representative investigators charged today that the State Department had lacked authority for a "fantastic" $28,000,000 housing program for American Foreign Service employes in Germany. The project included a $151,000 mansion for each of five United States officials.

LONDON, March 12 -- The stock markets were upset in the last few minutes of business today by the news of the shooting down of a British bomber in Germany. Prices lost much of their early gains, which had been a consequence, to some extent, of yesterday's strength on Wall Street.

ALBANY, March 12 -- The Senate approved and sent to Governor Dewey today a bill designed to purge the "deadwood" from upstate voter registration rolls in districts having permanent non-personal registration.

LONDON, March 12 -- A surprise for London fashion circles this week has been the plan of Queen Elizabeth's dressmaker to turn over his millinery salon to the famous French milliner Madame Claude Saint Cyr.

MEXICO CITY, March -- Education Minister Jose Angel Ceniceros nipped a revival of an ancient and bitter Mexican controversy today by refusing to consider a petition for co-education in the capital's national school for teachers.

The nation's primary aluminum production in January increased by 12,973,008 pounds over the December output, reflecting the industry's growing capacity and a steady improvement in the hydroelectric power supply to aluminum plants in the Pacific Northwest.

Charging that New York City had fallen into a deplorable condition, morally, socially and financially under its present administration, Representative Jacob K. Javits declared last night that the Republican party must take the lead in organizing the good government forces of the city for the coming municipal campaign.

Directors of the United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company declared a dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock, payable on April 15. In 1952 the company distributed dividends totaling $3 a share on the common stock, with payments of 75 cents each in March and June, 50 cents a share in September and $1 a share in December.

The declaration of the National Council of Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. on the proper functioning of Congressional investigating committees is a vigorous restatement of some elementary principles that too many people seem to have forgotten.
Your recent editorial calling attention to important matters now before the State Legislature for action is timely and should be given careful consideration by the people of this state.

" Why Did They Kill," a new work by John Bartlow Martin, will be issued by Ballantine Books on Monday in two editions, a paperbound at 35 cents and a hardcover edition at $1.50. It is a criminal case history of the murder of Paulina Campbell, a nurse, at Ann Arbor, Mich., in September, 1951.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 12 -- Film rights to the 1952 Pulitzer Prize play, "The Shrike," have been purchased by Jose Ferrer, who produced, directed and starred in it on Broadway. The sale, negotiated with Joseph Kramm, author of the melodrama, was a cash deal for an undisclosed sum.

A 14-year-old youth was shot in the back at 7 o'clock last night as he fled from an off-duty policeman who had sought to ques-from him at Lexington Avenue and Eighty-third Street after a complaint that the victim and a companion had been acting suspiciously.

Dorothy Hill, 15-year-old junior at the High School of Music and Art, has won first prize in the Fifth Annual Composition Contest sponsored by the Young People's Concerts Committee of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York, the society announced yesterday.

TOKYO, Friday, March 13 -- Eighth Army troops slashed through the Communist lines yesterday and rescued an Allied patrol surrounded and outnumbered by Chinese Reds south of Pyonggang on the central Korean front. Army censorship permitted identification of the rescuers as "European."

Strategic moves of an unprecedented nature will affect two of Broadway's outstanding musicals, "South Pacific" and "Guys and Dolls." According to a spokesman for "South Pacific," what is being planned is this:

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., March 12 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers clinched their first Eastern Division title in the National Basketball Association when they rallied in the final period tonight to beat the Philadelphia Warriors, 90 -- 85.
As an ardent reader of your International Edition I would like to express my opinion about a matter of general interest. Its subject concerns the necessity of blockading continental China.

LUENEBURG, Germany, Friday, March 13 -- Two Soviet MIG has shot down a four-engine British bomber in flames yesterday after a swift foray above the Elbe River valley at the East-West frontier of Germany.

Three thousand nine hundred and eighty-two teen-age journalists vied with the rain on the Columbia University campus yesterday on the opening day of the twenty-ninth annual convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association.
Leading zinc sellers reported yesterday they had received telephoned requests from the General Services Administration for offers of zinc for the national stockpile.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 12 -- The Eisenhower Administration has informed diplomats attending the United Nations General Assembly session that it will ask Congress to continue foreign military and economic assistance at the same level during the 1954 fiscal year, beginning July 1, as during the current fiscal year.
Paul Ronty, 24-year-old center of the New York Rangers, was named yesterday as the team's most valuable player by members of the New York Hockey Writers Association.
PARIS, March 12 -- Two factions disputing the custody of two missing Jewish orphans have reached an agreement that is expected to speed the children's return to France.

It has long been evident that the vast welfare activities of the Federal Government might well be united in a single department under a secretary with Cabinet rank. This much was advocated by the Hoover Commission four years ago. The proposal met with no serious objection on general grounds of principle but failed to be carried out under President Truman largely because of political opposition to former Federal Security Administrator Oscar Ewing.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 (AP) -- The nineteen-day-old trial of the Government's anti-trust suit against the National Football League was concluded today but the decision is not expected before September, at the earliest.

The committee on Federal legislation of the New York County Lawyers Association reported yesterday its disapproval of the proposed Bricker Amendment, which would limit the power of the President to make treaties and executive agreements with foreign powers.

Michael Dalessio, described as Staten Island's top racketeer, pleaded not guilty yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court to an indictment charging him with cheating the Government out of $93,118 in income taxes for 1946 through 1950.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Lord Ismay, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, warned today that an "ominous" rise in the Soviet Union's industrial capacity threatened the margin of supremacy now held by the free nations of Western Europe.
OBERLIN, Ohio, March 12 (AP) -- All but one of the fifty high - school - age youngsters Oberlin admitted a year and a half early did well, the college said today.
ALBANY, March 12 -- Following is the text of a special message sent by Governor Dewey to the Legislature today proposing that New York City receive authority to impose a payroll tax:

LONDON, March 12 -- Assertions published last week in the British Medical Journal that chlorophyll had failed under laboratory conditions to destroy various odors have been indignantly repudiated by British chlorophyll manufacturers. They have filled three columns of the current issue of the Journal with protests.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The New England Electric System, Northern Berkshire Gas Company and Berkshire Gas Company, all of Boston, applied today to the Securities and Exchange Commission for an order authorizing Northern Berkshire to sell its gas properties and business to Berkshire Gas.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 12 (UP) -- A syndicate rivaling the interests of Annheuser-Busch, Inc., which recently bought the Cardinals, is attempting to purchase the Browns and move the franchise to Milwaukee, but the transaction will be delayed at least a year, the United Press learned today.

MACAO, March 12 -- Lafsami Island, which lies north of the historic pirate hideouts in the Ladrones, has become a busy way station for transporting strategic goods to Communist China. The goods are reaching China over a sea route that short-circuits Western embargo controls almost midway between British Hong Kong and Portuguese Macao.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- Paint, sports and argument were blended at the du Pont anti-trust trial today before Federal District Judge Walter J. LaBuy as defense and Government lawyers took turns in questioning James Lynah, a 71-year-old former General Motors Corporation official who, a few years ago, sponsored an ill-fated "sanity code" for colleges in recruiting athletic talent.

Large-scale lay-off of workers by two important foreign plants in Brazil, on the grounds that import restrictions on parts and materials have forced curtailment, was viewed in foreign trade circles here yesterday as a move to gain some concessions from authorities.

NEWARK, March 12 -- Three agencies today opened investigations into the origin of the fire in the fermentation plant addition to the Anheuser-Busch Brewery yesterday in which thirteen workmen died from asphyxiation and at least thirty were injured.

BALTIMORE, March 12 (AP) -- Baltimore's Mayor Thomas D'Alesandro Jr. tonight confirmed reports that negotiations had been under way "for some weeks" to effect a transfer of the Browns to the Maryland city.
Following is the text of the speech delivered by British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden to the Foreign Policy Association here last night as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

A large-scale advertising and promotional effort on behalf of the bedding industry is planned this year from April 13 through April 25. This is the period of the bedding industry's annual promotion known as the "National Sleep Show," which means that bedding dealers will set up special displays and with manufacturers will loose a barrage of local and national ads in all media.

LONDON, March 12 -- From the Socialist left in Britain there is now arising an increasingly clamorous demand for negotiations with the new Soviet regime, for a meeting of Premier Georgi M. Malenkov, President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Churchill.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 12 -- The Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly approved today a resolution directing an "earnest appeal" to the Soviet Union and the satellite states to permit repatriation on a voluntary basis of about 3,000 Greek soldiers who were captured during the Grek civil war and have been held behind the Iron Curtain.

To strangers entering the New York Public Library through the Fifth Avenue entrance on March 22 and for two months thereafter, the stately arcade main lobby will look just as a library is supposed to look. Library personnel will have a respite from having to answer the oft-heard question, "But, where are all the books?"

An old-fashioned rate war was in the making yesterday as two Pacific freight conferences, representing forty-one steamship lines, indefinitely suspended regulations on rates for the movement of a wide variety of commodities from Japan to the United States.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- A former alcohol tax official said today that the Louisville District chief had been demoted to New Orleans in 1949 to "appease the politicians."
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, ordered the armed services tonight to reduce their civilian payrolls by 39,346 by the end of May.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- High Administration sources indicated today that George F. Kennan, who is generally regarded as the foremost American authority on the Soviet Union, would not receive another diplomatic assignment but would be retired in the near future.

Style trends in the women's outerwear trades indicate that the so-called "surface-interest" fabrics will be less in demand next fall, according to Miss Jeanne Pierre, fashion director of A. D. Juilliard Co., Inc.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., March 12 -- The police have been called in to find a mysterious pigeon poisoner responsible for destruction of one-quarter of the pigeon flock here. Strychnine poisoned oats have been blamed for the rapid depletion of the birds which used to flock in the green at the center of town and also at the Farm Service Exchange in Lackawanna Place and the Eggert Coal and Oil Company on Morris Street.

Of twenty-four persons injured by a runaway automobile in Forty-sixth Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue, Wednesday at 5:15 P. M., two women were still in a serious condition yesterday in St. Clare's Hospital.

ALL hunters, especially those who fall in the big game category, are interested in methods of reducing the hunting accident rate, but many have expressed doubt of the value of increased fines and penalties as deterrents to the trigger-happy or careless hunter.

ALBANY, March 12 -- The Appellate Division ruled unanimously today that the state had sovereign power over Lake George and authority to control or forbid the maintenance of any obstruction in its outlet.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 12 -- As an aftermath of a wage increase of 9.5 per cent granted to West Coast radio operators and deck officers in recent days, independent mess-department employes took steps today looking to similar or greater wage gains.

Commercial airline operations over the North Pole, making regular and scheduled connections between the United States and Europe, may be started some time this year if the "paper work" details of the necessary international agreements can be reached in time.

Lord Dunsany, Irish poet and playwright, spent two fleeting hours in the city yesterday, just time enough to travel from the Cunard pier to La Guardia Airport and to leave behind some comments on the state of the world. At 75, and still master of the symbolism that has marked a score of his plays, he mixed poetry with politics to express his views in the midst of the hubbub of arrival and departure formalities.
ELIZABETH, La., March 12 (AP) -- Patrols of the state police were increased in this strike-torn South Central Louisiana paper mill area after another dynamite explosion rocked the town.

In the hope of increasing the capacity of the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels and preventing long lines of vehicles from backing up at peak hours, the Port of New York Authority decided yesterday to increase the minimum speed from ten to twenty miles an hour. The rule will go into effect on May 1.

Pedestrian directional signs in mid-Manhattan have failed to restrain jaywalkers and others hurrying to beat the traffic lights from defying "death at the crossrods," the Thirty-Fourth Street-Midtown Association said yesterday.
Deliveries of machine tools, the machines that make the mass-production assembly line possible, are back to normal for the first time since the Korean outbreak in mid-1950.
Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady, with gains of 2 to 13 points net, yesterday. Old-crop months showed the most strength.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 12 -- The Giants for a time today appeared in a gay and versatile mood as they resumed relations with Al Lopez and his Indians. Sal Maglie gave another brief but commendable mound performance. There were two home runs, and in the sixth the boys executed an electrifying triple steal to move into a 4-2 lead.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Senate Permanent Investigating subcommittee heard testimony today that an Army counter-propaganda radio project designed to reach deeply into Soviet Russia and satellite countries from Vienna had been modified by the Voice of America to confine its broadcasts to Austria.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 11 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh today made a bid for effective governmental control of Iran's armed forces through the elimination of royal influence in the officer corps and offered in exchange to surrender to Parliament his plenary powers in all matters except those pertaining to the oil dispute and finance.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The shooting down of a British bomber over Germany by Soviet fighters today was viewed here with much concern, but the Government refrained from making any official statement pending completion of an intensive study.

The industrial and business picture continues highly favorable, with gains coming from the private sector of the economy rather than expanded Government spending, Martin R. Gainsbrugh, economist of the National Industrial Conference Board, said last night. He spoke at the annual meeting of the Limited Price Variety Stores Association at the Statler Hotel.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. March 12 -- Korea soon will get at least 50,000 new books to replace libraries destroyed during the war, the United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency announced today.

A realignment of executive responsibilities in the Macy's New York organization, designed to augment merchandising operations, was announced yesterday by Wheelock H. Bingham, president. He said the move is expected to promote maximum effectiveness in branch stores in Parkchester, Flatbush, Jamaica and White Plains.

CAIRO, March 12 -- The British Ambassador to Egypt, Sir Ralph Stevenson, called on Foreign Minister Mahmoud Fawzi today to complain about the statement of Premier Maj. Gen. Mahommed Naguib on Tuesday accusing British officials in the Sudan of acts of coercion and intimidation.

Volume was light yesterday on the New York commodity ex-I exchanges with only cottonseed oil: and hides showing activity. PricesI closed generally lower with hides,I potatoes, rubber, lead and tin reg-] istering declines. Sugar, cottonseedI off and soybean off were mixed and! cocoa, wool and zinc ended higher.

LONDON, Friday, March 13 (AP) -- Following is the text of a letter sent by Gen. Vassily I. Chuikov, chairman of the Soviet Control Commission in Germany, to Sir Ivone Kirkpatrick, British High Commissioner, as reported by Tass, Soviet news agency, and broadcast early today by the Moscow radio:

WASHINGTON, March 12 (UP) -- The General Accounting Office emphasized today that retiring officials of the Truman Administration had been within their legal rights in collecting cash payments of $709,538 for unused vacation time.

ALBANY, March 12 -- Bills appropriating $1,000,000 to continue state assistance to hard-pressed school districts to pay debt service on bonds for emergency school construction were introduced in both Houses of the Legislature today at the recommendation of the State Commission on School Buildings.

SAN JUAN, P. R., March 12 -- Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, said today that no university, public or private, should oppose investigation by Congressional committees, but should insist that the investigations be conducted fairly and objectively and not be utilized by "demagogues who may seek to use an indiscriminate smear campaign in order to further their own selfish political ambitions."

Tolls collected on the Port of New York Authority's six bridges and tunnels provided 70 per cent of the agency's gross revenue of $53,823,158 in 1952, paid all of its operating expenses and contributed 86 per cent of the $19,224,477 surplus, according to the financial report approved yesterday by the commissioners of the bi-state agency.

ALBANY, March 12 (AP) -- Reversing itself, the Third Department Appellate Division sustained today the convictions of the former Chief of of Binghamton's vice squad and nine gamblers indicted in a Broome county gambling inquiry. The decision was 3 to 2.

PARIS, March 5 -- At the annual Salon of Household Arts a booth marked "School for Parents and Educators" is drawing much attention. This booth, surrounded as it is by gleaming washing machines and electric refrigerators, in effect silently suggests to thousands of parents visiting the exposition that material comforts, however pleasant, do not constitute all the answers to successful family life.
BOGOTA, Colombia, March 12 (AP) -- Officials predicted tonight a quick rise in coffee prices as the result of removal of controls by the United States.

The Reynolds Metals Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries achieved a new high record in sales last year with $234,738,789, an increase of 9 per cent over the 1951 volume of $215,704,848. The 1952 net profit of $14,731,071 was exceeded only by the $15,837,846 earned the year before, according to the annual report issued yesterday by R. S. Reynolds Jr., president.
ALBANY, March 12 -- A new issue was thrown into the Legislature today when the Senate and Assembly Rules Committees introduced the so-called "Erwin-Travia" bills of the 1952 session.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- Wheat and other grain futures on the Board of Trade had momentary periods of strength today, with a buying spurt on the announcement that a British plane had been shot down over Germany, but the buying demand faded out on the upturns, with selling increasing following reports of rain in the dry areas of the Southwest.
CHICAGO, March 12 (AP) -- The first hospital in America specifically designed for atomic age treatments will open for business tomorrow.

Events today: "Samson et Dalila," Metropolitan Opera, 2; Boston Symphony, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; John DeMerchant, baritone, Town Hall, 5:30; "Don Giovanni," Metropolitan Opera, 8:15: "Carmen," Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:30; Philharmonic-Symphony, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Gwendolyn Geddes, soprano, Town Hall, 8:30.
Two hours of hard work on a midtown resturant safe early yesterday morning yielded three armed thugs $60. More skill or perseverance might have meant $1,500.

What could be more fitting than that on St. Patrick's Day next Tuesday a young Irish designer will present her first collection to be seen in America. The showing will take place at Gimbels, Philadelphia. The designer is Miss Sybil Connolly of Dublin.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 13 -The Federal Executive Council ordered today the postponement of the national elections, scheduled for May 24, until an undesignated date in the fall.

BOSTON, March 13 -- The office of Frederic C. Dumaine, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, announced today the names of nine men who have been proposed as new members of the board of directors. The election will be held at the annual stockholders' meeting on April 8 at New Haven.

NEW ORLEANS, March 13 (UP) -- The Fair Grounds will ring down the curtain tomorrow on the richest season in its eighty-year history with the twenty-eighth running of the $40,000 added Louisiana Derby.
Four of the newly opened exhibitions of paintings are, in one way or another, rewarding occasions for those who like to keep abreast of the rapidly changing art scene.

MANILA, March 13 -- United States Ambassador Raymond A. Spruance issued one of his rare public statements Thursday warning Americans in the Philippines to refrain from any kind of participation in the coming national elections or in election campaign activities.
MOSCOW, March 13 -- A new poster bearing the legend "Vigilance -- Our Weapon" was displayed today upon billboards all over Moscow.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 13 -Twentieth Century-Fox reaffirmed today that it would forsake all other film techniques and use only its wide-screen process called CinemaScope, to be introduced with the release of "The Robe."

LONDON, March 13 -- A steady increase in world steel production to between 235,000,000 and 240,000,000 tons a year was forecast in the February Bulletin of the British Iron and Steel Federation published today.
MELBOURNE, March 13 (AP) -Australian officials, trying to keep the 1956 Olympic games for Melbourne, believed they had come up today with the solution of the housing problem for visiting athletes.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (UP) -- The Government's head alcohol tax collector said today that he was told a tax official in Louisville, Ky., was transferred at the insistence of former Vice President Alben W. Barkley.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Powerful Senate Republicans were split tonight on whether the Senate should approve President Eisenhower's nomination of Charles E. Bohlen to be United States Ambassador to Moscow.
Young matrons are working for the success of the performance, of "Hazel Flagg" Wednesday night at the Mark Hellinger Theatre for the benefit of the Sarah Lawrence College Scholarship Fund.

ALL is not quiet along the Outer Banks of North Carolina these days, for word has spread that plans are being considered to permit shell dredging in Currituck Sound, which would have a serious effect on the food supply of the countless thousands of ducks and geese that winter on this shallow body of water.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies increased 4.7 per cent in February over the same month last year, according to a compilation of forty-one companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

A few days ago the European Assembly, meeting in Strasbourg, capital of the "Europe" that is trying to be born, passed by a vote of 50 -- 0 the first draft of a European Constitution. As far this Charter is only for what its critics rather derisively call "little Europe," but the six nations of that community include France and Germany and contain a population and resources equivalent to those of the United States.

NEWARK, March 13 -- Superior Court Judge Walter C. Freund today reserved decision on an application for an injunction to restrain the Newark Housing Authority from evicting two tenants who had refused to sign loyalty oaths under the Gwinn Amendment to the Independent Office Appropriations Act.

VIENNA, Saturday, March 14 (AP) -- The Prague radio, breaking the news suddenly of M. Gottwald's illness in a pattern like the Moscow announcements on the last illness of Stalin, issued several communiques signed by the doctors in at tendance.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., March 13 -- A group of American business men engineered and financed the recent flight of a Russian-built MIG-15 jet fighter from Poland to Denmark so that it could be examined by Allied experts, it was disclosed here tonight.

Cotton futures prices closed steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, off 2 to 6 points net. The market opened 3 points higher to 3 lower than Thursday's final levels and eased after the March notices had circulated.

Mary Drayton's comedy, "Debut," originally planned for presentation here during the week of April 20, will be delayed until next fall. William Dozier, its producer, plans to test the comedy on the summer circuit in August, following the pattern established in recent years by other Broadway ventures. Mr. Dozier, executive producer for the Columbia Broadcasting System, was to have made his initial entrance into the managerial field with the play this season.

TOPEKA, Kan., March 13 (AP) -- C. Wesley Roberts charged today that a reporter for The Kansas City Star had set out in a "calculated plot" to destroy his usefulness as chairman of the Republican National Committee.

TRENTON, March 13 -- Nelson F. Stamler testified under oath here today before a joint legislative committee that Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll twice offered him the Prosecutorship of Union County on condition that he leave Bergen County.
A heavy downpour of warm, pre-spring rain drenched New York and the metropolitan area for thirty-one hours ending at 10 o'clock yesterday morning.

ST PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13 (AP) --Dutch Harrison or Ardmore, Okla., came up from seventh place to tie Dick Mayer for the leadership in today's second round of the $10,000 St. Petersburg open golf tournament.

GUATEMALA, March 13 -- Congress observed one minute's silence in tribute to Stalin during last evening's session. The motion, presented by Victor Manuel Gutierrez, Communist member and labor leader, had the support of twenty-nine members belonging to the militant left wing revolutionary parties.

The executive committee of the American Council of Christian Churches announced yesterday that it would begin circulation of a petition among clergymen requesting the House Committee on Un-American Activities to make an investigation of the infiltration by Communists into religious organizations.
NEWBURGH, N. Y., March 13 (UP) -- The Eastern Air Defense Force announced today a thirty-day test of a new system to tighten identification of inbound trans-Atlantic planes would start Sunday.

SYRACUSE, March 13 (UP) -Syracuse University's defending champions advanced seven tonight in the first round, of the Intercollegiate Boxing Association tournament to clinch their fifth straight team title.

MIAMI, March 13 -- Last October the Dodgers couldn't tie the Yankees in the eighth inning of the seventh game, but tonight it was different. They tied the world champions at 4 -- 4 in the eighth, then Roy Campanella singled home the winning run in the ninth for a 5-4 triumph.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today postponed from April 1 to May 1 the date on which changes in the division of through railroad receipts between carriers in the East and those in the South and in the Southwest, must be made.

RARITAN TOWNSHIP, N. J., March 13 -- Thirty-five volunteer firemen who cover District 5 of this sprawling township are on strike today over the type of fire engine the Board of Fire Commissioners intends to purchase.
PARIS, March 13 -- The death of Premier Stalin is unlikely to result in any changes in Soviet policy, according to Adnan Menderes, Turkish Premier.

The Coast Guard pressed its search for the bow end of the tanker Angy and the eight persons last seen aboard it yesterday as an American freighter reported that she had placed hawsers aboard the stern half from which twenty-eight men were saved on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (UP) -- The Defense Department said tonight that the Communists were playing on the family ties of some American prisoners of war in Korea to turn them into "tools of the Communist propaganda machine."
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker:
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 13 (AP) --Clearwater's Francis Seavy won the final race in the international Midwinter Snipe Regatta today to succeed Ted Wells as the champion.

LINCOLN, R. I., March 13 (AP) -- Favored by a sudden improvement in the weather, Lincoln Downs opens its thirty-day spring meeting tomorrow launching the earliest season in New England racing history. The season runs through Nov. 28, when Lincoln is to close it.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 13 -- Penn State's defenders and Lehigh each placed five men in the semifinal round of the forty-ninth Eastern intercollegiate wrestling tournament in Dillon Gymnasium tonight.
The thirty-seventh International Flower Show here will close at 10 P. M. tonight, but before it does, new arrangements of cut flowers will be entered in competition during the day.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- A Federal Court jury found Eastern Airlines today liable for damages for the deaths of fifty-five persons in the collision of an airliner and a small plane near National Airport on Nov. 1, 1949. In a test case the jury awarded $65,000 damages in the deaths of two persons.

" Salome," Columbia's Technicolor production based on Scriptural incidents and starring Rita Hayworth and Stewart Granger, has been scheduled to open Tuesday evening, March 24, at the Rivoli Theatre. William Dieterle directed and Buddy Adler produced from a screen play by Harry Kleiner and a story by Jesse L. Lasky Jr.

With the good wishes of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles, Cardinal Spellman, Foreign Minister Georges Bidault and former Foreign Minister Robert Schuman of France, Foreign Minister Paul Van Zeeland of Belgium and other leading statesmen of Europe, the Christian Democratic Union of Central Europe held the opening sessions yesterday of its first international congress here.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The National Labor Relations Board laid the basis today for a countrywide injunction against certain demands and practices of the International Typographical Union, A. F. L., in bargaining with newspapers.

Chico Vejar, 21-year-old New York University sophomore from Stamford, Conn., who has found the prize ring a profitable place to work his way through college, battered out a ten-round decision over Vince Martinez of Paterson, N. J., in Madison Square Garden last night.
AUGUSTA, Ga., March 13 (AP) -- Patty Berg registered a two-over-par 74 today but still managed to add a stroke to her lead in the women's titleholders' championship.

A 27-year-old man was shot in the chest during a chase by the police through the midtown theatrical district last night. He was taken to St. Clare's Hospital, where his condition was reported "not serious."

The provisions of the McCarran-Walter Immigration and Nationality Act limiting alien seamen to a maximum stay in this country of twenty-nine days have been liberalized to allow extension in case of illness or other reasons beyond their control.

Boxing bouts in Motor City Arena in Detroit will be televised over the A. B. C. network beginning Thursday at 9 P. M. A four-round semi-final bout and the eight-round main event will be presented each week.

VIENNA, March 13 -- A lieutenant and two noncommissioned officers of the Czechoslovak Air Force fled their homeland last night in a training plane and landed at Thalerhof airfield outside Graz in the British zone of Austria at 6:15 o'clock this morning.
PITTSBURGH, March 13 -- Justice Michael A. Musmanno of the State Supreme Court today was charged with "hindering a witness,'' a misdemeanor under Pennsylvania law.

I have read with a great deal of interest the letter of William A. Eddy in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 19, which makes charges against the Government of Israel. Because they are so serious I have tried to ascertain, first, the objectivity of the writer, and secondly, the accuracy of the statements themselves.

GLEN COVE, L. I., March 13 -The third rooming house fire here within a week caused the death of two young children early this morning. The victims were Patricia Anne Simpson, 10 months old, and her brother, William, 2 years old.

LONDON, March 13 -- The stock market was still subdued today as a result of aircraft shootings over Germany. Not until late dealings was there any attempt at recovery and then industrials, South African gold-mining shares and Japanese bonds rallied slightly.

The rain it seems to rain every day now. All action in nature, with the exception of frantic rivulets that pattern the gray pavements, is suspended, no bird calls and the city waits out a spell of overcast skies. Only the wind is buoyant as it drives occasional gusts against a tightly shut window.

The Knickerbockers, Eastern division champions of the National Basketball Association for the first time in seven years, end their home season today by playing the Syracuse Nationals at Madison Square Garden. A school game between La Salle Military Academy and St. Mary's of Manhasset will precede the circuit contest.
CINCINNATI, Saturday, March 14 (AP)--The long-threatened strike of 1,100 machinists hit the General Electric jet engine center at Evendale at 12:01 A. M. this morning.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Germaine E. Malarkey of Wooster, Ohio, patented this week what appear to be the ultimate in decorated neckties. The decoration, appliqued to the broad end of a four-in-hand, consists of a girl's figure that is well-stuffed in all three dimensions and modestly covered by a dress with a zipper down the front.

Dr. Abraham Granott, chairman of the board of directors of the Jewish National Fund in Jerusalem, the land-purchasing and development arm of the World Zionist Movement and Israel, reported yesterday that four-fifths of Israel's food production was derived from the Fund's land holdings in Israel.

Deputy Commissioner George Butterly of the State Liquor Authority announced yesterday that the authority's case agains Bill Connolly's, Inc., a restaurant at 985 Second Avenue, had been "won by default" since the licensees had failed to appear at hearings called to determine what interests William J. Connolly, a Democratic district leader, held in the restaurant.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 13 -- The port of Rio de Janeiro has been so seriously crippled by a slowdown and a wildcat partial strike of dock workers that shippers are threatening to boycott it. The food market has been seriously affected since important items come in by the coasting trade and thirty-six coastal vessels are awaiting a chance to unload.

TRENTON, March 13 -- The establishment of an experimental non-commercial television station and continued pioneering in educational television programming were recommended today by the New Jersey Commission on Educational Television in its initial report to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll.
