CHICAGO, March 13 -- While pressure continued heavy on wheat and corn, investment buying developed as a result of the announcement that 1953 wheat stocks under the loan aggregate a record 455,800,000 bushels. The estimate that 228,000,000 bushels of corn also had been placed under the loan failed to spur buying, early selling being fairly heavy.

CHICAGO, March 13 -- A picture of the counter-espionage side of big business warfare was drawn at the du Pont anti-trust trial here today before Federal District Judge Walter J. LaBuy as a confidential "super - discount" plan granted to General Motors Corporation by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., came under discussion.
Hal Cook has been appointed national sales manager of Capitol Records Distributing Corporation, effective April 1. Al Levine will succeed Mr. Cook as district sales manager.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 13 (UP) -- Ralph Kiner objected today to the "criticism" he had been subjected to for dickering with Branch Rickey over salary terms but said he "most certainly" wanted to play with the Pirates this year and hoped the dispute could be settled soon.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Investigations by Senate and House Civil Service Committees were projected today to determine what, if anything, could be done about "terminal leave" payments to departing members of the Truman Administration.

Fifteen shipyards, five of them foreign companies, bid yesterday on the job of converting three of the American-Hawaiian Steamship Company's C-4 type vessels to combination oil tanker-bulk ore carriers.

ALBANY, March 13 -- The State Banking Department announced today that the Manufacturers Trust Company, 55 Broad Street, Manhattan, had filed an application for permission to open a branch office at 205-19 Hillside Avenue. Holliswood, Queens.

WEST POINT, N. Y. March 13 -- Jean Cronstead, Penn State's defending champion in the all-around competition, gained an early lead in his specialty as the twenty-sixth individual championships of the Eastern Intercollegiate Gymnastic League got under way.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (UP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations urged Congress today to approve a stand-by wage-price control law today but declared a proposal to let President Eisenhower declare a ninety - day "freeze" in case of emergency was "absurd."

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Decontrol of food prices has exerted little influence on the normal trend of prices in that field, John A. Logan, president of the National Association of Food Chains, said here today.

Wallace Turner of The Portland Oregonian won the American Newspaper Guild's competition for the 1952 Heywood Broun Award of $500 for his stories exposing fraud in the purchase of timberlands in Oregon and Washington from Indians.

Following are textual excerpts from yesterday's majority and dissenting opinions of the Appellate Division, which upheld Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber in refusing to overrule General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente in barring press and public from the vice trial of Minor F. Jelke:
TOKYO, Saturday, March 14 -- United States F-86 Sabre jets in a series of fights over North Korea yesterday shot down six enemy MIG's, probably destroyed one other and damaged another.

The old Knickerbocker Ice Company plant at Northern Boulevard and Susquehanna Avenue in Great Neck, L I., has been purchased for personal investment by Joseph K. Alliger and Hyman Ratner, president and treasurer of the Sterling Investing Corporation. Walter Omelia was the broker and Julius Schnapper was attorney for the buyers.
Cheese importers renewed their efforts yesterday to assure an end to quotas now applied to the foreign varieties.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 13 -- Net income of $3,011,384, equal to $1.92 per share, compared with $1.97 in 1951, was reported today by the Matson Navigation Company for last year.
ALBANY, March 13 -- A new effort will be made by Republican legislative leaders to push to passage Governor Dewey's proposal for a commission to make a broad study of the court system of the state.

The Government brought to a close yesterday the presentation of its anti-trust case against seventeen major investment banking houses, with Richard O'Donnell, special assistant to the Attorney General, asking Judge Harold R. Medina to find that prima facie proof had been shown of a conspiracy linking all the defendants.

Attendance set a new high record at the American Toy Fair at the McAlpin and New Yorker Hotels and in private showrooms when about 10,000 buyers registered during the first six days of the show, Robert B. M. Barton, president of the Toy Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A., sponsor of the event, announced yesterday.

BONN, Germany, March 13 -- Sir Ivone Kirkpatrick, British High Commissioner in Germany, accused the Soviet Union today of the murder of six airmen and sternly demanded punishment of the Russians involved and payment of reparations.
Efforts of small business concerns to obtain defense contracts by banding together in pools are being encouraged by the regional office of the Small Defense Plants Administration.
DULUTH, Minn., March 13 -Albert Woolson, now the one-man Grand Army of the Republic thinks it is high time that the last embers of the Civil War be snuffed out.
TOKYO, Saturday, March 14 (AP) -- Un: Nations Command communique 1,553, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday, Korean time:
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 13 -- Crafty Admiral of the Charfran Stable and George D. Widener's Battlefield will head the list in tomorrow's $50,000 added Gulfstream Park Handicap.

ALBANY, March 13 -- Governor Dewey wound up today a series of recommendations for rescuing the City of New York from a severe budgetary crisis by urging that a city manager-type of municipal government be considered as a substitute for the present system.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- A subcommittee of three Senators won a tussle with State Department security officers today over the matter of putting in the public record a directive, rescinded last Feb. 19, concerning the use in the International Information Administration of material written or produced by artists of questionable loyalty to the United States.

WEST POINT, N. Y., March 13 -- President Eisenhower in a letter to the United States' Military Academy, has congratulated its graduates for their contributions to the growth and development of America's world leadership.

Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College, said yesterday that Section 903 of the New York City Charter and its operation should be left intact. Under the section, city employes who refuse to answer questions put by Government committees automatically vacate their jobs.

The Guild Aluminum Products, Inc., manufacturer of aluminum storm sash, screen and allied products, has leased the one-story industrial building at 722 Liberty Avenue in North Bergen, N. J., from the Leo Uhlfelder Company. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker. The building contains 10,000 square feet of space and is on a plot 213 by 100 feet.

LONDON, March 13 -- Spokesmen for this country, official and unofficial, were unusually bitter and indignant today in expressing their condemnation of the attack on a British bomber destroyed by two Soviet MIG fighters over Germany yesterday.
Spencer B. Koch Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, will dissolve on March 31.

The fifteenth annual conference on eastern rites and liturgies will open at 8 P. M. next Friday at Fordham University. A liturgical celebration that will be conducted at 11 A. M. next Saturday at St. Patrick's Cathedral will mark the end of the conference.
Shall New York City both increase the transit fare and impose a payroll tax?

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., March 13 -- Praise for the Voice of America in Germany was expressed tonight at Mount Holyoke College by Benjamin Shute, former Director of Intelligence for the United States High Commission in Germany.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- The Alberta Government will be asked again to permit the export of natural gas to the United States, the Federal Power Commission was told today.

PAUL SMITH'S, N. Y., March 13 -- The greatest collection of cross-country runners to appear in the East in many years marked time here tonight for the national championship to be held over an exacting 18-kilometer course (11 1/4 miles) tomorrow.

ALBANY, March, 13 -- Following is the text of Governor Dewey's message to the Legislature suggesting a city manager for New York City and recommending creation of a commission to study the organizational structure of the municipality:

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13 (AP) -- The transfer of the St. Louis Browns to Baltimore will receive the unanimous approval of the American League owners' contingent on the ironing out of a few details, a source high in baseball said tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The United States said today that the Czechoslovak fighter-plane attack on two United States jet planes over West Germany Tuesday was a "provocative incident" and warned the Communist Government in Prague that the "necessary" measures would be taken to prevent a repetition of such action.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -President Eisenhower nominated Philip Young, dean of the Graduate School of Business at Columbia University, as a member of the Civil Service Commission today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 13 -Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion, speaking in the same hall where in 1948 he read out Israel's proclamation of independence, declared today that only the enemies of the United States "can wish her to deal with the new and small countries as if they were vassals or satellites."

Commodity prices advanced yesterday on the New York exchanges. Coffee jumped the limit for the day as soon as trading was opened. Prices had been at ceilings for more than a week and with the removal of controls prices soared. Volume continued light in other commodities with only hides active.
With the total attendance now topping 4,000, the twenty-ninth annual convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association continued yesterday on the Morning-sides Heights campus.

Before departing by air yesterday for London, Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, characterized his ten-day visit here as second to none in his long diplomatic career in meeting world problems mutually shared by the British Commonwealth and the United States.

Eight high school students from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut were introduced at a special student matinee of "Aida" at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon as the winners in this year's "Art in Opera" contest. The competition was conducted by the Metropolitan Opera Guild.
After exercises at sea, eight Navy warships arrived here yesterday to allow their crews recreation ashore.

Hope for rehabilitation of a vital section of Greenwich Village seems to lie ahead in the plans of the Mayor's Committee on Slum Clearance, of which Robert Moses is chairman, for a survey of the region. If present suggestions materialize, private industry will build 1,000 apartments in the area and educational buildings for New York University will rise on land between West Third and West Fourth Streets.

Two connecting one - story buildings containing 17,500 square feet of space at 311 to 315 Scheles Street and 318-322 Stagg Street, Brooklyn, have been purchased by the Franz-Mar Realty Company and leased to the Starr Overall Company, which will use the property as a garage and repair shop.
The five-story apartment house at 1415-19 Stebbins Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Samuel Hurwitz, operator. It is assessed at $118,000 and was bought through Pease Elliman, Inc., brokers.

ASPEN, Colo., March 13 (AP) -Stein Eriksen of Norway and Jeannette Burr of Sun Valley scored today as the Roch Cup giant slalom, held in conjunction with the national ski meet, was run in intermittent sunshine and snow.
" Genocide means [the] intent to destroy, in whole or in part, a national, ethnical, racial or religious group.

As President Eisenhower must now realize, appointments present an ethical as well as a practical problem to any new Federal Administration. While the desire of Cabinet officers to fill the top advisory posts in their departments with men of their own choosing is entirely proper, it is important in the interests of good management that this principle of change not be applied to high-ranking jobs of a technical or totally nonpolitical nature.
CARLE PLACE, L. I., March 13 -- Three youthful Long Islanders got the word today, straight from a top-flight paratrooper at Fort Benning, Ga.

NEW ORLEANS, March 13 -- A rebirth of the downtown business section of cities in the United States was predicted here today by Arthur Rubloff, author of Chicago's $200,000,000 "Magnificent Mile Plan," in addressing the conference of the American Planning and Civic Association.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -President Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, are scheduled to speak tomorrow morning at an unusual session of the American Medical Association's House of Delegates. The "house" is the policy-making group of the association.

An altered and retouched photograph published in the Soviet newspaper Pravda last Tuesday has excited interest in diplomatic circles, where it is regarded by some observers as the beginning of a Soviet campaign to magnify the role played in foreign affairs by Georgi M. Malenkov before he became Premier following Stalin's death.

MADRID, March 13 -- Relations between Britain and Spain were described today as being worse than at any period since the end of World War II following an intense anti-British campaign here that was understood to have led to a strong protest lodged recently by the London Foreign Office with the Spanish Ambassador, Duke Miguel Primo de Rivera.

The Minneapolis and St. Louis Railway Company has made arrangements for the extension of time on six equipment obligations, with a reduced basis of monthly payments to March 31, 1956, effective April 1, L. C. Sprague, president, says in a report to stockholders.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (UP) -- The Government, acting almost on the eve of the March 15 income tax deadline, today ordered a "vigorous and impartial" crackdown on big and small tax evaders alike.

The Democratic election district captains of the West Side Democratic Club, 2463 Broadway, have designated Leonard M. Cohen as acting Tammany leader of the middle section of the Fifth Assembly District. Mr. Cohen replaces Herbert J. DeVarco, who resigned recently. He has been recognized as acting leader by Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany.

" Enchanted Island," by Walter Lowrie, which combines reminiscences and travel descriptions of the island of Ischia in the Bay of Naples, will be published March 31 by Philosophical Library. Mr. Lowrie, a former rector of St. Paul's American Church in Rome, Italy, is the author of thirty-five books, fifteen of them about Kierkegaard.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 13 -- The prospect that business may wrest from Government the leadership for social planning and social security in a trend toward the "welfare corporation" rather than the "welfare state" was offered at a business conference here today.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Senator Wayne Morse, independent of Oregon, told a nearly empty Senate chamber today that some of his colleagues were conducting a "vendetta" against him because he bolted the Republican party last fall and supported Adlai E. Stevenson for the Presidency.
WASHINGTON. March 13 -Average primary market prices remained unchanged over the week ended March 10, at 109.9 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
A Red Cross bloodmobile completed a four-day visit to the Naval Supply Depot in Bayonne, N. J., yesterday, where it collected donations from 607 military and civilian personnel.
CHICAGO, March 13 (AP) -- There were new leaders in all divisions of the American Bowling Congress' golden jubilee tournament as a result of sensational scoring today.

WICHITA FALLS, Tex., March 13 (UP) -- Tornadoes hit eight Texas and Oklahoma towns tonight, killing at least sixteen persons and causing millions of dollars worth of damage. There was no immediate estimate of the total injured.

Comdr. Carl Arthur Setterstrom Jr., United States Navy, retired, who helped make United States history during his forty-two years in the Navy, is now studying that subject, among others, at Long Island University, where he is working for a degree.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Mar. 13 -- The military chiefs of the North Atlantic Treaty nations ended here today a five-day review of their growing defenses, highlighted by a solemn assurance that in the event of aggression United States atomic power would be delivered to its proper targets at the right time, in the right quantities and in face of any opposition.

The Appellate Division by a 3-to-2 vote yesterday upheld Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber in refusing to overrule an order by General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente barring the press and public from the vice trial of Minot F. (Mickey) Jelke.

Although the number of automobiles on the city's streets and on the highways suggests, and the summer vacation-land advertisements beginning to appear about now might lead one to believe, that every family in the United States owns a car, the fact is that every family does not own a car.

Retail distributors of aluminum windows and doors will spend more than $5,000,000 on advertising (monthly in newspapers) during the first year following full removal of restrictions on the use of aluminum. This was predicted yesterday by Allan M. Douglass, president of the National Combination Storm Window and Door Institute.

Boys High captured the Public Schools Athletic League track and field championship for the seventh straight time when it tallied 23 points to outscore a city-wide representation at the 102d Engineers Armory in Washington Heights last night.

GENEVA, March 13 -- In general debate on Europe's economic status and problems in the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, Western European speakers so far this year have been better on the attack than on the defense.

With the lifting of price controls on coffee, beer and a number of other products the process of removing Government curbs on upward movements of prices consumers pay has been completed. The restrictions on such rises are now those implicit in the operations of free markets, that is, the rises are limited by the willingness or unwillingness of consumers to pay higher prices and by the competition among producers of different products.

BOSTON, March 13 -- Dr. Harold C. Case, president of Boston University, asserted today that no one in America was more concerned with maintaining undivided loyalty to the best methods of education than educators themselves. He addressed the concluding sessions of a four-day observance of Founders Day at the university.

Herbert Brickman, director of the New York City Veterans Service Center, 500 Park Avenue, criticized Army officials and the Veterans Administration yesterday for their asserted failure to impress men recently discharged from the service with the importance of retaining their Government insurance.

In his fourth special message to the Legislature on New York City's problems Governor Dewey deals with the basic issue, how to get better administration, better management. If the city had itself cured this fundamental weakness, through the years, there would probably have been no need for this series of special messages.

Members of the Committee of French-American Wives have arranged a dinner dance, known as the Bal des Berceaux, to be held on March 27 in the St. Regis Roof for the benefit of the organization's post-war program in France and relief in the Far East.

" La Traviata" came to the Metropolitan Opera last night for its first performance of the season. A seasoned cast with Licia Albanese, Eugene Conley and Robert Merrill in principal roles was directed by Alberto Erede. Also singing were Paula Lenchner, Margaret Roggero, Gabor Carelli, George Cehanovsky, Algerd Brazis and Clifford Harvuot.

Minklers Corners, N. Y., the upstate community that for a time seemed as elusive as Shangri-La, became somewhat less elusive yesterday. It exists, all right, and has since at least 1930, according to Arthur J. LaBaff.

BERLIN, March 13 -- In a message of greeting to Dr. Ernst Reuter, West Berlin's Mayor, on the eve of his departure for the United States, President Eisenhower warned today that the situation in Berlin might get considerably worse before it got better. He added that the city's present difficulties could reach "crisis proportions."
Stock market prices rallied in the final hour yesterday under the leadership of the steels and closed generally higher after a day of sluggish trading. Oils and motors lagged.

BONN, Germany, March 13 -The West German Federal and state police are rounding up leaders of the Communist party's Free German Youth Organization in an effort to forestall the party's campaign of demonstrations and strikes against the Allied-German treaties.

This world is a funny place. The survivors of wars in which the top sergeant was immortalized by Bairnsfather, Mauldin and Vip are shaking their heads today. A woman, no less, is the top sergeant in an Air Force squadron at Hancock Field. And she is giving orders to persons other than the feminine components of the services.

Sometimes when a man and woman marry, friends and relatives of each partner will shake heads sadly and declare, "It will never last." Sometimes they are right; sometimes they are not. During the next four years a $200,000 research project will be conducted in an attempt to learn what types of personality combinations in man and wife are most likely to lead to trouble and what can be done about such trouble when it comes.

CHICAGO, March 13 -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, said today the United States "would be particularly foolhardy if we proceeded on the assumption" that the death of Premier Stalin and Georgi M. Malenkov's "succession as No. 1 man in Russia" ended the threat of Communit aggression.
Dr. Young said yesterday that he would not comment on the designation until he had been confirmed by the Senate.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- A former Voice of America engineer estimated today that the international counterpropaganda organization had wasted $1,000,000 in preparing its first ship for broadcasting at sea into Iron Curtain countries. In return, Lewis J. McKesson, who quit Government service last October, told the Senate Permanent Investigating subcommittee, the Voice was ineffective in telling the American story to Soviet and satellite peoples.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Following is the text of the United States note delivered by Ambassador George Wadsworth today to the Czechoslovak Foreign Ministry protesting against shooting down of a United States fighter plane in the United States zone of Germany Tuesday:

Maj. Gen. George E. Armstrong, Surgeon General of the United States Army, said last night that it appeared that Army medical officers in Korea were saving limbs that in 70 per cent of past cases would have had to be amputated.

The 5 cent chocolate bar much skimpier than in pre-war days is perhaps the most obvious indication of the higher price of the cocoa from which it derives. Today cocoa beans cost five times as much as in the late nineteen-thirties, while foods have doubled in price in the same period.

LONDON, March 13 -- Seven Scottish rabbits released on the Swedish island of Gottland in the Baltic in 1907 have multiplied to such an extent that the islanders have sought British and Australian help in wiping them out with the rabbit virus disease myxomatosis transmitted by fleas. Virus-infected rabbits will be released at 200 points on the island, according to a report received here from the Swedish forestry department.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 3 -- Asian and African countries eaten to raise the Tunisian and Moroccan questions before the United Nations unless France ends "repressive measures" in the two African protectorates.
The Silex Company of Hartford, Conn. producer of glass coffee makers, may acquire the Chicago Electric Manufacturing Company, maker of commercial and home appliances, Silex announced yesterday.

VIENNA, March 13 -- President Klement Gottwald of Czechoslovakia, according an announcement today by the Prague radio, is seriously ill of pneumonia, apparently contracted while attending the funeral of Stalin in Moscow. It is believed possible here he may also be suffering from a tubercular or cancerous lung condition.

ROME, March 13 (UP) -- Egypt's exiled King Farouk charged tonight that Premier Mohammed Naguib, who ousted him from his throne also had broken up his home by "using that most powerful weapon -- the mother-in-law."

A stock dividend of one share of common stock for each share now outstanding has been ordered by directors of the R. C. Mahon Company of Detroit, it was announced yesterday. The payment will be made April 15 to holders of record March 27.

A chemical processing plant with some new design concepts, including direct maintenance, has been put in operation at the national reactor testing station of the Atomic Energy Commission at Idaho Falls, Idaho. The announcement was made yesterday in that city by L. E. Johnston, manager of the commission's Idaho operations office.

Mayor Impellitteri let another day pass yesterday without commenting on the four-part program laid down by Governor Dewey for rescuing the city from its financial woes. However, the Mayor called the Board of Estimate to meet in executive session at 1 P. M. on Monday to discuss Mr. Dewey's proposals.

A 17-year-old youth was arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Adolescent Court and held in $15,000 bail on a robbery charge after his arrest late Thursday night as the young bandit who robbed the Borough Park branch of the National City Bank of $4,200 last Feb. 16.

Distributors of securities face a variety of substantial transactions next week both in the field of corporate equity and debt securities and in that of local government tax-exempt-interest bonds. On Monday, Nassau County will offer at public sale $27,094,000 of sewer bonds, the State of Oregon will offer $10,500,000 of veterans' welfare and compensation bonds, and Kansas City, Kan., will take bids on $5,500,000 of water and electric revenue obligations.
MESA, Ariz., March 13 -- One sour inning again proved the downfall of the Giants today, and this time the Cubs capitalized on it.

MONTPELIER, Vt., March 13 -- The way was paved today for the Iroquois Six Nation Confederacy of Canada to put its claims to 2,225,000 acres of Vermont land before the Legislature. Under a resolution presented by Representative Ezra Dike, chairman of the Committee on Claims, the House will sit as a commitee on the whole on April 9 to hear the evidence.
PHILADELPHIA, March 13 -- Directors of the Liberty Title and Trust Company and the Real Estate Trust Company voted today to merge, forming a new bank with assets of almost $88,000,000.

The current fund for Holland Flood Relief, Inc., reached $800,241.21 yesterday with a contribution from residents of Philadelphia of $61,272.70. A check for the amount was presented to Clarence G. Michalis, president of the fund, by Miss Nina Foch, granddaughter of the former Governor General of the Netherlands East Indies, at a brief ceremony in the Netherlands Club, 10 Rockefeller Plaza.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 13 -- The Soviet Union vetoed tonight a recommendation by the Security Council that Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Secretary of State for External Affairs, be named to succeed Trygve Lie as Secretary General of the United Nations.

PARIS, March 13 -- There is increasing evidence that the Malenkov Government of the Soviet Union has decided for tactical reasons to stress in its propaganda a desire for a "prolonged" period of peaceful coexistence between the so-called capitalist and socialist systems.

The Federal Government is culling another rich harvest on its island possessions in this region -- a yield of $1,449,924,555 so far with as much more to be harvested within the next seventy-two hours.

One hundred thousand are expected to be following Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan next Tuesday when he takes a walk up Fifth Avenue. Mr. Monaghan will be wearing a top hat and the green, white and orange sash of the grand marshal of the St. Patrick Day parade as he toes the green line. And 3,770 other policemen will be on parade duty that day, too.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Using powers it has seldom invoked since its creation, the Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered trading suspended for ten days in the $1 par value common stock of Adolf Gobel, Inc., South Bergen, N. J., meat products company, listed on the American Stock Exchange.

HOBOKEN, N. J., March 13 -- A tobacco-hating nightingale that has made its chief duty the destruction of any and all cigarettes it can find, is the chief source of amusement for officers on the Holland-America Line freighter Arkeldyk, now docked at Pier 2, here.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, today proposed three changes in the Taft-Hartley Labor Act.
St. John's quintet, the surprise team in the event, will meet top-seeded Seton Hall in the final of the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The executive branch of the Government now has under consideration reinsertion in another bill of a $9,814,333 appropriations item for this country's contribution to the United Nations Children's Emergency Fund. A like amount was cut from the Second Supplemental Appropriation bill by Congress.

RALEIGH, N. C., March 13 (UP) -- Holy Cross moved into the quarter-finals of the National Collegiate A. A. basketball tournament tonight, defeating Wake Forest, 79 -- 71, in a game the Crusaders dominated until the final three minutes.

TOKYO, Saturday, March 14 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida faced the most important crisis of his political career today as Japan's Diet (Parliament) prepared to vote on an Opposition motion of no confidence in his conservative-minded, pro-American Government.

MISS DAPHNE DU MAURIER'S new book, "Kiss Me Again, Stranger,"* presents contemporary England in a wonderful wild and violent light. These eight tales of assorted terrors may bring disquieting surprises to Americans who think of the British as a comparatively tranquil people. Not a bit of it, as Miss du Maurier's characters like to say from time to time.

It cannot be argued that the Soviet attacks on British and American airmen in Germany are the irresponsible acts of trigger-happy individuals. Soviet fliers never move except under orders; they are not impulsive soloists, inspired to defiant deeds of derring-do by personal hatred of the enemy.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 13 -- Led by John Tori's perfect performance, the University of Pennsylvania won the intercollegiate epee team championship today.

TACOMA, Wash., March 13 (AP) -Donald W. Eastvold, Washington State Attorney General, announced today he had been named by President Eisenhower as an alternate United States delegate to the United Nations Commission on Human Rights.
Production of secondary copper increased sharply last month, supporting the copper industry's contention that abolishment of price controls would attract much hoarded scrap into consumer channels.

ROME, March 13 -- Reports from Belgrade of an impending anti-Communist revolt in Albania are regarded here as premature and greatly exaggerated. Some reports went so far as to hint that Yugoslav army units, disguised as partisans, are operating in northern Albania.

Governor Dewey's special message to the Legislature that the city eliminate "bad financing and wasteful management" by adopting a city manager type of administration precedes by two weeks recommendations of a similar nature by the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey.

Federal alcohol agents and a plainclothes squad of city policemen broke into an "abandoned" waterfront warehouse in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn yesterday and found a huge, three-decker distillery that was producing outlaw liquor at a rate believed unmatched in the eastern United States since Prohibition.

The stern half of the Liberianflag tanker Angy lost a week-long struggle against stormy Atlantic seas late Friday night and went down several hundred miles east of New York, the Coast Guard reported yesterday.

The cost of a pension annuity, purchased by the employer upon retirement of an employe, may be subject to income tax to the employe unless the annuity is furnished by an exempt pension trust. Such a case was discussed in this column two weeks ago.

LAST Sunday the public was admitted for the first time to "The Dade County Art Museum." No title could possibly be more misleading. For "The Dade County Art Museum" is really Villa Vizcaya, the fabulous estate of the late James Deering.
The Park Department, noting the scheduled arrival of spring next Friday, came up with a timely reminder yesterday: it's planting time in New York City.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 14 -- The man who designed, for the German Luftwaffe, the first jet airplane engine to be mass-produced and tested in combat is now working quietly here on commercial and military aircraft engines.

ILLINOIS--Training Center Students at Illinois College interested in Latin America will have the opportunity to observe and participate in the activities of a UNESCO-Pan American Union training center at Patzcuaro, Mexico, this summer. The students will work with the educational leaders from various parts of Latin America who come to Patzcuaro to study together methods of improving literacy, health and sanitation in various backward areas of the Spanish-speaking world.

William S. White's "The 'Midwest Mind' in Congress" (March 1) is, in effect, a study of the migration of the Yankee. Americans have long had a way of turning to Yankees when in doubt It is interesting that the intuitive sense of the voters did not confuse geographic location with the human object of their search.

In view of the country's acute shortage of trained nurses -- recently estimated at 65,000 in a report of the American Nurses Association -- Fairleigh Dickinson College (Rutherford, N. J.) has established a two-year college program in nursing.

LONDON, March 14 (UP) -- Alan Dick scored the first triple victory in the eighty-nine-year history of the meet as Oxford University defeated Cambridge, 73 to 53, today in their annual dual track and field competition.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 14 -- The five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council will meet early next week to try to find a way out of the deadlock on the selection of a new Secretary General, but most diplomats here think the bargaining and the maneuvering have just begun.

The problem of communism in Latin America is serious. But Spruille Braden, former Assistant Secretary of State for American Republics Affairs, makes a rather disquieting assertion when he suggests that communism's suppression, "even by force, in an American country, by one or more of the other republics, would not constitute an intervention in the internal affairs of the former."
" I CANNOT forecast to you the action of Russia. It is a riddle wrapped in a mystery inside an enigma."

A HUNGARIAN-BORN journalist and sometime novelist, Hans Habe fought under two flags in World War II. When the Germans overran France, he was an infantry sergeant in a French volunteer regiment. "A Thousand Shall Fall," published in 1941, is a memorable record of his experiences under fire and his dramatic escape to unoccupied France after two months' confinement in a prison camp near Nancy.

Experiences of the last forty years have exploded the myth that the way to provide adequate oil supplies for emergency military use is to set aside probable petroleum-bearing Federal Government land for that purpose.

HOPE being one of the theatre's more reliable staples, it behooves this department to report that the light -flickering on occasion -- has not gone out for William Faulkner's "Requiem for a Nun." A meeting with Mr. Faulkner last week disclosed that though Lemuel Ayers no longer is to be the producer, nor Albert Marre, the director, plans still are afoot for a production this fall.

It can't be long now. A warm February raised hope in our hearts for an early spring, hope which March chilled in a hurry. But the chill can't last too much longer, not with the sun where it is, lighting the east windows once more in the mornings and setting almost west again.

SIX years ago Francis Poulenc created a fuss in Paris with his opera based on a libretto by Guillaume Appollinaire, "Les Mamelles de Tiresias." Last year considerable interest was stirred in Switzerland when the Zurich Municipal Theatre presented "Don Pedro," a work evolved from Mozart's operatic fragments by a Swiss team consisting of Hans Erismann, who arranged the music, and Oskar Waelterline and Warner Galluser, who worked out the libretto.
TRENTON, March 14 -- The New Jersey Legislature returns Monday from a month's recess to begin meetings several days a week to clear calendars of nearly 1,000 bills.

Inasmuch as the opinion about producers revealed in John Sheldon Davis' letter in your section last Sunday may be shared by others, it might be appropriate to explain why the producer of a successful show deserves all the credit he gets.

CHICAGO, March 14 -- Business continued at a fast pace in February and indicated that the first half of the year would bear out optimistic predictions. However, the purchasing Agents Association of Chicago in its monthly survey said there has been a steady buildup in inventories of items for production and resale during the last three months.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 14 (AP) -- Dick Mayer, of St. Petersburg and Dutch Harrison, of Ardmore, Okla., fired identical 68's in today's third round of the $10,000 St. Petersburg open golf tournament to remain in the first place deadlock.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 14 -- The Brazilian Government has promised workers that factories will be kept going despite difficulties in getting raw materials and parts from abroad, it was reported today.

MARCH is a time of particular significance for a farmer in these parts. It is a time when he makes up his mind what he is going to do in the coming season. Since last autumn's harvest he has been thinking things over. Maybe he has decided to move; maybe he wants to buy or rent additional acreage.
Eugene Burke, 28 years old, of 68 Delmont Street, New Brighton, S. I., was shot dead at 10 o'clock last night on a crowded sidewalk in a shopping district of New Brighton.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur called last night for victory in Korea as the only acceptable solution to the Korean conflict in a message delivered to 350 persons attending the annual West Point Founder's Day dinner in the Astor Hotel.

THE death of a mere composer on March 4, though he was Russia's greatest composer of the period, and certainly one of the leading creators of music of his age -- Sergei Prokofieff -- was naturally not such news as the death of Russia's Premier and the appointment of his successor.

The National Guild of Community Music Schools will hold its twelfth annual conference next week-end at the Turtle Bay Music School, 244 East Fifty-second Street. The extension of guild schools to offer greater musical and educational opportunities to communities throughout the nation will be the theme of the conference.

East Side House and its affiliated charitable organizations, the Winifred Wheeler Day Nursery and the Stepney Camp at Botsford, Conn., will be the beneficiaries of a luncheon and fashion show, known as "Whispers of Spring and Summer," to be given on April 16 in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre.

ASPEN, Colo., March 14 (AP) -- Ralph Miller, a student at Dartmouth College, Hanover, N. H., added to his laurels and those of the Dartmouth Outing Club today when he captured first place in both the national open and amateur downhill ski races.

HAITI, colorful stop on the winter cruise circuit, bids fair to become the locale of the first dramatic feature picture to be filmed on that Caribbean island. Last week, independent producer Richard de Rochemont and scenarist Marc Connelly returned from Port au prince after successful conferences with President Paul Magloire and other government officials to prepare for the production of "The spring."

CHICAGO, March 14 (AP) -- Three tornadoes tore at Arkansas and Mississippi today in the third day of crushing twisters that have killed seventeen persons. One twister whirled through Booneville, Miss., killing one man, and two tornadoes cut a twenty-mile swath of damage in north central Arkansas, injuring seven persons.

Everyone agrees that "The Crucible" is good, but did not Arthur Miller make a mistake in having John Proctor rather than the Reverend Hale the central character? John Proctor was an unsophisticated farmer with a sound sense of right and wrong, a man of integrity who died rather than sacrifice his integrity.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 14 -- The shift of power in Moscow, followed so closely by the series of plane incidents in Europe, has raised more insistently than ever the question of what our policy toward Russia is to be.
IN her new novel, Corinne Running dives swiftly into the problematic waters of three sets of marriages and comes up with partial solutions for each of them.

MIAMI, Fla., March 14 -- Russ (Monk) Meyer, the new Dodger pitcher, is a mild mannered, pleasant young man who hardly seems to fit his reputation, as baseball's Terrible Tempered Mr. Bang. He even gets a trifle bitter at some of the stories that have been written about his fits of petulance, his temper and his temperament.

An interior designer's views on ailing decor and what to do about it will be heard on Tuesday at 6:15 P. M. in the second of a series of free art lectures at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The lecturer will be Kim Hoffman of New York, a member of the American Institute of Decorators.

TEN-year-old Sarah Hastings makes her bow to young readers by living up to a schoolmate's taunt that "preacher's kids are always worse than anybody else's." Her sense of duty, her rebellion against its insistent voice, her yearning for luxuries, and her ever-watchful personal God keep Sarah constantly ready to boil over.

Mrs. Richard C. Bondy Jr. heads the committee in charge of the plans for the performance of Cinerama on May 5 at the Broadway Theatre for the benefit of the Washington Square Home for Friendless Girls. Serving with Mrs. Bondy are Mrs. Oscar A. de Lima, Mrs. Van Rensselaer Wittman, Robert W. Fisher and De Witt Ter Heun.

A machine that compresses time in the sense that it speeds up words or music without changing tone or ease of understanding has been invented by Prof. Grant Fairbanks, VV. L. Everitt and R. P. Jaeger of the University of Illinois.

SYRACUSE, March 14 -- Syracuse won the team title in the Intercollegiate Boxing Association tournament for the fifth straight year tonight when its captain, Bill Miller, rallied to take the decision from Pete Potter of Virginia for the 156-pound championship.

Thank you for Gertrude Samuels' "The Wounded -- And the Red Cross" (March 1). The volunteer "gray ladies" are a most important and needed asset to all hospital facilities. However * * * occupational therapy is a treatment and must always be prescribed by a physician.
THIS is the first of two or three columns dealing with that strange creature of our period, the "intellectual," and his part in the writing of our time.

General Electric Company sent its annual report for 1952 to thousands of stockholders all over the country last week. It was a meticulous document. The reader was smitten with imposing statistics on earnings, dividends, sales, inventories and other standard features of annual reports.
TORONTO, March 14 (UP) -- The Boston Bruins jolted the Toronto Maple Leafs' play-off chances tonight by defeating the Leafs, 3 -- 1, before 14,004 fans at the Maple Leaf Gardens.
America's largest body of yachtsmen, the United States Power Squadrons, with 136 branches coast to coast, is adding to its traditional functions of converting landlubbers into water-minded skippers.

BEETHOVEN: Sonatas in D, Op. 12, No. 1, and G, Op. 96; Jean Fournier, violinist, and Ginette Doyen, pianist (Westminster). A continuation of the series that these two fine artists have been doing. Suave, polished performances, very well recorded.

" OPERATION DOORSTEP," the atomic bomb tests at Yucca Flat, Nev., will be brought into the nation's homes with three pool telecasts over the A. B. C., C. B. S. and N. B. C. networks and one pool broadcast over the A. B. C., C. B. S., M. B. S. and N. B. C. radio networks.

A NEW, year-round island resort to he designed, built and operated by Americans expressly for the American luxury trade, is soon to rise atop the ruins on Grand Bahama Island of the spectacular failure in 1950 of the William E. "Billy" Butlin Vacation Village.

Fabrics for all types of underwear and outerwear are now being produced by William Heller, Inc., one of the country's largest manufacturers of knitted fabrics. Ben Heller, vice president and general manager, announced last week that the company will introduce this fall a new line of jersey worsteds for both the men's and women's suiting trade.
Veterans of the blizzard of '88, men and women with long memories of the deep snow that paralyzed New York in its horse-car era, held their annual reunion luncheon yesterday at the Statler Hotel.

Columbia University "hopes" that Queen Elizabeth of England will attend the third and last of its bicentennial convocations next year, 4,000 teen-age journalists were told yesterday at the conclusion of the annual convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Southbound local service was delayed on the I. R. T. Lexington Avenue line yesterday at 6:33 A. M. when the front part of a train slowly passed a man lying under an overhang of the subway platform at the Seventy-seventh Street station. Power was shut off between the Seventy-seventh Street and Grand Central stations for twenty-six minutes and southbound local trains were shifted at 125th Street to express tracks.

IF America is a way of life, England is a tradition, and every Englishman embodies in himself something of the storied past of his people. That is why he usually enjoys looking back as much as the American does looking forward.

The new passenger liner now being built for the Greek Line at Alexander Stephen Sons Shipyard in Glasgow, Scotland, will be launched on April 16 and will enter the Atlantic service to New York in the fall, it was announced yesterday.

WITH road-building costs soaring ($1,000,000 a mile is becoming a common construction figure), aerial photography is now being utilized to plan highways and map rights of way. Where surveying crews with transits and chains once tramped over the countryside mapping the proper course for a new highway, pictures are being taken from planes and routes marked out on the resulting mosaic and strip maps.

The murderous Communist attacks on American and British planes over Western Germany, coming on top of a long series of similar "incidents" in the past, demonstrate that Stalin's death has not changed the Soviet leopard's spots and that the ever-present danger of further Communist aggression has only been increased by jittery nerves in the Kremlin.

LOS ANGELES, March 14 -- Smarting under the sting of two successive defeats, the Giants laid violent hands on the Indians today and gave the Tribe such a thorough thrashing it probably was just as well General Man ager Hank Greenberg was off to distant Florida to attend a meeting that may transfer the Browns' franchise to Baltimore.

LIKELY to leave its mark on other parts of the country, despite climatic differences, is the building boom currently taking place in this state. Outstanding among contributions is the concept of what is called the "Florida room," at present being incorporated into many of the modern houses rising here by the score.

PRUNING of shrubs, when done at the right time of year and according to basic principles, improves their appearance, increases quantity of bloom and stimulates vigorous growth. Seldom can annual pruning be skipped for any of the deciduous flowering shrubs.

POSTMASTER GENERAL ARTHUR E. SUMMERFIELD announced last week six additional special stamps for 1953. Denominations, colors and designs together with dates and points of first-day sale were not immediately disclosed.

STALIN'S death will undoubtedly have many repercussions throughout the Soviet satellite world. What happens now in the vast empire seized by the Russians since World War II? Although no precedent approaches the magnitude of present events in their impact upon the lands behind the Iron Curtain, the whole globe is watching. For tension and terror were already mounting inside the satellite countries even before the latest crisis behind the walls of the Kremlin.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 14 -- Crafty Admiral of the Charfran Stable sped to victory in the $59,500 Gulfstream Park Handicap today, beating George D. Widener's Battlefield by a neck. The mile-and-a-quarter race attracted eleven thoroughbreds, three of which ran as an entry, but as far as pre-race calculations had it, it was purely a test between the eventual winner and runner-up.

BERLIN, March 14 -- One of East Germany's express trains routed non-stop through West Berlin reportedly made an unscheduled halt in the British sector Thursday. The engineer and the fireman jumped off and headed for a refugee reception center a few blocks away.

Three hundred graduate students at Hunter College are participating in an unusual feature of New York City colleges. On the theory that advances in education of the physically handicapped should keep abreast with progress made in medicine and therapy, the college offers a twenty-eight course graduate program in teacher education in the area of the physically handicapped.
Miss Samuels writes: "Many wounded have no need for medical social work; they do. however, need encouragement and counseling about their personal problems * * * warmth * * * skilled guidance."

Your column of Sunday, February 23rd, in relation to the future of 3-dimension in motion pictures, was of particular interest to the undersigned -- for the most obvious of reasons. As president of Natural Vision Corporation, the company that precipitated what you have so engagingly described as an "atomic bomb," I feel with you that 3-dimension will not make a bad story, bad performance or bad direction good.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (UP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations today endorsed the "trade, not aid" approach to the economic development of free nations, but warned that the slogan was "dangerous."
TOKYO, Sunday, March 15 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,554, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Sunday, Korean time:

IT is a curious fact that second string music critics are often far keener judges of performing musicians than first string critics are. This is simply because in their frantically busy job of covering all the New York concerts their bosses stay away from, they hear a far greater variety of music.

There are few tasks in the world that are more important, and few that are more difficult, than that which Trygve Lies successor will undertake. It is vital, therefore, that the United Nations should choose the best man who can be found.

PARIS, March 14 -- The French Cabinet is debating an elaborate plan to place the war in Indo-China on a new basis, relieving the French Army of much of the human burden and relieving the French budget of the bulk of the cost of the war.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- President Eisenhower assured the American Medical Association today that the Administration would maintain a hands-off policy in the direction of the medical profession's affairs rather than attempt to act as "the big Pooh-Bah."

Coffee prices will rise during the next few days on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, dealers predicted last week. Futures prices, under the rulings of the exchange, are allowed to rise or fall only 3 cents a day on the earliest contracts (in this case March deliveries) and 2 cents on the other options.

FOAMS and froths are an important part of good eating. Without them there would be no angel food, chiffon cake, meringue glacee, cheese souffle or Bavarian cream. We would be missing even such a simple thing as hot chocolate with whipped cream.

The death of President Klement Gottwald of Czechoslovakia is a "severe blow" to the Communist regime there, the Czechoslovak delegation to the international congress of the Christian Democratic Union of Central Europe said yesterday in a statement read to the congress.

The phenomenal growth of industrial production throughout the world during the past quarter of a century emerges as the central fact in a new report issued by the United Nations. In 1951 world industrial output is calculated to have been more than three times that of depression-ridden 1933, more than twice that of prosperous 1929, and (not least impressive) one-third higher even than in 1948.

A GOOD chance for local movie goers to take a full look at Leslie Caron and determine wherein the attractiveness of this little French actress-dancer resides is currently being provided by Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer, which has two new pictures with the starlet obligingly showing on local screens.
MILWAUKEE, March 14 -- Lieut. Ken Wiesner of Great Lakes, Ill., set a new world and American indoor record in the high jump tonight with a leap of 6 feet 9 7/8 inches at the Milwaukee Journal games.
LONDON, March 14 (AP) -- Britain, which once carried half the world's seaborne cargoes, fears her once proud merchant fleet is dwindling dangerously away.

The pending marketing of $200,000,000 of Allied Chemical and Dye Company bonds will mark the first time that the financial district's foremost trade rivals -- Morgan Stanley Co. and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. -- have been associates in an underwriting syndicate.

LONDON, March 14 -- An active role for the United States in the Anglo-Egyptian negotiations on British evacuation of the Suez Canal Zone seemed to be indicated today by the presence of Jefferson Caffery, the American Ambassador in Cairo, at the first conference on that subject.
PERFORMANCES are coming these days in a regular freshet. Final showings of the ballet-biography of Poe, "Poor Eddy," will take place at Columbia, and there are other events of various characters.
WEST POINT, N. Y., March 14 -- Penn State's gymnastic team dominated the twenty-sixth annual individual championships of the Eastern Intercollegiate League today.

ITHACA, N. Y., March 14 -- Cornell closed its basketball season tonight with an 80-55 victory over Dartmouth to guarantee the Big Red at least a tie for third place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League.

HAVERSTRAW, N Y., March 14 -- Contests in five of the eleven Rockland County village elections next Tuesday are of interest to county leaders of the two major parties, because the results may indicate the trend in the fall elections, when the control of township and county government will be the issue.
CAMP KILMER, N. J., March 14 -- If this sprawling Army post had a mayor, Tony Codella would undoubtedly be swept into office.
A hold-up man took $115 within a half hour yesterday from two Loft Candy Shops in Brooklyn managed by sisters. Through his timing and their cooperation, however, he missed $400.

DESPITE its many rather formidable responsibilities, the Department of Agriculture still has a warm spot in its heart for the home gardener whose problems may be no more cosmic than fencing with a broad-leaved weed, being thwarted by a recalcitrant lilac bush or just figuring out whether it is a question of more technical know-how or less carbon dioxide for success with that window box filled with geraniums.

" It won't last long" was the common judgment in Japan when a new Cabinet headed by Premier Shigeru Yoshida took office after national elections last October. The reasons were plain. Though Premier Yoshida's Liberal party held an absolute majority -- 245 out of 466 seats in the Diet--its ranks were split.

During the long years in opposition, a number of Republicans in Congress developed an abiding distrust of virtually every act and policy of the Democratic Administrations. Victory at the polls last November did not change this attitude. One result has been to complicate life for the Eisenhower Administration, particularly in its efforts to implement a foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Val Peterson, the former Governor of Nebraska, knows precisely where he is going as Federal Civil Defense Administrator, but confides he is still too new in the job to know specifically how to get there.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (UP) -- Dr. Harold Lyons, research director of the National Bureau of Standards, will be honored by his colleagues because he took some atoms and made a better timepiece than the earth.

Such substantial increases in volume and profits were recorded during 1952 by Heineken's Breweries in Amsterdam and Rotterdam that Melchior J. Weymershausen, export manager, reported here last week that a dividend of 9 per cent would be paid to its stockholders throughout the world.
A train pulled out of Nieuw Amsterdam yesterday morning, rumbled through the Bronks and toured slowly up the Haarlem River Valley and then down the valley of the River of the Prince of Mauritius.

MINEOLA, L. I., March 14 -- Most of Nassau County's voters, satisfied with their ballot contribution in the recent national elections, turn their democratic power next Tuesday to the equally important task of selecting home-rule officials in fifty-two incorporated villages.

FOR many years, and with increasing tempo of late, we have heard that the United States is running out of great natural resources, exhausting its gas and oil and forests. We have become a have-not nation.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 14 (AP) -- Doris Hart won the women's title in the first annual Masters' invitation tennis tournament and Art Larsen upset Vic Seixas, United States Davis Cup captain, in a men's semi-final match today.

ATHENS, March 4 -- The five-member Evaluation Team made up of "distinguished Americans of competence and experience," chosen by Harold E. Stassen, Director of the Mutual Security Agency and headed by Thomas A. Morgan, charman of the Sperry Corporation, New York, has just completed a two-week investigation of United States aid administration in Greece.
AFTER reading Sidney Hook's uncritical review of James Bryant Conant's "Education and Liberty," I can only wonder why Roman Catholic opposition to Conant's appointment to Germany wasn't far greater.

The battle between New York City and New York State over city fiscal problems reached the showdown stage last week. Governor Dewey set out four proposals to enable the city to balance its budget, avoid its annual financial crises and improve its government.

Experiments in growing a live baby chick from an embryo which has been treated in an anti-freeze, like glycerol, frozen by immersion in liquid nitrogen (at -- 320 degrees F.), and thawed are under way at St. Louis University. Prof. Basile J. Luyet, director of the Institute of Biophysics, is directing the project.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 14 -- Chaudhri Mohammed Ali, the Finance Minister, introducing Pakistan's budget in the Constituent Assembly today, announced increased commodity import duties. He budgeted for a surplus in the fiscal year 1953-54 of 1,400,000 rupees (one Pakistan rupee equals $.30225) out of a total estimated gross revenue of 1,448,500,000 rupees (about $437,810,000).

The changing of dictators in Russia will "make no difference" with the retention of totalitarian principles in the Soviet Union, declared Capt. Joshua L. Goldberg, staff chaplain of the Eastern Sea Frontier, in a sermon at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, yesterday morning.
MIAMI, March 14 -- Both the wind and the Dodger pitching favored the Yankees today as the Bombers belted four homers at Miami Stadium and beat the Brooks, 8 -- 3.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today 102 additional casualties of the Korean war. The list included nineteen killed, seventy-eight wounded, two injured accidentally and three missing. In addition, fourteen persons previously listed as missing were identified as captured by the enemy.

LONDON, March 14 (Reuters) -- The International Federation of Airline Pilots stated in London today that present developments were leading to overcrowding in civilian passenger planes. It urged that all passenger planes should have enough exits to allow evacuation in an emergency. These subjects will be discussed at the federation's eighth conference in Chicago April 6 to 10.

ALBANY, March 14 -- The State Workmen's Compensation Board warned today that employer-sponsored legislation to reduce the costs of workmen's compensation would actually increase costs by several million dollars and result in a breakdown of the present compensation system.
DETROIT, March 14 (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks strengthened their bid for a Stanley Cup play-off berth tonight by defeating the Detroit Red Wings, 3 to 1, before 13,981 fans at the Olympia.

PETER VIERECK'S new book covers a lot of country, and uses for the journey a whole rhetorical stable, from Nietzschean aphorism to sober essay to poetic ode. It is about many things, almost everything, but one thread charts the general drift.

THE study of medicine -- beginning the very first day with death at the anatomy table, and only concentrating upon life in the obstetrical department during the fourth year -- generates its own macabre sort of humor. Not surprisingly, that humor doesn't ordinarily appeal to the non-medical, until once in a generation or two a real physician-humorist comes along.

BONN, March 14 -- Germany must be counted one of the failures of the late Joseph Stalin. Fully aware of the decisive importance to communism and Russian imperialism of the control of all Germany, he failed between 1945 and 1952 to extend Russian authority beyond the western pickets of the Russian group of armies in East Germany and even to compel submission of the stout republicans of West Berlin.

LONG BEACH, Calif., March 14 (AP) -- Parry O'Brien, the Olympic shotput champion from the University of Southern California; broke the meet record in the Long Beach Relays today with a toss of 55 feet 4 1/2 inches.

THE future looks rosy to Technicolor, Inc., at least. The company, according to its annual financial report issued last week, did a record volume of business in 1952 and, although the year still is quite young, its prospects for 1953 look to be even brighter.

IN 778 the Emperor Charlemagne was recalled from an indecisive campaign in northern Spain by a revolt of heathen Saxons on the banks of the Rhine. He left behind him a rear guard which was commanded by one Hrodland, warden of the Breton marches, a man otherwise unknown to fame, and this rear guard was set upon and utterly annihilated in the Pyrnees not by the Saracens but by Christian Basque mountaineers.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (UP) -- Should all-out war come the United States would have trained men ready to fight for the first time in its history, a military manpower expert said today.

NOTRE DAME, Ind., March 14 -- The 1953 Laetare Medal, awarded annually by the University of Notre Dame to an outstanding American Roman Catholic layman, will go to I. A. O'Shaughnessy of St. Paul, Minn., and Golden Beach, Fla., oil industry executive and philanthropist.

LONDON, March 14 -- Returning today from his visit to the United States, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden disclosed that a further effort to improve relations between Yugoslavia and Italy would be made when the Yugoslav President, Marshal Tito, comes to London next week.

LONDON, March 14 -- In a defiant communique, the British Air Ministry announced tonight that, despite the destruction of a British bomber by Soviet jet fighters in Germany on Thursday, Royal Air Force exercises over the European Continent would proceed next week and that the participating planes would be armed.
Bette Davis, stage and screen actress, will be operated on tomorrow morning at New York Hospital for the second time in eight days, her physician announced yesterday.

FOR THIS WEEK: Sow seed of peas, both edible and flowering, and larkspur as soon as soil can be prepared. . . . Cut and stack brush to be used later in spring as support for peas and other climbing plants. One source of brush is stems of storm-damaged branches removed from trees. . . . Feed deciduous shade trees with a balanced commercial fertilizer. . . .

THE fine bold type and the poet's drawings make this new collection of Harry Behn's poems a joy to the eye as well as the ear. The subject-matter varies from aspects of nature to everyday happenings and to the realm of pure imagination -- like "The Gnome" and "Moonvine" -- which are successful both as fantasy and as poetry.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 14 -- All was in readiness here today for the new series of atomic tests scheduled to begin at 5:20 o'clock Pacific Standard Time (8:20, Eastern Standard Time) on Tuesday morning on the desert of Yucca Flat, eighty miles to the northwest of this frontier town of former days.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 14 (UP) -- What may be Boston's final intra-city baseball series opened today with the Red Sox squeezing out a 2-1 victory over the Braves. All of the runs in the game were unearned.

MANY people have been led to believe that broadleaved evergreens should not be pruned. The misunderstanding is probably based on the obsession that people have about pruning any plant while its leaves are present.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- In his annual report for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1952, published today, Earl James McGrath, Commissioner of Education, urged a thorough nation-wide survey of the teacher shortage.
CAIRO, March 14 -- The United States today joined formally for the first time the Anglo-Egyptian negotiations over the withdrawal of British troops from the Suez Canal Zone.

ALBANY, March 14 -- Following are the texts of Governor Dewey's message to the Legislature today recommending legislation to implement the proposals of the State Crime Commission on election procedure and of the commission's recommendations:

The University of Pittsburgh successfully defended its Eastern Collegiate Swimming Association championship last night at the John Quigley Memorial Pool on New York University's University Heights campus. The Panthers took the James H. Reilly Trophy with 97 points, 27 points more than their nearest rival, Lehigh University.
AS the Soviet empire created by Stalin hovers between an obscure past and an inscrutable future, there are these questions:

Carlos Chavez, Mexican composer, will be the guest composition instructor at this summer's session of the Berkshire Music Center, the Boston Symphony Orchestra's music school run concurrently with the Berkshire Festival at Tanglewood, near Lenox, Mass.
Secondary school administrators are finding that the teen-age boy or girl is putting increasing emphasis on planning a college program as a springboard to a career.

AMERICA offers hardship and opportunity to the Zarins when they come to Mississippi from Latvia, via a German DP camp. Cotton-picking and tenant farming have little appeal to the independent father, who wants a business or a farm of his own.

WITHIN the year the Empire Theatre will be rubble. Once Shirley Booth has had her final word in "The Time of the Cuckoo," its hallowed walls will be battered down that a skyscraper, trumpeting the triumph of commerce, may be reared on its site. Outraged at this blasphemy.

ALBANY, March 14 (AP) -- Capitol correspondents sang their way through their annual dinner show tonight as Governor Dewey watched his stage double lose control of "President Eisenhower" and national Republican policy.

John De Merchant, baritone soloist at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon. Assisted at the piano by Merrill Brockway, he presented an unhackneyed program that included Bloch's Psalm XXII, Faure's L'Horizon Chimerique and Virgil Thomson's "Pigeons on the Grass Alas."
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Something in the nature of a cloud, certainly no bigger as yet than a man's hand, has now appeared on the horizon for the Congressional investigators.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, the Majority Leader, admitted today that the Senate's pace was "too slow" and said he was trying to "hurry up" the committees to get legislation onto the floor. His remarks reflected the concern felt by other Republicans in the Senate.

BOSTON, March 14 (AP) -- Paddy (the Billy Goat) DeMarco of Brooklyn mauled his way to a unanimous ten-round decision over Henry Davis of Los Angeles tonight in a nationally televised bout at the Boston Garden. DeMarco weighed 133 3/4, Davis 135.

LINCOLN, R. I., March 14 (UP) -- A record-breaking crowd of 35,000 turned out at Lincoln Downs today for the opening of the New England racing season and watched their hero, Tony De Spirito, boot home four winners, including three in a row.

JEANNE ANTOINETTE POISSON, Marquise de Pompadour, was a career woman. By a chronological accident, because she was born in France in 1721, her profession was that of official mistress to the King of France.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 14 -- Yale won the Big Three basketball title for the first time since 1949 by defeating Harvard, 83 -- 69, tonight.
THE Belgian fence provides a practical way of growing apples or pears for the family in a sunny part of the garden -- be it large or small. What is more, it's all surprisingly simple.

" FEVER OF LOVE" is an aptly titled novel about a midsummer madness which struck during a house party at the Devonshire home of Richard and Jane Longacre, raged on afterward in London and came to its climax in Spain.

THIS month, under the Security Council's rotation system of picking officers, the president's chair is being occupied by Prof. Ahmed Shah Bokhari, a Pakistani from the Khyber Pass country who is a scholar turned diplomat and in the opinion of the trade one of the two or three ablest representatives of a point of view -- in his case, the Asian-Arab bloc -- to turn up in the United Nations' seven years.

TOKYO, Sunday, March 15 -- United States Sabre jets, in the second successive day's fighting along the Manchurian frontier on the Yalu River, shot down three of Red China's Soviet-designed MIG jet fighters yesterday, probably destroyed two more and damaged two others.

LONDON, March 14 -- Gen. Francisco Franco's Government has been informed that, contrary to the supposition in Madrid, Britain has not interfered in the negotiations between Spain and the United States for a bilateral defense and aid agreement.
YONGDUGPO, Korea, March 1 -- The one thing that bothers Pfc. Edward J. Affsa of Dorchester, Mass., is exactly what he's going to tell the folks back home when they ask him what he did during the war.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 14 (AP) -- The glove worn by the man who made the first unassisted triple play in the major leagues will be added to the exhibits in the baseball Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, N. Y.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., March 14 -Eight mayors, twenty-four trustees and three police justices will be elected Tuesday in twelve Suffolk County communities.

ON behalf of the Italian film industry I should like to take sharp issue with Bosley Crowther's assertion in his last Sunday column that "the fairly consistent post-war flow of superior product from Italy appears to have played out this season."

CHICAGO, March 14 -- Teachers of English were told here today that the outbreak of censorship of paper-bound books and other media had posed a threat to our fundamental liberties, the country's literacy and the role of the educator.

SINGAPORE, March 14 -- Lau Mah, one of Malaya's leading Communist terrorists, has died of tuberculosis, according to an announcement issued in Kuala Lumpur today. The news came from a recently surrendered terrorist.

Patrolman Joseph R. Supple Jr., attached to the Far Rockaway precinct for the last five years, died yesterday in St. Joseph's Hospital of a wound received when his revolver discharged accidentally on Wednesday night. He had not regained consciousness after the accident.
The annual celebration of Negro Newspaper Week began last night with a radio tribute by President Eisenhower to the Negro press for its contributions to the nation's spiritual progress.

THE national intercollegiate bridge tournament, in which 110 college teams are competing, is now in process. The qualifying hands have been played by some 3,000 students. After their scores are judged, the pairs representing the sixteen highestranking colleges will meet in Chicago and play for the championship.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., March 14 (AP) -- Michigan showered Minnesota with four goals in the final period to win the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey championship tonight, 7 -- 3. It was the third straight title for the Wolverines.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Senators fighting the choice of Charles E. Bohlen as Ambassador to Moscow pinned their hopes almost entirely on stirring sufficient controversy to induce withdrawal of the nomination by President Eisenhower.

With anxiety over the Russian political situation somewhat abated, apprehension in financial quarters was lifted and a firmer trend in prices prevailed in the stock market last week. There was no disposition, however, to assess favorably the change in the Soviet high command, despite the protestations of peaceful intentions by the new Premier, Georgi M. Malenkov.
Twenty-seven managing and news editors from twenty states will meet tomorrow for the first session of a two-week seminar at Columbia, University's American Press Institute.

TWO shows with different concepts of photography as a medium are on view this week. One is the nineteenth New York International Salon of Photography, sponsored by the Pictorial Photographers of America, at the American Museum of Natural History, where it will hang through next Sunday.
BRONXVILLE, N. Y., March 14 -- Westchester County parkway police today arrested Nathaniel Toelman Bull Jr., 23 years old, of Providence, R. I. -- they think.

AMERICANS who have fretted and worried over the lack of action on the part of American airplane builders in the field of jet-propelled transports will be heartened by a recent survey of the jet-airliner situation in this country.

TRENTON, March 14 (AP) -- The only reason New Jersey does not have an official Potato Chip Week is that Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll refused to go along with the idea. Press agents also have tried to use the prestige and publicity value of the Governor's office for such causes as Cat Week, Cotton Week, Sisterhood Week, Anti-Depression Week, and Expectant Fathers' Day.

Bayard F. Pope has traveled a long way since 1910, when he made his first bond sale to a man shingling a roof in Provincetown, Mass. In fact, as head of a sprawling New York State banking empire, during recent years he has traveled to every city and most of the towns of this state.

On the turbulent Brooklyn waterfront -- the scene of murder, shakedown and rackets -- there was a pause in the day's more widely publicized activities yesterday for what might be termed the children's hour.

MOSCOW, Sunday, March 15 -- The Soviet Union announced today that it was sending a delegation, headed by Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Minister of war, to attend the funeral of President Klement Gottwald of Czechoslovakia.

Sidney Hook writes that "there is nothing undemocratic in principle in requiring attendance at public schools." He should let Russia, Hungary, Czechoslovakia and other totalitarian countries know how democratic they have been in abolishing private schools. * * *

ANATOLE LITVAK, of Hollywood and Europe, who demonstrated convincingly with his 1948 picture, "The Snake Pit," that a film can deal honestly with human and social problems and still entertain the millions, is hard at work here trying the formula out again, this time in both French and English versions.
Korean ammunition shortages and the problem of what next in that war-torn peninsula claimed the attention of Congress and the United Nations last week.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Charles Munch, brought its New York season to a close yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The program presented was meaty, and its four numbers enjoyed notably fine performances.

UNHAPPILY, James Hall's book leaves the reader confused as to its intentions. Is it supposed to be a sort of "appreciation" of the art song for laymen? If so, the inclusion of detailed musical analysis of a few songs is an error.

A singularly successful ambassadorial term has just come to a close in New Delhi, India, as Chester Bowles prepares to take his leave. Few diplomats of recent years can have made such an impression of warmth and goodwill in the nations to which they were sent as spokesmen of this country.

TRENTON, March 14 -- The joint legislative committee investigating the ouster of Nelson F. Stamler as Deputy Attorney General will be unable to make even a preliminary report when the State Legislature reconvenes here on Monday after a four-week recess.
Useful amounts of electric power have been produced with a new experimental "homogeneous reactor" at Oak Ridge National Laboratory, though the designers did not have any economic purpose in view.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Figures just compiled by the Federal Security Agency show that public assistance to the aged, a $1,500,000,000 Federal-state item annually, is a major problem in Federal-state relationship studies soon to be in full swing.

ONE could always expect a good story from Charles Tenney Jackson. Now he has written a story of his own boyhood, of boys in Nebraska seventy years ago when that country was young. He calls it "A Prairie Boyhood" in his subtitle, and that's what it is, boyhood remembered with the deep patina of the years.

ERIC BENTLEY is one of the most penetrating and dogmatic critics writing on drama and the theatre today. And by dogmatic I mean no derogation at all. For he knows. He has been there. He has seen and felt. He has experienced the theatre. For this reader he has a right to be dogmatic, such is his authority.

AT midnight on the 15th of September, 1951, in Ann Arbor, Mich., Miss Pauline Campbell, 34, a nurse, was found lying in a quiet tree-shaded street, bloody and fatally beaten. The police figured a maniac was loose, pointing to the fact that another nurse had been beaten almost to death for no apparent reason in Ann Arbor a week before.

The John and Mary R. Markle Foundation has appointed twenty-one doctors, faculty members of medical schools in the United States and Canada, as the sixth group of "scholars in medical science," it was announced yesterday.
