LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 14 (AP) -- Ninety-one horse-owners, dreaming of the thrill that goes with a visit to the Kentucky Derby winner's circle, today nominated 137 hopefuls for the May 2 race.

FORT DIX, N. J., March 14 -- An intensified search was pushed today for two New York and Newark recruits who escaped last night with five others from a company stockade. Objects of a thirteen-state alarm are Pvt. Alberto A. Comia, 20 years old, of 5750 Sixty-ninth Lane, Queens, and Pvt. Edward P. Pitman, 21, of 128 Broome Street, Newark.

AFTER an earlier career that cannot be regarded as calm and prosaic, Jay Richard Kennedy now has his life departmentalized. This even goes so far as having, at strategic points about town, offices to fit the right hand and the left.

THIS is the last Sunday of winter, 1953. And though darkness and devils are everywhere, the fact that the crocuses are visible and the heat has been turned on in the commuters' trains gives us a small sense of beginning all over again.

A BABY-SITTING kangaroo, four young bunnies, their friends and relatives and a zooful of animals stir up a zany, slapstick furor in this picture book. Mrs. Roo's troubles started when she took her original charges on a tour of the countryside, kangaroo style.

Bellevue Hospital fears a mass exodus of its nursing staff next year to better-paying jobs at the Veterans Administration Hospital that is nearing completion just the other side of Twenty-second Street, according to Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals.
HAGERSTOWN, Md., March 14 (AP) -- Two Marylanders said today that their project for stealing a top-secret Russian-made MIG-15 from Poland was strictly a private enterprise.

MOBILE, Ala. -- This is the deep South. If there is any doubt about it, one has only to look skyward on lower Government Street and there flying over the city's newest hotel is the Stars and Bars -- on the mast just below the Stars and Stripes.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 14 -- Annual village elections will be held on Tuesday in twenty incorporated villages of Westchester County. There are contests in ten villages. Mayors, trustees and other local officials will be chosen.

THERE is a paradox to Graham Sutherland's art. Visual sensibility is the chief characteristic of this famous contemporary English painter (an excellent exhibition of whose work is now at Curt Valentin's), yet he invariably deals with appearances as they become transfigured in his imagination.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 14 (AP) -- Doris III, Hub Isaacks' big cutter from Fort Worth, stepped out front in the St. Petersburg-to-Havana yacht race tonight as soon as the fleet hit deep water.

The composite picture above contains all the ingredients of "The Correct Collection" of our time. It includes the seventeen currently most popular and expensive French painters, seven of them appropriately with more than one example The paintings were loaned by New York's most famous collectors to an exhibition opening March 18 at the Paul Rosenberg Gallery for benefit of the Public Education Association. How many can you identify? Answers below.

Mass production, quantity distribution, big-scale consumption -- these are American ideas, born and developed in this country. They are the heart and soul of the highest standard of living the world has ever seen.

Henry R. Liebermann, who wrote "How Firm Is the Moscow-Peiping Axis?" (March 1 ) is not an old "China Hand," as stated; but an "Old China Hand." Both of us are. The meaning of this phrase should be explained to your readers.

SAN FRANCISCO, March l4 -The state of California will give serious study to a proposal to convert the northern part of San Francisco Bay into a 250-square mile fresh water lake if the Legislature approves appropriations measures now before it.

Mrs. Louise Riley, who has been trying to make American service men feel at home in England for the last thirteen years, arrived here yesterday to take a look at the country they've been telling her so much about.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 14 (AP) -- Danish Foreign Minister Ole Bjoern Kraft insisted tonight that the young Polish pilot who flew a Soviet MIG-15 jet fighter to Denmark was a genuine political refugee without American undercover connections.

The legality of the present syndicate system of distributing new securities, questioned for years by anti-trust lawyers of the recent national Administrations, is likely to remain under a cloud indefinitely, despite the change of Administration in Washington and regardless of the outcome of the current investment banking trial.

MISS STEEN'S well-earned public, accustomed as it is to such jumbos as "Twilight on the Floods" and "The Sun Is My Undoing," may be puzzled, at first, by this deceptively slight novel of country life in George IV's England, with its gentilities, its lavender-lace dialogue, its Jane-Austenish primness.

TOKYO, March 14 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida's Government was overthrown by a vote of no confidence by the House of Representatives tonight. Mr. Yoshida immediately dissolved the House and made plans to carry his fight for political survival to the people in a general election.
Klement Gottwald held office as a Soviet viceroy longer than most Kremlin puppets.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 14 -- Nearly 100 well-preserved skeletons of 60,000,000-year-old frogs that were collected early this winter in one of the suburbs of Bombay, India, have been added to Princeton University's collections of fossil vertebrates by Prof. Erling Dorf of the Department of Geology.
MONTREAL, March 14 (UP) -- Montreal Canadiens clinched second place in the National Hockey League race by defeating the New York Rangers, 3 -- 2, before 14,435 fans tonight.

AUGUSTA, Ga., is enjoying a tourist boom simply because President Eisenhower vacationed at the Augusta National Golf Club before his inauguration and spent his first official vacation there -- a week-end of golfing. The reflected glory of the Presidency has caused people to stop by just to see the cottage where the Eisenhowers lived, and it has shone also upon William Parteet, the 49-year-old caddy who regularly carries Mr. Eisenhower's golf clubs.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 -- The 175th anniversary issue of the William Penn Charter Magazine, which claims to be the oldest school publication of its kind in the United States, will be published on March 23.

BONN, March 14 (AP) -- Following is the test of the note seat by Dr. James B. Conant, United States High Commissioner to Germany, to Gen. Vassili I. Chuikov, Soviet commander in Germany, concerning Soviet attacks on British aircraft:

ALBANY, March 14 -- Governor Dewey endorsed and sent to the Legislature today the second in a series of reports by the State Crime Commission. It urged that measures be taken to improve the caliber of county and district political leaders, encourage wider citizen participation in party organizations and improve the state's judicial system.

With two-thirds of its capital invested in chemical plants, the Celanese Corporation of America, major domestic producer of cellulose acetate yarn, has become an integrated chemical company. Twelve of its subsidiaries operate plants in Canada, Colombia, Mexico and Venezuela, so the company has also attained international stature.

KEY WEST -- Even without Presidential patronage Key West is booming, and one sees only a few vacancy signs around the town in front of motels and tourist courts. The gimmick which draws visitors to the nation's southernmost city like trout to a No. 3 fly is its climate.

PAUL SMITH'S, N. Y., March 14 -- Tauno Pulkkinen, 29-year-old Brooklyn Finn who has dominated skiing since his arrival in the United States a short time ago, again demonstrated championship form under the toughest conditions today.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- President Eisenhower sent his condolences today to the widow of President Gottwald.
Let us hope Robert Bendiner's "If TV Moved Into the Classroom -- (March 8) brings some progressive action in New York State.
AUGUSTA, Ga., March 14 (AP) -- Patty Berg virtually cinched her fifth women's titleholders golf tournament today with a one over par 73.

Displaying a brand of basketball that was far from their best, the New York Knickerbockers, Eastern Division champions, dropped a 95-to-81 decision to the Syracuse Nats in a rugged National Basketball Association game at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -Alben Barkley, former Vice President, indicated today he had no personal interest in the transfer of a Louisville Revenue Bureau official who allegedly did not "cooperate" in making minor political appointments.
PUSAN, Korea, Sunday, March 15 (AP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson flew to Cheju Island today to inspect United Nations prisoner - of - war camps and South Korean Army training centers.

RALEIGH, N. C., March 14 -- Louisiana State, the nation's seventh ranked quintet, forged an 18-point lead in the third period and then held off a last-minute Holy Cross rally to whip the Crusaders, 81 -- 73, tonight to win the National Collegiate Athletic Association Eastern regional basketball tournament.
HAMILTON, N. Y., March 14 (AP) -- Colleges were urged today to "pioneer in experimental courses of civilian-military value."

WE think it's wonderful that George Axelrod, the subject of an article in your section on March 1, has had a great success with his first play, "The Seven Year Itch." We also think he is entitled to his opinion about the New Dramatists Committee, although other play-wrights (including William Inge, Joseph Kramm and Ronald Alexander) did apply to the organization, joined it, and apparently have not found the association with other new playwrights "unhealthy."

Sponsored by the Committee for Economic Development, college-community economic research centers have been founded witch weld academic knowledge of economics with practical business experience. Under the direction of colleges and universities, top-level business executives meet with the professors to determine economic problems in their own areas which need solution, and proceed to solve them through open debate based on factual research.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 14 -- The requests of African and Eastern Mediterranean countries and territories for about $1,000,000 in aid will be considered by the executive board of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund here beginning next Thursday.

SEOUL, Korea, March 14 -- Every American can take merited pride in the unexcelled record that our medical forces have made here in Korea. They have provided our fighting men with the finest care known in military history. Only by seeing this war-torn city first-hand, however, can one fully realize that the mission of our military forces here is far more than logistical support of our fighting men.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Following is the stenographic transcript of President Eisenhower's informal remarks today to the American Medical Association House of Delegates:

CHICAGO, March 14 -- Cars of the future held the center of the stage, as the forty-fifth annual Chicago Automobile Show opened this afternoon in the Stockyards arena that housed the 'Republican and Democratic National Conventions last July.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- President Eisenhower signed a bill today that will save 5,400 junior Naval officers from being demoted on April 1.

A YOUNG Greek who writes in English. Kay Cicellis, has published a first novel of considerable psychological impact. The hero of "No Name in the Street" is Gregory, whose late teens are lived out in his uncle's home in Athens where, in the company of his sister Alice and her success-minded husband, he tries to adjust himself to precarious post-war middle-class life.

ST. PETERSBURG -- Tourists reaching Florida's west coast in the next few weeks will find ample accommodations and some bargain prices. Summer rates in these parts generally do not become effective until April and May.

By the old lunar calendar March 15 was the day of the full moon. The month and the year began with the new moon and the promise of spring. Even after the Julian calendar was adopted and New Year's was set back to Jan. 1 -- the beginning of the sun's northward movement -- March 15, the Ides, was an important day in the life of the Roman people.

WHEN Heinrich Schuetz' Passion According to St. Matthew was released in a Renaissance recording a year ago, the seventeenth-century opus was revealed to modern listeners as a remarkable achievement -- a lengthy work that, relying mostly on recitative, and without any instrumental accompaniment, succeeded in telling the story of the last days of Christ in a manner that was absorbing, dramatic and moving.

The New York Infirmary will be the beneficiary of an entertainment known as the Ciro Ball to be held on April 28 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The fete has been underwritten by Ceil Chapman and Parfums Ciro, Inc.
From hesitant World War II beginnings has been built a new type of foreign trade business known as "without recourse financing."
LYNCHBURG, Va., March 14 (AP) -- How important is a college education to a girl who intends to get married and raise a family?
A long-standing question confronted the West in a new context and with a new urgency last week. It is the question of where Russia is heading.
Democratic State Chairman Richard H. Balch said yesterday that his party would seek a $500,000 legislative appropriation to build an experimental television station upstate.

The annual membership dinner of the Studio Club of the Young Women's Christian Association will be given Wednesday night at the headquarters of the organization, 210 East Seventy-seventh Street. The guests of honor will be Miss Susan Alice Trowbridge and John Robert Powers.

TAKAMATSU, Shikoku, Japan, Feb. 25 -- A slow swing in favor of national rearmament has begun to appear in the rural districts of Japan, of which this most isolated of the four home islands may be considered as typical.
THE correspondence between Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes and Harold Laski, painstakingly edited by Mark De Wolfe Howe, would be an idyl of friendship if it were not also a facade for tragedy.

BONN, Germany, March 14 -- The United States Government's policy on Germany was described today as "an illusion" by the official bulletin of the Executive Committee of the West German Social Democratic party.

THERE are now six LP versions of that most imposing of all piano concertos -- the Brahms B flat, Op. 83. The last two have arrived almost simultaneously, on Victor and Vox, the former with Artur Rubinstein and the Boston Symphony under Charles Munch, the latter with Monique de la Bruchollerie and the Pro Musica Orchestra under Rolf Reinhardt.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 14 -- Cornell's track squad handed Yale its first indoor dual track defeat since 1947 by winning the two-mile relay, the final event on the program today for a 59 1/3-to-49 2/3 triumph.

SINCE work on "Camino Real" has occupied my thoughts -and lately even my dreams -for about two years, not including the couple of months that it took me to do the original sketch for it, it would not only be dishonest but also practically impossible to pretend that I have enough interest in anything else to compose a piece for THE TIMES upon some other subject.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Congress is taking another look at demands for a fairer labor-management law, but it is not going to get much help, by way of agreement or compromise, from unions and business.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, announced today an agreement had been reached to settle the $500,000 libel suit he brought against The Syracuse (N. Y.), Post-Standard.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- President Eisenhower was reported today to look with high favor on a proposal that he appoint a roving economic ambassador to try to improve private trade dealings between the United States and foreign nations.
EVIDENCE of spring's imminent arrival maybe seen this week at flower shows across the country. From New England to California, half a dozen cities will play host to exhibitors and visitors.

Vincent Richards, who at 15 electrified the sports world in 1918 by winning the national doubles and national indoor singles teams championships, will celebrate his fiftieth birthday at a dinner to be given him by some 200 friends at the New York Athletic Club Friday night.

A 19-year-old City College freshman will get a chance to compete in the annual United States women's national table tennis tournament later this month, thanks to her fellow students who are raising the necessary funds to send her to Kansas City, Mo.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 14 -- Penn State tonight won the Eastern intercollegiate wrestling championship for the third successive year although Cornell's surprising team carried off the most individual titles in finishing second.

BONN, Germany, March l4 -- The United States, British and French High Commissioners protested today in similarly worded notes to Gen. Vassili I. Chuikov, commander of Soviet forces in Germany, against the unprovoked attacks on three British planes within twelve hours.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- President Eisenhower will send to the Senate soon the nomination of William Howard Taft 3d, New Haven, Conn., as Ambassador to Ireland. This was announced at the White House today.

Again Douglas Southall Freeman is quoted, this time by Dumas Malone in "When a Legend Becomes a President" (Feb. 22), as believing that George Washington occasionally "put on something of an act," as when bidding farewell to his officers at Fraunces' Tavern he embraced every one of them.

" KENTUCKIANS," notes Rexford Newcomb at the end of this handsomely illustrated monograph on the architecture of the Blue Grass state, "have been more interested in monumental, external form than in enclosed, livable space or volume as the actual content of architecture."

SYDNEY, March 14 (AP) -- High hopes of Australian Olympic officials that athletes at the 1956 Games could be housed in Army barracks in Melbourne were dampened today by reports from the Capitol at Canberra that objections were being raised.
Robert Bendiner's article ignores the present use of motion pictures by educators to secure the same objectives that he hails as revolutionary.

IF there is one thing we can be sure George R. Stewart, author of "Storm" and "Names on the Land," won't pop up with it is an unoriginal idea. This time he has picked for a subject Route 40, which is a highway of varying importance and usage, running from Atlantic City to San Francisco.

Ten days after the death of Joseph Stalin the Soviet Union presents a surface appearance of calm and almost unchanged routine. Georgi Malenkov nominally sits in the position of state and party power formerly occupied by Stalin.
THE newest issues from Young People's Records are diverting for small listeners, but behind the pleasant foolery there is a serious educational purpose.

WRITTEN by a French-woman who has spent some years in Indo-China, this remarkable novel relates what happens to people when they are driven to extremes of human misery. Marguerite Duras is concerned with the effect.

GENEVA, March 14 -- Of all the waves of refugees that have flowed across Europe in recent years, the movement of people from East Germany into West Berlin, on which the attention of the world is focused, is undoubtedly the strangest and, in many respects, most baffling.

Easter business began to gain headway in department stores in the area in the week, and store operators estimated the gain over the 1952 period as 5 per cent. Spring outer apparel especially was requested. The rainy but mild weather was not considered a handicap.

PORTLAND, Ore., March 14 (AP) -- The chemical process by which human skin is colored has been duplicated at the University of Oregon Medical School here. Two research scientists believe that it is a long step forward in the battle against melanoma -- the "black" cancer.

THE short-novel form, with its strictures of precision and restraint, is seldom, perhaps too seldom, chosen for a first novel. But Ovid Williams Pierce, the author of the present example, seems to feel as unconfined in small measure as, say, Gray in a country churchyard.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 14 -- Except for the formalities of obtaining official approval, the transfers of the St. Louis Browns to Baltimore and the Boston Braves to Milwaukee were virtual certainties today.

SINGAPORE, March 14 -- The British naval frigate Alert today moved alongside the Finnish 7,717-ton tanker Wiima, which entered Singapore harbor Feb. 23 with a cargo of jet engine fuel destined for Communist China. An authoritative source said the placing of the Alert was "a precaution in case the Wiima attempted to leave Singapore by unauthorized channels."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 14 (AP) -- The defending champion, Williams, paced by Dick Martin, swept five of ten first places today to win the New England Intercollegiate Swimming Association championship.

HONG KONG, March 14 -- Three Soviet Ambassadors have been assigned to Peiping since the Chinese People's Republic was established there under Communist leadership on Oct. 1, 1949. Of the three, the latest, Vasily V. Kuznetzov, has by far the highest rank and is presumably the best qualified to deal with Chinese-Soviet relations at the basic Communist party level.

Detroit has taken the national leadership in organizing an educational television station which will go into operation before the year ends. The new station will be a noncommercial venture operated under a joint committee representing the combined educational and cultural institutions and agencies in the Detroit metropolitan area.

IT would be difficult to think of a more depressing subject for a novel than this: the tracking down, by a heartbroken, widowed father, of a deceased adolescent's motive for the wanton murder of the father's 6-year-old daughter.
A delightful temperature that climbed to a high of 65.5 degrees at 3:35 P. M. yesterday brought New Yorkers out of their homes to swarm over the city's main streets and parks.

IT'S a curious fact that people who write about dogs seldom write about cats -- and vice versa. It isn't often that we find an author like Sally Scott, who treats both with equal understanding and enjoyment. In her new story, "Jonathan," she draws a sly portrait of a self-reliant cat in the process of making a home for himself.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said today his investigations subcommittee has asked the State Department for a list of all newspapers and periodicals used in its overseas information program and any money paid to them.

The National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. announced yesterday the appointment of the Rev. Alcwyn Lloyd Roberts as general director of its Commission on General Christian Education with headquarters in Chicago.

MANILA, March 14 -- The United States of America went through several crises of democracy in its earlier days. The Philippine Republic is meeting one such crisis head-on now in a national election campaign.

The Port of New York Authority has awarded a $112,134 contract for repairing and replacing the piles supporting the pier at Columbia Street, Brooklyn, to the low bidder, the General Contracting and Engineering Company of 120 Greenwich Street.

JACKSONVILLE, FLA. -- Over the past five or six years the gap between winter and summer tourist business in Florida has been gradually narrowing, with the winter season extending on through March and April, and May growing in tourist popularity.

ALTHOUGH I wasn't consciously aware of it, what I needed most of all in the world was a friend -- someone I could talk to, someone with whom I could share my ideas, not only about music but about all sorts of things which were beginning to interest me.
JERSEY CITY, March 14 -- A 19-year-old car looter was fatally wounded early today in attempting to escape two city policemen.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- An unhappy Republican party leader estimated this week that not more than 400 Republicans have been placed since Jan. 20 upon the payroll of the Federal Government, which now numbers well over 2,000,000 persons.

The death yesterday of Klement Gottwald, Moscow's Gauleiter for Czechoslovakia, is rich in irony. On the basis simply of the official death announcement it is plain that Mr. Gottwald found Moscow's atmosphere a source of mortal danger, taking the asserted form in this case of pneumonia and pleurisy.

Offices of Internal Revenue directors in New York and the suburbs did a rushing business yesterday, the next to the last day for the payment of 1952 income taxes. Thousands of melancholy taxpayers went in person to file returns, with the help of clerks, while postal trucks unloaded tens of thousands of mailed returns.

Expansion of the overseas recreational facilities offered to American merchant seamen in the clubs maintained abroad by the United Seamen's Service was announced here yesterday by Otho J. Hicks, executive director of the organization.

New Utrecht and Flushing earned the right to play for the city Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship next Saturday by scoring victories in the semi-final round at the Garden yesterday morning. The Brooklyn quintet defeated a borough rival, Thomas Jefferson, 62 -- 47, while the Queens team edged Commerce Of Manhattan, 70 -- 66, before 6,000 fans.

A new vitamin required by man to digest his food has been discovered and synthesized by Prof. I. C. Gunsalus and his research associates of the University of Illinois. Professor Gunsalus has named the new vitamin "lipoic acid." Leafy vegetables, liver and yeast are rich in it.

WHAT Americans like to call the paradox of Japan is the subject of this "character study" by Frank Gibney. Through five Japanese men of different occupations and social origins, the author explains the Japanese character as it has been shaped by its history and institutions from the earliest contacts with foreign cultures down through the Allied occupation of yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 14 -- Any program of national security must be organized so that both the executive and legislative branches of government carry out their duties to attain "that maximum of security compatible with the maintenance of a free society," James P. Warburg, economist and author, asserted tonight.

The wholesale markets were busy here last week with rush orders to fill in Easter stocks, the resident buying office of McGreevey, Werring Howell Company reported. Customers were said to be value-conscious and buyers requested off-price items and promotional goods along with regular merchandise.

THE question of whether the Government has a responsibility to help maintain our artistic and cultural institutions has not been met head on in this country. It has been touched upon in passing by private and official groups, but it has not had a full debate squarely on the issue.

THIS autobiography of "Manny" Celler, urbane Brooklynite, old-time liberal politician and Congressman for thirty years, confirms what many who have known him in Washington have long felt: that he is a sturdy foe of cant, that he understands what is possible in an agglomeration like the House of Representatives and that, therefore, he understands politics.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 14 -- Although the midshipmen from Annapolis are accustomed to more modern weapons, the Navy fencing team could not be stopped as it went on to win the three-weapon title in the Intercollegiate Association tournament today.

WHEN Richmond fell in the spring of 1865, the waning hopes of the Confederacy were shattered. On April 2 an oddly assorted wagon train with a small cavalry escort left the fallen capital and embarked on one of the most exciting and least known adventures in American history.

NEW ORLEANS, March 14 -- Matagorda, 4-to-5 favorite, flashed like lightning down the stretch today to capture the $46,450 Louisiana Derby, the closing feature at the Fair Grounds, and establish himself as a top contender for the Kentucky Derby at Louisville in May.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 14 -Premier Mohammed Mossadegh of Iran is expected to reject the latest United States-British terms for settlement of his dispute with the British former owners of Iran's oil in a broadcast to the nation on Friday, the second anniversary of the oil nationalization law and the eve of the Persian New Year's holiday.

It finally has happened -- the North and South of Ireland have joined forces -- even if 'tis in an indirect way. Irish linen, most of which is produced in the northern part of the Emerald Isle, will be extensively promoted this week despite the fact that Tuesday is St. Patrick's Day.

Plans are being advanced rapidly at meetings in private homes for the entertainment known as the Skyline Dinner Dance to be held on the night of April 23 in the St. Regis Roof for the benefit of the Kips Bay Boys Club. Mrs. Reginald V. Hiscoe and Mrs. A. Schuyler Clark are co-chairmen of the benefit committee.

Cholesterol, a fat-like substance produced by many tissues of the body and sometimes deposited on the walls of arteries, is generally regarded as the cause of arteriosclerosis. Abundant in the brain, it may insulate nerve fibers. When it blocks the tiny vessels that supply the heart with blood it causes coronary thrombosis.

WHENEVER there is a lull in the world of broadcasting it is almost certain that someone will ask about color television. Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat of Colorado, is the latest gentleman to do the honors by hinting darkly that "powerful interests" are deliberately trying to delay the advent of color TV.

PARIS, March 14 -- Perhaps the best commentary on Georgi Malenkov's peroration in favor of peace was the ruthless attack by Soviet jets on American and British aircraft just a few days later. In the long run this was probably a useful lesson for the Allied world. It served as a brutal reminder of the overriding reality of our time -- that the Soviet menace continues, regardless of which individual leader rides the juggernaut.
The International Flower Show closed at 10 o'clock last evening after a seven-day preview of spring.

Industrial uses for platinum have broadened so rapidly since the beginning of the war in Korea that market authorities are pondering what may happen when Government controls on the precious metal are relaxed -- possibly within the next few months.

NOW that "Porgy and Bess" has settled down in New York, the people who last September opposed the project of sending it abroad ought to feel ashamed of themselves. Some of them opposed the project on the grounds that the George Gershwin opera would give Europe and England a cheap impression of American culture.

Czechoslovakia's top Communist leadership is split into three major groups battling for Soviet favor in the new succession contest set off by President Klement Gottwald's death, Voice of America broadcasts to Czechoslovakia said yesterday.

HARTFORD, March 14 -- Chester Bowles, retiring United States Ambassador to India, is expected by Connecticut Democratic party leaders to return to this state within the next few weeks to begin an "active" campaign for re-nomination as Governor in 1954.

AMONG the numerous and highly diverse exhibitions of the week is a show of recent paintings by Frank Duncan at the Durlacher Gallery. In the years since his last previous show Duncan's work has greatly matured.

IT was a typical gray winter afternoon. The black, city-owned Mercedes sedan drove up to the varicolored brick building at 8 Kuno Fischer Strasse, in West Berlin. The long lines of refugees from East Berlin were waiting in the snow. "A heavy day," said Mayor Ernst Reuter grimly, thinking perhaps of his own days of escape and exile.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 14 -- Pennsylvania's program of semi-annual inspection of motor vehicles has become a model in that field of accident prevention. The National Safety Council has cited the state's program for merit for four consecutive years.

HOMESTEAD, Fla. -- One need not be an ornithologist or even an inveterate bird-watcher to enjoy a visit to Everglades National Park, which since its dedication by former President Truman on Dec. 6, 1947, has attracted over 140,000 visitors a year.

ALBANY, March 14 -- Governor Dewey's four-point program for rescuing New York City from the financial crisis in which it finds itself has focussed new attention on the state's power over city governments and the political considerations that frequently are involved in the use of this power.

IT takes a lively imagination to picture a rose so small that several may be displayed in a thimble, or the whole rose bush covered by a teacup. Yet the miniature roses are rugged, attractive plants with almost lacy foliage and a generous number of flowers -- although they open to scarcely an inch across from buds smaller than the head of a corsage pin.

A WEEK or so ago the daily newspaper carried a photograph of two white-haired sisters, strikingly similar in appearance, embracing each other for the first time in thirty- three years. The women were twins.

The developments hindering a speedier integration of Western European countries, given by David Thomson in a letter published in your columns recently, are essentially the arguments given by Anthony Eden in New York in 1951 in interviews and an off-the-record discussion.

Northwest Airlines, which is celebrating the twentieth anniversary of the pioneering flight it made from Minneapolis to Seattle in search of a "Northwest passage," has announced it will spend more than $20,000,000 to enlarge its sky fleet but still isn't saying publicly what type of airliner the new order will involve.

CHICAGO, March 14 (AP) -- Don Schlundt's record-breaking 41 points led the Big Ten champion, Indiana, the nation's No. 1 team, to a 79-66 victory over Notre Dame in the N.C.A.A. Eastern regional basketball final at the Chicago Stadium tonight.

CLEVELAND, March 14 -- A police drive to outlaw sin in books and pictures, which drove pocketsize editions of such standard works as Sigmund Freud's "general introduction to psychoanalysis" off many of this city's book store shelves, has lost some of its steam.

Any man, whether a newspaper editorial writer or columnist, or a radio or television commentator, who assumes that his ideas on public affairs are important, is definitely off the beam; yet it is clear that we do think so, or we wouldn't beat our brains out day after day and year after year trying to express those ideas clearly and forcefully.

French eighteenth century furniture, paintings and objects of art, in perhaps the finest sale in this category this season, will be auctioned on Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue. The collection, now on exhibition, is from the Comte Charles de Rohan-Chabot, Chateau de Conde, Conde-sur-Itou, France, and Fiesole, Italy.

The Italian liner Conte Biancamano has been scheduled for four additional trips to New York this year. This will result in a postwar record for the line of thirty-seven sailings in twelve months to this port.

PRE-EASTER trade is increasing and bears watching for its significance from the standpoint of immediate volume and as an index of consumer buying into the summer period. The holiday, on April 5, comes a week realier than last year.
Madison House will be the beneficiary of the March 26 performance of "Hazel Flagg" at the Mark Hellinger Theatre.

TRENTON, March 14 -- Primary battles in both the Republican and Democratic parties in this state will get under way this week-end. For the Republican organization such a fight is no novelty, but the Democrats are embarking on their first primary contest over the Governorship in twenty-five years.

MOSCOW, March 14 -- From throughout the Soviet Union 1,200-odd delegates of the Supreme Soviet gathered in Moscow tonight for a session called for tomorrow to approve changes attendant upon the death of Stalin and the appointment of Georgi M. Malenkov and others to leading Government posts.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Dr. Hermann J. Muller, noted biologist whose scientific background includes four years in Russia, says Soviet methods "represent an even greater danger to civilization than the prospects of an atomic war."
LONDON, March 14 (Reuters) -- A goal by Bill Holden decided today as Burnley defeated Manchester United, 2 -- 1, to gain a clear lead in the first division of English League soccer.
SEOUL, March 14 (AP) -- Front line officers and the top Army commander agree there is no general ammunition shortage on the Korean battlefront today.

Samuel W. Anderson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for International Affairs, asserted last night that Israel could make strong strides toward a balanced economy if her leaders would sacrifice some "of the desirable but costly cultural benefits they have planned," seek markets abroad and attract foreign investors "who can help them produce the goods with which they can fight effectively the battle of exchange."

THE purge of Rumania's former Communist boss, Ana Pauker, last summer, posed a ticklish problem for the leading Soviet playwright, N. Virta, a problem which might have ruined a lesser figure but which Mr. Virta managed to solve, though how he did it remains obscure.

Without being an old China hand, I had the distinct impression that Henry R. Lieberman's informative article. "How Firm Is the Moscow-Peiping Axis?" (March 1), omitted one crucial point. What are Communist China's real motives in fighting and prolonging the Korean war?

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 14 -- Patrick Duncan, son of a former Governor General of South Africa and one of the leading figures in the movement of resistance to racial segregation, declared in an address here this week that native leaders were having great difficulty in working up feeling among the South African natives.
OREGON, according to its Travel Information Division, will probably play host to more than a million out-of-state motorists during the coming summer.

NO bona fide actor has drawn the headline press notices given Willie (The Actor) Sutton. In these memoirs William Francis Sutton Jr., renegade son of a Brooklyn blacksmith, acts out the most difficult role of his sensational bank-robbing and jail-breaking career, the portrayal of himself.

Two men, charged with operating an unregistered still for the unlawful manufacture of alcohol, were arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court and held for the Federal Grand Jury in bail of $7,500 each.

Seton Hall won its first National Invitation Tournament last night. Faced by an underdog St. John's University quintet, which had surprised by reaching the final from an unseeded berth, the Pirates of South Orange, N. J., experienced little difficulty as they registered a 58-46 triumph at Madison Square Garden.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 14 -- Contract awards on engineering projects in eleven Western states, generally a weather vane for business, aggregated $89,100,558 in the week ended March 7, bringing the total for the year to $845,138,161.

Dr. Conant feels that "the greater the proportion of our youth who fail to attend our public schools" the greater the threat to our democratic unity. He also deplores the use of taxpayers' money to assist private schools. But private schools do not expand at the expense of public schools.
Schubert's Fifth Symphony was one of the works Arturo Toscanini and the N. B. C. Symphony presented in last night's broadcast concert from Carnegie Hall.
CLEVELAND, March 14 (AP) -- The United Rubber Workers, C. I. O., today adopted a 1953 contract program calling for "substantial" pay increases and improved pension and insurance benefits.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 14 -- A Yale University ichthyologist reported from British Guiana this week that he had taken what is believed to be the largest fresh-water fish ever caught on light tackle.

VIENNA, March 14 -- President Klement Gottwald of Czechoslovakia died in Prague at 11 o'clock this morning, nine days after the death of Stalin and four months after the Czechoslovak Communist leader had sent one of his best friends and eight other prominent Reds to the scaffold as traitors.

IN justice to Mr. Conant, it should be recognized that his discussion of the difficult problem of public and private schools is motivated by no hostility to any religious group. His primary concern is with the improvement of our public schools, which in some communities have been under severe and unjustified attack.

LAST April thousands of trout fishermen who shivered through the opening day with empty creels firmly resolved to forswear these frigid initial outings in the future, but a glance at the reservation books of angling hostels from the Ten Mile to the Beaverkill would reveal that such resolutions have weakened with time.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- A Senate investigation of ammunition shortages in Europe as well as in Korea was projected today as the result of new tensions growing from recent Red attacks on Allied planes over Germany.

GUATEMALA, March 14 -- The Congress confirmed today the temporary appointments of Chief Justice Marcial Mendez Montenegro and three associate justices, who were named to the Supreme Court Feb. 6 after the old court had granted a temporary injunction against the Government in a dispute over agrarian reform.

Under the direction of the Schools and Social Agencies Committee of the Bronx Welfare and Health Council, a guide to group work and recreation resources in the Bronx has been issued, It has been distributed to the schools as part of a series of activities sponsored by the committee to help schools and social agencies keep informed about each other's services and methods of work.

CHICAGO, March 14 -- The University of Chicago formally opened its $4,200,000 Argonne Cancer Research Hospital today with private dedication ceremonies held in the conference room of the Nathan Goldblatt Memorial Hospital, which adjoins.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 14 (UP) -- An Ohio State University physicist, suspended for refusing to answer questions before the Un-American Activities Committee of the House of Representatives, said today the committee had not "produced a single thread of evidence" against him.

JACKSON, Mich., March 14 (UP) -- A leader in the fiery 1930 Ohio State Penitentiary mutiny, who turned from the sword to the pen as he mellowed with age, pledged one-third of the royalties from his new book today to help rebuild the riot-scarred Jackson Prison chapel.

The present discussion of communism in American education has drawn relative silence from those to whom education means the most -- the students. Therefore the Harvard Student Council wishes to present a point of view it feels should be carefully considered in such a discussion.
Buddy Combs' Red Bank Polo Club and Squadron A gained the semi-final round of the annual Eastern twelve-goal indoor championship tournament last night with easy triumphs at the Squadron A Armory.

HOW long has it been since you read a book that made you exclaim, "Why wasn't it longer?" Mr. Edmonds' new book is that kind of charmer. Its people take hold of your affections. Its animals leap in your imagination.

The Erie Railroad had a net income last year of $8,992,611 after capital and sinking fund requirements, equal after preferred dividends to $2.85 a common share. This compared with $9,735,972, or $3.15 a common share, in 1951.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15 (AP) -- The big cutter Doris III stretched her lead to about ten miles in the St. Petersburg-to-Havana yacht race tonight, but still was moving slowly in light winds.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 15 (AP) -- Art Larsen, San Leandro, Calif., upset Gardnar Mulloy, top-franked amateur in the United States, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3 today to win the men's singles championship in the first masters invitation tennis tournament.

CAIRO, March 15 -- The United States and Britain are expected to issue a joint statement this week, possibly tomorrow, giving their stand in the forthcoming negotiations with Egypt on British evacuation of the Suez Canal Zone.

The alternate-side parking rule will apply after Oct. 1 to the entire cross-section of Manhattan except for Central Park, between Eighty-sixth Street and 155th Street from river to river, Andrew W. Mulrain, Commissioner of Sanitation, announced yesterday.
Elimination of the United States requirements for consular invoices covering importations from abroad was urged over the week-end by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.
A modern odyssey of "a man without a country" confronted immigration officials yesterday.

TOKYO, March 15 -- Leaders of all Japanese political parties laid plans today for a general election next month following a House of Representatives no-confidence vote against the Government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida last night that resulted in his immediate dissolution of the Diet (Parliament).

LONDON, March 15 -- The damper placed on the stock markets by the death of Premier Stalin has persisted in the last week and has been accentuated by the shooting down of British aircraft over Germany.

John Haynes Holmes, minister emeritus of the Community Church of New York, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, condemned yesterday this country's entrance into the Korean war and urged a united effort to end it soon.

Most of the decorative details associated with contemporary furniture design in the past year may be found on a new collection of modern pieces introduced here by Charak, 444 Madison Avenue, and available there through decorators. Among these details are touches of brass, the use of colored lacquer, a somewhat oriental line and combinations of wood with other materials; leather, marble and cane.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period March 7 to 13 are given in the appended tabulation:

The world's merchant marine fleet has become 20,000,000 gross tons heavier in the last thirteen years. But it contains fewer passenger vessels and more freighters and tankers than it did before World War II.

The East Side Chamber of Commerce, 231 Grand Street, is offering forty prizes in an essay contest designed to spread the word for cleaner streets on the lower least Side. The contest is open to the thirty elementary and junior high schools in this area, south of Twenty-third Street.
CORVALLIS, Ore., March 15 (AP) -- Ten N. C. A. A. basketball tournament records were set in the Far West Regional play-offs Friday and last night.

Varied divertisements are being planned for the annual Spring Festival of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, to be held April 23-24 in the Parish House of the church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, for the benefit of St. Luke's Hospital and the Youth Consultation Service.
Designed for the amateur carpenter are new plans for storage units and furniture that have been made available by the Douglas Fir Plywood Association.
The New Jersey Commission on Educational Television has made the New York Temporary Commission on Educational Television look a little foolish.

Marked changes in pension practices in American industry in recent years, with emphasis on liberalization of plans, are explained in the new survey, "A Study of Industrial Retirement Plans -- 1953 Edition," published today by the pension division of Bankers Trust Company, New York.

VIENNA, March 15 -- More than thirty hours after the death yesterday forenoon of President Klement Gottwald of Communist Czechoslovakia from the after-effects of a cold he apparently caught at Stalin's funeral, there had been no announcement of a successor to the 56-year-old dictator.

It was a sunny day last fall. Footballs were flying through the air as Axel Forslund, athletic director at Mount Hermon School, watched the varsity scrimmage against the reserves. Reuben McDaniel, a 6-foot 7-inch end, was pulling down a long lead pass and as he scampered for a touchdown.

The plan of one of the world's most experienced airlines to begin scheduled operations between the United States and Europe by way of the North Pole may seem to be a drastic step in commercial aviation, but veteran airmen with years of transocean and Arctic flying behind them applaud the idea.

A six-story building containing six stores and twenty-five apartments on lot 62 by 75 feet at 100 Macdougal Street, corner of Bleecker Street, was sold by Mrs. Baptista Miele to MacLeon Associates, Inc., representing a realty investment holding company owned by Leon Weiss and Maxwell E. Miller.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15 (AP) -- E. J. (Dutch) Harrison played the Pasadena municipal golf course in 66 today to win the $10,000 St. Petersburg open tournament with a record-tying 72-hole score of 266.
TOKYO, Monday, March 16 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,555, covering Sunday's actions:

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -The Democratic National Chairman, Stephen A. Mitchell, said today that he thought Adlai E. Stevenson, who was defeated for President in November, would be seriously considered for the party's 1956 nomination.

BERLIN, March 15 -- The bodies of five crew members of a Royal Air Force plane shot down Thursday by the Russians over the EastWest German border were carried from the Soviet zone today to the British military hospital in Hamburg.

PUSAN, Korea, March 15 -- A plan to revolutionize and strengthen specialized medical practice in Korea at a saving of hundreds of thousands of dollars vitally needed elsewhere in the rehabilitation of this country was proposed here yesterday by Dr. Howard A. Rusk. The proposal was enthusiastically accepted immediately by Republic of Korea officials.

In spite of the expected Soviet vetoes, the question of a successor to Trygve Lie as Secretary General of the United Nations is by no means closed. At most, there has been a preliminary test of opinion and strength. The free nations still have the opportunity to support and forward the candidacies of two admirably qualified persons.
ROME, March 15 (AP) -- Pope Pius pleaded for European unity today in his first speech since he became seriously ill nearly two months ago.
Lieut. Gen. Leon W. Johnson, commanding the Continental Air Command, yesterday warned his fellow Congressional Medal of Honor recipients against efforts made to exploit them.

Establishment of a $500,000 medical fellowship program to raise the standards of medicine and science in Israel to levels prevailing in the United States was announced last night by Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, which has a membership of 300,000.
PIERRE, S. D., March 15 (UP) -Two concert pianists and the mother of one were rescued today from a stalled truck after being marooned sixteen hours in a blizzard.

The Mariners, the male quartet that sings on Arthur Godfrey's radio and television programs, gave a program yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. It was the men's first full-length concert in the city, and an audience of 1,100 persons turned out to hear them.

Members of lodges of Free and Accepted Masons in the Metropolitan area attended religious services here yesterday morning and marched to the Astor Hotel for their annual breakfast. The services were conducted at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street; the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street, and Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 15 (UP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman proved almost as big an attraction as a championship basketball game he tried to see last night.

Vacant land covering the blockfront on the north side of West 235th Street from Henry Hudson Parkway to Netherland Avenue and the blockfront on Henry Hudson Parkway from West 235th Street to West 236th Street in the Riverdale section of the Bronx has been sold by Borchard Affiliations, Inc., Stuart Borchard and Evelyn B. Metzger to Abe and Alice Spirer, who insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
A total of 1,263 deep-sea American merchant ships flew the house flags of private companies on March 1, three vessels and 19,000 tons less than had done so a month before.
Approximately 88,000 employers in this state will be rewarded for stable payrolls last year by having their unemployment insurance tax rates cut in 1953.
Price-cutting by specialty store is the major competitive problem of the carpet and rug department in department stores.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 15 -- Leaders of Yugoslavia are openly overjoyed at the resplendent welcome in store for President Tito in Britain.

CRANFORD, N. J., March 15 -- Industrial goings-on in the salt marshes between Newark and Elizabeth could mean more mosquitos this summer, if the weather were unfavorable. It all depends on the weather; the industrial problem is slowly being solved.
BUENOS AIRES, March 15 -Completely discrediting its former leadership, the Communist party of Argentina has changed its "line" and has again become an opposition party.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -Taxpayers depressed by the general gloom peculiar to the time of year are assured of a smile by going, of all places, to their nearest Internal Revenue office. There, according to official pronouncements, they are regaled by the "let's meet 'em with a smile" technique initiated this year.

Foreign exchange market during the past week was quiet with the British pound sterling and the Canadian dollar developing a softer tone. Business transacted was not very large and aside from a few instances was mostly routine.

PITTSBURGH, March 15 -- Under the surface of a dynamic steel market is the view that events in Russia may affect the steel industry more than generally supposed. It seems logical to some steel observers that the easier tone expected in steel may be a little longer in coming because of Stalin's death. This is the way some people see the situation:

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 15--Preparations are under way here for the formation after the April 15 elections of a liberal white party founded on the principle that members of the African Negro majority of the population must be treated as human beings, having equal rights with the whites.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -Senator William Langer, Republican of North Dakota, a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, today called the Malenkov speech "very good news."

Consolidated net earnings of the St. Joseph Lead Company last year declined to $9,638,455, or $3.55 a share, on 2,716,222 shares outstanding from the record $13,577,236, or $5 a share, earned in 1951.

There was a Gilbert and Sullivan touch about yesterday's meeting of the Supreme Soviet in Moscow. The more than 1,200 members of this body had come from all over the Soviet Union to attend the session; many had traveled thousands of miles to engage in the serious deliberative task of considering the most important change of Soviet governmental leadership and organization in many years.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association has filed with the House Judiciary subcommittee a fortytwo-page memorandum to support the charge by police line organizations that recent widespread protests against alleged police brutality were the result of a Communist plot in New York and other cities.

Two hold-up men, driving 85 miles an hour in a 1950 sedan, escaped with more than $5,000 yesterday morning, after being chased five miles up the West Side Highway by three automobiles driven by employes of a taxicab company they had just robbed.

MOSCOW, March 15 (AP) -- Foreign correspondents received tickets yesterday for today's session of the Supreme Soviet in the Great Hall of the Kremlin, where Georgi M. Malenkov was confirmed as Premier.

A number of Protestant Episcopal churches here observed "Mothering Sunday" at services yesterday morning, with the blessing of the traditional Simnel cake, a custom dating back to the Middle Ages in England.
Senator Francis J. Mahoney, Minority Leader of the State Senate, assailed the Republican rent decontrol proposals yesterday as a "billion dollar grab for the real estate interests."

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -- Senator Barry M. Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, said today that the Taft-Hartley Law had failed to rout Communists from the labor movement. He urged tough new legislation to deal with the problem.

Rey de la Torre, Cuban-born guitarist, who made his debut here eleven years ago, gave a program late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall that held many delights for those who love the subtle and delicate art of the classic guitar.

LONDON, March 15 -- President Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia, first Communist head of state ever to visit Britain, arrived late this afternoon in the Thames Estuary aboard the Yugoslav training ship Galeb.
ASPEN, Colo., March 15 (AP) -Ralph Miller of Hanover, N. H., won the men's national combined open ski championship today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 15 -- During the final quarter of 1952, Harvard University received gifts totaling $3,507,418.31, it was announced here today. Of this amount, $2,247,087.55 was in capital gifts for endowment. Gifts for current use amounted to $1,260,330.76.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Senator Alexander Wiley, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said tonight that early committee action on Charles E. Bohlen's nomination as Ambassador to Moscow hinged on the success of efforts "to cut through rumor and get at the facts."

AMSTERDAM, March 15 -- No definite financing plan to pay for the damages from the recent floods has yet been announced. Apparently the Government is in no hurry to announce anything for two reasons: Treasury liquidity is overabundant and damage is still unknown.

ALBANY, March 15 -- Assemblyman Samuel Rabin, Republican of Queens, accused Democratic leaders today of deliberately distorting the facts in discussing the proposals. Mr. Rabin is a member of the State Rent Commission, which recommended the program.

Development of its telephone system has placed the United States far ahead of any other nation in the world in this form of communication. There are presently approximately 83,000,000 telephones tied into global voice transmission, 60 per cent of which are owned and operated by United States citizens.

The appointment of Hans Busch as executive director of the New Friends of Music was announced yesterday by Hortense Monath, president of the organization. Miss Monath also said that the New Friends of Music would present a concert in Town Hall in April, which would fulfill the obligations to New Friends subscribers that resulted from the cancellation last month of the two final concerts of the group's series.

The Christian Democratic Union of Central Europe, adopting a permanent constitution yesterday, ended its three-day international congress with a reminder to the free world that the "only language which Communist bosses in the Kremlin understood is the language of strength."

FORT DIX, N. J., March 15 -Pvt. Edward P. Pitman, 21 years old, of 123 Broome Street, Newark, one of seven men who broke out of a company stockade on Friday, turned himself in today after spending almost two days mingling with the other soldiers on this sprawling military reservation of 30,000 personnel.
SAN JUAN, P. R., March 15 (UP) -- Bishop James P. Davis said today that local Roman Catholic authorities "hope for a reconciliation'' with the Administration of Gov. Luis {ufioz 'vIarin.

NEW DELHI, India, March 15 -- Nepal's leading political party, the Nepali Congress, has adopted a resolution demanding the recall of an Indian military mission and other Indian advisers, according to reports from Katmandu, capital of the little mountain kingdom, by the Press Trust of India, this country's leading news agency.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 15 -- Delegates from eighteen countries will participate tomorrow as the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women opens its seventh session at headquarters here, under the chairmanship of Mme. Marie Helene Lafaucheux of France. Meetings are scheduled to last through the remainder of this month.

TOKYO, Monday, March 16 -- Only a few scattered patrol thrusts and skirmishes, occurring before dawn, were reported yesterday from the 155-mile Korean war front. One of the largest actions involved thirty to forty Chinese Communists who attacked a South Korean outpost east of the Pukhan River about 2:30 A. M.

The fact that Russia's Supreme Soviet did not consider the 1953 budget at its brief session in Moscow yesterday leaves the outside world ignorant of its most important comprehensive clue to the trend of Soviet armament, diplomatic observers pointed out yesterday.

Perry O'Neil's concise program of piano music last night in Town Hall took four works into account -- Schumann's "Papillons," Brahms' F minor Sonata, Carlos Surinach's "Trois Chansons et Danses Espagnoles" and Norman Dello Joio's Sonata No. 3. In the Schumann-Brahms portion of the program Mr. O'Neil somewhat overextended himself, with rather erratic results both pianistically and interpretively.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 15 (AP) -- Four teams that take their national ratings seriously -- Indiana. Washington. Kansas and Louisiana State -- open a two-day showdown test Tuesday night for college basketball's premier prize, the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship.
MIAMI, March 15 -- "It's just like the world series," said Peewee Reese with a grin, "except for the palm trees."

CLEVELAND, March 15 -- The shifting of the Soviet Union's mantle of power from master to pupil will not check anti-Semitism in Russia or terminate communism's militant opposition to all democratic people, Mrs. Irving M. Engel of New York, president of the National Council of Jewish Women, warned tonight.
NANTUCKET, Mass., March 15 (AP) -- The "Crossroads of the Atlantic" changed its position today when the Nantucket lightship moved to a station fifteen miles east of her previous location.
One hundred and twenty-five persons attended the annual meeting last night of the George Bernard Shaw Society of America at the Grolier Club, 47 East Sixtieth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -President Eisenhower now has a personal staff of eleven principal assistants, exactly the number in former President Truman's "Kitchen Cabinet," but there is a world of difference in the make-up and organizational patterns of the groups.

ALBANY, March 15 -- A bill that extensively revises the state's program of financial assistance to localities for welfare and tuberculosis care will be introduced in the Legislature tomorrow with the strong support of Governor Dewey.

LONDON, March 15 -- The abstract work of British sculptor Reg Butler that won for him last week the first prize in an international sculpture competition on the theme "The Unknown Political Prisoner," was smashed to pieces here this afternoon by a young Hungarian artist who is now stateless.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -- The Commerce Committee of the House of Representatives announced today that its hearings to find out what was holding back color television would begin March 24.

A survey of the flow of world news indicates thus far that "Europe and Asia are not getting an accurate picture of us" and "the picture we get of the rest of the world is very inaccurate," Lester Markel, chairman of the executive board of the International Press Institute and Sunday editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, reported here last night.

A woman identified as Mrs. Helen Elmendorf Duran, 36 years old, fell to her death yesterday at 10:30 A. M. from her room on the eighth floor of the Hotel Iroquois, 49 West Forty-fourth Street, the police reported.

" UNLIKE are we, unlike, O Princely Heart!" wrote Elizabeth Barrett in the first line of the third of her "Sonnets From the Portuguese," the love poems she penned to Robert Browning during their strange and celebrated courtship. They were indeed unlike, but the future Mrs. Browning at that time had no notion how unprincely was her suitor's heart.

ALBANY, March 15 -- The Dewey Administration's rent control bill and its fiscal program for New York City top a long list of controversial measures awaiting final action this week as Republican leaders seek to adjourn the Legislature by Saturday.
Is it easier, in proportion, to run a small business than to direct a big one?

A personality analysis of the Soviet Premier, Georgi M. Malenkov, and an account of his life has been scheduled for May publication by McGraw-Hill. Written by Martin Ebon, "Malenkov: The Career and Policies of the New Soviet Premier" describes his rivalry with the late Andre A. Zhdanov and his relationship to the four Deputy Premiers, Lavrenti P. Beria. Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Nikolai A. Bulganin and Lazar M. Kaganovitch.

A Bronx couple and their 25year-old son were burned to death yesterday in a fire that destroyed the interior of their one-story frame house at 68-E Edgewater Park, at the edge of Eastchester Bay near 177th Street in the Throggs Neck section of the borough.

Cotton futures prices staged a moderate advance on the New York Cotton Exchange last week, but some of the gains were lost on the final trading day. Active futures showed net gains of 5 to 26 points, or 25 cents to $1.30 a bale.

BOSTON, March 15 (UP) -Johnny Peirson, his broken jaw encased in a steel mask, fired the winning goal tonight as the Boston Bruins rallied to beat the Montreal Canadiens, 2-1, before 10,435 National Hockey League fans and pick up point in their race with Toronto for a Stanley Cup play-off berth.

President Eisenhower will be asked to exert "vigorous guidance and leadership" and "your personal prestige to safeguard liberty whenever it is attacked and from whatever source" in a report to be submitted to him by Freedom House today.

Senator Taft has taken the curious position that he is willing to vote for the confirmation of Charles E. Bohlen as Ambassador to Russia, but that since "our Russian Ambassador can't do anything" the matter is not of "sufficient importance to have a battle about."
WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson has told Congress that there ought to be more flexibility in the farm price support programs.

Neil Lazar of the Salle Santelli regained the All-Eastern threeweapon fencing championship by defeating Dr. Paul Makler of the Philadelphia Fencers Club, 8 to 5, in the final of the direct elimination competition at the Fencers Club yesterday.

Accused of holding up a young veteran and his fiancee, who joined in subduing one of the attackers as the other fled, two men were held in $600 bail each for hearing Wednesday by Magistrate Hyman Korn in Bronx Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Amherst Alumni Association of Washington has adopted a "Declaration on Academic Freedom." It accuses "certain members of both houses of Congress of desecrating our American traditions of intellectual honesty and fair play" in their inquiries into alleged subversion in education.

The Zionist Organization of America adopted yesterday a program "to mobilize its manpower and resources" to promote private investment in Israel. A feature was formation of an economic committee to carry out the program.

ALBANY, March 15 -- Democratic minority leaders of the Legislature announced tonight that the so-called Erwin - Travia bills curbing political contributions by labor unions would be opposed as a party measure.
MOSCOW, March 15 -- Following is the composition of the new Soviet Council of Ministers after changes approved today:

TEHERAN, Iran, March 15 -- An Italian oil trader who has a contract to buy 20,400,000 tons of Iran's nationalized oil in the next ten years gave the details today of the "squeeze" play by which he hoped to bypass the boycott organized by the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company, holders of the oil concession canceled by Iran two years ago.

Announcement by the Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn that its affiliated agencies would withdraw from the Queensboro Council for Social Welfare if planned parenthood groups remained as members, was viewed with "alarm" yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Donald William Ruth, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Jamaica, 89-60 164th Street, Jamaica, Queens.
LOS ANGELES, March 15 -- Sal Maglie put his arm and back muscles to a five-inning test today and met with only partial success.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -The Russians "have learned" to raise hell without spending money and we had better learn that too," Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican of Vermont, said today in a discussion of tax cutting and budget balancing on the National Broadcasting Company's "American Forum of the Air" televesion program.

ATLANTIC BEACH, L. I., March 15 -- Italo Conte, a Wall Street stock broker who was reportedly suffering from an incurable ailment, was found dead of illuminating gas today in his boarded-up summer residence here at 95 Clayton Avenue. He was 55 years old.

Yucca Flat, Nev., will be in the television camera's eye tomorrow, beginning at 8 A. M., Eastern Standard time, when "Operation Doorstep," the atomic explosion, is carried over nation-wide networks on A. B. C., C. B. S. and N. B. C.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 15 -- Columbia has transferred to the independent Warwick Productions its interest in "The Black Knight," based on the character of Lochinvar in Sir Walter Scott's poem, "Marmion."

A tubeless truck tire mounted on a one-piece, drop-center rim has been developed by the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, it was announced over the weekend by Raymond C. Firestone, vice president in charge of research and development.

Paul Nordorf and Richard Donovan were the composers represented on Saturday evening's Composers Forum concert at the McMillin Theatre. Mr. Nordorf's contributions were an excerpt from his "Lyric Sonata," played by Alice Smiley, violinist, and tea songs from his cycle. "The Path of Love," sung by Rawn Spearman tenor. Mr. Nordorf himself was the accompanying pianist in these works.

BONN, Germany, March 15 -- A group of German engineers sponsored by the Federal Government is scheduled to depart tomorrow for Cairo where discussions will be held with the Egyptian Government on contracts offered West Germany's heavy industry to improve the existing Aswan Dam and to construct new dams and power plants in the same region.

MOSCOW, March 15 -- Premier Georgi M. Malenkov today bid for peace between Russia and the United States and declared any and all "troublesome and unsolved questions may be resolved by peaceful negotiations."

" For the first time in the six-year history of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund there will be no new United States contribution to plan on," says an article in THE TIMES on March 11.
WASHINGTON, March 15--High diplomatic officials seemed favorably impressed, on the whole, by Premier Georgi M. Malenkov's speech to the Supreme Soviet in Moscow today.

MEMPHIS, March 15 (AP) -- None of the tornadoes that roared through sections of Tennessee, Arkansas and Mississippi yesterday came close to a population center. One man was killed. About seventeen persons were hurt. About twenty-five homes were destroyed

It is ironical that the one United Nations agency that has probably done the most to popularize the U. N.'s cause throughout the world with its humanitarian and constructive deeds must perennially fight for its pittance to exist. The U. N. International Children's Emergency Fund, known as UNICEF, is faced with terrible disaster unless the Government and people of this country do something about it at once.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- An English setter to whom main show laurels are almost routine, although he gets beaten now and then, added the National Capital Kennel Club event to his long list tonight.

Two important exhibitions of French art dominate this week's events in museums and galleries. On Friday, the Metropolitan Museum will show French drawings, masterpieces of five centuries. To supplement this loan show, a group of French prints from the museum collection will also be displayed.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx, a Democrat, announced yesterday his personal support of Mayor Impellitteri as a candidate for re-election next fall. At the same time he announced that he would seek re-election to his present office.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -- World cotton trade "should show some increase over the same months a year earlier" the rest of the current cotton season, the International Cotton Advisory Committee said today.

The National Petroleum Council comprises some 100 representatives of the oil industry appointed by the Secretary of the Interior to give him its expert opinion on what we have learned to call "offshore oil." Because of the dispute over state and federal offshore rights it is fair to infer that there must be much oil beneath the waters -- an inference borne out by the Council's recent report to the Secretary of the Interior.

" A ditch in a desert" is a common description of the Suez Canal. Sea and sand are so near a level that at some points the big ships that ride through the 100-mile-long waterway connecting the Red Sea and the Mediterranean look like a mirage, a cavalcade of monstrous camels passing over the dry land.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 15 (AP) -- Ralph Kiner was standing pat in his contract rhubarb with General Manager Branch Rickey of the Pirates today. He said he was "hurt and baffled" by Rickey's latest blast at him from the Pittsburgh camp in Havana.
Following is the text of a statement by Controller Lazarus Joseph analyzing Governor Dewey's tax program for solving New York City's fiscal crises:

It has been very gratifying to me to note the several important statements made recently by the Republican Administration regarding its intention to take a greater interest in the problems of Latin America than that of its Democratic predecessor.

More than an inch and a half of rain drenched the New York area yesterday and cut off electric power in Greenwich, Conn., throwing about 3,000 dwellings there into sudden darkness. Flights at La Guardia Airport were curbed for five hours and eager motorists who had spent some of sunny Saturday polishing their cars for a Sunday drive devoted most of the day to glowering out of their living room windows.

LYNCHBURG, Va., March 15 UP) -- A professor of religion at Yale University said today that Christianity was fundamental "to any concept of education which presumes to train people to understand who and what they are and what their society is and might become."
A hospital handyman confessed yesterday to the police that he had fatally shot a 28-year-old man and seriously wounded a 23-year-old woman outside a Staten Island bar Saturday night.

The Voice of America is not only "ineffective" in India but its materialistic and "so-called liberal" attitude is antipathetic to the "deep spirituality of the East," the Most Rev. Leonard Raymond, first native Roman Catholic Bishop of Allahabad, India, declared yesterday.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 15 (AP) -- Paul Goldsmith drove a Harley-Davidson to a new record today in the American Motorcycle Association 200-mile expert race which was marred by accidents in which two persons were killed and six injured.

Self-portraits by youngsters from Tasmania to Norway and from India to Mexico, expressing artistic opinions of themselves alongside snapshots, will go on display today for two weeks at Teachers College, Columbia University. They will then start on a nation-wide tour.

Prompt police action averted a melee yesterday afternoon as 100 Ukrainian anti-Communists stormed an East Side hall where a memorial service for Joseph Stalin was being held. Heavily outnumbered Communists were escorted to safety by the police as they left the building after the service was called off.

In the last forty years there have been striking advances in all fields -- communications, transportation, medicine, industry and agriculture. But, according to "High Adventure in Advertising," by William A. Thomson, change for the better was greatest in the field of newspaper advertising.
Coat dresses, like suits, are always in fashion. Combining the virtues of coat and dress, they are both trim and wearable.

ALBANY, March 15 -- Republican legislative leaders have told Governor Dewey they could obtain passage of a compulsory automobile inspection program if he would agree to allow licensed private garages to do the inspection work on an annual instead of a semi-annual basis.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 15 (AP) -- Baseball Commissioner Ford Frick and other high officials today told Bill Veeck and Lou Perini that they would have to follow the established rules if they wanted to shift the St. Louis Browns and Boston Braves franchises.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 15 (AP) -- A grim "dummy" picture of a happy family and some visiting neighbors about to be caught unaware by an atomic explosion was shown today as a preview of Tuesday's test here.

It was Benjamin Franklin who wrote that oft-repeated sentence: "Nothing is certain in this world but death and taxes." He penned this statement in a letter to a Mr. M. Leroy in 1789, but he was not referring to an income tax, but rather to poll taxes, taxes on land, imports and on a few articles of personal property.

The number of female alcoholics seems to be increasing in New York and the average age of drunkards is decreasing, according to Edward J. McGoldrick Jr., director of the Bureau of Alcoholic Therapy, which operates under the Department of Welfare of the city.

Gwendolyn Geddes a fresh-faced, intelligent soprano from British Columbia, gave her first New York recital Saturday night at Town Hall. It was a debut that was a credit to her country, her teachers and the young singer herself.

A new award for outstanding port service, set up several months ago by the Barnacles, an organization of men engaged in maritime and other transportation industries, has been given to Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., city Commissioner of Marine and Aviation.

WASHINGTON, March 15--Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio said today that the best way to handle the Voice of America, now under Senate investigation, would be for John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, to wipe it out and start all over again.
PRINCETON, N. J., March 15 -Alarm over the current political investigation of universities was expressed today by the Princeton chapter of the American Association of University Professors.
PRINCETON, N. J., March 15 -- Dr. Albert Einstein, the world's foremost physicist, gave his name today to the first medical school to be built in New York in more than half a century.

FRANCONIA, N. H., March 15 -- Sel Hannah, former Dartmouth captain, today carried off the first national seniors slalom and alpine combined ski championships with performances that recalled the Big Green star's supremacy in his intercollegiate days.

MIAMI, Fla., March 15 -- Casey Stengel's Yankees took the "rubber" game from the Dodgers today, 4 -- 1, before the season's largest crowd at Miami Stadium, 12,340. They did it easily, too, for the Brooks were unable to score until the eighth inning off Ewell Blackwell, the third Bomber pitcher.
