PARIS, March 15 -- Negotiators of the six-nation European Defense Community treaty are speculating on what the results may be if the West German Bundestag, or lower house of Parliament, ratifies the treaty before the interim committee now in session in Paris decides what to do with the proposed French protocols.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) The Committee for Economic Development today endorsed the Eisenhower Administration's plan to use so-called "indirect" controls to combat "the twin evils" of inflation and deflation.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public, which will mature within twelve months, amount to $75,875,421,149. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

Bill Cook's New York Rangers were plenty sharp last night, but not quite sharp enough to carve out a victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden. The Broadway Blues and the Leafs played a 1-1 tie.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- Senator J. William Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, said tonight that the educational exchange program that he fathered should be broadened ultimately to include American education for Russian and other Communists.

PARIS, March 15 -- The Ministers of Agriculture for sixteen European countries will meet tomorrow in the Palais de Chaillot to lay the foundations for a vast agricultural cooperative, which, it is hoped, will help to reduce the dependence of the European continent on food imports from the United States and thus will help Europe to save dollars.

Dr. Ernst Reuter, Mayor of West Berlin, said yesterday on his arrival here that many of the East German refugees pouring into West Berlin were in the economically most desirable age bracket of 20 to 45, one of many indications that even the sturdiest now wanted to leave the Soviet-controlled German Democratic Republic.

Among other national trends in travel, an increase of 7 per cent in hitchhiking was noted by the National Travelers Aid Association in 1952. Plane travel increased 15 per cent, but most travelers continued to ride trains, it was reported.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said today his Senate Government Operations Committee had asked Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, for a complete report on "irregularities" in finance and contract operations of the United States Army in Europe.

At this stage a vote of non-confidence in Japan's Premier Yoshida was not unexpected. Indeed, it was surprising that the elderly Premier was able to maintain his position for so long. The situation in Japan is not a peculiarly Japanese phenomenon in a political vacuum.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -The enforcement office of the Civil Aeronautics Board has started an investigation of alleged too-frequent-flight violations by a group of nonscheduled airlines and individuals it identified as "North American Combine."

Governor Dewey's four-point program for remedying the city's financial ills was criticized yesterday by Controller Lazarus Joseph as one designed to impose upon "the transit straphanger and the rent payer" the additional burden that real estate ought to bear to balance the city's 1953-54 budget.
BOGOTA, Colombia, March 15 (AP) -- Colombians voted quietly and with little apparent enthusiasm today in Congressional elections being boycotted by opposition Liberals and dissident Conservatives.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The latest study to guide defense officials on how best to prepare the United States for air attack proposes additional defense expenditures running to $20,000,000,000.
A new comedy by George Axelrod is scheduled for Broadway this fall as the first offering of the recently formed production firm of Courtney Burr and John Byram.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 15 -- Best in show in the thirtyseventh annual all-breed competition of the Providence County Kennel Club tonight went to an imported wire foxterrier, Ch. Arley Adorable of Harham, owned by Mrs. Harold Florsheim of Chicago, and handled by Tom Gately. The triumph was the third for the terrier that had taken five specialties and twelve terrier groups.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 15 -- Playing host to the United Nations has turned out to be a handsome paying proposition for the United States -- and especially for New York City.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey. Democrat of Minnesota, declared today that Secretary of State John Foster Dulles had said that the original version of the stalled resolution to condemn Soviet enslavement of free peoples "may not be sufifciently strong for purposes of Republican domestic politics."

Suppose you're making a good jag of money but have a number of dependents. They cost you a lot more than their $600 deductions. Have you ever thought of making them shareholders or partners in your business? Even with gift taxes, it's apt to cost you a lot less than it does now.
AUGUSTA, Ga., March 15 (AP) -- Although brisk winds sent scores climbing today, Patty Berg nevertheless captured her fifth women's titleholders golf tournament today with a record-breaking 294.

The annual festivities honoring this harbor as the greatest in the world -- Port of New York Day -will take place on Thursday and the observance is assuming gala proportions. Ships in the harbor will be decorated with strings of signal flags and will be joined by waterfront factories in the traditional noontime whistle salute to the port.

CHICAGO, March 15 -- An irregular price course marked grain futures last week, with wheat affected by a measure of drought relief in the Southwest, corn by expected larger Commodity Credit Corporation sales, and all cereals by the plane shooting incidents in Germany.

Factory operations in the men's clothing industry began to increase last August, recovering from the severe depression that started in May, 1951, according to Harry A. Cobrin, executive secretary of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A. From May, 1951, to the end of the slow period last July the industry operated at 66 per cent of capacity.

The collection of fashions presented at the Plaza Hotel yesterday by B. Weinstein, 7 East Fifty- seventh Street, included combinations of luxurious furs and timeless, elegant clothes. There were many examples of subtly contrasted furs and fabrics in soft, muted shades, while some ensembles were outstanding for color variations.

In the March 13 issue of THE TIMES it was reported that a bill designed to "purge the deadwood" from up-state voter registration rolls, in non-personal districts, passed the Assembly and Senate and was sent to the Governor on March 12.

The juiciest of income tax plums dropped lightly into the Internal Revenue Bureau's baskets here late yesterday to bring the day's yield for the Federal Government to an estimated $1,207,791,638, which is considered very good indeed for the first quarter of any year.

As the city's financial crisis deepened yesterday, the Board of Estimate held a two-hour executive session at City Hall and issued a 1,200-word statement attacking Governor Dewey's proposals for a city fiscal program as showing "a total disregard of the welfare of the great majority of our citizens."

Of interest for travelers were the packing hints and demonstration given by Miss Mary Gordon, travel adviser of Trans World Airlines, yesterday at Peck Peck's store, 677 Fifth Avenue. For illustration purposes, Miss Gordon used a wardrobe suitable for a month's vacation in Europe.

The $250,000,000 expansion program of the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company will require further financing early in 1954, Elmer L. Lindseth, president, told stockholders in the annual report issued yesterday.

Your timely editorial of March 14 entitled "A Public Trust" impels me to suggest that your advice about maintaining the integrity of federal agencies to insure resistance against "terrific pressures from various interests seeking special benefits at the expense of public welfare" should be extended to cover the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 16 -- An appeal by Roman Catholic and Jewish parents for a permanent injunction to prevent distribution of the King James version of the New Testament in the Rutherford public schools was denied here today in Superior Court by Judge J. Wallace Leyden.
DETROIT, March 16 (AP) -- Every automobile maker is talking of increased production for this year.

BONN, Germany, March 16 -- German steel workers and coal miners apparently are gaining victories in the political battle of Western Europe for West Germany while Governments and political parties wrangle over treaties, army divisions and military budgets.

Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga late yesterday reduced from $350,000 each to $200,000 each bail for John (Johnny Dee) Dalessio, and his brother Alexander (Pope Dee), both held as material witnesses in Special Prosecutor William B. Herlands' investigation of gambling and corruption in Richmond, S. I.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Mr. Wickard is expected to be succeeded by Ancher Nelsen, Lieutenant Governor of Minnesota. The shift is expected to presage a change in the Government's attitude toward the development of rural power and telephone facilities.

PHILADELPHIA, March 16 -- Ten national human relations agencies, all of which have their headquarters in New York City, tonight received the 1953 national awards of the Philadelphia Fellowship Commission.

CIDADE DE GOA, Portuguese India, March 11 -- With the assistance of Japanese mining interests, the Portuguese Government has embarked upon an integrated program for prospecting and developing this colony's rich mineral deposits, notably iron and manganese. Mechanization of a number of mines are in progress.

New overhead directional signs for the city's parkway system have been set up in Queens to sort out traffic more easily at major interchanges and bridge approaches. They are on Grand Central Parkway to the east of Cross Island Parkway, on Cross Island Parkway at the Whitestone Bridge approaches and on the southbound roadway of the Whitestone Bridge near the interchange with the Whitestone and Cross Island Parkways.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to order an immediate hearing by a special three-judge Federal tribunal of a case testing the validity of the Government's program to evict subversive from Federally-aided low-cost housing.

Members of the all-metropolitan first and second teams and John (Honey) Russell, Seton Hall coach, were honored at a luncheon of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association at Leone's Restaurant yesterday.

The prolonged struggle between private and public power in the Pacific Northwest appears to have been settled in favor of the private operators. Kinsey M. Robinson, president of the Washington Water Power Company, announced yesterday that directors of his company had approved the basic terms of a proposed merger between Washington Water Power and the Puget Sound Power and Light Company, as agreed upon between the managements of the two companies.

John A. Brullmann, suspended New York policeman, pleaded not guilty yesterday before Judge Robert A. Inch in the United States District Court, Brooklyn, to an indictment charging him with violating the Civil Rights Act. He was released in $1,000 bail for trial on May 4.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16 -- The proud earned run average of the Yankees' pitching staff was blasted to bits and sprayed to the verdant corners of Al Lang Field today as the Cincinnati Reds stopped the Bombers, 11 -- 2.
TOKYO, Tuesday, March 17 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,556, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M., Tuesday, Korean time:

ALBANY, March 16 -- To get a single cent of increased local taxing power to balance next year's expense budget, the City of New York will have to commit itself to complete elimination of the transit operating deficit, which is estimated at $50,000,000.

Passenger service to the Mediterranean will be augmented in May by the Italian liner Roma, it was announced here yesterday by Capt. Mario F. Vespa, North American representative for the Home Lines, general agent for the vessel.

WIESBADEN, Germany, March 16 (AP) -- The United States Air Force rushed some fast new Sabre jet fighters here from England today as an answer to Communist shooting attacks, which have brought down an American fighter plane and a British bomber.

TOPEKA, Kan., March 16 (AP) -- The Governor of Kansas said today he had approved the state's 1951 purchase of the building that resulted in an $11,000 fee for C. Wesley Roberts, now Chairman of the Republican National Committee.

The Internal Revenue Department has been requested by Harry W. Wolkstein, Newark certified public accountant, to reconsider a ruling approving immunity from Federal income taxation for a recent issue of 5 per cent convertible revenue bonds issued by the city of Florence, Ala., to finance construction of a building to be used by a private corporation for the manufacture of ceramic tile.

Members of the Government and Civic Employes Organizing Committee, C. I. O., set up a token picket line in front of City Hall yesterday in an effort to convince Mayor Impellitteri that city employes are entitled to a $900 across-the-board increase in the next fiscal year.
LOS ANGELES, March 16 -- It seems things never can run smoothly in spring training and today Max Lanier went slightly off the boam for the Giants.

After having refused to lend his name to any enterprise whatsoever, Dr. Albert Einstein consented on his seventy-fourth birthday to have Yeshiva University's medical school called the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Even if there is no closer relation between physics and medicine than is apparent, the association of Einstein's name with that of a great medical institution is fitting.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 16 -- Gian-Carlo Menotti's "The Consul" was presented tonight at the National Theatre by the Belgrade Opera Company, and received an enthusiastic ovation marked by more than a dozen curtain calls.
Ralph (Tiger) Jones, 152 3/4 pounds, Yonkers, fought to a ten-round draw with Danny Womber, 152, Chicago, before 3,000 fans at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn last night.

Several dinner parties will be given in advance of the preview tonight of the "Collectors Choice" exhibition in the galleries of Paul Rosenberg Co., 16 East Fifty- seventh Street. The preview is a benefit for the Public Education Association.

TAMPA, Fla., March 16 -- President Bill Veeck of the Browns, who sought permission from the American League to shift his franchise from St. Louis to Baltimore, failed today to obtain sufficient votes to make such a move at this time. For one year, at least, Veeck will have to continue at Sportsman's Park, where last season, with a club that finished seventh, the operation showed a deficit of $400,000.

CHICAGO, March 16 -- Production capacity of the domestic aluminum industry will rise to more than 3,000,000,000 pounds a year before the end of 1953 as a result of an expansion program which started after the outbreak of the Korean war, Edward S. Christiansen, president of the Industrial Smelting Corporation, Chicago Heights, Ill., estimated today.

Martin Block, conductor of the "Make-Believe Ballroom" disk jockey program over radio station WNEW, has been signed to a long-term contract by the American Broadcasting Company. Beginning Jan. 1, when it becomes effective, his record program will be presented over WABC, the network's local station, on Mondays through Fridays from 3:30 to 7 P. M.

CINCINNATI, March 16 (UP) -- The second strike in three days halted production today at the nation's largest jet engine plant, which turns out power units for Sabres, devastators of Soviet MIG's in Korea.

Contracts covering nearly 10,000,000 pounds of Brazilian coffee changed hands at record high prices yesterday in the first trading in coffee futures here in two weeks. Prices at the close ranged from 58 cents a pound for delivery of green coffee one year hence to 61.7 cents for delivery this month.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 16 -- There may be a brighter day just over the horizon for the movies as a result of various technical developments, but unemployment now is on the rise because of the anxiety the industry is experiencing while the many experiments await the test of public opinion.

ALBANY, March 26 -- The Assembly approved by a party vote tonight a resolution fixing the adjournment of the 1953 regular session of the Legislature at 5 P. M. on Friday. The resolution now goes to the Senate where action on it will be held up until it is determined whether more time will be needed for administration measures.

Aaron and Edith Flanzbaum have sold the gasoline service station and repair shod on a plot 100 by 100 feet at Centennial and Myrtle Avenues in Cranford, N. J., to Loomis J. Grossman, New York real estate operator. Ely Maran Son and Frederick Zittle Co. were the brokers.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 16 (AP) -- Ralph Kiner said today he hoped to join the Pirates in Havana no later than Thursday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Administration spokesmen recommended to Congress today early approval of President Eisenhower's plan to make the Federal Security Agency an executive department as a step toward greater efficiency and not necessarily toward large dollar savings.

It is time that the "Voice of America" be evaluated in a calm non-partisan manner, for there are sound reasons for doubting its efficacy as aim to our defense plans. In the first place even if the material for our propaganda by the "Voice" were well chosen, it does not reach the people we want to reach behind the Iron Curtain.

The United States Government now has about 75,000,000 pounds of butter in storage and is constantly buying additional quantities of butter in its efforts to bolster the price of that commodity. So Secretary of Agriculture Benson's testimony recently before a subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee revealed.
Favorable operating results for 1952 were reported yesterday by two textile manufacturing companies.

ST. LOUIS, March 16 (AP) -- Seven minority stockholders are going ahead with a receivership suit against the Browns, even though American League club owners have blocked Bill Veeck's move to transfer the club to Baltimore before the season opens.

ALBANY, March 16 -- A committee headed by Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore urged the Legislature tonight to sidetrack action begun at last year's session aimed at granting fiscal independence to school districts in five cities outside New York, among them Yonkers.

The New York Legislature has been in session since Jan. 7 and has accomplished almost nothing in the breaking of new ground. It is now in its final week, a week that will determine whether it goes down in the record as a do-little Legislature. Governor Dewey, over the past week-end, made an effort to salvage some hope or appearance of limited constructive action.

Arthur Schwartz and Alan Jay Lerner have reached an agreement with A1 Capp to make a musical of his popular cartoon, "Li'l Abner," for presentation on Broadway next season. The comic strip, begun eighteen years ago, is reported to be syndicated to nearly 700 newspapers.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 16 -- Jockey Charley Burr had the roses draped across his shoulders at the conclusion of the main event at the Gulfstream Park race course today. Assigned the job of riding Jay D. Weil's Streaking in the mile-and-a-sixteenth test called the Dunhill, Burr guided the 5-year-old gelding to victory over M. Kahlbaum's Conty Bay in a tingling finish.
The futures market closed barely steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, and final prices were 9 to 17 points lower than on last Friday.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 16 (AP) -- The hook-shot wizardry of Bob Houbregs and the all-around marksmanship of Sophomore Don Schlundt make Washington and Indiana favorites to win semi-final games tomorrow night in the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship.

NEW HAVEN, March 16 -- In another step aimed at resolving the bitter controversy over the location of an all-purpose expressway between West Haven and Greenwich, the Roads, Rivers and Bridges Committee of the Connecticut General Assembly held a series of "roadside" hearings today at scattered locations in New Haven and Fairfield Counties.

CHICAGO, March 16 (AP) -- Despite an anti-bowl bloc that includes Michigan State, Minnesota and Wisconsin, speculation grew today that the Western Conference would muster enough votes to carry the Rose Bowl renewal proposal.

Salvatore Sollazzo, 47-year-old jailed basketball fixer, was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan to two more years in prison and fined $12,000 for income tax evasion and for illegally acquiring large amounts of gold to be resold on the black market.
Clear blue skies and moderate westerly winds were forecast last night for the 80,000 sons and daughters of Erin who expect to march today in the St. Patrick's Day parade.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The American Psychiatric Association issued a statement today warning against state laws that licensed any profession other than the medical profession to treat mental ailments.

FRANCONIA, N. H., March 16 -- The unseasonable rains the past two days cut heavily into the cover of the "nose dive" descent and the result is the Eastern downhill-slalom championship ski races for men, to be combined with the nineteenth annual Hochgebirge Challenge Cup competition, will not take place here this week-end.

DETROIT, March 16 -- General Motors Corporation announced today that it would establish thirty-five centers across the country to provide practical service training for mechanics employed by G. M. dealers.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 16 -- The proposed tax on payrolls in New York City was denounced as "taxation without representation" today by the legislative committee of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors. Members said thousands of county residents commuting to jobs in New York would pay the levy without having a voice in the city's government or using the city's chief facilities.

CHICAGO, March 16 -- Directors of General Motors Corporation in 1945 generally were opposed to the idea of putting Gen. George C. Marshall, Army Chief of Staff in World War II, on the board of the big automobile agency, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., General Motors chairman, testified today at the du Pont anti-trust trial before Judge Walter J. LaBuy in Federal District Court.

A vacant plot about 712 by 982 feet on the east side of Unqua Road, about 1,899 feet south of Sunrise Highway, in Massapequa, L. I., has been sold by Nurman Raben and others to Oak Gardens Estates, Inc., for improvement with seventy dwellings.

A drive to permit manufacturers for the first time to fix minimum store prices on their products in Vermont is gathering momentum in the State Legislature. Frank Masterton reported yesterday. He is assistant to John Anderson, president of the American Fair Trade Council, which represents some 2,000 fair-trading manufacturers all over the country.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (UP) -- The Army will soon put six Army posts on a stand-by basis and reduce strength at seven others in a $40,000,000-a-year economy move. Representative Paul W. Shafer. Republican of Michigan, said today.
PHILADELPHIA, March 16 -- The National Catholic Family Life Conference called today for the "rejection of all divorce" and voiced its "unalterable stand" against the Planned Parenthood movement.

BATON ROUGE, La., March 16 (AP) -- A man-made material said to be far superior to natural rubber for tire treads was announced today by the Copolymer Corporation of Baton Rouge as a major contribution to the synthetic rubber industry.

BOSTON, March 16 (AP) -- Gov. Christian A. Herter, the Massachusetts Legislature, Boston Mayor John B. Hynes and the Chamber of Commerce teamed tonight to fight the planned transfer of the Boston Braves to Milwaukee.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 16 -- Dave Philley smacked perhaps the longest single of his career off Jim Hughes in the ninth inning today to give the Athletics a 2-1 victory over the Dodgers at Connie Mack Field.

VIENNA, March 16 -- Although three weeks have passed since the Austrian electorate rejected neo-nazism and communism to vote almost evenly for the People's and Socialist parties. Parliament will meet Wednesday with no government in being.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- A new department of Cabinet rank having full responsibility for the coordination and direction of psychological warfare, the Voice of America and other international informational and counter - propaganda programs of the Government, was recommended to a Senate Investigating subcommittee today by Lewis K. Gough, National Commander of the American Legion.
The following booklets, published recently, may be of interest to parents (40 cents each from Science Research Associates, 57 West Grand Avenue, Chicago 10):

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, chief of staff of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization army, said today that the growing strength of the Allies was such that it tended to discourage any warlike intentions of the Soviet Union.

Three hundreds years ago the city's first public works project was undertaken. It was on March 15, 1653, that three representatives of the burgomasters of Nieuw Amsterdam announced their readiness to accept bids for a "high stockade and small breastwork" for the defense of the city.
MOSCOW, March 16 -- Following is the text of the speech delivered by Premier Georgi M. Malenkov at yesterday's session of the Supreme Soviet:

LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 16 (UP) -- Two typical white frame homes have been erected near the bomb-topped detonation tower. House No. 1 is three-quarters of a mile from point zero. It was expected to disappear in the atomic blast. House No. 2 is a mile and a half away. It was expected to take quite a beating but probably will remain standing after the explosion.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Air Force officials said tonight that they believed unindentified aircraft, probably Russian, had made infrequent reconnaissance flights over Alaska and the northern parts of Canada.

The Lewyt Corporation, in an expansion move, has leased four floors containing 20,000 square feet at 84 Broadway, Brooklyn, adjacent to its factory at 60 Broadway. The lessee manufactures vacuum cleaners and precision electronic equipment.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Senator Knowland, referring to yesterday's speech by Mr. Malenkov, said today that if the Soviet Premier really believed that issues between the Communists and the Free World could be settled peacefully, the Reds should demonstrate their good faith by:

CHICAGO, March 16 -- The grain market had a reactionary tendency today, with not much inclination to follow rallies, although there was the usual absorption on setbacks. Weather news was no more bearish than it has been recently and dryness was the rule over the major winter and spring wheat areas. Export business was not much in evidence.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 16 -- The General Assembly's Political and Security Committee voted, 52 to 5, today to extend the life of the Collective Measures Committee till 1955. The committee was set up to devise counter-aggression methods to prevent future "Koreas."

One of the dishes served at the Duchess of Windsor's Ball, held earlier this winter at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel for the benefit of the hospitalized veterans' music service, was a so-called "crown of spaghetti with mushrooms." It was created with a bow to one of the four sponsors of the party, the Buitoni Foods Corporation, manufacturer of pasta.

Dedicated to seeking better living for 675,000 New Yorkers 65 years old and over, the Mayor's Advisory Committee for the Aged heard yesterday at its first 1953 meeting that 41 per cent of teachers and other city employes who have retired on pensions appear dissatisfied with retirement.

Stockings take on a new glamour this spring. The twelve-denier yarn is the big news in the hosiery field. Acclaimed the sheerest stocking ever made, it practically does a vanishing act on the leg. Although of the lightest texture, these stockings are as closely knit as the ones made of heavier thread.

The withdrawal from the Maryland Legislature of a bill that would permit night employment in bowling alleys of youths under 16 years old is encouraging, Mrs. Gertrude Zimand, executive secretary of the National Child Labor Committee, announced yesterday when word was received by the committee on the fate of the bill.
Simplified retail selling techniques, involving self-selection of merchandise by customers, are gaining among department stores, but merchants must beware of pitfalls in this new method of selling.

ANYONE who has ever made a pack trip in the Rockies or a canoe trip in the lakes of northern Ontario has wondered what would happen if his appendix burst. Those of us who live near doctors and hospitals and all the wonders of modern medical science are prone to think it would be impossible to get along without them. Yet most of mankind does and always has.
The statement of the Board of Estimate on Governor Dewey's proposed fiscal plans for the city follows:

LONDON, March 16 -- An increasing Soviet challenge to the naval supremacy of the Western powers was described in the House of Commons today by J. P. L. Thomas, First Lord of the Admiralty, the civilian chief of the Royal Navy.
Corey M. Allan has purchased Col. Roswell Doughty's home at 1001 Grove Street in the Rye Neck section of Mamaroneck. Peter C. Doern Jr., Inc., was broker in the sale.

BERLIN, March 16 -- Six refugees fled to West Berlin over the week-end in a 500-passenger excursion steamer, city officials announced today. In the past, fugitives from the Soviet Zone of Germany. have broken through police barriers on the border in trucks, buses and private cars.
Clay Township, Mich., School District No. 1 announced yesterday that it will receive bids April 2 on $1,300,000 of bonds dated April 1, 1953, and due July 1, 1954 to 1970.

CAIRO, March 16 -- It appeared tonight that the United States and Britain had made a joint proposal to Egypt hinging the evacuation of the Suez Canal zone by the British to some sort of mutual defense arrangement and that Egypt had turned thumbs down both on the presence of the United States as a third party to the negotiations and on making the evacuation conditional on the defense agreements.

The Mitsui Steamship Company, Ltd., of Tokyo, Japan's largest shipping company, operating a fleet of 125 ocean-going and coastal vessels, will start in May monthly trans-Atlantic cargo services from New York as part of an eastbound round-the-world freight run.

Four municipal college faculty members and two office clerks, who refused to answer questions put to them last month by a Senate investigating subcommitee about alleged membership in the Communist party, were dismissed last night by the Board of Higher Education.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 16 (AP) -- E. J. (Dutch) Harrison, who won the St. Petersburg open golf tournament yesterday with a record-equaling 266 for 72 holes, today carded a 34, 34 -- 68 to win individual honors in the La Gorce pro-member tournament. The victory was worth $500.

Strength in rail, steel, electrical equipment and amusement issues developed in the late hours of trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and the session ended firm, with gains mostly limited to small fractions.

The 1952 Stephen Wise Awards of the American Jewish Congress for outsanding leadership in the extension of civil rights in the United States have been won by former President Truman, Joset Sprinzak, Speaker of the Israeli Knesset (Parliament), and the late Dr. Hayim Greenberg, chairman of the department of culture and education of the Jewish agency for Palestine. Each carries a cash value of $1,000.

The ruling of the New York State Commission Against Discrimination with reference to "churches near by" is of particular interest and concern to the Travel Agents Committee to Combat Discrimination in the Travel Industry.

NEW DELHI, India, March 16 -- Officials of India and Pakistan began a conference here today in an attempt to resolve one of the controversial issues that has been hampering the free flow of trade between the two countries for the past year.

LOS ANGELES, March 16 -- When science and government have found a better way of working together, the nation will be better and stronger, Dr. Lee A. DuBridge, California Institute of Technology president, told members of the American Chemical Society tonight.
BONN, Germany, March 16 -- Political support for the Allied-German treaties solidified behind Chancellor Konrad Adenauer today.

A. frequency modulation radio station can transmit simultaneously two or three different programs or a single channel under a new transmission system announced yesterday by Dr. Edwin H. Armstrong, Professor of Electrical Engineering at Columbia University and inventor of FM radio.
In the old story an alchemist of surpassing wisdom perfected a substance so powerful no vessel could hold it without dissolving in a cloud of vapor.

A new note of sophistication was sounded in a children's wear spring collection presented to the press yesterday by Best Co. It was the use of the color gray. Unusual in children's wear, gray was featured and made fresh and gay throughout the show.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- A four-year controversy between the Department of the Interior and the Federal Power Commission over whether a private power company should be licensed to build a multimillion-dollar hydroelectric generating plant at Roanoke Rapids, N. C., was settled by the Supreme Court today in favor of the commission.

OTTAWA, March 16 (UP) -- The Canadian National Railways collected the highest operating revenues in its history last year -- $675,219,415 -- and recorded its first peacetime surplus since the boom year of 1928, the annual report showed today.

The need for new paper products with a wide range of uses, to lift the thin profits of the paper sales and distribution field, was the dominant theme yesterday at start of the fiftieth annual convention of the National Paper Association.

On record net sales of $314,228,747, the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., realized last year the second highest earnings in its history, totaling $58,891,282, John F. Thompson, chairman, and Paul D. Merica, president, reported in the annual statement mailed to stockholders yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 16 -- Representatives of the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and Nationalist China will meet Wednesday in what some delegates believe will be a showdown on whether they can agree on a successor to Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- President Eisenhower has instructed John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, to talk with Congressional leaders about the possibility of amending the McCarran-Walter Immigration and Nationality Act.

LONDON, March 16 -- The first statutory step to reinforce Britain's embargo on the export of strategic goods to Communist China was taken here today. It was a sequel to the British decision to tighten control on trade with China, announced after the recent talks of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden in Washington.

LONDON, March 16 -- A weakness ascribed mainly to the approaching end of the bookkeeping account was evident in most sections of the stock market here today. Losses, however, were small and relieved by gains in several selected issues.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The nomination of Leo A. Rover to be United States Attorney for the District of Columbia was sent to the Senate today by President Eisenhower. If confirmed, Mr. Rover, a Republican, will succeed Charles M. Irelan, a Democrat, who resigned a few days ago.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 16 -- The area of the Indo-China war never has been so extensive as now. Pending military events concern not only North Vietnam (Tonkin), but also Laos and Central Vietnam (Annam). The armed watch covers a territory as big as one-third of France.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Consolidation of the nation's two major independent air line associations was proposed today.

Debt management can make its greatest contribution to monetary stability under current conditions by working for a better balance in the maturity distribution of the Federal debt, by reducing the size and frequency of refinancing operations and by fitting the terms of Treasury borrowings to the needs of the economy and the conditions of the market place.
Several measures, some of them tentative, intended to conserve military manpower or to make better use of it, have been instituted by the services in recent months.

ST. LOUIS, March 16 (AP) -- A surprised, jubilant St. Louis -- from the Mayor to the little guy who sits in the bleachers -- today welcomed the news that the St. Louis Browns are still the St. Louis Browns.

PARIS, March 16 (AP) -- The Ministers of sixteen West European nations voted today to admit Spain to their deliberations on a proposed "green" pool, an agricultural program similar to the European community plan for coal and steel.

HARTFORD, March 16 -- The Connecticut General Assembly may increase the state's cigarette tax from 3 to 4 cents a pack to help achieve a balanced budget for the biennium starting on July 1. Some $42,000,000 in additional taxes must be raised to balance the $275,000,000 budget submitted by Gov. John Davis Lodge.

LONDON, March 16 -- President Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia, the only head of a Communist state free from Soviet domination, told the people of Britain today that they should regard the Yugoslavs "as their stanch allies" because "the people of the new Yugoslavia are striving toward the same ends" as the British.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16 (AP) -- The defending champion, Caribbee, took a fifteen-mile lead tonight in the St. Petersburg-to-Havana yacht race, and with stronger and more favorable winds springing up may reach Havana before daylight.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Top United States officials said today they would study "with great interest and sympathy" any new proposals calling for the United States to increase military aid to the Indo-Chinese forces battling the Vietminh.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 14 -- Yugoslav trade union leaders are renewing their efforts to win friends abroad and gain membership in the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions. Last year's efforts by the Yugoslav trade unions to get into the I. C. F. T. U. was thwarted by the report of the organization's secretary-general, J. H. Oldenbroek, who denounced them at the confederation's executive board meeting in Berlin.

The nation's steelmakers established another new production record last week, turning out 2,284,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings by operating at an average of 101.3 per cent of rated capacity, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The previous record of 2,262,000 tons was set the week before.

Donal F. Collins, who came over from Killarney to represent the Irish in the annual St. Patrick's Day parade here today, dropped in at the Red Cross blood donor center at 70 West Fortieth Street yesterday to contribute a pint of County Kerry blood as a "goodwill gesture"
LONDON, March 16 -- Reports from Cairo on the recent meetings between Premier Naguib and the British and United States Ambassadors were being studied in London as in Washington today.

TAMPA, Fla., March 16 -- It was as untidy a moving job as you ever did see. The clothes were hanging out of suitcases and the crockery was under the piano on the van. Everywhere there was evidence of disorderly haste. So the law stepped in to order Bill Veeck to unpack his belongings and remain where he was for another year at least as the reluctant tenant-owner of Sportsman's Park in St. Louis.

Two shareholders of Foster Wheeler Corporation, maker of steam plant and oil refinery equipment, moved yesterday to inquire into its possible absorption by General Dynamics Corporation, ship and boat builder, which was said to own 53,600 shares of Foster Wheeler stock as of the end of last year.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 16 -- High officials in the United States Armed Forces are said to be becoming seriously concerned over the persistent trickle of criticism in the mass-circulation European press against Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander here.

GENEVA, March 16 -- The United States charged today that the Secretariat of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe was being unduly pessimistic about developments in the West and unduly optimistic about developments in the Communist economies.

Since the publication by Harper in February of Capt. J. Y. Cousteau's "The Silent World," two other concerns have scheduled books about undersea adventures. They are "The Undersea Adventure," by Philippe Diole (Julian Messner), and "At the Bottom of the Sea," by Otis Barton (Crowell).
WEST POINT, N. Y., March 16 -- The Corps of Cadets of the United States Military Academy marked the 151st anniversary of the founding of the academy at a special mess tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Senator William F. Knowland of California, a member of the Senate's Republican leadership, called on the Eisenhower Administration today to move in the United Nations to denounce the Russians as aggressors in Korea, notwithstanding the "risks involved."

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., March 16 -- A lot of water has gone over the Cornell Dam here since last Thursday's heavy rainfall. Two and a half billion gallons raced over the spillway today into the swollen Croton River 130 feet below. From there it rushed three miles westward to the Hudson River.

Sales of fox furs, which have been poor several years, are increasing and may be stepped up further as a result of promotional efforts by the American Fox Breeders Association. According to the Fur Trade Review, the breeders have been trying to meet the strong competition of mink and are also bringing out new models designed to make fox furs more attractive and competitive in style.

CHICAGO, March 16 -- Prospects indicate that the General Motors Corporation's sales this year will approximate $9,000,000,000, Harlow H. Curtice, president, said here today. About 20 per cent of these sales will be defense items.

PARIS, March 16 -- While Washington dispatches conspicuously displayed in the French press report growing impatience in the United States with the slow progress of the European army treaty, French officials hope that agreement on some of the proposed French protocols to the treaty may be attained a few hours before the departure of Rene Mayer, Premier, and Georges Bidault, Foreign Minister, for Washington Tuesday.

Administrative changes intended to increase the usefulness of the city's new Riverside Hospital for youthful narcotic offenders were recommended here yesterday by the twelve-member Inter-Organizational Council on Youthful Narcotic Addiction.
TAMPA, Fla., March 16 (AP) -- Commenting on the meeting, Harridge said:

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The State Department said today the United States Government had received "with interest" the address of Premier Georgi M. Malenkov in Moscow yesterday. However, a spokesman let it be known that the new Soviet leader's words about Russia's "peaceful intent" would have to be backed up by action for peace in Korea and other world trouble spots before they could be fully accepted here.

The nation's 396 leading securities underwriters have a combined capital worth of $617,700,000, an increase of about 6 per cent over the total for a like aggregate of banking firms at the end of 1951 according to a survey published in the current issue of Finance magazine.

The best-laid plans oft go awry, it has been said, and the difficulties so encountered are compounded when one is far from home and the helping hands of relatives and friends. Last year the vast majority of the 2,377,670 persons who sought help from the Travelers Aid Society found themselves away from home with seemingly unsurmountable problems.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 16 -- An explosion of a nuclear device at Yucca Flat of the Nevada proving grounds about eighty miles from here at 5:20 tomorrow morning (8:20 o'clock, New York time) will be the first public demonstration of a prototype of the tactical atomic bomb that may be used to annihilate armies of a would-be aggressor before they had succeeded in crossing the border of their intended enemy.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Supreme Court ruled, 5 to 4, today that an alien barred from this country could be held indefinitely on Ellis Island, then in a 7-to-2 opinion, the tribunal decided that a habeas corpus action was the only method by which an alien could challenge a deportation order in the courts.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- One of the basic American freedoms, asserted in the Bill of Rights and the Fourteenth Amendment, that has lapsed in many parts of the United States by the failure of government to protect it since the union-labor movement became dominant in Democratic party politics, was reaffirmed today by the Supreme Court -- this time by eight of the nine members.

Dr. Ernst Reuter, Mayor of West Berlin, was received by Mayor Impellitteri at City Hall yesterday and gave his promise that his countrymen in his beleaguered section of the former German capital would defend their liberties to the end.
Senator Charles W. Tobey of New Hampshire, a Republican proposed Kings County Judge Samuel Leibowitz, a Democrat, last night for Mayor of New York.

The fantastically surging interest of the man of the house in doing his own chore today is both documented and demonstrated in a show that opened yesterday at noon at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- The man charged with wiping out overlapping supply systems in the armed services told Congress today he was making substantial progress but indicated it would take time to eliminate some duplication.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- President Eisenhower has formally accepted the resignation of David L. Cole of Paterson, N. J., as director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan warned the members of the police force yesterday against "every form of brutality." Noting that policemen were subject to the laws of the land, he declared he would not tolerate assaults on prisoners.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., March 16 -- James A. Hard, the nation's oldest war veteran, was buried here today under overcast skies punctuated by the staccato volley of an honor guard and the strains of "Taps." The flag-draped coffin of the 111-year-old Grand Army of the Republic member was lowered into its Mount Hope Cemetery grave in the waning hours of the afternoon.
LONDON, March 17 -- The Royal Air Force's Bomber Command began today a six-day exercise in skies over Western Europe in which every one of its squadrons will take part.

ALBANY, March 16 -- Louis Hollander, state president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, tonight condemned three of Governor Dewey's proposals for rescuing New York City from its financial dilemma.

PARIS, March 16 -- The Chief Rabbi of France, Jacob Kaplan, said today in an interview in the newspaper Le Figaro that the French rabbinate and officials of the Roman Catholic Church have been seeking a solution for the controversy over two missing Jewish war orphans, Robert and Gerald Finaly.
The United Nations is considering means to end discrimination in marine insurance by which countries require their citizens to buy insurance at home at the expense of older foreign concerns.

The defense rested yesterday in the $3,600,000 damage suit brought against the Pan American Airways as a result of the crash of its Yankee Clipper near Lisbon, Portugal, ten years ago. The last witness was Capt. Robert O. D. Sullivan, pilot of the plane, who told his story to Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer and a jury.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 17 -- Troops of the United States Second Infantry Division fought a grim hand-to-hand engagement in their own trenches early this morning with Chinese attackers, who struck shortly after midnight in western Korea.

A banking syndicate headed by Johnston, Lemon Co. will place on the market today 229,880 shares of common stock of Hot Shoppes Inc., a food and restaurant chain doing business in nine states and the District of Columbia. The shares are priced at $10.25 a share.

RYE, N. Y., March 16 -- Taft School, Housatonic Valley League champion, defeated the Westchester Interscholastic Hockey League All-Stars, 7 to 3, before 1,000 spectators at Playland Casino tonight for its fourteenth victory of the season.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, March 4 -- One of the most dramatic triumphs in the brief history of the antibiotic medicines is to be found here in Haiti where the widely prevalent and dreadful disease of yaws is well on the way to elimination.

The plane incidents have provided a field day for guessers, as did the death of Stalin. Trigger-happy pilots, testing our will and readiness to fight, Malenkov's uncertainty over his own security -- these are some of the more unlikely answers. The logical explanation may lie in a combination of two reasons:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 16 -- Mrs. Lorena B. Hahn, leading off a discussion on the effect of marriage on women's nationality, told the eighteen-member United Nations Commission on the Status of Women today that the United States had repeatedly expressed its interest in the establishment of equality for women in the field of nationality.

EVEN the woodchuck was deceived by the balmy day that was wedged between the downpours, although it may be some of these varmints were flooded out of their burrows, for while covering a half-dozen miles of Connecticut country lanes, we spotted nine of the hungry 'chucks, foraging for the first green shoots of spring.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, March 17 (AP) -- Three artillery shells fired by Chinese Communists exploded today on a hill from which Adlai E. Stevenson watched United States Second Division troops in action on the western front in Korea.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that a state could prohibit peaceful picketing when the purpose of the picketing conflicted with the state's law banning all forms of the closed shop.

This is a good morning on which to extend greetings to Melospiza melodia, without whose cheerful attentions spring would not be spring. Melospiza melodia has been around for several weeks now, starting to work about dawn no matter whether the day be glowering or bright. Even his friends and admirers would not say that he is a great singer.
BALTIMORE, March 16 (AP) -- Dazed and groping for words to express their bitter disappointment over the flop of the Browns deal, Baltimoreans today hurled accusations of a "double cross."

Dick McGuire, out of action for six games because of a foot injury, will be in the starting line-up tonight when the Knickerbockers play the Baltimore Bullets in the opener of the National Basketball Association play-offs at Madison Square Garden. The game starts at 9.
CHICAGO, March 16 -- Confusion marked a double session of Probate Court in the Cook County building today as two downstate judges held court simultaneously.

The most charitable construction that can be put on Senator Taft's remarks about the Voice of America in a hurried television interview is that they were offhand and ill-considered. His suggestion that if he were in charge he would wipe out the Voice by firing everybody in it and then begin all over again from scratch to construct a foreign propaganda organization hardly represents the best thought on the subject.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 16 -- Joseph Kolodny of New York, managing director of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors, said here today that the nation's small independent retailers were enjoying their soundest economic position in more than twenty years, with sales increases of 459 per cent since 1931.

The leasehold ownership of the fifteen-story and penthouse store and office building at 711 Fifth Avenue has been acquired by Webb Knapp, Inc., through the purchase of a majority of the outstanding stock in the owning corporation. The building is on a plot owned by the Langdon estate at the northeast corner of Fifty-fifth Street.

FLORENCE, Italy, March 16 -- Four "enemy" air strikes at Italian cities and air bases were successfully intercepted by twenty-two sorties of "defending" aircraft on the first day of Exercise New Moon, which, from today to the twenty-fourth of this month, will test the effectiveness of the Allied Air Forces of Southern Europe under the command of Lieut. Gen. David M. Schlatter of the United States Air Force.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, declared today that the Pentagon was "trying to pass the buck to Congress" in a dispute over whether enough money was supplied to keep this nation's forces in Korea well stocked with ammunition.

Jacobo Bolbochan and Julio Bolbochan, two brothers from Argentina, were victors in the first round of the international chess masters tournament at Mar Del Plata, according to a report from Buenos Aires yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Claude R. Wickard, head of the Rural Electrification Administration, was forced to resign today as the Eisenhower Administration continued its efforts to force Democrats out of policy-making positions.

TRENTON, March 16 -- The New Jersey Legislature reconvened today after a four-week recess and immediately Plunged into the task of disposing of nearly 1,000 bills received since January. At the top of its agenda were two appropriations bills totaling $220,795,368, which were introduced in the Senate shortly before it adjourned at 5:15 P. M.

A five-acre tract on Engel Street in Hicksville, L. I., has been sold by Geer Brothers to the Supreme Sunrise Food Exchange in a transaction negotiated by Cushman Wakefield, Inc., as broker. The new owner plans to improve the parcel with a warehouse, distribution center and main offices, for which ground will be broken today.

Operating revenues of the Kennecott Copper Corporation in 1952 were the largest in its thirty-eight-year history, but its consolidated net income declined to $86,150,718 from $91,347,153 the year before as a result of higher costs.

Attractively displayed as if on European kiosks and streets, forty posters by four well-known European designers were put on public view yesterday in the auditorium gallery of the Museum of Modern Art. The artists are Raymond Savignac of France, Abram Games of Britain, Max Bill of Switzerland and Otto Aicher of Germany.

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 17 -- The Bergen County special grand jury heard nine more witnesses today in connection with gambling activities in the borough of Cliffside Park. No indictments were handed up, but Deputy Attorney General Albert M. Ash,

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 17 -- Israel, which during the first four years of her existence enjoyed almost full employment in spite of massive immigration, is now confronted with an army of 24,000 unemployed. The Government has restricted public works and private business is in a decline.

LONDON, March 17 -- Although Britain has recognized the Chinese Communist Government, Anthony Eden declared today that so long as he was Foreign Secretary of this country he would not be prepared to advocate that the United Nations admit "a Government that is in full aggression against the United Nations and shooting down our troops."

PHILADELPHIA, March 17 -- Establishment in this country of a "family allowance" system, to be financed and administered by the Federal Government, was advocated here today at the twenty-first annual convention of the National Catholic Family Life Conference.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 17 -- The Dodgers scored a tenth-inning, 11-10 victory over the Senators today before 6,500 fans, the largest crowd in Tinker Field history. However, the pre-game revelation that Jackie Robinson would become the Brooklyn third baseman probably overshadowed the contest in the interest of Dodger fans.

The city should take a lesson from the self-help efforts of Puerto Rico and "get an 'Operation Bootstrap' going in New York among the Puerto Rican people here," the Board of Superintendents of the city school system was told yesterday at its weekly meeting at 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 17 -For the first time this spring, the Yankees lost two straight, bowing to the Braves, 5 -- 2, before 3,248 fans today. The Bombers ran into Warren Cpahn and Johnny Antonelli when the two were enjoying one of their better days of the training campaign, and the world champions were handcuffed with four hits in eight innings, each hurler yielding two blows.

Oliver Colbentson, violinist, and Robert Schrade, pianist, appeared in joint recital at Town last evening, playing a program made up of French music. Works heard ranged from the A Major Sonata of LeClair (1697-1764) to the unaccompanied Violin Sonata in D Minor of the contemporary Arthur Honegger.

With April approaching, this is the silly season, as evidenced by the statement of the Controller of the City of New York reported in THE TIMES of March 16. The Controller seems to forget that most of the residents of our city are tenants and straphangers. The additional millions claimed to be needed by the city must come, in the final analysis, from the people at large.
Patrolman Thomas McNoble of the Bath Beach precinct in Brooklyn yesterday missed his first St. Patrick's Day parade in twenty years because of an encounter with an apparently rabid dog.

HONG KONG, March 17 -- Foreign banks in Shanghai, following the example of Chinese banks, have published notices advising persons who had "pre-liberation accounts" with them to register for repayment of outstanding balances.

Statistics related to the volume of new public financing since 1935 in themselves disprove the Government charge that seventeen major investment banking houses conspired to an industrial monopoly, defense counsel in the investment banking anti-trust trial declared yesterday as the defense began the presentation of its case.

The stock market advanced yesterday with all the enthusiasm of the Irish on parade. The highs of the day sent all three of THE NEW YORK TIMES averages to their best levels in more than seven weeks. Railroad issues spurred the advance, and steel, motor and chemical shares carried the rest of the list forward.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- Merger of the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois into Commonwealth Edison Company, formally unifying one of the country's largest and fastest growing utility systems, was voted by stockholders of the two companies' at brief special meetings today.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Let the botanists dispute. President Eisenhower believes there is such a thing as a shamrock.

HAVANA, March 17 -- Caribbee, the fifty-seven foot yawl owned by Carleton Mitchell of the Annapolis Yacht Club, was first across the finish line off Morro Castle today in the twentieth annual St. Petersburg to Havana yacht race. Caribbee had an elapsed trine of 72 hours 49 minutes 22 seconds.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Department of Justice defended today the indictment of Prof. Owen Lattimore for perjury and asked the Federal District Court not to dismiss the case.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -Henry W. (the Dutchman) Grunewald pleaded guilty today to a charge of contempt of Congress and received a chance to lighten his sentence.

REGINA, March 17 (AP) -- Saskatchewan has decided to export her natural gas but only on a "Province first" basis. Announcement of a gas export policy was made in the Legislature by Resources Minister J. H. Brockelbank. The policy follows the same general pattern as that laid down in the House of Commons last Friday by Trade Minister Clarence D. Howe.

The motor passenger-cargo liner Guadalupe, the first of two sister-ships now being completed for the Spanish Line, has just completed her sea trials in the Bay of Biscay and will leave from Bilbao, Spain, on March 28 on her maiden trans-Atlantic voyage.

The Long Island Transit Authority called on the Public Service Commission yesterday to start proceedings against William Wyer, trustee of the Long Island Rail Road, to compel him to rehabilitate the bankrupt road immediately.

As the Board of Estimate and City Council prepared to take up in detail today Governor Dewey's program for helping the city out of its financial troubles, Rudolph Halley, City Council President, charged yesterday that the city government had six basic defects that made "government by crisis" inevitable.
Events tonight: "La Traviata," Metropolitan Opera, 8:30 o'clock; Anatole Kitain, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Mannes Orchestra, Carl Bamberger conducting, Ruth Watson, pianist, Mannes School 8:30.

Twice a year Macy's sends its stylists to scour European fashion centers and bring back models illustrating the most important trends, then set about copying the designs to offer line-for-line adaptations at the store's own prices.
YUCCA FLAT, Nev., March 17 -About 1,500 troops and observers crouched head down in five-foot trenches at dawn this morning -closer to an atomic blast than any Americans had been before.

The current trend in world shipbuilding, particularly in the tanker field, is toward large and deep draft ships, a Federal report said yesterday. It added that super-bulk carriers with a draft of forty feet or more would now be on the ways if it were not for the limiting depths of harbors and channels.

TAMPA, Fla., March 17 (UP) -Bruce Dudley, American Association president, agreed today that his league eventually should be merged with the International League. But he disagreed with the International League president, Frank Shaughnessy, as to when.

A little more than four hours before the time set for her husband's funeral, Mrs. Ruth Harris Yaeger, 50 years old, escaped the watchfulness of a nurse and jumped to her death early yesterday morning from her sixth-floor apartment at 19 East Eightieth Street, the police reported.
Sulphur, the yellow mineral used in many consumer and industrial products, is to be raised in price to slightly more than a penny a pound, leaving it still one of the cheapest of all raw materials.

PARIS, March 17 -- The French-Saar talks for a revision of the agreement linking the Saar economically with France moved nearer to solution today when the French National Assembly approved a bill revoking the confiscation of property in the Saar after World War II.
The smartest proposal that I have heard for a long time is Dewey's suggestion that a city manager form of business government be set up for New York City.
Edward Hintz, 8 1/2-year-old son of Anthony Hintz, boss stevedore, who was murdered six years ago, disappeared yesterday from the street in front of his home, the police reported.

Three buildings occupying a site that forms an "L" around the southwest corner of Second Avenge and Forty-fifth Street passed to new control when the 833 Second Avenue Corporation sold 833-835 Second Avenue and 244 East Forty-fifth Street to an investing client of Joseph Engel, attorney.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (UP) -- Sinclair Weeks, the Secretary of Commerce, has informed Senator Joseph R. McCarthy that foreign shippers who bought surplus United States ships could use them to trade with Communist countries whether this nation liked it or not.

YUCCA FLAT, Nev., March 17 (AP) -- Quick inspection was possible of only about ten of the fifty-nine dealer-donated automobiles subjected to the blast because of the extremely high radioactivity of the vehicles nearest the blast, said J. Slayton Jenner, project officer for the Federal Civil Defense Administration.

President Eisenhower has accepted the resignation of David L. Cole as Director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, to become effective when a successor is found. As an interim appointee of President Truman Mr. Cole served creditably for six months.

NEW DELHI, India, March 17 (AP) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today India would regard as an unfriendly action any use by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization of French and Portuguese possessions in India as military bases.

Pakistan's sixth budget has just been presented. For reasons that should be understood it is less favorable in some respects than most of its predecessors. Revenues for the coming fiscal year have been estimated at a lower level than those of the current year, and it has been necessary to increase some taxes, both excise and import, and to restore some of the cuts that had previously been made.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The United States and Belgium reaffirmed today, their joint concern for the early ratification of the European Defense Community treaty and formation of the six-nation Europe army.

A capsule wardrobe for an American woman attending the Coronation this June was included in a "Coronation Clinic" held yesterday at the English Speaking Union, 19 East Fifty-fourth Street. Designed by Bonnie Cashin, the wardrobe was composed of separates that would not take too much of the weight of forty-four pounds allotted for air travel.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Eisenhower Administration's first specific recommendation for reduction of the Truman budget was given to Congress behind closed doors today. Members present later reported that it entailed cuts of about 15 per cent in funds earmarked for the Commerce Department.

Underwriting syndicates will place on the market today new issues of public utility and industrial securities valued at more than $45,000,000. Among the offerings are common stock of a public utility, oil company debentures and common stock and convertible preferred shares of a manufacturer for the electronics industry.

LONDON, March 17 -- The Presbyterian Established Church of Scotland will participate for the first time in a British coronation in June when Queen Elizabeth II is crowned, Dr. Geoffrey Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury, disclosed today.

The Knickerbockers maintained their mastery over the Baltimore Bullets this season by taking the opening game of their National Basketball Association play-off series, 80 -- 62, before a crowd of 2,340 at Madison Square Garden last night.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (UP) -- The Army said today it would close six installations June 1 at a saving of $6,000,000 a year.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 17 (AP) -- Pete Cooper, who was brought up in Florida but now plays out of White Plains, N. Y., took a 2-stroke lead in the professional division of the Seminole Golf Club's pro-amateur tournament today with 6 under par 66.

BERLIN, March 17 -- Another in a series of bizarre defections from the East occurred here today when a carnival owner escaped from the Soviet sector of Berlin with his entire menage, including a merry-go-round.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The belief of Yugoslav miners that their union has been admitted finally to the International Mineworkers Federation is not well-founded, in the opinion of certain informed trade union officials here.

LONDON, March 17 -- Without giving his reasons, Prime Minister Churchill publicly rejected today Communist Hungary's offer to exchange Edgar Sanders, an imprisoned Briton, for Lee Meng, a convicted Chinese woman terrorist serving a life sentence in Malaya.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 17 (AP) -- Thomas C. Robbins, Larchmont Acres, N. Y., medalist in the American Seniors' Golf Association tournament for amateurs aged 55 and above, won his first-round match today from George Hardy, Evanston, Ill., 1 up.

During recent years the United States has made great progress in securing equal educational opportunities for American children. But in one respect very little has been done. That is in the field of education for children of Americans who work abroad. Some of these Americans serve their own Government, while others work for international organizations, such as the United Nations and its agencies.

TAIPEI, Formosa, March 17 -- The United States Military Assistance Advisory Group to Nationalist China disclosed today greatly accelerated deliveries of fighter planes and artillery ammunition and a stepped-up training program for Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's airmen and army officers.

The United States Steel Corporation in its annual report mailed to stockholders yesterday declared that governmental policies have removed incentive for creating any increase in real income. "Such denial of the profit incentive must sooner or alter undermine the nation's productive power," the corporation warned.

ALBANY, March 17 -- Republican legislative leaders received assurances today of enough votes to pass all of the administration's New York City fiscal program measures as a result of separate Senate and Assembly party conferences.

ALBANY, March 17 -- The Senate Codes Committee reported out tonight for floor action three highly controversial bills aimed at curbing the financial participation of labor unions in political campaigns.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, announced today the appointment of four women to the executive staff.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized the Central Railroad Company of New Jersey today to issue $2,460,000 of equipment trust certificates in connection with equipment purchases.

LOS ANGELES, March 17 -- Within ten years infantile paralysis will have been wiped out by vaccination just as smallpox has been, Dr. W. M. Stanley, Nobel Prize-winning scientist of the University of California, said here today.

The 15-per cent rent increase now proposed is a policy of indiscriminate giving by our legislators, who seem woefully uninformed as to conditions. Landlords who have reduced to a skeleton force the maintenance of their buildings are now to be rewarded along with the landlord who has kept some semblance of order.

At 2:45 P. M. yesterday afternoon Inspector Patrick Kirley of the New York Police Department, whose origin is County Offaly, Ireland, announced that 1,820,000 men, women and children were watching the grandest St. Patrick's Day parade in the city's long and distinguished history.

An American edition of a French journalist's portrait of America, as translated by Fletcher Pratt, will be issued April 20 by Twayne, entitled "The Great American Parade." The author is H. J. Duteil, who lived in America from 1941 to 1948. He presents his opinions

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- John Foster Dulles. Secretary of State, now has reached the point where he must choose between defying the McCarthy-McCarran-Bridges axis in the Senate or losing the confidence of the men who work for him in the Foreign Service and the State Department.

The success of the new Administration's foreign policy, which endeavors to close the dollar gap in import and export trade, depends on cooperation of American business on broad general lines, Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican of Manhattan, asserted yesterday.

A new series of television drama productions, using the talent of various actors, producers, directors and writer, will make its debut over the American Broadcasting Company network on Sunday, April 12, 7:30 to 8 P. M., under the title of "A. B. C. Album."

Attendance records were established at the American Toy Fair, which completes its ten-day run today at the New Yorker and MoAlpin Hotels and at the International Toy Exhibit, which completed its five-day run at the Governor Clinton Hotel last week.

PASADENA, Calif., March 17 -- Replying to criticism of the Ford Foundation voiced by Mr. Jackson, H. Rowan Gaither Jr., president of the foundation, late today sent a telegram to Mr. Jackson that said in part:

The percentage of exported West German goods stolen in transit through the Russian zone is infinitesimal compared to the theft loss percentage on New York docks, Dr. Ernst Reuter, Mayor of West Berlin, said here yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 17 -- A discussion in the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women disclosed divergent points of view today on the advisability of an attempt to draft a convention on the nationality of married women.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 17--The Soviet Union carefully dropped word today that it would accept Mme. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit or Sir Benegal N. Rau--both prominent Indian diplomats--as Secretary General of the United Nations.

Johnny Bratton of Chicago, welterweight contender, is so anxious to meet the champion, Kid Gavilan, in a title fight that he is willing to donate his entire purse resulting from such a contest to the Damon Runyon Cancer Fund.

The Actors Equity Council, the union's governing board, yesterday suspended Jenny Hecht, 9-year-old daughter of the celebrated writer, Ben Hecht, who was applauded for her performance in the Vina Delmar, play, "Mid-Summer," which marked her first Broadway appearance.

Corp. Serafin Agostini of Clifton, N. J., a student at the Army Signal Corps School at Fort Monmonth, N. J., was the 10,000th contributor to the Red Cross blood bank at that post since the visit of the first bloodmobile in July, 1951. His contribution yesterday brought the total for the day to 322 pints. For the two-day visit of the bloodmobile from Red Cross headquarters the aggregate was 578 pints.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 17 -- Bill Veeck sat on a chair with his back against the wall. There almost was something symbolic about that back-against-the-wall position. His eyes bore a dazed, unbelieving look as reporters clustered around him. Here was a fighter who had been boxing the ears off his opponents for fourteen rounds and then had unexpectedly caught a looping swing flush on the chin for a knockout in the very last round.

PARIS, March 17 -- Baron Guy de Rothschild, head of the French branch of the international banking house and lay leader of the Jewish community in France, today compared the case of the two missing Jewish war orphans to the Dreyfus case that tore France apart around the beginning of the century and blamed the French Roman Catholic Church for the children's disapperance.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The House of Representatives was urged today by a member of its Committee on Un-American Activities to bring to a prompt voting showdown a pending resolution seeking to dismiss Representative Harold H. Velde, Republican of Illinois, from the chairmanship of that investigating panel.

There is an old adage in Wall Street that stocks must always react to earnings, but that apparently doesn't apply to the New York Stock Exchange. Yesterday the Exchange disclosed that its profits in 1952 had slipped 52 per cent to $157,012, from $326,982 in 1951.
LONDON, March 17 (AP) -- Randy Turpin, leading middleweight contender, defeated Walter Cartier of New York tonight on a disqualification in the second round of their scheduled ten-round fight.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 17 -- Joan Crawford will be back under the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer banner in "Why Should I Cry?" with Michael Wilding as her leading man.

LONDON, March 17 (Reuters) -- Britain will make a second protest to the United States soon against new security restrictions on British sailors in United States ports, informed quarters here said today.

Speakers at a housing panel forum to be held by the Real Estate Square Club of New York at the New Yorker Hotel tomorrow will include Herman Cohen, counsel of the State of New York Division of Housing, who will represent Herman T. Stichman, housing commissioner; Irving Gerdy, economist for the Federal Public Housing Authority, and Harold Klorfein, secretary of the New York City Housing Authority.

Herbert, the walrus, who liked everybody and everything except scales, died yesterday at 10:30 A. M. at the Bronx Zoo of an intestinal obstruction caused by a rubber ball thrown into his pool by a visitor last week. He was about 2 years old.

Many parties will be given at the luncheon and fashion show today in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre for the benefit of the Masters Nursery. Mrs. James P. Gallatin heads the committee in charge of plans for the fete. Her aides include Mrs. Derek L. O'Donoghue, Mrs. Burdette Pomeroy, Mrs. David H. McConnell and Mrs. William S. Goedecke.

The Texas Company broke all records in sales, earnings, crude oil production, capital expenditures and net working capital last year, according to the annual report issued yesterday by J. S. Leach, chairman, and Augustus C. Long, president.

YUCCA FLAT, Nev., March 17 -- A nuclear device designed to serve as a tactical atomic weapon for use in place of artillery against an enemy entrenched on a wide front was exploded from a 300-foot steel tower at 5:20 here this morning (8:20 New York Time) as dawn was breaking above the range of mountains surrounding this desert basin.

Following up his funeral oration for Stalin, Premier Malenkov delivered an inaugural address as Stalin's titular successor in which he pledged himself to a policy of peace and did so in terms which have attracted international attention because he avoided the usual recriminations of the past and dealt only with the "present" and the "future."

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, will give to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee tomorrow his personal evaluation of the data assembled in a Federal Bureau of Investigation inquiry on Charles E. Bohlen concerning loyalty and security.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -A wealthy dye manufacturer who said he "had faith in human beings" testified today he gave more than $20,000 to a group of persons who promised, but failed, to fix his tax troubles in Washington.

On record net sales of $1,141,295,700, the National Dairy Products Corporation last year increased its net profit to $27,799,252 from $26,517,668 earned in 1951 on the previous peak volume of $1,066,177,231. E. E. Stewart, president, in his annual report, mailed to stockholders yesterday, noted that the larger earnings were achieved despite the highest tax bill and payroll in the company's history.

Motion-picture advertising techniques need to be modernized and adapted to new conditions and competition, according to a study by the Herald Institute of Industry opinion. Representatives of the production, distribution and exhibition branches of the industry were surveyed.

" The proposals I have outlined in these messages * * * contain no panaceas. None of them is mandatory. All are permissive only." These words from Governor Dewey to the Legislature, after proposing a transit authority, real-estate tax rise and payroll tax as a solution to New York City's financial

ALBANY, March 17 -- The Dewey Administration's residential rent control bill, permitting increases up to 15 per cent, was approved tonight by both the Senate and the Assembly and sent to the Governor. The vote in the Senate was 36 to 20; in the Assembly, 80 to 67.
WASHINGTON March 17 -- A new system that will permit a woman to buy all her clothing by reference to her dress size has been worked out by the Department of Commerce.

UNITED NATIONS, N.
