Y., March 17 -- The United Nations General Assembly directed an "earnest appeal" today to the Soviet Union and its satellites to allow the repatriation of 3,000 Greek war prisoners who, according to the Athens Government, were captured during the Greek civil war and have been held against their will behind the Iron Curtain.

Although most American companies in Latin America are spearheading desired social reforms, they must become more definitely identified with such progress in the public mind, not merely in fact, it was urged yesterday by John M. Cabot, new Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs.

I consider the proposal of Governor Dewey undemocratic and based on the erroneous belief that an expert can solve the complex problems of municipal government if only the people can be removed from the realm of such matters. Some observers would lay the city's ill to the presence of "pressure

Canada's rejection of a proposal by the Aluminum Company of America to develop the immense power potential of the upper Yukon River was final, according to Robert H. Winters, Canadian Minister of Resources and Development.

MANILA, Wednesday, March 18 -- The second resignation this month from President Elpidio Quirino's Cabinet was announced yesterday. Mariano J. Cuenco, who heads a powerful political faction in Cebu Province of the Central Philippines, resigned as Economic Coordination Administrator, a recently created portfolio designed to concentrate direction of the country's economic rehabilitation efforts, and also as a member of the Council of State, the President's chief advisory body.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 17 -- There was a new stakes run at Gulfstream Park today -- the Turf Club Dinner Stakes. It drew so many entries that it had to be run in two divisions, with fourteen 2-year-olds in each section.

Yesterday morning's explosion of an atomic device, the second to be shown over television, was an impressive sight on the home video screen, even though the camera did not catch the flash at the exact moment of the blast. But as a means of stimulating greater interest in civilian defense preparations -- one one of the chief purposes of the test -- the telecast raised a number of questions.

TEHERAN, March l7 -- An informal political truce, scheduled to last throughout the two-week Iranian New Year season, settled on Teheran today but Premier Mohammed Mossadegh has given notice that he will come out fighting to retain and strengthen his control of the Government at the end of it.
FLORENCE, Italy, March 17 -Twenty simulated air attacks on six Italian cities and airbases and sixty-six sorties by defense fighter aircraft featured the second day of Exercise New Moon.
Business and industrial failures have been edging upward in both number and liabilities so far this year in comparison with 1952, but credit executives here do not view the rise as abnormal.

The security regulations being what they are, no one expects detailed information on the current tests of atomic bombs and other weapons on Yucca Flat, near Las Vegas, Nev. Not even the type of bomb exploded from a 300-foot tower yesterday morning was disclosed. The reporters in trenches two

TRENTON, March 17 -- John J. Dickerson, State Republican Chairman, and Walter G. Winne, superseded Prosecutor of Bergen County, were accused today by Nelson F. Stamler of exerting political pressure which, among other things, resulted in his dismissal as Deputy Attorney General in charge of the corruption and gambling inquiry in the county.

The wide acceptance that the recent European couture collections are receiving in New York was confirmed at Gimbels yesterday morning, when a comprehensive showing of twenty-nine dresses, suits and coats from France, Italy and England was reviewed for the fashion press.

ALBANY, March 17 -- The Senate Banking Committee has again voted down a motion to report out the Banking Department bill to liberalize the state's policy on branches for savings banks. While no vote was taken to kill the bill outright, Senator John H. Hughes, chairman of the committee, said he saw no chance for further action this year.

CAIRO, March 17 -- Lieut. Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser, second ranking man in the Army officers' group gocerning Egypt, renewed today his six-month-old threat of guerrilla warfare against British troops in the Suez Canal Zone.

TRENTON, March 17 -- With the New York State Legislature considering bills this week for compulsory state inspection of motor vehicles, a spokesman for the Division of Motor Vehicles of the New Jersey Department of Law and Public Safety stressed today the advantages of this state's system of state-operated inspection stations.

A French nobleman who in World War I was a munitions buyer in this country for France was found near death early yesterday morning on a couch on the mezzanine floor of the Commodore Hotel. He had stabbed himself in the left side with a paring knife.

DETROIT, March 17 -- The Ford Motor Company indicated today that revision of its five-year escalator agreement with the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., would hinge on concessions the union could win from the General Motors Corporation.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, March 17 (AP) -- Favorites from the United States and an Australian star easily won first-round matches in the Puerto Rican tennis tournament today.

MEXICO CITY, March 17 -- A six-year program aimed at bringing under irrigation 3,458,000 acres of land in the states of Lower California, Sonora, Sinaloa and Nayarit was announced today by Eduardo Chavez, Minister of Hydraulic Resources.
SANTIAGO, Chile, March 17 (AP) -- The United States defeated Argentina, 34 -- 22, to remain undefeated in the women's world basketball championship tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Arrangements were completed today to bring before the House of Representatives tomorrow President Eisenhower's plan to elevate the Federal Security Agency to the Cabinet status of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare. The plan will be debated for two hours.

March 17 -- The stock markets were quiet but steady today. British Government securities made small gains and Japanese bonds recovered part of the previous day's losses on the Japanese Foreign Minister's assurance that Japan would honor the service on the pre-war external debts regardless of what government was returned at the forthcoming elections.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 17--Stanley M. Rumbough Jr., assistant to Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, said here today this nation, is faced with a situation in government that calls for officials "young in mental years."
A bored 5-year-old's decision to emulate the superman behavior of one of his television heroes caused a considerable disturbance in his Brooklyn neighborhood yesterday afternoon.

After two rounds of the international chess masters tournament at Mar Del Plata in Argertina, Herman Steiner of Los Angeles, the only player invited from the United States in a field of twenty, was in a triple tie for first place yesterday, according to a report from Buenos Aires.

On orders from the Justice Department, Charles A. Doyle, former vice president of the United Gas, Coke and Chemical Workers, C. I. O., was taken to Ellis Island yesterday pending determination of his deportability.
In disputing the correctness of my figures on displaced persons F. J. Proch quotes in his letter published March 9 an estimate of thirty million from Eugene M. Kullscher's book, "Europe on the Move."

TOKYO, Wednesday, March 18--Troops of the United States Second Division yesterday, in the heaviest fighting of recent weeks in Korea, beat off a Communist attack on the western front, inflicting heavy casualties on the assaulting Chinese.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- A government charge that bonus plans of General Motors Corporation were designed to make executives respond when the du Ponts pulled the strings was termed "ridiculous" today by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., General Motors chairman, as he continued testimony at the du Pont anti-trust trial before Federal District Judge Walter J. LaBuy.

BONN, Germany, March 17 -Negotiations between the West German and Egyptian Governments for the participation of West German industry in the modernization of Egypt's backward and underdeveloped economy are now centered on a project, prepared by German engineers, to construct the world's greatest irrigation and power dam on the Nile River, four and a half miles south of the Aswan Dam.

It was good to learn in a dispatch by James Reston to this newspaper that President Eisenhower is not pleased with the operations of the McCarran-Walter Immigration and Nationality Act and is sounding out Congressional leaders to ascertain if amendments are possible at this session of Congress.

At a small luncheon for the press yesterday at the Pierre Hotel, Barton's Bonbonniere introduced its new frozen dessert for the Passover. It is a raspberry-pineapple ice that may be served at a Jewish table during the holidays at either a meat or a dairy meal in accordance with the dietary laws.

KANSAS CITY, March 17 (AP) -Kansas upset favored Washington, 79 to 53, and Indiana defeated Louisiana State, 80 -- 67, tonight to gain the final round of the National Collegiate A. A. basketball tournament.

No one segment of the textile industry can be wholly blamed for poor performance of textiles in their end-uses, according to panel members participating yesterday in a textile forum sponsored by the Textile Square Club.

Two redpoll birds came ashore here yesterday with the jaunty gait of seasoned mariners, obviously impressed with the fact that they were the first of their breed known to have ventured south of the Carolinas.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Federal Government gave up its last authority over prices today, leaving all buyers and sellers free to strike their own bargains for the first time since Jan. 26, 1951, when President Truman imposed them as a result of the Korean war.
HAVERSTRAW, N. Y., March 17 -- Local officials in five of ten Rockland County villages were chosen in contested elections today. The remaining five village slates were unopposed.

Playwright Arthur Miller recently said what badly needed saying in his reply to a spokesman for the American Bar Association, some of whose members found in "The Crucible" lines they interpreted as disparaging the legal profession."* * *

Governor Dewey's message to the Legislature on the transit situation in New York City is indeed a most states-manlike document, and from the angle of the financial future of the City of New York it is deserving of your editorial praise.
MINEOLA, L. I., March 17 -Six of the eight villages in Nassau County, which held elections today, reported the following results tonight:

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -Mayors of the country's cities told Congress today that the system of civil airports must be greatly extended soon. They asked that the Federal Government match construction funds that the cities had made available.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today that a hearing examiner had rejected motions by Doubleday Co., Inc., book publisher, of Garden City, L. I., to dismsis charges that it had "indirectly discriminated" against retail book stores through arrangements with book clubs.

Employment and policing practices at the Port of Baltimore, which has remained free of longshoremen's strikes for the last eight years and has virtually no pilferage or theft problems, were described here yesterday by Stacey Bender Jr., New York manager of the Baltimore Association of Commerce.

BONN, Germany, March 17 -The Court of Appeals of the British High Commission ruled today that Dr. Werner Naumann, leader of the group of seven Nazis arrested by the British, can be interviewed by the British and German lawyers representing him in a habeas corpus petition.

ALBANY, March 17 -- Senator Earl W. Brydges, Republican of Niagara Falls, and chairman of the Education Committee, asserted today that New York City schools were financially better off than schools generally throughout the state and charged that deficiencies in building were the result of bad planning.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The first children's party at the White House in this Administration, held yesterday afternoon, included only the Eisenhower grandchildren, Mrs. Eisenhower's two nieces and the four children with the Helen Hayes play, "Mrs. McThing."

BRADENTON, Fla., March 17 -- Undaunted by the American League's rejection of Bill Veeck's plan to transfer his Browns from St. Louis to Baltimore, Lou Perini, owner of the Braves, tomorrow will go through with his plea to the National League owners that he be permitted to switch from Boston to Milwaukee.

PARIS, March 17 (AP} -- A highly placed American official said today the allied fighting forces in Western Europe had only an average of three to five days' supply of artillery and anti-aircraft ammunition.

As part of a program to make available the abilities of retired or emeritus professors, the John Hay Whitney Foundation has designated six new visiting professorships at small, independent liberal arts colleges in the nation.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- President Eisenhower gave assurance today that the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service would be maintained at the highest standard of "impartiality, acceptability and effectiveness" under the new Administration.

IT is thirteen years since the publication of Richard Wrights famous novel, "Native Son," and eight since that of his even more celebrated autobiography, "Black Boy." Both those books were bitterly angry, fiercely eloquent denunciations of the racial discriminations and social and economic pressures that condition the lives of Negroes. And both were so powerfully

ALBANY, March 17 -- The State Public Works Department reported today that increasing availability of steel and other critical materials made possible a record volume of highway and building construction during 1952.

Sol C. Stoumen, president of the National Association of Carpet Retailers accused the National Retail Dry Goods Association and its department store members yesterday of circulating "false, damaging and distorted" statements about carpet specialty stores.

The New York Life Insurance Company, the nation's fourth largest, paid $164,014,099 to living policyholders in 1952. Death benefit payments for the same year were $103,900,538. The comparative figures for 1951 were $156,156,481 and $96,463,004, respectively.

Last year was a disappointing one for members of one of the world's most exclusive clubs. In the annual report for 1952, issued yesterday, Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, disclosed that while the "Big Board's" gross income was only $495 short of 1951's, net income dropped to $157,012 from $326,982 in the previous year.

Every member of the family, according to a film shown last night, can find help with individual problems, further special interests and add to life's pleasures through a variety of services to be found at the public library.
Senator Charles W. Tobey hunted pier payroll "phantoms" at a closed hearing yesterday and came upon the ghost of Thomas Plunkett a waterfront hoodlum whose murder last April is still a mystery.

WASHINGTON, March 17--The Senate subcommittee looking into the United States overseas information program has sent to Germany as an investigator a former chief of the Government's important radio station in Berlin whose resignation in 1949 was said today to have been "forced."

Nassau County, N. Y., borrowed $27,094,000 yesterday in the public market on bonds maturing serially from 1954 to 1982, to finance sewerage improvements. The issue was sold at sealed bidding to a syndicate headed by National City Bank of New York, Lehman Brothers and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 100.869 for interest of 3.1 per cent.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange continued steady yesterday, closing however somewhat irregular, 5 to 15 points off on all months except new July, which gained 7 points.
TOKYO, Wednesday, March 18 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,557, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Wednesday, Korean time:

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -Investigators of the House of Representatives reported today that the State Department had ordered, voluntarily, a $2,500,000 cut in the $20,000,000 United States building program in Germany.
YUCCA FLAT, Nev., March 17 (UP) -- Today's nuclear explosion destroyed one typical American home, wrecked the interior of another and tossed automobiles around like kiddy cars at a half-mile range.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 17 -- Twenty incorporated villages of Westchester County held local elections today. Ten of these were uncontested.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- The general undertone in the grain market was strong today, with both wheat and corn showing pronounced strength. Initial prices were lower on scattered overnight selling but commission buying took the slack out of the pits quickly and offerings on the advances were well absorbed.
Following is the text of a letter from the Long Island Transit Authority to the Public Service Commission, roads public yesterday, urging prompt rehabilitation of the Long Island Rail Road:
Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. described a new Federal anti-subversion program last night to 2,200 guests at the 169th annual dinner of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the Astor Hotel.
The National Association of Manufacturers, long regarded as the voice of big business, reported yesterday that the excess profits tax takes its heaviest toll -- of small business.
A woman rushing to the spot at which her 9-year-old son had just been injured critically by a truck was herself run down and injured yesterday afternoon by another truck on the lower East Side.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- Mary Jane Keeney, a one-time State Department employe and a former United Nations worker, was convicted today of contempt of Congress.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 17 (AP) -- Donald R. Heath, United States Ambassador, left by plane for Washington today to join in conferences on military and economic aid to France and Indo-China there next week.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 17 -- Yugoslavia's trade unions are about to be reorganized and profound changes are planned in the country's labor legislation.

PARIS, Wednesday, March 18 (Reuters) -- The Secretariat of the French Communist party rebuked Communist artist Pablo Picasso today for his drawing of Stalin that appeared in a Communist weekly, Les Lettres Francaises, last week.

Vast requirements of the defense program and civilian markets have resulted in expansion of the aluminum industry to its mightiest size, but demand for its products probably will not be satisfied for some months, A. V. Davis, chairman, and I. W. Wilson, president, informed shareholders of the Aluminum Company of America, in the annual report, released today.

SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., March 17 -- The Browns of St. Louis, who only recently were heading for Milwaukee, Baltimore land way stations, seemed to be doing well enough in picturesque Southern California today as they sent the Giants skidding out of here as though somebody had shoved them over Niagara Falls without a barrel.

The controling interest in the Fifth Avenue and Forty-sixth Street Corporation, owner of the leasehold at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-sixth Street, has been sold by Charles and Milton A. Kimmelman to a group of builders headed by Monroe E. Hemmerdinger, president of Atlas Terminals and Hemmerdinger Estates.

Mrs. Charles H. Buckley gave a luncheon yesterday in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for Mrs. Roelif H. Brooks, wife of the rector of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church. Mrs. Buckley is chairman of the committee for the card party that will be held April 8 at the Colony Club under the auspices of the Service Club of St. Thomas.
LONDON, March 17 -- President Marshal Tito, the anti-Stalinist chief of Communist Yugoslavia, lunched today at Buckingham Palace with Queen Elizabeth and the royal family.
The New York County Lawyers Association said yesterday that it favored broad revisions of the McCarran-Walter Immigration and Nationality Act. The law became effective Dec. 24.

TAMPA, Fla., March 17 (AP) -Bill Veeck, president of the Browns, put a $2,400,000 price tag on his ball club before he started for home today "with my right foot forward, my chin out and all set to face the music."

LONDON, March 17 -- Prime Minister Churchill acknowledged today that the British bomber shot down by Soviet fighters last Thursday "may through a navigational error have accidentally crossed into the Eastern zone of Germany at some point."

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The United States demanded today that the Hungarian and Soviet Governments pay $637,894.11, plus interest, for damages incurred when an unarmed United States Air Force cargo plane was forced down in Hungary sixteen months ago.
James Robinson Co, importer of antinque English silverware, in 12 E 57th St through H. Clayton Smith Co -- Kreisel Co and Residence, Inc. co-brokers.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (UP) -- The Army said as flatly as possible today that the armed forces in Korea now had an adequate supply of ammunition.

ALBANY, March 17 -- Bertram D. Tallamy, State Superintendent of Public Works, announced today that Joseph J. Darcy, Long Island district engineer, would retire April 11, after forty-three years of state service. He will be succeeded in the $11,925 post by Milton E. Goul of Loudonville, associate civil engineer with the department.

Most coffee futures declined yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, with only the May position showing any gain. Prices had soared after controls were removed but profit-taking and lower prices for green coffee in Brazil weakened the market for the first time in three weeks. Speculator selling was noted.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Air Force disclosed today that a Soviet MIG-15 jet fighter had attempted to shoot down a Strategic Air Command RB-50 weather reconnaissance plane twenty-five miles east of the Siberian Peninsula of Kamchatka over what the United States Government considers international waters.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 17--Since the calendar plays an important though not generally recognized role in United Nations General Assembly proceedings, it is now likely that the 1952 session will come to an inconclusive halt just before Easter, which this year falls on April 5.

The building with fifty-one apartments and six stores at 1290 Lafayette Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Leo A. Bercow and Walter Berger, investors and operators, to clients of Lewis Steinfeld, lawyer. The Metropolitan Title Company insured title to the property, which is assessed at $190,000. Charles H. Kelman, lawyer, represented the sellers.

THE arrival of flounders normally opens the salt-water season, but despite the assorted portents indicating an early spring, the fiat fish have not been too plentiful along the South Shore of Long Island, although anglers have been increasing during the past week.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 18 -- A consolidated net profit for 1952 of $43,950,791, or $4.46 a share, on the 9,853,200 shares outstanding was reported today by Transamerica Corporation. This compares with $22,692,115, or $2.30 a share, for 1951 on the 9,859,350 shares then outstanding.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously approved today President Eisenhower's nomination of Charles E. Bohlen to be Ambassador to the Soviet Union, thus assuring his confirmation by the Senate by a heavy majority.

BONN, Germany, March 18 -- The Bundestag, the lower house of the West German Parliament, ratified tonight the restitution agreement with the State of Israel under which the Federal Republic undertakes to pay partial compensation for the depredations committed by the Nazis against the Jewish people.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that a no-strike clause in a contract and the Tart-Hartley ban on strikes during a sixty-day renegotiation period did not apply in a strike against unfair practices arising from noncontract matters.

NORTH PELHAM, N. Y., March 18 -This village of 6,000 inhabitants went over tonight to Democratic control for the first time since 1935 when a hat-drawing gave the vacant job of village trustee to Ernest J. Feleppa.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Governor Dewey approved today a bill authorizing the Jones Beach State Parkway Authority to impose a 10-cent toll for use of the Southern State Parkway to finance a $40,000,000 parkway improvement program in Nassau County.

Carlos E. Guimard, one of the eleven representatives of Argentina in the international chess masters tournament at Mar Del Plata, gained the undisputed lead yesterday with his third consecutive victory, according to a report from Buenos Aires. His opponent was Jacobo Bolbochan, another Argentine contestant.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., March 18 -- The Mount Pleasant Planning Board was directed today by the Town Council to study a plan filed by the General Electric Company for development at Valhalla of executive offices for 400 officials and aides.
TORONTO, March 18 (Canadian Press) -- The British American Oil Company, Ltd., had net earnings in 1952 of $14,130,399, an increase of $1,031,098, or 8 per cent, from 1951, and a new high.
PALM BEACH. Fla., March 18 (AP) -- Pete Cooper, White Plains, N. Y., won the Seminole Golf Club's $10,000 pro-amateur golf tournament today with a 36-hole score of 138 to earn $1,800.

Sales of petroleum products and natural gas set new records during 1952 for the Cities Service Company system. Assets of the company and its subsidiaries topped the $1,000,000,000 mark last year for the first time since the sale of a number of electric properties in the late Nineteen Forties.

Members of the National Federation of Financial Analysts, who are to hold their 1953 convention in Philadelphia from April 12 to 15, are being asked to choose among a baker's dozen of field trips that have been arranged to cover industries in the area.

MOSCOW, March 18 -- The Soviet Art under the headline "Outstanding Soviet Composer" paid a memorial tribute today to Sergei Prokofieff. The obituary notice of the composer, who died March 4 and who had been buried in Novo Devichie Cemetery, was signed by most of Russia's best-known composers including Tikhon Khrennikov, Reinhold Moritzovitch Gliere, Youri Shaporin, Dmitri Shostakovich, Dmitri Kabalevsky, Aram Khatchaturian and others.

TOPEKA, Kan., March 18 -- Harold R. Fatzer, Kansas Attorney General, filed suit here today to recover $110,000 from a fraternal insurance company that sold a tuberculosis sanitarium to the state and paid an $11,000 fee to C. Wesley Roberts, the present chairman of the Republican National Committee, for his part in negotiating the sale two years ago.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., March 18 -- A permanent injunction prohibiting Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc., from using the name "Robinson" in operations in the Western States was issued today by Superior Judge Stanley W. N. Barnes in a suit filed by J. W. Robinson Company, department store operator.
PINEHURST, N. C., March 18 (AP) -- Pat O'Sullivan won medal honors today on a one-over-par 78 to lead a field of sixty-seven in the North and South women's golf championship tournament.

NEW DELHI, India, March 18 -- India's Socialists and their political associates are interested in Prime Minister Jawaharial Nehru's suggestion for working out a combined approach to this country's economic problems with the ruling Congress party.

Charges by a group of doctors that former President Truman's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation had slanted its five-volume report in favor of compulsory national health insurance and socialized medicine were denied by commission members yesterday.

Unbeaten in their last five games, the Boston Bruins fought off a rally by the New York Rangers to gain a 2-1 victory over the Broadway Blues in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. It was the final appearance of the season here for the Hub skaters.

TOKYO, March 18 (AP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson returned to Japan today after a five-day tour of Korea. He said in Seoul he was tremendously impressed "with the infinite difficulties that this cruel war presents."

Andre Morice, French Minister of Public Works, Transportation and Tourism, confirmed yesterday the recurrent rumors that his country would have a new liner ready for the trans-Atlantic trade in four years.

The Republic Steel Corporation in a statement issued yesterday in Cleveland said it deems the annual stockholders meeting May 13 "an appropriate time to consider an increase in the authorized common stock of the corporation from 10,000,000 to 20,000,000 shares."

Twenty-two universities have agreed to cooperate with the Columbia Broadcasting System in televising a series of programs dramatizing higher education's contributions to individual and national welfare.

The novelty at last night's Carnegie Hall recital by the pianist Anatole Kitain was Paul Dukas' Piano Sonata in E flat Minor. Although it was written in 1901, the performance of the sonata heard last evenings was announced in the program as being the first in this city.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 18 -- Coincident with the first in a series of demonstration showings by Twentieth Century-Fox of its new wide-screen process called CinemaScope, Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer announced today that it had made a deal with Fox to use the system and would shortly announce its first picture.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 18 -- United States Ambassador Loy W. Henderson paid a long call today on Iranian Premier Mohammed Mossadegh forty-eight hours before the government leader was scheduled to make a public declaration rejecting the United States-British proposals for settlement of Iran's dispute with the British former owners of her nationalized oil.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 18 -- Prince Bernhard left tonight by air for the United States with a message from his wife, Queen Juliana, for President Eisenhower believed to be an appeal for action to solve the refugee problem, a question close to her heart.
TICONDEROGA, March 18 (AP) -- Five persons were burned to death and five were injured today in a fire that raged through the Ticonderoga Inn.
The State of New Jersey announced yesterday that it will receive bids May 1 on an issue of $25,000,000 of state institution bonds dated May 1, 1953 and due May 1, 1955 to 1968.

ALBANY, March 18 -- The Legislature was ready tonight to place its approval tomorrow on the Dewey Administration's fiscal program for New York City, despite expected Democratic opposition to all but two of the measures.

The percentage of consumer disposable income spent on men's clothing has declined in the last thirty years because of poor distribution and selling methods, according to Morton Freund, executive vice president of Lawrence C. Gumbiner Advertising Agency, Inc.
PHILADELPHIA, March 18 (AP) -The University of Pennsylvania student newspaper said tonight Penn and the Ivy League will continue their mutual "boycott" into the 1955 football season.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- A House of Representatives Judiciary subcommittee approved a bill today seeking to compromise the long-standing dispute between the states and the Federal Government over which should develop oil and other subsoil wealth in submerged coastal lands.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -Business loans increased $213,000,000 at reporting member banks in leading cities during the week which ended March 11, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The General Electric Company offered its 205,000 workers yesterday a wage increase of about 2 3/4 cents an hour, but two unions immediately condemned the proposal as "confusing," "insulting" and "contemptuous of employes."
PRESNO, Calif., March 18 -Look for an explosion out in these parts within the next twenty-four hours that should make the recent Nevada atomic disturbances sound like the popping of a toy pistol.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 18 -- Father Jasper Mduma, one of three Negro priests of the Community of Resurrection, was arrested and handcuffed today near the order's priory in white suburban Johannesburg because he did not have proper identification in his possession.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (UP) -- United States battle casualties in Korea rose by 252 this week to a total of 131,244, the Defense Department reported today. The week's increase included seventy-five dead, 183 wounded and ninety captured. The number of missing decreased by ninety-six.

ALBANY, March 18 -- The State Thruway Authority announced today that it was planning to install twenty-nine service areas along the main route of the 427-mile Thruway from New York to Buffalo. They will be spaced at intervals of approximately thirty miles and will include eating facilities of three types.

The twenty-seventh biennial convention of the National Federation of Music Clubs will be held here April 8-18, with delegates from the forty-eight states and with possible representation from Canada and Mexico. It will be the first biennial convention held in this city in the federation's fifty-fifth year history.

The City Council's rules committee yesterday asked Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan to appear before it in executive session next Tuesday at noon to give his views on a pending resolution involving alleged mistreatment of citizens by the police.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The unanimous approval by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee of the nomination of Charles E. Bohlen to be Ambassador to Moscow should quiet the cries -- some sincere, some politically animated -- that the Eisenhower Administration retreats from any showdown with Senator McCarthy of Wisconsin.

HARTFORD, March 18 -- The Connecticut General Assembly approved today a Republican Administration bill changing the boundary lines of the thirty-six State Senate District. The measure now goes to Gov. John Davis Lodge for his signature, which was expected within the next week or two.

Bernard Newman, in his collection of ready-to-wear originals shown yesterday at Bergdorf Goodman, continued his subtle good taste clothes that, in ready-to-wear styles, closely approach a custom look.

LONDON, March 18 -- For sometime disquieting rumors of gross discrimination by one of the British Government departments have been circulating in this country. Allegations have been made that while everybody else's wages have gone up, cats in post offices have not had an increase in pay since 1873 and that London cats have been getting more money than cats in the provinces.

Police details assigned to the Easter Parade on Fifth Avenue on April 5 will be under official orders to prevent any commercial advertising, clowning or "distasteful activities," it was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan.

MEXICO CITY, March 18 -- The Mexican Government today announced two measures that give the first clear indication of its over-all economic policy. The measures are aimed at promoting formation of domestic capital by curbing luxury purchases abroad and offering more inducement to savings and productive investments.
As an employe of the "Voice of America" I must take exception to the statement by Senator Robert Taft that this agency is "certainly full of fellow-travelers."

The Amalgamated Laundry Workers Health Center, Inc., of 150 Fifth Avenue, has filed plans for erection of a two-story building a 222-30 East Thirty-fourth Street which the group will occupy as a clinic, light storage and garage. Lee Schoen, the architect, estimated the cost at $800,000.

Investment banking statistics show that houses charged by Government with conspiring to prevent the spread of private placements and public sealed bidding were, in fact, leaders in such fields, defense counsel claimed yesterday in the anti-trust trial before Judge Harold R. Medina.

Failure to educate the members of the Police Department concerning "the rights of all people" was alleged yesterday by Arnold L. Fein, chief counsel to the President of the City Council. He said it was an important factor in the recent controversy over civil rights in that department.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week increased 1,435,000 barrels, according to the weekly figures of the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 160,869,000 barrels, compared with 159,434,000 a week earlier and 154,740,000 a year ago.
The recent drop in the price of beefsteak has not hurt Wilson Co., to judge by the remarks made by Edward F. Wilson, president, at the annual meeting in Chicago yesterday.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 18 (AP) -- The radioactive cloud from yesterday's atomic explosion has been tracked to Ohio.

A study of the men closely associated with President Eisenhower will be issued this spring by McBride under the title "Republicans on the Potomac." It is a new work by Jay Franklin, author of "The New Dealers," and is said to include "much unknown and semi-confidential material."

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 18 -- Yesterday's free hitting was conspicuously absent in today's game at Holman Stadium, which the Senators won from the Dodgers, 1 -- 0, the run coming in the ninth inning off Joe Black.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- A diminutive Rutgers Law School Associate Professor, who showed great persistence in legal sparring, swore to the House Un-American Activities Committee today that he was not now an actual card-carrying, official member of the Communist party."
Despite liberalization of margin rules on Feb. 24, the aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange showed little change in the reporting period just ended.

ALBANY, March 18 (UP) -- The New York State Commerce Department returned today a borrowed' New Hampshire trout stream that had dressed up the Empire State's "Vacationlands" handbook for several years.
Speaking yesterday before public school teachers in the New York Times auditorium John B. Oakes of THE TIMES editorial staff urged that Communists be forbidden to teach in our schools.

ALBANY, March 18 -- The Senate approved today three bills revising and making uniform the income requirements for admission to low-rent public housing, limited dividend and cooperative housing. The measures passed by a vote of 33 to 21, with most of the negative votes cast by Democrats.
Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were barely steady yesterday and the active months lost 6 to 13 points.
MILWAUKEE, March 18 (AP) -- Milwaukee became a big league baseball city today and a stampede developed immediately to buy tickets for the opening home game April 14 against the St. Louis Cardinals.

PITTSBURGH, March 18 (AP) -- George H. Love, president of Pittsburgh Consolidated Coal Company today reported that eight months of testing an experimental coal pipeline near Cadiz, Ohio, proves the project is economically feasible.

A campaign for blood donations in the financial district and for increased support of the 1953 Red Cross Fund Appeal was begun at noon yesterday with a rally on the steps of the former Sub-Treasury Building, Wall and Nassau Streets.

The new Tennessee Williams play, "Camino Real," will give its first New York performance this evening at 8 o'clock at the National Theatre. Cheryl Crawford and Ethel Reiner, in association with Walter P. Chrysler Jr., are the producers. The production has been staged by Elia Kazan.

A total of $504,830, more than half the goal set for the relief of refugees fleeing from behind the Iron Curtain into West Berlin, has been raised in three and one-half weeks, it was announced last night by the International Rescue Committee.
PRINCETON, N. J., March 18 -- The 116th anniversary of the birth of Grover Cleveland was commemorated here today in a brief ceremony at the former President's grave in the Princeton Cemetery.

National advertising in 1952 made the biggest billings on record in four media, reaching $958,347,692, an increase of 9.4 per cent over 1951, according to the Publishers Information Bureau's fifth annual edition of "National Advertising Investments."

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 18 -- Harold J. Adonis, former executive clerk to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey, indicated today he was planning to sue the Dutch Government on the ground of illegal detention in order to force his release from this counry.

David Greenglass, serving fifteen years as a confessed atom spy, denied to members of his family recently that he had been coached by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the drawing of segments of the atom bomb, or that he had given perjured testimony against his sister, Mrs. Ethel Rosenberg, and her husband, Julius.

In his inaugural address Premier Malenkov pledged his Government, among other things, to "observance of established international norms." How the Soviets have been observing these "norms" is demonstrated again by the air battle over the Pacific Ocean in which a Soviet fighter opened fire on an American weather plane twenty-five miles off Kamchatka.
ALBANY, March 18 -- A bill restricting sales in New York City to curb the activities of teen-age gangs using "zip guns" was defeated in the Assembly today after a heated two-hour debate.
LONDON, March 18 (Reuters) -- The British Government is quietly pressing a campaign to promote investment of British-held dollars in Canada's booming development program.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- President Eisenhower said today that a balanced budget should be in sight as a proved capability before the Administration would undertake to reduce taxes.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican of Iowa, said today "the wolves are out to get" Mr. Heimlich, a special investigator sent to Germany to check United States information activities for the Senator's Foreign Relations subcommittee.

The University of Puerto Rico dedicated and opened yesterday a $500,000 rum research laboratory and pilot distillery on the campus of its Agricultural Experiment Station at Rio Piedras, in the heart of the sugar cane fields.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 18 -- Bernard Sless, assistant to the president of Bayuk Cigars, Inc., warned here today that the nation's cigar industry must continue innovations in merchandising to meet the growing self-service retailing movement.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- The armed forces said today they were preparing to pay $100 to almost every officer who has gone on active duty since the Korean war started. No estimate of the number was made.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The United States "vigorously" protested to the Soviet Foreign Office in Moscow today against the attack last Saturday on a United States Strategic Air Command RB-50 weather observation plane over international waters near the Siberian peninsula of Kamchatka.
TOKYO, Thursday, March 19 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,558, covering Wednesday's actions:

James R. Hardie purchased the two-story dwelling at 40-73 Denman Street in East Elmhurst, L. I., from August F. Mark and Nellie M. Graef. The North Shore Realty was the broker in the transaction, in which title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

What are most investors looking for -- capital gains or investment income? The New York Stock Exchange says the primary motive behind the purchase of securities by individuals is the desire for long-term capital gains. It bases its opinion on an analysis it made of public activity in the market on two days last year, Sept. 10 and 17.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., March 18 -- Social scientists and those in the mass media field should stop exchanging sneers and study each other's methods of operation, it was urged here today by Dr. Ernest Dichter, president of the Institute for Research in Mass Motivations, Inc.

The ballot is America's glory -- the peaceful and democratic means of electing officers, determining policy and redressing grievances; but when, as in New York, it becomes obstructed by numerous and legal impediments and hurdles and becomes manipulated by political bosses, it then becomes increasingly the form and not the reality for the expression of the popular will.

LONDON, March 18 -- The stock markets strengthened today and prices rose in nearly every section. British Government securities were stimulated by the firmness of the sterling dollar exchange rate and closed at the day's best level. Store and woolen textile shares provided most activity in the industrial market although all groups generally were firm except breweries.

The Planned Parenthood Federation of America said yesterday that its affiliates in Brooklyn and the Bronx had been notified by borough welfare councils that Catholic Charities would resign from those regional bodies if the parenthood groups continued membership.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The possibility of greatly increased national health and productivity through human rehabilitation was stressed in many sections of Volume 2 of the report of the Truman Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation, published today.
SYDNEY, Australia, March 18 (Reuters) -- The chairman of the Australian Wheat Board, Sir John Teasdale, said here tonight he did not think there would be a new International Wheat Agreement.

ALBANY, March 18 -- The Senate approved today by a vote of 33 to 21 a bill that would give to the Boroughs of Queens and the Bronx representation for the first time on the Board of Election Commissioners.

Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer directed a jury of eight men and four women yesterday to return a verdict of $9,050 in favor of Jane Froman, singer, and $9,580 in favor of Gypsy Markos, dancer, after the jurors had voted 11 to 1 in favor of Pan American Airways, defendant in a $3,500,000 damage suit.

I wish to take exception to Governor Dewey's curious statement that the "nonresident employed in * * * [New York] city * * * enjoys its diverse services and makes no contribution to their cost." Does he think a nonresident rides the subways and buses without paying his dimes, or eats in New York City restaurants without paying his checks?

The Greater New York Councils set new highs in the recruitment of Boy Scouts last year, Gerald F. Beal, retiring president, said in the 1952 report given at the annual meeting at 120 West Forty-second Street yesterday. Thomas J. Watson Jr., president of International Business Machines Corporation, was installed as the new president of the councils.

CHICAGO, March 18 -- Wheat and corn showed more signs of bullish activity today but the trade was of moderate volume, the market edging up against fairly free selling. Argentine corn news as suddenly taken on a bullish tone, the trade having been informed of serious drought and heat damage during February.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Two Maryland Congressmen, James P. S. Devereux, Republican, and Samuel N. Friedel, Democrat, asked the Department of Justice today to investigate the refusal of club owners of the American League to sanction the transfer to Baltimore of the Browns' franchise.

CLEVELAND, March 18 -- Thurman W. Arnold, former associate justice of the United States Court of Appeals, declared today that the "conduct of colleges is not a Federal affair." He asserted that "presidents of colleges, their boards of trustees are thoroughly competent to handle the question of who should be on their faculty and who should be discharged."

The Board of Estimate declared yesterday that it would not accept the "intolerable and onerous" transit authority legislation introduced in the State Legislature under Governor Dewey's sponsorship as the keystone of his three-point "permissive" program for alleviating the city's financial ills.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- A check of the nation's gold and silver and coin has ended and, a Treasury official said today, "everything is there."
Men who have seen the sea know its capabilities -- its wealth of untapped resources, its power that has yet to be harnessed, the beauty and enjoyment it can offer.

CHICAGO, March 18 -- The du Pont anti-trust trial, which has enough lawyers for a dozen ordinary cases, was enlivened today by some twenty-eight-year-old letters expressing doubt about whether lawyers make good business men.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 18 (AP) -- The Army's newest and largest amphibious cargo vehicle, the BARC, sank last night and its three crew members drowned, the Sixth Army said today.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- A referee's award announced today will give the country's railroad employes a wage rise of 4 cents an hour, effective as of last Dec. 1. The decision is binding and will raise the carriers' wage bill about $120,000,000 a year.

LONDON, March 18 -- Tragedy interrupted Britain's sumptuous and impressive entertainment of President Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia today when two jet planes, part of an air display, collided and crashed before his eyes.

For the ninth successive day, prices on the New York Stock Exchange have shown a gain. THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average of fifty stocks yesterday. closed 0.14 point higher at 194.84 At the high of the day, which was 195.87, it had bettered the February top by 0.02 point.

DON'T look now, but I think we are having a flourishing revival of supernatural literature. It is fraught as all get-out with trends. The bug-eyed monsters and men from Mars that infest science fiction are becoming slightly old hat. In their places we are beginning to have interstellar characters as believable as those created by H. G. Wells.

Jeremiah A. Sullivan, chairman of the Richmond County Democratic Committee, has opened the way for a series of contests in the September primary by ousting three of the five ward chairmen in a reorganization of the county's Democratic party.
More than 600 New York University students demanded immediate and unqualified reinstatement of football yesterday in a protest rally on N. Y. U.'s Bronx campus.

IN their efforts to abolish anti- firearms legislation and promote the passage of measures to improve fish and wildlife conditions, sportsmen are not always victorious, but they are learning things concerning the various legislative procedures that should be of real value in the future.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 18 (UP) -Austria's hopes of staging the 1956 Olympics virtually disappeared today when Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies announced the Government would not permit athletes to live in the Albert Park barracks at Melbourne, the proposed site of the games.

PARIS, March 18 -- Louis Aragon, the poet, whose talents along with those of Pablo Picasso, the painter, have long been at the service of the Communist party, joined M. Picasso today as a target of public scolding from the party's secretariat.

ALBANY, March 18 -- The Senate rejected today by a vote of 32 to 24 a bill to license the practice of chiropractic in New York State. All twenty-four votes in favor of the bill came from Republicans. Ninteen Democrats and thirteen Republicans voted against the measure.
LENOX, Mass., March 18 (AP) The twenty-o-room CardinaI Inn, 122 years old, a sprawling wooden structure, was destroyed by flames early today. - summet resort, it was unoccupied.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 18 -- An evolution that may profoundly mold the future leadership of the armed forces of the United States is taking place here at Supreme Allied Headquarters through the "integration" of 185 hand-picked American Army, Navy and Air Force officers into a single military staff that includes 223 Allied officers from nine other nations.

DENVER, March 18 (AP) -- A team of former Oregon collegiate stars scored a major upset today in the National Amateur Athletic Union basketball tournament defeating the Bartlesville (Okla.) Phillips Oilers in the second round, 66 -- 52.
BALTIMORE, March 18 (UP) -- Ten Baltimore business men today offered to buy the Browns at Owner Bill Veeck's price of $2,400,000, but Veeck told them to "wait a while."

TOKYO, Thursday, March 19 -- United Nations land and carrier-based bombers swarmed over North Korea yesterday and last night, following Tuesday night's forty-plane attack by B-29's at Pungha, close to the Manchurian border.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today nominated Walter S. Robertson of Richmond, Va., an investment banker and an Eisenhower Democrat, to be Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs. He would succeed John M. Allison, who has been named Ambassador to Japan.

The real sufferers from any action that will limit the spread of information on planning parenthood are those low income families whose stability, health, happiness and -- in some cases -- lives may depend on such help, Dr. Sophie J. Kleegman, medical director, New York State League for Planned Parenthood, said yesterday.

The actetylene torch operator who set up a one-man picket line in front of the Bethlehem Steel Company shipyard at Twenty-seventh Street in Brooklyn on Tuesday and kept 450 workers from entering, did a repeat performance yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- A proposal to give Philadelphia parity with Baltimore in import iron ore rates was supported today by four steel company officials at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Assemblywoman Janet Hill Gordon, Republican of Chenango, today amended her bill setting up a state commission for a study of New York's divorce laws. The change was made in an effort to get the measure out of committee before the Legislature adjourns.

William O. Douglas, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States, yesterday received the fifth annual Henrietta Szold Award for Distinguished Humanitarian Service from Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Confident of their financial position this year, American consumers are prepared to make major outlays for homes, automobiles, furniture and the larger electrical appliances for home use, the Federal Reserve Board said in a special report today.

MADRID, March 18 -- A group of thirty-eight persons belonging to the youth front of the Communist party of Catalonia received sentences today of from one to fifteen years in prison by a military court in Barcelona. They were convicted of having attempted to organized the Partido Socialista Unificado Catalan, which is the regional name of the Spanish Communist party.

MEXICO CITY, March 18 (AP) --Resumption of shipping service between Mexico and Japan got off to a bad start this week when Mexican customs officials charged the captain of the Maitoku Maru with trying to smuggle part of the ship's cargo into this country.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 18 -- Naval dockyard workers were ordered into action as strikebreakers today to defeat a move by the Rio de Janeiro longshoremen to tie up the port by refusing to work overtime. It was reported that armed marines would patrol the docks to see that none was molested.

Seven Beautiful Baby Elephants (7) will get their first haircuts with a blowtorch this week as a signal that everything down to the last, long adjective is in order with the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus. Whereupon, the 2,000 folk of the big top will gather their animals, props and costumes and start northward from Sarasota, Fla., for the grand opening at Madison Square Garden on April 1.
FLORENCE, Italy, March 18 -- United States and British aircraft came into Exercise New Moon for the first time today.
Prompt and drastic reduction of tariffs and trade restrictions by the United States was urged yesterday by David Rockefeller, senior vice president of the Chase National Bank.

It is time now to put away the things that are winter's, and in the course of a year there are few occupations that provide more pleasure. Time now? Well, some of the mornings yet ahead will be sharp, and some of the March winds have not yet blown themselves away, yet it is time.
The Board of Estimate issued the following statement yesterday which was concurred in by all members except James A. Lundy, Borough President of Queens:

Commodity prices closed irregularly higher yesterday in light trading on the New York exchanges. Only the domestic sugar and cocoa markets were active. Cocoa, coffee, hides, rubber and zinc ended higher. Sugar, potatoes and lead were mixed and cotton-seed oil, soybean oil and wool closed lower.

SINGAPORE, March 18 -- The Federation of Malaya's emergency regulation 17D which gave the Government powers of mass deportation and detention is being abolished forthwith, the High Commissioner, Gen. Sir Gerald Templer announced today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 18 -- Representatives of the five great powers today discussed nine additional possible candidates to succeed Trygve Lie as Secretary General of the United Nations, but announced later that they had not been able to agree on any recommendation to the Security Council.

BONN, Germany, March 18 -- Dr. Werner Naumann, held by the British as the leader of the first major Nazi plot against the postwar German democracy, returned to Werl prison tonight after a British court had rejected his petition for a writ of habeas corpus.

The membership of the Port Watchmen's Union in the Port of New York has rejected by a margin of fifteen to one an offer for a new two-year contract that was made the independent labor group by the New York Shipping Association on March 1.

MOSCOW, March 18 -- The Communist party newspaper, Pravda, declared today that so long as "capitalist encirclement" continued all measures must be taken to strengthen Soviet power. Pravda explained that this meant the strengthening of "the dictatorship of the proletariat" and particularly the power of the Soviet armed forces, the punitive organs of the Soviet state and the organs of Soviet intelligence.

A meeting of 300 local government-bond specialists was told here yesterday that over a forty-year period the proposed five-mile bridge over Michigan's Straits of Mackinac would invite a tripling of motor vehicle traffic now carried by ferryboats and would generate enough surplus revenues to pay off a projected $96,000,000 bond issue before it could come due in 1993.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18 -- Somewhere around the fifth inning of today's game with the Yankees, the Boston Braves learned that they were wearing the wrong uniforms. The Boston lettering on their shirt-fronts was in error. They had just become the Milwaukee Braves.

FRANKFURT, March 18 (AP) -William Heimlich, a special investigator for a Senate subcommittee looking into the United States overseas information program, said today he resigned as director of the American radio station R. I. A. S. in Berlin in 1949 in a dispute over policy.

Generally conservative in tenor, the current exhibition by members of the American Artists Professional League at the National Arts Club brings together more than 200 oils and water-colors together with a few examples of sculpture and entries in black-and-white.

The buds on the shrubbery outside the old frame house at 3 East Eighty-third Street, just off Fifth Avenue, are sprouting hard. And well they may, for next year they and the house itself will be gone. The city's growth, which has struck all around them, is about to replace them and neighboring structures with a twelve-story apartment building, with penthouse.
BOSTON, March 18 (UP) -- Boston reaction to the transfer of the National League franchise to Milwaukee ranged from deep gloom to hopeful optimism today.

Cooperative international action in the social field is essential if world problems are to be settled by peaceful means, Dean Rusk, president of the Rockefeller Foundation and General Education Board, said last night.

KANSAS CITY, March 18 (AP) -- A free throw by Bob Leonard with 27 seconds to go gave Indiana a thrilling 69-to-68 victory over Kansas tonight for the National Collegiate A. A. basketball championship.

Concentration of American aid in Europe and Asia at the lessening of such aid in Latin America has caused resentment of Brazilians against the United States, according, to Dr. Euvaldo Lodi, president of the Brazilian National Confederation of Industry.

Some of the lettuce that has arrived here this winter from California and Arizona has been packed by a new, more economical method that eliminates the use of ice. Earlier this week, at the request of the Western Growers Association, which represents vegetable and melon producers in those states, a group of food writers and television and radio cookery experts compared this green with lettuce shipped with ice in regular wooden crates.
Traffic relations in force in the Madison Square area were assailed yesterday as dating from the horse and buggy era and consequently as causing accidents congestion and confusion.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 18 -- Jockey Ken Church is enjoying his suspension.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18 -- Unlike Bill Veeck, who had failed to effect an American League transfer of his Browns from St. Louis to Baltimore two days ago, Lou Perini succeeded today in shifting his National League baseball franchise from Boston to Milwaukee.

The Columbia Broadcasting System had a net income last year of $6,445,506, the highest in its twenty-five-year history, the company reported yesterday. Despite Government restrictions on materials, each operating unit except C. B. S. Radio showed increases in sales volume.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., March 18 (AP) -- An Air National Guard pilot pinned a Navy and Marine Corps Medal today on the Navy doctor who probably saved his life with a pocketknife operation last July after a plane crash.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The House of Representatives adopted and sent to the Senate today a joint resolution to expedite the creation of a Department of Health, Education and Welfare out of the components of the Federal Security Agency. On a roll call, the vote was 291 to 85, with three members voting present.

LONDON, March 18 -- An ovation such as Covent Garden rarely, if ever, has heard was given tonight to Margot Fonteyn, star of the Sadler's Wells Ballet, when she returned to the stage after an absence of five months.

This is the day chosen for legislative action on the Dewey Administration's fiscal program for New York City. This program includes transit reform that would prevent chronic use of real estate taxes to subsidize an operating deficit; a rise in the constitutional rate of real-estate taxation for city operating expenses; a payroll tax, and, for general improvement of city government, a study of Charter revision for a manager plan.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18 -- A Federally-financed "family allowance" system, designed to provide supplemental income to parents for the support of children under eighteen years of age, was endorsed here today at the closing session of the twenty-first annual convention of the National Catholic Family Life Conference.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today cotton consumption in February averaged 38,931 bales for each working day.

The Russian Children's Welfare Society, Inc., will be the beneficiary of the entertainment known as the "Advent of Spring" dinner dance, which will be held tonight in the Carnaval Room of the Sherry-Netherland. Mrs. Willard Case Whitehouse and Mrs. Myron A. Lomasney are co-chairmen of the benefit committee.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18 -A near classic in springtime pitching was performed today when young Bob Buhl of the Braves hurled five innings of no-hit, no-run ball against the Yankees.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement also shows die following changes: Increases of $965,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, and $271,000,000 in borrowings, and a decrease of $672,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 18 -- The United States challenged Soviet Premier Georgi M. Malenkov today to prove his talk of "peace" by cooperating to end the six-year-old deadlock in the United Nations over a world disarmament plan.

" The time has come," the walrus might have said, "to talk of many things. Of nuts -- and rocks -- and paper bags -- of rubber balls -- and nails -- and why some people just can't look -- and whether men have brains." Actually, the walrus didn't have a chance to say anything.

PARIS, March 18 -- Both Foreign Minister Georges Bidault and his predecessor, Robert Schuman, have suggested that a national election or referendum might be necessary to get ratification by the French of the European army treaty.

CAIRO, March 18 -- There were no new developments today in the Egyptian campaign for the British evacuation of the Suez Canal military base, but the role of Washington in the week-end talks among Egypt, Britain and the United States was the subject of clarifying statements from both Egypt and the American Embassy.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The State Department issued today a new series of rules for its world information activities, permitting the use of "Communist material" solely to "expose Communist propaganda or refute Communist lies."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 18 -- The United States challenged Soviet Premier Georgi M. Malenkov today to prove his talk of "peace" by cooperating to end the six-year-old deadlock in the United Nations over a world disarmament plan.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 18 (AP) -- What happened in the big test of civil defense installations on the atomic proving ground yesterday? A good deal of it will not be known until scientists evaluate what they saw and examine scores of instruments, but some things were obvious.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Paul Arnold, a New York lawyer, told at a Congressional hearing today of advising a client to pay $1,000 as "expenses" for a Washington newspaper correspondent to arrange a conference in 1950 with Theron Lamar Caudle, then Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's Tax Division.
Milton M. Bergerman, chairman of the Citizens Union called on Mayor Impellitteri yesterday to save more than $150,000 a year by abolishing the city's Department of Commerce.

HAVANA, March 18 -- Fortuna, a 39-foot cutter owned by W. W. Jennings of St. Petersburg, Fla., today won Class B honors in the twentieth annual St. Petersburg to Havana yacht race. Fortuna arrived in Havana Harbor at 3:14 A. M., with a Class B corrected time of 84 hours 51 minutes 29 seconds.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 18 -- A complete re-appraisal of the nation's lagging civilian defense program, which will include a study of the feasibility of the partial evacuation of key cities, has been ordered by President Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, said today, after getting a "sympathetic" reaction from President Eisenhower, that he would introduce a bill soon to relieve the overpopulation pressures of Western European countries.
SYDNEY, Australia, March 18 -- The Japanese whaling fleet lost a 9,500-ton refrigerated whaling ship worth nearly $2,500,000 last week and the Japanese have abandoned any more whaling this season.

New issues of public utility securities, consisting of about $20,000,000 of mortgage bonds and preferred and common stock, will be offered to investors today. The money raised from the sale will be used largely to finance expansion projects.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The experts monitoring Communist broadcasts to catch the "tone" of propaganda since the recent "peace" pronouncements of Soviet Premier Georgi M. Malenkov thought a few days ago they sensed a quieting down of vituperation against the United States.

The Senate Codes Committee in Albany has reported out for floor action three highly controversial bills, sponsored by the Senate and Assembly Rules Committees, which aim to curb the financial participation of labor unions in political campaigns. Last year these measures were known as the Erwin-Travia bills and, while they were reported out of committee late in the session, they were not brought to a vote.
UTRECHT, the Netherlands, March 17 -- The sixtieth semi-annual Utrecht International Trade Fair opened tday with concerns from thirty countries showing their wares.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- Spurred by Communist attacks on United States planes, the Senate today voted $167,000 for an investigation of ammunition shortages and other defense needs.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 18 -State Referee Alfred C. Baldwin said today that his one-man grand jury investigation had failed to prove official or political graft in Norwalk and Stamford.

The annual presentation of awards by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences will be telecast nationally tonight by N.B.C. in simultaneous ceremonies to be held on both East and West Coasts. Some of this year's winners will receive "Oscar" statuettes at the R. K. O. Pantages Theatre in Hollywood from predecessors.

How Billy Bryant, a 17-year-old sailor from Vista, Calif., held up maneuvers of a carrier, six destroyers, and some submarines for half an hour yesterday simply because he lost his cap is now inscribed forever in the log of the U. S. S. Pelau.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- President Eisenhower has asked C. D. Jackson, former publisher of Fortune magazine to succeed Admiral Alan G. Kirk, retired, as chairman of the Psychological Strategy Board. Admiral Kirk resigned several weeks ago.

ALBANY, March 18 -- The temporary State Commission on Coordination of State Activities called today for "substantial reorganization" of the state Civil Service Department to streamline its procedures and offer better service to the state and to applicants for public jobs.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 18 -- The United Nations was urged by 135 United States physicians today to conduct an investigation into the Soviet Union's charges that nine Moscow physicians had plotted against the lives of Russian leaders.

Despite preventive campaigns, the total number of blind men, women and children continues on the increase in the nation. The number of persons expected to lose their sight this year is estimated at 22,000.

Parental discipline and control is needed "even when it hurts," a group of senior high school students agreed this week at a panel discussion on parents' attitudes. The students, who attend the Evander Childs High School in the Bronx, spoke at a meeting of the parents' association at the school.
The Department of Agriculture is again planning to use vessels of the Maritime Administration's Hudson River reserve fleet as floating warehouses for grain, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- A former Truman economic adviser predicted today it would be increasingly difficult to maintain prosperity when defense spending hit its peak in the second half of this year.

Henry H. Rotenberg and Samuel Teitelbaum have sold the former Jonathan Logan building at 83-85 Newark Avenue and 293 Henderson Street in Jersey City, N. J., to Isidore Cohen, whose Manhattan Sweater Company will occupy a portion of the property in a major expansion move. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker and the attorneys were Bernard Shadow for the sellers and Leon R. Rosen for the buyer.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 19 (UP) -- Basketball's controversial one-and-one foul rule was left on the books today for at least another season by the nation's rule makers.

The discovery of an age-inhibiting factor said to be so important in forestalling the effects of old age that it might be termed the anti-old-age antibiotic was reported here yesterday by a Ger man physician. The anti-age antibiotic is free. It is physical exercise.

A possible link between a member or members of the Police Department and three bookmakers allegedly bent on a robbery is being investigated by Kings County District Attorney Miles F. McDonald's office.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn, March 19 -A surprise disclosure that most Tennessee Valley Authority offices here and 500 employes would be moved to Muscle Shoals, Ala., in the summer of 1954, today brought swift objections.

The Board of Estimate gave tentative approval yesterday to proposals submitted by the Board of Transportation for a $24,800,000 reduction of operating expenses of the municipal transit lines in 1953-54.

Trading in cotton futures yesterday was moderately active, and final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were 21 points lower to 1 point higher than on Wednesday, with the old May position showing the most weakness.
The only "bug" that is holding up the development of the fully automatic factory is the fact that it is impractical to have expensive machine tools in operation only half the time.
ALBANY, March 19 -- Following is the vote by which the Senate and Assembly approved the bill authorizing a payroll tax in New York City:

DANBURY, Conn., March 19 -In the belief that Thomas Luchese (Three Finger Brown), alleged rackets boss who figured recently in the New York State Crime Commission investigation, may have concealed assets here, the Bureau of Internal Revenue has filed income tax liens of $173,164 against him and his wife with Danbury Town Clerk J. Augustus Deakin, it was disclosed today.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., March 19 (UP) -- The United States Air Force disclosed today that a B-29 Superfortress crashed off Newfoundland yesterday while searching for an RB-36 bomber that crashed a few hours earlier, taking a one-day toll of thirty-three United States airmen dead or missing.

The Newspaper Guild of New York, C. I. O., announced yesterday its annual Page One awards for outstanding performance in the fields of public affairs, journalism, sports, radio and television, labor, films, stage, books and photography.

Carlos E. Guimard of Argentina retained the lead with a score of 3 -- 0 as his fourth-round game with Herman Steiner of Los Angeles was adjourned in the international chess masters tournament at Mar Del Plata yesterday, according to a report from Buenos Aires.
CLEVELAND, March 19 (AP) -- Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Company announced today it would charge 28 cents a ton more for iron ore during the second quarter of this year.

Those who feared that any Presidential nominee not previously stamped O. K. by Senators McCarthy and McCarran would be cast forth into outer darkness can be pleasantly surprised by the progress of Charles E. Bohlen's nomination to be Ambassador to the Soviet Union.

PARIS, March 19 -- Former Premier Antoine Pinay, who has been resting in retirement since his resignation at the end of last year, returned to political activity tonight with a speech that made him once again a factor in French politics.
CHICAGO, March 19 (AP) -- Montgomery Ward Co. has deferred a directors' meeting, and an official today denied rumors that Sewell Avery, 79-year-old chairman of the board, plans to retire.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) Senator Wayne Morse, Independent of Oregon, said today that he had asked Senate leaders to switch his seat and desk on the Senate floor from the Republican to Democratic side.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- President Eisenhower today strongly rejected the idea that any good would result from a Congressional investigation of communism in the churches.

Fines on charges growing out of the practice of some firemen of letting outside employment interfere with their regular duty were imposed yesterday by Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet against five members of the department.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- During the week ended March 18, member bank reserves increased $653,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
TOKYO, Friday, March 20 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,559, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korean time:

The thirty-fourth fellowship of the Eugene F. Saxton Memorial Trust has been awarded to Kimball Flaccus to enable him to complete a biography of Edgar Lee Masters. Mr. Flaccus, who was born in Philadelphia and studied in this country and abroad, met Edgar Lee Masters in 1940 and has based his book on personal correspondence, interviews and private papers furnished by Mr. Masters.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 19 (AP) -- Australia's hopes of holding the 1956 Olympic Games received another jolt tonight when the Victorian Premier, John Cain, rejected a request that the state government finance the building of an Olympic village.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Department store sales in the week ended March 14 were 11 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board in the following listing of percentage changes from like periods of 1952:

WITH THE FIRST MARINE AIRCRAFT WING IN KOREA, March 18 -- Baseball jargon has taken on a new meaning for Jerry Coleman, former Yankee second baseman who is flying with the Marines in Korea. When he mentions "strikes," he means combat operations against Red positions.

Permissive incorporation for member firms of the American Stock Exchange was virtually assured yesterday by unanimous vote of the board of governors. A constitutional amendment is being sent to the members, who will have two weeks to vote on it. If approved it will become effective on May 1, the same date set by the New York Stock Exchange.
Leaders of the Congress of Industrial Organizations have agreed on John V. Riffe, Southern organizing director, as the C. I. O.'s executive vice president, succeeding the late Allan S. Haywood.
ALBANY, March 19 -- Following is the text of a joint statement by Senator Arthur H. Wicks, majority leader of the State Senate, and Speaker Oswald D. Heck of the Assembly:

The dollar will buy more meat, fish and vegetables this week-end. Noting that sirloin and chuck steak prices had dropped to the lowest level in four years, the city Department of Markets reported yesterday that several other beef cuts as well as two of veal showed declines of 4 to 12 cents a pound.

LONDON, March 19 -- Economy cuts have reduced basic research in some government science departments in Britain to a "meager effort," Sir Ian Heilbron, chairman of the Department of Scientific and Industrial Research said today in his annual report.
MIAMI, Fla., March 19 -- The Dodgers took the odd game from the Senators, 4 -- 1, before 5,396 at Miami Stadium tonight and Preacher Roe should have had a shutout in the six innings he hurled.

NEW DELHI, India, March 19 -- The main mutually discriminatory practices that have prevented the growth of healthy trade relations between India and Pakistan will be removed in a few days as the result of a conference now concluding here between official delegations of both governments.

Future prices closed irregular yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges with sales generally light. The domestic sugar and rubber markets had good volume, and hides and coffee were moderately active. Sugar, hides, cocoa, cottonseed, oil and soybean oil were mixed.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 19 -- The sentencing at Mahagi, in the northeastern Congo, of thirty natives to various terms of penal servitude for burning buildings on farms owned by whites as part of the activities of a secret society called Rotanga raised issues here among various institutions and establishments that keep constant watch on developments among natives in the African continent.
Department of Commerce proposals to standardize all women's apparel sizes brought a loud and decisive "No!" from leaders of the New York garment industry yesterday.

The preliminary earnings statement of the National Container[ Corporation for 1952, released , 'es- I terday, showed a net income of] $3,812,000, equal to $1.17 a comL mon share. This compares with! $8,617,796, or $3.09 a share, a yeas' earlier.
