WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, said today that he thought that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation should be abolished.

ALBANY, March 19 -- The State Adjutant General's office has been notified that Congress has approved Federal recognition for two brigadier generals of the New York National Guard, Maj. Gen. Karl F. Hausauer, commander of the state guard, said today.

The State of Massachusetts sold yesterday $39,113,000 of bonds for various purposes to a banking syndicate headed by National City Bank of New York and the First Boston Corporation at a bid of 100.26 for 1.90s. Other bids were: First National Bank of Chicago, 100.22 for 1.90s, and Chase National Bank, 100.13 for 1.90's.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The resignation of Dillon S. Myer, Commissioner of Indian Affairs since May, 1950, has been accepted by President Eisenhower to become effective tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- A plan for establishing the Office of Defense Mobilization on a permanent basis and entrusting that agency with the programming of economic and industrial mobilization moves to be made in event of war has won White House approval and is expected to be sent to Congress for action next week.

GUATEMALA, March 19 -- The United Fruit Company was officially notified today that the Supreme Court had denied its appeal against the Government's expropriation of 233,973 acres of the company's Pacific holdings. The ruling leaves the company no other legal recourse.

The item in THE TIMES about jaywalking shows, no doubt, a commendable preoccupation on the part of the authorities for the life and limb of the citizens, but there is another aspect of the traffic problem.

Operations last year of Foremost Dairies, Inc., resulted in new highs in gross sales and pre-tax earnings, according to the annual report of Paul E. Reinhold, president, mailed to stockholders yesterday. Sales rose to $87,044,618 from the 1951 volume of $58,538,075 and profit before taxes climbed to '$4,434,305 :from $2,969,093. ' ' '

The Board of Education suspended its bylaws yesterday to permit 8,000 teachers, supervisors and clerks of the Jewish faith to observe Rosh ha-Shanah holy days in September without loss of pay. The Jewish New Year falls on Sept. 10 and 11, when these employes ordinarily would be registering children for the fall term.

Eleven artists collaborated last night to see that the works on the program presented by the International Society for Contemporary Music received skillful, thoughtful performances. The event, the second of a series of three, was held at the Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19 -- Problems? Casey Stengel has problems that seven other American League managers would like to have. At Lang Field today, 3,928 fans watched the Yankees down the Cardinals, 3 -- 1, and when the contest was completed, Casey carried a worried expression to the clubhouse.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- The forthcoming plan might provide the National Security Council with a better civilian-military basis, it was said, but it will seek "nothing drastic" in the way of personnel changes. President Eisenhower makes more use of the council than did President Truman.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 19 -- Mr. Willie of the Duntreath Farm ably ridden by Jimmy Stout, was the winner of the claiming race that was the nominal feature at the Gulfstream track today. The triumph was unexpected, for the straight return of the 6-year-old son of Sir Lancelot was $28.60 for $2.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- A Senate committee voted today to report to the Senate the nomination of Edward F. Howrey, Washington attorney, to be a member of the Federal Trade Commission.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 19 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark, the United States Commander in the Far East, arrived by plane today from Manila for a four-day visit to Indo-China. His arrival drew new attention to Asia's second biggest shooting war, a war that the French - Vietnamese forces have been fighting for seven years against Ho Chi Minh's Communist-led Vietminh troops.

LONDON, March 19 (AP) -- Walter Cartier, American middleweight who was the principal in the controversial fight with Randy Turpin last Tuesday, lost his license to fight in Great Britain for three months today and had 1,000 ($2,800) deducted from his purse.

In an action that should go far to determine the future destiny of Europe, the Bonn Bundestag, the decisive lower house of the West German Parliament, has now ratified two international compacts which place West Germany squarely in the camp of the Western World and provide the keys to both further European unification and an adequate Western defense.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 19 -- Associate Professor Abraham Glasser of the Rutgers University Law School, who clashed repeatedly yesterday with the House Un-American Activities Committee, which is investigating Communist infiltration into American schools and colleges, was suspended today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 19 -- At about 11:30 this morning, Jose Vela Zanetti put aside his pipe, took his brush and wrote his name in the corner of a sixty-foot-long mural that he had been painting for five months on the third floor of the conference building at the United Nations.

Refusing to give up its football team without a fight, New York University's only daily newspaper, The Heights News, yesterday initiated a series of articles on an imaginary marble team which is intended to replace the gridiron squad.

PARIS, March 19 (AP) -- Pablo Picasso said today that he just couldn't understand the official Communist criticism of his portrait of Stalin. But Louis Aragon, the poet, said he had made a mistake in using the portrait in his weekly paper.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- Two lawyers differed sharply today over whether a former Washington society editor was hired in a tax fraud case because she supposedly had influence with Representative Sam Rayburn, Democrat of Texas, then Speaker of the House of Representatives.

The termination of Drew Pearson's broadcasts -- he is already finished on the DuMont television network and will leave the A. B. C. radio network on March 29 -- has raised once again the question of balance in commentary heard on the air.

A first mortgage of $1,250,000 was placed by the Sonnenblick-Goldman Corporation, brokers, on the fifteen-story apartment house at 1178 Madison Avenue, the west blockfront between East Eighty-sixth and Eighty-seventh Streets, for Bond Fromer, owners.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 19 -- A dangerous problem is arising in Washington from efforts of the Eisenhower Administration to deny to newsmen access to department heads and aides from whom they formerly had gained background information, Stephen A. Mitchell, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said here today.
TRUMANSBURG, N. Y., March 19 (AP) -- A plane plowed into the main street here today, killing both occupants, one a General Mills vice president and the other his assistant.

The way defendants in the investment banking anti-trust trial shifted in rank in the trade's standing of negotiated underwritten business shows that they were motivated by competition, not by the non-competitive conspiracy charged against them, defense counsel argued yesterday.

An alteration involving $90,000 on the store building at 437-439 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Thirty-ninth Street, is among plans filed with the Department of Housing and Buildings. Lindley House, Inc., of 562 Fifth Avenue is the owner and Sapolsky Slobodien are the architects.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 19 -- With Vivien Leigh on the way home to England by plane to undergo treatment for an "acute nervous breakdown," Paramount Pictures has arranged with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to borrow Elizabeth Taylor to take over the British star's role in "Elephant Walk."

LONDON, March 19 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler's optimism over Britain's eocnomic situation helped the securities market in general and British Government securities in particular to maintain a firm front today.

THOUSANDS of shooters interested in the "idea" of bench-rest shooting, but who hesitate at the rather steep investment involved in putting together a special bench-rest rifle, probably would enter these shoots if the proposed "light rifle" classification was approved by the National Bench Rest Shooter Association for local matches.

In February the average share on the New York Stock Exchange lost 44 cents in value, dropping from $43 on Jan. 31 to $42.56 on Feb. 28, the Exchange reported yesterday. This 1.1 per cent decline contrasted with a 2.3 per cent decline in the leading industrials and rails represented in THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average.

Christopher O'Malley, baritone, who made his recital debut at Town Hall last evening, is a native of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., and studied at the Juilliard School. He continued his vocal studies at the Paris Conservatory and during the last two and a half years has sung 150 recitals in Europe, as well as appearing with orchestras and chamber music groups.

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, Guido Cantelli conducting, John Corigliano, violinist, Laszlo Varga, 'celist, Leonid Hambro, pianist, Adolph Anderson, narrator, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; "Der Rosenkavalier," Metropolitan Opera, 8; "Carmen," City Center, 8:15; Liederkranz Society of New York, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Frank Martori, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 19 -- Mme. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, sister of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India, failed tonight to obtain a Security Council recommendation for her selection as Secretary General of the United Nations. She received two votes, one against, and eight abstentions.

Abolition of "artificial distinctions" between cases that may be disposed of by Supreme Court, City Court and Municipal Court justices wag urged last night by President Justice William Lyman of the Municipal Court.

The program of the concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Guido Cantelli guest conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall, was a hodgepodge. It opened wittily enough with Mozart's "Musicalischer Spass" -- the "musical joke," as it has been misnamed.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 19 -- Jimmy McLane, who won twelve national titles and an Olympic crown before he entered Yale four years ago, tonight captured his first collegiate swimming championship.

A "Dear Joe" letter of support from Governor Dewey to Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., was made public last night by Mr. Ryan's attorney a few hours after he had lost a court effort to keep the union leader's accounting records and his union's books from a New York County grand jury investigating waterfront racketeering.

Long-term United States Government bond prices could find nowhere to go on their own yesterday, so dealers marked them down -- this time to new lows. Corporate bonds of long maturity likewise sagged in price, especially new issues of public utility and industrial obligations not fully seasoned in the market.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- President Eisenhower outlined today a policy of conciliation plus strength as the best means of defending the republic.
If you hear a provocative low whistle, it's a woman and if you hear "Hi Doc," it's bound to be a man who is walking into the New York headquarters of the United Seamen's Service.

Delta Air Lones has given a new twist to contests. To promote its "millionaire dream vacations" in Miami Beach it will give a prize a week for eight weeks preceding June 12 to the man or woman who has spent eight days and seven nights on its packaged tour and who writes the best fifty words in praise of Miami Beach and the tour.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- Representative Richard M. Simpson, Republican of Pennsylvania, today was elected chairman of the Republican Congressional Committee and promptly began planning for the 1954 Congressional campaign.

GENEVA, March 19 -- The drive for expansion in the centers of Communist power and the Communist conviction that all peoples must choose between two systems of which one, their own, must end by destroying the other are "in fact today the principal obstacles to the re-establishment of peace," Max Petitpierre, Swiss Foreign Minister, said yesterday in a major foreign policy address to the Swiss Parliament in Bern.

LONDON, March 19 -- A society that had its inception in a conversation between two Americans and an Englishman in the smoking room of the Carlton Hotel in London in 1902, The Pilgrims of Great Britain celebrated its fiftieth anniversary tonight with a dinner in honor of Winthrop W. Aldrich, the new United States Ambassador to London.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on March 14 were 700,108 cars, the Association of Amerlcan Railroads announced today This was 15,092 cars, or 2.2 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 8,867 cars, or 1.3 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 45,020 cars, or 6 per cent, fewer than in the same week two years ago.

Pressing Theatrical Problem That sententious saying to the effect that every question has two sides is not always true, as many old saws are not, but surely it is true when applied to questions pertaining to a number of theatrical problems, and especially to the problem of employment (or unemployment) in the theatre.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 19 -- Theodore H. Parker, The Hartford Courant's veteran drama critic, said that he had been barred from tonight's opening of Clifford Odets' play, "The Country Girl," at the New Parsons Theatre.

CHICAGO, March 19 -- The largest bookings of corn to arrive in a long time headed off advances in the corn market, but nevertheless there was surprising buying resistance. The country sold about 1,000,000 bushels corn, which entailed hedge pressure and modified bullishness.

Waiter Klem has been appointed senior vice president and actuary of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States and Alvin B. Dalager and Charles W. Dow have been appointed senior vice presidents, Ray D. Murphy, president, announced yesterday.

Plans are well under way for a "Nightcap" supper party to be held in the Rendez-Vous of the Plaza after the performance on the night of April 13 at the Shubert Theatre of "The Love of Four Colonels,'" which has been taken over to augment the Finch College Building Fund.

In the season's third "Samson et Dalila," last night at the Metropolitan Opera, the leading female role was sung by Blanche Thebom for the first time this year. Kurt Baum, who was to have been the Samson, was indisposed, and Ramon Vinay again sang the part.

ALBANY, March 19 -- The Legislature fixed 2 P. M. Saturday as the adjournment time for the regular 1953 session, which began Jan. 7, and with this objective in view today waded through scores of bills.

Borrowing for tax purposes pushed commercial loans from New Yok banks $109,000,000 higher in the week ended on Wednesday. The advance, which compared with a gain of $65,000,000 in the similar week last year, brought the expansion since the start of this year to $7,000,000, against an increase of $11,000,000 ayear ago.

The Board of Estimate's rejection of the Dewey transit authority plan represents the politics-as-usual approach to city government that has pauperized municipal services. The decision to proceed, instead, with a meat-cleaver "economy" program in the transit system, based on a ridiculous demand that the Board of Transportation come back at once with savings of approximately $50,000,000, is typical of a childish, cut-off-the-nose-to-save-the-face policy that dominates the city administration in its relations with the state.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today announced dismissal of price-fixing charges against the Vitrified China Association, Inc., of Washington, and fourteen chinaware manufacturers.

It is unfortunate that the highly regarded Citizens Housing and Planning Council of New York, through its able executive vice president, Ira S. Robbins, should at this time oppose the passage of the housing bill legalizing certain cellar and basement apartment now deemed illegal under the Multiple Dwelling Law.
MILWAUKEE, March 19 (AP) -- A seven-day celebration of Milwaukee Braves Week, starting April 8, was planned today as a welcome to the city's new National League baseball team.
SEATTLE, March 19 (AP) -- Two months ago Seattle University's Johnny O'Brien told folks: Eddie and I are going for the little ball," and they did just that today with the usual O'Brien flourish.

The New Haven Railroad's new, Diesel-electric powered tugboat, Cordelia, went down the ways of Jakobson's Oyster Bay shipyard yesterday and soon will take her place with nine other harbor vessels, shepherding car-floats from the company's Bronx terminal to Brooklyn and Jersey City railheads.

ALBANY, March 19 -- The City of New York withdrew today from the State Conference of Mayors because the executive secretary voted as a member of a special committee headed by Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore to approve a restriction on the city's right to use the full amount of any increase in constitutional taking power on real estate.

United Aircraft Corporation's sales increased 60 per cent last year, compared with those of 1951, and net income was up about 26 per cent, the annual report of the aeronautical manufacturing concern showed yesterday.

The disturbing spread of a new type of eye disease, retrolental fibroplasia, which now causes more infant blindness in the United States than any other, was described yesterday, at the annual conference of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness.

PURCHASE, N. Y., March 19 -- A plane that not only leads a double life but spends a large part of its existence "shooting landings" with no human being at its controls is based here at Westchester County Airport.

The local opening date of "Horses in Midstream," previously scheduled for April 16, has been advanced to April 2, when it will be presented at the Royale. The foregoing details were confirmed yesterday by Gilbert Miller, co-sponsor, in Washington, where the Andrew Rosenthal comedy began a two-week engagement Tuesday night.
After a sixty-day trial period, the Civil Defense Advisory Commission decided yesterday to lift permanently the ban on the use of sirens on city ambulances and Police and Fire Department vehicles.

There's a new millinery feeling in the hats that Otto Lucas of London showed to members of the press yesterday at the Plaza Hotel. They have a slightly more important appearance than those seen in recent seasons, yet, paradoxically, they are featherweight.

Optimism over the business outlook is exaggerated, Dr. Jules Backman, Professor of Economics at New York University, said yesterday at the annual meeting of the Textile Fabrics Association at the Statler Hotel.
ALBANY, March 19 -- Following is a digest of the major provisions of the legislation dealing with New York City's fiscal problems, including excerpts from the measures:

The second in a series of basketball play-off games between the New York Knickerbockers and the Baltimore Bullets will be televised over Channel 11 tonight beginning at 9 o'clock. Radio station WMGM also will broadcast the game from the Baltimore Coliseum.

Mr. Eisenhower's press conference yesterday gave us the picture of a President sure of certain things and trying to make up his mind about others. He was sure the Government could not or should not cut taxes without first cutting expenditures. He wasn't sure what expenditures for defense should be.

MIAMI, Fla., March 19 -- Nothing in recent years has stirred up more conversational winds in Florida than Charlie Dressen's announced move to make a utility infielder out of Billy Cox. The first reaction everywhere was a rather rude: "The guy must be nuts." But the longer folks thought about it the more they warmed up to the idea.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 19 -- Miss Catharine Schaefer of the World Union of Catholic Women failed today in a move for deletion from a resolution on equal rights for men and women before the Commission on the Status of Women of a reference to the "dissolution" of marriage.
Carmine Nappa's one-man picket line in front of the Bethlehem Steel Company shipyard at Twenty-seventh Street in Brooklyn was called off yesterday, and work was resumed.
BONN, Germany, March 19 -- West Germany took a decisive step toward arms and equality in a United Europe tonight when its Bundestag ratified the Allied-German treaties.

TOKYO, Friday, March 20 -- The Chinese Communist Command sent two companies against United States Marine positions on the western front in Korea yesterday. The Marines chopped up both attacks and in return launched a raid with flamethrowers against an enemy outpost, burned out the foe's bunkers and entrenchments and put the Chinese Reds to flight.

BERLIN, March 19 -- Gen. Vassily I. Chuikov, chairman of the Soviet Control Commission, in a note made public tonight expressed regret that seven British fliers had died as a result of the shooting down of a Royal Air Force plane by Soviet jets March 12 but clung to his contention that the Britons were in the wrong.

A prosperous business man whose pinched childhood in the slums of the Lower East Side was brightened by the Henry Street Settlement House, expressed his gratitude yesterday with a check for $1,000 to the settlement in honor of its sixtieth anniversary.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 19 -- The Soviet Union dismissed today as "artificial" the United States' day-old challenge that the new regime in Moscow prove its peaceful intentions by taking another look at the West's disarmament proposals.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 19 -- With rain keeping both his first and second teams idle, Leo Durocher was able to bring all his Giant forces under one roof today, but the explosion which this event had threatened to bring about never developed.

NEW DELHI, India, Friday, March 20 -- Mr. Bowles and embassy aides were mystified today at testimony that Mr. Bowles had urged the Voice of America to tone down anti-Communist broadcasts to India. Mr. Bowles said comments on the Voice to the State Department from here were almost entirely confined to criticism that the programs were virtually worthless in this area because of the nearly impossible reception caused by technical difficulties.

BIELEFELD, Germany, March 19 (AP) -- Three former Nazi officials, arrested by the British two months ago on suspicion of plotting against the Bonn Government, lost their bid for freedom today in the British High Court.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 19 (UP) -- A collection of papers dealing with the Lewis and Clark Northwest Expedition 150 year ago has been found in an attic here, the State Historical Society announced today.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, declared last night that he was unalterably opposed to establishment of a Transit Authority to take over the city's transit lines, as proposed by legislation sponsored by Governor Dewey, or any increase in the 10-cent fare.

GROTON, Conn., March 19 -- Twenty-three volunteers, who have been sealed in the hull of the fleet submarine Haddock since Jan. 19, in an effort to help Navy scientists find out how much carbon dioxide can be tolerated, climbed out of the Haddock today, their test mission successfully completed.
As 300 persons looked on, Mayor Impellitteri yesterday administered the oath of office to three Brooklyn men named by him Wednesday to court posts.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan announced yesterday that within two months the police would be embarked upon a new training program in "up-to-date ways of getting along with minority groups with the least degree of friction."

VIENNA, March 19 -- President Klement Gottwald of Czechoslovakia was carried to his last resting place in Prague today to the sound of Russian military music. An escort of Czech soldiers marched in Russian parade step and carried Russian machine pistols.

HAVANA, March 19 -- Cuba is suffering from a sharp economic recession and the Government should adopt a tax policy that would be an incentive for investments of foreign capital, according to Dr. Gustavo Gutierrez, president of the National Board of Economy.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Charles P. Arnot has resigned as director of the State Department's International Press Service, a unit of the International Information Administration. He submitted his resignation yesterday and it was accepted and made effective at the close of business last night.

The bedroom, which, compared to the kitchen and living room, has been somewhat neglected in surveys and discussions over the last few months, was the subject of a luncheon meeting held by McCall's magazine this week in the Park Lane Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- From the night last spring when President Truman announced he would not accept renomination the Democrats who sought to succeed him and the party organization after Governor Stevenson was chosen bought all the time they could on television.
The 32-year-old National Health Council is split by a bitter internal controversy with the American Medical Association, a member organization.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 19 -Virgil D. Dardi of this city, president of Blair Holdings Corporation, and ten other directors of the organization were accused of "gross mismanagement" of its affairs in a suit filed in Federal District Court here today by Giuseppe Schnone of San Francisco, a stockholder.

Contrary to the viewpoint taken by THE NEW YORK TIMES, it is a firm conviction of the author of this letter and of other well-informed American citizens of Eastern European origin that the proposed draft resolution of the executive branch of the Government condemning the violation of the war-time agreements and understandings of the Soviet empire is contrary to the interests of the United States.

Medals and cash prizes for the daring rescues of five persons in danger of drowning were presented yesterday to seven New York policemen at Police Headquarters by William D. Winter, president of the Life Saving Benevolent Association of New York.

Looking into the corners of his heart, Tennessee Williams has written a strange and disturbing drama. "Camino Real" he calls it. It was played with great skill and ingenuity at the National last evening. Since "Camino Real" is a kind of cosmic fantasy, one must not interpret it literally.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, New York, proposed tonight that the universities investigate Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin. The suggestion was made at a dinner session of the fifth annual Conference on Civil Liberties of the National Civil Liberties Clearing House.
A sophisticated Easter wardrobe for little girls was displayed yesterday at a fashion show in Jensen's new children's shop at 682 Fifth Avenue.

DETROIT, March 19 (UP) -- Gordie Howe scored twice tonight to move within one goal of the National Hockey League season scoring record as the Detroit Red Wings defeated the Boston Bruins, 6 to 1, at Olympia.

The Pennsylvania Railroad had a net income last year of $36,981,364 after charges and taxes, or $2.81 a share. This compared with $26,697,717 or $2.03 a share in 1951. Walter S. Franklin, president, attributed the improvement in earnings to a better control over expenses and greater efficiency resulting from the modern equipment now in use.

CAIRO, March 19 -- Egypt and the United States signed today an agreement launching the biggest single Point Four project undertaken so far in the Middle East. By reclaiming 20,000 feddans of marshland [a feddan is 1.038 acres] in the Nile Delta province of Beheira and 60,000 feddans of desert wasteland in Fayum province, sixty-five miles south of here, the project aims to provide farms for 16,000 landless families.

Jerry-building the payroll taxes has caused the entire wage structure to get out of kilter and any more top stories on the rickety structure will cause the leaning tower to topple over. We now have four standard payroll deductions: Social Security, unemployment insurance, withholding tax and disability insurance.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., March 19 -- Newspapers are the ideal media to use when launching a new product backed by a small ad budget. This was the theme of a demonstration here today at the second day's sessions of the forty-fourth spring meeting of the Association of National Advertisers in the Homestead.
PHILADELPHIA, March 19 -- Prickly Pete, a famous Philadelphian who loathed his fellow-citizens, is dead.

Miracles, as far as the Boston Braves are concerned, have been hard to come by since 1914, when their team captured the world championship and the imagination of the entire baseball world. That was the year when George Stallings' team rose from last place late in the season to beat the Athletics in four straight games of the world series.

One hundred and ten insurance companies in the downtown area were honored with a special certificate of merit yesterday for their contributions of 2,500 pints of blood last year to the regional program of the Red Cross.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 19 -- Leroy F. Ball, president of King Cigar Company, Flint, Mich., was elected president of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors at the twenty-first annual convention here today at Convention Hall.

J. Sellers Bancroft has been appointed vice president and secretary of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Bancroft is vice president of the Wilmington Trust Company, Wilmington, Del.
The basic potential of the Port of New York remains sound despite the impact of frightening and "repulsive" disclosures by recent and current inquiries, Mayor Impellitteri said last night.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Two officials of the Voice of America told the Senate Permanent Investigating subcommittee today that Chester Bowles, then Ambassador to India, requested last year that anti-Communist counter-propaganda broadcasts to that country be "toned down."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 19 -- With an estimated 40,000,000 persons looking on with television, Hollywood personalities tonight jammed the Pantages Theatre at the famous movietown crossroads of Hollywood Boulevard and Vine Street for the twenty-fifth annual awards ceremony of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 19 -- The United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund received new promises of financial aid today from Britain, Canada and half a dozen smaller countries, but no indication of hoped-for support from the United States, which always has been the biggest donor to the six-year-old welfare enterprise.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 19 -- Dissatisfaction with United States treatment of Brazil has boiled up in soma leading groups here to a pitch unequaled in recent years. The reason is not clear but some United States observers feel it is at least partly an effort to find an excuse for the financial and economic muddle that has been allowed to develop here.

GONEN, Turkey, March 19 -- Reports late today by the Red Crescent, the Turkish Red Cross, put the toll in yesterday's earthquake in Canakkale and Balikesir Provinces at 535 known dead, and nearly 50,000 homeless. [Istanbul newspapers put the death toll at 1,000, The Associated Press said.

ALBANY, March 19 -- The Legislature today passed unanimously without debate a Dewey Administration bill authorizing the State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles to issue a uniform "nonfixable" traffic ticket for use by police officers and courts throughout the state.

PARIS, March 19 -- Today's ratification of the European Army treaty by the Bundestag of West Germany took place while France -- whose Government proposed the single army plan -- was engaged in a confused debate on the treaty of which the French public is still incompletely informed.

Plans for altering the nine-story and penthouse apartment building at 168 East Seventy-fourth Street into smaller suites were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase of the property by Henry Goelet, realty investor and builder, from the Niki Realty Corporation.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- President Eisenhower announced today the designation of Lewis W. Douglas, former Under Secretary of the Treasury and former Ambassador to Britain, as head of a study group to re-examine the nation's foreign economic policy and recommend changes required to strengthen the free world.

Johnny Bratton of Chicago, anxious to obtain a return bout with Kid Gavilan for the welterweight crown, will face Bobby Jones of Oakland, Calif., in the ten-round feature at Madison Square Garden tonight.
PINEHURST, N. C., March 19 (AP) -- Favorites swept through the sixteen first-round matches today in the fifty-first North and South women's championship golf tournament.

Middle South Utilities, Inc., plans to offer to stockholders next month the right to subscribe to one share of common stock for each fourteen held. The company filed a registration statement yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering the 475,000-share offering, which it expects will become effective on or about April 8.

Miss Leigh departed from the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday for London. Miss Leigh's health broke recently in Hollywood where she was continuing work on "Elephant Walk," most of which had been filmed in Ceylon.

ROME, March 19 -- Pope Pius XII was judged to be well on the way to complete recovery by about 5,000 persons whom he received today in the second public audience he had granted since he fell ill exactly eight weeks ago.

Twenty-six members of the Department of Sanitation received medals of valor yesterday for performing heroic acts while on duty. The awards were presented by Mayor Impellitteri at a ceremony at City Hall that was attended by 400 relatives, friends and co-workers of the recipients.

ALBANY, March 19 -- Seven of the eight bills in the Dewey Administration's fiscal program for the City of New York were approved in both the Senate and Assembly today, and now go to the Governor for his signature.

Stockholders of First Boston Corporation approved yesterday a change in the charter of the investment banking company which would permit the business to join directly in developing oil and mineral leases.

A second stevedoring company official was indicted yesterday on charges that he had conspired with two accountants to falsify business records to conceal from the State Crime Commission illicit payments to three dock union delegates for their "goodwill."
We make a final appeal to the New York Legislature to redeem itself as a servant of the public interest by voting compulsory liability insurance for automobile owners before it adjourns this session.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 19 (AP) -- The civil defense test house, 3,500 feet away from 'Tuesday's atomic blast, was blown apart in two and one-third seconds, spectacular pictures released by the Atomic Energy Commission showed today.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- More than 100 members of faculties of California schools and colleges have been removed since last June for alleged Communist activities or affiliations, Richard E. Combs, chief counsel of the California Senate Committee on Un-American Activities, testified today.

CLEVELAND, March 19 -- Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, president of Barnard College of Columbia University, sharply criticized tonight the "almost psychopathic fear of Russia" that she said was prevalent throughout the country and had resulted in the stifling of a free exchange of ideas.

After nine days of successive advances the stock market declined yesterday, apparently on the basis of two news developments. Trading was irregular, with almost as many stocks rising as falling in price, but the standard issues that enter into market measures were under pressure.

LONDON, March 19 -- President Tito of Yugoslavia devoted himself today to conversations with senior British ministers which are expected to result in a declaration this week that Britain and Yugoslavia will assist each other in maintaining peace and security in souteasthern Europe.

WASHINGTON, March 4 19 (UP) -- Senator Margaret Chase Smith announced today that her Armed Services subcommittee would open its ammunition investigation next week with televised questioning of Gen. James A. Van Fleet. The Maine Republican said the group would "focus attention on Korea" for the present, perhaps turning to Europe and other areas later.

UNION, N. J., March 19 -- Northern New Jersey Mayors were urged here tonight to cooperate with the air transport industry in its efforts to eliminate the problems of low flying and noise at the Newark Airport.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -A Government farm survey indicated today that farmers plan to plant large enough acreages to food, livestock feed, fiber and other crops to produce a record volume this year if weather conditions are favorable.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- President Eisenhower voiced his opposition anew today to any tax cut before spending reductions and announced he would ask Congress for substitute revenues if the excess-profits levy were permitted to expire on schedule June 30.

OTTAWA, March 19 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's trade with the United States on outstanding securities resulted in a record Canadian purchase balance of $92,400,000 in 1952, the Bureau of Statistics reported today. This compared with a small $5,700,000 purchase balance in 1951 and a peak sales balance of $255,700,000 in 1950.

Gilbert Harrison, new publisher of the New Republic magazine and one of the founders of the American Veterans Committee, was elected a member of the executive committee of Volunteers in Politics at a meeting last night at the Delmonico Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (UP) -- The Senate Finance Committee sought today to trim the authority of Senator John J. Williams to expose tax scandals, and the Delaware Republican promptly turned thumbs down on the proposal.
CHICAGO, March 19 (UP) -- A child's happiness depends to a great degree upon whether the parents had a happy childhood, a psychologist said yesterday.

BOSTON, March 19 -- A group of Boston University faculty members and students has protested to Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Speaker of the House of Representatives, on the "perversion of Congressional committees proper activity," a spokesman said today.

CHICAGO, March 19 -- Two more stories of friction between Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of General Motors Corporation, and the du Ponts were put in the record of the anti-trust trial in Federal District Court today as the defense continued a rebuttal of Government charges that Mr. Sloan was subservient to alleged du Pont domination.
Lamb is as much a delicious tradition of spring as fresh asparagus, and it is inevitable at this season that cooks, amateur and professional, should turn their attention to it.

In two of the current art exhibitions, artists take long looks at the American scene. That their pictorial reports differ is not due solely to their preference for dissimilar scenes. In his water-colors at the Ferargil, Bernard Shirley Carter Jr. devotes his attention to land and sea on Cape Cod, while Staats Coatsworth's pictures at the Hammer Galleries deal with the more sullen quarters of big cities.

TRENTON, March 19 -- Representative Clifford P. Case announced this morning his withdrawal from the Republican race for Governor and notified the Secretary of State of New Jersey of his action. The decision of the veteran member of Congress from Rahway reduced to two the major contenders for the top position on the Republican state ticket.

NAPLES, Italy, March 19 (AP) -- Organization plans for the new North Atlantic Treaty Organization Naval command to be known as Naval Striking and Support Forces Southern Europe, or Strike for South, in abbreviated form, were announced today at the headquarters of United States Admiral Robert B. Carney.

Bela Bartok's "Bluebeard's Castle" and Maurice Ravel's "L'Heure Espagnole," which opened the spring season of opera at the City Center last night, have certain attributes to recommend their being a double bill. Though their subject matter, ways of love, is much the same, their mood is so much in contrast that they complement each other.

TOPEKA, Kan., March 19 -- Alvin McCoy, Kansas correspondent of The Kansas City Star, swore under oath today that Gov. Edward F. Arn had testified untruthfully in an effort to attack the press and divert public attention from a "sorry" affair involving C. Wesley Roberts, chairman of the Republican National Committee.

Three Roman Catholic Bishops served luncheon yesterday to hundreds of elderly persons in three homes for the aged operated by the Little Sisters of the Poor. Each March 19, in memory of St. Joseph, patron saint of the order, prominent Catholic clergymen and laymen visit the order's houses throughout the world.

Hiram C. Bloomingdale, son of a founder of Bloomingdale Brothers department store, left the bulk of his estate of more than $5,000,000 in trust for the benefit of his family, it was disclosed yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court.

Directors of Aluminium Ltd. approved yesterday in Montreal a proposal to offer shareholders rights to subscribe for additional shares in the company at the rate of one share far each ten shares held. It was proposed that 818,657 additional shares be issued at a price not to exceed $37.50 (Canadian) a share or alternatively, at the option of each subscriber, the equivalent in United States dollars on the date on which the price is determined.

Victor Clemente, central figure in the Queens sewer construction inquiry, was named yesterday in a superseding indictment handed up by the holdover June, 1952, Queens Grand Jury as having "bribed" a dismissed city engineer. The true bill said the contractor had built a $250 house connection with the city sewer for Gerard J. Brinkman at 86-24 Palermo Street, Hollis, Queens, without charge.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The formation of a national committee for equal pay was announced today. Its purpose is to eliminate wage differentials between men and women through education, collective bargaining and Federal and state legislation.

Minot Frazier (Mickey) Jelke, heir to an oleomargarine fortune, was sentenced yesterday in Special Sessions to an eight-month workhouse term on his plea of guilty to violating the Sullivan Law by possessing two revolvers.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 20 (AP) -- A review of Clifford Odets' play, "The Country Girl," in today's edition of The Hartford Courant consists of about a quarter of a column of blank newsprint on the second page.

Stockholders of the Toledo Edison Company will be asked at their annual meeting on April 21 to approve two amendments to the utility's articles of incorporation. Both amendments are designed to provide greater flexibility in financing a four-year expansion amounting to $51,850,000, Charles E. Ide, the president, said yesterday.

ST PETERSBURG, Fla., March 20 -- One can't knock a winning performance -- the Yankees turned back the Phillies today, 8-3 -- but the jury is still out, deliberating the merits of the pitching by Allie Reynolds and Ewell Blackwell. Tom Gorman hurled the last two innings in workmanlike fashion at Al Lang Field.

Consideration of higher tariffs on such products as dehydrated garlic powder, dehydrated kibbled onions, onion powder and mustard seed will come up soon for Government action, according to trade-association information distributed yesterday to importers.

Loyalty to the Soviet Union was the main theme of the three speeches delivered in Prague on Thursday when Klementon Gottwald was buried. Soviet Marshal Bulganin found Gottwald's main merit in the fact that he had coined the phrase "with the Soviet Union forever," while Czechoslovakia's Premier and Deputy Premier essentially echoed the same thought and swore to continue the dead gauleiter's policy.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today that the Government had received no "great comfort" from the recent talk of peace by Soviet Premier Georgi M. Malenkov and other Soviet leaders.

Serious conflict can be stirred in the mind of a child who is encouraged to express himself freely in art at home but must conform to standardized methods of teaching at school, Mrs. Marion F. T. Johnson, head of the educational program of the Delaware Art Center, Wilmington, Del., said yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 20 -- France, Australia, Canada and Uruguay urged the Soviet Union today to demonstrate the peaceful intentions of the new regime in Moscow by agreeing to examine the long-standing Western proposals for disarmament.

MOSCOW, Saturday, March 21 -- Premier Georgi M. Malenkov has relinquished, at his own request, his post as a secretary of the Communist party, and a plenary meeting of the party's Central Committee has elected a new five-member Secretariat.

LONDON, March 20 -- Britain disclosed today that she had offered to the Iranian Government a twenty-year easy payment plan for paying compensation for the nationalization of the British-owned oil industry in Iran.

Stalled for the last few weeks because of a major casting problem, "Masquerade," the comedy by L. S. Birchard and Jeroam Stagg, is now moving fast toward Broadway with the engagement of Charles Korvin for a starring role.

The new State Department directive concerning the use of Communist material for overseas propaganda purposes brings us practically right back where we started from six weeks ago. It is on the whole a reasonable directive, permitting the various agencies of the International Information Administration (I. I. A.) to make appropriate use of the writings or statements of Communists to "expose Communist propaganda or refute Communist lies."

The six-story apartment house accommodating thirty-six families at 1701-1705 Dorchester - ad in Brooklyn has been purchased for investment by the Elroad Holding Corporation. Julius A. Siegel and Frank Wolk were the sellers. Hussey Hoeh were the brokers and the attorneys were Louis Kaplan for the buyer and Joseph H. Sand for the sellers.

TOKYO, March 20 -- More than 2,000 Japanese men, women and children left Communist China for their homeland today, ending years of exile on foreign soil. It was the first contingent of an estimated total of 30,000 Japanese civilians who are expected to return to Japan in the next few months after having been stranded on the Chinese mainland at least since the end of World War II.
Employes of Time and Life magazines and other concerns in the building at 9 Rockefeller Plaza contributed 460 pints of blood to the Red Cross bank in a three-day collection this week.
Mayor Impellitteri defended Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan yesterday against charges that he had condoned police brutality.
Real estate activity in Manhattan reported yesterday centered largely on the East Side.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Mrs. Hope Ridings Miller, a public relations agent with influential social contacts here, denied under oath today that she had taken $5,000 to help "fix" a $150,000 tax fraud case in 1950.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Mrs. Mary Jane Keeney, former employe of the State Department and of the United Nations, was fined $250 today and received a year's suspended sentence for contempt of Congress.
OAKLAND, Calif., March 20 -- A giant transport plane crashed and exploded south of here today, killing thirty-five crewmen and military personnel en route to the Far East.

The United States must strive to eradicate its "still excessively large" population of 2,500,000 illiterates to strengthen its military arm, enhance its economic well-being and spur democratic growth, a Columbia University research group reported yesterday.

BONN, Germany, March 20 -- A new investment program to prime the pump of West Germany's industrial expansion was announced today by the United States Mutual Security Agency in agreement with the West German Government.

TRENTON, March 20 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll was in a self-effacing mood today, admitting to newspaper men that he really knew very little about politics and was about to submit to a test for possible deficiency in his automobile driving ability.

In the death of Katharine Ludington the country has lost one of its outstanding leaders. Born eighty-three years ago, she was an active participant in the movements which have seen the United States take a place of leadership in world affairs.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 20 (UP) -- Fred Hawkins of El Paso, Tex., a comparatively unknown golfer amazed everyone -- including himself -- today by firing a sensational seven-under-par 65 to take the first-round lead in the $10,000 Jacksonville open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Republican leaders agreed today on a Senate schedule calling for beginning consideration next week of the offshore lands bill.

BALTIMORE, March 20 -- The New York Knickerbockers advanced to the semi-final round of the National Basketball Association play-offs by eliminating the Bullets, 90 to 81, in an exciting encounter before 2,500 at the Baltimore Coliseum tonight.

Mild weather and a fairly early Easter are a combination pleasing to merchants. Usually indicated is an upturn in sales, with cash registers operating at a faster clip as customers come in for new spring finery, the latest millinery, confection or a bunny to please the youngsters.

ALBANY, March 20 -- Governor Dewey accused Mayor Impellitteri and his associates on the Board of Estimate tonight of attempting a "shotgun" solution of New York City's transit problem. To block such a development, he urged the Legislature to take measures obviously designed to coerce the city administration into making use of the new transit authority legislation that was approved only yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 19 -- Throughout 1952 Latin-American countries continued to benefit from "a series of favorable factors" that raised their total production of goods and services to $38,000,000,000 at 1950 prices, according to an economic survey for 1951 and 1952, prepared by the Secretariat of the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America.

Yesterday ,the last day of winter and the first day of spring, was a day of seasons rolled into one. It was warm, it was cold, it was sunny, it was cloudy, it snowed, it rained and the wind blew and then the wind stopped.

Many dinner parties will be given in Louis Sherry's Salon at. the Metropolitan Opera House tonighti before the performance of "Borisi Godunov," which has been taken over for the benefit ef tile Scholarship Fund of thc Vassar Club of! New York.
LONDON, March 20 (UP) -- Following is the text of the communique issued from 10 Downing Street tonight on the British-Yugoslav talks:

Admiral William H. P. Blandy, retired, told the New York Naval Academy Graduates Association last night that he favored the "whole works," including use of the small, tactical atomic bomb, in the war in Korea.

Progress in cutting down eye injuries resulting from careless use of BB guns and other juvenile weapons was described yesterday at the closing session of the three-day annual conference of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness.
WASHINGTON, N. J., March 20 -- Ten members of one family were killed near here tonight when their new sedan crashed head-on with a trailer truck.

Simon W. Gerson, legislative representative of the Communist party, said yesterday that his party still believed in the concept of "proletarian revolution." He testified at a hearing conducted by a State Board of Regents committee, which is seeking to determine whether the Communist party is subversive and whether party members should be barred from employment in the public school system.

After several months of on-again, off-again negotiations, the Federal Government announced yesterday that it had leased the Grand Central Palace at 480 Lexington Avenue, for the Bureau of Internal Revenue, Third District.

A narcotics ring that imported 3,000 pounds of marijuana a year into the United States and retailed it at $25,000 a day has been smashed, it was announced yesterday with the opening in Federal Court of sealed indictments charging eight men and a woman with conspiracy to violate the narcotics laws.

The federal grand jury in this district is now trying to find out whether there was an agreement between Police Commissioner Monaghan and the Department of Justice that the F. B. I. would forgo their usual questioning of policemen in civil rights cases.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 20 -- United Nations delegates tasted fish flour today while they listened to the pioneering plans of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund to introduce the unfamiliar high-protein food- stuff in countries where chronic milk shortages cause malnutrition among children.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) The Senate confirmed today without debate the nomination of Robert D. Murphy of Wisconsin as an Assistant Secretary of State for United Nations Affairs. Mr. Murphy, a veteran diplomat, now is Ambassador to Japan.

CLEVELAND, March 20 (AP) -- Len Truex beat off a last-lap bid by Fred Wilt, the F. B. I. agent, and won the mile run at the Knights of Columbus track meet tonight. Warren Druetzler was third as Fred Dwyer, Villanova senior, finished far back in fourth for his first defeat this season.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. announced today the arrest for deportation of Gordon Abraham Barragher, Canadian-born official of Local 252, Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. The local has jurisdiction in Suffolk and Nassau Counties of New York.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 20 (Reuters) -- The head of the powerful Kenya African Union, Wycliffe Awori, demanded today that all British troops be withdrawn from the colony as the first major step toward ending the five-month-old Mau Mau emergency.

The advertising department of Harper and Atlantic Magazines is taking issue with Arthur W. Kohler, vice president and advertising director of the Curtis Publishing Company, who earlier this month held that the editorial type advertisement arouses resentment among readers.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., declared today that the union hiring hall "is the most important single labor relations device ever to be developed in the maritime industry," and that the Taft-Hartley Act "has operated to destroy it."
The American Cancer Society, largest organization in the country devoted to research, education and service in the field of cancer, has withdrawn from the National Health Council.

LONDON, March 20 -- The British Government has instructed its embassy in Washington to investigate charges that American manufacturers are imitating British silver hallmarks and registering them with the Patent Office as their own trade-marks, Henry Strauss, Parliamentary secretary to the Board of Trade, told the Commons today.

Ground will be broken in Brooklyn within the next few weeks for what is expected to be the nation's largest medical education center. It will be part of the State University's $20,000,000 medical facilities expansion program, which includes doubling the capacity of the College of Medicine at Syracuse.

Adjourned games were completed in the international chess masters tournament at Mar Del Plata yesterday, and Svetozar Gligoric tied Carlos E. Guimard of Argentina for the lead, according to a report from Buenos Aires.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., March 20 -- Members of the Association of National Advertisers will receive the local rate cards of nearly 600 newspapers belonging to the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association, it was announced here today.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 20 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark, the United States Commander in the Far East, observed today that the problems of the Indo-China war were different from those in Korea and declared the French command here was "capable of handling" the American military aid that is being funneled into this war theatre.

The recently completed Japanese school ship Hokuto Maru will sail soon on her maiden training voyage as part of the Japanese Transportation Ministry's efforts to obtain qualified replacements for Japan's growing merchant marine.

LONDON, March 20 -- In a communique that came very near being a defense agreement, the British and Yugoslav Governments undertook tonight "to work closely together and with other freedom-loving nations to defend peace."
Last year was the biggest in the history of The New Yorker Magazine, Inc., in every way but one -- net profits.

CAIRO, March 20 -- The storms of defiant nationalism and suspicion that for ten days have troubled implementation of the recent Anglo-Egyptian agreement on the future of the Sudan and dimmed prospect of amicable negotiations on the status of the British military base in the Suez Canal Zone have given way almost overnight to an atmosphere of relatively calm reasonableness on both issues.

WITH SEVENTH DIVISION, in Korea, March 20 (UP) -- An Army corporal who went A. W. O. L. from Fort Knox, Ky., and hitch-hiked 16,000 miles to fight in Korea has received the Bronze Star Medal for valor, it was disclosed today.

ALBANY, March 20 -- The Senate approved and sent to Governor Dewey today a bill that would make extensive revisions necessary in the composition of the political organizations in Manhattan. The measure provides that not more than four county committeemen may be elected in any election district.

BONN, Germany, March 20 -- Sir Ivone Kirkpatrick, British High Commissioner, will consult his United States and French colleagues before replying to a Russian offer for a British-Soviet conference on air safety.

HAVING slumbered through a 5 A. M. fox hunting appointment with Bart Allen, a local hound-enthusiast whose assorted pack insures against dull moments, we deserve to have missed what undoubtedly was one of the most interesting hunts conducted by this master of the chase.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Jack Frye, president of General Aniline and Film Corporation, said today that "unfounded charges" about the big Government-operated concern have "hurt the morale of our employes and hurt us with our customers and suppliers."

HARTFORD, Conn., March 20 (AP) -- David I. Mackie, chairman of the Eastern Railroads Presidents Conference, said today American railroads "have spent more on improvements alone since World War II than has been spent for the Atomic Energy Program."

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- John Foster Dulles and the State Department's old antagonists in the Senate collided today and the Eisenhower Administration appeared to be standing firm behind its Secretary of State.
A two-way radio circuit linking emergency ambulances with dispatchers in Police Headquarters was opened yesterday in Manhattan, last of the city's five boroughs to introduce this time-saving system.

Seventh Day Adventist youth leaders are attending this weekend a "Pathfinder's Institute" at the City Tabernacle, 562 West 150th Street. In the group are laymen and ministers in charge of Pathfinder Clubs in Adventist churches in Greater New York.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., March 20 -- National defense security measures have become the source of "an immense barrier of over-secrecy" that has "far too often merely cloaked weaknesses of which the public should be aware," Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler asserted at Fort Slocum today.

When people from the Old World came to this part of a New World they found the region now included in the United States inhabited by Red Indians who were mostly nomads depending on wild game, though some of them planted corn between hunting seasons.

President Eisenhower opened the door for any serious negotiations the new Soviet regime may have in mind when he declared, in answer to Premier Malenkov's recent declaration in favor of a peaceful settlement of disputes, that the United States, too, is seeking peace, and that if the Soviets are similarly inclined he will meet them at least halfway.

In the recent article "Jews Here Assail Policy of Soviet" we must point out that the statement condemning the American Friends of the Middle East reportedly made by Rabbi Irving Miller is without foundation in fact.

Midland, Tex., sold yesterday $3,170,000 of revenue and general obligation bonds maturing over twenty-seven years at interest costs ranging from 3.214 per cent to 3.314 per cent. The bonds were bought by syndicates headed by First Southwest Company.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Senator Wayne Morse, Independent, of Oregon, said in Senate speech today that President Eisenhower "engaged in the big lie technique" during the 1952 campaign. He rejected a colleague's suggestion that he apologize.

The circumstances which projected Dr. Paul N. Guthrie, Professor of Economics at the University of North Carolina, into a dispute over productivity on the nation's railroads led him to eschew the extreme positions taken by the employes and the managements. Before his intervention the parties had been unable to agree.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- The United States moved tonight to crack down on foreign shippers who had been trading with Iron Curtain countries -- using vessels bought on mortgage from this country.

Circulation of all the Curtis Publishing Company magazines increased substantially in 1952 and the company's gross operating income reached a record $163,003,270, according to the annual report issued yesterday. Net income, however, slipped to $4,403,936, or 44 cents a share, from $4,849,920, or 55 cents, in the preceding year.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of use to the homemaker.

" I Confess," a suspense drama co-starring Montgomery Clift and Anne Baxter and directed by Alfred Hitchcock, opens this morning at the Paramount Theatre. The Warner Brothers offering was filmed in Quebec, from a screen play by George Tabori and William Archibald and a play by Paul Anthelme. Karl Malden, Brian Aherne, O. E. Hasse, Roger Dann and Dolly Haas are among the featured players.

Because of the threat to hundreds of thousands of Jews in Iron Curtain countries and, in fact, the threat to the entire free world in the Soviet campaign against Jews and the State of Israel, we know that freedom-loving New Yorkers will give their wholehearted support to the 1953 fund campaign of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York, 220 West Fifty-eighth Street, New York 19.

The city's plan to slash transit costs by curtailing service and laying off 3,200 employes of the Board of Transportation ran into strong opposition yesterday from Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Shippers in the Eastern part of the country will not have to pay an additional charge to railroads for the service of pick-up and delivery service for another sixty days.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Representative Herman P. Eberharter, Democrat of Pennsylvania, predicted today that the press and radio would follow the school and perhaps the church to the investigation stand in the Congressional search for Communist infiltration.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, predicted today that economy measures in the Pentagon would reduce the size of the standing military forces. They now number more than 3,500,000 men and women in uniform backed up by 1,330,000 civilian employes.

Presiding Justice David W. Peck of the Appellate Division signed an order temporarily staying a New York County grand jury inspection of the accounting records of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., and its president, Joseph P. Ryan.
TOKYO, Saturday, March 21 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,560, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday, Korean time:

The New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra has declined to recognize the jurisdiction of the American Guild of Musical Artists, the union that represents vocalists, choristers and dancers, in the case of such choral works as Beethoven's Ninth, Verdi's Requiem and similar presentations. The result is that, with one exception, there may be no choral works on next season's programs.

MIAMI, March 20 -- Jackie Robinson is not griping about his transfer from second to third base but he is not happy about it. Not that Jack isn't willing to play any position Manager Chuck Dressen wants him to, but Robinson's right arm is very sore.

CHICAGO, March 20 -- Mrs. Grace Cummins, 71 years old, of Champaign, Ill., church and social worker, was killed today in a head-on traffic collision five miles south of Kankakee. Her husband, the Rev. Dr. Ralph Cummins, is General Presbyter of the Illinois Synod of the Presbyterian Church.
Yields on United States Government long-term bonds continued to move upward yesterday as dealers let prices drift downward in nominal trading marked by an absence of both demand and offerings.

TOPEKA, Kan., March 20 -- A joint committee of the Kansas Legislature finished hearing testimony from witnesses tonight and went into executive session to prepare a finding on whether C. Wesley Roberts, the present Republican National Chairman, had engaged in lobbying or otherwise had peddled political influence during the 1951 legislative session.

Liberals in this country are confronted by a series of paradoxes between a professed faith in freedom and equality, and abuses of these basic ideals, Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, said last night.

BOSTON, March 20 -- Kenneth H. Redmond, president of the United Fruit Company, said today that the expropriation of 233,973 acres of company land by the Guatemalan Government "amounts to confiscation of the company's properties on the Pacific."

LONDON, March 20 -- Despite widespread speculation here on the meaning of Premier Malenkov's replacement as Secretary of the Soviet Communist party, experts agreed that he was still master of the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The Voice of America, now under Senate investigation, is not expected to continue in its present form beyond June 30, authoritative sources said today.

ON THE KOREAN FRONT, March 20 -- The season of mud has come to Korea. Ground that through the winter was frozen hard has begun to thaw and yesterday a drenching rain started to fall at 9 A. M. It did not let up until just before dawn today.

The Loard of directors of the Queens Federation of Churches adopted a resolution last night expressing "clear condemnation" of any action that might lead to the forced withdrawal of any member organization from the Queensboro Council of Social Welfare.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 20 -- Federal Judge Edward P. Murphy ordered today the seizure of the 10,195-ton tanker Seven Seas at the Richmond dock of the Standard Oil Company of California on the ground that the ship's United States registry was fraudulent.
Vital city services will be "cut to the bone" because of the "strait-jacket program" being forced upon the city by the Republican-controlled Legislature, Mayor Impellitteri declared yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 20 -- Representatives of the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and Nationalist China agreed today to meet Monday in another attempt to agree upon a successor to Trygve Lie, who submitted his resignation last fall as Secretary General of the United Nations.
DUNSMUIR, Calif., March 20 (AP) -- L. D. (Babe) Taylor returned from British Columbia today with stories about a most unusual hunt -- for 700 black bears.
LONDON, March 20 (AP) -- The text of the Soviet note:

Sellers of domestic copper had a busy day yesterday after April copper allocations were issued by the National Production Authority. It was the first allocation since last June that did not require fabricators to take at least 40 per cent of their share of copper in the form of higher-priced foreign metal.

ALBANY, March 20 (AP) -- Governor Dewey reappointed John F. O'Connell of Larchmont to a full, five-year term on the State Liquor Authority today. Mr. O'Connell, the chairman of the authority, was later confirmed unanimously by the Senate.

At the suggestion of a connoisseur of vinegars, this department recently explored the advantages of homemade versus commercially produced versions of this condiment and preservative. Our interest was in vinegar for salad dressings, because it had been said fine, old varieties with outstanding taste and aroma no longer were obtainable.

THE explosions that shake Nevada these days are almost domesticated in Ralph E. Lapp's book, "The New Force."* This is a timely, readable and informing narrative of events in the Atomic Age's first decade. Mr. Lapp is a young scientist with a notable flair for nosing out and answering questions. He served in leading no-admittance places where atoms were encourage to expand their influence during the war.
Three of this week's group shows of painting and sculpture by contemporaries demonstrate once again that today's artists are certainly bound by no common mode of expression.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 20 -- President Getulio Vargas has personally ordered five diplomats relieved of duty for suspected Red connections and has had a woman removed from a responsible post in the code section of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to the Ministry of Finance for the same reason, it was announced today.

The Hoosiers of Indiana University, victors in the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament this week at Kansas City, were voted the No. 1 college basketball team of the 1952-53 season yesterday in the last weekly Associated Press poll.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, accused the Senate Finance Committee today of trying to "censor" its members in a move that could be used to cover up Republican scandals.

DETROIT, March 20 -- Guided missiles capable of using the atomic warhead will be in the hands of American troops within three weeks. Brig. Gen. Thomas K. Vincent said in an address to the American Society of Tool Engineers here tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican of Vermont, in a speech on the Senate floor today charged the Air Force with "waging psychological warfare on the people of the United States" by its account of the attack last Sunday by Soviet-made MIG-15 fighter planes on a United States plane engaged in a "routine weather reconnaissance flight" off Kamchatka, a peninsula jutting out from the Pacific coast of Siberia.

The United Nations Economic Commission for Europe has recently been treated to its seemingly annual flood of crocodile tears shed by Soviet representatives over the allegedly terrible conditions of workers in Western Europe. This time, however, the West spoke back in rebuttal clearly and effectively.

Another mild and reluctant recession yesterday wiped out virtually all the gains that remained from early in the week, and returned THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average of fifty stocks to within 0.02 point of its level of Friday, March 13.
Rudolph Halley at the Board of Estimate meeting suggested a program for the rehabilitation of the slums of this city. There appears to be much value in his suggestion.
ALBANY, March 20 -- A supplemental budget bill making appropriations of $16,614,477 on top of the $1,061,849,349 called for in the regular budget bills was submitted to the Legislature tonight.

TOKYO, Saturday, March 21 -- The Communists continued pressure on the western front in Korea yesterday; but troops of the Republic of Korea First Division stood off the attacks, holding their positions on the sensitive valley approaches to their capital at Seoul.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- A 700 per cent increase in installment credit since World War II is part of a mounting load of private debts which endangers the economy, the American Savings and Loan Institute was told today.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- An invention patented this week ought to shorten the period of tortured suspense that begins when the night-club waiter appears with the bill. It is a restaurant check on which the total can be read in the dark.

PARIS, March 20 -- Speaking to the executive committee of the Radical party regarding the visit he and three other Ministers will make to Washington next week, Premier Rene Mayer said today: "We shall not go as beggars but as allies.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- The Marine Corps uncovered its Mighty Mite, a baby brother to the wartime jeep, today in a preview showing at Quantico Marine Base.

LONDON, March 20 -- An unexpectedly friendly gesture by the Soviet Union toward Britain, virtually promising the release of ten civilians imprisoned in North Korea for nearly three years, stimulated speculation tonight about the possibility of a favorable change in Moscow's foreign policy.
ALBANY, March 20 -- Governor Dewey made a last-ditch stand tonight in defense of his recommendation for a law that would make liability insurance compulsory for all motor vehicle owners.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- A cheese industry spokesman said today import quotas on dairy products were necessary to save American producers from foreign competition.

Although more Negro children are being adopted, far too many of them must remain too long under care of an agency while they are being placed, members of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Services' interracial committee said yesterday.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 20 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh of Iran rejected today the proposals by London and Washington for a settlement of the issues arising from the nationalization of the British-owned oil interests here in terms that left little hope for early reopening of negotiations.

To the extent that such a thing is possible from a distance the Dewey administration is attempting to mandate something like good government in New York City. The toughness of the state's attitude, as further demonstrated by new developments at Albany yesterday, goes beyond anything observed in state-city relations of recent memory.

Higher fourth-quarter operations enabled the Packard Motor Car Company last year to better its 1951 earnings and increase net sales to $233,737,020, third largest on record, from $178,168,319 the previous year.
Moonshining and bootlegging are increasing slowly but steadily in this area and are causing concern to state and Federal authorities and to the distilling industry.

A real estate appraiser must have imagination as well as technical and scientific skills in order to make a comprehensive analysis of property, R. McAllister Lloyd, president of the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association of America, declared at the luncheon session of the metropolitan area appraisal conference yesterday at the Astor Hotel.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 20 -- In an appeal today from a recent ruling here by State Supreme Court Justice Frank H. Coyne, the Yonkers Committee for Peace chided the justice for having barred "controversial" meetings from Yonkers schoolhouses.

The announcement that Premier Malenkov is now no longer a secretary of the Communist party appears to be the strongest evidence yet available that he has not fully inherited the power held by Stalin, and that the Soviet Union is ruled today by a group of leaders rather than by Mr. Malenkov alone.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 20 -- Alvin R. Randall, veteran of several generations of students who enlivened his assignment as chief of the Harvard College yard police with springtime riots, was dismissed today. He suffered a back injury in a skirmish at the medical school last May and had been able to work only part time since then.

As its last drama of its fourth season, the Equity Library Community Theatre is producing "Mamba's Daughters," which opened at the De Witt Clinton Community Center in the Bronx last evening. Next week it will be repeated at the Bryant Adult-Youth Center in Queens for two week-end performances.

Mayor Impellitteri, notables of sport and other friends of Vincent Richards, to the number of 200, gathered at the New York A. C. last night to do honor to the former "Boy Wonder" of the tennis courts.

A new electronic brain -- an ultra-high-speed general-purpose electronic digital computing system -- that will do many tricks earlier models could not do was announced yesterday by the Engineering Research Associates division of Remington Rand, Inc.

Potatoes, coffee, cocoa and wool were active yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Prices were irregular with sugar, coffee, cottonseed oil and tin closing mixed. Cocoa, potatoes and soybean oil were lower and wool, hides, lead, zinc and rubber ended higher.

BALTIMORE, March 20 (AP) -- Mayor Thomas D'Alesandro, angered by the "inconsistency" of major league baseball owners, today blasted American League members and Frank Shaughnessy of the International League for blocking the transfer of the Browns to Baltimore.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat of Colorado, introduced a bill in the Senate today to legalize a baseball club's withholding of its consent to telecasts or broadcasts of contests from stations in its home territory.

New York City collected more taxes, spent more money and ended up deeper in debt last year than in any other year in its history, according to a study released yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission.

PINEHURST, N. C., March 20 (AP) -- Stirring comebacks by Mrs. R. M. Torgerson of Forest Hills, Queens, N. Y., and Mary Lena Faulk of Thomasville, Ga., and a twenty-one-hole victory by the defending champion, Barbara Romack of Sacramento, Calif., marked the second round today of the North and South golf championship.

To support the assertion that defendants in the investment banking anti-trust suit competed against each other for business instead of conspiring to divide it up, defense counsel yesterday put in evidence a letter sent by an executive of Blyth Co., one of the seventeen defendants, to the head of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- That contemporary British designers still work most successfully in those crafts traditional to their own country was indicated by a display opened to the public at the Corcoran Gallery of Art this week.

NEW DELHI, India, March 20 (AP) -- Retiring United States Ambassador Chester Bowles confirmed today that he had recommended that the Voice of America not give "excessive treatment" to anti-Communist statements by Indian leaders. Mr. Bowles said he feared such emphasis would cause the Indians to make "balancing" statements against the United States as part of their policy of keeping neutral in the "cold war."

SAN FRANCISCO, March 20 -- Before the Giants' game against the Oakland Acorns was postponed tonight because of rain, Manager Leo Durocher called a press conference which, he hoped, would be the last one to clarify the status of Alvin Dark, Giant captain, shortstop and possibly the next second baseman.
ALBANY, March 20 -- Following is the text of a special message Governor Dewey sent to the Legislature tonight on New York City fiscal problems:

NEW DELHI, India, March 20 -- India and Pakistan hope to widen and expand the scope of trade between the two countries in discussions to follow the conference, ended today, that removed the principal barriers to the resumption of normal commerce curtailed for past two years.
