PHILADELPHIA, March 20 -- A 30-year-old woman whose heart stopped beating for fifty minutes during an operation was reported in good condition today at Doctor's Hospital here.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 20 -- The sun was shining on Hollywood today in more ways than one. The weather man had taken his rain clouds out to sea, and almost everyone appeared to be happy over the way things went last night at the twenty-fifth anniversary presentation of the Academy Awards.

PARIS, March 20 -- On his way to Washington to participate in the French-American talks there next week, Donald R. Heath, the United States Ambassador in Indo-China, said today that with the growing strength of the Vietnamese national forces a military solution to the present stalemate in the fighting was probable "within the reasonably near future."
SPARTANBURG, S. C., March 20 (UP) -- Louise Suggs of Atlanta shot a 68 today to take the first-round lead in the $3,500 Betsy Rawls invitation golf tournament.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 20 (AP) -- A Federal Court lawsuit asking triple damages of more than $500,000 for alleged gambling losses today named as co-defendants the University of Kentucky's basketball coach, Adolph Rupp; the gambler, Frank Costello, and Ed Curd, reputed former Lexington bookmaker.

CHICAGO, March 20 -- Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of General Motors corporation, wound up eight days of testimony for the defense today at the du Pont anti-trust trial in Federal District Court here and Government attorneys said they would begin cross-examination of the 77-year-old industrialist on Monday.

HILLSIDE, N. J., March 20 -- Forty-five ninth grade pupils of the Hillside High School Annex were astounded here this morning to find that their school bus driver, a new man on the route, didn't know the way to school.

TAIPEI, Formosa, March 20 -- Adlai Stevenson paid an unscheduled half-hour visit to Nationalist President Chiang Kai-Shek this morning shortly after he alighted from a Northwest Airlines plane into a huge welcoming crowd. Mr. Stevenson's rousing welcome was one of the warmest accorded to a "private citizen" of a foreign country.

Johnny Bratton, the Chicago welterweight who wants a championship bout with Kid Gavilan badly enough to give his share of the purse away, entered a strong claim for such a contest by knocking out Bobby Jones of Oakland, Calif., in Madison Square Garden last night.

William E. Buckley has purchased the one-family dwelling at 34-42 Eighty-eight Street in Jackson Heights, Queens, from Agnes Griffin Lacey. James D. McGuire was the broker in the transaction, in which title was insured by the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 20 (AP) -- The Organizing Committee of the 1956 Games tonight voted a ten-day extension of time to prepare its report to the International Olympic Committee after two possible solutions to the housing problem had been proposed.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 20 -- The Florida Derby shaped up today as a good race for 3-year-old horses. The pessimism that had existed earlier in the week because of unlooked-for defections and withdrawals was cleared up when Racing Secretary Horace Wade announced that a field of seventeen would compete in the $100,000-added mile-and-a-furlong test tomorrow at the Gulfstream Park course.
Cotton futures prices closed irregular on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, 6 points lower to 7 points higher than Thursday, with near months relatively weaker than distant months.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Representative Daniel A. Reed, Republican of upstate New York, predicted today that House leaders soon would give clearance to his tax-reduction bill.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., March 20 -- Those attending the seventh annual Williamsburg Garden Symposium heard discussion today of a number of methods for improving amateur gardens.

The New York City Opera Company last evening presented its first "Carmen" of the season at the City Center. The title role was sung by Gloria Lane and the performance featured the debuts of Dolores Mari as Micaela and Andrew White as Escamillo.

CHICAGO, March 20 -- A number of witnesses appearing before the City Council subcommittee investigating violent television programs for children testified today that there was no statistical evidence linking video crime shows and juvenile delinquency, and they asserted that censorship of programs was undesirable.

As a NEW YORK TIMES reader and also as a person interested in a major philanthropy I cannot allow the recent letter from Albert S. Bard, vice chairman of the National Roadside Council, to go unanswered.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) -- The Marine Corps announced today it would consolidate its recruiting, reserve and office procurement offices throughout the country on April 1 to save money and manpower.

TRIESTE, March 20 -- The Italian Government was reported here today to have instructed all police prefects and all rank and file leaders in the four political parties that make up the Government coalition to prevent any further emotional demonstrations in connection with the dispute with Yugoslavia over the occupation of the Free Territory of Trieste.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, on State Department security processes, which he issued at a news conference today:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 20 -- Dick Thoman and Kerry Donovan broke meet records tonight in Harvard's pool as Yale continued its domination of the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League's thirteenth annual invitation individual championships.
ALBANY, March 20 -- Following is the text of the Governor's message urging passage of the compulsory automobile liability insurance bill.

An illustrated, informal explanation of psychiatry is scheduled for May 18 publication by Knopf under the title "The Inside Story: Psychiatry and Everyday Life." Compiled under the direction of Fritz Redlich, the text was written by June Bingham in collaboration with Jacob Levine, chief clinical psychologist at the Veterans Administration Hospital, Newington, Conn.
VIENNA, March 20 (AP) -- The first results of the twentieth annual world table tennis championships in the Rumanian capital of Bucharest were announced tonight by the Bucharest radio.

BONN, Germany, March 20 -- Hans Ulrich Rudel, a Luftwaffe hero in World War II, planned a raid last December on Werl prison to release war criminals held there by the British, Dr. Erich Mende, a Bundestag deputy, revealed today.

The tax-exempt-interest borrowings of municipal governments will again figure prominently in the marketing of new issues of prime securities next week. The City of Philadelphia will top the list by offering on Tuesday $33,350,000 of sewer and gas bonds.

LONDON, March 20 -- The conciliatory tone of the Soviets' explanation of the aircraft incidents and some good dividend announcements prompted a little extra buying in the stock markets today. Prices in most sections advanced during the morning and held their gains until the close despite later slackening of business.

CLEVELAND, March 20 -- The National Council of Jewish Women today urged the United States to give stronger economic and military aid to free nations to prevent Communist aggression and to "support, strengthen and implement" the decisions of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- A spokesman for the United States High Commissioner for Germany testified today that General Accounting Office investigators made "some mistakes" in their report on a housing project for Americans at Bonn, Germany.

CHICAGO, March 20 -- With contracts in March grains and soybeans being evened up, the market was a choppy affair, with nervous fluctuations in all pits. At times there was buying in a fairly large way of wheat on dry weather reports from the Southwest and on small primary receipts, but volume of business was lagging, and the market displayed no definite trend.

TRENTON, March 20 -- The New Jersey Society, Daughters of the American Revolution, adopted a resolution today declaring that the United Nations General Assembly was being used as "a sounding board for Communist propaganda."

IN his fifteenth year in the Senate, and in the year following his defeat in one of the great party struggles of American history, Robert A. Taft of Ohio has ascended new heights of political authority and influence.
Re: "'Beetle' Is Back on the Eisenhower Team" (March 1), by W. H. Lawrence:
HONG KONG, Sunday, March 22--A Chinese Communist gunboat captured a yacht flying the United States flag near here yesterday. The yacht was reported to be carrying three Americans.

" Push-button banking" is already a reality in suburban New York. Use of electronic equipment in some banking procedures of course is not new. At the County Trust Company in Westchester, however, virtually all of the regular banking routines are now performed automatically. The single major exception, the handling of commercial checking accounts, exists only because the bank has not obtained the additional necessary machines.

BONN, Germany, March 21 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer has been informed that the French Government, although it is willing to reword the protocols it has attached to the European Defense Community Treaty, is not prepared to alter their substance or to abandon them.
A burst of gunfire high in the subzero air off Kamchatka, Russia's Siberian outpost, emphasized once again last week the important role of Alaska and the Arctic in a strategy for the atomic age.

" GOD has made us neighbors, let justice make us friends," said Secretary of State William Jennings Bryan more than a quarter-century ago. Mexico is more than a neighbor. It is the threshold to another world, the immediate and, consequently, the most important link in the chain that joins the United States and Latin America.

IN his first novel Alfred Slote is concerned with the Denhams and the ties that bound them to the Westchester town that bore their name. Even more, it is a story of Robert Denham Manning (whose mother was a Denham), his inheritance of family traditions and responsibilities, his attempt to rebel against the pattern. Mr. Slote not only shows exceptional writing talent but a craftsmanship that reveals discipline and a respect for his trade.

THE listener with a built-in appetite for contemporary music may easily find himself with jaded aural taste buds, these days. This is not necessarily from over-indulgence; it is more likely to come from an over-rich diet. Too often, if he makes it his business to catch every concert premiere and all the unfamiliar new music that is released on records, he will find himself with a large portion of froth and very little substance.

BACK in 1921 when William Inge was a tow-headed 8-year-old in Independence, Kan., he used to hear his sister, Helene, practicing a recitation for the inevitable elocution class. Master Inge was the youngest of five children and, like the youngest in many other families, he felt that he never got enough attention.

BERLIN, March 21 -- Probably the most debated question in Berlin in the past few weeks has been why the Communists have not hitherto taken measures to halt the stream of refugees daily entering West Berlin.
Two New York factoring houses last week came to the defense of Cuban and Panamanian importers.

ON April 1 the international airlines will raise their tourist fares, adding $5 to the New York-London tariff, and start feeding tourist passengers "free." Thus, one of the principal differences between first-class arid coach-class plane flights will disappear, less than a year after the reduced-fare tourist service was instituted internationally.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 21 -- Tuning up for an all-out bid for the National Collegiate Athletic Association team title at Columbus, Ohio, a week hence, Yale's brilliant array of aquatic stars tonight completed a near clean sweep of the top honors in the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League's thirteenth annual invitation individual championships.

CUCUTA, Colombia, March 21 (AP) -- The Chief Executives of Venezuela and Colombia met on an international bridge linking their two lands tonight and pledged themselves to defend South America against alien doctrines.

A seventeenth century Persian silk rug will be auctioned on Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, in a sale that will include other valuable rugs and French eighteenth century furniture and decorations.

A NUMBER of plants display an almost diabolic versatility With equal ease they can assume two entirely different roles: in one setting they are villainous weeds, in another they emerge as lovely leading ladies.

Paintings and sculpture on religious themes by leading American artists will be on exhibition. beginning today, in the parish hall of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension at 12 West Eleventh Street.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 21 -- Tommy Bolt, refreshed by a two-week rest from the tournament tour, covered the Hyde Park municipal course in 66 strokes today and tied Fred Hawkins at the midway point in the Jacksonville open golf tournament.

DULUTH, Minn., March 21 -- Albert Woolson, 106-year-old Civil War veteran and last survivor of the Union's 2,675,000-man army, this week was besieged by autograph and photograph hunters and magazine and newspaper writers. His daily routine now includes long periods away from home to escape them.
Your correspondent Blanche Thompson in the Letters Columns of March 15 criticizes your use of the words "sculpt" and "ceramic" in the phrase "to sculpt a ceramic."

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 21 -- Money Broker, slightly less than 16 to 1, held off a mighty stretch challenge by Louis B. Mayer's Blaze to win the $133,750 Florida Derby today. The chestnut colt, owned by Allie Grissom and Ed Grosfield of Detroit, scored by a head.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 21 -- The United States again urged the Soviet Union today to show evidence of a will for peace by working "side by side with the United States" in the attempt to find a workable and safe disarmament formula.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 21 -- From watch posts all along this side of the Iron Curtain, the United States has put together for the first time the story of the men and women -- 15,000 so far -- who have risked the mine fields and electrified barbed-wire fences that guard the borders of Soviet-ruled Eastern Europe and made the dash westward.
" Sunday" painters attending a Saturday lecture on art education at the Museum of Modern Art yesterday were advised by a professional artist to take themselves seriously.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 21 (UP) -- Adolph Rupp, the University of Kentucky basketball coach, went to Federal Court today to fight back against a suit accusing him of setting up a gambling conspiracy with Frank Costello, the gambler, now in jail, and Ed Curd, another gambler.
ST. LOUIS, March 21 (AP) -- Owner Bill Veeck reported to the Browns board of directors today on his recent unsuccessful effort to move the club to Baltimore.
STAMFORD, Conn., March 21 -- Dr. Shuster ridiculed today Senator McCarthy's charge that he had failed to join other Americans in the fight against communism.

The Reynolds Metals Company's part in the National Packaging Exposition on the Navy Pier in Chicago April 20 is named "The Greatest Sales Show on Earth" with a circus atmosphere carried out in the many bright colors of its foil wrappings -- plain printed and lithographed.

Headed by Al Parsells, high scorer of the season, the Ramapo Polo Club rode into the final round of the national twelve-goal ndoor championship tournament last night by eliminating the New York A. C., 1952 victor, 10 -- 8, at the Squaadron A Armory.

OF the six additional special stamps which Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield has announced for issue during 1953, the one for the silver anniversary of the Future Farmers of America has prompted the greatest surprise among the country's philatelists.

One of the first steps in eradicating police brutality in a community is to break down the fear of victims about reporting incidents and to establish their rights in relation to the police, Miss Ella Baker, president of the New York branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said yesterday in a discussion of civil rights.

MIAMI, March 21 -- Emil J. (Buzzie) Bavasi, Dodger vice president, said today that he "is satisfied there is no racial problem on this club" and that "the players have assured me there is no such problem, never has been and never will be."

The completion during February of three ships brought the volume of new tonnage under construction or contracted for in United States shipyards down to eighty-five vessels, the lowest total reported by the Shipbuilders Council of America in the last twenty months.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (UP) -- Senator Allen J. Ellender urged today that his fellow backers of state ownership of offshore lands settle for title to submerged lands out to historic state boundaries lest they meet complete defeat.

RICHMOND, Va., March 21 -- Walter S. Robertson, Richmond investment banker who was nominated this week to be Assistant Secretary of State for the Far East, got into foreign affairs because he was too old to fight in World War II.

AMERICAN motion picture labor unions were misguided in starting a fight against the production of television films abroad, says Sheldon Reynolds, who produces "Foreign Intrigue" in Europe. His program is televised here over Channel 4 on Thursday at 10:30 P. M. and syndicated to more than forty other stations around the country.

COMMENTING on the book about the Prince Regent, "The Loves of Florizel," by Philip Lindsay, the reviewer, Lillian de la Torre, writes that he rejected his consort before he saw her and was repaid by childlessness. May I point out that he and his lawful spouse, the Princess Caroline of Brunswick, had one daughter, the Princess Charlotte Augusta, who was christened on Feb. 11, 1796.

THE small boy Michael was lonesome, so he sallied forth along Nelson Avenue in the Bronx to find friends. He did Find them -- but his acquisition of a kitten, a puppy and a pig takes two days and too many words in this twenty-eight-page picture-story.

Richard H. Wels' "Causes and Cures of Divorce -- An Inquiry" (March 8) contained many worthwhile ideas. In the light of my own experiences (I am divorced), I support the following views, which parallel a number of those of the article (with perhaps an altered emphasis in some respects):

SOME years ago I presided a radio panel on "the role of the intellectual in American life." It was the season of baseball; and we were asked to stand by for the game to end, then to stand by again, and again.
Mike Parenti, 6-foot 8-inch center, led New Utrecht High to its first city P. S. A. L. basketball championship yesterday afternoon.

BOSTON, March 21 -- The appointment of the Rev. Dr. Howard Thurman as university preacher and Professor of Spiritual Disciplines and Resources at the School of Theology was announced today by Boston University.

THE frontier army was a sad collection of "scum," rag-tags," illiterate foreigners and fugitives from failure. The fact that it was composed of men of low ability, dubious morals, and shiftless ambitions was itself a hindrance to recruiting.

CALIFORNIA, among other claims to fame, produces practically all of the ranunculus grown in the United States. This refers not only to the corms and seeds from which the plants are grown but also to the cut flowers that are shipped from the West Coast to every one of the forty-eight states.
LOS ANGELES, March 21 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities will begin hearings here Monday into Communist activities in a number of fields ranging from education to entertainment.

" Tristan und Isolde" was abruptly halted for several minutes yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House so that a broadcast appeal for opera funds could be made to the estimated radio audience of 15,000,000 persons. The plea, announced by Milton Cross, was greeted in the packed Opera House by boos and hisses as well as applause.

ANY momentous trends this spring in the world of records, phonographs and the higher regions of high fidelity? There must be, but we won't look for them. What about resounding generalizations on what the long-play disk has done for America's musical culture?

TOKYO, Sunday, March 22 -- Planes from United States Navy carriers in the Sea of Japan carried out their heaviest raid in the past six months of the Korean war yesterday against enemy targets in northeast Korea, about thirty miles from the Manchurian border.

FIFTEEN thousand pots of spring-flowering plants and bulbs will be used in the "Pageant of Spring" display which opens Friday in the Conservvatory of the New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park. The display may be seen daily through April 12.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican of New Jersey, said today Amos Peaslee, New Jersey attorney, had been picked to be Ambassador to Australia. The State Department has approved the appointment, he added, and President Eisenhower probably will send the nomination to the Senate early next week.

MILAN, Ind., March 21 (UP) -- Firemen and police from neighboring cities kept order in a "ghost town" today as Milan's 1,014 residents moved en masse to Indianapolis for a high school basketball tourney.

Dr. Philip C. Jessup, former United States Ambassador at large, declared here yesterday that to lead the free world against communism this country needed unity at home based on free discussion and honest disagreement. He said unity was being undermined by the actions of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin and Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, March 22 -- The yacht Kert has been at the center of a war correspondents' dream world here for more than a year. Most of the reporters covering the Korean war have talked of the day they would quit their jobs and take the Kert on a cruise through the islands of the South Pacific.

PHILADELPHIA, March 21 (AP) -- The truce between the factions supporting Athletic Director Fran Murray and Football Coach George Munger continued today as the Pennsylvania campus awaited the restatement of the university's athletic policy, to be made Thursday night at the Varsity Club dinner.

TO the average, or 40 regular, male buying a suit, clothing salesmen represent an element of inexorable hazard, something like the tides as viewed by a Channel swimmer. It is the chilling fear of every customer that, once he has committed himself to a salesman, he may be borne, willy-nilly, to an objective he hasn't foreseen, isn't especially attracted to, and mightn't like the color of once he gets it out into daylight.

A hold-up man who had pretended he was a detective was shot and killed in a running pistol battle with three policemen through congested streets in the heart of Harlem last night. A hostage of the fugitive escaped injury.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, majority leader, voiced hope today that military spending could be cut at least $4,000,000,000 below projected levels as part of an effort to hold the budget for the fiscal year 1954 to $70,000,000,000.

IS the white shirt for daytime wear on the way out? A recent advertising blurb for shirts that were colored, checked, striped -- anything but white -- declared startlingly, "No gentleman wears a white shirt until after 6 P. M."
Innovations in production planning of textiles have cut the risk of top-heavy inventories, textile engineers said last week.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 21 -- Experts sent to Bolivia by the United Nations Technical Assistance Administration have been "really astounded" by the potentialities for cheap hydro-electric power in that country, Dr. Carter Goodrich, chief of the mission, said today.

SYDNEY, March 21 (AP) -- Kel Nagle, former Australian professional champion fired rounds of 67 and 68 today to win the MacWilliams golf tournament with a record score of 277, 11 under par and seven strokes ahead of his nearest competitor.

CONTEMPORARY diaries and journals of the westward migration of the Eighteen Forties and Fifties are in accord on one point: the journey to Oregon or California was one of endless hardship and backbreaking toil with adventure as rare as cool springs in the Humboldt Sink, or smooth going in the passage of the Blue Mountains.

A DISTINGUISHED physician, Dr. E. L. Bortz, recently predicted at a scientific meeting that human life expectancy would soon be 100 years, and his forecast drew much attention from the papers. "Is this really possible?" it was asked. People began to wonder what would happen to our society under the impact of such extended longevity: would it mean additional miseries or blessings?
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 21 (UP) -- The Government has "strictly prohibited" all visits to Aloysius Cardinal Stepinac at Krasic, it was disclosed today.

THE American Society of Magazine Photographers, whose membership includes many of the most important photographers in the United States, will honor on Wednesday evening three men whose contributions in their separate fields have had unique influence on American photography both as medium and craft.

HERE will we sing of piano playing on records. Not piano music; piano playing. And when it comes to piano playing I am an incurable romantic. I confess it. My attitude is that of old Matthew Prior to his Cloe: "I court others in verse but I love thee in prose, And they have my whimsies but thou hast my heart."

A search for the cause of cancer throws new light on the cause of arthritis. Such is the purport of an article published in Science by Drs. C. H. Li and William O. Reinhardt of the University of California.

IN the abstract realms of the Higher Technique, nothing is more entrancing than the Problem of the Locked Room -- or more difficult to present with both plausibility and novelty. Now Roman McDougald has created something wonderfully new in THE BLUSHING MONKEY (Simon Schuster, $2.50):

PARIS, March 21 -- Those in close touch with the negotiations predicted tonight that the major protocols to the European army treaty proposed by the French would be agreed upon by the interim committee of the six signatories by Tuesday night when Premier Rene Mayer and three other ministers will depart for Washington.

IF a lieder record enthusiast were to find himself on the proverbial desert island the modern institution of LP would be small comfort to him. Most song programs, though they may contain an outstanding piece or two, are in total unsatisfactory, partly because they cover too wide a repertoire, and partly because most artists do certain songs better than others.

EARLY last I was flown to Assam, that fabulous border between India and Burma, to gather material for a motion picture involving the Nagas, a group of aboriginal tribes who indulge in head-hunting for sport and social advancement.

THE addition of another ship to the crowded trans-Atlantic service was promised last week with the announcement that the modern 15,000-ton liner Roma of the Lauro Lines of Naples would begin operations between Mediterranean ports and New York with a sailing from Genoa on May 3.

SIX years ago Miguel Aleman, who had taken office as President of Mexico several months earlier, saw to it that a law was passed setting up an Institute of Fine Arts. The Institute, established in the Ministry of Education, was instructed to make music, painting, drama and the dance as its principal domains, and it was provided with Government funds to do its work of ministering to the arts.

ALTHOUGH there are now some 7,800 garden clubs in this country, the number increases each year. New clubs spring up in well-established communities as well as in newly developed areas. Recently a young matron who felt that her town needed a garden club asked a veteran garden club member how to organize one.

AIKEN, S. C. March 21 (AP) -- Greentree's Stable's Lotus Eater, a nominee for the 1953 Kentucky Derby, jumped off to a lead of five lengths and stayed in front the rest of the way to win the City of Aiken cup, which featured the Aiken Trials today.

Frederick V. Goess, who has been in banking all his life, has turned salesman temporarily, and is making good at it. "Right now, we are 25 per cent ahead of last year," he said yesterday as he looked over returns in the Brooklyn Red Cross 1953 Fund, in which he is chairman of the commerce and industry division.
THE Edwardian look, dominant in the clothes worn by fashionable Englishmen, is being crowded these days by a new look -- the military style.

The Yale varsity played a game of football here yesterday and it is a matter for the Ivy League to look into, seeing as how there's not only a ban on extramural contests but they dasn't even hold practice at this time of the year.

CAIRO, March 21 -- The first official indication of a break in the already weakening determination of the member nations of the Arab League to boycott West Germany over ratification of the reparations agreement with Israel came today in a cautious suggestion by a high-ranking Government Minister that the boycott was irreconcilable with Egypt's desire to consolidate relations with Bonn.

THERE is every good reason why this collection of essays ought to be the ready answer furnished by every art critic when his dinner or tennis partner asks him "What is modern art?" But good reasons, or at least good reason, are equivalent -- like Herbert Read's own aspirations -- to a Platonic ideal, and, unfortunately, those who ask that question have not been bred in the ideal society of a Platonic state.

THERE is undoubtedly more than one way to establish the popularity of certain pieces of recorded music: request programs, popularity polls, letters to the editor that complain about the dropping, or keeping, of certain items in the catalog.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- Steel production in the Chicago area continued to pace business activity here with the setting of new production records during February. The Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported that February output, a new high mark for the month, reached 1,580,000 net tons despite a three-day strike in the plant of Inland Steel during the month.

The Military Sea Transportation Service's request for twenty Government-owned Victory ships to carry military cargoes was reviewed by the National Shipping Authority yesterday in the light of strong protests against the move by private shipping operators.

AMERICANS are deeply disappointed at the news that the Bavarian State Parliament has voted against sending overseas the eighty-three masterpieces from the Munich Alte Pinakoteca which were scheduled to arrive here in May for showing at the museums in Washington, New York, Philadelphia, Boston and San Francisco.
The new regime in the Kremlin last week appeared to be hewing to a tactical line that Lenin long ago defined as the ability "to tack, to make agreements, zigzags, retreats * * * "
In your layout, "Life and Times of Times Square" (March 1), the theatre in the picture entitled "Age of Elegance" couldn't possibly be the Lyric. It is the Criterion Theatre.

A short sail on one of the city's ferries to Staten Island, a mere aspirin for a nostalgic seaman who has been office-bound for the last few years, recalled to him, one of these spring mornings, the mad harbor rush of the war years.

Events of the past week have made it clear that a new major Soviet "peace offensive" is now in progress. Premier Malenkov, in a speech before the Russian legislature last Sunday, declared flatly that there were no outstanding issues between the Soviet Union and the United States which could not be settled peacefully.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon, as a one-man Independent party in the Senate, is playing hob with the seniority rules of the world's greatest deliberate body.

IF one achievement stands out supremely among the spectacular accomplishments of the career of Serge Koussevitzky, early a conductor of international fame, it is the immense encouragement and impetus that he gave, throughout his lifetime to the cause of the composer.

SEOUL, Korea, March 21 (AP) -- A United States Sabre jet pilot who flies against Communist MIG's under a cloak of personal secrecy may become an anonymous jet ace. For his own reasons, the pilot does not want his name revealed by the Air Force.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 21 -- Virtually on the eve of British Parliamentary debate on the proposed federation of the African territories of Northern Rhodesia, Southern Rhodesia and Nyasaland, the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions has sent a protest against the proposals from its Brussels headquarters to Prime Minister Churchill and leaders of the Opposition in the British Parliament.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- President Eisenhower was reported by callers today as looking none too favorably on the recently published Standard Revised version of the Bible.

President Eisenhower had hardly taken office before Washington buzzed with talk of a coming fight between his Administration and the most bitter Senatorial critics of the Truman Administration. A focal point of the fight, it seemed certain, would be Secretary of State John Foster Dulles.

ATHENS, Greece, March 21 (AP) -- The Greek Government is preparing legislation providing severe penalties for owners of any Greek ships that carry strategic goods to Communist countries, a reliable source said today.

TRENTON, March 21 -- The Legislature reconvened last Monday after a four-week recess, met again briefly on Wednesday and then adjourned until next Monday without taking action on any major bills awaiting its consideration. Its sole accomplishment appeared to be the passage of half a hundred minor measures.

According to John B. Campbell's assignments for the forty-fourth Paumonok Handicap, the six-furlong, $25,000-added, opening-day feature of the Metropolitan Jockey Club's golden jubilee meeting on April 1 at Jamaica, F. Ambrose Clark's 10-year-old Tea-Maker, with 126 pounds, and the Woolford Farm's Delegate (116), a year younger, are asked to spot twenty-three other nominees from 4 to 7 years in age as well as weight.

There have been many signs recently that the country is waking up to the menace of attacks by irresponsible Congressional committees, or the chairmen thereof, on the basic rights of American citizens. If these attacks have not yet reached a point of grave danger it is because they are mainly conducted by men of small intellectual stature.

Five well-dressed and well-armed men held up a cashier and fifteen United Parcel Service delivery truck drivers in a company office in Richmond Hill, Queens, last night, and fled with $2,900 in collections after having been unable to open a safe containing $50,000.

BOSTON, March 22 -- Joseph W. Martin Jr., Speaker of the United States House of Representatives, today pledge tax reduction as soon as it could instituted without endangering national security and prosperity.

THE world of letters is full of love letters to France postmarked from foreign parts. In English, there are Laurence Sterne's, Stevenson's, Henry James' and many another. Now comes the veteran novelist, A. Hamilton Gibbs, member of that alert writing clan which included an eminent war correspondent of World War I, Sir Philip Gibbs, and the novelist brother, Cosmo Hamilton.

Suggestions from Government officials that cotton farmers this year voluntarily cut back their cotton acreage is going unheeded throughout the belt. Reports from the principal cotton producing areas have indicated that domestic growers may even devote more acreage to the growing of the staple than they did last year.

BUSINESS skies took on a brighter tinge last week with the issuance by the Federal Reserve Board of its annual survey of consumer buying attitudes and financial status. The report, usually awaited with keen interest by retailers and manufacturers because of its accuracy in the past, was notably optimistic in tone.

CINCINNATI, March 21 -- Christianity and Judaism must have mutual respect for each other's differences and should question each other about them, Dr. Leo Baeck, president of the World Union for Progressive Judaism," said in an address read here today at Founders Day exercises of the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion.
EASTHAMPTON, Mass., March 21 (AP) -- Mrs. Shirley Beddell Crabtree was the happiest person in town with her Mother's Day present last year. "Just what I needed." she said. "A concrete mixer!"

HUGE in its effort to present a vivid, half-century panorama of life in the Great Lakes region, from its days of frontier recklessness to the complex tensions of its modern industrial cities, "The Beckoning Waters" is also very large in its success.

SEOUL, Korea, March 21 -- Dr. Syngman Rhee, 78-year-old President, who plays a central role in almost every activity in governing this country, has been ailing for several weeks, and quite naturally there has been speculation as to what would happen should it be necessary to find a successor.

College graduates seeking managerial positions will find chances almost twice as good in smaller businesses as compared with big companies, a study at the University of Illinois has found. Although there are more managerial jobs in large businesses numerically, the competition is keener for each opportunity.

LAHORE, Pakistan, March 21 -- In the restless wake of political riots that brought death to at least 330 persons, and possibly 1,000 during the first half of March, Mian Mumtaz Mohammad Khan Daultana, Prime Minister of Punjab Province and leader of the Punjab Moslem League, said today he would quit the office and "shed the last drop of my blood" to help a successor if the national welfare required such action.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 21 -- Steve O'Neill is a mountain of good nature without a speck of braggadoccio or pretense to his make-up. Hence it was a mite disconcerting when the massive manager of the Phils made his rather startling statement. He pushed his cap to the back of his head with gnarled fingers -- a souvenir of his trade -- and spoke the incongruous words.

MIAMI, March 21 -- Lou Boudreau's Red Sox were just another woeful group of "Saturday's Children" against the Dodgers at Miami Stadium today before 3,876 fans. The Brooks took the game, 8 -- 4, after permitting the Sox to tie it at 4-all with a three-run surge in the sixth inning.

MR. PUTTERBEE, an engagingly lazy man never managed to clean his backyard further than halfway. Seventeen years after he had planted a single rambler rose and honey-suckle vine along the back fence, Mr. Putterbee had a jungle, with, it turned out, a tiger who had been living there quietly for five years.

THE Abbey Theatre's first offering in the way of a new play for 1953 was something worthwhile in Michael J. Molloy's long-awaited fourth play, "The Wood of the Whispering." In two of his earlier plays, "The Old Road," and "The Visiting House," Molloy made rural depopulation in Ireland one of his main themes.

I was glad to read Ladislas Farago's letter in THE TIMES of March 6 discussing the relative values of different media of communication and their respective effectiveness in the work of the United States International Information Administration. He classified radio as "virtually useless * * * in an area of free information * * * wide open to all media where people need not cull information through static from a foreign radio."
FORT DIX, N. J., March 21 -- A new moonlight firing range, said to be the first of its kind built in the United States, has been put into operation at Fort Dix.

THIS is one of those curious political tracts whose central argument is probably sound but whose method of presentation is regrettable. T. H. Tetens has spent many years of his life collecting materials on Germany and clearly possesses a rich archive of clippings.

Russian emigres, including scholars and former Soviet Government experts in economics and engineering, agreed yesterday that the Russian economy was geared completely to war preparations at the expense of domestic comforts.

On these pages are the grand prize winner and some of the runners-up of the first worldwide sculpture competition. Based on the theme of the "Unknown Political Prisoner," the competition was sponsored by the Institute of Contemporary Arts, London.

IF there is one thing every competent bridge player thinks he knows all about it is finessing. In fact, he considers it "baby stuff," something to be taught to beginners in the second or third lesson.

Lifting of price controls on cigarettes last month gave manufacturers their first price increase -- after taxes -- since July 28, 1950. Generally this rise was a cent a pack -- equivalent to $150,000,000 annually. A hearing in Washington this week may give one segment of the industry a chance to snatch away a goodly share of this $150,000,000. Here's how:
A program of unusual interest, even by Arturo Toscanini-N. B. C. Symphony standards, was presented at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon by Mr. Toscanini and the orchestra.

The "transistor," new mite of the electronics world that soon may replace vacuum tubes in much of today's radio equipment, will receive a large share of the attention of 30,000 engineers and scientists this week at the forty-first annual convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers.

A CORNER planting may vary in size from a simple group of three small trees to a mixed group of trees and shrubs. Such a planting may be wanted, for example, at the corner of a property, particularly on the side facing the street.

THE reasons that impel a person to cling to certain records through the years are apt to be personal and, occasionally, inexplicable. Among my accumulation of popular and jazz records is an aged Vocalion disk called "Tear It Down, Bedslats and All" by the Memphis Jug Band.
BUFFALO, March 21 -- New York City's Grand Street Boys Club mile relay team of Olympic champions set a new unofficial world indoor record tonight, winning the 174th Armory games mile in 3:14.4.

WASHINGTON, N. J., March 21 -- The driver of a trailer truck involved in the crash with a passenger car near here last night in which ten members of one family were killed was committed to Warren County prison today on a mandatory charge of causing death by automobile.

PARIS, March 20 -- Efforts to extend the Saar's autonomy by a revision of its economic conventions with France have stirred up the rivalry of Lorraine, with resulting delays that extend to the resumption of the long-abandoned talks with Germany on internationalizing the Saar.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., March 21 -- Work is expected to start next week on construction by Nassau County of the long-discussed half-mile highway that will lead through the Incorporated Village of Cove Neck to Sagamore Hill, President Theodore Roosevelt's home, which is being restored as a museum.

By virtue of birth into the Waterman family alone, Frank D. probably could have written his way to the top of the writing equipment company. But he also inherited the determination of his great-uncle who, seventy years ago this month, invented the first practical fountain pen, so there was little doubt of his destiny.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 21 -- It rained here today. No matter what Al Lang may have called it, a heavy rainstorm deluged the city of sunshine and washed away the Grapefruit League game listed between the Yankees and Milwaukee Braves, giving the New York squad its first full day off since the athletes reported for spring training on Feb. 22.

FOUR years ago an obscure Canadian pianist waited several hours up in Montreal for the chance to audition for Benny Goodman, who was playing a one-night engagement there with one of his bands. Benny, who never showed up for the date, has lived to regret his forgetfulness, for the pianist was Oscar Peterson, easily the most publicized and popular jazz keyboard artist of 1953.

Exports by Great Britain to the United States this year will increase at least 10 per cent over the record 1952 volume, according to a conservative estimate made by a key trade official here. A gain of as much as 20 per cent was seen possible.

Victories gained in the fifth round, yesterday, by Eric Eliskases and Miguel Najdorf, both of Argentina, enabled them to join in a quadruple tie for first place with Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia and Carlos E. Guimard of Argentina in the international chess masters tournament at Mar Del Plata, according to a report from Buenos Aires. All four have scores of 4 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- A major shake-up of the Department of Commerce field service, eliminating all but twelve or fifteen of the fifty-five offices scattered through the country, is under discussion by Secretary Sinclair Weeks.

This is the time of year when nice, comfortable home life, around the hearthside with its warmth and tranquillity, has a change in the thousands of families where pleasure boats are owned. Unseasonably warm, but nevertheless welcomed, springlike weather has sent skippers to the yacht clubs and shipyards to start the long succession of springtime fitting-out chores.

LINCOLN, R. I., March 21 (UP) -- Shadows Start, a stretch-running son of Hoop Jr., scored his second victory in four days at Lincoln Downs, turning back Futuresque by a half length today in the Fall River Purse.

THIS first novel shows, with gusty reality and intimate knowledge, what can befall a group of individuals when suspicions and jealousies take over their emotions. It concerns the reactions of Wade Johannes' neighbors when they learn that his wife Naomi has met an untimely end.

This country's techniques for controlling the quality of manufactured products are being studied by French research engineers and statisticians as a means of increasing France's industrial productivity, according to word from the Mutual Security Agency.

Questionnaires have been sent to eighty-five public and private agencies in Brooklyn by the Brooklyn Council for Social Planning as part of a survey to determine the facilities and services available to the borough's Puerto Rican population.

The Hunter College Gilbert and Sullivan Society will open its fifteenth annual season Thursday evening with "The Gondoliers." The production will be at the Hunter College Playhouse on Sixty-eighth Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues.

Special programs in American studies are now developing in a number of colleges and universities throughout the United States. Several of these reflect the culture of the region in which the institution is located. One that is aimed at extending students' experience beyond the lines of their own regions is an unusual "Junior Year at Pembroke" plan, which will open this fall at the women's college in Providence, R. I.

CARACAS, Venezuela -- The world's newest "resort" area is the Gran Sabana of Venezuela, a remote region inhabited by primitive Indians and known to the civilized world only as a wild and unknown "lost world." It was visited, until last month, only by an occasional explorer or geologist drawn by the legends and rumors of its vast wealth in diamonds, gold, iron ore and other minerals.

THE salt-water anglers will need a lot of skill and luck during 1953 in order to make as many changes in the record book as were made during 1952, when a total of sixty-seven new marks were established in the various categories.

LONDON, March 21 -- President Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia briskly departed from London today at the end of a six-day visit that apparently was regarded by both himself and the British Government as a triumph of diplomacy and strategy.

PHILADELPHIA, March 21 -- Close to full employment has been maintained by industry in this Federal Reserve District throughout this quarter. In wholesale and retail merchandising the effects on price decontrol has been almost negligible.
TOKYO, Sunday, March 22 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,561, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Sunday, Korean time:

MORE than a quarter of a century has elapsed since the last new legitimate theatre was constructed on Broadway. The sad fact is that the great majority of theatres put up between 1912 and 1928 were badly conceived in design, cramped in space and even unsound for the economy of their period.

NEW DELHI, India, March 21 -- Jagjivan Ram, Communications Minister, introduced today in the House of the People, or lower house of Parliament, a measure authorizing the Central Government to acquire all airline companies, to be operated as state-owned enterprise.

ALBANY, March 21 -- Governor Dewey s plan for forcing a reluctant Democratic City Administration to transfer the New York City transit system to a new transit authority, which would be required to operate it without a deficit, received final legislative approval tonight a short time before the regular legislative session adjourned for the year at 11:34 P. M.

MEXICO CITY, March 19 -- More than two-thirds of Mexico's 150,000 Federal Government officials have complied with the provisions of law against "illegal enrichment," the ambitious project of President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines to legislate corruption in government out of existence.

Last week scores of reporters went to Nevada to witness the latest tests of what are enigmatically called "new and improved nuclear devices." A few of the reporters, chosen by lot, huddled in trenches and saw more of the atomic explosion than outsiders were ever permitted to see before -- more because they were closer.

ALTHOUGH every highway leading out of New York City is choked with traffic on a pleasant Saturday morning in spring, inevitably a few automobiles get clear of the pack and break out over a bridge or through a tunnel onto the highroad.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The President's naming of C. D. Jackson to carry on the work of the Psychological Strategy Board is the newest sign of the urgency being attached to the field of Government operations that includes this country's overseas information programs.

RICHMOND, Va., March 21 -- The Democratic party must swing more toward middle ground to keep the Republicans from holding their gains, particularly in the South, a Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner session was told here tonight.

LONDON, March 21 -- "Great men gain doubly when they make foes their friends." That aphorism written more than one hundred years ago by Edward Bulwer-Lytton was being put to a practical test this week in London.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 21 -- Jimmy Carruthers of Australia knocked out Vic Toweel of South Africa in the tenth round tonight to retain his world bantamweight championship. Toweel lost the title to Carruthers last year.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy suffered new setbacks today in his fight against confirmation of Charles E. Bohlen as Ambassador to Moscow as the Eisenhower Administration evidenced firm resistance to the tactics of the small but powerful bloc of Senate opponents.

HARTFORD, March 21 -- The Connecticut General Assembly this week approved a bill that, for the first time in half a century, makes a general revision of the boundary lines of the thirty-six State Senate districts. The measure will be before Gov. John Davis Lodge for his signature in the next few days.

MONTREAL, March 21 (UP) -- The Boston Bruins clinched a play-off berth in the National Hockey League tonight by turning back the Montreal Canadiens, 2 to 1, on a goal by Fleming Mackell with 83 seconds remaining.

It is ten months since the European Defense Community Treaty was signed by the six member nations. The treaty is the cornerstone of the West's defense program for Europe. It provides for inclusion of a 500,000-man German military force in a unified army linked to NATO. The European army treaty is also indissolubly tied to the Big Three's contractual agreements with Bonn, granting virtual full sovereignty to West Germany.

NEW ORLEANS, La. -- With the Louisiana Purchase anniversary as its major theme, the annual New Orleans Spring Fiesta will open on April 5 (Easter Sunday) before crowds of Orleanians and the first of tens of thousands of visitors expected here for this major south Louisiana fete.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Problems still stand in the way of televising President Eisenhower's news conferences, although the project has been a subject of study ever since the White House suggested the possibility two months ago.

The tanker Olympic Cloud, under construction at the A. G. Weser shipyard in Bremen, Germany, for Libertys S. A., will be launched on Wednesday. The Cloud, of 21,500 deadweight tons, is the first of six such vessels being built for the company headed by A. S. Onassis, international financial figure.

Reflecting greater confidence in the business outlook, stock prices for the second successive week continued their upward trend in heavier trading. Ending of price controls and publication of good earnings reports and forecasts were factors which influenced sentiment favorably.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Poland has repeated her charges that the United States is interfering in internal Polish affairs with the aim of espionage and subversion of the Communist Warsaw Government and has accused this country of oppressing minorities and discriminating against foreigners.

BUENOS AIRES, March 21 -- President Juan D. Peron's hopes of acquiring the collective sympathies and support of all Latin-American workers and of uniting them in one huge organization oriented to his ideology appeared to be facing a major setback today as leaders of the Communist-dominated Confederation of Latin-American Workers (C. T. A. L.) made final preparations for the opening in Santiago tomorrow of their fourth general congress.

COMPANY personnel chiefs, college advisers and placement officers and college graduates are faced this year with a situation which they variously call "ridiculous," "fantastic," "absurd," even "funny." The situation in essence is this: about 300,000 men will get college degrees this year.

Again, as Easter approaches, millions of Americans will receive through the mail the familiar Easter Seals with the white lily of hope and the words "Help Crippled Children." These seals will be sent to them by friends and neighbors who constitute the 67,000 members of the Board of Trustees of the 2,000 local Easter Seal societies affiliated with The National Society for Crippled Children and Adults.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 21 -- Even in its present reduced state of effectiveness the United Nations offers vast opportunities to direct the course of history. And since the United Nations Secretary General has similar opportunities to direct the work of the organization, there is no cause for wonder about the intensity of the current struggle over a successor to Trygve Lie, who submitted his resignation last fall.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 21 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., served notice today that his union would demand -- and if necessary, strike to achieve -- a guaranteed annual wage in 1955, when its five-year escalator agreements expire.

TRENTON, March 21 -- Robert B. Meyner, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, outlined today his plan for ridding New Jersey of "crime and corruption."

PIERRE, S. D., March 21 (AP) -- The South Dakota State Historian said today he favored moving the bones of the Indian leader, Sitting Bull, since his grave would be below the high-water line of the Oahe Dam reservoir. Will G. Robinson added that he would like to see the grave moved to a site on the Standing Rock Reservation, where a monument would be more accessible to visitors.

These are hard and bitter times for most of the nation's lead and zinc miners. Falling prices have plunged them into a recession at a time when producers of other major metals are basking in prosperity. Mines are closing. Unemployment is growing.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The last of Government controls over prices were cut loose this week, and it looks as though the switch to a free - floating economy will scarcely register on the average consumer's budget.

IN the headline and review of "The Silent World," the plural of octopus appears as octopi! Shy or otherwise, the eight-footed ones should be known in the plural, in English, as octopuses, or, if one must be self-consciously classical, as octopodes, perish the thought! For the plus part of the word is the Greek pous, podos Latinized.

THE title defines the aims, and hints at the limitations, of this new biography of James McNeill Whistler. Two Whistlers existed; and, preferably, they should be treated as one. There was the dandy, the poseur, the envenomed conversationalist, symbolized by the butterfly with a barbed sting that he adopted as his signature; and there was the artist, passionately attached to his art, who lived primarily for his secret vision of a mysterious and beautiful world.

LONDON, March 21 (Reuters) -- Owners and charterers of the United States tanker Seven Seas denied today that she had ever carried oil cargoes to Communist countries, as alleged in United States press reports yesterday.

PARIS, March 21 -- The three principal French ministers -- Premier Rene Mayer, Foreign Minister Georges Bidault and Finance Minister Maurice Bourges-Maunoury -- will visit Washington next week to lay some of France's troubles before President Eisenhower, Secretary Dulles and other American officials. WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower expressed great concern today over lags in the American Red Cross drives for funds and blood donations. She declared it "unthinkable" that the public should fail the Red Cross.

Elizabethan and other early English keyboard works will be represented in a two-disk set, and the series will continue through to the Vaughan Williams "Pastoral" Symphony in an interpretation by Air Adrian Boult and the London Philharmonic.

Five parties for hospitalized service men and veterans will be given this week by the 52 Association of New York, Inc. Tomorrow night a group of patients from Fort Dix Army Hospital will be the association's guests for dinner and theatre.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 21 -- The Israeli Cabinet at its weekly meeting in Jerusalem tomorrow, is expected to ratify the treaty with the West German republic under which Bonn will deliver goods worth $833,000,000 over twelve years as part compensation for the Nazi war crimes.

TOPEKA, Kan., March 21 -- The political future of C. Wesley Roberts, chairman of the Republican National Committee, was in doubt today as a Joint Investigating Committee of the Kansas Legislature met in executive session to decide whether he was innocent or guilty of peddling political influence during the legislative session two years ago.

Easter shopping increased during the week as a result of favorable weather. An increase of 6 to 7 per cent over the 1952 week was estimated. However, the selling season is one week closer to Easter than at this time a year ago.

TOKYO, Sunday, March 22 -- Rioting broke out again Thursday among the North Korean Red prisoners of war on Yongcho Island, near Koje off the coast of South Korea, where twenty-three prisoners were killed and forty-two injured in a stockade mutiny March 7.

A radio "book festival" consisting of a series of broadcasts concerning "every phase of the writing, production and appreciation of books" will be presented in the week of March 29 over New York's Station WNYC, Seymour N. Siegel, its director, announced yesterday.

A two-day meeting of the Marine Section of the National Safety Council, which will be held in conjunction with the twenty-third Greater New York Annual Safety Convention and Exposition, will open Wednesday morning at the Statler Hotel.

THE ancient poison-tester, whose longevity was determined largely by the number of enemies surrounding his royal boss, has a modern counterpart in New York in the person of Samuel Plotkin, who has been fearlessly pursuing his unorthodox profession for twenty-odd years and is still going strong.

The success of the country's first "Do-It-Yourself" show last week indicates that the American public has rediscovered the satisfaction of working creatively with its hands. The sixty-five exhibitors at the show now are convinced that the multibillion-dollar home market for lumber, carpenters' power tools, painting equipment and other items sought by amateurs will continue to grow.

TWENTIETH CENTURY-FOX took the wraps off its CinemaScope process last week with a series of demonstration showings of the wide screen system. The limited reaction of production personnel available at press time was generally enthusiastic.

PINEHURST, N. C., March 21 -- Eighteen-year-old Barbara McIntire of Toledo, Ohio, finished with three birdies today to eliminate the defending champion, Barbara Romack of Sacramento, Calif., 2 up, and gain the semi-finals of the North and South golf championship tournament.

A salary survey of municipal employment in Westchester County, compiled at New York University, has been incorporated in a preliminary study prepared by the Municipal Administrators Association for the Westchester County Village Officials Association.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 21 -- The battle of big-screen systems, which got under way Wednesday when Twentieth Century-Fox began showings of its CinemaScope process, was joined today by Paramount Pictures, which demonstrated its new screen and projector lenses, designed to give greater scope and illusion of depth to films made in the conventional manner.

LONDON, March 21 (AP) -- Blackpool and the Bolton Wanderers, Lancashire soccer clubs only forty miles apart, will meet in the final of the English Football Association Cup tournament at Wembley Stadium, May 2.

SPARTANBURG, S. C., March 21 (AP) -- Mrs. Jackie Pung of Glasgow Ky.. posted a one-under-par 70 today to take first place after the first thirty-six holes of the Peach Blossom-Betsy Rawls invitation open golf tournament.

NOBODY wanted to ride through Central Park in Mr. O'Flaherty's carriage because his horse was so slow. Josie plodded along because she was hungry and the hungrier she got the slower she walked and the less money Mr. O'Flaherty made to buy food.

Brooklyn College has received a Ford Foundation grant to undertake an evaluation study of an unusual experiment in educational processes that has been conducted at the college since 1949. It is an attempt to substitute individualized education for the mass production type and to instill into a large institution small college intimacy.

EVEN though Havana is not Paris by a long jai-alai shot, it is a very exciting city and one better understood by the casual visitor who brings with him some knowledge of the Cuban capital's history. Unfortunately, most Yanquis come to Cuba with no more background than a ready leer for the nightlife they read about in the travel brochures, the remembered fragrance of a good Havana cigar.

The few basic techniques needed by the beginner in art and materials of aid to the amateur will be described by James A. Ernst, artist, at 6:15 P. M. Tuesday at the third in a series of free art lectures at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

BY way of novelty, the current week's schedule contains the first New York appearances (at the Lexington Avenue "Y") of Lester Horton's Dance Theatre, from Los Angeles, one of the most firmly established dance enterprises on the West Coast.

THE big loan exhibition, "French Drawings: Masterpieces From Five Centuries," which has just opened at the Metropolitan Museum, is a doubly interesting event. Lent chiefly by French museums, with supplementary examples from other European collections, it includes work from Fouquet and Clouet to Lautrec which would take much time and travel to see in Europe.

Robert Bendiner's article, "If TV Moved Into the Classroom -- " (March 8) largely overlooks an important element in learning. A teacher is much more effective if he is standing in a room with his students, praising their efforts, forestalling their failures, inspiring and guiding them when they falter, than if he must teach on TV with no way of knowing when his pupils switch off their minds.

VIENNA, March 21 -- Antonin Zapotocky, hitherto Premier of Czechoslovakia, was unanimously elected President by a show of hands today in the Czechoslovak Parliament, which acted on the initiative of the Communist party. He succeeds Klement Gottwald, who died last Saturday.

WHEN the City Center first produced Bernard Shaw's "Misalliance" a month ago, everyone was happily astonished to find it so tonic and amusing. For more than thirty-five years "Misalliance" has been catalogued as one of those Shaw plays too prolix, too clever and too aimless to be tolerable in the theatre.

THE slimmed-down, more natural look continues to dominate the news for 1953. It has led to an increasing emphasis on texture in fabrics, and to color in new combinations. For spring, the trend to lighter clothes continues. while progress in man-made fibers brings new comfort to warm weather wear.

IF readers of this page will permit me to digress, I shall put off until next week, continuation of my little excursion into the mind and nature of the contemporary American intellectual. Meantime, you will find the discussion admirably advanced by Prof. T. V. Smith, in his review of the Partisan Review's symposium on this subject. (See Page 14.)

THE independence of India, on Aug. 15, 1947, was one of the greatest events of our fateful century; the partition which accompanied it was a colossal tragedy. In India, the man who dominated the event was Lord Mountbatten.
HANOVER, N. H., March 21 -- In the final indoor track meet of the season Yale defeated Dartmouth today, 671/2 to 411/2.

LONDON, March 21--In a seeming switch in the old Soviet propaganda line, one of the Moscow radio's best-known commentators told the world today that it was harmonious cooperation by the Soviet Union, the United States and Britain that produced victory in World War II.

TORNADOES -- whose winds sometimes exceed the speed of sound and whose concentrated force has made seventy-ton railway cars airborne -- are the most violent of known storms. Those who have taken cover from onrushing funnel-shaped clouds (and these include residents of every state) will find in this book much data of pith and value -- including ways to build a better tornado shelter.

OAKLAND, Calif., March 21 (AP) -- The slow, grim task of identifying the bodies of thirty-five air crash victims continued tonight as engineers studied wreckage in hope of learning what caused a four-engine plane to fall from the skies late yesterday. No one aboard survived.

To the Radio-Television Editor: AGENT OLGA LEE is so right! As an actor directly hit by the union ruling she mentions, I'd like to ask by what right may an American union deny agent representation to art actor unless his salary is above minimum scale?

Inflation-harried France is turning again to the purchasing power bond in the hope of breaking down the resistance of French people to investing in fixed-income securities and of thereby restoring a public bond market worthy of the name.

AGAIN the United Nations General Assembly is in session and again the cold war of words between the Kremlin and the Western powers, which has gone on throughout the seven years of the U. N.'s operation, is apparent at every proceeding. The accusations and countercharges grow ever more bitter.

SINCE the area of the average house being built today is 25 per cent smaller than it would have been fifteen years ago, the ability to create an atmosphere of spaciousness, in the small home seems one of the most important challenges the contemporary residential architect must meet. How one architect met and solved this problem is shown in the home pictured on these pages.

Members of the Bennett Club of New York, comprising alumnae of Bennett Junior College in Millbrook, N. Y., formerly known as the Bennett School for Girls, will take over the performance of Cinerama the night of April 3 at the Broadway Theatre for the benefit of the college's building fund.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, has instructed the heads of the three armed services to examine their tables of organization with a view to paring personnel in clerical, supply and other administrative positions.

Many boxes and' seats have been purchased for the concert to be given by rturo Toscanini and members of the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra on Saturday afternoon at Carnegie Hail for the benefit of the Artists Veterans Hospital Programs and the Hospitalized Veterans Music Service.

NEW DELHI, India, March 21--Further efforts by India for an Asian peace settlement based on New Delhi's Korean truce resolution of last December, which was rejected by the Soviet Union, were suggested by Chester Bowles today on the eve of his departure for the United States. Mr. Bowles is being replaced as Washington's envoy here by George V. Allen, now Ambassador to Yugoslavia.

THE extremely large number of musical works of all kinds, made accessible to the public last season on disks, gave rise to a half-serious quip to the effect that "everything will be recorded by Christmas." In the operatic category alone surely the output was unexpectedly comprehensive, but the choices often seemed capricious.

THE narrow trousers without cuffs, prominent in London, will also be greatly in evidence in Italy this spring. Waistcoats, too, contribute importantly to current styles, with the single-breasted flannel popular. Spring topcoats, by and large, will be the raglan type.

CLOTHES do not make the traveling man (in the tourist sense that is) as much trouble as they used to. Whether he is a fly-by-night tourist or the tweedy shipboard type, it is possible for him to go around the world in one big suitcase without looking like a tramp.

Dr. Lewis Webster Jones, president of Rutgers University, urged yesterday that all universities open their doors to investigators, as "it will be an opportunity to show the public what we are like." Less subversiveness would be found, he said, than in other professions.

THE life of a salesman, according to those who sell records, is an alternation of harmony and discord enforced by those who buy them. Yet the seller must adjust to the squawk as well as to the chortle if he is frequently to hear the sound of the cash register, which he not unnaturally regards as the sweetest music of all.

WITH the Metropolitan Opera season having only three more weeks to go, devotees are naturally beginning to wonder what Rudolf Bing will have in store for them next season. He has already announced revivals of "Faust," "Tannhaeuser" and "The Barber of Seville."

THE man in charge of programming recorded music for a radio station like WQXR can hardly be in a better position to estimate public tastes. Each month hundreds of letters, post cards and phone calls bombard his office with comments, criticism, praise and requests.

THERE'S no telling how this natural and man-made fiber debate is going to get settled, or blended, but it certainly won't be over lunch. That one was tried the other day. The intransigeants displayed a low blend factor. You never heard so many cutting remarks about "pilling," "wicking" and "crocking."

VIENNA, March 21 -- The death of Joseph Stalin, followed closely by that of President Klement Gottwald of Czechoslovakia, his principal lieutenant in the satellites, caught the "people's democracies" of the East bloc in a state of near crisis.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, March 22 (UP) -- South Korea's acting Premier, Paik Too Chin said today that his battered nation would have to curtail its war effort unless substantial aid was furnished by the United States. Mr. Paik, who is also Finance Minister, said in a statement that the Republic of Korea's finances had been strained to the breaking point.
LONDON, March 21 (Reuters) -- Results of today's British football games:

Rabbi Israel Goldstein said yesterday morning at Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 257 West Eighty-eighth Street, that he had found in West Germany "a large mass of people" who were "indifferent to moral issues" and still believed Adolf Hitler's worst blunder was to lose World War II.

IT was in 1938 that Richard Wright, then 30 years old, published his first book, a collection of four tendentious stories called "Uncle Tom's Children." In the Forties he published only two books; only two books, but each of them with a heavy impact upon its readers.

TWENTY-NINE years ago the dirigible ZR-3 appeared out of the east and floated gracefully over an excited New York, whose citizens, in that brash and happy day, were concerned with nothing much more cosmic than prohibition and the flapper.

CAUSES and costs of accidents, great and small, ranging from pinpricks to truck collisions, will be analyzed at the twenty-third annual Safety Convention and Exposition sponsored by the Greater New York Safety Council at the Hotel Statler and New Yorker from Tuesday extending through Friday.

Supplementing comments made in this column a week ago on the taxability, under the Federal estate tax, of the value of a survivorship annuity elected by a member of a pension plan, it should be pointed out that in all of the three court decisions discussed therein the employe had made his election prior to Oct. 8, 1949, the effective date of the Technical Changes Act.

ONE of the less conspicuous aspects of the traffic on movie theatre screens, but one which has caused some apprehension among more thoughtful customers in recent years, is the steadily diminishing appearance of the information or "documentary" type of film, not alone in the feature-length area but most particularly in the way of one and two reel shorts.

GENEVA, March 21 -- In the three principal industrial countries of Western Europe, Britain, West Germany and France, there is a pronounced wave of mourning over the demise of the private saver, a fellow for whom hardly anyone ever had a good word during the period of his long and fatal illness.

New York is operating this year with the largest budget in its history -- $1,469,265,101 for the fiscal year ending June 30 -- a budget exceeding that of any other unit of government in the nation except the Federal Government itself. For the year ahead it is facing a financial crisis.

Several new singers were in the large cast of "Boris Godunov" at the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday evening. Margaret Roggero, as Fyoder; Genevieve Warner, as Xenia; Paul Franke, as Shuiski; Arthur Budney, as Shchelkalov; Nell Rankin, as Marina; Gabir Carelli, as the Simpleton, and Tibor Kozma, the conductor, were seen for the first time.

CHICAGO, March 22 (UP) -- A chubby, six-year-old boy, one of five orphans who are trying to "go it alone" following the death of their parents, stared in wide-eyed excitement today while scores of friends and well-wishers brought or sent him birthday gifts.

A portion of your editorial "Tito in London" seems untenable to one who usually regards your opinions as well considered and soundly reasoned. You state that "Tito has been patriot enough to lead his country out of Soviet bondage to which he had subjected it." Does not such an evaluation make a virtue of a necessity?

The final work of Sholom Aleichem, "Adventures of Mottel, the Cantor's Son," will be published on April 13 by Henry Schuman. The story follows the adventures of "a Yiddish Huck Finn" as he travels from his native land through the chief cities of Europe to "the Promised Land," America.

DETROIT, March 22 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens kept Gordie Howe from equaling the National Hockey League scoring record tonight but had to settle for a 1-1 tie with the champion Detroit Red Wings in the final game of the regular season.

Ceremonial robes and bright-hued Japanese kimonos brought a splash of Oriental color to uptown Manhattan yesterday in a slow-measured "chigo" procession put on by Buddhist youngsters in costumes of the Tendoji, or the "heavenly children."

CHICAGO, March 22 -- Grain futures prices worked upward moderately after a few sinking spells early in the week. No great conviction was shown on either side of the market, the general idea being that the future trend will depend on the weather for the next few weeks, and on the volume of marketings, especially of wheat and corn.

The recent testimonial to Adolph Zukor as the father of motion pictures may recall to old-timers the Eden Musee, on Twenty-third Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. This fabulous landmark duplicated Madame Tussaud's Waxworks, with many novelties added.

AMSTERDAM, March 22 -- Professor Jelle Zijlstra, Minister of Economic Affairs, said in the upper chamber last week that the balance of payments on current account last year showed a surplus of 1,950,000,000 guilders against a deficit of 300,000,000 in the preceding year.

Passion Sunday was defined yesterday by the Very Rev. James A. Pike, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, as an Easter "prelude" in which "we look ahead to the mighty works of God to be enacted in the next two weeks."

ALBANY, March 22 -- Extensive changes in traffic laws affecting pedestrians as well as automobile owners and drivers are provided in a long series of bills pending before Governor Dewey for his approval or veto as a result of this year's legislative session.

Reforms in New York's traffic courts in the last three years have reduced intentional flouting of traffic summonses from 100,000 to 20,000 annually, Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh said yesterday in his annual report for the City Magistrates Courts in 1952.

The major menace to the supremacy of New York as the nation's first port is rail rate differentials that give competitor ports an advantage, Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, said yesterday.
Six metropolitan high school students examined the Taft-Hartley Act yesterday on the New York Times Youth Forum and agreed unanimously that the law needed amendment.

It has been a well kept secret that Ted Atkinson, the great jockey, has been in Mercy Hospital in Miami since last Wednesday, suffering with head pains that were the result of a fall from a horse that dropped dead under him in a race at Gulfstream Park on Friday, March 13.
Cotton futures in the domestic market turned lower last week. At the close of trading on Friday on the New York Cotton Exchange prices were down 29 to 53 points, or $1.45 to $2.65 a bale.
Color books and other art teaching methods tending to curb creative thinking on the part of children were deplored by three art instructors in a panel discussion Saturday at the Museum of Modern Art.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 22 -- The Israeli Cabinet ratified today the agreement under which the West German Republic will pay to Israel and to the Jewish Claims Committee representing worldwide Jewish organizations $840,000,000 in reparations.

MOSCOW, March 22 (UP) -- The Government organ Izvestia said today ratification by the West Ger man Bundestag of the Bonn convention and the European army pact was "a staged farce such as Hitler staged in the Reichstag."
FORTH WORTH, Tex., March 22 (AP) -- Three prisoners died here today in a sensational but brief struggle to break out of the Tarrant County jail.
