WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- Maple T. Harl, chairman of the Federal agency which insures bank deposits, said today 13,645 out of the nation's 14,575 banks now have Federal insurance against losses to their depositors.
Seven new films, including importations from England and Sweden, are arriving in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
ALBANY, March 22 -- Following are the principal actions taken by the Legislature during the 1953 session, which ended last night:

Wagner's "Parsifal" will have two performances during the twenty-first week at the Metropolitan Opera House. The first will be on Wednesday evening, April 1, and the second Good Friday afternoon. Both will have some different artists from those involved in tonight's performance of the consecrational music-drama.

ALBANY, March 22 -- A bill making savings and loan associations subject for the first time to a revised version of the present tax on dividends paid by savings banks is now before Governor Dewey, awaiting his signature.

Home Service workers in the 3,700 chapters of the American Red Cross assisted nearly a quarter of a million persons each month in 1952 with their personal and domestic problems, E. Roland Harriman, national president of the Red Cross, announced yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, March 22 -- Seeking to shatter the specter of continued depression and growing food shortages in the once-rich Punjab Province of Pakistan, Mian Mumtaz Mohammed Khan Daultana, Provincial Prime Minister, outlined plans in an interview in Lahore yesterday for a rehabilitation program to overcome the present plight of the area's 18,000,000 weary and often hungry people.

Too many persons today, including Christians, have little or no understanding of the meaning of "the church," the Rev. Dr. Arthur B. Whiting asserted in a sermon yesterday morning at the First Baptist Church, Seventhy-ninth Street and Broadway.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 22 -- The Screen Extras Guild, A. F. L., has reached agreement on the terms of a basic bargaining contract calling for increased salary minimums and extra pay for working over and beyond an established schedule with the Alliance of Television Film Producers and two non-member producing companies, Roland Reed Productions and Hal Roach Productions.

TOKYO, Monday, March 23 -- United States and South Korean troops struck out in two large-scale raids yesterday against Communist soldiers holed up in caves along the Western Korean front. United States Marines fought off a Chinese Red attack east of the truce conference site of Panmunjom in the same general area.

The emotional and philosophic contours of a pianist do not change too much over the years. This listener heard Monique de la Bruchollerie during the war years in Paris, and her playing then closely resembled the playing she displayed last night in Carnegie Hall.
British pound sterling and the Canadian dollar moved higher in the foreign exchanges during the past week in a market that was moderately active.

Mayor Impellitteri fired oratorical barbs yesterday at potential rivals in this year's Mayoralty race and other critics. He cast an Italian epithet at Council President Rudolph Halley, and hurled a Scotch joke to imply that other Board of Estimate members would like to see him drown so they could get his job.
TAMPA, Fla., March 22 -- It appears that the time has arrived to view with alarm the condition of the Yankees' pitching staff.

The younger industrial worker often looks forward to retiring from his job while the older worker generally tries to put it off as long as possible, a study conducted at Columbia University's Teachers College has found.

UIJONGBU, Korea, March 22 -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, Eighth Army commander, stood reverently in a rough-hewn Army church this afternoon and said that all soldiers, to be good soldiers, but be men of faith.

Sid Abel's Chicago Black Hawks clinched a Stanley Cup play-off berth last night by downing the New York Rangers, 3 -- 1, in the finale of the regular National Hockey League season for both teams at Madison Square Garden.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., March 22 -- The dangerous effect on United States foreign relations of policies of racial segregation and discrimination at home was cited repeatedly here this afternoon at a symposium at Sarah Lawrence College.
The statement of the American Psychiatric Association, reported in the March 17 issue of THE TIMES, has a number of misconceptions which confuse the issue as to who should do psychotherapy.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Two of the leading authorities of Congress in the economic field lined up in opposition today to a bill that would abolish the Reconstruction Finance Corporation at the end of the year.

PARIS, March 22 -- Speaking of his visit to Washington next Wednesday, Premier Rene Mayer said today that France was willing to help unify Europe if she were accepted as a world power and provided with the means to fulfill her role.

Six thousand policemen heard a police chaplain defend the department yesterday as the world's finest police organization and make an appeal to the public to presuppose the "right" to be on the side of the police against any charges of brutality.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The formation of a private organization to be known as the Nationwide Committee of Industry, Agriculture and Labor on Import-Export Policy was announced here today. Purpose of the organization is to bring "before the public the basic facts relating to import competition and the present low level of our tariff" and to "counteract the ruinous free trade proposals recently made by Henry Ford II and the Detroit Board of Commerce."

Plans for erecting two six-story apartment houses on a property in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn that had been held by the seller's family for more than fifty years were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of a vacant plot 258 by 170 feet at 339-63-67 Webster Avenue by Eleanor E. Maloney to a client of the Bulkley Horton Company, broker.
PINEHURST, N. C., March 22 (AP) -- Pat O'Sullivan of Orange, Conn., and Mary Lena Faulk of Thomasville, Ga., today gained the final of the Women's North and South golf championship.

PARIS, March 22 (AP) -- From a crude peasant home in Yugoslavia, a former mathematics teacher who boasts the support of 50,000 guerrillas is reported to be plotting revolution against the Moscow-directed Communist Government of Albania.

KANSAS CITY, March 22 (AP) -- A total of fifty-one member schools will share dividends in the $1,151-109.22 paid by sponsors for the National Collegiate Athletic Association's controlled football television program last year.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public, which will mature within twelve months, amount to $73,374,104,149. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

UNITED NATIONS, New York, March 22 -- In anticipation of a bitter attack against the United States by Czechoslovakia tomorrow in the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly, a group of Czechoslovak refugees submitted to Secretary General Trygve Lie Saturday a mass of evidence concerning past and current conditions in their homeland under the Communist regime.

ROME, March 22 -- With the Government's electoral reform bill still stalled in the Senate by the delaying tactics of the Communists and the Left-Wing Socialists, Premier Alcide De Gasperi opened the electoral campaign today with a speech to small landowning peasants gathered in Rome from all parts of Italy.

The New York Legislature adjourned its regular session, which began on January 7, with a rush of business done in the final three or four days that considerably redeemed a barren previous record and that, in respect to New York City's affairs, wrought a major change in the administration and fiscal policy of the transit system.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., March 22 -- This early spring day, the first on which sailing dinghy races have been held, brought out twenty-eight craft at the Larchmont Yacht Club, the largest number since the start of the cold-weather windjamming in November.

The United States, Canada and Switzerland should be prepared to provide a "very substantial" stabilization fund to aid limited convertibility of free-world currencies, acording to an outline yesterday of recommendations drafted by directors of the International Chamber of Commerce.
LOS ANGELES, March 22 -- Mr. Truman will be guest of honor at a distinctly nonpolitical $30-a-plate dinner here tomorrow night.

In the midst of all the present controversy about Congressional investigation of possible subversion in American education there is one thought, I am sure, which has occurred to many, many educators in our colleges.
ADVANCE U. S. AIR BASE, in Korea, Monday, March 23 (AP) -- Do you know why Sabre jet pilots completely outclass Communist airmen in day-in, day-out battles over North Korea?

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., sent yesterday to Governor Dewey and Mayor Impellitteri telegrams requesting individual conferences with the two executives to discuss proposed changes in the New York rapid transit set-up.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 22 -- Harry S. Truman emphatically declared himself in retirement today "as a professional politician." But, before sailing for a month's vacation in Hawaii, he announced his intention of settling down in Missouri afterward to "work to help keep this the great country it is now."

ALBANY, March 22 -- Governor Dewey announced today that he would use a $200,000 fund voted to him yesterday in the closing hours of the 176th Legislature to finance an inquiry into the high cost of workmen's compensation insurance in New York State.

ZURICH, March 22 -- Three agreements signed by West Germany and Switzerland on August 26, 1952, became effective last Thursday, enabling the Washington accord of May 26, 1946, between the Allies and Switzerland covering liquidation of the assets in Switzerland of "Germans in Germany," to be amended so as to satisfy the claims of the Allies by the payment of a lump sum in Swiss francs by the Government of West Germany.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, stanchly supporting the nomination of Charles E. Bohlen to be Ambassador to the Soviet Union, told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee last week his security officer had said he could not "automatically pass" a Federal Bureau of Investigation report on the case.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 22 -- The formation of a new producing company, Lincoln Productions, Inc., was announced today by Hal Roach Jr., who will be its president. A minimum of six features is scheduled for the first year's operations, with a property titled "Captain Scarface" slated to go before the cameras within five weeks at the Hal Roach Studios in Culver City, where the company will make its headquarters.

Carmen Shepperd, mezzo-soprano, was heard in a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. With Norman Johnson at the piano, she presented a carefully devised program including early classics by Cesti, Strozzi and Handel, a Mozart aria, a group of German songs by Wolf, French lyrics by Milhaud and Faure, Negro spirituals and Ned Rorem's "The Resurrection," which received its first performance.

PITTSBURGH, March 22 -- At the rate steel poured from the mills last week, it appeared today that more than 10,000,000 tons would be produced this month -- a record. There is a good chance the 10,000,000-ton mark will be exceeded by 200,000 tons or more.

BALBOA, C. Z., March 22 -- Brig. Gen. John S. Seybold, Governor of the Canal Zone, will leave by air tomorrow for Washington to appear at hearings of the Senate Appropriations Committee and attend a meeting of the board of directors of the Panama Canal Company to be held Friday.
MIAMI, March 22 -- The remnants of yesterday's Gulf Coast storm descended on Miami Field today, with the result that the Dodgers' exhibition with the Boston Red Sox was washed out.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., March 22 (AP) -- The Rochester Royals pulled ahead late in the third quarter tonight to defeat Fort Wayne, 83 -- 71, and even their play-off series in the National Basketball Association.
A housing project here will be named for Samuel Gompers, founder of the American Federation of Labor.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 22 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, presented today its terms for merging with the American Federation of Labor. They included a clean-up of New York waterfront racketeering.
OAKLAND, Calif., March 22 -- The Giants concluded their California barnstorming tour on a curious note today that left Leo Durocher wondering whether to smile or bawl out everyone in sight.

ALBANY, March 22 -- A resolution urging Congress to make service in the National Guard mandatory for inductees under the Universal Military Training program after they had completed their two years of active duty failed to get through the Legislature.

Atlantic Refining Company last year had gross sales and other operating revenues of $602,805,000, a new record, according to the company's pamphlet report, for 1952. This compares with the previous high of $560,964,000 in 1951.

Legislation, organizational drives and the affiliation of a hitherto independent union are expected to be among the principal topics of discussion at the sixth biennial convention of the Seafarers International Union opening this morning in San Diego, Calif.

OMAHA, March 22 (AP) -- Researchers today transmitted the brain waves of a laboratory aide over ordinary telephone lines in what was described as the first such successful test. This means it is now possible for a medical expert to make an immediate analysis of brain waves of a distant patient.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 22 -- The principal objectives of a proposed Northern California Ports and Terminals Bureau would be to combat railroad, truck and steamship rates considered injurious to ports of this area and to recommend ways to develop new cargoes and to regain traffic lost to other parts of the country, a report on the project showed today.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, will take his first official step tomorrow toward what the Eisenhower Administration hopes will be the restoration of a firm and effective relationship between the United States and Latin America.

The complete modernization of the fifty-five-year-old Brinckerhoff Theatre at Barnard College and the establishment of the Minor Latham Drama Workshop will be undertaken this summer in connection with the projected renovation of Milbank Hall, the college's oldest building.

Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia and Carlos E. Guimard and Miguel Najdorf of Argentina, all winners in the sixth round, broke away from the quadruple tie for first place yesterday and, with scores of 5 -- 1, assumed the lead in the international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata, according to a report from Buenos Aires.

The peepers have been about for several days now, so obviously it is spring. They are never wrong. High in ivory towers, official weather forecasters consult maps and figures, committing in the process many a fancy blooper. Not so the peepers.

Most New Yorkers think that yesterdays are forever lost, but Dr. Theodore Kazimiroff reaches back into countless New York yesterdays and fills his home with them. He finds them just off the pavement, or under it.

NEW CITY, N. Y., March 22 -- Mrs. Maxwell Anderson, wife of the Pulitzer prize winning dramatist, was found dead today in the garage on the grounds of the Anderson home. The police gave the cause of death as apparently suicide from carbon monoxide poisoning.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (UP) -- Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican of New Hampshire, said today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy "may be doing what he thinks right" but his methods are "wrong -- un-American."

Fifty-four new settlements at a cost of $26,600,000 will be constructed in Israel by July to put urban dwellers on farms, to settle newcomers and to accelerate food production, Rudolf G. Sonneborn, national chairman of the United Israel Appeal, reported yesterday to its board of directors.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- Foreign aid by the United States in 1952 totaled more than $5,500,000,000, divided almost evenly between military and economic assistance to the free world, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Claramae Turner, who created the role of Madame Flora when Gian-Carlo Menotti's "The Medium" had its premiere at Columbia University seven years ago, returned to the part last night in her first appearance as a member of the New York City Opera Company at the City Center.

TO be intelligent is not necessarily to be wise and to revere virtue does not necessarily mean the avoidance of sin. David Flint, the intensely fallible hero and the narrator of "Hear and Forgive,"* by Emyr Humphreys, was highly intelligent and often extremely foolish, sincerely religious and often weakly sinful. Reading about him in this subtle and thought-provoking novel is an intellectually interesting experience, although certainly not an engrossing or emotionally moving one.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (UP) -- A group of twenty-four top farm and retail food officials said today they are launching a program aimed at disposing of troublesome farm surpluses on the marketplace without cost to the taxpayers.

It was an interesting and unusual twist. Bill Butterfield, athletic director and basketball coach at Oakwood, a co-educational school at Poughkeepsie, N. Y., was in the gymnasium talking about his cage squads' successes in recent years. Suddenly he switched to the school's pretty cheerleaders.

BOSTON, March 22 -- The Most Rev. Richard J. Cushing, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Boston today defended Louis J. Perini's moving of the Boston Braves to Milwaukee as a possible "blessing in disguise" for this city.

ALBANY, March 22 -- Governor Dewey urged today that the Federal Communications Commission extend the deadline for allocation of all educational television channels to permit consideration of "every possible sound action" to establish educational television in New York State.

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 22 (AP) -- A vactioning Detroit motorcycle policeman, Paul R. Cox, became exasperated with a motorist weaving around his car today and finally fired a shot that hit the man's dashboard.

Voicing apprehension for the school budget in the face of the city's financial predicament, the Public Education Association urged Mayor Impellitteri yesterday to grant the Board of Education sufficient funds for 1953-54.

The little woman likes it easy in New York. The "Inventory of Food and Drug Products" conducted for Joseph Jacobs Advertising and Merchandising, Inc., by The Pulse, Inc., during January, 1953, shows the largest increase in home acceptance for those products that make housekeeping easier.

The remarks of Baron de Rothschild as reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 18, blaming the Roman Catholic Church in France for the disappearance of the Finaly children, do little to calm what is already a greatly troubled situation.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 22 -- Yugoslavia is about to abandon her involved system of forced industrial production and replace it with the traditional system of incentive production, with profits to be taxed progressively as in Western capitalist countries.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (UP) -- Edgar G. Brown, president of the National Negro Council, said today that he had urged President Eisenhower to award the Medal of Honor to two heroes of the Korean war, a Negro Army private and a white lieutenant colonel.

At a short ceremony in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral preceding solemn mass yesterday. Cardinal Spellman presented the Papal award "Pro Ecclesia et Pontifice" to Judge Harold A. Stevens of the Court of General Sessions, who is president of the Catholic Interracial Council, and Gerard L. Carroll, chairman of the council's board.

General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen has denied an application for an order that would keep the grand jury from inspecting the accounting records of Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association. He rejected the argument made on behalf of Mr. Ryan that to produce his records would violate his constitutional right against self-incrimination.

Michael Robin, violinist, gave a recital Saturday night at Hunter College Auditorium as the tenth and last event in the school's Jubilee Series. The highly gifted 17-year-old artist again impressed deeply by the inborn musicality and the technical proficiency he manifested throughout an exacting and diversified program.

How does anybody ever learn anything in school? How can a youth with no more moral fiber than he can accumulate from comic strips and television serials ever bring himself to open a textbook, that dank dungeon where knowledge rots in rusted gyves?

" Improvement in selling techniques is retailing's top priority problem," John C. Williams, president of L. Bamberger Co. of Newark, said in a statement issued over the week-end, calling for a concerted effort to overcome existing deficiencies.

President Eisenhower's appointment of Lewis W. Douglas to head a new study of America's foreign economic policy is an excellent one. Former Ambassador to Great Britain and former Under Secretary of the Treasury, Mr. Douglas brings to this task a broad experience and deep knowledge of the questions with which he will have to deal.
LONDON, March 22 (AP) -- Peace and collaboration with the West were the main themes over the Moscow radio tonight as the Soviet Union pushed its new "peace offensive" to the hilt.
TEANECK, N. J., March 22 -- The dice player's dream figure seven, proved a winning one for a white standard poodle in the fourteenth show of the Kennel Club of Northern New Jersey today.

The third day of spring, and its first Sunday, brought the perennial thousands of appreciative out-of-towners yesterday to Manhattan's places of interest that are consistently taken for granted or ignored by the natives.
A new shop called Habitat Associates has been opened on the second floor at 837 Madison Avenue. The offerings are available through decorators.
Four race horses and a lead pony burned to death and three more horses and a second pony were believed dead in a fire that last night destroyed a barn at the Jamaica Race Track in Queens.
SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 22 (AP) -- Christian Pravda, Austrian Olympic star skiing for Sun Valley, won the men's downhill of the thirteenth annual Harriman Cup races on Baldy Mountain today.
A dentist, who was the object two weeks ago of an attempted robbery and assault by a man posing as a patient, identified his assailant yesterday at a police line-up by examining the suspect's teeth.

Democratic family living not only repays all concerned in satisfaction and happiness but is basic to developing in children the strength and understanding required to support democracy against dictatorship, according to Dr. Ernest Osborne, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the only important roll-call in Congress during the period March 13 to 19 are given in the appended tabulation:

HANOI, Vietnam, March 22 -- Nguyen Huu Tri, a Dai Viet (Great Vietnam) Nationalist who resigned as Governor of North Vietnam in March, 1951, because of the slowness with which his country was then acquiring independence, expressed satisfaction today at the emergence of a more liberal French attitude toward autonomous Vietnamese rule.

PARIS, March 22 -- During the session of the Marshall Plan council tomorrow and Tuesday the chief topic of discussion will be the situation of the European Payments Union. The positon of the union involves four principal features:

BONN, Germany, March 22 -- Unity of Germany is an objective policy of the Federal Government, but at the moment the nation's watchwords must be patience and hope, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer declared today.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Victory in Korea was almost within his grasp during the counter-offensive of June, 1951, but it was snatched away by the fruitless armistice talks at Panmunjom, Gen. James A. Van Fleet, former Commander of the United Nations Ground Forces in Korea, told the Senate Armed Services Committee in testimony released today.

Mayor Impellitteri said yesterday "I don't know exactly what the city can do" in the bitter choice between swallowing Governor Dewey's financial prescription for a higher-fare transit authority before new taxing powers could be used, or trying to find drastic economies against an impending $173,000,000 deficit.

Steve Grivnow's goal five minutes before the end enabled the Harmarville (Pa.) Soccer Club, the United States champion, to gain a 1-0 victory over the New York Americans in the opening game of the Eastern final series of the National Challenge Cup at Sterling Oval in the Bronx yesterday.

The establishment of a four-year scholarship to be awarded annually at Manhattan College's School of Engineering was announced yesterday by Arthur H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works, at the fourteenth annual communion breakfast of the Manhattan College Engineers Society.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22 (AP) -- The Cardinals lost Grant Dunlap, a rookie first baseman, to the hospital detail today while dropping an exhibition game to the Braves, 5 -- 1. Manager Eddie Stanky and Catcher Del Rice were ejected from the game by Umpire Art Gore.
TOKYO, Monday, March 24 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,562, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Monday, Korean time:

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- Alger Hiss, former State Department official, was pictured as having played a limited role at the Yalta conference in February of 1945. This picture was developed in testimony by Mr. Bohlen, released today.
LONDON, March 22 -- A nationalized and nation-wide health service available to everyone has become a well established fact of British life.

MAIZURU, Japan, Monday, March 23 -- The attention of the 84,000,000 Japanese turned today to this bustling West Coast port where 4,000 men, women and children are arriving as repatriates from Communist China.
NAIROBI, Kenya, March 22 -- More than 2,500 African tribesmen were arrested in one raid today by hundreds of troops and policemen with armored cars at the shanty town of Pumwani here.

It is perhaps startling to many of us to realize that a far greater number of men are graduated each year from the armed forces than from the nation's colleges. During 1952 more than 1,000,000 service men were discharged to take up civilian life and employment, while only 350,000 graduates left college.

The National Association for American Composers and Conductors completed its activities for 1952-53 late yesterday afternoon when it presented its fifth and final free concert of the season at Town Hall.

The inevitable marriage of television and the Hollywood motion picture industry moved a step nearer with the televising of the annual awards of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. It is now pretty evident that Hollywood's dog-in-the-manger attitude toward TV has harmed the films more than video.

There have been times when the Moscow radio has indicated that the Russians thought the Second World War was won entirely by the Red Army. On our own side of the line it has been natural to wonder if the Western Allies didn't contribute at least a little to the final victory.
The outstanding art event this week in New York is the exhibition of Japanese painting and sculpture that opens Friday at the Metropolitan Museum.
" The Marriage of Figaro," staged at the City Center Saturday evening, continues to be one of the best productions offered by the City Opera.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The arrival here Wednesday of Premier Rene Mayer and Foreign Minister Georges Bidault will bring the United States Government directly to grips with several explosive questions of current French politics and international diplomacy.

The first of the following tabulations compares the fares and operating experiences of the transit systems of the fourteen largest cities in the United States; the second compares the public transit systems in six cities:

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today fifty-five Korean war casualties in a list that included twenty-three killed, thirty wounded, one missing and one injured. Listed as captured were twenty-three men previously reported missing in action.
In a cash deal negotiated by Frank Deutscher, broker, the one-family dwelling at 46-16 261st Street, Great Neck, was sold by Fred O. Eck to John and Mildred Butcher.
Maternity clothes can be as stylish as they are comfortable today. In recent years, talented designers have devoted their attention to them, making them both good-looking and useful.

VIENNA, March 22 -- Chancellor Leopold Figl reported to his People's party today that he had been unable to form a government in the four weeks since the elections on Feb. 23 resulted in a photo finish between the People's party and the Socialists.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 22 (AP) -- Lew Worsham, a former national open champion, shot his third straight 68 in the Jacksonville Open golf tournament today to share the lead with Tommy Bolt, who had a 70. They stood at 204, with the final round scheduled tomorrow.

The board of directors of the Jewish National Fund of America, the land development arm of the World Zionist Organization in Israel, elected Dr. Harris J. Levine yesterday for a fourth consecutive term as president of the fund at its annual meeting at the Biltmore Hotel.

The Congress for Cultural Freedom, which last year staged "Masterpieces of the Twentieth Century" festival in Paris, next year will offer $3,000 for a violin concerto, $2,000 for a short symphonic work and $1,200 for a work for solo voice and a small group of instruments.

KANSAS CITY, March 22 (AP) -- The largest meeting of aviation organizations ever planned opens here tomorrow among indications of sharp disagreement on the Administration's budget balancing attitude toward the nation's airports.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 22 (AP) -- The Minneapolis Lakers scored an 85-69 victory over Indianapolis in the first game of a Western Division play-off series in the National Basketball Association today. Vern Mikkelsen's 18 points led the winners.

Another protest against the international sculpture competition for the "Unknown Political Prisoner" and the "strange and contorted mass of wire" adjudged winner of the competition held recently in London by the Institute of Contemporary Arts, has been made here.

Our general diet may become lighter as spring advances, but our beer gets heavier. The traditional brew of this pleasant season is the bock -- the mahogany-hued, slightly sweet, heavy-bodied beverage that now returns to the city's groceries, tap rooms and restaurants.

Carmine G. DeSapio, the leader of Tammany Hall, charged last night that Governor Dewey's plan for forcing the city administration to accept a transit authority and his accompanying tax program for the city constituted "a frightful and unbearable burden" on the wage-earners of the city.

Recent attacks on educators and the application of "very special" loyalty oaths are keeping many persons out of the short - handed teaching profession, Dr. Alvin C. Eurich, vice president of the Fund for the Advancement of Education of the Ford Foundation, declared yesterday.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 22 -- Malayan tin ore production hit a post-war peak in January of 4,998 tons, according to figures published by the International Tin Study Group. However, Indonesian output slipped in January to 2,544 tons and declined further in February to 2,142, the lowest level in at least two years.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- General Van Fleet's testimony, together with that of the Pentagon chiefs, caused Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican of Vermont, and Senator Case to question whether the ammunition shortage had not been in fact part of a deliberate Government policy to hold the Army in check.

Chester Bowles wound up his mission to India with some parting words of good advice to his fellow countrymen as well as to the people of India. He hoped the United States would help finance India's five-year plan, at a cost between $600,000,000 and $700,000,000. That would be our contribution to a people who are "struggling to create a great new democracy in Asia."
THE NEW YORK TIMES editorials on the Governor's fiscal and administrative proposals for New York City have served to clarify these complex problems for the discouraged citizen.

In Topics of The Times of March 8 you report under the title "Unique from 'Unicus,'" on the "* * * quixotic effort * * * to revive Latin as a vehicle for articles of general interest on contemporary topics." This effort may be unique today, but there were societies and magazines bent on a similar purpose in different countries not so many years ago.

LONDON, March 22 -- The markets now have entered the pre-budget phase with a show of confidence that was scarcely contemplated even a week ago. The shadow cast over the international situation by Premier Stalin's death and the disturbing aircraft incidents in Germany has, in the last few days, been dispersed by a feeling that international political tension is more likely to diminish than increase as the new Russian administration gets into its stride.

Religious, fraternal and labor organizations in Brooklyn banded together last night at a special meeting in the Brooklyn Academy of Music to protest Soviet Russia's persecution of racial and religious minorities and the Communist anti-Semitic campaign behind the Iron Curtain.

Outside of doing "The Deep Blue Sea" this season with Alfred de Liagre Jr. and aligning himself with television, John C. Wilson hasn't been as active on Broadway as he generally is. He promises to make amends during the 1953-54 campaign.

HOLLAND, Mich., March 22 (UP) -- Chairman Livingston Osborne of the Illinois State Athletic Commission issued a warning today that commission rules would be enforced strictly in the Rocky Marciano-Jersey Joe Walcott fight at the Chicago Stadium April 10.

PUSAN, Korea, March 22 -- If an American soldier fighting in Korea becomes paralyzed as a result of combat wounds, disease or an accident, he receives immediate emergency care at the front and then is flown by helicopter to an evacuation hospital, then to Tokyo and finally to the United States.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 22 -- An announcement in Cairo by Harold Davies, the lawyer who defended Jomo Kenyatta, charged with being the man behind the Mau Mau terrorist movement in Kenya, that a pan-African nationalist congress would be held in Cairo has come as a shock here.

PHILADELPHIA, March 22 (AP) -- The controversy at the University of Pennsylvania over the type of schedule the Quakers' football team should play uncovered a new angle today -- a survey by the General Alumni Society.

One hundred and twelve contract bridge pairs played yesterday afternoon the first of two sessions in the mixed pair championship, third of nine scheduled events in the twenty - seventh annual Eastern States Contract Bridge Championships.

WAITSFIELD, Vt., March 22 -- Two spectacular dashes down the thirty-five gate three-eighth mile course enabled Mrs. Anne Jones, Rutland, Vt., housewife, to annex the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association slalom championship today in a field of forty.

A "first-hand investigation and field study" of Board of Transportation operations has shown that the agency could cut its budget $30,000,000 by eliminating 8,200 "wasted and misused personnel," the City Affairs Committee asserted yesterday.

Individuals in Government or the church who use the Communist label as a "weapon of subterfuge" are "keeping us from knowing the truth, from correcting our errors, from building the better world, and, in the end -- if they succeed -- they will keep us from being free," the Rev. Dr. John Paul Jones, pastor of the Union Church of Bay Ridge (Presbyterian), Ridge Boulevard and Eightieth Street, Brooklyn, said in his sermon yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23 -- No one can give the same intonation to the word tremendous that Casey Stengel gives it. He lands on that first syllable with both feet. But when he applies the adjective to Master Mickey Mantle his rasping voice becomes caressing.

ITHACA, N. Y., March 23 -- The contemporary home -- its design, furnishings and accessories -- is a leading subject of talks and exhibits at the annual Farm and Home Week Program, which opened here today at Cornell University.

LOS ANGELES, March 23 -- The 1941 Broadway hit revue "Meet the People" was described today as a Communist propaganda vehicle in testimony before the House Un-American Activities Committee, which opened hearings here.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Federal Communications Commission, ruling against five American communications companies, held today that the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund should be granted reduced rates for official telegrams to member countries.

A court order directing the Algonquin Gas Transmission Company to remove two and one-half miles of new natural gas pipeline from eleven parcels of private lands in northern Westchester County was reversed yesterday by the Appellate Division, Second Department.

Commodity future prices closed irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume was generally light but potatoes were[ active and lead and zinc showed improvement. Coffee, potatoes and hides closed mixed and lead, zinc, wool and tin ended higher.

BONN, Germany, March 23 (AP) -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway said today he was not aware of any dissatisfaction among non-American officers at his military headquarters for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., stepped into second gear yesterday in the production of its new polyester "Dacron" fiber. Production of the fiber was begun at the new $40,000,000 plant which du Pont has erected at Kinston, N. C., and the so-called pilot operation for Dacron output at Seaford, Del., is being shut down.

Shirt sleeves and blouses appeared suddenly on New York's streets yesterday for a little while when the sun beat down in summer warmth. Along Fifth Avenue and through Central Park the top-down convertibles were out in force.

With three of the ten games of the seventh round unfinished, Miguel Najdorf of Argentina slipped into the lead yesterday in the international chess maters tournament at Mar Del Plata, where he defeated Karl Ojanen in 20 moves, according to a report from Buenos Aires.

MONTREAL, March 23 (UP) -- Hockey's "grand old men," the Chicago Black Hawks, today prepared to meet the Montreal Canadiens in the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup semi-finals, which open here tomorrow.

The bond market continued to drift downward yesterday. Most of the fully taxable notes and bonds of the United States Government closed the day at their low prices of record, the three longest-maturing issues -- 2 1/2's due in 1972 -- falling below 94 for the first time.
LONDON, March 23 -- Restrictions on Britain's trade and travel expenditures in Western Europe were relaxed today to the extent of about 40,000,000 ($112,000,000) a year.
For future biographers of President Eisenhower a bright new anecdote was provided last night.

The dropping of price controls by the new Administration has "drastically weakened" the program of dispersal of plants of the Office of Defense Mobilization, it was asserted yesterday by Dr. C. E. Waring, vice president of the Davison Chemical Corporation.

PARIS, March 23 -- Five of the protocols the French proposed to the European Defense Community Treaty were agreed upon today by the Interim Committee representing the six signatory countries -- France, West Germany, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- E. Merle Young conceded at his perjury trial today that he had made a false statement to Senators investigating an alleged "web of influence" in operations of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Bernard M. Baruch told Congress today the very survival of the nation could hang on the establishment of stand-by authority and machinery to invoke the price, wage and other economic controls that would be needed immediately in the event of all-out war.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 23 -- The Supreme Court of Appeals of the Union of South Africa handed down a constitutional decision today invalidating racial segregation unless equal facilities were offered to both whites and other races in the union.
Two measures to improve service at the Fifty-ninth Street-Columbus Circle Station of the IND subway were announced yesterday by the Board of Transportation.

WASHINGTON, N. J., March 23 -- The state police said tonight that John Joseph Scarantino, driver of the trailer truck in Friday night's accident that killed a family of ten near here, was unlawfully at the wheel. The police said Scarantino's New Jersey license privilege had been revoked last March after his arrest for illegal passing of another vehicle on Route 6, in Mount Roxbury Township, and had not been restored.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 23 -- The next few months will be decisive in the financial crisis confronting the expanded Technical Assistance Administration program of the United Nations, David Owen, executive chairman, informed the eighteen-member Technical Assistance Committee today.

MUTTONTOWN, L. I., March 23 -- Headquarters for the Nassau County Police Department's Second Precinct, located since 1926 in a building on an estate purchased two years ago by exiled Albanian King Zog, will be moved to Hicksville soon because the King has refused to continue renting the building.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 23 -- Representatives of the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and Nationalist China again failed to agree today upon a successor to Trygve Lie as Secretary General of the United Nations.
Branch McCracken, whose Indiana team swept to the Big Ten and N. C. A. A. titles, yesterday scored some of his fellow coaches for employing tactics that bring about rule changes "almost every year."

A complete television transistor amplifier as large as a match, which needs only about a millionth of the operating power necessary for the bulky ten-pound "repeaters" now utilized in coaxial cable television was demonstrated here yesterday for the first time at the convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers.

Plans are under way for the use of British Royal Air Force jet planes to fly television films of the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II to this country on June 2. Based on tentative program arrangements by the networks, this super-speed service would permit viewers here to see films of certain coronation proceedings about twelve hours after they had occurred in London.

TEL, AVIV, March 23 -- Prof. Benjamin Mazar, rector of Hebrew University in Jerusalem and an archeologist of note, was elected president of university for a two-year term by the Board of Governors today. He will continue to serve as rector. He succeeds Prof. Selig Brodetsky of Manchester, England, who resigned owing to poor health.

SEOUL, Korea, March 23 -- A special team sent by the United States delegation in the United Nations to investigate conditions in camps where Chinese prisoners of war are interned has forwarded to the delegation graphic documentary evidence of cruelty practiced by hard-core Communist leaders on their fellow prisoners.

HANOI, Vietnam, March 23 -- After completing a four-day visit marked by briefings, exchanges of views, inspections of Vietnamese officer training schools and a trip to the strategic Red River Delta. Gen. Mark W. Clark, United States commander in the Far East, made it plain today he would recommend increased United States military aid to Indo-China.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23 -- Not a Yankee reached third base today and the world champions suffered their first shutout of the spring. Bucky Harris' Senators hopped over from Orlando and embarrassed the Bombers with an exhibition of long-range hitting that led to a 9-0 rout of Casey Stengel's lads.

Representatives of the New York Shipping Association and the Port Watchmen's Union in the Port of New York will meet at 11 A. M. today at 80 Broad Street in the first talks since the independent union rejected last week a two-year contract offered by the employer group.

The production of men's shirts continues to show the improvement which started last fall. The January figure was 397,200 dozen shirts, a 21 per cent increase over the corresponding month last year. The increase was made despite the record-breaking production of 1952, the National Association of Shirt, Pajama and Sportswear Manufacturers reported yesterday.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 23 (AP) -- Garnett Y. Booker's Mad Hare, a consistent 6 - year - old daughter of Hairan, did the expected as she defeated six others in the Vilabella Purse for fillies and mares at Gulfstream Park before 14,719 today.

Virtually every major group in the stock market headed for lower ground yesterday, but volume failed to climb appreciably. Despite declines that carried THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average of fifty stocks below the midpoint between the 1953 high and low, volume was only 1,750,000 shares, against 1,730,000 on Friday.

MEXICO CITY, March 23 -- The Government has canceled the oil distribution monopoly granted last year to Jorge Pasquel, industrialist, in a move hailed as the most significant evidence yet of President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines' independence of his predecessor, Miguel Aleman.
A large field of contract bridge players last night played the first qualifying round of the Reisinger Cup team-of-four championship, the blue-ribbon team event of the Eastern States Championships.

After investigating waterfront crimes and racketeering for thirteen months, a special Federal rackets grand jury was dismissed yesterday after United States Attorney Myles J. Lane said it had done a "remarkable job" in focusing public attention on deplorable conditions along the New York and New Jersey piers.

OMAHA, Neb., March 13 (AP) -- Dr. Howard Rusk, director of the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation at the New York University-Bellevue Center, was back from Korea today with visions of a nation-wide campaign to "get Korea off its knees."
ATLANTIC CITY, March 23 -- The United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., armed its international executive board today with new constitutional authority to curb Communists and racketeers in local unions.

Orlando Zulueta, 135 1/4, Havana, Cuba, gained a split decision over Wallace (Bud) Smith, 138, Cincinnati, in the ten-round feature bout before 1,692 spectators at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn last night. Referee Pete Scalzo voted for the winner six rounds to four and Judge Joe Agnello had it 8 -- 2 for Zulueta, Judge Bill Recht picked Smith, 7 -- 2, with one even.

Lorna Sydney, Australian mezzo-soprano, who has spent most of her career in Vienna, gave a song program last night at Town Hall. Miss Sydney was a member of the New York City Opera Company two years ago and with it sang Amneris in "Aida" and the Witch in "The Love for Three Oranges," This, however, was her first recital here.

Veal, for some reason, is one of the most difficult meats for many Americans to prepare. Because it is now in excellent supply, and likely to continue so during the spring, the recipes presented today can be a help in meeting food budgets in the weeks ahead.

DENTON, Tex., March 23 (AP) -- Six members of the national champion North Texas State College golf team and Billy Maxwell, a former student and former national amateur champion, were notified today by the United States Golf Association that they had lost their amateur standing.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Mrs. Hiram Cole Houghton of Red Oak, Iowa, former president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs has been appointed Assistant director for Mutual Security by Harold E. Stassen, director. She will be in charge of programs dealing with refugees and the migration of surplus populations.
ALBANY, March 23 -- Governor Dewey said today that the Legislature's session that ended Saturday night had made more major achievements than any he could remember.

The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday that it is streamlining its operating department, effective April 1. Under the new set-up, general managers in charge of various segments of the system will report directly to Karl A. Borntrager, vice president of operations and maintenance, with headquarters here, instead of through two regional operating department vice presidents.

January factory shipments of electrical refrigerators, home and farm freezers, ranges and water heaters increased substantially over the corresponding month last year, the National Electrical Manufacturers Association reported yesterday. In 1952 the freezer was the only one of the four important household appliances to show a gain over the previous year.

LONDON, March 23 -- The limit of the flood that ravaged the East Coast of Britain just eight weeks ago is now marked by a false shoreline of wreckage up to eight or ten miles inland in the worst affected areas of East Anglia.
The second of this spring's series of "diagnostic" atomic tests is scheduled to be held today at the Nevada Proving Grounds of the Atomic Energy Commission.
The proposal of the Richmond County Medical Society to combat crime among narcotic addicts by providing clinics where they could obtain narcotics cheaply under medical control deserves consideration.

The Consolidated Edison Company expects to spend $95,000,000 this year for new plant facilities, only $2,900,000 less than in 1952, Ralph H. Tapscott, chairman, and Hudson R. Searing, president, declare in the 1952 annual report being mailed to stockholders today.

BERLIN, March 23 -- Two trucks, one of which pulled a trailer laden with refugees' belongings, breached wooden barriers around West Berlin today and escaped into the city. The incidents occurred more than twenty miles apart on opposite sides of Berlin.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved the nomination of J. Edward Lumbard to be United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York. Mr. Lumbard, 51 years old, an attorney, formerly was a State Supreme Court Justice.

PINEHURST, N. C., March 23 (AP) -- Pat O'Sullivan of Orange, Conn., led all the way today to defeat Mary Lena Faulk, 2 and 1, and win her third women's North and South golf championship in four years.
Most of the perennial favorites in the opera repertoire evoke a special feeling in their admirers, but none more special than "Parsifal."

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee investigating the Government's international information and counter-propaganda services was told by witnesses today that the student exchange program was the best long-range method to build up understanding and lasting peace.

SALAMANCA, N. Y., March 23 -- The state is going to build a $1,500,000 housing project here on the Allegany Indian Reservation, but most of the 100 garden-type apartments will go to the red man's poor white brothers who now live in a slum.

THE few prophets with honor in the vicinity of Sebago Lake in Maine will not need to consult their private oracles on the matter of ice-out dates this season. Most of the lake has been almost entirely free of ice all winter and should provide excellent fishing on the April 1 opening.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- Foreign countries spent $5,000,000,000 more in the United States in 1952 than they earned here, but foreign aid plus private loans and investments allowed them to increase their reserves of gold and dollars by $1,182,000,000.

ST. LOUIS, March 23 -- "Disciplinary action" by the American Medical Association against the executive director of the American College of Surgeons, Dr. Paul R. Hawley of Chicago, was requested today by the Congress of Delegates of the American Academy of General Practice.
John P. DeLaney has been appointed general manager of the transportation services of the American Locomotive Company, according to W. S. Morris, executive vice president.

New records were achieved last year by the Sinclair Oil Corporation in net income, crude oil production, transportation, manufacturing and sales. For the first time in its history assets exceeded $1,000,000,000, P. C. Spencer, president, reported in the annual report mailed to stockholders yesterday.

Continuation by Congress of import quotas on dairy and other agricultural products, now imposed under Section 104 of the expiring Defense Production Act, was opposed yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council.

A suit by a minority group of stockholders of the International Railways of Central America, which charges that the United Fruit Company, as the parent company, improperly diverted to itself revenues of the railway system, its subsidiary, was started yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Ernest E. L. Hammer.

ATHENS, Ga., March 23 (UP) -Mrs. Lee Bradberry said today that she had ordered a Lexington, Ky., attorney to drop a suit filed in her name against Adolph Rupp, basketball coach at the University of Kentucky, and Fran Costello and Ed Curd, gamblers.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 23 (AP) -- Christian Pravda, of Austria, and Mrs. Andrea Mead Lawrence, Rutland, Vt., flashing down the zig-zag slalom course of Ruud Mountain in championship form, won the thirteenth annual Harriman Cup races today.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- President Eisenhower reorganized the staff and procedures of the National Security Council today to strengthen it for the mission of advising him on vital security issues during the world crisis.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- The Textile Workers Union, C.I.O., urged today that the Secretary of Defense immediately advertise for bids for 3,000,000 yards of woolen and worsted fabrics as a step toward relieving unemployment in the industry.

HARTFORD, March 23 -- The Connecticut Legislature, which has just finished a major conflict over the redistricting of the State Senate, appeared today to be heading for another constitutional struggle -- this one over a proposed reduction in the membership of the House of Representatives.

The United States Government, which just two years ago had the pleasure of entertaining President and Mme. Auriol of France, is preparing for the visit, beginning tomorrow, of other distinguished representatives of that country. They are Premier Mayer, Foreign Minister Bidault, Finance Minister Bourges-Maunoury and the Minister for Associated States, M. Letourneau.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 23 -- Ambassador Walter Moreira Sales left by air for his post in Washington this morning with full authority to complete the $300,000,000 loan from the Export-Import Bank that is expected to clear up Brazil's big backlog of commercial debts in the United States.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Senator Allen J. Ellender of Louisiana, ranking Democrat on the Agriculture Committee, criticized today the Mexican Government's attitude on the migrant labor problem.
Watches silent since they told time for kings and queens two centuries ago will soon tick again as the result of a project started yesterday by the United States Time Corporation.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation, established as an anti-depression measure under President Hoover twenty-one years ago, served a useful purpose, but has long since outlived the reasons that brought it into being. The decision reached yesterday by President Eisenhower and the top Congressional leaders of the Republican party to let the agency expire next year on schedule seems to us to be sound.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. is preparing to ask Congress to legalize the use in espionage cases of evidence obtained by wiretapping, a Department of Justice source disclosed tonight.
Three hundred and thirty-five pints of blood were donated here yesterday to the Red Cross by students, parents and faculty members at Hunter College and Yeshiva University.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, March 23 -- Generalissimo Rafael L. Trujillo said in an interview today that when he saw President Eisenhower during a recent visit to Washington he proposed a Pan-American conference for the purpose of condemning communism in the Western Hemisphere.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., March 23 -- Five days after his seventieth birthday, Montague Roberts came here today to renew acquaintance with the automobile that made international motor history with him at the wheel forty-five years ago.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 23 -- Tension mounted today in North Sumatra as the death toll from last Monday's incident rose to six. Press reports said at least forty peasants were wounded in the clash with police and several were not expected to recover.

The nine-story and penthouse building containing seventy-five apartments at 139-147 West Eighty-second Street has been sold by Philip P. Zipes, real estate operator, to a client of Harry J. Fine, attorney. The property occupies a plot 125 by 90 feet and is assessed at $450,000.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Powerful Republicans led by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio directed against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin today the first general and determined counter-attack ever made on him from within his own party in the Senate.

Net sales and income of the American Machine and Foundry Company and consolidated subsidiaries last year were 95 per cent and 54 per cent, respectively, above the 1951 levels, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Morehead Patterson, chairman and president.
BRADENTON, Fla., March 23 (AP) -- The Phillies hit three homers in defeating the Braves, 11 -- 5, today.

The foreign aid sent by the United States to the free world last year came to something more than $5.5 billions, according to a Department of Commerce report. In the last quarter of 1952 military aid for the first time exceeded economic aid. Of course, the two things cannot be entirely separated.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 23 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh revealed today that distrust of his potential successors as well as of his British opponents had influenced his decision to reject proposals to submit claims of the British former owners of Iran's nationalized oil to the International Court of Justice.

Spot radio and television discussions on vandalism to increase public awareness of the problem was one of many recommendations made yesterday in a junior high school forum at the St. Clair McKelway Junior High School, 2163 Dean Street, Brooklyn.

How far can the experimenting clinician go in testing on his human patients a new drug or treatment? The question is discussed in Science by Drs. Michael B. Shimkin and Otto E. Guttenberg of the University of California, Dr. Alexander M. Kidd of the University of California School of Law and Col. W. H. Johnson (Judge Advocate Corps, U. S. Army).
Six new issues of municipal bonds totaling $11,500,000 were posted yesterday for sale during forthcoming weeks.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 23 -- Miss Guri Lie, daughter of Secretary General Trygve Lie, will become an American citizen and remain in this country after the expiration of her father's term in office, she said today. She is 27.

A final check-up yesterday revealed that seven thoroughbreds, awaiting the start of the season on April 1, and a Palomino lead pony died in the stable fire Sunday night at the Jamaica Race Track in Queens. Damages were estimated at about $110,000.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, assured the Latin-American republics today that the United States was as much interested in them as in Korea and Europe and was determined to develop "relations of mutual trust and respect" in this hemisphere.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- An official idea of how much ammunition has been fired at the Communists in Korea was offered at the Senate Arms Service Committee hearings by Gen. J. Lawton Collins, Chief of Staff of the Army.

A man's age may be measured not only in the passage of years, but also by the accumulation of things. The gardener who, about now, is rooting on the floor of a closet in search of an old pair of shoes suitable for ambling around the garden in may be struck by the fact that whereas when a youth he had perhaps three or four pairs of shoes he now possesses six or eight.

Many persons in the ad field spend considerable time decrying the fact that the business is not understood by the general public, college professors or legislators. Mostly their remarks are contained in speeches at advertiisng meetings, convention or in articles in the ad trade press.
Mayor Impellitteri and the majority of the Board of Estimate were prepared yesterday after a two-hour executive session to accept Governor Dewey's "higher fare" transit authority plan.

The building with fifty-eight apartments at 829 Adee Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Jacob Zagelbaum to a client of Samuel Friedman, attorney, for cash over mortgages of $160,000. The property is assessed at $165,000. Paul Maslin Co. were the brokers.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (UP) -- The National Association of Radio and Television Broadcasters urged Congress today to outlaw a provision in the contract of the American Federation of Musicians that virtually prohibited the televising of many movies.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 24 -- In the heaviest fighting so far this year in Korea, the Chinese Communists thrust furiously last night and this morning against United Nations lines on the western front. For a time they drove Allied troops off an outpost at "Porkchop Hill," north of Yonchon, on the valley approaches to the South Korean capital of Seoul.

A syndicate of thirty-five investment houses headed by Blyth Co., Inc., will place on the market today a new issue of $20,000,000 of $4.75 dividend cumulative preferred stock of Pacific Lighting Corporation at $100 a share. The offering consists of 200,000 shares.

Two new films open in first-run theatres today. At the Rivoli, the attraction is "Salome," the adaptation of the Biblical story filmed in Technicolor and presented by Columbia with Rita Hayworth in the title role.
SPARTANBURG, March 23 (AP) -- Louise Suggs of Atlanta defeated Betsy Rawls in a sudden-death play-off today to win the first annual Peach Blossom-Betsy Rawls invitation open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- William L. Franklin, a State Department security officer, told a Judiciary subcommittee of the House of Representatives today that five United Nations employes whose loyalty had been questioned were selected from 477 names supplied by Alger Hiss contrary to a policy established by James F. Byrnes, then Secretary of State.

It is understood that the White House is still studying the question of televising Presidential press conferences. The television people probably regard this suggestion as eminently sound. It is only human that they should. The spectacle of six cameras with their crews and their accompanying lights focused on a President and a group of correspondents would make any normal person in the TV industry as happy as a lamb in spring.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (UP) -- Texas and Louisiana Congressmen temporarily abandoned their fight today for a share of offshore oil revenues from the outer belt of the continental shelf.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today 138 Korean war casualties in a list that included 35 killed, 98 wounded, 2 missing and 3 injured. It also listed as captured 18 men previously recorded as missing in action.

DETROIT, March 23 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings, who needed only eight games to win the Stanley Cup last year, will open the defense of their hockey laurels tomorrow night against the Boston Bruins at Olympia.

CHICAGO, March 23 -- Charles F. Kettering, inventor-scientist of the General Motors Corporation, was kept off the company's policy committee because he talked too well and too much, the du Pont anti-trust trial was told today in Federal District Court here.

CHICAGO, March 23 (AP) -- Ray Mihm, a floor-covering dealer from Green Bay, Wis., today became the twelfth man in the fifty-year-old history of the American Bowling Congress tournament to roll a perfect 300 game.

MAIZURU, Japan, March 23 -- Exile on foreign shores ended today for nearly 4,000 Japanese. Two transports flying the Rising Sun flag returned from Chingwangtao and Shanghai with Japanese civilians finally permitted to return to their homeland by the Chinese Communist Government.

MIAMI, March 23 -- Carl Erskine, the little Hoosier righthander who pitched a no-hitter last year and later was one of the heroes in the fifth game of the World Series, today became the first Dodger pitcher to go nine innings.

PARIS, March 23 -- Fears of a split on economic policy between Britain and the Continent, which would have set back European unity, were allayed today when two British Ministers informed their European neighbors here that Britain would remain in the European Payments Union for another year pending the creation of a "wider" system.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Senate Committee on Government Operations recommended today approval of the joint resolution, already adopted by the House, to speed elevation of the Federal Security Agency to the Cabinet rank of Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- Representative Laurie C. Battle, Democrat of Alabama, said today the Communists still "get pretty much what they want" in strategic material from the West, and the United States should wage "a vigorous and comprehensive" campaign to shut it off.

The State of New Jersey's General Investment Fund earned $1,318,282 for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30, State Treasurer Walter Margetts disclosed yesterday in his second annual report. Until 1949, when the present treasurer took office, these accounts had lain idle in a few banks.

Fifty men and women from business, civic and municipal groups gathered yesterday at 500 Park Avenue to plan a springtime refurbishing that will make the city -- in all its five boroughs -- a "healthier, cleaner, tidier and better place in which to live."
ROME, March 23 -- An increase in the Roman Catholic hierarchy during 1952 is shown in the 1953 issue of the Pontifical Year Book, the first copy of which was presented to Pope Pius XII yesterday.

MANILA, March 23 -- The first major attack of the Communist-led Hukbalhaps in many months was reported from the southeast coast of Luzon Island, giving evidence of renewed rebellious activity following the resignation of Ramon Magsaysay as President Elpidio Quirinos' Defense Secretary early this month.

The Public Education Association asserted yesterday that Section 903 of the City Charter, under which several school and college teachers have been dismissed for refusing to answer questions about alleged Communist party membership, did not apply to teachers because public education was a state function, beyond municipal control, and teachers were not city employes.

Governor Dewey's special message to the Legislature, which advocated the passage of the compulsory insurance bill, was a moving appeal. Couched in simple yet eloquent language, it answered all the arguments advanced against the bill by its opponents so clearly that any rebuttal which could appeal to intelligent minds is impossible.

The possible merger of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, which went their separate ways almost seventeen years ago, is a matter of public interest. A single labor organization of twelve million wage-earners rather than two separate organizations may pose some questions which the man in the street may wish to have answered.

The Kaiser Manufacturing Corporation, a subsidiary of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, purchased Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., last night for an estimated $62,300,000, subject to approval by Willys-Overland common stockholders. A special meeting of the stockholders will be held on April 24.

LONDON, March 23 -- Under the lead of British Government securities, which generally advanced about one-eighth per cent, most industrial groups overcame profit-taking sales and finished modestly better on the stock market here today.
The cotton futures market closed barely steady yesterday but eased 16 to 36 points on the day, with trading on the New York Cotton Exchange moderately active.

A large parcel of land on Highway S-3 at the junction of Passaic Avenue and Allwood Road in Clifton, N. J., has been purchased by the North American Van Lines, Inc., of Fort Wayne, Ind., for improvement with an office building for its eastern operations.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- President Eisenhower and Congressional leaders decided today to try to assure a natural death for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation when its legal authority expired on June 30, 1954.

The observance of this week as Greater Safety Week offers New Yorkers an opportunity to take stock and dedicate themselves anew to the good work of preventing needless loss and misery caused by accidents. Though the special observance lasts only one week, it should inspire us to try to live more safely throughout the year.
Vladimir P. de Smitt was quite convinced yesterday that he would find himself just as much at home on the ocean floor -- although he's never been there -- as he is on his living room alone.

After weeks of negotiation, Leonard Sillman has resolved in the affirmative the question of whether or not his production of "New Faces of 1952" is to be made available to the waiting public out-of-town following the conclusion of the New York engagement on Saturday.
If Carl (Bobo) Olson wants to participate in the American middleweight elimination tournament, he'd better make up his mind quickly, Bob Christenberry said yesterday.
CHICAGO, March 23 -- Poor support in the markets for grain and soybean futures today resulted in sharp declines in all pits on the Board of Trade.

Democratic state legislative leaders charged yesterday that Governor Dewey's advocacy last Sunday of a program under which the state would assist local educational and cultural groups to take advantage of television was an attempt by him "to bail himself and his party out of an embarrassing situation."

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Advances in the design of artificial limbs through Government sponsored research were hailed today before the Third National Conference on Placement of the Severely Handicapped, sponsored by the American Federation of the Physically Handicapped.

The annual luncheon for the "Lots For Little" thrift shop, that is maintained at 1214 Third Avenue for the benefit of various philanthropic organizations, will be held April 21 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.
TOKYO, March 24 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,563, for the twenty-four hours ending a 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:

The one-story building and yard at 57-69 Fifty-eighth Place, in Maspeth, Queens, has been leased by Magic Brand Syrups from James Clark through Queens Industrials, brokers. The lessee will occupy the property for the manufacture and distribution of syrups.

ALBANY, March 23 -- Governor Dewey said today that he planned to act promptly, probably some time later this week, on the series of bills the Legislature approved on his recommendation to provide a solution for the financial troubles of the City of New York.
LONDON, March 23 -- The Soviet Government has rejected a United States charge that a Russian jet fighter fired on an American plane March 15 off Siberia, the Moscow radio announced tonight.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 23 (UP) -- Australia's Prime Minister approved a 2,000,000 (about $4,500,000) loan to construct an Olympic village today, but that appeared just the first shot in a war to decide the site of the 1956 games.

High-level strategic problems that must be solved in the event of a national mobilization were presented yesterday to 400 business men and officers of the armed services by members of a six-man team of experts from the Industrial College of the Armed Forces.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Tuesday, March 24 -- The Israeli Parliament began passing last night a bill under which property owners must lend the Government up to 10 per cent of the value of their property or -- if they prefer -- pay half as much in the form of a capital levy.

WESTMINSTER, Md., March 23 (AP) -- Whittaker Chambers, former Communist courier, said today he knew nothing "by direct knowledge, that bears in any way adversely or otherwise" on Charles E. Bohlen, nominee for Ambassador to Moscow.

ST. LOUIS, March 23 (AP) -- Bill Veeck today gave up one of his battles against American League opposition and signed the league's radio and television agreement, thus permitting his St Louis Browns' road games to be telecast.

TOKYO, March 23 (AP) -- The Army newspaper, Pacific Stars and Stripes, deleted from its news columns today five of Gen. James A. Van Fleet's key charges that there was a shortage of ammunition for United Nations troops in Korea.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- In forty-one states 19-year-olds will be drafted for military duty next month and in two others it is possible, an Associated Press survey showed today. For fourteen of the forty-one states it will be the first draft of 19-year-olds since World War II.

NEWBURYPORT, Mass., March 23 -- This small city's long past, dating to 1620, is being reviewed in an exhibition of the enduring work in silver that colonial and later craftsmen have handed down to posterity. The display will run through April 4.

TRENTON, March 23 -- Action on a state rent control law -- a measure that would supersede the present stand-by legislation in the event Federal controls are relaxed -- was postponed by the State Assembly again today after three attempts by Assemblyman William V. Musto of Hudson County, the Minority Leader, to force such action were voted down.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 23 -- The Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia took turns today accusing the United States in bitter terms of plotting against the Communist world by espionage, subversion and fifth-column practices -- all financed out of Mutual Security funds.

Eighty-five parcels in Brooklyn were sold at auction by the city yesterday for $443,551, which was $64,801 above the upset prices of $378,750. About 750 persons attended the sale in the Council Chamber at City Hall.

It is gratifying to read in your editorial of March 17, on the occasion of Tito's visit to London, the reminder (voiced several times before) that he "* * * is and remains a Communist whose first allegiance is to Communist ideology and a Communist dictatorship * * *."

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 23 -- Leo Durocher was able to look upon his Giants with some measure of satisfaction today. Just a week ago, Leo, off on a barn-storming tour with his second team in California, saw his jayvees blow a ball game to Japan's remarkable Tokyo Giants. For a full week that defeat stuck in Leo's craw.
The Metropolitan Golf Association yesterday announced that all its 1953 handicaps would be issued to golfers in this area on the basis of the United States Golf Association's "current" handicaps.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 23 (AP) -- Lew Worsham shot his fourth straight 68 today to fight off a closing birdie barrage by Jim Ferrier and win the Jacksonville open golf tournament with 272.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- Three witnesses today accused Garry D. Iozia of "fantastic" lying in testifying they took cash from him on claims they could fix his tax evasion case through high-level political connections.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The main issue in the "Bohlen case," now before the Senate, is no longer what happens to the career or reputation of Charles E. Bohlen, President Eisenhower's nominee to be Ambassador to the Soviet Union, but what happens to the confidential files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

RIO GRANDE, Ohio, March 23 (AP) -- Coach Newt Oliver of Rio Grande College said today he was severing all connections with the National Collegiate Athletic Association because of its recent action in stripping Rio star Clarence (Bevo) Francis of his phenomenal basketball records.

All classrooms in public schools from Seventy-second Street to 100th Street on the west side of Manhattan will now be able to display American flags as the result of the gift yesterday of 100 flags from the Capt. Belvidere Brooks Post of the American Legion.

HOLLYWODD, Calif., March 23 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has orders for the installation of CinemaScope from seven theatre circuits operating 750 houses from coast to coast, it was disclosed today by Al Lichtman, director of distribution for the company.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (UP) -- Charges that Representative John L. McMillan, Democrat of South Carolina, obtained an illegal oil lease were taken under advisement by Judge T. Blake Kennedy today after a brief trial in Federal Court.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 23 (AP) -- Battelle Memorial Institute today reported development of a low-cost aluminum-antimony compound for use in many electrical gadgets. Dr. A. E. Middleton of Battelle, private research laboratory, said rectifiers of the new material already have been produced.

TOPEKA, Kan., March 23 -- A Joint Investigating Committee of the Kansas Legislature heard today secret testimony from a registered lobbyist for the medical profession concerning his "transactions" with C. Wesley Roberts, now chairman of the Republican National Committee.

Children's clothes look their best with the coming of spring. From tailored suits and coats to party frocks and play clothes for warmer days, a large selection is available for doting mothers and fashion-minded youngsters.

Coverly Fischer, president of the Welfare and Health Council of New York City, announced yesterday the appointment of a committee to attempt a solution to the controversy aroused by denial of council membership to a planned parenthood agency because of the opposition of Catholic Charities.

CHICAGO, March 23 -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, told a meeting of leading dairymen today that their surplus problems could be reduced sharply and possibly ended if they worked out an effective and efficient method of production and marketing.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- President Eisenhower told a group of Zionist leaders today that the United States had "only the friendliest feelings for Israel and the Arab States" and intended "to use its best offices to bring about peace in the Middle East."

A "questioning formula" has been devised to simplify the interrogation of alien seamen entering this port. Edward J. Shaughnessy, district director the Immigration Service, said last night. Resentment had been aroused by the questioning methods used when the McCarran-Walter Act went into effect three months ago.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Improvement of general quality of national advertising is the purpose of continuing negotiations between the Federal Trade Commission and the Association of National Advertisers and the Association of National Advertising Agencies.
