LOS ANGELES, March 23 -- Footlights were turned today on the twentieth annual one-act play tournament in the Pasadena Playhouse with an estimated 350 students from thirty-one California high schools scheduled to tread the boards during the three-day event.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- United States business concerns plan to spend more this year than ever before for new plant and equipment, thus keeping a principal economic boom factor working hard, the Department of Commerce reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Dark hints of something in the history of Charles E. Bohlen that makes inadvisable his appointment as Ambassador to Moscow, but cannot be revealed because it would imperil the "security of the United States," are not enough material with which effectively to challenge the new Administration on its choice.
LOS ANGELES, March 23 -- Harry S. Truman and his family arrived here this morning from San Francisco on the American President liner President Cleveland, on a two-day stopover on the way to Hawaii.

Alan Jay Bradshaw, former Los Angeles credit union manager, was held in $25,000 bail in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday on a charge of embezzling $103,887 in cash and savings bonds from the credit union's treasury.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Representative Kenneth A. Roberts, Democrat of Alabama, told a luncheon meeting of the Women's National Press Club today that purely as a matter of equity there inevitably must come an income tax deduction for money paid by working mothers for the care of their children.

On President Walter P. Reuther's initiative the convention of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., has amended its constitution and plugged a loophole to curb Communists and racketeers in local unions.

Mayor Impellitteri and the majority of the Board of Estimate voted yesterday to accept Governor Dewey's plan for a five-member New York City Transit Authority to take over the municipal transit system by July 1 under mandate to run it at a fare sufficient to cover all operating expenses.

TORONTO, March 24 (Canadian Press) -- Noranda Mines, Ltd., big base metal producer of Northern Quebec, had net income in 1952 of $12,210,000, or $5.45 a share, compared with 1951's record earnings of $12,769,000, or $5.70.

PARIS, Wednesday, March 25 -- To take off by air early this morning for his scheduled Washington visit, Premier Rene Mayer had to accomplish both a diplomatic and a parliamentary victory, neither of which was easy. He did both and then left by plane at 2:30 A. M.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 24 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan, in a formal statement today in Capetown, openly espoused the principle of racial discrimination. He promised that, in view of the case decided yesterday by the Supreme Court, his Nationalist
Art Persley, 136 3/4 pounds, New Orleans, gained a unanimous decision over Harold (Baby Face) Jones, 137 1/4, Detroit, in the main bout of ten rounds at Ridgewood Grove, Brooklyn, last night.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Maj. Gen. Harlan N. Hartness, who has been commanding the Fourth Infantry Division in Europe, has been named chief of the Armed Forces Information and Education Program. He will fill a post that has been vacant since the retirement of Maj. Gen. John M. Devine last July 31.

Reduction of industrial accidents was discussed yesterday at the twenty-third annual convention of the Greater New York Safety Council. The four-day meeting of 6,000 safety engineers and accident reduction experts is at the Statler Hotel.

BERLIN, March 24 -- Evangelical church officials said today an East German court had sentenced one of its pastors to six years imprisonment because his sermons were allegedly hostile to the Government.
Members of the New York Central-Pullman Blood Bank, composed of officers, various personnel and union employes of the two corporations, began a three-day contribution yesterday to the Red Cross.

With Treasury obligations evidencing firmness after Monday's renewed price declines, interest in investment-grade securities was centered yesterday on the prices developed by banking syndicates bidding for $35,000,000 of new securities of public utility enterprises.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- A provision of a 1930 contract between the General Motors Corporation and E. L. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., which said G. M. would offer its chemical developments to a jointly owned concern, was dwelt upon by a Government attorney today in cross-examining Alfred P. Sloane Jr., General Motors chairman, at the du Pont anti-trust trial in Federal District Court here.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 24 -- To the average citizen of the Western world, the Secretariat building of the United Nations is a skyscraper -- pure and simple. In Iran, it is a ship, and no nonsense about it.

Seaboard and Western Airlines, the transatlantic cargo line seeking authorization from the United States Government to operate certificated all-freight flights between this country and Europe, plans to fly 286 round trips annually with Lockheed Super-Constellations in its first year of scheduled operations.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- An optimistic forecast that sales of major electric appliances will double in the next ten years and a not-so-optimistic forecast of a business recession in the months ahead were made today by J. H. Ash baugh, vice president of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. He spoke at the Installment Credit Conference of the American Bankers Association.

RIVERHEAD, L. I, March 24 -- Dr. Herman Benjamin Baruch, former United States Ambassador to the Netherlands and Portugal, who died at his home in Wyandanch March 15, left an estate valued at approximately $2,000,000, a petition for the probate of his will filed here today in Suffolk County Surrogates Court showed.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 24 -- Wreckers have begun to tear down a famous resort landmark, 1 Atlantic Ocean, the home of the late Capt. John L. Young, a thousand feet out over the ocean at the end of the Million Dollar Pier.

CAMP DESERT ROCK, Nev., March 24 (UP) -- Nine volunteer officers in a five-foot trench today survived an atomic explosion from a distance of only 2,500 yards, half a mile nearer than human beings ever have been to a nuclear blast without being under military attack.
TOKYO, Wednesday, March 25 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,564, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Wednesday, Korean time:

There was a seven-act show in a single ring at Madison Square Garden last night. It drew 9,300 spectators, who paid $29,553 to see dropkicks and tackles -- not of the football variety -- right hooks, left jabs, eye-gouging and slapping.
Human failure far exceeds mechanical flaws in causing automobile accidents, Commissioner James R. Macduff of the State Motor Vehicle Bureau said last night.
It was an eventful day yesterday for William Kaiser, tall Virginia-born chief engineer of the superliner United States.

TAMPA, Fla., March 24 -- "I don't like to sound egotistical," said Rogers Hornsby, who couldn't sound egotistical if he tried, "but every time I stepped up to the plate with a bat in my hands, I couldn't help but feel sorry for the pitcher."

HARTFORD, March 24 -- The proposed route of the Fairfield County Thruway and its extension across Connecticut to Rhode Island at a cost estimated at $200,000,000 was approved today by the Joint Roads, Rivers and Bridges Committee of the Connecticut General Assembly.

Sugar, hides, lead and zinc were active yesterday. Prices closed irregularly higher with hides, cocoa, soybean oil, cottonseed oil and rubber showing gains. Sugar, lead, potatoes and wool were mixed and zinc, coffee and tin closed lower.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 24 -- The Security Council held another inconclusive meeting today on the question of a successor to Trygve Lie as Secretary General of the United Nations. No additional candidates were presented and the entire meeting was taken up with a discussion of the date of the next meeting, which is to be held Friday.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 24 (AP) -- A single by Mel Clark with two out in the ninth provided the winning run today as the Phillies downed the Senators, 5 -- 4.

Americans with the check-writing habit turned out 7,000,000,000 of them last year. That is the first official estimate and one of the first results of a survey of check collections throughout the nation undertaken by a joint committee of Federal Reserve and private banking authorities.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Charles E. Bohlen, President Eisenhower's choice to be Ambassador to the Soviet Union, was cleared for loyalty and security today by an extraordinary Senate jury of two. The clearance was the third for the nominee.

BOSTON, March 24 -- Francis W. White, president of the American Woolen Company, told stockholders at the fifty-fourth annual meeting today that the management was embarked on a program of diversification in synthetic fibers, accompanied by a liquidation of "excess capacity" in woolens and worsteds.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 24 -- Israel today accused the Soviet Union and its satellites of a campaign of "anti-Jewish incitement" that used charges of espionage by Zionists allegedly linked to a United States intelligence network.

The Gulf Oil Corporation reported yesterday for 1952 a consolidated net income of $141,820,328, or $6.01 each on the 23,598,120 shares outstanding at the year-end. This compares with $140,070,932, or $5.94 a share, in 1951, when there was a nonrecurring profit of $4,876,500 from the sale of assets.

Apparently in retaliation against the state for forcing a progressive reduction in the city's pari-mutuel tax, a resolution calling for condemnation of the Jamaica and Aqueduct race tracks was introduced yesterday in the City Council.
PARIS, March 24 -- There are many indications that as far as external affairs are concerned, the new Soviet Government is devoting ever increasing attention to Asia rather than to Europe.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 24 -- David J. McDonald, president of the United Steelworkers, proclaimed today his continued devotion to the Congress of Industrial Organizations and pledged support to its new president, Walter P. Reuther.

MILWAUKEE, March 24 (UP) -Baseball fans who bought tickets for Milwaukee Brewer games started exchanging them for seats at Braves' contests today as the first shipment of new tickets arrived from the printer.

THOSE who are temperamentally unable to await the arrival of the fresh-run Atlantic salmon will have an alternative beginning next Wednesday, when the spring salmon season officially opens on some of the New Brunswick rivers.
BERLIN, March 24 -- A United States Army private turned himself in to military police here Sunday after almost two years in East Germany, the Berlin Command announced tonight.

The International Freighting Corporation, operators of cargo-passenger services from the United States and Canada to the East Coast of South America, will receive three new cargo liners this year, all of them especially designed to meet the company's requirements.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Bernard M. Baruch said today that the cloak of official secrecy thrown around discussions of world crisis was a major reason for the lack of public demand for stand-by price and wage control authority.

Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, announced yesterday plans for a graphic arts center that will make available to the printing and lithographic industries the university's collection of books and other items concerned with the arts. Industry has been asked to help endow the center for $750,000.

A steady increase in economic development and raw materials output by the rich Belgium Congo, without the stimulus of defense emergencies or war, was forecast yesterday by L. C. Ameye, economic advisor to the Banque Belge d'Afrique.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 24 -- The last major obstacle to holding the 1958 Olympics in Melbourne seems to have been removed with the Victorian State Government's acceptance today of the Commonwealth Government's offer to finance housing for the 6,000 athletes that officials expect to attend.

Building and permanent mortgage loans amounting to $6,139,000 have been arranged by J. Halperin Co., brokers, for Greystone Gardens, a "213" cooperative apartment development to be built on forty-six acres on the east side of North Broadway, south of Odell Avenue in Yonkers, N. Y.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Testimony designed to show that E. Merl Young participated in a loan application to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation by the Lustron Corporation was offered by the Government today in Mr. Young's perjury trial.

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 24 (AP) -- The former mayor and the former police commissioner of Cliffside Park were indicted today by the holdover Bergen County rackets grand jury on charges of ignoring a big-time book making operation.

BONN, Germany, March 24 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer sought tonight to allay the fears of many Frenchmen who oppose ratification of the European Defense Community Treaty on the ground that the treaty system would bring about the return of German domination over Western Europe.

DETROIT, March 24 (UP) -- Marty Pavelich and Ted Lindsay each scored a pair of goals tonight as the Detroit Red Wings opened their defense of the Stanley Cup with a 7-to-0 victory over the Boston Bruins before 12,683 fans at Olympia.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 24 -- Two Canadian wild geese tried to help a fellow with a broken wing to rise off the water and accompany them to their northern breeding grounds when the flock left here last week, an unimpeachable authority on the subject revealed today.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 24 -- Undergraduates of Smith College have elected Miss Elizabeth Lunt Saunders, New York City junior, president of the Student Council and Miss Kathleen Ann Compton of Rosemont, Pa., also a junior, president of the House of Representatives.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Most of the 15 per cent cut that Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks proposes be made in the Truman Administration's budget estimate for his department is at the expense of the Maritime and Civil Aeronautics Administrations.
KARACHI, Pakistan, March 24 (Reuters) -- An important reshuffle in the administration of Punjab State, recently the scene of savage religious rioting, was reported here today.

What color television may be like a few years from now if the Federal Communications Commission approves the work of several years by the National Television Systems Committee, an industry-wide group representing more than twenty leading manufacturers, was covered technically yesterday at one of the sessions of the convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers.

Costumes and accessories worn by well-known New Yorkers between 1790 and 1910 form an interesting exhibition opening today at the Museum of the City of New York, 103d Street at Fifth Avenue. The show, which will run through Labor Day, will be open from 10 A. M. to 5 P. M., Tuesdays through Saturdays and from 1 to 5 on Sundays.

TOKYO, Wednesday, March 25 -- Heavy fighting continued today on the muddy shell-scarred slopes of "Old Baldy Hill" on the western Korean front, with Chinese infantry, backed by heavy mortar and artillery fire, still were clinging grimly to the ground captured in their three-pronged attack of Monday night, the heaviest in the past six months of the war.

MIAMI, Fla., March 24 (AP) -- A manufacturer of pharmaceuticals who was commissioned in the Army during World War II said today that certain Army staff officers were "plotting to throw off civilian control of the armed services.''

Electricians on great steel rolling carriers, painters with pots of brilliant paint and curators and other staff members of the Metropolitan Museum of Art were putting the last touches yesterday to the exhibition of Japanese treasures that will be opened to the public Friday.

PARIS, March 24 -- Benoit Frachon, Communist chief of the powerful General Confederation of Labor, was sought tonight by the police, who earlier had arrested and jailed two other Communist leaders of the Confederation and Andre Stil, editor in chief of the party's official organ, L'Humanite.

DENTON, Tex., March 24 (AP) -Byron Nelson, one of golf's greats, today entered the fight to clear charges of professionalism levelled against members of North Texas State's national intercollegiate champions.
It's plain enough what rain does in the country, but what does it do in the city?

The American Bach Society closed its third season last night at Town Hall with one of the loveliest concerts it has presented. The star of the evening was not a performer -- though the collaborators were still good -- but a small organ in a white and gold case that was only 7 feet high and 2 feet deep.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Senatorial prerogative added to the woes of the Secretary of Labor, Martin P. Durkin, today as he kept trying to put an official family together.

The sale of $127,735,000 of notes for the temporary financing of subsidized low-rent public housing was made yesterday by fifty-three municipal housing authorities. The sale included $29,075,000 of seven-month notes offered by the New York City Housing Authority to refund outstanding short-term development debt related to the Alfred E. Smith Houses, a state-aided project.

Council President Rudolph Halley, refusing to accept defeat for his economy proposals at the hands of Mayor Impellitteri and a Board of Estimate majority yesterday, resorted last night and early today to a half-dozen radio and television appeals.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- The dairy industry moved today to adopt the self-help program called for yesterday by Secretary Benson. The action was taken by more than 200 delegates at the annual meeting of the American Dairy Association.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The president of one of the country's largest labor unions, A. J. Hayes, of the International Association of Machinists, A. F. L., proposed today compulsory arbitration of national emergency disputes.

LONDON, March 24 -- The projected central African federation of three British dependencies aimed ultimately at creating a new nation in the Commonwealth was approved tonight by the House of Commons after a heated debate in which one opposi
Phelps Dodge Corporation announced yesterday that its price for domestically mined refined copper would be raised 1 1/2 cents a pound to 30 cents, delivered Connecticut Valley, effective today.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -United States District Judge Charles F. McLaughlin rejected today a Government motion to reinstate an indictment against Ray Brennan, reporter of The Chicago Sun-Times.
The Knicks will meet the Boston Celtics tonight at Madison Square Garden in the opener of a best-three-of-five series to determine the Eastern play-off winner in the National Basketball Association.

Delightful music for small orchestra by Ottorino Respighi, in the form of his suite "The Birds," and the tremendous music of Peter Ilich Tchaikovsky, in the instance of the "Pathetique" Symphony -- which remains, despite the criticisms of academicians, one of the greatest and most original of all modern symphonies -- began and ended the concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra, conducted by Eugene Ormandy, last night in Carnegie Hall.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 24 -Johnny Podres, the 20-year-old southpaw from Witherbee, N. Y., took another long step toward winning a place or the Dodger pitching staff today when he shut out his Montreal teammates for seven innings, allowing only three hits.

MONTREAL, March 24 (UP) -- Gordie Howe of the Detroit Red Wings won the National Hockey League scoring title for the third straight time with a record 95 points, but failed in his bid to better Maurice (Rocket) Richard's 1944-45 mark of fifty goals for a season.

A shipload of African slaves mutinied in 1839, taking possession of a Spanish slaver, and sailed an erratic course along the American coast. It was captured by an American naval vessel and brought into New London. This led to a series of legal battles with international complications.

In your issue of March 19, you discuss the action of the Conservative Government in England in denationalizing the steel industry. Your editorial raised some questions of fact on which I was doubtful. A conversation with a prominent British Labor M. P., briefly in this country on private business, confirms my doubts.

The formation of the Magna Theatre Corporation, the latest company to enter the burgeoning wide-screen motion picture field, was announced yesterday by Joseph M. Schenck, film pioneer who recently resigned as executive head of production of Twentieth Century-Fox and who will serve as board chairman of the new organization.

Two new films will arrive at first run theatres today. At the Roxy is "Call Me Madam," the Twentieth Century-Fox Technicolor version of the Broadway musical comedy. Ethel Merman is starred in the role she created on the stage.
LONDON, March 24 -- The news of Queen Mary's death halted nightlife and frivolity throughout Britain tonight.
LONDON, March 24 -- Business fell off and prices dropped in the stock market today but closed steady at slightly lower levels. South African gold mining shares recovered part of early losses.

Menachem Myerson, young Israeli 'cellist, made his debut last evening at Carnegie Recital Hall. The Jerusalem-born musician, son of Golda Myerson, Israeli Minister of Labor, has toured the Near East as 'cellist of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra and has appeared in chamber music concerts and recitals throughout Israel.

CHICAGO, March 24 (AP) -March onions sold off sharply on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange today as trading in the contract came to a close. The final price was $3.72 to $3.65, down 34 to 38 cents a sack from yesterday's finish.

The increase in the size of tankers plying the Arthur Kill and Kill van Kull, between Staten Island and New Jersey, is making the waterways less safe for navigation, shipping industry representatives told the Army Corps of Engineers at a conference here yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Don Fernando Berckemeyer, the Peruvian Ambassador to the United States, accused the Government of Ecuador today of sending a military contingent "into Peruvian territory with the deliberate purpose of moving the boundary landmarks" between the two countries.

Many parties will be given at the Bal des Berceaux, a dinner dance, on Friday night in the St. Regis Roof under the auspices of the Committee of French American Wives. The event is being held to raise funds for the organization's post-war program in France and for relief work in the Far East.
LOS ANGELES, March 24 (AP) -- Harry S. Truman took a turn at the piano for his former war buddies today before sailing for his Hawaiian vacation. The tune? "The Missouri Waltz."

PARIS, March 24 -- British proposals for prolonging the European Payments Union for one year from July 1 obtained the approval today of the Marshall Plan Council, which accepted also suggestions made by the British for the study of a wider system of trade payments and credits.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- It was Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower who revived the White House's Easter-egg rolling, an old custom that many here had considered as dead as the half-forgotten White House New Year's reception until it was revived recently.

ST. LOUIS, March 24 -- An executive's advancement in industry apparently can depend on his stomach's ability to resist peptic ulcers, as well as other factors such as the man's talents, it was indicated in a speech today before the American Academy of General Practice.

Judging from the testimony that Alfred P. Sloan Jr. gave during the anti-trust action brought against the du Ponts one would say that Charles F. Kettering was as interesting as Scheherazade when he talked to the old policy committee of General Motors about scientific research. Scheherazade talked herself out of a death sentence.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 24 (AP) -- W. A. Zarick's Khan and Ten Hills Farm's Shamrock, a couple of cast-offs from the Wheatley Stable, staged a scorching duel in the featured Davie Purse at Gulfstream Park today, with Khan gaining the honors by a neck. It was the most exciting finish of the program, seen by a crowd of 14,193.
KUWAIT, March 24 (AP) -- The American Independent Oil Company (Aminoil) announced success today in its sixth attempt to strike oil in a potentially rich field at the head of the Persian Gulf.

Broadway's acute booking congestion hasn't been alleviated yet, but should be straightened out soon as the result of a general drop in theatre attendance. Undoubtedly, the temporary jam can be traced to the shortage of legitimate houses plus the fact that several attractions are stubbornly earning their keep through the artificial respiration method of two tickets for the price of one.
With traditional generosity Americans have taken the lead in extending aid to war-ravaged and underdeveloped areas of the world.

Concern over recent protests by some United States politicians and publishers against United States "dependence" on Canada as a source of newsprint was expressed yesterday by Robert M. Fowler of Montreal, president of the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 24 -Gil McDougald slammed a 385-foot triple and a 410-foot double, the Yankees routed the Red Sox, 9 -- 0, and today's developments at Payne Field may have convinced Casey Stengel to leave well enough alone.

LOS ANGELES, March 24 -- A Communist party "writers' clinic" in Hollywood succeeded in recent years in imbuing its pupils with such fanatical loyalty that they used the tiniest details of their film work to further Red causes, the House Committee on Un-American Activities was told today.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Public Housing Administration announced today the sale by fifty-two local housing authorities of $98,660,000 in short-term loan notes at competitive bidding. The average interest rate of all notes sold was 1.4445 per cent. Interest rates on the individual issues ranged from 1.09 per cent to 1.48 per cent.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Mar. 24 -- The United States and its North Atlantic Treaty allies in Europe are planning a sharp rise this summer in their jet fighter strength on the Continent, notably in jet fighters able to match the Soviet Union's MIG-15.

LOS ANGELES, March 24 -Management at Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, Burbank, Calif., has been "exploring the possibility" of purchasing the Hughes Tool Company's aircraft interests for more than two months, it was disclosed today.

TRENTON, March 24 -- Nelson F. Stamler today asserted that the murder of Willie Moretti, notorious gambler, resulted from the imprisonment of his brother, Salvatore, and Joe Adonis, Willie Moretti's visit to Republican State Chairman John Dickerson and the gambler's general record.

ITHACA, N. Y., March 24 -- The individual is the most important factor in family life, it was agreed at several sessions yesterday and today at the Farm and Home Week program now in progress at Cornell University.

Four Eastern racing associations, conducting meetings at Jamaica, Belmont Park, Aqueduct and Delaware Park, will participate in a ten-week program of television and radio broadcasts of stakes events this season.

The ten-day Eastern States contract bridge championships continued last night at the McAlpin Hotel, with thirty-nine teams playing the second and final qualifying session of the Reisinger Cup team-of-four championship.
LONDON, Wednesday, March 25 -- Queen Mary's death is not likely to cause any change in the date for coronation of her grand-daughter as Elizabeth II.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed very steady yesterday, with gains of 24 to 39 points net in active months.

The Duchess of Windsor learned about the death of Queen Mary while listening to the radio last night in her apartment at the Waldorf Astoria Towers. Shortly thereafter she received a cablegram from her husband, the Duke, who went to London several days ago because of his mother's illness.

Spring has been described as a pack of canines in hot pursuit of a cold trail. It has been described as a bonfire for the disposal of heavy and lugubrious garments. It has been described as a time when moisture precipitated from the atmosphere has a nacreous effect on earthy slopes, when a species of small singing bird is in flight.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The House Judiciary Committee approved today a bill with more liberal provisions than the Eisenhower Administration had proposed for settling the offshore oil dispute.

A sudden onrush of spectators who broke through the Broadway police lines and descended upon Rita Hayworth on her arrival at the Rivoli Theatre last night came very close to marring the gala premiere of "Salome."

LONDON, March 24 -- Prime Minister Churchill announced today that Britain would accept the proposal of Gen. Vassily I. Chuikov, chairman of the Soviet Control Commission in Germany, for a Soviet-British conference in Berlin to discuss measures for "avoiding regrettable air incidents."

LONDON, Wednesday, March 25 -- At 11:15 last night Queen Mary's personal standard was hauled down over Marlborough House as news of her death was posted at the gate. Hundreds of Londoners, who had waited hours for the news, filed past the bulletin. Some looked grave and others openly showed their grief.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, plans to tell the French Government mission arriving here tomorrow that the United States has a sizable financial and budgetary problem of its own that limits the amount of aid available to its allies.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Congressional investigators heard today that a $300,000 house with $1,000,000 worth of furniture was being considered for the Ambassador to the United Nations, Henry Cabot Lodge Jr.

WASHINGTON, March 24 - The acquisition of the automotive assets of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., by the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation has given both the Kaiser interests and the Government an "earning asset," Harry A. McDonald, administrator of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said today.

Queen Mary, who died yesterday, occupied a unique place in the hearts of the British people, and her erect, dignified figure and Edwardian hats, parasol and hair-do were almost as widely recognized in America is in her own country.

A "minority report" on the much-criticized Port of New York was "filed" yesterday by "The Barnacles," an association of shipping executives and Government officials connected with maritime activity in this area.
PHOENIX, March 24 -- Resuming competition against major league opposition, the Giants revealed today that their long ball is still their most formidable weapon.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- When a visitor reaches the door of the Oval Office of the White House and before he turns toward President Eisenhower himself, his eye is arrested by the juxtaposition of two other noted Americans -- Lincoln and Lee.

A few years back my friends used to say that the Republicans were for "the Wall Street boys" and "big shots" -- not for the little fellow, I did not believe them. Since the Republicans came into office something tells me that my friends are right.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- A crack down on the remaining New Dealers in the Agriculture Department was threatened by Secretary Ezra Taft Benson today.

BONN, Germany, March 24 -- Six Czechoslovaks chose "freedom and justice" in the West today after a flight past the Iron Curtain in a Czechoslovak airliner. Four plotters seized control of a two-engine plane of the Czechoslovak National Air Line while it was on a scheduled flight between Prague and Brno last night and one of them, Miroslav Slovak, the pilot, hedgehopped the plane, a C-47, and its passengers to Frankfurt's Rhine-Main airport.

Removing the operation and fare-making of New York City's huge transit system from the realm of politics and into the hands of an authority promises benefits to the people of this city that, in our opinion, would be difficult to overestimate or overstate. The Impellitteri administration deserves no credit for the initiative and political courage that bring about this change, of course.

One of the unhappiest effects of the present Red hunts in education is the increasing breach between the academic community and the Congress. There is no question that the majority of the electorate support the Congressional inquiries. On the other hand, educators are convinced that their criticism of the investigations is sound.

Wind-slanted rain sloshed across the city and metropolitan area yesterday, flooding cellars and roads in New Jersey and Westchester, causing auto accidents and forcing airlines to divert planes from major airports in the city.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Earl Browder, former head of the Communist party in the United States, refused today to testify whether he was now or ever had been a Communist because, he said, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, was "out to get me."

The Citizens Committee on Children of New York City and the Day Care Council of New York City have sent strongly worded letters to Mayor Impellitteri protesting a reported plan to eliminate the day care program of the Department of Welfare from the 53-54 budget.

Of all the charges hurled by the Communist bloc against the United States, the accusation that this Government is plotting to overthrow the "peaceful democracies" in Eastern Europe through subversion, terrorism and Fifth Column activities is surely the height of something which defies description in parliamentary language.

LINCOLN, R. I., March 24 (AP) -Vital Sun, a 7-year-old owned by Walter Wilkerson, found a sloppy track to his liking and romped to a five-length victory in the $4,000 Watch Hill Purse today at Lincoln Downs.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -The Department of Justice tonight denied reports that it had ordered an immediate investigation of organized baseball.

A law enacted last year to give state courts jurisdiction over non-resident owners of aircraft by means of substitute service of process on the Secretary of State was declared unconstitutional yesterday by the Appellate Division, Second Department.

" Johnny Jupiter" is television's newest hit. It is a delightfully witty item of video fantasia that has charm, intelligence and a wonderful satirical point of view. It is something not to he missed at 7:30 P. M. Saturdays over the Du Mont network (Channel 5).

There were a few red faces around the American Stock Exchange yesterday and it was all because someone hadn't yet learned that two and two make four. On Monday there was such a demand for the common stock of Sapphire Petroleums, Ltd., that the opening of trading in the stock was delayed more than ten minutes.

Excellent fall retail sales in the men's clothing field can be expected because of stronger than normal replacement demand, a high rate of discharge from the armed forces, the market created by new fabrics and patterns, and a growing reaction to sloppy dress habits, according to Jerome I. Udell, chairman of the board of Max Udell Sons Co.

MONTREAL, March 24 (UP) -- Defenseman Emile (Butch) Bouchard scored the tie-breaking goal tonight as the Montreal Canadiens downed the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 to 1, in the opening game of their Stanley Cup semi-final series.

Motors, oils, amusement and railroad issues led the stock market higher yesterday. But the favorites of the day were the low-price issues, with the result that of the ten most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange, seven were in the $20 or less class.

Henry Rosenfeld has completed negotiations for production and distribution of a line of dresses carrying the Rosenfeld label with one of the Iragest dress manufacturers in Great Britain, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The State Department dismissed today as fabricated and "unfounded" the Soviet Government's version of an attack by Russian MIG fighters on an Air Force reconnaisance plane off the Siberian coast March 15.
LONDON, March 24 (Reuters) -- Queen Mary was the third woman in the British Commonwealth after Queen Elizabeth II and Queen Mother Elizabeth. Like them, she was entitled to the prefix "Her Majesty."
GENEVA, March 24 -- Britain may have just saved the day for trade liberalization in Europe.

Ray Bolger will star in a weekly half-hour television program, beginning in September, under an exclusive long-term television and radio contract announced yesterday by the American Broadcasting Company. The program will be produced and filmed in Hollywood. The network said that Mr. Bolger "will enjoy the widest scope and latitude to bring his abilities into full play as a dancing pantomimist."

HARTFORD, March 24 -- The Connecticut Light and Power Company told a legislative committee today that it would be a "physical and financial impossibility" to place its overhead transmission lines underground.

W'ASHINGTON, March 24 UP)The Administration opened up more than 1,400 choice Postmaster appointments for new examinations today by canceling the eligibility tests for these places that had been held during the past few months.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Radio Corporation of America expects to ask the Federal Communications Commission for a go-ahead on commercial color television in six months or possibly sooner, a company spokesman told a committee of the House of Representatives today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 24 -- There was a real debate in Yugoslavia's Communist - led Parliament today. One Deputy proposed amendments to a bill already approved by the Federal Executive Council, provoked a heated exchange with Edvard Kardelj, Vice President of the Council under President Tito, and finally walked out before the vote was taken rejecting his proposals.

The question of how noisy a noise is will be answered by a group of experts. Excessive industrial noise has led to claims for $2,000,000,000 in the nation's courts, and the judges, seeking to still the plaintiffs' clamor for re-imbursement for loss of hearing, want some standards or criteria to use as a guide.

LONDON, Wednesday, March 25 -- Queen Mary, who lived through two World Wars and a series of personal and family tragedies without bowing her regal head, died last night at 10:20 o'clock, only a few weeks before what would have been her eighty-sixth birthday anniversary.

PITTSBURGH, March 24 (AP) - The Aluminum Company of America said today that it had succeeded in using ordinary household power to heat a giant aluminum ingot to working temperatures fifteen times faster than could be done in a conventional furnace.

ALBANY, March 24 -- Governor Dewey disclosed today that a commission study of state finances and state fiscal relations with the Federal Government and with local governments, which he proposed in his budget message last January, would be much broader in scope than originally contemplated.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- Local traders on the Board of Trade yesterday placed too much stress on peace possibilities and found themselves oversold this morning. Prices for both grains and soybeans moved upward in sharp contrast to the weakness of Monday. Drought continued in the hard winter wheat sections of the Southwest and subsoil moisture remained deficient in the North American spring wheat areas.

ELMSFORD, N. Y., March 24 -- A large truck and trailer left Saw Mill River Road here at 4:05 A.M. today, crashed into a brick building and broke gas pipes in the structure. Escaping natural gas exploded thirty-five minutes later with a blast that shook buildings a mile away.

When the Senate votes on the nomination of Charles E. Bohlen to be Ambassador to Russia it is inconceivable that it will fail to give him, and to President Eisenhower who appointed him, an overwhelming endorsement. To do anything else under present circumstances would be to smooth the way for what can best be described as the anarchical approach of Senators McCarthy and McCarran to the delicate balance of powers within the Federal Government.

Soviet Russia cannot achieve world domination unless it first establishes superiority in air power, Col. James E. Reilly of the United States Air Force told 400 business and military leaders yesterday at the second session of a two-week Economic Mobilization Course at the Astor Hotel.

Vacant parcels in the East New York section of Brooklyn were the subject of spirited bidding by at least six syndicates yesterday at the second day of the city's auction of properties acquired "in rem" foreclosures of tax liens. Fifty-four properties were sold for $380,100, which was $166,250 above the upset prices.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Representative Carl Hinshaw, Republican of California, said today public hearings would be held within two or three weeks on the possibility of applying atomic energy to private enterprise, probably through the generation of electric power.

In Topics of The Times you mention the foolish objections of lawyers and hotel maids to recent individual theatrical portrayals, and add your own objection to other "relatively unimportant'' sensitivities that "threaten to deprive us of much that has been pleasant in American humor."

TORONTO, March 24 -- The Municipality of Greater Toronto will come into existence on April 15. The merger of twelve suburban communities with the city proper was dictated by the Ontario Provincial Government to end the chaos that was threatening to throttle the hub of Canada's wealthiest region.
TORONTO, March 24 (UP) -- Joe Primeau quit as coach of the Toronto Maple Leafs today, and Managing Director Conn Smythe said he would offer the job to a former Leaf great, King Clancy.

HOUSTON, Tex., March 24 (AP) -- Frank Coyle and Bill Baier of Chicago, won their first-round match in the national handball doubles championships today, eliminating James Donovan and Joe Szurek, Galveston, Tex., 21 -- 11, 21 -- 4.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 24 -- There is a good chance that Johnnie Ray, the cry singer, will make his film debut for Twentieth Century Fox in Irving Berlin's "There's No Business Like Show Business." With Donald O'Connor out of the picture because of a conflicting commitment, Sol Siegel, the producer, is thinking about using Mr. Ray provided his dramatic talent matches his musical ability.

ROME, March 24 -- Two major maneuvers, which for the last nine days have involved the naval and air forces of six North Atlantic Treaty powers locked in simulated combat all over the central and eastern Mediterranean, were brought to a successful conclusion today.

CAIRO, March 24 -- The already dim prospect of re-establishing an effective monarchy in this country became considerably dimmer tonight with the announcement that the subcommittee set up solely to weigh the merits of the monarchical versus the republican form of government had decided unanimously in favor of the latter.

A brief opposing legislation now before Governor Dewey to prohibit acceptance by stores of telephone orders for merchandise on Sunday, will be filed soon by the New York State Council of Retail Merchants.

The other day at lunch the articulate Francis Guth said one of his main interest was eating well and getting other people to do the same. The youthful manufacturer from Andover, Mass., said he thought it important they do so for psychological, physical and aesthetic reasons.

With reference to your editorial of March 17, those of us associated with the Albert Einstein Medical Center of Philadelphia wish to offer our felicitations to the second great medical institution to pay homage to the foremost exponent of objectivity of our day.
LONDON, Wednesday, March 25 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Churchill last night drew up a formal address of condolence to Queen Elizabeth II on the death of her grandmother, Queen Mary.

There appears to be a relatively simple way of establishing a two-zone system for metropolitan New York subways. Revenue could be increased 50 per cent on all interzone travel without disturbing the 10-cent fare for intra-zone travel.

A three-alarm fire in three loft buildings around the junction of South and Dover Streets threw such colorful showers of sparks into the air last night that motorists on the Brooklyn Bridge halted to watch.

Anheuser-Busch, Inc., St. Louis, is embarking on the heaviest newspaper ad campaign ever put behind a nationally distributed beer for its Budweiser product, according to the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

Svetozar Gligoric, who yielded this year's championship of Yugoslavia to Dr. Petar Trifunovic but is outranking his rival in the international chess masters tournament at Mar Del Plata, took the lead there yesterday with victories in the seventh and eighth rounds, according to report from Buenos Aires.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (UP) -- A high Justice Department official testified today that Garry D. Iozia, New Jersey business man, received favored treatment in his tax troubles on orders of T. Lamar Caudle, later ousted as head of the Tax Division.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (UP) -- The Senate Interior Committee today rejected a bill for Federal control of marginal lands and took up a measure to give to coastal states title to lands offshore their historic boundaries.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The formal remarks of Mr. Stanton were taken to indicate that his network had abandoned its system completely.

AIKEN, S. C., March 25 (AP) -- Lean Dave Douglas clipped three strokes off par on the back nine of the 6,676-yard par-71 Palmetto Golf Club course today to chalk up a 34, 33 -- 67 and head the pro contingent in the club's annual pro-amateur tournament.

Sixteen surviving contract bridge teams out of a starting field of thirty-nine played last night the first knockout round of the Reisinger Cup team-of-four championship, the most important team event in the twenty-seventh annual Eastern States Championships. The play is at the McAlpin Hotel under the auspices of the Greater New York Bridge Association.
CLEVELAND, March 25 (UP) -- The Cleveland Browns declared war on football players who prefer baseball by trading two of them to Baltimore today in a ten-for-five player deal.

The calendar will be a hard task-master if the terms of the transit authority law are to be met. Every consideration, statutory and otherwise, calls for all the speed that is consistent with thoughtful consideration of the important and complex problems involved in transferring operation from the Board of Transportation to the new five-member Authority.

New York City has borrowed $50,000,000 on tax anticipation notes due on May 4 at an interest rate of 1 5/8 per cent, Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday. The notes were sold by allotment to twenty-three banks and trust companies as follows:

A four-story apartment house accommodating thirty-five families at 97-20 Van Wyck Expressway, between Ninety-seventh and 101st Avenues, in the Kew Gardens section of Queens, attracted the greatest interest yesterday in the auction sale by the city of realty acquired through "in rem" tax lien foreclosures.

One of Broadway's top-notch musicals, "Wonderful Town," starring Rosalind Russell at the Winter Garden, will shut down for one night early next month rather than play a performance partly sold to an alleged left-wing group.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 25 -- Following is the text of the statement made today by Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States representative, before the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee:

Hamilton House was dedicated yesterday as the community center for the Gov. Alfred E. Smith Housing Project at 50 Madison Street. The neighborhood center, which has served the Lower East Side for the last fifty years, moved recently from 72 Market Street to sixteen rooms on two floors of the new project.

The maximum sentence of ten to twenty years was imposed yesterday by Judge Nathan R. Sobel in Kings County Court on Donald Ferrick, 18 years old, who was convicted of first-degree manslaughter in the slaying last June 26 of a 23-year-old rabbinical student.

For a little while yesterday morning a new upward push for the stock market seemed to be in the making. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange went to 620,000 shares in the first hour and the ticker fell behind transactions on the floor.

A virtual end to the ten-year-old controversy over color television appeared certain last night after the Columbia Broadcasting System announced that it had no present plans to broadcast programs or to manufacture receivers under its color transmission system.
LONDON, March 25 -- The stock markets were quiet today and domestic issues moved narrowly except a few that were affected by dividend announcements.

A pamphlet on the kitchen issued this week by Cornell University should interest many persons: housewives and their husbands and psychologists, anthropologists, sociologists, designers, architects and equipment manufacturers.
NORFOLK, Va., March 25 (AP) -- The destroyer escort Cross, bound from Boston to Bermuda on a Reservist cruise, met and mastered two of the seafarers' gravest dangers in rapid succession yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 25 -- United Nations delegates were told today how a talk, a drink and a dinner with a British diplomat cost a minor Czechoslovak official twenty years of freedom.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The White House sent to the Senate today the names of eighteen major generals and 104 brigadier generals of the Army Reserve who had agreed to accept indefinite appointments in place of their previous five-year renewable terms.

The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway Company had a net income last year of $44,999,175 after charges and taxes, equal after preferred dividend requirements to $5.66 each on the 7,838,036 common shares outstanding according to the road's 1952 annual report. This compared with $38,122,534 or $4.80 a common share in 1951.

Samuel Sedletz, Brooklyn furrier, who allegedly stole $200,000 in furs and fled to Antwerp, Belgium, with the loot, returned here yesterday aboard the freighter Lualaba in company of two detectives and was taken to the Kings County Distrct Attorney's office for questioning.

Col. Alvin R. Glafka of the Army described Africa as "the continent of tomorrow" in stressing its strategic importance yesterday to 400 business leaders and officers of the armed services who are attending a two-week Economic Mobilization Course at the Astor Hotel.

Aline van Barentzen, a French pianist and a veteran of the concert stage, made her American debut last night in Town Hall. Those who are familiar with her pre-war H. M. V. recordings will not need to be told of her professional status.

A ship that was supposed to have started for Korea loaded with artillery shells has been diverted "to another part of the world" because this type of ammunition has become so plentiful in Korea it has exceeded storage space, it was learned yesterday.

ALBANY, March 25 (AP)--The Public Service Commission today ordered the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation to cancel the $2,400,000 electric power rate increase the utility proposed for Niagara frontier industrial and commercial customers.

A plot of 32,000 square feet at Seventy-second Street and Forty-first Avenue in Jackson Heights, Queens, has been sold by Irving Domnitch to Sol Atlas, builder, who plans to improve it with a six-story apartment house to accommodate 130 families.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 25 -- The Government prosecutor in the high treason trial of Sultan Hamid II of Borneo, accused of attempting to overthrow the Indonesian Government in 1950, asked today for an eighteen-year sentence as the trial recessed until April 8, when the verdict will be heard.

The Knickerbockers were able to hold off a resurgent Boston Celtics team in the final two minutes in Madison Square Garden last night to become one up in the final Eastern Division play-off series of the National Basketball Association.

CHICAGO, March 25 (AP) -- Oklahoma A. and M., kingpin of the Missouri Valley Conference, and independent Bradley today were threatened with expulsion from the nation's strongest academic accrediting association, mostly for alleged athletic malpractices.

Irving Kolodin, The Saturday Review's music editor and critic, who is the author of a book on the Metropolitan Opera, has written a history of the famous lyric theatre titled "The Story of the Metropolitan Opera." It will be published April 13 by Knopf.

CHICAGO, March 25 -- Grain futures weakened again today as buying support failed to sustain market rallies. No special news developments were reported to account for the reactionary trend, and the weather news, which was bullish, failed to register with pit professionals, who presently are doing most of the trading. The flare-up in the Korean war also failed to excite the trade.

Council President Rudolph Halley demanded yesterday that Mayor Impellitteri speak for himself in a proposed television debate on the city's budget crisis last night, instead of sending a representative, Budget Director Abraham D. Beame.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- The Department of Defense said today that draft calls might be reduced, starting in July, from the current monthly rate of 53;000 to around 37,000 or lower.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 25 -- If Rex Barney, Tommy Byrne and some of the other talented wild men of recent major league history had even a fraction of the control possessed by Robin Roberts of the Phils, they would be highly successful pitchers. But they haven't. In fact, no one in the Big Time has as much control as the large Mr. Roberts.

ITHACA, N. Y., March 25 -- There is no such thing as "the easiest way to do housework; it's all a state of mind," several experts of the State College of Home Economics agreed today at meetings during the forty-second annual Farm onnd Home Week, now in its third day at Cornell University.

NEW DELHI, India, March 25 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru announced today that India's twenty-eighth state, her first to be formed deliberately on a linguistic basis and to have a Communist political plurality, would be inaugurated Oct. 1.

Rabbi Clifton Harby Levy, oldest living past president of the New York Board of Rabbis, yesterday installed Rabbi David J. Seligson of Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and Fifty- fifth Street, as president of the board.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- The Rev. Edward L. R. Elson, President Eisenhower's pastor, said he believed the nation's citizen-ministers were ready to cooperate with any Congressional investigation of communism and would not shink from any "personal scrutiny."

WASHINGTON, March 25--Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of New York City's public schools, reported to the Senate Internal Security subcommittee today that, while the long fight to rid classrooms of Communist teachers had been effective, "we are by no means satisfied that we have cleaned up the situation."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 25 -- There are indications of further changes in the economic policy of the Yugoslav Government. The most outstanding is a decision of the State Secretariat for National Economy to permit the establishment by Yugoslav enterprises of joint stock companies with foreign concerns.

YONKERS, March 25 -- Maj. Reginald H. Thayer, engineer officer of this city's Auxiliary Police Corps, resigned his commission today rather than make his civil defense rounds with only flashlight, nightstick and whistle.

Push cart clothes-carriers swarming through mid-Manhattan areas were likened yesterday to a plague of destructive locusts by the Broadway Association and Thirty-Fourth Street-Midtown Association. The itinerant trundlers were accused of causing more damage and creating more perils than any single descent of the winged insects that ravage crops.

Magnetic-tape recordings of picture information, as well as sound, eventually will make obsolete the use of films for television and greatly reduce the over-all cost of video programming, David Sarnoff, chairman of the board of the Radio Corporation of America, predicted last night at the annual dinner of the convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers.

CHICAGO, March 25 -- More than a few of the country's banks have been making unwisely liberal consumer credit terms, G. Ardee Ames, vice president of General Motors Acceptance Corporation, said today at the National Installment Credit Conference of the American Bankers Association.

CHICAGO, March 25 -- Hughston McBain, chairman of Marshall Field Co., today characterized the company's January and February business as disappointing, but said a brisk upturn in volume this month should bring sales for the first quarter close to the level of a year ago. He spoke at the company's annual stockholders' meeting.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The circumstances surrounding the $10,000,000 stock issue offered by the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation in 1948, which Otis Co., Cleveland investment banking house, declined to market at the last minute, seemed headed for another round of legal proceedings today.

TOKYO, Thursday, March 26--Troops of the United States Seventh Infantry Division withdrew from "Old Baldy" Hill on the western Korean front early today and Allied planes and artillery began to batter the summit and slopes seized by the Chinese Communists in a powerful assault Monday night.

The complex problems arising from the operation of mobile equipment in a large shipyard are similar to the traffic control difficulties of a small city, Frank K. Lower, assistant works manager of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation, declared here yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 25 -- Sears, Roebuck Co. in 1952 made a profit of $110,236,311, equal to $4.56 a share on the common stock, compared with $111,894,654, or $4.73, in 1951, Gen. Robert E. Wood, chairman, and Fowler B. McConnell, president, disclosed today in their annual report to stockholders.

A labor organizing scheme that had been aimed at messenger service companies in this city came to an abrupt end with the arrest of two union officials for conspiracy, coercion and extortion, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan reported yesterday.

Israel is leaving no stone unturned, not even that of monetary chaos, in its struggle to shape an undeveloped region into a modern industrial community. According to Pick's Currency Report, the Paris coinage mint is being commissioned to turn out an Israel gold coin of the weight and fineness of the English sovereign.

The death in Buenos Aires of Ezequiel Pedro Paz, co-owner of the newspaper La Prensa and son of its founder, reminds us that it was just two years ago that the Peron Government was pushing laws expropriating the great daily through the subservient Argentine Congress.

CHICAGO, March 25 -- Long-awaited policy proposals for permitting private industry to enter the field of electrical power production through the use of atomic power will be made public "within two or three weeks" Representative Carl Hinshaw, Republican of California, a member of the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy, told a meeting of the American Power Conference here tonight.

Lieut. Gen. C. R. Huebner, State Civil Defense Director, declared yesterday that the atom bomb test on March 17, at which he was an observer, showed that "people don't have to live under the fear that everyone is going to die" in such an attack.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The White House announced today that segregation would be ended in schools operated by the Army with Federal funds for children of Army personnel.

In the belief that the growing economy of Colombia now warrants such an organization, Antonio Angel, industrialist of Bogota, and Maximilian Elser Jr. of Elser Cothran here have formed Compania Colombians de Publicidad Elser y Cothran, Ltda., in Bogota.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 25 -- Walter P. Reuther, re-elected today to his fifth term as president of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., announced a step directed toward obtaining a guaranteed annual wage.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 25 -- An Israeli spokesman, commenting on a complaint filed yesterday by six Arab nations that the Tel Aviv Government had begun to sell the property of Arab refugees, said today that legislation now being considered by the Israeli Parliament dealt only with property owned by Arabs living within Israel's borders.

Schiess A. G. of Duesseldorf, Germany, an important manufacturer of heavy machine tools, is investing $250,000 to form an American affiliate, the American Schiess Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Wilhelm Zangen, president.

RANGOON, Burma, March 25 (AP) -- Burma asked the United Nations today to brand Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalist China as an aggressor. The Rangoon Government charged the Formosa regime was maintaining guerrilla troops on this country's frontier with Red China.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States, urging twenty-three changes in the Taft-Hartley law, declared today that labor leaders and unions exercising "monopolistic powers" should be made laible under the anti-trust laws or have the facilities of the National Labor Relations Board denied to them.

An elderly, retired postman of Portland, Ore., has discovered by accident the skull of a 10,000,000-year-old mastodon, it was reported yesterday by Dr. George Gaylord Simpson, curator of fossil mammals at the American Museum of Natural History. It is the only known fossil of its kind.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (UP) -- The capital's civil defense chief circled a busy intersection in a helicopter during a simulated atomic bomb attack today to see if the craft would help in directing traffic and preventing panic during a raid.
The number of non-residential construction jobs in New York State increased in 1952 over the previous year but the total cost of the construction was less.

Exposed to a renewal of Monday's selling pressure, and beset by rumors about the imminence of an announcement regarding the Treasury's next financing moves, the market for United States Government securities lost further ground yesterday, with most of the intermediate and long-term issues touching new low prices.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Mortgages held by the United States Government on seven Italian merchant vessels were declared in default today by the Maritime Administration. The action, it was conceded, was based on a technicality and was taken because the ships were included in a Defense Department list of vessels known to have been trading behind the Iron Curtain.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended March 18:

CHICAGO, March 25 (AP) -- Joe Kissoff, East Lake (Ohio) machinist, and Ed Koepp, 61, Solon (Ohio) gardener, today captured the lead in the doubles event of the American Bowling Congress tourney with a score of 1,339.

BERLIN, March 25 -- Sir Ivone Kirkpatrick, British High Commissioner, informed Gen. Vassily I. Chuikov, his Soviet counterpart, today, that he agreed to the Russian's proposal for a conference in Berlin on air safety problems. Sir Irvone asked General Chuikov to name the time and place for the talks.

TAIPEI, Formosa, March 25 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark, the United States Far Eastern Commander, held a thirty-minute private talk with President Chiang Kai-shek this evening, nine hours after his arrival in Formosa to conduct a round of conferences with American and Chinese Nationalist officials.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- On a keynote of French-United States unity in peace and war, Premier Rene Mayer and members of his Government were welcomed in the name of President Eisenhower today as Vice President Richard M. Nixon and John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, recalled the historic ties of friendship between the two republics.

An increase last week of 2,455,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 163,324,000 barrels, compared with 160,869,000 a week earlier and 158,416,000 a year ago.
The law firm of Liebman, Eulau Robinson, floor in 32 E 57th St; Rocco Custom Tailors, Benjamin Patek, jeweler, in 562 5th Ave -- Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., broker.

CLEVELAND, March 25 (UP) -- George Araujo of Providence, R. I., won a unanimous ten-round decision tonight over Teddy (Red Top) Davis of Hartford, Conn., and a shot at the lightweight championship of the world some time this summer.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Senator George A. Smathers, Democrat of Florida, added his voice today to a chorus of Senators suggesting that the Army retain Gen. James A. Van Fleet on active duty.

The disparity between pension and disability payments made to dependents of reserve officers and enlisted men who die in military service, and those made to families of Regular and National Guard officers and enlisted men killed in service, was denounced yesterday by Herbert L. Brickman, director of the New York City Veterans Center, 500 Park Avenue.

BUENOS AIRES, March 25 -- In a search for foreign capital, the Argentine Government is developing a law designed to attract large - scale investments of hard currencies which may permit a modicum of success in achieving the ambitions of the nation's second five-year plan, reliable sources reported today.

The Atlantic Coast District headquarters of the Maritime Administration received instructions from Washington yesterday to withdraw from fleet lay-up four Government-owned Victory ships to meet emergency shipping needs of the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service.

VIENNA, March 25 -- Word reached here today from a reliable source that Zoltan Vas, former head of the Hungarian State Economic Planning Office, who was reported to have committed suicide, appeared last week in Parliament in Budapest. What is more, the report said, he was seen to kiss his old friend, Premier Matyas Rakosi, on both cheeks.

PARIS, March 25 -- To back up the emergency aid to towns destroyed by floods in Britain, the Netherlands and Belgium with permanent assistance, 500 of the largest cities of Europe are being asked to "adopt" one or more of the villages facing the problem of rebirth.

The first test to determine whether machines can or cannot detect drunks more proficiently than arresting policemen and police surgeons was staged yesterday at Police Headquarters with inconclusive results.

The Senate is scheduled to vote tomorrow on the appointment of Charles E. Bohlen as Ambassador to the Soviet Union, and it will have an opportunity then to register its confidence in the integrity of both President Eisenhower and his nominee, its recognition of Executive responsibility and its rejection of the effort of Senator McCarthy and his allies to blacken once again a good man's name.

BONN, Germany, March 25 -- A powerful lobby of West German industrialists has forced the Bonn Government to retreat from its proposed legislative ban on all cartels and to agree in principle to permit the recartelization of industry in the event that an economic recession or depression should cripple this country's export trade.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (UP) -- United States battle casualties in Korea rose by 280 last week to a new total of 131,524, the Department of Defense reported today.

" By the Light of the Silvery Moon," which arrives at the Radio City Music Hall, is today's lone film newcomer. The Warner Brothers romantic comedy-drama, filmed in Technicolor from the "Penrod" stories of Booth Tarkington, starring Doris Day and Gordon MacRae, was directed by David Butler and produced by William Jacobs from a script by Robert O'Brien and Irving Elinson.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 25 -- An electronically operated traffic control system recently installed at this city's busy eight-corner intersection of Main Street, Broadway and Westchester Avenue was found to be so successful today by officials that equipment for a similar system at Broadway and Lake Street was ordered.

MOSCOW, March 25 -- The Soviet Union and Communist China have signed a new trade protocol under which the Soviet Union will assist China in constructing electric power stations and in equipping metallurgical, mining, machine construction and chemical industries, it was announced today.
TOKYO, Thursday, March 26 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,565, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Thursday, Korean time:

On gross income of $1,622,254,935, the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., had a record consolidated net income last year of $171,091,587, equal to $5.27 each on the 32,464,000 average number of shares outstanding in 1952, the report to stockholders, issued yesterday, reveals.

The last unsettled point of dispute remaining from last month's ten-day strike of tugboat workers was dissipated yesterday as union officials agreed to a decision granting the employers the right to determine manning scales pending arbitration of a manning disagreement.

LOS ANGELES, March 25 -- A hearing of the House Committee on Un-American Activities was thrown into turmoil for fifty minutes today by the verbal jousting of Edward Huebsch, a screen writer whom committee members repeatedly called "contemptuous." The writer declined to say, on the ground of possible self-incrimination, if he was or had been a Communist.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (UP) -- A Washington consultant testified today that he gave E. Merl Young, former Reconstruction Finance Corporation examiner a check for $312.50 for services to the Binkley Manufacturing company of the Warrenton, Mo. Hubert B. Steele, also a former R. F. C. examiner, was the witness.

LONDON, March 25 -- The body of Queen Mary, who died yesterday, will be buried beside that of her husband, George V, in St. George's Chapel at Windsor next Tuesday after lying in state Sunday and Monday in Westminster Hall.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The next and third issue in Congress in the area of international affairs will arise over the Bricker resolution to restrict the treaty-making power of the Executive and the Senate, and comments on the subject by the President and Secretary of State Dulles indicate differences of opinion within the Administration.

Treatment with the new isoniazid and other anti-tuberculosis drugs at Health Department clinics has proved a practical way of reaching TB sufferers who are either unable to get into a hospital or unwilling to remain in one, according to Dr. Arthur B. Robins, chief of the department's Tuberculosis Bureau.

A small but select display of Japanese applied art now at Bonniers, 605 Madison Avenue, should prove an appropriate supplement to the exhibition of Japanese art opening at the Metropolitan Museum of Art tomorrow. The objects in the Bonniers show are the work of Japanese craftsmen working in that country today and continuing to apply the tenets of the traditional Japanese arts shown at the museum.
John K. Cochran has been elected a vice president of the Duplan Corporation.

NEW DELHI, India, March 25 -- A storm has been created in Indian newspaper circles by the Bombay State Government's recent ban on official advertising in the Times of India, which has the largest daily circulation in the country, and its allied publications because of the paper's criticism of the local administration.
BOSTON, March 25 -- The American Woolen Company asked an arbitrator today for a 20 per cent wage reduction for workers in its New England mills.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 25 (AP) -- One upset was registered in the Everglades tennis tournament today as second-round and quarterfinal singles matches were played.

John and Alexander Dallesio pleaded not guilty yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court to income tax indictments two hours after the brothers had been released in $75,000 bail each as material witnesses in the Staten Island crime inquiry.

The United States Steel Corporation is proceeding as rapidly as possible on construction work at the new Fairless Works near Morrisville, Pa., and expects to complete the project on schedule by the end of this year, a company spokesman said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- The American Federation of labor and a spokesman for Texas citrus and vegetable growers today criticized the Labor Department's administration of the law governing importation of Mexican farm labor.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 25 -- The Dodgers ended their East Coast activities today with a 1-0 victory over the Milwaukee Braves, the second single-run game in which they have been involved. They lost the other one to the Senators here a week ago.

New York State motorists were cautioned yesterday by James R. Macduff, Motor Vehicle Commissioner, against "tighter, tougher enforcement of traffic laws and regulations" following the implementation of Governor Dewey's highway safety program.

The Dartmouth College Alumni Fund opened its 1953 campaign for $600,000 at a dinner last night in the Dartmouth Club of New York, 37 East Thirty-ninth Street, with John Sloan Dickey, president of Dartmouth, as the guest of honor.
SAN BRUNO, Calif., March 25 (UP) -- Two jockeys were injured in a three-horse spill in the fifth race at Tanforan today.
WASHINGTON, N. I., March 25 -- The ten members of the Clarence Matlock family, who died as the result of one of the nation's worst automobile Crashes near here last Friday, were buried today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 25 -- The United States told the Communist delegates and the men in the Kremlin today that this country longed for honest negotiation and stood ready to meet the Soviet world halfway, but would continue to look to its defense until the threat of Russian aggression was lifted.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 25 -- The story of how a young atomic engineer, carrying classified information in his head, was kept in Letterman Army Hospital for "security reasons" during a long illness was revealed today some forty-eight hours after his death.

Ownership of the eight-story apartment house at 100 Remsen Street in Brooklyn has been conveyed through the sale of stock of 100 Remsen Street, Inc., by Maurice Magid and associates to David and Mary Serota. The building, completed in 1949, occupies the blockfront on Henry Street between Remsen Street and Hunts Alley.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

MIAMI, Fla., March 25 (UP) -- A special Federal grand jury reported after a months-long study of Florida terrorism today that the Ku Klux Klan was a "cancerous growth as destructive of basis civil liberties as communism itself."
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 25 -- The Giants didn't have their long ball or much of anything else today as Paul Richards' White Sox stalked off with the final meeting between the two clubs, 6 to 3.

There are some 10,000,000 men, women and children in Korea who are in desperate need of clothing. More than 100,000 of these are children who have been orphaned by the war. About 300,000 are women who have been widowed. During the past eighteen months American Relief for Korea, Inc., 67 West Forty-fourth Street, New York 36, has sent 6,500,000 pounds of clothing to Korean civilians. The total represented donations from 5,538 communities throughout the country.

Staff scientists at the Museum of Natural History will relate the stories behind some of the museum's $40,000,000 collection of exhibits in a new weekly television program to be presented by the Columbia Broadcasting System network beginning Sunday, May 10, from 5 to 6 P. M.
AT THE KOREAN FRONT, March 25 -- Once more dead and wounded were taken down today along the familiar muddy, winding road that led away from the slopes of "Old Baldy."

As reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES, S. M. Burke, Pakistani Minister in Washington, recently informed an English Speaking Union audience in New York City that, with respect to our foreign aid program, equal treatment of India and Pakistan by the United States -- despite India's declared neutrality and Pakistan's cooperation with the Western nations -- is "puzzling" to many Pakistanis.

Teachers -- and parents -- can create a real interest in nature in children if they are interested themselves and take advantage of the opportunities each day brings. Dr. Zachary Subarsky, chairman of biological science at the Bronx High School of Science, advocated a relaxed, "learning together" approach in this field yesterday in a talk to school nature curators at the American Museum of Natural History.
CHICAGO, March 25 (AP) -- Representatives of the nation's railways today termed an arbitration award of a 4-cent-an-hour wage increase to railroad employes "completely unjustified."

PORTLAND, Me., March 25 (AP) -- Federal Judge John D. Clifford Jr., today approved a plan for liquidation of the Northern New England Company and the New England Public Service Company, utilities holding companies.

A suspect taken into custody ten hours after the beaten and stabbed body of a personnel executive was found yesterday has confessed to murdering him, Deputy Chief Inspector James B. Leggett announced early this morning.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25 -- Until Rip Repulski, a rookie up from Rochester, tripled with the bases loaded in the eighth inning today, the Yankees had a chance against the Cardinals at Al Lang Field. Once Repulski dented the base of the wall in left field, the Bombers were out of contention and the Red Birds finished with a 7-1 victory before 3,105 fans.

A compromise solution of the controversy over cutting corporate and individual taxes is likely to be sought, John D. Morris of the Washington Bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES reported yesterday before the in-service course for teachers under auspices of THE TIMES in cooperation with the Board of Education.

HERSHEY, Pa., March 25 -- Tenley Albright, the 17-year-old world champion from Boston, began her bid to retain her United States crown at the Hershey Rink today in an effort to complete a sweep of three major figure-skating titles.
TUCSON, Ariz., March 25 (UP)--Frankie Baumholtz made four hits off Don Larsen and Virgil Trucks, but got little help from his team-mates as the Cubs lost to the Browns, 4 to 1, today.

Governor Dewey was asked yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri to veto legislation granting rent increases of 15 per cent above maximum rents in effect on March 1, 1943. The Mayor also asked the Governor to urge the special legislative session scheduled for May to extend the emergency housing rent control law "without any weakening changes."
SARASOTA, Fla., March 25 (AP) -- Ken Wood's long three-run homer capped an extra-inning uprising today as the Senators downed the Red Sox, 4 -- 0, in ten innings.
New issues of public utility and natural gas mortgage bonds, preferred stock and common stock with a value of more than $65,000,000 will be offered to investors today. The offerings are as follows:
LAKELAND, Fla., March 25 (AP) -- The Tigers suffered their first defeat by a National League team this spring as the Phillies shut out Detroit, 7 -- 0, in an exhibition game today at Henley Field.
LONDON, March 25 (UP) -- Queen Mary's death brought messages of condolence from all parts of the world today.
