WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Eisenhower Administration told Congress today that it was not seeking and felt it did not need a detailed law setting up stand-by price and wage controls for use in the event of a major war or emergency.

ITHACA, N. Y., March 25 -- A total of $3,340,012 in gifts, bequests and grants to Cornell University for the first six months of the fiscal year ended Dec. 31, 1952, was reported today by Willard I. Emerson, vice president for university development.
CHICAGO, March 25 (AP) -- The Harlem Globetrotters and College All-Stars will play their impending cross-country basketball series without the one-and-one free-throw rule.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- A bill cutting taxes on "economy" cigarettes, maybe leading to a price war that would bring down the prices of all brands, ran into Treasury opposition today.

FRANKFURT, Germany, March 25 (AP) -- Six anti-Communists who escaped from Communist-ruled Czechoslovakia by having seized a Czechoslovak airliner in flight said today 95 per cent of all Czechoslovaks would choose freedom if they could.
PARIS, March 25 -- Severe criticism in the French press today followed the departure of Premier Rene Mayer and three of his ministers for Washington for talks with United States Government officials.

Mayor Impellitteri began yesterday the thankless job of finding the $70,000,000 combination of service cuts and additional city revenues required to produce a balanced executive budget for 1953-1954 by the April 7 deadline fixed in a bill just signed by Governor Dewey.

More than forty members of the toy industry and educational authorities are meeting this week at the Park Sheraton Hotel to select the 250 toys to be included in the annual Yearbook of the Toy Guidance Council.

Tariff reduction, increased imports and an end of aid-financed exports should be among main points of United States foreign trade policy, according to a survey report issued yesterday by the Council on Foreign Relations.

SEATTLE, March 25 -- Members of the Columbia Basin Inter-Agency Committee, including Governors of four Pacific Northwest states, today received disquieting reports indicating that slashes in the Federal dam building program might bring this region another power shortage, in advance of previous estimates.
Only one offer has been received by the United States Government to make a swap for its abandoned Assay Building at 30-32 Wall Street, the official bid opening disclosed yesterday.

THOSE interested in throwing the javelin, tossing the saber or flighting an arrow may exhibit a vague interest in the fish-spearing season which is now open in New York on such waters as are not inhabited (officially) by trout.

Making the most of a favorable position in his adjourned game from the eighth round, Miguel Najdorf of Argentina defeatd Carlos E. Guimard, another Argentinian, in 64 moves, yesterday, and thereby overtook Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia to tie him for first place in the international chess tournament at Mar Del Plata, according to a report from Buenos Aires.

Operations of the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company in 1952 resulted in a net profit of $25,112,312, equal to $7.52 a share, it was announced yesterday. This compares with $24,441,943, or $7.62 a share a year earlier.
The experience of American business with workers' stock selling, savings and investment plans is detailed in two surveys published today by the National Industrial Conference Board.

The cashier in the cafeteria of the New York Medical College of Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals is rarely seen wearing the same pair of earrings twice. She makes the ornaments herself, and examples of her hobby, from which she receives pleasure both in the doing and the wearing, are on exhibition today with hobbies of doctors, students, nurses and other college personnel.

CHICAGO, March 25 -- Alfred P. Sloan Jr. was confronted today with a letter he wrote twenty-seven years ago describing himself as "a member of the du Pont family," at the du Pont anti-trust trial in Federal District Court here.

PARIS, March 25 -- The possibility that a new and serious crisis is shaping up in the Middle East has begun to worry Allied diplomatic authorities just as they had begun to feel somewhat more optimistic about the improving prospects of the European Army, the keystone to continental defense.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 25 (UP) -- Pensava, a "hard luck" horse owned by Joseph Gavegnano, finally reached the winner's circle today by running away from a field of nine in the featured North Miami Purse at Gulfstream Park.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, March 26 (AP) -- The Fifth Air Force took over the counter-attack on the Chinese Communists on "Old Baldy" on the western front during the night as units of the United States Seventh Infantry Division pulled out of the way.

Coffee prices eased for the second consecutive day yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange bringing the December and next March positions below the former ceiling levels. Spot March options closed 3.12 cents above the former limits.

Despite intensified competition, United States exporters continue to hold their own in a Latin-American market now ranking as the second fastest-growing import area according to Latin - American Business Highlights, quarterly published yesterday by the Chase National Bank of New York.

TOMORROW, 4 P. M.: Stories by Hans Christian Andersen will be told at The New York Public Library's Tremont Branch, 1866 Washington Avenue, the Bronx. Children 8 to 12 years old are invited to hear them. The stories will be told in connection with the birthday anniversary next Thursday of the famous author.
ALBANY, March 25 -- The State Tax Commission reported today that only 500,000 of the expected 4,500,000 state income tax returns for 1952 had been filed. The deadline is April 15.
The Board of Estimate is scheduled to approve at its regular meeting today the extension through April 30 of the interim fares now charged by private bus companies operating within the city limits.

Donald Wolin is bout to acquire an untitled contemporary comedy by James D. Proctor for production next fall. Contracts are being drawn up and, barring a last-minute hitch, will be signed in a few days. Celeste Holm is being sought for the leading feminine role.

CAIRO, March 25 -- The British Embassy formally announced tonight Britain's acceptance of the appointment of two Sudanese to the remaining vacancies on the Sudan Governor General's Commission including the well-known pro-Egyptian Sudanese politician, Dardiry Mohammed. Osman, whose candidacy has been a subject of controversy between Cairo and London.

The five-story dwelling on lot 25 by 100 feet at 45 East Sixty-eighth Street has been sold by Michel Porges to Richard Kollmars for occupancy in a deal negotiated by Douglas L. Elliman Co. It contains an elevator and originally was the home of William H. Porter, banker.

WASHINGTON, March 25--Senate antagonists of Charles E. Bohlen's nomination to be Ambassador to the Soviet Union fought a rear-guard action today against his confirmation and the Administration leadership put the vote over until Friday.

TOKYO, Thursday, March 26 -- United Nations troops using tear gas and rifle fire suppressed three demonstrations by Communist war prisoners in internment stockades on the islands off the South Korean coast Monday and Tuesday, the high command here announced today. Three captives were wounded, one seriously, and many were overcome by the "non-toxic irritants," the announcement added.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 25--A slight, gray-haired physician from Urbana, Ill., has been sitting through the long hours of United Nations debate this week, waiting for Soviet-bloc delegates to drop a word that might give her a clue about the fate of her two brothers.
DETROIT, March 25 -- The rest of the automobile industry today showed no inclination to follow the Chrysler Corporation in reducing prices on passenger cars and some trucks.
ST. LOUIS, March 25--Penicillin is much less effective than when it was introduced ten years ago, the American Academy of General Practice's annual meeting was told here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 25 -- The United States failed today to give any firm promise of assistance for the financially threatened United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund despite a dozen appeals from small powers that the popular welfare agency be saved from a shut-down.

That newspapers stand an excellent chance of profiting by the revolution in retailing now taking place was the theme of a presentation yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the New York Chapter of the American Association of Newspaper Representatives in the Lexington Hotel.

Engineering and construction of a $19,000,000 nitrogen plant to be built by the Grace Chemical Company near Memphis, Tenn., will be directed by the Foster Wheeler Corporation, it was announced yesterday by William P. Gage, president of Grace Chemical, which is a wholly owned subsidiary of W. R. Grace Co.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- There is a "strong possibiity" that acreage allotments will be proclaimed for the 1954 wheat and cotton crops, Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson declared today at a hearing of the Senate Agriculture and Forestry Committee.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 25 -- Collier Young and Ida Lupino, active in independent production under the corporate name of Filmakers, announced today their expansion into the distribution field with the formation of Filmakers Releasing Organization.

ALBANY, March 25 -- Governor Dewey approved today the first of a group of bills designed to permit about 100,000 public employes in the state to obtain Federal Social Security coverage if they so desired. The measure empowers the Governor to designate a state agency to enter into agreements on behalf of the state with the Federal Security Administrator, who must approve the plan.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- President Eisenhower sent to Congress today a plan for reorganization of the Agriculture Department, based primarily on a concept of vesting in the Secretary of Agriculture responsibilities now assigned to many of his subordinates.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., March 25 -- A New York City realty and building syndicate headed by Jay Bonomo of 332 East 149th Street, the Bronx, has signed a contracts for the purchase of a 250-acre Dutchess County tract as the site for a $2,000,000 shopping center and a 500-dwelling residential development.

DETROIT, March 25 (UP) -- Two druggists were indicted today on charges of illegally shipping drugs to Iron Curtain countries and Federal authorities said it apparently was part of a Communist drive to obtain scarce drugs.

GUATEMALA, March 25 -- The Guatemalan Congress approved last evening a recommendation to President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman requesting immediate cancellation of the award in 1945 of the Order of the Quetzal to Spruille Braden, then a United States Assistant Secretary of State.

The Florida Supreme Court, in a far-reaching decision, yesterday voided the City of Miami's contract to sell $27,100,000 sewer and sewage disposal bonds to a syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation.
Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 3 to 21 points on the active months yesterday.

The problem of Indo-China is being laid squarely on Washington's doorstep today by Premier Rene Mayer of France, Jean Letourneau, Minister for the Associated States of Indo-China, and other members of a delegation from Paris.

After Actors Equity Association had disposed of the charges on Tuesday against Jenny Hecht, 9-year-old actress-daughter of Ben Hecht, author-playwright, resulting in the child's withdrawal from the cast of "Mid-Summer," Mr. Hecht yesterday voiced his indignation as an outraged parent over the tactics employed by the union in handling the controversy.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 26 -- There is extreme danger in a "narrow interpretation of the slogan 'trade, not aid,'" W. A. L. Sibley, president of the American Cotton Manufacturers Institute, warned here today. Proponents of the slogan who have recently started a campaign for the elimination of what remains of United States tariff protection, he said, are losing sight of the damage that can be done to American industry and agriculture.

NEWARK, March 26 -- More than 7,200 plant and accounting employes of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company went on strike at noon today as officials of the company and the independent Telephone Workers Union remained deadlocked on major issues in their protracted dispute.
TOKYO, Friday, March 27 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,566, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Friday, Korean time:

Young women headed by Miss Sarah Helen Shrady, chairman, and Miss Mary Elizabeth Brooks, vice chairman, are serving on the debutante committee for a card party benefit for the Youth Consultation Service, to be held April 8 in the ballroom of the Colony Club under the auspices of the Service Club of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church. Among those serving are Miss Martha Lattner and Miss Cynthia Robinson.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The only conclusion to be drawn from the President's comment today on the proposed Bricker amendment to the Constitution is that the Chief Executive opposes it and that Secretary of State Dulles, though he conceded in April, 1952, that "the treaty-making power * * * can override the Constitution," including the Bill of Rights, is largely responsible for the Presidential attitude.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on March 21 were 701,142 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 1,034 cars, or 0.1 per cent, more, than for the preceding week; 18,867 cars, or 2.6 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 47,736 cars or 6.4 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (UP) -- A former director of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, Harvey J. Gunderson, testified at the perjury trial today of E. Merl Young that the one-time R. F. C. examiner never had anything to do with loan applications made by the Lustron Corporation.
A small group of insurgents employed as waterfront watchmen threatened yesterday to take legal action in an effort to unseat officers of the Port Watchmen's Union in the Port of New York.

West Penn Electric Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $12,847,797 for 1952, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges. This was equal to $3.24 a share on the utility's outstanding common stock, and compared with a net of $10,442,821, or $2.96, in 1951.

Stock market prices wilted under a blast of selling at the start of the last hour yesterday. For eleven minutes the tape ran behind the floor, at one time by as much as two minutes. Then, with thirty minutes to go, a rally set in and reduced losses.

BONN, Germany, March 26 -- The West German Government assumed today the risks and rewards of investigating and punishing the Nazis, headed by Dr. Werner Naumann, who plotted the overthrow of democracy in this country.

Trading was very light on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday and prices closed lower in generally dull markets. Cocoa was the only item to close higher. Potatoes, soybean oil and wool were mixed. Cottonseed oil, coffee, sugar, zinc, tin, lead, rubber and hides ended lower.

ON THE WESTERN FRONT, Korea, March 26 -- The job of cutting down the Chinese Reds on this front was passed by the Army to the Air Force this morning. The ground troops, who had been taking it on the chin the past few days, drew back to let the Allied fighting planes have an open target.

CHICAGO, March. 26 (AP) -- John Fitzpatrick, Hollywood, Calif., upset the favored Ezequiel Navarra, Argentine champion from Buenos Aires, tonight in the opening match of the world three-cushion billiard tournament.

One hundred and fifty thousand men's clothing workers, members of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, C. I. O., will receive hourly wage increases of 12 1/2 cents as the result of an agreement reached yesterday.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., March 26 (AP) -- Oaklawn Park paid off the first consolation daily double in its history today when a freak set of circumstances eliminated H. E. Riley's Battle Scarred, the probable favorite, from the second race.

Executives of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation earning over $500 weekly have accepted 50 per cent salary cuts this year under a voluntary salary reduction plan, Spyros P. Skouras, president, told shareholders in the annual report issued yesterday.

The taxpayer with eight stores at 122-29 Westchester Square, blockfront between Ferris Place and East Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, which was recently bought by the Westchester Square Realty Company from the Estate of Henrietta Aron, has been resold to an investing client of Emanuel Goldberg, lawyer.

Two men, one with a pistol, held up and took a $7,874 payroll from two men on the southbound platform of the B. M. T. subway station at Broadway and Twenty-third Street yesterday at 9:30 A. M., the police reported.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics said today that the Consumers' Price Index had declined 0.4 per cent between mid-January and mid-February. It was the largest drop in a year, and the third consecutive month in which a decline was reported.

Mrs. William K. Beard Jr., 47-year-old wife of the president of Associated Business Publications, Inc., New York, a trade organization, was killed instantly Wednesday in an automobile accident in Elkton, Md., according to word received here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Representative Leslie C. Arends, Republican of Illinois, said today it was unlikely that Congress would change the basic system of promotion now prevailing for officers in the armed forces. He is the Majority Whip of the House.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., chairman of the board of governors of the State of Israel Bond Organization, emphasized last night the need for Israel to maintain an "open door policy" to absorb immigrants who may escape "from continued oppression in Europe."

MONTREAL, March 26 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens battled from behind with a three-goal burst in the second period to defeat the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 to 3, tonight and gain a two-game lead in their National Hockey League semi-final playoff series.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- The Deputy Secretary of Defense, Roger M. Kyes, appeared today to be the first of four new top defense officials to complete the sale of privately held stock in line with promises to put their business affairs in a "glass goldfish bowl."

Manufacturers and retailers complained about declining mark-ups in the house dress field and called on one another for help during a panel discussion held last night by the House Dress Institute at the Hotel Astor.

The Variety Club Foundation to Combat Epilepsy has set up an amusement industry fund-raising committee, William J. German, chairman of the foundation, announced yesterday at a luncheon of the group in the Piccadilly Hotel.

Two police officers who were transferred from the Eighteenth Division in Brooklyn on Feb. 9 after complaints had been made of failure to arrest gamblers in that area, have applied for retirement, according to information yesterday from Police Headquarters.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 26 -- For the first time in a dozen years, the Dodgers visited their old training ground here and really made quite an occasion of it. They played eleven innings with the Phils before beating them, 8 -- 7, for the third time in as many spring meetings.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 26 -- In terms closely resembling arguments in behalf of the free enterprise system, the official Communist newspaper Borba paid formal recognition today to the thesis that economic progress depends on the free operation of economic laws and the independence of business enterprises.

The desire to see "my first baseball match" and first American drug store and visit with "my old friend President Eisenhower," brought Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery to New York yesterday, a passenger with Andrei Y. Vishinsky, head of the Soviet delegation at the United Nations, aboard the Cunarder Queen Mary.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 26 -- Jimmy McLane and Wayne Moore put across a one-two slam in the 1,500-meter free-style and Martin Smith grabbed sixth place in the distance test tonight to send Yale off to a 13-point head start on Ohio State's defenders in the thirtieth annual National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming championships.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 26 -- Jan Strauss, leader of the opposition United party, has followed Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan in rejecting the right of Negroes to equal facilities, as laid down Monday in a decision of the Supreme Court of Appeals.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 26 -- Miss Dorothy Lynch, secretary to a Princeton physician, tried to help the state-wide drive of the New Jersey Conference of the Methodist Church by asking eighteen pharmaceutical companies to contribute free samples for India.

HANOI, Vietnam, March 26 -- More than 10,000 war prisoners, including 2,900 Vietminh regular soldiers, 1,200 "dangerous persons" and the rest suspects of various kinds, are now being held by French military authorities at three camps in the Hanoi area.

ALBANY, March 26 -- Governor Dewey signed today a bill that will gradually increase the state's 10 per cent tax on pari-mutuel betting to 15 per cent and ultimately provide the state with additional revenue estimated at $17,800,000 a year.

Two short pieces of Italian origin were the novelties on last night's New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra program at Carnegie Hall when Guido Cantelli started his final week of the season as guest conductor. There also were two large works -- Mozart's D minor Concerto (K. 466) with Rudolf Serkin as the piano soloist and the Mussorgsky-Ravel "Pictures at an Exhibition" with Mr. Cantelli and the orchestra providing all the virtuosity.
ALBANY, March 26 -- Following is the text of the memorandum issued today by Governor Dewey when he signed ten bills embodying his fiscal program for the City of New York:

HERSHEY, Pa., March 26 -- The first title to be decided in the current United States figure skating championships at the Hershey Rink went to a 14-year-old California girl, Janice Marie Crappa of Pasadena.

LONDON, March 26 (AP) -- The Tirana radio said today the leader of an Albanian spy ring had confessed that Greek authorities had paid him "from President Truman's hundred million dollar fund for financing subversive activities in the people's democracies."

MOSCOW, March 26 -- Western diplomats in Moscow noted with interest today an unofficial proposal for a new basis of settlement of the German question, through extension of a treaty system of mutual guarantees, that was advanced by a Frenchman at a "peace committee" session in the Kremlin.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- President Eisenhower declared today that Charles E. Bohlen was the best qualified man to be Ambassador to the Soviet Union and expressed sadness at the attacks being made on Mr. Bohlen's nomination from within the President's own party.

Art of today and yesterday is featured in three current exhibitions. That at the Nicholson Gallery, entitled "French Impressionists and Their Nineteenth Century Forerunners," covers almost one hundred years of painting, and, at both the Argent Gallery and the Kaufmann Gallery of the Y. M. H. A., work by contemporaries is being shown.

MADISON, Wis., March 26 (AP) -- Two Democratic Assemblymen proposed today that the Wisconsin Legislature investigate loans made to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, by his home town bank.

Competition for the Reisinger Trophy, symbol of team-of-four supremacy in the annual Eastern States Contract Bridge Championships, last night had narrowed down to eight teams out of a starting field of thirty-nine.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The United States agreed in principle today to increase its contribution toward the French effort against the Communist guerrillas in Indo-China but insisted that France in return should produce a program for winding up hostilities in a victory for the Associated States.

A 43-year-old mother and her two daughters were found dead yesterday in the gas-filled kitchen of their home at 84-45 247th Street, in the Bellerose Manor section of Queens. Five jets on the kitchen stove had been opened and a note from the woman, Mrs. Margaret Hoell, to her husband, Walter, said she was "sorry," the police reported.

Whether or not Frank Stanton of the Columbia Broadcasting System has changed his mind about introducing what is called a "non-compatible" system of projecting television images in color is not clear to us from reports of the testimony that he gave before the House Commerce Committee.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 26 -- Following is the text of a message received by the United Nations today from Burma's Foreign Minister:

Supreme Court Justice Matthew M. Levy ruled yesterday that the section of the Public Housing Law that permits rent increases under certain circumstances was constitutional and that it was applicable to limited-dividend housing developments such as Knickerbocker Village, Brooklyn Gardens and similar projects.

In the event of total mobilization the Federal Government will function over Industry and the military establishment as "the greatest board of directors the world has even seen," Col. Champlin F. Buck told 400 military and business leaders at the Astor Hotel yesterday.

The electronic computer -- the massive device whose cost runs to six or seven figures and which tosses such figures around in a maze of blinking lights -- is about to be manufactured on a mass-production basis.
City Counsel President Rudolph Halley charged last night that Mayor Impellitteri shared with Governor Dewey the responsibility for the proposed transit authority and the fare increase it will bring.

One hundred and fifty representatives of member houses of the Investment Bankers Association are booked to attend the opening session of the new Institute of Investment Banking, Ewing T. Boles, I. B. A. president, said yesterday. The first session will be held from March 30 to April 3 at the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce, University of Pennsylvania.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 26 -- Burma submitted a complaint to the United Nations General Assembly today accusing the Chinese Nationalist Government of having committed aggression by refusing to require 12,000 Nationalist troops on Burmese territory "to submit to disarmament and internment in accordance with international law."

The nation's automobile makers received nearly 1,300,000 tons of steel in January -- the highest monthly total since October, 1950, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The January figure represented 18.4 per cent of total steel shipments in that month, compared with a monthly average of 16.2 per cent for all of last year.
The Military Sea Transportation Service, the ocean hauling agency of the armed forces, came under fire yesterday from private shipping interests and Congressional leaders.

Plans for renovating the five-story building at 66 West Fifty-fifth Street were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the property by the Maed Realty Corporation to J. Charles Haidinger and Darrell Landrum for occupancy by their furniture business known as Avard.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. Doyle O. Hickey, chief of staff of the Far East Command, will retire July 31 after more than thirty-five years of service, the Army said today.

YONKERS, March 26 -- Mrs. Walter A. Hirsch has retired from the presidency of the Neustadter Home for Convalescents here, after having held the post continuously since 1937, when the institution became affiliated with Mount Sinai Hospital in Mew York City as its convalescent center.

PARIS, March 26 -- Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin, commander of the Allied land forces in the central European sector, told the Defense Committee of the French National Assembly today that the means of defending a line on the Elbe River were still very inadequate.
The Staten Island Rapid Transit Company announced yesterday that it would discontinue passenger service on its north and east shore branches at midnight Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Seven top positions of the Federal Security Agency have been removed from Civil Service classification at the request of the administrator, Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby.

CLEVELAND, March 26 -- The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad was the recipient of the Federation for Railway Progress Award for "outstanding achievement in progressive passenger service" at the Federation's sixth annual dinner tonight.

By a curious coincidence with which New York is not unfamiliar hundreds of members of the Transport Workers Union failed to report back on time from their lunch hour yesterday in a "spontaneous" demonstration that broke out simultaneously at a half-dozen maintenance shops and one powerhouse of the city-owned transit system.

The Red Cross reported yesterday that 1,246 pints of blood were contributed in this area Wednesday for the armed services. Leading the donors were the New York Central Pullman Company with 534 pints; the Naval Supply Corps School, Bayonne, N. J., with 235, and residents of New Rochelle, N. Y., 242.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- A list furnished the Office of Education today by the Army, Navy, and Air Force showed that twenty segregated schools on defense installations, all of them Federally aided, were a part of the school systems of the states in which they were located.

A 50-year-old unemployed research writer who apparently had contemplated suicide for eight years, was found dead in his East Side apartment last night with a near-empty bottle of barbiturates close by.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands thanked the people of the United States tonight for about $2,000,000 in private aid following last winter's disastrous floods in his country, as well as for hundreds of tons of donated clothing, and asked for two further forms of assistance.

TOKYO, Friday, March 27 -- The Chinese Communists launched new attacks today on the western Korean front and in savage fighting overran two United Nations' outpost positions on the Imjin Valley approaches to the South Korean capital of Seoul.

As is far too generally known, the month of March has been something more than a damp one. It has been, to speak bluntly, plain wet. The rainfall has been measured not only in inches, which is proper and customary, but also in what at times seemed to be fathoms covering the lowest part of the flooded cellar.

When Chester Bowles returns home from India he deserves not only our thanks for a job remarkably well done: he deserves our respectful attention to whatever he may have to say about America's role in Asia.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 26 -- The United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., served a deferred-action ultimatum today on the General Motors Corporation and other auto manufacturers.

Rossini's "La Cenerentola" was revived last night by the New York City Opera Company with brilliant success. And it was high time. This opera is second only in inspiration to "The Barber of Seville," which it followed by one year, in 1817, and to which it has certain affinities.

ITHACA, N. Y., March 26 -- Cornell College of Engineering has named Miss Janice Button of Needham, Mass., editor-in-chief of The Cornell Engineer, a periodical for students and alumni of the college. Miss Button is an engineering physics student.

LOS ANGELES, March 26 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities laid the foundation today for possible contempt proceedings against Simon M. Lazarus, principal backer of the controversial left-wing labor film "Salt of the Earth."

Ground was broken yesterday at 196th Street and Broadway for the new two-story laboratory and research building that is the first unit to be constructed under Jewish Memorial Hospital's $3,000,000 expansion program.

BOSTON, March 26 -- Four Massachusetts educators, including a 74-year-old retired woman high school teacher, refused to tell the Senate Internal Security subcommittee today whether they had been active in the Communist movement.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- President Eisenhower asserted today that the supply of ammunition of the United Nations forces in Korea was perfectly sound for the present scale of operations.

Indian jute producers are ready to put strong emphasis on merchandising their product in the United States in an effort to counter inroads of competitive substitutes, according to a report made here yesterday on recent industry conferences in Calcutta.
A Harlem block where painting and minor repairs in the five-story brick and brownstone buildings will make the difference between near slums and adequate housing has been selected for rehabilitation.

Delegates to a general meeting of the International Boxing Managers Guild of America, assembled here from California and Illinois as well as New England and other Eastern sections, demanded yesterday that a minimum of $5,000 be paid to each principal of a main bout televised over coaxial cable, starting June 15.
PHILADELPHIA, March 26 (UP) -- A judge today dismissed gambling charges against nine women whose canasta game was raided by the police on the complaint of a hungry husband.

Joseph H. McConnell, general chairman of the Salvation Army's fund campaign, announced yesterday that contributions of $875,491 had been received thus far from corporations and individuals in the annual appeal for operating funds.

Heavy fighting has again broken out in Korea and the roar of battle rises above the political din of the "cold war" to remind the world that a "hot" war is still going on in that country and that men are dying in a struggle for freedom for which no end is yet in sight.

CHICAGO, March 26 -- Drama critics of Chicago newspapers were notified today by a representative of J. J. Shubert, theatre owner and impresario, that they would not be invited to attend opening night performances of Shubert-booked productions here in the future.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 26 -- Howard (Howie) Davis, 18-year-old star halfback of the White Plains High School football team, whose spine snapped when he slipped on a muddy field while tackling an opponent in a game here last Nov. 15, was released today from White Plains Hospital.

CAIRO, March 26 -- The two Sudanese issues that automatically rub Egypt the wrong way, the possibility of an independent Sudan's joining the British Commonwealth and the continued existence of "closed districts" in southern and western Sudan, nearly shattered the British-Egyptian political truce today and endangered the newly established harmony in the implementation of the Feb. 12 agreement providing for Sudanese self-government by an elected Parliament.

TOPEKA, Kan., March 26 -- Indications mounted today that a joint investigating committee of the Kansas Legislature had agreed on a report that, in some ways, was critical of the activities of C. Wesley Roberts, Republican National Chairman, during the 1951 state legislative session.

Sales finance companies led the borrowers whose repayments last week cut business loans from New York banks by $69,000,000 -- the first decline in five weeks. During the week ended on Wednesday the reduction brought the decline in borrowings since the start of this year to $62,000,000, against an increase of $74,000,000 in the similar period a year ago.

Despite heroic efforts by a dock construction worker and two Fire Department officers, two men died and another was hospitalized yesterday in a flash fire, apparently resulting from gasoline fumes, under Pier 57, North River, at Fifteenth Street.

A report issued yesterday by Rev. Michael F. Dwyer, director of the child care department of New York Catholic Charities, showed that forty institutions and agencies supervised by the parent organization cared for 18,424 dependent, handicapped and delinquent children last year.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 26 -- The State Parks and Reservations Committee of the Connecticut General Assembly voted an unfavorable report today on a bill authorizing the state to lease land at Sherwood Island State Park in Westport for use as a site for the proposed American Shakespeare Festival Theatre and Academy.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Senator Paul M. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, warned of "danger signals ahead even in advance of any armed attack" as he questioned today the Eisenhower Administration's failure to endorse a stand-by price and wage control program.

CAIRO, March 26 -- Aly Shamsy, chairman of the board of the National Bank of Egypt, took a long critical look at Egypt's sagging economy in his annual report published today and concluded that land reclamation was the only cure for the country's basic ills.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 26 -- Ceremonial swords handed to Allied leaders by senior Japanese officers in token of their surrender in 1945 and other exhibits relating to Japanese war crimes have been withdrawn from display in the National War Memorial Building at Canberra.

It is to be hoped that no one at the Oratorio Society's Town Hall concert last evening who felt ready to fall out of his chair from ennui and heaviness of spirit believed that the performance was on so lofty a plane of excellence as to be above the heads of all but the most discerning.

The city's present financial plight was attributed last night by Mayor Impellitteri to Governor Dewey's action in "personally" jamming through "a ruthless Republican Legislature" a fiscal program forcing unjust and unnecessary sacrifices upon the municipality.

The current issue of Science, official weekly publication of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the nation's senior scientific organization, carries a notice that two editors of the association have resigned for "administrative" reasons.

Duties more directly devoted to the care of patients was urged for professional and practical nurses yesterday at the opening session of a two-day conference on the curriculum given by the New York State League for Nursing and the state Department of Education in the New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street.
Nine special awards, in addition to 135 varsity letters, were presented to Columbia athletes last night at the annual dinner of the Varsity "C" Club in John Jay Hall on the Morningside campus.

Michael J. Quill issued another strike threat yesterday, this time warning he would shut down the entire public and private transit system if a single member of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., lost his job as the result of service curtailment and economies.

NUTLEY, N. J., March 26 -- Selections of Mrs. S. Rush Mountsier Jr. of 205 Rutgers Place, Nutley, as New Jersey Mother of 1953 was announced today by the New Jersey branch of the Golden Rule Foundation. Mrs. Mountsier is the mother of five sons and two daughters.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Two authors who admitted they formerly had been so sympathetic to communism that they reflected that ideology in their writings expressed surprise today that some of their earlier books had been found in public libraries set up throughout the free world in the effort to counteract Soviet propaganda.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 26 -- Kevin Snider, age 3 1/2, knows all the answers. Almost, anyway. His adoring father, Duke Snider, is continually amazed at the scope of his offspring's baseball knowledge. They once were driving along Route 1 when little Kevin pointed a stubby finger at the number on a signpost.

TEN years ago thousands of young Americans in hundreds of ships were learning a little about the far Pacific, something about their shipmates and a lot about life in the Navy. Some were officers and some were gobs. Several wrote novels about the Navy's war, which already are forgotten, and Herman Wouk wrote "The Caine Mutiny," the most popular American novel about the last war yet written and one of the best.

Having just brought to an end the last vestige of direct federal controls over prices, President Eisenhower has been notably unenthusiastic about Congressional suggestions for continuing his authority to impose controls after expiration of the present law. However, he has now stated through an Administration spokesman that if Congress wishes to give him the right to place a freeze on wages and prices in case of emergency, such a measure "would be acceptable."

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 26 -- The Netherlands and Indonesian Governments started negotiations here today for the liquidation of the Dutch military mission which has been instructing the Indonesian Amy during the past three years.

An engineer shoved a crowbar through a window of an old-law tenement yesterday, and the Port of New York Authority began demolition of the first ninety structures in the Manhattan approach area to the $90,000,000 third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel.
WATERTOWN, N. Y., March 26 -- The Black River in Lewis and Jefferson Counties went on a spring rampage today, flooding 15,000 acres of farmlands and cutting highway connections over a wide area.

There is no reason for believing that a transit authority will solve New York City's transit problem. That problem is not an isolated one but is related to all other city problems -- most of all, particularly, to my mind, to the problem of housing.
ALBANY, March 26 (AP) -- The state will get an extra $8,000,000 from horse players this year.

Students of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism are presenting their own half-hour news program on television (9 P. M. Mondays over WPIX), and they have the makings of a first-rate program. All they need is a production budget, and they might even garner a sponsor.

TAIPEI, Formosa, March 26 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark strongly hinted today that a coordinated defense against communism was shaping up in the Far East when he said at a press conference that affairs "should be and are being" coordinated.

CHICAGO, March 26 -- A story of how a big oil deal was prevented by the assassination of a Mexican President, and an eyewitness account of the late William C. Durant, first chief of General Motors Corporation, sending telegrams in wholesale lots prior to a big corner in General Motors stock, went into the record of the du Pont anti-trust trial today.

Today's single new film, a Swedish importation, "Each Heart Has Its Own Story," starring the portly singer, Edvard Persson, arrives at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse. Inger Juel, Hilda Borgstrom and Dagmar Ebbesen head the supporting cast.
PHILADELPHIA, March 26 (AP) -- The University of Pennsylvania will work out its controversial football future within the framework of the Ivy League.

Internal evidence of the unsoundness of your assertion in your editorial "Where Television Doesn't Fit" that "We know newspaper men * * *. They are hardworking, self-effacing and modest to a fault" is to be found in the somewhat startling pronouncement itself.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- During the week ended March 25, member bank reserves decreased $717,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The programs and policies of many child care organizations, adoption agencies and hospitals would be changed in many ways if what is now known to be good for children's emotional development were put fully into practice, Dr. John Bowlby declared yesterday.
The most effective weapon against the nation's highway death toll is compulsory driver training for all high school students, Robert Young, the actor, told 900 night.

Taking money out of the bank will become even easier because of television. The New York Savings Bank yesterday demonstrated a new system designed to speed its operations, described as the nation's first regular use of television in the banking field.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 26 -- The seventy-six-year-old Tap Day ceremonies at Yale University, in which six senior honor societies publicly selected ninety juniors, has been discontinued as a humiliating experience to the students rejected.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 26 -- Allied experts at Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers in Europe, have completed a master logistics plan designed to coordinate in a far-reaching, orderly way the military supply systems of the fourteen North Atlantic Treaty Organization members.

CHICAGO, March 26 -- Montgomery Ward Co. reported today that its net income declined to $49,593,351, equal to $7.41 a common share, in the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31 from $54,342,330, or $8.14 a share, in the preceding twelve months.

The mounting rates for Workmen's Compensation Insurance, which reflect the high cost of waterfront accidents, constitute a serious threat to the maritime industry in this port, stevedoring and shipping executives declared yesterday.

A total of $1,262,525 in contributions was received last year by the Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, it was announced yesterday by Walter P. Marshall, president of the Western Union Telegraph Company, who is chairman of the association's $2,500,000 development fund drive.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was barely steady yesterday and closing prices on active months were down 2 to 7 points net.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- Talks on renewing the International Wheat Agreement were suspended for the week-end today amid reports that a break is nearing in the deadlock over prices.

GENEVA, March 26 -- Europeans who are vitally, indeed almost desperately, interested in a more liberal United States policy toward imports have a good deal of sympathy nevertheless for Washington's effort to invoke the aid of import embargoes in its latest struggle with the flood of high priced farm products.

BONN, Germany, March 26 -- Erich Ollenhauer, leader of the Social Democratic opposition, announced tonight that his party had applied to the Federal Constitutional Court for an injunction that would prevent Chancellor Konrad Adenauer from submitting the European Defense Community treaty and the Bonn Convention to President Theodor Heuss for signature pending a decision of the court on constitutionality of the treaties.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The State Department gave to a House of Representatives Judiciary subcommittee today a frank report of the way in which it had dealt with twenty-five cases of Americans employed by the United Nations about whom derogatory loyalty reports had been received.
BOWIE, Md., March 26 (AP) -- Torrential rains stopped early today, and the weatherman promised clearing and warmer conditions for the opening tomorrow of Bowie race track's thirty-ninth season.

Spring fashions were presented yesterday by Milgrim's at the Plaza Hotel. In addition to Sally Milgrim's made-to-order collection, there were many ensembles for all occasions from the immediate wear department on the second floor.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 26 (UP) -- The E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., listed publicly for the first time today the stockholdings of its twenty-nine directors in du Pont and three other companies, and the remuneration they received from du Pont, General Motors Corporation and a Canadian company last year.

HOUSTON, March 26 (AP) -- The defender, Vic Hershkowitz of Brooklyn, defeated Harold Schrutt, Buffalo, 21 -- 13, 21 -- 8, tonight to gain the semi-finals of the national handball singles championship.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- A labor leader's remark that the Taft-Hartley Law was "conceived almost in shame," angered a member of Congress today and led to cancellation of an afternoon hearing by the House of Representatives Education and Labor Committee.

Moscow has announced the signing of a new trade protocol with Communist China. Its exact details and its precise implications have not, of course, been revealed and probably never will be. Moscow says merely that the Soviet Union will provide certain categories of machinery and technical assistance for Communist China and the Chinese in turn will supply a substantial group of raw materials to the Soviet Union.

A book about the American woman and another about the Japanese woman have been scheduled for publication by two concerns. On May 11 Bobbs-Merrill will issue "Women Today: Their Conflicts, Their Frustrations and Their Fulfillments," edited by Elizabeth Bragdon, the publisher's director of publicity.
Westinghouse Electric Corporation placed on the market yesterday the first completely automatic elevator system designed for use in commercial and other buildings with heavy daily human traffic.
Toledo, Ohio, announced yesterday that it will receive bids April 15 on 3,400,000 of water revenue bonds dated March 1, 1953, and due June 1 and Dec. 1, 1954 to 1973.

A motion-picture house since "Life With Father" moved out on June 14, 1947, the cozy Bijou, 209 West Forty-fifth Street, will revert to the so-called "legitimate." The happy event will take place on April 20 when Emlyn Williams begins a three-week engagement through May 9 in his own dramatization of the Charles Dickens novel, "Bleak House."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 26 -- United Nations delegations rejected today Communist demands that the General Assembly condemn the United States for "aggression" against the countries of the Soviet bloc.

On the eve of tonight's bout at Madison Square Garden between Paddy Young and Ernie (The Rock) Durando, Manager Sid Flaherty yesterday cabled Chairman Robert K. Christenberry of the New York State Athletic Commission from Manila that Carl (Bobo) Olson was "interested in meeting the winner."

With reference to the existing dictatorship in Cuba: in your information about "Students Protest Batista Coup," on March 11, you state that the situation can be boiled down to three points: Batista has set back the political clock of Cuba; economically hard times are ahead, and, finally, "present signs point to a stable, orderly Government for the next two years."

United Paramount Theatres, Inc., earned a consolidated net profit of $6,961,113 last year, including $5,613,626 from operations and $1,347,487 from capital gains, it was reported yesterday by Leonard H. Goldenson, president of American Broadcasting-Paramount Theatres, Inc.

Beginning today the Metropolitan Museum will have on display a special exhibit of art treasures from Japan. This is an extraordinary collection, possibly unique, and will give us an opportunity to re-establish some of the sensitive communication in the field of the fine arts that has attracted us to the Japanese.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Optimistic reports on the proximity of satisfactory color television were challenged today by Dr. Allen B. DuMont, television broadcaster and manufacturer. He told a House of Representatives committee that it would be from five to ten years before workable standards were set and production of receiving sets started.

Jewish home cooks in shopping for Passover, which begins Monday night, will find that for the first time in fifteen or twenty years fresh-water fish are "really cheap." John Von Glahn of the Fishery Council reported yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 26 -- A $5,300,000 welfare program to help needy youngsters in thirty countries was adopted today by the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund.

Indicative of the variety of pattern and fabric to be found in decorative materials today is a group of designs that went on view yesterday at a special showroom of F. Schumacher Co., 535 Madison Avenue, near Fifty-fourth Street. Available through decorators, the collection will be exhibited during the annual conference of the American Institute of Decorators, which opens tomorrow at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 26 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, who made a tearful departure from the General Assembly after Stalin's death three weeks ago, returned this afternoon on the liner Queen Mary to take up his new duties as permanent Soviet representative to the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The Senate Committee on Interior and Insular Affairs reported a bill late today giving the states full title to and developmental rights in submerged lands, some rich with oil, within the offshore boundaries to which they lay claim.
LONDON, March 26 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill said today that as far as he knew, United Nations troops in Korea-bad all the ammunition they needed.

BOSTON, March 26 -- This is a story of a missing player, a pair of forgotten sneakers and an astonishingly one-sided contest. Involved in all three situations tonight were the New York Knickerbockers as they tangled in the second game of their play-off series with the Boston Celtics and finished on the short end of an 86-70 count.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Ezra Taft Benson, the Secretary of Agriculture, submitted to Congress today a revised 1954 Department of Agriculture budget in which approximately $130,000,000 was cut from the figure that had been asked in the Truman budget.

DETROIT, March 26 (UP) -- A pair of goals by Dave Creighton and superb net-minding by Jim Henry carried the Boston Bruins to a 5-3 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight to even the Stanley Cup semi-final series between the teams at one game each.

THOSE persons not tempted to participate in the openings of the Finger Lakes special rainbow trout or the New Jersey striped bass seasons, both scheduled for next Wednesday, can put in a pleasant day at the Jockey Hollow field trials at Clinton, N. J.

RALEIGH, N. C., March 26 (UP) -- The North Carolina Legislature voted today to allow its appropriations committee to hold closed sessions and to make reporters liable to $250 fines if they refused to leave such meetings. Both houses approved the measure after newsmen had told legislators they would have to be thrown out bodily if the subcommittee tried to enforce a closed session.

A simple television camera -- no larger than a hand movie camera -- that in the near future could permit a housewife to scan the nursery, kitchen, backyard and see a caller at the door, was demonstrated yesterday at the convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- President Eisenhower declared today that the Administration was working desperately to bring the nation's expenditures within manageable proportions because deficit spending was having a very bad effect on the whole economy.

AT THE KOREAN FRONT, March 26 -- A truck labored up a steep, narrow, mud-filled road. At times its wheels spun hopelessly. Then its tires would take hold again and the vehicle would resume its tortuous climb.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- New York State today renewed its objection to a proposed increase in passenger fares for the Long Island Rail Road Company.

LONDON, March 26 -- The stock markets remained quiet today with prices moving narrowly and irregularly. A late improvement in industrials enabled most miscellaneous leaders to close with small gains. Oils also strengthened.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 26 (UP) -- The Brookmeade Stable unveiled its Kentucky Derby hopeful, County Clare, for the first time this year at Gulfstream Park today and the 3-year-old colt impressed 14,173 fans by galloping to a two-length victory in the featured Dania Purse.

LONDON, March 26 -- As the British Government perfected its plan today for the funeral of Queen Mary, the question of the permanent return to Britian of the Duke of Windsor was brought up again by his supporters.

The Seder service of Passover, the eight-day Jewish religious festival that begins Monday evening, follows a traditional order. But as the ceremony is celebrated at home dining tables, many of the accompanying customs, especially as to foods, originate with each family and are passed from generation to generation.

Buddy Combs, ten-goaler, scored nine times as his Red Bank Polo Club beat the New York A. C., 14 -- 9, while Squadron A halted Ramapo, 11 -- 6, in the opener of a benefit double-header at the Squadron A Armory last night. Proceeds went to Troop 627, sponsored by Squadron A, Boy Scouts of America.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 26 -- Four of the United Nations' largest specialized agencies have run into sharp differences with the United States on the handling of the investigation into the loyalty of all United States citizens employed in international organizations.
Dishwashing, dusting and cleaning are no more the natural work of a woman than they are of a man, Mrs. Rebecca Reyher, author and lecturer, said this week.

The tie for the lead between Svetzor Gligoric of Yugoslavia and Miguel Najdorf of Argentina in the international chess masters tournament at Mar Del Plata remained unbroken yesterday as the undefeated players won in the ninth round, according to a report from Buenos Aires.

Red-faced Board of Education officials were gently taken to task by Board of Estimate members at City Hall yesterday for their "mistake'' in neglecting to tell other city agencies that two private dwellings were being erected on a Queens site proposed for erection of a new public school and playgrounds.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 26 -- A blistering sun blazed out of a cloudless sky today and in the ratified desert air the Giants strove manfully to match the Browns, homer for homer.

A survey to determine whether the school children of this city are receiving adequate health supervision is being undertaken by the Welfare and Health Council, it was announced yesterday by Raymond M. Hilliard, the council's executive secretary.

A small strip of vacant land five inches wide and seventy-eight feet deep was among fifty-seven Manhattan properties sold at auction yesterday by the city for $478,700, which was $95,350 above the upset values. It was the fourth day of the sale, which will be concluded this afternoon in the Council Chamber at City Hall with the offering of seventy-seven parcels in the Bronx and fifty-six on Staten Island.

The National Council on Freedom From Censorship, an affiliate of the American Civil Liberties Union, sent a telegram of protest yesterday to Robert Fryer, producer of "Wonderful Town," over his decision to cancel the April 8 evening performance because some tickets were purchased for the benefit of an alleged left-wing publication.

ROME, March 26 -- The Italian Government expressed regrets to the British Embassy today for acts of hooliganism that occurred in Rome yesterday when a group of young men identified by the police as neo-Fascists broke into the library of the British Council, official cultural organization, and set it afire after binding and gagging a girl secretary.

Governor Dewey was urged yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., to veto the bill (Sen. 2861), passed by the Legislature, to amend the penal law to prohibit Sunday sales, offers for sale or purchase, including the placing or accepting of orders by telephone or telegraph for any property except foods or drugs.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 26 (AP) -- Miami's Tony Vincent upset Billy Talbert of New York in the quarter-final rounf of the Everglades tennis tournament today.

CHICAGO, March 26 (AP) -- The North Central Association, heeding a plea of Oklahoma A. and M.'s president, today granted a thirty-day reprieve to the college to prove its athletic house was in order before proceeding with an academic ban.

The City Housing Authority filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings plans for La Guardia Houses, a $16,750,000 low-rent housing project to be erected on Manhattan's lower East Side.

Ignoring the need to court the public's understanding and friendship can be fatal for the insurance business, it was asserted last night by Joseph A. Neumann, a member of the executive committee of the National Association of Insurance Agents. He spoke at a dinner following an all-day meeting of the Insurance Advertising Conference in the Vanderbilt Hotel.

CHICAGO, March 26 -- The grain futures market reversed its early trend later in the session today and, helped by a brisk upward move in soybeans, made a substantial recovery. Commission buying broadened on the weak spots made in the forepart of the session, when prices were as much as 1 cent lower for wheat.

The Commissioners of Health, Hospitals and Welfare announced yesterday a coordinated drive to bring every case of tuberculosis in the city under systematic treatment, using isoniazid and other drugs in clinics and in patients' homes when hospital beds are not immediately available.

Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, United States Ambassador-designate to Italy, asked the help yesterday of her fellow members of the Overseas Press Club in interpreting to the American people American foreign policy and conditions abroad.

MUNICH, Germany, March 26 (AP) -- The United States Consulate here announced today that Charles W. Thayer, American Consul General in Munich and a brother-in-law of Charles E. Bohlen, has resigned from the Foreign Service after a new investigation into his diplomatic career had been ordered. Mr. Bohlen has been nominated as Ambassador to Russia but has not yet been confirmed.
The Alleghany Corporation reported yesterday that the net asset value of its common stock at the year-end was $1.47 a share. This contrasts with a deficit of $3.25 a share at the end of 1951.

BERLIN, March 26 -- The Evangelical Church reported today that Pastor Werner Gestrich, 41, of the East German town of Heinersdorf had been sentenced to twelve years in prison for making statements "hostile to the state."

A vaccine against polio that has been used safely and successfully in preliminary trials on ninety children and adults, producing protective immunity bodies against all the three viruses causing the disease, was announced last night at a special meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel under the auspices of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

ST. LOUIS, March 26 -- Dr. Arthur M. Master of New York told a concluding session of the American Academy of General Practice today that many people -- and their physicians -- were concerned about high blood pressure when they really had no reason to be so.

The twenty - five - family apartment house at 41-53 Hampton Street in Elmhurst, Queens, has been resold by a client of M. S. Selby, attorney, to Alexander Dubrovitch. Sydney M. Siegel Co. were the brokers. The present seller acquired the property about two weeks ago from the construction company headed by Richard Eppler.
The text of Mayor Impellitteri's broadcast last night on "Our Transit Problem," follows:

NEWARK, March 26 -- That a child's perception of his world grows keener with each year is demonstrated in a group of twenty drawings and sketches by 3 to 10-year-old members of the Junior Museum now being shown at the Newark Museum.

The Monsanto Chemical Company during 1952 invested almost $73,000,000 in additional plant and facilities, twice the amount spent in any previous year, Charles Allen Thomas, president, told stockholders at the company's annual meeting in St. Louis yesterday.

Eikichi Araki, Japanese Ambassador to the United States, was the guest of honor last night at a members' preview of the exhibition of Japanese art treasures that will be opened to the public today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at Eighty-second Street.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26 -- Not nearly so disturbing to the Yankees as today's failure by Allie Reynolds as the Bombers lost to the Cardinals, 10 -- 2, was the physical condition of Mickey Mantle. It could be serious enough to cause Mantle to miss the opening game at Washington on April 13.

BONN, Germany, March 26 -- A total and simultaneous integration of all branches of the agrarian economy of West Europe has been put forward by the Advisory Council of the West German Ministry of Economics as the only practical solution to the problem of establishing a unified agricultural market.

The New York City Federation of Women's Clubs celebrated its golden jubilee yesterday with 800 of its members, representing more than 200 affiliated groups, joining in a spring festival and luncheon at the Astor Hotel.

ALBANY, March 26 -- Low bids totaling $28,724,324 were received today by the Department of Public Works and the State Thruway Authority for six Thruway construction projects that are scheduled to get under way this spring.

ALBANY, March 26 -- Legislation terminating the state's emergency housing program for World War II veterans and providing for evacuation of all remaining tenants from the temporary projects by Sept. 30 was approved today by Governor Dewey.

The press got another glimpse of Paris yesterday when Ohrbach's selected twenty-eight of its French and Italian imports and showed them with its line-for-line copies at the store. The merchandise will be available to the public Monday.

ALBANY, March 26 -- Governor Dewey signed into law today ten bills embodying his program for solving New York City's financial crisis by setting up an authority to take over the deficit-plagued municipal transit system and authorizing a new $60,000,000 payroll tax and a $50,000,000 increase in real estate imposts.

Danny Thomas was signed yesterday by the American Broadcasting Company for a television comedy program beginning in the fall. This was regarded in the trade as a further indication that the network is moving to improve its competitive position by acquiring new talent and expanding technical facilities.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 26 -- Ronald Reagan is the owner of a story, "Battle Mountain," which he intends to offer to a major studio for filming with himself as its star. The script, written by James Warner Bellah, is based on the author's story, "The Apache," which appeared recently in a national magazine.

LONDON, March 26 -- The theory that long-dead supernovae or exploded stars leave behind radioactive "ghosts" has been propounded by Dr. William H. Ramsey of the physics department of the University of Manchester. The remains of the stars are being sought in the most distant or extra-galactic regions of the universe by astronomers using the new radio telescopes.

One of the silliest and most annoying reasons for New York City's deficits is the lack of adequate information about the city's public transportation system. Subway maps and stations do not show connecting bus lines. The Manhattan bus map is obsolete. Maps of the other boroughs appear to be nonexistent.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Army said today that it would start this summer to protect large cities and industrial centers vulnerable to enemy air attack with guided missiles capable of searching out and destroying a target thirty miles from their launching point.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 27 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, recommended today that the Eisenhower Administration begin at once to shape plans for a broad public works program against the time when defense spending would be cut off.
New York's basketball fans may take their choice or watch both the professionals and the collegians play at Madison Square Garden this afternoon and tonight.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., March 27 -- Employes of three bus lines serving 40,000 commuters in Nassau County voted tonight to end a 49-day-old strike and to submit their grievances to a board of inquiry to be named by the State Industrial Commission. Some buses will resume their runs on Monday and normal service is expected by Wednesday morning.

It was to a distinguished gathering that Grayson L. Kirk, president of Columbia University, talked yesterday. Representatives of foreign countries in the United Nations turned out to listen to his presentation of the theme that Columbia has adopted for its Bicentennial celebration in 1954 -- "Man's Right to Knowledge and the Free Use Thereof."

ALBANY, March 27 -- Three bills authorizing the conversion of six temporary state technical schools into community colleges supported in part by units of local government were approved today by Governor Dewey. He said the program would "make secure and permanent the advantages of this fine training."

HOUSTON, Tex., March 27 -- Increases in ammunition-shipping activity at the near-by San Jacinto Ordnance Depot are cutting sharply into the number of longshoremen available for handling general cargo in the Port of Houston.

Graduation exercises were held yesterday afternoon for the first class to complete the city's new ten-week training course in housework, designed to make the graduates -- all recipients of public assistance -- self-supporting.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Edward W. Barrett, who, as an Assistant Secretary of State, directed the Government's international counter-propaganda service from 1950 to 1952, testified today that the Voice of America and other programs had "important shortcomings."
The traditional devotions of Palm Sunday and Holy Week will be carried out, starting tomorrow, by Protestant, Eastern Orthodox and Roman Catholic churches.

CAIRO, March 27 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Premier of Egypt, was welcomed by cheering throngs upon his return home this evening from a six-day political tour of Upper Egypt. After receiving an ovation at the railroad station the Premier and the Army officers and Cabinet Ministers who had accompanied him, drove to the Presidency through streets lined with admirers while hundreds trotted on foot before and behind the small motor caravan.

TOKYO, Saturday, March 28 -- Reinforced Chinese Communists forced the United States Marines this morning to yield the crest of the outpost position northeast of "Bunker Hill" on the western Korean front, which the enemy overran Thursday night and the Marines had recaptured at dusk yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March. 27 (AP) -- A House Foreign Affairs subcommittee was told today that the State Department would slice about $225,000 from budget requests for contributions to forty international organizations.
Three of this week's exhibitions are devoted to nonfigurative painting, in which the data of the eye is replaced by its dreams and fancies.

ROME, March 27 (AP) -- The United States and Italian film industries announced today a new joint agreement, reducing United States financial aid to the Italian industry and increasing the American "take home pay."

VIENNA, March 27 (AP) -- Czechoslovakia has demanded that the United States hand back the airliner in which four Czechs fled their homeland. The Prague Government also called for return of the plane's twenty-nine passengers and crew.

BURLINGTON, Vt., March 27 (AP) -- Warren R. Austin, retired United States Ambassador to the United Nations, suffered a cerebral attack at his home today and is in "grave but not critical condition" at Mary Fletcher Hospital.
LONDON, March 27 (AP) -- An American oarsman who once rowed for Harvard will have an important role tomorrow in the historic boat race on the Thames River between the Oxford and Cambridge shells.

NAPLES, Italy, March 26 (AP) -- An Italian ship owner denied today a United States charge that his trading with Communist nations violated terms of a contract under which he bought two surplus American Liberty ships.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Following is the 74-to-13 vote by which the Senate today approved the nomination of Charles E. Bohlem to be Ambassador to the Soviet Union:

ITHACA, N. Y., March 27 -- Indicative of the "do-it-yourself" trend, the first two and a half days of this week's Farm and Home Bureau program at Cornell University here found 6,000 persons attracted to the exhibit of the use of foam rubber in the upholstering of chairs and the lectures on the process.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 26 -- The picture of the Dominican Republic under Generalissimo Rafael L. Trujillo Molina today is a startling contrast in good and bad. Materially it ranks with the best run, most prosperous and contented of all Latin-American countries. Politically it is a personal tyranny to a degree surely unparalleled on either side of the Iron Curtain.

In a resolution adopted yesterday by the Eastern States Association of Professional Schools for Teachers, universities and colleges were urged to reassure the public that they were competent to insure the loyalty of the teaching profession.

MOSCOW, March 27 (AP) -- Even though the Soviet Union is "pursuing a peace policy," the increase of military training among the Soviet masses is a first-rate obligation of the Communist party, the official newspaper of the Soviet Ukraine said today.

The seventh annual Antoinette Perry Awards, otherwise known in the trade as "Tonys," will be distributed tomorrow at 8 P. M in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. More than a thousand persons, notables of the theatre and others associated with various phases of the entertainment world, are expected to witness the presentation.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Wesley Roberts resigned as chairman of the Republican National Committee late this afternoon and President Eisenhower said his decision to quit was "a wise one."

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- The Government reported today that its investment in commodities stored under farm price support programs increased nearly 50 per cent during the year ended on Jan. 31. The investment grew from $1,953,761,000 to $2,912,719,000 during the period.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- The Fish and Wildlife Service is going to expand its Alaska salmon research into off-shore areas of the North Pacific, including the Bering Sea.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- A thorough restudy of Government subsidies to shipping companies was demanded today by Senator Charles E. Potter, Republican of Michigan, after several witnesses told about "phantoms" carried by the Grace Line on its New York payroll, allegedly with the knowledge of company officials.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- Letters presented by the Government in an effort to support a charge that John L. Pratt was an "enforcer" of du Pont policy at the General Motors Corporation were explained by the 72-year-old retired G. M. vice president today at the du Pont anti-trust trial in Federal District Court here.
TOKYO, March 27 -- Japanese repatriates from Communist China began arriving at their homes today, and the critical process of absorbing them into the stream of Japanese life started.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Henry W. Grunewald, silent witness of the 1951-52 tax scandal investigations, reversed his field today and started answering a Congressional subcommittee's questions.

The "drivotrainer" method of teaching students how to drive by simulating on-the-road experience in the classroom, which has been at the Brooklyn High School of Automotive Trades for a month, has proved only a third as costly as the conventional behind-the-wheel experience being given pupils in other city high schools.

NEWTOWN, Conn., March 27 -- An irate motorist, who apparently resented an attempt to question him about a minor traffic accident opened fire with a 20-gauge shotgun here today and seriously wounded a state policeman.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- Reports alleging violations of academic freedom and of the rights of college instructors are "swamping" the American Association of University Professors, Dr. Ralph E. Himstead, the association's general secretary, said today as the organization opened its thirty-ninth annual meeting.

Actors Equity Association characterized as "erroneous" recent statements voiced by Ben Hecht, author-playwright, charging the union with improper handling of the case involving his nine-year daughter, Jenny, and the current Broadway attraction, "Mid-Summer," from which she withdrew.

There is no doubt that Dr. Jonas E. Salk of the University of Pittsburgh has made a notable contribution to the development of a vaccine that will confer immunity for a reasonable period against poliomyelitis. But it would be a mistake to accept the vaccine as the long-sought immunizing agent. Like the cautious scientist he is, Dr. Salk said so himself at a press conference arranged by the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

When Augusto Rodriguez and the Chorus of the University of Puerto Rico made their debut here three seasons ago, their performance was so remarkable that it seemed inexplicable except as a lucky coincidence. A student chorus, like a winning football team, is subject to constant turnover; one's tenors graduate, and one has had it.

On July 6, 1893, the wedding of His Royal Highness the Duke of York (later George V) to Princess Mary of Teck (later Queen Mary) took place. The late Martin Colnaghi, well-known art connoisseur, proprieter of the Marlborough Galleries in London, opposite Marlborough House, invited, among others, my people and me -- a child -- to view the procession after the ceremony at the Chapel Royal, St. James.

The Amalgamated Clothing Workers, C. I. O., reported yesterday that it had won a general wage increase of 10 cents an hour and welfare benefits worth 2 cents for 100,000 shirt and cotton garment workers in all parts of the country.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 27 -- Lew Burdette walloped a 370-foot home run off Ralph Branca with two out in the ninth inning today for a 3-2 Braves' victory over the Dodgers and the Milwaukee manager, Charley Grimm, fell in a mock faint in the third-base coaching box.

Louis Sacks has sold the three-story fourteen-family apartment house at 260 Broadway in Lynbrook, L. I., to Edwin Klein of Hempstead. The Frederick Realty Company was the broker and the attorneys were Lester Bauman for the buyer and Sidney Kates for the seller.

TOPEKA, Kan., March 27 -- Following is the text of part of the 15,000-word report of the joint investigating committee of the Kansas Legislature in its inquiry into alleged lobbying activities in 1951 by C. Wesley Roberts:

Although hampered by rainy weather, Easter trade continued active here this week. Eight shopping days now remain before the holiday, and store executives were optimistic that sales will top last year's even when allowance is made for the earlier Easter this year.

BONN, Germany, March 27 -- Lawyers for Dr. Werner Naumann and six other Nazis arrested by the British for planning to destroy democracy in Germany, demanded today the release of their clients by the West German Federal Government.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- A device calculated to "minimize, if not eliminate, the personal attendance of a baby sitter" was patented this week. It rolls, rocks and bounces a baby carriage for a predetermined period, say from ten minutes to an hour, thus soothing the occupant.

BONN, Germany, March 27 -- The handicraft guilds, Germany's ancient and indestructible monopolies, administered last night one of the most serious and humiliating defeats suffered by United States policy makers since the Occupation authority was established in 1945.

TRENTON, March 27 -- A former member of the Bergen County special grand jury on gambling asserted today in Lyndhurst that the dismissals of both the panel and of Deputy Attorney General Nelson F. Stamler were brought about for the same reason.

Negotiators for the Port Watchmen's Union in the Port of New York agreed yesterday to recommend acceptance of a new 12-cent-an-hour wage increase and other terms of a contract proposed by waterfront employers.

The National Shipping Authority announced yesterday that it had authorized the release of eight more Victory ships from the Federal Reserve Fleet to carry military cargoes for the Military Sea Transportation Service.
