CHICAGO, March 27 (AP) -- John Fitzpatrick, Hollywood, Calif., engineered the second straight upset tonight in the world three-cushion billiards tournament.

The Embassy of Indonesia is sponsoring an exhibition of Indonesian contemporary art that has been touring museums and other institutions and is to be seen until April 18 at the National Arts Club. Wood carvings from Bali and Java in traditional style in the various beautiful woods of the region; metal work including silver utensils; illustrations for the Ramayana done in the ancient manner; textiles and other handiwork are included.

Philip LeBoutillier, president and general manager of Best Co., Inc., in a telegram yesterday to Governor Dewey, urged him not to veto the bill (Sen. 2861) that would prohibit the acceptance of telephone orders on Sundays by department stores in this state.
CLEVELAND, March 27 (AP) -- Robert R. Young predicted today that the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway will control the New York Central Railroad in a year.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 27 -- Attorney General Suprato left by plane today for Medan, capital of Northeast Sumatra, to investigate the March 16 incident at Tanjong Morawa, twenty miles south of Medan, in which six peasants were killed in a scuffle with police.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- The Secretary of the Army, Robert T. Stevens, wrote to the Senate Armed Services Committee today that Gen. James A. Van Fleet was being retired because, while he was qualified, there were no Army vacancies for his four-star rank.

The chance for the election of a Democratic Mayor on Nov. 3 has been greatly increased by Governor Dewey's program for enabling the city to meet its expected $173,000,000 deficit next year, party leaders say, but only if they nominate a strong candidate who will be able to get substantial independent support.

Today's new feature is "Off Limits," a Paramount comedy staring Bob Hope and Mickey Rooney, at the Astor. Marilyn Maxwell, Eddie Mayehoff and Stanley Clements head the supporting cast of the Army life offering.

Commodity prices closed generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume was rather light but metals and potatoes were active. Cocoa, coffee, lead, tin, cottonseed oil, soybean oil and hides registered gains. Rubber and wool closed lower as potatoes, sugar and zinc wound up mixed.

BIRMINGHAM, England, March 27 -- In one of the bitterest British labor disputes of recent years a large majority of 2,300 striking automobile body and finishing workers defied the Austin Motor Company here today and accepted permanent dismissal rather than go back to their jobs.
The New York Chamber of Commerce recommended yesterday that no changes be made in existing provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act dealing with national emergency strikes.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent in the week ended March 24 to 110 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The decrease of 1.2 per cent for farm products was caused by lower prices for barley, corn, livestock, coffee and fresh vegetables.

I am in entire agreement with the main thesis of your editorial on "Mr. Lodge and Moscow." Mr. Lodge rightly pointed out that Czechoslovakia is not a "peaceful democracy," and that there, as elsewhere, "since the end of the war the Soviet Government has persistently followed a policy of aggressive intervention in the domestic affairs of other peoples."

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 27 -- Joe E. Brown, the comic, who is to do the pre and post-game television work at the Yankee Stadium, was introduced at Al Lang Field today, but the Detroit Tigers got all the laughs. They were funnier, turning the contest with the Yankees into a comedy of errors and handing the Bombers a 9-3 victory.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- Prospects for continued dry weather in the drought areas for the next five days, and announcement of export sales of both wheat and corn, gave the grain market a firmer tone today, but there was the usual caution in following advances.
RANGOON, Burma, March 27 (Reuters) -- Burma risked a halt in United States financial aid today by approving a private shipment of rubber to Communist China.
CONNEAUT, Ohio, Saturday, March 28 (AP) -- Estimates of the dead in the train wreck near here ranged from eleven to twenty-five.
The Southwest Research Institute has opened a building research laboratory at 240 Nassau Street in Princeton, N. J., to replace one formerly maintained there by the John B. Pierce Foundation.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- There is nothing on the business horizon to cause anxiety among business men, Walter Williams, Under Secretary of Commerce, said here today.

LOS ANGELES, March 27 -- A hearing of the House Committee on Un-American Activities was thrown into confusion today by a witness' refusal, during a half hour of interrogation, either to answer questions or to decline explicitly to answer them.

Svetozar Gilgoric of Yugoslavia defeated Francisco Burgalat of Argentina in a tenth-round match yesterday to gain undisputed posession of first place in the international chess masters tournament at Mar Del Plata, according to a report from Buenos Aires.

In the last two legislative sessions efforts have been made with Governor Dewey's encouragement to introduce a little more common sense and consistency into the laws governing what may or may not be done on Sunday. It is admittedly a difficult problem, for many reasons.

This week will go down in the record books as the one in which the American Telephone Telegraph Company's outstanding capital stock crossed the 40,000,000-share mark. A. T. T. has three issues of convertible debentures and their holders have been turning them in for stock at an accelerated pace, of late.

VIENNA, March 27 -- President Theodor Koerner gave expression in public for the first time today to his impatience with the failure of the People's party to form a coalition Government, five weeks after the Austrian electorate had given it one more seat but 36,000 fewer votes than the Socialists.

TOPEKA, Kan., March 27 (AP) -- The committee, in finding that Mr. Roberts had not registered as a lobbyist, added the question as to why Mr. Roberts "did not wish to be identified or considered as a legislative agent had not been explained to the satisfaction of your committee."
In France an April fool is a poisson d'avril. It is a custom to present a candy "April fish" by way of consolation to the one who bites and is caught.

An immediate outcome of the current visit of French Premier Rene Mayer to the United States is the prompt announcement that the United States proposes to assume a larger share of the burden of the defense of Indo-China against Communist aggression.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 27 -- Yugoslavia's economic reforms, abandoning traditional Communist controls and adopting some measure of free enterprise by the workers' collectives, and not being accomplished without severe pains.

MOSCOW, Saturday, March 28 -- The Soviet Government ordered early today a general amnesty of all short-term prisoners and a general lightening of all prison terms except those for persons serving long sentences for counter-revolutionary activities, major crimes against the State, banditry and premeditated murder.
The annual automobile show in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel will be televised over the C. B. S. network on Tuesday, April 7, from 9:30 to 10 P. M. Irene .Dunne will be mistress of ceremonies.
The city's two-hour limit for the loading and unloading of trucks in the midtown area was declared invalid yesterday by three justices sitting in the Appellate Term of Special Sessions Court.

Vacant' industrial plots in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx drew spirited bidding yesterday at the final session of the five-day auction by the city of properties acquired through in rem foreclosures of tax liens.

LUXEMBOURG, March 27 (UP) -- Mrs. Perle Mesta said today she had been dismissed as United States Minister to Luxembourg, although Secretary of State John Foster Dulles promised her that she could "stay indefinitely."

The four-story tenement building at 515 Forty-ninth Street in Brooklyn has been sold by Marie Simon to Anna Sloan. The Sale was made through the Nelson Real Estate Company as broker and title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 27 -- A team of Mexican All-Stars, composed of Arizona-Texas League Mexican players and Mike Garcia of the Cleveland Indians, surprised the Giants tonight by triumphing, 10 -- 3, in a charity game before 3,610 fans.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Senate confirmed today by roll-call vote of 74 to 13 President Eisenhower's nomination of Charles E. Bohlen to be Ambassador to the Soviet Union.

WINCHESTER, Va., March 27 (AP) -- Miss Kathryn S. Eisenhower, 19 years old, niece of President/Eisenhower, was chosen today to be queen of the twenty-sixth annual Apple Blossom Festival here April 30-May 1.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 27 -- Political opponents of Premier Mossadegh of Iran are freely predicting his imminent overthrow and have even picked a candidate to succeed him in the post he has held for nearly two years except for a three-day interval last July.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- What is wrong with the way the Federal old-age-benefit program is run and how to cure its ailments engaged the attention of 300 business leaders from twenty-five states at the National Social Security Conference here today.

EASTVILLE, Va., March 27 -- Civic organizations and governing bodies of towns on the Delmarva Peninsula won their fight today to force the Pennsylvania Railroad to continue its ferry service across lower Chesapeake Bay between Cape Charles, Old Point Comfort and Norfolk.

GREENSBORO, N. C., March 27 (UP) -- Sam Snead shot a three-under par 67 with the help of six birdies today to lead a big field in the opening round of the $10,000 Greater Greensboro open golf tournament.

Two individuals and a New York importing company were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury for violations of the Treasury Department's Foreign Assets Control regulations on dealing with Communist China.

WASHINGTON March 27 -- AI minor tempest in the House of Representatives Education and Labor Committee blew over today when a labor leader agreed to withdraw from the record of yesterday's hearing his assertion that the Taft-Hartley Law was "conceived almost in shame."

Mayor Impellitteri's task of preparing a balanced executive budget for 1953-54 was complicated yesterday when a taxpayer's suit was filed in Supreme Court to test the constitutionality of the law signed by Governor Dewey on Thursday creating a transit authority to take over the city's subway, bus and street car lines.
TOKYO, Saturday, March 28 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,567, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday, Korean time:

IF an ounce of prevention is good, several pounds should be better. That is the attitude of the National Wildlife Federation, which seems to be taking definite steps to prevent the possibility of the prairie chicken from joining the now extinct moor hen.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 27 -- A disabled military cargo plane outbound for Honolulu and Tokyo crash-landed in the Pacific Ocean 312 miles southwest of here early today and its four occupants floated almost six hours on a liferaft before being hauled safely aboard a rescue ship.
Paddy Young of Greenwich Village hammered out a unanimous decision over Ernie (The Rock) Durando of Bayonne, N. J., in a bristling twelve-round contest in Madison Square Garden last night.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., March 27 (AP) -- Jean Cronstedt of Penn State captured the all-around championship tonight to cap the opening day of the N. C. A. A. gymnastics tournament and pace the Nittany Lions into the lead for the team title.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Following is the text of a speech today by Premier Rene Mayer of France before the National Press Club:
Although defense production is beginning to slide off, as measured in buying of new machine tools, civilian goods manufacturers are buying so heavily that orders are climbing.

Burglars using acetylene torches with the facility of skilled craftsmen looted two safes of $50,000 to $60,000 early yesterday in the four-story brick factory and office building of Barton's Bonbonniere, Inc., at 80 De Kalb Avenue, Brooklyn.

TOPEKA, Kan., March 27 -- A joint investigating committee of the Kansas Legislature concluded unanimously today that C. Wesley Roberts, now Republican National Chairman, had "deliberately and intentionally" violated the "spirit" and intent of the Kansas law calling for registration of lobbyists and legislative agents during the 1951 legislative session.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 27 -- Following is the text of the address today by Dr. Grayson L. Kirk, president of Columbia University, except for two paragraphs of introductory and closing remarks. Dr. Kirk spoke at a luncheon meeting for delegates to the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, the Deputy Supreme Commander of Allied Forces in Europe, spent the first day of his visit to the Capital in a round of calls to his former comrades-in-arms and a conference at the Department of State.

Sol Levy, a former referee for the National Basketball Association, was convicted yesterday of accepting bribes to rig scores on games played during the 1950-51 season. Levy, who is 41 years old and lives at 1679 East Third Street, Brooklyn, had been on trial in Special Sessions before a three-member bench comprising Justice Doris I. Byrne, who dissented from the majority finding of guilty, and Justices Gerald P, Culkin and John V. Flood.
LONDON, March 27 -- Draped with her personal standard Queen Mary's coffin was placed today in the Queen's Chapel attached to Marlborough House where she often worshiped.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The country's railroads asked their regulatory mentor, the Interstate Commerce Commission today, to remove the expiration date of Feb. 28, 1954, from the 15 per cent freight rate increase the I. C. C. granted them in April of last year.
SOESTERBERG, the Netherlands, March 27 -- The Netherlands became today the latest country to get an independent air force when its army aviation service was inaugurated as the Royal Air Force.

PARIS, March 27 -- Observers here were puzzled today by reports of both United States and French correspondents in Wash ington that President Eisenhower and John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, objected to Premier Rene Mayer's policy of subordinating ratification of the European Defense Community Treaty to an agreement on the Saar.

MADRID, March 27 -- In its current issue, El Economista, a weekly financial magazine, said that retail trade in Madrid was going through a "preoccupying crisis" because of decrease in sales caused by the lack of purchasing power.

HERSHEY, Pa., March 27 -- Hayes Jenkins, Colorado College undergraduate, who earlier this year became the world, and then the North American champion, tonight made it three in a row by capturing the United States figure skating title at the Hershey Arena.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 27 (UP) -- The Alabama Supreme Court held today that a 7-year-old boy of "Creole" descent cannot attend a white school in Mobile because "Creole," in Mobile, means "part Negro."

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 27 -- Israel will not consider any plan for peace with the Arab states that does not include the integrity of her frontiers and full sovereignty, Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett assured the Parliamentary Foreign Affairs and Security Committee today.

Chiang Kai-shek, the Chinese Nationalist leader, cannot hope to defeat Red China's "vast armies" with his relatively small ground force, estimated at 600,000 men, and must therefore resort to hit-and-run tactics, 400 military and civilian leaders were told here yesterday.

LONDON, March 27 (AP) -- Delegates from nearly fifty tin-producing and consuming nations have voted to consider again the establishment of an international scheme to control the marketing and price of tin, it was disclosed today.

A recommendation that the trustees of the Welfare and Health Council of New York City appoint a committee to formulate "a full and complete statement of the board's present position in regard to the exclusion of the Planned Parenthood Committee of Mothers Health Centers from membership and the full reasons therefore" was made yesterday by the special committee appointed by Coverly Fischer, president of the council.
KANSAS CITY, March 27 (AP) -- The nation's airport operators reaffirmed today their belief in the principle of Federal aid for airfield construction and improvements.
MOSCOW, Saturday, March 28 (AP) -- Following is the text of the amnesty decree, as broadcast by the Moscow radio:
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, 6 to 18 points net higher than Thursday on active months.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Judge John J. Parker, arguing against a proposal in Congress to restrict treaty-making powers, said today it would hamper President Eisenhower in his efforts to resist the Soviet Union's plans for "world domination and plunder."

Eastern leaders in the campaign for an American Bar Center in Chicago discussed yesterday plans for raising funds among lawyers in this area at a meeting in the Harvard Club, 27 West Forty-fourth Street.

The new issue market will come to grips next week with a major piece of industrial financing which has been conditioning the course of basic investment yields ever since a first announcement was made of it in January. This is the issue of $200,000,000 of Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation debentures to be marketed by a syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co.
NEWARK, March 27 -- The strike of 7,200 plant and accounting employes of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company ended its second day with no progress toward settlement.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of use to the homemaker.

The New York license of Willie Pep, Hartford boxer who formerly held the world featherweight championship, was restored yesterday by the State Athletic Commission. It had been revoked seventeen months ago for fouling tactics in a September, 1951, title bout with Sandy Saddler.
SALEM, Ore., March 27 -- Liquor by the drink will go on sale in Oregon May 4 under a compromise bill signed yesterday by Gov. Paul Patterson.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- The Small Defense Plants Administration asked Congress today to keep it going for another year and increase its powers.

The program of the Fleischwaren G.m.b.H., association of West German packers, to exchange $14,000,000 worth of canned German hams for American fats and tallow has proved so successful that the campaign will go "whole hog."

BOWIE, Md., March 27 -- In an atmosphere reminiscent of the cold, damp, sunless afternoons of the late football season, the combined Bowie and Laurel race meeting began today. Despite the unpleasant weather, 10,046 fans turned out for the inaugural.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 27 -- At least 150 men, women and children of the Kikuyu tribe are known to have been killed by their Mau Mau fellow-tribesmen in a three-and-a-half-hour massacre in the Uplands area, near Nairobi, last night. The massacre was skillfully organized and was directed against all loyal Kikuyu in the distinct, mainly Government employes and Home Guards.

Prices worked higher in desultory New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday. Oils, rails, aircrafts and electrical equipments made progress. Motors lost ground and chemicals, metals, and steels were mixed. Most changes were fractional.

The new $3,988,000 First Avenue vehicular tunnel to enable through traffic to by-pass the United Nations site will be opened to motorists next week, possibly on Wednesday. The exact date will depend upon the completion of paving work, which is to start on Monday.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, fidgeted in his seat during protracted Senate debate today and there was a good reason for it. He wanted to catch a train for New York.

LONDON, March 27 -- Business dwindled further on the stock markets here today and most prices failed to develop any decided trend. British Government securities closed with a few scattered gains after some slight falls during early trading.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 27 -- Sixteen nations fighting for the United Nations in Korea struck back today at Communist charges that the United States was using germ warfare weapons by formally challenging the Soviet world to accept international investigation of the accusations.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 27 -- Dr. Charles Bean, chairman of the board of management of the National War Memorial, said today the arrival of Japanese Ambassador Haruhiko Nishi had nothing to do with the removal of certain relics of the war with Japan from the memorial building.

The pen ceased to be mightier than the sword along about 1949. But Parker Pen Company refused to accept the adverse trend. Despite falling sales of "writers trader water" and other miracles of the calligraphic art, Parker turned to a good diagnostician.

A collection of 200 dolls from all parts of the world are on exhibition at a hobby show for the benefit of the Greenwich Village Fresh Air Fund, arranged by the Washington Square Business and Professional Women's Club. The show, which opened last night and will run through today from 1 to 6 P. M., is in the studio of the doll collector, Esther Bialo, 8 West Thirteenth Street. Admission is $1.

The Soviet slander machine has gone into high gear again on two stale and long since discredited accusations against the United States which Moscow apparently still considers to be effective for its own purposes. One accusation, parroted this time by Czechoslovak puppets, is that in consequence of its Mutual Security Program the United States is waging "aggression" against countries of the Soviet bloc and should be condemned for doing so.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 27 (UP) -- A thin, extremely white sheet of paper made from swampland sawgrass and hailed as a new low-cost newsprint rolled off a printing press here today, but cautious publishers were not certain it was an answer to their problems.

Two items in THE TIMES referring to our relations with Latin America need to be stressed in these days when the Eisenhower Administration is working out its policy toward our American neighbors. In the financial section on March 18 is an encouraging report of an address made by the new Assistant Secretary of State, John M. Cabot.

Arturo Toscanini may give the word tonight after his performance of Beethoven's "Missa Solemnis" at Carnegie Hall that he wishes to go through with the plan he has already broached -- to lead the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra on a five-week transcontinental tour starting at the end of April.

BOSTON, Marcs 27 -- One man was known to have drowned and hundreds of persons were forced to leave their homes in Maine and New Hampshire today in the path of floods caused by heavy rains and swollen rivers in northern New England.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- President Eisenhower nominated Ray Gidney of Cleveland today as Controller of the Currency and John Roger Lewis of New York as Assistant Secretary of the Air Force.

AUSTIN, Tex., March 27 (AP) -- Wes Santee carried Kansas to the fastest sprint medley relay ever run as the Jayhawks ripped off the mile in 3:21.8 today to headline the opening session of the Texas Relays.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- E. Roland Harriman, president of the American National Red Cross, cautioned today against any slackening of the blood bank program as long as both Korean war and civilian demands continued high. He stressed that as many children as possible must be protected against poliomyelitis until the newly announced polio vaccine was made available for general use.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 27 -- Yoshi Oyakawa swam the fastest time ever recorded for the 200-yard back-stroke tonight. But despite this tremendous performance by its Olympic champion and the victories of Jerry Holan in the 200-yard breast-stroke and Jerry Harrison in the one-meter dive, Ohio State fell farther behind Yale in their battle for team honors in the thirtieth annual National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming championships.
Ten years of service in the Coast Guard will end for Comdr. Alf S. Lie on Tuesday, when he retires as senior investigating officer of the Third District, centered in this area.
A sharp upsurge in American demand for handmade children's apparel imported from the Philippines was forecast yesterday by a major dealer in this field.
LIVERPOOL, March 27 (AP) -- Little Yid, who was bred by a bookie and once sold for 40 guineas today held to his new-found station in life -- top favorite in tomorrow's Grand National Steeplechase.

CLEVELAND, March 27 (AP) -- The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen decided tonight to postpone "indefinitely" a strike set for 6 A. M. tomorrow on the Nickel Plate, the New York, Chicago and St. Louis Railroad.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (UP) -- Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, said today that he would fly to Tokyo tomorrow to see for himself whether United States soldiers in the Far East had enough ammunition.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Professor Stern testified today that, "on the spur of the moment," he could not think of anything serious to criticize about Soviet policy, although "many phases of Soviet policy I find somewhat inadequate."
SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, March 28 -- United States Marines stormed and rewon today the crest of a western Korean hill that they had lost twice in two days of furious combat.

Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, denied yesterday that he had acknowledged a deficiency in his company's field sequential color television system, requiring a revolving disk in a sequence of basic colors, in testifying before the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce committee Wednesday.

Prices of men's and boys' tailored clothing are below those immediately before the start of the Korean conflict, Harry A. Cobrin, executive secretary of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A., said yesterday. At the same time, it was pointed out that since June, 1950, the Consumer's Price Index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics has increased 11.4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Representative Clare E. Hoffman, Republican of Michigan, called off today a proposed investigation of 1950 Democratic Congressional District conventions in Detroit. The chairman of the House Government Operations Committee said both Republican and Democratic House leaders believed that it lacked the jurisdiction to undertake such an investigation.

VIENNA, March 27 -- Prospects that the new Soviet Government might follow up Premier Georgi M. Malenkov's recent conciliatory words to the Western world by adopting a more lenient attitude toward Austria were not encouraged by the action of Moscow's representatives in the Allied Council here today.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 27 -- Penn State, the East's hope to end the two-year reign of the University of Oklahoma Sooners as the wrestling kingpin of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, was on equal terms with its rival from the West tonight as the first half of the 23d annual competition was concluded in the Nittany Lions big recreationn hall.

Members of the new Tea Council of the United States of America, Inc., a non-profit corporation, met for the first time yesterday at its headquarters, 500 Fifth Avenue, marking the formal beginning of an international effort by the Governments of India, Ceylon and Indonesia and the Tea Association of the United States to promote consumption of tea here.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (UP) -- President Eisenhower approved a recommendation today that Capt. Hyman C. Rickover, the Navy's atomic expert, be kept on active duty for another year.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27 -- The University of Pennsylvania was leading Navy, New York University and Columbia's defending titleholders tonight at the end of the first day of competition in the National Collegiate Athletic Association fencing championships.
OGDEN, Utah, March 27 (AP) -- Led by Allan Fisher, Washington State College took the three top spots in the cross-country event of the national intercollegiate ski championships at Snow Basin today.
SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, March 28 -- United States Marines stormed and rewon today the crest of a western Korean hill that they had lost twice in two days of furious combat.

Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, denied yesterday that he had acknowledged a deficiency in his company's field sequential color television system, requiring a revolving disk in a sequence of basic colors, in testifying before the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce committee Wednesday.

Prices of men's and boys' tailored clothing are below those immediately before the start of the Korean conflict, Harry A. Cobrin, executive secretary of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A., said yesterday. At the same time, it was pointed out that since June, 1950, the Consumer's Price Index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics has increased 11.4 per cent.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 27 -- The Federal and Intergovernment Relations Committee of the Connecticut General Assembly voted today to rescind a resolution approved in 1949 memorializing Congress to favor the establishment of world government.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The United States and France agreed today on a policy of watchful skepticism toward any gesture of peacefulness that might be made by the new regime in the Soviet Union.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa March 27 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's Nationalist party evidently regards the Supreme Appeal Court's decision that segregation on railways cannot be enforced without equal facilities for white and Negro as an election bonanza.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- Government practices in the electric power field over the last twenty years have bequeathed to the Eisenhower Administration an appalling and unhealthy situation that threatens to destroy private utilities and result in nationalization of the industry, a private utility executive warned today. He said the practices raise the question whether the strength of the country itself is in jeopardy.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 27 -- North Atlantic Treaty authorities are making final preparations for a $100,000,000 network of underground jet fuel pipelines and storage tanks destined to link more than fifty Allied air bases in a defense arc from the northern Netherlands to the French-Swiss Alps.
Ship chartering is continuing to be a seller's market, with ship-owners naming their own price to shippers, but the situation is expected to reverse within the next several months.

GENEVA, March 27 -- Some help is at last in sight for German victims of Hitler's concentration camps. These are the most forgotten of all forgotten sufferers from the wave of brutality that passed over Germany to be checked only by the end of World War II.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 27 (UP) -- A former Flying Tiger pilot threatened to kill himself in crash dive with a stolen plane today, but landed here instead after four hours in the air.

Flowers and plants at the New York Botanical Garden soon will burgeon and flourish in an atmosphere as natural as man can simulate under a vast glass-domed greenhouse. Visitors at the Pageant of Spring Easter Show, which opened in full bloom yesterday, had the first glimpse of this new naturalism.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., March 27 -- More rain in this area during the last twenty-four hours and melting snow in the Adirondacks today continued to increase the flow of the Black River, already far over its banks in parts of Lewis and Jefferson Counties.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 27 -- The Security Council held another inconclusive meeting today on the question of a successor to Trygve Lie as Secretary General of the United Nations. No additional candidates were proposed, and the Council decided not to hold another meeting until the five great powers had held further consultations.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 26 -- Burma served notice today that she expected the help of states "in and outside" the United Nations in her fight against Nationalist Chinese troops now on Burmese territory.

CONNEAUT, Ohio, Saturday, March 28 -- Two speeding New York Central Railroad passenger trains crashed into a derailed freight train in a freak collision near here shortly after 10 o'clock last night and Ohio State patrolmen said twelve persons had been killed.
The twenty-seventh annual Eastern States Championships continued last night at the McAlpin Hotel with 500 contract bridge players competing in three simultaneously conducted events.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 27 -- The prospect that the Matson Navigation Company might have to abandon its passenger service between the mainland and Hawaii unless a way can be found to prevent labor troubles from causing frequent delays in the liner Lurline's sailing schedule was put to the line's stockholders today.

Once again the political football of postmasters' appointments is being kicked around in Washington and finding place on the front pages of newspapers, THE NEW YORK TIMES included. In addition you carried a letter on the subject from an upstate postmaster who attempts to "clarify an erroneous impression," to use his own words.

Lumber production for the week ended on March 21 was 12.2 per cent above the comparable week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by regional associations. Shipments were up 10 per cent and orders 42.3 per cent.

There is a song, currently popular on the radio, which, because of its long range implications, could stand a little dark scrutiny. As she sings it, she is going to California. She doesn't want him to feel lonely, and so for companionship she will buy him that doggy in the window.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- United States efforts to assure prompt French ratification of the European Defense Community Treaty appeared stymied tonight behind Premier Rene Mayer's demand that the future role of the Saar region be clearly defined before his Government could accept the plan.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 27 -- Dr. Grayson L. Kirk, president of Columbia University, asked member states of the United Nations today to support the theme of the university's bicentennial next year, "Man's Right to Knowledge and the Free Use Thereof."
WASHINGTON, March 27 (UP) -- E. Merl Young denied at his perjury trial today that he had lied intentionally about his finances to Senate investigators and a Federal grand jury.

LOS ANGELES, March 27 -- California designers have put their strongest efforts into creating fashions that will make the spring and summer seasons important ones. From the costume to the playsuit, the designs are lively. Fabrics have been selected with an eye to excellence of quality and beauty of color.

Walter Hoving, chairman of the City Affairs Committee, whose plan for transit economies was attacked Thursday by Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., returned the compliment yesterday.

" Pan-Slavism: Its History and Ideology," by Hans Kohn, is one of two books published today. It covers the story of Slav nationalism from its beginning after the Napoleonic Wars to its climax after World-War II. The book is Dame Press at $6.25.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 27 -- Jose Ferrer and John Huston will get together again in London, come January, to film Shakespeare's "Richard III" under the banner of Romulus Films, Ltd., the company that was sponsor of their first association in the current "Moulin Rouge."

LONDON, March 27 (UP) -- The Bulgarian Communist regime has decreed that all Bulgarian citizens who have left the country without permission or who have refused to return from authorized trips are subject to the death penalty and that their families in Bulgaria will be placed in concentration camps.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- Scientists at the University of Chicago have developed what they call the world's smallest peephole through which they are shooting an atomic beam measuring only 1-12,000th of an inch in diameter to explore the innermost secrets of living cells, the school disclosed today.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan ordered departmental charges drawn yesterday against Deputy Chief Inspector Daniel A. Mooney, who applied on Thursday for retirement after he had been relieved of his Brooklyn command on Feb. 9.

Butler Brothers, Chicago distributor of medium-priced dry goods, variety goods and merchandise, last year increased consolidated net sales to $117,507,779, from $114,079,229 in 1951. But earnings declined, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

BONN, Germany, March 27 -- The West German Government announced today it would not deposit the ratification instruments of the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies and the European Defense Community Treaty until all other signatory nations also had ratified the pacts.

PALM BEACH, March 27 -- The building of depth, breadth and resiliency into a market that is governed by the law of supply and demand instead of by Government controls will require effort and patience on the part of all business men, William McChesney Martin, chairman of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, declared here today.

A three-to-six-year state prison term was imposed yesterday on Minot Frazier (Mickey) Jelke, the 23-year-old heir to a $3,000,000 oleomargarine fortune, who had been convicted of having procured two young women for prostitution.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Donold B. Lourie, Under Secretary of State for administration, and Scott McLeod, administrator of the department's Bureau of Security and Consular Affairs, today disputed the assertion by Dean Acheson that the employment of Americans of questionable loyalty by the United Nations did not constitute a danger to the security of the United States.

PINKHAM NOTCH, N. H., March 28 -- Brookie Dodge, Dartmouth captain and American Olympian, today prevailed in a brilliant field of seventy-four to regain the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's downhill championship over the heavily wooded Wildcat Trail.

I resent your article on the Irish ["'St. Pathrick's Day in the Morning'" by Sean O'Casey, published March 15]. The article, as well as the pictures captioned "Faces of Ireland," is a gross misrepresentation and an insult to the people of one of the most beautiful countries on the face of the earth -- people of character who have always been noted for their loyal allegiance to God and country.

LONDON, March 28 (Reuters) -- Four of the top six teams in the first division of English soccer were downed today as Charlton Athletic triumphed over Liverpool, 2 -- 1, to tie for first place with Preston Notrh End and the Wolverhampton Wanderers.

How corporations can help keep plants and equipment operating at top technical efficiency, provide incentives to bring out the best in management and give employes a sense of security and participation in company activities is shown in an article, "Joint Capital Trust," by Gustave Simons in the Harvard Business Review for March-April.

CHICAGO, March 28 -- Lieut. Ken Wiesner, Navy dentist, set a new world indoor high-jump record of 6 feet 10 3/4 inches tonight for the top performance in the seventeenth annual Chicago Daily News Relays before 16,762 fans.

All of the boxes and many of the seats have been purchased for Wednesday night's premiere of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus at Madison Square Garden for the benefit of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City.

NOW the name of Toscanini can be placed beside that of Walter and Weingartner as conductors represented on records by the nine Beethoven Symphonies. Victor has just released the nine, all played by the N. B. C. Symphony, in an elaborate seven-disk album.

A pre-Easter recorded program of traditional Holy Week music will be heard on Wednesday from noon to 2 P. M. at the weekly concert at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
Students in 117 colleges and universities have used, or are using, the recording service of the National Committee for Recording for the Blind, Inc., 36 West Forty-fourth Street.

MARCH COST has lost none of the vitality and dramatic flair that first brought her acclaim twenty years ago with "A Man Named Luke." In the impeccably written novels that followed she has always had something interesting to say and has taken intricate and devious ways of saying it.

The apparent downtrend in deposits of New York City banks during the first quarter of this year is a new and uncertain factor in the otherwise favorable outlook for earnings in 1953. First quarter interim reports of banks to be issued next week are nevertheless expected to indicate earnings for this year at a rate about 6 per cent ahead of 1952.

PETER GOWLAND'S "How to Photograph Women" (New York: Crown Publisher's, Inc., $1) is one of two new volumes with which Aaron Sussman inaugurates his editorship of the Little Technical Library. The book should immediately become the standard reference work for camera club "studio nights," for amateur field trips "with models" and for that time-honored pictorialist institution known as "the study."

Last week's conferences with the French mission at Washington happened to coincide with the 150th anniversary of the negotiations at Paris which brought about the Louisiana Purchase. Nothing done at Washington last week will prove so eventful for this country as these negotiations at Paris.

BEIRUT, Lebanon -- The countries of the Near East, embracing within their borders the fabulous Holy Land, are rapidly awakening to the value of tourism, to their economies and have embarked on ambitious plans to capture a larger share of the American traffic as one of their few sources of foreign exchange.

Mayor Vincent Impellitteri, describing himself as "behind the eight ball," last week accepted Gov. Thomas Dewey's proposal to transfer New York City's vast transit system to a public authority. The move relieved the Mayor of a $50,000,000 transit deficit as he sat down to draw up his budget for fiscal 1954 (beginning July 1).
SOCORRO, N. M., March 28 (AP) -- It started with a traffic fine, and now Socorro County is planning to secede from the Union and take sizable chunks of Arizona and Texas with it.

ROME, March 28 -- Pope Pius, in a long speech he addressed today to the parish priests and Lenten preachers of Rome, urged the clergy to redouble its effort to contain "the enemy," making it clear that he referred to communism.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 28 -- Even though the Dodgers were some twenty miles away at Tampa, their influence was felt here today at Al Lang Field. In a roundabout sort of way. the Dodgers were responsible for the 2-1 victory the Red Sox registered over the Yankees.

GLINKA, "father of Russian opera," was used as a model by composers who came later -- Borodin, Mussorgsky, Rimsky-Korsakoff among others. But while "Boris" and "Le Coq d'Or" are almost as familiar as "Rigoletto," the Glinka works from which they derive are unknown in this country.

AN American colony as divergent as the Paris and Rome expatriates is sinking its roots in Japan. They are a motley crew who have come to Asia "to live and die. " They are resident vice presidents of oil companies, gamblers, lawyers, piano players, loafers seeking atmosphere, airline p{lots, missionaries, night-club operators and studentac

C. Wesley Roberts is a 50-year-old Kansan and former weekly newspaper publisher who entered Republican politics in 1936. After World War II service with the Marines in the Pacific, he was Kansas G. O. P. chairman from 1947 to 1950. In the Presidential campaign last year Mr. Roberts was on the Eisenhower bandwagon early, directing the General's pre-convention headquarters in Washington.

The amnesty decreed in Moscow yesterday for various groups of criminals is obviously another major move by the new Soviet regime in the pattern of repudiation of Stalin's handiwork which has been obvious these past three weeks. But unlike the previous acts of repudiation, which involved only Communist party and Government administrative organization, this move truly affects large numbers of the population.

KINGS POINT, L. I., March 28 -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Speaker of the House, declared here tonight that "the Republican party would be wise indeed to name Leonard Hall as its national chairman to succeed C. Wesley Roberts," who resigned yesterday.

THE tourist who returns from an inspection trip of the Florida spring training camps usually brings back a suntan, some impressions and mighty few convictions. Only the last category has any semblance of permanency to it. This wanderer emerged from among the palm trees with just two convictions.
The Cuban Government has taken the first concrete step to curb activities of smugglers who spirit American television receivers illegally into the island republic.

THE easiest way to learn about houses is to watch the day-by-day construction of one in company with a patient adult who will answer all the important questions. The Hurds' newest informational picture book, "Somebody's House," offers children a similar fictional experience.
BONN, March 28 -- The self-satisfaction of the German Government, politicians and press has been overpowering for the past week.
SNOW BASIN, Utah, March 28 (UP) -- Utah was running a close second to Washington State in the national intercollegiate ski championships with victories today in the slalom and downhill events.

RAISING money through cookbooks is a time-honored and ecclesiastically approved custom, but this is the first time to my knowledge that it has reached the stellar - theatrical world. Simultaneously in both England and the United States famous personalities of stage, screen, radio and politics have donated their favorite recipes for a worthy cause.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The State Department, exercising caution and urging restraint, today described the Communist offer for an exchange of sick and wounded prisoners of war in Korea as "an unconditional acceptance" of a voluntary repatriation proposal last made by the United Nations Command on Feb. 22.

When the late Rabbi Dov Ber Manischewitz established a small matzoh bakery under the name of the B. Manischewitz Company in Cincinnati back in 1888 he laid the groundwork for one of the most unusual business organizations in the country.

WERE this book a motion picture it would be listed as a "documentary." Oliver Nelson was 16 when, in 1877, he reached El Dorado, Kan., some sixty miles north of the Cherokee Strip. Farther west was No Man's Land, an alley 168 miles long and thirty-four wide which was completely overlooked in designating state boundaries.

ROBERT SHERWOOD has completed the first play under his contract with the National Broadcasting Company and has titled it "The Backbone of America." He is committed to write nine plays in three years for television presentation. Scheduling now calls for Mr. Sherwood's play to be presented in the fall but it is possible that it might be offered sooner.

CANNES, France, March 28 (UP) -- Bernard Bartzen of the United States entered the final of the men's singles in the international tennis tournament today when he beat the self-exiled Pole, Wladyslaw Skonecki, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1.

It is easy to record the fact that Arturo Toscanini performed Beethoven's "Missa Solemnis" yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, with the N. B. C. Orchestra, the Robert Shaw Chorale and a group of distinguished soloists, whose names are listed above, for the benefit of the Artists' Veterans Hospital Programs and the Hospitalized Veterans Music Service.
TOKYO, March 28 (AP) -- Following are the texts of a Communist reply to a letter from Gen. Mark W. Clark, United Nation Commander in Chief, and of General Clark's letter which was sent Feb. 22:

Miss Schoolmarm-in-Distress and Captain Hero-to-the-Rescue, along with their pals in puppet land, the denizens of outer space and the hard-riding cowpokes, are not all that tele vision has to offer. The noisy screen is doing a quiet job for industry fully as important as its work in keeping the children quiet while Daddy's slippers are fetched.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said today he had effected an agreement with Greek owners of 242 merchant ships to break off all trade with Communist China, North Korea and Far Eastern ports of the Soviet Union.
On March 22 there appeared in the Review of the Week on page 6-E an article purporting to describe the change of the location of my seat on the Senate floor.

DETAILS of casting and the full schedule of performances of the forthcoming "American Dance" season at the Alvin Theatre under the auspices of the B. de Rothschild Foundation for the Arts and Sciences make assurance doubly sure that this will be the most impressive modern dance series in a number of years.

PART of the pleasure of spring gardening is watching for firsts -- the first crocus, the first robin, the first dandelion (provided it is in the neighbor's lawn). To these might be added the first butterfly.

The new Soviet Government headed by Premier Georgi M. Malenkov has apparently decided that it must liberalize its totalitarian rule if it is to allay the popular discontent that is believed to exist and win mass support for its claims to leadership of the Soviet Union.

HOW long a rose bush will grow and flower is seldom considered when it is planted in spring or fall. There are no tables of "life expectancy" and it is impossible to quote any real statistics as to the longevity of a rose bush.

TAKE an elephant and her Hindu trainer, a country sheriff and his surly son, a young inventor, and assorted, youthful, wise-cracking campers. Set them down in the Maine woods and mix well. Result: a fast and wacky tale.

" OKLAHOMA!", the Theatre Guild baby that had to go begging for godfathers, will be ten years old on Tuesday. Members of the original cast, Government officials and theatrical figures will celebrate the occasion at a backstage birthday party at the National Theatre in Washington, D. C., where the touring company is currently holding forth.

PARIS, March 28 -- The prestige abroad of the United Slates is being visibly tarnished by the attacks on some of its most distinguished diplomatic servants by a handful of Senators. Not even President Eisenhower's staunch defense of the latest victim, Ambassador Charles E. Bohlen, has restored the situation.
A spirited battle over the long-dormant issue of the protective tariff was in the making last week as the "trade-not-aid" movement met with its first strong opposition.

LONDON, March 28 -- The bones of the fifth woman victim of a sadistic strangler were disinterred today in the garden of a house of murder at 10 Rillington Place. Notting Hill, a decaying residential section of cheap apartments and rooming houses.

I watched, on television, the first coast-to-coast program of the Academy Awards presentations and never in the history of these awards do I remember the Motion Picture Academy of Arts and Sciences debasing itself the way it debased itself at this year's presentations.

Lillian Genth, an artist whose work is to be found in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, this city, the Carnegie Institute in Pittsburgh, and other permanent collections, died yesterday at her home, 225 West Eighty-sixth Street, after an illness of several months. Her age was 76:
We were much interested in the excellent account by Herbert L. Matthews, published in your issue of March 17, of the U. N.'s aid to Haiti in fighting yaws.

THE world premiere of Carl Orff's "Trionfi" at La Scala in Milan last month has been followed by the first German production in Stuttgart and concert performances in Munich and other cities of Germany and Switzerland.
The spring rains came to Korea last week and with them the enemy began a series of strong local attacks along the routes toward Seoul.

BOWIE, Md., March 28 -- Tuscany, Mrs. Samuel Pistorio's 5-year-old campaigner, did the same thing today that he did last year. The speedy son of The Rhymer took the $10,000 added Rowe Memorial Handicap with the greatest of ease, to the surprise of practically nobody in the crowd of 20,060 fans.

LIKE a good reporter and commentator on world affairs, Bruce Bliven discovered a few years ago that what happens in the research laboratory is news second in importance only to what happens in the international struggle for power.

THEY stopped the music at the Metropolitan Opera Saturday a week ago. The sudden interruption came during the introduction to the second act of "Tristan" and the purpose was to dramatize for the radio audience -- the audience in the theatre also had the benefit of the dramatics -- the desperate situation of the Metropolitan's financial position.

Swept by cross-currents of conflicting business and political developments, the stock market seemed undecided as to which way to go last week. Prices alternately declined, rallied abruptly, and declined again. The high level of industrial activity in the first quarter was coming to an end, with one of the leading automobile manufacturers cutting prices.

THE development of the "aqualung," a simple and relatively inexpensive self-contained diving apparatus, has opened the margin of the sea to all who have the curiosity to enter. A rash of books and magazine articles has appeared describing the feelings and experiences of a variety of people just become aware of the fascination of this last unexplored portion of our earth.

Another attendance record for bridge tournaments was shattered yesterday at the McAlpin Hotel when 150 contract bridge pairs played through taro qualifying sessions of the Goldman Open Pairs, final blue-ribbon event in the twenty-seventh annual Eastern States Championships.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Washington has been unusually conscious of the F. B. I. and its records this week because of two matters that have been of concern to the Senate and to a House Judiciary subcommittee. The first was the nomination of Charles E. Bohlen to be Ambassador to the Soviet Union.

ROME, March. 28--A left-wing Filibuster to delay approval by the Senate of the Government's electoral reform bill entered its third day today and no hope was seen of its ending before tomorrow morning.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 28 -- While French forces press their offensive in the hills and marshes barring the way to Thanhhoa Province, and the Communist-led Vietminh is completing preparations for an attack against Samneua in Laos, important political and international events are taking place in Indo-China.

IN view of the American intellectual's usual tendency to run with the pack, to be aboard the bandwagon with the fashionable "ism" of the moment, I found it a refreshing and even a somewhat hopeful sign that the contributors to the Partisan Review's symposium on "America and the Intellectuals," reviewed last Sunday by Prof. T. V. Smith, reveal such wide dis. parity in their attitudes.

POLICE chiefs across the nation, and even into Canada, are aroused over recent disclosures of "dirty work at the crossroads" -- that tendency among officials in some localities to set up speed traps in which the out-of-state motorist gets his pockets picked by devious legal devices.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The United States and France warned the Chinese Communist regime today that violation of any Korean armistice by aggressive warfare anywhere in the Far East "would have the most serious consequences for efforts to bring about peace in the world."

Representatives of social agencies in this city and in neighboring states joined in a discussion of the problems of foster care yesterday at a conference arranged by the Committee to Develop Adoption Resources of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service, 304 East Thirty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- C. Wesley Roberts, chairman of the Republican National Committee, today called a meeting of the committee for April 10 in Washington for the purpose of accepting the resignation he tendered yesterday and electing his successor.

THOSE who have read Edgar Pangborn's "Angel's Egg" will find in his first science fiction novel much of the sensitivity and sense which characterized that much-anthologized story. An expedition of four men and two women land on a planet five light-years from Earth, are stranded there, and set up the first Earth colony.

As one sidelight on the old question: What is the proper age for retirement? we now have the finding of a study conducted at Columbia University's Teachers College that the younger industrial worker often looks forward to retiring from his job, while the older worker generally tries to put it off as long as possible.

The results of a four-year study of the nation's transportation were submitted last week in the form of a 260-page report to President Eisenhower and members of Congress by the board of directors of the Transportation Association of America.

NOT long ago Senator Theodore Francis Green of Rhode Island bounded up the long flights of stairs to the lofty Capitol dome to inspect the frieze there with a Congressional committee. "I didn't think," he said later, "some of those fellows would make it.

Yes, the "Danger in What We Don't Know" is great, as demonstrated by some of the answers to the questionnaire items published. For example, in the answer to Question 15, the differentia of "socialism" and "communism" are regarded as the latter's belief "that its goals can be accomplished only by physical seizure of power."

Howard Taubman's elation over the banishment of the box office in the coming season of concerts at Philadelphia's Dell makes one wonder whether he or his readers are naive enough to see in this move a victory for the cause of music in Philadelphia.

NEWARK, March 28 -- The declining week-end demand for service brought operation of the strikebound New Jersey Bell Telephone Company system almost to normal today as mediation efforts remained bogged down on the issues of wages and fringe benefits.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 28 -- The acquisition by Princeton University's Firestone Library of two sets of papers relating to the life of the late James Forrestal, first Secretary of Defense and a member of the Princeton class of '15, was announced today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university.

MANY stories have been written about the pressing social problems of high school life, but with very few exceptions they attack the subject from the girls' viewpoint. Reversing the usual approach, James Summers, who will be remembered for his "Open Season," has written a bright, knowledgeable comedy about a few harassed weeks in the life of Don Morley, high school junior.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- The American Association of University Professors adopted today a series of resolutions reaffirming the basic loyalty of the teaching profession and condemning Congressional investigations of education, attempts to impose loyalty oaths and censorship of textbooks.
TOKYO, Sunday, March 29 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,568, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Sunday, Korean time:

THE job of determining what is going on inside Russia -- a fact of critical importance to this country as mysterious moves take place behind the red-brick walls of the Kremlin -- is in the hands of America's "silent service." That organization is the Central Intelligence Agency, whose business is collecting every shred of fact, rumor and speculation we can lay our hands on.

THE Rev. Gordon Prang was not only a man of words but also a man of action. Even though his church was in one of the poorer sections and his salary far too small for his wife and three children, he was happy. He had ambition and hoped that by doing his best he would reap his just rewards.

Defiance of local and Federal investigating bodies and reliance on constitutional rights were urged yesterday by speakers at the seventeenth annual educational conference of the Teachers Union of New York.

HONOLULU -- This crowded vacationland is ready to welcome today another well-known American, Harry S. Truman, to its tourist ranks. The former President is scheduled to arrive here with Mrs. Truman and Margaret aboard the S. S. President Cleveland.

TOKYO, March 28 -- Chinese propaganda broadcasts indicated general satisfaction at United States involvement in the war which -- in Communist judgment -- America dare not abandon and can not win on present terms. "The fact is, of course, that the United States forces in Korea do not lack ammunition," the Peiping radio said. "

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- A former political aide to Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City revealed himself today at a televised hearing of a Senate subcommittee as an undercover man who had used a pier job, which Mayor Kenny helped him get, to gather data on waterfront racketeering and misuse of Government funds.

PARIS, March 28 (UP) --The United States Mutual Security Agency here is reducing its staff 10 to 12 per cent, it was reported authoritatively today. Up to 165 employes in this city alone are to be dismissed.

The plan for a California state marketing order to require that every eighth row in the vineyards be "plowed under" or cut back to reduce production does not apply to quality wines or good table wines, according to Alfred Fromm of Fromm Sichel, proprietors and marketers of the Paul Masson domain in Saratoga, Calif.

Passover -- Judaism's holiday of freedom that commemorates the Exodus of the Israelites from Egyptian bondage more than 3,000 years ago -- will be ushered in at sundown tomorrow with services in synagogues and temples and the holding of the traditional first night seder in homes.

PARIS, March 28 -- Maurice Thorez, still limping from the effects of a paralytic stroke, is coming back to Paris next week to resume formal leadership of the French Communist party after a lengthy convalescence in the Soviet Union. He will find his organization at its lowest ebb since the end of World War II.

The Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference season will get under way on Saturday, with St. John's, the defending champion, entertaining C.C.N.Y. at Dexter Park in Brooklyn and Brooklyn College playing host to N.Y.U.

ANNUAL asters need a long growing period before they flower. This means here in the East that most gardeners set out seedlings in May rather than start asters from seed. May transplanting provides flowers to cut in August.

THE stories here anthologized depend least upon science and most on imagination. Not imagination in the poetic sense, but in the sense of a fresh treatment of old themes -- as in August Derleth's own quite unusual and touching approach to the problem of rejuvenation in "McIivaine's Star."

Observers bewildered by the purchase of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., by the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation constantly return to one question: "How can Kaiser-Frazer, which has operated profitably in only two years since 1945, and which owes the Reconstruction Finance Corporation $48,417,000, buy thriving Willys-Overland, instead of the other way around?"

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 28 -- The Southern Association of Science and Industry reported this week that Southern industrial progress "has reached the point where 2,018 Dixie business concerns could now give Henry Grady's famous 'one gallus' Georgia farmer a funeral service without a single Yankee embellishment."
Tanker owners, affected by a slump in the petroleum trade and a surplus of available tonnage, are seeking to rent their ships out at cost or even at rates that would mean a loss.

FOR little boys and girls who can turn at a second's notice (are there any who can't?) into a galloping horse or a fierce lion or a slow, poky turtle, this book is loaded with delights. It's the story of how Little Boy and his rabbit friend face up to the question: "What animal would you like to be?" Their answers are given in a cadenced text and equally imaginative full-page drawings.

Last week the question came up in the Senate whether Charles E. Bohlen, chosen by President Eisenhower to be Ambassador to the Soviet Union, should be subjected to a lie-detector test. The proposal was made by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin. Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio squelched McCarthy's proposal.
LAKELAND, Fla., March 28 (UP) -- The Tigers took advantage of a wild pitch and an error to beat the Milwaukee Braves, 2 to 1, today.

EVER since American Photography Magazine passed from the hands of the late Frank R. Fraprie, who was one of the most powerful influences in recent American pictorialism, this publication and its annual have followed, except for a brief period, an aimless course.

The Federal laws governing the eligibility of pension trusts for income tax purposes have been developed, for the most part, in the last decade. Only pension trusts qualifying under Section 165 of the Internal Revenue Code are now considered tax exempt. While the statute itself is neither voluminous nor complex, the administrative regulations and rulings on the subject have become numerous and diffused.

CAIRO, March 28 -- British-Egyptian friction over the implementation of the Feb. 12 agreement providing for Sudanese self-government has been eliminated, at least for the time being, according to a joint communique issued today by the Egyptian Government and the British Embassy after a meeting between Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Premier of Egypt, and Selwyn Lloyd, British Minister of State, who is returning to London tonight after a week-long fact-finding mission to Khartum.

TRENTON, March 28 -- The State Legislature entered the doldrums this last week, and its noticeable disinclination to act on any major legislation, particularly that of a controversial nature, was explained in two ways.
NEWARK, March 28 -- Plans for the construction of a new city hospital and rehabilitation of the present institution at a cost of $13,000,000 were moved into final legal processing this week.
HERSHEY, Pa., March 28 -- Tenley Albright of Boston completed her own grand slam in figure skating tonight by retaining her United States crown at the Hershey Arena tonight.

One of the busiest and happiest persons at the Easter Dawn Service in Radio City Music Hall next Sunday will be Herbert Stavely Sammond, 78-year-old organist and choirmaster at the Middle Collegiate Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street.

The second section of the Cleveland Limited, more than eight hours late, reached Grand Central Terminal at 4:20 o'clock yesterday afternoon with several passengers from the Southwestern Limited, one of the trains wrecked Friday night near Conneaut, Ohio.

Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands said here yesterday that while a Federation of Europe was an eventual possibility, such a development should only come after thorough economic integration of Western Europe.

The other leading automobile companies indicated they were not following suit, but nevertheless the significance of the Chrysler action was pondered by marketing executives, retailers and business men generally.

ALBANY, March 28 -- The chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on the Sabbath Law defended today two of its bills that have come in for sharp criticism from business groups. The bills are before Governor Dewey for signing.

The warmer weather, coupled with the early Easter season, resulted in excellent retail business last week. The sudden sales spurt brought immediate - delivery requests to many sections of the wholesale market here, according to Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. But inadequate preparation on the part of manufacturers made rush orders difficult to fill, it was said.

THE oldest of baseball's spring training stories is still the best and the most illustrative. It concerns the rookie sensation who had been capturing all the early headlines by knocking the cover off the ball. But the day finally came when he wrote the inevitable letter to his mother.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 28 -- California, the only West Coast state without state-wide fair employment practices legislation, is watching the resurgence of a campaign bidding for creation of a fair employment practices commission.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The introduction of an "escalator" arrangement tying the base pay of service men to living costs and adjustable at one to two-year intervals was recommended to the Department of Defense today.
In 1951 and 1952, lead poisoning killed fifteen children here from 3 months to 4 years old and made twenty others seriously ill, Dr. John F. Mahoney, Commissioner of Health, announced yesterday.

Heavy rains checked expansion of retail trade in department stores here in ttfe week. Store operators estimated gains over the 1952 week for the big outlets here at 5 to 6 per cent, although Easter this year is a week earlier than last year.

AUSTIN, Tex., March 28 (UP) -- Wes Santee and his University of Kansas team-mates wrote a blazing chapter into the annals of the Texas Relays today as they set an American four-mile relay record and equaled the two-mile mark.

TOKYO, Sunday, March 29 -- United States Marines recaptured today their "Vegas" outpost north of Munsan, on the western Korean front, after a seesaw two-day battle during which the crest of the battered hillock repeatedly changed hands.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The story of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, which President Eisenhower this week proposed letting die, might have its analogy in the tale of the doctor who, called in an emergency, stayed to set up a clinic in the living room.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (UP) -- E. Roland Harriman, president of the American Red Cross, said today the $93,000,000 fund drive was lagging. He urged local chapters to spur collecting efforts.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 28 (AP) -- Australians said today that they fully intend to start the 1956 Olympic games at Melbourne despite a statement by a high Olympic official in Switzerland that the games should be held somewhere else.

LONDON, March 28 (AP) -- The Soviet Embassy spread out the red carpet with a big, broad smile today for a party of American newspaper and radio executives who called to have their visas stamped for a trip to Moscow.

Y., March 28 -- A $67,000,000 five-year plan to rebuild Korean schools destroyed by the war and to make changes in that country's underdeveloped educational system, was recommended today to the United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency by an International team of six educators.

In a game marked by stylish shooting on both sides, the East scored a 72-54 triumph over the West in the seventh annual College All-Star basketball game before 17,187 fans at Madison Square Garden last night. Ritchie Regan, star play-maker for Seton Hall's National Invitation Tournament champions, was voted the most valuable player in the contest.

AMATEUR as well as professional decorators have an opportunity to study the latest trends in interior design at an exhibit which opened at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday and will remain on view there through Thursday of this week. The occasion is the Twenty-second Annual Conference of the American Institute of Decorators.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 28 -- The Taft-Hartley Act has been invoked in many labor disputes where no emergency existed, David L. Cole, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, said today. He said the coal disputes in 1948 and 1950 were prolonged by premature use of the labor law.

AMONG the traditional exhibits which mark the Easter season in New York is the one in the Channel Gardens at Rockefeller Plaza, the first display to be staged there this year. It goes on view Friday, at which time the garden beds will be filled with more than a thousand Easter lilies.

THE sermons of John Donne, said T. S. Eliot in 1931, "will disappear as suddenly as they have appeared." However that may be, the editors of this monumental edition have undertaken to gather for the first time and make permanently available the 160 extant sermons of the poet-preacher.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (UP) -- Representative W. R. Poage, Democrat of Texas, asserted today that Administration plans to cut lending for rural electrification could lead to "the same old dog fight over rates with private power companies."

LOS ANGELES, March 28 -- Jim Thorpe, the Indian whose exploits in football, baseball and track and field won him acclaim as one of the greatest athletes of all time, died today in his trailer home in suburban Lomita. His age was 64.

FAST daytime service on through trains between New York and Portland, Me., will be resumed this summer for the first time since 1949. STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 28 -- Something new in the history of National Collegiate Athletic Association wrestling happened tonight. A strong Penn State squad, unbeaten in three years of dual meet competition, capped a sensational season by bringing the national crown to the East for the first time since the event was inaugurated in 1928.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (UP) -- The outgoing chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, James M. Mead, warned the new Administration today the nation was moving into a "buyer's market" and that anti-trust agencies must be on the alert to prevent efforts to stifle increasing competition.

Moscow is sending out appeals for "unity," "closer ranks" and increased vigilance against the "hidden enemy" -- and the appeals are echoed throughout the satellite capitals.

MILWAUKEE, March 28 -- Milwaukee is going to roll out a red carpet for its new baseball team when the Braves come home for the first time, on April 8, to play two exhibition games here with the Boston Red Sox.

J., March 28 -- A twenty-two-month manhunt following the waterfront slaying of a dock boss in a longshoreman's union office here ended last last night when Federal Bureau of Investigation agents captured Francis and Michael Murphy, formerly local pier workers, in a tourist cottage at Madeira Beach, Fla.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28 -- March average industrial employment in Pennsylvania and Delaware showed an increase of 33,000 above a year ago. Seasonal expansion in the apparel industry was partly responsible. In durable goods there was a slight reduction in payrolls and working hours, including less overtime at primary metal plants.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Raking leaves, papers and other debris from under hedges and shrubs is part of spring clean-up. So is removing tufts of grass and weeds, especially mats of chickweed, from flower beds and borders. It is still too cool for weedkillers to be effective on dandelions, chickweed and other undesirables. The one exception is onion grass.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 28 -- Gov. John Lodge is expected to send to the General Assembly in a few days the nomination of a Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court to succeed Allyn L. Brown of Norwich, who soon reaches the mandatory retirement age of 70.

FIFTY years ago Sir Francis Galton founded the Eugenics Society, a group devoted to the problem of how science can help improve the hereditary qualities of homo sapiens. Ever since, this field of study has aroused heated debate, and "Eugenics: Galton and After" is the most recent attempt to explain some of the most controversial issues to laymen.
NEWTOWN, Pa., March 28 (UP) -- The father of Gene Tierney, the actress, was held in $500 bail today on a charge of "willfully and maliciously" killing a pet pony belonging to a neighbor.

PEOPLE who speak of the "inscrutable" Japanese have never toured Japan by bicycle. Of that we are certain, my husband and I, after a three-week trip over the hilly roads and green level fields of Honshu, the main island.

PARIS -- For more than two hundred years, generations of Frenchmen have been faced with the task of repairing the Palace of Versailles, their nation's most popular public monument, and one of Europe's greatest tourist attractions.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin and leader of the fight against Charles E. Bohlen, admitted defeat today but did not change his mind about the qualifications of the new Ambassador to the Soviet Union.

EVERY business has its heels, and the newspaper press agency is no exception. It is the rise of one such double-dealing sycophant from a tank town telegrapher to head of World Press Service that furnishes the material for the book.

THE DeJur Twin-Lens Reflex, DeJur-Amsco Corporation's first still camera, was introduced here last week. When available, in May, it will sell for $99.50. The taking lens is the coated Chromtar 85mm f/3.5 in a self-cocking shutter with speeds from 1/10th to 1/200th; the finder lens, a coated 80 mm f/3.2 anastigmat.
Six apprentice bricklayers entered in a contest restricted to those with less than two years' experience, competed here yesterday for the championship of Local 34 of the Bricklayers Union, A. F. L.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Within terms of reference that require the most severe restriction and qualification, the Eisenhower Administration has now met and once mastered Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin -- in the United States Senate but not necessarily in the United States.

THE still bare branches of trees afford the property owner at this season vistas which are not granted to him in summertime. Some of the glimpses of the distant landscape might be even more entrancing if they could also be seen at other times of the year.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 28 -- A $3,000,000 expansion program, calling for construction of an area reservoir and a second Greenwich filter station, has been announced by the Greenwich Water Company. The proposed development is contingent, however, on the Representative Town Meeting, which must approve the sale of a town-owned mill pond site upon which the filter station would be erected.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 28 -- Producers of a newsprint made of sawgrass from Florida's Everglades expressed enthusiasm today after the first press-run test of the paper.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 28 -- A thirty-acre, $5,000,000 shopping center has been proposed for the Post Road in Greenwich, to lure local trade back from White Plains, N. Y., and New York City shopping areas. Plans are being held in abeyance, however, pending a decision by the Greenwich Planning and Zoning Commission on a requested zone variance.

ALBANY, March 28 -- Creation of a temporary state commission to study the possibility of setting up a city manager system in New York City and to seek ways to "wipe out the grim toll of years of mismanagement and waste" in the city's government was approved today by Governor Dewey.

Convinced that all physically fit young men are going to have to give at least two years of their lives to military service for a long time to come, defense officials have begun a year-long study intended to take the guesswork out of the draft and close the loopholes that enable some youths to duck service altogether.

The granting of a general amnesty for short-term prisoners and a general lightening of certain prison terms by the new rulers of the Soviet "is no sign they have changed," declared Rabbi J. Howard Ralbag of Congregation Ohav Sholom, 270 West Eighty-fourth Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.
