MOSCOW, March 28 -- The first prisoners to be freed under the Soviet Government's amnesty marched out of Soviet prisons, corrective labor camps and other penal institutions today.

I completely agree with the thesis of Delbert Clark's "Dan ger in What We Don't Know" (March 22), but strongly disagree with the answer given to the last test question, "Can a government be both democratic and authoritarian?"

Investigations, both national and local, into Communist influence in schools and colleges have produced questions about the effects of such inquiries on the attitude and performance of the classroom teacher. In recent weeks some educators have asserted that an atmosphere of fear has developed on campuses and within school systems, with the result that teaching is in danger of becoming barren of new ideas.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 28 -- A thirty-acre, $5,000,000 shopping center has been proposed for the Post Road in Greenwich, to lure local trade back from White Plains, N. Y., and New York City shopping areas. Plans are being held in abeyance, however, pending a decision by the Greenwich Planning and Zoning Commission on a requested zone variance.

ALBANY, March 28 -- Creation of a temporary state commission to study the possibility of setting up a city manager system in New York City and to seek ways to "wipe out the grim toll of years of mismanagement and waste" in the city's government was approved today by Governor Dewey.

Convinced that all physically fit young men are going to have to give at least two years of their lives to military service for a long time to come, defense officials have begun a year-long study intended to take the guesswork out of the draft and close the loopholes that enable some youths to duck service altogether.

The granting of a general amnesty for short-term prisoners and a general lightening of certain prison terms by the new rulers of the Soviet "is no sign they have changed," declared Rabbi J. Howard Ralbag of Congregation Ohav Sholom, 270 West Eighty-fourth Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.
MOSCOW, March 28 -- The first prisoners to be freed under the Soviet Government's amnesty marched out of Soviet prisons, corrective labor camps and other penal institutions today.
GLENS FALLS, N. Y., March 28 (AP) -- Staunton Military Academy of Staunton, Va., tonight won the Eastern States scholastic basketball tournament by downing Cathedral Prep of Erie, Pa., 63 -- 57.
BONN, Germany, March 28 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, head of the West German Government, is going to the United States next week to offer thanks rather than to ask for aid, he said today.

Some years the spring plowing doesn't get under way until late April, or even May; but this year has been different. The robins came north several weeks ago -- those that hadn't spent the winter here -- in great flocks. They salute the sunrise, and they scatter over the pasture lands, and they follow the chuffing tractors and the plows, certain that spring plowing is done especially for them.

THERE has been so much satisfied back-slapping over the presentation of the "Oscar" awards and the opportunity the occasion permitted for a cordial union of the movie medium and TV that it comes rather hard for this reviewer to raise a dissenting voice and suggest that the happy occasion left something to be desired -- desired, that is, by a party who is concerned for the advancement of the screen.

IF effects should be traced in a neat, orderly line back to causes, then the Literary Guild's current selection, "Stephania," probably owes its being to a Nazi concentration camp. The steps in this case are not so logical, however, as they are impressive.

THE abrupt decline in hard-cover mystery publishing in 1953 may be temporary; perhaps the rest of the year will pull up the average. But by this date in 1952 I had received for review sixty new hard-cover mystery novels; so far in 1953 I've received forty-five -- a falling off of precisely 25 per cent.

IT was the sardonic Charles Fort who first presented science fiction writers with the intriguing postulate that this earth is but a pasture for alien life-forms and man nothing more than their cattle. John D. MacDonald has softened the Fortean hypothesis a bit.

LAST June's graduates currently adapting themselves to -- and even more those who are still looking for -- jobs may well envy Ilona Karmel, Radcliffe, Phi Beta Kappa, 1952, a young woman with nothing to worry about except making her second novel as good as this, her first.

ALTHOUGH the Army has tried everything from importing checker boards to providing unpopped popcorn ready for the popping, almost any soldier will tell you that the best way he has of passing time is to go to the movies.

TOKYO, March 28 -- The Chinese and North Korean Communist commanders accepted today a long-standing United Nations proposal for an immediate exchange of sick and wounded prisoners of war by both sides in Korea.
To the amazement of my wife and myself, who found "I Confess" thoroughly engrossing and completely entertaining, we read that your man was unhappy about Alfred Hitchcock s latest effort.

AN old gentleman who rarely ventures out of his home in the American Sector of Berlin did so not long ago and stopped dead before he had gone ten paces. On the wall of the building opposite was a portrait of Stalin seventy-five feet high.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 28 (UP) -- Dry Run, a 13 to 1 shot, turned in a thrilling come-from-behind run to gain a one-length victory in the $10,000 Magic City Handicap at Gulfstream Park today.

TRENTON, March 28 (AP) -- Clifton city officials told the New Jersey Highway Authority this week that the tentative line of the Garden State Parkway through the city would cost Clifton some $400,000 a year in property tax losses.

Buddy Combs, the only ten-goal polo player indoors, scored ten times last night as his Red Bank team regained the national twelve-goal championship by routing the Ramapo Polo Club, 16 -- 6, at the Squadron A Armory.

Clogging of U. S. Army communications systems by an avalanche of wordage brought an order recently to "reduce the volume and verbosity of electrically transmitted messages," meaning, "cut down on phone calls and telegrams."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 28 -- Last Dec. 20, just before it suspended its seventh session for the long holiday recess, the United Nations General Assembly completed a convention on political rights for women, which had been three years in preparation.

Concerning the use of the word "ceramic" as a singular noun, reference to which has been made in your letters columns, an article on the subject by Ralston Russel Jr. and Arthur S. Watts of Ohio State University appeared in the Journal of the American Ceramic Society in 1949.

Dr. O. G. Villard Jr. of Stanford University came forth at last week's meeting of the Institute of Radio Endi neers in lew York City with a method of sending long-distance radio signals by bouncing them off meteor trails. His method promises to double the capacity of high-frequency channels.

CONNEAUT, Ohio, March 28 -- A weary band of rescue workers dug deeper today into the twisted hulks of nineteen railroad coaches in search of more victims of last night's three-train wreck here. Twenty-two bodies were found, and the coroner said he believed at least one more might be found under one car dug far into the ground.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 28 (AP) -- Art Larsen defeated Miami's Gardnar Mulloy, the nation's No. 1 ranking player, today to move into the men's singles final of the Everglades tennis tournament.
An 18-year-old sophomore, Natalie Fridkin, is the only girl among the eighty-four students enrolled in City College's School of Industrial Arts.

DURING recent years so many stories of wonder grasses have appeared that the home owner here in the Northeast finds himself completely befuddled, on the subject. He is told .that if he sows such and such a seed he can sell his mower or, at least, reduce the number of cuttings to the point where mowing is fun.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 28 -- In the face of some plain criticism from India, Norway and other countries, the United States endorsed today Secretary General Trygve Lie's campaign to dismiss al subversives -- past, present and "likely" -- from the United Nations staff.

PARIS, March 28 -- Accusing the Cabinet of Premier Rene Mayer of having failed to keep its promises to farmers, the National Council of the French Peasants party today instructed its leader, Camille Laurens, to resign as Minister of Agriculture.

MANY young Americans, it seems, are not cut out for the sea. Their nerves are too tight, their needs too ambitious, for them to hold up in a life so cramped. Indeed, a high-ranking medical officer, recently addressing a doctors' convention in Boston, observed that Navy life should be considered inherently neurotic, the human material being what it is.

SPRING comes without trumpets to a city. The asphalt is a wilderness that does not quicken overnight; winds blow gritty with cinders instead of merry with the smells of earth and fertilizer. Women wear their gardens on their hats. But spring is a season here and it has its own harbingers, constant as daffodils.

HAVANA, March 28 -- The Cuban Government began a round-up today of "undesirable foreigners" connected with gambling in Cuba in a campaign to suppress illegal games that have been protested by tourists from the United States.

AN original despite its modest price, Miss Caldwell's latest novel comes out of her mixmaster with the ingredients intact -- and, though she has skimped on length this time, those ingredients are as calorific as ever. The love-versus-duty theme, always one of her favorites, is here again, with all its gaudy trappings, as her earthy heroine struggles to resolve her passionate yearnings.
VINELAND, N. J., March 28 -- A small boy checking his traps on the banks of the Salem (N. J.) River forty years ago saw a flash of red and white in the black mud.

Seven members of a special committee of the House of Representatives that reported last year that the Soviet secret police had committed the massacre of thousands of Polish Army officers in the Katyn Forest in Russia in 1940, received last night the highest non-military award of the Polish Government in Exile.

MOST people class cabbage turnips and kale among the more plebeian vegetables, thinking of corned beef and over-boiled cabbage or "hot dogs" and sauerkraut. They do not know that the young, green heads of cabbage can be fit for the table of a king.
CITY cousins and country cousins being notoriously fish out of water in each others' habitats, Melvern Barker uses this as the crux of a small boy's problem in "6 O'Clock Rooster."

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., March 28 (AP) -- Curragh King surged from second place in the stretch to win the seventeenth running of the $10,000-added Arkansas Derby before a record crowd of 13,579 at Oaklawn Park today.

GRASS seed mixture have passed through a rather revolutionary stage on the West Coast in the past ten years. Lawns recently seeded in this area show little resemblance to those which existed several years ago. The introduction of improved varieties plus dissatisfaction with the old has been the motivating factor behind the new look.

THE last of Manhattan's Els -- the Third Avenue -- may some day soon be doomed to join its vanished mates of Second, Sixth and Ninth Avenues, if city authorities carry out the proposal to abolish it to save transit operating costs. This would mark the end of a transportation epoch.

TREES make an important contribution to the first flowers of spring. Some may even start to open in February and many species, like the maple, flower before their leaf buds open. Although all trees bloom, only a few are as showy as, for example, dogwood and catalpa.

Goose Tatum, Marques Haynes Co., otherwise known as the Harlem Globetrotters, will be on display twice before capacity crowds at Madison Square Garden today. The games, set for the afternoon and evening; will be against the College All-Americans.

Dr. Ernest O. Melby, dean of the New York University School of Education, declared yesterday that because of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and persons similar to him teachers were "fighting for their lives."

IN the program of "Camino Real" the scenic legend reads: "The Time and Place: Not specified." To one theatregoer that statement seems like a polite evasion. For the time is obviously now and the place is the mind of Tennessee Williams. "Camino Real" is a sensitively composed fantasy about the hopelessness and degeneracy of life in the world today.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 28 (AP) -- A gang of Mau Mau terrorists killed at least twelve pro-British native Home Guards in a night attack on an Africa nvillage near Nyeri, it was announced today. The killings followed the massacre of at least 120 loyal natives near Nairobi Thursday.

THE formation of Magna Theatre Corporation, a formidable combine of showmen and scientists headed by Joseph M. Schenck, which joined the ever-growing list of wide-screen projection and exhibition companies, touched off as much commotion as any event in recent screen history.

THE international trains London-Berlin and Paris-Berlin stop at such cities in Germany as Aachen, Koln, Dusseldorf, Essen and Hanover. A look at these cities is not a pleasant sensation. There are still ruins and shambles all over, seven years after the war's end. Reconstruction is slow -- too much was destroyed.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 28 -- Albania's Communist regime, most of which is in the hands of a police force manned in key positions by Soviet personnel, still is as firmly installed as it ever was, although economic conditions continue to deteriorate, according to the best available information gathered here.

One of the traditional "big three" of speedboat regattas, the annual Red Bank National Sweepstakes Championship, will have another site and sponsor this year. This two-day event on the Nave-sink River, popular for more than two decades with the speedboat pilots and voted two years ago as the "best regatta of the season," has been abandoned at least for this season by the moguls, solons and badge-wearers for a variety of reasons.
Many of the smaller communities throughout the United States and Canada have sent forth their native sons to make marks in the fields of industry, finance and business. Cobalt, Ont., is no exception.

A SKINNY, unhandy little shrimp, Flan Taylor wasn't a bit like the typical boy heroes of the American frontier. When, in 1782, he started out on the Wilderness Trail with Chapman Green, the Long Hunter, Flan couldn't handle a rifle or a horse and was miserably ashamed of his own backwardness.

KRISTOS voskresye . . . This is the ancient Easter greeting of old Russia -- "Christ is risen." One extends it, customarily with three kisses, early Easter morning after a midnight mass, on one's way home to the most elaborate meal of the entire year.

While German industrialists still battle with the Bonn Government for a more liberal policy toward cartels than either the Allies or the politicians want, the I. G. Farbenindustrie -- popularly known as the German Dye Trust -- is being dissolved.

THE controversy over educational television continues apace, but there are increasing signs that the supporters of noncommercial video for cultural purposes are catching their second wind and pushing forward with plans.
GREENSBORO, N. C., March 28 (AP) -- Sam Snead put together a pair of two-under-par 33's today to increase his Greensboro open golf tournament lead to two strokes at the half-way mark.

SYRACUSE, March 28 (UP) -- Don Perry of U. C. L. A. cracked his one-day-old world rope-climb record and Penn State-captured the team championship in the eleventh annual N. C. A. A. gymnastics tournament today in Archbold Gymnasium.

YOUR critic's report on March 15 that certain groups (hotel maids and lawyers) had taken exception to characters in "Mid-Summer" and "The Crucible" convinced me of the need of a service which some friends and I hope to launch soon.

A number of steps to aid students in the Middle East to continue their studies in the United States have resulted from the visit of Charles R. Hulac, director of admissions at Lafayette College, to Iran, Lebanon and Egypt.

Although the peoples of the free world understand the ideological and political reasons for the presence of United Nations troops in Korea, only the person who has actually been there can understand the full impact of the war upon the Korean civilian population.

OF immense importance to everyone in this country, active gardener or not, is the work being done by the Division of Plant Exploration and Introduction. Functioning on a global scale, the division responds to demands made upon it by hybridizers (amateur and professional), botanical gardens, research workers and agencies in many lands.

ONCE again the fate of the drama hangs in the balance at the City Center. This lamentable intelligence is passed along because the figures for the recent three-play program offered on Fifty-fifth Street indicate the kind of deficit which the Center is unlikely to look upon with equanimity.

As another spring approaches motorists again look to the open road, planning Sunday drives and vacations by auto. There are more and better roads in some states, and there will probably be more drivers on the road, but will the drivers be any better? Or will each holiday again be preceded by the unfortunate but too often true predictions of a record toll of traffic deaths?

LONDON, March 28 -- The Cambridge University crew, with an American pulling its No. 6 oar, defeated the Oxford eight today by eight lengths in the four-and-a quarter-mile race from Putney to Mortlake on the Thames River. The time was 19 minutes 54 seconds in unfavorable rowing conditions.

The Jewish festival of Passover will open at sundown today to celebrate the emancipation of the Jews from Egyptian slavery. It will continue for seven days among Reform congregations and for eight among Orthodox and Conservative Jews.

A record number of 1,149 alcoholics applied last year to the Bureau of Alcoholic Therapy for rehabilitation, but only 279 could be accepted because of space and staff limitations, Edward J. McGoldrick Jr., the director, reported yesterday.

There is a big gap between the theoretical instruction received in college by advertising students and actual practice in the field. In an effort to bridge it, the New York University Chapter of Alpha Delta Sigma, in conjunction with Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., will conduct next month a three-day exposition entitled "Blueprint of an Advertising Agency."

An apartment house for eighty families on plot 87 by 132 feet at 100 Remsen Street, in the Brooklyn Heights section of Brooklyn, has been purchased by Louis J. Glickman for cash over mortgages amounting to $755,000 in a deal negotiated by Fitch Robinson and Mrs. Paul Edelstein, brokers. Assessed at $760,000, the property occupies the entire blockfront on Henry Street from Remsen Street to Hunts Lane.

The New York City Opera presented its first "Aida" of the spring season yesterday afternoon at the City Center. Joseph Rosen-stock, director of the company, conducted the work with authority, and the cast, for the most part, was a strong one.

Madison Square Garden had 36,944 persons, equally divided between the afternoon and evening and all the place could hold yesterday, for basketball games in which competition was a secondary attraction.

United States immigration policy, as enunciated in the McCarran-Walter Act, was found wanting in many respects by a panel of six high school students who participated yesterday in the New York Times Youth Forum.

The Congressional investigating committees have forced many of us to look at our educational system more closely. It is obvious that the committees will root out only the most conspicuous exponents of left-wing ideologies, but it is also clear that the committees may do much harm in creating panic and sympathy for those who are suspected of Marxist affiliations.

NEW DELHI, India, March 15 -- Six hundred thousand children and youths of India's capital and the adjacent old city of Delhi have been tested for tuberculosis in less than three weeks by local government health authorities with the assistance of the World Health Organization and the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund.

Pascaltide, commemorating the sorrow of Christ's crucifixion and the joy of His resurrection and the redemption of mankind, was ushered in at St. Patrick s Cathedral yesterday with the solemn liturgical ceremonials of Palm Sunday.

Two widely known New York Protestant clergymen used Palm Sunday and the Crucifixion of Christ as their texts yesterday in condemning character defamation, irresponsible criticism and political expediency.

ROME, March 29 -- Amid rowdy and violent scenes such as seldom have been witnessed at its sittings, the Italian Senate approved today the Government's electoral reform bill, against which the extreme Left, aided by the extreme Right, had fought with extraordinary fierceness and pertinacity in a filibuster more than seventy-two hours long.

Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany, said yesterday that he intended to have a canvass of the enrolled Democrats in New York County to determine whom they wanted for the Democratic candidate for Mayor. He added that he would even support Mayor Impellitteri for re-election, if a majority wanted him.

The oldest spectator at the National Collegiate Athletic Association wrestling championships at Penn State last Saturday was James Hughes. Although 88, he is an inveterate sports fan and probably the oldest man with headmaster experience in America.

To aid needy Jews throughout the world and to provide funds for Jews who may escape from behind the Iron Curtain, the United Jewish Appeal staged a series of rallies in thirty cities of the United States yesterday.

LONDON, March 29 -- The stock markets have taken a moderate downward turn in the last few days and business has contracted to its lowest level for several weeks. This was perhaps to be expected after a long period of sustained steady advance and because of the proximity of a long Easter holiday to be followed shortly by introduction of the budget.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, March 29 -- A new pattern for the garrison state -- one that would startle those brought up in the belief that compulsory military service was bound to promote militarism and tyranny -- is evolving in peace-loving American communities like this flourishing little city in the Corn Belt.

It will require one pint of blood to protect one child from polio this coming summer. Last year gamma globulin, a solid fraction of human blood containing most of the antibodies and disease fighters, was used as a temporary protection for 27,386 children against the three viruses that cause crippling poliomyelitis.

IT was almost like losing an old and valued friend. The New York University football team passed away without a struggle not so long ago. Yet it hardly could be said to be unexpected. The Violet had been a weak and sickly patient for a long time.

Uranium seekers with their Geiger counters, and oil men with their seismographs, have been much in the public eye in recent years. But there is another group of modern prospectors whose quiet explorations all over the world have gone relatively unnoticed -- the asbestos hunters.

MANILA, March 29 -- President Elpidio Quirino indignantly accused the United States Embassy in the Philippines today of siding with the opposition Nacionalistas in their election-year struggle for political supremacy over the Administration Liberal party.

LEWIS, Ind., March 29 (AP) -- Residents of this village wandered among their windowless homes today and marveled that they were alive after artillery shells from three ammunition cars on a derailed and burning freight train had shot fire on the town for five hours last night.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, March 29 (AP) -- The United States Army's European Headquarters confirmed today reports that there was a flaw in the gun of the new M-47 Patton II medium tank, America's best in service, but added that it was not serious and steps were being taken to correct it.

The Staten Island Republican party, which has filled most of the cabinet posts for the Borough President of Richmond for the last twenty years learned yesterday that the Democrats will now take over. Jeremiah Sullivan, Democratic county chairman, made this announcement yesterday after a conference with Borough President Edward G. Baker.
OTTAWA, March 29 (AP) -- French Premier Rene Mayer arrived in the Canadian capital from Washington today on a courtesy visit.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- The economic climate in the United States has changed in the last few months, a spokesman for the National Association of Manufacturers said tonight, but the guard must be kept up against a new drift toward "socialism."
WASHINGTON, March 29 (UP) -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, has ordered a top-level study into the problem of why a steadily decreasing number of men are choosing military careers.

The last of the World War II veterans stubbornly holding onto their converted barracks in the state's "temporary" housing project at Manhattan Beach sadly made up their minds yesterday to leave soon the community that they, their wives and children had grown to love in the last seven years.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 29 -- The Giants said farewell to Arizona today but it wasn't the sort of hearty leave-taking Leo Durocher had envisioned.

Fear, inducing mental disintegration in the world today, is impelling a rapid drive toward anarchy in our social order, the Rev. Dr. Bernard Iddings Bell declared yesterday at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street.

Defeat of the Celler bill (H. R. 2237), which would raise maximum fines under the Sherman Anti-Trust Act from $5,000 to $50,000, is urged by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc. In letters being sent to members of Congress today, the association expresses amazement that the House Judiciary Committee has reported the bill out of committee.

Last night's concert given by the League of Composers at the Museum of Modern Art was not one of its most successful. Lack of time prevented this listener from hearing the Turchi work, but the three others on the program had little too offer.

JERUSALEM, March 29 (Reuters) -- Seven companies, including American and Canadian, will start oil drilling in Israel within four months, Pinhas Sapir, director of the Israeli Government Development Department, announced at a press conference here this afternoon.
LONDON, March 29 -- In the flickering golden light of six tall candles Queen Mary lay in state in Westminster Hall tonight as thousands of sorrowing Britons filed slowly past her coffin.

LONDON, March 29 -- The discovery of what seemed to be the bones of a sixth woman victim added horror tonight to London's gruesome crime sensation -- the Notting Hill house of murder. The remains of five women had been found there and four of them were identified as the victims of a sadistic strangler.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Congress squared off tonight for a legislative free-for-all as it prepared to take up in both the Senate and the House of Representatives bills seeking a settlement of the long-standing offshore oil dispute.

TOKYO, Monday, March 30--Gen. Mark W. Clark and his United Nations Command staff waited today for instructions from Washington on how to reply to Communist acceptance of an Allied proposal to exchange sick and wounded war prisoners and the enemy's suggestion to revive the armistice talks in Korea.

Activity in the foreign exchange market during the last week was limited and confined solely to the British pound sterling and the Canadian dollar. Business transacted was mostly routine and moderate in volume.

Revised methods of inspection of smoke offenses put into effect by Dr. Leonard Greenburg, Commissioner of the city's recently organized Department of Air Pollution Control, have increased collections of fines from $800 a month to $1,500.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -President Eisenhower did the listening when he met a friend from Scotland in church today.

Albert Einstein, named by George Bernard Shaw as one of the eight "Universe Builders" in recorded history, has returned from a three-year sojourn on the lonely summit of his scientific Sinai with a new set of laws for the cosmos.

Mayor Impellitteri, in a renewal of his attack on Rudolph Halley, accused the President of the City Council yesterday of presenting "wrong and malicious" distortions in his plan for solving the city's financial problems.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 29 -- The Indian Harbor Yacht Club's frostbite dinghy season ended today as Martin A. (Skip) Purcell, the national junior champion, sailed Squeak to victory through five races for a total of 68 points. Purcell won three events, Phil Miller with Say When and Walt Pierson Jr. with Sphinx took the others.

Chicks and bunnies dominate a collection of dolls, cuddly dogs and sophisticated turtles in a room portioned off for objects and toys for children at the Penthouse Gallery, 15 West Fifty-fifth Street.

MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, B. W. I., March 29 -- Directors of the Inter-American Press Association adopted a resolution at the board's final session today asking members to avoid any transactions with newspapers that had been expropriated and are now being run under false guises.
Arthur Miller's drama, "The Crucible," and the musical, "Wonderful Town," received Antoinette Perry awards here last night for "distinguished contributions to the current theatre season."

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -Walter P. Reuther, president of the C. I. O., said today that he would not go into politics but would stay in the labor movement "where my heart is." He declared, however, that if unity of the labor movement was achieved, "whether I am a part of the leadership is very unimportant.''

For today's column we dip into the reader mail bag. First letter to come to hand is from French-born Jean Arabo, who writes from his wine shop on Madison Avenue about something closely allied to wine -- that is, vinegar. (The root of the word is vin aigre, French for sour wine.)

IMPHAL, India, March 29 -- A classic boat race between a god and a king was re-enacted today on the broad half-mile-long moat of the Maharajah of Manipur's palace to demonstrate for two visiting Prime Ministers that spiritual power still prevailed over temporal rule.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., March 29 -- Because of the special problems confronting American industry in its steadily increasing use of radioisotopes as research tools for improving quality and lowering costs, the Oak Ridge Institute of Nuclear Studies has scheduled its first symposium for management personnel.

Keith R. J. Homer, vice president and general manager of the Ciba Company, Ltd., Montreal, has been named executive vice president of Ciba Company, Inc., a new post, with headquarters in New York City. William H. Kieffer, for the last three years assistant to the president of Ciba Company, Inc., has been appointed general sales manager. Samuel I. Parker, whom he succeeds, will have other administrative responsibilities.

SEOUL, Korea, March 29 (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. Glenn O. Barcus, commenting on the current air war against the Communist supply lines, remarked last night, "I regret to - say it hasn't stopped the flow of supplies to the front."

CLIFTON, N. J., March 29 -- A business man who had sat through the night at the wheel of a parked car in which lay the body of his 5-year-old son told the police today he had killed the child with a single shot because he could "not stand to see him suffer any longer" from cerebral palsy.

PITTSBURGH, March 29 -- Momentum alone is going to carry the steel industry into the second quarter at record-breaking levels. Behind that momentum are demand factors which have been stronger than generally anticipated.
Straus' "Fledermaus" on Monday evening, April 6, will open the twenty-second and last week of the Metropolitan Opera season.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (UP) -- Theron Lamar Caudle, former Assistant Attorney General, said today he had granted a 1950 conference to Garry D. Iozia, tax evader, at the request of David K. Niles, one of President Truman's advisers.
A dress under a short bolero and jacket is the perfect answer to the problem of a double duty costume for women who lead busy lives and find it inconvenient to go home to change their clothes.
The half-mile-long circus train with its blazing red and blue cages and silver-hued cars glistened in the sunlight in the Mott Haven railroad yards up in the Bronx early yesterday morning.

In a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 8 Zachary De Gaster clearly sets forth the proper view of pending affairs in Moscow. At one point, however, he dismisses with one sentence what appears, to me at any rate, one pillar of hope for the West.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Senator Hugh Butler, Republican of Nebraska, said today that a questionnaire he had sent to 15,000 business and industrial leaders showed strong interest in a study looking to a return of this country to the gold standard.

Once more the interlocking character of the areas of tension in the Far East has been emphasized. The joint communique summarizing the just concluded French-American conversations not only pointed out that Communist aggression, whether in Korea or Indo-China, was part of the same pattern.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (UP) -- The Justice Department has cut 4 per cent from its budget as proposed by former President Truman, but has left untouched funds for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

This country's attempts to produce an absolutely fair plan of military service haven't fully succeeded yet. Nor does the existing system guarantee us the exact number of soldiers we need at the exact time we need them. Exemptions for fathers, students and various occupations may have been pushed too far.

All of the works that figured on the orchestral program conducted by Leonard Bernstein in Town Hall yesterday afternoon were commissioned by the Koussevitzky Music Foundation in the Library of Congress and Koussevitzky Foundation, Inc., and were heard for the first time in this city.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 22 -- The Belgian Congo, deep in Africa, is making rapid progress on a strategic railway line that could be of the greatest importance if the situation in Egypt should result in the loss of the Suez Canal base to the West, Latest reports from the Congo indicate that the Belgians are pushing ahead with their construction job.

The two-story taxpayer building at 184,96 East 161st Street, also known as 871 Sheridan Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Morris A. and Charles Pomeranz to a group of investors represented by Netter Netter, lawyers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 29 -- While East-West commerce has shrunk to one-half or less of pre-war volume, trade between Communist China and Eastern European countries virtually doubled between 1948 and 1952. Within Eastern Europe the exchange of goods has tripled.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29 -- Remove the palm trees, take the beautiful bay from the background, change the date, reduce the temperature thirty degrees and Al Lang Field might have been Ebbets Field or the Yankee Stadium today.
TOKYO, Monday, March 30 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,569, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Monday, Korean time:
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -A two-part plan to overhaul the Panama Canal in the next ten years to enable it to handle more ships was announced today.

CAIRO, March 29 -- British-Egyptian negotiations on the Egyptian demand that the British evacuate the huge military base in the Suez Canal Zone will begin in the next few days, according to a usually reliable intimate of Egyptian Government circles who reported the gist of a conversation held yesterday between the Egyptian Premier, Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, and the British Minister of State, Selwyn Lloyd.

BOSTON, March 29 (UP) -- Lanky Jack McIntyre staged a dash from center ice tonight to back-hand a shot 25 feet into the Detroit net and give Boston a 2-1 victory in overtime play and a 2-1 game edge in their best-of-seven National Hockey League Stanley Cup semifinal series.

As a result of the "stretch-out" policy of the Department of Defense for tank production, the American Locomotive Company's contract for combat tanks was reduced by approximately $397,000,000 in the latter part of 1952. D. W. Fraser, chairman, told stockholders in the annual report to be issued today.

Three outstanding art exhibitions are among the thirty or more scheduled for this week. One is the large retrospective of work by the veteran French painter, Georges Rouault, opening at the Museum of Modern Art on Wednesday.

CHICAGO, March 29 (AP) -- Champion Jodo Von Liebestraum, a 3-year-old German shepherd, was named best-in-show in the International Kennel Club all-breed exhibition tonight. He beat 2,199 dogs front thirty-six states and Canada.

A working woman living with her family in this city in September, 1952, needed to earn $47.23 a week, or $2,456 a year, to support herself adequately, according to a State Labor Department survey released yesterday.

PINKHAM NOTCH, N. H., March 29 -Egil Stigum, Dartmouth's Norwegian freshman from Oslo, twice roared through a 33 gate course near the timberline of Mount Washington today to outscore a field of sixty-two for the men's United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association slalom championship.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (UP) -- Officials of the Department of Agriculture have discovered that they may have as much as 362,000 pounds of spoiled turkey meat, part of a surplus acquired for the school lunch program.

In the first step of a broad program to curb crime in the city's parks, particularly muggings, Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan has established a new, permanent ten-man detective detail for Central Park.

George Gershwin's "135th Street," an operetta written by the composer at the age of 22, had its first local production yesterday on the "Omnibus" television program over C.B.S. (Channel 2). As an interesting sidelight on Mr. Gershwin's career, the operetta undoubtedly had a certain curiosity value, but otherwise the work proved most ordinary and pedestrian.

Ever since Stalin's death the world has been been watching the Kremlin for the slightest hint of changes in Soviet policy. "What will happen when Stalin goes?" was the question in the back of the minds of most people on the earth -- those who inhabited his vast domain and those outside whose life has been conditioned by uncertainty as to his decisions.

CANNES, France, March 29 (UP) -- Bernard Bartzen, America's eleventh ranked tennis player, won the men's singles final at the international tournament today by defeating Sven Davidsson, Swedish Davis Cup star, 6 -- 2, 6 - 4, 7 -- 5.

The Sun Oil Company expects to spend about $130,000,000 this year to modernize and expand its facilities and to search for new sources of oil, according to the company's pamphlet report for 1952, released today. This would be $18,400,000 more than the $111,620,000 spent for such purposes in 1952.

PARIS, March 29 -- Certain new contacts between Egypt and Israel, still formally at war, have recently taken place with a possible and ultimate view to starting peace negotiations. To date, however, it is impossible to forecast whether these very secret soundings will provide any basis for new talks.

Some years ago somebody wrote "Five Acres and Independence" and blisters and sunburned necks burgeoned along the outer edges of Suburbia. Now "Industries for Small Communities."* a new book by Arthur E. Morgan, former president of Antioch College, has the same inspirational, why-not-do-it-now feeling about it.

BOSTON, March 29 -- The New York Knickerbockers fought back from a 14-point first-half deficit to defeat the Boston Celtics, 82--75, in the Boston Garden today before a capacity crowd of 13,909. The victory enabled the New Yorkers to win the final play-off series of the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association, 3 games to 1.

A "jury" of Fordham University students ended an "interracial hearing" yesterday afternoon by bringing in a series of findings that called for the enactment of Federal, state and municipal legislation to assure Negroes of nondiscriminatory treatment throughout the country.

Cotton prices in the domestic market held to a narrow trading range last week. Closing prices on the New York Cotton Exchange in active futures were off 5 points to up 7 points, or 25 cents lower to 35 cents higher a bale. The near-by deliveries showed the only declines.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public, which will mature within twelve months, amount to $73,374,919,149. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

Mrs. N. Penrose (Margaret Bowditch) Hallowell, who died a few days ago, was a rare personality. She was a true Bostonian, a descendant of Nathaniel Bowditch, the famous author of the "Practical Navigator." Happily for us, the Hallowells have lived in New York for the last thirty years.

The 423 charitable hospital, health and welfare agencies depending in part on the Greater New York Fund to meet their expenses suffered an apparent over-all deficit of $3,130,000 last year, even though the central money-raising organization received a record total of $6,132,699 in gifts and pledges.
When Comdr. Frederick K. Arzt takes over his new job here as senior merchant marine investigating officer for the Coast Guard today he will be able to throw his own book at offending mariners.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 29 -The Brazilian Government is facing a serious showdown tomorrow with merchant marine officers and with Rio de Janeiro longshoremen. The ship's officers are threatening a strike that would paralyze all Brazilian shipping and, if successful, would cause a serious crisis in food distribution.

BONN, Germany, March 29 -German politicians have been impressed by a recent survey of political preference in the Federal Republic which showed that Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Christian Democratic Union and the Social Democratic party today represent the political choice of a little more than two-thirds of the German voters.
Net income of the Pepsi-Cola Company last year increased to $3,880,362 from $2,632,181 in 1951, according to the annual report of Alfred N. Steel, president, released today.

An overwhelming air of lavishness and luxury keynotes "Decoration 1953," the display of decorative arts on view at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The settings arranged for it by the decorative trades, in conjunction with the twenty-second annual conference of the American Institute of Decorators, would seem to indicate that restraint and simplicity -- with few exceptions -- have been eliminated from the working vocabulary of the interior decorator.

Some students and teachers of English have been mildly disturbed by news from up Ithaca way suggesting that the American Council of Learned Societies somehow is party to a scheme to teach foreigners to speak English on the level of "cuppa coffee," "gonna," "useta" and "samore.

LOVE is not only the most interesting of human emotions; it is also the most various. One of the greatest abstract concepts, it can no more be defined than beauty or poetry or freedom. But if we try to limit its meaning, excluding lust and greed and the fashionable psychological abnormalities, we find that love ought at least to have some connection with spontaneous joy and with sincere concern for the welfare of another.

CHICAGO, March 29 (UP) -- Al Dewsbury blasted a 40-foot screen shot past Gerry McNeil into the Montreal net at 5:18 of a "sudden-death" overtime period tonight to give the Chicago Black Hawks their first Stanley Cup semi-final play-off victory in three games over the Canadiens, 2 -- 1, before 16,114 fans at Chicago Stadium.

Stockholders of the Kentucky Utilities Company are being offered 208,057 additional shares of common stock at $18.50 a share through exercise of rights in the ratio of one new share for each ten held. When the subscription period terminates on April 13 an underwriting group headed jointly by Blyth Co., Inc., and J. J. B. Hilliard Son will buy any un-subscribed shares.

The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad last year had a net income of $11,262,693, equal after appropriations for sinking funds and preferred dividend requirements to $2.32 each on the 2,123,214 common shares outstanding, according to the pamphlet report for 1952.

PARIS, March 29 -- What the semi-official French News Agency calls "authorized circles" do not come up to their normal standards of articulateness on Sundays. Anyhow, those circles are somewhat depleted while Premier Rene Mayer and three Cabinet colleagues are in North America.

CHICAGO, March 29 -- Choppy fluctuations within a moderate range were the rule on the Board of Trade last week. For most of the week there was a heavier tone. The free marketing of Government corn exerted a bearish influence.

PARIS, March 29 -- The index for industrial production in France for February has been announced at between 140 and 141 on basis of 100 for 1938. This is a drop of 6 or 7 per cent as compared with February, 1952.

Title to the Brady Building, a twenty-three-story office building at 90 West Street and 140 Cedar Street, has been taken in the name of Cedarwest Properties, Inc., representing Dubowski Associates of Jersey City, N. J., who bought the property recently from Louis Schleifer.

GUATEMALA, March 29 (UP) -- Rebel forces seized control of the provincial city of Salama, 100 miles from this capital city, for eighteen hours today but were routed by Government ground and air forces, the Army announced tonight. Two rebels were killed and sixteen wounded.

The troupe's first "Boheme" of the season was offered Saturday evening, with Frances Yeend as Mimi, Rudolf Petrak as Rodolfo, Jean Fenn, a newcomer to the company, making her debut as Musetta, and Norman Treigle, another debutant, as Colline.

To a whole generation of American sport-lovers "the greatest athlete of them all" is gone with the passing of Jim Thorpe. Most, if not all, of his track and field records have since been surpassed, but no one has equaled the hold that he had on the imagination of all who saw him in action.

The prospect that Governor Dewey's influence with the Administration of President Eisenhower may be put to a severe test came yesterday when it became known that Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. of the House of Representatives had said that Leonard W. Hall, Surrogate of Nassau County, "does not need local endorsement" to be elected chairman of the Republican National Committee in place of C. Wesley Roberts.

There's treasure of purest yellow gold hiding these early spring days amid the dead leaves and grasses of untrammeled woodlands. It's the coltsfoot, which, more often than not, out-rivals even the popular hepatica as the new season's traditional first wild flower.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 29 -A "sick" shipping industry in San Francisco Bay, after a diagnosis on which the "doctors" spent six months, was declared today to be suffering from a malignancy described as lack of cooperation between unions and employers "almost unequaled in American industry."
LARCHMONT, N. Y., March 29 -- Twenty -five sailing dinghies were out today off the Larchmont Yacht Club and took part in eight races.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 29 (AP) -- Vic Seixas, Philadelphia, defeated Art Larsen, San Leandro, Calif., in the final of the Everglades invitation tennis tournament today. 5 -- 7, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1.

HONOLULU, March 29 (AP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman, arriving with his family on the liner President Cleveland for a month's vacation, said today, "I think there is a prospect that we will have peace."

NEW ORLEANS, March 29 (AP) -- Patty Berg of St. Andrews, Ill., overcame a wrist ailment to shoot par golf and take a one-stroke second-round lead today in the $3,500 New Orleans Women's Open Golf Tournament.

Aluminium, Ltd., big Canadian aluminum-maker, shared in the industry's substantial expansion achievements last year by attaining the largest production and sales of aluminum products in the company's twenty-five-year history, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

TOKYO, Monday, March 30 -Artillerymen of the United States First Marine Division drove off Chinese Communist infantry who twice during the night surrounded the embattled Marine outpost of "Vegas" on the western Korean front.

IMPHAL, India, March 29 -- Prime Minister U Nu of Burma said today he hoped the United Nations would instruct the Formosa Government to order Nationalist Chinese forces in North Burma to surrender their arms and submit to internment.

YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, March 29 -- Some day-dreaming in children was to be desired, Dr. Boyd McCandless, director of the Child Welfare Research Station, University of Ohio, told several hundred members of the Society for Research in Child Development this week-end.

ALMA, Israel, March 29 -- Few Israelis will celebrate the Seder tomorrow night with more enthusiasm than "the Jews of San Nicandro," who have found their portion of the Promised Land here in the mountains of Galilee.

The alternating occupancy of first place between Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia and Miguel Najdorf of Argentina was halted yesterday when they met in the twelfth round of the international chess tournament at Mar del Plata, according to a report from Buenos Aires.

The Savings Banks Association of the State of New York which is conducting an intensified public information campaign, today announced appointment of two new executives. John R. Meekin, who has been with the association since 1948, has been named secretary of the Committee on Public Information, and Edward L. Stamm, formerly of the Manufacturers Trust Company, has been appointed secretary of the Subcommittee on Promotional Activities.
Hope and not fear should be stressed in fighting cancer, 450 volunteer workers were told yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the New York City Cancer Committee at the Astor Hotel.

In 1929 Oswald Jacoby, then a promising young bridge expert, outpointed a small but select field to win the first contract bridge tournament ever held in this country -- the Eastern States Open Pair championship. The 1929 Eastern, with only a few events, attracted a handful of contestants.

Complete revision of the city's governmental structure and management methods, coupled with a "belt-tightening" economy program, was recommended yesterday by the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey in a general statement announcing that its final report would be made public in eight installments, starting today.
Your R. F. C. editorial of March 24 touches off wrongfully, I believe, a timely issue.

LARGO, Fla., March 29 -- A fierce, pre-dawn fire today destroyed a rambling, one - story frame nursing home here, and hours afterward the police counted thirty-three bodies in the debris. All were burned beyond recognition.
Opposition to a fare increase to help the city meet its transit deficit was expressed yesterday by Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O.

April 29 has been designated by producers Ben Tomkins and Alvin Cooperman as the opening date for their "Masquerade" at the Alvin. With a cast headed by Veronica Lake, Charles Korvin and Lisa Ferraday, the romantic comedy by L. S. Birchard and Jeroam Stagg will receive tune-up performances in Springfield and Philadelphia, beginning April 9 and 13, respectively.

One of the least popular features of the New Deal's farm program was the restrictions placed on the acreages farmers could plant. Such restrictions became largely memories during the past decade of high demand and good farm prices. Now, however, the term "acreage restrictions" comes up ever more often in farm policy discussions.

PITTSBURGH, March 29 (AP) -- The Harmarville Hurricanes won the Eastern Division final of the National Challenge Cup soccer series by defeating the New York Americans, 2 -- 1, at Freeport Road Field today.

HARTFORD, March 29 -- Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce of Ridgefield, United States Ambassador to Italy, will be honored by Connecticut Republicans at a "Godspeed" testimonial dinner in the Ritz ballroom in Bridgeport on April 10, a few days before she leaves for Rome.

A new novel by Rosamond Lehmann, her first in eight years, has been scheduled for May 7 publication by Harcourt, Brace, entitled "The Echoing Grove." Moving backward and forward in time, the story deals with the love of two sisters for the same man.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- President Eisenhower received "a respectful suggestion" today to give Congress and the nation personally an "inventory" on Russian military and atomic strength and American defenses.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 29 -- The principal organizations of the South African labor movement issued over the weekend a declaration that labor and union organization on a racial basis must be abandoned.

Six small children, trapped by fire in the third-story back bedroom of a Canarsie tenement, were rescued yesterday morning by two neighbors who responded to cries for help by the mother. She had been unable to battle her way to them past the flames from an oil burner that had exploded in the kitchen of the flat at 912 Rockaway Avenue, Brooklyn.

NEWARK, March 29 -- Secretary of Labor Martin Durkin received tonight the annual Rerum Novarum award made by the School of Business Administration of St. Peter's College of Jersey City. The plaque, presented at a dinner in the Essex House Hotel, cited the Secretary for his "contribution to the welfare of the working man."

Two thousand worshippers at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine heard Dean James A. Pike, in a Palm Sunday sermon, praise the courage of clergymen throughout the world who suffer unfair criticism, prejudice and smears with the dignity and steadfastness that Christ bore His crushing burden to the site of the Crucifixion.

Fifty years ago on March 30, 1903, the Bankers Trust Company was formed. Today, with total resources in excess of $2,000,000,000, and operating seventeen offices throughout Greater New York, Bankers Trust is the eighth largest commercial bank in the United States.
Six new films, including imports from England, Italy and Germany, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

GREENSBORO, N. C., March 29 (AP) -- The $10,000 Greensboro open golf tournament ended in a four-way tie for top money of $2,000 today, with Sam Snead, Doug Ford, Art Wall and Earl Stewart Jr. at 275, five under par. They will meet tomorrow afternoon in an 18-hole play-off.

The three-year labors of the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey, to find out what is wrong with the city government, are completed and the publication of its findings and recommendations, released in nine installments, begins today. The survey summoned for fact-finding jobs some of the top management experts of the country.

As a result of a sweeping reorganization, the American National Theatre and Academy, a non-profit group that holds a Congressional charter, granted in 1935, has elected a new board, one "more truly representative of the geographical and theatre interests of its membership."

PHILADELPHIA, March 29 -- A glittering half-million dollar array of gems was the center of attraction today as jewelry experts from the United States and Canada gathered for the eighteenth annual meeting of the American Gem Society.

The trade that Stavros Livanos, Greek shipowner, has promised Senator Joseph R. McCarthy he will Break off with Communist China is a small one under charter, and all outbound, Mr. Livanos' attorney, Donald D. Geary of 120 Broadway said yesterday.

HANOI, Vietnam, March 29 -- A lively miltary chess game is going on in the lower sector of North Vietnam's Red River Delta and in the highlands of eastern Laos. The thinly populated kingdom of Laos is the northwesternmost of Indo-China's three Associated States. The others are Vietnam and Cambodia.

Mayor Ernst Reuter of West Berlin said yesterday that recent peace overtures by the Soviet Union indicated a slight possibility of improvement in East-West relations. He added that he was going to test the sincerity of the Communists on his return to Berlin by again asking for free elections in the four sectors of the city.

Little pulses will quicken and many an adult heart will drum a staccato beat this week. Visions of fluffy cotton candy, colored balloons, feats and freaks will dance in many a head. The blare of brass bands, the labored breathing of calliopes, the snarls of caged tigers and the intonation of the ringmaster's "Ladies and Gentlemen" will play on the eardrums.

Five persons, including two children, were injured yesterday when a bus and automobile crashed at Schenectady Avenue and Avenue N, Brooklyn. The auto was so badly smashed that the doors had to be burned open with acetylene torches to remove the injured.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The first survey on a broad scale of technical assistance given to foreign countries by public and private agencies has been undertaken by the National Planning Association in Latin America.
AMSTERDAM, March 29 -- Despite the impact of flood damage on the Netherlands' finances, the Government, in carrying out its declared policy, has announced some fiscal relaxations for trade.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 29 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is planning to film in the late fall, very likely in a wide-screen process, large-scale color production based on the granting of the Magna Charta by King John at Runnymede in 1215.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., March 29 -- Four members of a family living in a rural section of Dutchess County were burned to death early today in a fire that destroyed their seven-room frame dwelling.

SPRING VALLEY, March 30 -Under state law, Frank M. Eckerson, village clerk here for twenty years, will be too old to continue his job next April 6 when the new fiscal year begins. So the 72-year-old official is retiring to work full time in his, blacksmith shop.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Eisenhower Administration was in the midst of another dispute with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, tonight -this time over the Senator's assertion that he had negotiated an agreement with Greek shipowners that should reduce the shipment of supplies to Communist China by 10 to 45 per cent.

CHICAGO, March 29 (AP) -- Frank Santore, 35-year-old Brooklyn bowling instructor, today took over top spots in the singles and all- events classifications at the American Bowling Congress tournament with tallies of 749 in the singles and 1,994 in the all-events.

LONDON, March 29 -- Some members of the mother of Parliaments are finding the cost of belonging to the "most exclusive club in the world" more than they are willing to pay. About a score of M. P.'s from both the Conservative and the Labor parties already have announced that they will not run for re-election, many of them explaining that they can not live on the 1,000 ($2,800) a year they receive.

I wonder how many readers of THE TIMES have sensed the direct parallel between the arguments advanced in Frederic Mills' letter advocating the commercial development of the Olympic National Park and those raised in support of similar development of the New York State Forest Preserve.

THE danger in writing about Jim Thorpe is that the chronicler finds himself losing all restraint in an unavoidable tangle of superlatives. Yet there is almost no other way to describe the man and still do justice to him. Let's start with a few facts.
LONDON, Tuesday, March 31 -- Early this morning Britons still were lining up to pay a last tribute to Queen Mary as she lay in state in historic Westminster Hall.
BOSTON, March 30 -- Two masked gunmen invaded a family Passover dinner here tonight, shot and killed one man and seriously wounded two others.

NEWARK, March 30 -- Another attempt to settle the Telephone Workers Union strike against the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company will be made tomorrow, beginning at 10 A. M., in the office of the New Jersey Mediation Board, 1060 Broad Street.

PROBABLY no one was more surprised than the impatient surfcaster who hauled a 56 1/2-pound channel bass from the surf at Hatteras, N. C., on Friday, and most of the fish prophets from Big Kinnikeet to Buxton are drawling: "I told you they'd be early."

American business, through the Advertising Council, will launch its eleventh national ad campaign tomorrow to help conserve the country's forest resources. R. Z. Eller of Sunkist Growers, Inc., will again serve as volunteer coordinator.

The first two games of the National Basketball Association championship play-offs will be held in Minneapolis Saturday and Sunday, the following three in New York's Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory if the Lakers eliminate Fort Wayne. Maurice Podoloff, N. B. A. president, made the tentative dates public yesterday.
LONDON, March 30 -- "Encouraging" was the word used in Whitehall today to describe Communist China's new proposal on the repatriation of Korean war prisoners.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Foes of the bill to give the states a quitclaim to oil-rich lands beneath the marginal seas charged in the House of Representatives today that the proposal was part of an attempt "to put everything Uncle Sam owns on the auction block."

LONDON, March 30 -- The British Government's Economic Survey for 1953, published today, looked back upon the last year with modest satisfaction but visualized future prospects as far from rosy. Only by producing more and selling a greater volume of exports can Britain maintain her living standards, the Treasury warned.

The volume and value of waterborne foreign commerce shipped through the port of New York in 1952 declined more sharply than that of the nation's foreign waterborne commercial trade, an analysis of official trade statistics showed yesterday.

LONDON, March 30 -- From the Humber to Kent along Britain's east coast 800 miles of battered seawalls and tidal river dikes must be rebuilt or strengthened to make this island secure against the sea. The question that faces the nation is: "How much security at what price?"

ALLAMUCHY, N. J., March 30 -- Big-hatted men from Texas and Oklahoma joined canny Aberdeen-Angus breeders from twenty-six other states and Canada here today in buying fifty-five head of cattle for an average price of $2,143 at the first auction on the estate of Clendenin Ryan.
ALBANY, March 30 -- Following is the text of the memorandum released today by Governor Dewey with his approval of the State Administration's rent control bill:

The Freedoms Foundation 1952 awards were presented yesterday afternoon to New York City recipients who were among the 800 individuals and organizations to receive the organization's annual cash prizes and medals.
Net income of the Arkansas Natural Gas Corporation and subsidiaries last year was $10,796,996, equal to $1.25 a common share, compared with $11,141,122, or $1.29, earned in 1951.

Aluminium, Ltd., Canadian producer, announced yesterday that it had registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission a new issue of 818,657 shares of stock intended for offering to stockholders at the rate of one share for each ten shares held.

The consulting engineering firm of Ammann Whitney, 76 Ninth Avenue and Milwaukee, announced at its local office yesterday that it had received word that James S. Whitney, 31-year-old associate partner in the firm, was believed to have been drowned last Friday at Nassau, the Bahamas.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Bureau of Federal Investigation, has told Congress Communists have gone underground, broken up into small cells of five persons each and were running their own loyalty checks.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 30 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander, told his international military commanders at North Atlantic Treaty Organization headquarters here today "we must continue unremittingly to seek from our Governments the means required to accomplish these missions which they have given us."

GARDEN CITY, L. I., March 30 -- As a child grows, his area of interest widens. First, he is concerned with family and home, then with school, village, county, state, nation and the world. This is the message brought to parents in a new publication, "Social Studies in the Elementary Schools," just published by the Board of Education here.

Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet promoted eighty-seven officers and appointed forty probationary firemen yesterday to bring the department to within 400 of its authorized strength of 11,266 for all ranks.

The principal organizations of the South African labor movement which have adopted a declaration that labor and union organization on a racial basis must be abandoned have taken a courageous stand. The South African Federation of Trade Unions and the South African Trade and Labor Council, in conjunction with several subsidiary organizations, maintain that union membership should be open to all, "irrespective of race or color."

GENEVA, March 30 -- Enough of the outlines of a coordinated policy for economic relations among members of the Western community of nations is now known to European Governments to give for the first time in many years a definite sense of direction to those charged with responsibility in this troublesome field.

TRENTON, March 30 -- Motorists of New Jersey received a last warning today that enforcement of the state's new motor vehicle se;i curity measures would begin promptly and energetically Wednesday. Five laws designed to meet the problem of the uninsured and financially irresponsible motorist were passed by the Legislature last year.

A site at the foot of Manor Road, fronting 275 feet on Fort Pond, in Montauk, L. I., has been purchased by the Venture Air Service for improvement with a motel and a seaplane base. Mrs. Andrew M. Kenyon of New York was the seller and Alan A. Stevenson was the broker.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Prof. Owen Lattimore renewed his attack on the Government's seven-count perjury indictment against him today by raising the question of freedom of the press.

When March goes out tonight, a soggy lamb, it will carry a rainfall record with it. Gauges on the Weather Bureau roof showed at 4:21 P. M. yesterday a total for the month of 7.91 inches, the wettest March in the bureau's eighty-two official years.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- John L. Pratt -- 72-year-old retired executive of the General Motors Corporation, who is alleged by the Government to have been an "enforcer" of du Pont policy at General Motors -- said today at the du Pont anti-trust trial that he knew of no conspiracy to favor E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., in buying supplies.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The creation of a commission to realign Federal, state and local government relationships, especially to eliminate duplication and waste in mutual programs, was proposed by President Eisenh0wer today.

The Communist chieftains, who have adopted treachery and deceit as weapons of their psychological warfare against free peoples, have so often tricked and disappointed the world with cunning proposals made in the name of peace that any new declaration from their side is bound to be regarded with great skepticism.

ROME, March 30 -- An overwhelming display of police strength quashed Communist attempts today to foment riots as a protest against the Senate's adoption yesterday of the Government's electoral reform bill. Policemen and carabinieri, in full battle kit and equipped with armored cars, tanks and jeeps, so overawed the would-be rioters throughout Italy that forceful intervention was seldom required and the incidents that did occur were comparatively few and slight.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- The revival of peace rumors, based on intimations that armistice talks possibly would be resumed with what seemed to be more amicable disposition on the part of Red leaders, sent grain futures into a tail spin today.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Navy disclosed today that a jet-propelled guided missile known as the Regulus and carrying a "powerful warhead" had been put into production, and that one of its submarines had been equipped to launch the weapon against ship or shore targets.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 30 (AP) -- Archie Moore, light heavyweight champion, scored a ninth-round victory over Frank Buford, Oakland heavyweight, in a scheduled ten-round non-title bout tonight. Moore, from San Diego, weighed 180 pounds and Buford 200.

Production by the Republic Aviation Corporation of the F-84G Thunderjet, a fighter plane now in Korean service, will be halted in June, Mundy I. Peale, president of the concern, disclosed yesterday. At that time, he said, Republic will concentrate on its new F-84F Thunderstreak, a much faster and otherwise superior jet fighter that is just getting into quantity production.

Of all of the business practices of New York's government, none is so "shockingly wasteful" as "the systematic neglect of maintenance" of plant, resources and property, the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey reported yesterday to Mayor Impellitteri.

Tight nation-wide manpower controls are necessary to all-out mobilization, Comdr. John W. Seager, United States Navy, told 400 military and civilian leaders yesterday at an Economic Mobilization Course at the Astor Hotel.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 30 -- Six persons were injured in a spectacular fire that swept the $1,000,000 Strand Hotel on the Boardwalk here this afternoon.

Food packaging has taken on a diversity of faces in the last decade. Ever since grocers gave the old cracker barrel the heave-ho, manufacturers have beer parading their wares in new guises. The increase in self-service super markets is a factor in this trend as are the new developments in the science of food preservation.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Julius and Ethel Rosenberg filed a third appeal asking the Supreme Court to save them from execution as atom spies.

The Association of American Universities declared yesterday that full academic freedom must be guaranteed to professors and scholars, but it should not include the right to membership in the Communist party.

Gordie Howe of the Detroit Red Wings was named the National Hockey League's player of the year for the second straight season yesterday in a United Press poll of sports writers in the six league cities.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 30 -- France charged today that staff policies under Secretary General Trygve Lie had precipitated an "internal crisis" within the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Senator Eugene D. Millikin of Colorado, ordinarily the most silent member of the Senate Republican leadership, denounced from the floor today "gross abuses" of the rights of citizens through unfounded Senatorial denunciations.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- A dock union leader testified today that Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City used his waterfront police to block men from shipping Army goods overseas during a warehousemen's strike last June.

Establishment of a state agency to administer waterfront employment centers and license pier workers ,was recommended yesterday by the City Club in a report to Governor Dewey and the State Crime Commission. Walter M. Weis, club president, requested in a letter to the Governor that legislation to create such an agency be passed at the special session of the Legislature in May.

TRENTON, March 30 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court upheld today the 1951 indictment of Walter G. Winne and ordered the superseded prosecutor of Bergen County to stand trial on nineteen counts charging him with criminal nonfeasance in office.

Ballots for voting on a new two-year contract negotiated last week between the independent Port Watchmen's Union in the Port of New York and the New York Shipping Association will be in the mail by Thursday, Samuel Nathan, union president, said yesterday. The-vote will be tallied on April 8.

When the Washington staff of this newspaper asked the appropriate authorities for enlightenment Sunday in the matter of Senator McCarthy's operation with Greek shipowners in his new capacity of roving, unofficial Secretary of State, the authorities did not hesitate to assail the importance, validity and propriety of the McCarthy-Greek compact.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., March 30 -- Declaring that the fight against infantile paralysis had progressed to the "very threshold of victory," Basil O'Connor, president of the Georgia Warm Springs Foundation, announced today that construction had begun here on a new $600,000 rehabilitation building to be known as Roosevelt Hall.
TRENTON, March 30 -- The State Senate, inactive since it reconvened March 16 after a four-week recess, acted today on three important matters, two of them controversial.

JOHANNESBURG South Africa, March 30 -- Johannes G. Strydom, Minister of Lands, head of the most important of the four sections of the ruling Nationalist party and possible successor to Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan, has given a new warning that "there will be no place in South Africa for whites" who do not follow the Nationalist policy of strict racial segregation.

Robert L. Joseph is in the midst of negotiations for the American stage rights to Jean Anouilh's three-act romantic comedy, "Colombe." If the deal is made, the producer intends to introduce it to Broadway theatregoers early next fall.

Long Island Sound's full schedule of yacht racing for the coming summer was adopted last night at a meeting of the Yacht Racing Association in the New York Yacht Club. It cimprises thirty-six regattas, the first on May 23 and the final on Sept. 20.
ALBANY, March 30 -- The new residential rent control bill, permitting increases up to 15 per cent for 835,000 to 1,000,000 tenants in the state, was approved today by Governor Dewey.

General expectations concerning the outcome of the important encounter between Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia and Miguel Najdorf of Argentina, adjourned from the twelfth round of the international chess masters tournament at Mar Del Plata, were fulfilled yesterday when Najdorf resigned after 48 moves had been recorded, according to a report from Buenos Aires.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 30 (AP) -- Jockey Charlie Burr, 19-year-old rider from Arkansas City, Kan., today rode in six races at Gulfstream Park and brought in winners every time.
Staten Island railroad commuters will be riding the short lines from Arlington and South Beach to the St. George ferry terminal for the last time today.

" War babies," unsettled by new Communist peace feelers on Korea, led stock prices downward yesterday in the widest one-day break since October, 1951. Except for a few oils with special situations and for the public utilities, virtually the entire market went on the toboggan. Prices were shaved 1 to 3 points and ended near the lows.

The 1953 Red Cross Fund Campaign, which is seeking for raise $7,000,000 in the city toward the national goal of $93,000,000 will be extended to April 15, Albert C. Simmonds Jr., general chairman of the appeal, announced yesterday. The drive was to have ended today.

The "Four Star Playhouse," a filmed dramatic program presented over the C. B. S. network on alternate Thursdays, will be televised each Thursday from 8:30 to 9 P. M. beginning Sept. 24. It will continue under the sponsorship of Singer Sewing Machine Company.

The General Dynamics Corporation, which in April, 1952, acquired the assets and business of the Electric Boat Company, has contracted to buy 400,000 shares, approximately 17 per cent of the common stock, of the Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation from the Atlas Corporation, an investment company, it was announced yesterday by John Jay Hopkins, chairman and president of General Dynamics, and Floyd B. Odlum, president of Atlas.

The New World, with the Atlantic as a moat, has in time past been little scathed by the upheavals of the Old. How different is the case of the countries of Europe which have so often felt the nailed fist of Prussia and have learned to have a deep distrust of things German.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 30 -- Lester B. Pearson of Canada, President of the United Nations General Assembly, said today that Communist China's offer concerning Korean prisoners of war was "very important," and added that it "obviously should be followed up."

Simplicity of line and a balance of proportions characterizes a new collection of Directoire-inspired furniture, which, with a new group of lamps, is now on view at the Cassard Romano Company, Inc., 305 East Sixty-third Street. The pieces are available through decorators.

EVANSTON, Ill., March 30 (AP) Northwestern's faculty athletic committee has voted unanimously against renewal of the Big Ten-Pacific Coast Rose Bowl pact, Faculty Representative F. George Seulberger revealed today.
The shows will go on, at Grand Central Palace, until the end of October, it was learned yesterday.

Today's single new feature at a first-run house is "Fear and Desire," at the Guild Theatre. The independently made war drama was produced, directed, photographed and edited by Stanley Kubrick. Howard O. Sackler wrote the screenplay.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Harold E. Stassen, Director for Mutual Security, told the Senate Investigations subcommittee today that secret negotiations by its staff under the direction of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy had hampered if not wholly undermined the efforts of the State and Defense Departments to stop shipments of materials that strengthened the enemy in Korea.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The State Department made public today a recent communication congratulating Ambassador Raymond Spruance in Manila for warning American citizens in the Philippines to maintain "absolute neutrality" in the coming elections there.

LONDON, March 30 -- Most prices moved narrowly and irregularly on the stock markets here today. The only discernible effect of the Communist overtures in Korea was some weakening in commodity prices and minor falls in the shares of base metal and rubber companies.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Walter Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, said today he believed President Eisenhower had a "moral obligation" to suggest specific changes in the Taft-Hartley labor law since he had advocated revisions during his election campaign.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The executive board of the International Longshoremen's Association reported today to George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, that it was making progress on the job of cleaning up the union, but Mr. Meany refused to say whether he thought the progress was satisfactory.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 30 -- Detroit, last in the American League in 1952 and a strong candidate to repeat this season, walloped four homers today and flattened the Yankees, 9 -- 5. Ray Scarborough was the victim of four-baggers by Matt Batts, Walt Dropo and Owen Friend, and Frank Carswell took liberties with a fat pitch by Bob Kuzava.
LOS ANGELES, March 30 -- Cotton exports from California ports have dropped by nearly 50 per cent this season, the Los Angeles Harbor Department reported over the week-end.
