THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 23 -- Reconstruction of the sea defenses in the southwestern Netherlands, shattered in the February floods, is now under way in earnest.

GREENSBORO, N. C., March 30 (AP) -- Earl Stewart Jr., 31-year-old Dallas redhead, won the Greensboro open golf tournament today with a par 4 on the nineteenth hole of a sudden-death play-off with Sam Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va. They had tied over eighteen holes with 2-under-par 68's.

In his last major theoretical treatise Stalin told the world in October that there are now two parallel international markets, one Communist and the other non-Communist. The new United Nations' report on world economy supplies the statistical detail to show the extent of integration among the economies of Sovietized nations.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 31 -- Communist China's Premier and Foreign Minister, Chou En-lai, proposed last night that the deadlock on a Korean armistice be settled by turning over to a neutral state all war prisoners who refuse to be repatriated to their own forces.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Sarah C. Caldwell, president of the National Education Association, told a tea time gathering of representatives of women's organizations today that the real danger to education was not Communist teachers but no teachers or poorly prepared teachers.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation achieved last year the highest earnings in its twenty-one-year history, on an 85 per cent increase in sales, despite taxes that were more than double those of 1951, according to the annual report of Robert E. Gross, president, issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The State Department reported today that Greece last week had become the sixth country, including the United States, to prohibit vessels flying its flag from calling at Communist China ports.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 30 -- The career of Cyd Charisse is a matter of top-most concern among the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer executive hierarchy and no efforts will prepared to establish her as an important star personality. Her dancing with Fred Astair in "The Bandwagon," previewed the other night, turned the trick.

UNITED NATION, N. Y., March 30 -- As joint sponsor with Venezuela of a resolution demanding rectification of what she termed a discriminatory attitude in the United Nations against employment of women in top posts, the Dominican-Republic, in the person of Senorita Minerva Bernardino, led off an unusually sharp discussion of the matter this afternoon in the Commission on the Status of Women.

Mayor Impellitteri and his Administration were accused last night by City Council President Rudolph Halley of resorting to the use of the "technique of the 'big lie' in an endeavor to obscure the facts" in dealing with Mr. Halley's proposals for balancing this city's budget.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- The Senate delayed action today on President Eisenhower's nomination of Harry H. Vaughan for an indefinite term as a major general in the Army Reserve.
Beginning tomorrow dried milk will become the third product subject to a complete import ban by this country. The others excluded are butter and peanuts.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The State Department has sent to the Polish Embassy in Washington an urgent request to stop distributing a booklet attacking the United States.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., March 30 -- Hess Brothers, Inc., elected two new directors today, the first additions to the directorate in twenty-one years. Max Hess Jr., 42-year-old president of the Allentown department store, made the announcement after the corporation's annual meeaing here.

Members of the Connecticut College Club of New York, of which Mrs. Edward L. Mertz is president, have taken over the performance of "My 3 Angels" on the night of April 13 at the Morosco Theatre for the benefit of the clubs' scholarship fund.

Nassau County's forty commercial banks are planning to establish the nation's first regional check clearing system "on wheels." The new system, scheduled to begin operation shortly, is designed to speed an annual collection volume of 18,750,000 checks worth $1,400,000,000.

Robert Christenberry, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, and George A. Barton and Abe J. Greene of the National Boxing Association agreed yesterday that the fifteen-round bout between Randy Turpin of England and France's Charles Humez in London could not be for the world middleweight championship.
TOKYO, Tuesday, March 31 (AP) -- The text of a statement Monday by Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China offering a new Korean armistice plan, as broadcast by the Peiping radio:

Last night's elaborate concert at Hunter College was a double benefit arranged by the Austrian consulate general for reconstruction of the Vienna Opera House and in behalf of the Margit Bokor Memorial Fund of Columbia University.

Record operating revenues were achieved by the Greyhound Corporation and subsidiaries in 1952, Orville S. Caesar, president, reported yesterday, in announcing last year's net income of $16,813,723, equal to $1.26 a common share. This compares with a net income of $16,953,684, or $1.27 a share, in 1951.

Teams of inspectors from the Department of Housing and Building and the Department of Health began listing yesterday all the violations they could find in the Harlem block bounded by St. Nicholas and Eighth Avenues and 118th and 119th Streets.

ROME, March 30 -- Final plans for creating a large center near Geneva for non-military nuclear research are under discussion in Rome by fifty-three scientists and officials representing twelve European countries, the Council of Europe and the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Charles E. Bohlen became the new United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union today in a private ceremony before John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, and ranking State Department officials.

The Nation's steel production has set new weekly records for four weeks in a row, and March output appears certain to top 10,000,000 tons for a historic new monthly high. The steel makers operated at an average of 103.1 per cent of rated capacity last week in turning out 2,324,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

For about a century the idea has gained ground among physicists that we ought to stop talking about "mass" and talk instead about the "field," which is a region of influence. A brick is therefore part of a field, a region. Einstein placed this conception on solid ground when he formulated his general theory of relativity.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- President Eisenhower discussed proposals for reducing foreign aid expenditures with Congressional leaders this morning.

The remodeled five-story apartment house at 60 West Ninety-sixth Street has been purchased by Herman Raphel and Morris Sloma from Dora Edid in a transaction negotiated by Joseph Hidalgo as broker. The property occupies a plot 20 by 100 feet.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Diplomatic officials here express themselves as unhappy over Burma's decision not to continue United States aid, and they do not see what can be done about it.

Rabbits, eggs and flowers, traditional motifs of the Easter theme, appear in a number of new guises that might delight adults as well as youngsters. Patterned material, accessories and toys are some of the items keyed to Easter.

HARTFORD, March 30 -- The State Highway Department has recommended to the Roads, Rivers and Bridges Committee of the Connecticut General Assembly the adoption of a $400,000,000 long-range program of expressway and thruway construction in the state.

BONN, Germany, March 30 -- The West German Government has resumed German cultural activity abroad through the medium of approximately 200 schools owned and operated by German educational societies and religious corporations in Western Europe and overseas.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Word went out today that the Administration's economy drive would eliminate about 270 jobs in the Labor Department and 750 in the Agriculture Department's Production and Marketing Administration.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Col. Royal N. Baker, leading United States jet fighter ace of the Korean war, called on President Eisenhower at the White House today.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Oswald Ryan, Chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, conceded today that there might have been a deliberate effort to conceal from him and other members of the board three years ago an important letter from the Defense Department on the need for trans-Atlantic air freight services.

WASHINGTON,, March 30 (AP) -- Representative Richard M. Simpson, Republican of Pennsylvania, introduced a bill today that would extend the Reciprocal Trade Act for one year, but would bar any lowering of tariffs to levels that "imperil" United States producers or workers.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Ancher Nelsen, Lieutenant Governor of Minnesota, was nominated by President Eisenhower today to be Administrator of the Rural Electrification Administration, an agency of the Department of Agriculture.

PARIS, March 30 -- A cut of about 10 per cent in France's imports from Western Europe and the sterling area will be made by a new policy the Government will put into effect Wednesday. It is planned to last for seven months.
Israel's first passenger ship to visit America will sail from here May 22 on a special voyage.

It has suddenly been brought out into the open that among the Mayor's economy measures to bail New York City out of its impossible financial situation the closing of all the Day Care Centers financed through the Department of Welfare is being contemplated.

MANILA, March 30 -- The political controversy that had embroiled the United States Embassy and threatened a demand for the recall of Ambassador Raymond A. Spruance, simmered down today into an exchange of statements to the press.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 30 -- Any idea that the Yugoslav Government is abandoning socialism in agriculture because collective farms were being discontinued was shattered today with publication of the text of the Federal Executive Council's decree permitting peasants to join Western-type cooperatives.
SARASOTA, Fla., March 30 (UP) -- Earle Combs, who picked up $72,000 in world series money alone, retired from baseball today and was replaced as a Boston Red Sox coach by Del Baker.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 30 -- Billy Loes and Glenn Mickens today combined to pitch the Dodgers to their fifth shut-out victory in eight days, downing the Red Sox, 5 -- 0, before 3,911 fans at Payne Field.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 30 -- Confined to his hotel with bronchitis, Nicolas E. Ambatielos missed today the climax of his thirty-four-year legal battle with Britain -- the conclusion of hearings by thirteen judges in the almost deserted chamber of the International Court of Justice.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 14 to 21 points lower than Friday on active months.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Senate approved and sent to the White House today a joint resolution to speed the creation of a Department of Health, Education and Welfare, with full Cabinet status, fashioned out of the present elements of the Federal Security Agency.

The Association of American Universities, acting through a committee of five eminent university presidents headed by Dr. A. Whitney Griswold of Yale, has just come forth with a policy statement on academic freedom and academic responsibilities which ought to satisfy any reasonable person.

BOWIE, Md., March 30 (UP) -- Dark Destroyer, a bay colt owned by S. D. Sidell, easily won the featured Millersville Purse today at the Bowie-Laurel meeting, forcing Isasmoothie, a 7-to-10 favorite and the Brookfield Farm's Kentucky Derby candidate, to accept second money in his 1953 debut.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., March 30 -- The Indians were shooting for the distant Rockies today and, while they didn't quite make it, they touched off an explosion heavy enough to send our Giants reeling down to another crushing defeat.

Mrs. Helen M. Harrison has sold her home at 14 Summit Drive in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., to Victor B. Sarkissian through the Herman A. Acker Corporation, brokers. The property consists of an eight-room house and an acre overlooking the Saw Mill River Valley.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, March 31 -- Sir Alvary Gascoigne, British Ambassador, will leave Moscow for London by plane at 9:30 A. M. today for consultations on what are regarded by British diplomats as basic developments in Soviet foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Leonard W. Hall, former Representative from New York and now the Nassau County Surrogate, was acknowledged today to be a leading contender for the post of Republican National Chairman, but a highly placed Administration adviser questioned whether any New Yorker could escape a "Dewey label" and be satisfactory to Midwestern party leaders.
CAIRO, March 30 -- The imposition of severe prison sentences was announced tonight against eleven army officers and three civilians arrested Jan. 14 and accused of a counterrevolutionary conspiracy.

Dean Thorndike Saville of the New York University College of Engineering and Dean Adolph J. Stern of Wagner College announced yesterday two new combined programs leading to engineering degrees to be instituted cooperatively by the two colleges.

Just a few days ago the United States Ambassador to the Philippines, Admiral Spruance, addressed a warning to all Americans in the Philippines telling them "to refrain scrupulously from any kind of participation in the Philippine elections." He stated that this was necessary "to avoid any possible interference" on the part of Americans.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- The Government announced today it had agreed on a new contract with Falconbridge Nickel Mines, Ltd., Toronto, Canada, to buy at lease 100,000,000 pounds of nickel by June 30, 1962.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery said today that Western nations with policies that he called purely "negative and defensive," were not equipped to cope with the threat posed by the "positive and aggressive" aims of the Communist world.

PITTSBURGH, March 30 (AP) -- Robert P. Lane, executive director of the Allegheny (Pittsburgh) County Community Chest since 1950, and former executive director of the Welfare Council of New York, was found dead of a heart attack today in his apartment. He was 60 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The State Department spotted a number of glaring ambiguities today in Communist China's new offer to negotiate a truce in Korea, but agreed it was worth ex ploring . A department spokesman said tonight: "We of course welcome any indications that the Communists are now interested in resolving the entire prisoner of war question on a humanitarian basis."

PHILADELPHIA, March 30 -- Twenty-eight New York City officials, business men and civic leaders studied Philadelphia's mid-city parking ban this afternoon to find out whether it offered a solution to traffic congestion in their metropolis.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Richard M. Nixon is trying earnestly, though cautiously, to be a good Vice President. The earnestness springs from his own character, and the caution from the complexity of the relationship between the Executive and the Legislative Branches of the Federal Government.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 30 -- An operation that produces a "bloodshot heart" and apparently has prolonged the life of sufferers from heart disease was described to the American Association for Thoracic Surgery today by Dr. Samuel A. Thompson of the Flower Hospital in New York.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 30 (AP) -- Seeded players advanced as expected in opening rounds of the fifth annual Good Neighbor tennis tournament today. Fourth-seeded Hamilton Richardson Jr., Baton Rouge, La., was the only player who did not see action. He is due to arrive tomorrow.

What this country needs at times of the year such as the Easter season and Christmastide is the accordion-apartment. Most family habitations expand adequately for their own young, home from school and college.
It was with a deep feeling of appreciation and gratitude that we read "The Crime of Genocide."
TOKYO, Tuesday, March 31 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,570, for Monday's action:

WASHINGTON, March 30 (UP) -- Counsel for E. Merl Young branded his perjury trial today as as "political prosecution" hinged on a $9,450 mink coat owned by his wife, Lauretta, a former White House stenographer.

Foreign news affected the New York commodity exchanges yesterday as the reports of the peace moves in Korea led to lower prices when the markets closed. Volume was generally light, except on rubber and the metals. Potatoes and sugar closed mixed.

JERSEY CITY, March 30 -- Deputy Mayor William J. Flanagan said today that lists of job- seekers prepared at City Hall had been sent to longshore union officials and pier hiring bosses, but insisted there was nothing wrong in that.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower came to her front steps today to welcome Mary Pickford to the White House, where the movie star gave a preview of the all-Pickford film that she would show in cities from coast to coast in the April bond-a-month drive.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 30 -- A bill in the Maryland Legislature that would prohibit prosecutors and the police from discussing pending criminal cases publicly or for publication has aroused the opposition of the state's press, which has termed the measure a "gag" rule.
Economies proposed by city officials to help balance the budget met yesterday with opposition from labor unions representing municipal workers.

In its "general findings," made public today, the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey comes to one conclusion at least that is not likely to be seriously challenged. "Of all business practices of the City of New York," says the committee, "no one practice is so shockingly wasteful as the systematic neglect of maintenance."

A "decorator" refrigerator is one of the items on view in the Ben Rose showroom, which opened yesterday at 41 East Fiftieth Street. The fabrics and wallpapers designed by Mr. Rose are available there through decorators.
DANBURY, Conn., March 30 -- This industrial city in the lake district of Fairfield County re-elected a Republican Mayor today for the first time in nearly thirty years.
Mrs. Glen William Thomas heads the committee for the eightieth anniversary appeal for funds to further the work of the New York Diet Kitchen Association.

NEW ORLEANS, March 30 (AP) -- Patty Berg won the $3,500 New Orleans women's open golf tournament today for the second straight year with a final-round one-under-par 76 for a 54-hole total of 227, four under par. The St. Andrews (Ill.) player earned $875.

The French Foreign Legion, "the most romantic military organization of modern times," is the subject of a new book by Howard Swiggett entitled "March or Die." Mr. Swiggett, author of "The Rebel Raider" and "The Extraordinary Mr. Morris," presents an informal history of the Legion with chapters on famous Legion characters, life in the organization today and on false legends and misrepresentations that have grown up about the outfit.

Although aggregate market value of bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $881,068 in February, average market price fell 51 cents for each $100, the Exchange said yesterday. The apparent discrepancy arose because par value of all bonds listed rose $545,688,844 between Jan. 31 and Feb. 28.
Mayor Impellitteri extended "warmest greetings" yesterday to New Yorkers of the Jewish faith on the occasion of the Passover festival, Judaism's holiday of freedom, which began last night at sundown.

The maximum term, an indeterminate sentence up to three years in the City Penitentiary, was imposed yesterday on Jack Gross, younger brother of Harry Gross, by Judge Louis Goldstein in Kings County Court.

NEWARK, March 30 -- Although the New Jersey Motor Vehicle Division started selling 1953 licenses on Feb. 2, a full month in advance of other years, auto owners who waited until almost the zero hour to have their cars inspected and to get 1953 tabs created record jams today at inspection stations and motor vehicle license agencies.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 30 -- Abdullah Jusuf, representative of the Nationalist party and a member of the parliamentary team investigating land disturbances in East Sumatra, described the region today as "seriously disquieted.

The Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company last year had a net income of $17,325,674, equal to $21.03 a common share, according to the 119th annual report. This compared with $13,170,209 or $15.98 a common share in 1951.

Wool manufacturers object to the current Quartermaster practice of purchasing a certain proportion of its wool textile requirements through negotiated bids, according to Edwin Wilkinson, executive vice president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- An airplane, a helicopter and a $5,900 limousine figures into the cost of a natural gas pipeline these days. Richard C. Ricketts, vice president of Fish Engineering Corporation, listed these items today in presenting cost estimates on a line the Pacific Northwest Pipeline Corporation, Houston, Tex., wants to build.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 30 -- The Dutch are going all out to honor the 100th anniversary today of the birth of Vincent van Gogh, their most famous modern painter.

KOHIMA, India, March 30 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru suffered a public snub by 3,000 Naga tribesmen who walked out booing and waving spears from a meeting he addressed here today. Mr. Nehru is touring the area with Prime Minister U Nu of Burma, who was with him on the platform.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 31 -- South Korean infantrymen and United States Marines turned back Chinese attacks on the eastern and western fronts in Korea yesterday, but fighting dwindled after the savage enemy onslaughts and Allied counter-attacks of last week.
Following is the text of a statement on "The Rights and Responsibilities of Universities and Their Faculties," issued yesterday by the Association of American Universities:

ALBANY, March 30 -- Governor Dewey approved today without comment two supplemental budget bills authorizing expenditures of $17,103,477 and bringing the state's total spending program for 1953-54 up to $1,089,440,700.

A "considerable time in intergovernment negotiations" has been saved by the agreement made last week with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin and chairman of the Senate investigating subcommittee, to halt voyages of Greek-owned ships to Red China, Manuel E. Kulukundis, president of the Greek Shipowners New York Committee, said here last night.

LOS ANGELES, March 30 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities indicated today that it would institute contempt proceedings against Abraham Minkus, Los Angeles school teacher, who, in several hours of interrogation, persistently refused to answer "yes" or "no.

ALBANY, March 30 -- Governor Dewey signed into law today a bill that will subject savings and loan associations to a franchise tax for the first time and that will enable savings banks to save up to $1,200,000 in taxes that they otherwise would have paid in the 1953-1954 fiscal year.

A high rate of participation by small business in defense contracts received by the Eastman Kodak Company is indicated in a study made by the company in cooperation with the Department of Defense and released yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -Democrats moved their national headquarters closer to the White drive to bring in at least $2,250,00 in the next twenty-one months as an essential first step toward electing a Democratic Congress in 1954 and putting a Democrat back in the White House in the 1956 elections.

The new Soviet price reductions are apparently equivalent to approximately an 8 per cent reduction in the Soviet cost of living, analysis of the percentage data released by the Soviet Government indicates.

PITTSBURGH, March 31 -- The Allegheny County Sanitary Authority is ready to start construction of a $70,000,000 sewage disposal plant on the Ohio River within a year, the Ohio River Valley Water Sanitation Commission was told at a public hearing here today.

Stockholders of the Jewel Tea Company at their annual meeting yesterday approved a two-for-one split in the company's common stock and a change in the shares from no par value to $1 par value. Under the proposal, the company will offer 142,000 of the new shares to stockholders on the basis of one new share for each eight shares held.

The twenty-six-story office and showroom building at 245 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of Twenty-eighth Street, has been sold by the 245 Fifth Avenue Corporation to a group of merchants in the textile industry who plan to occupy it.

ALMA, Israel, March 31 -- "The Jews of San Nicandro" celebrated Passover in Israel last night for the fourth time, but it was the first time that their observance was strictly in accordance with rabbinical precepts.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (UP) -- A spokesman of the Bureau of Standards pointed out a statement by Dr. Astin to the Commerce Committee of the House of Representatives Feb. 10. In it Dr. Astin said the bureau had made several exhaustive tests of the battery substance and had found it valueless. He also said the Air Force had made a test and had found the product of "no value."

For the second successive day, the stock market declined sharply yesterday the heaviest trading in more than two years. Virtually every sec on of the list was lower with the rails, motors, air-crafts and oils the weakest. With few exceptions gains were minor and confined to issues in which special developments are taking place.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, said after the session that Mr. Allison had suggested the United States proceed cautiously in accepting Communist proposals for an exchange of prisoners of war in Korea.
Mayor Impellitteri requested Governor Dewey in a letter yesterday to sign a bill increasing the state's aid to the city and counties for care of tuberculous patients from $2.50 to $5 a patient a day.

TOKYO Wednesday, April 1 -- Fighting died down along the Korean front yesterday as the troops speculated on the new possibilities for an armistice as a result of Chinese Premier Chou En-lai's proposal to end the deadlock over the exchange of war prisoners.

FRANKFURT, Germany, March 31 -- The Army staged a ceremonial farewell review today for Lieut. Gen. Manton S. Eddy, who until today commanded the United States Army in Europe and who before that commanded the Seventh Army in Germany. General Eddy is retiring from active service.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 31 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's Bubbley, a Kentucky Derby nominee, is "coming along nicely" after an illness, but it "may be late spring or early summer before she comes to herself," trainer Ben Jones said tonight.

You can have your sleek, chromium-laden, internal-combustion machines at other times, but today it really is the horse that's important. Today the horse is king. And, as far as a large segment of this area's sports followers is concerned, he will be king until Saturday, Nov. 14.

An overflowing schedule isn't preventing Jose Ferrer from going after any likely prospect that has merit in his opinion. He has done just that by acquiring "L'Heure Eblouissante" ("The Dazzling Hour"), a walloping Parisian success.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 31 (AP) -- Deputy Foreign Minister Dag Hammarskjoeld, a bachelor, is regarded as one of Sweden's most brilliant diplomats. He springs from a family of statesmen and military men and is the fifth member of that family to hold high Cabinet posts in this country.

ROME, March 31 -- In an editorial clearly inspired by the Secretariat of State, the Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano urged the Western Powers to accept Chinese Premier Chou En-lai's proposal for repatriation of Korean war prisoners wherefrom, it said, it is possible to "rise toward vaster horizons of peace."

SINGAPORE, March 31 -- The Singapore rubber and tin markets deteriorated sharply today. Tin closed at 466.625 Malayan dollars a picul (133 pounds) -- a drop of 4 Malayan dollars in twenty-four hours. The price of rubber fell by 5/8 Malayan cent, a net loss of 4 3/4 Malayan cents since last Thursday.

Natural fibers give a tropical flavor to a new collection of neatly tailored wood and upholstered furniture now on view in the new Ficks Reed showroom at 305 East Sixty-third Street. The furniture is available through decorators.

In their search for salesmen, sales managers should not overlook unusually short men and former actors. This was asserted yesterday by Georgie Harris, national sales mangaer for Dunhill Cigarettes, who is 4 feet 9 inches tall and a former actor.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- United States officials studied the new Communist peace offensive today with special reference to Germany and Japan.

The French obtained very little out of their visit to this country except a pledge that they would receive more help in the war in Indo-China. But this is all-important because our attitude took an explicit and, in view of Communist China's offer on the war prisoners, a timely form that has received less attention than it deserves.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 31 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, in telling the National Press Club in Washington yesterday that the size of all North Atlantic Treaty headquarters should be "cut in half," has publicly exposed a problem of growing concern to top Allied commanders in Europe.

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., March 31 -- On April 1, 1888, while this village was digging itself out of the Great Blizzard, young Dr. William Loveridge Vroom celebrated his twenty-second birthday by hanging his sign outside a tiny office across the street from Westervelt's grocery store.

A score of postal inspectors have been sent here from Washington to make a comprehensive "management" survey of the New York Post Office as a pilot study that will serve for the entire nation, it was announced here yesterday.

LONDON, March 31 (Reuters) -- Imperial Chemical Industries Britain's huge chemical combine will spend more than $20,000,000 in building a Canadian plant to make a new synthetic fiber. Terylene, it was announced here today.

A five-month investigation of the theft of a $1,500 cultured pearl necklace from Bergdorf Goodman, Fifth Avenue store at Fifty-eight Street, has resulted in the recovery of the jewelry and the arrest of an 18-year-old packer at the establishment, the police reported yesterday.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., March 31 -- Upsala College's baseball team won a double-header from Hamilton, 8 --1 and 16 -- 1, on Viking Field today. Roy Sundgren, Up sala right-hander, went the distance in the opener, giving up seven hits and fanning four to post his first victory of the season.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The big cities of the nation raised their voice today against any move by the Eisenhower Administration to permit state domination of airport, public housing and slum clearance programs in which the cities now had a direct working and fiscal relationship with the Federal Government.

The Cantata Singers and the Metropolitan Museum of Art collaborated last night to present an all-Handel program. The event, the third and last of the season's concerts for members, drew an audience of 1,000, who sat on folding canvas chairs ranged across the Great Hall facing the Egyptian Wing.

Mayor Impellitteri got an un-opened letter yesterday from the Army's Casualty Mail Section in Korea. His office had mailed it on March 4 to Cpl. Donald J. McAvoy, a Brooklyn boy who had asked for and had been sent a New York City flag to fly at the front.
AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, March 31 (UP) -- Albert M. Ash, Deputy Attorney General of New Jersey, failed today in an attempt to persuade Harold J. Adonis to return to the United States voluntarily.
BONN, Germany, March 31 -- Dr. Werner Naumann and other Nazi plotters planned to seize power in West Germany within the next four years, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer declared today.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 31 -- French military authorities here pondered today the question of whether the Chinese Communist Premier's proposal for an exchange of prisoners in the Korean war would have any immediate effect on the protracted war in Indo-China.

" Ding Dong School," one of the unique and worthwhile television programs on the air, has stubbed its toe badly. In its understandable desire to become a commercial success, the program is condoning advertising practices that are most ill-advised and could do real harm to a fine show.

PITTSBURGH, March 31 -- A strike of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen on the Union Railroad, a United States Steel Corporation subsidiary, today closed four big plants of the corporation and brought indefinite furloughs to an estimated 40,000 steel workers.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (UP) -- Representative John E. Lyle Jr. Democrat of Texas, called today for an end to public disclosures of military weaknesses and criticized "retired generals" who, he said, talked too much.

SEOUL, March 31 -- The Republic of Korea Government indicated tonight that if it had the power of veto it would almost certainly disapprove any peace agreement the United Nations and the Chinese Communist and North Korean Governments might reach in renewed peace negotiations at Panmunjom.

The old Hollywood Theatre at 1662 Broadway, which has been closed for the past five years, is being demolished as the first step in clearing the block bounded by Broadway and Seventh Avenue between Fifty-first and Fifty-second Streets for a new building development.

Thousands of New Yorkers -landlords and tenants -- lined up at offices of the Temporary Rate Housing Rent Commission yesterday to learn from the new residential rent control law how on the one hand to increase rents up to 15 per cent, and how on the other to avoid the increase or possible overcharges.

Abolition of the traditional shape-up system of dockworker hiring, recently the principal waterfront target of investigatory bodies and long considered the source of most of the stevedore industry's troubles, has been ordered. It is to be replaced in the next labor contract of local longshoremen.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- E. Merl Young, key figure in a Senate investigation of alleged influence peddling in the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, was convicted today on four counts of perjury.

On the eve of an educational fund-raising drive this month for a record $18,000,000, the American Cancer Society said yesterday that "the best interests of the attack on cancer" were served by an independent fund-raising campaign and resistance to joining united funds. April has been proclaimed by President Eisenhower as Cancer Control Month.

LOS ANGELES, March 31 -- The most probable thing in the universe just now is World War III, it was asserted today by one of the three or four most important atomic scientists in the United States, Dr. Harold Clayton Urey of the University of Chicago.

The construction of a waterside chemical bulk storage plant at a Bayonne (N. J.) pier, capable of berthing tankers up to 560 feet long, will be started in May by the Lehigh Warehouse and Transportation Company of Newark.

After five weeks of multiple pricing that caused considerable confusion among copper consumers, the market for domestic refined copper appeared yesterday to be settling at a uniform quotation of 30 cents a pound.

The first harbinger of drifting ice -- an annual potential danger to shipping in the North Atlantic -melted away harmlessly over the week-end at a point 1,250 miles due east of Portsmouth, N. H., the Coast Guard reported here yesterday.

In THE TIMES of March 26 there is a letter written by Paula Newfield criticizing the care of mental patients at Rockland State Hospital. Such criticism recurs at intervals and most frequently it stems from inadequate observation and a lack of inquiry into the facts.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm product prices increased one-third of 1 per cent during the month ended March 15 --ending a decline that had been going on steadily for six months.

Easter season is not always the happy time it should be for rabbits, baby chicks and ducklings. Purchased thoughtlessly by doting relatives for little Nancy or Dick, they are often mistreated and cast aside like used toys after the "present" has lost its newness.

The 1952 Lamme Gold Medal for a member of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers who "has shown meritorious achievement in the development of electrical apparatus or machinery" has been awarded to I. F. Kinnard, engineering manager of the meter and instrument department of the General Electric Company at West Lynn, Mass.

Premier Rene Mayer of France, who last week in Washington won promises of increased American aid for French forces opposing Communist aggression in Indo-China arrived here yesterday by air from Ottawa, telling of "very friendly" talks with Canadian officials on the Atlantic Pact and mutual trade.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- Representative John Taber, Republican of upstate New York, raised his budget-cutting sights today and said Eisenhower Administration agency heads were being a little modest in their own estimates of what they could save.

A syndicate of 235 underwriting houses headed by Morgan Stanley Co. will undertake to market today $200,000,000 of twenty-five-year 3 1/2 per cent debentures of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation, the largest new-capital issue of industrial securities ever placed in public distribution in the United States.

IF there are any who still doubt the popularity of angling as a sport, a visit to the Finger Lakes area at daybreak this morning should banish such doubts, for a report received from Catherin Creek late yesterday indicated that many of the more impatient opening-day anglers were on hand early, to insure a good spot on the bank.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The House of Representatives put finishing touches today on an offshore oil bill giving the states title to submerged lands within their historic boundaries, while providing for development of natural wealth lying to seaward under Federal lease and law.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- A Defense Department spokesman took the side of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, but with reservations, today in the controversy over the Wisconsin Republican's unorthodox making of a secret agreement with Greek owners of 242 ships to stop delivering cargoes to Iron Curtain ports.

Net sales and net profit of the Raytheon Manufacturing Company for the nine months ended on Feb. 28 increased 76 per cent and 190 per cent, respectively, from a year ago. Raytheon is a manufacturer of electronic tubes and equipment.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Three witnesses from the public relations field, advised a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee today to enlarge and invigorate the international information programs to target areas overseas. However, they differed on the emphasis of the programs and the organization to run them.

Students from schools in the Grand Central area are learning how a savings institution operates as they sit in this week as under-studies to officers and department heads of the Century Federal Saving Association at its main office. Lexington Avenue and Forty-fourth Street.

Life insurance on personal credit loans will be extended to include borrowers in the commercial department of the National City Bank of New York under a plan announced yesterday. The plan, which covers borrowers for the amounts of their loans up to a maximum of $10,000 each, is believed to be the first of its kind to be established by a bank.

CHICAGO, March 31 (AP) -- Purdue climbed aboard the Rose Bowl bandwagon today with a vote that virtually assured continuation of the Big Ten-Pacific Coast Conference football series on New Year's Day for at least another three years.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 31 -- United Nations diplomats were hopeful today that the Security Council's recommendation of a new Secretary General would help put a graceful end to what had been a sharp debate on the staff loyalty controversy.

BERLIN, March 31 -- Negotiations between British and Soviet representatives on air safety procedures over Germany began tonight but they were buried under a mantle of secrecy that even conceled the location of the talks and the identity of the participants.

MOSCOW, March 31 -- A partly of seven United States newspaper and radio editors and owners arrived tonight for a week's visit in the Soviet Union, the first to be paid by an organized group of United States editors since four members of the American Society of Newspaper Editors came here in 1946.

The Yankees, Giants and Dodgers just now are heading homeward in inching steps from their training chores in sunny climes. But baseball's 1953 debut in this citadel of the diamond sport did not await the arrival of the doughty major leaguers. There was a ball game -- and a good one -- in New York yesterday.

Net income of Olin Industries, Inc., amounted to $10,709,643 last year, compared with $12,108,673 in 1951, John M. Olin, president, reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders. Earnings before taxes were $24,066,610, compared with $29,568,149.

CHICAGO, March 31 (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks squared their Stanley Cup semi-final playoff series with the Montreal Canadiens at two games each tonight with a 3-to-1 triumph before 16,487 fans. Vic Lynn's first goal of the season, with less than eight minutes left in the game, was decisive.

Shareholders of the Lanston Monotype Machinery Company on April 24 are to vote on its absorption by a new company, Lanston Industries, Inc., which will also own the Cuno Engineering Company of Meriden, Conn., it was announced yesterday.

A collection of pottery bowls and vases made by American Indians is on view at Pottery of All Nations, 108 Seventh Avenue South. Most of the pieces are from the Hopi tribe in the Southwest, while a few are from the Cherokee in North Carolina. All are one of a kind.

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 1 -- The United Nations Command waited today for a reply from the Communist Chinese and North Korean Army commanders to offer to start immediately working out plans for the exchange of seriously ill and wounded prisoners of war in Korea.

Dag Hammarskjoeld, who has been nominated by the Security Council to succeed Trygve Lie as Secretary General of the United Nations, has been Sweden's Minister of State since 1950, and, although now in Sweden, is still chairman of Sweden's delegation to the seventh session of the General Assembly.

Although there is no fixed date for Easter, which varies each year according to a fickle moon and a vague calendar, New Yorkers are pleased when it occurs in April instead of in March. The later the date, the closer we are to real spring weather and the more comfortable it is likely to be for half a million wearers of lightweight coats and suits in the Easter parade.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., March 31 -- Five National Guard divisions from the First Army will train 45,155 men at Camp Drum this summer during five separate periods. This total is 6,255 more than the number in training in 1952. An estimated 16,000 organized Reservists also will receive training at the camp during the coming summer.

LISBON, Portugal, March 31 -- After having deliberated for almost eighteen hours the judges of a Lisbon military tribunal found seven men guilty today of plotting a revolutionary movement against the present organization of the state.

CAIRO, March 31 -- Foreign Minister Mahmoud Fawzi categorically denied tonight a report emanating from Paris that a "distinguished individual" had established "certain new contacts" between Israel and Egypt by acting as go-between in a series of private talks with Dr. Fawzi and Israeli officials.

Plans for erecting a fifteen-story apartment house with stores at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Eighty-first Street were announced in connection with the purchase of the property by Leo Kossove from Jack, Samuel and Milton Brause through George E. Maran, broker.
Provoked over the abuse by Government workers of curb parking privileges outside public buildings, Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley has decided to ring the areas with parking meters.

The financing of public school building construction through bonds secured by leasehold revenues instead of by the full-faith-and-credit obligations of a municipal or state taxing authority was denounced here yesterday as unsound by David Ellinwood, municipal credit rating expert of the Moody's Service.

Paul Matthen, bass-baritone, underwent last evening one of the most searching tests of musicianship and singing technique that a singer is called upon to face, by singing Schubert's "Winterreise" song-cycle at Town Hall.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (UP) -- Francis V. duPont of Wilmington, Del., was sworn in today as Commissioner of Public Roads, succeeding Thomas H. MacDonald, who had held the post for about thirty-five years.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 31 (AP) -- Harry Faccini, Colombia's first-ranked player, upset sixthseeded Sidney Schwartz of Fort Lee, Va., in the second round of men's singles in the Good Neighbor tennis championship, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3, today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Atomic Energy Commission disclosed today that the main element for an atomic engine to be installed in a submarine, a model reactor, had started to turn out energy at a testing laboratory in Idaho.

Retail volume in men's hats next fall should run 15 per cent ahead of 1952, James B. Lee, president of the Frank H. Lee Company, Danbury, said yesterday at the spring sales meeting at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Federal Communications Commission will speedily approve the first satisfactory color television system brought to its attention but it will not rush the radio industry into developing such a system, Paul A. Walker, commission chairman, told a House of Representatives committee today.

AT THE KOREAN FRONT, March 31 -- On a warm, pleasant day of spring the hope of peace came to fighting men who face the enemy in trenches and bunkers along the high ridge lines of this war-devastated peninsula.

Two elderly women, both veteran passengers of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Company, patiently waited at the Livingston Street station of the line last night, their arms loaded with two huge bouquets of red and white roses. When the train pulled into the station, the women, who refused to reveal their names, presented the bouquets to the conductor and the motorman.

TRENTON, March 31 -- Nelson F. Stamler declared here today that Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll was opposed to his investigation of Walter G. Winne, superseded prosecutor of Bergen County, who was indicted on charges of nonfeasance in office.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks told the Senate Banking Committee today that he was "opposed to the continuance of price and wage controls on any basis."

CHICAGO, March 31 -- Sharp declines were registered in grain and soybean futures, with free long liquidation following a modest price improvement early in the session. However, late profit-taking by shorts coupled with commission buying on resting orders resulted in a brisk recovery in the late trade.

CinemaScope. Twentieth Century-Fox's new wide-screen process with stereophonic sound, already on order for installation in 1,200 film houses throughout the country, has been ordered for 217 showcases of the National Theatre circuit, it was announced yesterday by Al Lichtman, director of distribution.

HARTFORD, March 31 -- The Roads, Rivers and Bridges Committee of the Connecticut General Assembly approved today a bill to set up a thruway and expressway program that eventually would cost the state about $400,000,00.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The President's grandson, Dwight David Eisenhower 2d, celebrated his fifth birthday in the White House today with chocolate cake and chocolate ice cream of his own choosing. The cake, made in the White House kitchens, was decorated in Easter colors of yellow and green.
BONN, Germany, March 31 -- The Soviet Union added today the question of Germany's reunification to those it wished to discuss with the Western powers.

TOPEKA, Kan., March 31 (UP) -- The Kansas House of Representatives, trampling a Democratic protest, today let die a committee that found that C. Wesley Roberts, Republican National Chairman, had violated the "spirit" of the state lobbying law.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 31 -- Egypt protested to the United Nations today that Israeli authorities had seized an Egyptian ship illegally, arrested its crew and refused to allow an investigation of the incident.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday and 5 to 11 points higher, after some early hedge selling. Trading was moderately active.

The National Academy of Design will open its 128th annual exhibition of paintings, sculpture and graphics with a preview this evening for members and friends in the galleries of the organization, 1083 Fifth Avenue. Awards and prizes will be officially presented.

CHICAGO, March 31 -- Trial of the du Pont anti-trust suit was recessed by Judge Walter J. LaBuy in Federal District Court today to next Tuesday, when the witness will be Charles F. Kettering, retired research chief of General Motors Corporation known for his numerous inventions.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 31 -- The Government, in outlawing blind selling and block booking of movies by the producing-distributing companies, figuratively lifted small independent theatre owners out of the frying pan into the fire.

MANILA, Wednesday, April 1 -- Oscar Castelo, Secretary of Justice in President Elpidio Quirino's Cabinet, cautioned yesterday all aliens, including Americans, to stay out of Philippine politics under pain of deportation. Mr. Castelo, who is also Acting Secretary of Defense, has administrative supervision over the Deportation Board.

Dimitri Mitropoulos, appearing with the Philharmonic-Symphony for the first time since Dec. 7, will conduct Prokofieff's Fifth Symphony at Carnegie Hall tomorrow evening and Friday afternoon in memory of the composer, who died March 8.

Adoption of basic trade provisions for the men's and boys' clothing industry was explored yesterday at a meeting of representatives of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A. and the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Statler Hotel.
DENVER, March 31 -- The Giants followed the Indians clear over the Rockies today but with still no change in their fortunes.

Bonds called for payment before maturity in March amounted to $18,438,000, the smallest sum for any March since 1934, when $16,574,000 was redeemed in that month. The month's figure compared with $17,744,000 in the preceding month and with $230,970,000 in March, 1952, when four issues of Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority bonds totaling $211,620,000 were included.
New issues of public utility, railroad and department store securities, having a market value of more than $8,900,000 will be offered to investors today. The issues are as follows:

In its general recommendations made public today the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey proposes a "drastic and revolutionary" reorganization of the management of the city government of New York. There are twelve major recommendations, resting on the principle of strong autonomous city departments, topped by a central directorate composed of Mayor, Board of Estimate and City Council.

MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L. I., March 31 -- Two aviation cadet selection teams here will start interviewing and enrolling volunteers for the Air Force's pilot and observer training programs in mid-April, it was announced today by Maj. Gen. Howard M. Turner, commanding general of the First Air Force.

President Eisenhower has asked that Congress set up a commission to study the pattern of federal-state relations in the field of fiscal policy, with particular emphasis on the questions of overlapping taxes and federal grants-in-aid. "It is time," said he, with the first of these problems obviously in mind, "to relieve the people of the need to pay taxes on taxes."
BONN, Germany, Wednesday, April 1 -- Women became the legal equal of men in West Germany -- in a country long a stronghold of masculine domination -- at one minute past midnight tonight.

Your paper has done its usual excellent service for its readers by reporting as fully as it has Senator Joseph McCarthy's questioning of Earl Browder and others in connection with the use of books written by "Communists" by the State Department in its various libraries throughout the world.
BOSTON, March 31 (AP) -- All four seeded stars advanced easily today in men's singles play as the national badminton championships got under way at the University Club courts.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Last week's visit to Washington by a French delegation is to be followed shortly by a visit by a German delegation, headed by Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor.

The New York Regional Blood Program appealed yesterday for volunteers to assist medical staffs in operating bloodmobile units that collect group donations in all parts of the metropolitan area. Volunters are particularly needed in Manhattan and the Bronx, where 200 assistants are being sought.

A provocative letter in this month's issue of The Beer Wholesalers News charges that the light, dry beer prevailing in this country is more in the interests of brewers than of consumers, Milo J. Cepelak is the writer.

LONDON, March 31 -- Mau Mau terrorism in Kenya has developed from sporadic murders into a coordinated military operation, Oliver Lyttelton, the Colonial Secretary, told the House of Commons today. He said Thursday's massacre and a successful diversionary raid on a police post bore evidence of careful planning and direction.
BONN, Germany, March 31 -- West German aircraft designers are confident they can put their country in the forefront of Western research in jet engines and aerodynamics by the end of 1954.

The challenge to freedom posed by the conflict Korea, anti-Semitism in Russia and oppression in the slave camps of many sections of the Old World, was the keynote of sermons delivered yesterday in various synagogues of the city on the festival day of the Passover, which ended at sundown.

ALBANY, March 31 -- The State Tax Commission announced today that it planned to begin collecting state income taxs on corporate distributions to stockholders during the past four years resulting from revaluation of real property.

Dr. Gene Weltfish, who publicized last year Communist charges that the United Nations forces employed germ warfare in Korea, will be dropped from the academic staff of Columbia University at the end of the current academic year.

Arthur Godfrey will take his entire television and radio troupe to Miami Beach and originate his C. B. S. programs from there for a five-day period beginning Monday, April 13. His Wednesday evening television program on April 15 will be a swimming and water show production, taking place in the pool and the surf at the Kenilworth Hotel.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- When a President gets a black eye it's news, even if it is discovered nine months late.

LONDON, March 31 -- A weeklong manhunt ended today when Constable Thomas Ledger saw John Reginald Halliday Christie walking on a London street and challenged him. Nine hours later the 55-year-old trucking clerk was charged with the murder of his wife, whose body was found with those of five other women at the place where he had lived -- the Notting Hill house of murder.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 31 -- More important to the Yankees than their 4-2 victory over the Dodgers today was the fine pitching of Ewell Blackwell. The Whip had it. He threw hard over his six-inning outing and left with a 4-1 lead. But with better luck Blackie would have blanked the National Leaguers.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- The Army said farewell today to Gen. James A. Van Fleet with a parade and the full military honors reserved for career's end of a four- star soldier.

MOSCOW, March 31 -- The Soviet Government ordered price decreases tonight on 125 categories of retail products, including 10 per cent cuts on major food items and reductions of 5 to 15 per cent on principal clothing items.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 31 -- Seventeen nations formally signed today the United Nations convention on political rights for women, approved last Dec. 20 by the General Assembly after three years of discussion and revision. An eighteenth -- Israel -- accredited her representatives for the signing, but postponed the action until tomorrow because of the Passover holiday.

A suggestion that a "general directorate" type of city government be set up for New York, with much of the supervisory authority delegated to a "director of administration" appointed by the Mayor was put forward yesterday by the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey.

Defending his stand in canceling next Wednesday night's performance of "Wonderful Town," Robert Fryer, producer of the hit musical starring Rosalind Russell at the Winter Garden, issued a statement yesterday, saying: "Our object is to prevent an organization from reselling tickets to our production at a profit that it will then use to disseminate ideas thoroughly hostile to the interests of America."

ALBANY, March 31 -- Governor Dewey approved today a bill whose only function is to change the word "who" to "whom" in the section heading of an existing law, but he had little sympathy for the grammatical sensitivity of the Brooklyn Democrat who introduced it.
Dwellings dominated the trading in Long Island areas in transactions reported yesterday.

The conciliatory messages from ,the Communists resulted in further declines yesterday on the New York. commodity exchanges. Only cocoa, soybean oil and cottonseed J oil were able to show increases. i Coffee, potatoes, sugar, hides, rubber, wool, lead, tin knd zinc closed I lower.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Department of Justice announced today it would offer for sale 50 per cent of the outstanding capital stock of Jasco, Inc., a concern that holds basic patents on the processes of making synthetic rubber.

The past was praised and the modern movement in architecture and interior design was severely criticized (unfortunately with no audible defenders present) at a panel meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday. The discussions formed part of the program of the twenty-second annual conference of the American Institute of Decorators now in session here.

LONDON, March 31 -- Uncertainty over implications of the latest developments in Korea, coupled with yesterday's setback on Wall Street, made for dull and still quieter conditions on the stock markets here today. Selling was generally light and losses were small outside commodity groups, which were again sharply lower.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 31 -- The Security Council decided tonight to recommend the election of Dag Hammarskjoeld, Swedish Minister of State, to succeed Trygve Lie as Secretary General of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (UP) -- Representative John P. Saylor, Republican of Pennsylvania, and a group of liquor distillers urged the House of Representatives Ways and Means Committee today to extend the present tax-free period on whisky in a bonded warehouse from eight to twelve years.

At 72 Frank M. Eckerson, for twenty years village clerk of Spring Valley, N. Y., is judged too old to continue his duties. A man of that age, as everybody knows, can't push a pen or thump a typewriter or answer inquiries the way a younger man can. At that age a man is too feeble for such activities and needs a rest.

Volume of trading on the New York Stock Exchange in March was the largest for any month since October, 1951, and sales for the first three months of this year totaled considerably higher than for the same period in 1932.

Charles Herman Contracting Co, Vernon and Elizabeth Pope, public relations, in 50 E 42d St; W. R. Cosentini Associates, consulting engineers, additional space in 237 1st Ave -- Cushman Wakefield, Inc, brokers.
A committee of the City Club of New York which has been investigating waterfront crime has come up with a carefully formulated report which merits serious consideration.

VIENNA, March 31 -- Prague sent Washington today a second note protesting against what it called the "hostile activity of American occupation authorities against Czechoslovakia" as indicated by the provision of $100,000,000 for the relief of fugitives from the Soviet bloc.

Member of the Uniformed Firemen's Association have voted to discontinue annual payments of $4,780 to John P. Crane, former president of the union, who resigned in 1951 after refusing to waive immunity before a grand jury investigation of the union's activities.

A military history of Erwin Rommel's campaigns, edited by B. H. Liddell Hart from the German field marshal's papers, will be published May 14 by Harcourt, Brace. When Rommel died he left behind in various hiding places papers concerning his career and the exact details of his campaigns.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Dr. Allen V. Astin has resigned by request as Director of the National Bureau of Standards in a controversy that prompted Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, to question the integrity of the bureau's testing work.

LOS ANGELES, March 31 -- Radio "soap opera" serials were solemnly appraised by the Communist party as hindering "the revolution" through their emphasis on women's specialized role in American life, it was testified today before a House Un-American Activities subcommittee.

LONDON, March 31 -- Britain, it appeared today, is prepared to have the new Chinese Communist proposal on the repatriation of Korean war prisoners discussed at Panmunjom. It is thought here that the United States also will wish to explore the proposal and that following the lead of Washington and London the other nations participating in the war will readily agree to discussions with the Communists.

To the latest Communist overtures in Korea General Clark has made a preliminary reply which should provide the first test of whether the Communists are sincere in accepting the United Nations stand on the prisoner-of-war issue or whether they are merely engaged in another maneuver to trick the free world.
RALEIGH, N. C., March 31 -- The Board of the North Carolina Press Association adopted a resolution today asking for repeal of a secrecy law adopted last week by the state General Assembly.

BOSTON, March 31 (UP) -- Boston's surging Bruins, fighting to gain the Stanley Cup final, routed Detroit tonight, 6 -- 2, before a crowd of 13,909 Boston Garden fans to take a 3-1 edge in their best-of-seven play-off series.

Johnny Saxton, unbeaten Brooklyn welterweight, increased his string to thirty-nine by scoring a unanimous decision over Charlie Williams of Newark in the ten-round main bout at Ridgewood Grove last night. Saxton weighed 149 pounds and Williams, New Jersey welterweight champion, weighed 152 3/4.
TOKYO, March 31 (AP) -- Following is the text of Gen. Mark W. Clark's letter today to the Communist High Command on an exchange of sick and wounded prisoners of war:

BOWIE, Md., March 31 (AP) -Yildiz came back to the races in winning form today when he drove to a three-quarter length decision over Iswar in the six-furlong Congressional Purse. The 5-year-old horse, owned by Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords, was making his first start since November.

ALBANY, March 31 -- A bill granting an additional $100,000 in state aid to city and county library systems approved for participation in the state extension program by the Commissioner of Education was approved today by Governor Dewey.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 31 -- The Chinese Communist Government submitted today its new proposal for the repatriation of prisoners of war in Korea to Lester B. Pearson, president of the United Nations General Assembly. This was the first official presentation of the proposal, which was circulated yesterday by radio, and Mr. Pearson transmitted it this afternoon to the United States, which holds the unified command of United Nations forces in Korea.

IMPHAL, India, March 31 -- The recently tamed headhunting Naga tribes, whose warrior chieftains vowed in weird rites to stop fighting the Burmese Government after battling troops up to only last week, are being inspected today and tomorrow by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India and Prime .Minister U Nu of Burma.

MANCHESTER, March 31 (AP) -- The United States became the world's leading exporter of cotton piece goods in 1952, with Japan second, followed by Britain and India, the British Cotton Board reported today.
JERSEY CITY, March 31 -- Record -breaking numbers of autos lined up outside New Jersey's thirty state-operated motor vehicle examination stations today in a last- day rush for 1953 license tags.

Call it a tailleur, a trotteur or just a jacket and skirt, a suit is a suit is a suit. Backbone of a year-round wardrobe, it can be varied in many ways by the use of accessories attuned to the mood of the wearer or the occasion.

Although negotiations in Washington for renewal of the International Wheat Agreement have been reported deadlocked over prices, J. Charles van Essche, Belgian representative to the conference, said here yesterday that approval might come within the next forty-eight hours.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Federal Judge Luther W. Youngdahl agreed today to postpone until October the district court trial of Prof. Owen Lattimore on perjury charges. The trial opening had been tentatively set for May 11.

Your March 2 issue contains an article, datelined Jakarta, Indonesia, March 1, "Indonesia Begins Nationalizing Tin." After reading the article I cannot escape the impression that the headline certainly does not represent its contents. Furthermore, the article contains certain inaccuracies.

New issues of bonds and stock publicly offered here in March declined from the previous month. But compared with other years, bond financing was the largest for March since 1948 while stock flotations were the smallest since 1950.

WINDSOR, England, March 31 -- In ancient St. George's Chapel, traditional burial place of British kings, Queens Mary was laid to rest today in the presence of her mourning family and an imposing assemblage of royalty from many lands.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Under pressure from the White House, Arthur S. Flemming, acting head of the Office of Defense Mobilization, has consented to head that agency on a permanent basis. Mr. Flemming's consent, it was understood, was given reluctantly after President Eisenhower reported that he was unable to get a business man with the necessary qualifications to take the post.

Alexandria, Va., sold yesterday $4,550,000 of public improvement bonds due March 1 from 1954 to 1976 to a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 100.01 for 4s, 3s and 2 1/2s, an interest cost of 3.016 per cent. On reoffering, the bonds were priced to yield from 1.35 per cent to 3.15 per cent.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, March 31 (UP) -- Fred E. McManus, an 18-year-old Valley Stream, L. I., marine, was captured tonight and the police said he had confessed the slaying of five persons in three states on a wild week-end of crime.

John T. Loughran served on the Court of Appeals for nearly twenty years and had been Chief Judge of this highest court in New York State since 1946. He presided with distinction in an office whose standards had been maintained and elevated by such predecessors as Benjamin Cardozo, Cuthbert Pound and Irving Lehman.

The Board of Transportation agreed yesterday to meet next Monday with the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., and Michael J. Quill, union president, immediately called off all plans for "job action" against the city's subway, bus and elevated lines.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- Rudolph Faupl of Milwaukee, an official of the Machinists Union, A. F. L., said today that the union was strongly opposed to a proposed constitutional amendment curbing treaty-making powers.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 31 -- President Tito reported to the Yugoslav people today that Prime Minister Churchill had promised him that Britain would defend Yugoslavia if she were attacked. In turn, the Yugoslav marshal made his own promise that, in the event of aggression elsewhere, Yugoslavia would take sides against the aggressor.

ST. LOUIS, March 31 (AP) -- The Wabash Railroad Company today reported its total revenues for 1952 reached new high of $115,884,741. Arthur K. Atkinson, president, said this compared with $111,022,651 during 1951, the previous high year.
Events tonight: "Parsifal," Metropolitan Opera. 7:15 P. M.; Max Pollikoff, violinist. Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A., 8:40; "La Boheme," Dorelle Opera Cameos. Studio 1101. Carnegie Hall, 8.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 31 -- As a precautionary move reflecting optimism on the possibility of a truce in Korea, James J. Wadsworth of the United States proposed to the United Nations Economic and Social Council today that discussion of relief and rehabilitation in that country be postponed until the summer meeting of the council in Geneva.

Eighty-two moves were required by Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia to win his adjourned game from the thirteenth round of the international chess masters tournament at Mar Del Plata yesterday, and to retain thereby his lead of 1 1/2 points, according to a report from Buenos Aires.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Some of the leading figures in the American theatre joined the cast of the fifth company of "Oklahoma!" in celebrating the tenth anniversary of the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical tonight.

Traffic Patrolman Martin M. Killoran, who expects to retire soon from the Police Department after having served thirty-four years, modestly refused yesterday to be the guest of honor at a little farewell party his friends along the midtown waterfront had planned for him.
The small collection of fifteen hats shown yesterday at Emme, 26 East Forty-sixth Street, was just a tantalizing suggestion of what to expect from Adolfo.
Economic development of Canada and Alaska as strategic locations in the polar concept of warfare was called a vital factor in American security yesterday by Col. Alvin R. Glafka.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Democratic leaders today gave favorable preliminary consideration to a proposal for a national party convention in 1954 as part of an effort to wrest control of Congress from the Republican party in the middle of President Eisenhower's first term.
DUBUQUE, Iowa, April 1 (AP) -- An 18-year-old boy, held on his admission of killing five persons in a four-day cross-country crime swing, snubbed the effort of his father to aid him tonight.

Willis D. Crittenberger Strode into a newly decorated office on the fifth floor of 11 West Forty-second Street at 9 A. M. yesterday to begin his first civilian job since 1908 -- that of executive vice president of the Greater New York Fund.

A Brooklyn public loader was indicted yesterday on charges of extortion and coercion in what District Attorney Miles F. McDonald described as a test case to challenge the position of public loaders on the city's waterfront.

AGARTALA, India, April 1 -- The Communist hold on Tripura State, a remote and sequestered but strategically placed former princely territory in Northeast India, and the only state where the Communists gained a majority in last year's general election, is being broken gradually by improved communications and other betterment projects, officials here said today.

BONN, Germany, April 1 -- The future of the Saar, the tiny coal basin that has been a cause of French-German discord for two generations, will be raised by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer in his talks with President Eisenhower and John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, in Washington.

The height of fashion at a hat bar price is available to all searching for new Easter bonnets this year. Not only have French imports been reproduced in spanking fresh copies tagged with good low prices, but every important trend is represented.

To local cryptologists the year of 1953 may be made memorable by a chalked slogan of exceptional impact which appeared overnight on the risers of the steps of the Forty-second Street Independent subway station about Jan. 1.

SINGAPORE, April 1 -- The Federal Government announced tonight the surrender of Chong Paak, a Communist terrorist organization section leader in the Batu Kurau area of Taiping in Perak state. With Chong was another less important Red.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The National Science Foundation announced awards today of graduate fellowships to 556 United States citizens to aid them in research in the natural sciences.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) -- Freda Utley, writer and former Communist, testified today she found State Department libraries in Germany last year contained "shocking" books by Communists and few opposing communism.

Trans World Airlines, Inc., last year achieved the highest gross revenues in its twenty-six-year history and the second largest earnings on record, Warren Lee Pierson, board chairman, and Ralph S. Damon, president, reported to stockholders yesterday in the 1952 annual statement.

Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister, warned here yesterday against being "taken in" by the latest Communist peace proposals, against relaxing defensive efforts because of this "maneuver," and against letting a cease-fire in Korea be used to start an avalanche on Indo-China.

The horse player's great day was observed at Jamaica yesterday, where the local turf season of 196 racing days began, with 40,364 fans in attendance. Since November 15 last, there had been no racing in this state, and in that period that turf addict had plenty of time to put aside a strong enough bankroll to battle the mutuel machines.

BUENOS AIRES, April 1 -- Saying that the labor unions over which he once had complete control "have thrust a knife into my belly," President Juan D. Peron today promised that he personally would hawk vegetables or become a street-corner butcher to bring an end to the rapidly rising spiral of the cost of living in Argentina.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended March 25:

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) -- Four business groups asked Congress today to repeal "excessive" and "needless" import barriers on foreign products and to encourage private United States investment abroad.

Today's new film is "The Seven Ravens," a German-made feature-length puppet film based on the Grimm Brothers fairy tale, at the downtown Art Theatre. The Diehl Brothers production is being re leased by Alexander Productions Inc.

WASHINGTON, April (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks today presented to Congress a revised budget request calling for about $12,000,000 less to run the department next year than was appropriated for the current fiscal year.
ROCHESTER, Minn., April 1 (AP) -- Patients' brains are "wired for sound" with hairlike electrodes sometimes left in place for several weeks in a new technique reported at the Mayo Clinic today.

The largest number of contested cases in twenty - five years is swamping the Tax Court of the United States, according to a study of the court's figures made public yesterday by the Commerce Clearing House. This organization, which has its headquarters in Chicago, studies and interprets tax and business law reports.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 1 -- African natives in Northern Rhodesia began two days of prayer today in an effort to balk formation of the Central African Federation proposed by the British Government. In Lusaka, the capital, a large number of Negro Government workers and Negro employes of commercial concerns left their work to join prayer services.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 1 -- Universal - International unveiled today the handiwork of its technicians in the development of still another wide-screen system designed to enlarge the longitudinal dimension of standard-size pictures and also to accommodate exhibition of three-dimensional films.

An eleven-count criminal information, which charged John Paul (Frankie) Carbo with contempt in his refusal to answer questions before the State Crime Commission last Dec. 19, was dismissed yesterday by three justices in Special Sessions.

MOBILE, Ala., April 1 -- A pair of former local stars, George Shuba and Don Zimmer, proved heroic as ever today to the 8,825 fans who overflowed Hartwell Field and saw the Dodgers beat the Braves, 3 -- 2, in ten innings.

Prices closed irregular on the commodity exchanges here yesterday, with cocoa, rubber, lead, zinc and tin lower. Coffee, sugar, soybean oil and cottonseed oil were higher and potatoes, wool and hides ended mixed. Most items were dull with potatoes the only commodity to register sizable volume.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) -- Irving Goldman, a Sarah Lawrence College professor and admitted former Communist, challenged the right of Senate investigators of alleged communism in education today to make him inform on others.

A new play by Andrew Rosenthal entitled, "Horses in Midstream," which has for its theme the problems arising from flight from convention, opens this evening at 8 o'clock at the Royale Theatre under the banner of Gilbert Miller and Donald Oenslager.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) -- The General Accounting Office announced today it was withholding $6,350,000 in Government subsidies from the American Export Lines on the ground the company had been overpaid that amount for two passenger liners, the Independence and Constitution.
I have been told that the city contemplates the closing of 110 day-care centers, due to what it terms insufficient funds.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan congratulated yesterday four patrolmen who arrested hold-up suspects in two separate incidents Monday and he also praised three civilians who participated in the captures.

Local offices of the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission were deluged again yesterday with inquiries from landlords and tenants seeking clarification of the new residential rent control law. Signed by Governor Dewey on Monday, the bill will affect 850,000 tenants here and 150,000 tenants upstate.
A public hearing held by the City Planning Commission at City Hall yesterday brought to light a plan devised by Park Commissioner Robert Moses for rezoning virtually all of Coney Island.
If the President were to invite Malenkov to visit Washington it might go some way toward a better understanding and consequent easing of tension.

Two design traditions are represented in two new contemporary groups of ceramics, one, that of America in designs by Russel Wright, the other, that of the Orient in the work of Fong Chow. The former collection, a group of dinnerware, will be available at Macy's on Monday.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) -- Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, urged Americans today to contribute money for cancer research and medical care.
