ROME, April 1 -- Differences of opinion within the Cabinet as to the advisability of dissolving the Senate at the same time as the Chamber of Deputies caused a further delay today in the scheduled Cabinet meeting. The meeting is now scheduled for tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio engaged in a heated argument today with the head of the International Typographical Union. A. F. L., over whether printers should be allowed a closed shop. The Senate Republican leader said that if printers were to be exempted from the Taft-Hartley Law's ban on the closed shop then all other unions should be.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- Private business has regained the balance it lost in early 1951 and is in far better shape to withstand the test that might be imposed by the diminishing importance of defense expenditures, Martin R. Gainsbrugh, chief economist of the National Industrial Conference Board, asserted today.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today extended for another ten days the order it issued originally on March 13, suspending trading in the common stock of Adolf Gobel, Inc., on the American Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- President Eisenhower has been informed that Congress is anxious about the adequacy of this country's defenses and somewhat restive at the Administration's delay in suggesting the shape and scope of its new military program.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- James Mr. Mitchell resigned today as a member of the Civil Service Commission and was immediately named by President Eisenhower to become a deputy to Dr. John A Hannah, Assistant Secretary of Defense.

Undoubtedly spurred on by increasing production of frozen foods, processors of canned foods are stepping up efforts to improve the quality of their products. So-called can-opener cookery is quicker and easier than that based on fresh foods; it may be more economical than using frozen foods.

SYRACUSE, April 1 (AP) -- The rowing coaches of America have indicated that they would like to have the climax race of the year, the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta, held at Syracuse for a long time to come.

Steel production will be at capacity rates through the third quarter of 1953, T. M. Girdler, chairman, and C. M. White, president, of the Republic Steel Corporation predicted in the annual report mailed to stockholders yesterday.

Resources of the Manufacturers Trust Company on Tuesday amounted to $2,691,583,352, according to the bank's quarterly condition statement published today. This figure compares with $2,948,974,541 at the close of the previous quarter on Dec. 31.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) -- The Government reported today that new construction financed with Federal funds totaled $4,400,000 in 1952 -- a 5 per cent increase over the previous year.

It is now evident that the new Soviet regime has embarked on a new "peace offensive" which the free world may welcome for what it may prove to be worth. The significant fact is that for the first time since the end of the war the Communist chieftains are beginning to proffer concessions and accommodations which appear to be the results of considered policy.

BOWIE, Md., April 1 (AP) -- The Carolyn K. Stable's Hierarch turned in a fine effort today in the Greenbelt Purse to win the seven - furlong event by a head over Conty Bay. A neck behind the runner-up was King Jolie, the 4-to-5 favorite with the crowd of 10,928 fans.

Dr. Leonard Greenburg has been Commissioner of the city's new Department of Air Pollution Control only since last November, but he has already taken many steps that should improve anti-smoke techniques over those formerly employed by the old Bureau of Smoke Control.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 1 (AP) -- Both men's and women's singles ran true to form in the Good Neighbor tennis tournament today, although two young players knocked at the upset door.

Miguel Najdorf of Argentina dropped another half-point behind Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia, leader in the international chess masters' tournament at Mar Del Plata, when Najdorf was held to a draw by Herman Pilnik of Argentina in the fourteenth round, according to a report from Buenos Aires yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today in favor of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes in a jurisdictional dispute with the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers over the operation of certain equipment at the New York television studios of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Fifty-six longshoremen who got their jobs on Jersey City piers through the influence of Mayor John V. Kenny were shown today to have criminal records. Most of them had been employed at the Claremont Terminal, which the Army abandoned last November as a shipping center for Air Force supplies because racketeering and waste had resulted in excessive costs.

Television's coverage of the Easter parade on Fifth Avenue on Sunday will be somewhat curtailed as an aftermath of last year's coverage, when commercialism and press agentry dominated the programs. Home viewers still will be allowed a peek at the promenaders, but no single TV program will be devoted entirely to Fifth Avenue crowds.

GENEVA, April 1 -- Amid many signs of improvement in Western Europe's economic climate as spring moves north, dismal news emanating from Paris and London within the last few days about the finances of the Central Governments of Western Europe's two leading nations has profoundly disturbed responsible financial opinion in Europe.

JACKSON, Miss., April 1 (UP) -- Two Negro ball players signed by the Hot Springs, Ark., club of the Cotton States League were banned today from playing in Mississippi, home of four of the league's eight teams.

In reading your editorial of March 28 "Mr. Bohlen Confirmed" I was amazed to read that the delay on the confirmation "has been entirely due to a destructive and wildly irresponsible attack on the integrity of the present Administration. * * *"

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 1 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov's endorsement of Communist China's Korea proposal has convinced United Nations delegations that the Kremlin has now embarked upon its most comprehensive peace offensive since the start of the "cold war."

Study of proposals for a special joint committee to give the American export trade a means of unified action on common problems was approved yesterday at a meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau in the Statler Hotel.

MADRID, April 1 -- In contrast with former years, Spain's official commemoration of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's victory in the Spanish 1936-39 civil war was confined today chiefly to laudatory newspaper editorials.
Futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular, yesterday, 10 points higher to 15 lower.

Paralleling its Christmas exhibition, the Morgan Library has opened to the public in its East Room an exhibition of illuminated manuscripts depicting the Easter cycle Dating from the eleventh to the sixteenth centuries, the miniatures come from missals, Books of Hours, psalters and breviaries.

It is a bit surprising to find the editor of such a distinguished paper as THE NEW YORK TIMES endorsing the popular illusion that it is desirable, in a time of emergency such as the appearance of war, to freeze prices and wages. All of our experience with price-fixing during the Second World War demonstrated clearly that it had no effect upon the movement of the general price level.

Coal barge crews in this port have received a wage increase of $30 monthly, retroactive to March 16, Capt. William V. Bradley, acting president of the Tidewater Boatmen, Local 933-1, International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., said yesterday.

IN addition to countless big ones that were hooked and lost, a number of rainbow trout ranging from two to twelve pounds were taken by cold but determined opening-day anglers along Catherine Creek yesterday, where the usual crowd was on hand to participate in the special season effective on the Finger Lakes tributaries.

BERLIN, April l -- Such elaborate arrangements have been made by the British for the air safety talks they are conducting with Soviet air force officers here that London appears determined to insure that conversations prove a fair test of Soviet intentions in Germany.

After months of negotiation, the Congress of Industrial Organizations indicated yesterday that it was on the verge of readmitting a group of former leftist unions that had rid themselves of Communist influence.

The sale of men's clothing has started to increase after a long period of subnormal retail buying, Michael Daroff, president of H. Daroff Sons, Inc., Philadelphia, said yesterday at the semi-annual sales meeting at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. The upsurge in sales is expected to continue at least into 1954, he added.

LONDON, April 1 -- The stock market was again depressed here today by uncertainty over the economic consequences of a truce in Korea and by the setback in prices on Wall Street. However, losses though widespread were small on balance.
Record rainfall here last month cut gains in local department stores' Easter trade to 2 per cent over March of last year, according to the monthly survey, made yesterday, by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The present "onslaught" on free speech and free thought in the United States is weakening the nation's psychological warfare against the Soviet Union, Lester Markel, Sunday Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, advised the Senate Armed Services Committee today that he had disposed of all his General Motors stock, which was worth about $2,500,000 when he took office.

WASHINGTON, April 1--The Republican Administration moved a step closer to fulfillment of a major campaign promise today as the House of Representatives approved, 285 to 108, an offshore oil bill following lines President Eisenhower is known to favor.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- Following is the text of a report issued by the State Department today on Secretary John Foster Dulles' luncheon talk with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin:

A majority of the twenty-seven- man Mayor's Committee on Management Survey declared yesterday in the fourth installment of its report on overhauling New York City's government that an immediate program of "belt-tightening" economy could mean savings of between 5 and 10 per cent of payroll costs in most city departments.

The millinery industry is-starting to use direct trade advertising to open a new hat season, according to Sam Finkelstein, executive director of the Millinery Stabilization Commission, Inc., a trade association. Buyers are being urged to come to New York immediately after Easter to make their commitments for summer merchandise.

SATURDAY, 10:30 A. M.: The Children's Zoo of Bronx Zoo, which houses many animals that can be picked up and fondled, will open if weather permits. Adults must be accompanied by children, and admission is: adults, 18 cents; children, 20 cents.

The two new articles in recent issues of THE NEW YORK TIMES are, in my opinion, of the greatest significance in the evaluation of the tuberculosis problem which still exists in New York City. There are a few points which I think are worthy of re-emphasis and which are in line with the thinking of the many workers in the public health and hospital field, not only in this city but throughout the country.

Ashley Montagu's article, "The Natural Superiority of Women," which appeared last year in The Saturday Review of Literature, will be published by Macmillan on April 21 in an expanded version under the same title. The thesis is that mentally woman is "certainly" equal to man, physically better off than her male counterpart, lives longer and is more resistant to illness and morally outstrips her companions by many lengths.

The public should take with a few grains of salt the announcement that the International Longshoremen's Association has "ordered" abandonment of the shape-up system of hiring on the waterfront. Under this method longshoremen form a semi-circle at pier entrances and are employed by hiring bosses, a semi-padrone method which has given way to more civilized employment practices in most ports.

NOT until Jim Thorpe died would Pop Warner grudgingly admit that the fabulous Sac and Fox was the greatest football player he ever coached or saw. For a quarter of a century he had stubbornly insisted that the leader in his hit parade was Ernie Nevers of Stanford. The leonine Pop knew in his heart that he was wrong but he had strong reasons for his private heresy.
Quaker women volunteers celebrated the finishing of the 500,000th garment sewn in their workshops by seeing it modeled yesterday by the grandchild of one of their members.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Valentine E. Macy Jr. and J. Noel Mack, wealthy New York brothers, won a $397,000 tax suit against the Federal Government in a decision announced today by the Tax Court of the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The deferential language of the communique that was issued after the luncheon meeting of Secretary of State Dulles and Volunteer Secretary of State McCarthy does not obscure these facts:

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Dr. Allen V. Astin, ousted Director of the National Bureau of Standards, defended tonight the scientific work of the agency and said that it must stand by its findings regardless of "pressures."

WASHINGTON, April l -- Representative W. Sterling Cole, Republican of Upstate New York, was elected chairman by the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy today to break a two-month deadlock between Senate and House of Representatives members of the committee.

LONDON, April 1 -- In another fortnight, N. C. Hunter's "Waters of the Moon" will be two years old at the Haymarket Theatre, which is even older. Built originally in the time of Garrick and Dr. Johnson, the Haymarket has no office building overhead, or a garage underneath.
It was a question of a dog's life yesterday for Pal, a taffy-colored mongrel owned by 16-year-old Irene Pollinger of 1362 East Ninth Street, in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

The 1953 Eastern States Contract Bridge Championships, recessed since Sunday, resumed last night at the Park Sheraton Hotel. Four teams paired off in two thirty-six-board total-point matches in the semi-final round of the Reisinger Cup team-of-four championship.

Although the form of the United States Golf Association's open championship has been changed this year, with all players except the defender required to take part in a thirty-six-hole qualifying test immediately before the tournament proper, Ben Hogan intends to make a bid for the 1953 crown.
Soviet Russia's war potential is being reduced through economic warfare measures by Western nations, Col. Champlin F. Buck told 400 conferees yesterday at the Economic Mobilization Course.

A cartoon caricature of a young teacher who says the wrong things at the right times, a classful of precocious pupils who are more entertaining than a Joe Miller joke-book, and a battery of written questions covering a wide range of topics, may help shed some light on a problem that has perplexed school of officials for many years.

LONDON, April 1 -- After nearly five years of free medical and health service for the people of Britain, the Conservative Government has decided to institute an independent inquiry into the cost and efficiency of nationalized medicine, Iain MacLeod, Minister of Health, announced today in the House of Commons.

The apartment house accommodating fifty-four families at 35-07 147th Street in Flushing, Queens, has been sold by Abraham J. Morgenstern to the Trebla Realty Corporation, represented by Abraham Karp, attorney. The property is assessed at $195,000. The Trylon Business Exchange, Berman-Glassman Associates and Irving Kotzen were the brokers.
DENVER, April 1 -- With an effort born of despair, the Giants almost brought a little joy today into the harried life of Leo Durocher.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- Grains and soybeans followed a choppy price course in futures trading today. The markets were alternately strong and weak, but the general tone was mostly on the weak side. Prices were strong at first but demand faded quickly and on successive rallies there was free selling in all pits.
A horse in its declining years, hitched to a venerable Victoria, stole the show at a display of old cars yesterday in front of Plaza Hotel, Fifty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue.
New issues of public utility and oil securities aggregating more than $28,000,000 will be offered to investors today. The offerings are as follows:

Stock prices dipped at the opening yesterday but rallied before they could establish a new low for the year -- the day's bottom was 185.64, against 185.55 on Tuesday -- and advanced unsteadily on a narrow front to close the day with a gain of 0.94 point in THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The State Department snapped back impatiently today at suggestions that the Communists were taking the "initiative" in seeking peace, describing any such idea as "utter nonsense."

A scheduled hearing on a taxpayer's request for a temporary injunction to prevent the city from turning its subway, bus and street car lines over to the transit authority created by Governor Dewey and the Legislature was postponed yesterday until next Thursday after State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein intervened to uphold the constitutionality of the law establishing the new agency.

OTTAWA, April 1 (Canadian Press) -- Combines Commissioner T. D. MacDonald cleared a group of Canadian and United States companies today of charges that they had combined to fix prices illegally in Quebec's huge maple products industry.
Private deposits at commercial banks in this Federal Reserve district declined during the past year for the second time since annual surveys were started in 1943, according to data issued yesterday.

The appointments of James M. Landis, former dean of the Harvard Law School, as chancellor, and James Michener, Pulitzer prize-winning author, as president, were announced yesterday by the Asia Institute, 7 East Eighty-fourth Street.

ALBANY, April 1 -- Governor Dewey vetoed today a bill that would have required school buses, to begin flashing their signal lights 200 feet from the point where they planned to stop. He said it would seriously weaken the effectiveness of the present law, which requires lights only when buses are stopped.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 (UP) -- Ezzard Charles, lashing out with a deadly left hand, pounded out a unanimous ten-round decision over Rex Layne, the Utah farmer boy, tonight at Winterland Arena.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- The Forest Service told Congress today that the time has come for successful development of a newsprint industry in Alaska to meet anticipated newspaper printing needs.

Skunks can be very handy in the city. Ascanio Spolidoro, a gentle-voiced man who directs the city's park-touring marionette shows, has kept his skunk as a pet for two years and no longer worries about getting a seat on the subway.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- The Census Bureau estimated today that 3,440,000 or 77 per cent, of about 4,500,000 persons employed by state and local governments late last year had retirement coverage. It said that they came under state and local government plans or Federal Social Security.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 1 -- Dag Hammarskjoeld, dapper 47-year-old Deputy Foreign Minister of Sweden, has accepted the Security Council's nomination to succeed Trygve Lie of Norway as United Nations Secretary General, he said here today.
LONDON, April 1 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement on the Korean war by Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, as broadcast by the Moscow radio:

LINDEN, N. J., April 1 -- The development of a new all-synthetic jet engine lubricant that will help more powerful jet engines of the future to push planes to higher altitudes and at faster speeds was announced here yesterday by the Standard Oil Development Company.

NEWARK, April 1 -- The General Dyestuff Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Analine and Film Corporation, filed suit for $6,200,000 damages in Federal Court today against fourteen defendants, including Ernest K. Halbach, the former president.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week decreased 446,000 barrels, according to the weekly report of the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 162,878,000 barrels, compared with 163,324,000 a week earlier and 158,816,000 a year ago.

JERUSALEM, April 1 -- The remains of about seventy Biblical scrolls believed to be 2,000 or more years old, have been found in a cave on the shore of the Dead Sea, about twenty-five miles east of here.

WITH SEVENTH DIVISION, at Korea Front, April 1 -- All this talk about a truce or a possible peace agreement on Korea is purely academic for a freckled-faced, red-headed officer from Frederick, Md. Capt John R. Fitzpatrick -- a legend if ever there was one in this outfit -- is headed home, albeit against his will.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, reported as irked at recent news stories reporting Department of Defense developments, has ordered a tightening of security measures within the Pentagon and has attempted to control information about policy discussions that frequently have no security classification.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) -- United States battle casualties in Korea rose by 404 last week to a new total of 131,928, the Department of Defense announced today.

TOKYO, Thursday, April 2 -- The Communists proposed today that liaison officers of both sides in the Korean war meet in Panmunjom on Monday to begin making arrangements to exchange the sick and wounded prisoners of war and discuss the resumption of armistice negotiations.

CLEARWATER, Fla., April 1 -- Two lazy flies, one by Forrest Burgess against Tom Gorman in the tenth, gave the Phillies a 2-1 victory over the Yankees today. If placed end to end, these mighty blows might have covered 600 feet, but in this ball park, where the right-field foul line runs 291 feet, they were home runs.

In the past year or two there have been several occasions on which metal stocks were strong on reports of oil discoveries on their properties. But yesterday the most active stock on the Big Board was the Panhandle Oil Corporation and the rumor in the Street was that the company has discovered a show of manganese on its properties.

A building-wide blood donor day at 444 Madison Avenue, in which forty companies and persons from near-by shops participated, brought 560 pints of blood for the American Red Cross yesterday. Three Red Cross bloodmobiles were on hand for the contributions.

ALBANY, April 1 -- The state wound up its fiscal year yesterday with a surplus of $6,992,071, the largest since 1946-47. It was the second consecutive year that the Dewey Administration had closed its books with cash on hand.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- The annual Congressional junket season gets under way with a bang this week, aided and abetted by a ten-day Easter recess of the House of Representatives. The end of the week will find House members in or nearing such distant lands as India, Pakistan, France, Italy, Thailand, Formosa, Hong Kong, Indo-China and Japan, to say nothing of Florida, Texas, Louisiana and Puerto Rico.

The whole family should be consulted in plans for decorating the home, several speakers agreed yesterday at the afternoon meeting of the American Institute of Decorators at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. William Pahlmann was master of ceremonies at the three-hour session, entitled "What's Your Problem ?"

BONN, Germany, April 1 -- Dr. Werner Naumann and his fellow Nazis will be charged with plotting against the security of the Federal Republic of West Germany, the office of the Federal Prosecutor announced today.

CHICAGO, April 1 (AP) -- Harold Worst of Grand Rapids, Mich., youngest player in the world three-cushion billiard tournament, took over the Undisputed lead today, defeating Mel Lundberg, Minneapolis, 50 to 34, in 49 innings.

VIENNA, April 1 -- The new coalition Government, made up of the People's and Socialist parties, will be sworn in tomorrow. It was formed tonight on the same lines as the old one, but with Julius Raab as the People's party Chancellor instead of Dr. Leopold Figl and two new Socialist State Secretaries.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 1 -- The Communist clique here has been put in a rather embarrassing position by the vote of the principal South African labor organizations last week-end calling for a labor union front to include all races.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Arguments on motions to dismiss the perjury indictment against Prof. Owen Lattimore, once head of the Walker Hines Page School of International Relations of Johns Hopkins University, and for a bill of particulars were concluded in Federal District Court here today.
Clover sprigs on chintz give a sprightly look to a small series of bedroom settings at Altman's. Used in combination are matching small checked prints and solid colors.

The chapter of the final report of the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey that is published today apparently provoked much dissension within the committee. It is titled "Program for Economy," and specific savings claimed as possible are challenged by city officials and former city officials on the committee.

The State of Texas borrowed $10,000,000 yesterday on veterans' land bonds due from 1960 to 1989 at an interest cost of 2.38 per cent. The state accepted a purchase bid of a banking syndicate headed by Harris Trust and Savings Bank, marking the fourth successive time that this syndicate account has won award of a Texas state borrowing.

TRENTON, April 1 -- The State Senate, by a unanimous vote, today passed and sent to the Assembly a bill extending the life of the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council for two years. The measure had been the subject of considerable controversy and several long Senate caucuses since it was introduced in January at the request of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The White House announced today the appointment of Stanley N. Barnes, presiding judge of the Superior Court of California in Los Angeles, to be an assistant attorney general. Judge Barnes, who will resign his judicial post, will become head of the Anti-Trust Division of the Department of Justice. Confirmation by the Senate is required .

TOKYO, Thursday, April 2 -- The Chinese Communists unleashed a sharp attack today against South Korean positions on the central front in Korea and were beaten back with heavy casualties in an hour's fight.

An advance in the price of sheets will take place soon after Easter, according to a consensus of sheet buyers who have their fingers on the pulse of the cotton textile market. The rise is likely to be at least 10 per cent, but buyers expect that it will be accomplished in two stages rather than all at once.

MOSCOW, April 1 -- In his initial foreign policy statement since resuming his old office as Foreign Minister, Vyacheslav M. Molotov pledged full Soviet support today to the Chinese statement on Korea and expressed the conviction that the proposals "will be correctly understood by the United States Government."

To the accompaniment of city and Army fanfare, the first contingent of Korea war veterans ever to be shipped directly to an East Coast port will arrive off Quarantine at 6 P. M. today and watch an all-night entertainment aboard ship by Broadway stars before debarking tomorrow morning.
TOKYO, Thursday, April 2 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,572, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korean time:

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy assured John Foster Dulles,Secretary of State, today that in the future his Senate Investigations subcommittee would keep the State Department more fully informed than it had in the past when shipowners agreed to refrain from carrying cargoes from free world ports to points where they could be used against United Nations troops in Korea.

The American Gas and Electric Company reported yesterday that its net earnings continued upward to a new high level in the twelve months ended Feb. 28. They reached $28,366,000, compared with $24,644,000 for the twelve months to Feb. 29, 1952, a gain of 15.1 per cent.
CHICAGO, April 1 -- Butter consumption in the United States fell last year to a new low of 8.8 pounds a person, the National Dairy Council reported today.

" Parsifal" when well done is a work of enchantment, but one waited in vain last night for the spell to descend at the Metropolitan. Instead one sneaked a glance at one's watch, reflecting that nearly two mortal hours were to elapse before the conclusion of Act I.

MONTE CARLO, April 1 (AP) -- John Ager of Atlanta, and Bernard Bartzen of Fort Sill, Okla., a pair of young Americans who are putting a new zip in the spring European tennis tournaments, triumphed again today and gained the quarter finals of the Monte Carlo international tournament.

HONG KONG, April 1 -- More than 1,000,000 persons in southwest China are reported to be affected by a famine in 133 counties in Sikang, Yunnan and Szechwan Provinces. The famine still is spreading and many persons are committing suicide because of cold and starvation, according to a report in the Chungkong Hsin Hua Jih Pao of March 24.

LOS ANGELES, April 1 -- A Senate subcommittee indicated today that it may seek revision of the anti-trust consent decrees under which the production of motion pictures has been "divorced" from the business of exhibiting them.

MINEOLA, L. I., April 1 -- Supreme Court Justice Marcus G. Christ received today a $50,000 damage suit by a resident of East Island who contended that sale of the Morgan mansion to a Roman Catholic order without a covenant limiting it to one-family use had caused the value of his property to deteriorate.
WEST POINT, N. Y., April 1 -- Army and City College played a 4-to-4 tie in baseball at Doubleday Field today. The game was called because of darkness at the end of the ninth inning.

It still seems almost incomprehensible to me that so raw a proposal as the transfer to the states of the tideland oil lands can be approved by Congress. The Supreme Court has held that these lands belong to the United States. Now it is actually intended to give them to the adjoining states, that is, to part of the people of the United States.

George V. Allen, the new United States Ambassador to India, said yesterday that he knew of no plans to reverse or cancel the policies this country has been following toward India for some time. He explained that they had the support of both Democrats and Republicans.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- President Eisenhower set in motion today a thorough scrutiny of the civil service system with the aim of withdrawing job protection from many Democrats in confidential or policy-making positions.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 1 -- The state parks and reservations committee of the Connecticut General Assembly raised a bill in committee today authorizing the state to sell a part of some state-owned land in Westport as a site for the proposed American Shakespeare Festival Theatre and Academy.

Dock workers of the International Longshoremen's Association refused to cross a picket line established by another American Federation of Labor union last night in front of the Isbrandtsen Company pier at Twenty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, and loading operations aboard the freighter Remsen Heights were halted.

Americans are undersaving and underinvesting, the New York Stock Exchange declared yesterday, and changes in the laws are urgently demanded to maintain prosperity by swelling the flow of equity capital.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, April 1 -- The first graduating class of thirty-seven officers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization will finish in England tomorrow a ten-day course in defensive measures against atomic, bacteriological and chemical warfare -- three categories in which the Soviet Union is known to be devoting considerable research.

VIENNA, April 1 -- Twenty-three of the occupants of the Czech plane which was flown by its flight captain and some of its passengers to Frankfurt instead of to Brno last week returned to Prague today complaining that they had been "tortured" by United States occupation authorities in Germany.

GUATEMALA, April 1 -- Assets of International Railways of Central America, estimated at $65,000,000, have been attached by order of a local court for compulsory collection of a $3,500,000 charity tax which the Government charges the company failed to cover since 1904.

As our distinguished French visitors -- the Premier, the Foreign Minister and their associates -- leave our shores today for their homeland, both they and we have reasons for satisfaction. There are reasons for anxiety, too. The frank speech delivered by Foreign Minister Bidault at Hunter College yesterday afternoon was an eloquent expression both of the accomplishments of the visit and the problems still to be faced.
A huge, spectacular, tuneful -- but also somehow placid -- show opened last night at Madison Square Garden as the 1953 premiere of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus.

TORONTO, April 1 -- The Inter-provincial Pipe Line System, originally opened in 1950 to transport crude oil from Edmonton, Alberta, to Superior, Wis., at the head of the Great Lakes, will be extended this summer 635 miles at a cost of $76,000,000 from Superior to Sarnia, Ont, T. S. Johnston, president, announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet, retired Commander of the United Nations Ground Forces in Korea, testified to a Senate Armed Services subcommittee today that he had been stopped from making an amphibious landing behind enemy lines in the spring of 1951 at a time when he and his commanders believed such a maneuver would have captured hundreds of thousands of prisoners and much heavy equipment.

PARIS, April 1 -- Europe has begun to formulate its first intimate impressions of the diplomacy of President Eisenhower's Administration. First Anthony Eden and R. A. Butler of Britain, then Rene Mayer and Georges Bidault of France, and now Konrad Adenauer of West Germany have been making the pilgrimage to Washington.

LONDON, April 1 -- Warmly and hopefully the British Government and Parliament welcomed today the new prospects for peace in Korea, and a Government spokesman said this country would do nothing to discourage or minimize any Communist bid to improve relations with the West.
Representatives of sixteen housing cooperatives comprising 10,000 units in the New York area met yesterday for the first members' meeting of the United Housing Foundation.

BUFFALO, N. Y., April 1 (AP) -- Gwilym A. Price, president of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, said today it was still too early to predict what effect a Korean War truce would have on the nation's defense industry. But, he told news men, Westinghouse would probably complete the biggest part of its backlog of defense orders.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 1 -- Trygve Lie, with just a "few days more" left as Secretary General, put behind him today the one problem that has involved him most personally in the last six months: the explosive controversy about the loyalty of some of the United States members of his staff.

SEOUL, Korea, April 1 -- Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, said at a press conference tonight, after inspection of the Thirty- first Regiment at "Old Baldy" and a handful of divisions during the day, that he was convinced there was no ammunition shortage in Korea.
SANTIAGO, Chile, April 1 (UP) -- President Carlos Ibanez del Campo swore in a new Cabinet today after having accepted the resignation of the old one.

BELGRADE, April 2 -- In a flurry of articles in the Yugoslav press, including an editorial in today's Borba, official Communist newspaper, Yugoslav leaders have publicly attacked United States policy in the Far East. Heretofore, Yugoslav officials have been content to voice their objections privately.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 2 -- Yugoslav military officials expect to broaden their staff contacts with individual members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and work out in great detail some of the broad principles of cooperation discussed in London during President Tito's visit with Prime Minister Churchill.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 2 -- Jimmy McLane tonight completed a sweep of the available American distance free-style titles by splashing home far in front of the field in the 1.500-meter event, first test of the Amateur Athletic Union's national indoor swimming championships.
VIENNA, April 2 -- Austria's new People's party-Socialist coalition Government was sworn in today and it will ask Parliament April 15 to approve its program.

TOKYO, Friday, April 3 -- Fire from enemy shore batteries hit the United States heavy cruiser Los Angeles yesterday as she was standing in Wonsan Harbor off the Korean east coast, bombarding the Communist port. The Reds' shrapnel sprayed the Los Angeles' deck wounding thirteen crew members, none seriously, the Navy said.

New borrowings by sales finance companies held the net decline in business loans from New York banks to $26,000,000 last week. The reduction compared with $114,000,000 in the similar week a year ago and brought the total decline since the start of this year to $88,000,000, against a decrease of $40,000,000 in 1952.

North Haven, Conn., yesterday sold $1,150,000 of school bonds due from 1954 to 1973 to Glore, Forgan Co. and associates at a bid of 100.016 for 2 1/4s. Reoffering was at yields ranging from 1.3 per cent to 2.35 per cent. Lee Higginson Corporation, W. E. Hutton Co. and Bache Co. are associated in the offering.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (UP) -- Housewives one of these days may carry home fruit juice, potatoes and vegetables in their pocketbooks -- at much cheaper prices.

Judges can do their part toward reducing crime in this country by making intelligent and wider use of probationary procedures, a conference arranged by the National Probation and Parole Association was told yesterday.

PARIS, April 2 -- French officials, who tend to take the latest Communist proposals more seriously than previous ones, insist that a cessation of Chinese Communist intervention in the war in Indo-China must be a major condition of any general Far Eastern settlement.

Walter Gieseking, the German pianist who as a result of anti-Nazi demonstrations and questioning by the Immigration Service canceled his 1949 recital here, has become "not excludable" under the McCarran Act.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- President Eisenhower said today that he favored a straight one-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act pending a profound study, as he put it, to determine long-range trade policy for the country's over-all good.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 2 -- The election of Dag Hammarskjoeld, Swedish Deputy Foreign Minister, as Secretary General of the United Nations is now expected to take place on Tuesday, and he plans to arrive Thursday to take the oath of office.

LONDON, April 2 -- Much of the industrial water used by London is becoming contaminated by salts from the tidal section of the Thames, according to reports from engineers of factories along the river estuary.

TOKYO, Friday, April 3 -- The United Nations Command prepared today for new meetings next week with the Communists at Panmunjom to negotiate an exchange of sick and wounded prisoners of the Korean war, a new step toward an eventual armistice in the conflict that is already almost three years old.

Among yesterday's contributors at the Manhattan Blood Center at 70 West Fortieth Street was Mrs. Marie McMillin, a 50-year-old parachutist who has made 699 jumps and expects to make her 700th in St. Louis in September.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- President Eisenhower will be on a short vacation April 13, so he won't be available to make the first pitch of the 1953 major league baseball season. But he named a relief pitcher, Vice President Nixon, to start the game between the world champion Yankees and the Washington Senators.
Starting as early as the age of 13, women begin to outspend men, Lester Rand, president of the Youth Research Institute, declared yesterday.

Since, basically, household budgeting and municipal budgeting are much alike, our citizens will regard with sympathetic interest and -- an eye cocked at possible new "nuisance taxes" -- with some trepidation Mayor Impellitteri's struggles to produce a balanced executive budget by April 7.

MIAMI BEACH, April 2 (AP) -- Top-seeded Gardnar Mulloy of Miami and Hamilton Richardson of Tulane University, fourth seeded, gained the semi-finals in the fifth annual Good Neighbor tennis championships today.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- President Eisenhower made it clear today that he did not intend to allow the Kremlin's long catalogue of broken promises to interfere with his determination to explore the present Soviet peace offensive.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The State Department announced today that thirty-six jobs in the Voice of America, all in the New York area, would be eliminated and that 610 posts here and abroad, now vacant, also would be abolished.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 2 -- Fourteen Southern Governors joined tonight in petitioning the Federal Communications Commission to extend for at least two years its present deadline of June 2, 1953, for the filing of applications to reserve noncommercial educational television channels.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (UP) -- The House of Representatives was told today that veterans worth up to a half a million dollars were getting free treatment in Government hospitals on the ground they cannot afford private medical care.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 2 -- Princeton University's varsity worked out today for the first time in the newly launched "Delos C. Schoch," an eight-oared racing shell named for the Tiger coach and given to the university by the 1952 crew.

The United States and its Allies must not make the mistake of regarding Russia and the Russian people as the enemy in the struggle against Soviet communism, the Russian Political Committee of New York has declared in a public statement. Such a mistake "might strengthen the Communist power in Russia," the statement added.

Walter Hoving, president of Bonwit Teller, Inc., said yesterday that he would form a citizens committee to try to induce Robert K. Christenberry, president of the Astor Hotel and chairman of the State Athletic Commission, to run for Mayor on the Republican ticket.

The Mayor's Committee on Management Survey wisely recognizes the paramount importance of transit. The transportation chapter of its final report, published today, is an excellent, penetrating discussion which might well be must reading for appointees to the new Transit Authority as an introduction to their task.

The Public Service Commission ruled yesterday against a cut in gas rates for 1,200,000 natural-gas customers of the Consolidated Edison Company in Westchester County and areas of Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 2 -- The Dutch Government has taken the position that the Soviet Union must relax its grip on the satellite states and put a halt to Communist agitation in Asia if it really is in earnest about a settlement with the West.

Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia, leader in the international chess masters' tournament at Mar Del Plata, suffered his first defeat there yesterday in the fifteenth round when he lost to Julio Bolbochan of Argentina, according to a report from Buenos Aires.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 2 -- Struck below the right knee by a line drive from the bat of Dave Philley, Vic Raschi did not appear to be hurt seriously today, but he left the game between the Yankees and Athletics -- the Yankees won, 6 -- 0 -- and went to Mound Park Hospital for examination.

New labeling requirements for all dutiable goods entering the United States from East Germany, especially cameras, will increase market opportunities here for Japan's high-precision camera products, according to Alex K. Reddin, executive of Balfour, Guthrie Co., Ltd., United States distributor for the Canon Camera Company, Inc., of Tokyo.

HATTIESBURG, Miss., April 2 (AP) -- Carl Creel, 26 years old, who cut off his left arm midway between the wrist and the elbow with a pocket knife, explained calmly. "I didn't figure there was anything else I could do." The mechanic's left arm was pinned under his ear yesterday when the car turned over three miles from New Augusta, his home town.

United States Attorney J. Edward Lumbard, who took office on Wednesday, swore in six assistants yesterday, all Republicans and World War II veterans. The six, "recruited" by Mr. Lumbard from various law firms throughout the city, received their appointments from Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- President Eisenhower nominated Kenton R. Cravens, St. Louis banker, today to be administrator of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. Mr. Cravens would succeed Harry A. McDonald as head of the lending agency. Mr. McDonald's resignation was accepted yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- President Eisenhower asserted today that he and not the Secretary of Defense would determine what the nation's level of combat strength should be.
NAIROBI, Kenya, April 2 (Reuters) -- Easter leave for all security forces in this African colony was canceled today as the Mau Mau war boiled up.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, April 2 -- In a colorful ceremony commemorating the second anniversary of the creation of Supreme Allied Headquarters here, Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander, warned today that the "threat" to the free world from the military capability of the "potential aggressors has not diminished an iota in the last two years."

Hand-woven fabrics, by Jack Lenor Larsen, some of whose designs were used in a handsome setting at the American Institute of Decorators exhibit this week, are now on view in a larger collection at Mr. Larsen's new quarters in the Silkar Studios showroom, 38 East Fifty-seventh Street. The materials are available through decorators.

NEW ORLEANS, April 2 -- Manager Charley Grimm's Braves beat the Dodgers today, 11 -- 3, at Pelican Field before 8,300 fans, who had defied the all-morning rain and had appeared at the park at a time when it did not seem play would be possible.

Nine policemen, including a deputy inspector, a lieutenant and a sergeant, pleaded not guilty yesterday before Third Deputy Police Commissioner Aaron Frank to charges of neglecting to enforce the gambling laws.
Thor Heyerdahl, the Norwegian anthropologist who crossed the Pacific in 1947 on a balsa raft named Kon-Tiki, unlocked a large leather bag and surveyed a wide assortment of coffee and tobacco cans.

WILMINGTON, N. C., April 2 (AP) -- Mike Souchak, the 25-year-old Pennsylvanian who turned professional after graduating last spring from the Duke University, and Tommy Bolt, registering out of Maplewood, N. J., each put together a pair of 33's today to take a one-stroke lead in the $10,000 Azalea open golf tournament with six-under-par 66's.
Cyril G. Fox has been elected a director of Bayuk Cigars, Inc. Mr. Fox is president of Fels Co., Philadelphia, Pa.
ROME, April 2 (AP) -- For the first time since the war, the Italian lira today was bringing the full official exchange rate on the dollar black market.

Getting ready for its three-day holiday, the stock market yesterday moved uncertainly and closed somewhat easier, with plus and minus signs peppered over almost every group. Oils, rails and aircrafts had wide swings but they were in both directions.
Three New York hostesses, fine cooks and cook book writers, suggest today what might be good to eat and dring at an Easter brunch.
DUBUQUE, Iowa, April 2 (AP) -- An anxious father had what he termed a "satisfactory" visit late today with his 18-year-old son, confessed slayer of five persons.

LONDON, April 2 -- Moscow made still another small goodwill gesture to the West today. George Edward Robinson, a British seaman sentenced to prison in the Soviet Union last October, was released under last week's Soviet amnesty decree.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- During the week ended April 1, member bank reserves decreased $843,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

GENEVA, April 2 -- In both official and religious organization circles here that have had most to do with refugee problems since World War II, there is strong belief that the Western Governments are still misinterpreting and underestimating the political significance of the refugees from Eastern Europe.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Navy today canceled contracts for the construction of 100 F-10-F Jaguar jet fighter aircraft that were to have been built by the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation of Bethpage, L. I.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 2 -- Incomplete returns tonight indicated that members of the Marine Firemen, Oilers, Watertenders and Wipers Union had voted today in favor of a resolution looked upon as a stepping stone for the return of this 6,000-member union to the American Federation of Labor after sixteen years as an independent organization.

TOKYO, April 2 (AP) -- Japan and the United States signed today a new treaty of friendship, commerce and navigation. The treaty restores full commercial and friendly relations between the two nations for the first time since the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt abrogated an earlier one in 1939 in an effort to halt Japanese aggression.
MUNSAN, Korea, April 2 -- The moment an agreement is reached on an exchange of prisoners a receiving city will spring up at Panmunjom to care for United Nations men.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 2 (AP) -- Two records were broken today in the first two events of the National Amateur Athletic Union women's indoor swimming and diving championships.

CONVENT STATION, N. J., April 2 -- Eleven gay young college girls abandoned Easter shopping, parties and other vacation activities to flock back to the College of St. Elizabeth today for a very serious pre-Easter egg hunt -- for salamander eggs.
Pennsylvania Railroad trainmen and conductors are taking courses to learn how to put into practice the saying: "The customer is always right."
MONTREAL, April 2 (UP) -- Chicago defeated Montreal, 4 -- 2, tonight in the fifth game of their National Hockey League semi-final series.

A new plan for conducting professional tennis tours was announced yesterday by Jack Kramer of Los Angeles, promoter of the matches in which he has been appearing with Frank Sedgman of Australia and which has been breaking records for gross receipts.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- President Eisenhower gave Congress today the outline of a plan for reorganizing the Office of Defense Mobilization and establishing it on a permanent basis. The mobilization agency also would assume the duties of the present National Securities Resources Board and the stockpiling functions of the existing Munitions Board.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 13 points lower to 5 points higher.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- President Eisenhower said today that he did not believe Administration foreign policy had been "undermined" by the actions of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, in obtaining and publicizing voluntary agreements made by Greek owners of 242 vessels to refrain from shipping cargoes to Iron Curtain ports.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 2 -- A shift in international thinking has developed over the last few years with regard to international commodity arrangement the Interim Coordinating Committee for such agreements reports in its 1952 review, issued today for its parent group, the Economic and Social Council.

BERLIN, April 2 -- The United States and France accepted today a Soviet invitation to participate in the air safety conference here, at which the British and Russians previously had been the only participants. Each of the four powers will be represented by an air force officer of moderately high rank. Their first meeting probably will take place Monday or Tuesday.

Harold M. Parsekian has been appointed sales manager for all plastics manufactured by the Naugatuck Chemical division of the United States Rubber Company, and Chester W. Ort has been named assistant divisional manager of the Western division of the United States Tires division of the company.

Those managerial complaints about a Broadway booking jam aren't justified, according to William Brandt, who operates any number of grind picture houses in Greater New York, including seven former legitimate theatres on Forty-second Street.
WICHITA, Kan., April 2 -- Coming down from the higher altitudes of the Rockies, the Giants, it can be mercifully said, showed considerable improvement today. They allowed the Indians only three runs.

Two versatile and durable fabrics, denim and corduroy, have been combined in a small group of room settings at Macy's, some of which have a fresh, country look, others a sophisticated town appearance.

BONN, Germany, April 2 -- The West German Government wants a "positive" reply from the Soviet Union to past Allied conditions as a pledge of Moscow's sincerity in any new approach to reunification of this country, it was learned authoritatively today.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Spring renovation at the White House this year is in the East Wing, which was untouched in the recent reconstruction.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (UP) -- The Senate confirmed with high praise and by voice vote today the nomination of William Howard Taft 3d to be Ambassador to Ireland. Senators of both parties made speeches recommending the nominee while his father, Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Republican leader, read at his desk.
Three of this week's exhibitions of painting and sculpture show to what varying lengths away from nature artists will go to express what they consider significant ideas.
Robert A. Inch, who was appointed to the United States District Court bench in the Eastern District on April 28, 1923, will observe his eightieth birthday today.

" NO one can kid me into believing this was anything but a last-minute idea," said one of the Boston Braves angrily. "I passed by Braves Field just before I came here to Florida and the painters already were at work getting the park ready for the new season. Lou Perini wasn't painting a ball park that he expected to abandon a few weeks later."

ROME, April 2 -- An Italian Foreign Ministry spokesman issued today a warning against placing too much reliance in the more conciliatory attitude that the Kremlin seems to have assumed toward the West since Premier Georgi M. Malenkov's rise to power.

As a former member and one of the last few survivors of his old New Orleans Item staff will you permit me to thank you for your very full telegraphed account of the death of Marshall Ballard, editor of The Item for so many years?
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect quotation as required by White House rules:

WASHINGTON, April 2 (UP) -- The Treasury announced today it had cut $50,883,000, or 7.6 per cent, from the $665,328,000 requested by former President Truman to run the department in the new fiscal year beginning July 1.

President Eisenhower, in a letter to Senator Saltonstall, has reaffirmed the primary concern of the Administration with the proper fashion in which to meet our defense needs. Not merely in its budgetary aspects, he points out, but in the whole field of the implementation of policy there is continuing and extensive study.

Aronowicz of 19 West Fifty-seventh Street never does the usual or ordinary in furs. His showing yesterday at the Plaza Hotel of spring and summer designs was delight in its fresh, uninhabited approach to styling, which was at all times in excellent taste.

Guaranty Trust Company of New York, in its quarterly condition statement issued today, reports resources of $2,899,021,670 on last Tuesday. At the end of 1952 resources were $3,149,028,289, while on March 31, 1952, the figure was $3,085,389,645.
CHICAGO, April 2 (AP) --Livestock: prices reported today by. the Department ot AgricuLture fort?: . ,: : . . :. -.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 2 -- The Screen Directors Guild has denied the applications pending since last September of Herbert J. Biberman for reinstatement to active membership and also has removed him from the list of members holding "withdrawal" classifications, the writer-director said today.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., April 2 (AP) -- American Federation of Labor stereotypers voted today to end their two-day strike against the two Syracuse daily newspapers and return to work.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Leonard W. Hall, Surrogate of Nassau County, L. I., and former chairman of the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee, continued today as the front-runner in the race for chairman of the Republican National Committee, but he still lacked the important approval of President Eisenhower.

Major banking and investment banking groups in the United States are organizing syndicates to bid for the prize $128,400,000 General Aniline and Film Corporation, one of the nation's largest dyestuffs and film combines.

An 18,000-ton troopship was converted last night into the most talented night club in America to help Korea war veterans pass the time as they waited anxiously to establish their first American beachhead in eighteen months.

Columbia opened its seventy-second baseball season at Baker Field yesterday, against Manhattan, but the occasion proved a drab one for the Lions. Under cloudy skies, the visiting Jaspers registered a 9 to 1 victory, scoring their second triumph in two days.

Governor Dewey's memorandum approving the Rent Control Bill and the fight for and against the measure have obscured the real issue behind controls. Rent control has never been a cure for housing. It creates tensions between landlords and tenants, accelerates, disrepair, encourages disrespect for law, is an unjust restriction upon private operations.

The City Center scored another bull's-eye last night. A week after its acclaimed revival of Rossini's "La Cenerentola," it put on a brilliant production of Marc Blitzstein's "Regina." There was electricity on the stage and in the pit, and there was electricity in the audience. With this achievement, the Center's opera company not only did itself proud but, even more important, restored a notable American lyric work to the stage.

Volume was light yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Only potatoes and hides were active. Prices were irregularly lower with cocoa, soybean and cottonseed oils, wool, hides and lead registering declines. Coffee, rubber and zinc closed higher and sugar, potatoes and tin were mixed.
COCONUT ISLAND, Hawaii, April 2 (AP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman said today that "no one was ever hurt" by a shortage of ammunition in Korea while he was in the White House.

Under the auspices of the women's advisory board of the Lenox Hill Hospital, a dinner dance for the benefit of the hospital will be held on April 15 in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. James M. Snowden heads the committee in charge of plans and Mrs. John W. Drye Jr. is vice chairman. Among their aides is Mrs. William G. McKnight.

A slight but seemingly significant shift toward greater objectivity and fairness with regard to the non-Communist world has been observable in the Moscow newspapers Pravda and Izvestia during the last three or four days, diplomatic sources with contacts in Moscow reported yesterday.

The Port of New York Authority asked the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday to equalize the rates for grain shipped from the Great Lakes for export on the railroads serving this port and on those hauling the grain to Baltimore and Philadelphia.

CHICAGO, April 2 (AP) -- A nose injury to Champion Rocky Marciano today resulted in a five-week postponement of his world heavyweight title defense against Jersey Joe Walcott from April 10 until May 15 at the Chicago Stadium.

Plans are being mapped by American industry to spend $18,000,000,000 to $20,000,000,000 annually on new plant and equipment from 1954 to 1956, about $4,000,000,000 more than in the peacetime prosperity years of 1947-1950.

First quarter earnings of the Shell Oil Company are expected to be somewhat below the $1.80 a share earned in the corresponding period last year, H. S. M. Burns, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- President Eisenhower told his news conference today he had no knowledge of reports that Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks dismissed Dr. Allen V. Astin as director of the National Bureau of Standards without hearing Dr. Astin's side of the case. The President added he had faith that Mr. Weeks would be the last person to be arbitrary and unjust.

MOSCOW, April 2 -- United States and Soviet newspaper editors, in an evening of unusual friendship and cordiality, exchanged toasts tonight to Premier Georgi M. Malenkov of the Soviet Union and President Eisenhower of the United States.

A heavy newspaper campaign for its R. C. A. Room Air Conditioner has been started by the R. C. A.-Victor division of the Radio Corporation of America. The campaign, announced by the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, features a carefully-planned market-by-market approach designed for each area at the time of peak sales opportunity.

The actual cost to the city of a ride on its subways, buses and other lines, including depreciation and interest on the 1952-53 debt, is slightly more than 16 cents, according to the newest report of the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey, made public yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 2 (AP) -- Joe Procita of Gloversville, N. Y., rallied to defeat John Fitzpatrick, Hollywood, Calif., 50 to 49, in sixty-three innings as today's four-match session in the world three-cushion billiards tourney opened at the Town Club.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- The Department of Justice said today that Julius and Ethel Rosenberg had "waited too long" to raise some of their present challenges to their convictions and death sentences for slipping atomic secrets to Russia.
JERSEY CITY, April 2 (AP) -- Mayor John V. Kenny and his bitterest political enemy, former Mayor Frank Hague Eggers, filed complete tickets today for the Jersey City municipal elections May 12.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 2 -- Delegates to the United Nations General Assembly are looking forward to next Tuesday, when the Assembly will start back to work after the Easter recess, to see whether the Soviet Union is now willing to make a conciliatory gesture regarding the germ warfare question.
Safety standards for the proper identification of non-toxic paints and on the flammability of children's clothing will be set up by the American Standards Association.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 2 (AP) -- Taking an early lead, the Minneapolis Lakers tonight romped to an easy 74-58 victory over Fort Wayne to take the National Basketball Association Western Division play-off series, three games to two.

The authors of the American Constitution failed to provide that when a Senator answering to the description of Joseph R. McCarthy appeared on the scene other agencies of Government, including the State Department, should abdicate. There is nothing Mr. McCarthy won't do for his country, or won't seem to do, provided he can get a mention of himself on the front pages of newspapers, on radio and on television.

State officials opened last night a vigorous radio and television campaign to answer critics of the Dewey administration's new residential rent control law and of its creation of a transit authority to run the city's lines.

Felix Olkowski, 46-year-old ex-convict from Utica, N. Y., was arrested early yesterday in a furnished room with hold-up equipment that is alleged to have included two loaded revolvers, three blackjacks, two masks, rolls of tape and wire and typewritten cards that warned potential victims a hold-up was in progress.
MOSCOW, April 2 (Reuters) -- The party of American newspaper men and women which made history by getting permission to visit Soviet Russia today saw some of the sights of Moscow.

Although most banks will remain open, the principal security and commodity markets of the United States, England and Canada will be closed today, Good Friday. In this country most dairy, poultry and livestock markets will continue to do business.

It is a truism today that we must have a large and able group of scientific personnel if we are to be strong and if we are to continue to benefit from technological progress. Against this background it is good news that the National Science Foundation has awarded 556 fellowships for graduate work to promising young scientists throughout the country.

The magnificent exhibition of Japanese art at the Metropolitan Museum has well earned the attention you have given it, in both your editorial and art columns. What is on display is in almost every case a masterpiece.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Western Maryland Railway Company today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to approve changes to be made in its three classes of outstanding stock to eliminate more than $22,000,000 of unpaid dividends on its first preferred shares.

The Reisinger Cup, representative of the 1953 Eastern States team-of-four championship, was won last night by the contract bridge team of Oscar Yablon, William Yablon, Norman Neiger, Lester Glucksman and Milton Roth.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (UP) -- Joseph R. Farrington, Hawaiian Delegate to Congress, introduced a bill today to force the Army to restore white crosses over the graves of 14,000 American war dead on Honolulu's "Hill of Sacrifice."

Mayor Impellitteri spent four hours yesterday working on his executive budget for the fiscal year 1953-54 in the office of Budget Director Abraham D. Beame in the Municipal Building. He will continue the task this afternoon, and if necessary, devote tomorrow to the job of completing the budget schedules and his budget message to the Board of Estimate.

To make effective use of gamma globulin -- the blood derivative used to fight the paralyzing ef fect of polio -- the Red Cross, at the request of the Office of Defense Mobilization, has expanded its defense blood collections to provide the maxi mum amount possible.

The Isbrandtsen Company freighter Remsen Heights was forced to sail from her Twenty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, pier yesterday without all of her cargo, when dock workers of the International Longshoremen's Association refused for the second day to cross a picket line established by another American Federation of Labor union.
Sidney S. Levine, former City License Commissioner, was convicted of twenty-four traffic violations and paid fines totaling $1,050 when he appeared yesterday before Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh.

Higher operating costs in all phases of oil industry operations reduced the 1952 net income of the Humble Oil and Refining Company to $145,292,100 from the 1951 net of $169,480,600, which had included $4,673,500 of nonrecurring income from the sale of capital assets and investments.

John J. McCloy, former United States High Commissioner for Germany and now chairman of the board of directors of the Chase National Bank, told the State Chamber of Commerce yesterday that abuse of Congressional investigating powers and processes was helping advance Communist aims by sowing unwarranted suspicion of the loyalty, integrity and competence of career officials.

A group of twenty-six bungalows and four one-family dwellings at the northeast corner of Beach 106th Street and St. Marks Avenue at Seaside, Rockaway Beach, Queens, has been sold by Edward C. Teperman to Shamrock Enterprises, represented by Vincent T. McCarthy, attorney. John J. Brennan was the broker.

We wish to enter a strong protest against the inhuman and barbaric practice, as reported in your paper, of slaughtering 700 innocent black bears for the purpose of providing the hideous headgear known as shakos for the Royal Guard to wear at Queen Elizabeth's coronation.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Friday, April 3 (AP) -- United States Ambassador Karl Rankin gave an unqualified no today to a question on whether an armistice in Korea would be followed by a betrayal of Nationalist China.

Directors of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation have designated May 5, instead of April 29, as the date for a special meeting of stockholders to vote on a proposal to eliminate cumulative voting from the corporation's bylaws.

LONDON, April 2 -- A new zinc and iron alloy has distinct possibilities as a steel coating and may be used as a substitute for costlier nickel as an undercoating for chromium plating, according to the British Iron and Steel Research Association.

Resources of The National City Bank of New York on Tuesday amounted to $5,823,569,978, according to the bank's quarterly statement of condition, issued today. This figure compares with $6,117,115,200 last Dec. 31 and $5,883,765,872 on March 31, 1952.

ALBANY, April 2 -- A measure making it an unfair educational practice for institutions of higher education to accept any endowment or gift of money or property conditioned on the teaching of any doctrine of racial superiority was approved today by Governor Dewey.

MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L. I., April 2 -- Col. Royal N. Baker, this country's leading jet ace, returned today to the base where he had served five years ago as commander of a peace-time reserve fighter group.
The Crucifixion of Christ on Calvary will be solemnly commemorated today as churchgoers throughout the city join in the sorrowing prayers and meditations of Good Friday.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- Peace developments appeared to be taking a more positive turn causing considerable selling pressure on grains early in the session. Later evening-up set in with the shorts showing a little more willingness to accept profits.

The just-concluded hearings on color television before the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce have helped to clear the air on the whole subject of tinted video. So far as the average set owner is concerned, he can relax: color TV still is quite some time off.

MOSCOW, April 2 -- A Soviet diplomatic offensive of broad scope and great speed, which appears to have as its objective the opening up of a whole series of major deadlocked issues between the East and the West, in now under way, in the opinion of veteran Moscow diplomats.

MONTE CARLO, April 2 (UP) -- Bernard Bartzen of San Angelo, Tex., gained the men's singles semi-finals in the Monte Carlo international tennis tournament today with a three-and-a-half-hour 6 -- 3, 9 -- 11, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 0, 9 -- 7 victory over Philippe Washer, Belgium's No. 1 player.
In a first-floor classroom of Public School 135, First Avenue at Fifty-first Street, twenty-six enthralled children watched for the first time yesterday a television broadcast on their big, new set.

OTTAWA, April 2 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's traditional deficit in trade with the United States widened sharply during January as imports continued to rise while the ports remained almost unchanged from a year ago.

Charles Walzer and Seymour Chinich, operators, sold the six-story loft building at 114-18 West Seventeenth Street for cash over mortgages amounting to $130,000 in a deal negotiated by L. V. Hoffman Co., brokers.

Sixteen thousand blouse and waist makers in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania will receive wage increases and other improvements beginning July 1 under a new contract ratified yesterday by Local 25, International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The prospect of getting control of nearly 100 well-paying jobs, now under Civil Service, opened up to the Eisenhower Administration today as Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, attacked as "a dismal failure" last year's effort to set up a blue ribbon career service in the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

LONDON, April 2 -- The stock markets today shook off some of the dullness of the first part of the week. Trading eased before the long Easter week-end holiday through Monday, but there were some scattered gains.

HOBOKEN, N. J., April 2 (AP) -- Two aliens slid down an improvised rope from their Ellis Island dormitory early this morning and swam a frigid half-mile to a Jersey City pier but were recaptured here at the home a friend.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 2 -- Reports from Central Java today warned that the situation for 2,000,000 persons in the area of the Merapi Volcano had turned critical. There is a lava stream along the northern ridge reaching a width of more than fifty feet and dispatches from Surakarta, on the eastward slopes of Merapi, said that "rumbling noises" could be heard and that lava streams rapidly were developing on the eastern and western slopes.

The Appellate Division refused yesterday to let a grand jury investigating waterfront rackets examine the personal records of Joseph P. Ryan, which District Attorney Frank S. Hogan had subpoenaed from the union leader's accountant.

Solomon Fried has sold the four-story twenty-five-family apartment house at 2073 Seventy-eighth Street, Brooklyn, to the Terrace Realty Corporation, represented by Leo Zivin, attorney. Goldstein Goldstein were attorneys for the seller and the Security Title and Guaranty Company insured title.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Federal Government is engaged in a legal drive to bring under its control the voyages, cargoes and profits of $100,000,000 worth of oil tankers once owned by the Government but sold as surplus to private interests after the war.

Elements of credit-fed boom are still riding with the economy to an extent that might justify an increase in the prevailing Federal Reserve Banks' rediscount rate as well as entry of the Treasury into the long-term bond market to compete with other borrowers for the economy's available capital savings, according to the April financial letter of the National City Bank.

DETROIT, April 2 (UP) -- Ted Lindsay and Bob Goldham sent the Red Wings off to a fast start with goals in the first minute tonight, but Detroit was hard pressed for a 6-4 victory over the Boston Bruins to keep alive their hopes of retaining the Stanley Cup.
Airlines here were preparing yesterday for a great travel rush over the Easter week-end, but railroads expected no record traffic for the period.
Soviet Russia can now provide the economic support required for a full mobilization, Col. James E. Reilly of the Air Force declared here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- President Eisenhower said today that he would rather see Government-purchased butter marketed at a loss, even a complete loss, than have it spoil while some people were starving.
