Philippine Air Lines, Inc., has leased one-third of the Fifth Avenue store frontage in the sixteen-story and penthouse office building being built at 589 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of East Forty-eighth Street. The space will be used for ticket and sales offices now at 590 Fifth Avenue.

A paint and paper version of the circus moved into the Franklin Savings Bank this week on Eighth Avenue at Forty-second Street, a mere eight blocks south of the live seals and elephants at Madison Square Garden.
By accident or design, three out of every 100 motorists using parking meters overstay the legal limit and 75 per cent of them are being caught.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (UP) -- Miss Grace Lumpkin, an author, testified today that she had written Communist propaganda into a 1934 novel after being told that Communist book reviewers would "break" her literary career if she did not.

LOS ANGELES, April 2 -- A subcommittee hearing of the Senate Small Business Committee turned today into a session of polite name-calling between two antagonistic elements in the motion picture business -- those who make and rent the films and some of those who exhibit them.

Easter dinner based on the traditional baked ham will cost more this year than last. But if leg of lamb or a small turkey is chosen for the festive table, the food bill will be lower than last Easter. Eggs, however, are not only scarce but costlier than a year ago, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday.
TRENTON, April 2 -- Joe Adonis, one of the country's most notorious criminals, is not going to get out of prison even long enough to attend his own deportation proceedings.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Some Administration officials near, but not on, the topmost tier emitted sounds that resembled the man-eating Cornish giant's "Fee, fi, fo, fum" when they read that Senator McCarthy's staff had "negotiated" a compact with Greek shipowners.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Pentagon concluded today that a new chapter in the world struggle was opening, and it viewed -- with mixed feelings -- the Communist overtures for peace in Korea.

Four buildings with 103 apartments at 1325 to 1337 Grant Avenue, the Bronx, have been purchased by Rodac Associates, Inc., for investment from 1337 Grant, Inc., for cash over mortgages of $280,000. The sellers were represented by Levy, Gutman Goldberg, lawyers, and Smith Isaacs acted for the buyers. Abbott Adams, Inc., were the brokers.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- The proposal of Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, for a reduced budget for his department would wipe out Federal aid to shipbuilding amounting to $118,500,000.

It was only a claiming race, but as far as the larger part of the crowd of 24,108 was concerned, the third event on yesterday's card at Jamaica was of greater importance than either of the tests accorded nominal feature rating.

John J. McCloy, former High Commissioner for Germany, has been elected to the board of trustees of the Rockefeller Foundation, it was announced yesterday by Dean Rusk, president. Mr. McCloy had been a trustee before his appointment to the foreign post in 1949.

LONDON, April 2 -- Queen Elizabeth II who on Tuesday attended the funeral of her grandmother Queen Mary at Windsor, today performed the traditional ceremony of distributing the Maundy money at St. Paul's Cathedral.

THE light-tackle enthusiasts who picked this week to fish at Bimini must have checked with a crystal ball before leaving, but the report on the records broken during the past few days indicates that the male anglers "also fished."
Thirty-two thousand employes of the United States Rubber Company, members of the United Rubbers Workers, C. I. O., went on strike early yesterday at eighteen plants in ten states.
ROME, April 3 -- Premier Alcide De Gasperi celebrated his seventy-second birthday today and it was evidence of his modesty that the event was almost totally neglected by the Italian press.

SCHENECTADY, April 3 -- The American Locomotive Company delivered to the Army Transportation Corps today the first of eighty-three new diesel-electric locomotives adaptable to world wide use on tracks of differing width and in temperatures as low as 65 degrees below zero.

LISBON, Portugal, Saturday, April 4 -- Former King Carol of Rumania died near here early today of a heart attack. He was 59 years old. Princess Helena, the former Magda Lupescu, was at his bedside when he died.
There were 353 deaths here as a result of tuberculosis in the first three months of 1953, as compared with 498 in the same period last year, the Department of Health reported yesterday.

Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Columbia University School of Journalism announced yesterday that he has stopped cooperating with Federal, state and police agencies investigating his students "except on written request and advice of counsel."
LONDON, April 3 (AP) -- British Overseas Airways opened its fourth and longest jet airline route today as a Comet took off from London airport for Tokyo, half a world away.
FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korea, April 3 -- A new town is coming into being tonight.

CHICAGO, April 3 -- Chester W. Anderson resigned today as vice president and general operating manager of Montgomery Ward Co.'s retail and mail-order divisions, complaining that Sewell L. Avery, chairman, failed to delegate "even minor authority" to executives of the company.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 3 -- "Profound changes" taking place in the trade patterns of Asia should have encouragement from this country in order to help Japan resist Soviet overtures, a spokesman for business told the Commonwealth Club today.
WILMINGTON, N. C., April 3 (AP) -- Tommy Bolt moved into a one-stroke lead at the halfway mark of the Azalea open golf tournament today with a 69 for a 36-hole total of 135.

Major security and commodity markets in the United States, Canada and the United Kingdom were closed yesterday in observance of Good Friday. Most banks in this country were open, however, as were the livestock, dairy, poultry and fruit and vegetable markets.
A two-day-old strike of 35,000 workers at nineteen plants of the United States Rubber Company was ended early this morning with the signing here of a new contract that will run until March 31, 1955.
The Moscow announcement of the release of the accused doctors is in line with widely voiced Western skepticism regarding the truth of the murder accusations of last January.

" WHAT lured you into playwriting, Mr. Mizner?" Ashton Stevens once asked Wilson Mizner. "Stringent vagrancy laws," was Wilson's sturdy, forthright, memorable answer. It is the profusion of just such helpful thoughts for today that makes Alva Johnston's "The Legendary Mizners,"* a joint biography of Wilson and his brother Addison, such a magnificent album of rascality in the modern world.

With three more rounds to be contested in the international chess masters tournament at Mar Del Plata, Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia, who defeated Eric Eliskases of Argentina in the fifteenth round, yesterday, maintained a lead of 1 1/2 points with a score of 14-2, according to a report from Buenos Aires.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 3 -- The Commission on the Status of Women -- the United Nations' only all-feminine group -- ended today a three-week session devoted to the advancement of political rights for women and the improvement of their economic and social well-being.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- Robert Ramspeck, former chairman of the Civil Service Commission, said today the records of Congress would show that Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, "is not telling the truth" in saying Mr. Ramspeck had promised that there would be competitive examination for all top posts in the reorganized Bureau of Internal Revenue.

Walt Dukes, Seton Hall's All-America center, will head the New Jersey quintet that will play New York in the fifth annual college all-star basketball game tonight at the Dickinson High gymnasium in Jersey City. New Jersey is favored to capture its third victory in the series.

LOS, ANGELES, April 3 -- Superior Judge Stanley N. Barnes, appointed Wednesday to be Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Department of Justice's Anti-Trust Division, indicated today the keynote of his regime would be "prosecution but not persecution."

We do not think that the summary dismissal of Dr. Allen V. Astin from his post as Director of the National Bureau of Standards by Secretary Weeks has been adequately explained. Mr. Weeks declares that he acted on "more" than the complaint of a manufacturer of a battery revivifier who had "no luck in getting the National Bureau of Standards to run tests" of his product.

The annual celebration of Easter will begin with services at midnight tonight and dawn tomorrow. Special Easter Eve services will be held this afternoon and tonight for Protestant Episcopal congregations, while Eastern Orthodox congregations will attend Resurrection services which, in some cases, will start at 11:30 P. M. today and continue several hours.

LONDON, April 3 -- Recent wavings of the olive branch over the Kremlin have been accepted by the popular press in Britain at what seems to be more than their face value. The Government takes these gestures pretty much as President Eisenhower does -- at what they are worth as words go until they are backed up by deeds that will help undo the aggressive acts of the Soviet Union in the last few years.

Congress is in some cases abusing its investigatory powers. With this statement in a speech made in this city by John J. McCloy, former United States High Commissioner for Germany, most Americans who call themselves liberals would agree. So would those Americans whose conservatism includes a respect for ancient traditions of intellectual honesty and fair play.

A 53-year-old foot patrolman was shot and killed last night by a man he had pursued as a suspect in a Harlem robbery earlier in the evening. The assassin, who may have been injured in the pistol duel, escaped.
PARIS, April 3 (AP) -- French aircraft manufacturers showed publicly today a "convertible" jet-propelled airplane-helicopter capable of both vertical motion and speedy horizontal flight.

LONDON, April 3 -- A spokesman of the Greek Cooperation Committee, which is composed of the London owners of Greek-registered merchant vessels, indicated today that the committee would do nothing about a proposal from the United States that the owners should undertake not to send their ships to Far Eastern Communist ports.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Deportation proceedings against three alleged alien racketeers were announced today by Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr.

SEATTLE, April 3 (AP) -- Directors of Puget Sound and Light Company approved today the basic terms of a proposed merger with Washington Water Power Co., which operates in eastern Washington and North Idaho.

As one who had a large share in the preparation of many amendments to the election law of this state during more than two decades past I feel competent to disagree with many of the suggestions and criticisms of M. Maldwin Fertig, as set forth in his letter to you of March 19.
ABILENE, Tex., April 3 (AP) -- Leonard Warren, Metropolitan Opera baritone, was singing a vigorous aria here last night. "Louder!" hollered a man in the audience.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 3 -- Important changes in the credit arbitration terms of the basic contract between the Screen Writers Guild and the Motion Picture Producers Association will be voted on by the union membership at a meeting on April 22.

The diplomatic shake-up which traditionally follows a change in Administrations naturally has its unfortunate as well as its good side. Some first-rate Ambassadors have to leave their posts because they are political appointees, not career officers. One of the best such envoys of the last years of the Truman Administration was Ellsworth Bunker, who left Rome yesterday after only eleven months as Ambassador.
A wildcat strike of New Jersey longshoremen halted the loading of two Navy ammunition ships yesterday at the Leonardo loading depot.

Andrew Rosenthal's new play, "Horses in Midstream," which opened Thursday night at the Royale Theatre, was unanimously rejected by the critics, who, although conceding the presence of good acting, pleasant scenic effects and expert direction, characterized it as generally ineffectual.

A 35-year-old Internal Revenue agent was held in $2,500 bail yesterday, charged with accepting a $4,000 bribe from a wealthy clothing manufacturer, who passed him the money to help tax authorities trap the agent.

Mrs. Anna Maier of 351 East 136th Street, the Bronx, was accused last night by the police of having caused the death of two of her five children by dropping them out of a window of her fourth-floor apartment. She was booked on two charges of homicide and sent to Bellevue Hospital for observation.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 3 (AP) -- The $12,500 series for the National Basketball Association crown starts tomorrow night on a floor the New York Knickerbockers have never seen before -- but it doesn't bother Coach Joe Lapchick much.

Moshe Sharett, Israeli Foreign Minister, arrived at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday. Mr. Sharett, who will be here eight days, said he will "compare notes on the problems of the Middle East and world peace" with President Eisenhower and Secretary of State John Foster Dulles.

" A Challenge to Jewry: A Discussion on Basic Jewish Problems," by Joseph L. Tepper, is one of two books published today. Issued by Vantage Press, the volume sells for $2.50. The other book is a science-fiction novel by George O. Smith entitled "Hellflower." It is published by Abelard Press at $2.75.
MOSCOW, April 3 -- Pravda declared today that the Soviet Government was manifesting a "desire to improve relations with the Western powers."

HARTFORD, April 3 -- Robert Anderson, State's Attorney of New London County, began an investigation today into charges that a Republican party leader in that county sought to raise a $4,000 fund to help kill an anti-fireworks bill in the Connecticut General Assembly.

An application for $500,000 in Federal assistance has been filed by twenty-five Nassau and Suffolk County school districts whose population, including a large influx of defense workers, has almost doubled in the last fourteen years.

Tahitian King and Eddie Arcaro made the figures stand up at Jamaica yesterday. The 3-year-old colt owned by Ben Whitaker responded to a precisely rated ride by the master jockey to take the five - and - a - half - furlong feature race by a neck over Alfred G. Vanderbilt's Social Outcast.

VIENNA, April 3 -- Hungary, once the granary of Europe, but now reduced by Communist rule to a state that can scarcely grow its own food, seems to be facing perhaps the most serious crop crisis in her history. There are indications that Czechoslovakia and Rumania may find themselves in similar though less acute difficulties.

LONDON, April 3 -- Doubts about the wisdom and value of the role that the United States has often played in the Middle East -- the role of "honest broker" -- have lately been expressed in British diplomatic circles.
A New York University associate professor, his wife and two children were found dead in their Queens apartment yesterday after a sudden outburst of violence.
Two armed men held up the Air Craft Hardware Manufacturing Company, Inc., 810 Edgewater Road, the Bronx, at 3:15 P. M. yesterday and escaped with $24,000.

TOKYO, Saturday, April 4 -- Radio stations at Peiping and Pyongyang have launched a major propaganda effort in support of the Communists' extensive and apparently well-coordinated "peace offensive," which gets its first significant test Monday at Panmunjom, site of the Korean armistice talks.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- The present outlook is for a deficit at the end of the fiscal year, on June 30, of about $6,500,000,000 or about one-half a billion more than was expected, according to Government fiscal specialists.
LONDON, April 3 (AP) -- Preston North End, Charlton Athletic and the Wolverhampton Wanderers remained tied at the top of the first division in English soccer today.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "Murder Will Out," a British-made suspense melodrama with Valerie Hobson and Edward Underdown is at the Normandie. The Eros Films presentation was produced by Robert S. Baker and Monty Berman from a screen play by John Gilling.

PARIS, April 3 -- The disposition here to believe that the latest Communist "peace offensive" represented more than mere propaganda was accentuated today by an official announcement that the Soviet Government had finally obtained the release of fourteen French civilians seized by North Korean forces when they captured Seoul in June of 1950.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (UP) -- Interior Secretary Douglas McKay today proposed a $54,000,000 cut in his department's money request for next year, and a Republican appropriations leader in the House of Representatives said he planned to slash it still more.

Manhattan began donning her floral finery yesterday in preparation for the spiritual and temporal celebration of Easter that marks for Christian the rebirth of hope and for all the ascendance of spring over winter.

A horse-drawn wagon laden with flowers came trundling down the street. They were Easter flowers -- jonquils, tulips, hyacinths, narcissus -- lovingly arranged by the driver, an Italian, into a bed of joyous color reminiscent of the flower stalls on the Spanish Steps in Rome.

ST. LOUIS, April 3 -- St. Louis' long - cherished ambition to be a major inland port will be realized to a degree soon when direct waterborne freight service to Alaskan, Canadian and West Indies ports is inaugurated.
CHICAGO, April 3 (AP) -- Ray Kilgore of San Francisco tied for the lead in the world three-cushion billiards tournament tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, acted tonight to carry out his intention to "get the best brains I can find" to evaluate the operations of the National Bureau of Standards, the director of which, Dr. Allen V. Astin, was forced to resign this week.

Retailers are extremely interested in new style features in men's and boys' sportswear and outerwear, according to Mrs. Haydon Fields, fashion coordinator of Waldes Kohinoor, Inc. Mrs. Fields recently completed a tour of Chicago, Minneapolis, San Francisco and Los Angeles, where new designs were shown to retailers and manufacturers.

HARTFORD, April 3 -- The Joint Judiciary Committee of the Connecticut General Assembly voted a favorable report today on a bill increasing the membership of the Common Pleas Court bench from ten to twelve judges.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (UP) -- President Eisenhower feels his lunches and breakfasts for members of Congress are adding to his friends on Capitol Hill, a White House aide said today. Congressional response was described as "generally satisfactory."
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 3 -- A child was killed and seven persons were injured in a three-car crash on the New Jersey Turnpike just south of here at 2:40 P. M. today.

BOSTON, April 3 (AP) -- The seven-time winner, Dr. Dave Freeman of Pasadena, Calif., and the defender, Ethel Marshall of Buffalo, N. Y., gained the finals of the national singles badminton championships in their respective divisions tonight at the University Club.

Three parakeets -- one studying to be a Shakespearean actor, a second with a bill generously smeared with lipstick and a third named Benny after its owner's brother -- were reported missing from their homes yesterday. All disappeared this week. Nature lovers who might suppose the birds flew off because of some kind of parakeet spring fever will be disappointed. The departures have but one reason in common -- open windows.

YORK, Pa., April 3 -- York Corporation's 1953 production of room air conditioners should be 125 per cent over 1952, and it is possible that this year's output will be doubled in less than five years, Stewart E. Lauer, president of the corporation, one of the world's largest builders of air-conditioning equipment, said last night.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 3 -- Like a string of exploding firecrackers, Yugoslavia's collective farms are reacting to a Government decree permitting their discontinuance. Now the Government is worried that the announcement of agricultural reform may have been premature, since this year's harvest may be at stake.

Lumber production for the week ended March 28 was 14.6 per cent above the like week last year, according to reports wired to THE NEW YORE TIMES by regional associations. Shipments were up 14.3 per cent and orders 6.1 per cent. Following are the weekly statistics in thousands of board feet.
DUBUQUE, Iowa, April 3 (AP) -- Fred E. McManus, 18-year-old confessed slayer of five persons, agreed today to waive extradition to New York.

LUBBOCK, Tex., April 3 -- A lot of pent-up emotion exploded with a loud detonation today as Leo Durocher's long-suffering Giants finally got around to knocking the props out from under Al Lopez' cocky Indians.
Governor Dewey announced yesterday his support of Leonard W. Hall, Surrogate of Nassau County and former Representative, for the post of Republican National Chairman.

CHICAGO, April 3 (UP) -- The International Boxing Club was busy today denying rumors the postponed Rocky Marciano-Jersey Joe Walcott heavyweight title bout, reset for May 15, would be shifted from the Chicago Stadium.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., April 3 -- Transports flying 600 miles an hour at altitudes up to 40,000 feet will be in operation within the next ten years, Edgar Schmued, engineering vice president of the Northrop Aviation Corporation, said today at an engineering conference on the frontiers of man-controlled flight.

ATLANTA, April 3 -- Scoring five runs in the eighth inning off Dave Jolly and Dick Donovan, the Dodgers today beat the Braves, 9 -- 8, before 4,033 fans, but they almost blew it in the ninth when George Shuba muffed a simple fly ball.
Four of this week's exhibitions of painting include work that can be classified as realistic, though in two of these fantasy modifies plain statements.

SINGAPORE, April 3 -- Prospects of peace in Korea and reports of impending United States strikes by 30,000 tire and other rubber workers have caused one of the blackest weeks ever known on the Malayan share market. Singapore share brokers tonight estimated $10,000,000 has been slashed from quoted values of Malayan securities this week.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 3 -- A statement by North Korea that summarized Communist China's recent offer to end the deadlock on prisoners of war in Korea and urged the United Nations forces to "accept our just proposals" was received today by Lester B. Pearson, President of the General Assembly.

HERRING-EATING bears and bear-eating convicts have complicated matters for several residents of Stumpy Point, N. C., one of whom is now satisfied that birdshot is inadequate for repelling fish thieves weighing 390 pounds and clad in bearskin.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Harold E. Stassen, Director for Mutual Security, said today that he agreed thoroughly with President Eisenhower that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, was not "undermining" United States foreign policy with the
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles made it clear today that he wants Congress to repeal curbs on the importation of dairy and other farm products.

BEAUMONT, Tex., April 3 (UP) -- Mrs. Babe Zaharias took a one-stroke lead in the first round of the women's golf tournament named in her honor, as she shot 34, 37 -- 71, two strokes under women's par.

The blossoms on gift plants received at Easter may last several weeks, and with a little knowledge and care most of those plants will flourish year after year to provide beautiful flowers. William Harris, vice president and treasurer of the Goldfarb Flower Shops, a concern that has some of the largest greenhouses on the East Coast, was consulted on the best ways of caring for these plants.
NAIROBI, Kenya, April 3 (UP) -- British troops and native police, fearing a mass Easter Sunday attack by Mau Mau killers, round up 7,000 natives in pre-dawn raids today.
The new and old in automobiles will be shown at two exhibitions opening here today.

Earnings of Climax Molybdenum Company last year declined to $6,071,519, or $2.41 a share, from $7,964,169, equal to $3.16 a share in the previous year, according to the company's annual report issued yesterday by Arthur H. Bunker, president.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Anybody can drive a nail straight and fast with an invention patented this week. It's a .22-caliber rifle that shoots nails. The inventor, Chester Tietig, a Cincinnati patent lawyer, says the rifle "may be used by cripples and unskilled persons, for example women, to drive larger diameter nails than they would be able to drive by conventional means."

Of the various "peace offensives" that the Soviet Government has staged since 1945, the closest parallel to the present situation seems to be offered by the events that surrounded the lifting of the Berlin blockade in the spring of 1949.
LONDON, Saturday, April 4 (UP) -- The Moscow radio and the Soviet Tass news agency reported today on President Eisenhower's press conference in Washington Thursday. They said:

MOSCOW, Saturday, April 4 -- The Ministry of Internal Affairs early this morning announced the release of the nine doctors arrested last January on charges of plotting to kill Soviet leaders. Six other doctors who had been detained also were said to have been freed.

The American Jewish Congress strongly protested yesterday the decision permitting Walter Gieseking, German pianist, to enter the United States under the McCarran Act. The congress declared that "Gieseking's admission flatly belies the claim of the authors of the law that it was designed to protect us against subversives."

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved a plan of reorganization for the thirty-eight-mile New Jersey and New York Railroad Company, which will give entire ownership of the reorganized company to the Erie Railroad Company.

Three hundred and fifty-one G.I.'s from New York and New Jersey returned yesterday morning from a year or so of mud and fire in Korea and fell, amid tears of joy, into the arms of their waiting mothers, wives, sweethearts and other dear ones.

In this era of "cold wars" and Iron Curtains, an editorial such as yours of March 15 is one which should be read and remembered. "Intervention Is No Remedy" is the truest word that could be said on the subject of the spread of communism in Latin America.

MILWAUKEE, April 3 (UP) -- The Milwaukee Braves ticket mix-up reached its height today when the club began giving bleacher seat tickets to fans who tried to exchange the box seat ducats they already had bought.
TOKYO, Saturday, April 4 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,574, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday, Korean time:
The national council of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., voted approval yesterday of an increase in membership dues and the establishment of an initiation fee.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 3 (AP) -- Mitchell Long, a Knoxville lawyer who was a power in state Democratic circles and who had served on the Board of Governors of the American Bar Association, died yesterday at the age of 63.

TRENTON, April 3 -- The records before a joint legislative committee investigating the dismissal of Nelson F. Stamler as Bergen County crime investigator disclosed today that Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons had been prepared to resign his state position if Mr. Stamler remained.
Bernard M. Baruch expressed the opinion yesterday that the Eisenhower Administration was dangerous to the peace of the world through being "lukewarm" to stand-by economic controls.

MONTE CARLO, April 3 (AP) -- Jaroslav Drobny, a self-exiled Czech, trimmed Bernard Bartzen of San Angelo, Tex., and Wladislaw Skonecki, a self-exiled Pole, upset Denmark's Kurt Nielsen today to enter the final of the Monte Carlo intrnational tennis tournament.
JERUSALEM, April 3 -- From the courtyard of Rawdat el' Maaref to the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, 5,000 Christian pilgrims followed the Way of the Cross through Jerusalem's old Walled City today.

It is a tribute to the comprehensiveness of THE NEW YORK TIMES to find it interested in the geographically remote problems of Olympic National Park. Being one of the few New Yorkers who has spent time hiking in the park, I should like to present my views.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- The Eisenhower Administration struck its first blow at one of Washington's most popular institutions today: the "coffee hour."

Jack Kramer and Frank Sedgman of Australia will return to New York today for a return engagement on the tennis courts, along with Francisco (Pancho) Segura of Ecuador and Kenneth McGregor of Australia.

MOSCOW, Saturday, April 4 (AP) -- Last January, in Stalin's waning days, the Soviet regime accused nine doctors, five of them Jewish physicians, on the lines of statements made by Dr. Timashuk, a cardiograph specialist who is the wife of Dr. M. B. Kogan, one of the physicians now freed.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (UP) -- Mrs. Eisenhower didn't bother to buy a new dress for Easter. She bought a hat instead -- and an extra one.

Except for the "dark" days following the Crucifixion, the world has never been in more urgent need of a positive Christian faith, Bishop William C. Martin, president of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U.S.A., declared yesterday in an Easter message.

ROME, April 3 -- L'Osservatore Romano, Vatican newspaper, urged the Western powers today not to reach any conclusions on the Soviet peace overtures without taking Moscow's anti-religious policy into due account.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 3 -- In a move interpreted here as a setback for a group of Vice President Richard M. Nixon's California friends interested in patronage matters, Assemblyman Laughlin E. Waters of Los Angeles has been recommended by California's two Senators for the Federal Attorneyship in Southern California.

The 724th Mayor of Bath, England, will meet the 101st Mayor of New York at City Hall on Monday morning, and when Alleyne William Steward Berry leaves, Vincent R. Impellitteri is likely to be a wistful and discontented man.
Governor Dewey has signed the bill granting $100,000 additional state aid to approved city and county library systems. As your dispatch from Albany reports, the Governor stated in his memorandum:
LONDON, April 3 (Reuters) -- Results of football games in Britain today:

When children suffer seriously from headaches, strangely enough it is often their parents who require the most attention, according to specialists at the headache clinic of the division of neuropsychiatry, Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx.

The merging of Pellegrini Cudahy with Farrar, Straus Young, book publishing concerns that were founded in 1945, was announced yesterday. A statement explaining the merger was made jointly by Sheila Cudahy, editor and publisher of Pellegrini Cudahy, and Roger W. Straus Jr., president of Farrar, Straus Young, Inc.

TOKYO, Saturday, April 4 -- An outpost unit of the United States Third Infantry Division fought a savage two-hour battle with Chinese Communists on the west-central front in Korea early yesterday. The Americans, reinforced, finally beat off the Red attackers.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 3 -- It would have to be an emergency, but Casey Stengel would not hesitate to use Yogi Berra at any one of six positions during the forthcoming season.

Canada and Connecticut appeared last night to be close to the point where diplomatic relations might be severed over the question of jurisdiction over a crippled Canada goose, downed in the waters of Long Island Sound just off Point Byram, Conn.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, lashed out today at the head of one of his largest unions for proposing what Mr. Meany called an "unworkable, unconstitutional and dangerous" method of avoiding strikes affecting the national safety.

Members of the newly-formed Advisory Council of Judges of the National Probation and Parole Association advocated yesterday the extension of probation services throughout the country. They opposed legislation that required judges to impose specified minimum terms.

Dan Bucceroni of Philadelphia wore down Dave Davey of Seattle to the point where their scheduled ten-round heavyweight bout was halted at the end of the eighth round in the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 3 -- Jimmy McLane won the 220-yard free-style, for his second title of the meet, and Dick Thoman and Burwell (Bumpy) Jones retained their respective crowns in the 100-yard back-stroke and 300-yard individual medley tonight at the second session of the Amateur Athletic Union's national indoor swimming championships.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- The Justice Department announced the arrest of two persons tonight in connection with the theft of nine oil paintings from St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Cathedral at Bardstown, Ky., last November. The paintings, including three masterpieces, have been recovered.

There is a music season in New York just getting under way. Its opening does not hang on booking dates or season programs, but merely on the first warm breeze that opens the windows of the city. It is the music that comes from the streets, from back courtyards, from the fire escapes and window ledges -- the music that scales the brick of apartment buildings and comes into the home.
Deacon, the aging greeter at the Children's Zoo, will have a fellow crow named Inky to assist him this morning at the opening of the special youngsters' section of the Bronx Zoo.

Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany Hall, pledged yesterday the support of his organization in the campaign to prevent any reduction in the city budget of the appropriation for day care centers for children of working mothers. In a letter to Mrs. Randolph Guggenheimer, chairman of the Day Care Council, Mr. DeSapio wrote:

LONDON, April 3 -- When Terence Rattigan's "The Deep Blue Sea" received a professionally grumpy reception in New York last autumn the Internationalists exclaimed: "Yes, but you ought to see the London performance." Some of the Gotham curmudgeons were impervious to Mrs. Hester Collyer's fatal infatuation with Freddie Page, the sullen wayward aviator whose real life stopped after the Battle of Britain in 1940.

" Give Children a Brake" is the slogan of the National Safety Council's April Bulletin. As this is the season for children to get out their roller skates and bicycles, the council stresses the importance of youngsters being safety conscious.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 3 -- Officers of the Eisenhower Foundation, meeting here this week to discuss an Americanization program in the nation's schools, announced that the memorial building now under construction at the President's Abilene, Kan., home, was expected to be completed within sixty days.

There is reason to be anxious lest the preoccupation with the possibility of a truce in Korea bring about a slackening-off in the planning and execution of means of relief and rehabilitation. There is an inevitable tendency to "wait and see what develops." This can be hurtful.

The American editors now visiting Moscow have been greeted with cordiality in an atmosphere which correspondents on the scene describe as comparable only with that which prevailed during the Second World War. There is even to be a reception on Monday, with Soviet editors playing hosts to the Americans.

Mrs. Clara Cohn Weissman, 74-year-old widow living at the Murray Hotel, 66 Park Avenue, was fatally injured at 10 A. M. yesterday, the police reported, when she was struck by a truck at Thirty-eighth Street and Park Avenue. Mrs. Weissman was the mother of Mrs. Wilma Soss, public relations consultant and president of the Federation of Women Shareholders in American Business, Inc.

J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., reported as of March 31 deposits, including official checks outstanding, of $706,098,966 and assets of $788,017,012, compared, respectively, with $671,241,398 and $753,807,957 on Dec. 31. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $214,677,664, against $169,447,277; holdings of United States Government securities to $171,478,740, against $197,176,353, and loans and bills purchased to $321,163,463, against $297,856,497.

To lend an international note to tomorrow's dinner, dessert might be Italian Easter bread, Greek koulourakia or Russian pashka and kulich. For Easter is being celebrated on the same day this year both by the Eastern Orthodox Church and Western Christians and bakeries throughout the city offer confections traditional for the holiday in many lands.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The two-day conference of representatives of the nation's dairy industry will probably result in a coordinated program aimed at the industry's mounting problems. The conference ended today.
ROME, April 3 (AP) -- Flaring torches lighted a mournful Way of the Cross tonight on the Palatine Hill in the Good Friday commemoration of Christ's passion and death.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- Communist "brain-washers" may have so twisted the minds of some American soldiers captured in Korea that after the Korean war ends they will publicly declare they do not want to come home.

As Mayor Impellitteri continued his budget retreat in the Municipal Building yesterday afternoon, City Treasurer Spencer C. Young reminded city business concerns that the last day for paying the general business and financial taxes for 1952 would be May 15.

The "Monthly Review" of the New York Federal Reserve Bank devotes several pages of its current issue to analyzing and expressing its concern over the present situation with respect to installment credit. Borrowers' debts in 1952, the Bank's study points out, increased faster than their incomes.

Most retailers are confident they will set a new Easter season sales record this year by surpassing the previous peak figures of last year, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., declared yesterday. Retail volume for the week ended Wednesday was estimated by the financial agency to be 5 to 9 per cent greater than in the corresponding 1952 week.

For the general public the name Emanuel Alexander Goldenweiser, who died this week at his home in Princeton, will perhaps produce no clearly identifiable response. But there are at least two sizable groups that are conspicuous exceptions to this generalization.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent over the week ended March 31, 1953, to 109.8 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The drop of 1 per cent in farm products resulted mainly from lower prices for eggs, grains, cows, lambs, raw cotton, copra, green coffee, some live poultry and fresh fruits and vegetables.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, warned today that the Soviet Union constituted a "grave danger" to the free world and that its so-called "peace" moves did not justify any relaxation of defense against Communist aggression.

CLINTON, N. J., April 3 -- Pointers dominated the competition as the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club held its Puppy and Derby Stakes today on the state public hunting preserve during the third day of its five-day spring program.

The Red Cross is a volunteer organization, with volunteers directing its activities both at the national and chapter levels. The national president, E. Roland Harriman, is one of the non-salaried volunteers.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 3 (AP) -- Carolyn Green of the Fort Lauderdale Swim Association won the 500-yard free-style today by a judge's decision over Delia Mulenkamp of San Francisco Crystal Plunge Swim Club in the women's A. A. U. national indoor championships. They had identical times of 5 minutes 59.1 seconds.

Two weeks ago Senator Joseph R. McCarthy fought a shifting, bitter- end battle against the President's appointment of Charles E. Bohlen as Ambassador to Moscow. The Administration fought back and won. But it showed no inclination to press its victory, and brushed aside any suggestion that the Senator's action justified a clean break with him.

The date of Easter is fixed by the vernal equinox, the astronomical beginning of spring. The first Sunday after the first full moon on or after the 21st of March usually fixes the date of Easter. If the Paschal full moon should fall on Sunday, however, then Easter falls on the next Sunday.

The States Marine Corporation, in a move to broaden upper echelon control, has elected Neil S. Walsh and Arnold D. Frese to top posts, effective immediately, Henry D. Mercer, chairman of the board of the steamship line, said yesterday.

AN exhibition whose purpose is to assemble a cross-section of photographic activity in a limited region is announced by the Mansfield (Ohio) Advertising Club, sponsor of the Third Annual Exhibit of Photography.

Tennessee Williams, in his preliminary defense of "Camino Real," was "at a loss" to explain the precipitate exits of some members of the play's New Haven audience. He infers that these malcontents, unwilling to meet the play half way, had found it obscure and confusing.

PARIS, April 4 -- Maurice Bourges-Maunoury, French Minister of Finance, announced today that the Government would not be able to repay to the Brank of France on the date due, May 31, the 80,000,000,000 francs ($232,000,000) borrowed on the eve of Premier Rene Mayer's departure for the United States for his recent visit.

The New York A. C., 1952 victor, got the jump in its bid to keep the title as it halted Buddy Combs' Red Bank Polo Club, 16 -- 12, in the opening match of the best-of-three series for the national senior indoor championship at the Squadron A. Armory last night.

BOSTON, April 4 -- Gov. Christian A. Herter of Massachusetts has undertaken to solve a problem that has been vexing Greater Boston commuters for thirty-five years -- how to put their public transit system on a paying basis.

JOINING the parade of Easter floral displays is one which opens today in the greenhouses of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn. Over a thousand tulips, hyacinths, hydrangeas and other spring flowers are on view there.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Practically all the signs pointed today to the election of Surrogate Leonard W. Hall of Nassau County, N. Y., a former United States Representative, to chairmanship of the Republican National Committee on Friday, when the committee convenes here to act on the resignation of C. Wesley Roberts.

There are 7,000,000 women in this country who have some sort of cosmetic allergy, which means that they cannot use the ordinary types of beauty products without experiencing such unpleasantness as coughs, sneezes, hives, rashes or other skin disorders.

In his "War Humor in Three Wars" (March 22) Bill Mauldin modestly neglects to comment on the incomparable worth of his own "Up Front" cartoons. His magnificent Willie and Joe were members in the best standing of every combat outfit.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 4 -- The Government of Israel made a bid for resumption of diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union tonight after receiving the Moscow announcement that charges against fifteen Soviet physicians, including a number of Jews, had been proved false.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 4 -- The Northern Rhodesia Government was reported today to have dismissed or suspended 700 Negro Government employes for taking part in a two-day halt of work, organized by the African National Congress of Northern Rhodesia, to pray for delivery from a prospective Federation with Nyasaland and Southern Rhodesia.

THANKS to the successful showing in this country of the film "The Devil in the Flesh" based on Raymond Radiguet's novel, many literate Americans think of the author as a post-World War II youngster who met a premature death.

TRENTON, April 4 -- Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons charged today that Clendenin Ryan, independent candidate for Governor, was seeking to "block the extradition" from the Netherlands of Harold J. Adonis, a former clerk in the office of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll.
ALBANY, April 4 -- Governor Dewey signed eight election reform bills today to correct conditions disclosed by the State Crime Commission and to improve election and party procedures.

Fordham's nine routed Adelphi by 13 -- 4 at Fordham Field yesterday, collecting thirteen hits to triumph behind the hurling of Charlie Dietlin The right-hander yielded one run and five safeties in a six-inning performance and aided with two doubles. He clouted his second two-bagger with three on in the fifth.
PARIS, April 4 (UP) -- The president of France's Olympic committee said today he hoped Australia would either volunteer to give up its selection as the site for the 1956 games or else be forced out.

PINKHAM NOTCH, N. H., April 4 -- A strong Harvard array easily turned back Yale and Princeton today in the concluding intercollegiate ski meet held over Hillman's Highway on Mount Washington. The Cantabs, placing their three scoring men within the first five, rolled up a commanding score of 97.4 points (318.6 seconds) to regain the Triangular Trophy captured by the Elis last year.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, April 5 (AP) -- United States and South Korean troops shattered a company-sized Communist attack and seven smaller Red thrusts with rifles, machine-guns and hand grenades just before Easter sunrise touched the winding 155-mile Korean war front.
IN common with a number of English writers, Anne Barrett has the ability to take an improbable situation and turn it into a plausible-sounding, diverting story.

TIRED of civil war, runaway inflation and the ills of a collapsing Nationalist Government, the Chinese people accepted the prospect of Communist rule back in 1949 with varying degrees of assent. Some were enthusiastic. Many more were passively acquiescent. But by and large, there was a widespread feeling that China needed a change.

What is the best lighting system for airports when planes have to land in a fog? Because there is no agreement the 'National Bureau of Standards decided it was about time to step in. In cooperation with the Navy Bureau of Aeronautics it has developed the kinorama, a device that enables a pilot to appraise the merit of a system of approach lights without leaving the ground.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, policy-making instrument and official watchdog in the multi-billion-dollar atomic energy program, finally has a chairman after one of the most curious tugs of war ever witnessed on Capitol Hill.

John Kramer of Los Angeles and Frank Sedgman of Australia qualified last night for this evening's final of the experimental two-day professional indoor tennis tournament at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

EDGAR WIND has a double title at Smith College. He is Professor of Philosophy and of Art. A tall man, whose sharp owlish look is combined with a sardonic grin, he is one of the most brilliant of the German-born art historians, an intellectual detective who tracks down historic, philosophic, sociologic and economic implications and symbols in pictorial representation.

TOKYO, April 4 (AP) -- Gen. Mark W. Clark, in an Easter message to the troops in his United Nations and United States Far East Commands, said today "our hearts hold new hope that we may be near an honorable end of this grim but imperative task of upholding with our lives the ideals which flow from the influence of Christ on mankind."

MRS. CHARQUES' tale of the Third Crusade is not quite as outstanding as Miss Prescott's "The Man on a Donkey" -- that would hardly be possible -- nor is it any more so than Edith Simon's "The Golden Hand."

WASHINGTON, April 4 (UP) -- The Senate Republican leader, Robert A. Taft of Ohio, said today a settlement of the Korean war would make the Administration's budget-slashing job "even harder" because too big a cutback in military spending would be expected.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Top-ranking Republicans, led by President Eisenhower, were searching this week for a man of many talents, some real and some probably fancied, to assume the tough and important job of Republican National Chairman and chief patronage dispenser to a host of job-hungry Republicans who haven't held national power for twenty years.

ROME, April 4 -- One of the first tasks of the new Parliament, which is to hold its first sitting June 25, will be to ratify the European Defense Community treaty, said Premier Alcide De Gasperi this morning in a broadcast speech to the Italian nation in which he announced that the Senate and Chamber of Deputies had been dissolved and that general elections would be held June 7.

LIP service never cured a traffic problem or stopped a highway accident, Norman Damon, executive vice president of the Automotive Safety Foundation, says, pointing out that until business leaders are willing to give time and energy instead of bombastic speeches to solve congestion and traffic problems, conditions will keep getting worse.

ROME, April 4 -- Everyone except the Communists and other left-wingers is agreed that last Monday's strike called by the Communist-dominated General Confederation of Labor to protest against approval by the Senate of a law reforming the electoral system was a resounding failure.

ROME -- The newest tourist attraction in Italy is The Martian, a shiny gray-green super-luxury streamlined electric train that roars from Milan via Florence and Rome to Naples (523 miles) in 8 hours 55 minutes.

IN one of his movies Orson Welles declares derisively: "Switzerland? What has she produced in five hundred years? The cuckoo clock!" Mr. Welles might take a look sometime at this book by a young Swiss who, single-handedly, and with good cause, has sparked more bad jokes about the Swiss Navy than probably any other Swiss in history.
WILMINGTON, N. C., April 4 (AP) -- Tommy Bolt remained atop the $10,000 Azalea open golf tournament field for the third straight day today, but for the second time he had company.
Resources of the New York Community Trust increased from $19,178,449 in 1951 to $21,055,904 in 1952, Ralph Hayes, director of the trust, announced yesterday.

LONDON, April 4 -- The Soviet satellite regime in Rumania announced tonight that it was opening prison gates for many convicts as the Malenkov Government in Moscow did a week ago. It said prosecutions also would be eased in Rumania.

FROM Pennsylvania to Louisiana, from the Mississippi River to the Atlantic, the countryside and the main and secondary highways are dotted with markers, plaques, monuments and well-preserved battlefields of the Civil War.
TEL AVIV, Israel, April 4 (AP) -- Following is the text of an official Israeli statement:

THERE is a theory among producers on Broadway that the issuance of "twofers" -- coupons enabling the holder to purchase two tickets for the price of one --is undignified and tends to cheapen a show. However, as it is said, pride goeth before the fall, and several of our local entrepreneurs are discovering that "twofers" have stopped their fall.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The prospects of a truce in Korea were greeted with mixed emotions this week by the Pentagon and by politico-military observers in Washington.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., April 4 -- Official percentages for the Riverside Yacht Club's 1952-53 frostbite dinghy season which ended a week ago were released today, with the title going to Moragen, jointly owned and alternately sailed by Barbara and Teddy Sheldon.

CITY gardeners lead complicated lives. After a weekend in The Country I arrived back in town Sunday with an eight-foot redwood trellis ($2.77) strapped to the side of the car, a bag of peat moss ($1.65) in the trunk and three mint plants (free) dug from a friend's garden. Such goings-on may be involved but they're a normal part of spring and gardening in town.

PARIS, April 4 -- The reversal of Moscow's decision regarding the doctors accused of treason in January monopolized the first pages of the Paris press today and led to lively speculation in official and other quarters about what Le Monde called "an event without precedent in the history of Soviet justice."

The new $5,500,000 structure at 170 William Street to house the Beekman-Downtown Hospital will be dedicated at noon Tuesday. Patients in the present building at Beekman and Water Streets will be transferred to the new hospital next Saturday.

MERIMOND, only son of the Sultan of Dalmeria, is granted at birth the gift of having all his wishes fulfilled. Though the Sultan is delighted with the possibilities of this endowment, the Sultana fears that power without knowledge and judgment may prove her son's undoing.

Only thirty days have passed since Joseph Stalin's death transferred power to a new regime in the Kremlin. Last week the signs multiplied of a sharp and wide-ranging change in the tactics of world communism under its new leadership. The developments came both outside and inside Russia.
MELBOURNE, Australia, March 24 -- The Australian Government will send an expedition to the Antarctic next summer to establish a scientific station on the Antarctic continent.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The Department of Commerce and the Department of Labor reported today that expenditures for new construction in March rose by 10 per cent to $2,500,000,000, spurring the spending for the first quarter of 1953 to a record total.

NEWARK, April 4 -- The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company charged tonight that twenty instances of sabotage of cables and other equipment had occurred during the ten-day strike of its plant and accounting workers.

LONDON, April 4 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden declared tonight that Britain would "meet halfway any genuine attempt to reach a settlement" between East and West but at the same time he said this country should not relax its defense effort or become separated from its friends.

WITH the lengths of the seasons and bag limits for waterfowl based on the status of the ducks and geese during the nesting and rearing season, plans have been completed for detailed breeding ground surveys to be carried out by United States and Canadian wildlife agencies.

Chancellor Henry T. Heald has named Alan M. Stroock, partner in the law firm of Stroock Stroock Lavan, as a member of the Board for Development at New York University. The board was established last December to help determine and carry out policies in the ten-year program to raise $102,105,000 for buildings and endowment.

To further research and other efforts to improve judicial administration in this country, the Rockefeller Foundation has made a grant of $250,000 for a five-year period to the Institute of Judicial Administration, Inc., Arthur T. Vanderbilt, president of the institute, announced yesterday.

THE 1953 assault by high- powered Western livestock interests on the public lands has officially begun. With the introduction of a bill (H. R. 4023) that would turn their present grazing privileges in the national forests into a vested right, the stockmen have resumed the attempt they have been making for years to undermine, if not destroy, the firm control essential for effective public management of these Federal properties.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 4 (AP) -- Billy Goodman's grand-slam home run in the eighth inning today powered the Red Sox to a 6-3 victory over the Birmingham Barons of the Southern Association.

TO judge by their acting in Noel Coward's "Quadrille," Lynn Fontanne and Alfred Lunt are enjoying their visit to London. And, to judge by the laughter and the applause, audiences are enjoying them as guests. On everybody's part this is a sound critical attitude with which this column would like to associate itself.

BOWIE, Md., April 4 (AP) -- The Sidney Jacobs-trained entry of Hueso and Main Bout finished one-two in the $10,000-added Cherry Blossom stake here today before 21,757 fans -- biggest crowd of Maryland's 1953 racing season.
The Augusta National Golf Club course at Augusta, Ga., which President Eisenhower has been selecting for his vacation golf, will be the scene this week of the famed Masters tournament.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 4 (AP) -- Dave Schneider's Elixir won the $15,000 Fort Lauderdale Handicap by four lengths while under restraint through the final sixteenth of a mile before 16,732 spectators at Gulfstream Park today.

Despite the best efforts of professional records managements and the microfilmers, business, industrial and government leaders are swamped daily by an avalanche of reading matter, some of it marked "must," the rest of it merely "essential."

AIJAL, Lushai Hills, India, April 4 -- In Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's view, political necessity suggests that foreign evangelical missions in India should be staffed by Indian workers instead of outsiders, particularly in these primitive border areas where integration of tribes in all stages of civilization into the Indian body politic is a serious problem.

HARRY PARKER, a pioneer in the development of electronic flash, and Milton J. Schwartz, a leading specialist in the field, will discuss "Electronic Flash as a General Purpose Light Source" at 7:45 P. M. Wednesday at the April meeting of the New York Section, Technical Division, Photographic Society of America.

IN his scholarly surveys of various aspects of human behavior -- "Gamesmanship," "One-Up-manship" -- Stephen Potter has provided a guide calculated to help all of us who circle the racetrack of life. For this, much thanks. But nobody has provided a similar guide examining the relatively new world of the gramophone, that bewildering complex of wires, tubes, resistors and electronics which deposits Mozart in your home and you in Elysium.

THE controversy over the origin of Kaiserschmarrn, and whether it is eaten with Apfelmus or Zwetschkenroster has provoked a number of requests for the recipe which Leonard Jan Mitchell, author of "Luchow's German Cookbook," has been happy to supply. Here it is:

It has often been observed that the celebration of the Holy Easter, the observance of the Feast of the Passover and many other expressions of religious faith that come in the season of the spring have much in common. Each has its peculiar significance to the devout.
ELMSFORD, N. Y., April 4 -- The Sonotone Corporation has suspended without pay for one week 111 of its 650 employes here for walking off the job without permission to attend Good Friday Services.

Three major works, by Sisley, Corot and Matisse, will be auctioned Wednesday evening in a sale of modern paintings and African sculptures at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue. The works of art are from James Sauter and Mrs. Winifred C. Bowman of New York, among other owners.

An increasing number of parents are resorting to "strong-arm measures" to keep their children from joining neighborhood gangs or committing delinquent acts, according to Frank J. Hertel, associate general director of the Community Service Society.

THE possibility that geese mightn't be as silly as supposed was raised recently, not by an ornithologist but by two Canada geese themselves. On a lake out Connecticut way went the report, these two skittered along the surface beside a crippled fellow-goose in an attempt to help him take off for the nesting grounds.

UNLESS present trends are radically reversed, April and May promise to be exceptionally busy months for those who keep pace with the wildflower procession. Ever since March nature lovers have been reporting that spring was racing through the woodlands.

THE important role being played by the air carriers in developing resort business is highlighted by the announcements by National Airlines and Eastern Airlines of their spring-summer program of vacation promotions.

TEHERAN, April 4 -- Premier Mossadegh of Iran has now accepted simultaneous combat with the British Empire on the oil issue, with powerful domestic royalist and parliamentary factions, and with awesome economic problems -- and all while propped up in the bed from which he conducts most of the nation's business.

iVfembers of the St_ Nicholas Society of New York will give a dinner tomorrow night in the main ballroom of the Plaza to celebrate the 106th Paas Festival of the society. :The guest of honor and principal speaker will be %rice Admiral Arthur D. Struble, U. S. N., Naval Representative on the 1V[ilitary Staff Committee of the United Nations.

I ENJOYED Clyde Kluckhohn's review of Simone de Beauvoir's "The Second Sex" but I disagree strongly with what he wrote on the effect of housekeeping on women. * * * It should be, it really ought to be, that the continuous buying of goods, cleaning, washing and polishing, food preparation and purchasing is no more frustrating than filing papers and the like, but the fact is, it is.

Moscow's startling repudiation of the entire "doctors' plot" fabrication focused attention once again on the key question: What is happening at the top of the present post-Stalin Soviet power structure? Like the concrete proposals advanced earlier for a Korean truce, as well as other moves in the past month, this abrupt reversal seemed to represent a clear repudiation of policies initiated and carried out in the last months of Stalin's life.

The final week of Easter shopping brought department store sales here reasonably close to the levels of the corresponding 1952 week. However, Easter is a week earlier this year, and retailers estimated that sales volume in the week showed a slight increase if compared with the final week of Easter trade in 1952.

Ecumenical Patriarch AthenagorasI of the Greek Eastern Orthodox Church will broadcast an Easter message for the Greek language service of the Voice of America at 3:30 P. M. today. The message was recorded in Istanbul, Turkey, and flown to New York.

BONN, April 4 -- An American correspondent once wrote a visiting publisher that there were two things he must see in Germany: Chancellor Adenauer and the Ruhr. His perception was not misplaced. By any standards the 77-year-old Rhinelander who arrives in the United States on Monday is an authentic German phenomenon -- a moderate, logical internationalist from a nation that so often in the past has been led by immoderate, illogical nationalists.

BONN, Germany, April 4 -- The Chinese Communist Government is planning to use the Trans-Siberian Railroad to move machinery and precision instruments, purchased in West Germany and presumably in other European countries, in an effort to circumvent a United States-sponsored international shipping ban.

WHEN the Ballet Theatre appears in Newark on April 16, it will be its last times in the vicinity of New York until the end of 1954. Next month it begins a European tour which is scheduled to occupy it for eight months.

SAIGON, Vietnam, April 4 -- An armistice in Korea, where truce prospects suddenly brightened this week as a consequence of Communist China's new prisoner exchange proposal, would still leave four Communist-sponsored "little wars" disturbing the Far Eastern peace in Indo-China, Burma, Malaya and the Philippines.

ONE of the most obvious places to grow vines is on a fence. Not all kinds of fences, however, are suitable supports, nor are all of the vines appropriate for a fence of any style. But some successful combinations can be worked out and there is a large group of vines which will tumble over walls of brick, stone, stucco or concrete.

Throughout the history of Federal income tax laws the taxation of stock dividends has been in a state of uncertainty. This column has stated that at least in one set of circumstances there is absolute certainty as to the nontaxability of a stock dividend -- when the corporation has only common stock outstanding and the distribution is made in the same class of stock.

Women active in bellf of the Jacob A. Rfis Settlement, of which Mrs. Jacob A. Riis is president, have taken over the performance of Cole Porter's new musical comedy, "Can-Can," on the night of May 14 at the Shubertk Theatre to raise funds for'the settlement.

THE quality and variety of movies available in first-run theatres at Eastertime may be no more reliable indication of the over-all state of the screen than the weather on Easter Sunday may be a sample of the kind we'll have all spring.

Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany, announced yesterday that Senator John F. Kennnedy of Massachusetts would speak at the annual dinner of the New York County Democratic Committee at the Commodore Hotel on Wednesday, April 15.

THE visitor to Michigan's historic Mackinac Island is struck by its blend of past and contemporary modes: the horse and carriage replacing the private automobile; the police jeep; the Indians who still inhabit part of the island; the flashy summer guests.

RAVELLO, the tiny one-time pirates' lair perched high above the Amalfi coastline south of this city, provides, in one of the civilized world's less accessible spots, what must be the most exclusive, as well as the most colorful, movie location in Italy today.

TRENTON, April 4 -- The state political campaign swung into high gear last week with little more than two weeks left before the April 21 primary election. Interest was centered in the nominations for Governor, with heated contests under way in both major parties.

BOSTON, April 4 (AP) -- Thanks to a six-minute handicap, Johnny Holt of New York gained his first road race victory in the Cathedral Club's ten-mile event today as Browning Ross of Woodbury, N. J., starting from scratch, won the time prize in 56:32.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (UP) -- Three Democratic members of Congress from Washington State charged today that the Republican Administration was "disarming" the Pacific Northwest and Alaska.

New and recent releases of works by several composers will be heard in a variegated program on Wednesday, between noon and 2 P. M., at the weekly recorded concert of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

EVERYBODY knows, or should know, that the best-selling book today, and for a long time past, is the Bible. Currently it appears on the best-seller list of this Review, for the reason that a new and much revised version made its appearance late last year.

" THE wisest fool in Christendom" was one of the more pleasant things said of James Stuart in his lifetime, and one modern biographer has the bad taste to describe him, more or less accurately, as "a rachitic pederast."

CLEVELAND, April 4 (UP) -- Representative Harold H. Velde said today that letters he had received "are 17 to 1 in favor" of his proposed investigation of the clergy for pro-Commmunist affiliations. The Illinois Republican, chairman of the House Un-American Activities Committee, in a speech to the weekly City Club Forum here, said "only individual clergymen" rather than churches or religion should be investigated.

DECORUM, dignity and good taste will be the keynotes of this year's television coverage of Easter Sunday activities on New York's Fifth and Park Avenues as opposed to last year's orgy of commercialism and press agentry.

IN his twelfth science picture book Mr. Zim presents a great deal of information about the sun -- its size, weight, heat and composition. In addition to material frequently dealt with in other science books, the reader will find here much that is new and fascinating.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (UP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon, who developed his delivery on television last season, said today he was fit and ready to undertake baseball's first big relief assignment.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- President Eisenhower, in a statement commemorating the fourth anniversary of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, said today that NATO was "an instrument of peace," but he warned that "the faint of heart and the slow of deed are the first and surest to invite the torment of aggression."

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The Federation of American Scientists entered the controversy today over the dismissal of Dr. Allen V. Astin, head of the National Bureau of Standards, by his superior, Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce.

Pancho Villa's efficiency expert played host at a big party in the Waldorf last night. He is Royce G. Martin, an effervescent Irish Texan with flashing black eyes who heads the $278,000,000-a-year Electric Auto-lite Company.

I HAD a strong sensation of seesaw in rereading Mr. Maugham's agreeable book; what dear old Dr. Johnson in one of his prayers called "vacillation and vagrancy of mind." No wonder; perhaps a kind of telekinesis? For I first read the book last November, aboard my favorite S. S. Media, crossing the North Atlantic in what the chief officer's daily bulletins described as a long, very heavy vesterly swell.

Longshoremen at the Navy's ammunition loading depot at Leonardo, N. J., resumed work yesterday morning after winning on two of the three disputed points responsible for a wildcat work stoppage a day earlier.

Even the most hardened observer of Soviet affairs can hardly help but be astonished by the latest turn of affairs in Moscow. The astonishment, of course, is not provoked by the fact that the doctors accused so recently of medical murder are innocent and that their confessions were extorted from them by "impermissible means"; all Western public opinion, except that of fanatical Communists, reached that conclusion immediately on hearing the original charges.
CAMDEN, N. J., April 4 -- South Jersey's industrial statisticians had some new figures to play with this week.

TWO young Spaniards, Senores Luis Berlanga and Juan Bardem, have given a nudge to Spain's slumbering film industry that may do big things for it and them. With no experience in the local blood-and-sand drenched film-making school to live down, they have come up with a film called "Bienvenido, Mr. Marshall" ("Welcome, Mr. Marshall") in which they give a light-touch portrayal of what the Spanish man-in-the-village thinks U. S. aid would mean to him.

QUEEN ELIZABETH II's Coronation on June 2 will be one of the most exciting and thoroughly exploited episodes in contemporary philatelic history. Literally millions of first-day covers, their postage prepaid with commemorative stamps featuring, most of them, portraits of the youthful sovereign as the design, will enter collections the world around.

CHICAGO, April 4 -- Eight more men have been arrested in connection with the theft of nine valuable paintings from a Bardstown, Ky., church and a plot to send some of the paintings to Europe for sale, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced tonight.
CAMDEN, S. C., April 4 (AP) -- Rustling Oaks, 8-year-old bay gelding, scored an upset three-quarter-length victory over favored Sunless Sea in the big Carolina Cup Steeplechase today.

A strike against the Hearn department store at Third Avenue and 149th Street, the Bronx, by 300 employes will start tomorrow at 9:30 A. M., David Livingston, president of District 65, Distributive, Processing and Office Workers of America, independent, said last night.

THIS collection of children's games has been compiled for three interesting reasons. First, like many observant people, Paul Brewster has become alarmed at the increasing regimentation of our twentieth-century lives, even to the rigid, unimaginative supervision of our children's play.
Youth's part in the fight against cancer was shown in a display of posters and exhibits that opened yesterday at the Museum of Natural History.

" I feel like the man who couldn't see the forest for the trees," said Capt. George B. Young, veteran New York docking pilot, who returned on the Holland-America liner Ryndam last week from his first ocean voyage -- a Bermuda cruise.

Recreating in "The Forsyte Saga" the mood on that dark February day in 1901 when Queen Victoria was buried, John Galsworthy described how the note of "simple sadness" among the people lining the streets broke through the "dusky pomp" of the royal funeral. Such was the note
Thanks for another good article by Dr. Martin Gumpert on the retirement problem, "We Live Longer -- But for What?" (March 22).
WIESBADEN, Germany, April 4 (AP) -- The United States Air Force has saved perhaps $15,000,000 in the last year by buying parts and supplies in Europe, Air Force authorities estimated today.

PITTSBURGH, April 4 -- A five-day strike of Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen on the Union Railroad, a United States Steel Corporation subsidiary, which made nearly 50,000 steelworkers and coal miners idle, was settled in mediation early today.

An automobile show yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel was estimated to have drawn 35,000 visitors. Hundreds had stood in line outside the hotel awaiting the opening of the exhibition at 1:30 P. M. It will continue through Thursday but will be closed Tuesday.

Another high-level conclave of power cruiser yachtsmen, involving three separate but interrelated bodies, will be held April 15 at 7:30 P. M. at the Hotel Shelton under the chairmanship of William Edgar John of Rye.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 3 -- Although Senator Joseph R. McCarthy has found the United States Information Service library program "such an awful mess" that its directors never learned who put pro-Communist books on its shelves, private observers here have found the Information Service library in Tel Aviv one of the most effective components of an unusually successful United States information program.

If the talks starting tomorrow in Panmunjom, Korea, on the exchange of sick and wounded prisoners of war are successful, American troops now held in North Korea will find everything in readiness for their return. Basic plans were made as far back as December, 1951, when United Nations military leaders first made the proposals.

The past week has been a historic one in the field of women's rights at the United Nations. The Convention on Political Rights for Women was signed by representatives of eighteen nations, and the Commission on the Status of Women completed its seventh session, the most harmonious on record.

Straining to meet the insatiable demand for electric power in all sections of the country, the nation's private electric light industry in the last twelve months has invested more than $2,500,000,000 in new plant and related facilities.

A spring festival celebrating the return of life to a green and growing world is probably as old as man's observation of the seasons. There has always been something awe-inspiring in the way a winter-weary world resumes its leaf and bud, its visible form of life renewed.

How can we train engineering students to use their imagination, to speculate? Prof. John E. Arnold of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and his colleagues have been asking themselves this question for years. The conclusion was reached that as we gather more facts and information we become more analytical and less imaginative.

EACH book of E. M. Forster's is, at least, a small masterpiece. That may be going far, but I defend anyone's right to say it. Years ago, when Forster was associated almost exclusively with "A Passage to India."

I was shocked by Bill Mauldin's condescending remarks about Yank Magazine, the wartime Army publication. As a former reader of Yank, I think the magazine would have been better if it had printed Mauldin cartoons regularly. He was a wonderful cartoonist. But even without them I remember Yank as one of the best magazines I've ever known. * * *

Many hotels and office buildings have ruled out installation of central air-conditioning systems in favor of individual window-type units, Jack Cherry, air conditioner sales manager of Philco Corporation, reported yesterday. He said the trend was taking shape because of lower installation costs and preference for temperature control by room occupants.

APPLETON, Wis., April 4 (AP) -- Waste products from paper mills which once killed river fish and made the old swimmin' hole unfit to bathe in are today serving mankind in many ways -- as textile dyes, road-surfacing materials, food flavors, fuel and other useful products -and giving the paper industry a money-making sideline.

MOSCOW, Sunday, April 5 -- Moscow and all of the Soviet Union marked this morning the advent of Easter with services in every Christian church, of both the Eastern and Western rites. In a rare coincidence the Russian Orthodox and Western Easters fell on the same Sunday.

Three of the ten American newspaper and radio executives now visiting Moscow were heard here yesterday in a six-minute radio broadcast. Their words were transcribed at American Broadcasting Company studios here and then rebroadcast over its nationwide network.

CHICAGO, April 4 -- Jacques Plante, 24-year-old last-minute substitute goalie, scored the first shut-out by a rookie in Stanley Cup history tonight as he led the Montreal Canadiens to a 3-0 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks that threw the semi-final series into a seventh game.

BARTOK: For Children; Menahem Pressler, pianist (M-G-M). Pressler here plays the forty pieces on Hungarian folk songs. They are attractively colored sketches, neatly played. The recording is not very good; a slight waver is present and the piano has a tinny sound.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Major revisions of the Truman Administration's defense production program are planned to concentrate the output of arms in fewer plants rather than to keep many factories in a "warm but not red-hot" state.

THERE are four major characters in this quiet, bright novel: all of them are young; the summers are their times, and their place is alongside the great lake on whose shore their families spend the annual swift seasons in the sun.

Last week the Princeton University Press brought out a fourth edition Einstein's "Generalization of Gravitation Theory." An additional appendix was heralded in front-page articles. It set forth in equations, comprehensible only to those familiar with higher geometries, that light, magnetism, radiation and gravitation are a unity -- part of one "continuum."
Scores of persons converged on Point Byram, Conn., yesterday, for a glimpse of the crippled Canada goose, whose status is at issue between Canada and Connecticut.

HARTFORD, April 4 -- The first reorganization in the membership of the Connecticut House of Representatives since 1818 is being pressed by the Republican Administration of Gov. John Davis Lodge in the current session of the General Assembly.
