The Northeast Regional Committee on the Field of Latin American Studies will hold an organizational meeting Saturday at 10 A. M. in the Faculty Council Room of the City College School of Business and Civic Administration, 17 Lexington Avenue.
MINNEAPOLIS, April 4 -- New York beat Minneapolis, 96 -- 88, tonight in the first game of the best-out-of-seven play-off series for the National Basketball Association championship.

Norway's newest passenger ship, the 7,000-gross-ton Leda of the Bergen Steamship Company, will be delivered to her owners on Tuesday at the Tyneside port of North Shields, Great Britain, in a twin ceremony coinciding with the opening of a modernized passenger terminal for use by the company in its passenger service between Newcastle and Bergen.

ANEMONES, as a garden flower, are undoubtedly better known in the Southwest than in any other section of the country. As a cut flower, however, their popularity is nation-wide. Florists offer the blooms during the early spring months.

PROBABLY the most aptly titled television program on the air is the "Arthur Murray Party," presented over the Du Mont network on Sundays at 10 P. M. It is packaged by Arthur Murray, produced by Arthur Murray, and sponsored by Arthur Murray. And the star is Mrs. Arthur Murray.

MONTE CARLO, April 4 (AP) -- Mrs. Dorothy Head Knode of Alameda, Calif., recovered after a slow start to trounce Joan Curry of Great Britain, 9 -- 7, 6 -- 0, today and advance to the final of the Monte Carlo international tennis tournament.

IN the summer of 1790 a group of 300 Frenchmen journeyed by foot and wagon from Alexandria, Va., to Pittsburgh and thence by boat down the Ohio to what is now Gallipolis. There, in a crude clearing on the river bank, were the "estates" they had purchased sight unseen from smooth-talking land speculators in Paris as a haven from the French Revolution.

JOHANNESBURG, April 4 -- Two events within the last two weeks have served to a remarkable extent to clarify the essential issue in the ideological struggle regarding the status of the black majority of the South African population which has come to the boiling point during the present election campaign.

THE biennial convention of the National Federation of Music Clubs begins this week in this city, lasting from the eighth to the eighteenth of the month, with conferences and music programs representative of the whole range and character of the federation's activities in the more than half century of its existence.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (UP) -- The soft coal industry, which is in the midst of a "severe recession," had been hit harder by the new developments in Korea, an industry leader reported today.

" MACBETH," with Ian Keith starring in the title role, will be presented six times during the fourth annual Shakespeare Festival at Hofstra College in Hempstead, L. I., beginning on April 21. The production is to be offered on a faithful reconstruction of the stage of Shakespeare's famous Globe Playhouse.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 4 -- Foreign Minister Sharett conferred in New York today with other members of the Israeli Government on how to handle Tel Aviv's charges of Communist anti-Semitism in the light of the new developments in Moscow.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 4 -- A little more than a year ago J. Paul St. Sure, an Oakland attorney with about twenty years of experience in dealing with labor-management issues, was asked by shipowners of this area to help them find a new president for their Pacific Maritime Association.

ATLANTA, April 4 -- Entirely satisfactory was Ed Lopat's six-inning pitching stint against the Southern Association Atlanta Crackers today at Ponce De Leon Park. The portsider, whom Casey Stengel has, more or less, left to his own conditioning program, gave up only four hits, all singles, and no runs as the Yankees downed the minor leaguers, 8 -- 2.

TOKYO, Sunday, April 5 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark, the United Nations commander, put off today the reopening of full-dress Korean cease-fire negotiations until the United Nations and the Communists reached agreement on the exchange of sick and wounded prisoners of war.

HARTFORD, April 4 -- Chester Bowles of Connecticut, retiring United States Ambassador to India, has written to a Hartford newspaper man saying that "it may well be that I shall decide to devote my time permanently to the field" of American foreign affairs when he returns to this country in May.

Engineers and scientists from more than 200 major companies will be making their annual pilgrimage during the next few weeks to an unpretentious beach station in North Carolina to swap reports on their battle with a relentless common enemy -- corrosion.

The crew of the battleship Missouri has become the "foster parent" of a little Korean boy, fulfilling one of the last wishes of the late Capt. Warner R. Edsall, the ship's commander, who died on board March 26, 1953.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4 (AP) -- The former United States submarine, U. S. S. Bumper, was overhauled in 1950 at the Philadelphia Navy Yard before it was turned over to Turkey under the Mutual Defense Assistance program. The Bumper was one of six United States undersea craft, all 1,500-ton vessels, given to the Turkish Navy.
ALBANY, April 4 -- A total of 4,500,000 New York Staters are expected to file income tax returns this year -- and it looks as if most of them will be doing it at the last minute.

Mild temperatures and no showers to dampen Easter finery are promised for today by the Weather Bureau.

Warren Neuberger held St. John's University, winner of the Metropolitan Baseball Conference title last year, in check as his City College team-mates went on to win by 9 -- 1 yesterday at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, Queens. It was the opening league test for both teams.

FENCES of wide horizontal boards are traditional in most sections of the United States. Patterns, construction and even the wood from which these fences are made may vary from region to region, but their simplicity and purpose are seldom lost or out of place.

NEWARK, April 4 -- The Public Service Coordinated Transport, in a letter to the Board of Public Utility Commissioners this week, reported a loss of $358,666 in ten months of operation under the 10- cents-a-zone basic fare rate.
The National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System have rejected for New York showing the television film, "I Beheld His Glory," it was learned last night.
The controversy between New York's commercial and savings banks over branch office expansion is settled -- for the moment.

After four years of effort, the American Heart Association is rapidly replacing fear, ignorance and indifference about heart and circulatory ailments with keen interest and dedication by both professional workers and the public, the annual report, published last week, declared.

My sympathies to the four New York critics who almost dissuaded me from the most rewarding theatrical experience of the current season. Important increases in ammunition production were reported yesterday by the Army Ordnance Arsenal at Ravenna, Ohio, the second largest in the country.
ROME, April 4 -- A controversy between the Vatican and the sovereign Military Order of Malta, which has been raging for the last eighteen months, has been settled to the satisfaction of both parties.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 4 -- For the first time in months there now seems a real prospect of an armistice in Korea, and with it arises the necessity of appraising the policies with which the United States will confront a new series of problems.

EXACTLY a quarter of a century ago, in April, 1928, there occurred what may very well be called the most important single event in the publication of hardcover mystery novels in the United States: Doubleday, Doran founded The Crime Club.

About the only thing on which most drug manufacturers seem to agree in appraising their operations in 1952 is that it was a tough year. The one before had produced sales and earnings for most concerns in the field far above any previous totals, so that the contrast of retreating sales and profits last year spread gloom with a liberal hand.
JERUSALEM, April 4 -- The resurrection of Christ was celebrated by the Eastern churches here today at the Church of the Holy Sepulcher.

THOSE hardy pioneers who swung maul and ax three- quarters of a century ago so that they might have rail fences around their homesteads little knew how picturesque those fences would appear to a later generation. In fact, the freshly split oak, chestnut, sassafras and walnut rails were not as pleasing then as they are today.

The Bureau of Labor Statistics has completed a survey which indicates that arbitration as the final step in a grievance procedure in collective bargaining contracts is rapidly becoming a standard feature of such agreements. The bureau surveyed 1,442 agreements in effect during 1952 and found that 89 per cent provide that disputes over interpretation or application of agreements shall be referred to arbitration.

TOKYO, Sunday, April 5 -- China's Soviet-designed MIG jet fighters crossed the Manchurian frontier yesterday after five days' absence from the air over North Korea. In duels with United States Sabre jets one MIG probably was destroyed and three others were damaged.
BETHPAGE, L. I., April 4 -- The formation of a new women's organization has become a disruptive force in this community, threatening to start an open war among housewives.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 4 -- Nearly all the 2,207 G. I.'s who landed in New York yesterday from the first troop transport arriving from the Korean war zone had been processed through Camp Kilmer tonight.

THE first spring chore in the rock garden consists of taking off all the materials used for winter protection. The task is approached hoping that the elements have been kind and the ravages of rodents are nonexistent.

TORONTO, March 25 -- Ask any Torontonian what civic project or institution has reflected most credit on this metropolitan area of 1,200,000 and chances are he'll pick the public-owned Toronto Transportation Commission.

ALBANY, April 4 -- Legislation authorizing the State Racing Commission to impose civil penalties up to $5,000 for violations of racing laws or regulations by track operators, horse owners, jockeys, trainers or grooms has been approved by Governor Dewey.

YOUNG people in search of a new and exciting way to spend the summer will be delighted with Anne Emery's latest novel. In "Vagabond Summer" we follow 17-year-old Peg Madison on her trip by way of hostels through the United States and Canada.

One of the signs of spring is the return of the N. B. C. Symphony to the Belasco Theatre for its Saturday afternoon Summer Symphony performances. The initial program yesterday was conducted by Milton Katims.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (UP) -- Senator Earle C. Clements said today he thought regional "grass roots" conferences might be more useful to the Democratic party in 1954 than a proposed national convention.
A hundred excited parents accompanied by their patient children were lined up in the bright April sunlight yesterday morning when the Children's Zoo opened for its thirteenth season in the Bronx Zoo.

CAPETOWN, South Africa -The vast reaches of Africa south of the Sahara are not yet overrun with tourists, but the day may come, and soon, when there are more people staring at the elephants and antelopes in the game preserves than there are elephants and antelopes staring back.

The field trial program on Long Island contains an event that will be exclusively for Chesapeake Bay retrievers this spring. It is the first with such a breed restriction in the east since 1941. The trial will be conducted by the American Chesapeake Club on April 21 and 22 at Westhampton Beach.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has advised Congress that "enemy espionage rings are more intensively operated today than they have been at any previous time in the history of the country."

St. John's College, Annapolis, in cooperation with Study Abroad, will hold its first seminar in Europe this summer. Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia defeated Karl Ojanen of Finland in a seventeenth-round match last night in the international masters chess tournament at Mar Del Plata and now leads with a record of 15 to 2, according to a report from Buenos Aires.

Anxiety of death, of meaninglessness, and of condemnation: Pascal knew and faced them.

Our Ambassador to the Soviet Union, Charles E. Bohlen, has taken off for his new assignment -- his seventh trip to Moscow -- at the end of a momentous and dramatic week. He faces, in the days to come, one of the most important and complex tasks in the history of American international relationships.
Dr. Samuel Z. Levine, chairman of a medical team for the World Health Organization and the Unitarian Service Committee, arrived here last week after a two-month study of medical conditions in India.

Works to be heard are the "Brandenburg" concertos Nos. 1, 2, 3 and 5, Suites 2 and 3 and Cantata No. 78, "Jesu, der du meine Seele."

DYLAN THOMAS, who has recently been described by a well-known critic as the greatest living poet in English, is perhaps the most startling phenomenon in an era of startling poetic experiment. HEAVY student interest and a severe shortage of low-cost trans-Atlantic ship space mark the student travel picture for this summer. FEW exotic trees have achieved the fame and popularity of the ginkgo, or maidenhair tree. The ginkgo is planted throughout New York City, along streets, in parks, playgrounds and private gardens. April is a good time to plant the ginkgo.

Mills of Columbia University, made for the National Bureau of Economic Research, which points up the extraordinary characteristics of the nation's economic progress in the last sixty years.

" Cigars by the carton," embodying what was described as a major advance in cigar packaging, were announced yesterday by Bayuk Cigars, Inc., of Philadelphia. The company is introducing a Phillies perfecto "Self-Service Ten-Pak" and a "Self-Service Twenty-Pak."

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Plant roses, shrubs and trees without delay. Dig a hole wide and deep enough to accommodate roots of each plant without crowding. While holding plant erect, work fine soil among the roots, then fill hole with water. After water has drained away, fill with soil to ground level and tread firmly. Mulch, and water weekly.

CHATTANOOGA, April 4 -- Loose play and some loose pitching cost the Dodgers their game with the Braves at Engel Stadium today. Chuck Dressen's men made more hits and more for extra bases, but wound up on the short end of a 9-8 score. There were 6,125 fans on hand, many of them around the edges of the field, lured by the major league attraction and the sunshiny and warm day.

NO one has ever called Shakespeare's "Romeo and Juliet" a profound tragedy or indeed a tragedy that reveals any but a comparatively narrow aspect of life; but no one has ever denied that it reveals that aspect with superb felicity and that it is, in fact, the most magical expression of youthful passion in all literature.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, April 4 -- This sleeply little town that hardly qualifies as a town at all is about to come once again into the focus of the world's attention.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 4 -- Mrs. Pat McCormick, the world's foremost woman diver, was dethroned today in the National Amateur Athletic Union women's indoor swimming and diving meet. She hit the board while trying an intricate dive and lost 55 points.

IN my judgment * * * of the situation in which mankind finds itself at the present time, I am pessimistic. I cannot make myself believe that that situation is not so bad as it seems to be, but I am inwardly conscious that we are on a road which, if we continue to tread it, will bring us into "Middle Ages" of a new character.

MOSCOW, April 4 -- United States Charge d'Affaires Jacob Beam called upon Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov today in what was described as a "courtesy call" conducted on both sides with cordiality and pleasantness.

PARIS, April 4 -- A suspicious Western world, its nerves frayed by seven years of Soviet aggression both "cold" and "hot," has greeted Moscow's mounting "peace offensive" with a curious mixture of satisfaction, anxiety and sheer perplexity.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public, which will mature within twelve months, amount to $73,374,704,149. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, April 5 -- A Territorial police force, patterned after Canada's Royal Northwest Mounted, will be organized in Alaska in the hope that it may help solve an alarmingly high crime rate in unincorporated areas.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today 140 Korean war casualties in a list that reported thirty-five killed, ninety-eight wounded, two missing and five injured. The following were from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 5 -- New York City receives top mention from the World Health Organization this week in a listing of five community and national administrations that have proved to be canny shoppers in the field of preventive medicine. The United Nations body issued its citations as a preliminary to observance of World Health Day Tuesday.

More than $1,000,000, nearly a fifth of the Park Department's budget, will be spent this year to prevent erosion from turning the city's parks into dust bowls. Heavy rains in March made the problem particularly critical this year, Park Department officials said yesterday.

BILL DICKEY had just been telling Casey Stengel some details about the fabulous 1927 Yankees, whom he had barely glimpsed since he hadn't joined the team until a year later. He told amusedly about their antics on and off the field.

TOKYO, Monday, April 6 -- Chinese Communist troops made sharp local attacks against United Nations outpost positions on the western front in Korea early today, a few hours before the liaison officers of both sides sat down at Panmunjom.

The Rev. Edward B. Rooney, executive director of the Jesuit Educational Association, criticized yesterday those educators who have imparted the impression that educational institutions and educators were "untouchables" and should not be subject to any investigation.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- President Eisenhower and members of his family attended Easter services at their church this morning and were greeted en route by thousands, many of them visitors sharing a week-end of ideal weather.

The formation of a sort of central port promotional bureau, a suggestion that has been put forth from time to time over past years, is now being given serious consideration by local shipping and port leaders.

" I believe it would be a tragic mistake and an appalling setback of America's entire humanitarian record if Congress did not remedy the omission of funds for UNICEF. For a comparative pittance we and like-minded nations have achieved magnificent results for these youngsters and their mothers. * * *"

I read your editorial, "Sense on the Highway," with the greatest of interest. I have driven an automobile since 1912, and my engineering and geological work has taken me all over these United States and into many foreign countries. Much of my travel has been by automobile.

TRENTON, April 5 -- Clendenin Ryan, independent candidate for Governor, called tonight for the resignation of Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons, asserting that the state official was trying to "pass the buck" for his failure to obtain the extradition of Harold J. Adonis from the Netherlands.

MOSCOW, April 5 -- For the first time since the early post-war days, Russian and American guests mingled on pleasant social terms today in the ballroom of Spasso House, the residence of the United States Ambassador in Moscow.

The immediate transmission of horse race results from the track is not a crime in this state, even though the transmittor may have "implied knowledge" that the information is to be used illegally by gamblers, Magistrate J. Irwin Shapiro held yesterday in an opinion filed in Queens Felony Court.

Easter is the most important and the "gladdest" day of the year because it celebrates with triumph "the central fact of the Christian religion: Christ is alive," the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken, pastor of the Riverside Church, declared at morning services yesterday.

WHILE scores of crudely written and cheaply sensational historical novels are published every year the art of historical fiction is still practiced by several distinguished writers. The most notable in this country are A. B. Guthrie Jr. and Conrad Richter. And in England a remarkable group of greatly gifted woman writers has produced a series of books which, it seems to me, are certain to rank among the best of their kind.

Pacific Western Oil Corporation last year had gross income of $12,135,616 and consolidated net earnings of $8,968,934, or $1.86 a share of common stock, after preferred stock requirements, it reported yesterday. In 1951 its gross income was $10,420,628 and net earnings $7,805,680, or $1.60 a share.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 5 (AP) -- The National A. A. U. swimming championships at Yale were notable for three things: 1 -- the triple victory of Jimmy McLane; 2 -- the absence of record breaking; 3 -- the boycott by the Big Ten on a team basis.

CLINTON, N. J., April 5 -- Fast Delivery Boy, white and orange pointer owned by A. V. Holmes of Washington and handled by Fred Arant of Barnwell, S. C., won the two-day $1,000 Imperial Stake which concluded the spring meet of the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club today.

Associated Business Publications has issued in booklet form its second annual study of leading advertisers in the business publications. It lists 641 advertisers spending over $50,000 in 1952 for a total of $108,621,500 or about 36.2 per cent of the $300,000,000 estimated to have been spent in this field.

The Daily Worker, in an editorial prepared for publication today, praised the Soviet Union for uncovering a threatened "miscarriage of justice" in releasing the fifteen doctors who had been arrested in Moscow on charges of plotting to kill Soviet leaders.
Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., suggested yesterday that unessential private cars be kept from Manhattan's streets to solve the city's traffic problems.

LONDON, April 5 -- Rain and clouds put a damper on London's Easter spirit. Little finery was displayed by the crowds that filled the churches. Here and there in the congregation that gathered under Saint Paul's vast dome a gay little hat was seen on the head of a girl eager to show off a bit of hear Easter finery.

Our politicians are beating the Romans at their own game -- to the famous "bread and circuses" they are adding "free rides." We New Yorkers are seeing a spectacle of office-chasing politicians using our wonderful and unique transportation system for a political football, promising bargain, below-cost rides in exchange for votes next fall.

Joyous tribute to the risen Christ was paid yesterday as worshipers by the tens of thousands filled the churches of New York. A spot check by interested observers and churchgoers indicated that many houses of worship attracted record-breaking crowds.

ZURICH, April 5 -- Addressing the Swiss - German Chamber of Commerce here last week, Dr. H. C. Seebohm, German Traffic Minister, after depicting the swift trend towards integration of western Europe, made an earnest appeal for investment of Swiss capital in Germany to accelerate the movement, holding that this would best serve the vital economic interests of Switzerland herself.

SILCHAR, India, April 5 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru returned to New Delhi today after seeing the heartening penetration of his conglomerate five-year nation-building program into the jungled mountain country of recent (and some present) headhunters.

For one reason or another the news columns have been particularly active in recent weeks in discussing things about the New York metropolitan area. There have been tax problems and transportation troubles, accidents and robberies, human interest stories and routine happenings that merited attention.

The first step in a far-ranging program to change the functions of the Women's Court was taken yesterday by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh with the announcement that hereafter the court would be known as the Court for Vagrant Women.

Mayor Impellitteri and the Board of Estimate, defendants in the pending taxpayer's suit to prevent the city from transferring its transit properties to Governor Dewey's newly created transit authority, will join with the taxpayer in attacking the constitutionality of the law creating the agency, it became known yesterday.

BOSTON, April 5 (UP) -- Fleming Mackell fired home the winning goal tonight as Boston beat Detroit, 4 -- 2, to take the semi-final play-offs and move into the Stanley Cup final for the first time in seven years.

Svetozar Gligoric, 30-year-old grand-master from Yugoslavia, won first prize in the international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata last night. He drew in the eighteenth and semi-final round, according to a report from Buenos Aires, to repeat his triumph of three years ago.
MUNSAN, Korea, Monday, April 6 (AP) -- The Allies suggested to the Communists today that an exchange of sick and wounded prisoners begin within seven days after an agreement on procedure.

The largest crowds in memory turned out yesterday for the most dignified Easter Parade in recent years on Manhattan's Fifth Avenue. Blessed by sunny skies and fair weather with just enough nip in it to provide the perfect excuse for new fur stoles and scarfs, worshipers and paraders crowded the avenue from early morning to midafternoon. By 1 P. M., the police estimated, they numbered 1,250,000.

LONDON, April 5 -- Anthony Eden, Foreign Secretary and Prime Minister Churchill's deputy and presumptive successor, must undergo an immediate gall-bladder operation, the Foreign Office announced today.

LOS ANGELES, April 5 (AP) -- The Board of Regents of the American College of Surgeons declared today that "a small minority of the medical profession chooses to circumvent its moral and ethical responsibilities."
TEHERAN, Iran, April 5 (Reuters) -- The newspaper Ettelaat said today Premier Mohammed Mossadegh had protested against the United States' "lackadaisical attitude" toward Iran's shaky economy.

BERLIN, April 5 -- East Berlin's two official Communist newspapers in effect pictured the Soviet "peace offensive" today as a counter-measure to the militant policy of the new Administration in Washington and to preparations for rearmament of West Germany and Japan.
HANOI, Vietnam, April 5 -- A Vietminh offensive against Laos is in full swing.
Television has done its worst to the motion picture exhibitors -- at least in the big city areas -- and they are fighting back with increasing success. Box office receipts are running 25 per cent

May I comment on your editorial of March 31 "The Freedom of the Scholar" with regard to the policy of the statement issued by the Association of American Universities on academic freedom and responsibilities.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll call in Congress during the period March 28 through April 3 are given in the appended tabulation:

WILMINGTON, N. C., April 5 (AP) -- Little Jerry Barber crashed through to his first major professional golf tournament victory today with a 4-under-par 68 to win the $10,000 Azalea open by a stroke with a 276 total. Barber's rounds of 71, 65, 72, 68 put him 12 under par and earned for him the top money of $2,000.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (UP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced today that it planned to hold a series of "anti-crime" regional conferences throughout the country this year in an effort to cut down hijacking and other crimes involving interstate shipments.

A two-volume publication of the scientific papers of Wilbur and Orville Wright is planned for issuance by McGraw-Hill prior to Dec. 17, the golden anniversary of the Wrights' first flights at Kitty Hawk, N. C. The Wright papers, now in the Library of Congress and not to become public property until 1960, are being prepared for the press by the library's aeronautics division on a grant from Oberlin College.

PUSAN, Korea, Monday, April 6 (AP) -- The United Nations Prisoner of War Command said today that two Communist prisoners had been shot to death and one wounded, that another had been found slain and that a threatened uprising had been choked off Friday in three incidents at camps on and near Koje Island.

OMAHA, Neb., April 5 -- Below normal snowfall and the orderly melting of river ice throughout the upper Missouri River Basin appeared today to have eliminated the danger of spring floods such as those of last year in the area.

In line with a recommendation of Governor Dewey, the State Council of Parks has increased the parking fee at its seventy-eight developed parks from 35 to 50 cents. The new tariff will go into effect on May 23, the informal start of the summer recreation season.

Successfully produced in 1937 for a run of 500 performances and subsequently processed into a movie (1938) and then a musical film (1944), "Room Service" will receive its initial Broadway revival this evening at the Playhouse. The opening-night curtain is advertised to go up at 8 o'clock.

HOT SULPHUR SPRINGS, Colo., April 5 (AP) -- Two young gunmen kidnapped Sheriff Chauncey Van Pelt and then died before his blazing six-shooter yesterday in the climax to a wild chase through a blinding snowstorm high in the Colorado Rockies.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., April 5 (UP) -- Minneapolis turned back a second-half rally tonight to beat the New York Knickerbockers, 73 to 71, and tie the National Basketball Association best - of - seven championship series at one game each.

Easter morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church was celebrated in its traditionally joyous atmosphere, but mingled with a touch of disappointment for hundreds of worshippers who were turned away because of the record-breaking attendance.

ATLANTA, April 5 -- Six southeastern states have passed the halfway mark in completing or starting construction of dwellings reserved in the low-rent public housing program. A. R. Hanson, director of the Atlanta field office of the Public Housing Administration, announced today.

In the near future the Board of Health will consider the arguments for and against the dating of fresh fluid milk that were brought out last month at a public hearing before that agency. The milk industry asserted at that time the measure was no longer necessary; various consumer groups said it was.

No significant improvement was shown in department-store profits last year, according to a report issued over the week-end by the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association. The report was based on a sampling of 241 department and specialty stores with an aggregate annual sales volume of $3,200,000.
Chatter on about your crocuses, your lengthening days, your balmy breezes, your bright clothes, Your vacant eye, your budding trees. Spring's true harbinger is the first fly.

Marian Anderson gave her only New York recital of the season yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. Resplendently gowned in cloth of silver, the contralto was handsome to look upon, and by the musicianship, dignity and earnestness of purpose displayed in her offerings she gripped the attention of a large and responsive audience.

Joy was the principal theme of the services commemorating Christ's resurrection at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. It was reflected not only in the symbolic gold-and-white vestments worn by the clergy but in the choral alleluias and the bright finery of the 5,000 worshipers who attended the 10 A. M. solemn pontifical mass.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- President Eisenhower has made one major concession to high-tariff Republicans in the House of Representatives and may feel compelled to follow with others as the price of saving the eighteen-year-old reciprocal trade program from virtual destruction.
A variety of "firsts" dotted the Saturday evening program that Dimitri Mitropoulos conducted with the Philharmonic-Symphony.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 5 -- The Israeli authorities are tensely awaiting sequels in the satellite countries to the exoneration of fifteen physicians, some of them Jews, in Moscow. Especially is Tel Aviv looking for the resumption of the emigration of Jews from the satellite countries to Israel.

Resources of state-supervised banks rose $5,200,000,000 last year to a new high of $105,971,589,000 on Dec. 31, according to the annual report to be issued today by Newton P. Black, president of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks.

The Philippine Foreign Affairs Department has announced the signing of an interim agreement with Japan covering the salvage of sunken ships in Philippine waters. The Japanese are committed to the supply of the services of their nationals together with operating facilities and equipment for this work.

An extensive program for the international exchange of art under the jurisdiction of the Museum of Modern Art will be made possible, beginning this month, by a five-year grant of $125,000 a year from the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, it was announced yesterday by John Hay Whitney, chairman of the museum's board of trustees.

Rates for the British pound sterling and the Canadian dollar were irregular in the foreign exchange market during the past week. Transactions were reported to be fairly heavy during some periods of trading.

When Bob Mathias, Stanford's great performer, received the Associated Press' male "athlete-of-the-year" award early this year, one person who took great pride in the selection was Dr. L. M. Clark, president of the Kiskiminetas Springs School, Saltsburg, Pa.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 5 -- The United Nations' new $40,000,000 irrigation development in Jordan's Yarmuk River Valley may owe its start to a lucky mishap that took a United States engineer over unfamiliar terrain in a plane.

CAIRO, April 5 -- Representatives of Nationalist parties in the French North African protectorates of Tunisia and Morocco and in the Algerian Departments of France renewed today appeals to the Arab League for support in their efforts to obtain a greater measure of self-government.

The Post Office Department in Washington issued a four-item bill of sharp self-criticism yesterday on the operations of New York's postal system, which was described as having "deteriorated badly" in recent years.

In a statement sent to 700 newspapers, a group of twenty-eight persons, mainly writers, asserted yesterday that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, had not been treated fairly by segments of the press, radio and television.
BONN, Germany, April 5 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer expects the continuation of a moderate, reasonable policy for Germany under "any" government of his country.
A whisper of a spring wind gently tilted a few bonnets yesterday morning shortly after dawn as 6,500 early risers made their way to Radio City Music Hall to attend the United Easter Dawn Service.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 5 -- The "perfection" by Columbia Pictures studio technicians of a "four-way camera which will shoot simultaneously" a picture that may be projected on standard or large-size screens either in the conventional manner or as a three-dimensional film requiring the use of viewing glasses by the audience was announced today by Harry Cohn, president of the company.

The Chase National Bank of New York had resources of $5,437,494,346 on March 31, according to the bank's quarterly statement of condition, issued today. The figure compares with $5,742,760,745 at the end of 1952 and $5,446,879,594 a year ago.
Letters from readers of this column show a preponderant interest in books on the stock market.
LONDON, April 5 -- The outbreak of peace talk has proved a little too much for the nerves of the stock and commodity markets in the last few days.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 5 -- Warren Spahn, one of the better pitchers in the National League, was wondering today what a fellow has to do to beat the Dodgers. The Brooks outscored the Braves for the sixth time this spring, 3 -- 1, before an overflow crowd of 12,059 at picturesque Sulphur Dell, and Spahn was the victim.
Passenger ship piers will experience an unusually busy day today as 6,323 passengers troop ashore from eight liners bringing them from Europe, South America and the West Indies.

On the second active sector of the Asian battle front, Indo-China, French and Vietnamese are watching the Panmunjom negotiations with apprehension as well as hope. They have felt that any easement in the north might be the signal for increased Communist pressure in their defense area.

The one-story taxpayer building containing five stores and occupying a plot 100 by 75 feet at 3011-27 Westchester Avenue, in the Bronx, has been sold by the Mara Operating Corporation to John Bernabo for investment. The purchase included a one-family home and was made for cash over a first mortgage of $24,500.
The board of directors of Fish Marvin has named Remsen Duryee resident vice president. He will continue to be manager of the company's office in Pelham Manor, N.Y.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 5 (AP) -- Vic Seixas of Philadelphia defeated Miami's Gardnar Mulloy today in a two-hour, five-set battle for the championship of the good neighbor tennis tournament. The score was 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1, 4 -- 6, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 1.
BEAUMONT, Tex., April 5 (UP) -- Mrs. Babe Zaharias of Tampa, Fla., won the $3,500 Zaharias women's open golf tournament today with a 54-hole total of 217.

ROME, April 5 -- Addressing one of the largest crowds ever assembled in St. Peter's Square, Pope Pius XII called on "the entire Church, whether pulsating with apostolic growth or bound with fetters that redound to its honor," not to weary of the good fight to "win peace for fearful humanity" but to "spread everywhere the life-giving waters drawn from Christ as the source."

CHICAGO, April 5 -- The revival of peace talks, with evidence of a more conciliatory policy on the part of Communist leaders, was responsible for a major setback in grain and soybeans last week. The more favorable overtures last weekend took the trade by surprise. The effect was to start another round of long liquidation which was too much for the limited demand to withstand until big losses were registered.

It's cotton pickin' time. By that we mean it's time for the home-sewer to pick her cottons for summer. This is one of the biggest cotton seasons we have had. All of America's top designers have fallen for this beautiful and distinctively American fabric.

JERUSALEM, April 5 -- A thin rain was falling through the last darkness as a small band of American pilgrims prayed bare-headed at today's first Easter celebration in the Holy City, held at the Garden Tomb a short distance outside the Damascus Gate of the Old City's crenelated walls.
CHICAGO, March 5 (AP) -- Ray Kilgore of San Francisco took first place in the world three-cushion billiard tournament today with a 50-to-33 triumph over Joe Procita of Gloversville, N. Y.
BURLINGTON, N. J., April 5 -- Two men were rescued from the Delaware River here this afternoon after the small rubber boat in which they had set sail from Croyden, N. J., was capsized.

Easter is a time when Christians are especially concerned with the contemplation of life and death, and "it is the love within us that cries out for immortality," the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman asserted in a sermon yesterday morning.
DUBLIN, April 5 -- The first Ireland at Home Festival began in Dublin today, with millions of flower-lights gleaming on the streets and standards with the coat of arms of every county.
Small flower hats in pale colors were important fashions in yesterday's Easter parade. Emphasis was on shades of pink that varied from light pastels to soft mauves.

This week it is the turn of the Germans to visit Washington. The British and French have come and gone, leaving questions in their trail that require more considered thought than a few days of the frankest talk could answer. Demands and suggestions were made on both sides that have to be looked at in the light of developing, events.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 5 (UP) -- Outfielder Gil Coan of the Senators fractured his right ankle today when he crashed into the fence in the fifth inning of an exhibition game won by the Reds, 6 to 2.
Four new films, including an importation from France, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

Duplicating his third-set rally against Kenneth McGregor of Saturday evening, John Kramer of Los Angeles defeated Frank Sedgman of Australia last night to win the professional indoor tennis tournament at the Seventh Regiment Armory. The score was 8 -- 6, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4.
This is the first of three articles describing the modern teaching program now being used in the New York City elementary schools.

Coney Island snapped out of its winter hibernation yesterday but concessionaires, despite the joyous tumult of rides and cash registers, sounded as dismal as though they were standing in the rain, not sunshine.
Four additional toll bridges will be constructed within the next five years to link the east and west banks of the Hudson River to provide a maximum of access routes for the new State Thruway.
I beg leave to reply to a letter printed in your columns on March 26 signed by Dorothy Norman.

As the result of action being taken by the city, guests for the three convocations and other special events at Columbia University's bicentennial celebration next year will find an integrated and beautified campus.
Religion sets the pattern for a person's way of life, six young participants in a panel discussion of the topic "What Does Religion Mean to Youth?" agreed last night.
An unusually lively performance of the double bill of "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" was Saturday evening's attraction of the New York City Opera Company at the City Center.

AMSTERDAM, April 5 -- The Netherlands Bank on Thursday reduced the bank rate by one-half to 2 1/2 per cent. This is the third reduction by one-half per cent since January, 1952, when it stood at 4 per cent. The bank rate now stands at the level prevailing until September, 1950, when the Dutch foreign exchange position began to assume an unfavorable trend.

Several large and important art exhibitions are in this week's program of paintings and sculpture in museums and galleries. On Thursday, the Whitney Museum opens its annual show of contemporary American sculpture, drawings and water-colors.

MIAMI, Fla., April 5 (AP) -- Six fugitives were still at large today, almost twenty-four hours after their escape from Dade County's skyscraper jail. Among the fugitives were Joseph Albert, 20 years old, and William Chapman, 25, who had been sentenced to life for killing Dr. Clifton Springmyer, a Miami doctor.

BROCKTON, Mass., April 5 (AP) -- Rocky Marciano said tonight he was "sure everything will be all right" by May 15 -- the new date set for his world heavyweight boxing championship bout with Joe Walcott.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Charges that the Civil Aeronautics Board is seeking to "eliminate rather than regulate" the country's independent airlines will be investigated by the Senate Subcommittee on Relations of Small Business with the Government.

Stanley Jorgensen, art director of a Manhattan advertising agency and a resident of Mariners Harbor, S. I., won the first prize of $100 yesterday for his oil painting at the opening of the nineteenth annual spring art exhibition at the Staten Island Museum, Wall Street and Stuyvesant Place, St. George, S. I.

Comedy shows starring Milton Berle and Bob Hope, and the drama series featuring plays by Robert E. Sherwood will share the 8 to 9 P. M. Tuesday evening hour next fall over the National Broadcasting Company television network.

Because of the difference in time the negotiators met at Panmunjom at what was about 8 o'clock in the evening of beautiful Easter day in New York. There was optimism here, just as there was on Easter day in London, in Paris, in Rome and in Korea itself. There was the ardent wish for peace.

The first chapter of Phi Beta Kappa in a Negro university is being inaugurated at Fisk University in Nashville, Tenn. Congratulations to Fisk and congratulations to Phi Beta Kappa! Each is an honor to the other.

The latest news from Moscow appears to give added support to earlier speculation that the Soviet repudiation of the alleged murder plot by the fifteen Soviet physicians represents a strengthening of the position of Lavrenti P. Beria, Minister of Internal Affairs, at the expense of Premier Georgi M. Malenkov.

A Bronx mother, her 3-month-old daughter and her 3-year-old son were returning from a visit yesterday when they decided, at the Queens entrance to the Sutphin Boulevard station of the IND subway, to honor a venerable New York custom -- three on a dime.

LAS VEGAS, Nov., April 5 (UP) -- Two jet drone fighter planes carrying mice and monkeys will fly through the atomic cloud that will follow an atom bomb explosion scheduled at Yucca Flat tomorrow, the Atomic Energy Commission announced today.

Louis J. Lefkowitz, chairman of the law committees of both the Republican state and New York County Committees, said yesterday that the law limiting membership on county committees of the legal political parties to four committeemen from any election district would not apply to members elected at the primary on Sept. 15.

the Red Cross placed its resources at the disposal of civil defense authorities. Since 1950, the Red Cross here has trained about 200,000 men and women in first aid; another 25,000 have received training in home nursing, and 500 nurse's aides have been trained to serve in hospitals here.

ATLANTA, April 5 -- For the world champion Yankees to lose, 4 -- 3, to the Atlanta Crackers of the Southern Association today was embarrassing enough for Casey Stengel, but the manner in which they lost was more upsetting.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 5 -- Research activity in laboratories of Government, industry and schools throughout the South continued to expand at a "significant and challenging pace" in 1952, the Southern Association of Science and Industry reported today.

PARIS, April 5 -- Economic and financial experts here foresee that the Government must conduct this month a decisive fight for future of the franc and French economy. Two major difficulties are, in fact, in prospect:

The conquering of materialism and of a lack of religious faith was urged by Athenagoras I, Ecumenical Patriarch of the Greek Orthodox Church, in a recorded Easter message beamed by the Voice of America yesterday afternoon. Recorded in Istanbul and flown here, it was one of the Easter messages by clergymen in more than forty languages used in Voice broadcasts.
CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., April 5 (UP) -- Authorities said today that Fred Eugene McManus, 18-year-old marine who killed five persons in four days, might be committed to a state hospital for sanity tests.

No respite is yet in sight for the bond market. After coping with the heaviest first-quarter aggregate of new corporate and municipal financing in more than twenty-five years, the public market for prime investment yields is now facing another wave of heavy capital requisitions, much of them stemming from the continuing need of expanding public utility enterprises to fund swollen short-term bank debt into bonds not maturing for thirty years.

Yesterday's coverage of the Easter Parade by the city's television stations was in marked contrast to the video presentations of a year ago. Gone was the worst of the disgraceful commercialism that marked the parade on Fifth Avenue in 1952.

In the last Congress a serious drive developed to deflate the key agency created under the Employment Act of 1946; the Council of Economic Advisers. It was with difficulty that friends of the C. E. A. succeeded in averting a drastic reduction in its budget for 1952-53 from the customary $300,000 a year to $200,000.
WESTERN FRONT, Korea, Monday, April 6 (UP) -- Eight hundred American soldiers knelt on ammunition boxes under a cloudy sky to celebrate Easter Sunday.

Somewhere there are theatre-goers who will respond with warmth and enthusiasm to the production called "Which Way Is Home?" This is the title of the offering that opened Saturday night at the Theatre de Lys, down on Christopher Street.

MOSCOW, Monday, April 6 -- The Communist party newspaper Pravda said today that the former deputy chief of the Ministry of State Security, a man named Ryumin, had been arrested and charged with chief responsibility for concocting the false case against prominent Soviet doctors.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- The first official explanation of how designers expect to harness an atomic engine to an airplane came to light tonight with the publication of testimony before a Congressional committee.

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved irregularly within a narrow range last week but closed the period with a moderate net loss. Thursday's closing prices showed active future contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange down 6 to 19 points from the level of the previous week. The Exchange was closed Friday.

Two score and ten years ago P. H. (Pat) Cummings started to work in the express industry as a porter. Today Mr. Cummings, as general manager of the air express division of the Railway Express Agency, will celebrate his jubilee anniversary in the same business.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 5 (AP) -- All hope was abandoned tonight for eighty-one American-trained Turkish sailors who went down in the rammed submarine Dumlupinar in the Dardanelles yesterday. The Defense Ministry issued a communique detailing the loss of life: seven officers, thirty-five petty officers, thirty-nine enlisted men.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, April 5 -- At 10 o'clock this morning, just twenty-four hours before a conference about an exchange of sick and wounded war prisoners was scheduled to begin here, North Korean security guards temporarily laid down their rifles and took up shovels.
SAN DIEGO, April 5 (AP) -- Herbert Allen (Herb) Gorman suffered a heart attack as he played left field in a Pacific Coast League baseball game here today and died on the way to Mercy Hospital.

MONTE CARLO, April 5 (AP) -- Mrs. Dorothy Head Knode of Alameda, Calif., won the women's singles of the Monte Carlo invitation tennis tournament today after a three-hour match with Tota Zehden of Germany, 7 -- 5, 10 -- 12, 6 -- 4.
AUSTIN, Tex. April 5 -- The tide seems to have shifted in this transcontinental tour. First, Leo Dutcher was wearing the deep brown; now Alphonse Lopez has flat worried look.

The Marine Corps' "Mighty Mite," baby brother to the Army jeep, was ejected unceremoniously from a show of shiny passenger cars at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday, but quickly established a new beachhead two blocks away. The stubby vehicle was installed last night in real sporting company at the Grand Central Palace, where the International Motor Sports Show will continue through next Sunday.
The Atomic Energy Commission announced yesterday that Richard L. Kirk had been appointed director of production of its New York operations office, 70 Columbus Avenue.

Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians demonstrated its goodwill to the music public yesterday. It herped present to New York music lovers, free of charge, the program under the auspices of the New Friends of Music it had prevented Feb. 15.
LONDON, April 5 -- On this quiet and rainy Easter Sunday in London the loudest sound that can be heard is the cooing of doves in the faraway Kremlin.

TOKYO, Monday, April 6 -- United Nations and Communist liaison delegations met at Panmunjom, Korea, for forty-eight minutes this morning to discuss an exchange of sick and wounded prisoners of the Korean war, then adjourned until tomorrow.

Dr. James B. Conant, United States High Commissioner for Germany, reported here yesterday that "everybody" he had met in West Germany since taking up his Bonn post Feb. 10 wanted "a closer economic, political and military union" among European nations.

M. Chapin Krech has sold the four-story and basement dwelling on 18.2 by 100 feet at 228 East Sixty-eighth Street to a buyer for occupancy in a deal negotiated by Pease Elliman, Inc., brokers. The property has a garden and the house contains ten rooms and three bathrooms.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- From Western stories to the classic -- that is the before and after report on President Eisenhower's reading habits. Before and after his inauguration, that is.
ROME, April 5 (AP) -- The official English translation of the Easter address by Pope Pius follows:

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 5 (UP) -- Some forty members of the House of Representatives were expected to be on hand tomorrow for the beginning of spring baseball training. No one explained how practice during an Easter vacation would prepare the Representatives for a game weeks away -- the annual June classic in Washington -- but the Congressmen hoped to be in shape for an exhibition game scheduled here Friday night.
LONDON, April 5 -- "Stalag 17" by Donald Bevan and Edmund Trzcinski, which opened here yesterday at the Prince's Theatre, received a cool reception from the London critics.

PITTSBURGH, Apr. 5 -- The steel rate suffered a setback last week due to an outlaw railroad strike in this area. The steel loss at United States Steel plants here was enough to bring the national ingot rate down to 95 per cent -- a drop of 8 points from the revised rate in the week before.

Twenty-three honorable mentions, including two for men who gave their lives in the performance of duty, were included in departmental orders issued yesterday by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan. Altogether 408 citations were announced.

Five thousand worshipers thronged the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday and heard the Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, describe the resurrection story as the "hope for all mankind."

Bernard Bartzen of San Angelo, Tex., and Budge Patty of Los Angeles defeated Philippe Washer and Jacques Brichant of Belgium, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, to capture the men's doubles. The Belgian team won the event last year.

An exaggerated idea exists of the extent of business expansion and a misconception of the way in which it has been financed -- as a consequence of "incomplete statistical analyses," the National Association of Manufacturers declared yesterday. The group warned against complacency on the financing of post-war business.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The Supreme Court will reconvene tomorrow after a recess since March 16 with thirty-nine argued cases awaiting decision. Most important among them from the standpoint of issues involved and public interest are five cases involving racial segregation in the public schools.

Now that the traditional time for spring cleaning and wok in the garden has arrived, the Greater New York Safety Council, Inc., has issued a list of safety reminders to observe in the home, which in the past has been rated second to the highway as the scene of most accidents.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 5 -- With a bright sun but dimpled water, twenty-one sailing dinghies competed in nine races today at the Larchmont Yacht Club. There was a favorable northwest to west breeze which behaved until the last two contests when it piped up to 25 knots in puffs.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- John Foster Dulles, the Secretary of State, is expected to urge tomorrow that Congress reject any limitation of the President's treaty-making authority until the matter has received further serious study.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (UP) -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, the Minority Leader, warned today against any "slow down, cut back or stretch out" of the nation's rearmament program as a result of recent Russian peace moves.
TOKYO, Monday, April 6 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,576, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Monday, Korean time:

Millions of New Yorkers left the city yesterday for the country and shore in the first mass exodus of the spring. After enjoying a few hours of fresh air and sunlight, they funneled back into the city again at sundown.

The first exceptionally heavy arrival day of the year, involving the docking of seven passenger liners and one troop transport, with a total of 6,323 persons, was handled smoothly yesterday by immigration and customs officers.

BELGRADE, April 5 -- In an unusually speedy action, impelled, it was said, by the seriousness of the situation, the United States has made available an additional grant of $11,000,000 of emergency drought belief for Yugoslavia.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said today his investigating subcommittee would hold public hearings next week into alleged "influence peddling" in tax cases by a West Coast publicity man.
TOKYO, Tuesday, April 7 (AP) -- United Nations Command Communique 1,577, for the twenty-four hour to 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korean time:

Word was received here yesterday from Kingsville, Ont., famed bird sanctuary, that the first flight of Canada geese from Point Byram, Conn., had arrived. The sanctuary at Kingsville is believed by Canadian authorities to be the summering spot for Canada geese from Connecticut

First-quarter sales of Chas. Pfizer Co. were the highest for such a period in the company's history, John E. McKeen, president and board chairman, told shareholders at yesterday's annual meeting of the 104-year-old Brooklyn chemical and pharmaceutical manufacturer.

CAIRO, April 6 -- The Arab League today welcomed a reported proposal by United States Senator William Langer for the establishment of a Congressional commission to investigate the condition and prospects of 900,000 Arab refugees displaced from their homes during the Arab-Israeli war.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, April 6 --A stockholder's suit asking for payment of $1,000,000 by Howard Hughes to the R. K. O. Radio Pictures Corporation was filed today in Federal Court in Los Angeles by attorneys for Milton Friedman, who was identified as the owner of 1,000 shares of the company's stock.
WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration has stopped trying to collect money for treating veterans whose hospital insurance bars any payment to persons entitled to free care.
Teen-agers, including a contingent of "hot-rod fans," turned their attention from sports cars to safety yesterday at the second annual International Motor Sports Show at Grand Central Palace.

The annual spring craft exhibit has opened at the Pen and Brush Club, 16 East Tenth Street, and will continue through April 20. All of the articles on display, many of which are for sale, have been made by club members.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Falling retail prices, as reflected today by the "old series" Federal consumers index, will cut three cents an hour from the wage rates of 1,250,000 railroad workers. The cut will aggregate about $7,500,000 a month.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, assured Congress today that the Eisenhower Administration would not sign any treaty on human rights drafted under United Nations auspices or the already-drafted convention on political rights of women.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Against a background of increasing concern for the projected European Defense Community, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer will receive the same welcome here tomorrow as was extended the French Government delegation under Premier Rene Mayer.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, the largest retail food company in the country, has moved to end its anti-trust dispute with the Federal Government.

The Columbia Gas System, Inc., as a first step in a $62,000,000 financing program for this year, plans to sell 1,700,000 shares of its common stock through competitive bidding, it was announced yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, April 6 (AP) -- The Braves will play to a sell-out crowd of 36,011 in their National League opener in their new home here. The last tickets for the opening day -- some 7,500 bleacher seats -- were put on sale at 9:30 A. M. today and by nightfall between 3,000 and 4,000 fans had gobbled them up.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio called today for a "thorough investigation of the Truman Administration" to dramatize the political differences between Democratic and Republican Government control.

Soviet Russia apparently intends to "fashion a concordat" with the West if her recent peace feelers can be taken at face value, Rabbi Louis I. Newman said yesterday in a sermon at Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 6 -- President Eisenhower in a message of greeting opened the third annual convention of the Young Presidents Organization here today at the Arizona Biltmore Hotel. The members are presidents of 525 companies who attained that position before reaching the age of 39 and whose companies report at least a million dollars a year in sales.

The Silver Star was awarded posthumously yesterday to Second Lieut. John D. Elmore of Leonia, N. J., who was killed last October while leading his faltering platoon through heavy fire against an enemy-held hill near Kumhwa, Korea.

MONTE CARLO, April 6 (UP) -- Bernard Bartzen of San Angelo, Tex., and Philippe Washer of Belgium won the men's doubles in the international tennis tournament today by beating Budge Patty of Los Angeles and Jean-Noel Grinda of France, 6 -- 4, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 1.
TOKYO, Tuesday, April 7 -- The United Nations and the Communists agreed today to voluntary repatriation of all sick and wounded Korean war prisoners, including those with minor disabilities.

ALEXANDRIA, La., April 6 -These things are difficult to explain, but our noble Giants who, only a short time ago, were making blind stabs at this game of baseball as though they had never heard of it, are now playing as though they invented it.

Except for those engaged in the three adjourned games from the eighteenth and next-to-last round, a rest period was allowed yesterday for the competitors in the international chess masters tournament at Mar Del Plata, Argentina, according to a report from Buenos Aires.

THE HAGUE, April 6 -- New Jersey has abandoned its efforts to induce Harold J. Adonis, former executive clerk for Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of that state, to return voluntarily to the United States. This was announced today by the state deputy Attorney General, Albert M. Ash, who added that he would press for early extradition and was confident he would win.

Since the hysteria, shenanigans and downright madness of producing a show in 1953 are no different from what they apparently were back in 1937, "Room Service," which was revived at the Playhouse last night, remains a hilarious farce.

Deadlocked at one game apiece in their best-of-seven final series, the New York Knickerbockers resume fighting with the Minneapolis Lakers for the National Basketball Association title at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory tonight.
Bids will be received May 5 on issues of Pima County, Ariz., school district bonds totaling $6,200,000. Dated June 1, 1953, the bonds will come due from June 1, 1954 to 1973.

In a market notably lacking in hysteria -- there were virtually no big blocks after the opening -- but with the public well represented on the selling side, stock prices yesterday crumbled to the lowest levels since Nov. 17. Two waves of selling in the morning and late afternoon had the tape lagging minute or more behind the floor.
LOS ANGELES, April 6 -- Evidence that a lack of oxygen may be a factor in the development of cancer was reported today by the Cedars of Lebanon Hospital's Institute for Medical Research.

The General Sessions trial of John E. Gleason Jr., former city employe, on charges of perjury arising from the investigation of the shakedown of fuel oil installers by Fire Department inspectors began yesterday with the selection of four jurors.

Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West Germany's Chancellor, arrived here yesterday for major conferences with President Eisenhower, but amid the pressures of politics and international affairs he managed to fulfill one preliminary he had enjoined upon himself:

JERUSALEM, April 6 -- The Jordanian Government urged Arab refugees today to stop filing applications for the recovery of blocked bank accounts in Israel. It also requested Barclay's Bank, the Ottoman Bank and the United Nations Relief and Works Agency to refuse to accept any applications filed.

W. T. Grant Company, which retails low-priced merchandise in wide variety through a chain of 491 stores, had record net sales of $283,240,067 in the fiscal year ended last January, an increase of 5.6 per cent over the previous year's volume of $268,332,908.

Patrolman Samuel Katz, 36 years old, who had completed seven years in the Police Department on March 18, died yesterday morning in Harlem Hospital of wounds received in a pistol duel Saturday night. He was shot at 220 West 146th Street, near Seventh Avenue, while investigating a complaint that three men were behaving suspiciously there.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads estimated today that net income for the Class I rail systems amounted to $57,000,000 in February, compared with $51,000,000 in February, 1952.
The apparent willingness of the Chinese Communists to make concessions on the issue of the voluntary repatriation of prisoners of war has raised the hopes for peace throughout the world.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 6 -- The prospect of India's serving as the "neutral state" to supervise prisoners of the Korean war who are unwilling to return to their homes arose here today with persistent reports that the New Delhi Government had been asked by the Chinese Communists to take the assignment.

DETROIT, April 6 -- The GeneralI Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O.,] will resume negotiations here to-I morrow on a formula for keying] [their five-year escalator agreement l to the new consumers price index. The rest of the automobile indus try was standing by to see what pattern wduld emerge.
The New York cotton futures market was moderately active yesterday and closed steady, 4 to 8 points net lower than on last Friday.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The White House announced today that President Eisenhower's speech before the American Society of Newspaper Editors April 16 would be of major importance and would be broadcast by all television and radio networks at 1 P. M.

SINCE the publication five years ago of Alan Paton's great and beautiful novel, "Cry, the Beloved Country," about the tragedy of racial conflict in South Africa, there have been a number of other novels on the same subject. Some of these were written by white men and some by black. But until "Blanket Boy"* was published last week there was none worthy to be mentioned in the same paragraph with Mr. Paton's.

ALBANY, April 6 -- Governor Dewey today signed a bill giving the State Harness Racing Commission, instead of the United States Trotting Association, full control over harness racing in New York State.

BONN, Germany, April 6 -- Extension of the current Soviet peace campaign by any, outwardly convincing offer to the West on the reunification of and a peace treaty for Germany would shake the security system of Western Europe, according to authoritative United States sources.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Former Attorney General Francis Biddle, as national chairman of Americans for Democratic Action, called on Herbert Brownell Jr., the present Attorney General today to institute a thorough investigation into the personal affairs of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.
SALT LAKE CITY. April 6 -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, stressed today his continued belief "that farmers basically do not want to be dependent upon Government handouts."

The Southern Natural Gas Company expects its construction expenditures this year to be about $70,000,000, C. T. Chenery, chairman, and C. P. Rather, president, told stockholders in the annual report issued yesterday. They said the program will be financed through early issuance of first mortgage bonds and of debentures, convertible into common stock.

An early morning eight-mile chase of a speeder on the Bell Parkway, in which a roadblock was set up and three shots fired by police, resulted in the arrest at 3:30 A. M. yesterday of Paul A. Roge, 28 years old, of West Hills New Canaan, Conn.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 6 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh said today that his life had been threatened by plotters in the court of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi and demanded that the 33-year-old monarch be reduced to a figurehead without power to rule.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 6 -- Junior Joe Castle, making his debut as a varsity starter, pitched a four-hitter today as Princeton opened its home baseball season with a 5-0 conquest of Manhattan at University Field.

TRENTON, April 6 -- The New Jersey Superior Court, Chancery Division, ruled today that a former Middlesex County prosecutor, who had sought to ban the sale of a book as obscene and indecent, acted arbitrarily and violated the Constitutional guarantee of freedom of the press.

ALTHOUGH almost anything can happen to the water table between now and Saturday morning, the opening-day fishing prospects are getting brighter by the hour. As a result, many New York and New Jersey anglers, who had planned merely to "drive around and watch the suckers freeze," have almost decided to start early and take along a rod.

NEWARK, April 6 -- The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company and the Commercial Workers Union, an independent group representing 1,800 clerical workers and telephone directory advertising salesmen, reached an agreement this afternoon on a contract that was to have expired at midnight.

MOSCOW, April 6 -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, mingled affably with Western diplomatic representatives and exchanged cordial and friendly toasts tonight at a big reception given by the Finnish legation.
There is little resemblance between the teaching methods of a New York City elementary classroom, 1953 style, and the 1923 or 1933 brand.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 6 -- Allie Reynolds, who will pitch the Yankees' opener at Washington, worked five innings today and blanked the Birmingham Barons with two hits. Chief Wahoo left for a pinch-hitter in the sixth and it was against Bob Kuzava that the Barons scored as the Yankees went on to record a 6 -- 2 victory over their Southern Association farmhands.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 6 -- The United States set off an atomic explosion today more than 5,000 feet above the Nevada proving ground, a record altitude for its use or tests of such blasts. The radiation potential of today's explosion was so great that high-level air traffic was prohibited over a 100,000-square-mile area.

Helicopter night mail service between La Guardia Airport and towns and cities in Westchester and Connecticut will start tomorrow. New York Airways, operator of the helicopter service, announced yesterday that these communities along its northern route would be first line airmail stops.
The Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., paid out $103,000 in maternity benefits to wives of members in the last year under the union's welfare plan.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (UP) -The Army ad Air Force have protested vigorously against proposed manpower cuts by Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, on the ground they would cripple the nation's fighting power.

MOSCOW, April 6 -- Pravda suggested in an editorial today that the Bolshoi Theatre include works of Richard Wagner in its repertoire. Wagner has not generally been presented in the Soviet Union for many years, with the exception of a brief revival in 1939 and 1940.

The Italian electoral reform law has at last been forced through Parliament and has been signed and promulgated by President Einaudi. All that remains to be done is a Presidential decree naming the date for the general elections, which are almost certainly going to be held on June 7.

Although the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II is two months away, American business men are losing no time in capitalizing on the interest it engenders. They already are merchandising such items as coronation jewelry, candy, salads, perfumes, carpets, dolls and joke books.
LONDON, April 6 (Reuters) -- The Wolverhampton Wanderers downed Portsmouth by 4 -- 1 today to maintain their one-point lead in the first division of the English League.

There is nothing that is "delightful" or "fun" for a child in having his tonsils out, and parents should not set the stage for disappointment and shock by trying to make the experience seem like a lark. Dr. Lester L. Coleman, associate attending surgeon at the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, emphasized this point in a recent interview, expanding on a talk he had given earlier at Finch College on preparing children for surgery.
CHICAGO, April 6 -- Mr. Slezak was born on April 18, 1896, in the Hungarian area of what is now Czechoslovakia. His father was a general produce merchant.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- Congressional investigators searching for Reds in schools and colleges have found fifty-four educators or former educators who refused to answer questions about possible Communist links.

HAVANA, April 6 -- Gen. Francisco Tabernilla, Chief of Staff of the Cuban Army, said today military intelligence service had uncovered a "vast conspiracy" against the Government as detentions continued. The general said former President Carlos Prio Socarras was furnishing the money for the conspiracy.

MILWAUKEE, April 6 -- Two of the nation's great stores, Marshall Field Co. and Gimbel Brothers, Inc., announced today that they would establish large department stores in a new $15,000,000 suburban shopping center being built here.

DENVER, April 6 -- Nearly $11,000,000,000 would be required to take care of classroom needs in the elementary schools of the United States, delegates were told today at the Study Conference of the Association for Adult Education International.

For the first time in nearly two years, Fred Allen will be seen on television on a regular basis next September, when he will conduct a new program entitled "Judge for Yourself" over the N. B. C. network on Tuesdays from 10 to 10:30 P. M.

Members of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America were urged yesterday by R. Manning Brown, assistant vice president of the New York Life Insurance Company, to keep a careful watch on their credit policies. He was one of the speakers at the eastern conference of the association, which continues today at the Commodore Hotel.

TRENTON, April 6 -- Former State Senator Robert B. Meyner, Democratic organization candidate for Governor, accused John J. Dickerson tonight of six "breaches of public trust" and called for his immediate resignation as Republican state chairman.

The editorial board of Medical News, official publication of the Medical Society of the County of New York, charged yesterday that proposals to provide a built-in clinic for the low-income residents of the new Carver Houses were "economically and philosophically unsound."

The John Burroughs Memorial Association medal for excellence in nature writing was presented yesterday to Gilbert Klingel for his book, "The Bay" (Dodd, Mead). Mr. Klingel, a boat designer and research engineer by profession, is a natural scientist by avocation.

The Kellogg Company, processor of cereal products, last year transacted the largest sales in its history and increased the net income to $9,003,948 from $8,342,830 earned in 1951, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
Stock market prices demonstrated last year, as they have done many times in the past, that their relationship to earnings is tenuous.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 6 -- United Nations delegates, returning from the Easter recess tomorrow, are expected to vote approval of Dag Hammarskjoeld of Sweden to succeed Trygve Lie as Secretary General by secret ballot at a meeting of the General Assembly.
Mayor Impellitteri prepared yesterday to submit his 1953-54 executive budget, expected to be a record-breaker, to the Board of Estimate at 10:30 o'clock this morning at City Hall.

Eighteen men, including one who had worked as an investigator for the Senate Crime Investigating Committee and the New York City Anti-Crime Committee, were sentenced yesterday to terms up to three years in the penitentiary on their pleas of guilty last February to participating in a payroll-padding scheme on the Brooklyn waterfront.

The fall retail prices of Max Udell Sons Co., Inc., manufacturer of Gramercy Park Clothes, will be unchanged from last season despite increased labor costs, Jerome I. Udell, chairman of the board, said yesterday. Prices were held, he said, by concentrating the line into featured ideas that lend themselves to individual promotions and by limiting the number of models in which each fabric is made.

The idea of a central port promotional bureau which is now being considered by local shipping and port leaders is all to the good. The proposal is that all the organizations devoted to shipping in this port form a loose federation which would seek to offset increased competition from other ports and to find solutions for problems that hamper operations here.

The way in which certain defendants in the investment banking anti-trust action won larger portions of the negotiated underwriting business reflects the play of competition in the field and the unlikelihood of the conspiracy charged by the Government, defense counsel argued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- Following is the text of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles' statement before a Senate Judiciary subcommittee on proposals to curb the President's power to make treaties:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 6 -- Mr. Dulles' announcement that the United States would not sign the human rights pact or the convention of political rights for women is likely to have profound effect on the eighth session of the Human Rights Commission, which opens tomorrow in Geneva. For the first time, Mrs. Oswald Lord will be sitting as a successor to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who guided the commission from its start.
INDIANAPOLIS, April 6 -Brooklyn fans will see a new second baseman but they won't see a new shortstop next Tuesday when the Dodgers take the field for their opening day battle with the Pirates.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- The first evidence that the pancreas gland of animals and men also produces an anti-insulin hormone, which causes an effect directly opposite to that of insulin, was presented here today at the scientific exhibit of the annual meeting of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology.

Abandonment of the city's line-item method of budget-making and the substitution of a program budget was recommended yesterday by the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey in the sixth installment of its over-all report on proposed improvements in municipal government.
