SAMMY SNEAD'S golf swing is a thing of beauty and a joy forever. The experts will tell you that Slammin' Sam is the perfect stylist. From outward appearances the one-time hillbilly from Virginia has the disposition to go with his exquisite form. He talks with a drawl, moves with careless indolence and seems completely happy-go-lucky.
CHICAGO, April 6 (AP) -- Harold Worst took over a share of the world three-cushion billiard tournament lead today by defeating John Fitzpatrick, Hollywood, Calif., 50 -- 35, in 46 innings.

The Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University for thirteen years until 1949, warned last night that private education in the United States would vanish unless all students received financial aid through the Federal Government.

The thirty,sixth season of outdoor concerts at Lewisohn Stadium will begin Aionday, June 22, qth the opening program led by Leonard Bernstein, who has not conducted at the amphitheatre since 1947. As ill the two previous summers, the season will run six weeks.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to rule on whether the United States District Court here had authority to order two Chinese Air Force officers not to dispose of any funds placed under their control by the Republic of China.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., April 6 -- Public hearings on proposals of the State Rent Commission to decontrol rents in fifty small communities in the Hudson River Valley area will start here on April 20, the local rent commission office announced-' today. A study has shown that there are only a. fev

BOSTON, April 6 -- A group of fifty-six Massachusetts educators asserted in a formal statement today that they felt that some Congressional investigating committees were "contributing to a subtle breakdown in our democratic processes."

CHICAGO, April 6 -- Unexpected rain in the Southwest drought areas accentuated the bearish sentiment, encouraged by more hopeful peace prospects in Korea, and prices for all grains and soybeans were lower under pressure of liquidation sales and local pressure today.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that labor union contracts that provided job seniority credit to World War II veterans need not give preference to workers previously employed by the company involved.

Reports that President Eisenhower has felt it necessary to make concessions to high-tariff Republicans in order to preserve the reciprocal trade agreements program stirred reactions among foreign traders yesterday ranging from pessimistic to skeptical.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 6 (AP) --Because its play reviewer has been banned from the New Parsons Theatre here, The Hartford Courant said tonight it would reprint in tomorrow's editions articles by two New York theatre critics who gave favorable reviews to "The Fourposter," which opened here tonight.

Two New York City judges described city and municipal court buildings as "dilapidated" and "below minimum standards" yesterday as they urged prompt building of a new City Municipal Courts Building. They spoke at ceremonies on the steps of the United States Courthouse in Foley Square commemorating the 150th anniversary of the beginning of the Greater New York Civic Center.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to hear an appeal from a ruling of the Court of Appeals here that restaurants in the District of Columbia had a legal right to refuse to serve Negroes. It set the case for argument April 27.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- The Red Cross said today that its 1953 drive to raise funds for a program that includes a new project to aid the fight on poliomyelitis was "lagging away behind" the objective of $93,000,000.
ALBANY, April 6 -- Governor Dewey vetoed on safety grounds today a bill to permit defense plant workers to place windshield stickers on their cars for identification.

The Belair Stud's Game Chance outlasted G. C. Ganter's Virtuous in a duel between the Kentucky Derby nominees for first money in the $4,500 Sunnyside Purse, yesterday's feature at the Jamaica race track.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6 (AP) -- Rain prevented practice for the Masters golf tournament today, but officials at the Augusta National course weren't complaining.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Supreme Court refused today to permit Philadelphia to intervene in a case involving the effort of New York to divert more water from the Delaware River. In an unsigned 7-to-2 opinion, the tribunal held that Philadelphia's rights would be adequately protected by the State of Pennsylvania, which already is a party to the proceedings.

A canned Jiffy Cream Sauce was introduced to food writers yesterday by Sardi's. The first product to which the restaurant on West Forty-fourth Street has lent its name, it is available now in Gristede and Associated Food stores.

The ten-story office building at 1 Hudson Street, northwest corner of Chambers Street, has been sold by Martin Diamond to a syndicate of investors represented by Dreyer Traub, attorneys. Berman-Glassman Associates and Arthur W. Walker were the brokers and Allen Marcus was attorney for the seller.

Fund-raising must be very difficult, but need it be presumptuous? More and more frequently I have been receiving "gifts" in the mail for which I am supposed to send a check to some undoubtedly worthy cause. I consider it an invasion of privacy and a thorough nuisance. Often these "gifts" come in sets, which means repackaging and postage, and for a busy person it is more than a bore.

The contemporary practice of utilizing simple, sturdy materials to produce furnishings of elegance is demonstrated by a new group of lamps and lighting fixtures. Plastic or Fiberglas sheeting -- some decorated with such simple items as burlap or leaves -- metal tubing, opaque glass and cord are some of the materials used in this new collection.

Steel production in this country topped 10,000,000 tons last month for the first time in the industry's history, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday on the basis of its weekly volume figures. March output was estimated at 10,100,000 tons.

DELFT, the Netherlands, March 9 (by airmail) -- The closing of the first big gap in the Dutch sea defenses -- a 175-foot hole in the dike near Hellevoetsluis on the island of Voorne -- went like clockwork.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee is expected to report a limited economic controls bill giving President Eisenhower authority to impose a ninety-day freeze on prices and wages in the event of a grave emergency.

TOKYO, Tuesday, April 7 -- United Nations representatives at Panmunjom, Korea, accepted today a Communist proposal to free all sick and wounded prisoners of the Korean war, including less seriously injured, who would be transferred to the custody of neutral nations.

WASHINGTON, N. J., April 6 -- Independent tests by Consumers Research, Inc., have shown that additives "do not improve the performance of automobile storage batteries as claimed," Frederick J. Schlink, technical director of the testing organization, declared today.

The thirty-first annual Fifty Books of the Year exhibition of the American Institute of Graphic Arts, which opened last night, is, according to the foreman of the jury of selection, "the first positive evidence that what we call 'modern' design has reached maturity in the contemporary book."

PATZCUARO, Mexico, March 81 -- A cheap and simple printing process primarily designed for production of posters, has been developed by 36-year-old Jerome Oberwager of New York for the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization's fundamental education center here.

An item in this section yesterday failed to make clear that Whitney Darrow, retiring as executive vice president and continuing as a director of Charles Scribner's Sons, is also continuing actively in the company as assistant to the president.
ALBANY, April 6 -- Governor Dewey may call the Legislature into special session two or more times this year because of the large number of urgent problems requiring action before 1954.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Secretary of State, John Foster Dulles, undertook today one of the most difficult assignments of his distinguished career as lawyer and statesman when he argued before the Senate Judiciary Committee against any immediate move to restrict the treaty-making power of the President and the Senate.

Readers learning of the sadness with which ex-GI's and their families are leaving their hut-and-barracks homes at Manhattan Beach may easily question why. The temporary housing built for or adapted to veterans' use after the Second World War was never especially nice to look at either from the inside or the outside.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- The Washington Senators got some cheering news today. Doctors reported Gil Coan's injury is not as serious as it was thought and he'll probably be back in action within a month.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- President Eisenhower nominated today as Assistant Secretaries of the Army, James P. Mitchell, New York department store executive, and John Slezak, president of an Illinois brass works.

Regally surveying about half a century of her career in the theatre, Ethel Barrymore proffered the opinion yesterday that a great deal of nonsense had been written about changes in her profession. With the customary Barrymore verve and crisp speech she ticked off some tart remarks on playwrights, actors and audiences.

In an effort to show the culture of India to the people of the United States, the Indian Consulate General opened last night a week-long program of lectures and performances on Indian art and thought.

TOKYO, Tuesday, April 7 -- Fighting intensified along the Korean front yesterday as the armistice negotiators of both sides sat down at Panmunjom to resume discussion of the exchange of war prisoners -- the main stumbling block to a cease-fire.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (UP) -The Supreme Court got a chemistry lesson today as lawyers sought to establish that Government carelessness was to blame for the Texas City, Tex., dockside disaster that took 560 lives in 1947.

A curious impression is being created in me by the current Washington political situation. From what's happening and from the mud that is being spattered toward the White House and the State Department it would almost seem that the Democrats are still in office and nothing has changed.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., April 6 (AP) -- The General Electric Company closed its electronics plants here today because of what it called illegal mass picketing at the plants, which employ about 11,000.

A visit to grown-ups, a rainy day at home, a trip in the car or even playtime in the park can be a trying experience for both parent and child if the youngster hasn't enough to do, says Mrs. Rowena Shoemaker, assistant director of the Play Schools Association.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges closed lower yesterday with many items still reacting to the influence of the Korean peace news. Hides registerd the most activity since Jan. 30 and coffee was fairly active. Cocoa, hides, rubber, potatoes, wool, cottonseed oil, soybean oil and tin were lower.

A grand-slam home run by sophomore Tony Palladino in the sixth inning capped a 5-run Columbia rally and gave the Lions a 7-6 victory over N. Y. U. yesterday at Baker Field. The game was called after seven and a half innings because of darkness.

Good judges! That is the plea by lawyers and citizens. The proposed legislative study of the courts has the same objective. Why the outcry for a different method of selecting judges -- for the adoption of the so-called Missouri plan?

Exciting vistas are opened up by the announcement of a five-year plan for an international art exchange. The program will be directed by the Museum of Modern Art and it has been made possible by a generous grant from the Rockefeller Foundation. Exhibits from various parts of the world will be brought here and we, in turn, will send the work of our own artists to many countries.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 6 -- The widening of rivers and construction of detention reservoirs, channels, tunnels, dikes and levees to control flash floods in Westchester would cost at least $17,431,700, James C. Harding, county Commissioner of Public Works, told the Board of Supervisors today.

Seventy-five members of the Marine Corps Reserve, New York Chapter, gave blood yesterday at the Manhattan Center, 70 West Fortieth Street, in honor of the First Marine Division, which suffered severe casualties in the recent fighting on Vegas Hill in Korea. The Red Cross had designated the day as First Marine Division Day.

TRENTON, April 6 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll went to Detroit this morning to deliver an address on judicial reform before the Economic Club. Tonight he will travel to Key West, Fla., for a few days of relaxation before returning to his office in the State House here.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 6 -- The Coast Guard was charged today with having weakened the job security of West Coast stevedores by "standing in judgment" on them through its waterfront screening program while giving work clearances to "every thug, ex-con and racketeer who operates in the East Coast International Longshoremen's Association."
OKLAHOMA CITY, April 6 (AP) -- An Oklahoma A. and M. College spokesman said today the school, facing a threat of scholastic disaccreditation, would abolish athletic scholarships.

Chris Anderson, who has been attempting to break through the managerial barrier since 1948, is confident that he will become a full-fledged producer next season with "Jealousy," the two-character play Al Woods presented about twenty years ago with Fay Bainter and John Halliday.

Seventeen million telephone calls are made in New York on the average business day, and of these it is estimated that one in every hundred is a wrong number. Statisticians have never officially calculated the total of profanity, bad manners and embarrassment produced by these 170,000 calls, but the subscriber who has been got out of bed by one of them can be depended upon for a vigorous private opinion.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- President Eisenhower, who braved many a campaign crowd, today came smiling through a mob scene, the first Easter egg rolling on the White House grounds since 1941.

A stormy session has been predicted for tonight, when the New York District Council of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., will meet in Brooklyn to act on the abolition of the shape-up.

State and municipal financing during the first quarter ended on March 31 was the heaviest of the post-war period, according to the Daily Bond Buyer, the trade publication. For 1953, the three months ended on March 31 developed bond sales totaling $1,186,678,000, compared with $1,028,925,305 in 1952, and $1,178,740,000 -- the previous high record -- in 1950.
President Eisenhower, in a message to Douglas Fairbanks, national chairman of American Relief to Korea, yesterday urged support of the organization's clothing drive.

BONN, Germany, April 6 -- Two representatives of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's subcommittee on Government Operations arrived last night to investigate the United States information program in West Germany and West Berlin.

Prospects for retail trade continue favorable whether there is a truce in Korea or the cold war continues, Fred Lazarus Jr., president of Federated Department Stores, Inc., said yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Society of Security Analysts at Schwartz' Restaurant.

WEST POINT, N. Y., April 6 -- Swarthmore's nine handed Army its first defeat of the season at Doubleday Field today, downing the Cadets by 5 -- 2 in a game called at the end of the eighth because of darkness.

ELMSFORD, N. Y., April 6 -One hundred eleven employes were considering tonight an offer by the Sonotone Corporation here to compromise its order suspending them for one week without pay because they walked off the job three days ago "without permission" to attend Good Friday church services.

The building with thirty-seven apartments and eight stores at 1032 Aldus Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Caron-Linda Realty Corporation to a client of Maxwell Fox, broker. It is assessed at $135,000.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, April 7 -- The Central Committee of the Communist party has released Semyon D. Ignatiev from his duties as a secretary of the committee, it was announced today by Pravda.
If Peter Klein, a tailor from Israel, lives to be a hundred years old, he decided last night, he will never forget his first visit to New York.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today announced it had issued a complaint against the Kordol Corporation of America for what it called "misleading and deceptive" statements about an anti-pain tablet.

Posters and programs tracing the 150 years of circus history in the United States compose an exhibit that will open today at the New York Historical Society, Central Park West at Seventy-seventh Street.

An observance commemorating the election of George Washington as the first President of the United States on April 6, 1789, was held yesterday on the steps of the Sub-treasury Building at Nassau and Wall Streets. Several hundred persons stopped to listen to speeches eulogizing Washington.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 6 -- An issue under official consideration is whether to dismiss the Negro civil servants in Northern Rhodesia who stayed away from work last Wednesday and Thursday to pray for deliverance from the British Government's Rhodesia-Nyasaland federation plan.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Abraham J. Isserman, one of the lawyers who defended the eleven Communist leaders convicted in New York of conspiring to teach and advocate the overthrow of the Government by force and violence, was barred by the Supreme Court today from practicing before it.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations today elected John V. Riffe, a former coal miner, as executive vice president to succeed the late Allan Haywood.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 6 (AP) -- Harold M. Salvey, one-time head of the S G gambling syndicate, died of a heart attack today while playing golf. He was 53 years old. Salvey collapsed after driving from the eighteenth tee at the Bayshore golf course and was pronounced dead on arrival at Mount Sinai Hospital.

MINEOLA, L. I., April 6 -- A formation of four Sabrejet fighter planes, throttled down to 350 miles an hour, cruised along Franklin Avenue six times here this morning while an inexperienced crew of civilian technicians almost made a farce of demonstrating the Skysweeper, the Army's new rapid-firing, completely radar-controlled anti-aircraft cannon.

VIENNA, April 6 -- United States Army headquarters in Salzburg announced tonight that Wilhelm Hoettl, former S. S. (Elite Guard) officer, had been arrested because of his alleged connection with Kurt L. Ponger and Otto Verber, now awaiting trial in Washington for espionage on behalf of the Soviet Union.
LONDON, April 6 (AP) -- Following is the text of Pravda's first editorial today on the "doctors' plot," as broadcast by the Moscow radio:

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 8 -- Communist negotiators at Panmunjom, Korea, told United Nations representatives today that about 600 Allied prisoners would be returned under the terms of a proposed agreement for immediate repatriation of all sick and wounded of the Korean war.
HOUSTON, Tex., April 7 -- The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company is planning to buy a one-quarter interest in the American Republics Corporation at a cost estimated at $25,000,000.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 7 -- Edvard Kardelj, Vice President of the Federal Executive Council, disclosed today the Government's disillusionment with the complicated system of production planning and wage payments. He said the "accumulation" system -- a devious form of pre-taxation -- had to be abolished because it hampered economic progress.

Two narcotics addicts were arraigned yesterday on charges of killing Patrolman Samuel Katz, who was shot Saturday night when he surprised the hold-up of a dice game in a Harlem alley that netted $100.

ALBANY, April 7 -- Governor Dewey announced today his approval of business and commercial rent legislation that extends controls until July 1, 1954, and provides for increases up to 15 per cent for some tenants not now paying 30 per cent more than the "frozen" 1943 rent.
Fitting into the current revival of what used to be known as art glass are some crystal pieces introduced by Steuben, 718 Fifth Avenue.

If the object of the new Soviet leaders is to confuse and bewilder the leading Governments of the non-Communist world they have certainly succeeded. It is obvious that London and Paris, New Delhi and Washington, do not know what to make of the Kremlin's sudden change of front.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- Former Senator Chan Gurney of Yankton, S. D., and former Representative Harmar D. Denny Jr., of Pittsburgh, both Republicans, were sworn in today as members of the Civil Aeronautics Board.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 7 -- The formation of the Vistarama Corporation to produce wide-screen theatrical and industrial movies with either 35mm or 16mm film by a camera using a wide-angle distortion lens was announced today by Carl Dudley, president of Dudley Pictures Corporation, makers of motion pictures used in industrial public relations and for training personnel.

State Housing Commissioner Herman Stichman said yesterday the Mount Sinai Hospital-Carver Houses clinic extension plan would make available clinic treatment for groups in South Harlem whose health problems had been neglected.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Herbert A. Philbrick, who worked for the Federal Bureau of Investigation for nine years in the Communist underground, testified today that between 1947 and 1949 he had known "seven or eight hardened, disciplined and steeled" Reds who were "posing as ministers of the gospel" in the Boston area.
Spot prices of lead, tin and quicksilver declined yesterday -- but not all for the same reasons.

Agnew Nicholson is one Briton who takes his politics seriously -- especially when it leads to austerity and affects the pocketbook. So he boarded up his London home, sold his business, gathered his family, including eight children, and left.

Net asset value of the Lehman Corporation on March 31 was $149,544,481, equivalent to $72.02 a share on the trust's 2,076,562 shares of capital stock outstanding, Robert Lehman, president, reported yesterday to stockholders. Net asset value on June 30, 1952, the end of the corporation's previous fiscal year, was $71.57 a share.

Funds invested by the nation's $80,000,000,000 life insurance industry earned a higher rate of interest in 1952 than in any other year since 1943. The net rate of interest earned by all United States life insurance concerns was 3.28 per cent last year, compared with 3.18 per cent the year before.
TOKYO, Wednesday, April 8 -- United Nations troops threw back two enemy attacks on the western and central fronts last night and early today.

Federal Judge John F. X. McGohey denied yesterday two applications of the Government that sought to have a receiver appointed for all the property of Frank Costello and to restrain Costello or his wife, Loretta, from disposing of any of the property.
The Montauk Beach Company has organized a new department to engage in the general real estate brokerage business in the Montauk, Amagansett and East Hampton area in the eastern end of Suffolk County.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 7 -- Dag Hammarskjoeld, a Swedish professional diplomat and economist, was elected Secretary General of the United Nations today. On Friday, when he takes the oath of office, he will succeed Trygve Lie of Norway, who was elected Secretary General in February, 1946.

The new home of the Beekman-Downtown Hospital, a bright spot in the cavernous financial district, was dedicated at noon yesterday by Governor Dewey, in a ceremony attended by Mayor Impellitteri and a throng of other dignitaries.

A ship maintenance union local to which a charter was quietly given by the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., while the State Crime Commission's investigation of waterfront evils was under way is now being investigated by the commission and by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, it was learned yesterday.
TOKYO, Wednesday, April 8 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,578, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Wednesday, Korean time:
Offerings diminished and stock prices turned firmer yesterday, although the gains were small when compared with the recent setbacks suffered by most sections of the list.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (UP) -- American workers earned money in January and February at a rate which would net them a record $280,500,000,000 in the full year, the Department of Commerce reported today.
Four gas companies in the city proposed yesterday to the Public Service Commission at a public hearing that their existing rate schedules be altered to permit a surcharge on their present rates.

ROOSEVELT, L. I., April 7 -- A certain "big stick" has become the object of a search by residents of this community in connection with the scheduled opening of Sagamore Hill, Theodore Roosevelt's Oyster Bay home, as a national shrine.
INDIANAPOLIS, April 7 (AP) -- The Eli Lilly Company, Indianapolis pharmaceutical manufacturer, reported today a net profit of $11,711,000 for 1952 and announced election of a new president.

Prof. Robert S. Lynd of Columbia University, in a statement made public yesterday, labeled as "the most serious blow that education has received" the recent announcement by the Association of American Universities on common policy toward any Congressional investigations of their faculty members.
WASHINGTON April 7 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today authorized the overtime employment of laborers and mechanics on atomic projects essential to national defense.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- The Steele-Wedeles Company, ninety-year-old Chicago grocery wholesaler, announced today that it was going out of business. An official said the reason was that supermarkets had cut deeply into the volume of the small independent stores which were Steele-Wedeles' main customers.

The Television Committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association opened a series of meetings yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore to formulate a plan for televising college football games next fall.
MOBILE, Ala., April 7 -- This was a clear, sunny afternoon that was to see both managers of this roving baseball circus indulge in broad, complacent smiles.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., April 7 -- The life of commuters in running the "Gravel Gantlet" in the Bronx has become so hazardous, what with vandals throwing rocks through the windows of passing trains, that Paul Jenisch of 353 Egmont Avenue, this city, demanded today that the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad install shatterproof glass.

" Eye Witness" should be reported to the television humane society. The only kind thing to do is put the program out of its misery. The latest addition to the ranks of video mystery thrillers (9 P. M. Mondays over N. B. C.) is really one for the books. Never say television can't get any worse. Brother, it can!

CHICAGO, April 7 -- A description of the foul odors, disappointments and ingenuity that went into the development of ethyl gasoline drew interest and laughter at the du Pont anti-trust trial today as Charles E. Kettering, master inventor of General Motors Corporation, began testifying as a defense witness.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 7 -- Dr. Arthur S. Adams, president of the American Council on Education, declared here today there was no body of persons in this country more loyal than school teachers and college professors.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 7 (UP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson said here today that he saw no relation between the wars in Korea and Indo-China.

BALTIMORE, April 7 -- A sentence of death by hanging was imposed today on G. Edward Grammer, former New York office manager, convicted of the near "perfect" murder of his wife and mother of their three children. No date was set for the execution.

Not the least interesting Soviet development of the past week or so is the seeming loosening of Moscow's censorship over the dispatches sent out by American correspondents there. As a result, the close reader of recent Moscow dispatches is able to find clear hints and clues to the situation in the Soviet Union on topics that the censors formerly would have regarded as too sacrosanct for discussion.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 7 -- A rift threatens in the Swedish Communist party following the exit of Set Persson, one of the leaders, whose resignation today just beat the party executives' decision to oust him. The decision was made after the stormiest Easter convention here, during which Mr. Persson repeatedly was assailed for deviationism.

WASHINGTON April 7 -- President Eisenhower told the United Nations Commission on Human Rights in Geneva, Switzerland today, "freedom is an indispensable condition to the achievement of a stable peace."

BALTIMORE, April 7 -- Although nothing else has stopped the Dodgers often this spring, the weather kept them in their hotel for the second straight day when tonight's game with the Baltimore Orioles was called off shortly after 7 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, today challenged an assertion by the Senate Majority Leader, Robert A. Taft of Ohio, that the majority of Washington writers "tend to be anti-Republican."

A new film short in color that reflects the medical profession's concern over the mortality rate of lung cancer -- rising faster than any other type of the disease -- was shown for the first time yesterday. It was released by the American Cancer Society and the National Cancer Institute, and recommends that every man over 45 have a chest X-ray twice a year so the disease may be detected at its earliest stage.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Committee for Economic Development said today that a $6,600,000,000 reduction in Federal expenditures would be sufficient to justify tax relief this year, even though it would entail a $3,300,000,000 budget deficit.

The St. Lawrence Corporation, Ltd., and its subsidiaries, producers of pulp and paper, boxboards and shipping case materials, had a consolidated net profit last year of $6,210,511, or $5.63 a share of common stock, the twenty-third annual report disclosed yesterday.

Events tonight: "Samson et Dalila," Metropolitan Opera, 8:30 o'clock; "Die Fledermaus," City Center, 8:15; Elinore Sharp, violinist, Town Hall, 8:30; Ellen Gilberg, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Pasquier Trio, Lexington Avenue "Y," 8:40; Irene Fabry and Millie Island, sopranos Y. W. C. A., 210 East Seventy-seventh Street, 8:30

MONTREAL, April 7 (UP) -- Eddie (Spider) Mazur, a 200- pound rookie, helped the Montreal Canadiens gain the Stanley Cup finals tonight by scoring twice as the Chicago Black Hawks were eliminated, 4 -- 1, before 14,400 raucous fans in the Forum.

LISBON, Portugal, April 7 -- Escorted by motorized units of the Republican Guard, the coffin containing the body of former King Carol II of Rumania was taken today to a provisional resting place. A space in the Pantheon of St. Vincent's Roman Catholic Church, where the kings and queens of the House of Braganca are buried, has been set aside for the monarch until such time as a final burial can take place in Rumania.

GUATEMALA, April 7 -- Foreign Minister Raul Osegueda announced today the Government's decision to withdraw from the Organization of Central American States and cancellation of the organization's meeting here set for May 2. Central-American diplomatic representatives here have been informed of the decision in a document outlining the reasons.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- President Eisenhower nominated Guy O. Hollyday of Baltimore today as commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration to replace Walter L. Green, who has been serving in a "temporary" status since July 1, 1952.

The Bricker resolution to hobble the treaty-making powers of the United States is unnecessary, unwise and dangerous. This proposal to amend the Constitution, now being considered by the Senate Judiciary Committee, inexplicably has attached to it the names of sixty-four Senators.
CHICAGO, April 7 -- A sharp reversal in the price trend in grains and soybeans developed today. Corn led a substantial recovery.
ST. LOUIS, Wednesday, April 8 -- The Democrats scored a substantial victory yesterday in the municipal election here.

WASHINGTON COURT HOUSE, Ohio, April 7 -- Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and the police of three states were checking tonight to determine whether a story told to the police here was a hallucination or would lead to the discovery of a double-killing and the end of a cross-country search for a 10-year-old girl who vanished from Connecticut last July.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin and chairman of one of three Senate groups investigating the Government's international information services, called on John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, today to find out who were responsible for putting books written by Communists in overseas libraries designed to help the "cold war" against communism.
ROME, April 7 -- More than fifty parties will compete for the seats in the Senate and Chamber of Deputies in the June 7 general election.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- America's rival labor federations took a stride in the direction of unity today by setting a joint subcommittee to work on three logical "first" problems -- the elimination of raiding, drawing the structural and jurisdictional lines of the unions, and drafting an agenda.

A corner property containing seven stores and eleven apartments at 375-385 Sutter Avenue and 211-213 Christopher Avenue in Brooklyn has been sold by Leleiko, Pollack Leleiko to West Winds, Inc., in a transaction negotiated by the M. Morgenthau Seixas Company as broker.

Dining at Miss Irma Rhode's the other evening, we ate what our German-born hostess called a "new animal." That excellent cook, whose most recent book is "Cookbook for Fridays and Lent" (McKay, 1951), served a roast leg of lamb that, on biting into, tasted like lamb but on swallowing left an after-flavor that was tangy, almost game-like.

BERLIN, April 7 -- For the first time in almost two years representatives of the Big Four powers sat down at one table tonight to thrash out one of the many problems vexing their relations in Germany.

LONDON, April 7 -- Most sections of the London stock market were depressed today. Uncertainty over the economic effect of a Korean settlement, the break on Wall Street and the ending of the bookkeeping account were factors in the widespread decline.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- Experiments promising to make possible the prolonged use of fever-producing bacterial toxins in the treatment of a wide variety of chronic diseases were described here today at the annual meeting of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology.

WHIMSICAL nature has again stepped in to smear the bright picture for the opening day angler, and while, the current precipitation may be very pleasing to farmers and water supply agencies it brings no joy to those who had looked forward to low, fairly clear streams on Saturday.

The introduction of the modern electronic computer into scientific laboratories is as important as the invention of the microscope for the progress of science, Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer declared here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, is planning to go to the North Atlantic Treaty Council meeting in Paris on April 23 with a restatement of this country's defense policy predicated on ten or twenty years of tension.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 7 -- Valerian A. Zorin, the Soviet representative, repeated today in the United Nations General Assembly the standard Communist charge that United States forces had used germ warfare in Korea but, by comparison with previous Soviet statements, did so in extremely mild language.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Atomic Energy Commission, with the approval of President Eisenhower and the National Security Council, will soon recommend to Congress that the Federal Government end its absolute monopoly on the possession and development of fissionable materials for the production of atomic energy.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. told a Senate Judiciary subcommittee today that proposed amendments pending before it to limit the treaty-making authority of the President would upset the balance of power established by the Constitution.

A possible heavy cut in the nation's atomic bomb expansion program, reduction of naval uniformed personnel by 12,000 to 30,000 men, and reduction in size of the Army's strategic reserve divisions in this country are among the tentative. military economies for the next fiscal year now under study in Washington.

A final accounting of the forty-first annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund disclosed yesterday that a total of $391,892.52 had been received from 12,373 contributors. The 1952-53 appeal, in which seven private social welfare agencies participated, ended March 1.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Although there is widespread support in this country for the United Nations, professional "hate mongers" have made the international organization a target for lies and half-truths, James J. Wadsworth, deputy United States representative at the United Nations, warned here tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture today announced it would abolish its Production and Marketing Administration commodity offices in San Francisco and New York City on June 30.

Deadline bidding yesterday for three new issues of public utility bonds totaling $29,100,000 tested severely the pricing ideas of underwriting syndicates in the market's current effort to absorb a heavy volume of new corporate debt financing.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7 (AP) -- Middleweight Joey Giardello rallied in the late rounds tonight to clobber his home-town Philadelphia rival, Welterweight Gil Turner, for a unanimous ten-round decision before 7,377 at the Arena. Turner was a 3-1 favorite.

CONNEAUT, Ohio, April 7 -- A westbound New York Central mail, express and baggage train was derailed here tonight, blocking the railroad's four-track main line. A brakeman was injured, New York Central officials said.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Soviet "peace offensive" has had at least one good influence here. It has alerted the Government planners whose job it is to define long-range United States policies in Europe and Asia and to make provision for the day when defense spending will not assure full employment.

The crippled Canada goose at Greenwich, Conn., will be reunited with its kinfolk in Canada, the jurisdictional dispute between Connecticut and Canada has been settled without warfare, and all's well with the feathered world this morning.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 7 -- With the help of the United Nations, Israel is trying to fill the "middle ranks" of industry, business and the professions with a corps of newly trained men and women, Prof. Sune L. Carlson, Swedish consultant, said today.

LONDON, April 7 -- Electrified underwater "fences" now are being used to guide Scottish salmon away from dangerous hydroelectric turbine sluices in the Highland rivers according to a report issued by the Scottish Hydroelectric Board today.

As part of its present "peace offensive," and in view of the renewed negotiations at Panmunjom, Soviet Russia offers what it would like to represent as a generous and conciliatory settlement of the Communist germ-warfare charges against the United States. It does not drop the charges.

A house-by-house study of Chelsea to determine the nature of the population and its needs has been begun by New York University's Center for Human Relations and Studies, under the auspices of the Hudson Guild Neighborhood House.
LONDON, April 7 -- None of the new plays of the season has made so deep an impression on Londoners as Roger MacDougall's "Escapade," which is playing to packed audiences at the Strand Theatre.
DETROIT, April 7 (AP) -- Nearly 400,000 General Motors employes took a cent-an-hour wage cut today and twice that many more automobile workers are expected to follow suit in the next few days.
The Appellate Division unanimously upheld yesterday the right of the State Crime Commission not to call Thomas (Three Finger Brown) Luchese as a witness at its public hearings.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee voted today to give the Eisenhower Administration authority to control consumer and real-estate credit.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh yesterday set a ten-day "amnesty on traffic scofflaws," but this period of grace did not help one woman violator, who was assessed $2,950 in fines on her guilty plea to having ignored fifty-nine parking-tickets in the last three years.
Three unions in related fields. now separate, moved close yesterday to unity within the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Commodities on the New York exchanges were inactive yesterday with only lead, zinc and potatoes showing slightly better than average volume. The close was irregular with coffee, sugar, cocoa, soybean oil, wool and hides higher. Lead, zinc, potatoes, rubber and tin were lower and cottonseed oil ended mixed.

The Staff Officers Association of America, A. F. L., agreed yesterday not to picket ships of the Isbrandtsen Company, provided the line would refrain from discharging pursers pending action on a collective bargaining petition before the National Labor Relations Board.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 7 -- Xavier Federmann, a principal partner in the Israel Oil Prospectors Company, announced today that his concern with the Lapidot Company and the Jordan Exploration Company would begin to drill for oil in the Dead Sea area "not later than six months from now." The companies expect to be the first to drill for oil in Israel.

First quarter retail sales of General Electric Company's large household appliances were up 10 per cent compared with the like period of last year. Clarence H. Linder, vice president and general manager of the major appliance division, reported yesterday.

The security program of the Western world was further strengthened yesterday when the first United States Navy ship to be transferred under the Mutual Defense Assistance Program was turned over to the Portuguese Government.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 7 -- The United States is trying to work out a settlement of Burma's complaint against Nationalist China that would involve the transfer to Formosa of thousands of Nationalist troops now on Burmese territory.

HARTFORD, April 7 -- Gov. John Davis Lodge sent to the General Assembly today the nomination of Justice Ernest A. Inglis of Middletown to be Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court, effective in October.

PHOENIX, Ariz, April 7 -- Reasonable optimism on business prospects in general and "downright enthusiastic" reports on the outlook for their own businesses were expressed by members of the Young Presidents Organization today during the third annual convention at the Arizona Biltmore Hotel.

NOW that the maneuverings of Albany and City Hall have managed to put the city in a financial straitjacket there appears to be a considerable danger of an increase in the subway fare to a flat 15 cents or even higher.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 7 (AP) -- Supporters of Iran's two rivals for power, Premier Mohammed Mossadegh and Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlevi, were quickly dispersed by the police today when they tried to stage demonstrations.

Passers-by hurrying through the deluge yesterday noticed two middle-aged men calmly playing chess in the shelter of a back door of the Selwyn Theatre in West Forty-third Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. Despite the downpour, the players had remained engrossed in their game from about 11 A. M. until 1 P. M.

Nat Holman, former basketball coach at City College, and the counsel for Dr. Frank S. Lloyd, former chairman of the college's hygiene department, accused the Board of Higher Education yesterday of trying to make them "scapegoats" for the 1949-50 basketball "fix" scandals.

Underwriters headed by the First Boston Corporation will place on the market today $8,000,000 of new first-mortgage 3 7/8 per cent bonds of the California Electric Power Company, due in 1983, at 101.335 to yield 3.8 per cent. The bonds were bought at public bidding by the bankers Monday at a bid of 100.539.

JERSEY CITY, April 7 -- Figures released today by the Hudson County Board of Taxation showed increases in the tax rates of eight municipalities and reductions in those of four others, including a $2.01 drop in Jersey City.
It is now possible to sit comfortably on glass, in the form of a new upholstery filling made of Fiberglas utilized in some furniture available at Bloomingdale's.

MUNICH, April 7 (AP) -- The president of the German National Olympic Committee said today he would urge the streamlining of the Olympic program through elimination of minor events and the limitation of athletes.

A recommendation that a new department of civil service be established by the city with a single full-time personnel administrator was made to Mayor Impellitteri yesterday by the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey.

PARIS, April 7 -- The French franc observed its 150th birthday as the national currency today. Only the newspaper Figaro took public note of the occasion and then only to show how the franc was not what it used to be.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 7 -- On the basis of a report by an investigating committee that millions throughout the world were living in conditions of servitude more oppressive than that of chattel slaves, Britain launched today a vigorous attempt in the Social Committee of the United Nations Economic and Social Council to correct such abuses.

Curiosity about a caption in a recent issue of our Magazine has brought home to old hands who had followed show business through the fifty years since Times Square became the heart of it that their memories do not carry back to the nineteenth century's last decade when it wasn't yet Times Square.

During the Second World War the United States Government blocked some $134 millions in gold, securities, and other assets belonging to Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania, to prevent their falling into Nazi or enemy hands. After the conclusion of the peace treaties with these countries the United States Government refused to un-block these "enemy" assets.

OTTAWA, April 7 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Government will prosecute fine paper manufacturing and merchandising companies on charges of operating an illegal price-fixing combine in the $50,000,000 industry, Stuart Garson, Minister of Justice, told the House of Commons today.

Iron ore output of the M. A. Hanna Company is expected to increase about 33 per cent to 19,000,000 tons from the 14,356,740 handled in 1952 when strikes cut production, stockholders were informed at the annual meeting in Cleveland yesterday.

As prospects have increased for the resumption of full-scale armistice negotiations in Korea, the stock market has been subjected to recurrent storms of selling. The heaviest of these, to date at least, broke on Monday, when sales crossed the 3,000,000 mark for only the second time since early 1951.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Leonard W. Hall of New York will be the next chairman of the Republican National Committee.

GENEVA, April 7 -- The United States began a move here today to persuade the United Nations Commission on Human Rights to give up trying to draft a legal instrument defining social, political and economics "rights" and to work in other ways for the objectives such a covenant would seek to obtain.
LONDON, April 7 -- An indomitable breed of Briton -- the London tax driver -- is losing the battle for survival, a five-month parliamentary survey shows.
PARIS, April 7 (AP) -- Whirlaway, winner of the triple crown of American racing in 1941 and holder of the Kentucky Derby record, died yesterday at Marcel Boussac's stud farm in southern Normandy.

BUENOS AIRES, April 7 -- Widespread changes in the Argentine Government appeared to be shaping up today as the President's Economic Advisory Committee emerged from several days of study of the cost of living with a report that seemed unsatisfactory to labor and business alike. It suggested that prices be frozen at current levels and that wages be raised to achieve parity with the wage and price levels of a year ago.
BONN, Germany, April 7 -- The number of unemployed in West Germany declined by 417,825 in March.

Mayor Impellitteri submitted yesterday to the Board of Estimate a 1953-54 executive budget of $1,528,812,795 with the warning that it must be cut by $97,000,000 if the city continued to operate its own transit lines at a 10-cent fare instead of turning them over to Governor Dewey's "higher fare" transit authority by June 15.

The brokerage fee for handling the purchase or sale of a car lot (50,000 pounds) of potatoes has been increased from $15 to $18 for non-members of the New York Mercantile Exchange and from $7.50 to $9 for members, it has announced yesterday.

Certificates of merit were presented yesterday to the Guaranty Club, an employes' group of the Guaranty Trust Company, and to the New York office of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company in recognition of their support of the American Red Cross blood program. John S. Sinclair, chairman of the New York Chapter of the Red Cross, made the presentations.
Los Angeles County, Calif., borrowed $30,000,000 in the public market yesterday on tax-exempt-interest serial bonds to finance flood control improvements at an interest cost of about 2.725 per cent.
Sagittarius, Eric Guerin and the weather provided the highlights of yesterday's race program at Jamaica.

MIAMI, April 7 (UP) -- Pat Stewart of Rollins College rallied from a 4-1 deficit in the third set to oust third-seeded Mrs. Laura Lou Kunnen today, 6--4, 3--6, 8--6, and enter the quarter-finals of the Miami invitation tennis tournament.

Macy's San Francisco, a division of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., will construct a $6,000,000 department store in the new Bay-Fair Shopping Center, about fifteen miles from San Francisco in the East Bay area.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 7 (UP) -- An Ohio State University physics professor announced he never had been a Communist today shortly after the university's president recommended that he be dismissed for refusing to make such a statement before a House of Representatives committee.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- President Eisenhower said today that even should United States peace hopes for Korea be realized, American and other Allied troops would have to remain "in that region for quite a while."

SAN FRANCISCO, April 7 -Hugh Brys0n, president of the National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards, unaffiliated, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on a charge that he falsely stated in a Taft-Hartley law affidavit that he was not a Communist.

BOSTON, April 7 (AP) -- An officer of the National Citizens Committee for Educational Television said today twelve applications had been granted to date and eight Federal Communications Commission of the 242 channels reserved for educational purposes.

Three more city teachers who refused to answer questions about alleged Communist party membership will be suspended from their posts when the schools re-open Monday, it was announced yesterday by Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools.

MOSCOW, April 7 (AP) -- The United States newspaper and radio editors who have just ended a week's visit here have told Premier Georgi M. Malenkov they hope "many more American journalists will be permitted to visit your country and see what it is like."
Active cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday 10 points higher to 1 point lower than on Monday.

Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., in a proxy statement mailed to its stockholders yesterday, estimated that under present tax laws it would have net assets of $61,391,612 if shareholders approve the proposed sale of the company's physical assets to the Kaiser estimate makes no provision for retirement of the company's 100,545 shares of preferred stock and possible contingencies.

LONDON, April 7 -- "From cocoon to coronation" is the name given to a small but fascinating exhibition that opened this morning at the tea room center in Regent Street. It told the story of the development of raw silk in all its stages from the silkworm egg to the finished hank of raw silk.

GENEVA, April 7 -- European countries must adopt a "dynamic forest policy" if Europe is not to suffer from a prolonged timber crisis within the next ten years, the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations reported in a long study of European timber resources released here today.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Charles W. Crawford, Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, issued a statement today calling attention to yesterday's Supreme Court decision making final the ban on chemical bread softeners manufactured by the Atlas Powder Company and the Glyco Products Company.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., April 7 -- Dr. Courtney Craig Smith, 36 years old, American secretary of the Rhodes Scholarship, was elected president of Swarthmore College at a special meeting of the board of managers today.

The Mayor's Committee on Management Survey tackles the question of personnel management on a broad front in the chapter of its final report made public today. The size of the problem is manifest: of all people gainfully employed in New York one in sixteen works for the city government.

HONG KONG, April 7 -- The Chinese Communist party has embarked on a nation-wide movement to purge its ranks of "undesirable elements" and by more stringent restrictions make it less easy for people to join the party, according to press reports from the mainland.

President Eisenhower has made two happy choices in nominating Assistant Secretaries of the Army. To these posts he has named James P. Mitchell, New York department store executive, and John Slezak, president of an Illinois brass works.

I wish to call your attention to two factual errors in Herbert L. Matthews' second article on Haiti, published in THE TIMES of March 21. He claims that only the rank and file of occupation marines in Haiti, "not the officers," had attitudes of white supremacy. His assumption, it seems, is that upper-class white Americans (who might have furnished most of the officers) were less prejudiced than their lower-class brothers.

The Minneapolis Lakers defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 90 -- 75, in the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night and took a 2 -- 1 lead in the play-off series for the championship of the National Basketball Association.

Play in the nineteenth and final round of the international chess masters tournament, which was concluded last night at Mar Del Plata in Argentina, determined the award of the third and fourth prizes. Third prize went to Julio Bolbochan of Argentina and fourth to Dr. Petar Trifunovic of Yugoslavia, according to a report from Buenos Aires.

Headlight glare is one of the most dangerous and baffling problems in night driving, Leslie H. Middleton, vice president and director of engineering of the AutoLite Company, said yesterday. Top-flight automotive engineers are continually experimenting to subdue headlight dazzle, he said but no remedy has been found.

PARIS, April 7 -- French officials, who fully expected that Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, would be received in Washington as cordially as the French ministers were, are worried in this connection mainly about two things -- what Dr. Adenauer may propose regarding the Saar and what the Kremlin in its new mood may propose regarding Germany as a whole.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- In Washington there's a sign of spring even more certain than the celebrated cherry blossoms. That's the sound from Capitol Hill of this nation's legislators talking about daylight saving time.

Universal Pictures Company, Inc., and subsidiaries increased consolidated world gross sales to $15,526,975 in the thirteen weeks to last Jan. 31 from the $13,426,766 volume for the corresponding period of the previous year, a company report disclosed yesterday.

Pitfalls in advertising that must be avoided if more retail buyers are to be changed from prospects to customers are tricky headlines, involved figures of speech, illustrations that have nothing to do with the manufacturer's products or objectives -- and downright cuteness.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Charles W. Crawford, Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, issued a statement today calling attention to yesterday's Supreme Court decision making final the ban on chemical bread softeners manufactured by the Atlas Powder Company and the Glyco Products Company.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., April 7 -- Dr. Courtney Craig Smith, 36 years old, American secretary of the Rhodes Scholarship, was elected president of Swarthmore College at a special meeting of the board of managers today.

ALBANY, April 7 -- A bill to remove any criminal stigma for violators of New York's highway use tax was approved today by Governor Dewey. The measure provides that truckers who fail to file returns or who operate vehicles loaded beyond their stated weight will not be guilty of a crime.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Peter Campbell Brown, a former special assistant to the Federal Attorney General, has submitted to President Eisenhower his resignation as chairman of the Subversive Activities Control Board.

The management of Hiram Walker-Gooderham xrrorts, Ltd., likes the old adage "hoernker, stick to your last." Howard R. Walton, president, told the New York Society of Security Analysts i yesterday that while the company i has explored other lines, with partitular attention to opportunities that might exist in chemical fields, it ha not yet found opportunities equal to those in the beverage dis, tilling industry,

MILWAUKEE, April 7 (AP) -- The city that beer made famous will open the taps to the limit tomorrow to welcome its big league baseball team. A rousing reception will hail the arrival on a mid- morning train of Manager Charley Grimm and his Milwaukee Braves.

The five-story building with forty-five apartments at 1081 Anderson Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Geisinger Rau, operators, to Charles Dammann through Snyder Co., brokers. It is assessed at $118,000.

The major league baseball season will be discussed in a special program entitled "Play Ball" over the N. B. C. television network on Sunday afternoon from 3:30 to 4 o'clock. Participants will be Tommy Henrich, formerly with the New York Yankees, and Jimmy Cannon, sports columnist for The New York Post Films made at various training camps also will be shown.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The chairman of the House of Representatives Labor Committee, Representative Samuel K. McConnell Jr., Republican of Pennsylvania, indicated today the major provisions he favored for a new labor relations law.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of West Germany, assured the United States today that his Government was anxious to be a strong and loyal partner in the free world alliance against Soviet aggression.

Drastic changes made in the teaching methods of the New York City school system go beyond the three R's. The "unit method," or project approach, is used extensively. For a period ranging from three to six weeks the pupils build the heart of their classroom program around a specific project.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- President Eisenhower formally asked Congress today for a one-year extension of the present Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act, which expires June 12, as "an interim measure."

Despite a record budget of $1,528,812,795 submitted yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri, sixty of the city's 113 agencies will operate with less money in the fiscal year beginning July 1 than in the current year ending June 30.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 7 -- The International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, in biennial convention today, gave notice of an intention to seek "a shorter work day with increased daily pay" as it asserted in a resolution that employers felt that "with a Republican Administration they are in the driver's seat."

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Defense Department is ready to produce information that Gen. James A. Van Fleet reported in June, 1951, that an advance by his Eighth Army in Korea would cost "unacceptable" casualties.
The following are textual excerpts from, and digests of Mayor Impellitteri's message to the Board of Estimate and the City Council in submitting the executive budget for the fiscal year 1953-54:

The four-story building containing apartments and business space at 874 Lexington Avenue, between Sixty-fifth and Sixty-sixth Streets, has been resold after a brief ownership by David S. Meister to an investing client of Norman Elson, attorney, for cash over a first mortgage of $42,500 in a deal negotiated by Joseph A. Polsky, broker.

LOS ANGELES, April 7 -- A former State Department consular secretary and cultural attache declined to tell a subcommittee of the House of Representatives Committee on Un-American Activities today whether he had untruthfully disavowed past Communist party affiliation in a departmental job application.

The nation's scheduled domestic air carriers had the lowest accident rate last year in the history of commercial aviation. Non-scheduled lines also reduced their accident rate in 1952, while the record of international air transports fell below that of other years and personal flying accidents showed slight improvement.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Eisenhower Administration ran today into skeptical Republican questioning in its campaign for quick Senate approval of additions to the North Atlantic Treaty that military and diplomatic officials had termed urgently needed.

James A. Roe and Frank Kenna, Democratic and Republican leaders of Queens, respectively, have agreed on revision of legislative district lines in the county. Their proposals will be submitted jointly to the Republican-dominated Legislature at Albany and the Democratic-dominated City Council at City Hall.

LONDON, April 8 -- By a bit of private enterprise a bourgeois British Boy Scout earned two shillings and six pence (thirty- five cents) today from the Soviet Embassy which has lately become real "matey," as the British say.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 8 -- With filming operations at a standstill and apparently destined to remain in a dormant state for an extended period, Warner Brothers has asked its executive staff members to take salary reductions said to range up to 50 per cent.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The State Department said tonight that George F. Kennan, former Ambassador to the Soviet Union, would retire from the Foreign Service "in the near future."

Military and civilian employes of the New York Port of Embarkation, First Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, contributed a total of 179 pints of blood Tuesday, the New York chapter, American Red Cross, reported yesterday.

In a light market that some observers thought might have been dominated by chart-readers, stocks yesterday advanced steadily on a broad front, only to lose some of their gains in the final hour of trading. Motors, tires and some of the oils were notably strong.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended April 1:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 8 -- I. V. Chechyotkin of the Soviet delegation told the Committee on Nongovernmental Organizations of the United Nations Economic and Social Council today that there were no concentration camps nor forced labor camps in the Soviet Union.
DETROIT, April 8 (AP) -- The number of auto plant workers who have received notice of a 1-cent-an-hour cost-of-living pay cut passed the 600,000 mark today.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz said yesterday that men willing to pick up the challenge of the International Longshoremen's Association and make a major issue of waterfront clean-up were needed as Mayoralty candidates next November.

The successful designer of tomorrow will be in "constant contact with the client," Adam Gimbel, president of Saks Fifth Avenue, declared yesterday at a luncheon-meeting at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel. The luncheon was given for Jean Luce, French designer of china and ceramics.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee reached final agreement today on terms of a new defense production bill that honored the Eisenhower Administration's request for a straight five-month extension of rent controls to Sept. 30.

The Department of Defense has not authorized and will not authorize any official Armed Forces Day publication for which advertising is solicited. This is the word received by the National Better Business Bureau, Inc., from the department. Armed Forces Day will be celebrated this year on May 16.

Those who have ears to the ground in Wall Street are predicting that the special committee of the New York Stock Exchange that has been investigating commission rates for the last ten months will approach the policy meeting of the Exchange governors today with a proposal for an overall increase of 12 per cent.

Customs activities in the Port of New York, already hampered by a shortage of personnel, will be curtailed further if the Treasury Department's proposed cut of $1,500,000 below the $42,000,000 earmarked for Customs in the budget estimate by former President Harry S. Truman is carried out.

The free nations must maintain a disciplined effort toward increasing collective economic and military strength as the only basis on which they can hope to reach a satisfactory settlement of world problems. Sir Roger Makins, Ambassador from Britain, warned yesterday.

Inspection of the twenty-nine tenements in the Harlem block selected last month for an experiment in rehabilitation through strict enforcement of tenement laws has yielded a total of 1,108 violations, the Department of Housing and Building disclosed yesterday.
This country's business structure should look ahead to peace in Korea as a helpful rather than a depressing factor, Walter Williams, Under Secretary of Commerce, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Citing the Panmunjom armistice negotiations as an example, Frank C. Nash, Assistant Secretary of Defense, testified today a requirement that Congress approve all executive agreements "just wouldn't work."

Johann Strauss' music for "Die Fledermaus" is indestructible. It has supported a thin plot for decades, and it has been the justification for version after version of the operetta. It made the difference at the City Center last night when the opera company there took its turn at giving it a production.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 8 -- The United States dollar took a heavy fall today and was quoted at the close of dealings this afternoon at 45 cruzeiros 50 centavos selling rate and 44 cru zeiros 50 centavos buying rate.

CHICAGO, April 8 -- Synthesis of a substance present in normal blood that may provide vital clues to the understanding of the mechanism underlying the major form of heart disease, and to its possible prevention and alleviation, was announced here today at the annual meeting of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology.

Sets literally falling apart, obsolete plumbing and a creaking stage elevator too narrow for a fat basso were offered by the Metropolitan Opera yesterday as evidence that its current $1,500,000 fund drive, if successful, would cover only the bare necessities of running the company.

TRENTON, April 8 -- Nelson F. Stamler took the stand again today at a public hearing of the joint legislative committee investigating his ouster by Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons and for five hours sought to prove that State Republican Chairman John J. Dickerson was implicated in Bergen County corruption.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 8 (AP) -- The Shah's Court Minister challenged today the accuracy of Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's version of events leading to the current conflict between the Premier and the monarch.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (UP) -- United States battle casualties in Korea increased by 1,039 last week as a result of fighting for "Bunker Hill" and "Old Baldy," the Defense Department reported today.
CAIRO, April 8 -- The Soviet Union was reported today to have informed Egypt that the latter's participation in a Western-oriented Middle Eastern defense pact would be viewed unfavorably by Moscow.
Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, announced yesterday that he would not run for Mayor of New York or for any other elective office.

The 1,075-acre Hicks Beach property on Reynolds Channel in Lawrence, L. I., was sold at auction yesterday for $210,000. Philip Godfrey, president of the Harding-Marathon Corporation of Plandome, was the successful bidder.

Governor Dewey Called on the people of New York State yesterday to observe World Jewish Child's Day on Sunday in tribute to the work of major Jewish women's organizations in the rehabilitation and resettlement of refugee children in Israel.

In your editorial of March 30 "Tensions in the Far East" your statement that Burma's "abrupt decision to terminate all United States assistance" is to a large extent due to the fact that they are "irritated at the United States because of continued American support for the Chinese Nationalists on Formosa" is not quite correct.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 8 -- Dag Hammarskjoeld, new United Nations Secretary General, left for New York today aboard a Scandinavian Arlines plane. The airliner is due at Idlewild Airport, New York, at 10:35 o'clock tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Donald S. Tydings, whose stormy career as a field official of the Internal Revenue Bureau was the subject of a recent Congressional investigation, has been discharged from his $8,500 post.

One of the highweights took the biggest share of the $22,600 purse and the other one, bet into favoritism, finished sixth in the running of the six-furlong Experimental Free Handicap for 3-year-olds at the Jamaica track yesterday.
Following is the text of Governor Dewey's radio and television address last night over WCBS-TV on the city's financial situation:

LOS ANGELES, April 8 -- Violent argument between Representative Donald L. Jackson and a witness marked the final session today of a House of Representatives' Un-American Activities Committee inquiry into Communist infiltration in Hollywood and other fields.

This is an officially proclaimed national holiday in the Philippines, Bataan Day, commemorating the heroic defense of Bataan by Americans and Filipinos. Though it recalls the tragedy of the surrender it was, and is, designed primarily to emphasize that Filipinos and Americans fought and died together in the same good cause in mutual trust and esteem.

BONN, Germany, April 8 -- In the opinion of Western diplomats and German politicians, any Soviet proposal on reunification of Germany would have to include solid concessions and iron clad guarantees to win popular support in West Germany.

With the exception of high-octane aviation gasoline, for which new facilities are under construction or planned, stocks of principal petroleum products are somewhat above normal levels, the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) has advised its 269,474 shareholders in its annual report. The report was issued for publication today.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges were generally higher yesterday in quiet trading. Sugar showed moderate activity. Wool, soybean and cottonseed oils, sugar, cocoa, hides and zinc increased. Coffee, lead and tin were lower and potatoes and rubber ended mixed.
Dean Lawrence H. Chamberlain announced yesterday the appointments of three prominent alumni to the Columbia College Council, which advises the college on development programs.

TOKYO, Thursday, April 9 -- The Communist liaison delegation at Panmunjom promised today to return 100 United Nations prisoners daily in an agreement for repatriation of the sick and wounded captives of the Korean war.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined 629,000 barrels last week, according to the weekly report of the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 162,249,000 barrels, compared with 162,878,000 a week earlier and 158,431,000 a year ago.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 8 -- Fifty-two United Nations delegates voted today to set up an impartial inquiry into Communist charges that the United States had used germ weapons in the Korean war. However, because of Soviet refusal to cooperate, the investigation probably never will be carried out.
International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and its subsidiaries had consolidated net income of $22,147,753 or $3.09 a share last year, the largest in the concern's history.

Trotting races at two metropolitan area tracks will be televised over WOR-TV each Wednesday evening from 9:30 to 10:55 throughout the spring and summer, beginning next week with the opening of Yonkers Raceway. Clem McCarthy will call the races.

The new tone of Soviet diplomacy, as distinct from its immediate aims or ultimate objectives, is illustrated again by the latest performance of Mr. Vishinsky in the United Nations debate on disarmament. Heretofore Mr. Vishinsky has distinguished himself as the most violent and vituperative Soviet spokesman against the West.

FRANKFURT, Germany, April 8 (Reuters) -- Roy M. Cohn, a touring investigator for the United States Senate Permanent Investigating subcommittee, fired a new charge of Communist tendencies today against Theodore Kaghan, a New Yorker who is acting deputy chief of the United States High Commissioner's Public Affairs Office.
Fabric combinations and color blends were stressed in Bonwit Teller's collection of spring and summer shoes shown yesterday at a luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
TORONTO, April 8 (Canadian Press) -- The major Canadian rubber companies today pleaded guilty to a charge of operating a combine in restraint of trade and fixing prices of goods they sold.

Although we have in some respects become a mentally sick society, in the opinion of Dr. Robert G. Foster, director of the marriage counseling service and training program of the Menninger Foundation, Topeka, Kan., the blame should not fall on the family for this or other failures.

KAPENGURIA, Kenya, April 8 -- Jomo (Burning Spear) Kenyatta, Moscow-educated tribal leader, was found guilty today of organizing the dreaded Mau Mau secret society, which aims to throw the white man out of Kenya.

Helicopter mail service twice nightly between La Guardia Airport and towns and cities in Westchester and Connecticut began at 4:25 A. M. yesterday when a rotary-winged aircraft went aloft with a 700-pound mail cargo.

ALBANY, April 8 -- Governor Dewey signed two bills today making an additional $1,700,000 in emergency state aid for education available to school districts that are financially hard-pressed because of recent extraordinary increases in population.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Dave Gallardo, a 3-to-1 under-dog, tonight scored a ten-round unanimous decision over Percy Bassett, the interim featherweight champion. The title was not at stake. Gallardo weighed 129 1/4 pounds, Bassett 129 1/2.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 8 -- The Soviet Union declared today that it was making a major attempt to break the long stalemate on disarmament, but the majority of the United Nations reacted -- in speeches and in voting -- with polite but plain skepticism.

NEWARK, April 8 -- The Federal Government today, in an indictment naming ten longshoremen, checkers and timekeepers who worked at the Claremont Terminal in Jersey City, unfolded details of an alleged payroll-padding conspiracy that added an estimated $15,000 to the costs of Army and Air Force shipments abroad during a few months in 1951.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., April 8 -- Sale of the historic Van Cortlandt Manor House and surrounding acreage on the Albany Post Road, at the mouth of the Croton River here, to the head of a food concern was announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Senator James E. Murray, Democrat of Montana, told the Senate today that President Eisenhower had been a "victim of his political friends" when he had promised to support state ownership of offshore submerged oil lands.

A major revision in automobile insurance rates for private passenger cars, reducing the cost to adults who do a limited amount of pleasure driving and to parents with young "part-time" drivers in the family, has been adopted by leading insurance companies.
Behind the tight pitching of right-hander Don Metz, Navy scored its fourth straight baseball victory of the season today, defeating Columbia, 5--3, in an Eastern Intercollgiate League contest

Last summer's fifty-four-day steel strike cost the Government five and one-half times as much in lost tax revenue as it cost the steel-makers in lost profits, according to an industry analysis made by The Iron Age.
LONDON, April 8 -- A squad of seventeen boxers from New York triumphed over London rivals, 9 -- 8, in a boys tournament at Empress Hall tonight to take the Duke of Edinburgh Trophy.

A syndicate of investors represented by Samuel Sussman, attorney, has purchased the twelve-story apartment house for 107 families at 140 East Twenty-eighth Street from the 140 East Twenty-eighth Street Corporation, which is controlled by Bing Bing, Inc.

The reputed successor to James J. Moran as "guiding genius" of the $500,000-a-year fuel oil shakedown racket in the Fire Department personally accepted a week's "payoff," Assistant District Attorney Alfred J. Scotti charged yesterday in his opening statement at the perjury trial of John E. Gleason Jr.

The Board of Examiners' experimental personality test for teachers, which was given recently to 1,600 job-seekers, came under heavy fire yesterday from George Timone, senior Manhattan member of the Board of Education.

District Judge Harold R. Medina indicated yesterday that the Government's move in calling Harold L. Stuart, president of Halsey, Stuart Co., as a witness last year in the investment banking anti-trust trial had backfired and that the financier's testimony "broke the case for the Government."

Bernard M. Baruch, who sponsored the Soviet-vetoed American plan for United Nations operation of the world's major atomic plants to insure their use for peaceful purposes only, said yesterday that private development of atomic power here would be safe -- and would strengthen the nation.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8 -- President Eisenhower will have a white-painted brick cottage for his use when he comes to Augusta next fall for a golfing vacation.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 8 -- As a result of "unfair" methods used by Congressional committees investigating education in this country, academic freedom is endangered and the morale of the teaching profession has been weakened, Roman Catholic educators declared here today.
