TOKYO, Thursday, April 9 -- United States Marines before dawn today threw back a sharp Chinese Communist attack on Outpost Carson, near "Bunker Hill" on the western front, one of the three advance positions where bitter fighting occurred a fortnight ago.

All Americans can well rejoice over the decision of the President and the Secretary of State that the United States Government "does not look upon a treaty as the means which we would now select as the proper and most effective way to spread throughout the world the goals of human liberty to which this nation has been dedicated since its inception" and, therefore, will not sign the U. N. Covenant on Human Rights.

General Tire and Rubber Company may dispose of the 249,000 shares it holds in the Mansfield Tire and Rubber Company, M. Gerald O'Neill, executive assistant to the president, said yesterday. He declared that the company had been contemplating selling but said it has taken no steps yet to do so.

ROCKY MARCIANO and Jersey Joe Walcott will fight for the heavyweight championship tomorrow in -- what's that? Zounds and gadzooks but you're absolutely right. The match has been postponed for another five weeks, a delay that means Jersey Joe will be another five weeks older. The Old Gentleman can't stand too many delays because even he can't continue to sidestep his advancing years much longer.

The tone of President Eisenhower's message asking for a one-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act indicates a clear understanding of the critical nature of the problem in foreign economic policy that now faces Congress.
The full board of directors of the American-Korean Foundation held its first meeting yesterday and voted to raise $5,000,000 for its immediate program of assisting and rehabilitating Koreans.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee called today for the lists of all officers and faculty members of the Jefferson School of Social Science in New York City, from the time of its first semester in 1944 to the present.
CHICAGO, April 8 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The city's highest police officials joined with the ranks and throngs of civilians yesterday to pay respects, at separate funeral services, to the memory of two police heroes slain in the same Harlem precinct last week.

GENEVA, April 8 -- President Eisenhower's decision to postpone for at least one year any significant revision of the tariff laws inherited from his Democratic predecessors dashes many European hopes for new leadership from the United States in these matters. But its most serious effects will be felt by Japan.

It is just a year today since Victor Paz Estenssoro and his followers in the National Revolutionary Movement (M. N. R.) seized power in Bolivia. An anniversary is always a good time to take stock. The Bolivian coup aroused intense interest throughout Latin America because Bolivia is synonymous with tin and because the M. N. R. was supposed to be revolutionary in the true sense of the word.

IS J. D. Salinger bucking to be a prose Chas Addams? His second book, "Nine Stories,"* is rich -- over-rich, I think -- in small monsters and large shadows of the macabre and the malign. It fits right into the current revival of supernatural literature. But it is somehow disappointing, coming from the man who wrote the outstanding first novel of 1951, "The Catcher in the Rye."

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, April 8 -- The seventh annual conference of the International Association of University Professors and Lecturers met here today to discuss a common international stand on academic freedom.

New issues of corporate securities aggregating more than $36,000,000 will be offered to investors today. The flotations include public offerings of $29,100,000 of public utility company first mortgage bonds and more than $7,000,000 of common stock of industrial enterprises, shares offered preferentially to holders of outstanding stock. The offerings are as follows:

BURLINGTON, Vt., April 8 -- A vanguard of a dozen Iroquois Indians representing six nations of their tribe stopped off here today to break bread with representatives of the white men -- the Burlington Chamber of Commerce -- who occupy what once was the Indian's hunting grounds.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 8 -- A charge from the floor that Harry Bridges, president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, and a majority of the executive board had "consistently followed every twist and turn of the "Communist party line" set off hours of rebuttal speeches today at the union's biennial convention.

Governor Dewey recommended last night the adoption of a city manager form of government for New York as the best means of escape from the financial morass into which it has been plunged by a city administration unable to develop a sound long-range program.

" His mother is an old Danish oak tree and I am his father," Kay Bojesen said yesterday in attempting to balance his newest toy -- a young elephant -- on two hind feet. Mr. Bojesen, a designer who is here on a short visit from Copenhagen, had come upon the animal while helping unpack the toys and tableware included in an exhibition of his work now on view at Georg Jensen, 667 Fifth Avenue.

A last-ditch rally by the New York Knickerbockers fell short by two points last night, and the Minneapolis Lakers won, 71 -- 69, to take a 3-1 lead in the four-out-of-seven National Basketball Association championship play-offs at the Sixty-Ninth Regiment Armory.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 8 -- General Assembly delegates expressed intense interest tonight in the news from Washington that, once an armistice had been concluded in Korea, the Eisenhower Administration might favor radical changes in United States and United Nations policy toward Korea and Formosa.

LONDON, Thursday, April 9 -- Two subway trains jammed with 1,200 homeward-bound commuters smashed into tangled wreckage in an East London underground tunnel during the rush hour last night and seven persons were known dead.

DENVER, Colo., April 8 -- Delegates to the study conference of the Association for Childhood Education International were told here tonight, "no challenge in education today has greater vitality than education for democratic relationships."

The State of New Jersey borrowed $25,000,000 yesterday on serial bonds maturing over fifteen years to finance the construction of state institutions. The bonds were sold at competitive bidding to a banking syndicate headed by J. F. Morgan Co., Inc., Drexel Co. and Shields Co. at an interest cost of 1.869 per cent. A syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Lehman Brothers bid a cost of 1.876 per cent.
CINCINNATI, April 8 (AP) -- The National League today completed the job of revising its 1953 schedule -- a job made necessary by the moving of the Boston franchise to Milwaukee.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, April 9 (AP) -- Capt. Harold E. Fischer Jr., double jet ace of the Korean war, failed to return from a flight into North Korea Tuesday after his Sabre jet became separated from other planes of his flight.

MIAMI, April 8 (UP) -- Harry Faccini, seventh-seeded player from Bogota, Colombia, was three points away from being upset today in the third round of the Miami invitation tennis championships when rain halted his match with Orlando Garido, but other favorites advanced to the quarter-finals.
From his garden on a Flushing hilltop in Queens, Fred Ferraro now is bringing the first fresh herbs of spring to his market at 1312 Avenue of the Americas, near Fifty-third Street.

HACKENSACK, N. J., April 8 -- John J. Dickerson, Republican State Committee chairman, and Walter G. Winne, superseded prosecutor of Bergen County, denied allegations made in Trenton today by Nelson F. Stamler, ousted Bergen County investigator.

Elinore Sharp, a young violinist from Portland, Ore., gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. Her program was half classical and half contemporary, and it was in the latter half that she did much the best playing.

BUENOS AIRES, April 8 -- President Juan D. Peron indicated today in a bitter forty-eight-minute nationwide broadcast that Argentina's cost-of-living problems were the direct result of machinations by his domestic and foreign political enemies.

The Theatre Guild, which was founded in the spring of 1919, will celebrate thirty-five seasons of operation with a stage exhibition to which the public will be admitted without charge. Under the auspices of Lawrence Langner, Theresa Helburn and Armina Marshall, the exhibition will be held at the organization's headquarters, 23 West Fifty-third Street, for three weeks starting April 21.

Dominick R. Peluso was sworn in as a member of the New York State bar yesterday and United States Attorney J. Edward Lumbard has announced that he will appoint the 27-year-old former newspaper man as an assistant next week. In addition to prosecuting Government cases, Mr. Peluso also will handle publicity for Mr. Lumbard and his staff.

Fears over the present level of consumer credit are unjustified and such credit could safely expand by 75 per cent, Arno H. Johnson, vice president and director of research of the J. Walter Thompson Company, said yesterday.
TOKYO, Thursday, April 9 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,579, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Thursday, Korean Time:

Earnings of the Western Union Telegraph Company thus far are running about 75 per cent ahead of a year ago, Walter P. Marshall, president, told stockholders yesterday. Speaking at the annual meeting, he said that net income for first quarter of this year will approximate $1,850,000, compared with $1,060,445 in the similar quarter of 1952.

Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, the new American Ambassador to Italy, declared last night that the current policies of the Soviet Union amounted to a "peace defensive" forced on the Kremlin by the firm foreign policy of the Eisenhower Administration.

Your paper has reported the loss of one of the stanch defenders of this country. A few observations seem timely and pertinent. Clinton Havill was a simple man. Even the funeral services held for him were very simple. He would have wished it that way. He wanted nothing for himself -- neither fame, riches, power nor glory.

The Red Cross announced recently that less than 70 per cent of its $93,000,000 goal had been reached by April 1, and its drive, scheduled to end on that date, has been extended indefinitely. The Red Cross did not announce, and did not have to announce, that if the goal is not met the lack of funds may be paid for by human lives.
WIVELISCOMBE, England, April 8 (AP) -- This Somerset marketing town of 1,255 has sent a letter to the United Nations insisting that it exists.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 8 -- A business organization must be built around systems, procedures and controls and not around people. Such was the conclusion arrived at by the Young Presidents Organization today during its third annual meeting in the Arizona Biltmore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- As Republican leaders assembled here to pick a new chairman of the National Committee Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, the runner-up for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1940, 1948, and 1952, predicted today that President Eisenhower would be a successful candidate for re-election in 1956.

Many years ago the city felt it had the right to levy a 1 per cent tax on sales, this tax being only a temporary levy. Today our city has found it necessary to raise this "temporary" tax to 3 per cent, increase the transit fare and real-estate tax, and inaugurate a car-use tax.

GENEVA, April 8 -- The United States presented to the United Nations Human Rights Commission today, in outline form, its new theory of how the United Nations could best promote respect for human rights. The proposals did not get a very warm reception.

MEXICO CITY, April 8 -- A group of Mexico's political generals have launched a demand for confiscation of immense illicit gains made by officials during the last administration headed by President Miguel Aleman.

KEHL, Germany, April 8 (AP) -- This Rhine River city of 12,000 was handed back to the Germans by the French today, thus completing a step-by-step return agreed on by France, the United States and Britain in Washington on April 8, 1949.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 8 -- Yugoslavia suddenly attacked Italy and United States-British authorities in Trieste today, bringing up old charges of the alleged mistreatment of Slovenes in Italy proper and in Zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste.

CHICAGO, April 8 (AP) -- Ray Kilgore of San Francisco took the undisputed lead in the world three-cushion billiard tournament tonight as Kinrey Matsuyama of Tokyo upset 24-year-old Harold Worst, Grand Rapids, Mich.

In St. Clare's Hospital, in Fifty-first Street between Ninth and tenth Avenues, there are tastefully decorated rooms with colonial mahogany chests of drawers, poster beds, colorful draperies and pastel-tiled bathrooms. Patients can almost forget they are in a hospital.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- War is inevitable if the United Nations is permitted to fail, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, director of the Department of Trusteeship of the United Nations, warned today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 8 -- Stockholders of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad at a meeting here today elected the management's slate of directors without a dissenting vote. This virtually assures the re-election of Frederic C. Dumaine Jr. as president at the organization meeting of directors scheduled to be held on April 30.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Bob Waldele, 6-foot 2-inch right hander from Maplewood, N. J., pitched the Georgetown Hoyas to a 4 to 3 victory over Fordham at the winner's field today.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 8 (UP) -- Members of the International Typographical Union, A. F. L., have adopted a California local's proposal to limit borrowing from other funds for a "defense program." A canvassing board counted 34.840 vote for the proposal and 33,118 against.
BERLIN, April 8 -- The air safety proposals presented by the Soviet delegation at last night's opening meeting of the Big Four conference were "not particularly new," according to Allied sources.

It is good news that the resources of the Community Trust, 250 Park Avenue, New York 17, rose in 1952 to a record total of $21,055,904. Additions of $1,330,042 made to the philanthropic trust during last year more than doubled the 1951 figure of $589,539. Last year was the first since the Trust's operations began in 1924 that grants and receipts each exceeded $1,000,000.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Robert A. Lovett, former Secretary of Defense, blamed the Department of the Army today for ammunition shortages in Korea. He was supported in most of his views by Wilfred J. McNeil, Assistant Secretary of Defense since the unification of the armed services.

" America First: The Battle Against Intervention," by Wayne S. Cole, a faculty member of the University of Arkansas, will be published by the University of Wisconsin Press on May 1. The author treats of the America First Committee, its activities and campaigns from its inception in 1940 to its dissolution immediately after Pearl Harbor.

The views of the Mayor's Management Survey consultants on city finances, Professors Haig and Shoup of Columbia University, have been widely disseminated and discussed. But some comments made in the survey committee's final report have special pertinence at this time.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- A controversy over basic defense concepts is arising in the wake of authentic reports that Charles E. Wilson, the Secretary of Defense, is planning to modify severely if not unhinge completely the "broad mobilization base" that has been painstakingly developed for the nation's security.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The revisions in the collective security concept of the United States Government that Secretary of State Dulles is soon taking to Paris for the consideration of the North Atlantic Treaty Council do not derive in any particular from the recent series of Soviet overtures for the relief of world tensions.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The steel and coal industries asked Congress today to tighten the labor laws.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The chairman of the Senate Republican Policy Committee, Senator William F. Knowland of California, broke with some of his party colleagues today to warn against rising Congressional sentiment for heavily reduced military spending.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 8 -- The Israeli Foreign Ministry delivered today to the United States, the British and French embassies an oral demarche drawing attention to the renewed wave of "murderous" Jordanian infiltration and asserting that "something must be done to impress upon the Jordanians the necessity of keeping the peace along the border."
NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 8 -- The Giants outscrambled the Indians today, 11 to 10, but the triumph brought Manager Leo Durocher small measure of comfort.

Your dispatch of April 5 announced that United Airlines is currently flying "paper jet" airliners between New York and San Francisco. Although these flights are for the purpose of studying weather, the very fact that such research is in progress indicates that domestic jet air transport is not too far in the future for immediate consideration.

A disposition on the part of traders to believe that there will be no international peace even if the Korean war is ended, led to covering in the cotton futures market yesterday and closing prices were barely steady, 4 points lower to 4 points higher than on Tuesday.

Spotty, a waterfront roamer of pure alley cat ancestry, returned to New York yesterday after seventeen days of hobnobbing with a dozen blue-blood dogs and a Persian cat aboard the United States liner America.

The decision by the New York District Council of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., to abide by an American Federation of Labor directive to divest itself of the shape-up system of hiring failed to evoke any enthusiasm yesterday among local stevedoring employers.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Two days of rest didn't do the Dodgers any good. While 23,265 Washington fans cheered the Brooks' misfortunes lustily, they were shut out by the Senators tonight, 7 -- 0, with Dick Porterfield hurling a four-hitter.
CHICAGO, April 8 -- Prices for grain futures receded sharply from early high spots, but on the setbacks there was a broader demand from commission houses.

TRENTON, April 8 -- This is the story of a woman driver. But don't snicker, foolish male. If you're smart, you'll forget those trite jokes and cease ridiculing mother and daughter for their handling of the family car. Times have changed, thanks to the gallantry of a Long Island man.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 8 -- An indignant protector of the stray goose that has suddenly become the center of a tug-o'-war between Canada and Connecticut served notice tonight that only those courting real trouble had better try to seize the bird.

The city's financial squeeze will continue indefinitely until something is done about it, the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey told Mayor Impellitteri yesterday in the eighth installment of its $2,196,250 report on how the city should be run.

Two Dominican political refugees have been kept surrounded in the Mexican Embassy in Ciudad Trujillo, capital of the Dominican Republic, for months, according to information that reached New York yesterday. Jose Tomas Reyes fled to the Embassy more than six months ago and the other refugee, Rafael Mieses Peguero, entered the building five months ago.

A news story the other day furnished a little further proof that the United Nations is just a family household on a somewhat larger scale. The wranglings constitute, of course, an average dinner table conversation, and now it develops that the house itself leaks.
Summer fashions designed by Alan Phillips for Lentz Diminutives were presented by De Pinna at the Pierre Hotel yesterday. In silk, cotton and linen were town dresses for many occasions.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (UP) -- The Department of Defense canceled today all public demonstrations of major near weapons in the interests of economy and security.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8 -- A record entry of seventy-three international experts concluded preparations today for tomorrow's start of the seventeenth Masters tournament at the Augusta National Golf Club.

LOUISVILLE, April 8 -- Talk to Manager Casey Stengel about the Yankees' pitching staff and his face lights up. Discuss the team's outfield and he beams. Conversation about the catching brings out the most complimentary adjectives in the manager's lexicon. However, all is not serene among the Yankees as they draw near to the opener at Washington next Monday.

LONDON, April 8 -- The stock markets here staged a modest rally today, except the commodity share markets. The rise was most pronounced in foreign bonds, in which interest was again directed chiefly to Chinese and Eastern European issues. There was also some buying of Japanese and German loans.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 8 -- Following is the text of the resolution on disarmament adopted this morning by the General Assembly:
Mayor Impellitteri was urged yesterday to close the Veterans' Service Center at Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street and sell the building it occupies.

The one-story taxpayer building on an irregular plot about 60 by 124 feet on the west side of South Main Street, about 150 feet south of Merrick Road, in Freeport, L. I., has been sold by Elsie W. Easterlin to Harry and Martin M. Weinstein. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Treasury took its first big step today to redeem a major Republican campaign pledge and push back the overhanging load of short-term Government debt by announcing an offering of $1,000,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent securities maturing June 15, 1983.

HANOI, Vietnam, April 8 -- Every night French and Vietnamese forces await the beginning of the Vietminh offensive. Military circles here are of the opinion the great migration of Vietminh divisions through the jungle is practically ended. Three to four divisions are concentrated around Mocchau. The French are holding a large number of troops in reserve to defend the point of the Vietminh attack.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 8 -- The United Nations' planned $250,000,000 program for Korean reconstruction will be inadequate and must be reassessed within the next few months, J. Donald Kingsley, agent general for the United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency, said today.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Attorney for Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, atomic spies awaiting execution in Sing Sing Prison, accused the Federal Government in a reply brief filed in the Supreme Court today of "deliberately evading [issue] which it cannot meet" in opposing a high court review of the Rosenbergs' conviction.

A rental agent of a building in which a 2-year-old girl died of coal gas poisoning last October was sentenced to an indeterminate term up to three years in the City Penitentiary yesterday by Special Sessions Justice Irwin D. Davidson.

Committed as it is to the encouragement of private enterprise, the Eisenhower Administration intends to ask for legislation which will permit our larger industrial organizations to make the most of atomic power. Actually the first step in this direction was taken under President Truman when the National Security Resources Board recommended a revision of the Atomic Energy Commission Act.

CHICAGO, April 8 -- Charles F. Kettering, 76-year-old inventor-scientist of the General Motors Corporation, testified today at the du Pont anti-trust trial in Federal District Court here that he never was interested in tetraethyl lead from the standpoint of manufacturing the gasoline anti-knock compound.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Eisenhower Administration is willing to accept a settlement in Korea based on a boundary at the narrow waist of the peninsula. This new line between Communist-controlled North Korea and the South Korean Republic would be approximately ninety miles north of the present battle line, which crosses the Thirty-eighth Parallel diagonally.

LONDON, Thursday, April 9 (UP) -- The second train, following close behind the first in the single-line tube, hit it with such impact that the bodies of passengers were forced through the windows and tops of the cars. A major tragedy was averted because the second train was moving slowly.

GUATEMALA, April 8 -- As a result of conversations between President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman and Thomas F. Bradshaw, president of the International Railways of Central America, the attachment of railway assets, estimated at $65,000,000, has been canceled A local court last week had ordered compulsory collection of a $3,500,000 charity tax from which the company contended it was exempt under its operating contract.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer pictured West Germany today as a reformed nation, whose Government was dedicated to freedom and democracy and whose people sought peace above all else.
MILWAUKEE, April 8 -- A crowd of 60,000 to 80,000 cheering Milwaukeeans lined Wisconsin Avenue today to give an enthusiastic welcome to their new National League baseball team, the Braves.

Ten prominent leaders in the fields of business, industry and education recalled yesterday the inauspicious experiences of their boyhood as they received Horatio Alger awards, symbolic of their contributions to the American tradition and of their advancement to positions of great responsibility.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 8 -- Massachusetts Institute of Technology released today a report showing that the institute made no recommendations as to the commercial possibility of a compound designed to rejuvenate storage batteries.

Declaring that he was "fairly certain" the committee would vote next week to keep the 1956 Olympic Games in Melbourne, Otto Mayer, chancellor of the International Olympie Committee, arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday aboard a Swiss Air Lines plane.

MOBRIDGE, S. D., April 8 (AP) -- A group of South Dakotans today lifted the bones of Sitting Bull, famed Sioux Indian medicine man, from the North Dakota burial ground in which they had been buried sixty-three years and reburied them across the state line in South Dakota near the Chief's boyhood home.
MILWAUKEE, April 8 -- A crowd of 60,000 to 80,000 cheering Milwaukeeans lined Wisconsin Avenue today to give an enthusiastic welcome to their new National League baseball team, the Braves.

Ten prominent leaders in the fields of business, industry and education recalled yesterday the inauspicious experiences of their boyhood as they received Horatio Alger awards, symbolic of their contributions to the American tradition and of their advancement to positions of great responsibility.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 8 -- Massachusetts Institute of Technology released today a report showing that the institute made no recommendations as to the commercial possibility of a compound designed to rejuvenate storage batteries.

ELIZABETH, N. J., April 8 -- Three marriages performed by a police justice here since March 19 are void because of a state law that became effective on that date, according to an opinion given today by City Attorney Louis P. Longobardi.

A RAPID run-off following the recent rains has cleared many of the popular Catskill streams, and although a few are higher than normal and slightly discolored, clear weather today and tomorrow should leave them in better than average condition for Saturday's opening.

Declaring that he was "fairly certain" the committee would vote next week to keep the 1956 Olympic Games in Melbourne, Otto Mayer, chancellor of the International Olympie Committee, arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday aboard a Swiss Air Lines plane.

MOBRIDGE, S. D., April 8 (AP) -- A group of South Dakotans today lifted the bones of Sitting Bull, famed Sioux Indian medicine man, from the North Dakota burial ground in which they had been buried sixty-three years and reburied them across the state line in South Dakota near the Chief's boyhood home.

A loaf of bread left standing for four years on a table in a hut in the Antarctic gave bakers the clue on how to eliminate loss from stale loaves returned by grocers, food authorities were told yesterday at a luncheon in the St. Regis Hotel.

The teachers' colleges of the State University of New York will have to increase their enrollments by one-half to help meet the anticipated demand for elementary school teachers upstate in the next five years, the university's board of trustees was told yesterday.

After more than a week of definite movements, the market yesterday returned to its earlier habit of starting in one direction, running out of momentum and ending with a net change in the other direction. This time the initial move was upward and the final result a net loss of 1.29 points in THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 9 -- Experiments with a tiny electrical probe, less than four one hundred thousandths of an inch in diameter, has measured for the first time the electrical charge on a living heart muscle cell, it was reported here tonight at the first scientific session of the annual meeting of the American Heart Association.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 9 -- James J. Wadsworth of the United States informed the United Nations Economic and Social Council today that for reasons of security, visas for entrance into the United States has been refused to Mrs. Margarette Luckock of Canada and Jan Dessau of France.

MOSCOW, April 9 -- Izvestia, official Government newspaper, promised its readers today that persons found guilty of falsely accusing fifteen Soviet doctors and attempting to sow seeds of racial prejudice in the Soviet Union would be justly punished.

TOKYO, Friday, April 10 -- United States Marines dug trenches anew and shored up battered bunkers atop Outpost Carson on the western Korean front today, after a bitter fight yesterday in which they threw back an attack by two Chinese Communist companies.

THE world series contestants for next October will be performing in our village this weekend. No guarantees go with that statement, of course. You even are cordially invited to do your own identifying. But here's the way they will pair off in a last exhibition flourish before the start of the season itself. The Yankees and Dodgers will meet at the Stadium today and then at Ebbets Field on Saturday and Sunday.

Food shoppers will find their best values at the vegetable markets this week-end. An early spring along the Eastern Seaboard has rushed New Jersey asparagus and spinach to market, along with cabbage from Georgia and peas from South Carolina.

Two taxpayer buildings, each containing a store and an apartment, at 172-20 and 172-22 Jamaica Avenue in Jamaica, Queens, have been sold by John A. Sarli to A. V. S., Inc. Title was insured by the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company.

AT daybreak tomorrow New York anglers will begin dunking worms, minnows, flies and assorted other lures in the 772.1 miles of state-controlled streams in pursuit of the elusive trout. No angler should suffer from the lack of opportunity.

BERLIN, April 9 -- Nine rural United States newspaper and radio executives, who suddenly found themselves a focal point of Moscow's news "soft policy" toward the United States, arrived here by train today from the Soviet capital smiling and bringing hundreds of photographs.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 9 -- The United States, in a report today to the United Nations on current press problems, assailed Soviet curbs on journalists as a chief obstacle to press liberty. The same report objected that increased radio-jamming and strictly enforced control of the press in Iron Curtain countries was depriving one-third of the world of freedom of information.

TRENTON, April 9 -- Walter E. Wolfrath realized his fondest dream yesterday -- service in the Army of the United States. But his entire hitch lasted less than four hours, and today he was in Mercer County prison, accused of impersonating a soldier.

Arthur Krock in his recent columns has on more than one occasion commented at length on the Bricker amendment to the Constitution, which would curtail the treaty-making power in such a way as to prevent treaties from having any effect on our constitutional rights or on federal or state laws.

ATLANTIC CITY, April -- The new seventy-two-piece Atlantic City Symphony Orchestra presented its premiere concert here this evening before an enthusiastic audience of 1,000 at the auditorium in the Atlantic City Senior High School.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (UP) -- The Senate Banking Committee voted today to permit rent increases of up to 8.3 per cent for about 5,600,000 families covered by Federal rent controls.

Now the Great Golden Curtains (as our ears have long since been taught to know them) close for the last time at the Metropolitan Opera this season. Immediately thereafter fifty-six solo artists, seventy-eight choristers, ninety-two members of the orchestra, the ballet, a cluster of conductors and stage managers and a technical and administrative staff depart in two special trains on the annual majestic spring tour of numerous American cities.

Three of the five supervisory employes of the Atlantic Stevedoring Company, who had received indeterminate sentences up to three years as participants in a payroll-padding scheme, had their terms cut yesterday to three months by Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz in Kings County Court.

MONTREAL, April 9 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens peppered thirty-seven shots at flu-ridden Sugar Jim Henry tonight and defeated the Boston Bruins, 4 -- 2, in the first game of the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup finals.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 9 -- Al Bryant, a senior who had never before received a starting assignment, pitched a one-hitter today as Princeton edged City College, 1 -- 0, on an unearned run at University Field. It was the Tigers' third straight shutout and stretched their string of consecutive scoreless innings by the opposition to twenty-eight.
BUENOS AIRES, April 9 (UP) -- Juan R. Duarte's letter to President Peron follows :

SAN JUAN, P. R., April 9 (UP) -- D. Malcolm Neill, director and past chairman of the Canadian Broadcasters Association, said today that 135 private broadcasters in the Dominion were seeking relief from the "competition" of the Government - owned Canadian Broadcasting Corporation.

The Moscow radio, which addresses itself on short wave to American listeners every evening, is going full blast with the current Soviet peace offensive. After an evening of hearing the Russians "report" the currently momentous international events it is hard to avoid the conclusion that the Western world had better keep its propaganda powder dry.

The "danger" of an increase in subway fare, to which William Vickrey refers in his letter published on April 8, cannot rightly be attributed, as he attempts to do, to the "maneuvering of Albany and City Hall." The simple fact is that it costs more to run the lines than the riders pay.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 9 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky took the same uncompromising line today on the repatriation of Korean prisoners of war that he had followed last fall, before the death of Stalin and the start of the widespread Soviet peace offensive.

TOKYO, April 9 -- Government and business circles here are giving close attention to the far-reaching economic and political problem that are expected to arise in Japan if a peace settlement of the Korean war is realized.
On the second day of Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh's period of amnesty for delinquent driving violators, 600 motorists appeared in court yesterday to clear up 1,491 unanswered summonses.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Mandatory controls on the imports of agricultural products in order to protect the domestic market were advocated today by Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture.

ALBANY, April 9 -- Legislation that will mean $6,400,000 more in state aid to localities for welfare and tuberculosis care was approved today by Governor Dewey. The Governor praised the new program as "a major advance in the administration of social welfare."

Today's new film is "House of Wax," Warner Brothers' first feature filmed by the Natural Vision, three-dimensional process in WarnerColor, at the Paramount. The melodrama, which requires the use of polaroid glasses by viewers, features Vincent Price, Frank Lovejoy and Phyllis Kirk.

MILWAUKEE, April 9 (AP) -- Major league baseball's return to Milwaukee after a half-century absence got a soggy reception today when a drizzling rain halted the exhibition game between the Braves and Boston Red Sox.

BUENOS AIRES, April 9 -- Juan Ramon Duarte, brother of the late Senora Eva Peron and until last Tuesday private secretary to President Juan Peron, was found dead early this morning, an apparent suicide. His body, with a bullet wound through his head, was reported discovered in his well-appointed apartment by his chauffeur.

TOKYO, Friday, April 10 -- United Nations and Communist liaison officers held their fourth meeting today at Panmunjom but failed to reach a final agreement on terms for exchange of sick and wounded prisoners of the Korean war. They scheduled a new session tomorrow at which it was hoped arrangements would be completed and the last documents signed.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The White House denied today that the Eisenhower Administration had decided to accept the permanent partition of Korea at the narrow waist of that peninsula.

In his article headed "Old Russian Debt Brought Up Again," published on the first page of the Business and Financial Section of THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 8, Paul Heffernan contrasts the Soviet repudiation of foreign money debts incurred by the Czarist and Kerensky regimes with "the scrupulousness with which the Soviet Government serviced its own external borrowing on gold bonds in the Thirties."
Valentino Marconi, pianist, a native of this city trained at the Juilliard School, made his recital debut at Town Hall last evening.
MANILA, April 9 -- Philippine veterans of World War II made a pilgrimage today to the plot on Mount Samat where 6,000 wooden crosses mark the graves of those who fell in the Battle of Bataan.

BOSTON, April 9 (AP) -- Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, said here tonight that business conditions were good and that if they should change "the new Administration would not hesitate to use strong measures."

A delicate international problem affecting the American position in Asia and in the United Nations has arisen in Burma, from whose soil some 12,000 Nationalist Chinese soldiers in loose liaison with the Government on Formosa are conducting a desultory guerrilla war against Communist China in defiance of the Burmese Government.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Representative Harold H. Velde, chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities who had been in hot water for a month for having suggested the possibility of investigation into Communist infiltration among the clergy, tried today to give such an assignment to the Senate Internal Security subcommittee. The Senate group, finding itself a victim of circumstances, rejected the tender.

The shape-up system of hiring, which has been ordered banned by the American Federation of Labor and the two governing bodies of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., received strong support yesterday from union Local 1258.

Robert Moses, who has had a large hand in remaking and beautifying this city in our time, castigated yesterday those of little faith in the city's future and assured them vehemently that "New York is not going to become a ghost town."

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 9 -- Israel's Foreign Ministry answered today complaints under which the Government of Jordan warned Jordanians Monday not to accept funds released by Israel from Arabs' blocked accounts.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 9 -- Aided by Federal grants, American colleges and universities are placing too great emphasis upon scientific research at the expense of the liberal arts and humanities, leading Roman Catholic educators declared here today.

Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, United States Ambassador to Italy, who will celebrate her fiftieth birthday today, credits two machines -- the sewing machine and the typewriter -- with having liberated women from the limited jobs available to them fifty years ago to their present wide career opportunities.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The United States assured West Germany today that it would help arm German units in the projected European army as soon as the treaty for the European Defense Community was in effect.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 9 -- Taking issue with the present tax structure in this country, leaders of a seminar on taxation at the annual convention of the Young Presidents Organization in the Arizona Biltmore Hotel today declared that many business men have been forced to become "petty thieves."

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9 -- Long-hitting Melvin (Chick) Harbert of Detroit led the field at the end of the opening round of the Masters tournament at the Augusta National Golf Club course today with a four-under-par 68 while a record-sized crowd looked on.

KINGSPORT, Tenn., April 9 -- The Giants and Indians regaled a gathering of 7,114 Tennesseeans with some tall and fancy swatting on this 80-degree afternoon, but once again Managers Leo Durocher and Alphonse Lopes derived no great amount of satisfaction from the performance.

Jacob Blaustein, president of the American Jewish Committee, asserted last night that Soviet Russia's retreat from its policy of anti-Semitism was "tactical, not fundamental, and an act of temporary strategy."

Events today: Haarlem Philharmonic Society, Waldorf-Astoria, 11 A. M.; "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera, 1 P. M.; Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Laselo Varga, 'cellist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," Metropolitan Opera, 8:15; "La Traviata," City Center, 8:15.

HELMSTEDT, Germany, April 9 (AP) -- Maurice Thorez, France's leading Communist, traveled across West Germany toward Paris tonight on the last leg of his train journey from Moscow. He is returning home and to art unknown political destiny after more than two years in the Soviet capital where he was treated for a stroke.

GENEVA, April 9 -- The outlook for the movement of people from overcrowded European regions to new homes overseas is improving, Hugh Gibson, director of the Intergovernmental Committee for European Migration states in report published here today.

Without a prompt and broad program of municipal improvements, New York City, under fire for unclean streets, lawlessness, substandard housing and crowded schools, stands in danger of soon reaching the end of its long period of rapid growth, Mayor Impellitteri was told yesterday.

OAKLAND, Calif., April 9 (UP) -- Ernie (Schnoz) Lombardi, a former major league baseball catcher who attempted suicide by slashing his throat with a razor, has been taken off the "critical" list and is on the road to recovery, hospital attaches said today.
From Asuncion, Paraguay, to New York by automobile is a journey of thirty-one flat tires, Ramon Echauri reported yesterday from personal experience.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Fraulein Lotte Adenauer, daughter of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of Germany, said at a press conference today that she found the United States overwhelming in size and its first lady, Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower, time-erasing in hospitality.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- A civil complaint charging major United States and other oil companies with violations of the anti-trust laws through an international oil cartel will be filed here before April 28 by the Justice Department, Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr., said today.

TOKYO, Friday, April 10 -- The Peiping radio reported today that Harold E. Fischer Jr., top jet ace flying in Korea, who had been reported missing in action this week, was captured April 7 after he had bailed out from his damaged Sabre jet.
Dismissal of the anti-trust charges against Morgan Stanley Co. in the current investment banking trial was asked yesterday by Ralph M. Carson, attorney for the banking firm.

Ground was broken yesterday for the $40,000,000 Downstate Medical Center that will house the College of Medicine of the State University of New York at 450 Clarkson Avenue, Brooklyn, across the street from the Kings County Hospital.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Delegates to the International Wheat Council, by a more than two-thirds majority, voted today to recommend to their governments a renewal of the International Wheat Agreement, which expires July 31. The proposed renewal would be at a new price range of $2.05 maximum, as against $1.80 under the old agreement, and $1.55 minimum, as against $1.20.
With an estimated attendance of 180,000 in five days, the "Easter Parade of Stars" automobile show closed last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The outstanding bonds secured by Public Housing Administration subsidy contracts has been reduced $3,271,000 by the use of bond premium money to repurchase the bonds from investors. Borrowing authorities can buy back their bonds whenever the money premiums paid by syndicates in buying the bonds at public bidding are not needed to defray development costs.

Built-in storage units are better than closets and other storage areas provided in many modern homes, Prof. Helen E. McCullough says in a bulletin entitled "Household Storage Units." Issued by the Small Home Council of the University of Illinois, it may be obtained free until May 1 and, threafter, for ten cents from the council, Mumford House, Urbana, Ill.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The senior Senator from Virginia did not need any new achievement to refute former President Truman's remark that there were "too many Byrds in the Senate." He did not need to furnish refutation at the time the remark was made, or before or since.

WEST POINT, N. Y., April 9 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, Deputy Supreme Commander of the Allied Powers in Europe and the hero of El Alamein, walked from the baseball field of the United States Military Academy here today clutching a bat and ball and as wide-eyed as a Brooklyn shaver who had just seen his beloved Bums take the Giants.

The grand jury testimony of John E. Gleason Jr., on which he faces charges of perjury in connection with the inquiry into the shakedown of fuel oil installers by Fire Department inspectors, was read yesterday to the jurors at his trial in General Sessions.

United States Government securities declined in price yesterday from 1-32 of a point to slightly more than 3/8 of a point following the announcement that the Treasury would offer for sale next week $1,000,000,000 of new fully marketable thirty-year bonds bearing interest of 3 1/4 per cent.

Senior Judge John C. Knox of the Southern District Court was honored last night for thirty-five years of service on the Federal bench. At a dinner given by the Foley Square Heads, an association of present and former assistant United States attorneys, letters of congratulation from President Eisenhower, Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. and Governor Dewey were read by Joseph W. Burns, president of the association.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 9 -- Pakistan's entire 75,000,000 population faces imminent famine unless 1,500,000 tons of wheat is poured into the fast-emptying granaries beginning this month, Prime Minister Khwaja Nazimuddin said today.
Be Gracious, a 6-year-old Discovery mare owned by Matthew Cremen, profited by a typically sound Eric Guerin ride to win the feature race at Jamaica yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, said today Federal executive agencies had reported 2,546,954 civilians on their payrolls in February but he could not vouch for the accuracy of the figures because some of the reports were "questionable."

NARROWSBURG, N. Y., April 9 -- Last Tuesday, to most people, was a gloomy, rainy day, with little to recommend it. But to thirteen young Explorer Scouts, and their two middle-aged leaders, it was a grand day.

Consumer credit can play a vital role in maintaining a balanced economy in the face of decreasing defense expenditures, one speaker said yesterday at the National Consumer Credit Conference being held by New York University in Vanderbilt Hall.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., April 9 -- The Bausch Lomb Optical Company began a year-long celebration of its centenial here yesterday when it showed visiting scientists and press some of the devices it is making for use in the scientific world.
Two Government-owned Victory ships that two weeks ago were lying idle in "dead-ship" upriver reserve fleets sailed fully loaded yesterday with military cargoes for the Far East.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 9 (AP) -- Communist Yugoslavia's rift with the Roman Catholic Church widened tonight with new charges by the official Belgrade radio that the Vatican had been blocking a reconciliation.

Enlisted men and women of the Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard joined yesterday in contributing 297 pints of blood to a Red Cross bloodmobile that was sent to the United States Naval Air Station at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Department store sales in the week ended April 4 were 8 per cent above those in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1952:

HANOI, Vietnam, April 7 -- Of Indo-China's three Associated States, Vietnam is the richest, the most heavily populated and potentially the strongest. Its principal political leaders are Chief of State Bao Dai, who resides at Banmethout, about 160 miles northeast of Saigon; Premier Nguyen Van Tam, whose National Government has its capital at Saigon; and Governor Nguyen Huu Tri of North Vietnam, which has its regional capital at Hanoi.

If the New York City Government has failed the people, as seems to us self-evident in many respects, it is also true that the citizens have failed their city. The Mayor's Committee on Management Survey remarks that it is implicit throughout its report "that there is a responsibility on the public to elect honest, able and sincere men to the public offices."
WASHINGTON, April 9 (UP) -- The Government reported today that expansion of the machine tool industry, the defense program's "biggest bottleneck" eighteen months ago, is now about completed.

An all-day conference on management problems, including the need for trained executives, will be held tomorrow at Keating Hall, Fordham University, according to James H. Lobb, president of the Fordham University Business Alumni Club.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., April 9 -- The world's only mine producing one of the world's oldest abrasives in commercial quantities found a new outlet for its product here today. The Walter Maguire Company, Inc., and the Cortland Stone Corporation opened a dockside plant here where stone from the near-by De Luca Mines is processed into a new type of heavy-duty flooring.

Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday that he would make a radio and television address Monday night to contradict "the garbled version of city-state fiscal relations as presented by Governor Dewey and his aides" on Wednesday.
Ship repairing in this port, as the result of a combination of unfavorable circumstances, is in danger of becoming a dead industry in so far as the privately-owned shipyards are concerned.

About the end of 1824, Schubert received a commission to compose a work for a new instrument called the arpeggione. Commissions were never too numerous in Schubert's career, and he polished it off quickly. The arpeggione, an offshoot of the viola da gamba, has long since disappeared, but its name has been immortalized, simply because Schubert composed a sonata for it.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- Development of a new drug that temporarily controls some cases of leukemia, a form of cancer of the white blood cells, was reported here today at the opening of the annual meeting of the American Association for Cancer Research.

PARIS, April 9 -- In his first public address in Paris, United States Ambassador C. Douglas Dillon today defined the aim of the Eisenhower Administration as the unity of the free world and sought to reassure the French nation on the question of the role that it would be called upon to play.

The Eye-Bank for Sight Restoration, Inc., has reported that from its founding in 1945 to the end of last year 3,112 eyes passed through its laboratory and were sent out locally and nationally to qualified physicians for corneal transplants. Thus, says the annual report, "many tragic cases" have been "completely restored to normal life and usefulness."

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Friday, April 10 -- United Nations and Communist liaison officers meeting here on the exchange of sick and wounded prisoners of the Korean war are now within a hair's breadth of complete agreement.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- How a hog serum concern in Denver, Colo., was making dangerous tetraethyl lead as a sideline twenty-seven years ago, was brought out at the du Pont anti-trust trial in Federal District Court today as Earle W. Webb, retired chief of the Ethyl Corporation, was questioned by defense and Government lawyers.

The Hempstead, L. I., Union Free School District 3 sold $4,600,000 of bonds yesterday to the National City Bank of New York at a bid of 100 for interest of 3.3 per cent. The bonds will come due on Feb. 1 from 1954 to 1983.

David E. Frankenstein, son-in-law of former Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy and his "unofficial secretary" prior to the jurist's retirement in 1951, was indicted yesterday for first degree perjury as a result of testimony about his finances and Army career before the State Crime Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today appealed to the investment community to forego transactions in German dollar bonds until the bonds have gone through the validating process prescribed under the terms of an agreement worked out by the Department of State and the S. E. C. with the Federal Republic of Germany.
TOKYO, Friday, April 10 (AP) -- United Nations Command Communique 1,580 for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korean time:

Joseph Moskoff, lessee of the one-story garage for forty cars at 1544 Boone Avenue, the East Bronx, has purchased the property from Mrs. Alice Curtis Desmond through the Wood, Dolson Company, brokers, who also arranged a new first mortgage of $20,000 for ten years at 5 per cent.

PITTSBURGH, April 9 -- Here at Forbes Field, where the right field foul line runs 300 feet to the wall, which then juts out sharply 75 feet more, the height from the base of the wall to the roof measures 90 feet. Well, sir, during the course of today's 10 -- 5 victory of the Pirates over the Yankees, Mickey Mantle slammed a screaming drive between the distance markers and over the roof.

LONDON, April 9 -- Although John Gielgud's production of "The Way of the World" has been running in Hammersmith since Feb. 19, the little Lyric Theatre was packed last evening with theatregoers who had had to make a special effort to get there.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Leonard W. Hall of New York was nominated without opposition today to be chairman of the Republican National Committee. His selection was endorsed by President Eisenhower, Vice President Richard M. Nixon and ten party Congressional leaders.

In a tense meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday, City Council President Rudolph Halley accused the Board of Transportation of trying to give part of a coal contract to a company against which the city had begun a civil court action.

Anyone who has given thought to the problem of inflation realizes that the greatest sufferers during the inflationary period of the past decade have been the various groups of people living on fixed pensions.

LONDON, April 9 (AP) -- Britain's Boxing Board of Control today agreed to recognize the Randy Turpin-Charles Humez fight as a world championship middleweight contest, an act which may prevent the formation of a world boxing organization.

TRENTON, April 9 -- A joint committee set up by the Republican majority in both houses of the Legislature reached agreement tonight on a rent-control bill to replace the present stand-by law. The new measure will be introduced in the Senate on Monday.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Arthur J. Altmeyer, who to many personified the nation's Social Security system, will retire tomorrow. Mr. Altmeyer is the Social Security Commissioner. He has been in the Federal service almost twenty years, nearly all of it in the Social Security field.

The steadily rising cost of newspaper publishing is resulting in an increase in the number of 6, 7, and 10 cent daily newspapers and a drop in the number of those selling for a nickel, 2 cents or 3 cents a copy.

TOKYO, Friday, April 10 -- The Pyongyang radio reported last night that seven British subjects captured by the Communist forces in the early days of the Korean war had been handed over yesterday to representatives of the Soviet Union for return to their homeland.

The Broadway legitimate theatre was characterized as earthbound and not daring enough in its conceptions by Maureen Stapleton, actress, at a forum presented yesterday by the Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy at the ANTA Playhouse, 245 West Fifty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Frank Pace Jr., Secretary of the Army from the outbreak of the Korean war until last January, testified today that the fighting during the first two years had been done exclusively with surplus ammunition left over from World War II.

DETROIT, April 9 -- Rex C. Jacobs, former president of an automotive supply concern, and his former board of directors, were charged today by a group of New York stockholders with diverting $700,000 in company funds to private use.

LONDON, April 9 -- The stock market rally that began yesterday widened today and widespread moderate rises were made in nearly all sections. The foreign bond market provided an exception, profit-taking cutting the prices of Japanese, German, Chinese, Russian bonds and eastern European bonds.

BEAUMONT, Tex., April 9 (AP) -- The fabulous athletic career of Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias spanning more than two decades and including virtually every competitive sport apparently was at an end today.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The Small Defense Plants Administration today prepared to lock horns with the Secretary of Defense, Charles E. Wilson, over his program for narrowing the mobilization base.

A family ownership of more than sixty-five years has been terminated in the sale by the Fitzgerald estate of the taxpayer property at 180-184 Newark Avenue and 263-265 First Street in Jersey City, N. J. The buyer, Harry Reiss, ocsupies a clothing store in the building, which has two other stores. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

A biography of the reigning Queen Elizabeth and her consort, Prince Philip, has been scheduled for April 29 publication by Holt, entitled "Elizabeth and Philip." The author, Geoffrey Bocca, American correspondent for Kemsley newspapers, presents a chronological development of the monarch's life from birth to coronation.
Our grandmothers brought warm weather to the dining table by serving what they called a "mess of spring greens."

GENEVA, April 9 -- The United States received some support today on its view that the United Nations Conventions on Human Rights in anything like their present form are not suitable for signing or ratification as binding treaties.

On a sales increase of 20 per cent, Libby, McNeill Libby last year chalked up a 229 per cent gain in earnings, bringing the net profit of the food-canning company to the highest in its eighty-five-year history.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregularly yesterday, 8 points lower to 4 points higher than on Wednesday.

Commodity prices on the New York exchanges closed irregularly lower yesterday with sugar, potatoes and hides active. Coffee prices dropped after showing strength earlier in the week. Coffee, potatoes, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, lead and zinc were lower.

The Tide Water Associated Oil Company had a net income in 1952 of $31,116,521, or $2.43 a share on 12,793,618 shares outstanding, compared with $37,060,606, or $2.90 a share earned the year before, William F. Humphrey, president, reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders.
ATHENS, April 9 -- The Greek drachma, hitherto valued at 15,600 to the United States dollar, will henceforth be 30,000 to $1, the Economic Coordination Minister, Spyros Markezinis, announced tonight.

The Commissioners of the Port of New York Authority appropriated $8,276,000 yesterday for the first stage of construction and rehabilitation of its Hoboken piers, leased last October from the Maritime Commission.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- Following is the text of the joint communique on the United States German talks:
MIAMI, Fla., April 9 (UP) -- Vic Seixas and Art Larsen were extended by determined foreigners today before advancing to the semi-finals of the Miami invitation tennis championships.

The nation's business leaders are a lot mere vocal in congratulating the Atomic Energy Commission on its reported move to modify the Federal monopoly over atomic power than they are in predicting actual advantage to private industry from that action.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 9 (AP) -- Task Fleet, returning $113.20 for each $2 to win, raced to a decisive victory over the Kentucky Derby eligibles, Bubbley and Cerise Reine, at Keeneland's opening today.

PARIS, April 9 -- The French Foreign Ministry made a first feeble effort today to meet what Western diplomats here consider may quickly become a major problem for the Atlantic alliance. This problem is the tendency in Europe to assume that the apparently conciliatory mood of the new Soviet leaders may remove the necessity for the West to rearm on the scale or at the rate hitherto contemplated.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- By matching their scoring output with the same number of errors, the Dodgers made it fairly easy for the Senators to win the "rubber" game of their spring series, 6 -- 4, tonight before a chilled gathering of 8,422 fans at Griffith Stadium.

A special concert of American music was presented late yesterday afternoon in Town Hall by the National Association for American Composers and Conductors. The program, played by the Little Orchestra Society under the direction of Thomas Scherman, was given in honor of the first New York biennial convention of the National Federation of Music Clubs.

It has just been announced by Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey that on Monday of next week the Administration will transact a borrowing operation that, to put it conservatively, must be regarded as one of exceptional significance.

LONDON, April 9 -- These are the busy days for London's "big eleven," the couturiers who are making the most glorious of the gowns to be worn at Westminster Abbey on Coronation Day. Ever since they showed their collections earlier in the season the ladies fortunate enough to be among those who will be privileged to see the great function on June 2 have been frequenting their salons.

The American-Korean Foundation, which has steadily been gaining momentum, has now made an announcement of its immediate goal. It will seek to raise about $5,000,000 for urgent relief and rehabilitation needs. At the same time a committee will continue the study of the long-range objectives and possibilities of the organization.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today the dollar value of business inventories was estimated at the end of February to be $75,300,000,000.

NAPLES, Italy, April 9 (AP) -- Tony Starte, an unknown from Cambridge, Mass., today surprised himself, his opponent and the crowd by defeating the experienced Kurt Nielsen of Denmark in the Naples tennis tournament.
ALBANY, April 9 -- The Court of Appeals, in a 4-to-3 decision, today placed a sharp limitation on the power of the State Civil Service Commission to override local commission decisions.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on April 4 were 704,517 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 10,820 cars, or 1.5 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 2,372 cars, or 0.3 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 35,006 cars, or 4.7 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.

The Board of Education, at a meeting yesterday that was marked by exchanges between board members and angry speakers, dismissed a high school department chairman and appointed a trial examiner to hear charges against three suspended teachers.

W. H. Rowand, chief engineer of the boiler division of the Babcock Wilcox Company, has been elected a vice president, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Rowand will continue to hold the post of divisional chief engineer.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- President Eisenhower appointed Henry J. Tasca today as his special representative for Korean economic affairs.

MADRID, April 9 -- In the first official statement on United States - Spanish relations issued since the advent of the Eisenhower Administration, the United States Government said today not only that it intended "to strengthen the cordial relations existing between our countries," but that it considered these relations an "important bulwark" in the defense of Western Europe.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (UP) -- The Senate Finance Committee today unanimously confirmed the nomination of Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby to be Secretary of the new Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., April 9 -- Leonard W. Hall, slated to be elected Republican National Chairman at a meeting of the party's National Committee in Washington tomorrow, recalled today how the way had opened unexpectedly for some of the public offices he had held.

Rockefeller Center held a little corner of Holland yesterday. It was made up of 5,000 brilliant tulips, a group of dignitaries, many little girls in bright Dutch costumes and some of the merry folk music of the old country's annual tulip festivals.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- During the week ended April 8, member bank reserves increased $324,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 9 -- With a July starting date now definite for "The Caine Mutiny," Stanley Kramer has begun the task of rounding up a cast.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- The Government is going to try to recover about $86,000 paid to Federal workers in what Representative John Phillips, Republican of California, calls "a clever little conspiracy" to turn unused vacation time into cash.

New borrowings by sales finance companies pushed New York bank loans to business $51,000,000 higher last week in a contraseasonal advance. The rise, first in three weeks, contrasted with a decline of $70,000,000 in the similar week last year, and brought the reduction in business loans so far in 1953 to $37,000,000, against a decline of $110,000,000 in 1952.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (UP) -- The Justice Department said today more indictments were expected "in the near future" against union officials suspected of falsely denying they were Communists.

The Knickerbockers will strive to stay alive in the play-off finals in the National Basketball Association tonight when they meet the Minneapolis Lakers in the fifth game of the series at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. The Westerners boast a 3-to-1 lead and need only one triumph to clinch the series.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 9 -- Dag Hammarskjold, a man with a taste for high mountains and free verse, walked down the ramp of a trans-Atlantic plane today into the lights, cameras and demands for quick answers to world problems that go with one of diplomacy's highest jobs -- the Secretary Generalship of the United Nations.
After several months of comparative stability building costs have started to climb again, according to data from many key cities compiled by Engineering News-Record.

Canadian Consul General Ray Lawson received a fine gander yesterday from the State of Connecticut in ceremonies at the Bronx Zoo. He got the famous bird only after the gander had been captured by smart tactics employed at sunrise in the Belle Haven regions of Greenwich, Conn.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 9 -- Instead of meeting a request of Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, for a voluntary 18 per cent cut in acreage to produce a 1953 cotton crop of 12,000,000 to 12,500,000 bales, the nation's cotton farmers now seem likely to plant about 1,000,000 acres more than they did last year.

BONN, Germany, April 9 -- Two important United States public information officials in West Germany today received dismissal notices in line with what is now believed to be the new policy of liquidating the backlog of incompleted security investigations simply by discharging the persons concerned.

MONTPELIER, Vt., April 9 -- The timely arrival of F. Elliott Barber, Attorney General of Vermont, successfully stemmed a bloodless invasion of the State Capitol by a force of 200 Iroquois Indians today during a public hearing on their claim to 2,225,000 acres of old tribal hunting grounds.

TORONTO, April 9 (Canadian Press) -- Pulp-making capacity of Canada and the United States may, for a long time, exceed demand, D. W. Ambridge, president of Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., said today at the company's annual meeting.

ROME, April 9 -- The Rev. Anthony Caliandro, Italian-born American Evangelical pastor who was informed by Italian authorities last January that his residence permit had expired and that he must leave Italy immediately, has informed the police that he plans to leave for the United States Monday aboard the liner Saturnia.

A deputy chief inspector and eight plainclothes men went on departmental trial yesterday in Brooklyn police headquarters, charged with failure to suppress open bookmaking in the streets of the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

Brig. Gen. Alfred G. Tuckerman of New York was elected president of the National Horse Show Association for a sixth term last night at the Brook Club. At the same time it was announced that invitations had been sent to Canada, France, Great Britain, Ireland, Italy, Mexico and Spain to send jumping teams to the show.

James A. Roe, Queens Democratic leader, protested yesterday that the proposed increase in legislative representation for his borough was inadequate and unfair. Instead of getting one more State Senator and one more Assemblyman, Queens should get at least two additional Senators and four additional Assemblymen, he asserted.
CHICAGO, April 9 -- Fourteen awards for distinguished service in American journalism during 1952, were announced here today by Sigma Delta Chi.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to approve an increase of about 34 per cent in the special fourth class rates for catalogues and similar printed advertising matter.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 9 (Reuters) -- Southern Rhodesia's 49,000 accredited voters, who today balloted in a referendum, that will determine the future of more than 6,000,000 persons, gave a decisive nod in favor of federation.

TRENTON, April 9 -- Prosecutors and assistant prosecutors from all of New Jersey's twenty-one counties met here today with Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons and made plans for a state-wide drive against all forms of gambling.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- Grain futures fluctuated narrowly today on small volume, with many operators inclined to watch from the sidelines until after the Government's April crop figures are issued tomorrow. Offerings increased on small rallies, but there was fair support on fractional setbacks.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The International Monetary Fund said today it "welcomes and concurs" in the action of the Greek Government eliminating multiple currency practices and adjusting the official exchange rate from 15,000 drachmas to the United States dollar to 30,000.

Postponed for the second time, "Can-Can" is now scheduled to have its premiere at the Shubert on May 7, rather than April 30. In the meantime, the Cole Porter-Abe Burrows musical, which is enjoying banner trade in Philadelphia, will continue for a sixth week there through May 2. . . .
LINCOLN, R. I., April 9 (AP) -- Tony DeSpirito, leading jockey in the country last year, was injured in a three-horse spill at Lincoln Downs today.
ALBANY, April 9 -- Governor Dewey signed a bill today barring any Knights of Pythias lodge in New York State from refusing membership to applicants because of race, creed, color or national origin.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 10 -- The running battle between Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Mario Lanza over production of "The Student Prince" was ended today when the studio announced the termination of its employment contract with the singing star.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- Senator Charles E. Potter, Republican of Michigan, said today a bill to give coastal states title to offshore oil lands was "legally and morally in accordance with the principle of Federal-state relationship."

Winnie, the Canada gander that was stranded at Greenwich, Conn., last month because he had lost his tail feathers, returned to Canada last night by airplane to rejoin his flock. The celebrated passenger was met at the airport in Windsor, Ont., by Mayor Arthur J. Reaume when the plane landed at 9:15 P. M. After posing for cameramen, he was escorted to a car and driven to the Jack Miner Bird Sanctuary at near-by Kingsville.

PARIS, April 10 -- The Soviet peace gestures notwithstanding, Allied defense chiefs in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization are putting the finishing touches on plans to increase the Allied ground strength in Europe by the equivalent of eight divisions and the Allied air strength by approximately 1,000 combat aircraft by the end of 1953.

In its first change of ownership in 27 years, the five-story apartment building at 908 Tiffany Street, the Bronx, has been sold by Elias Wien to an investing client of Maxwell Fox, broker. It is assessed at $47,000.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of West Germany, left by plane today for a nine-day coast-to-coast tour of the United States after he had said that he was "extraordinarily satisfied" with his diplomatic talks with United States Government leaders here.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 10 (UP) -- Another top secret atomic device will be exploded on the southern Nevada desert shortly before dawn tomorrow.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Saturday, April 11 (UP) -- The ten points agreed to by the United Nations and the Communists for exchanging sick and wounded prisoners of war were:

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- Chairman Alexander Wiley said today the Senate Foreign Relations Committee would have a "heart-to-heart" talk with Secretary of State John Foster Dulles on world problems next Friday.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Flight problems robbed Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York of a full luncheon with President Eisenhower at the White House today.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The State Department announced today that the Soviet Union had agreed to use its good offices to obtain the liberation of thirteen Americans seized by the Communist North Korean Government after the outbreak of the Korean war in June, 1950.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 10 -- The victory for federation, won in yesterday's South Rhodesian referendum on the issue of a new state comprising Southern Rhodesia, Northern Rhodesia and Nyasaland, has had swift repercussions in South Africa.

When New York City sets about reorganizing on a sound basis its retirement system for city employes there is an aspect of the system that deserves serious attention. This is the investment of its trusteed pension funds. Five retirement funds help to finance the pensions of teachers, policemen, firemen, other city employes and employes of the Board of Education.

Sugar was active yesterday on the New York exchange with the world market registering the highest volume since last July 27 and the domestic options most active since March 11, 1952. Prices on the exchange were irregulaly higher in generally light volume.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 10 -- The potentialities of manufacture and distribution in foreign countries have been recognized by American business and industry for a long time, members of the Young Presidents Organization were told here today by Thomas Bata, president of the Bata Shoe Company, Batawa, Canada.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 10 -- The Nationalist and Communist party coalition in the Indonesian Parliament succeeded last night in getting adopted by a vote of 82 to 43 a motion asking the Cabinet to establish an exchange of Ambassadors with the Soviet Union.

VIENNA, April 10 -- A Soviet refusal at today's Allied Council to permit an Austrian concern in Urfahr in the Soviet zone to obtain a connection with the Austrian teletype network in Linz evoked from the British High Commissioner, Sir Harold Caccia, the remark: "It is obvious there will be no tunnel of friendship dug in Austria."

Two new films arrive at first-run houses this morning. "Naughty Martine," a French-made comedy drama, with Deny Robin and Claude Dauphin, will be at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse. E. E. Reinert directed and Andre Hakim produced the Globe Film Distributors presentation, which has a scenario by Jacques Companeez and a supporting cast headed by Henri Vidal and Marguerite Moreno.

Mr. Vishinsky's harangue at the U. N. on Thursday did nothing to clarify any of the questions arising out of the negotiations over Korea, but it did do something to help explain the motives behind Russia's recent peace offensive.

A deportation hearing in the case of Lyulph Stanley, a British subject employed by the United Nations who is a permanent resident of the United States, was called off yesterday when Mr. Stanley, on instructions from the United Nations Secretary General's office,' agreed to sign on Monday a waiver of all immunities and privileges, which is required of aliens returning from visits abroad.
A steady drizzle and a heavy mist enveloped the city yesterday and, among other things, was blamed for causing a comparatively light turnout of state income tax payers.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina indicated yesterday that a Government charge that Morgan, Stanley Co. "masterminded" the conspiracy alleged against seventeen investment banking houses might have an important bearing on the fate of all defendants.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 10 -- At 3:13 P. M. today, Dag Hammarskjold of Sweden became the second Secretary General in the seven-and-a-half-year history of the United Nations. A few minutes later he gave his concept of the work of the United Nations: "Reconciliation and realistic construction."

The people of New York are being crushed between the arrogance of Governor Dewey and the incompetence of Mayor Impellitteri's administration, City Council President Rudolph Halley declared last night.
