Methods of approving new sewer contracts are bogged down in red tape and have caught the taxpayer in a vicious circle between rising construction costs and plodding government machinery, Queens Borough President James A. Lundy charged yesterday.
CINCINNATI, April 10 (AP) -- The home-run-minded Reds found the range three times again today to whip the Tigers, 7 to 4, in an exhibition game before 1,012 fans at chilly Crosely Field.

CLEVELAND, April l0 -- A Harvard University anthropologist suggested today that modern man would be better advised to breed some intelligence into his own species than to congratulate himself on building synthetic intelligence into machines of destruction.

CHICAGO, April 10 -- A chemical that greatly potentiates the action of a number of important drugs, promising to make possible great reductions in their dosage while prolonging their action, was described at the closing sessions here today of the annual meeting of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology

PARIS, April 10 -- The White House denial that the Eisenhower Administration had decided to accept permanent partition of Korea at the waist of that peninsula and was considering United Nations trusteeship for Formosa was not taken seriously in France today.

Homecoming Day was a washout yesterday, so the Yankees and Dodgers, their Spring training about to be concluded, will meet at Ebbets Field today at 1:30 P. M. Prevented from playing at the Stadium because of the rain, the teams are hopeful of squeezing in single contests today and tomorrow at Flatbush, before Casey Stengel takes his world champions to Washington for the season's official opener on Monday.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today increased its forecast of the winter wheat crop 17 per cent and in doing so raised prospects of Federal production controls on the 1954 bread grain crops.

BONN, Germany, April 10 -- Joseph M. Franckenstein, former Office of Strategic Services officer who was dismissed yesterday from his public information post, challenged today the right of the United States High Commissioner for West Germany to take such action and asserted that the reason given for it was "only a subterfuge in order to avoid passing on my loyalty."

When parents night after night must pace the floor with a crying infant who just cannot be quieted the experience does something to them -- and very likely to the baby -- which is scarcely to be desired. What causes such excessive crying, night or day, and what may be done to relive it is the subject of a study being carried on at the Child Health Center, University of Washington.

TOKYO, Saturday, April 11 -- United Nations and Communist negotiators at Panmunjom today signed the agreement for the repatriation of sick and wounded prisoners of the Korean war after four days of discussion of the proposal, first advanced by the United Nations two years ago and recently accepted by the Chinese and the North Koreans.

Among the various conferences which President Eisenhower and his aides have held with foreign statesmen visiting this country, one of the most important and apparently most successful has been the frank exchange of views with Chancellor Adenauer, who has guided Germany's destiny during the post-war years.

NEWARK, April 10 -- Political leaders here were assessing today the repercussions of the sharply worded presentment handed up yesterday by the Essex County grand jury which described Mayor Ralph A. Villani and top officials in his Department of Parks and Public Property as "beneficiaries of a systematic shakedown of employes."

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The official art of denying the truth without actually lying is as old as government itself, and the Eisenhower Administration has given an excellent illustration this week of how this sort of thing happens.

New commission schedules for transactions on the New York Stock Exchange have been sent to the membership for comment. Cutting rates on both modest deals -- some under $1,200 and all under $400 -- and those involving 1,000 shares or more, they increase charges for the transaction between those limits and are expected to bring in 12 1/2 per cent more revenue.

TOKYO, April 10 (AP) -- Following is the text, as released here by United Nations Command Headquarters of a Communist reply to a message from Gen. Mark W. Clark, United Nations Commander. Except for a few minor differences, the text followed a broadcast earlier by the Peiping radio.

In a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 30 Patricia McCarthy Diamond makes a circuitous defense of Congressional investigations into education by declaring that they will prove of "untold good" if they force a "complete reappraisal of American education today."

Narcotics dealers and addicts in Harlem, associates of a suspect in the fatal shooting of Patrolman Samuel Katz, have been organizing a fund to buy the silence of eye-witnesses to the murder or otherwise to make the witnesses "inaccessible" to the prosecution, it was asserted yesterday.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 10 -- A woman's wish to have her birthday ignored was respected here tonight by 1,000 friends of Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, who bade farewell before her departure next week for Rome to assume the duties of the United States Ambassador to Italy.

We hear that the present Congress may be asked to consider a slight automatic reduction in the size of the House after each future census to or toward the 300 members often mentioned on the floor or in committee as desirable but unattainable, and indeed until the automatic apportionment act was passed in 1929 it was unattainable.

TOKYO, April 10 (UP) -- Gen. Mark W. Clark's headquarters announced today it was setting aside a number of usual security regulations to permit rapid news coverage of the release of sick or wounded war prisoners.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and closing prices for active months were 1 to 6 points net higher than on Thursday. Opening prices were 1 to 6 points lower, but there was enough price fixing to steady the market later.

CHICAGO, April 10 -- Earle W. Webb, retired chief of the Ethyl Corporation, testified today at the du Pont anti-trust trial in Federal District Court here that another Ethyl executive had not stated the facts in a 20-year-old letter which asserted that the company was not in control of its own business.

Underwriters will be called upon to price another succession of new issues of public utility bonds next week. On Monday, Texas Electric Service Company will offer at sealed bidding $7,000,000 of mortgage bonds and $10,000,000 of preferred stock.
TOKYO, Saturday, April 11 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,581, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Saturday Korean time:
The twenty-seventh biennial convention of the National Federation of Music Clubs officially got under way yesterday morning at the Roosevelt Hotel With an open meeting headed by federation officials.

ALBANY, April 10 -- Governor Dewey disapproved today a bill designed to give a Queens Village osteopath, who has been blind since the age of 12, the same right to use anesthetics, narcotics and biological products in his practice that other osteopaths have had since 1939.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, has sounded out members of the Senate Armed Services Committee on the possibility of relaxing the stock disposal law so he can hire competent aides from big business.

BONN, Germany, April 10 -- The warmth of the welcome and the pledges of aid given to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer by United States Government officials have dispelled to a considerable degree the apprehensions raised here by the Russian hints of a German settlement.

The three-story building accommodating twelve families at 768 Rockaway Avenue in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn has been sold by the Dorco Holding Corporation, of which Lewis Krasner is vice president to Sol and Sarah Mines. The City Title Insurance Company insured title to the property, which occupies a plot 25 by 100 feet.

The Speech Association of the Eastern States opened its convention doors to critics yesterday, listened to reasons why some colleges nd universities were not interested in departments of speech, and then answered the criticisms.

A salesman with seven unpaid traffic tickets drove to court yesterday to settle accounts while the prevailing bargain rates lasted. He said he had "had enough." A traffic policeman apparently disagreed, though, and promptly gave the man a start on a new collection.
"Carmen" was presented at the Metropolitan Opera yesterday afternoon, with Brenda Lewis singing the title role for the first time there and Laura Castellano singing her first Metropolitan Micaela.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 10 -- Following are excerpts from a statement today by Ernest A. Gross of the United States in the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Social Committee:
STURBRIDGE, Mass., April 10 -- Within the precincts of this New England community is another that, tucked away in about 200 acres of hill and dale and stream, mirrors a former, vanished way of life.

The light-hearted eloquence with which you spoke of the baffling mystery in your Topics of The Times on April 2 was of real interest to me. Your insight into the difficulties encountered when one chooses to write on sidewalks and subway steps is quite accurate.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., April 10 -- Residents of this city and Yonkers, two of the communities hardest hit by the state's new Thruway construction shook their heads disconsolately today as they told of dislocations in business and social life caused by the loss of shops, offices, factories, homes, churches, parks and local streets in the paths of the Thruways.

The Distributive, Processing and Office Workers Union has given assurances to the Congress of Industrial Organizations -- with which it is on the verge of reuniting -- that it does not support communism.

NOVI SAD, Yugoslavia, April 10 -- Serious apathy and disillusionment have struck the ranks of the Communists in Yugoslavia. These moods have been particularly noticeable in the villages and towns and have been pronounced in the great agricultural region of Vojvodina of which this city is the capital.

A more liberal policy on depreciation allowance by the Internal Revenue Department was urged yesterday to advance national security by helping industrial producers to modernize and replace their equipment.

PARIS, April 10 (Reuters) -- The international staff of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization declared today that the United States State Department had no right to check on the loyalty of Americans in UNESCO employ.
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 10 -- Commenting on the United
DETROIT, April 10 -- The Ford Motor Company said today that more than 40,000 of its 130,000 hourly rated employes would be laid off Monday because of a strike at a key parts plant in Monroe, Mich.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 10 -- The United Nations Legal Department told the United States today that it did not approve Washington's refusal of visas to two representatives of Communist-dominated organizations who wished to attend sessions at United Nations Headquarters.

NEW DELHI, India, April 10 -- The prospects for a solution of outstanding differences between India and Pakistan are expected here to be advanced by a high-level conference of Foreign Office representatives of the two countries beginning in New Delhi Monday.

SEATTLE, April 10 -- two-man congressional subcommittee looking into Seattle waterfront tie-ups, heard an official of the Alaska Steamship Company declare today that Seattle might lose the major share of its maritime passenger trade to Alaska at the end of the summer.

LONDON, April 10 -- Awaiting the 1953-54 national budget that will be presented next Tuesday, the London stock market was hesitant today and trading fell away appreciably after yesterday's lively movements.

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 10 (AP) -- Most of the top talent in the National A. A. U. free-style wrestling championships remained in the running tonight as fourth-round matches cut the field to thirty-seven.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Leonard Wood Hall of Oyster Bay, L. I., was elected unanimously today as chairman of the Republican National Committee and immediately summoned its members to "man the dikes for Ike" in the crucial 1954 mid-term Congressional elections.

For a half-hour yesterday afternoon, a 13-year-old, 150-pound boy dangled precariously from a Brooklyn roof while his sister and a cousin prevented him from falling thirty feet to a concrete areaway. Finally, as a drizzling rain threatened to loosen his relatives' grip, the boy was rescued by the police.
Witty Brothers is entering the synthetic blend field for fall with combinations of Dacron and worsted, worsted flannel and gabardine, Spencer Witty, member of the clothing concern, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 10 -- Wheat futures showed a steady tone today on the eve of the April crop report. Corn, oats and rye were firmer under the influence of a report that Secretary of Agriculture Ezra T. Benson had suggested a measure to control imports of grains that are under Federal price supports.

The second annual Better Brooklyn Month -- April 10 to May 10 -- dedicated to benefiting the borough's cultural institutions, was proclaimed yesterday by John Cashmore, Borough President. Institutions that will benefit are the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, the Brooklyn Children's Museum and the Brooklyn Museum, all departments of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Decisive action soon by the Administration or Congress, perhaps both, to tighten import controls on agricultural products appeared likely today.

ST. LOUIS, April 10 (UP) -- With a nudge from Baseball Commissioner Ford Frick, the Cardinals changed the name of their ball park from Budweiser Stadium to Busch Stadium today. Too much trouble was brewing.

Employes of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad began their contributions yesterday to the Red Cross blood bank in the railroad's Harlem River yards at 82 Willis Avenue, the Bronx. One hundred and fifty pints were collected from the day shift.

A new type of textile dryer utilizing superheated steam for the first time holds the promise of improved dyeing and finishing of natural and synthetic fabrics and blends, according to James H. Hunter, vice president of the textile finishing machine company bearing his name.

A "clever," 27-year-old freelance writer who avoided service in the armed forces by successfully delaying his induction until after he became 26, was acquitted yesterday, on a technicality, of violation of the Selective Service Laws.

The lure of tilting at the tote board drew 20,093 persons to the Jamaica race track yesterday They saw C. V. Whitney's 4-year-old Cold Command, in the role of 9-to-5 favorite, win the six-furlong race in the feature spot, and then they saw Christopher T. Chenery's 3-year-old filly Queens Moon give a much better performance in the event that was run seventh.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, April 10 (UP) -- A Caribbean International Airways plane crashed at sea a few minutes after taking off today, killing thirteen persons.

A study of the Employment Act of 1946 by Edwin G. Nourse, first chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers to the President, will be published next Thursday by Harcourt, Brace. Its title is "Economics in the Public Service." The author gives his views on the future usefulness of the act and presents some details of the tensions and final clash of personalities that led to his withdrawal from the council.

A former Communist, a grand jury foreman and a financier-philanthropist received Americanism awards last night at tile annual Loyalty Day Pageant held under the auspices of the Catholic War Veterans, Department of New York, at Manhattan Center.
Randy Sandy, Harlem middleweight, gained a technical knockout over Jimmy Beau of New Canaan, Conn., in the eighth round of their scheduled ten-round bout at St. Nicholas Arena last night.

A survey by a city teacher of the opinions business men have about high school graduates has shown that the employers feel that most boys and girls cannot spell or do simple arithmetic and that if there were not a shortage of young office workers many graduates "would be without work for long, long time."

LONDON, April 10 -- A relation between cancer of the stomach and blood type has been discovered by Drs. Ian Aird and N. H. Bentall of the University of London and the Postgraduate Medical School of London.

The man probably does not breathe who spent his childhood in or near New York City and has no memories of Coney Island. Ferris wheels, Luna Park, shooting galleries, the Comet, the L. A. Thompson, penny movie machines, hot corn on the cob, Steeplechase, cold custard, arcades, the Cyclone, the Thunderbolt, freak shows, merry-go-rounds, the Boardwalk, the Bowery, fun houses, Feltman's, the crowds, the hot dogs, the soda pop.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 10 -- Deploring the commercialization of images of the church, Sister Mary Jeanne, editor of The Catholic Art Quarterly, declared today that the sale of religious pictures and statues had become a "racket."

EDMONTON, Alberta, April 10 (Canadian Press) -- Yukon citizens are talking about taking the title of "Nickel Capital of Canada" away from Sudbury, Ont., following recent claim-staking activity in the White-river area, about 250 miles northwest of Whitehorse.

Representatives of thirty-one civic and educational organizations protested yesterday that the city's health, welfare and educational services would be crippled if Mayor Impellitteri's proposed budget was adopted.

POCATELLO, Idaho, April 10 (AP) -- Three Louisiana State boxers scored semi-final victories tonight to take a narrow lead for the championship of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. The Tigers had 11 points to 10 for second-place Idaho State College, host to the meet.

There comes a season in a man's life when, on this morning, the alarm clock does not ring at 4 o'clock, as it has been known to do, and when no creel, rods, boots and thermos jug full of coffee are placed by the front door in readiness for the impatient toot of a horn in the pre-dawn darkness.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 10 -- A study of the nation's law schools today said the legal profession was inheriting from the schools an army of graduates who had a "patchwork" of prelegal education and who had come out of the law schools ill-equipped to cope with facts.

SAN SALVADOR, April 10 -- Foreign Minister Roberto E. Canessa in a message broadcast last night to the republic over all radio stations and quoting a note sent to the Guatemalan Foreign Minister, Raul Osegueda earlier in the day, denounced Guatemala's diplomatic communication announcing withdrawal from the Organization of Central American States.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Donald C. Cook, retiring chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, declared today that investment "sharpers" would have a wide field in which to operate next year because of slashes in the agency's budget.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee set out today to uncover the design through which groups of alleged Reds, exposed at one point of Government service, had been able to transfer promptly to another within the Federal establishment.

Private industry should be permitted immediately to begin "definite, full-scale" commercial applications of atomic energy, Walter L. Cisler, president and general manager of the Detroit Edison Company, declared yesterday. He spoke at the final sessions of the American Management Association's manufacturing conference in the Statler Hotel.

BONN, Germany, April 8 -- Otto Ernst Remer, who helped foil the 1944 plot against Hitler and who later was one of the leaders of Federal Gemany's strongest neo-Nazi party, is now in Egypt, the Government announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- A bibulous automaton was patented this week by two Californians, who report that, in order to make the movements lifelike, they first studied "the motions made by an average person in pouring a drink into a glass and drinking the contents thereof."

A call to become associate field director of Christian Education for the New York State Synod of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. has been accepted by the Rev. Donald B. Reitz, associate pastor of Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

The ports in the India-Pakistan area are doing a good job of cargo handling within the restrictions of their present equipment but a real need for mechanized pier equipment exists there, John W. McGrath asserted here yesterday.
CLEVELAND, April 10 -- Clifford F. Hood, president of the United States Steel Corporation, pleaded tonight for greater participation by private industry in the atomic energy program.

The European Boxing Union will not recognize the winner of the Randy Turpin-Charles Humez bout in London on June 9 as the world middleweight champion, Robert K. Christenberry, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, said yesterday.
The wine-tasting held this week at the Plaza Hotel for the benefit of the Goddard Neighborhood Center was in many respects a model of what such occasions should be.

A pastoral letter from Cardinal Spellman urging churchgoers in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York to give "at least one day's wage" to the 1953 appeal of New York Catholic Charities will be read in all churches tomorrow. The appeal goal has been set at $2,477,138, to be raised in a campaign beginning April 19 and ending April 29.

The Isbrandtsen Company agreed yesterday to an election among pursers on thirteen of its ships to determine if the men wish to be represented in collective bargaining by the Staff Officers Association of America, A. F. L.
DENVER, April 10 -- The six-day conference of the Association for Childhood Education International adjourned Friday after delegates participated in panel sessions.
The St. Regis Paper Company increased its sales and earnings in the first quarter this year over the 1952 period and also announced the election of Kenneth D. Lozier as a vice president.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- Representatives of the retail industry urged the Senate Labor and Welfare Committee today to make the employer's right of "lockout" as broad as a union's right to strike.

Members of thirty-eight choirs from thirty-three churches in the metropolitan area are scheduled to participate at 5 P. M. tomorrow in a hymn festival at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

WITH almost every New York and New Jersey angler now shivering on the margin of his favorite trout stream, a discussion of local conditions would be futile, but we have some reports from Maine which should interest those who have been waiting to begin landlocked salmon fishing in the northern lakes.

BERLIN, April 10 -- Representatives of Britain, France and the United States met near Bonn today to consider a Soviet proposal for the amalgamation of the three air corridors leading from West Germany to Berlin.

The Milwaukee Journal is starting a new low-cost run-of-paper color service, it was announced yesterday. Through arrangements with Lake Shore Electrotype, Chicago, the Journal will make available all kinds of newspaper color material.
LYNCHBURG, Va., April 10 -- The Giants and the Indians brought their transcontinental tour into its final lap today with the Polo Grounders still breathing defiance.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 10 -- The Limited States is prepared to take "every honorable step" toward real agreement on specific issues in dispute with the Soviet Union, Ernest A. Gross told the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today.

BUENOS AIRES, April 10 -- Juan Ramon Duarte, who was described as a victim of a defamation campaign which has involved the highest leaders of the Argentine Government, was buried today with all the honors usually accorded a top-ranking peronista leader.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The typical rural teacher today differs markedly from her counterpart of fifteen years ago. That was shown today in an analysis by the National Education Associ ation on the basis of a nationwide study by questionnaire.

BOWIE, Md., April 10 (UP) -- Royal Bay Gem, the colt that flashed into prominence in the Kentucky Derby picture with a fast-closing second in the Flamingo Stakes, heads a field of 16 three-year-olds entered today for the 32nd running of the $25,000 Chesapeake Stakes at Bowie tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Moshe Sharett, Foreign Minister of Israel, expressed confidence today that the Eisenhower Administration would show "sympathetic understanding" to the problems of the Tel Aviv Government.
NAPLES, April 10 (AP) -- Two Americans reached the semi-final round of the Naples International Tennis Tournament today and set up a chance for an all-American final.

MANCHESTER, N. H., April 10 (UP) -- Representative Harold H. Velde, chairman of the House Un-American Activities Committee, tonight charged that most critics of the committee did not actually know what the group was doing. To foster public understanding of the group's investigations, he announced that it would open its public hearings to television.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Fredrick J. Lawton, long a civil servant, and Budget Director in the Truman Administration, was nominated by President Eisenhower today to be a member of the Civil Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Average primary market prices were unchanged over the week ending April 7, at 109.8 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Farm products increased 6 per cent, with higher prices for corn, cows, hogs, lambs, eggs at Chicago and some fresh fruits and vegetables.

A fashion show of Carrousel Sportswear for teen-agers and sub-teens was previewed for the press yesterday by Oppenheim Collins. The clothes will be modeled informally today on the store's fourth floor from noon until 4 P. M.

The Minneapolis Lakers continue to rule the National Basketball Association. They proved this conclusively last night when they defeated, the Knickerbockers, 91 - 84, to end the play-off series for the loop crown after only five games.
BUENOS AIRES, April 10 (UP) -- President Juan Peron and his twenty-one Ministers met in emergency session for nearly four hours tonight amid reports the entire Cabinet might resign.

The 654 West 161st Street Corporation bought for investment the six-story apartment house for forty-eight families at that address from the Building Servicing Corporation in a deal negotiated by Efim Fuhrman, broker. The property is 150 by 100 feet and is assessed at $205,000.
Developments in Washington on restriction of agricultural imports were viewed in foreign trade circles here yesterday as confusing and discouraging.
A great variety of styles and mediums is to be met in current art exhibitions.

With the crashing brass fanfares that conclude the fourth act of "Carmen," the sixty-eighth season of opera at the Metropolitan will come to an end tonight, and Fritz Reiner, the evening's conductor, will take his last Metropolitan curtain-call within the foreseeable future.

PHILADELPHIA, April 10 -- Premier Georgi M. Malenkov of the Soviet Union probably started Moscow's present peace offensive to increase disunion in the West while consolidating the power he inherited from Premier Stalin, Clarence Streit, author and president of the Federal Union, Inc., asserted here today.

PASADENA, Calif., April 10 -- Evidence that the visible universe is eight times as large as previously conceived by astronomers, and twice as old, was detailed today. by Dr. Walter Baade of the Mount Wilson and Mount Palomar Observatories in California.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- Under Secretary of Agriculture True D. Morse said today he had "hopes" Great Britain will change her stand and stay in the International Wheat Agree ment for another three years. Mr. Morse, United States delegate to the International Wheat Council, conceded however that there is no way to predict what the United Kingdom will do.

Yesterday was one of those stock market days that would hardly have been missed had it never dawned. Trading was lackadaisical amounting to only 1,360,000 shares against 1,520,000 on Thursday. Prices slumbered through most of the day, sinking quietly, then turned over to stage an inconsequential rally that still left THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average down 0.31 point on the day. The only lower close this year was that on Monday.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- An investment banker said today that a feasible plan had been worked out to finance construction of a natural gas pipeline from the Canadian Peace River field to western Washington and Oregon.

The New Jersey Zinc Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1952 a net profit of $12,060,192, equal to $6.15 a share, after $3,600,000 taxes. This compares with $9,913,553, or $5.06 a share, earned the year before.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 10 -- Following is the text of a statement made this afternoon by Dag Hammarskjold, new United Nations Secretary General, during swearing-in ceremonies at the General Assembly:

The New York City Opera Company may tour Japan for at least one month next year. Negotiations between Joseph Rosenstock, general director of the opera, and the Nippon Broadcasting Corporation are almost completed.

An unusual class in A. B. C.'s is being conducted uptown at a new branch of Public School 157. The school annex is a staff room of Sydenham Hospital and the pupils, duly enrolled as elementary school students, all possess academic degrees no lower than M.D.

The City Club of New York, whose study of waterfront conditions in the Port of New York deserves careful consideration, points up the need for a forthright handling of the lucrative "public-loading" racket. This evil, which has become institutionalized, centers around goods unloaded from ships by longshoremen and transferred by the so-called "public loader" from pier shed to a waiting delivery truck.
ALBANY, April 10 -- Governor Dewey signed today a bill designed to make it easier to convict careless hunters who use guns or bows recklessly and injure or kill persons. It will take effect July 1.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10 (AP) -- Bob Jones, the master golfer of the golden era of sports, sat down in the press hut at the seventeenth Masters tournament today and talked about his favorite sport.
BEAUMONT, Tex., April 10 (AP) -- Messages by the thousands flooded Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias today, expressing hope for her recovery from a malady that may end her athletic career.

With tonight's showing at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre, "Guys and Dolls" will qualify for membership in the charmed circle of Broadway attractions that have achieved or passed the 1,000 performance mark. That the feat is no mean accomplishment can be attested by the fact that only sixteen productions have made the grade.

CLEVELAND, April 10 -- The outcome of a police campaign in Youngstown, Ohio, against obscene books may hinge on a lawsuit filed in Cleveland by the New American Library of World Literature, Inc., of New York.
MIAMI, April 10 (AP) -- Top-seeded Gardnar Mulloy of Miami and sixth-seeded Hal Burrows of Charlottesville, Va., reached the semi-finals of the Miami Invitation Tennis tournament today.

BONN, Germany, April 10 -- The West German Government announced today it had smashed a Russian - directed spy ring, described by Vice Chancellor Franz Bluecher as the biggest uncovered in the Western world since 1945.

Stavros G. Livanos, Greek shipping official, said yesterday the shipping interests he represented in the recent agreement concluded with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, went beyond any restrictions placed by any of the Governments whose flags their approximately thirty vessels fly.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 10 -- New experimental evidence suggesting that common drug store aspirin produces under special circumstances just about the same effects in the human body as the miracle drugs ACTH and cortisone produce was presented here today at the annual meeting of the American Heart Association.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 10 (AP) -- Correspondent, the prominent West Coast nominee for the Kentucky Derby, made his debut in the Bluegrass today and handily won a six-furlong prep at Keeneland.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, assured a Senate Armed Services subcommittee today that new ammunition production had brought stocks in Korea and Japan to a satisfactory level. However, the depleted reserve in the United States has not been replenished in certain critical items, he testified.

A junior city council of 185 youthful delegates from Hi-Y clubs for the Brooklyn and Queens Young Men's Christian Association "took over" the council chamber at City Hall all yesterday and voted for a city manager for New York City.

The challenge to United States leadership was never so urgent as in these days of apparent softening of Soviet policy. The immediate furor stirred up in the United Nations and in most foreign capitals by the evidently well-founded report that a split-up of Korea at the "waist" and a trusteeship in Formosa were being considered in Washington is typical.

A half-hour pilot film for a proposed series of television programs had a sneak preview last night at the Gramercy Theatre, 127 East Twenty-third Street, as an adjunct to the theatre's regular attractions. It was believed to be the first time that a movie house here had loaned its facilities and paying audience to a television producer to test his program.

"CORPUS OF JOE BAILEY,"* by Oakley. Hall, is like a vast summary of all the growing-up-in-America novels that have been written in the last twenty or thirty years. It is a work of organization rather than a work of creation. The representative experiences of young Americans growing up in the Nineteen Twenties and Nineteen Thirties and Nineteen Forties are dramatized with skill and insight.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Signing of the agreement at Panmunjom, Korea, for exchanging sick and wounded prisoners raised United States official hopes tonight that the Communists might be ready now for a Korean settlement.

Consumer credit promotes world well-being because it is an important factor in the mass production and mass distribution necessary for a high standard of living, Dr. G. Rowland Collins, Dean of the Graduate School of Business Administration of New York University, said yesterday at the National Consumer Credit Conference at the Commodore Hotel.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The National Production Authority today ended its tonnage limitations on the purchase of refined copper by brass, bronze and copper wire mills.

In his letter published March 18 H. F. March accepted that "displaced persons" under the Hitler regime were only those foreign civilians "who were brought to Germany to work and were found there at the end of the war." On this arbitrary assumption his thesis is based that the number of persons displaced under Hitler never reached the proportions of the displacements carried out under the Potsdam Agreement.

Changes in the Federal rent control law, now under consideration in Congress, will not affect rents are in New York because state controls are in effect here, Joseph D. McGoldrick, State Rent Administrator, explained yesterday.

Two witnesses at the perjury trial of John E. Gleason Jr. told in General Sessions yesterday of a visit to the insurance office of Frank J. Sampson, a former leader of Tammany Hall and now administrative assistant to Mayor Impellitteri, a few days after the mayoral election in 1950.

There is a Spanish adage something to the effect that the best of meals consists of bread, cheese, wine and an onion. Old Omar imagines a paradise made up of a jug of wine, some lyrics and a damsel indicated as "Thou." It has remained for a local song writer to merge excellent features of these listings and produce a song entitled "An Onion and You."

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10 -- With an assist from the weather man, today proved to be a Ben Hogan day at the Masters golf tournament. After the lightning and rain of the morning, the skies cleared and in the warm sunshine the famed Texan put together a 69 to take the lead at the end of thirty-six holes with an aggregate of 139.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 10 -- In a precautionary step suggested by Harry Bridges himself, the biennial convention of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union decided today to name a president pro-tem to head the organization in the event Bridges has to serve a prison term.

TOKYO, Saturday, April 11 -- Savage fighting raged on the central Korean front today white at Panmunjom the negotiators were concluding the agreement for the exchange of sick and wounded prisoners of war.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (UP) -Department of Agriculture officials prepared today for strong protests against a budget cut eliminating programs to control and eradicate the Japanese beetle, sweet potato weevil and peach mosaic.

Cholesterol is a fatty substance im such human foods as egg, milk and animal fats in general It can also be !produced in the body itself as a result of chemical reactions in the liver. I IV[any physician9 believe that the accumulation of cholesterol in the walls 'of arteries restricts the flow of blood.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 11 (UP) -- Pet Bully, Mrs. Ada L. Rice's 5-year-old speedster, ruined Hill Gail's comeback bid today by nosing out the 1952 Kentucky Derby winner in the $10,000 Phoenix Handicap at Keeneland.

BOWIE, Md., April 11 -- Royal Bay Gem, owned by Eugene Constantin Jr., started running when the others were tired and he registered a convincing triumph in the 34,050 Chesapeake Stakes at the Bowie course today. The strong son of Royal Gem II was in last place at the halfway mark of the mile and a sixteenth, but Jimmy Combest called on him to go, on the turn into the stretch, and go he went.

BY a quick tally of the list facing the title page of her latest novel, Georgette Heyer has written twenty-five books. All of them, at least all I know about, concern a brief era in English history known as the Regency -- roughly the early decades of the nineteenth century.

THE period covered in "The Faith of Our Fathers" extends from the American Revolution to the Civil War. As the editors put it, "the faith of our fathers is presented through writings, speeches, resolutions and petitions which exemplify the ideals of political, social and economic betterment of the American plain people," and "depict the struggle of ordinary men and women to fulfill the promise of the Declaration of Independence."

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, April 12 -- United States F-86 Sabre jets today shot down six Red MIG jet fighters for a two-day score of nine and plucky South Korean infantrymen again knocked the Chinese Communists off hotly disputed Outpost Texas in savage fighting.

PASSAIC, N. J., April 11 -- A white boy drowned in the tailrace of Weasel Brook today in an unsuccessful attempt to rescue a Negro boy who had fallen from a makeshift raft. Both bodies were recovered, almost side by side in eight feet of water.

ONE of the more felicitous aspects of the fall and winter seasons just past has been the unostentatious but consistent flow of nice little British films. (You'll notice we use the word "season" -- vedy clawsy -- when referring to British films.)

THE last month or so has seen a temporary LP drop in the complete-opera situation and a corresponding rise in the symphonic one. To begin with, let's look at some hitherto unrecorded (on LP, that is) works, starting with Bruckner's Ninth Symphony, on three SPA sides (the fourth is devoted to Bruckner's early and inconsequential Overture In G minor).

For the first time in the history of the municipal colleges, a "Visit Your College Week" will be held to give New Yorkers the opportunity to become better acquainted with the work of the city-supported institutions of higher education.

PRACTICALLY since the first day of television the point has been made that video must have vigorous and mature writing if the medium is to flourish artistically. The point is still as valid as it ever was but to hand at the moment is an episode which illustrates why it never will be easy to attain and how disappointments can come from strange and unexpected quarters.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO -- Government encouragement of tourism has made the Dominican Republic a comfortable stopover for Caribbean island-hoppers. Coming to it, as one usually does, from colorful Haiti or lively Puerto Rico, it seems unnaturally quiet, particularly for a Latin-American country.

The first newsprint mill on the mainland of Asia, and the only modern one in the world designed to use bamboo as the major raw material, is slowly, laboriously approaching completion in the tiger-infested woodlands at Nepanagar, 325 miles northeast of Bombay in central India.

The largest wholesale looting in history of national assets -- the natural resources in oil and other minerals in the submerged lands of the sea -- is taking place in Congress with the approval and encouragement of the Eisenhower Administration.

Columbia's baseball team allowed two runs to Rutgers in the opening inning but came back to defeat the Scarlet, 6 -- 3, as the ancient rivalry between the schools was resumed at Baker Field yesterday. A three-run outburst in the sixth, featured by Lee Guittar's circuit clout and some fine pitching by Southpaw Larry Contillo, turned the trick.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 11 (UP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission today set off a "medium-sized" nuclear explosion to reach the mid-way mark in its spring series of tests that will be brought to a climax by the firing of the first atomic artillery shell.

ST. THOMAS, V. L -- Lift Greenwich Village out of its big black city and set it down by a brilliant blue sea, give it a perfect year-round climate, and have its shops declare a permanent price cut of 50 per cent -- there you have the American Virgin Islands.

VIRGILIA PETERSON, a rangy, erudite woman of 48 who is in the business of having a definite opinion on just about everything literary, Horatio Alger included, is herself a pretty good example of a person who worked her way up to the top.

Chess players from the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis gained a double triumph yesterday in the annual triangular meet with West Point and the New York Athletic Club at the N. Y. A. C. clubhouse. They defeated their Army rivals 6 games to 2, and followed with a 5-3 victory over the Winged Foot combination.

CONJECTURE about the movie future of "The Time of the Cuckoo" came to a halt last week with the acquisition of film rights to the Arthur Laurents drama, starring Shirley Booth, by Lopert Films, Inc. Although Ilya Lopert, who heads the producing-distributing company, was not ready to divulge price details, he was in a position to elaborate on plans for the projected picture.

The conviction of the leader of the Kenya African Union, Jomo Kenyatta, for his part in directing the brutal terrorism of the Mau Mau, is a significant legal step in the difficult process of suppressing the movement. The worst atrocities, however, were committed in the months that he has been in custody, showing that the conspiracy has deep roots among the Kikuyus, from whose tribe he comes.

WITH the opening of the trout season in New York and New Jersey yesterday, and with Connecticut, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Maryland due to open during the coming week, another freshwater season is officially launched.
The editorial you carried on April 5 on the death of former King Carol II, under the slighting caption of "Last of the Ruritanians," came as a shock to us.

NEW DELHI, India April 11 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's political role as the sole visible unifying force in a vast new state of disparate and contentious peoples was highlighted in a dim jungle setting last week in a way that left in the shadows his better publicized activities on broader stages.

THE chickadee with black cap and bib has all but turned cart wheels at our window ledge feeding station all winter. The cedar waxwings, fastidiously dressed in soft browns washed with yellow and with a reddish cast, have dropped in on their annual spring visit.

Dr. Selman A. Waksman, Nobel Priz winner and discoverer of streptomycin, denounced last night those nations that would limit science to their own national boundaries and "designate certain branches of science as characteristic of certain racial or religious groups."

IN his review of my novel, "The Money Song," G. M. states that Ring Lardner's picture of the songwriter as an "ignorant and vulpine megalomaniac," as drawn in a short story "Some Like Them Cold" is the "definitive portrait" of popular music business.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 11 -- Problems confronting the Roman Catholic schools and colleges of this country were considered here this week by leading Catholic educators. Meeting in the fiftieth annual convention of the National Catholic Educational Association, 8,000 diocesan superintendents, administrators, lay and religious teachers, and other school officials looked back over their half century of service, and looked ahead to an expanded program.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11 -- Yugoslavia believes that she will not reach an open conflict with the Soviet bloc despite "profound theoretical and ideological differences" with Russia, the American Academy of Political and Social Science was told tonight.

THE first public showing of a depth-illusion process took place in the autumn of 1952, when Cinerama had its world premiere at the Broadway Theatre here on Sept. 30. At least eighteen other three-dimensional and wide-screen processes have since been announced.

THERE are not nearly enough books by Ogden Nash, of course, and when years intervene between them the whole thing takes on the air of a national disgrace. Between "Versus" and "The Private Dining Room" four hollow years passed by, years in which Mr. Nash, instead of sticking to business, merely brought out collections while off on such tangents as writing for the theatre and lecturing.

Increased emphasis on armaments production in the Soviet Union since the outbreak of the Korean war has forced a serious slowdown in the expansion of civilian machinery output, analysis of available Soviet data indicates. This slowdown threatens to impede not only the future growth of Soviet industrial and agricultural production but also to make more difficult than ever Soviet possibilities for supplying Eastern Europe and Communist China with the in dustrial machinery those areas need.
PITTSBURGH, April 11 (UP) -- The Senators pounded out ten hits to defeat the Pirates, 3 -- 2 in an exhibition game today before 3,102.

DEEP in the heart of France, on one of its busiest and sunniest squares, stands a fortress. To the casual eye it seems not too different from any of the other sandstone buildings with iron balconies and half-mansard roofs that give Paris its particular character.

There is nothing new about the use of butter in sauces. It has been a treasured ingredient, and, indeed, in some sauces an essential one, for many generations of good cooking. One thinks in this connection of French cooking especially, for it is the French who have perfected the sauce and from whose language we derive the word.

I am writing you on behalf of the Social Studies Department of James Monroe High School whose members read Delbert Clark's article and were taken aback by some of the unwarranted conclusions which the author reached on the basis of merely (a) a twenty-question current events quiz given to thirty-four students and (b) his own analysis and percentage-wise breakdown of the individual pupil answers.
NAPLES, April 11 (AP) -- Bernard Bartzen of San Angelo, Tex., and Budge Patty of Los Angeles swept into the final round of the Naples international tennis tournament, today.

THE most talked about man in the capital today is, next to the President, a junior Senator from Wisconsin named Joseph R. McCarthy. His name arouses deeply felt emotions on the part of seasoned politicians as well as political novices; his face has become familiar to nation-wide audiences, and his methods of political warfare have given a new word to the language.

Local trains on the I. R. T. Seventh Avenue line by-passed the Fiftieth Street Station until 8:10 A. M. on the northbound track and until 12:30 P. M. on the southbound track yesterday as a result of a three-alarm fire in a four-story building at 1627 Broadway shortly after 4:30 A. M.

Your correspondent Meade C. Osborne, writing with reference to George May's "Behind the Curtain in Hungary" (March 15), wonders how it is that the British Broadcasting Corporation has established such a high reputation behind the Iron Curtain for the accuracy and balance of its broadcasts.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11 (AP) -- Harry Byrd, the American League's outstanding rookie in 1952, pitched the Athletics to a 5-1 win over the National League Phillies today in the first tilt of a three-game city series. All six runs were unearned.

The members of the Port Watchmen's Union in the Port of New York have voted two-to-one to ratify a two-year contract with waterfront employers, Louis Waldman, attorney for the union, announced yesterday.
Commodore Pieter H. G. Verhoog ended forty-three years of seafaring yesterday when he retired in Rotterdam as master of the Holland-America Line's flagship Nieuw Amsterdam.

Legislation approved by Governor Dewey last week granting New York's savings banks additional borrowing power permits a "direct approach" to an operating problem previously met by dubious methods. This is the view of top banking observers active in support of the bill signed by the Governor on Monday.

AL SIMMONS hit the home run and angrily threw away his bat. "Whata dope you are," he snarled at himself as he began to circle the bases. "Why didn't you save that homer for when it would do some good instead of wasting it?"

A NUMBER of specialists in parent-child relations continue to decry "the disruptive effects of television on family life" and though such complaints are heard less often now, there is still too much truth in them. Television programs for the young often are unsuitable for them.

THERE is only one world premiere on the schedule of the "American Dance" season which opens at the Alvin Theatre on Tuesday under the auspices of the new B. de Rothschild Foundation, but there are no less than eleven other numbers which are officially to be considered as novelties, inasmuch as they have never been any closer to Broadway than Hunter Auditorium or the Lexington Avenue "Y."

A grant of half a millions dollars to Manhattan College to supplement contributions toward payment of the cost of the new science hall was announced last night by Brother Bonaventure Thomas, president of Manhattan, at the eighty-fourth annual dinner of the College Alumni Society at the Statler Hotel.

JUNIPER GREEN, a well-developed orphan, early discovers in her nature a "dark impulse which she must follow wherever it might lead." It soon leads her (if we may believe Susan Morley's slightly breathless novel) to become a not unwilling hostage aboard the warship of John Paul Jones, who is raiding Scottish waters for the revolutionary United States Navy.

At last week's meeting of the American Physiological Society in Chicago Dr. Jose M. R. Delgado, Yale neurologist, rose to tell about his way of treating mental afflictions by implanting electrodes in the brain and then turning on a feeble current. He has been developing this technique for the past five years.

Confronted with the possibility that private industry would soon be allowed to move into the atomic energy field, private enterprise experts said last week that as much as ten years might elapse before this privilege bore much fruit.

The Home Lines announced yesterday the completion of a highly successful cruise season, during which the liners Atlantic and Italia carried a total of 3,923 passengers from New York and New Orleans to the West Indies.

Back in 1933, in the depths of the great depression, it was not unusual for a person graduating from college to enter a field totally unrelated to that for which he or she had studied. This was particularly true of those who came from middle income or poorer families and who couldn't afford to wait for things to open up in their chosen fields.

THE author of this skit is "a famed London dealer in Wedgwood china." By coincidence, the narrator of "Make Me an Offer" is a London dealer in Wedgwood china who has a wide acquaintance in his craft. The story he relates is probably the first work since John Keats' in which the heroine is a piece of crockery.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 11 -Recent chemical discoveries suggest for the first time that the most common and deadly form of artery ailment is not an unalterable consequence of aging and it may be minimized or prevented in the future, it was reported here today at the annual meeting of the American Heart Association.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- Robert L. Johnson, the new chief of the nation's overseas information service, has charted this course for Voice of America broadcasts to Iron Curtain countries:

WASHINGTON, April 11 (UP) -- The Federation of American Scientists and a leader of a union of the Congress of Industrial Organizations demanded today prompt action by President Eisenhower and Congress on the dismissal of Dr. Allen V. Astin as head of the Bureau of Standards.

AFTER many years of laboratory research both here and abroad, I am able to announce my newest beauty miracle. It is called Contour-Lift Film and it can take 10 years off your appearance! Designed to be used both night and day, it is the only cosmetic of its kind that can give you this fabulous 24-hour-a-day beauty lift!

FOR the traveler who is contemplating a trip to France, or who has already been there, or who, for some reason, can only travel there vicariously, I recommend with all the extravagant adjectives at my command, Samuel Chamberlain's "Bouquet de France, An Epicurean Tour of the French Provinces."

CAMDEN, N. J., April 11 -- The Diamond Mariner, named for the Diamond State, Delaware, was launched today at the New York Shipbuilding Corporation's yard here, the twentieth of the Mariner class to be completed.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, promised today to explain to the Senate's Armed Forces Committee early next month his plans for narrowing the mobilization base.

Establishment of a Fordham Law School Advisory Board was announced yesterday by the Very Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, president of Fordham University, at the annual luncheon of the Fordham Law Alumni Association in the Biltmore Hotel.

CAIRO, April 11 -- Hopes have arisen here for an approach to the Anglo-Egyptian talks on the withdrawal of British troops from the Suez Canal Zone on a technical military basis that would bypass issues of principle that are politically explosive in both countries

Although the large sums of money spent by the United States Government to provide adequate fuels for Europe have aided greatly in the immediate post-war recovery program, the problem of supplying the energy needs of that area over a long period to sustain an expanding industrial economy remains substantially unsolved.

PARIS, April 7 -- A pool of rail, road and water transport systems of twenty European countries may be formed before the year is out if studies being pushed by the Marshall Plan Council here are completed and acted upon as planned.

THE monopolistic grip upon spring held by the poets and the young men with their lightly turned fancies is rapidly being broken. For generations the travel business left this season to the esoteric few who saw Paris in April and wrote lyrics and songs about it, and their companions in spirit with time to seek out the distant arbutus and only enough means for one white hyacinth for their souls' good.

ALBANY, April 11 -- Governor Dewey cleared the way today for the first wholesale investigation and reorganization of the state's court system since 1846. He signed a bill creating a temporary state commission of eleven members to report to the Legislature by next Feb. 1 its recommendations for speeding and simplifying justice.

IN spite of the popularity of azaleas, these shrubs are chosen more often by their color than by name. There are several groups which flourish in northern gardens. The color range is spectacular, but some knowledge of their habits of growth enables a home owner to make a more intelligent selection.

IN 1604, Sir Henry Wotton defined an ambassador as "an honest man sent to lie abroad for the good of his country." In 1950, the fictional S. Livingstone Locke, former banker and now Chief of the E. C. A. in Paris, thought that "diplomacy was a matter of selling the other fellow a bill of goods, convincing him that what you wished him to do was to his best interest and profit."

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- More than two months ago the Eisenhower Administration made known that it was devising an internal security program to replace the machinery installed during the Roosevelt and Truman Administrations for dealing with the loyalty of Government employes or applicants for Federal jobs.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- A mounting volume of investment by employes in the concerns for which they work prompted the Securities and Exchange Commission this week to ease its regulations concerning information required of a company for its employe investment issues.

PORTUGAL is issuing two stamps for the fifth centenary of "Princess Sainte Joana" and two for the fiftieth anniversary of the Portuguese Automobile Club. Joana (1452-90) was daughter of King Alfonso V and in 1471 served as regent while he was on an African expedition.

City Council President Rudolph Halley spoke at a testimonial dinner at the Grand Street Boys Club last night, and not once in his talk did he mention either Mayor Impellitteri, Governor Dewey or the transit situation.

VACATIONISTS planning to visit resorts of Florida, southern and southwestern United States, the Caribbean Islands, South America and Europe this spring will be thinking in terms of time rather than distance.

The Secretary General of the United Nations is potentially one of the most influential office-holders in the world. He is elected to office by the General Assembly on the recommendation of the Security Council, for a term of five years at an annual salary of $25,000.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 11 -- The first session of the annual all-club regatta for the sailing dinghies on Long Island Sound was held off the Larchmont Yacht Club today. The competition formerly was called the national class championships, but that designation was dropped because of distance limitations.

The New York Yankees will televise a record number of eighty-five games, including thirteen road contests, this season. The Bombers will also experiment with the efforts of TV by blacking out five home night games.

I have just read Bosley Crowther's "The Three-Dimen sional Riddle" (March 29). Many of his observations on depth and wide-screen films are well founded, with several exceptions, in the opinion of this writer.
DETROIT, April 11 -- Most of the nation's auto manufacturers expect this year to mark the peak of their current defense production effort -- regardless of what happens in Korea.

THE 16-year-old girl who began her journal from only "a wish to record the passing events of my life * * * even if quite unimportant to others" was already afire with longing not to remain unimportant. She was afire to serve those others of her own race, who unlike herself, had been born to slavery.

IF next, after reading this sentence, you were to cast your eye on the extreme right-hand column of the Best Seller List, a glittering may taketh you. Alongside "The Caine Mutiny" entry you will note the figure 104, a sizable statistic out of which qualitatively you can make almost anything you want.

SAN JUAN, P. R. -- In less than a decade America's "down under," Puerto Rico, has become a major vacation resort. This is one result of Operation Bootstrap, an economic assault on island poverty. The sea, beaches, year-round sun, palms and hibiscus were always here, of course.

THE Metropolitan Opera Association completed its sixty-eighth New York season of 1952-53 last night. The company now embarks upon its annual spring tour. which includes seventeen principal cities of the United States and Canada.

BONN, Germany, April 11 -- The results of recent Works Council elections in the Ruhr coal mines have strengthened the opinion, held by many observers, that the Social Democratic party, which opposes Chancellor Konrad Adenauer on all major domestic and foreign issues, may emerge as the leading -- although not necessarily the majority -- party in the general elections scheduled for early next September.

LOS ANGELES -- Although it is heresy in the southwestern credo to admit that the region has seasonal phenomena in common with other parts of the nation, from Santa Barbara, Calif., to Santa Fe, N. M., signs are multiplying of a vernal awakening to a new cycle of the travel, vacation and recreation year.

The Brooklyn Red Cross chapter reiterated yesterday its call for 500 volunteers for community service work, with the greatest need for workers in the blood donor program, Mrs. Walter McCadden, chairman of the chapter's service groups, said that even if peace was concluded in Korea many hospitalized veterans would still need blood.
Four steamship companies announced last week plans for cruises next summer and winter.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- Subcommittee hearings ended today on a Senate proposal to limit the Government's treaty - making power with testimony attacking the United Nations Charter as a "very dangerous treaty."

ELIZABETH, N. J., April 11 -- Police chiefs here and in Asbury Park, N. J., clamped the lid down last night on bingo games and raffles, which have been the traditional support of many charitable institutions.
The Giants' homecoming yesterday was a most happy one. Combing three of Al Lopez' pitchers for ten hits, Leo Durocher's outfit gained a 5-1 victory over the Indians at the Polo Grounds.
MIAMI, April 11 (UP) -- Hal Burrows combined deft passing shots with accurate placements to upset the defender, Vic Seixas, in the semi-finals of the Miami invitation tennis championship today.

The first all-gas turbine commercial vessel in the world, an 18,000 - deadweight - ton British tanker, was ordered recently by the Anglo-Saxon Petroleum Company, Ltd., operator of the British Shell tanker fleet. She is scheduled to be ready for service in 1956.

COMMISSIONS come in the form of a specific order, a definite and often complex assignment. The Louisville Philharmonic Society requested a composition from me involving a speaker as soloist. Recitation with music is nothing new -- it usually fails in the concert hall.
In a front room of the brick building that is Henry Street Settlement, at 265 Henry Street, a 5-year-old boy took up a set of flexible dolls.

Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany Hall, announced yesterday the speakers for the annual dinner of the New York County Democratic Committee to be held next Wednesday evening at the Commodore Hotel.

IT is a cliche of bridge literature that "defense" is the most difficult aspect of the game to master. Authorities find it convenient to agree that "dummy play" is relatively simple and that not even the finer points of bidding are so complex.
WASHINGTON April 11 -- President Eisenhower has invited the Governors of the forty-eight states to attend a special conference here May 4 and 5 for confidential discussions on world problems.
CLEVELAND, April 11 -- Former President Herbert Hoover urged the Federal Government today to "get out of the business of generating and distributing power as soon as possible."

More than 200 regattas for the 1953 season have been approved and sanctioned by the American Power Boat Association and the number may reach close to 300. The A. P. B. A.'s Carl Johnson in his Detroit headquarters has been breaking down the enormous list of race meets into various categories to include inboard regattas, those for outboard hydroplanes, those for stock outboards and the marathons for outboards.

EXHIBITION games not withstanding, the baseball season will get under way officially tomorrow, when Vice President Nixon throws out the first ball at the meeting between the Yankees and the Senators, for the edification of the opening day crowd at Washington and under the critical eyes of the viewers of WPIX in New York.

The events of the past week have, in general, gone along with the recently presented conciliatory policy of the Soviet Union. There has been nothing as startling as the reversal of the whole "doctors' plot" fabrication. Indeed, there have been a few signs of putting on the brakes by Communist spokesmen.

Seven newspaper and radio executives returned here yesterday from a week in Moscow with replies to criticism in some newspapers and magazine that they had unwittingly aided the Communists in promoting the latest. Soviet peace offensive.

Palmer Graham, Associate Dean of New York University's Washington Square College of Arts and Science, who will retire at the end of this semester, received a special citation yesterday from the college's alumni association. Dr. Graham has been at N. Y. U. thirty-three years.

TRENTON, April 11 -- The four principal candidates for the Republican and Democratic party hominations for Governor carried their campaigns into nearly every county this week and for the first time diverted their attention from the issues to indulge in personal attacks on each other.

JAN. 13. A Tass dispatch in the Soviet press stated: "Some time ago agencies of state security discovered a terrorist group of doctors who sought to cut short the lives of active public figures of the Soviet Union through sabotage medical treatment.

LOS ANGELES, April 11 -- Five Los Angeles public school teachers faced possible loss of their jobs as suspected Communist sympathizers and a sixth had resigned as developments in part of hearings of the House Committee on Un-American Activities here that ended this week.

VALIANT and alive and bumptious, a man of this very century -- a "little man" out of "the lower middle class, that great reservoir of English energy, ability and talent" -- Albert Woods makes a natural hero for a mid-century novel.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- It's all there, the Treasury Department said today, all $30,442,415,581.70 of it.

OF all the plants used as a groundcovers none is more universally satisfactory than trailing myrtle or periwinkle (Vinca minor). I have tried it out over a period of years in many different situations, and at the same time have experimented with a variety of other cover plants in similar locations.

THE teachings of Jesus spread steadily in the first century, from person to person, among the wealthy and important and among the poor. How these teachings influenced the life of a young slave is the theme of this new story by the author of "Beggar Boy of Galilee."

Most of our spring bulb flowers came originally from the Mediterranean area, and most of them are of French or Italian breeding. But the tulip goes far back, to Turkey. It was the Turkish gardeners who first collected tulips and selected and cultivated them to something like their present form of beauty.

A two-run homer by Gene Woodling and a two-run single by Phil Rizzuto off Carl Esrkine in the second inning gave the Yankees an edge over the Dodgers at Ebbets Field yesterday and the world champions went on to win, 5 -- 4 -- the fourth time they've beaten their 1952 world series opponents in six meetings this spring.
MOSCOW, April 11 -- Sometimes there is more news in the fact that a newspaper has not published a certain item than that it has. That has been the case in Moscow in recent days.
POCATELLO, Idaho, April 11 (AP) -- Idaho State College win the national intercollegiate boxing championship tonight, scoring their victories in the first six fights in the title round.

IT is hard to realize that a generation of Americans has grown up without ever seeing a circus parade. Ringling's last one was in 1920; smaller outfits gradually dropped theirs in the face of dense city traffic, the effect of heavy wheels on asphalt, and the increasing distance of circus lots from the center of town.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (UP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd predicted today that the Senate's ammunition investigation would lead to a "wholesale reorganization" in the Pentagon.
VINEGAR JOE STILWELL, "the acid-tongued, indomitable, gruff-voiced, kind-hearted old soldier," now takes his proud place in history with the publication of this book.

CHICAGO, April 11 -- More than 1,500 Northwestern University men and women students wielded brooms, mops, paint brushes, shovels and rakes today in a spring clean-up of thirty North Shore and Chicago recreation centers, hospitals, orphanages, homes for the aged and other agencies.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland. April 11 (AP) -- A commission appointed by the International Olympic Committee to study means of reducing the size of the Olympic games has recommended that participation be limited to 5,000 athletes and that the number of officials be reduced proportionately.
GENEVA, April 11 -- The West will get its first chance to see whether the Soviet Union's new peace offensive has any economic counterpart in a meeting opening here Monday.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, April 11 (AP) -- University professors of thirty countries expressed fear today of government suppression, under the guise of national security, of news of their research work.

WHEN Nancy played with her big sister, 9-year-old Marjory, it was the latter who invented all the games and thought up the costumes. Nancy wished that she herself were as imaginative a leader. However, after Nancy showed her reliability and good sense among the kindergarten bead-stringers and later, when the new baby came, the tables turned. It was Marjory who exclaimed. "Nancy, I wish I was just like you!"

WE have often heard of singing mice, but never have we met such a musical mouse as Maestro Petrini, who lived in a forgotten harp case, high up in the attic of the Metropolitan Opera House. Next to his family, Maestro Petrini loved the opera more than anything else in the world and happily earned his daily cheese as page-turner for the prompter.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (UP) -- Many Governors immediately hailed the President's invitation and said they would make "every effort" to attend.

MUNSAN, Korea, Sunday, April 12 -- The United Nations and the Communists settled today on April 20 as the starting date for an exchange of sick and wounded prisoners of the Korean war, after the Reds had turned down an Allied proposal to begin the repatriation earlier.

TOKYO, Sunday, April 12 -- The Communists pressed again yesterday for resumption of full-scale armistice talks in Korea but no answer was forthcoming by this morning from the headquarters of Gen. Mark W. Clark, United Nations commander.

A little more than two years ago a huge old aircraft engine factory at Stratford, Conn., near Bridgeport, stood almost deserted. A few chilled guards and maintenance workers idly watched flocks of barnswallows frolic under the vast roofs that covered 1,500,000 acres of nothing.

ALTHOUGH the current Whitney annual of sculpture, water-colors and drawings seems to be dominated by work in distinctly modern idioms, the museum as usual has included examples of all kinds of contemporary endeavor and at least half of them are fairly representational. There is much work in the various metals and not a little is frankly experimental.

While similar meetings were being held throughout the world in observance of World Health Day, a group of health specialists, educators and interested citizens met here last week at the first conference of the National Citizens' Committee for the World Health Organization.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11 -- With a scorching 44 finish. Pennsylvania defeated Rutgers by half a boat length, after trailing almost the entire distance, to sweep the opening 1953 regatta of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges today on the Schuylkill.

WHEN Marc Blitzstein's opera, "Regina," based on Lillian Hellman's play, "The Little Foxes," came back to the stage at the City Center some days ago and had a thumping triumph, some people were not surprised.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- South American tourist circles look forward to a bumper harvest of United States tourist dollars this year, through a process of steady improvement rather than any sudden development. Ever since the war, the tourist traffic has steadily grown, with more ships becoming available all the time.

Oscar L. Chapman, who was Secretary of the Interior under President Truman, declared here yesterday that proposed legislation to turn tideland oil rights over to individual states would mean an enormous loss to the public and would open the way to giving all Federal lands to the states.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 11 -- Tropical Africa has reached a critical stage in its economic development, United Nations experts reported today in a new regional study of the countries south of the Sahara.

THAT institution of the National Government known as the Cabinet has again become a focus of public interest through the addition to its ranks of a Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare -- especially because the new member of the President's official family is a woman, Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby.
HANOI, Vietnam, April 11 (UP) -- Large Communist forces have infiltrated into Laos and a full-fledged Communist offensive is feared to be imminent, a French military spokesman said tonight.

THE rise of Asian nationalism is widely recognized as a massive, if not the completely controlling, factor in the political-social revolution that is taking place in Asia. The end of the colonial era has left a series of vacuums in the political structure of the Far East.
