ST. LOUIS, April 11 (UP) -- The Browns defeated the Cardinals, 2 -- 0, today in the first of the two-game city series which was called at the end of the fifth inning because of rain.

NEW HAVEN, April 11 -- More than 600 Democrats attended the annual Connecticut Jackson-Jefferson Day dinner at the Hotel Taft tonight and more than $20,000 was raised for the state party treasury. Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana was the chief speaker. Main attention centered on pos-I sible clues to the party's nominee/ for Governor in 1954.
THERE are some plants which are so outstanding and distinguished that they constitute a true garden aristocracy. Star magnolia, tree wistaria and tree peonies are only three examples.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11 -- Business upturn continues into the second quarter in this district, especially in central industrial areas, where employment remains at or near record levels. Retail sales are upward and bank deposits increasing.

MIAMI BEACH -- One of the biggest bargains in vacations is awaiting spring and summer visitors to this South Florida resort, with April arrivals cashing in on the first substantial hotel and apartment rate reductions.

BONN, Germany, April 11 -- Government sources announced today that two more German agents of a Russian-directed espionage network in West Germany had been arrested and that one of the thirty-five persons previously rounded up by the security police had committed suicide.

EXACTLY a century ago Frederick Law Olmsted, a 31-year-old Connecticut-born Yankee, was traveling through the coastal slave states as a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES and sending back the first installments of his admirable series of articles on Southern economy as affected by slavery.

Since 1935 the value of real estate in New York City exempt from local taxes has increased from $4,565,484,911 to $7,000,255,418, or 53.3 per cent, while the value of taxable real estate has gone up from $16,649,771,199 to $19,912,291,020, a gain of 19.5 per cent.

EXCEPT for a short foreword by Justice William O. Douglas and an explanatory preamble, this brief book consists of a compilation of about 300 quotations from writings by or about or talks which the editor had with Justice Brandeis over a period of three years.

TICONDEROGA, N. Y. -- Motorists looking out of car windows this spring and summer will see between New York and Montreal a necklace of forts. They extend from Lake George along the New York shore of Lake Champlain and for thirty miles beside its outflow, the Richelieu River, in the Province of Quebec.

SINCE collecting proverbs is almost as old a custom as making them, Anne Marie Jauss follows an ancient tradition in this picture book, but she brings a sprightly, modern feeling to her portraits of the wolf in sheep's clothing, the early bird, the too-many cooks around the broth pot.

Winding Way Farm, a new name in racing, took the money when its big, black 7-year-old horse Sagittarius inched in front of Mrs. Samuel M. Pistorio's favored Tuscany in the final yards and won by a head in the $23,400 Jamaica Handicap at the Jamaica Race Track yesterday.

WITH a successful winter-cruise season over, the steamship lines are now looking confidently to the coming summer when, according to advance indications, the volume of vacationists bent on taking sea trips to the Caribbean, South America, Hawaii or Alaska will be just as heavy as it was a year ago.
Harness racing in the metropolitan area will begin Wednesday, with more than 20,000 fans expected to attend the opening of the thirty-four-night spring meeting at Yonkers Raceway.

ADDISON FOSTER, of Narberth, Pa., is the equivalent in record collecting of a shellback sailor who sets up his shrouds with deadeyes and lanyards instead of turnbuckles, and yells "Stink pot:" whenever a powerboat goes by.

DAFFODILS are approaching their peak here in the East. Displays in botanical gardens and at commercial nurseries afford an opportunity for gardeners to see new and old varieties of this popular flower.

RICHMOND, Va., April 11 (AP) -- Jordan, an 8-year-old bay gelding owned by James F. McHugh of Wilmington, Del., won the twenty-first running of the Deep Run Hunt Cup steeplechase in course record time here today.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., April 11 -- What it takes to transform a woman into an Ambassador was told today by Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, who will sail on Tuesday to assume charge of the United States Embassy in Rome. She spoke of the Cold War and hot water, of the cramming school for diplomats in Washington, of protocol and pizza pie.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- Senator William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, chairman of the Internal Security subcommittee, said today that it had "overwhelming evidence that there is a small but dangerous group of teachers" who were Communist agents.

BREWSTER, N. Y., April 11 -- The early birds with the worms were the anglers with the heavy creels at the opening of the New York trout season today, and although many were un-rewarded by fish, the bright sun and blue sky provided perfect conditions.

Controller Lazarus Joseph, whose three votes on the Board of Estimate are expected to decide whether the city accepts Governor Dewey's "higher-fare" transit authority, was challenged last night by City Council President Rudolph Halley to make up his mind "firmly and definitely" on the issue.

Concert singers, traditionally, go without sleep in their early years. John C. Bigbee Jr. who makes his New York debut this afternoon at the Carnegie Hall Recital Hall, has managed to keep both eyes as well as his mouth open for so long that he will soon have to take the first real vacation in his life.
MUNSAN, Korea, April 11 (AP) Following is the text of the agreement signed at Panmunjom today on exchanging sick and wounded prisoners:

Every person with humanitarian feeling will welcome the successful conclusion of the negotiation at Panmunjom for the exchange of sick and wounded prisoners. Although the number who will be released by the Communists is disappointingly -- and ominously -- small, we can rejoice over the case of each suffering individual who has this chance to get back to better care in the free world.

ST. LOUIS, April 11 -- Chancellor Arthur Holly Compton of Washington University announced tonight that he would resign in order to devote the next decade to intensive research in the field of "science and its relation to human affairs."

TO a visitor from overseas the London theatre looks like a flourishing institution. There are forty productions currently on West End stages in addition to the random activities of groups that are not basically commercial.

THE question of strawberries versus raspberries was presented to me recently by a neighbor. His garden space was limited and he wondered which of these two he should plant. If the decision had really been mine, I would surely have chosen the strawberries.
A historic plot of land in Jerusalem has been purchased as the future headquarters of the World Academy for Higher Jewish Studies.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 11 -- Navy suffered its first loss of the season today as Army, aided by five infield errors by the midshipmen, defeated the Annapolis nine, 5 -- 4.
The reinforced plastics industry -- maker of such items as light-weight and strong automobile bodies, bathtubs, aircraft parts, washing machine tubs and refrigerator linings -- is growing rapidly.

CHICAGO, April 11 (AP) -- The White Sox unloaded eleven hits off four opposing pitchers, including a home run by Chico Carrasquel, to back up Rookie Mike Fornieles' airtight mound job in blanking the Cubs, 6 -- 0, today at Comiskey Park before 7,800 fans.

CHICAGO, April 11 --A technique that makes it possible to grow human cancers in laboratory animals, expected to lead to a complete change in the methods of testing new chemicals against cancer, has been successfully developed at Memorial Cancer Center in New York City, it was announced here today at the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the American Association for Cancer Research.

An editorial in the Chess Review has now brought into the open serious issues that confront the entire chess world as the time for the new challengers' tournament to select world champion Botvinnik's next title opponent draws near. These issues arise because of the manner in which the Soviet Union today dominates world chess competition.

IT is something like 750 miles from Columbus Circle to Clingman's Dome in the heart of the Great Smokies. Not exactly conducive to a week-end motor jaunt, but this land of mountains which derives its name from the perpetual blue haze which enshrouds it, is much more accessible to New Yorkers than the map would indicate.

EDGINGS are the detail which add finish and distinction to a border or pathway. Annual edgings are especially satisfactory and their list is long and varied enough to please every gardener and to fit every color requirement.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 11 -- Harry Bridges was nominated today to succeed himself as president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, a position he has held for twenty years.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, April 11 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander, who returned yesterday from a four-day inspection of United States atomic bombing bases in French North Africa, is known to be increasingly concerned over a lag in the increase of Allied air power in Europe.

BOSTON, April 11 -- Die-hard followers of the Braves turned out today for the final home-coming of their self-exiled National Leaguers -- and agreed they had kept the right team in Boston as the Red Sox triumphed, 4 to 1.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of upstate New York, called on Congress today to give President Eisenhower far-reaching power to veto individual items in appropriation bills, a power long denied.

If a pleasure boat skipper wants to strut and show off with his starched white outfit like a Fancy Dan when good warm weather and yachting days arrive this summer, he must pay the penalty in April. Whether this penalty is plain fun, easy chores, or hard back-breaking work depends on how seriously the fitting-out program of the early spring overhaul days is taken.

IF you like Colonial romancing, complete with howling Indians, ardent woodsmen and a climax reminiscent of a Pearl White serial, Denton Whitson's feverish first novel deserves immediate attention. It is an expert entertainment of its kind, lurid, amorous and dramatic by turns.

THE 35mm Diax Ia camera, which costs $49.95 with 50mm coated Westar f/3.5 lens, has a number of unusual features for a camera at this price. Introduced by Penn Camera, 126 West Thirty-second Street, the Diax Ia has lens interchangeability; three built-in optical viewfinders for the normal, wide-angle and telephoto lenses; M-X synchronized Compur Rapid shutter with speeds to 1/500th; automatic transport, and other conveniences.

MADRID, April 11 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco today called on the university students of Spain to strengthen national unity, which, he said, was needed more than ever in "these crucial moments to win battles both at home and abroad."

PRINCETON, N. J., April 11 -- A Texas-League single by Jim Reardon in the eighth scored Bill Nolan from third and gave Seton Hall's baseball team a 3-2 triumph over Princeton today at University Field. The loss snapped a three- game winning streak for the Tigers. Their string of consecutive scoreless innings for the opposition was ended at thirty-two.

Income tax laws appear not to deny taxpayers the right of free choice in the selection of the form in which to carry on business. The United States Tax Court has recognized family trusts, created by gifts, as partners, where the trustees actually participated in the management of the partnership.

PENN YAN, N. Y. -- Spring has come to New York's Finger Lakes region. The blossom season is on the way, and the area once again has much to offer the motorist whether he plans to spend a day or a weekend -- or longer -- in this vicinity.
Leaders of the Distributive, Processing and Office Workers, independent, were authorized yesterday to negotiate for re-entry of the union into the ranks of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

The stock market continued to react nervously last week to the prospect of peace in Korea. Unlike the preceding week however, greater resistance to the decline developed as assurances came from many sides insisting that the country does not need a war to prop up its economy.

Your April 5 issue carried a letter from Seymour E. Harris of Harvard criticizing Secretary Humphrey's proposed refunding of United States Government securities at rates determined by the present free market situation. Professor Harris arguments, which I am listing here, do not seem to me to carry conviction.

In his accustomed place in the Book Review the other day J. Donald Adams confessed that whereas once he "could read Homer with enjoyment in the original, and the plays of Euripides * * * that ability had gone with the wind, along with most of my German, my Anglo-Saxon and my Chaucerian English, leaving me with some frayed French and a few odd gobbets of Russian."

Signing a new treaty of amity, commerce and navigation with Japan marks another post-war milestone on the road to normal international relationships. It is especially significant because its predecessor, the Treaty of 1911, became a symbol of those relationships and its abrogation a mark of their rupture.

BERLIN, April 11 -- Charles E. Bohlen's flight to Moscow today as the United States Ambassador was marked by what may have been new Soviet gesture of conciliation, but tonight its meaning was still a mystery.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (UP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell on plans to abolish the Justice Department's Customs Division to promote "efficiency and economy," it was disclosed today.

VIENNA, April 11 -- Roy Marcus Cohn and Gerard David Schine, special representatives of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, made it obvious today that they would depend partly on critical Austrian sources for their evaluation of the United States propaganda program in Austria.
TOKYO, April 11 -- The race by Japanese politicians for the support of this nation's 46,000,000 voters entered the homestretch today.

" TAKE a map of London and mark off a rectangle with Bond Street, Brook Street, Park Lane and Piccadilly as the four sides, and you will find that inside that rectangle, sex is different from anywhere else. DOWN the street, Peter Pan, in his Disneyan manifestation, was skylarking again. But, with characteristic ubiquity, he also materialized, one recent afternoon, in a small white bungalow in the heart of Hollywood, at the head of a whole procession of kindred spirits and memories.

IN the northeastern states, an apricot tree in the home garden or the home orchard is a rarity. Because an apricot tree flowers early, late frost more often than not ruins bloom and, of course, fruit.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti -- A new Haiti is in the making. Basic to its development is the Artibonite Valley project which, irrigating thousands of acres once subject to drought and flood, will raise living standards throughout the country.

THIS collection of twelve saltwater tales is a sampler of rescues, wrecks, storms, mutiny. South Sea adventure, plus a delightfully slap-happy interlude, Paschal N. Strong's "The Terror of Buccaneer Bay." As is often the case in anthologies, some excerpts from books suffer without the context.

THERE is a pleasant, nonsensical notion -- it exists mainly in movie scenarios -- that stars are born overnight. Real life offers very little to support such a notion, but you might like to consider a perky, fresh-faced girl named Helen Gallagher, whose rise to fame has been remarkably rapid, if not strictly in the overnight category.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 11 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of West Germany declared today that his country would refuse to end its participation in the European Defense Community regardless of what tempting concessions the Soviet Union might offer.

The Metropolitan Opera Company, which completed its sixty-eighth local season with last night's performance of "Carmen," will leave Grand Central Terminal this morning at 9:10 in two passenger and two freight trains for a seven-week tour covering 7,586 miles.

WASHINGTON, April 11 --President Eisenhower heard impersonated members of his Cabinet tell the story of their transformation from "riches to rags" tonight while they sat around a can of Mulligan stew.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (UP) -- President Eisenhower was reported today to be studying a new plan that would take from the State Department all overseas information programs and the Point Four program of technical aid for underdeveloped countries.

A CURIOUS thing about some tourists was expressed best, perhaps, by the Colonel Blimp who said: "Paris is a jolly good place, but there are too many foreigners around." There's another curious thing: some Americans in Europe always seem to be in constant search for (a) hotels like American hotels; (b) transportation like American transportation and (c) a martini like an American martini (and not like a European martini which is sweet, dark and undrinkable).

BOSTON -- New England in early spring is a combination of skiing the headwall of Tuckerman's Ravine, stepping gingerly across the low sections of golf courses, whipping a trout rod in icy streams and scraping and painting the hulls and topsides of motor and sail boats.

BONN, April 11 -- Germany, the key to Europe and to the great struggle between the United States and Soviet Russia for the political loyalties of the peoples west of the Soviet frontier, lay quiet under the first suns of spring this week while the cold intellects of the Kremlin prepared to focus their European peace campaign upon the issue of the Germans' future.

KINGSTON -- Discovered by Columbus in 1494 and, as the Jamaicans now say, rediscovered by Winston Churchill in 1953, Jamaica is the boom resort of the West Indies. The credit given to Mr. Churchill for the rediscovery of this island of loveliness is not fully deserved.

CHICAGO, April 11 -- Business activity in the Chicago area continued at a fast pace as first quarter reports gave rise to optimism. The monthly survey by the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago indicated improvement in production during March.

TOMORROW, Shirley Booth, this year's winner of the Antoinette Perry Award for her outstanding performance in Arthur Laurents' "The Time of the Cuckoo," at the Empire, as well as the 1952 Motion Picture Academy Award for her Lola in "Come Back, Little Sheba," will be a guest of honor at the monthly luncheon tendered by the Drama Desk, that organization of theatre reporters and editors.

BAYONNE, N. J., April 11 -- Battle-worn colors that flew over the ranks of the Blue and the Gray at the battle of Antietam, ninety years ago in one of the bloodiest conflicts of the Civil War, were presented today to the officers and crew of the Navy's aircraft carrier that bears the name and the heroic tradition of the battle.
SEATTLE, April 11 (AP) -- A Federal court of three judges upheld today the constitutionality of the new McCarran-Walter Immigration Act.

AMATEUR groups which have been attracted to the picture story theme as a competition idea will find stimulation and helpful advice in the instructions to the jury in the eastern regional judging of the University of Missouri School of Journalism's Tenth Annual Picture competition, held here recently.

MEXICO CITY -- Three requisites -- an automobile, ample time, and a taste that prefers colorful sights and sounds to shiny luxury -- can easily substitute for a large budget on a Mexican holiday. Given these essentials, there is no need to scrimp on comfort or cleanliness or to make the tour any less complete than available vacation time allows.
MOSCOW, April 11 -- Posters dedicated to the great Soviet May Day holiday were placed on sale today in bookstores and Stationery stores all over Moscow.

A survey of the heavens by Ohio State University's radio telescope has located dozens of "new" radio stars and is expected to reveal hundreds more, reports Dr. John D. Kraus. Radio stars are distant objects which emit radio waves that can be detected by means of a suitable radio receiver.

Just a line to express appreciation of Drew Middleton's "Then and Now" on Dr. Hugo Eckener (March 22). As we gave Dr. Eckener an award in 1936 for his distinguished services, we are particularly happy to note that his efforts in the field of aviation are appreciated even at this late date.

NOW something new is about to be added to the animated film form. Edward Nassour, the independent producer, has developed an amazingly life-like style in animation. Mr. Nassour, who has worked on the invention for seventeen years, will introduce it in "Ring Around Saturn," a full-length feature concerning the adventures of a little Mexican boy and a bull to be released by United Artists in the fall.

IT all began simply enough when the bugs started chewing on the apple trees and rose bushes, and an arsenate of lead spray was recommended as a control. Later somebody found that good old bordeaux mixture (copper) controlled blight.

And when they do reach Europe by plane or ship, they go about their holiday traveling by train, plane or bus.

CAROLINE GORDON'S review of the two books on Willa Cather ("Willa Cather," by E. K. Brown and Leon Edel; "Willa Cather Living," by Edith Lewis) is an example of "new critical" punditry at its worst. Why all this concern because Willa Cather was neither Henry James nor James Joyce. and hence refrained from "using a single consciousness as a prism for moral reflection"?
TRENTON, April 11 (UP) -- Thousands of anglers beat the sun to day as they went out in fair weather to the lakes and streams for the opening of the 1953 trout season.

A ROSE bush as it comes from the nurseryman is really a two-part plant, consisting of the understock and the bud or scion. The understock supplies the root system, while the bud supplies the top growth of stems (canes) and flowering branches. Occasionally, however, a rose bush sends up sucker growth.

HAMILTON -- Thousands of visitors have invaded Bermuda for the Easter season and with the assurance of solid business through the summer months, this travel-conscious Colony is already laying plans for the formal state visit that Queen Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh will make here on Nov. 24.

MONTREAL -- The roads to Montreal and Quebec lope through the lovely farmlands and hardwood forests of the eastern townships. There are temptations just to stay there, east of the Richelieu River, where it is very beautiful when the orchards bloom and the bees are busy making honey.

The Eisenhower Administration has decided to let private enterprise develop atomic power, provided Congress can be persuaded to amend the Atomic Energy Act. First steps in this direction were taken under President Truman last year. The National Security Resources Board recommended a change in the act so that the Atomic Energy Commission would no longer monopolize every aspect of atomic energy.

Rabbi David de Sola Pool of the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, Central Park West and Seventieth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning that "because we in the United States of America know so fully the blessings of freedom, we must be exemplars to the world."
MOST fantasy, today, is apt to take the form of science-fiction or the horror tale. It is good to see an artist of Elizabeth Coatsworth's stature take up the fantasy as an instrument of beauty.

A 3-year-old girl and a 46-year-old woman were killed yesterday when they were thrown from an automobile that went wild after collision with another car in New Dorp, Staten Island.

GLUCK: Concerto for Flute and Orchestra in G major; HAYDN: Toy Symphony; CORELLI: Concerto for oboe and strings; Rene Leibowitz conducting the Paris Philharmonic (Oceanic). Endearing works excellently recorded.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 11 -- A greater interchange of trade among Latin American nations instead of loans is recommended in a report presented by Raul Probitsch, executive secretary of the Latin American Economic Conference.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, Administrator of the Federal Security Agency, took the oath of office today before President Eisenhower and became the first Secretary of the new Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- The International Wheat Council announced today guaranteed quotas totaling 595,542,052 bushels annually that would be assigned to participating members in the event that a new three-year agreement was put into force. This figure is the total of sales by four exporting nations to the others.

EIGHTEEN months ago David and Benjamin Buchan, just 6 and rising 5, were demure little Londoners, typical residents of the quiet Kensington Street in which they lived. They wore white starched shirts and neatly pressed shorts, smart tweed overcoats, and on their heads a sort of tweed deerstalker.

IN perhaps no culture has organized sport become as important as in our own. Like the weather, we may like or dislike this but cannot ignore it. Until recently athletics have never found the proper writers, men who know intimately the complicated details of indigenous games and can place them in context, understanding clearly their part in American life.

A costly four-day wildcat strike of members of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen on the Union Railroad, a United States Steel Corporation subsidiary, has ended on a constructive note; perhaps we should say potentially constructive, for its outcome depends upon how the rank and file of union members react to it in future.

TWENTY-SEVEN years ago this week the newly organized Book-of-the-Month Club was hopefully distributing its first selection: "Lolly Willowes," by Sylvia Townsend Warner. A major revolution in the book industry, the full import and future development of which were at the time hardly apparent, had got under way.

The Treasury will open subscription books tomorrow on an offering for cash of $1,000,000,000 of thirty-year 3 1/4 per cent fully marketable bonds, the first long-term issue of this kind since the war.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Seeking a more compact form of dealing with the nation's war mobilization problems, President Eisenhower has asked Congress to put the Office of Defense Mobilization on a permanent basis.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The United States has withdrawn for reconsideration its proposal to the International Joint Commission for construction of the $300,000,000 Libby Dam in Montana.

ONLY the clowns, the elephants, the jungle demons and the showgirls in the pageant-like "specs" of the Circus let up after their winter training in Sarasota, Fla., and rely on the "two-a-day" shows to keep them in trim. The others -- aerialists, trapeze, slack and high-wire artists, acrobats, contortionists, roller skaters, cyclists, trampolinists and jugglers -- must practice daily lest muscles stiffen or splitsecond timing falter.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11 -- Once again Ben Hogan demonstrated his golfing skill today by scoring a 66 in the third round of the Masters tournament to extend his lead to four strokes.

Favorable Easter business encouraged store executives throughout the country. Orders were received in the wholesale markets here last week for organzas, chiffons and marquisettes for midsummer dress selling in dark sheers.

The area's department stores last week were under a double handicap in any attempt to meet the sales volume figures of the same 1952 week. The latest week. which followed Easter, had to compare with the final week of Easter shopping in 1952.

SWEDES, no less than other Europeans, have visited America and written books on their travels. Now to the accounts of Peter Kalm and Frederika Bremer, both well known and long available, must be added the hitherto forgotten "America" of Axel Klinkowstrom.
A youth gang skirmish in the Bronx Friday night ended with the arrest yesterday of thirteen members of two gangs from Harlem and the Bronx, which averted a bloody war between the rivals.

THIS, the second guide to the complexities of the bullring to be published within a few months, is also about the best yet in English. John Marks is a distinguished British newspaper correspondent who has been watching the corrida, mostly in Spain, for a generation.

AN easy-to-read adventure story, this gives an unhackneyed picture of the fur trade in the days when Oregon Territory, from California to Alaska, was held jointly by the United States and Great Britain and administered by the Hudson's Bay Company.

THE low-growing plants which are classed as groundcovers are a timesaving group for gardeners. By their use up-keep is reduced and appearance improved on difficult sites such as under a tree where grass will not grow, on a bank which would be difficult to mow or on a barren area where weeds would take over.

Young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons, including Mrs. Albert Perry-Miller and Miss Iris Miller, are serving on the entertainment committee for the annual spring frolic and tea dance for the benefit of the Humane Society of New York to be held on Friday afternoon in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

The New York City Opera Company presented "Madams Butterfly" at the City Center yesterday afternoon, with Walter Fredericks singing Pinkerton for the first time. Edith Evans, who was to have sung her first Suzuki, was ill and was replaced by Mary Kreste.

THERE has never been so much commotion over the freedom of the scholar or the educator as there is in this country today. In the past there has indeed been less, much less, academic freedom -- for in the ages of authority it was at best a very limited affair.

HELSINKI, Finland, April 11 (Reuters) -- The Constitutional Committee of the Finnish Parliament today decided to impeach four former Socialist Cabinet Ministers for fraudulently arranging a state loan of $11,200,000 to a bankrupt company.
MANILA, April 11 -- Selective softening of the Soviet line and the emergence of specific Chinese Communist armistice moves in Korea have produced varying reactions throughout this area.

Press conferences fall into three general categories. There is the "on-the-record" conference in which the person holding it wants and expects to be quoted. There is the "off-the- record" conference in which matters discussed are not supposed to be published in any shape or form.

BUENOS AIRES, April 11 -- Early this week in a bitter address to the nation President Juan Peron declared that one of the country's biggest industries was the production of rumors. The rumor factories, which received a fresh batch of raw material from the unexpected Cabinet meeting last evening, were still operating full blast today.
JACKSONVILLE -- Something new is being added to widen the popular appeal of the Florida spring and summer package tour -- a combination of airplane and automobile trip.
CALMER second-thoughts on the near-term effects of Korean developments replaced exaggerated fears in business circles last week. Steadier undertones were evident in securities and commodities.
ALEXANDER Lindey was quoted by David Dempsey in "In and Out of Books" as saying. "You don't need the copyright owner's permission to quote songs."

THE trees and the flowers that bloom in the spring act like a magnet on the motorist, drawing him out into the country where, peering between the vehicles of other motorists similarly inspired, he can get a view of the world of nature renewing itself.

The Atomic Energy Commission is enlarging the Pacific proving ground in the Marshall Islands to include Bikini as well as Eniwetok atoll. Bikini lies some 180 miles to the eastward of Eniwetok. It was last used in 1946 to test military effects of A-bombs.

IN St. Matthew's church in Northampton, England, Graham Sutherland's "Crucifixion" and Henry Moore's "Mother and Child" confront each other. These two English artists share billing here in an exhibition at the Institute of Contemporary Art, which will travel extensively.

S.S. VAN DINE'S daughter is a Little Theatre director; Ellery Queen's is a dancer; E. C. Bentley's son is by profession an illustrator and caricaturist (though he has turned out a couple of mysteries as a sideline); and the sons of Conan Doyle are by profession the sons of Conan Doyle.

MONTREAL, April 11 (UP) -- Returning to peak form with Milt Schmidt in action again, the Boston Bruins walloped the Montreal Canadiens, 4 -- 1, tonight to square the Stanley Cup finals at one game apiece.
Wagner College opened its Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference season with a 9-3 victory over previously unbeaten Brooklyn College at the loser's field yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 11 -- Yugoslavia is preparing to permit comparatively broad emigration for the first time since Marshal Tito's Government assumed power at the end of World War II. In addition, under regulations that have been quietly issued, Yugoslavs may now apply for passports for tourist purposes.

WASHINGTON, April 11-- The affair of Dr. Allen V. Astin, forced to resign two weeks ago as director of the National Bureau of Standards, has mushroomed into one of the most embarrassing political incidents the Eisenhower Administration has yet faced.

OTTIGA, a Michigan otter is shown here from his babyhood in a white pine stump to maturity. Mr. Liers describe the otter's nomadic wanderings with the detail and accuracy which made "Beaver Valley" (on which he worked as technical adviser) an exceptional documentary film.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 11 (UP) -- Louise Suggs, untroubled by a brisk wind and the tension of a duel with Patty Berg, gained the first-round lead in the Phoenix lap of the women's professional Weathervane open golf tournament today with a 4-under-par 72.

Despite stresses of the Korean war, rearmament and a resurge of inflation in the last two years, there has been a gradual revival of conservative financial policy in many countries. And among encouraging results of this trend is the opportunity it presents for restoring that essential characteristic of a strong world economy -- convertibility of curriencies.
PARIS, April 11 -- The French municipal election campaign, in which city councils will be elected April 26 and May 3 in nearly 38,000 localities, opened officially today.

When Patrolman Edward Pisano, who captains Police Launch 8 in Sheepshead Bay, reported for duty yesterday, he alerted his two-man crew to be on the lookout for possible trouble. It was, after all, the first real nice Saturday since the advent of spring and Brooklyn's amateur yachtsmen were expected to turn out en masse.

Householders with thoughts of spring refurbishing may well, with fortune, find the answer to this seasonal urge among the hundreds of pieces of furniture, paintings and prints and assorted decorative items that flow into the auction market weekly.

DANNY was 8 or 9 years old that summer, and he lived in a small town in upstate New York. Looking back now from the vantage point of maturity, Daniel Nathan thinks of that summer as a wonderful time and he writes of it with gusto and frank nostalgia. What Danny did that summer constitutes his story.

FORETHOUGHT and foresight are required if motorists wish to get the full measure of enjoyment and recreation out of a vacation. Both apply to the driver and car, and will help avoid discomfort and even accidents on the highways.

A 17-year-old boy rider wrestled valiantly for four hours yesterday to save his mud-frightened horse as it sank slowly to its death in a Canarsie marsh. Mechanized police, with trucks, gadgets and even a helicopter, stood by helplessly.

Why has Russia switched her line? This is the question that increases in depth and mystery day by day. The answer, if it can be had, may be the clue to both the immediate and the long-range future of the world. Whatever their motives, the Russians' peaceful gestures toward the West Continued last week.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 11 -- In the five weeks since Premier Stalin died the Soviet Union has embarked on a formidable attempt to bring about by conciliatory gestures -- perhaps some of them will turn out to be deeds as well -- what it had failed to accomplish with every sort of provocative action during the six years of the "cold war."

NEWARK, April 11 -- Mayor Ralph A. Villani denied today charges in a grand jury presentment that he and other officials in the Department of Parks and Public Property, of which he is director, had received money from employes "as salary kickbacks or payment for promotions."
Not since prohibition has the liquor industry been beset by so many problems. Four of them are the following.

I sorely missed a word about Vienna's famous amusement park, Prater, in Phyllis McGinley's enchanting article, "Carrousels! Spring!" (March 29), where some fifty merry-go-rounds and additional attractions, set against the green background of the park, created a real dreamland for children.

FACED with a fight against voodoo, leprosy, pellagra, flood, hurricane, corrupt local government and the inflexible social conventions of an aristocratic society in a changing world, the doughty protagonist of this Louisiana romance proves himself up to snuff in every department and battles his way through storm and swamp to self-respect and personal happiness.
CHICAGO, April 11 -- State Auditor Orville E. Hodge closed three Chicago area banks today for "examination and readjustment."

A live hand grenade was casually handed about in the police information booth in the middle of Times Square yesterday while the booth was crowded with policemen and the street outside was thronged with Saturday matinee-goers.

With the American League offering its mighty Yankees in a bid for a record fifth straight pennant victory and the National coming to the mark with a territorial realignment that brings Milwaukee into the picture in an equally astonishing move, major league baseball gets off the mark this week with an unusual amount of fanfare.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Spring is the time to grubproof the lawn against Japanese beetles. Applications of chlordane or other chemicals and of fertilizers should be completed as soon as possible. Before or after these treatments, rake the lawn for the sake of its appearance, and in the process remove dead crabgrass as well as debris. Seed any thin spots with grass or clover.

HAVANA, April 11 (AP) -- Cubans, worried about their chances/ of selling this year's sugar crop, got eneourg'ing news today fromI two sources. Washington at,-I nouneed it was buying an addi-I tiona 96,000 tons of Cuban sugar/ this year. And President Batista/ said in an interview that "pros-/ pects for our sugar industry, de- spite the congestion of the world[ market, could not be better" . .
The pot was calling the kettle black last week in testimony before Congress as the Senate Armed Services subcommittee continued its investigation of ammunition shortages in Korea.

With their exports of cotton textiles falling 25 per cent in 1952, the leading textile manufacturers of Japan will curtail expansion of cotton production facilities and diversify their output to include synthetics and non-textile products.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 11 -- Crown Prince Akihito was welcomed to the United States mainland today as the first member of the Japanese royal family to leave his country since World War II.

Encouraging musical talent is one of the chief functions of the National Federation of Music Clubs, and yesterday both first and second hand evidence of this aspect of the work of the nationwide group was brought before the delegates assembled at the Roosevelt Hotel for the federation's twenty-seventh biennial convention.

At the fourth in a series of free art lectures at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, Charles E. Tilton, architect, will discuss "The Human Side of Architecture" on Tuesday at 6:15 P. M.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The United States Government, the greatest buyer and storer of butter in the world, is seeing to it that the school children of the nation are benefiting from its purchases of this product.

AN automatic flash calculating and setting device is the novel feature of the latest Bolsey 35mm cameras, the B-22 Set-O-Matic and the C-22 Set-O-Matic twin-lens rangefinder-reflex, introduced here last week by Bolsey Corporation of America.

CLEARWATER, Fla. -- Sightseeing by automobile in peninsular Florida is principally confined to six U. S. highways and Route A1A. The greatest sight-seeing road of all is U. S. 1, with its paralleling Route A1A. Lining these highways are thick forests of "attractions"; wherever nature or history has short-changed an area, promoters have developed man-made sights instead.

Although their earning assets have declined since the end of 1952, leading commercial banks in New York City earned more in the first quarter than in the corresponding period of last year, according to recently published condition statements of the institutions for March 31.

DRAWING on his own extensive experience in European auto racing. Hans Ruesch, author of "Top of the World," gives in "The Racer" a convincing and sometimes wildly exciting picture of this demanding sport and of those who devote, and sometimes sacrifice, their lives to it.

WHENEVER a play by Shakespeare or a classic revival is produced on Broadway, there is gnashing of teeth, both critical and general, over the speech of the actors. Not only, it is claimed, is the articulation poor and undistinguished -- but there also is a lack of feeling for style.

Deductions and exemptions permitted under state and Federal income tax laws differ in a number of important particulars, the State Tax Commission warned yesterday. Its admonition was designed to help those using their Federal returns as the basis for preparing state returns. These must be filed or placed in the mail before midnight Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (UP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced an agreement today under which two concerns serving the utilities industry will make a study aimed at industrial production of atomic power in "the next few years."

Growing awareness of, and concern about, the problem of educating the children of migrant farm workers in many communities has been disclosed in the first half of an eighteen-month study of migrant education being conducted by the National Council on Agricultural Life and Labor.

SPRING may have been little apparent elsewhere recently but it is bursting out at Wildenstein's in a large and important exhibition of French paintings from the middle of the 16th century down to about 1914. For the School of Fontainebleau, nature could only be tolerated when fantastically adorned, as she is here in the pictures, by Caron and his circle, of fetes at the Valois court, possibly the most unnatural outdoor scenes ever painted.

BEAUMONT, Tex., April 11 -- Physicians disclosed today that Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias was suffering from a serious malignancy and that they would try to save her life and athletic career with a major operation.

Columbia University will offer 1,000 courses in its fifty-fourth annual session, starting July 6. Continuing a trend of previous years, an increasing number of summer courses will be given at night. The summer program also will provide intensive instruction in major foreign languages.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- President Eisenhower, by proxy, has been engaged this week in the opening skirmishes of a legislative battle, the outcome of which may materially affect the constitutional balance of powers in the conduct of foreign relations of the United States.
STILLWATER, Minn., April 11 (UP) -- A day-long riot at Stillwater State Prison abated tonight after surly convicts had smashed windows, ripped mattresses and hurled debris into the prison yard.

Recent squabbles in Washington over the Council of Economic Advisers created by the Employment Act of 1946 -- the legislation that commits the United States to policies tending toward full employment -- and the appointment of Dr. Arthur F. Burns to head a new Eisenhower economic team have given emphasis to the current debate on economic planning and the tools developed to make it possible.

London is the manufacturing firm, the performers (Orchestre de la Suisse Romande and the Motet Choir of Geneva, under Ernest Ansermet) are Swiss and the music is French.
The "Reading Is Fun" festival of children's books, an exhibit that has been seen by 12,000 pupils here, will move to the County Center in White Plains tomorrow continuing through next Sunday.

A DELUGE of letters being received at Washington suggests to postal officials that an organized campaign is in progress to induce the Post Office Department to place "In God We Trust" on all future United States stamps.

DEFINITIONS are a nuisance but they prevent misunderstandings. When E. M. Forster wrote a book on the novel, he accepted a French definition of it as "a prose fiction of a certain length" which was incontrovertible, like saying it was written on paper, but not very helpful, as it implied that practically everything "of a certain length" was a novel and consequently that there was nothing useful to be said about it.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, said today the free world must not be lulled into lowering its military guard by possibly false. Russian peace moves or an unstable truce in Korea.

An ingenious ambulance relay system was set into motion yesterday to speed a crippled 8-month-old girl from Knoxville, Tenn., to an orthopedic hospital in Brooklyn. The infant, whose arms and legs are in plaster casts, left Knoxville at 5 A. M. and arrived at St. Charles Hospital at midnight.

Women headed by Mrs. Edwin S. Webster Jr., as chairman, and Mrs. Jay Downer and Mrs. J. Baird Magnus, vice chairman, are aiding in furthering the sale of tickets for the performance of "My 3 Angels" on Friday night at the Morosco Theatre, which has been taken over for the benefit of the Children's Village.

ACCORDING to all the laws of logic and common sense, the obvious choice for the National League pennant is Brooklyn. However, this selector doesn't always act logically or sensibly in his annual eeny-meeny-miney-mo appraisal of the major league teams. The embarrassing part about it is that this represents too much newsprint to devour when he has to eat his words in October.

MOSCOW, April 11 -- Charles E. Bohlen, the new United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, arrived in Moscow by plane from Berlin late today and said he would carry out the normal functions of a United States plenipotentiary.

MANILA, April 11 -- More than 800 delegates of the Nacionalista party, now the minority party in the Philippines, are scheduled to convene here tomorrow to nominate a candidate for next November's Presidential election. The Nacionalistas are seeking to displace the Liberals, the party of President Elpidio Quirino.

PARIS, April 11 -- For the first time since Soviet Russia became the dominant power in both Europe and Asia, the democratic world finds itself confronted by Moscow's application of a strategy of peace. To governmental systems which depend for every political move on popular support this presents problems of a new and delicate nature.

SEOUL, Korea, April 11 -- Dr. Syngman Rhee, President of the Republic of Korea, said today that the necessary key to any satisfactory solution of the Korean problem must lie in the withdrawal of the Chinese forces from Korea. "That will be the actual end of the war as far as we are concerned," he said.

NO one should ever publish a book until he has read it aloud to a woman. . . . Women are the arbiters of words, and we should listen to them because they live close to the meanings of words. Men become infatuated with words themselves.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy asked Harold E. Stassen, Mutual Security Administrator, today to assure Greek shipowners operating out of London that removal of their vessels from trade with Communist China "would in your opinion have the wholehearted approval of our Government."

TOLEDO, April 11 (AP) -- Two defending champions repeated tonight in the National Amateur Athletic Union wrestling championships Members of the United States Olympic team also excelled in the finals at Toledo University.

ADVOCATES of strategic bombing will find an aggressive champion in this retired ground force general who maintains that our national defense effort is being weakened by a misplaced emphasis on ground forces.

IN spring the wild flower corner shelters the delicate, pastel blossoms of such all-time favorites as trillium, dutchman's breeches and lady's slipper -- names almost synonymous with the magic of this season when plant awaken after winter dormancy.

MONKTON, Md., April 11 (AP) -- Philstar, the favorite, won the My Lady's Manor Steeplechase over eighteen fences for the second straight time today and Stuart S. Janney Jr., the winning owner, seemed well on the way to a new domination of Maryland's point-to-point racing.

Seventy-two delegates from eighteen New York high schools will join Hunter College students in the college's ninth annual Model Congress on Friday and Saturday at Hunter College, Sixty - eighth Street and Park Avenue.

TRENTON -- Sun-seeking visitors to the New Jersey shore this spring will be greeted by a number of innovations, principal among them being the emergence of large motels in Atlantic City, which has heretofore shred away from such facilities.
Three persons -- an elderly man, a woman and a child -- were killed yesterday in three separate accidents in Queens.

London is the manufacturing firm, the performers (Orchestre de la Suisse Romande and the Motet Choir of Geneva, under Ernest Ansermet) are Swiss and the music is French.

One of America's largest underwriters of property insurance, the Home Insurance Company, celebrates its one hundredth anniversary today. Commencing operations in the directors' room of a Manhattan banking establishment on April 13, 1853, the company was organized by forty-five of New York City's leading merchants and financiers, many of whom had long felt the need for a new fire insurance enterprise that would provide protection on a nation-wide scale.

The fires of the "hot-stove" league are dying out. The coals that were kept glowing all winter by the hurt and anger of disappointed fans are charred and scattered. The gaps between what might have been, what could be and what will be are narrowing. Forgotten are the batting slumps, strikeouts in the clutch and fielding boners. Another season is upon us.

Most of the citizenry of New York may be occupied at this time of year with birds, flowers and other pleasant aspects of spring, but for the members of the Department of Insects and Spiders at the American Museum of Natural History, the season means just one insect after the other.

Prime Minister Nehru has announced that India's twenty-eighth state, Andhra, will be proclaimed and inaugurated on Oct. 1. Most of the state will come out of what is now Madras, with some areas also coming from the former Princely State of Mysore.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Warren G. Harding, after his election as President in 1920, confided that he wanted Albert B. Fall, who was later sent to jail following the "Teapot Dome" scandal, to be Secretary of State rather than Charles Evans Hughes.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- President Eisenhower, in a dramatic bid for greater hemispheric solidarity, announced today that he had named his brother, Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, to be his personal representative on a goodwill and fact-finding mission to Latin America.
The greatest source of faith is the Bible, where "faith was hammered out on the hard anvil of doubt," the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, minister emeritus of Riverside Church, declared yesterday.

AUSTIN, Tex., April 12 (AP) -- Jim Kimberly of Chicago, hitting 145 miles an hour on the straight-ways and averaging 86.1, won the featured 200-mile event at the national Sports Car Club of America races today before a crowd of 35,000. The races are amateur, with no cash prizes.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 12 (AP) -- Hungary's Communist-led People's Front hinted today that an amnesty might be declared for those who had committed "mistakes" against the regime.

TOKYO, Monday, April 13 -United Nations and Communist staff officers completed an agreement at Panmunjom, Korea, today on details for an exchange of sick and wounded prisoners of the Korean war beginning next Monday.

Cotton prices in the domestic market again moved within a narrow trading range last week. Final quotations in the futures market on Friday showed net changes of 30 cents a bale lower to 30 cents higher for the five-day trading session on the New York Cotton Exchange.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12 -Job-site arbitration along the Delaware riverfront, once plagued by turbulent labor-management relations, was credited today with bringing new prestige, employment stability and prospects of added business to the port of Philadelphia.

ST. LOUIS, April 12 -- The National Council of Catholic Men ended its thirty-third annual convention today by calling for legislation to admit additional numbers of refugees and expelled and displaced persons to this country on a nonquota basis.

BOSTON, April 12 (AP) -- The end of a onetime glorious National League era came for Boston today as its Milwaukee-shifted Braves beat the Red Sox, 4 -- 1, in the final of the cross-country "city" series.

The Du Mont Television Network, which often makes up in ingenuity what it may lack in production budgets, presents on Friday nights a program called "Dark of the Night." As a dramatic program it is often very weak and uneven but nonetheless it is an altogether worth-while experiment with several good lessons for video as a whole.

The Hotel and Restaurant Employes sand Bartenders International Union, A. F. L., announced yesterday that it would pay special tribute to the United Nations at its general convention, April 20-23, in Atlantic City.
Ernest H. Peabody, a man who counts automobile horn blasts, says it doesn't surprise him that the city's citizens have to count sheep.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12 -- Using children "to meet our own needs," worrying about what "other people think of us," misusing parental control, setting unattainable goals and overdoing "the necessity to be right" comprise some of the major threats to security, Dr. Howard A. Lane declared here yesterday.

It appears that the world is to enjoy a period of comparative peace because a relaxation of tension suits the convenience of the Soviet Government. For the past two or three weeks Governments and the press in other countries have talked of nothing else but the change of tactics in the Kremlin.

The Rev. Dr. L. Wendell Fifield declared in his sermon yesterday at the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, Hicks and Orange Streets, Brooklyn, that "the financial bankruptcy of this city" stemmed from the "moral bankruptcy that exists in this community."

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., April 12 (AP) -- On the eighth anniversary of the death of Franklin D. Roosevelt one of his secretaries said that it was not the Yalta and Potsdam agreements but their ruthless violations by the Russians that had bred the present world crisis.

HEIDELBERG TOWER, a curious little-known monument to mortal folly, stands nineteen stories high directly south of Times Tower in Times Square. Dreamy Missourians spent $400,000 on it in 1910 thinking they'd get rich renting its outer walls for space for electric signs -- for that, and nothing more.

TOKYO, Monday, April 13 (AP) -- The National Council for the Promotion of Japanese Repatriation has asked Premier Georgi M. Malenkov of the Soviet Union to give "special consideration" to the return of 300,000 Japanese still held in Soviet territory.

Associated Hospital Service New York's Blue Cross Plan, enrolled more than a quarter of a million new members last year and now protects nearly half the population in the seventeen New York counties covered, according to the organization's annual report issued today.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -Details of the Government's plan to sell $1,000,000,000 of thirty-year Treasury bonds, paying 3 1/4 per cent interest, were announced today by the Treasury Department.

Perhaps the most refreshing feature of "United States Foreign Economic Policy and the Sterling Area"* by James R. Nelson and Donald K. Palmer is its avoidance of the oversimplified approach. The troubles of the sterling area are not a stomach ache to be cured by a dose of $53 gold or an attack of economic hiccoughs to be checked by frightening the patient to death.

The first performance of Lucas Foss' "A Parable of Death" was performed in Town Hall last night at the concert of the Choral Masterwork Series by the Robert Shaw Chorale and Concert Orchestra, Mr. Shaw conducting.

A sharp division of opinion as to whether a clergyman should promote from his pulpit the "liberal" social gospel, with all its economic and political overtones, or stick strictly to messages of a spiritual nature has split the congregation of a prominent Brooklyn Presbyterian church into two bitter factions.

PITTSBURGH, April 12 -- The heavy influx of steel orders to the mills last week gave no indication of a slowing up in demand because of peace talk. Nor did steel people look for such a market condition in the near future. Availability of steel was tighter last week than at any time in the past few years.
Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet urged the members of the Fire Department yesterday to continue to be on the alert against the possibility of an atomic attack on the city.

Plans for:erecting a hospital at an estimated cost of about $1,000 000 have been announced by the West Merrick Road Realty Corporation, which has purchased the blockfront on the north side of Merrick Road, from WaShington Street to Bayview Avenue, in Freeport, L. I.

BRISTOL, N. H., April 12 -- They never did learn the answers to any huge world problems at the special town meeting on the United Nations here last night. But the delegate from Panama made a big hit with his "I am a Whooper for New Hampshire" button and everybody found out why the Ambassador from Indonesia didn't take his hat off.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 12 (AP) -- The split in Indonesia's army command appeared today to be building up to a new national crisis.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, and Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, made concurring statements today that the United States should beware of recent "peace gestures" by the Soviet Union. Both are members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and Mr. Wiley is its chairman.
MOSCOW, April 12 -- The British Ambassador, Sir Alvary Gascoigne, and Vyacheslav M. Molotov met yesterday for the second time since the Russian resumed his position as Foreign Minister.

LAST Saturday we were complaining in this quadrangle that endless repetition of familiar styles and themes is likely to have a sad effect on the vitality of the novel. The woods are full of young authors who write like old carbons of Steinbeck, Wolfe, O'Hara and Dos Passos. Not to mention Hemingway and Faulkner. Readers naturally prefer the originals. There is no particular pleasure in going over the same ground with apprentice guides.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, has told Congress that the Eisenhower Administration may shift a substantial share of United States aid from Western Europe to the Far East.
JERICHO, Jordan, April 12 -Seven human skulls upon which artists of the Neolithic Age modeled lifelike features with plaster have been unearthed in ancient Jericho.

Space for general offices has been leased by Pond's Extract Company, manufacturer of Pond's cosmetics, in the twenty-fivestory office building being built by Uris Brothers on the site of the old Ritz-Carlton Hotel at 380 Madison Avenue, the west blockfront between East Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets. It is due to be completed in October.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, April 13 (AP) -- The battleship New Jersey returned to Korean war action today and joined seventy-five Navy planes and the cruiser Los Angeles in bombarding Red strong points on the east coast of North Korea.

When John W. Davis speaks the word "Constitution," there is a resonance in his voice that gives life and power to plain, old-fashioned American words. For in a well-rounded lifetime of countless interests and services it is as a constitutional lawyer that John W. Davis has become best known.

AMSTERDAM, April 12 -- The decline on the stock market last Monday was followed by a slight recovery toward the middle of last week. The week's losses averaged between 1 and 4 per cent. On the other hand, Government bonds displayed considerable strength.
WEST ORANGE, N. J., April 12 -- A 2 1/2-year-old greyhound, Ch. Cherry Bounce of Mardormere, became best in show tonight in the largest of seven all-breed events held by the Twin Brooks Kennel Club.

Two young Americans were featured on the program given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Dimitri Mitropoulos, Saturday night at Carnegie Hall. Arthur Berger was represented by his "Ideas of Order," commissioned by Mr. Mitropoulos, which received its premiere, and William Kapell appeared as soloist in the Brahms Piano Concerto in D minor. Their respective contributions were warmly approved by the audience.

I Should like to take exception to a letter which appeared in your issue of March 29 in which the writer, Walter Sulzbach, seems to be criticizing the use of economics and economists in guiding public policy.

" The Attack," a collection of essays by R. H. Tawney, will be published on Friday by Harcourt, Brace. Mr. Tawney, author of "The Acquisitive Society" and "Religion and the Rise of Capitalism," has included among the essays a "prophetic" estimate of China as a future world power and a "spirited" restatement of the author's concept of freedom.
With Mother's Day less than a month off, it is time to begin planning and making personalized gifts. On this page we show five pattern that can be made in a Short time.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- President Eisenhower, preparing for a week of golfing, put in one of his busiest Sundays today.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's address at the Pan American Union in Washington today, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
PITTSBURGH, April 12 (AP) -Three of four incumbents running for district offices in the C. I. O. United Steelworkers Union won re-election, the union's Board of International Tellers reported today.

MIAMI, Fla., April 12 (UP) -Gardnar Mulloy of Miami never gave upset-minded Hal Burrows of Charlottesville, Va., a chance to get started today as he fashioned a workmanlike 6-4, 6-3, 6-3 victory in the Miami invitation tennis singles final.

CAIRO, April 12 -- Egypt's No. 2 strong man has advanced the cause of British-Egyptian understanding on the subject of the future of the Suez Canal Zone military base a long step forward with the statement that Egypt would accept the aid of British technicians in maintaining the base after the combat troops depart.

Nature's annual display of peach blossoms has opened in New Jersey's many orchards, and, unless warm weather comes this week to make the petals fall, motorists should be able to see the rosy spactacle in North Jersey counties next week-end.

ALBANY, April 12 -- The Public Service Commission has urged Governor Dewey to consider legislation that would set a lower speed limit for large trucks and buses and require them to carry recording speedometers to permit a state check on their compliance.
BOSTON, April 12 -- The state made a second effort today to end a three-day-old strike that had cut milk deliveries in eastern Massachusetts by an estimated 45 per cent.

Foreign exchange market was quiet during the past week due in part to the abbreviated session caused by the extended Easter holiday abroad. Business transacted was mostly routine and price fluctuation was narrow.

Tomorrow -- April 14 -- is Pan-American Day, an annual celebration that has more meaning this year than at any time in the last two decades. The recognition of its importance was symbolized by the fact that President Eisenhower himself attended a meeting of the Council of the Organization of American States at the Pan American Union yesterday morning and delivered the principal address.

Onions are used almost daily by cooks who consider flavor of food a primary consideration. Now, with onions in superabundance, is the time to think of them on their own, as well as a valued seasoning ingredient.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- Some American soldiers about to be returned from prisoner-of-war camps in Kore may appear to have been converted to communism, the Defense Department advised tonight.
The last of the Bennington Composers Conference series of concerts at the Lexington Avenue "Y" took place last night with a program containing music by several American composers.

ZURICH, April 12 -- German, Italian, Japanese and Yugoslav bonds were firmer here last week but industrials were weaker with bank and insurance stocks steady. The capital market as a whole thus clearly reflected the reaction in Switzerland to the hopes aroused for an early end of the cold war.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The Eisenhower Administration is faced with a morale problem among Federal employes that appears to be curtailing the efficiency of American diplomatic and propaganda efforts both at home and overseas at a critical moment in the "cold war."

WASHINGTON, April 12 (UP) -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, said today that Congress might be able to slash six to eight billion dollars from next year's budget and cut taxes by Jan. 1.
Optimism on the business outlook shown the Korean war end was shown in a survey of 347 companies issued over the weekend by the Standard Factors Corporation.

The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis has named Dr. Howard A. Rusk to its advisory committees. Dr. Rusk, a leader in the field of physical medicine and rehabilitation, will serve specifically as a member of the committee on research for the prevention and treatment of after-effects.

The United Negro College Fund is making its tenth annual appeal for funds on behalf of thirty-one private institutions of higher learning in order to insure their youth of proper training in the arts and professions. This year the sum requested is $1,500,000, which represents only 10 per cent of the combined educational budgets of the colleges and universities participating.

ST. LOUIS, April 12 (AP) -- Stan Musial drove in four runs with a home run and double, but the Cardinals were defeated again today by the rival Browns, 8 -- 5, in a city series game featured by three players hit by pitched balls.
HYDE PARK, N. Y., April 12 -- Memorial services were held today at the grave of President Roosevelt in the hedge-enclosed rose garden here.

Real and potential savings amounting to $28,628,405 were achieved by city departments and agencies in 1952 through economies and improved management, the Mayor's Board of Management Improvement declared yesterday in a report to Mayor Impellitteri.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (UP) -- "The Veep is itching for a comeback." That is the word being passed around Capitol Hill.

BERLIN, April 12 -- Britain, France and the United States have agreed to accept as a basis of discussion the Soviet proposal to combine the three air corridors from West Germany to Berlin, if the resulting single corridor is wide enough, official sources said tonight.

Estimating that 250,000 to 500,000 or more New Yorkers lived in "bad" housing, the housing committee of the Welfare and Health Council of New York City reported yesterday that "the condition is rapidly getting worse" and "New York is in a period of slum-making."

The American Jewish Tercentenary Committee, composed of 300 Jewish leaders, adopted yesterday a tentative program to recognize the Contributions that American Jews have made to the history of the United States.

The annual campaign of the New York Catholic Charities was heralded yesterday by a pastoral letter read in all parishes of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York and by a commumon breakfast for 300 parish lay chairmen.

Net profit of the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation and subsidiaries in 1952 amounted to $759,610, equal to $1.82 a share, according to the pamphlet report issued for release today by John H. Clough, president. This compares with $317,736 or 76 cents a share in 1951.

The executive board of Local 1-S, United Department Store Workers of America, C. I. O., yesterday called a strike for 12:01 A. M. tomorrow at Macy's five department stores in an effort to obtain a wage increase and other benefits.

Three thousand persons have signed for blood donations during "Insurance Week," which will open at 10:30 o'clock this morning when a Red Cross bloodmobile sets up at the National Board of Fire Underwriters, 85 John Street, for a full two-week visit.

Nine fencers, including Dr. Daniel Bukantz, the national titleholder, gained the final round-robin in the metropolitan open foil championship at the New York A. C. yesterday. The competition will be resumed on the Winged Foot strips on April 23.

To expedite personal injury suits arising mainly from automobile accidents, three additional non-jury parts will start to function in the Supreme Court Wednesday, with distinguished members of the bar serving as special referees without compensation.

Four New York college administrators expressed agreement yesterday that Communist party members should be expelled from American schools whether they be profesosrs, clerks or secretaries. They agreed also that members of the educational system who refused to say, when asked by legally constituted investigators whether they were Communists, should be dismissed.

CUYAHOGA HEIGHTS, Ohio, April 12 -- This village of 765 persons looked to Washington today for aid and comfort in its three-month struggle with the Air Force and the Aluminum Company of America over a building permit.
PITTSBURGH, April 12 (UP) -- The Pirates scored six unearned runs in the eighth inning today to defeat the Senators, 8 -- 5, as threatening weather kept the attendance down to 3,204 fans.

It was Saturday afternoon. Vic Gabriel, coach of lacrosse at Peekskill Military Academy, had visitors. They were Cadets Ronald Ballard of R. F. D. #2, Towanda, Pa., and Paul Wilhelm of Middlebury, Conn. They had gone to Gabriel's home, just off the campus, to find out whether practice was being held as scheduled.

PARIS, April 12 -- In reply to the proposal of the North Atlantic military authorities that France should increase military service from eighteen months to two years, the French Government has said this is neither necessary nor possible.

The windows are going up again, and that is a very good thing indeed. Although they have been down since only the fall, it had seemed at times as though they had been down forever and never would rise again.

CHICAGO, April 12 (AP) -- The White Sox edged the Cubs 4 to 3 at Wrigley Field today before 12,420 fans and now will carry a nine-game winning streak into their American League opener at Cleveland on Tuesday.
TOKYO, Monday, April 13 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,583, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Korean time:

When the Yankees can't do anything about beating the Dodgers, the weather comes to their aid, as it did yesterday at Ebbets Field. For, after the National League champions had scored six runs in the first inning and the world champions had scored none in two, a downpour halted everything.

On Thursday of last week a substantial majority of the nations that were parties to the 4year international wheat agreement, scheduled to expire on July 31, voted to continue the arrangement for another three years.

Programs of music by Lazare Saminsky have been a fairly recurring feature of the post-war music seasons, and another one was presented late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. It was given by the United States section of the International Society for Contemporary Music, the Canadian League of Composers and the National Association for American Composers and Conductors.

Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr., Council President Rudolph Halley and unions representing municipal employes all urged yesterday a fight by the city to obtain at a special session of the 1953 Legislature relief from alleged injustices contained in Governor Dewey's fiscal program for New York.

The patterned fabric takes the lead for summer. It doesn't matter what the pattern or whether it is printed, painted, embossed, embroidered, flocked or woven into the fabric, as long as it is there. This is indicated in a survey of fabric departments in New York stores.

The destination of two incoming comedies that had been knocking at Broadway's door was revealed yesterday -- "The Pink Elephant," opening April 22 at the Playhouse, and "Men of Distinction," arriving April 30 at the Forty-eighth Street. As a result of these bookings, "Room Service" and "On Borrowed Time," a brace of revivals, will vacate the Playhouse and Forty-eighth Street, respectively, on Saturday night.

BOSTON, April 12 (UP) -- Montreal shut out Boston, 3 -- 0, tonight to take a 2-1 lead in their best-of-seven series for the Stanley Cup before a crowd of close to 14,000 in the Boston Garden. The Canadiens scored once in each period.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 12 -Although winding up in a cold, driving rain, the three sessions of week-end dinghy racing were concluded today at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

During the first two months of this year the men's clothing industry operated at 86 per cent of capacity, compared with 78 per cent in the same 1952 period and 97 per cent in 1951, according to Harry A. Cobrin, executive secretary of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 12 -- Alexander Rankovic, Vice President of the Federal Executive Council, disclosed in an interview that there were more political prisoners in Yugoslav jails or labor camps on charges of Cominform activities than remained in custody on charges stemming from activities connected with the pre-Communist regime.

BALBOA, C. Z., April 12 -- A record 678 commercial vessels using the Panama Canal in March paid $2,883,000 in tolls. The sum, however, was $25,000 less than paid by 674 ships in October, 1952. The difference resulted from the smaller average size of ships in March.
Three new films, imported from Britain, Italy and Russia, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

In a special report to THE NEW YORK TIMES we are informed of the laboratory research by Dr. Henry Goldblatt of Los Angeles carrying forward the monumental contribution of the late Dr. Otto Warburg ("The Metabolism of Tumors") into a link between cancer and a cellular lack of oxygen.

Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, announced yesterday that eight speakers would make four-minute addresses on the need for good city government at the committee's $100-a-plate dinner at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel on Tuesday, April 21.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 12 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh continued today his own custom of refusing to pay traditional calls on the Shah, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, while political factions marshaled forces for a showdown on the issue of limiting the Shah's power over the army.

In the light of articles appearing in the newspapers recently on the school situation throughout the country we believe it important to bring to your attention a deplorable example of the kind of school planning presented to citizens of New York by its Board of Education.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 11 -- Lee A. Potter Jr., 34, president of Forman, Ford Co., Minneapolis, Minn., today was elected president of the Young Presidents Organization for 1953-54 at the conclusion of the group's third annual convention at the Arizona Biltmore Hotel. H. E. Chiles, 42 years old, convention chairman and president of the Western Company of Midland, Tex., was elected vice president.
PARIS, April 12 -- The French Socialists today informed the International Socialist Council meeting in a Paris suburb that they would not ratify the European army treaty in its present form.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., April 12 -- The medical profession was urged today by Dr. Austin Smith, editor of The Journal of the American Medical Association, to put more emphasis on acquainting the public with the role of recent advances in medical research in strengthening and enriching both the family and the community.
CLEVELAND, April 12 -- Former President Herbert Hoover, in a press conference here today, said that the Eisenhower Administration was making "remarkable progress" toward the goal of sound government.

Robert Kurka and Johan Franco were the composers whose music was played on Saturday evening's Composers Forum at the McMillin Theatre. Both Mr. Kurka's Piano Sonata and Violin Sonata were professional, well-written pieces in the romantic idiom that had little originality of their own. Lucy Brown was the piano soloist, and she joined Sidney Harth for the violin work.

A debut recital was given yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall by John Bigbee, American baritone. His program, consisting of songs and arias in Italian, French, German and English, was conventional, though an enterprising touch was lent by the presence of Ravel's "Melodies Populaires Grecques."

Customs collections at the Port of New York last month rose 25 per cent above March, 1952, with the increase due principally to a sharp jump in duties on imported goods, Frank B. Laughlin, acting Collector of the Port, said yesterday.

President Chiang Kai-shek has yielded to repeated pleas from Dr. K. C. Wu and has "with great reluctance," as he said, accepted the resignation of that dynamic and popular Governor of Formosa. Dr. Wu retains his Cabinet rank, however, and it is predicted that when he returns from his present sick leave he may receive a diplomatic appointment.

A syndicate of investors represented by Mandel Permutt, attorneys, has purchased the fifteenstory and penthouse apartment building for 112 families at 825 West End Avenue, corner of West 100th Street, from the Colonial Trust Company, trustee.

Instruction in water safety in New York has probably saved more lives than any local Red Cross activity. At its inception in 1924 New York, with its waterways and bathing beaches, had one of the nation's highest drowning rates.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (UP) -- Big league baseball opens its 1953 season here tomorrow with all the traditional hoopla, but without the star of the show -- the President of the United States.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 12 -The Indian High Commissioner here branded as a lie today reports in pro-Government newspapers that Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, refused to discuss the Kashmir and canal-water disputes at an early proposed meeting with Khwaja Nazimuddin, Prime Minister of Pakistan.
