MANILA, April 12 -- Ramon Magsaysay, former Defense Secretary who broke with President Elpidio Quirino's Liberal party in February, was nominated by a landslide convention vote today as the rival Nacionalista party's candidate for President in the election scheduled to be held in the Philippines next November.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (UP) -- Government sources were certain Mr. Dulles did not intend any immediate termination -- or swift cutback -- in the Point Four program. Funds for the program in the year starting July 1 are being reviewed by the Eisenhower Administration.

CHICAGO, April 12 -- Grain futures prices worked moderately higher last week, apprehension in regard to peace developments giving way to concern over the 1953 wheat crop prospects in this country and western Canada. The consensus now appears to be that peace in Korea would have little effect on grains here. It is possible that peace would increase demand for relief supplies of food grains.

Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner, declared yesterday that New York City was ripe for a change in government and that all parties and groups opposed to Tammany must unite in a genuine fusion movement to prevent the re-election of the present City Administration in November.

LONDON, April 12 -- In the last week the financial and commodity markets have been completely dominated by the apparent steady progress being made toward peace in Korea and the general and appreciable easing of tension in the international political situation.
Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoreman's Association, A. F. L., has been ordered to appear at the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan at 10 o'clock this morning.

Dr. Luis A. Quintanilla, Mexico's delegate to the Organization of American States, heard President Eisenhower's speech on inter-American unity in Washington early yesterday. Then he flew to New York and, early in the evening, six young panelists on the New York Times Youth Forum made him demonstrate his conviction that nonintervention was the core of the Pan-American system.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 12 -- Two stories, one based on fact stranger than fiction and the other a fictional yarn based on fact, will be incorporated by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to form the dramatic pattern for "Jet Squadron 8," a tribute to Navy fighter pilots in Korea.

A proposal that the city reduce its services, principally police, fire and sanitation, to Jamaica, Aqueduct and Belmont race tracks in direct proportion to the annual reduction of the city's fast-diminishing pari-mutuel tax will be laid before the City Council at its meeting tomorrow.
CINCINNATI, April 12 (AP) -- Cincinnati vs. Milwaukee. That's the way the schedule reads but it's a bit more than just the usual whoop-te-doo that goes with a Cincinnati opening day.

As spring advances, the number of metropolitan art exhibitions shows no sign of diminishing. Of special interest this week is the International Dada Exhibition, opening at the Janis Gallery on Wednesday, a large retrospective of work that rocked Europe a generation ago.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Monday, April 13 -- While Allied and Communist staff officers completed details here for an exchange of sick and wounded war prisoners, Gen. Mark W. Clark, United Nations commander, and his headquarters staff in Tokyo were studying an enemy proposal for renewal of the Korean armistice talks.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- There is only one hat that ever rests on the hatrack outside the President's office, and that is the President's.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today 121 Korean war casualties in a list that included twenty killed, ninety wounded, two missing, one injured and eight captured. The following were from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):

BONN, Germany, April 12 -- The Allied High Commission has agreed in principle to limit West Germany's monthly occupation costs, or defense contribution, as the Germans prefer to call it today, to 600,000,000 Deutsche marks ($142,857,000) until Dec. 31, 1953, if the European Defense Community is not established in the meantime.

ALBANY, April 12 -- Governor Dewey approved today a bill that will authorize the State Superintendent of Insurance to require all life insurance companies licensed to do business in New York to adopt uniform accounting procedures.

One hundred years ago this week the United States Trust Company of New York opened for business at 40 Wall Street. In observing its anniversary the institution celebrates a full century of operation without change of name, merger or modification of its original purpose of specialization in the fiduciary field.

Five hundred worshipers at the Salem Methodist Church, 129th Street and Seventh Avenue, celebrated the church's fiftieth anniversary yesterday morning in a service that lasted two and a half hours. The sanctuary, which was recently renovated, was reconsecrated. Bishop Frederick B. Newell of the New York Methodist Area presided.

W. Graham Cole, assistant secretary of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and a well-known safety engineer, was killed yesterday morning when he jumped or fell to the street from the bedroom of his eighth-floor apartment at 510 East Twenty-third Street, Cooper Village.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 12 -- The parties have concluded their campaigns for the election next Wednesday and the consensus among the experts seems to be that the Nationalist party of Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan has almost no chance of getting a majority of the electorate, but a reasonably good chance of winning the election.

The significant news from inflation-ridden Buenos Aires is not the suicide of Juan Duarte, brother of the late Eva Peron, but the expulsion from the peronista party of Col. Domingo A. Mercante. In fact, nothing has happened in Argentina since the death of Senora Peron herself that is so likely to shake the very foundation of the widower's regime.

CONSISTENCY is a trait that should be admired. In making the annual predictions of the probable order of finish in the National League, this guesser defied logic and common sense by veering away from the obvious Dodgers and picking the long-shot Phillies. Will he now do the same with the American League and again defy logic? Don't be silly. Consistency is an admirable trait only in the other fellow, not in one's own self.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 12 -- A number of new mechanical appliances, utilizing hydraulic engineering principles to repair weak, malformed or injured hearts, were discussed here today at the closing session of the American Heart Association's annual meeting.
New York's financial crisis is placing new strains on the city's municipal hospital system, already staggering under a burden of seemingly insoluble problems.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 12 -- The United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission urged Palestinian Arab refugees today to file claims at once for the blocked bank accounts that Israel has agreed to free. In doing so, the commission apparently sought to clear up any questions raised by new Arab attacks on the Israeli payment plan.

Leo Durocher may not have settled the score with the Indians at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but he did arrive at a most important decision. He named Larry Jansen as his starting pitcher when the Polo Grounders help the Phillies open the season tomorrow in Philadelphia.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 12 -- Ben Hogan became the Masters champion again today and a gathering of 12,000 at the Augusta National Golf Club agreed that his new title fitted him well.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public, which will mature within twelve months, amount to $73,267,125,411. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
PARIS, April 12 -- French financial difficulties resulted in a certain amount of speculation on the gold and currency exchange markets at the end of last week.

PARIS, April 13 -- Recently some observers have accepted as an indication of a change in the Soviet mood the fact that former Premier Stalin's name has been mentioned with relative rareness in Moscow's press and that the vicious spate of anti-American propaganda apparently had been toned down.
CHICAGO, April 13 (AP) -- Cattle receipts swamped livestock markets today and prices dipped as much as $1.50 a hundred pounds at the Chicago stockyards.

A check for $5,000 was presented yesterday by the Advertising Men's Post 209, American Legion, to Hank Viscardi, executive director of Just One Break, Inc. The presentation was made at a luncheon in the Lexington Hotel as part of the post's welfare program to help disabled veterans to return to private industry.

The International Society for Contemporary Music, at least its local unit, continues to be relentlessly contemporary. At the season's second forum concert at the Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A. last night, the program had an air about it of being militantly avantgarde, and though the elapsed time was no longer than that at the normal evening of music, one felt as though one had been listening for hours and hours.

For the first time since it began operations on Dec. 11, 1943, the City Center of Music and Drama, a nonprofit institution of which Mayor Impellitteri is president, is making a public appeal for funds to tide it over an emergency.

LONDON, April 13 (Reuters) -- The Sadler's Wells Ballet will return to the United States and Canada in the fall, opening a twenty-week tour Sept. 13 at New York's Metropolitan Opera House. The tour will be under the management of Sol Hurok, who handled the company's two previous North American visits in 1949 and 1950.
A new chapter is opening in Indo-China.

ATHENS, April 13 (AP) -- The Athens newspaper Apoyevmatini revived the five-year-old case of the slain American reporter, George Polk, today, promising "sensational new evidence" that would throw fresh light on his death.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Revenue Commissioner T. Coleman Andrews announced today that beginning July 1 most business men paying excise taxes might file returns quarterly instead of monthly.
Viscose rayon, one the first synthetic textile fibers to achieve mass production, will be promoted by a new bureau underwritten by five of the leading yarn producers, it was announced yesterday.

John Ed Roberts, a slender, red-haired, 16-year-old boy from Knoxville, Tenn., received yesterday the "golden boy" plaque of the Boys Clubs of America, signifying he had been chosen "boy of the year" for 1953 and had won that group's junior citizenship award.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Clark Griffith's elaborately planned baseball inaugural that was to have launched the American League's 1953 pennant race in the Capital went down the drain and into the swirling waters of the Potomac River today when rain washed out the opener between the world champion Yankees and the Senators.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy confirmed today reports that his Senate Investigations subcommittee had set out to determine whether certain Government departments or agencies were paying "subsidies" to informational media, including the press, television and radio.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 13 -- Premonitory rumblings of violence grew stronger today as this city tensed for the expected showdown tomorrow on whether Premier Mohammed Mossadegh or the Shah was to have control of the army.

LONDON, April 13 -- Across the Thames from the London bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES and about one mile east lies the bankside where Shakespeare lived and worked three and a half centuries ago. In honor of the Coronation, the borough of Southwark is organizing a festival of ten Shakespeare plays that will begin this week and continue until September.

The mercantile and apartment property comprising four buildings at 547-549 Jersey Avenue and 276-278 First Street in Jersey City, N. J., has been sold by heirs of the Fitzgerald estate to a group of investors represented by Martin Golub. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker and the attorneys were Max Druz for the sellers and Philip Mandelbaum for the buyers.

Public offering of 200,000 shares of Clevite Corporation common stock will be made today by a nation-wide group of 139 underwriters headed by F. Eberstadt Co., Inc. and Prescott, Shepard Co., Inc. The stock will be offered at $25.375 a share and proceeds will be added to general funds.

DENVER, April 13 (AP) -- Viruses must pick up little shocks of positive electricity to cause sickness, according to Dr. Theodore Puck, Professor of Biophysics at the University of Colorado School of Medicine. He suggested that drugs might be developed to prevent viruses from getting the electrical charges, with hope in the fight against poliomyelitis, influenza and other diseases.

Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education for the last fifteen years, does not intend to be a candidate for re-election when his current term expires next month. He said yesterday that he planned to notify the board of his intention at the next meeting Monday evening.

Joseph P. Ryan, 68-year-old lifetime president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., was indicted yesterday on charges that he misused $11,390 of the union's funds for his personal taxes, golf club dues, expensive shirts, life insurance premiums and a relative's funeral.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- In the Supreme Court of the United States today. Robert Hastings Lounsbury, Louis Clerk Stephens, Eileen Colligan Morrissey, John L. MacDonnell, and Bernard A. Feuerstein, all of New York City, among others, were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 13 -- Eastern Air Defense Force officers told today of the interception on Saturday of a large bomber and three jet fighters, all having silhouettes of Russian war planes, as they flew mysteriously at high altitude toward New York.
The Board of Health adopted yesterday a sweeping revision of the section of the Sanitary Code that applies to all hospitals here that offer maternity services.

The tenth annual drive of the United Negro College Fund, with a goal of $1,500,000, opened here yesterday. Five hundred friends of the fund, at a meeting in the Plaza Hotel ballroom, heard appeals on behalf of the thirty-one colleges -- all but one of them in the South -- that annually join in a national "community chest" type of drive.

LONDON, April 13 -- After a long spell of preliminary maneuvering, negotiations on Egypt's demands for British evacuation from the Suez Canal Zone are now expected here to start "within the not too distant future." There is some hope in London that the talks will end in a mutually satisfactory new defense arrangement.

HANOI, Vietnam, April 13 -- The French High Command announced today that it had withdrawn its garrison from Samneua, in northeastern Laos, in the face of an impending invasion of that Indo-Chinese state by an estimated 40,000 Vietminh troops.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The business man chosen for one of the posts of Assistant Secretary of Labor was reported today to be Milton M. Olander, director of industrial relations of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company, Toledo, Ohio.

DETROIT, April 13 -- The Federal Reserve System's non-participation in the bond market in connection with the current new financing by the Treasury on long-term bonds is in pursuance of a non-intervention policy adopted by the central hank for the Treasury financing of last December and applied, too, to the big refunding operation in February.

OTTAWA, April 13 (Canadian Press) -- Trade Minister C. D. Howe said today that the Canadian Government would "leave no stone unturned" to keep the International Wheat Agreement going for another three years and hinted that Anglo - Canadian relations would be "adversely affected" if Britain did not sign.

The owner of a Brooklyn tenement in which seven persons died in a fire last June 18 went on trial yesterday before Judge Nathan R. Sobel in Kings County Court on charges of first and second degree manslaughter.

Foremost Dairies, Inc., announced after a board meeting yesterday the election of Grover D. Turnbow as president to succeed Paul E. Reinhold, who was elected to the new post of chairman. Mr. Reinhold, who has been president of Foremost since the present company was formed in 1931, will continue as chief executive officer.
Mrs. Ada Holding Miller of Providence, R. I., was re-elected for a second term as president of the National Federation of Music Clubs at a meeting yesterday in the Roosevelt Hotel.

TOKYO, Tuesday, April 14 -- The Government - controlled Peiping radio charged the United States this morning with "reluctance" to resume negotiations at Panmunjom, Korea, for an armistice in the Korean war based on a proposal by Chou En-lai, Chinese Premier and Foreign Minister, to send all prisoners refusing repatriation to temporary custody of a neutral nation.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- This was the first working day as a full-fledged member of the Cabinet for Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby of Texas, Secretary of the new Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

BLANTYRE, Nyasaland, April 13 (Reuters) -- A meeting representing the African populace decided here last night to take their fight against Britain's Central African Federation plan to the United Nations.

For veterans whose disabilities are due to military service nothing can be too good. The people of the United States owe them an obligation which can never be repaid. There is not -- and there must not be -- any question whatsoever of depriving them of the best possible care at governmental expense.

GARRISON, N. D., April 13 -- The Missouri River, whose history is one of violence and destruction, was confronted by a new obstacle today when construction crews, under the supervision of Army engineers, began closing the huge Garrison Dam near here.

The Federal Government's chief mediator took a hand early this morning in efforts to head off a strike of 12,000 employes of the Sperry Gyroscope Company as Lake Success, L. I. Ninety per cent of the company's output of hydraulic devices, radar equipment and gun parts is for military use.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Representatives of seventeen countries signed the new International Wheat Agreement at a ceremony at the State Department today.

The projected merger of Sharp Dohme, Inc., into Merck Co., Inc., appears to require a new word in the financial vocabulary. Mergers generally can be described as "vertical," when the user joins the supplier, or the supplier joins the user; "horizontal," where the merging and merged companies operate in the same field, and "expansive" when the buyer moves into a new activity by buying an established plant.

" Angelic Doctor" is the title of the play being offered by the Blackfriars at their theatre on Fifty-seventh Street. The production has been resumed after a respite during Holy Week. It is a biographical drama about St. Thomas Aquinas, a theologian and philosopher and also an inquirer after the truth.

Continuing arguments supporting a motion to dismiss anti-trust charges against Morgan Stanley Co. and Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., defense counsel declared yesterday that the Government had either abandoned or significantly changed its position on the "successorship," "traditional banker," "historical position" and corporate directorate phases of the alleged conspiracy, and that the evidence failed to bear out the companion charge of conspiratorial reciprocity.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The National Federation of American Shipping asserted today that there had been a sharp drop in the amount of cargo carried by this country's ships in overseas trade. This decline, it said, emphasized the "struggle being waged by the United States merchant marine to carry a fair share of the nation's foreign trade."

Is it possible that Malenkov realizes that his name could easily go down in history as representing the savior of the modern world? The late news from Russia would seem to indicate that he is aware how quickly and simply all problems could be solved through a change of attitude on the part of his country.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today nominated Ralph H. Demmler of Pittsburgh to be a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission. He also selected Jerome K. Kuykendall of Olympia, Wash., to be a member of the Federal Power Commission. Both jobs pay $15,000 a year.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 13 -- In a progress report on the repair of flood-damaged dikes, the Netherlands Ministry of Traffic and Waterways announced today that 330,000 out of an original 360,000 inundated acres were dry again.
James B. Synnott in a recent letter made the excellent suggestion that there should be more popular study of the Constitution, but for insufficient reasons. He wants only to admire, not amend.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 13 -- Israel has learned "with deep satisfaction and relief" of the Soviet Union's recent repudiation of charges made against fifteen doctors, Mrs. Golda Myerson, Israeli Minister of Labor, said today. She added that "we sincerely hope that the recent cessation and repudiation of anti-Jewish propaganda is permanent."

The nation's steel makers established a new high production record of 10,153,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings in March -- and this brought production for the first three months of the year to a new quarterly record of 28,981,137 tons.
Richard M. Crooks has been nominated for the third successive term as chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange. The election will be held on May 11.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, has been indicted on charges of stealing union funds. The indictment is the result of a grand jury inquiry growing partly out of his recent testimony before the State Crime Commission. Mr. Ryan will be defended by able counsel and will have full opportunity to present an answer to the charges.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 13 -- Dag Hammarskjold had his first busy workday today as Secretary General of the United Nations.

TOKYO, April 13 -- The rearming of Japan has emerged as the major issue dividing this nation's political parties in the hotly contested campaign that ends with the election of a new House of Representatives this Sunday.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Mrs. Perle Mesta, retiring United States Minister to Luxembourg, has obtained State Department approval for a visit to Moscow.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Eight years ago today this capital and every other in the world had not even begun to recover from the impact of the news from Warm Springs, Ga., wholly unanticipated by most people, that Franklin Delano Roosevelt had died suddenly on April 12. The new President, Harry S. Truman, only a few hours in office, was asking all he encountered to pray for him.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- The Coast Guard has cut $34,350,000 from its budget request for the year beginning July 1, but it means a temporary halt in work on a special defense program, according to Vice Admiral Merlin O'Neill, Coast Guard commandant.

A pioneer effort to apply the principles of "chain store" mass purchasing to the operation of union welfare funds was set in motion yesterday by the Bakery and Confectionary Workers International Union, A. F. L.

GENEVA, April 13 -- In a few short weeks Russia, by talking mildly and doing a few little things that would be considered quite ordinary on the part of any other country, has done more to produce adverse economic repercussions in the Western world than have all Russia's threats, agitation and conspiracies in the previous post-war period.

PARIS, April 13 -- As they awaited news of a new military stroke in Indo-China, French officials said today that events there might soon provide the first great test of the recent professions of peaceful intentions by Moscow and Peiping.

Changes bigger than a small fraction were almost absent from yesterday's stock market, which drifted lazily lower on the smallest volume since Feb. 18 and the narrowest selection of the year. The combined averages of THE NEW YORK TIMES declined 0.62 point and ended at 183.04, only 0.51 above the lowest close of 1953, which came last Tuesday.

WINDSOR, Ont., April 13 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company of Canada, Ltd., reported net earnings for 1952 of $15,342,920 today. This is equal to $9.25 a share and compares with a net of $14,884,848, or $8.97 a share, in the preceding year.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- The Eisenhower Administration ran into bipartisan opposition today in its proposed economy move to cut $110,000,000 from an Agriculture Department lime-fertilizer subsidy program next year.

Control of the six-story apartment house accommodating eighty-four families at 91-50 to 91-56 195th Street in Hollis, Queens, has been acquired by a syndicate of investors represented by Harry Mabel of Goodman Mabel, attorneys, through the purchase of the stock of the Woodhall Apartments, Inc. Punia Marx, officers of the selling corporation, were represented by Abraham Traub of Dryer Traub.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, soon will order the three armed services to cut the size of their public information offices in the Pentagon and to channel the flow of defense information through the office of the Secretary of Defense.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Henry W. (The Dutchman) Grunewald, a mysterious figure in the Washington influence picture, talked for a change today to tax investigators of the House of Representatives but stopped short of telling them in public all that he had done in private.

HELENA, Mont, April 13 -- The Montana State Land Board announced here that more than half the applications to lease 82,097 acres of oil and gas land from the state at an auction on April 29 and 30 have been canceled. The cancellations were made on 55 per cent of the 159 tracts offered for lease.

Eleven hundred dollars in fuel oil shakedown funds were dropped in an open drawer in the desk of Frank J. Sampson at City Hall shortly after 5 P. M. of a Friday late in December, 1950, it was testified yesterday at the perjury trial of John E. Gleason Jr. in General Sessions.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- John M. Otter, president of the National Foundation for Consumer Credit, accused the Senate Banking Committee today of approving "a repulsive and useless piece of legislation" in recommending stand-by authority to impose credit controls.

JERSEY CITY, April 13 -- A ten-member board of directors for the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company was finally chosen today, President William Reid announced here tonight, after a compromise was reached. Five men were chosen from each of two slates of ten candidates.
LONDON, April 13 -- The West Indian Federation Conference, convoked with the aim of uniting Britain's Caribbean colonies into a new member nation of the Commonwealth, opened here today.

GENEVA, April 13 -- Eighty trade experts from twenty-six countries moved into the United Nations European headquarters here today to see whether, in addition to exchanging prisoners of war, the East and West could exchange a few more goods.

The first two of fifty Liberty ships that are to be used by the Department of Agriculture for the storage of 12,000,000 to 13,000,000 bushels of grain will be withdrawn today from the Government reserve fleet at Jones Point in the Hudson River.

John W. Davis celebrated his eightieth birthday yesterday by putting on a burst of speed and extending his usual twelve-hour day by about four hours in order to taper off a heavy schedule at an informal birthday party with his law partners and their wives.

MEXICO CITY, April 13 -- A decided official shift in the emphasis in Mexican economic development from industralization to agriculture was confirmed today by Antonio Carrillo Flores, Minister of Finance.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Rene Pleven, French Minister of Defense, told Senators today that the Communist military adventures in Asia were inseparable and that any Korean settlement might put dangerously rising Communist pressure on Indo-China.

BERLIN, April 13 -- Bishop Otto Dibelius, head of the Evangelical Church in both East and West Germany and chairman of the All-German Protestant Council, has asked Gen. Vassily I. Chuikov, chairman of the Soviet Control Commission, to intervene and ease the crisis facing the church in East Germany.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13 -- Predictions on the outlook for business that were on the bearish side for the balance of 1953 and on into 1954 held the spotlight today at the opening sessions of the sixth annual three-day convention of the National Federation of Financial Analysts Societies.

After the April 26 performance over the Du Mont network, the "Arthur Murray Party" television program will be off the air until June 28, when it will resume over the C. B. S. network on Sundays from 9:30 to 10 P.M. It has been purchased by the Bristol-Myers Company as a summer replacement for the Ken Murray and Alan Young comedy shows, which are presented alternately.

The Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., demanded yesterday that the Federal Maritime Board stop paying a subsidy to American Export Lines for its North Atlantic service to India and Pakistan via the Zuez Canal.
Each weekday morning Paul Mayo waves good-by to the 151- foot-one-inch lady who lives in his backyard. He then takes two boats to school.
Activity in college rowing picks up considerably this week, with three regattas listed for Saturday.

TRENTON, April 13 -- The State Legislature, holding its last session until May 18, tonight passed and sent to the Governor a bill extending the life of the State Law Enforcement Council for two years. At the same time the Assembly defeated a measure to legalize wire-tapping by the Attorney General's office and county prosecutors.

Joseph and Lillian Fuchs brought distinction to last night's concert of the National Orchestral Association at Carnegie Hall. It meant the training orchestra, under Leo Barzin, completed its seasonal Monday night series with one of its most creditable concerts.

Operations in the nation's steel plants are scheduled at an estimated 96.7 per cent of rated capacity this week, indicating production of 2,180,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

EDGEWATER, N. J., April 13 -- The murky tide-swept waters of the Hudson River have started giving up their annual spring harvest of silver shad to the veteran fishermen who devote seven weeks out of each year to tending the gill nets near the George Washington Bridge.

Secretary Dulles has told Congress that the Eisenhower Administration is contemplating both a cut in the funds for the Mutual Security program and the shift of a substantial share of these funds from Western Europe to the Far East, with a "little more" for the Middle East as well.

With one of the most attractive programs listed in the history of the meet, George Eastment's Manhattan College athletes are figured to carry away the top honors in the seventh annual Seton Hall relays Friday and Saturday at the Newark Schools Stadium.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified ninety-four Korean casualties in new list today that compromised twenty-eight killed, forty-three wounded and twenty-three missing. The following casualties were listed for New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):

Exporters concerned are beginning to grow impatient at the delay in signing of the $300,000,000 Export-Import Bank trade-debt loan agreement with Brazil, but well-posted trade sources here declared yesterday that action could not be put off much longer and might come within the week.
An unsettled bond market furnished the background yesterday for cash subscriptions to the first Treasury offering of a fully marketable long-term bond issue since World War II.

CINCINNATI, April 13 (AP) -- A 30-year-old pitcher and a 23-year-old rookie outfielder pooled their talents today to lead Milwaukee to a 2-0 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs as the Wisconsin city went into major league competition for the first time since 1901. The game was the first of the season in the National League.
Thirty-six years ago President Wilson proclaimed the founding of the American Junior Red Cross.

Two proposals to have E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., take action to dispose of its holdings in General Motors Corporation common stock were overwhelmingly defeated at the annual meeting of du Pont yesterday in Wilmington.

" Confederate Georgia," a study of the Southern state from 1861-65, by T. Conn Bryan, Professor of History at North Georgia College, will be issued April 27 by the University of Georgia Press. It is a portrayal of events in the state during the War Between the States, based in part on previously unpublished correspondence of Robert E. Lee, Jefferson Davis, Alexander H. Stephens, Joseph E. Brown and Howell Cobb.

America has no monopoly on the quick-mix. From the Federal Republic of West Germany -- Krumbach in Bavaria, to be exact -- come mixes for potato dumplings and potato pancakes. They are interesting products but as yet are available here only in Yorkville, at Bremen House, 224 East Eighty-sixth Street, and the Hansa Delicatessen, 1543 Third Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Representative Daniel A. Reed, Republican of upstate New York and chairman of the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives, moved today to force his bill to cut individual income levies by about 10 per cent this year to a voting showdown on the floor.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 13 -- Anne Baxter, now in France for the Cannes Film Festival, will remain in Europe to co-star for the King Brothers in "Carnival."

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Otto Verber, a former United States Army Intelligence officer, pleaded guilty today to taking part in a conspiracy to spy on United States military secrets for the Soviet Union.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 13 -- James J. Wadsworth of the United States delegation informed the Economic and Social Council this morning that the United States Government was gratified to note the steps taken during the last year by the International Monetary Fund toward removal of exchange restrictions as a method of increasing its potential assistance to countries requiring its aid.

The Rev. Dr. Paul Austin Wolfe, pastor since 1938 of the Brick Presbyterian Church, was unanimously re-elected yesterday to his second term as Moderator of the Presbytery of New York at a meeting in the West-Park Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street. The Presbytery embraces sixty-three churches in Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island.

CINCINNATI, April 13 -- The City Council was urged by the Mayor's Friendly Relations Committee today to "enact an ordinance forbidding the practice of discrimination in employment against persons solely because of race, color, religious creed, national origin or ancestry." The proposal would apply to "employers, employment agencies, labor organizations and others."

ATLANTIC CITY, April 13 -- Control of influenza appears to be within reach, although the changeable nature of the influenza virus has presented a baffling immunity problem, it was reported here today at the opening of the thirty- fourth annual meeting of the American College of Physicians.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Eight Democratic and one Independent Senator joined today in a statement assailing the Eisenhower Administration's decision to increase interest rates on Government bonds.

TOKYO, April 13 -- A fifty-year dream of Christians in Japan and the United States became a reality here today when the charter class of Japan International Christian University's College of Liberal Arts was matriculated in a special ceremony on its campus in Mitaka, a Tokyo suburb.

Two buildings with forty-two apartments at 1467 and 1471 College Avenue, the Bronx, are under contract of sale to Leo A. Bercow and Walter Berger, investors and operators. The property, assessed at $100,000, is being sold by a client of Charles Kelman, lawyer.
ALBANY, April 13 -- A more stringent policy to insure safety in school bus operations has been put into effect by the Public Service Commission.

It is not the practice of the Government of India to enter into controversy with another Government through the medium of the newspapers of a third country. It is also contrary to their policy to hinder, by word or by deed, the economic development of a neighboring or any other state.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 13 -- Ben Hogan's objective this year is to win the United States open golf championship in June at the Oakmont (Pa.) Country Club and thus become the third player in history to capture the title four times.

New York has lost one of its busiest, best-hearted and best-loved citizens in the death of Gano Dunn at the ripe age of 82. Active in his manysided interests until the very end of his long career. Mr. Dunn was the head of a great engineering corporation which built vast projects literally in every corner of the world.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, April 14 (AP) Allied infantrymen smashed back enemy attacks on two widely separated United Nations outposts in brief, bitter battles before dawn today. Small patrol actions flared along the 155-mile front.

Despite scattered improvement in recent years, rising costs of operation and maintenance are placing heavy financial burdens on the city's voluntary, nonprofit hospitals. Many of them are still running in the red and there is no immediate solution in sight.

Community Counseling Service, public relations consultants, in the Empire State Building, 350 5 Ave; California State Board of Equalization, tax office, in 104 E 40 St; United Aircraft Products, Inc, in 50 E 42 St; Kawecki Chemical Co, in 220 E 42 St -- Cushman Wakefield, Inc, brokers.
Isidor Bieber's King Jolie splashed through the mud and rain to an expected victory in the $7,500 added Tryster Handicap, a mile-and-a-furlong test for 4-year-olds and upward, at Jamaica yesterday.

The Country Antiques Fair, which opened yesterday at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, has a comparatively large number of exquisite European antiques. However, C. J. Nuthall, co-manager of the fair with Dorothy Hazen, reports that this season's assemblage of 400,000 articles includes the largest grouping of early American furniture and furnishings to date.

A sampling of wallpaper and fabric designs from France will go on view today in an exhibit arranged by the French Commercial Counselor in Room 414 at 610 Fifth Avenue. The materials in the display, on view through Friday, are available through decorators.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The economic outlook for Western Europe and much of the free world is unsatisfactory and even dangerous to the collective security of the North Atlantic Community, according to an estimate of the situation presented informally to the United States Government by the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 13 -- International control of the illicit manufacture of synthetic heroin is impractical, the United Nations Commission on Narcotic Drugs agreed today, because acetic acid and hydride, converted by chemists operating outside the law, also are used extensively by legitimate industry for such varied products as aspirin, aeroplanes and silk.

BOWIE, Md., April 13 (AP) -- Sidney Jacobs, leading trainer of this meeting, saddled his tenth winner of the 14-day-old session when Mrs. Sam Lewin's Reinforce, with Willie Hartack aboard, drove to a length-and-a-half decision in the Monticello Purse this afternoon.

Alex James, the 25-year-old Army veteran-artist-grocery clerk-composer who has chalked "An Onion and You," on countless New York subway staircases, said yesterday that if people didn't buy his song now, he might move to Philadelphia. He didn't mean it as a threat. He was just trying to convey how much his song ("An Onion and You," naturally) meant to him.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Locals of the International Electrical Workers Union, C. I. O., apparently are voting substantially against a strike in General Electric Company plants.

While not schooled in the law I find it difficult to follow your reasoning in your editorial "Pathway to Chaos." You say the Bricker proposal is not the way to progress and peace; it is the way to reaction and chaos.

Robert Conant, harpsichordist, made his recital debut in Town Hall last evening. Mr. Conant, who recently returned from overseas service with the Army, is a graduate of Yale. He has studied with Sascha Gorodnitzki, Robert Casadesus and Nadia Boulanger.
Following is the text of Mayor Impellitteri's talk last night on "The City and the State," over local radio and television outlets:

The International Electrochemical Society will issue a statement today attacking the method by which Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks removed Dr. Allen V. Astin as director of the National Bureau of Standards.

A proposal to merge the Smith-Douglass Company, Inc., and the San Jacinto Chemical Corporation, with Smith-Douglass as the surviving corporation, will be acted upon at special meetings called for April 28, according to R. B. Douglass, president of Smith-Douglass, and E. M. Fleischmann, president of San Jacinto.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Senator William F. Knowland, Republican of California, proposed today that the United Nations test the faith of the Soviet peace moves with a demand for free elections that might unite Korea.

Harold J. Adonis, the New Jersey political figure who has been fighting extradition from a Netherlands jail cell since last November, is "eating his heart out" for a chance to get back to Bergen County and face his accusers, Edmund Palmieri asserted yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- Wheat prices slumped sharply on the Board of Trade today, the winter wheat crop estimate of 714,000,000 bushels being much higher than anyone expected. The break in wheat carried other grains down in the early trade, but good recoveries were registered, especially in rye and oats, which were affected by Washington reports that limiting of grain imports is being considered.

AKRON, Ohio, April 13 (AP) -- Seiberling Rubber Company recently acquired nearly 15 per cent more capital stock in its Canadian subsidiary and now owns 99.6 per cent of the Toronto company, Seiberling's chairman and president reported to stockholders today.

City employes, descending upon City Hall by the hundreds yesterday for the first of three days of public hearings on the 1953-54 budget, voiced severe crticism of Mayor Impellitteri's financial plans for the next fiscal year and demanded that pay increases and broad benefits for municipal workers be included.

BEAUMONT, Tex., April 13 (UP) -- The notable sports career of Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias will be placed in the hands of an "internationally renowned" surgeon on Friday when she undergoes an operation for a "malignancy," possibly cancer.

Rocky Marciano, world heavyweight champion, received the Graham McNamee Memorial Award "for outstanding contribution to the general welfare of sports" at the Sports Broadcasters Association's sixth annual dinner at the Park Sheraton Hotel last night.

Teams from three Manhattan high schools, three Brooklyn schools and one each from the Bronx and Queens have been chosen finalists in the Shakespearean interscholastic contest jointly conducted by the Board of Education and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, producers of the forthcoming film version of "Julius Caesar."

MIAMI, Fla., April 13 -- The end of Government controls on business has placed responsibility on a free industry to make the economy work, Benjamin F. Fairless, chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, said here today.

SPOTSWOOD, N. J., April 13 -- Twenty angry mothers succeeded today in having a twenty-seven- car ammunition train removed from a spur 300 yards from the Spotswood Grammar School, after taking their children out of school in protest against a possible explosion.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 13 -- Adlai Stevenson, completing a four-day visit today, said in praising Indonesia that she was the only Asian nation to achieve independence through revolution and had maintained it by suppressing a Communist coup d'etat. He made the statement in a press conference shortly before his departure for Singapore

BOSTON, April 13 (AP) -- A quartet of 165-pounders provided the National A. A. U. boxing championship tournament with most of its first-night thrills as 95 of the 137 entrants waged trial round battles at the Boston Garden.

OTTAWA, April 13 -- Canada will spend more than the proposed $5,000,000,000 on her three-year defense program and the Government is prepared to extend the program beyond the original time set, Defense Minister Brooke Claxton announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Responsible observers among Federal employes on the "cold war" propaganda and diplomatic firing line at the edge of the Iron Curtain report a serious loss in morale and effectiveness at a time when the utmost energy, audacity and ingenuity of Americans abroad may be required to counter the Soviet "peace offensive" and preserve the unity of the Western alliance.

NEW DELHI, India, April 13 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared at a well-attended public meeting today that India welcomed Communist China's new proposal for a Korean armistice. He said the offer made by Chou En-lai, Communist Chinese Premier, for peace in Korea had been "received with pleasure by some and perplexity by others."

ALBANY, April 13 -- A bill to permit the 100,000 public employes in the state who are not members of any retirement system to obtain coverage under the Federal Social Security Act was approved today by Governor Dewey.

Shirley Booth, star of the current Arthur Laurents comedy, "The Time of the Cuckoo," will not renew her run-of-the-play contract when it expires on May 31. Her decision, she explained, was based on a desire for a much-needed vacation. Thus, the Robert White-head-Walter Fried production, housed at the Empire Theatre since last October, will be taken off the boards after the performance of Saturday evening, May 30.

Spectacular divertissements from Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus will be features of the pageantry to be presented at the entertainment, known as the April in Paris Ball, to be held next Monday night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel for the benefit of various charitable organizations here and abroad.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, denounced today on the ground of national defense the Holland Bill, now before the Senate, that would give to the states title out to their historic boundaries over coastal submerged lands.
TOKYO, April 14 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 584, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Tuesday, Korea time:
PANMUNJOM, Korea, April 13 -- Preparations for Operation Little Switch, which were continuing apace, were marked today by a noteworthy flurry of activity just behind United Nations lines.

Hold That Door Some years back when the Independent Subway was first put into service the public was for a time taken back by the uncompromising attitude of the Independent's double doors. New Yorkers had for decades been very gently treated by the IRT's shy and sensitive single doors, and now found the Independent's rather unfriendly, not to say a trifle frightening.

A steel and gilt bronze chair made by Thormire for Marie Antoinette, a fabulous Coromandel screen dating from 1550, a pair of Reisener lacquer commodes with bronzes by Gouthiere, a black lacquer chair elaborately inlaid with mother of pearl, and a glass menagerie are only a few of the rarities included in a series of room settings opening to the public today.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- In a seventeen-minute session today, the Supreme Court handed down one short opinion remanding a prison whipping case to a lower court, issued a few miscellaneous orders and recessed until April 27.
MILWAUKEE, April 13 (AP) -- The Braves' front office sent Outfielder Sam Jethroe to their American Association farm club at Toledo today on twenty-four-hour recall.
OTTAWA, April 13 (Canadian Press) -- The clash over a nickel in the International Wheat Agreement may appear to be petty dickering, but actually millions of dollars are at stake.

With only the Cincinnati Red-legs and the new Milwaukee Braves beating the gun yesterday, all clubs in the two major leagues will swing into action today, with an estimated 236,000 fans due to sit in on the eight contests.

Commodity prices were irregularly lower yesterday in light trading on the New York exchanges. The world sugar market, however, showed, sizable volume. Coffee, wool, potatoes, zinc, tin and rubber closed lower. Cocoa, soybean oil and hides were higher and sugar, cottonseed oil and lead ended mixed.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- The American Legion said today there should be more rigid screening of veterans with nonservice-connected disabilities who applied for treatment at veterans hospitals.
The insurance workers of New York, the city's largest blood-donating group started a two-week drive here yesterday by giving the Red Cross 225 pints.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Albert J. Fitzgerald, president of the United Electrical Workers, which was expelled by the Congress of Industrial Organizations for following Communist policies, told a House Labor Committee today that he charge of "communism" against labor leaders and unions had been proved to be nothing more than an attack on effective collective action.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, recommended today that Congress revise a tax law under which United States citizens living abroad seventeen out of eighteen months need not pay income tax on their earnings abroad.

The nation's newspapers, book publishers and authors were urged yesterday by Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, to join hands in a crusade against censors seeking to "spoon feed" the public with selected reading.
LONDON, April 13 -- Stock market trading was marked by caution today, investors preferring to wait for the Chancellor of the Exchequer's national budget tomorrow before making new commitments.

Small home owners in Queens pleaded yesterday at an "informal" hearing of the City Planning Commission that residential areas be safeguard against the encroachments of commercial and manufacturing enterprises.

Led by sharp increases in men's wear and shoes, sales of leading mail order and chain store companies showed a rise of 12.1 per cent in March over the same month last year, according to a compilation of forty-three companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

THE anglers who accepted the bright sunshine of opening day with some delight and considerable surprise accepted the overcast that followed with resignation, and the more experienced anglers who traveled to the Catskill streams were prepared for a rapid change in the weather.

MILWAUKEE, April 13 -- In his book "A Short History of Milwaukee," William George Bruce says "none of the historic events which has determined the fate of mankind or the fortunes of nations has been enacted in this region." The statement seems authoritatively sound and hardly calculated to arouse any sectional anger.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission issued a complaint today charging the National Electronic Distributors Association, Inc., Chicago, and thirty-seven wholesale-distributor members with practices tending to create a monopoly in the sale of radio parts and other electronic equipment.

When moral problems arise with adolescents, parents who feel inadequate in handling them should be willing to admit their own shortcomings rather than preach to youngsters or extoll their own moral virtues "as if they were wearing a halo,"

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., April 13 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, called tonight for a "complete, impartial investigation" of the country's military spending program aimed at a $10,000,000,000 reduction and a subsequent tax cut, beginning in 1954.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 13 -- President Eisenhower flew from rain-swept Washington today into the sunshine of his favorite vacation retreat to rest and wrestle with two knotty statistical problems: how to cut Federal expenditures below $69,000,000,000 a year and his golf score below 90 a round.
Television may reap benefits from Twentieth Century-Fox's conversion to its new wide-screen CinemaScope process, it was hinted yesterday by Spyros P. Skouras, president.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., April 13 -- Dr. Robert R. Smith, chief surgeon of the National Cancer Institute, said today that cancer control and public health education were closely linked. He underlined this interdependence by citing the value of mass chest X-ray tests in detecting a form of lung cancer that has been increasing in recent years.

The five six-story store and apartment buildings at 3301 to 3319 Broadway have been acquired by Francis Rogers through the purchase of the stock of Concord Properties, Inc., from Seymour M. Tannenbaum, real estate operator. Berman Lachover were the brokers and the City Title Insurance Company insured title.

BONN, Germany, April 13 -- West German industrialists have launched a campaign in the name of free enterprise to force the Government in Bonn to sell vast state-owned industries built and developed over a period of generations.

DETROIT, April 13 -- The unemployment directly caused by the strike at the Ford Motor Company plant in Monroe, Mich., rose to 47,000 today as the company closed thirteen of its nineteen assembly plants across the nation.

The eighth annual exhibition of "Amateur Needlework of Today," will open today at the Hammer Galleries, 51 East Fifty-seventh Street. Proceeds will go to the Friendship Fund of the Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind. Admission will be $1.

NEW HAVEN, April 13 -- The naming of thirty-six leaders in business, industry and the professions as members of a new Industry Advisory Council to the Yale Engineering Association was announced tonight by E. Carlisle Hunter, president of the association, at an organization meeting on the university campus.
Futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, 1 point lower to 4 points higher than on last Friday.

The wastefulness of the democratic system is one of the disadvantages we must all put up with in order to preserve the great virtues which are equally a part of democracy. Apparently it has been impossible to work out an arrangement to keep George Kennan in diplomatic work. This is a decided loss to the United States at a time when we can ill afford such losses.

A strike at Macy's five department stores in the metropolitan area became technically effective at 12:01 A. M. this morning, but company and union representatives continued to meet long after the strike deadline in an effort to end their contract dispute before the stores' doors were scheduled to open at 9:45 A. M.

BOSTON, April 13 -- Gov. Christian A. Herter of Massachusetts tonight invoked a state law giving him authority to seize twelve eastern Massachusetts milk distributing companies because of a strike by route drivers.

CORNELIUS McGILLICUDDY, a chipper young fellow of 37, packed his suitcase at the end of the 1900 season and left Milwaukee in order to open up shop in Philadelphia. He has been in Philadelphia ever since. The chances are that he will visit the Yankee Stadium today to watch his Athletics open against the Bronx Bombers.

Competition of supermarkets with drug stores was cited yesterday as an argument against an increase in minimum hourly wages for drug store workers in this state. In opposing an increase in the present minimum, Seymour Jefferies of the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy, said that super-market sale of national-brand toiletries and proprietary products was causing an annual loss in business of $30,000,000 to drugstores in the state.

PRETORIA, South Africa, April 13 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan, in a final radio appeal to the electorate tonight, declared that he considered Wednesday's election as "South Africa's last chance to remain a white man's country."

The Police Department has established a new "courtesy" squad to serve downtown Brooklyn, the city's second largest shopping area. Modeled after the Midtown Squad that operates in Manhattan, the unit's primary purpose will be to "assist lost shoppers."

WATERTOWN, N. Y., April 13-- The 100th anniversary of the invention of the bedspring was observed today in this city, where James E. Liddy first conceived the idea of using a buggy spring to provide more comfortable sleeping for mankind.

Mayor Impellitteri asserted last night that the "Dewey transit authority" was certain to result in a fare increase for subway riders and he urged New Yorkers to hold responsible those "giving" them the increase.

Reports were heard on the waterfront yesterday that some longshore leaders, including Alex DiBrizzi, boss of the Staten Island piers, had left the city as a result of the arrest of Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L. Ryan was indicted on Monday for pocketing $11,390 of union funds.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 14 -- In some respects the world economic situation has virtually reversed itself during the last two years, Eugene R. Black, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, reported today to the United Nations Economic and Social Council.

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 15 -About 700 sick and wounded Chinese Communist prisoners en route to Panmunjom to be released staged a sitdown strike in a United States Navy landing ship today, but it was broken up by American soldiers.

Blood donors in the metropolitan area contributed 1,307 pints of blood Monday to the American Red Cross, half of it from personnel at military posts. Fort Monmouth gave 283 pints, Fort Totten 216 and Fort Jay 177.

Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, the new United States Ambassador to Italy, sailed to her new post yesterday aboard the Italian liner Andrea Doria. She was accompanied by her husband, Henry R. Luce, editor in chief of Time, Inc., and her sister-in-law, Mrs. Maurice T. Moore.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, said today that authority to impose import controls on dairy and other agricultural products in emergency periods should be given to the President rather than the Secretary of Agriculture.

Defense counsel in the investment banking anti-trust trial charged the anti-trust division of the Justice Department with circular reasoning and legerdemain in its effort to make Government evidence bear out the charge of conspiracy.
It will soon be possible to buy an apartment in a department store.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 14 -The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested Ernest C. Munroe, a city councilman here, and twentyone other persons today in a move to smash an alleged coast-to-coast automobile theft ring. The roundup followed the returning of secret indictments by a Federal grand jury yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (UP) -- Government records disclosed today how the old Maritime Commission helped a Greek ship owner avoid taxes on his income from six surplus United States tankers recently seized by the Justice Department.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, prices 3 to 7 points net higher on active months than on Monday.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- New hope for a reduction this year in individual income taxes was held out by House Republican leaders today.

LONDON, April 14 -- The British housewife learned tonight from the budget speech of Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler that she would soon obtain a bigger sugar ration to enable her to provide her family with the little extras they crave at teatime.

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 15 -- United Nations liaison officers at Panmunjom asked the Communists today to furnish information regarding the nationalities of the sick and wounded prisoners of the Korean war who will be delivered Monday -- the first day of Operation Little Switch.

Trygve Lie, who retired last Friday as the United Nations first Secretary General, urged member nations last night to increase their collective security efforts, both regionally and through the world organization, and to share the military and economic burdens "on an equitable basis."

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, denied today that he had played any role in an investigation of Federal Judge T. Alan Goldsborough who imposed fines totaling $2,100,000 on John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers.

RICHMOND, Va., April 14 -- William M. Tuck, Democrat and former Governor of Virginia, was elected to Congress today in a special election. The race had attracted wide interest as an indication of the trend in a normally Democratic area that had voted Republican in last November's Presidential election.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Mrs. Jane Morrow Spaulding of Charleston, W. Va., was appointed assistant to the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 14 -- One man was bayoneted to death and three were critically wounded by gunfire in day-long sporadic street fighting in the downtown area of Teheran today. Heavy detachments of policemen and soldiers thwarted an attempt by the outlawed Tudeh (Communist) party to stage a mass demonstration in Parliament Square.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Kenneth C. Ray, former Ohio Director of Education, has been recommended by Senators John W. Bricker and Robert A. Taft, Ohio Republicans, for nomination as United States Commissioner of Education.

GREENVILLE, Miss., April 14 (UP) -The directors of the Cotton States Baseball League today reinstated the Hot Springs, Ark., club, which was ousted last week for refusing to release two Negro players.

BOSTON, April 14 (AP) -- It was snowballs instead of baseballs today at Fenway Park. Members of the Red Sox offered "Merry Christmas" greetings instead of wishing each other good luck for the opening of the American League season as an unexpected snow storm forced postponement of today's and tomorrow's games between Washington and Boston.

A second access road at the Fort Lee, N. J., approach to the George Washington Bridge has been opened by the Port of New York Authority in order to help speed rush-hour and week-end traffic over the big span to Manhattan.

One of the incidental, but important, functions of the annual budget message in any country is that it offers an excellent opportunity for taking stock not only of the Government's financial position but of the state of the national economy.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (UP) -- Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson today withdrew for further study an order designed to cut Army, Navy and Air Force information staffs and funnel military information through his own public information office.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Dr. Wallace R. Brode, Acting Director of the National Bureau of Standards, told the Senate Appropriations subcommittee today that the bureau had been under "terrific" pressure to report favorably on a commercial powder designed to lengthen the life of storage batteries. Included in the pressure, he said, were letters from twenty-four Senators.
More than 700 persons attended the annual welcome-home dinner for the Yankees last night at the Concourse Plaza Hotel, Bronx. Among the guests was Connie Mack.

Shipping under construction in United States yards on April 1 reached its lowest point in the last twenty-one months, with only eighty-two ships building or on order, the Shipbuilder Council of America reported yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, April 14 (AP) -- Pitcher Virgil Trucks set down his old team-mates, the Tigers, with four hits as the Browns scored a 10-0 victory tonight in their opening American League game.

THE Yankees won the toss at midfield before the game yesterday and elected to defend the north goal so that their punters would have the benefit of the following wind. Vic Raschi kicked off but his opening boot had no distance. The Athletics surged downfield until the Yankees braced with their backs to the goal line. Then the A's settled for a field goal.

Custom smelter intake of scrap copper more than doubled last month -- the first full month following the end of Government price controls on the scrap market. Mine production of copper was off slightly on an average daily output basis, while refined copper deliveries to fabricators increased, the Copper Institute reported yesterday.

An amendment to the Sherman Act to permit United States industries to set up foreign production units limited to specified overseas marketing areas without risking anti-trust prosecution was proposed yesterday by a major business organization.
Seven persons, including the former chief of the Internal Revenue Agent's office in Troy, N. Y., and four men who worked under him, were named here yesterday in two Federal grand jury indictments.

ALBANY, April 14 -- Governor Dewey approved today a bill authorizing a new design for the construction of "skip floor," fireproof apartments in New York City and Buffalo. The design provides increased cross-ventilation and better lighting for dwelling units.
JOHANNESBURG, April 14 -- South Africa's national elections is in danger of getting snagged in the law courts, as was last year's bitter constitutional crisis.

The opening of the baseball season at the Yankee Stadium and Ebbets Field yesterday was blamed for at least a degree of absenteeism among "first-string" members of the Board of Estimate as budget hearings droned through their second day at City Hall.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Justice Department said today that it would move on April 28 to drop criminal charges against an alleged international petroleum cartel. A civil suit under the anti-trust laws will be filed in Federal District Court here on April 21 against major United States and other oil companies, the department added.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Eisenhower Administration was challenged today for the first time to state specific charges for the dismissal of a policy-making bureau chief who was appointed in President Truman's Administration under Civil Service regulations.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The United States will agree to reopen the truce talks in Korea and will propose that all prisoners of war who do not wish to return to their homelands be turned over to the jurisdiction of Switzerland.

SEATTLE, April 14 -- A crippled chartered airliner carrying soldiers crashed into a snow-covered mountainside before dawn today, but rescuers reported that eighteen of the twenty-five persons aboard had survived.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 14 (AP) -- The chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation said today he expected a "good year and a full order book" in 1953 for the nation's second largest steel-producing company.

The City Administration must share with the state the blame for the "educational crisis" in which the municipal schools and colleges find themselves as the result of the city's financial troubles, the Board of Estimate was told yesterday by several of thirty-seven speakers who appeared at a city budget hearing.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Republican of Massachusetts, suggested today that the Maritime Administration might have gone too far in eliminating $118,500,000 from its new budget for the construction of four passenger ships and a prototype tanker.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (UP) -House of Representatives investigators charged today that the tax-payers got stuck with $2,600,000 worth of useless fork lift trucks that "exploded" under the driver when he tried to start them.
CHICAGO, April 14 (AP) -- Rocky Marciano, world heavyweight champion, arrived today to resume training for his title bout with Jersey Joe Walcott May 15.

PARIS, April 14 -- Politics, economics and the Mona Lisa smile of Georgi M. Malenkov, Soviet Premier, are combining to make exceedingly difficult the task of the Western statesmen and generals now assembling in Paris to decide how strong the North Atlantic Treaty armies should be by the end of this year.

In a frost-bitten setting that saw red noses provide the dominant color scheme, the four-time world champion Yankees set out in quest of their fifth straight American League pennant at the Stadium yesterday. But they didn't get very far.

With transports with the sick and wounded moving from both sides toward the point of liberation a resumption of the Korean truce negotiations now appears in sight. It is essential for the United Nations, therefore, to work out programs for both the larger peace negotiations that are to follow an armistice and for the actual truce negotiations themselves.

It was raining, which was not unusual for this season. What was unusual was the size and color of the umbrella visible through the door to this department. It was a brownish umbrella, hue and circumference suggesting that it might once have been attached to a peanut vender's stand, or a pretzel seller's wagon.

HANOI, Vietnam, April 14 (AP) -With Vietminh troops inside its borders in force, the little Kingdom of Laos ordered general mobilization of its manpower today to fight alongside the French, against the Communist-led rebels.

SINGAPORE, April 14 -- Adlai Stevenson arrived at Kuala Lumpur today to start his three-day visit to the Malayan Federation with the announcement that he was "traveling as a private citizen," and that there would be "no speeches on this tour." But he answered a barrage of questions from waiting newspaper men as he hurried along the airfield runway in the blazing sunshine.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Public Housing Administration announced today that seventeen local housing authorities had sold $95,544,000 in short-term loan notes at competitive bidding.

Three buildings, including the Ice Palace, at the northeast corner of Atlantic and Bedford Avenues in Brooklyn have been sold to individual buyers by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company. The entire ownership was offered at $300,000 and the transaction was negotiated by M. C. O'Brien, Inc., as broker.

HAVING toured a dozen public streams without witnessing the taking of a trout on any lure other than garden hackle, we stopped at the Dutchess Valley Rod and Gun Club near Pawling to see how the fly fishermen were putting in their time and were rather surprised to find them taking a toll of nice rainbows on dry flies.
New Yorkers will get their first view of the Army's new 280-mm. atomic cannon at the Armed Forces Day Parade down Fifth Avenue on Saturday, May 16.

Differing frown six other inquiries into the Voice of America now in progress, the investigation being directed by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, appears to have sharpened a cleavage among the employes who conduct the radio arm of the country's counter-offensive in the "cold war" from half a dozen office buildings along West Fifty-seventh Street.

The Metropolitan Opera has made a flat and final offer of a 2 per cent increase to all the employes represented by thirteen unions at the Opera House for next year. Since these terms appear to be unacceptable to two major unions -- those representing the instrumentalists and the stage hands -- there is a distinct possibility that there will be no opera at the Metropolitan next season.

Mr. Jamieson won the feature race, but it was Native Dancer, the Kentucky Derby favorite, who gave the 20,767 fans at Jamaica their biggest thrill yesterday, even though the pari-mutuel machines were silent as he went six furlongs in 1:14 2/5.

President Eisenhower's move for greater unity among nations of the Western Hemisphere -- the recent appointment of his brother, Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, as personal Latin-American representative--was hailed here yesterday before representatives of twenty American republics as "one more proof of the fraternity between nations."

New issues of corporate securities aggregating more than $55,000,000 will be offered to investors today. The offerings include debentures, convertible debentures and common stock of industrial enterprises, public utility mortgage bonds and preferred stock, and capital stock of a fire insurance company.

VIENNA, April 14 -- The Socialist party organ, Arbeiter Zeitung, usually friendly to the United States, declared today in an article by Oskar Pollak, its chief editor, that Senator McCarthy's "terror methods" did not differ essentially from those employed by the Nazis or Russia's G. P. U. (secret police).

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 14 -- Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies opened his Senate election campaign in the City Hall of Brisbane tonight. Brisbane was chosen for the occasion because, despite the emphatic Labor party majority in the recent state election, it is on Queensland that the Government is depending for preservation of its Senate majority at the election May 9.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. announced today that a Federal Grand Jury in Detroit has indicted three corporations on charges of anti-trust conspiracy in the machine tools field. The Department of Justice described this as the first major anti-trust action by this Administration.

Although it has built up its circulation to 1,300,000, Quick magazine will be discontinued as an entity with the June 1 edition and merged with Look magazine. Subscribers to Quick will receive Look for the unexpired terms of their subscriptions or have their money refunded if they wish.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Senate Rules Committee unanimously recommended today against restoring to Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon the two important committee seats he had held as a Republican, but lost when he became an independent.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- President Eisenhower soon will nominate Dr. Frances Elizabeth Willis, senior woman career officer in the United States Foreign Service, to be this country's first Ambassador to Switzerland.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., April 14 -- William J. Grede, chairman of the board of directors of the National Association of Manufacturers, declared here tonight that the housecleaning started by the new Eisenhower Administration is threatened by selfish groups and communities seeking Federal handouts.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 -Delegates to the sixth annual convention of the National Federation of Financial Analysts Societies were told today that companies equipped to cope with the scientific demands of "the coming atomic age" would face the greatest challenge in history during the next quarter century.

CHICAGO, April 14 (UP) -- Randy Jackson doubled to drive home two runs in the eighth inning today and give the Cubs their fourth straight opening-day victory, a 3-to-2 decision over the Reds before 21,222 Wrigley Field spectators.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 14 -- A broadcast over the Belgrade radio today was the latest in a series of attacks by Yugoslav trade union leaders on United States trade union leaders, in particular, David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, for their opposition to Yugoslav participation in the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions.
Eight thousand striking employes at Macy's returned to their jobs at 3 P. M. yesterday after a five-hour walkout that hampered but did not halt operations at the world's largest department store.

HARTFORD, April 14 -- Gov. John Davis Lodge sent to the General Assembly today the Superior Court nominations of James C. Shannon of Bridgeport, former Governor, and Charles S. House of Manchester, the Governor's legal adviser and a member of the Republican State Central Committee.

Combustion Engineering, Inc., was adopted yesterday by stockholders as the new name of Combustion Engineering-Superheater, Inc. At the meeting Marteus H. Isenberg was elected president and several other top executive changes made.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- The Department of Defense today identified 192 Korean war casualties. The new list reported 27 dead, 142 wounded and 23 missing in action. None were reported from Connecticut. Those reported from New York and New Jersey follow:
Six semi-finalists were chosen yesterday in the twentieth Young Artists Auditions of the National Federation of Music Clubs, now holding its biennial convention here.

The State of Delaware borrowed $6,000,000 yesterday on bonds maturing serially from 1954 to 1973. The issue was sold at public sealed bidding to a syndicate headed by the Guaranty Trust Company and Kuhn, Loeb Co. at a bid of 100.30 for interest of 2 per cent. A syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., bid 100.188 for 2s.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, April 14 -- A new plan for the joint international financing of a vital part of the North Atlantic Treaty defense program over three years is reported to be under consideration at high levels in the alliance's organization.

The American Civil Liberties Union urged yesterday that Walter Gieseking, German pianist scheduled to perform here next Wednesday, be permitted to enter the United States regardless of his alleged association with the Nazi movement.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Treasury closed its books today on cash subscriptions for the new 3 1/4 per cent thirty-year bond with indications that it would prove the most heavily oversubscribed issue in many years. Secretary George M. Humphrey said the subscription figure and the basis on which allotments were made would probably be announced Friday.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- President Eisenhower is almost through with his hospitable project of entertaining all the members of Congress and now Mrs. Eisenhower is going to have all their wives come to the White House.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 14 -Michael Curtiz, a top director at Warner Brothers, who has been responsible for several of the studio's biggest successes, has submitted his resignation instead of taking the salary cut asked of the executive staff last week.

LONDON, April 14 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler gave Britain a budget today that cut income and sales taxes as well as corporation levies in a program designed to give incentive for greater production.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 14 -- President Eisenhower, whose campaign pledges included one to reduce Governmental competition with private industry, today recommended to Congress prompt enactment of legislation for the sale to private interests of Government-owned synthetic rubber plants with a capacity of 806,500 long tons of rubber annually.
TOKYO, Wednesday, April 15 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,585, for the fwety-four hours ended, at 6 A. M. Wednesday, Korea time:

Much the best color television yet seen, enjoying good stability and definition and projecting hues restful to the eyes, was demonstrated yesterday by the Radio Corporation of America. The color program was broadcast over Channel 4 and owners of present TV sets could see the show in the usual black and white.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Secretary of Labor Martin P. Durkin told the country's prospective 1953 college graduates today that their chances in the job market were excellent.
