The installation of undergraduate officers at Barnard College and the presentation of honorary service awards to eleven seniors took place yesterday afternoon in Barnard Hall, Broadway and 117th Street. The new president, Miss Susan Nagelberg, a junior, was installed by Miss Renee Madesker, a senior, retiring president of the Undergraduate Association.

World sugar was extremely active yesterday on the New York Exchange, registering its largest volume since the reopening of the market on July 15, 1948. Rubber and hides also were active but most other commodities were quiet. Prices closed irregularly lower with sugar, wool, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, lead, zinc and tin showing declines.

CHICAGO, April 14 -- A dispute between E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc. and General Motors Corporation over the rejection of a personal plea by Gen. Robert E. Wood, chairman of Sears, Roebuck Co., for supplies of a refrigerator gas was disclosed today at the du Pont anti-trust trial before Federal District Judge Walter J. LaBuy.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 -- To every other club in the National League, Robin Roberts of the Phillies may be a pain in the bat, but to the Giants, baseball's biggest winner of 1952 is just another fellow who stands on a mound and throws baseballs.

LONDON, April 14 -- The budget statement of R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, came after the stock exchange had closed. However, the subsequently justified expectation that the budget would contain tax concessions to companies and a wide reduction of the purchase tax gave an all-around life to the industrials.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, made mystery of a luncheon talk today with Wilton B. Persons, a White House aide. But word spread on Capitol Hill that he was angling for Administration backing of his new moves to divert Greek shipping from trade with the Communists.

SEOUL, Wednesday, April 15 (AP) -High speed Sabre jets -- used for the first time as fighter-bombers -- devastated a big Communist troop concentration area in western Korea yesterday, blasting twenty-one buildings and leaving huge fires.

ROME, April 14 -- A little more than one week before the meeting in Paris of the powers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the fortnightly magazine Esteri, which accurately reflects the opinions of the Italian Foreign Ministry, warned the Western powers not to allow the Soviet peace overtures to lead them into the error of abandoning or relaxing their efforts to create a powerful European defensive force.

The Paramount Pictures Corporation and its consolidated domestic and Canadian subsidiaries increased operating revenues to $106,090,044 in the fiscal year ended on last Jan. 3 from $95,933,381 the year before, Barney Balaban, president, reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders.

ALBANY, April 14 -- The Public Service Commission announced today that it had authorized the Consolidated Edison Company of New York to convert from mixed to natural gas service in the Douglaston, Bayside, Little Neck and Flushing districts of Queens.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 14 -- Leendert A. Donker, the Dutch Minister of Justice, referred today the United States request for the extradition of Harold J. Adonis, former executive clerk in the office of New Jersey's Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, to an Amsterdam court for a new opinion.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (UP) -The Agriculture Department disclosed today that it had offered to sell the armed forces 50,000,000 pounds of butter from its surplus stocks at a price "competitive with" oleomargarine.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, April 14 -- "U. S. A. Today," an exposition of the American way of life presented by the United States Information Services and the Mutual Security Agency to show the British people how ordinary men and women in the United States worked and played, opened here today.

Interest in the stock market broadened yesterday and prices turned upward for the first time since last Wednesday. The "Street" was particularly cheered by the larger volume that accompanied the higher prices, following the reduced volume that attended the easier markets of Monday and late last week.

As reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES, Judge Sidney Goldmann, in a New Jersey decision filed April 6, has vigorously reaffirmed the American ideal of a free press. A Prosecutor in Middlesex County, acting on the advice of a so-called "citizens' committee," had circulated a list of "objectionable" titles and "suggested" to distributors operating in the county that they withdraw the titles from sale.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Brig. Gen. Bernard L. Robinson, Deputy Chief of Army Engineers, endorsed today a proposal to form a Government corporation to build, maintain and operate a portion of the St. Lawrence Seaway totally within the United States, the project to be self-liquidating over a period of fifty years.

Researchers of the American Stock Exchange had a busy day yesterday, and it was largely because the "Curb" tape had some of the appearance of a 1929 market. At one time during the morning a $1,000 bond of the Piedmont Hydro Electric Company crossed the tape at 90, up 16 points on its first sale since last September.

The Henry Street Settlement presented last night in its Henry Street Playhouse, 466 Grand Street, a musical work entitled "Universal Declaration" as the feature of a program arranged in honor of the settlement's sixtieth anniversary.

MOSCOW, April 14 -- Charles E. Bohlen, new United States Ambassador paid today what he described as a "purely prtocol call" on Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, preparatory to presenting formally his ambassadorial credentials later this week.

CINCINNATI, April 14 -- The Rev. Dr. Paul S. Rees, president of the National Association of Evangelicals and one of the top-ranking theologically conservative church leaders in this country, formally protested here tonight what he said were "severe, misleading and irresponsible attacks" made upon his organization by the ultra-conservative American Council of Christian Churches.
William Inge's play, "Picnic," was named yesterday "the best new American play" of the 1952-53 season by the New York Drama Critics Circle. Arthur Miller's drama, "The Crucible," was runner-up.

The substitution of industrial capacity ready for quick action in an emergency for part of the country's military stockpile, was urged last night by Harold S. Vance, president of the Studebaker Corporation and consultant to the Office of Defense Mobilization.
CLEVELAND, April 14 (UP) -- Bob Lemon hurled a one-hitter and smashed a home run today to lead the Indians to a 6-0 opening-day triumph over the White Sox.

THE eighty-four pastel-colored birds that darted and did acrobatics in the Delman Easter window at Bergdorf Goodman's in Fifth Avenue last week ungeared the social habits of the window dressers who dreamed up the idea.
The American Red Cross is the instrument chosen by the United States Government to aid in fulfilling the obligations of the

WASHINGTON, April 14 (UP) -- The Long Island Transit Authority charged today that the Pennsylvania Railroad was seeking unnecessarily legal delays in reorganizing the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road Company.

CHICAGO, April 14 (AP) -- Cattle receipts tapered off to 4,000 today after Monday's near record run of 29,000. Most prices were steady to 25 cents higher although the market generally was slow. Slaughter steers and yearlings were mostly steady, some yearlings were strong, and heifers were steady to 25 cents higher.

Today marks the twenty-fifth anniversary of Doubleday's Crime Club, whose registered trade-mark is the gunman that spells out the word "C-R-I-M-E." The organization, devoted solely to the publication of detective stories, issues four new titles every month and, by the end of this year, will have published 1,220 books by 293 authors.

The City Council approved yesterday by a vote of 16 to 2 a law permitting the use of fly-ash, a waste product of powerhouse boilers, in controlled concrete. Minority Leader Stanley M. Isaacs, Manhattan Republican - Liberal, strongly opposed the measure and implied that the Consolidated Edison Company was behind it.

The circumstances surrounding the dismissal of Dr. Allen V. Astin as director of the National Bureau of Standards require clarification. In firing Dr. Astin Secretary of Commerce Weeks has raised a number of questions that we hope will be answered at the public hearing on the Astin affair to be held next week by the Senate Small Business Committee.

An interesting use of accessories, paintings and objets d'art -- elements increasingly important in contemporary decorating -- enlivens a series of newly decorated model rooms at Bloomingdale Brothers. Oriental, English, French and modern American examples are presented against modern backgrounds.
HARTFORD, April 14 (UP) -- A group of Connecticut citizens opened a new attack on a law prohibiting the sale and use of birth control devices today by demanding that Gov. John Davis Lodge enforce it.

PRETORIA, South Africa, April 14 -- South Africa's approximately 2,600,000 voters go to the polls tomorrow to choose between race-conscious nationalism, with a hard-and-fast program, and a middle-of-the-way, rather unclear doctrine of crossing your bridges when you come to them.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A fight to restore the $9,814,333 United States contribution to the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund is being waged here by nine national organizations cooperating with the American Parents Committee and the Citizens Committee for the Emergency Fund.

Celanese Corporation of America is retiring from commercial weaving of textile fabrics, Harold Blancke, president, said yesterday In a statement, he said that the Staunton, Va., plant of the company would be closed permanently about June 1 and future woven fabric activities would be confined to experimental and promotional goods for the company's customers.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 14 (AP) -- The California champion, Barbara Romack of Sacramento, knocked four strokes off women's par today to capture the medal with a 72 in qualifying play of the women's Trans-Mississippi golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Portland Gas and Coke Company, said to be the largest user of gas in the Pacific Northwest, favored proposals to import natural gas from Canadian reserves at hearings today before a Federal Power Commission examiner.

LANCASTER, Pa., April 14 (AP) -- The Hamilton Watch Company postponed the election of four directors because a competitor was forbidden by a Federal Court order to take part in today's scheduled meeting of stockholders.

The recent conference sponsored by the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce of the University of Pennsylvania on how to reduce governmental intervention in labor-management relations was timely, constructive and challenging. The participants included spokesmen for labor and management groups that are actively engaged in collective bargaining, veteran mediators and arbitrators and state and federal officials familiar with labor relations.

CHICAGO, April 14 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, urged a large audience of Chicago and Milwaukee GermanAmericans tonight to contribute heavily to a "refugee loan" to aid 10,000,000 refugees in his country who had fled from Soviet occupation areas of Eastern Europe.
BOSTON, April 14 -- New England counted five persons dead today in the wake of the heaviest April snowstorm to hit the region since 1888. The fall ranged from two inches to one foot.

MUNSAN, Korea, Wednesday, April 15 -- If Communist reports to United Nations officers here are correct, and in this case there is no reason to believe they are not, sixty-five vehicles filled with sick and wounded Allied prisoners are moving through North Korea on their way toward Panmunjom.
The season of "American Dance" presented by the B. de Rothschild Foundation opened auspiciously last night at the Alvin Theatre before a large and quite distinguished audience.

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 15 -- About 700 of the 5,800 Commu nist captives scheduled for exchange began the first leg of their journey toward Panmunjom yesterday. Formed into groups of twenty-five -- the agreed unit of exchange -- they were loaded aboard landing ships at Cheju Island, off the South Korean coast, en route to Pusan.

THE natural man (who knows how to live life to the hilt, yet can seldom pass on his knowledge) has been celebrated in too few books these days. His twentieth-century successor, the rational man (who knows most of the answers, yet has no way of motivating his personal fulfillment) has also been pretty much in limbo lately -- at least among the novelists.

BOSTON, April 14 (AP) -- Heavyweight Jack Scheberies of Oakland, Calif., the only 1952 winner back to defend his title, led forty survivors into the semi-finals as the National Amateur Athletic Union boxing championships rounded out two days of rugged action tonight at Boston Arena.

An event in the career of Constance Bennett, film star and elder sister of Barbara and Joan Bennett, will be registered tonight when she makes her local stage debut in "A Date With April," opening at the Royale. For the premiere, the curtain is advertised to rise at 8 o'clock.
Residents of the Williamsburg section chased a bull through the streets yesterday morning, but Brooklyn is not Spain, and there was little fiesta spirit about the affair.

BOSTON, April 14 (UP) -- Maurice Richard tallied three goals tonight as Montreal beat the Bruins, 7 -- 3, before 13,909 at Boston Garden to give the Canadiens a 3-1 lead in the four-out-of-seven Stanley Cup hockey finals.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -A quick end to most Federal rent controls was proposed in the House of Representatives today, in the face of Administration recommendations, and a Senate committee's approval, for keeping them in force longer.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -A second former United States soldier pleaded guilty today to a conspiracy to give United States military secrets to the Soviet Union, and a Government official said there might be more arrests soon in the Communist spy plot.
Frederick E. Gibson, well known Long Island home builder, has purchased a large tract in Brightwaters, Suffolk County, L. I., for a development of ranch homes which he has named Greystone.

In a move that union leaders predicted might set a national pattern, employes of the Sperry Gyroscope Company approved yesterday a contract Junking their old cost-of-living "escalator" clause and incorporating into their regular wages 18 cents an hour in cost-of-living pay increases the 12,000 Sperry workers had received in the last three years.

The letter from Borden H. Mills in regard to election laws arouses interest. Surely a man of his experience should know that "the directly elected representatives of all three parties" (the County Committeemen) are actually designated by the district leaders and "elected" by a handful of party voters rounded up by the committeemen at the primaries.

NEWARK, April 14 -- Edward Richard Fredericks, a 42-year-old insurance company clerk, was said to have confessed here today to the killing of his wife, Ruth Hilda, 34, at their Los Angeles home last Jan. 6. The woman's body was discovered Feb. 10 in the desert near Ensenada, Mexico.

NASSAU, Bahamas, April 14 -A fifteen to twenty-mile breeze stirred a choppy sea today for the opening race of the Star Class spring championships in Montagu Bay as Jack Price of Miami pulled Comanche ahead of Robert Lippincott of Riverton, N. J., in Flower, which hit a reef on the last lap for home.

Early bulletins from the states where "sugarbush" is tapped for sap indicate that supplies of maple syrup and sugar are going to be limited this year. Prices now are holding to 1952 levels -- about $5 to $6.25 a gallon -- but predictions are that they will rise as the scarcity begins to be felt.

MILWAUKEE, April 14 -- The baseball readjustment of this city took place today in accordance with the hastily revised plans of the National League, and Milwaukee is now a big-league entry. The Braves, for a half-century the representatives of the National Loop in Boston, performed here for the first time for the honor and glory of Milwaukee, and the event was witnessed by about 36,000 fans, 34,357 of whom paid to watch the proceedings.

Eight short films representing both color and black-and-white works of the pioneer experimentalist, Oskar Fischinger, during the last twenty-five years, have been made available for renting through the Film Library of the Museum of Modern Art.

A small collection of imaginative and unusual hand-print drapery fabrics designed by artists was introduced yesterday by the Associated American Artists at 711 Fifth Avenue, where they are available. The fabrics, shown in settings, are on view through April 30.

Lewis K. Gough, national commander of the American Legion, said last night that the United States must take the offensive in the long "cold war" that will follow Korea and that, however distasteful, we should wage the "mind war" with the identical weapons "being used against us with disastrous effect."

CHICAGO, April 14 -- Wheat futures had a weak tone today, the bearish sentiment engendered by recent crop estimates tending to restrict outside buying, even though prices now look attractive to many. Corn and oats held well, and rye prices had narrow price swings.

Fourteen groups of winners of the Brand Names Foundation's Retailer-of-the-Year contest were the guests of manufacturers and trade publications here yesterday at various luncheons between tours of plants and advertising agencies.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 14 -- Sir Gladwyn Jebb, the British representative in the United Nations, appealed today to the Soviet Union to agree to an armistice in Korea and to the settlement of specific East-West issues as proof that it was carrying on its current peace offensive in good faith.

Warren Neuberger, 21-year-old senior right-hander, held New York University's baseball team to three hits as his City College mates rapped Vinnie Lupica for nine blows and a 5-1 victory at Ohio Field on the University Heights campus yesterday.

The forty-first season opener at Ebbets Field began on a threatening note yesterday but the home-run clouts of Roy Campanella and Duke Snider, plus eleven other Brooklyn blows, turned it into a success.
A retrospective exhibition of seventy paintings of the old West by William Robinson Leigh opened yesterday at Grand Central Art Galleries, 15 Vanderbilt Avenue.

The situation in Iran is clearly approaching some sort of a climax and it is therefore important to try to understand what is happening. On the face of it, there is a struggle for control between Premier Mossadegh and the Shah. In reality, the state of affairs is more complicated than that.

The election of nine directors, a new slate of officers and a chief executive officer was announced yesterday by the Old Town Corporation. The company manufactures duplicating machines, carbon paper and duplicating supplies.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 14 -- The most effective treatment known for the nation's most common fatal disease, an artery condition called atherosclerosis, is simply to reduce weight, it was suggested here today at the annual meeting of the American College of Physicians.

Events today: National Federation of Music Clubs, luncheon concert, grand ballroom, Roosevelt Hotel, 12:30 P. M.; Federation teaconcert, Town Hall Club, 5; Mikulas Grosz, violinist, and Mae Gross, pianist, Carl Fischer Sky Room, 3:30; "Der Rosenkavalier," City Center, 8:15; "Cosi fan tutte," Juilliard Concert Hall, 8:30, and United Singers of Greater New York, Carnegie Hall, 8:15.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 14 -- An organizing drive to bring stewards on West Coast ships into a local of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union became a possibility today.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Harold Glasser, a former Government economist who gave advice at international conferences to the then Secretaries of State George C. Marshall and Dean Acheson, refused to tell the Senate Internal Security subcommittee today whether he now was or had been a Communist during twelve years of Federal service.

Oswald D. Heck of Schenectady, Speaker of the State Assembly, dismissed as ridiculous yesterday Mayor Impellitteri's charge that the state was "short-changing" New York City in the distribution of state assistance payments.
CHUNCHON, Korea, April 14 -The Army today demonstrated the capabilities of a revolutionary helicopter company that has just arrived in Korea.

Relative to your story on the death of Malvina Thompson, for so many years friend and secretary of Eleanor Roosevelt, some of us who valued "Tommy" would like to suggest the need of adding to your familiar and essentially just picture of her as an "unobtrusive shadow."

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- The President's recommendation marked another move toward restoring the nation to a free economy. It followed a recent series of orders abolishing Federal controls over wages, prices and other segments of the economy.

BONN, Germany, April 14 -- The prestige won for Chancellor Konrad Adenauer by his conferences with President Eisenhower in Washington is expected to be an important, perhaps even a decisive, factor in West Germany's national election.

With the announced purpose of encouraging more and better driver training courses in the high schools, the Allstate Insurance Company will put into effect today a young driver discount plan that will cut by 5 to 15 per cent the auto liability insurance of parents of high school trained drivers.
George Antheil's comic opera, 'Volpone," will receive its first New York performance July 7 to open the 1953 season of Punch Opera at the Cherry Lane Theatre.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Charges of powerful Communist influence in Hawaii exploded today into a Congressional controversy.
Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber reserved decision yesterday after long argument on a taxpayer's suit to declare unconstitutional the proposed New York City transit authority.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 14 -- News that the United States, which holds the unified command of United Nations forces, had decided to resume armistice negotiations at Panmunjom was generally welcomed here tonight. A number of Western delegates had begun to express impatience over the fact that there had been no word about the resumption of negotiations despite the conclusion Sunday of the agreement for the exchange of sick and wounded prisoners.
Made in Italy, exclusively for B. Altman Co., a collection of summer sandals with definite Continental charm was shown yesterday morning in the store's shoe salon.

Beatrice Brown, who conducted three "Art Music Concerts" last season at the Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A., last night led the first of two similar concerts at the same auditorium. The program was free, as will be the second one on April 28.

The Blair Holdings Corporation management charged yesterday that sponsors of a stockholders' derivative suit alleging that directors of the company were guilty of "gross mismanagement and dissipation of assets" obtained the signature of the stockholder plaintiff through misrepresentation.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 14 -- Friends of the British General Orde Charles Wingate, including Premier David Ben-Gurion, gathered this afternoon on a pine-clad hilltop of the Carmel Range overlooking the Mediterranean to dedicate to the memory of the general a new Youth Aliya village called Yod Yemin Orde, which means "the right hand of Orde."

Francis E. Power, principal prosecution witness in the perjury trial of John E. Gleason Jr. in General Sessions, underwent a full day of cross-examination yesterday, but his story of the payment of fuel oil shakedown funds to Frank J. Sampson at City Hall emerged basically unshaken.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (UP) -The Food and Drug Administration now can tell quickly whether foodstufss have been contaminated by atomic radiation.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 14 -A heavy increase in postwar population, which has seen Greenwich grow to a community of 44,000, nearly 10,000 above its 1943 population, has been accompanied by real estate sales which have exceeded $137,000,000 during the past decade.
Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld ruled yesterday that a grand jury did not have the power to accuse without returning an indictment.

TRENTON, April 14 -- With only six days left before the primary election on Tuesday, three of the four major candidates for the Democratic and Republican nominations for Governor increased the momentum of their campaign today; the fourth took a day off to rest for the final drive.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Reed Harris, who clashed sharply with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, in a Congressional hearing early last month, resigned today as deputy director of the State Department's International Information Administration.

A small collection of new furniture is displayed in some handsome settings in the newly redecorated and enlarged showrooms of the Kittinger Company, 305 East Sixty- third Street. The furniture is available through decorators.

CLEVELAND, April 14 (AP) -- Kid Gavilan, welterweight champion, ran into unexpected opposition in Livio Minelli of Italy to night and barely managed to gain a split decision in their ten-round bout in Cleveland Arena before a crowd of 10,151.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -The American Newspaper Publishers Association today accused the International Typographical Union, A. F. L., of conducting sixty-eight strikes against 106 newspapers in "defiance and disregard" of the Taft-Hartley Law.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 14 (UP) -- Mrs. Jackie Pung of Honolulu, playing one of her best rounds since she turned professional, took a two-stroke lead today as the $3,000 first annual Palm Springs Women's open golf tournament started.
LONDON, April 14 (Reuters) -- Comparing income tax between the United States and Britain is a problem that has knit many an economist's brow -- and involved G. I.'s here in endless tavern debates.

ROME, April 14 -- In a speech this morning to several hundred leaders and members of the Civic Committees, Pope Pius made it clear that the Center parties, and particularly the Christian Democrats, will have the full moral support of the Church in their efforts to win this summer's general elections.

Jack L. Warner, who recently bought the residence at 1 Riverview Terrace, corner of Sutton Square, has resold it through Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers in the original deal, to a client of N. K. Winston Co. for occupancy.

The girls of today are facing a "difficult assignment" in living, and there is danger of their becoming "to efficient, too ambitious, too dominating, too artificial, too anxious and too demanding of themselves and others," Dr. Mary Fisher Langmuir, head of the child study department of Vassar College, told a meeting of the Girls Clubs of America last night.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 14 -- The dispute between the Netherlands and the United States about arms deliveries has revealed, hardly a week before the North Atlantic Treaty Organization conference in Paris, how far apart the Allies still are on the organization's goals and military aid procedure.

Many of your readers were startled when they read the headlines in your April 9 issue: "U. S. Would Accept Peace in Divided Korea; Considers a U. N. Trusteeship for Formosa." The dispatch by Anthony Leviero seemed to present such a complete reversal of the public's understanding of the Administration's whole foreign policy that in any paper of lesser stature than THE TIMES it would have been dismissed as irresponsible sensationalism.

PARIS, April 14 -- Several prominent champions of the strong secular and anti-clerical tradition in France issued a warning today to the Roman Catholic Church not to attempt to re-establish some of its lost temporal power.

YONKERS, April 14 -- Yonkers Raceway, spruced up and refurbished, was pronounced ready today for tomorrow night's opening of its fourth season of operations, which begins the metropolitan area's 184-night program of harness racing.
BALTIMORE, April 14 (UP) -- The Maryland Racing Commission today barred Larry MacPhai] owner of the Bowie race track from his own track, pending hearing April 23.

MEXICO CITY, April 14 -- Sentiment in favor of Australia retaining the 1956 Games appear edto be increasing today among members of the International Olympic Committee after the circulation of a detailed report by the Australians outlining their preparations for staging the games.
BONN, Germany, April 14 -- Negotiations are under way in Bonn for an eight-year $80,000,000 capital investment loan to Yugoslavia.
WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, asserted today that it was up to Congress to decide when Alaska was ready for statehood.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- A Senate Small Business subcommittee heard complaint today that the Department of Justice had been lax in enforcing Federal anti-trust laws in the motion-picture industry, and that if something were not done about it, the small theatre-owner might be wiped out.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in effect today accused Harold E. Stassen, Director for Mutual Security, of torpedoing efforts to get a group of Greek owners in London to withdraw their ships from trade with Communist China.

Mayor Impellitteri told the audience at one of the now concluded public hearings on his $1,528,812,795 expense budget that if citizens wanted a better budget, presumably a bigger budget, they should "make their fight" in Albany rather than here and that Albany was "the source of all our trouble."

Viscountess Astor sailed for home yesterday on the Cunard liner Queen Mary, with a parting shot for Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Wisconsin Republican, and an admonition for new United States Ambassadors.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Thursday, April 16 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's Nationalist party was steadily drawing ahead of the opposition United party in returns available early today from yesterday's Parliamentary election.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Charles Chaplin, film comedian, apparently has decided not to challenge the plan of the Department of Justice to seek his exclusion from the United States because of alleged subversive tendencies.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The techniques and effects of organized mind perversion of individuals by Communist Governments, which the Chinese have given the name of "brain-washing," was the subject of a very informing speech just made by the chief of this Government's principal unit engaged in collecting such information and determining its accuracy.

Unless any reduction in our foreign aid for defense against Communist aggression is matched by liberalizing our commercial policy to permit Western Europe to pay for the goods it must buy from us by sales in the American market, defense goals are bound to suffer, Felix Belair Jr. of THE NEW YORK TIMES Washington Bureau said yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, April 15 -- Superior Court Judge Haydn Proctor set aside today the places awarded on voting machines to candidates for the City Commission election here on May 12 and ordered City Clerk James A. Tumulty to hold a new drawing.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Further declines were registered in grain futures today. An overnight accumulation of selling orders gave the market a weak start, and while there was a fair midday recovery it was short-lived and pressure was fairly constant later.

Basil Goulandris, Greek ship-owner and one of the four brothers who operate the 150-ship fleet of the Orion Shipping and Trading Company, said yesterday that to the best of his knowledge "not an ounce of illicit trade has been carried in Greek-owned bottoms to Red China."
William W. Remington, 35-year-old former Government economist, surrendered yesterday at the United States Court House to begin a three-year prison term for perjury.

The Staff Officers Association of America, A. F. L., picketed two Brooklyn piers of the Isbrandtsen Company yesterday, halting loading of three of the company's ships when longshoremen refused to cross the picket lines.

ALBANY, April 15 -- The juvenile delinquency rate in New York State decreased slightly in 1952 from the figures of the year before, Lee C. Dowling, executive director of the State Youth Commission, reported today.

The thrills and frills of the season's opener out of the way, the Yankeees thawed out with the weather at the Stadium yesterday and finally got around to taking that first important step toward a coveted fifth straight American League pennant.

LONDON, April 15 -- In view of Scottish Nationalist objections to Queen Elizabeth's being called Elizabeth II, Prime Minister Churchill agreed today that in the future "whatever numeral in England or Scotland were higher" should be used in the sovereign's title."

Remembrances of the trial of eleven Communists before Judge Harold R. Medina, and an attack on the sociological motivation for the anti-trust investment banking suit, figured in courtroom colloquies yesterday as defense counsel in the banking suit continued to argue for dismissal of the complaint.

TRENTON, April 15 -- In final drives to win votes in Tuesday's primary election three of the principal candidates for the Democratic and Republican nominations for Governor today concentrated their attention on the more heavily populated counties.

When I undertake to drop you a note I hardly know how to make it specific or what to say, because my thought is the accumulation of impressions over a considerable period of time. I have always understood that THE NEW YORK TIMES stands practically at the top of the list as a worthy newspaper.
The cotton futures market was steady yesterday and closing prices on active months were 10 points higher to 1 point lower than on Tuesday.

LONDON, April 15 (Reuters) -Hugh Gaitskell, former Chancellor of the Exchequer, assailed the Conservative Government's "incentive budget" today, calling it "phony propaganda" and a rich man's program. He said the glitter of the tax reductions was a camouflage for the "stagnation into which British production has fallen."

PARIS, April 15 (UP) -- Claude Milazzo of France scored an easy ten-round decision tonight over Norman Hayes of Boston, and the referee asked the French Boxing Federation to hold up the American's purse.

Wall Street has been getting an unsatisfactory look in the last few days behind the shower curtain that covers the financial splashings of big league potentates. Lewis Stoehr, Inc., an investment house, has been offering fi00 shares of stock in the St. Louis Browns baseball club at $11.25. It has sold 200.
CHICAGO, April 15 (UP) -- A female psychologist said today a woman who wanted to become successful in the business world should cultivate "feminine" rather than "mannish" characteristics.

President Eisenhower must soon face his second "personal test" on tariff-trade policy. He will be required to act -- by May 13 at the latest -- as the result of a Tariff Commission investigation into competitive effects of a variety of silk scarves imported chiefly from Japan, import trade sources pointed out yesterday.
Baseball already may have had its inaugurals in a number of places, but so far as the Old Guard of the Polo Grounds is concerned, it hasn't opened yet.

General sessions Judge Saul S. Streit granted a motion by the District Attorney's office yesterday to dismiss a perjury indictment against William (Bill) Spivey, former University of Kentucky basketball star.
The discovery of a deposit of at least 40,000,000 tons of nickel-cobalt ore in the vicinity of Moa Bay, near the eastern end of Cuba, was announced yesterday by the Freeport Sulphur Company.

A campaign to rally state-wide support for a law requiring automobile drivers to pass periodic physical and mental examinations has been started by the Bronx County Medical Society and the Bronx Chamber of Commerce.

Just half of the day's volume and all but a handful of the gains in price came in the two morning hours on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Thereafter the market drifted lower until near the end, when a little added interest carried prices above their lows but left them well below their highs.

STROUDSBURG, PA., April 15 -- The Delaware tributaries, on the Pennsylvania side, had their full quota of opening day anglers, but like those who turned out for the New York and New Jersey openings on Saturday, the early-morning fishermen had the heaviest creels.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., April 15 -R. Ford Hughes, chairman of the Suffolk County Republican Committee, announced today that he would resign as County Clerk, effective June 1. The vacancy will be filled until the end of the present year by appointment by Governor Dewey and a successor for the balance of Mr. Hughes' unexpired term will be chosen at the November election.

The National Community Relations Advisory Council, the coordinating body of six national Jewish organizations and twenty-eight local councils, announced a joint plan yesterday to eliminate duplication in the field of Jewish community relations for this year.

CANNES, France, April 15 (AP) -- The Sixth International Film Festival opened here tonight to determine the best movies and individual performances of 1953 in the twenty-seven participating countries.

There will be no tax reductions until the Eisenhower Administration finds out how deeply it can cut the budget that was bequeathed to it, Representative Charles A. Halleck, Republican of Indiana, Majority Leader of the House, told the Brand Names Foundation here last night.

Three attorneys who had agreed to help speed the disposition of negligence cases reported yesterday at the State Supreme Court, Centre and Pearl Streets. They were sworn in as special referees by Supreme Court Justice Thomas L. J. Corcoran, to serve without pay for thirty days.

FRANKFURT, Germany, April 15 -- The United States will stick to its "fundamental" policy of developing the Combat strength of the United States and Allied armed forces, Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, declared here today.

The City Planning Commission took action on the first of the major improvements projected for the Fort Greene slum clearance area in downtown Brooklyn yesterday when it approved plans for the $3,714,073 Kingsview non-profit medium-rental cooperative housing development.

From Martin's Fruit Shop, 1042 Madison Avenue, has come a tip on the first-of-the-season arrival of midget or "refrigerator" watermelons. These sweet, juicy specimens weighing only four or five pounds were developed three years ago at the University of New Hampshire by Prof. A. F. Yeager.

While most investors thought Ward M. Canaday, president of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., threw a "life preserver" to Edgar Kaiser, president of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation when Willys agreed to sell its automotive assets to a Kaiser subsidiary, it looks more like a millstone to Col. K. O. Cuttle, chairman of the Kaiser-Frazer Stockholders Protective Committee.

BALTIMORE, April 15 (UP) -A. Baltimore syndicate has been quietly buying St. Louis Browns stock in the hopes of eventually gaining control and moving the club here, it was learned today. The syndicate already has made an offer for the team, but Bill Veeck refused it.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 15 -- As a surprise development of today's proceedings of the United Nations Commission on Narcotic Drugs, Harry J. Anslinger, United States representative, disclosed that three Americans seized last March 21 aboard a yacht leaving Hong Kong were captured by Communist narcotics smugglers led by a notorious woman pirate.

Russ Meyer, acquired by the Dodgers as pennant insurance in exchange for a couple of expendables in a winter trading coup, made his debut in Brooklyn flannels yesterday. The results were highly pleasing to Manager Charley Dressen and the 3,149 of the Flatbush faithful who turned out at Ebbets Field for the Flock's second game of the baseball season.

State Rent Administrator Joseph D. McGoldrick obtained yesterday an order from Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter directing the A. J. Clarke Management Corporation of 451 Lenox Avenue to show cause Monday why a temporary injunction should not be issued restraining the agency and landlords it represents from engaging in acts leading to the eviction of Harlem tenants.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- The University of Chicago has announced the establishment of a special project in parent education to help parents create environments for their children conducive to the development of mature, responsible citizens.

One hundred eighty feet below the sidewalk in Madison Square, workmen are stopping up a leak in the city's plumbing. The break is less than a quarter of an inch wide, but it had been wasting at least 1,000,000 gallons of water daily.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, April 16 (AP) -- Allied warplanes hit the Communists yesterday all across North Korea -- except for an attack-free corridor along the route the Reds said they were using to convoy United Nations sick and wounded prisoners toward repariation at Panmunjom.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 15 -- President Eisenhower will give the peoples of the world tomorrow his judgment of their chances for global peace this year.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- Leo Durocher is aware that "you can't win 'em all," but what happened to his Giants today was ridiculous. On this the second day of the season, defeat caught up with the New Yorkers at Connie Mack Stadium, where the Phillies, behind the five-hit pitching of Curt Simmons, pinned

I am a Navy Hospital Corpsman stationed aboard a hospital ship anchored in Inchon Harbor about three miles from the city of Inchon, Korea. I am writing this letter to try to explain to the folks back home the importance of sending clothes and whatever they can to the people of Korea.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- An estimate from General of the Army George C. Marshall, dated Sept. 27, 1950, when he was Secretary of Defense, that the fighting in Korea would end by June 20, 1951, was placed today in the record of the Senate Armed Services subcommittee investigating ammunition shortages.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Senator Charles W. Tobey, chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, tried two weeks ago to set up a quick public airing of the dismissal of Dr. Allen V. Astin as director of the National Bureau of Standards.

A nuclear power plant capable of lighting a city's homes can be built within two to five years of an "all-clear" signal from the Government, according to a group of industrialists and educators, which has been organized under the name of Atomic Industrial Forum, Inc.

Led by a youthful president who believes in putting his college on the road at least once a year, the entire student body of Palos Verdes College, Los Angeles, Calif., visited New York this week. The thirty-seven students left last night after studying at first hand the things they try to master in the clasroom.

LONDON, April 15 (AP) -- Greek shipowners in New York are putting pressure on their London colleagues to sign agreements promising Senator McCarthy to stop trade with Red China, a spokesman for owners said today.
Additional action by the waterfront grand jury against five notorious waterfront figures is expected soon, according to a report current yesterday in the Criminal Courts Building.
WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -The Eisenhower Administration renewed before a lukewarm House Banking Committee today its plea that general rent controls be extended until Oct. 1.

Ratification of a new contract covering 12,000 workers on military orders at the Sperry Gyroscope plant in Lake Success, L. I., was delayed yesterday by objections from night-shift employes. The contract had been approved by overwhelming vote of 5,000 day-shift workers at a meeting Tuesday.

BUENOS AIRES, Thursday, April 16 -- Torch mobs burned the Radical and Socialist party headquarters and the fashionable Jockey Club -- all anti-Peron strongholds -in a night of terror following a bombing yesterday that killed six persons at a big rally addressed by President Peron.

GENEVA, April 15 -- East-West trade talks here under United Nation auspices have got off to a very slow start. Trade experts say the chief barrier to the increased flow of trade across the Iron Curtain is the lack of salable export products in Eastern Europe.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 15 -- Polish anti-Communist leaders accused Moscow today of aiming for the "official incorporation" of Poland into the Soviet Union.

PARIS, April 15 -- The little Kingdom of Laos in Northwestern Indo-China used its recently gained independence today to appeal to the United Nations and the free world for "formal condemnation" of an aggression that it said had been made against it by the Communist-led Vietminh forces from the adjoining state of Vietnam.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 15 -- The highest appeals board for the staff of the United Nations began public hearings today on a case charged with political controversy: the demands for reinstatement filed by twenty United States citizens dismissed as the result of investigations into alleged subversive activities.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Senator Lister Hill, Democrat of Alabama, asserted today that the proposal to give title to submerged offshore lands, some of them rich in oil, to the coastal states was merely "a first step" in a raid on natural resources belonging to the whole country.

The creation of armored corps and the restoration of the principle of mobility to the modern United States Army by emphasizing the role of the tank is strongly advocated in the current issue of the military magazine Armor, the voice of the Army's tankers.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- An effective formula for evaluating the fairness and objectivity of newspaper, magazine, radio and television coverage of the 1952 Presidential election campaign cannot be devised, the executive council of Sigma Delta Chi, professional journalistic fraternity, was told today.

The cooperative advertising program initiated last week by the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation has been given a "shot-in-the-arm" by the confused state of color television, according to David J. Hopkins, advertising and sales director.

PARIS, April 15 -- The hopes for the imminent return of Robert and Gerald Finaly, Jewish war orphans who are the center of a struggle between Catholics and Jews, have been momentarily dashed by what appeared here to be the reluctance of Spanish Catholics, who now hold them, to let them return to France.

SAIGON, Vietnam, April 15 (AP) -- The French have picked Xiengkhouang as the base in Laos on which to make a stand against the invading Vietminh forces. All available civil planes have been requisitioned to help Army aircraft carrying troops and supplies from the big French base at Hanoi, 280 miles to the northeast.

Spring is a good time of year, no doubt of that. The air is soft, the sun is warm, the trees are budding, and the shad yield up their roe. It is a good time of year, no doubt of that. The poets are well within their rights to salute the spring, and the philosophers to gaze dreamily from their windows and not only at their inner souls.
GENEVA, April 15 -- A spokesman for the Swiss Federal Government said today that no request had been received by Switzerland to accept Dr. Frances Elizabeth Willis as United States Ambassador.

Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany, in effect ruled out Mayor Impellitteri for nomination on the Democratic ticket last night by defining the type of candidate for Mayor he believes the people of the city want.
CHICAGO, April 15 (AP) -- Everett B. Harris, secretary of the Chicago Board of Trade since 1949, has been named president of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the board of governors announced today.
The odyssey of a Mexican Chihuahua air-expressed to Miami to escape New York's wintry chills turned up in Federal Court yesterday -- all because of an unscheduled stop-over in the Bronx.

Trends in the decorative arts as reflected in wallpapers used from the mid-eighteenth century to the mid-Victorian era are shown in an exhibition that opened yesterday at the Newark Museum, 49 Washington Street, Newark.

LONDON, April 15 -- Britain and the revolutionary regime in Egypt have at last agreed to enter into negotiations on the long-standing Egyptian demand for evacuation of the British military base in the Suez Canal zone.

Albert M. Ash, deputy attorney general of New Jersey in charge of the Bergen County gambling inquiry, returned yesterday from the Netherlands after an unsuccessful two-week attempt to effect the extradition of Harold J. Adonis, former executive clerk to New Jersey's Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll.

LONDON, April 15 -- Publication of the budget yesterday with its ending of the excess profits levy and reductions in the purchase tax all domestic issues on the stock had a stimulating effect on nearly market here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. April 15 -- In a mutually conciliatory atmosphere, the United Nations Economic and Social Council agreed today to leave in the hands of the Secretary General for settlement its controversy with the United States over this country's contention that it is entitled to deny visas on security grounds to two representatives of non - governmental organizations to attend the sessions of the Council here.

MANILA, April 15 -- President Elpidio Quirino, who has announced his intention to run for re-election in November on the Liberal party ticket, lashed out at rival Nacionalista party leaders tonight in a radio speech. He accused them of "ultra-nationalism, foreign interventionism, pro-communism and sheer opportunism."
LONDDN, April 15 -- The position Britain will take on the Soviet peace moves and Western defense at the North Atlantic Council meeting in Paris next week was foreshadowed here today.
The Dow Chemical Company and its subsidiaries in the nine months ended last Feb. 28 had a net profit of $25,269,416 after all deductions, the company's report disclosed yesterday.

I have read your editorial on the Bricker resolution with interest and some astonishment, particularly its expression of a fear that it would "destroy the capacity of the President to fulfill his constitutional function of carrying on the foreign affairs of the United States."

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -The American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations joined today in opposing proposals before Congress to give the states a bigger share of unemployment compensation tax collections.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Arthur J. Altmeyer, who has been called the "father" of the Federal Social Security system, left his post last week after declining to serve out another four-week period that would have entitled him to full retirement rights.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., April 15 -- The illegal influx of Mexicans across the United States southwestern border has risen in the last month to a rate of more than one every thirty seconds, day and night.

DETROIT, April 15 -- Two strikes, in which more than 80,000 employes of the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation were made idle, ended today and both companies sought to restore fullscale production.
BOSTON April 15 (AP) -- Two college-trained sluggers beecame National Amateur Athletic Union boxing champions tonight at the Garden.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old, a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:
LAWRENCE, Mass., April 15 (UP) -- A man ran amok today, hacking and shooting seven members of his family to death before he committed suicide.

MEXICO CITY, April 15 (AP) -The International Olympic Committee informally discussed today the possibility of charging Olympic athletics entry fees or requiring them to pay their own expenses in an effort to reduce the number of participants in the games.
CHICAGO, April 15 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:

ROME, April 15 -- In a speech to a group of eminent psychotherapeutists and clinical psychologists, Pope Pius XII expressed today his approval of psychoanalysis as one of the weapons in the arnory of modern healers provided 'the truths established by reason and by faith and the obligatory precepts of ethics" were observed.

The consensus at a panel discussion last night on the topic, "Racial Bigotry in the Press," at the New York branch office of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, 165 West 131st Street, was that New York metropolitan newspapers had made "considerable progress" in the handling of news about racial minorities.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -Baseball is scheduled to make its belated bow in Washington tomorrow, with President Eisenhower throwing out the traditional first pitch. But all is not well, for the weather man says it's going to rain.

SOME twenty-odd years ago Jumping Joe Dugan of the Yankees stared in fascination at the first batting averages to be posted one Sunday in April. Like Abou Ben Adhem the name that led all the rest was Dugan's. Down at the bottom was that of Harry Heilmann The mischievous Dugan promptly circled both names and mailed them to Heilmann.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Administration's bill for a straight one-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act was introduced in the House of Representatives today by Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of upstate New York.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 15 (UP) -- Federal Judge H. Church Ford struck the name of Adolph Rupp, University of Kentucky basketball coach, from a half-million-dollar damage suit here today, then dismissed the suit entirely.

Some idea of the devastating effect on Government service of Senator McCarthy's investigations and of the Administration's steady retreat before him can be obtained from the series of three articles concluded yesterday in this newspaper. That Congressional committees have the right and in fact the duty to make investigations is not in question.

GENEVA, April 15 -- With the presentation of his budget in the House of Commons yesterday, Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler led Britain across the shifting but nevertheless definite line that separates Western Europe's "free" from "controlled" economies.

The three-story factory building at 125 Heyward Street in Brooklyn has been sold by Harry Koss and others to the Bais Yaakov Yeshiva of Williamsburg, Inc., which will renovate it and use it as a parochial school for girls. The Kalmon Dolgin Company was the broker.

There were certainly no secondnight blues last night at the Alvin Theatre where the B. de Rothschild Foundation is presenting its season of "American Dance." Another audience packed the theatre to overflowing and there was that air of lively concentration and released enthusiasm which characterizes a modern dance audience that it is really having a good time.

WEST POINT, N. Y., April 15 -- The pistols that Gen. George Washington carried as sidearms during the Revolutionary War were presented to the United States Military Academy today by Clendenin J. Ryan, New York financier and independent candidate for Governor of New Jersey.
PARIS, April 15 -- The first steps toward revision of the French finance and fiscal system and a proposal for a reform in the French constitution were approved by the Cabinet today.

On sales of $231,654,268, the Douglas Aircraft Company earned $4,389,787 in the quarter ended on Feb. 28, compared with $1,997,096 net income on sales of $81,271,046 in the same period a year before, Donald W. Douglas, president, reported at the annual meeting of stockholders held yesterday in Santa Monica, Calif.

Dollar Associates of California, of which R. Stanley Dollar, steamship executive, is president, has acquired an important block of common stock of Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc., operator of passenger and freight services to the east coast of South America and to Scandinavia.
TOKYO, Thursday, April 16 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,586, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korean time:

A general value of $48,000,000 was put yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri on management improvements that he said were developed by the city administration in the last five years. He put an additional value of $11,990,594 on improvements effected within the Board of Transportation.

A group of Columbia University's scholars have evolved something just a little different in the line of higher education and it deserves notice. This is what they have been calling, for want of a better name, the "University Seminar Movement." In reality it gives a new twist to the old institution of the seminar that has been a familiar part of our universities since the Eighteen Seventies.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 15 (AP) -- Pierre Langlois of France came back after two early knockdowns tonight to punch out a ten-round decision over Joe Miceli of New York in the main event at the Miami Beach Auditorium.

A sampling of what can be done with large plastics housings for radio and television sets, furniture, air conditioners, appliances, office machines and the like was shown yesterday to a group of 150 industrial designers, manufacturers and representatives of the plastics industry.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 15 -The joint judiciary committee of the Connecticut General Assembly held a hearing today on a bill that would forbid theatres, music halls and circuses in the state from barring front admission anyone who purchased a ticket, except those committing a nuisance or breach of the peace.
The Southern Company arranged yesterday for the underwriting of its offering of $14,000,000 of new common stock for underwriting compensation of 12.9 cents a share.

ALBANY, April 15 -- Governor Dewey signed a bill today that extended to public college and university faculties the provisions against subversive high school and grade school teachers contained in the Feinberg Law of 1949.

New York Roman Catholic charities allocated $3,147,854 to its 185 agencies and institutions last year, the Rev. James P. McKeown, head of the division of finance, reported yesterday to Msgr. James J. Lynch, director of Catholic charities.

Arthur Kelly, business representative for Mr. Chaplin in New York and vice president of the Celebrated Films Corporation, which owns the rights to most of Mr. Chaplin's films, said yesterday that the decision of Mr. Chaplin would not affect the management of his affairs in this country.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Senator Matthew M. Neely, Democrat of West Virginia, denounced President Eisenhower today for having offered "no word of censure" against C. Wesley Roberts, the Republican National Chairman who resigned recently under fire.
Spuyten Duyvil Parkway in the Riverdale section of the Bronx became Manhattan College Parkway yesterday after a sign-changing ceremony viewed by 300 Manhattan students and local residents.
CHICAGO, April 15 (AP) -- Another proxy battle, the second this year, is shaping up within the Webster-Chicago Corporation, manufacturer of radio, phonograph and electronic supplies.

Union Tank Car Company of Chicago plans a public offering of $20,000,000 of its sinking fund debentures to be dated April 15, 1953, and maturing April 15, 1973, according to a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Retailers should not succumb to fear psychology based on a Korean truce or predictions of a business readjustment, Bernard G. Cohn, president of the Independent Retailers' Syndicate said yesterday. He held that gains in retail trade are likely next fall provided merchants step up selling effort and coordinate quality throughout their stores.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 15 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, the Soviet representative, accused the United States today of "quibbling" and "digging up outlandish complications" about ...

Apparently Senator Paul Douglas of Illinois still has a great deal of educational work ahead of him if he hopes to bring the light of sound economics to the die-hard advocates of perpetually easy money among his colleagues. A group of eight of these Senators has underwritten a statement protesting the terms of the new long-term 3 1/4 per cent bond issue offered on Monday by the Treasury.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., April 15 (AP) -- An interim agreement was reached today between Sandia Corporation and union representatives, ending a short strike of 2,500 workers at Sandia Base, big atomic center here.

YONKERS, April 15 -- Wilmington's Star, 4-year-old owned by R. L. Craig of Urbana, Ohio, captured The Inaugural, one-mile pace that featured the opening of the fourth season of harness racing at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

TUNIS, Tunisia, April 13 -- The series of elections that began in Tunisia today and will continue until April 23 will be closely watched in this French protectorate because they represent the first serious attempt to implement the reforms that Paris is trying to introduce here in face of stubborn Nationalist opposition and reluctance on the part of the local French population.
BALTIMORE, April 15 (AP) -Larry MacPhail, dynamic sports promoter facing trouble with police and racing officials for his outspoken manner, today was reported to be suffering from cancer.

" Der Rosenkavalier" returned to the repertoire of the New York City Opera last night at the City Center. Strauss' work has been missing for several seasons. Its revival saw a cast that was, in the main, similar to previous ones, with leading roles sung by James Pease, Frances Bible and Virginia Haskins. A newcomer was Anne McKnight, singing the Marschallin.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (UP) -United States battle casualties in Korea increased by 496 last week to a new total of 133,463, the Deday. The second highest weekly figure since last Nov. 19, it reflected recent heavy fighting.

An elevator carrying twelve persons plunged out of control in a downtown office building yesterday noon and dropped three and a half floors before it was stopped by a safety device. Two men and a woman suffered ankle injuries and were taken to Bellevue Hospital. The other passengers were treated for shock.
The Treasury's new issue of thirty-year 3 1/4 per cent bonds sold at a premium of 1/4 of a point above 100 yesterday in the first public trading since the closing of subscription books on Tuesday.

BERLIN, April 15 -- East Germany's No. 1 Communist declared today that the Soviet Union sought a four-power conference on the reunification of Germany and demanded that the United States "show its readiness to accept."
The New York County Lawyers Association announced yesterday the appointment of a committee to study the proper scope of public report and comment on court proceedings.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -Representative Harold H. Velde, Chairman of the House of Representatives Committee on Un-American Activities said today that he was willing to talk informally with Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam, the Methodist churchman who has been outspoken in his criticism of the committee.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended April 8:

NEWARK, April 15 -- The deadlocked strike of 7,200 plant and accounting employes in New Jersey Bell Telephone Company ended its third week today, with service gauged at two-thirds of normal as 1,800 non-striking operators manned the key switchboards in the state on a sixty-hour weekly work schedule.
B. H. Wragge summer designs were shown yesterday by Bonwit Teller at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The designs of the attire were heightened by the colors and fabrics used.

The world's largest corporate enterprise, the $12,000,000,000 American Telephone and Telegraph Company system, had to put up the S. R. O. sign yesterday as more than 1,200 of its stockholders held their annual meeting at 195 Broadway, the concern s headquarters.

The volume of trading improved yesterday on the New York exchanges with lead and hides registering their third most active day of the year, the world sugar market approaching the previous day's record and zinc, rubber and cotton seed oil active.
LONDON, April 15 -- Peers of the realm lucky enough to draw an invitation to the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II have been receiving their summonses from the Queen this week.

Columbia scored two runs on two singles and three walks in the sixth inning to salvage a 5-5 tie with City College in a darkness-curtained seven-inning baseball game at Baker Field yesterday. It was the second tie in seven games for City. The Lavender has a 3-2-2 record, Columbia a 2-2-1 mark.

LINCOLN, R. I., April 15(UP) -- An ex-claiming horse named Harpes and Jockey Al Widman, both invaders from the New York racing circuit, teamed up today to win the 15,000 Lincoln Special Handicap -- richest race in the history of Lincoln Downs.

The Federal Administration and Congress were urged yesterday by the Shipbuilders Council of America to carry out national maritime policy by suitable recommendations and appropriations necessary to proceed with new construction or conversion of American-flag shipping.

Two more New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad trains were stoned yesterday as they passed through the Bronx. One jagged rock not only shattered a train window but it injured a soldier and spattered glass shards on other passengers.

Bond issues totaling $13,500,000 are planned for sale over the next two months by Kansas City, Mo. The city will receive bids on May 13 on $8,500,000 of water revenue bonds due from 1962 to 1978. On June 10, eleven issues of general obligation bonds totaling $5,000,000 and maturing over twenty years will be offered.

HARTFORD, April 15 -- The Joint Public Health and Safety Committee of the Connecticut General Assembly voted 11 to 8 today to favor a bill authorizing physicians to prescribe contraceptives for married women where their health was involved.

TOKYO, Thursday, April 16 -Dispatches from Korea said yesterday that United Nations planes spotting the progress of returning prisoners of war had flown through Communist anti-aircraft fire and observed an enemy build-up of supplies for the front along the roads designated to carry captives.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 15 -Every patient of every doctor is entitled to five or ten minutes of psychotherapy along with the pills, bandages and advice of a conventional visit, a psychiatrist suggested here today at the annual meeting of the American College of Physicians.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 15 -- Twentieth Century-Fox will depart from its exclusive Cinema-Scope production program to make "Water Front" as a standard type black and white drama about activities along the New York and New Jersey piers.

Legalizing off-track betting on horse races and the imposition of tolls on the four East River bridges were recommended yesterday to the Board of Estimate as methods of raising substantial new revenues to help balance the city's ever-growing budgets.

Recent discussions in these columns of the New York City transit fare problem, by Prof. William Vickrey (April 8) and Charles Madley (April 10), raise several issues of vital importance to the city's economic health.
A call for women volunteers to aid in registering and assisting blood donors at the New York chapter of the American Red Cross was issued yesterday by Mrs. E. Roland Harriman, chairman of volunteers.

WSHINGTON, April 15 (UP) -The United States delegate to the International Wheat Council expressed hope today that Great Britain still would decide to accept terms of a proposed extension of the International Wheat Agreement.

Gross income of the Hotels Statler Company last year increased $4,781,434 to $42,308,921, but earnings declined somewhat under higher operating costs, Arthur F. Douglas, president, reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The American newspaper editors are coming to Washington tomorrow to talk shop and have a look at the Eisenhower Cabinet. They are arriving at an appropriate time, for the relations between the press and the Government in this town are not precisely chummy.

A decline last week of 1,042,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 161,207,000 barrels, compared with 162,249,000 a week earlier and 157,781,000 a year ago.
Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of West Germany, who arrived yesterday by plane from Chicago, will receive New York's official welcome today at City Hall at noon.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 -The San Francisco Symphony Orchestra will play another season under guest conductors before a permanent leader is chosen to succeed Pierre Monteux, who retired last year at the age of 76 after directing the group for seventeen years.

Rear Admiral Sherman R. Clark will take over command of Destroyer Flotilla Four in a shipboard ceremony at the Norfolk Navy Yard on Saturday, relieving Rear Admiral Chester C. Wood for duty as deputy commandant of the National War College in Washington, it was announced yesterday.

Jack Benny plans to increase his television appearances next fall to once every three weeks, and will film six of the half-hour programs this summer. The six or seven remaining shows for the 1953-54 season will be done "live."
Proposed restrictions on imports of oil into the United States were described yesterday by Eugene Holman, president of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), as unwarranted and potentially harmful.

EL PASO, Tex., April 15 -- Officials of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the Mexican Confederation of Workers, closing a two-day conference here, today disclosed plans for an international committee to improve labor relations between the two countries.
YORK, Pa., April 15 (AP) -- Dr. Charles Maxwell McConn, former dean of Lehigh University and the Washington Square College of Arts and Sciences, New York University, died here today at 71.

VALLEY FORGE, Pa., April 15 -- The American Society of Ancient Instruments commemorated today the twenty-fifth anniversary of its founding with a concert at the Washington Memorial Chapel here. The concert was the first of three events to be offered by the society.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -The Senate's rash of investigations was broadened today with the Appropriations Committee's hiring of four former agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a practically unlimited field of Inquiries.

COLUMBIA, S. C., April 15 -Rene Pleven, French Minister of Defense, warned today that the free world nations "cannot run the risk" of side-tracking the development of the European Defense Community because on "the new attitude adopted by the new Government of Soviet Russia."

The color television system of the Columbia Broadcasting System, the only method to carry the official approval of the Federal Communications Commission, came off a poor second yesterday to the tinted video shown a day earlier by the Radio Corporation of America.
BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., April 15 -- Three men and a corporation pleaded guilty today to gambling charges tied to the operation of Newman's Lake House, a dine-and-dice house in Saratoga Springs, N. Y.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. William O. Reeder, who retired Jan. 31 as Deputy Chief of Staff for Army Supplies, conceded today that ammunition programming was "slow." He commented that it took about a month to get programs approved by the office of the Secretary of Defense.

BERLIN, April 15 -- Stefan Heym, a naturalized American author who won a Bronze Star fighting in the Battle of the Bulge, has taken his family to Communist East Germany, where he was born, and has asked for asylum there, the official East German news agency A. D. N. reported tonight.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Two officials of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., testified at the trial today that their tetraethyl lead salesmen are engaged in all-out competition with Ethyl Corporation for the gasoline anti-knock market. Evidence was presented at the marathon case before Federal District Judge Walter J. LaBuy.
A program for rejuvenating a waning American merchant marine was offered yesterday in a comprehensive report issued by the Committee of American Shipping Lines Serving Essential Foreign Trade Routes.

The defense in the perjury trial of John E. Gleason Jr. ended its cross-examination of Francis W. Power, a major prosecution witness, yesterday without ascertaining the nature of two visits the witness said he made to Fire Commissioner-designate George P. Monaghan in 1950 at the suggestion of Frank J. Sampson.

One of the biggest market distributions of textile stock in recent years took place yesterday in the form of a secondary offering of about $11,500,000 worth of common stock of American Viscose Corporation by a syndicate headed by First ]3oston Corporation.
WASHINGTON, April 15 (UP) -The Defense Department issued today a draft call for 32,000 men in June, 21,000 fewer than the number called up during each of the four previous months.

" State in the Making," an account of the diplomatic maneuverings from 1946 to 1948 that led to the establishment of the State of Israel, will be published by Knopf on Monday, the fifth anniversary of the proclamation of Israeli independence.

A strike of 1,400 grocery, produce and dairy clerks in 127 A. P. food stores in Brooklyn and part of Queens was called for 7:30 A. M. today by the Retail Food Clerks Union, Local 1500, A. F. L. The company said the stores would be open for business, despite the strike.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 15 (UP) -- Mrs. Jackie Pung of Honolulu scored her first victory since entering the pro ranks today by capturing the $3,000 Palm Springs open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -The American Red Cross said today that when United Nations sick and wounded prisoners of war cross into friendly territory next Monday they will:

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States representative to the United Nations, said tonight that one reason for the Soviet "peace offensive" was President Eisenhower's leadership of a strong and unified country.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The State Department assured Tokyo today of continued United States interest in the preservation of Japanese economic stability.
LONDON, April 15 (AP) -- Britain confirmed today that she would withdraw from the International Wheat Agreement.
PHOENIX, Ariz., April 15 (AP) -- Favorites, with the exception of Oregon's Grace De Moss, advanced today in the first round of match play in the women's trans-Mississippi golf tournament.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 15 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh has set the stage for a showdown tomorrow on the constitutional issue of whether he or the Shah, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, shall control the army, and his adherents spent today piling political gunpowder all over the place to bluff the opposition into reluctance to risk sparks.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -The United States has instructed Gen. Mark W. Clark, United Nations Far Eastern commander, what reply to give the Communists on their proposal to resume negotiations for a Korean armistice, officials here said tonight.

A deal is in the making that would bring Sig Miller's latest play, "An Ancient Instinct," to Broadway next fall under the banner of Donald Wolin. An agreement already exists, it is reported, between the author's representatives and the producer.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (UP) -The United Mine Workers Union today accused Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, of "clumsy appeasement" of supporters of the Taft-Hartley Act.

Two first-place prizes of $75 each in the American Automobile Association's ninth annual School Safety Poster Contest were won by Barbara Bomar, 15 years old, of 37-13 Eighty-Sixth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, Edward J. Reiger, safety director of the Automobile Club of New York, announced yesterday.

MARK TWAIN met Sholom Aleichem many years ago at a reception in New York. Aleichem was introduced as the Jewish Mark Twain, already famous for his timeless stories of European life, which are now classics everywhere. "I wanted to meet you," Mark Twain said, "because I'm told that I am the American Sholom Aleichem."

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Alcohol and Tobacco Tax Division of the Internal Revenue Bureau has reported that its agents destroyed 10,269 illegal stills and seized 5,700,599 gallons of fermenting mash in 1952. It estimates, however, that for every still seized ten continued to produced untaxed whisky, resulting in a loss of hundreds of millions of dollars to the Federal Government each year.

Representatives of the musicians' and stagehands' union said yesterday that they were negotiating contracts for the next two seasons with the Metropolitan Opera, and were confident that all problems would be resolved.
A large collection of furniture for every room in the house, inspired by French provincial designs, went on view yesterday in a group of room settings at McCreery's.

A banking syndicate headed by White, Weld Co. will offer to investors today $8,500,000 of new 4 per cent first mortgage bonds of the Jersey Central Power and Light Company, due in 1983. The bonds are priced at 102.2058 to yield 3.875 per cent.

Friends and associates dating back to the early days of the New Deal gathered together again yesterday to pay last respects to one of their inner circle, Miss lalvina Thompson, secretary, friend and companion to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt for the last thirty years.

To cheer sick and ailing youngsters, the walls of the new children's admitting and emergency service at Bellevue Hospital twinkle with gaily colored canvas murals of laughing clowns and smiling circus animals. The service, which will be opened on Monday by Emmett Kelly, the famous clown, and city officials, is believed to be the first separate admitting service for children ever instituted in a city hospital.

Jim Conway, trainer of Mrs. Ben F. Whitaker's 7-to-5 Grecian Queen, had the pleasure of seeing the 3-year-old filly outfoot the opposition in the $24,550 Prioress Stakes at the Jamaica track yesterday, but then he had a worrisome wait in the winner's enclosure while the stewards re-ran the race in the movie room.

Over in the Botanic Garden in Brooklyn, a tall, intent scientist is moving these spring days among the budding magnolia, cherry and crabapple trees performing mysterious rites with a gadget that looks like a small croquet mallet made of aluminum.

Probably the most unusual sports event New Yorkers can see takes place tomorrow through Sunday at the Armory at Columbus Avenue and Sixty-second Street, when such teams as the "New England Clippers" and the "University of Illinois Gizz Kids" compete for a national championship. All the basketball players in this tournament will do their dribbling and *qh0oting from wheelchairs,

Leon Jolson, president of the Necchi Sewing Machine Sales Corporation, made a down payment of $50,000 yesterday toward a $250,000 foundation he plans to establish to promote racial and religious amity in the United States.
