Five T-2 type tankers were taken over by the real estate concern of Webb Knapp, Inc., and its affiliate, the Pan-Oceanic Navigation Corporation, yesterday as the two companies bought all the shares of the Southern Trading Company of Wilmington, Del.

A race that was run at Jamaica last Friday turned out to be an important item in the order of business at the track yesterday. The race was won by C. T. Chenery's Queen's Moon, and the runner-up was Kitchen Maid, owned by Alfred G. Vanderbilt.

SALISBURY, N. C., April 16 (AP) -- President Eisenhower said today the United States must try to "convert" the peoples of the world -- even those in the Kremlin -- to the view that peace was possible.
LONDON, April 16 -- It has been some time since any pronouncement ment by a United States statesman has been received here with such universal acclaim as was President Eisenhower's address today.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Friday, April 17 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's Nationalist party has been returned to power as a result of Wednesday's election with its majority increased from thirteen votes in the previous Parliament to twenty-nine in the new Parliament of 159 seats.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- An opponent of the proposed St. Lawrence Seaway said today that its supporters had failed to show that it could be made to pay for itself.

A top-gallery spectator at the circus in Madison Square Garden last night attempted to "steal the show" with a high-wire act of his own. He failed to attract much attention, except in his immediate vicinity, but made a fifty-foot drop to the tanbark without suffering any apparent injury.

Many parties were given last night at the annual spring entertainment, known as the "Gay Thirties Dinner Dance," in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Boys Club of New York. Mrs. Jarvis Cromwell was chairman, and Mrs. Madison H. Lewis, vice chairman of the benefit committee.

CHICAGO, April 16 -- The Zenith Radio Corporation has stopped production of its new transistor hearing aids because of an unexpected flaw that showed up in field testing by human "guinea pigs," E. F. McDonald Jr., president, said today.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, United States Ambassador to Italy, said that "the embassy will continue to point out to Italian authorities the broader aspects of the problem of religious freedom."

America's educators were urged last night to take up their roles as "the priests of freedom and democracy." Dean Ernest O. Melby of New York University's School of Education advocated that teachers answer attacks on the profession by becoming outspoken exponents of the principles of freedom.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 16 -- Queen Juliana is reported to be keenly disappointed about the White House's chilly reception of her appeal for aid to refugees which her husband, Prince Bernhard, personally delivered to President Eisenhower last month.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Like the 1945 Vandenberg plan for a fifty-year alliance against the revival of German aggression and the Marshall Plan of 1947, President Eisenhower's foreign-policy speech was widely praised today as the kind of policy statement that could be effective in waging the "cold war" if necessary, or in ending it, if the Kremlin had the will.

The premium on the new Treasury issue of thirty-year 3 1/4 per cent bonds dwindled yesterday to 100 1/16 as the highly professional market of recent weeks put in another day of backing and filling, with markdowns prevailing at the close.

Scrutinize all aspects of freezer-food plans before buying. This was the advice given yesterday by George G. Cook, head of the frozen-foods department of Long Island Agricultural and Technical Institute. He addressed the opening session of the two-day conference of the New York chapter of the Electrical Women's Round Table.

LONDON, April 16 -- In a bleak religious mood, Graham Greene has written a literate and rather bloodless drama entitled "The Living Room," which opened at Wyndham's Theatre tonight. Although dramatic form often eludes novelists who are used to more time and space, Mr. Greene has made the transition competently.
New Yorkers who thronged to the suburbs in postwar years to live closer to the soil have been soaking up unpleasant lessons in the last six weeks on what people in the country do when it rains.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves increased $303,000,000 the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The principal changes supplying reserves were an increase of $122,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit and decreases of $143,000,000 in other deposits with Federal Reserve Banks, $27,000,000 in money in circulation, and $22,000,000 in Treasury cash holdings.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 16 -- Private citizens and welfare organization officials of Westchester County met here tonight to organize a private, county-wide, nonsectarian child adoption agency to be supported by private and public subscription.

ON the Matanzas at St. Augustine a coquina marker still advises the tourist that this is the Florida terminus of the Old Spanish Trail that once began in San Diego. If that same tourist chanced to motor to California he could still pick up markers of the old Camino Real far more easily than he could follow the drama of the same name now current in New York.

LONDON, April 16 -- Arthur Horner, the Communist General Secretary of the non-Communist British Miners Union, declared today his intention of going to the Soviet Union for medical treatment -- at his union's expense. He has been in poor health for some time.

In a dispatch from Los Angeles our correspondent Gladwin Hill reminds us that the illegal influx of Mexican farm workers into the United States is still rising and bringing in its train untoward social consequences with which we are not grappling.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's address to a luncheon of the America Society of Newspaper Editors in Washington yesterday, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

LONDON, April 16 -- Israel has asked the United States and British Governments for consultations on all aspects of the forthcoming treaty negotiations between Britain and Egypt that have a bearing on her interests. The negotiations will open soon in Cairo, it was announced yesterday.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 16 -- Tudeh (Communist) and Nationalist rioters sacked the United States Point Four regional office building in Shiraz last night and attacked the homes of United States staff members this morning.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, April 16 -- The first group of sick and wounded Allied prisoners of war arrived early this evening in Kaesong, a scant five miles by road from this neutral town. They were billeted in a stone building formerly used as a museum and will remain there until the first exchange of prisoners of the Korean war takes place Monday.

MANILA, April 16 -- Although the minority Nacionalista party has chosen its Presidential candidate, the ruling Liberal party will not hold its convention until May 23. The Presidential election itself is still seven months away.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 16 -- Suffering from the after-effects of food poisoning and running "a slight fever," President Eisenhower returned to his golfing retreat here tonight and went directly to bed under orders of his physician, Dr. Howard W. Snyder.
Emery N. Leonard has been elected a drector of the United Fruit Company. He has been with United Fruit thirty-four years.

Controller Lazarus Joseph reiterated last night his opposition to a transit authority in the form proposed by Governor Dewey and said he Would sooner go out of office than cast his three votes in the Board of Estimate in favor of it.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The House Banking Committee disregarded today the wishes of the Eisenhower Administration and voted to report favorably a bill ending Federal rent controls on April 30, except in critical defense housing areas. The vote was 16 to 10.

There are some technical difficulties in the matter of the appeal of Laos to the United Nations against Communist aggression. There may be some temporary ground of embarrassment to the French, and Paris is reported uneasy over the possibility of some type of United Nations intervention. This fear, in our view, is exaggerated.
MOSCOW, Friday, April 17 -- Soviet Justice Minister Konstantin P. Gorshenin warned today that any preaching of racial hatred or scorn in the Soviet Union would be punished by law.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., April 16 (AP) -- Dick Metz, a golf professional for nearly a quarter of a century, established a new competitive course record with an 8-under-par 61 here today to take the first-round lead in the $12,500 Virginia Beach open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, who was sworn in Saturday as Secretary of the new Department of Health, Education and Welfare, let it be known today that she preferred to be addressed as "Mrs. Secretary" -- not "Madame Secretary."

In its recent interpretations of Soviet events THE NEW YORK TIMES has regularly proceeded on the assumption that a struggle is in progress between Premier Georgi Malenkov and Interior Minister Lavrenti Beria. The main, indeed only, substantiation for this thesis is the supposed fact that Semion D. Ignatiev, former Minister of State Security and fabricator of the infamous "doctors' plot," is a protege of Malenkov.

CHICAGO, April 16 -- Grain futures rallied sharply from an early decline following the President's address, but the advance failed to attract any following of importance and all grain futures sold lower in late trading. Buying seemed to be based on the fact that the head of the nation disclosed no new peace moves of immediate significance.

If a trade-mark is not to be lost it is necessary for the owner to maintain watchfulness at all times, warns the National Better Business Bureau, Inc. For example, the bureau points out trade-marks are sometimes generically or descriptively used in news reports or editorials.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 16 -- Nearly every doctor carries in his bag a safe, simple and effective remedy for exposure to the deadly odorless and tasteless nerve gases that paralyze victims, the American College of Physicians was assured here today.

The American Broadcasting Company, which for the last couple of years has been living on rather meager rations, has served notice that it is now ready to give its network rivals some real competition.

A warning that "American civilian and military leadership * * * has lost faith in the most mobile ground weapon, the tank," is sounded by Brig. Gen. Paul M. Robinett, retired, in the current issue of the magazine Armor, the "voice" of the armored branch of the Army.

TRENTON, April 16 -- Nelson F. Stamler declared today that in his opinion there was little or no evidence to support the bribery indictment under which the state is seeking to extradite Harold J. Adonis from The Netherlands. He also expressed the opinion that the statute of limitations in respect to the bribery charges against Adonis had run out.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) -- Americans saved $14,600,000,000 last year, more than in any year since 1944, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

On a tour of four crowded Harlem tenements yesterday, State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman explained why three of them would have to be demolished and only one could be saved through his "block-by-block" rehabilitation plan.
NEWARK, April 16 -- A nervous, chain-smoking, 15-year-old boy confessed here tonight to the slaying of two men in a $53 tavern hold-up executed at the orders of his ex-convict father.

CHICAGO, April 16 -- Ralph J. Wirshing, research executive of General Motors Corporation in Detroit, testified today at the du Pont anti-trust trial before Federal District Judge Waler J. La-Buy that he never had been told to favor paints made by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., in reporting on tests made of various auto finishes.
MOSCOW, April 16 -- In an important declaration of principles, Pravda excoriated today individual leaders who acted as if they alone knew everything and took any criticism as a personal offense.

In a magnificent and deeply moving speech tinged with the idealism that guides this nation President Eisenhower has issued an appeal and a challenge to the new rulers of Soviet Russia to make good their words with deeds that would set the world on the road to a true and total peace.

PARIS, April 16 -- The fourteen powers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization have agreed to give priority on their agenda in next week's discussions by their foreign, defense and finance ministers to an analysis of Soviet intentions and capabilities.

Prices of foreign refined copper and domestic scrap continued to decline yesterday -- but tin prices turned upward for the first time since the revived Korean peace proposals weakened the world market at the end of March.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Friday, April 17 (AP) -- Following is the text of a letter from Lieut. Gen. William K. Harrison Jr., Senior United Nations armistice negotiator, delivered to the Communists today:

The Board of Education was informed yesterday that its radio station WNYE was the recipient of four national honors awarded by the Ohio State Institute for Education by Radio-Television. The competition included educational and commercial stations in the United States and Canada.
ALBANY, April 16 -- Governor Dewey signed today a bill reducing the New York City gross receipts tax on investment companies from 4/5 to 2/5 of 1 per cent, effective July 1.

Criminal charges were brought by New York and Brooklyn authorities yesterday against eight waterfront figures, accusing them of state tax evasions. The arraignment of three defendants in Kings County Court precipitated a sharp exchange between Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz and District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.
Writing as two members of the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey, we appreciate your complimentary editorial comments of April 10 concerning the end results of the committee's work.

The approval of psychoanalysis by Pope Pius XII will help remove one of the many obstacles that still prevent public understanding of mental and emotional illnesses, Dr. George S. Stevenson, medical director of the National Association for Mental Health, said here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, has started to dismantle the Munitions Board, which he recently described as a "fifth wheel" in the Defense establishment.

Yesterday, six weeks to the day after Stalin's death, Pravda declared that collective leadership, not "one-person decisions," must rule in the Communist party. Where there is one-man leadership, Pravda said, "individual leaders conduct themselves as if they alone knew everything and as if only they can say anything relevant and forceful, and as if it is the task of others only to support their opinions."

ATLANTIC CITY, April 16 -- Raymond E. Hanley of Camden, N. J., president of the New Jersey Home Builders Association, today urged the State Legislators to adopt the Municipal Planning Enabling Act which he said strengthens the planning statutes and clarifies the responsibility of municipal planning boards.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The 1953 baseball season was opened officially today by Dwight D. Eisenhower, a rookie, right-handed pitcher with a deceptive lob.

The quiz and panel discussion program entitled "Who Said That?" has been returned to the WNBT schedule and will be televised each Monday from 10:30 to 11 P. M. The program had been carried by the N. B. C. network in other cities but was not seen locally.

Twenty-three grants totaling $3,256,282 have been made by the Ford Foundation for basic research into the economic and social problems of the Near East and for vocational training, village development and leadership training in that part of the world, it was announced yesterday.

THE International Olympic Committee is scheduled to begin formal deliberations in Mexico City today and the harassed Olympic fathers will be faced with at least one major problem relating to the 1956 Games when they should have nothing more formidable to wrestle than a few trifling details. It may not be polite to point, but there is no escaping the fact that the Australians have badly bungled their end of the deal.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Treasury reminded holders of its series F and G savings bonds today that they had until May 1 to convert issues maturing between that date and Dec. 31 into the new 3 1/4 per cent fully marketable 30-year bond.

Vegetable markets are laden with an increasing variety of fresh produce from near-by farms as well as other growing areas. First of the season vegetables that have been added to the list this week include cabbage from Virginia, okra from Florida, radishes from Delaware and New Jersey.

BALTIMORE, April 16 -- Discontinuation of the Walter Hines Page School of International Relations, of which Owen Lattimore, under indictment on charges of perjury before a Senate subcommittee, is the director, was announced tonight by Dr. Detlev W. Bronk, president of Johns Hopkins University.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Congress responded today with an almost unbroken approval, though of varying degrees of warmth, to President Eisenhower's speech laying down the Administration's policy toward the Soviet Union.

New Jersey's Democratic candidates for the nomination for Governor next Tuesday have paid only limited attention to each other in their campaigns, but have heaped criticism upon the Republicans' handling of crime and corruption problems in the state.

The weather, which has been anything but kind to the baseball interests this spring, poured it on some more yesterday when heavy morning rains washed out the Giants-Dodgers game which was to have inaugurated the season at the Polo Grounds.

Mayor Impellitteri said at City Hall yesterday that he believed he possessed the qualifications that Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany, said a candidate for Mayor should have. He added, however, that he had made no decision on whether he would be a candidate for re-election.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Eight New Yorkers took refuge in a plea of possible self-incrimination in refusing today to tell Congressional tax investigators whether they had paid Henry W. (The Dutchman) Grunewald $60,000 in cash to stop a criminal tax fraud prosecution.

The Columbia University chapter of the American Association of University Professors issued a statement yesterday in which it defended the right of Communists to teach and attacked the investigations of American educational institutions as "unnecessary and unwise."

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- Paul A. Walker, Chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, urged Congress today to order more time for educational television stations to apply for channel assignments. The commission' order holding open 242 channels will expire on June 2.

The anti-trust investment banking case was inspired by Robert R. Young, chairman of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad, and might be termed "Young vs. Morgan," Ralph M. Carson, defense lawyer for Morgan Stanley Co., one of the defendants, asserted in Federal Court, here, yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 -- The over-all long range outlook for business in this country is good, Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks asserted here tonight. As defense expenditures, including expansions for military purposes, reach maturity, other investment programs will assume increasing importance, Mr. Weeks told 1,000 financial, industrial and business leaders at an "Invest in America Week" dinner.

In its first change of ownership since its erection by the Hillenbrand family in 1891, the apartment house for twenty families at 93 Bedford Street, in the Greenwich Village section of Manhattan, has been sold by Edward F. Hillenbrand to Swegal, Inc., for investment. Robert J. Glenn and Walter J. Dickerson were the brokers.
HANOI, Vietnam, April 16 -- The Communist-led Vietminh attack on Laos increased in fury today with large numbers of troops moving into the little Indo-China kingdom from the north and west.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Arthur Krock, the Washington Correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, announced today that on his own motion he would be succeeded in that post by James Reston, the newspaper's Diplomatic Correspondent.

Col. and Mrs. Louis Jacques Balsan will give a luncheon today in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre for Count Jean de Lagarde, minister in charge of the French Consulate General; Countess de Lagarde and members of the executive Committee for the "Paris in New York" festival, which is being held throughout this week for French-American philanthropies.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Proposing a five-point disarmament program, President Eisenhower declared today that the "first great step" toward global peace must be an honorable armistice in Korea that would include "an end to the direct and indirect attacks upon the security of Indo-China and Malaya."

BERLIN, April 16 -- Premier Otto Grotewohl told the East German Cabinet today that the Soviet Union had pledged far-reaching aid to help "peaceful reconstruction and improve the living standard" in East Germany.

CINCINNATI, April 16 -- Congressional investigation of religious leaders was unanimously approved here today by the National Association of Evangelicals at its eleventh annual convention. The association represents an estimated 10,000,000 theologically conservative members of thirty-six Protestant denominations.
Children can be "protected only by mature marriages." Dr. J. Louise Despert told the Psychiatric Forum Group at the New York Academy of Sciences, 2 East Sixty-third Street, Wednesday night.
Two sharp-eyed Connecticut housewives, who proved better than radar by spotting what looked like enemy war planes, were taken by surprise last night when they were rewarded for their alertness.

John E. Gleason Jr., 55-year-old veteran city employe, denied at his perjury trial in General Sessions yesterday that he had received $12,000 in fuel oil shakedown funds, or that he had ever discussed an extortion racket in the Fire Department with Frank J. Sampson.
Harry Gross' plea for a reduction of his twelve-year prison sentences for bookmaking was rejected yesterday for the second time in the Court of Special Sessions, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- Vancouver, B. C., and Spokane, Wash., took sides today in a contest over a license to pipe natural gas to the Pacific Northwest.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) -- Emil Rieve, president of the Textile Workers Union, C. I. O., said today the Taft-Hartley Law had stopped organization by labor unions "dead in its tracks." He appeared before the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee which is considering amendments to the labor law.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The history of Soviet Russia's conciliatory moves toward other nations, from the time the Bolsheviks took over the Government of that nation, has consistently been that these reversals from an attitude of belligerency come at a time when the Kremlin fears that a military power greater than its own has been built by these other nations.

Stockholders of Alexander Smith, Inc., floor covering manufacturer, will vote on a $9,000,000 financing program and a 400,000-share increase in common stock at the annual meeting, called for May 20, according to the proxy statement released yesterday.

The third performance in the Rothschild Foundation's season of "American Dance" at the Alvin Theatre last night drew another sold-out house with standees three lines deep. The attraction was Martha Graham's only appearance in "Appalachian Spring" and her first appearance this season in "Night Journey," both works cast with a virtually new company.

WOLFEBORO, N. H., April 16 -- New Hampshire is ready to make good on a proposal voted at an informal town meeting on the United Nations to supply Yankee know-how abroad, even in such a field as digging wells.
The two-story office and garage building at 415 Concord Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the S. H. Realty Corporation to John J. Casale, Inc., for cash above mortgages of about $56,000.
The number of group art exhibitions and one-man shows is about evenly balanced this week and it includes work by artists from both sides of the Atlantic.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today cotton consumption for the period of March 1-28 averaged 38,609 bales for each working day. This compared with an average 36,763 bales for the corresponding period a year ago, and with 38,931 for the Feb. 1-28 period this year.

MT. HOLLY, N. J., April 16 -- The Burlington County grand jury ended today its fourteen-month investigation into charges of official corruption by handing up seventeen indictments to Superior Court Judge Elmer B. Woods.
The Nelly Don collection of cottons, shown yesterday at McCreery's, is prettier this year than ever before.

Two detectives shot and captured a 21-year-old gunman on crowded Thirty-fourth Street, east of Eighth Avenue at 2 P. M. yesterday as pedestrians, thronging the sidewalks, ducked for cover in doorways and behind autos.
HOLLY WOOD, Calif., April 16 -- Arthur Lubin will go to England next month to direct "Star of India" for Raymond Stross, the British producer and theatre owner.

Increased expenses are making it necessary for the City Center of Music and Drama, Inc. (130 West Fifty-sixth Street, New York 19) to turn to its friends and the public for financial support for the first time since the center was founded in December, 1943. A City Center Tenth Anniversary Fund is being sought to replenish working capital.

A familiar experiment of the high school chemistry laboratory -- changing water, two parts of hydrogen and one of oxygen, into those two gases -- is being adapted so that the submarine of the future can stay under for long periods.

TOKYO, April 16 (AP) -- The Tokyo stock market soared today in the wake of the United States State Department's assurance that American spending would continue "at a relatively high level" even if peace came in Korea.

Completion of a 1,000-hour shakedown program in which a Boeing B-47 Stratojet medium bomber flew more than 432,000 miles under simulated combat conditions was announced yesterday by the New York office of Boeing Airplane Company with Department of Defense approval.

ANTHONY MAZZA'S job is one of the weirdest assignments a man ever undertook in The City of Ten Thousand Anomalies, although he doesn't often think of it in that light. He is probably the most overworked game warden in the country -- and his territory is effete Manhattan Island.

ST. LOUIS, April 16 (AP) -- Harvey Haddix, 27-year-old left-hander, pitched a four-hit shut-out and Capt. Enos Slaughter belted a two-run homer tonight as the Cardinals opened their home season with a 3-0 victory over the Cubs before 14,926 fans at Busch Stadium.
CHICAGO, April 16 -- At least eighteen persons died and thirty-seven were injured, some critically, when fire following an explosion this morning swept through a four-story factory building.

BUENOS AIRES, April 16 -- President Juan Peron emerged with a stronger grip on Argentina today after a night-long reign of terror in which groups of his supporters looted and burned buildings symbolizing the opposition.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 16 (AP) -- Eight nationally known amateurs remained at the top of the field tonight after the second round of the women's Trans-Mississippi golf tournament -- a round that produced the best and the tightest duels thus far in the event:

The Boys Exposition gold medal, emblematic of outstanding service "to the children of New York City," was presented yesterday to Arthur Huck, executive director of the Children's Aid Society, at a luncheon in his honor at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The top leadership of the Communist party and the Government of the Soviet Republic (or State) of Georgia have been purged for "trying to excite feelings of national hatred by concocting or helping to concoct charges of a "non-existent nationalism," radio broadcasts from Tiflis, Georgia, said yesterday.
BONN, Germany, April 16 -President Eisenhower's speech won warm approval of Bonn Government sources and was praised as a "positive" contribution to peace.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Opponents adopted the tactics of a filibuster today to delay or prevent a Senate vote on a bill to establish state ownership of submerged coastal oil lands, and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio promptly moved to break the first "talkathon" of his administration as Republican leader.
CHICAGO, April 16 (UP) -- Seven high school misses attended a stockholders meeting today of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad and were disappointed because it wasn't like the movies.

Although confirmation could not be obtained, it was learned on good authority yesterday that M. Lowenstein Sons, cotton textile manufacturers, will take possession of the Empire Theatre on May 31. A meeting of all concerned with the demolition of the famous house was held on Wednesday.

The extraordinary and unpredictable Dimitri Mitropoulos distinguished the concert he directed with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall by one of the most intimate, romantic and lyrical performances of the Schumann C major symphony that we have heard in years.

BERLIN, April 16 -- The Soviet Union has accepted a proposal of the Western Powers to hold a second meeting on air safety measures at 5 P. M. tomorrow at United States headquarters in West Berlin, it was announced this afternoon following a meeting of the British, French and United States representatives to map their reply to last week's Soviet proposals.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 (AP) The Red Sox, after having their American League opening delayed twice by snow and wintry weather, made up for lost time today by pounding four Athletics pitchers for nineteen hits and an 11-6 victory at Connie Mack Stadium.

ALBANY, April 16 -- Governor Dewey approved today a bill that would prohibit the blocking of traffic on open highways by "creeping" drivers moving at unreasonably low speeds. It will be effective after July 1.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 16 -- All the sixty member states of the United Nations voted today in favor of a Brazilian resolution expressing the hope that "the further negotiation as at Panmunjom will result in achieving an early armistice in Korea, consistent with the United Nations principles and objectives."

Two new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "The Assassin," a British-made melodrama with Richard Todd, Eva Bartok, John Gregson, George Coulouris and Margarot Grahame, is at the Sutton. The J. Arthur Rank presentation was producec by Betty E. Box and directed by Ralph Thomas, from a screen play by Victor Canning. United Artists is distributing.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- The Commerce Department renewed its airport aid program today with the approval of fifteen improvement projects across the nation. The cost to the Federal Government, in funds to be matched by city, county or state, will be almost $2,400,000.
The city of Baltimore announced i yesterday that it will receive bids ion Aiay 12 on $25,479,000 .of bonds maturing from 1956 to 1982 an having an average maturity about Seventeen yea.
H. Van B. Richard of the Princeton Club was elected president of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association at the annual dinner-meeting at the Union Club last night.

TOKYO, Friday, April 17 -- The United Nations Command agreed today to discuss with the Communists resumption of full-scale negotiations for an armistice in the Korean war. The Allies named a nation such as Switzerland as a suitable neutral nation to whose custody prisoners refusing repatriation might be turned over.

The gold medal for poetry of the National Institute of Arts and Letters has been won by Marianne Craig Moore, whose poetry has been honored eight times before. She is the fifth woman and the forty-sixth person to be so honored by the institute.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Walter P. Hedden, director of port development for the Port of New York Authority, and Alvin Shapiro, director of research of the National Federation of American Shipping, were among those who testified today in opposition to the seaway project.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on April 11 were 721,139 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, said today that continuation of the policy of high, rigid farm price supports would eventually bring on a consumers' revolt, possibly resulting in destruction of the entire price support program.

The five Red Cross chapters in New York City have "in hand or in sight" $5,250,000 of the $7,000,000 goal for the 1953 Fund campaign, Alber C. Simmonds Jr., general chairman of the appeal, announced yesterday. This is 5 per cent ahead of the 1952 campaign here on the same date last year, he said.

GARWOOD, N. J., April 16 -- Members of the Garwood Police Department were happy yesterday when they received their pay checks, for the checks included rises of $300 to $400 annually. The police were glum today, however, after having been obliged to surrender the checks for new ones that contained no pay rise.

Gerry Dreyer, 23-year-old British Empire welterweight champion from Pretoria, South Africa, will square off against Phil Burton of St. Louis in the feature ten-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena tonight. Burton is substituting for Tex Gonzales, who reports today for induction into service.

Italy's textile industry is maintaining a high rate of production and provides improved income for a large portion of the nation's working population, Gian-Franco Jucker, general manager of production of Cotonificio Cantoni, largest producer of cotton textiles in Italy, asserted yesterday.

SYDNEY, Australia, April 16 (UP) -- Sir Earle Page, Federal Health Minister of Australia, agreed today to a full investigation of a new plan to permit the admission of horses to Australia for the 1956 Olympics.
MOSCOW, Friday, April 17 -- Pravda published today President Eisenhower's five-point disarmament plan and his call to the nations of the world for "simple and honest" expressions of their intentions.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, April 17 (AP) -- United States soldiers drove 200 Chinese Reds off "Porkchop Ridge" today and smashed a nearby flank attack on the approaches to the main Allied line in western Korea.

Young women are aiding in the plans for the annual tea dance for the benefit of the Sacred Heart Alumnae Charities Fund to be held this afternoon in the Embassy Room and Garden of the Ambassador. Mrs. Frederick L. Kane heads the benefit committee and serving as co-chairmen are Mrs. Frederick F. Flach, Mrs. James A. Farley Jr., Miss Anne Tracy and Miss Julie Kammerer.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange held within a narrow range all day and closed steady, 4 points lower to 3 points higher than Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Department of Defense confirmed today, without explanation, that it had rejected all bids made for elements of a multi-million dollar power installation in Washington State and said the Army was now restudying the project.

CLEVELAND, April 16 -- Closer government-industry cooperation is imperative if the oil industry is to assure the nation a petroleum stand-by capacity adequate for defense without creating an over-supply which might wreck the industry, P. C. Spencer of New York, president of the Sinclair Oil Corporation, said today.

A plan to end acute bottlenecks at Central Park South by unifying the operation of the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue bus lines was submitted yesterday by Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley to his legal advisers.

Samuel J. Lefrak obtained a loan of $750,000 from the East New York Savngs Bank on the seventy-two-family apartment house being built by the Lefrak Organization at Bay Parkway and Kings Highway in Brooklyn. The building is named the Delaware and will contain apartments with two to four and one-half rooms. M. Robert Goldman, broker, arranged the loan.

Stock market operators played a waiting game yesterday. First they waited for the President's first major foreign policy speech. Then, when that seemed to them to contain nothing of market importance, they continued to wait. Volume slackened to 1,310,000 shares, from 1,580,000 on Wednesday, and prices eased moderately in virtually every section of the list.

Robert B. Blaikie, Democratic leader of the Seventh Manhattan Assembly District, called yesterday for immediate investigation to determine whether there was any violation of law at the meeting of the New York County Democratic Committee on Nov. 27, 1950, at which Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany, was re-elected a Commissioner of the Board of Elections.
LONDON, April 16 -- Prices have begun to tumble in many stores throughout Britain as a result of 25 per cent cuts in the purchase tax in Tuesday's budget.

A two-volume biography of Robert Marion La Follette, by Belle Case La Follette and Fola La Follette, is planned for fall publication by Macmillan. The biography was begun soon after his death by the Senator's widow, herself a lawyer, who actively participated in her husband's work throughout his life.

THE rain that fell on the Sawmill River yesterday came doom in the form of white flakes on the Beaverkill, and while it did nothing to raise the water levels, it let the bottom fall out of the thermometer. Anglers fishing during the afternoon wore gloves and mufflers.

MEXICO CITY, April 16 (AP) -- Australian. Olympic delegate today presented their report to the executive committee in an unscheduled afternoon meeting and later expressed concern over Melbourne's chances of keeping the 1956 games.

The Aluminum Company of America still has more offers of orders than it can fill and the only limiting factor in its business volume is the amount of aluminum it can make available, I. W. Wilson, president, said yesterday at the annual meeting in Pittsburgh.
PITTSBURGH, April 16 (AP) -- Danny O'Connell's three-run homer in the fifth inning gave the Pirates a 14-12 home-opening victory today over the Phillies.

PARIS, April 16 -- French officials were favorably impressed by President Eisenhower's speech, notably its emphasis on disarmament and on "direct or indirect aggression" against Indo-China and Malaya.

Events today: National Federation of Music Clubs, program of twentieth-century American music, Roosevelt Hotel, 1:30 P. M.; Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; National Federation of Music Clubs, Grass Roots Onara demonstration, Roosevelt Hotel, 8.

LONDON, April 16 -- The stock markets lost much of their immediate post-budget strength today. Only British Government securities and foreign bonds resisted the dull trend induced by profit-taking. South African gold mining shares in particular fell fairly sharply as a result of the victory for the Nationalist party in South African elections.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 16 -- The Soviet bloc returned today to the violent denunciations of Zionism that the Communist delegations at the United Nations had been playing down in the last few weeks.

Benjamin Fine's splendid series on the brave new world of happy and successful learning that New York City has created for its young millions and Leonard Buder's recent revealing story on major changes that have occurred in the procedures for examining prospective teachers should have opened many more eyes than they raised eyebrows.

Furnished models of two of the cooperative apartments being offered for sale by Gimbels will go on view at the store on Monday. The two apartments, which are included in the plans for the proposed Bay Terrace development in Bayside, Queens, are a four-room unit ($995 to $1,470) and a five-room duplex unit ($1,350 to $1,650).

The National Federation of American Shipping opposed yesterday the deletion of all shipbuilding appropriations from the proposed 1954 Department of Commerce budget and suggested instead that smaller amounts be made available to avoid the interruption of the replacement and modernization program for the American merchant marine.
TOKYO, Friday, April 17 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1.587, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Friday, Korean time:

" The Prince Regent's Style," a thoughtfully arranged exhibition, opens today at the Cooper Union Museum with a wealth of decorative items reflecting the tastes of the man who became England's King George IV and of eminent designers of the period.

MONTREAL, April 16 (UP) -- Elmer Lach scored at 1 minute 22 seconds of a "sudden-death" overtime period tonight to give the Montreal Canadiens a 1-0 victory over the Boston Bruins and the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup.

Spring, now that it has established itself officially, is apparent not only in garden, field and wood, where one expects to find signs of it, but also in other places one is not likely to look for it -- on the living room floor, for example, or under the bed belonging to the young man of the house.

YONKERS, April 16 (AP) -- A long shot and an odds-on favorite tonight won the two sections of the Kimball trot before a crowd of 15,869 at Yonkers Raceway. The first section went to Royal Comet, a 14-to-1 shot. Royal Pastime, 3-to-4, took the second.

TORONTO, April 16 (UP) -- Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, urged the Government today to give up its "stop-gap", investing in foreign recovery and leave the field to private investors.

Brooklyn schoolboys and Manhattan Colege are favored to score heavily in the seventh annual Seton Hall Relays today and tomorrow as the metropolitan interscholastic and intercollegiate outdoor track season gets under way at the Newark Schools Stadium.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 16 -- Finland's population has the highest literacy rate in the world and the British are the most avid readers of newspapers, the United Nations Educational and Scientific Organization reported today in a new statistical compilation called "Basic Facts and Figures."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 16 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, the Soviet representative to the United Nations, said today that President Eisenhower's five-point program for disarmament was "interesting but not completely accurate." He did not explain his cryptic remark.

Combined newsprint production in the United States and Canada for March was 576,187 tons, with shipments 536,017 tons, it was announced yesterday by the Newsprint Service Bureau. It was the highest combined production of any March on record and compared with output of 576,125 tons and shipments of 551,858 tons for that month last year.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Douglas McKay, Secretary of the interior, accused Marion Clawson, director of the Bureau of Land Management, of insubordination today and canceled a new job offer to the outgoing Democratic appointee.

Dr. Fahrettin Kerim Gokay, Mayor of Istanbul and one of Turkey's, leading psychiatrists, explained here yesterday that his city had little trouble in dealings with the state, or Province of Istanbul. Dr. Gokay is also governor.

The city's two biggest unions, representing 145,000 workers engaged in the manufacture of women's coats and dresses, filed demands for wage increases yesterday. It was the first time in nearly two and a half years that either union had asked for more money.

CLYDEBANK, Scotland, April 16 -- Queen Elizabeth sent her sleek new royal yacht, the Britannia, sliding gracefully down to the sea from John Brown's shipbuilding yard here today to the cheers of several thousand men who helped to build her, their wives, and a brassy salute from a military band playing "Rule Britannia."

" How can we be honest about what we're fighting for and yet be afraid of peace?" Lawrence A. Appley, president of the American Magement Association, asked last night at the annual dinner of the Society for the Advancement of Management in the Statler Hotel.

A resolution urging Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey to reconsider a proposed reduction in Customs personnel in view of the anticipated impact on overseas trade and passenger travel, was adopted unanimously last night by the New York branch of the National Customs Service Association.

CAIRO, April 16 -- Egypt will seek the aid of military technicians from the United States and Sweden as well as Britain in maintaining the Suez Canal Zone military base after the withdrawal of British troops, according to an official source here.

The enactment of the Canfield-Johnson bill to prohibit trade in dangerously flammable apparel was urged upon Congress yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association. Charles W. Dorn, chairman of the technical committee of the association and director of the research laboratory of the J. C. Penney Company, presented a brief to the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee strongly endorsing the measure.
The meals-in-a-dish that ease entertaining include the popular pizza which, in the company of cool beer, supplies everything needed for a late-evening supper or a springtime lunch on the porch.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Department store sales in the week ended April 11 were 13 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board which listed the following changes from like periods of 1952:

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Nathan Gregory Silvermaster, a former Government economist whose name has entered Congressional investigations of wartime spy rings here, refused to tell the Senate Internal Security subcommittee today whether he was now engaged in espionage or sabotage for the Soviet Union.

New York bank loans to business dropped $19,000,000 in a largely seasonal decline during the past week. The reduction in the week ended on Wednesday compared with one of $1,000,000 in the corresponding week last year, and brought the contraction since the start of this year to $56,000,000, compared with a decline of $111,000,000 a year ago.

In a recent letter your correspondent reports her annoyance at being sent merchandise as "gifts" by charitable organizations, with a covering letter asking for a contribution in return. She mentions in her letter receiving personalized pens, pencils, ash trays, and she might well have added name stickers, auto license tags, medallions, and so forth.

BONN, Germany, April 16 -- The Communist Government of East Germany under Russian direction has 120,000 men under arms and is exerting pressure to increase enlistments as part of a long-range plan to build strong ground, air and naval forces in the Soviet zone the United States High Commissioner's office reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- President Eisenhower threw out the first ball and stayed at Griffith Stadium long enough to see the Yankees score enough runs in the first inning to spoil the Senators' belated opening game of the season. Four New Yorkers crossed the plate in the first frame and from there Johnny Sain had little trouble going all the way to a 6-3 victory.

American Broadcasting - Paramount Theatres, Inc., estimated consolidated earnings for the first quarter this year at $5,732,000 compared with $2,049,000 a year ago, Leonard H. Goldenson, president, reported yesterday.

The efforts of schools, social agencies and churches in Brooklyn to prevent individual and family breakdowns were described yesterday by speakers at a conference on mental health under the sponsorship of the Brooklyn Council for Social Planning and ninety public and private agencies.
The National Multiple Sclerosis Society has extended its campaign for $1,200,000 through April, it was announced yesterday. The appeal began March 2.
Mrs. Bessie Honig, 43-year-old owner of a Brooklyn tenement in which seven persons perished in a fire last June 18, was acquitted last night on a charge of second-degree manslaughter.

One thousand grocery, produce and dairy clerks went on strike yesterday in 127 A. P. supermarkets in Brooklyn and part of Queens. The stores remained open, with two to six pickets marching outside each door.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Lieut. Gen. Williston B. Palmer, Assistant Chief of Staff G-4 (Materiel) of the Army, told a Senate Armed Services subcommittee today that Gen. James A. Van Fleet had used language that was too sweeping and too alarming in testifying last month about ammunition shortages in Korea.

DETROIT, April 16 (AP) -- Larry Doby knocked in five runs, two of them on a 400-foot homer off the right-field roof, as the Indians outslugged Detroit to spoil the Tigers' home opener, 11 -- 8, today before 25,253 chilled fans at Briggs Stadium.

The National Dairy Products Corporation will spend about $24,000,000 for improvements and replacements of equipment this year, bringing such expenditures to $230,000,000 since 1945, E. E. Stewart, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting in the Biltmore Hotel yesterday.
CLYDEBANK, Scotland, April 16 -- A passenger liner of 23,000 tons for the New York-Southampton service of the Greek Line was launched here today.

ALBANY, April 16 -- The State Public Works Department announced today the receipt of a low bid of $28,807,092 for construction of the steel superstructure of the controversial Tappan Zee Bridge, which will carry the Thruway over the Hudson between South Nyack and Tarrytown.

CHICAGO, April 16 (UP) -- Lefty Billy Pierce gave up only one hit today as the White Sox got two safeties off Harry Brecheen for a 1-0 opening day triumph over the St. Louis Browns before 11,354 fans.
Gian-Carlo Menotti's "The Consul" was presented at the City Center last evening, with David Aiken making his New York City Opera debut in the role of Mr. Kofner.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges closed generally lower yesterday. Sugar continued active but most markets registered light volume. Coffee, cocoa, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, hides, rubber and zinc were lower. Wool, tin and lead closed higher and sugar and potatoes ended mixed.

MEXICO CITY, April 16 (AP) -- The organization committee of the Central American games today fixed the dates of March 6 to 20, 1954, for the competition here and obtained permission from the international Olympic committee to include baseball, tennis, bowling and golf in its program.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A House of Representatives Judiciary subcommittee voted unanimously today not to bring Alger Hiss out of prison at this time to testify about Communist infiltration of the United Nations payroll unless he specifically demanded to be heard.

A good deal of thought obviously had gone into the all-Chopin program that George Fiore played last night in his Town Hall piano recital. Mr. Fiore avoided all the obvious choices, pulling out of the duatbin such forgotten works as the Fugue in A minor (a student work), the "Ludovic" Variations, Op. 12, the Bolero in C and the Allegro de Concert.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Four leading scientists, comprising the Visiting Committee of the Bureau of Standards, conferred today with Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, about "policies and constructive measures relating to the bureau."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 16 -- Representatives of various governments expressed cautious optimism today regarding the prospects for a gradual rise in global economic conditions as the Economic and Social Council opened debate on the world economic report for 1952 recently issued by the United Nations.

The Southern Company, a public utility holding system functioning in Alabama, Georgia and the Gulf area, is offering to holders of its common stock the right to subscribe for 1,004,869 new shares of stock at $14 a share until May 7.

Dr. Konrad Adenauer, the first Chancellor in Germany's history to make an official visit to the United States, received a City Hall welcome yesterday, and was hailed by Mayor Impellitteri as the spokesman of "a New Germany" that was moving under his leadership to a stable economy based on a humane social and political philosophy.

Charles Chaplin has apparently decided not to run the gantlet of the American immigration law. Last September, two days after he had sailed from New York (and two months before the Presidential election), the Justice Department took the unusual step of publicly announcing that Mr. Chaplin's right to re-enter the country in which he had been living for forty years would be seriously challenged if he should return.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) -- Reed Harris, who quit his State Department propaganda post this week, accused Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's investigating subcommittee in a parting blast of giving an "inaccurate picture" of his own and his agency's work.

NAIROBI, Kenya, April 17 (Reuters) -- Thousands of African families, driving goats, chickens and livestock ahead of them, tonight trekked north after having been evicted from two shanty villages known to be hotbeds of the anti-white Mau Mau cult.

CINCINNATI, April 17 -- The National Association of Evangelicals, ending its four-day annual convention tonight, adopted a resolution declaring that no Government appropriation, loan, or gift should be granted to any foreign nation that "does not protect for Protestant, Roman Catholic, Jew and other faiths, the right to believe, practice and propagate freely their respective faiths."

Between 20,000 and 25,000 Long Island Rail Road commuters were delayed for periods ranging up to slightly more than two hours during yesterday morning's rush-hour traffic as a result of a large fire in two warehouses near the Floral Park, L. I., station.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (UP) -- Informed House sources said today that the Administration soon will raise interest rates one-half of one per cent on homes purchased under the V. A. and F. H.A. mortgage insurance programs.

Gerry Dreyer, 23-year-old British Empire welterweight champion, put Phil Burton of St. Louis, a more experienced 26-year-old fighter, on the canvas twice in the sixth round last night for a technical knockout at the St. Nicholas Arena.

Arthur J. Altmeyer, who has retired as Social Security Commissioner, is generally regarded by those who have followed his career as having made an important contribution to the nation in his two decades of Government service. This career included supervision of the National Recovery Administration's Compliance Division, Assistant Secretary of Labor, membership on the tripartite Social Security Board and, since 1946, the post of Commissioner for Social Security.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Former Gov. Ernest Gruening of Alaska told the House of Representative Interior and Insular Affairs subcommittee today that Alaska is "ready for statehood and will not get readier by waiting." He was the last witness in a four-day hearing on the Alaska statehood bill.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., April 17 (AP) -- Doug Ford, fourth leading money winner in professional golf this year, fashioned a four-under-par 65 today to move into the halfway-mark lead in the $12,500 Virginia Beach open golf tournament.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 17 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of West Germany, closed out a tour of the United States today by asserting that President Eisenhower had taken the lead in the campaign for world peace.

The Metropolitan Opera is appealing to the American public for a fund of $1,500,000, and this money, if it is raised as it should be, will be spent for new productions and for urgent alterations backstage and in the orchestra seating plan. While it is conducting a campaign for contributions, it is also negotiating new contracts with the unions representing its instrumentalists and stagehands.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy announced today that Greek owners of fifty-three more vessels had volunteered pledges to his investigating subcommittee that they would refrain from shipping cargoes to Red China or Soviet-controlled ports in the Far East, and from serving in Russian intra-bloc trade anywhere in the world.

ALBANY, April 17 -- The State Banking Department announced today that the East River Savings Bank, 26 Cortlandt Street, Manhattan, received authority to move its branch office from 291 Broadway to 55 John Street.

Mayor Impellitteri's budget for the newly established Department of Air Pollution Control is sadly inadequate. His budget message spoke of a "small increased appropriation," and at the same time admitted that to find effective solutions of the smoke problem would require expenditure of "substantial sums of money."

Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson's salary as a member of the President's Cabinet is $22,500 a year. But last year, when he was president of the General Motors Corporation, he earned $581,100 in salary, director's fees and bonuses or $14,900 more than in 1951.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 17 -- The Pakistani Cabinet and Prime Minister Khwaja Nazimuddin were dismissed today by Ghulam Mohammed, the Governor General, as "entirely inade quate to grapple with the difficulties facing the country."

NASSAU, Bahamas, April 17 -- Durward Knowles of Nassau, sailing Gem III, captured the second race of the Star Class spring championships off Montagu Bay today and tied for first place on total points with E. W. (Skip) Etchells of Greenwich, Conn. Etchells finished third with Shannon in today's contest as Charles Lyons Jr., of Barnegat Bay, with Vega IV, placed second.

If Carnegie Hall still stands this morning, it could probably survive an atom bomb. Benny Goodman returned to action last night, after almost fifteen years of absence, with a band of his own. For good measure there were Louis Amstrong and his All Stars.

Secretary of Agriculture Benson has revealed that the cost of supporting the prices of agricultural products for the fiscal year beginning July 1 is now estimated to be in excess of $1,100,000,000, a rise of about $400,000,000 over President Truman's estimate and an increase more than sufficient to wipe out all the proposed savings in the Department of Agriculture's budget.

In an unexpected change of position, the Federal Government has arranged to bring Frank Costello here on Thursday from Milan Federal penitentiary in Michigan for pleading and for setting bail on the charge that the 61-year-old gambler evaded $73,417 in income taxes.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 -- University of California scientists said today that by the end of this year they hoped to begin treating human cancer patients with the largest X-ray machine known to the Western World.

It was another first-rate evening at the Alvin Theatre last night, when Jose Limon and his company and Pearl Lang and hers shared a program for the second time in the Rothschild Foundation's season of "American Dance."

John E. Gleason Jr., former general inspector in the Department of Sanitation, told a General Sessions judge and jury yesterday that luck with the horses had enabled him to bank $12,800 in 1947 and 1948, when his net salary was about $4,500.

Billings of the ACF-Brill Motors Company in the first quarter of 1953 were $6,667,406, slightly above the $6,208,478 in the corresponding period of 1952, C. W. Perelle, president told stockholders at the annual meeting in Philadelphia yesterday.

TOKYO, Saturday, April 18 -- Communist and United Nations commands agreed yesterday to a meeting of liaison officers at Panmunjom, Korea, tomorrow to discuss resumption of full-scale negotiations for an armistice in the Korean war.

ON THE WESTERN KOREAN FRONT, Saturday April 18 -- Pvt. John Woods, a rifleman in Company A, Seventh Infantry Regiment, Third United States Division, who came to Korea six days ago, is an amiable man who looks and acts just like any other G. I. of average height and build. The only difference is his background.
LONDON, April 17 -- Charles Chaplin, facing an inquiry into his fitness to re-enter the United States, said tonight that he had decided to give up his residence in the United States.
BALTIMORE, April 17 (AP) -- Larry MacPhai1 was removed today as president of Bowie race track, where he got himself in hot water last Saturday.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 17 -- In a bid to strengthen the United States position in Germany the White House announced today there would be no further confiscation of German-owned properties located in the United States. This action was announced in advance of the return to Bonn of Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of the German Federal Republic, who has been in Washington for conferences with President Eisenhower and other officials.

The six-story apartment building occupying a plot 150 by 100 feet at 583-93 West 215th Street, northeast corner of Indian Road, near Columbia University's Baker Field, has been resold by the Norwest 47 Corporation, representing Maxwell L. Low, an operator, to Ira Panzer.

Some 2,000 delegates are expected to attend the biennial convention of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, which will start tomorrow and end next Thursday. Sydney W. Roos, president of the New York Federation of Reform Synagogues, will welcome the delegates at the Commodore Hotel tomorrow morning.

NEW DELHI, India, April 17 -- Unofficially, Indians welcomed today the suggestion by President Eisenhower that defense expenditures by leading world powers be turned toward economic development of underprivileged countries. It was noted that this suggestion coincided with a sentiment repeatedly voiced by Indian spokesmen since the end of World War II.

The Citizens Committee on Children announced yesterday that it would appeal to each member of the Board of Estimate next week to reinstate a cut of $5,650 in the 1953-1954 budget for the Bureau of Handicapped Children of the Department of Health.

The Long Island Golf Association announced the discontinuance yesterday of one-day handicap tournaments from its schedule for the coming season. Gordon Stott, tournament chairman, said the "generally heavy" 1953 golf schedule was the cause for the curtailment.

MANILA, April 17 -- Two unsuccessful political aspirants cut themselves adrift from the Nacionalista party today in a defection that led to the complete reorganization of the Filipino Senate. The move gave President Elpidio Quirino's Liberal party the election-year control of the upper house by a 1-vote margin.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 17 -- Strong support was expressed today before the Joint Finance Committee of the Connecticut General Assembly for a bill providing for a $228,000,000 bond issue to finance construction of the Fairfield County Thruway, which will connect with the New York State Thruway in Greenwich.

TROY, N. Y., April 17 -- Supreme Court Justice Donald S. Taylor ruled today that civil service provisions against checking the political opinions of public employes did not bar the New York City Board of Education from questioning teachers about Communist party affiliations.
Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d have altered their production plans slightly to answer the booking needs of the new musical, "Me and Juliet," and the long-run "South Pacific."

Commodity prices closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Hides and world sugar had the second most active day of the year. Hides, coffee, wool, cocoa and rubber ended higher. Sugar, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, potatoes, tin and zinc were mixed and lead closed lower.

PRETORIA, South Africa, April 17 -- Nationalist students of Pretoria University paraded through the center of the capital today bearing republican flags. One declared the objectives of the Nationalist party were to transform South Africa into a republic and revive the tradition of the old Boer Transvaal and Free State Republics.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- Testimony was given in the du Pont anti-trust trial today in Federal District Court that the late Henry Ford ordered Ford Motor Company not to buy any du Pont products and that Chrysler Corporation cut purchases of du Pont wares to a trickle.

MUNSAN, Korea, Saturday, April 18 (AP) -- The Communists proposed today a timetable for Monday's exchange of disabled prisoners of the Korean war. United Nations officers replied that it "appeared reasonable."

Operations of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., and subsidiaries for the twenty-six Weeks ended on Jan. 31, last, resulted in a net income of $4,400,222, equal to $2.24 a common share, according to the semiannual report issued for publication today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 17 -- Burma opened her case today for United Nations condemnation of Nationalist China as an aggressor and won immediate support from the Soviet bloc, India and Yugoslavia.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- A full and complete investigation of last November's Senatorial election in New Mexico was voted today by the Senate Elections subcommittee.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 17 -- Dr. James R. Killian Jr., president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said tonight that he was "delighted" by Mr. Weeks' retaining the services of Dr. Astin at least temporarily.

CLEVELAND, April 17 -- Insects in this country destroy $4,000,000,000 worth of crops a year and some unfortunate farmers have 15,000,000 insects to an acre of land, Gustave Egloff, Universal Oil Products Company scientist, told leaders in the petroleum field today.

HILLBURN, N. Y., April 17 -- Peter D. Freytag, 30-year-old president of the American Aircraft Corporation of Teterboro, N. J., was killed at 11:30 A. M. today when a Spitfire racing plane he was piloting crashed into Bald Mountain in the Ramapos.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 17 (AP) -- Mrs. Lyle Bowman, the defending champion, encountered rough going in the women's Trans-Mississippi Golf Tournament today, but managed to win, 1 up, on the twenty-first hole, in the top match of the quarter-finals.

A 40-year-old steamship, which was once a well-known excursion steamer here, a veteran of two world wars, an immigrant carrier to Israel and passenger vessel in the Mediterranean, has ended her career and is headed for the scrap heap.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- A facial hammock in which milady can rest her features after a massage was patented this week by Leighton Budd of New York. She lies on her stomach and lays her face on a small blanket that is supported by a framework. There is a hole for her mouth and nose.

There is widespread interest in this country in the nomination of Ramon Magsaysay as the Presidential candidate of the opposition Nacionalista party in the Philippines. Mr. Magsaysay is known here through his reputation as a vigorous fighter of the Communist-led Hukbalahap dissidents in the archipelago.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The mysterious Henry W. (The Dutchman) Grunewald drew a perjury warning today with a story that a New York attorney brought him a paper-wrapped package of fish -- not a $60,000 pay-off to fix a criminal tax case in 1948.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (UP) -- Twenty Senate foes of the offshore oil bill offered today to "lay aside" their prolonged debate against the measure if the Republican leadership would call up the economic controls bill.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The United States made it clear today that it was not yet ready to go along with Western Europe's program for solvency through "trade, not aid" nor to modify its commercial policy to facilitate foreign sales of goods and services in this country.

Bucklin Moon, novelist and editor, was dismissed yesterday as an associate fiction editor of Collier's magazine because, he charged, an unidentified "pressure group" had accused him in a circular letter to advertisers of being subversive.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 17 -- The Government - controlled Teheran radio announced tonight that the security forces' commanders in Shiraz had been dismissed as the result of the sacking of the United States' regional Point Four office by a mob Wednesday followed yesterday by incendiary raids on the homes of the American staff members. Martial law has been in force there since noon yesterday, but the city is peaceful.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -The Army announced today that most Reserve Officer Training Corps graduates receiving their commissions after May 1 would be required to go on active duty before June 30, 1954.

SAN ANGELO, Tex., April 17 (AP) -- Officials of the Texas Company and Gulf Oil Corporation announced at a Texas Railroad Commission hearing today they are reducing second-quarter imports of foreign oil. The Commission set a May oil production allowable of 2,894,299 barrels daily -- an increase of 7,175 over the April allowable.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 17 (UP) -- Twenty men named by the Federal Bureau of Investigation as members of an inter-state stolen car ring pleaded innocent in the United States District Court today and were released in a total of $76,000 bail.

HANOI, Vietnam, April 17 -- With five divisions and a mountain regiment mobilized for an offensive that may have the Mekong river as its ultimate objective, the Vietminh increased its pressure today against the Kingdom of Laos where the French were feverishly preparing to make a stand.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The House Appropriations Committee, working on its first important measure based on budget estimates submitted by President Truman before he left office, reported today an Independent Offices Bill "showing total savings and improvement of cash position of the Government" amounting to $2,825,895,697.

DETROIT, April 17 (AP) -- Matt Batts, fighting for the No. 1 catching job on the Detroit Tigers, delivered a triple in the bottom of the ninth inning today to pave the Bengals to a 6-5 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

LONDON, April 17 -- In a few simple and direct words, Prime Minister Churchill welcomed tonight President Eisenhower's "massive and magnificent statement" of the Western World's peace aims and pledged to the President Britain's "resolute and wholehearted support."

ATLANTIC CITY, April 17 -- A sharp warning that Soviet Russia's sudden change of its anti-Semitic policy is "a tactical step" and does not offer any hope of a diminution of the Kremlin's anti-Semitic and anti-Zionist campaigns behind the Iron Curtain was sounded here today by leaders of the Jewish Labor Committee and in a documented report.

The monotonous drone of airplanes overhead causes little concern to most of us on the ground. A few persons may gaze skyward in admiration of the theory of aerodynamics or to betray a desire for controlled flight through the heavens. But the majority of persons display little reaction. Airplanes have become so common that our awareness is usually reflected in vibrating window panes or interrupted conversations.
In your issue of April 6 there is a letter written by J. J. Singh, president, India League of America, in which he is critical of THE TIMES' editorial "Tension in the Far East."

NEW DELHI, April 17 (AP) -- Sources close to India's Government said Prime Minister Nehru's regime thinks such a development as the Cominform disbandment "would be natural and not impossible to hope for" as the culmination of the current Communist peace campaign.
The Coast Guard "arrested" Rear Admiral Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter for speeding in New York Harbor yesterday afternoon.

ONE of Low's wartime cartoons, if memory serves, was called "The Burial of Colonel Blimp." That walrus-shaped symbol of bumbling and bluster was being forever consigned to oblivion. What gave such a disquieting sense of prophecy to the proceedings, however, was the identity of the pallbearers. They were very much alive. And every one of them was a Colonel Blimp.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Maj. Gen. Elbert L. Ford, Army Chief of Ordnance, testified today to a Senate Armed Services subcommittee that ammunition deficiencies in Korea were the inevitable result of having had to create a munitions industry "from scratch" after the fighting had begun.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Growing protests from Democratic and Republican Senators raised a possible roadblock in Congress today to an Administration decision to halt Government aid for airports.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17 (AP) -- Rookie Charley Bishop, a surprise starter, turned back the Red Sox with a five-hit shutout and drove home a pair of runs as the Athletics won a 5-0 victory today in a game marked by the major league season's first fist fight.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The United States set off today on a program of challenging the Russians to act for peace or face a marshaling with renewed vigor of all the free world's power.

Citing the absence of heavy losses on consumer credit despite its record expansion, J. Gordon Dakins, executive vice president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said yesterday that it appears safe "to assume that consumer debt is not out of line."

William W. Brady has been appointed director of sales of The Grand Union Company. He will be in charge of co-ordinating the sales efforts of the grocery, meat, produce and non-foods departments and will also handle the company's advertising and sales promotion plans.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 -- Liberalized world trade was declared essential today by Samuel W. Anderson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for International Affairs, if this country's ties to its friends were to be sound and if it was to live up to its responsibilities as a creditor nation.

When Johnny and Jimmy were 21 days old they were taken to the Babies Hospital of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center for an unusual scientific experiment. What effect has early training on the later development of a child?

BERLIN, Saturday, April 18 -- At the second meeting of the Big Four air safety conference here last night the Soviet delegation "clarified" its plan for merging the three air corridors between Berlin and West Germany, Allied sources reported. No details of the plan or the discussions were made public, however.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 17 -- One aspect of President Eisenhower's speech yesterday that has attracted special interest here was his revival of part of a disarmament proposal that former Secretary of State Dean Acheson submitted to the United Nations General Assembly a year and a half ago.

ALBANY, April 17 -- Governor Dewey signed today a bill appropriating $1,000,000 to continue the state's emergency school building program for another year. The money will go to districts with increasing enrollments or damaged and dangerous buildings.
SINGAPORE, April 17 -- Malayan terrorists struck again at two widely separated points in the last twenty - four hours, registering their second and third appreciable successes within nine days.

The United Nations Command and the Communists have now agreed to reopen the Korean armistice conference, and liaison officers will meet tonight to fix the time and place. This resumption of the truce talks, suspended since last October because of Communist insistence on the "repatriation" of all prisoners, even at the point of the bayonet, has been made possible by two Communist concessions.

Today the horse players at Jamaica will get a look at a champion. Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Native Dancer, winner last year of all of his nine starts, including the Belmont Futurity, will make his 1953 racing debut in the first division of the $30,000 added Gotham Stakes.

A new, thirty-minute opera named "Sunday Excursion" was unveiled yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Roosevelt. It was presented by the Grass Roots Opera Company of the National Federation of Music Clubs in cooperation with the Extension Division of the University of North Carolina.

Many dinner parties will be given in advance of the performance of "Hazel Flagg" Monday night at the Mark Hellinger Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Woman's Hospital. Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell and Mrs. Clendenin J. Ryan, who head the benefit committee, have among their aides Mrs. Harold F. McGuire.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent over the week ending on April 14 to 109.5 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

There is no lamentation at the Museum of Modern Art about the excessive rainfall during the last six weeks. The museum is soon to open its newly constructed and planted garden bordering on Fifty-fourth Street, between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Unless and until contrary evidence is presented, recognition for the longest ball ever hit by anyone except Babe Ruth in the history of major league baseball belongs to Mickey Mantle of the Yankees. This amazing 21-year-old athlete today walloped one over the fifty-five-foot high left-field wall at Griffith Stadium.

WHEN the ice went out of the Miramichi, one of New Brunswick's most popular salmon rivers, it took some of the camps, docks and bridges with it, but it left a lot of salmon, and anglers there for the spring salmon fishing have been getting unusually good sport.

NEWARK, April 17 -- Absent from the ranks of titleholders since 1948, New Jersey finally emerged with an eastern championship contingent this afternoon when St. Michael's High of Jersey City captured the mile relay at the seventh annual Seton Hall Relays at the Newark Schools Stadium.
The state Congress of Industrial Organizations demanded yesterday that the Legislature reconsider the fiscal and rent increase programs it "imposed" on the people of this city and state.

For more than seven years Trygve Lie handled one of the most difficult posts in the world. One would not want it also to be one of the most thankless of jobs, for Mr. Lie was a notable Secretary General of the United Nations.

BUENOS AIRES, April 17 -- Six victims of Wednesday's bombings in the Plaza de Mayo were buried today with full coverage given by the nation's press. The funerals presented a great display of floral offering which included wreaths sent by President Juan Peron himself.
Dense smoke from a two-alarm fire in a five-story brick converted loft building at 155 Suffolk Street felled eleven firemen yesterday.
A prolific female Darwin's rhea has created a complicated situation and raised a lot of zoological eyebrows at the Bronx Zoo.

PARIS, April l7 -- Gracious necklines that may be draped to the wearer's taste are part of the charm of Jean Desses' mid-season collection devoted to garden party, cocktail and evening ensembles for the Paris and London season.

Securities underwear are facing pricing problems because of the delicate market question raised by next week's allotments of the Treasury's new oversubscribed long-term bond. With about $40,000,000 of new investment grade public utility bonds still unsold at recent offering levels, syndicates will be called on to price $5,800,000 of Blackstone Valley Gas and Electric Company mortgage bonds and $6,000,000 of Chicago Great Western Railway mortgage obligations at public sealed bidding.

BONN, Germany, April 17 -- Dr. Reinhold Maier, President of the Bundesrat, proposed today that the upper house of Parliament postpone its decision on the Allied-German treaties until after West Germany's highest court had decided on their constitutionality.
